title: Immigrant Groups and R.N.C. Split on Outcome of Meeting
description: Immigrant advocates seeking to raise Republican support for an immigration overhaul met on Wednesday with Michael Steele, chairman of the Republican National Committee, but the effort got off to a rocky start when a dispute arose over what promises, if any, Mr. Steele had made during the meeting.

title: Borders Repays $42.5 Million Loan From Ackman
description: The Borders Group said late Wednesday that it had repaid a $42.5 million loan from William A. Ackmans Pershing Square Capital Management, its largest investor, and secured a new $700 million credit line from Bank of America and other banks. The struggling bookseller said it had also closed on a new $90 million term line.

title: The Pace of Deal-Making Picks Up
description: CORPORATE buyers are intensifying their hunt for deals  and theyre becoming a bit bolder.

title: Furor Over Promotions of Palin TV Show
description: David Itzkoff and Bill Carter examine the contretemps over promotions suggesting appearances by certain celebrities on Sarah Palins planned television show, with the celebrities  LL Cool J and Toby Keith  claiming they did not give their authorization.

title: Calculating Morgan Stanleys Fees for Citi Stock Sale
description: Morgan Stanley could could earn at least $23.1 million  and as much as $134.8 million  for its work advising the government on the sale of its Citigroup stake, according to the terms of its contract with the Treasury Department. (Read the contract after the jump.)

title: No Confetti as Apollo and K.K.R Move to List
description: As Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Apollo Global Management finally limp into the stock markets, the question again arises: does it make sense to buy into publicly traded private equity firms?

title: Zimbabwe: New Charge in Terror Trial
description: More than a year after Roy Bennett, one of Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirais closest allies, was put on trial for terrorism-related offenses, the attorney generals office has notified him that he will face a new charge of hoarding maize nine years ago, Mr. Bennetts party, the Movement for Democratic Change, reported Wednesday. The party contends that Mr. Bennett is being persecuted by its partner in governing, the ZANU-PF party of President Robert Mugabe. Mr. Bennett, who is white, is a former commercial farmer whose land was confiscated. State agents recently blocked him from collecting his fathers remains from the farm he used to own, his party said. Mr. Tsvangirai nominated him as deputy agriculture minister, but Mr. Mugabe has refused to appoint him.

title: Court Requires Warning About Deportation Risk
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that lawyers for people thinking of pleading guilty to a crime must advise their clients who are not citizens about the possibility that they will be deported.

title: France: More Publishers Sue Google
description: Several French publishing houses intend to bring a joint copyright infringement suit against Google, publishing executives said this week. As part of its Book Search project, since 2005 Google has digitized and made publicly accessible portions of at least 12 million literary works, many under copyright. Brice Amor, legal director at ditions Gallimard, the publishing house leading the suit, said that Google had continued scanning and posting Gallimard works despite requests that it stop doing so. Google declined to comment on the pending legal action. In December, a Paris court found Google guilty of copyright infringement in a similar suit brought by the French publishing group La Martinire. Google has appealed the decision.

title: For Start-Ups, Late Bursts of Private Cash
description: A FEW years ago, Facebook, which brought social networking to college students and grandparents alike, was expected to be a public company by now. Founded in 2004, it is cash-flow positive and is expected to bring in $1 billion in revenue this year.

title: Belgium: Burqa Bill in Parliament
description: In a reflection of growing anxiety in Europe over the use of Islamic symbols, a committee of Belgian lawmakers voted Wednesday to ban the wearing of burqas in public, paving the way for the first clampdown of its kind on the Continent. Exceptions would be possible for some festivities if the municipal authorities decided to grant them. The proposal will be put to the full Parliament after the Easter break. Caroline Sagesser, a social policy expert at the Universit Libre de Bruxelles, said the move was more significant politically than in terms of social impact. Some of the most likely offenders could be wealthy visitors from the Persian Gulf states staying in Belgiums luxury hotels and visiting its most exclusive stores, she added.

title: Applications to Elite Universities Rise
description: With many of the nations most selective colleges and universities scheduled to inform applicants of their decisions on Thursday, one trend already appears to be emerging: Applications to elite private colleges rose again this academic year, despite the economic constraints on many families.

title: Texas: Changing Her Mind, Senator Says Shell Stay
description: Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, announced Wednesday that she would serve out the rest of her term, after previously indicating she would resign before it ended. Ms. Hutchison, 66, fresh off an unsuccessful bid for governor, wrote in an open letter to Texas residents that she would stay put to fight the Democrats agenda and work to repeal the recently enacted health care legislation. The seat is next up for election in 2012.

title: California: Good-Bye to Ghost Fleet
description: The federal Maritime Administration has agreed to remove more than 50 obsolete military troop ships and tankers from World War II that have been anchored in the San Francisco Bay since the 1960s. Environmental groups sued the agency in 2007, after a study found that some 20 tons of lead-based paint had flaked off the warships, known as the ghost fleet. The 25 most decrepit ships will be removed by 2012, and stripped of loose paint, barnacles and plants before they are towed to Texas to be cut apart and recycled. The remaining ships will be removed by 2017.

title: Top Bloomberg Aide Will Lead His Charity Board
description: As he unveiled plans to vastly expand the foundation that will give away his fortune, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday formally appointed Patricia E. Harris, his first deputy mayor, as both chairwoman and chief executive of the $1.75 billion charity.

title: After 3 Days, Police Give Description of Subway Killer
description: Slowed by a shortage of surveillance cameras in New York Citys subway system, the police on Wednesday released their first detailed description of a man accused of fatally stabbing two other men on a No. 2 subway train, three days after a brawl that led to the deaths.

title: Schedule Favors Rangers in Push for the Playoffs
description: There is bad news and good news in the Rangers chase to make up 4 points in the seasons final six games and grab the final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.

title: A .483 Batting Average? Not Quite Good Enough
description: TAMPA, Fla.  In the long, rectangular-shaped Yankees clubhouse at Steinbrenner Field, players likely to make the team are assigned lockers on the perimeter. The four rows in the middle, parallel to the shorter walls, are mostly for nonroster invitees, long-shot rookies, those with no chance of making the team and players who are just passing through. More and more of those lockers go empty as camp progresses.

title: At Law Firms, Reconsidering the Model for Associates Pay
description: BIG firms are in a crucible of change. Some dont realize it yet. But the fat will be wrought from the system.

title: Twins Span Hits His Mother With a Foul Ball
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Minnesota center fielder Denard Span, who is from Tampa, purchased tickets for his family to sit next to the Twins dugout at Steinbrenner Field for Wednesdays game against the Yankees.

title: New York and Airline to Team Up on Tourism
description: The competition for supremacy among major airlines at New Yorks airports is paying dividends for the citys campaign to attract more visitors.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Holy Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations in

title: Christie Survives His Dive Into Uncharted Political Waters. For Now.
description: In more normal times, you would think the new governor had gone out and promptly laid an egg.

title: N.Y. Repeat Felon Law Is Found Unconstitutional
description: A key provision of a New York State law under which repeat offenders can be sentenced more harshly is unconstitutional because the longer prison terms are based on findings by judges, not juries, a federal appeals court ruled on Wednesday.

title: Court Ruling May Imperil Florida Deal
description: MIAMI  The federal judge supervising Everglades restoration issued a ruling on Wednesday that could make it impossible for Gov. Charlie Crist to complete a land acquisition he has described as the signature environmental achievement of his administration.

title: The Iraq Drawdown and Afghan Buildup
description: In one of the most complex logistical operations in military history, American troops and equipment are being pulled out of  Iraq and sent on to Afghanistan, or back home to refit the armed services.

title: No Shortcuts When Military Moves a War
description: JOINT BASE BALAD, Iraq  Early this year a fob in a box  military slang for 80 shipping containers with all the tents, showers and construction material needed to set up a remote forward operating base  was put on trucks here for the trip from one war to another.

title: Everyman on Everest
description: SEATTLE  My friend John Rudolf left for Mount Everest on Monday, off to clamber up toward the roof of the world at an age, 62, when some people have trouble getting out of bed in the morning  or at least finding a motivation to greet the dawn.

title: Iraq: The Wrong Type of Sand
description: CAMP ARIFJAN, Kuwait  On the very long and expensive list of materials that the American military had to ship to Iraq since 2003  many of which it is now shipping out again  one might not have expected to find sand.

title: Looking at the iPad From Two Angles
description: In 10 years of reviewing tech products for The New York Times, Ive never seen a product as polarizing as Apples iPad, which arrives in stores on Saturday.

title: Bloggingheads: Avant-Garde Politics
description: David Weigel, left, of The Washington Independent and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate whether Democrats are ignoring the concerns of average Americans.

title: Go Mad
description: "Perhaps you've never heard of the choreographer Faye Driscoll. But if you're reasonably plugged into the contemporary arts scene in New York, chances are you've seen some of her work," writes Claudia La Rocco. " 'Loneliness,' her video flip-book dance, was part of the New Museum's 'Younger Than Jesus' triennial. She was a member of Doug Varone and Dancers, has performed with Yasmeen Godder and served as the choreographic assistant to David Neumann, when he created a duet for himself and Mikhail Baryshnikov." Those who want to get more familiar with her work should head to Dance Theater Workshop to see "There Is So Much Mad in Me." "The piece, which includes fine dancers like Tony Orrico and Lindsay Clark, is drawn in part from media images of people in extreme states and investigates their enduring need to be seen. What better time to catch a glimpse of Ms. Driscoll?"

title: Urban Disaster
description: "Treme," the new HBO series from David Simon, about New Orleans in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, doesn't begin until next Sunday, but you don't have to wait until then to see a work that explores disaster in the modern American city. Tonight, The Kitchen presents the world premiere of "Bellona, Destroyer of Cities." The interdisciplinary theater work is adapted and directed by Jay Scheib from Samuel R. Delany's science fiction novel "Dhalgren," and is set in a city after a cataclysmic event. It is the second part in Mr. Scheib's trilogy, "Simulated Cities/Simulated Systems," and features passages from the novel with original material, movement and live video. Performances begin at 8 p.m.

title: Wonder Show
description: "The latest guise of the singer and songwriter Will Oldham, Bonnie (Prince) Billy sings rowdy and devastating songs in an Appalachian squeal that can be described only as miraculous," writes Amanda Petrusich. Tonight he is performing with the Cairo Gang, the alias of his longtime collaborator Emmett Kelly. At 8 and 10:15 p. m. at Monster Island Basement in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Mississippi A.C.L.U. Rejects $20,000 for Alternate Prom
description: To avoid further controversy, the American Civil Liberties Union of Mississippi has rejected a $20,000 gift intended to underwrite an alternate prom replacing one canceled by a local school district after a lesbian student demanded that she be allowed to attend with her girlfriend.

title: Successes (and Some Growing Pains) at Hulu
description: Hulu, the popular and free online video hub, has some things to celebrate as it heads into its third year.

title: Skepticism on Pledges for Haiti
description: UNITED NATIONS  An international effort to finance the reconstruction of Haiti attracted billions of dollars in pledges at a conference here on Wednesday, but the very size of the outpouring raised questions about whether the commitments would be met and how fast the financial support could help salve the needs of the Haitian people.

title: Drill, but Not Everywhere
description: For years, the debate over offshore drilling for gas and oil has been a war of sound bites between the drill now, drill everywhere crowd that dominated the Bush administration and the Republican campaign in 2008, and members of the environmental community who would leave the countrys outer continental shelf untouched.

title: A Web of Insider Trading Charges
description: Prosecutors charge that Galleon Group hedge fund was the at the hub of a broad network of traders who swapped insider information. Go to DealBook

title: Court Authorizes Inquiry of Kenyans
description: PARIS  The International Criminal Court has given the green light to open formal criminal investigations of the political leaders who organized the violence that shook Kenya after its disputed election in 2007, the court announced Wednesday.

title: Rushed From Haiti, Then Jailed for Lacking Visas
description: More than two months after the earthquake that devastated Haiti, at least 30 survivors who were waved onto planes by Marines in the chaotic aftermath are prisoners of the United States immigration system, locked up since their arrival in detention centers in Florida.

title: The Collector
description: Not many ex-wards of the New York City public school system would cherish a splinter that pierced the rear of their principal in 1942, but Martin Raskin, it is safe to say, is in a class by himself.

title: Charles Ryskamp
description: I owe an almost inexpressible debt to Charles Ryskamp, an extraordinary museum director, literary scholar, and a man of unlimited generosity. When I met him, I was a graduate student in the English department at Princeton University and he was a professor there. He also was the director of the Pierpont Morgan Library.

title: Scions of Detroit Families Share Hockey Passion
description: DETROIT  Since birth, William Clay Ford Jr. and Christopher Ilitch have been judged by their last names and their families businesses. It comes with being the great-grandson of Henry Ford and, for Ilitch, being the son of the founder of Little Caesars Pizza.

title: What France Can Do
description: President Nicolas Sarkozy of France got nearly everything he could have hoped for from his visit to the United States this week. Now he needs to return the favor by significantly increasing French combat strength in Afghanistan.

title: Hedge Funds Mediocre Middlemen
description: Hedge Funds Mediocre Middlemen

title: Events in the Case of an Accused Priest
description: The case of the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy, accused of molesting as many as 200 deaf boys at a school in Wisconsin, stands out among the cases of sexual abuse by Catholic priests because of the number and vulnerability of the victims, and the availability of documents revealing how church officials handled the matter.

title: China, Concubines and Google
description: Some 2,400 years ago, a Chinese king invited a legendary military strategist named Sun Tzu to give a demonstration in military training  using women from the palace.

title: Interpreting the Test Scores
description: To the Editor:

title: The Real Census
description: The Census Bureau  the real Census Bureau  reports the good news that 50 percent of American households have mailed in their decennial head-count forms so far. Theres no word on the ersatz census forms mailed out this year by the Republican National Committee and the National Republican Congressional Committee as a fund-raising gambit.

title: Mitt Romney, Liberal Icon
description: I need to apologize to Mitt Romney.

title: Rate of Caesarean Sections
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Happiness: Love Triumphs Over Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Are You Buying Illegal Drugs?
description: LAST month, thieves cut through the roof of an Eli Lilly warehouse in Enfield, Conn., shimmied down a rope, disabled the alarms and made off with $75 million worth of psychiatric drugs, including the antidepressants Prozac and Cymbalta and the antipsychotic Zyprexa. It is thought to have been the largest pharmaceutical theft in history.

title: The Pope and the Abuse Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: When Israel and France Broke Up
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: Risk Is Clear in Drilling; Payoff Isnt
description: WASHINGTON  In proposing a major expansion of offshore oil and gas development, President Obama set out to fashion a carefully balanced plan that would attract bipartisan support for climate and energy legislation while increasing production of domestic oil.

title: Inquiry Into Ex-G.O.P. Leader
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  The man chosen by Gov. Charlie Crist to lead the Republican Party of Florida is under criminal investigation after a new audit showed that he may have steered nearly $200,000 in party money to a company he owned.

title: Views on Reform, Then and Now
description: TWO and a half years have passed since the credit crisis upset the markets, leading to the collapse of several major investment firms.

title: Militia Draws Distinctions Between Groups
description: ADRIAN, Mich.  The Stone family, and the fiercely militant Christian group that revolved around them at a ramshackle homestead outside of town here, were best known by their neighbors for their active use of guns and their increasingly heated talk about fighting back violently against the government.

title: U.S. Agent Infiltrated Militia, Lawyer Says
description: DETROIT  An undercover federal agent attended training exercises with the Hutaree militia for at least eight months before nine members of the militant Christian group were arrested last weekend and charged with plotting an uprising against the government, prosecutors said Wednesday.

title: Coaches Finding No Tolerance for Losing
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Three years ago, when Royce Waltman was fired as the coach at Indiana State, he gave a memorable and prophetic news conference at the Missouri Valley Conference tournament.

title: Where All Are Counted
description: In Wolford, N.D., everyone who received a census questionnaire has filled it out and returned it. This is a distinction held by a smattering of tiny towns, mostly in the Midwest.

title: Trying to Break Down Resistance to the Census
description: Ni hao! the young volunteer exclaimed in Mandarin, greeting the stranger on the other side of an apartment door in Queens. First there was silence, but then the door cracked open, and the volunteer announced the reason for her visit.

title: Mets Murphy Will Miss Opener With a Knee Injury
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  With only a handful of days remaining before the regular season, the Mets were on the verge of concluding spring training without having sustained a single on-field injury. But then one faulty base-running play in the middle of a meaningless game on Tuesday brought back all the bad memories of 2009, and the Mets find themselves without their starting first baseman.

title: Donovan (and Willard) Take Over at Seton Hall
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J.  Three decades before Brittney Griner caused such a commotion at Baylor, a 6-foot-8 colossus named Anne Donovan swatted aside shots  and misconceptions about womens basketball  to build an astonishing rsum as a player, then as a coach.

title: Lavin Prepares for His Close-Up at St. Johns
description: Just about every coach can break down film, but Steve Lavin takes it to a different level. Lavin, the new boss at St. Johns, is married to an actress, Mary Ann Jarou, whose television roles include an appearance on The King of Queens.

title: Welsh, a Coach Who Has Won, Gets a Chance to Contend at Hofstra
description: The former Providence and Iona coach Tim Welsh had been looking to get back into coaching since leaving the Friars in 2008, but the right fit did not become available until Wednesday, when Hofstra handed him the keys to its program.

title: Like the Clues
description: Once upon a dreary midnight

title: Finding That Elusive One Person in Every 116 Acres in Mississippi
description: MAYERSVILLE, Miss.  According to the last census, there is one person  one hard-to-find, hard-to-prod, hard-to-pin-down person  for every 116 acres in Issaquena County, whose western horizon is narrowed by the bright green band of the levee along the Mississippi River.

title: Inventive New Private School Hits Old Hurdles
description: The founders of the Blue School aspired to create something different: a private school not fixated on the Ivy League prospects of preschoolers and devoid of admissions hysteria. An education that, as they put it, you dont have to recover from.

title: Pay of Hedge Fund Managers Roared Back Last Year
description: The Lazarus-like recovery of the nations big banks did not benefit just the bankers  it also created huge paydays for hedge fund managers, including a record $4 billion gain in 2009 for one bold investor who bet big on the financial sector.

title: Parking Lot Is a Battleground for a Bronx Hospital and a Doctors Union
description: To officials at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx, replacing an overcrowded parking lot with a five-story parking garage would end the daily hassle of fighting for a space, benefiting staff members and visitors alike.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 31, 2010

title: Blood on Defendants Knife Was Victims, Scientist Says
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Bloodstains on the blade of a knife that the police recovered from the Long Island teenager accused of fatally stabbing an Ecuadorean immigrant matched the DNA of the victim, a forensic scientist testified on Wednesday. Other bloodstains on the jeans and tank top the teenager was wearing also matched the victims DNA.

title: Empire Built by Developer Shows Signs of Distress
description: Sheldon H. Solows swooping 50-story office tower on West 57th Street with the giant red 9 in front is half empty, a stunning development for a building that commands some of the highest rents in Manhattan.

title: Few to Count, but All Eager to Get It Done
description: WOLFORD, N.D.  Kyle Yoder, 8, heard at school that the Census Bureau was starting to count the country and began asking his parents the same question every night: Had their form arrived in the mail today?

title: Nets Unable to Slow Nash or the Suns
description: Steve Nash had 24 points and 14 assists, Jason Richardson scored 23 points, and the Phoenix Suns ran their winning streak to nine games by beating the Nets, 116-105, on Wednesday night at the Izod Center.

title: Pfizer Chief Says Growth Is Imminent
description: The worlds largest drug company, Pfizer, has handled mergers badly, invented too few drugs and left its reputation in disrepair after two criminal cases.

title: David Mills, Television Writer and Producer, Dies at 48
description: David Mills, a former journalist who explored race relations and racial tensions as an Emmy-winning television writer for dramas like NYPD Blue, The Wire and Homicide, died on Tuesday in New Orleans on the set of a new show, Treme. He was 48 and had homes in Los Angeles and Silver Spring, Md.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 13 about the arrest in Yemen of Sharif Mobley, a New Jersey man accused of joining Al Qaeda and killing a hospital guard, described his familys origins incorrectly. According to law enforcement officials and friends of the family, both of Mr. Mobleys parents were born in the United States and his ancestors have lived in this country for generations. His ancestors were not Somali immigrants.

title: Tournament Tipoff: Unlikely Final Four
description: Butler and Michigan State broke a lot of brackets on their way to the Final Four, and they might not be done yet.

title: Deadlock Is Ending on Labor Board
description: Because of President Obamas recess appointments of two union lawyers to the National Labor Relations Board, business groups are warning that the panel will kick quickly into a pro-union gear after 26 months of near paralysis, when just two of its five seats were filled.

title: Mortimer D. Sackler, Arts Patron, Dies at 93
description: Mortimer D. Sackler, a psychiatrist who was a co-owner of the pharmaceutical company Purdue Pharma, makers of the controversial painkiller OxyContin, and whose lavish gifts to the Guggenheim Museum, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Columbia University made him one of New York Citys most prominent benefactors, died March 24 in Gstaad, Switzerland. He was 93 and had homes in London, Gstaad and Antibes, France.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a speech by the former Federal Reserve chairman Paul A. Volcker misstated, in some copies, part of the name of the organization he addressed on Tuesday. It is the Peterson Institute for International Economics  not Institute of.

title: Jaime Escalante, Inspiration for a Movie, Dies at 79
description: Jaime Escalante, the high school teacher whose ability to turn out high-achieving calculus students from a poor Hispanic neighborhood in East Los Angeles inspired the 1988 film Stand and Deliver, with Edward James Olmos in the starring role, died Tuesday at his sons home in Rosedale, Calif. He was 79 and lived in Cochabamba, Bolivia.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Wednesday about the Charleston Symphony Orchestras cancellation of the rest of its season because of financial problems misstated the action the orchestras board intends to take by May 1. It plans to notify ticketholders for next season of their options by that date  not make a decision by then on whether to go ahead with the 2010-11 season.

title: German Cabinet Agrees on Bank Tax for Bailouts
description: PARIS  The German cabinet agreed in principle on Wednesday to impose a tax on banks to help finance bailouts but left details of the plan to be worked out in legislation in coming months.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Friday about Hot Tub Time Machine, in suggesting that the movie might give viewers of a certain age and background a twinge of pained, slightly nauseated nostalgia, misspelled part of the title of a song whose lyrics such viewers would know. The song, released by Rick Springfield in 1981, is Jessies Girl, not Jesses Girl.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Fed Ends Its Purchasing of Mortgage Securities
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserves single largest intervention to prop up the American economy, its $1.25 trillion program to buy mortgage-backed securities, came to a long-anticipated end on Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: The Front Row column last Thursday, about Patrick McCarthys departure as editorial director at Womens Wear Daily, misstated the date of that publications 100th anniversary. It will be this May; it did not occur last year.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Thursday with an article about hiring fitness trainers for home workouts referred imprecisely to the people shown. Amber ONeal, the trainer, is at the right, next to Kristen Leigh, her client; the words at left referred to the pictures position in relation to the caption.

title: Optimism and Doubt Feed a Duel Over Greece
description: Even as Moodys downgraded its ratings on five Greek banks, the European Central Bank and Greece on Wednesday trumpeted optimism about the countrys financial prospects.

title: Haitis Founding Document Found in London
description: There is no prouder moment in Haitis history than Jan. 1, 1804, when a band of statesmen-warriors declared independence from France, casting off colonialism and slavery to become the worlds first black republic.

title: Albany Misses Its Deadline on the Budget
description: ALBANY  The state budget is officially late. Again.

title: One Last Sitting for Holocaust Survivors
description: Maciek Nabrdalik set out to photograph Holocaust survivors with a case full of studio equipment. At times, his subjects waited for him dressed in their best attire. He quickly realized that such formality would detract from his goal: to capture memories of the Holocaust through his subjects facial expressions.

title: Update: If You See a Quote from Professor Lirpaloof, Beware
description: Madison Avenue and marketers enjoy an April Fools Day prank just as much as the next person  or perhaps even more, given that fakes, gags and goofs can help draw attention to a product or brand.

title: Carbon Permits Said to Be in Excess in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  As the global economy faltered last year and factories idled, industries in the European Union benefited from one of the most lucrative outcomes of the recession: a huge excess of permits to emit carbon dioxide.

title: Fed Ends Its Purchasing of Mortgage Securities
description: The Federal Reserves single largest intervention to prop up the U.S. economy, its $1.25 trillion program to buy mortgage-backed securities, came to a long-anticipated end on Wednesday, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: A Call for Hong Kong to Clean the Air
description: HONG KONG  Top business leaders in Asias financial hub are sounding a bit like environmental activists these days, taking a stand against the persistently unhealthy levels of air pollution gripping this city.

title: SS&C Tech Sees Static Debut
description: Shares of SS&C Technologies Holdings remained almost flat in their market debut after the company raised $160.9 million in its initial public offering, The Associated Press reported.

title: Unemployment and Inflation Rise in Europe
description: PARIS  The unemployment rate in the euro area rose to 10 percent in February, while inflation accelerated more than economists had forecast, probably a result of higher food and oil prices, according to data released Wednesday.

title: Critics Exploit Tlcom Suicides, Ex-Executive Says
description: PARIS  Outsiders have taken advantage of the wave of suicides at France Tlcom to push their own agenda, a former top executive at the company said in an interview posted Wednesday on a Web site.

title: Peter Gowland, Pinup Photographer and Author, Dies at 93
description: Peter Gowland, who used camera, sunshine and imagination to portray ravishing women at a time when the pinup girl was a nearly ubiquitous fixture of American life, died on March 17 in Los Angeles. He was 93.

title: Behind the Fight to Regulate Derivatives
description: 8:46 a.m. | Updated By CYRUS SANATI

title: Crumbling Knicks Lose in Portland
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  The indignities came in waves Wednesday night, in alley-oops and ankle sprains and a scoreboard that seemed to light up only on one side. On a celebratory night at the Rose Garden, the Knicks were gloomy guests.

title: How to Register a Start-Up
description: Think registering your business sounds like a perfunctory and insignificant task? Think again.

title: Britain Questions Too Big to Fail
description: Speeches by central bankers tend to be dry affairs. For this reason alone, remarks by Andrew Haldane, the Bank of Englands executive director in charge of financial stability, deserve attention.

title: Immigrants and the Census in New York
description: New York Times editor Diego Ribadeneira discusses the challenges faced by census takers in Flushing, Queens.

title: Dr. Martens Kicks Off 50 Years of Boot Business With Cover Campaign
description: The British shoe brand Dr. Martens is marking the anniversary of its mainstay boot, introduced on April 1, 1960, with a campaign that salutes its youthful customers and their ardor for music.

title: Financial Laugh Lines
description: Because everyone needs a little laugh during these times of economic uncertainty. Weve compiled some recent cartoons about the financial crisis and efforts to prevent the next one from being as bad.

description: By CHRISTOPHER SWANN, Reuters Breakingviews

title: Hedge Funds Mediocre Middlemen
description: By CHRISTOPHER SWANN, Reuters Breakingviews

title: Successes (and Some Growing Pains) at Hulu
description: Hulu, the popular and free online video hub, has some things to celebrate as it heads into its third year, The New York Timess Brian Stelter and Brad Stone write.

description: Chris Kleponis/Bloomberg News, Comstock/Getty Images NEW OUTLOOK Mark Chandler, general counsel of Cisco Systems, said lawfirms attitudes were changing.

description: By CYRUS SANTI

title: For Start-Ups, Late Bursts of Private Cash
description: Paul Sakuma/Associated Press, Jim Wilson/The New York Times NOT YET Some founders, like Mark Zuckerberg, above, of Facebook andJeremy Stoppelman of Yelp, are not yet planning public offerings.

title: No Confetti as Apollo and K.K.R Move to List
description: 2:26 p.m. | Corrected

title: Flush and Looking to Spend
description: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

title: Business Jets, an Economic Indicator?
description: MAKING A COMEBACK Flights by business jets declined by double digitsin 2008 and 2009 as the economy slumped. But activity increased inboth December and January.

title: The Pace of Deal-Making Picks Up
description: Chip East/Reuters SPENDING TO GROW Deals were back in the news in the last few months,including Comcasts plan to buy a majority stake in NBC Universal.

title: Washingtons Scrap Dealers
description: By ERIC DASH

title: News Quiz | April 1, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Hedge Fund Managers Pay Roars Back
description: The Lazarus-like recovery of the nations big banks did not benefit just the bankers  it also created huge paydays for hedge fund managers, including a record $4 billion gain in 2009 for one bold investor who bet big on the financial sector.

title: A Web of Insider Trading Charges
description: By DIANA HENRIQUES and GUILBERT GATES

title: Extreme Makeover, Wall Street Edition
description: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

title: Optimism and Doubt in a Duel Over Greece
description: Even as Moodys downgraded its ratings on five Greek banks, the European Central Bank and Greece on Wednesday trumpeted optimism about the countrys financial prospects, David Jolly reports in The New York Times.

title: Word of the Day | paraphrase
description: paraphrase \per--fraz,pa-r-\ verb/noun

title: Big Earners: Hedge-Fund Leaders for 2009
description: As a financial crisis shook the world economy, these hedge fund managers generated personal earnings in the hundreds of millions and billions of dollars.

title: Meru Networks Prices at Top of Range
description: Meru Networks, the wireless network provider, on Wednesday said it priced shares of its initial public offering at the top of its expected range, raising $65.8 million, The Associated Press said.

title: A New Wave of Luxury Hybrids
description: This year's tendency at the New York Auto Show? Luxury Hybrids. Why would high end automakers want to go green? The answer with longtime contributor, Jerry Garrett.

title: Mary Schapiro: A Pushover?
description: Mary Schapiro. She runs the Securities and Exchange Commission. She used to run the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority. She has been appointed to positions of power by everyone from Ronald Reagan to Barack Obama  but who is she?

title: Bicycles Built for You
description: When it comes to bespoke bicycles, Michael Maharam happily calls himself a dilettante. A lifelong collector of one-of-a-kind bikes from around the world, Maharam, of the New York textile company of the same name, recently made friends with a true expert  Sacha White, a master builder who owns Vanilla Bicycles in Portland, Ore. Together, they conceived an exhibition devoted to the work of craftsmen like White, who make a living cutting steel, welding and filing for weeks on end. (You wouldnt want to be their manicurist, Maharam says.) The show, Bespoke: The Handbuilt Bicycle, which opens May 12 at the Museum of Arts and Design, collects 21 of the finest contemporary examples from America and abroad, from charming, Old World road bikes to aggressively styled titanium and steel mountain bikes. On the gallerys back wall, a set of drawings by the design firm 24 explains how bicycles are built. Maharam hopes the exhibition will open up the citys bicycle culture to more people. One reason bicycles have become so popular is because manufacturers are making the well designed and beautiful accessible to the masses, he says. This is the epitome of the well designed and beautiful.

title: Water, Water Everywhere
description: WHO declared the flooding in Rhode Island to be unprecedented in state history?

title: Britain Questions Too Big to Fail
description: Speeches by central bankers tend to be dry affairs. For this reason alone, remarks by Andrew Haldane, the Bank of Englands executive director in charge of financial stability, deserve attention, Breakingviews says.

title: An Up Quarter Ends With a Down Day
description: Wall Street ended its first quarter on a disappointing note on Wednesday as worries about the job market overshadowed enthusiasm for the energy sector, The New York Timess Javier C. Hernandez reported.

title: Femivores and Hegans
description: Stay-at-home-mom locavores, and middle-aged male vegans.

title: Starting From Discount, Dai-ichi Takes Off
description: Dai-ichi Life Insurance jumped 14 percent in its market debut on Thursday after Japans No. 2 life insurer (Nippon Life Insurance is the largest) priced its $11 billion initial public offering at a discount to rival insurers, Reuters reported.

title: N.Y. Fed Clarifies Toxic Bear and A.I.G. Assets
description: The New York Federal Reserve made new disclosures late Wednesday about the assets of Bear Stearns and American International Group that it acquired in the course of the subprime mortgage and financial crises.

title: Poor Diana  Engines Need Love Too
description: The drivers and their cars and engines have arrived in the paddock in Sepang for the Malaysian Grand Prix, and I sat down this afternoon to speak with Bruno Senna, the driver at the HRT team. As the Brazilian driver arrived at the table, another journalist and I were speaking with a person from the Cosworth engine program. Cosworth supplies engines to four teams, including HRT. At the Bahrain Grand Prix, Sennas engine blew out, and I think it was no fault of the poor engine, but perhaps something leading into it.

title: Review: Panoramic Hindsight on Wall St. Disaster
description: Roger Lowensteins account of endemic financial collapse is bookended by anecdotes about Robert L. Rodriguez, an unusually cautious fund manager. The prologue of The End of Wall Street describes a dream Mr. Rodriguez had in February 2006, The New York Timess Janet Maslin writes in her review of the book.

title: Amid Thaw, Obama Talks With Chinese Leader
description: WASHINGTON  Tensions between China and the United States have ebbed significantly in recent days, with the countries now working together to deter Irans nuclear ambitions and with the Obama administration backing off a politically charged clash over Chinas currency.

title: S.E.C. Mulls Publicizing Details, Even If You Settle
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering changing how it deals with settlements over breaches of financial rules, The Washington Post reports, citing Robert Khuzami, the S.E.C.s enforcement director.

title: Opposition Boycotts in Sudan Elections
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Several of Sudans biggest opposition parties announced Thursday that they were planning a full boycott of the national elections this month, casting a cloud of uncertainty over Sudans first multiparty vote in more than 20 years and complicating the landmark agreement that ended decades of civil war in the country.

title: Citigroups Primerica I.P.O. Raises $320.4 Million
description: Citigroup said Wednesday the initial public stock offering of its Primerica life insurance business has raised $320.4 million, The Associated Press reported.

title: Exploring Bohemian Mumbai
description: For a city of millions, Mumbai can be a lonely place for the art lover. The recently revived Bohemia: The Mumbai Art Walk, a mlange of art, music, theater, talks and poetry, aims to change that.

title: Kleiner Doubles Down on iFund
description: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers,  the Silicon Valley venture capital firm, isdoubling the size of its fund for iPhone application developers, as it seeks new opportunities with the arrival of Apples iPad, Reuters reported.

title: Morgan Stanley Sues Former St. Louis Manager
description: Morgan Stanley Smith Barney is suing a former St. Louis-based brokerage manager after he defected to Wells Fargo Advisors last Friday, Reuters reported.

title: UBS Brokerage Has No Plans For Split
description: UBS Wealth Management Americas will not change its name back to PaineWebber, nor will it split off from the embattled Swiss banking giant, the units top executive told UBS brokers on Wednesday.

title: Special Section: Wall Streets Makeover
description: Its no secret by now that Wall Street ranks low in the estimation of the general public, with firms like Goldman Sachs finding themselves the target of revulsion and scorn after the credit crisis. DealBooks latest special section explores how the financial industry is looking to fix that.

title: Pimco Recommends Investment in Asia
description: Europes actions to help Greece are likely to be ineffective in fixing the countrys problems, while Britains sovereign debt rating could be downgraded within a year, a top executive ofPacific Investment Management Company, the worlds largest bond fund manager, said Thursday.

title: Broker Who Aided Dreier Sentenced to Prison
description: A former securities broker who admitted helping a prominent New York City lawyer dupe hedge funds into making tens of millions of dollars in bogus investments has been sentenced to nearly four years in prison, The Associated Press reported.

title: General Growth Files Plan to Exit Bankruptcy
description: General Growth Properties asked a bankruptcy court judge late Wednesday to approve a plan for its exit from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection that gives the shopping mall giant until the end of the year to court buyout offers, The Associated Press reported.

title: New Directors/New Films Video: Yorgos Lanthimos
description: Family is the focus of Yorgos Lanthimoss odd, haunting film Dogtooth. But this isolated family plays strictly, and sometimes sickly, by its own rules. A film that has been dividing critics and audiences at festivals around the world, Dogtooth marks the second feature for its director. Mr. Lanthimos spoke about the unique family aspect of his film and what made him interested in exploring the lengths people might go to for the purpose of keeping their family together:

title: P.E.-Backed Firms Less Likely to Default, Industry Says
description: The private equity industry gave itself high marks in a new report that found that companies under private equity ownership were half as likely to default on their loans as their counterparts during the recession.

title: Capital Requirements Are Not Enough
description: Simon Johnson and James Kwak are the authors of 13 Bankers: The Wall Street Takeover and the Next Financial Meltdown.

title: Cuomo Said to Investigate Ivy for Madoff Advice
description: Ivy Asset Management, the fund of hedge funds that BNY Mellon Asset Management is reportedly shutting down, is the subject of a probe by the New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, for advice it allegedly gave on investments related to Bernard L. Madoff, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person familiar with the matter.

title: What Gartmore Means: U.K. Bankers Are Nervous
description: Gartmore Groups suspension this week of the hedge-fund manager Guillaume Rambourg underscores heightened caution among U.K. companies as the Financial Services Authority cracks down on illegal trading, Bloomberg News reported.

title: What Pranks, Jokes, Hoaxes or Tricks Have You Ever Fallen For or Perpetrated?
description: Happy April Fools day! How, if at all, do you celebrate this day? Do you tend to play tricks? To have tricks played on you? What is your reaction, in general, to pranks and hoaxes, whether those youve been involved in personally or famous public hoaxes such as those highlighted in the Top 100 April Fools Day Hoaxes of All Time?

title: What Can Be Done to Stop Bullying?
description: Nine students are being prosecuted for bullying a fellow student, Phoebe Prince, who committed suicide after being taunted and threatened. What, if anything, could and should the school have tried to protect Ms. Prince? What can and should teachers and administrators do at any school where students are bullying other kids?

title: Q.&A.: Backing Up a Sick iPod
description: Q.

title: Sampler: Warrantless Wiretapping Ruled Illegal, and Suede Stays Closed
description: Judge Rules Wiretapping Without a Warrant Was Illegal | Vaughn R. Walker, the chief United States district judge of San Francisco, ruled that federal agents had eavesdropped illegally on an Islamic charity based in the United States. Judge Walker said that the Bush administration lacked the authority to act without warrants to intercept phone calls and e-mail messages between Americans and foreigners as part of an effort to prevent terrorist attacks. The ruling delivered a blow to the Bush administrations claims that its surveillance program, which Mr. Bush authorized shortly after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, was lawful. The intercepts, Judge Walker ruled, violated a 1978 federal statute requiring court approval for domestic surveillance. The organization monitored by the taps, in this case, was Al Haramain, a now-defunct Islamic charity in Oregon. Two lawyers representing it in 2004 were also tapped. The judge said the plaintiffs had been subjected to unlawful surveillance, and said the government was liable to pay them damages. [The New York Times, The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: Speed Read for Thursday, April 1
description: Here are some highlights from Thursdays editions of The New York Times:

title: The Management Styles of Harold Hooper, Cosmo G. Spacely, and Eugene H. Krabs
description: One of the most memorable classes I took in business school was an elective called Management as Seen by the Arts. It was taught by Professor Culbertson, a character straight out central casting if ever there was one: Harvard-educated, bespectacled, gray hair and beard, slight paunch concealed by a tweed jacket with leather elbow patches. We read Bonfire of the Vanities and Death of a Salesman, and we discussed how drastically the economic landscape had changed since the filming of Norma Rae.

title: Bloggers Assess the 2010 Yankees, Part 2
description: As opening day draws near, The Times will be previewing the Yankees and the Mets seasons from all angles, with analysis from Tyler Kepner, Ben Shpigel, David Waldstein and others. But with so much happening this off-season, there are a lot of opinions to go around. As we did last season, we have reached out to some Yankees and Mets bloggers for their thoughts on the 2010 season.

title: Medvedev Vows Harsh Tactics Against Militants
description: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev, trying to demonstrate the governments resolve after a spate of terrorist bombings, made a surprise visit on Thursday to one of the most tumultuous areas of Russia and called for harsher tactics to combat the insurgency.

title: A Brooklyn Brownstones Costly Rescue
description: When he worked at one of New Yorks most respected preservation firms, Timothy Lynch would have spared no effort to save brownstone houses like the two in Brooklyn that stood before him on a January morning. They were landmarks on one of the prettiest streets in Bedford-Stuyvesant. But contractors renovating one had accidentally knocked down a load-bearing wall, threatening both with collapse.

title: For the Smart Grid, a Synchrophasor
description: Move over, smart meter  and make room for the synchrophasor.

title: Wall Street Ends Week Higher
description: Wall Street investors on Thursday pushed past doubts about the technology sector and seized on signs that the global recovery was firming up.

title: The Early Word: Come to Your Census
description: Today is the official deadline for turning in your census form.

title: A System for Grading N.F.L. Draft Evaluators
description: Andy Furman of the Ultimatenyg blog has a challenge for amateur talent evaluators.

title: Planned Rail Strikes in France and Britain
description: According to Reuters, Network Rail, the operator of the British rail infrastructure, began a legal challenge Wednesday to try to avert the first national rail strike in 16 years, accusing unions of including vote counts on the action from staff members who did not exist.

title: The Parents of the Bully
description: Emily Bazelon of Slate is in South Hadley, Mass., this week, pondering the case of 15-year-old Phoebe Prince, who committed suicide last January.

title: New York Times Company Sells Small Part of Its Red Sox Holdings
description: The New York Times Company said Thursday that it has sold a small slice of its minority ownership of the Boston Red Sox and related properties.

title: Scan Artist | Primary Resources
description: Scan Artist copies the latest fashion trends so you can, too.

title: Wont Get Fooled Again
description: 9:29 a.m. | Updated

title: New York Auto Show: Porsche 911 GT3 R Hybrid
description: Porsche parked its orange-and-white 911 GT3 R Hybrid at a media event on Tuesday at a former bathhouse in the East Village, where the racecar was definitely the hottest body in the room.

title: Chechen Rebel Leader Speaks via YouTube
description: As my colleague Ellen Barry reports, on Wednesday Doku Umarov, a former Chechen separatist who reinvented himself as a proponent of global jihad, took responsibility for two suicide bombings on Moscows subway that killed 39 rush-hour commuters.

title: Helpful Suggestions for N.H.L. Pranks
description: Today is April Fools day. And the N.H.L.s fun-loving players certainly love to joke around. Unfortunately, they dont tend to be very creative.

title: London Dance Journal: Troubling Signs in a Tribute to Diaghilev
description: LONDON  Last year brought the centenary of the founding of Diaghilevs Ballets Russes. The English National Ballet used the occasion for some spinoffs, like the premiere of David Dawsons Faun(e). Sadlers Wells Theater presented another spinoff, In the Spirit of Diaghilev, which involved collaborations between artists and choreographers like Russell Maliphant, who made Afterlight (Part One). This week brought a spinoff of those spinoffs, Ballet Russes  Encounters, involving both the English National Ballet and Sadlers Wells. Inevitably, parts of it had nothing to do with Diaghilev at all.

title: In Montana, Governor Stirs Ire Over Coal
description: Controversy is swirling in Montana after the governor, Brian Schweitzer, requested in a letter sent to local officials that they voice support for coal money from a proposed new mine in exchange for receiving funds to build roads and other infrastructure projects.

title: Tales of Overcoming Adversity
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Hey, you guys, baseball season starts next week. And President Obama is going to throw out the first pitch at the Nationals game. Meanwhile, Joe Biden will be on hand to make the first error.

title: Is It O.K. to Accept Hairdresser House Calls?
description: Last year, my hairdresser told me he was starting his own business. His service: at-home haircuts, coloring and blowouts. I thought it was a great idea and recently called and asked him to stop by my place when I needed a quick blowout before an important event. His price was the same as the salons.

title: Scientists are Celebrating
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Do you know in Switzerland, in Geneva, scientists are celebrating? They have a multimillion-dollar atom-smasher that has given us new information on how the universe began. Couldnt these scientists save some money and just ask Larry King?

title: Lets Have a Party
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: You know whos coming back to town? King Tut. His mummified remains will be on display here in New York City. And I was thinking, yeah, big deal. I mean, if you want mummified remains, watch Larry King.

title: Some Frightening Information
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: Well, earlier today, President Obama canceled the annual White House Easter Egg Hunt. Instead, the kids are going to be on the lawn of the White House drilling for oil.

title: Paterson Pick for Board Lacks Requirement
description: The Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan is one of New Yorks best-known state schools, and its board of trustees is stocked with designers, city business leaders and the wives of prominent financial executives.

title: Sparkly Stuff
description: Swarovski crystallizes new design collaborations.

title: Three Men in Custody in Subway Killings
description: Update, 11:38 a.m. | The police have a man in custody who they say has made statements implicating himself in the stabbing deaths of two other men on a No. 2 subway train early Sunday. He has not been formally charged yet, said the chief police spokesman, Paul J. Browne. Two other men also remain in custody.

title: New York Auto Show: 2011 Hyundai Equus
description: 12:18 p.m. | Updated

title: Thursday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Plan For 2012 London Olympic Tower Is Unveiled
description: Hours after the design for the tower that Anish Kapoor and Cecil Balmond will create for the 2012 Olympic Park in London was revealed, the work had already earned a few not-so-flattering nicknames, The Guardian reported, including the Colossus of Stratford and the Hubble Bubble. But the official name of the 377-foot, $29 million red steel structure is the ArcelorMittal Orbit, and when it is finished it will stand taller than Big Ben or the Statue of Liberty (though it will be several hundred feet shorter than its Parisian ancestor, the Eiffel Tower). Lakshmi Mittal, the chief executive of the steel company ArcelorMittal, is providing about $24 million for the cost of the structure, with the remaining amount coming from the Greater London Authority. Boris Johnson, the citys mayor, told The Guardian that while some people will say we are nuts, we are barmy in the depths of a recession to be building Britains biggest ever piece of public art, Londons Olympic Park needed it to spark peoples curiosity and wonder.

title: The 21st-Century Orchestra: Now Hear It This Way
description: THE modern symphony orchestra has thudded out of bed, stretched its lumbering limbs and woken up to the new reality of recordings: the industry has faded away. Its do-it-yourself time.

title: Cromartie Says Jets Pieces Were Already in Place
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On Thursday the Jets held their first media availability since last season ended. Not surprisingly, the biggest crowd of reporters surrounded the recently acquired cornerback Antonio Cromartie.

title: Incentives Foster a Major Jump in Auto Sales
description: DETROIT  Toyotas offers of subsidized leases and interest-free financing prompted a sales surge and touched off an industrywide incentive tussle that drew shoppers into showrooms last month.

title: Malaysian Custody Dispute Lost Between Courts
description: KUALA LUMPUR   Through most of their 17-year marriage, M. Indira Gandhi says she and her husband observed rituals that she considered integral to their Hindu faith. Each morning they would pray before a shrine and on Fridays they would fast. During festivals they donned brightly colored, traditional outfits to attend their local temple.

title: At Hulu, the Goal Is More Episodes of More Shows
description: In Thursdays New York Times, Brad Stone and I report on a milestone for Hulu: profitability.

description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Porsche Cayenne S Hybrid

title: Norris Church Mailer: The Last Wife
description: Imagine this: It is 1975, and you are a 26-year-old high-school art teacher, the divorced mother of a 3-year-old boy, living in Russellville, Ark. You hear that a world-famous novelist is in town for one night, so you wangle an invitation to the party in his honor, hoping hell autograph your book. You find yourself smitten with this 52-year-old man  as he is with you  and at the end of the evening you go home together. After he leaves, you pour out your heart in a love poem and mail it to him. He mails it back  copy-edited, in red pencil. Do you:

title: Hairy Comedian in Hairy Situation With Australian Prime Minister
description: Nobody said this comedy thing was easy: a crack about Australia made by Robin Williams during an appearance earlier this week on CBSs Late Show With David Letterman has drawn a sarcastic rebuke from that nations prime minister, Kevin Rudd  one that probably wont earn Mr. Rudd many fans in the United States.

title: Powerhouse Gallery Is Splitting Apart
description: Seventeen years after a merger made it a powerhouse gallery, PaceWildenstein is splitting and returning to the original brands. There was no logic in keeping it going, said Arne Glimcher, chairman of Pace, which was partnered with Wildenstein & Company. We are not exchanging clients in the way we once were.

title: Did You See What She Was Reading?
description: Yesterday, Motoko Rich asked what happens when e-books make it impossible to tell what someone is reading.

title: Yahoo Teams Up With Healthline
description: In an effort to bolster the popularity of its online health channel, Yahoo is teaming up with a specialist, Healthline Networks, a large provider of health-related content and applications.

title: Mary Gaitskill and Wells Tower Among Public Librarys Cullman Fellows
description: The New York Public Librarys Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers has announced its 2010-2011 fellows, a group that includes the novelist Mary Gaitskill; the historian Annette Gordon-Reed, author of the Pulitzer Prize-winning The Hemingses of Monticello: An American Family; and the New Yorker writer Larissa MacFarquhar. Other fellows include the fiction writers David Bezmozgis, Maile Chapman, and Wells Tower; David Sandlin, a graphic novelist; Geoffrey Brock, a poet; David Hinton, an essayist and translator of classical Chinese poetry; Michael Meyer, who is writing a book about a familys organic rice farm in China; and Matthew Stewart, who is writing a book about the role of Deism in the founding of the United States. The academics are Sara Lipton, who teaches medieval history at the State University of New York, Stony Brook; James Romm, a professor of Classics at Bard College; and Andrew McConnell Stott, who teaches English at the State University of New York, Buffalo.

title: ABC, NBC and CBS Shows Will Be Available on iPad
description: Updated: 1:31 p.m. ET: At least two of the major television networks will stream their programs onto the iPad, ensuring that buyers of the new Apple tablet will be able to watch plenty of free TV.

title: Seeing the World Through an Officers Eyes
description: Cops in uniform can be magnets to the public: blue beacons, with New York Police Department insignia, blaring through the chaos of New Yorks fury of urban activity.

title: The Calm Before the Semifinals
description: Thursday is a perfect opportunity to take a breath, enjoy a pause in the madness, perhaps consider cleaning out your refrigerator  really, those mystery items are not going to become edible for your Final Four party  because we know whats ahead. March madness bleeds into April, which transforms into Tiger mania (otherwise known as Tiger Woods blotting out the Masters), which begets hyperventilating over the first month of baseball season, which will mean nothing by the second month of baseball season, leads to N.F.L. draft overanalysis and then Tiger mania will be coming to the United States Open at Pebble Beach! Yes, lets all breathe. Pause. Repeat.

title: Leonor Scherrer | Death Becomes Her
description: Death has become banal, proclaims Leonor Scherrer, the daughter of the French couturier Jean-Louis Scherrer and the mind behind one of the ghastliest start-ups since the Grim Reaper: Leonor Funeral Couture. Scherrer is building a fashion line to outfit the bereaved that harks back to a time when a widows mourning dress was closely observed, as in Goyas painting of the Duchess of Alba. Her line even comes complete with its own fragrance, Maximilia, named after Maximilian Kolbe, the Polish friar who took the place of a condemned man at Auschwitz. Scherrers lavish youth is a roman  clef waiting to happen: Catholic school, a caretaker named Guigui, her fathers boutique on the Avenue Montaigne, which, she notes, was once called LAlle des Veuves or Widows Way. Lately, shes been dabbling in music, and one of the tracks off her forthcoming album is a cover of Schuberts Death and The Maiden. Givenchys Riccardo Tisci digs the six-feet-under-obsessed Scherrer, featuring her in a recent ad campaign. Im completely in love with her, he told Womens Wear Daily. For me, she represents France in all senses: the elegance, the aristocracy  and, videmment  the darkness.

title: Retroactive Grade Inflation
description: Apparently in response to the poor job market for law school grads, one school is trying to give its students a boost: retroactive grade inflation.

description: Introduced last Thursday: 2011 Kia Optima sedan

title: The iPad Consumer Case #1: Alone, Together, With an iPad
description: Your partner is watching The Amazing Race, which you find less than amazing. Your day is done and you just want to lay next to him/her and bathe in a glow. Youve already downloaded a rental of Sherlock Holmes, which cost $4.99 and took 30 minutes. Put on headphones, hit play. You are alone, together, each of you in your own mediated universe. You hold hands anyway.

description: Q.

title: BBC News and WNET: Together Again
description: Nearly two years after a nasty split BBC World News and WNET.org have made up. The weeknight newscast will return on Monday to WNET/Channel 13, where it will air at 5:30 p.m., and to Channel 13s sister station, WLIW/Channel 21, which will broadcast it at 11 p.m.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Panthers Date With Futility
description: How hard is it to miss the playoffs in the N.H.L.? The record for most consecutive seasons without a postseason appearance is held by the Colorado Rockies/Devils, who missed for nine straight seasons, from 1979 to 87. Thats not really that long a time, which shows that its pretty easy to make the playoffs at least once in a while.

title: Susan Tifft, Chronicler of News Dynasties, Is Dead at 59
description: Susan E. Tifft, a journalist who wrote sweeping histories of two newspaper dynasties, the Binghams of Louisville, Ky., and the Ochs-Sulzberger clan of New York City, in collaboration with her husband, Alex S. Jones, died Thursday morning at her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 59.

title: Bishops Who Get It
description: Via Rocca Palmo, heres a stretch from the Chrism Mass sermon delivered by the archbishop of Toronto, Thomas Collins:

title: F.S.A. Charges 7 in 2008 Insider Case
description: The Financial Services Authority, the British securities regulator, said Wednesday that seven people had been charged in an insider trading case that prosecutors claim made them $3.8 million in unlawful gains over two years. One individual has also been charged with money laundering, and another is missing, with a warrant out for his arrest.

title: London Dance Journal: One Actor Who Can Really Dance
description: LONDON  There are more important reasons to see the National Theaters new production of Dion Boucicaults 1841 comedy London Assurance than its dances: this is a vintage production, already hailed by Ben Brantley on this blog. But the actor Simon Russell Beale  never slim, sometimes apparently embarrassed by his girth  gives the most remarkable physical performance of his career as the fop Sir Harcourt Courtly and shows the audience how much he knows about ballet.

title: Auriemma Tries to Shift Some of Connecticuts Spotlight
description: Top-seeded Connecticut has basked in the pressure of the very bright spotlight during this N.C.A.A. tournament run.

title: On Generic Wine Lists
description: Funny thing happened in my aikido class the other night: I busted me nose. That tends to happen when a body is upended and a face, falling through the air, makes direct contact with someones knee.

title: U.K. Court Halts Rail Strike Plans
description: Britains High Court issued an injunction Thursday stopping a planned four-day rail strike next week.

title: Flavoring a Roast Chicken
description: As I tasted a stuffed-mushroom filling recently, I thought a similar mixture might work very well tucked under the skin of a chicken for roasting. Then, after wed paid a visit to the Union Square farmers market, the refrigerator suddenly contained a nice little La Belle Rouge bird and I had a chance to prove that theory.

title: Judge Acquitted in Campaign Finance Trial
description: Updated, 1:21 p.m. |  Nora S. Anderson, a judge in Surrogates Court in Manhattan, was acquitted Thursday on all counts in her trial on charges of campaign finance fraud. Her mentor and boss, who gave Ms. Anderson $250,000 that she donated to her own campaign, was also acquitted.

title: Bucharest Bus and Tram Drivers Go on Strike
description: More than 4,500 bus and tram drivers in Bucharest staged a strike without warning Thursday, demanding the annulment of wage and bonus cuts that are part of austerity measures.

title: New York Times Co. Sells Part of Red Sox Holdings
description: From Richard Prez-Pea of Media Decoder:

title: Signature Theater Adds The Illusion to Its Kushner-Themed Season
description: What, a new play by Tony Kushner and the first New York revival of his epic Angels in America arent enough to constitute a full-on, yearlong celebration of the playwrights work? Well, theres still one more component to the Signature Theater Companys Kushner-themed 2010-2011 season: on Thursday the company said it would present The Illusion, Mr. Kushners adaptation of LIllusion Comique by Pierre Corneille, to be directed by Michael Mayer (Spring Awakening, American Idiot) and performed in the spring of 2011.

title: M.L.S. Expands Designated Player Rule
description: There may be only one David Beckham, to paraphrase the chants of soccer fans in England, but Major League Soccer will allow teams to sign a second superstar under the so-called Beckham rule.

description: What, again?

title: Vivaldi Sound Pictures (Cue Birds)
description: SOME people hate Vivaldis Four Seasons for pretty much the same reasons others love it: it is an exceptionally vivid example of musical picture painting, complete with thunderstorms (two of them), rustic partying (including overt drunkenness), a hunt, crunching ice and a crackling fire. And for anyone with doubts about what Vivaldi hoped to show, a set of accompanying sonnets describes the action.

description: WASHINGTON  The federal government took its first formal step to regulate global warming pollution on Thursday by issuing final rules for greenhouse gas emissions for automobiles and light trucks.

Wakin writes: The modern symphony orchestra has thudded out of bed, stretched its lumbering limbs and woken up to the new reality of recordings: the industry has faded away. Its do-it-yourself time.

description: 1:44 p.m. | Updated BlackRock opposes part of a proposed safety net for the money market fund industry, although it supports efforts to provide liquidity during times of severe market conditions, according to a statement sent to DealBook by a spokeswoman for the firm.

title: Now Grooming | A Shave and a Haircut, New Orleans Style
description: Unlike many immigrant parents, Olga Rivera, who moved from Guatemala to New Orleans in 1965, wanted her son Cesar to become one thing and one thing only  a barber. Cesar, growing up amid the culinary splendors of the Big Easy, wanted to be a chef.

title: Apple Store Most Photographed in New York?
description: After studying some 35 million photos on Flickr, computer scientists at Cornell University said they were able to rank the most photographed landmarks in New York City. The top spot  the Empire State Building  may not be surprising, but No. 5 had the researchers doing a double take: the glass cube entrance to the Apple Store on Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. It even beat out the Statue of Liberty.

title: Hidden Corners of a City Within a City
description: Never mind the celebrities and the television studios, which house Saturday Night Live, the  Today  show, 30 Rock and Late Night With Jimmy Fallon. Rockefeller Center remains the star of its own universe. Embodying John D. Rockefellers vision of a city within a city, the 19-building complex has its own post office (for outgoing mail only), postage stamp (issued in 2001, a 10-cent depiction of Atlas) and, according to the 2000 census, a lone resident (a man). As one of Manhattans most conspicuous areas, the complex may astonish tourists, but a closer look also reveals hidden corners. To discover them, take the B, D, F or V train to the complexs namesake subway station, 47th-50th Streets/Rockefeller Center.

title: The iPad Consumer Case #2: A Digital Appliance for All Appliances
description: You want to catch up on some Web sites, but other urges call. Ever since there was a Web and computers for consuming it, media folks have invoked the bathroom threshold. Its not like youre going to take it into the bathroom to read something. Except now theres an app, or at least a device, for that. Without going into a lot of specifics, no, you do not want to draw a bath, light candles and read O magazine in the tub. But, yes, the iPad works great with other appliances in that room.

title: Roundabout Brings Rapture as Lips Together Departs
description: Patton Oswalt wont get his Broadway debut  not this season, anyway  but Sherie Rene Scotts Everyday Rapture will. On Thursday, Roundabout Theater Company officially announced that it will replace a planned production of Lips Together, Teeth Apart with Everyday Rapture, confirming the rumblings that surfaced soon after Lips Together collapsed.

title: F.T.C. Is Said to Have Looked Into Amazon-Google Ties
description: Last month, John Doerr, one of Americas most celebrated venture capitalists, announced that he would step down later this year from the board of Amazon.com, a company that he helped to finance and build. At the time, Amazon said Mr. Doerr has decided not to stand for re-election and will focus more of his time on new ventures.

title: When Lawyers Blog
description: So far this week, the city has settled at least two cases of wrongful arrests, each involving cycling, paying out about $140,000 to a handful of plaintiffs. While settling a case involving Critical Mass, a regular bugaboo of the New York Police Department, may have been unusual, doing so in wrongful-arrest cases is anything but.

title: iPad: Leading the Rise of the Tablets
description: The release of the iPad raises the question of who owns the content it displays.

title: Conductor Slatkin Leaves Mets La Traviata
description: 5:07 p.m. | Updated The conductor Leonard Slatkin has withdrawn from the Metropolitan Operas remaining performances of La Traviata, the Met confirmed on Thursday. Peter Clark, a spokesman for the Met, said that Mr. Slatkin, the music director of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, was withdrawing for personal reasons.

title: Kangaroo Stunt to Promote Australia Boomerangs
description: Ads promoting Australia tourism almost invariably feature boomerangs, crocodiles or kangaroos. But Tourism Australia got into hot water when it used a real live kangaroo, which it caged and left on a busy street in Beverly Hills in January.

title: Getting Rid of Norovirus
description: Norovirus has been in the news of late for sickening passengers on cruise ships, closing a middle school and postponing a college swim meet.

title: The iPad Consumer Case #3: A Device That Can See Through Walls
description: You are shopping for a house in an unfamiliar town with your partner and a 3G-equipped iPad. You fire up Zillow, a real estate app, and it shows you everything that is for sale. As you drive, a rolling list appears and you see a domicile in your price range. You pull up in front of a house that looks perfectly quaint and lovely. You open up the digital listing and discover through photos that the people who own it are either Leave It to Beaver nostalgics or have not redecorated since it was a well-rated show. You finger drop it from your list of favorites and keep moving, on to the next highlighted property on your illustrated wish list.

title: Media Decoded: A Video Discussion of the iPad
description: Media reporters Brian Stelter and David Carr go all fan boy on the iPad and then take a breath, stepping back to look at the implications of the device for people who make media and for people who consume it. As David Pogue has already pointed out, the iPad is a different device depending on who is holding it.

title: The Morning Skate: The Guillotines Tightening in N.H.L. Playoff Races
description: A few weeks ago, the races for the last playoff spots looked over. But after last nights games (the Canadiens loss to Carolina and the combination of the Avalanche losing to Anaheim and the Flames defeating the Coyotes), theyre on once again.

title: San Francisco Entertainment Commission Fate Uncertain After It Suspends Clubs License
description: Last night, San Franciscos Entertainment Commission called for a monthlong closure of North Beachs Club Suede. The suspension of the Place of Entertainment license goes into effect April 5. It follows two months of voluntary closure by the club since a February shootout outside its doors culminated in four injuries and one death.

title: Autograph Request Catches Venditte Off Guard
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Two days after Pat Vendittes first switch-pitching appearance in a major league exhibition game, Venditte found himself back in the Yankees clubhouse at Steinbrenner Field, summoned as an extra pitcher for the trip to Dunedin, Fla., to play Toronto. He sat in an empty locker, alone, waiting quietly before boarding the team bus.
