Primerica Climbs in First Day of Trading
description: Shares of Primerica, which Citigroup spun off, leaped as much as 30 percent above their initial public offering price on Thursday, on optimism that the life insurer is poised to benefit from a rebounding economy, Reuters reports. The shares opened at $19.15 and rose as high as $19.94 on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday afternoon.

title: Seeing Things | Yelena Zhelezovs Modern Puppets
description: Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, a design writer and curator based in Los Angeles.A few weeks ago, on an uncharacteristically rainy Los Angeles night, I visited Iko Iko, a small shop in the Echo Park neighborhood, to watch a performance by the artist Yelena Zhelezov that was billed as an evening of experiments  that contemplate the notion of self-improvement. (The self-improvement theme was pre-established by Iko Ikos proprietor, Kristin Dickson, who curates a new retail display every month or so. Japanese cleaning implements and vintage craft and design books were highlighted in March.)

title: Afghan President Rebukes West and U.N.
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Hamid Karzai, the Afghan president, delivered extraordinarily harsh criticism on Thursday of the Western governments fighting in his country, the United Nations, and the British and American news media, accusing them of perpetrating the fraud that denied him an outright victory in last summers presidential elections.

title: Inside the List
description: MARRIED TO MONEY: The Devils Casino, Vicky Wards book about the rise and fall of the banking giant Lehman Brothers, jumps onto the hardcover nonfiction list this week at No. 14. An excerpt in the April issue of Vanity Fair has raised eyebrows for its intimate account of employees marriages. For all the senior-executive wives, Ward writes, there were unwritten rules. If you were married to a Lehmanite, you belonged to the firm. She goes on to quote one desperate housewife: As a Lehman wife, you raised your kids by yourself. You had your babies by yourself in the hospital. And then you were supposed to be happy and pretty and smiling when there was an event, and you really would have liked to strangle somebody.

title: The iPad Consumer Case #4: Memories, of the Way They Were
description: You are drinking coffee at the breakfast table on Sunday, reading The New York Times, and you notice someone in Vows you think your partner went to school with. You slide it across the table. He/she picks it up, the story and images pivot to the new orientation. Yes, its true; it is that jerkwhom your partner once dated. Together you go to the persons Facebook page and laugh. A shared, digitally enabled Sunday morning media experience.

title: Answers About Growing Indoor Plants, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of responses from Tibor Fuchs, the president of the Metropolitan New York Chapter of the Indoor Gardening Society of America who responded to readers questions about growing plants and keeping them alive inside.

description: Members of the San Gonzalo brotherhood leave their church in Seville after their procession was canceled because of rain. Hundreds of processions take place throughout Spain during the Easter Holy Week.

title: After Injury, Greene Gets New Game for UConn
description: DAYTON, Ohio  The memory remains intact even if the knee did not.

title: Primary Colors and Abstract Appetites
description: Even before you see his eyes, youre aware of the force of his gaze. Portraying the artist Mark Rothko, Alfred Molina sits with his back to the audience at the beginning of Red, John Logans intense and exciting two-character bio-drama, which opened on Thursday night at the Golden Theater. Yet the set of his neck and shoulders makes it clear that he is staring hard and hungrily, locked in visual communion with the object before him.

title: A Tough Quarter for Evening Newscasts on ABC and CBS
description: With buyouts and layoffs in progress, the mood at ABC News cant be good  and it was not likely enhanced by the ratings report for the first quarter of the year, which showed that the networks evening newscast, World News had sunk to the lowest numbers the program had seen in a first quarter since the People Meter was introduced by Nielsen in 1987.

title: Charlie Crist and the Liberals Who Love Him
description: E.J. Dionnes latest column is a classic of a well-worn liberal genre: He heaps praise on the nonpartisan, non-ideological Charlie Crist, with his sunny attitude and his buoyant moderation, and bemoans the rising tide of right-wing extremism thats going to cost Crist the chance to be the next Republican senator from Florida.

title: Correction: Tharp Is Back Where the Air Is Rarefied
description: An article on March 7 about Twyla Tharp and her new Sinatra-inspired Broadway musical, Come Fly Away, using information from Ms. Tharp and her autobiography, misstated the year that Sinatra Suite was created. It was conceived in 1983, a little over a year after Ms. Tharps Nine Sinatra Songs; it was not created in 1984.

title: The iPad Consumer Case #5: You See It, You Want It
description: You are finished working and on an airplane watching the in-flight movie, Hannah Montana: The Movie. For the second time. The person next to you pulls out an iPad and opens up Broken Embraces, a movie you are dying to see. Your seatmate has headphones on, but even from the side, the images of Penelope Cruz are achingly, gorgeously beautiful. You stay with the movie by glancing sidelong at the subtitles and vow that sometime after you land, you are going to buy one of these suckers. You cant sit next to it and not want it.

title: New York Auto Show: Hyundais iPad Connection
description: Buy a new Apple iPad for more than $50,000, get a free Hyundai.

title: A Closer Reading of Roman Vishniac
description: In 1983, Farrar,  Straus & Giroux published a book of pictures of prewar Eastern European Jewish life by the photographer Roman Vishniac. Titled A Vanished World, the book evoked what many have come to imagine as life in the shtetl: elegiac images of small cities and provincial villages, their hunchback rabbis walking cobblestone streets, Talmud prodigies studying by candlelight, men whispering in courtyards  a vision lighted with authenticity and charged with nostalgia. Through this and other books, Vishniacs body of work has come to be thought of as the last photographic record of a universe on the cusp of being comprehensively and cataclysmically destroyed. His pictures were used in so many influential books about Jewish life before the Holocaust  as illustrations for books by Isaac Bashevis Singer and Irving Howe and later serving as what Janusz Kaminski called the guiding force for his Oscar-winning cinematography of  Schindlers List   that Vishniac, who died in 1990, has virtually become, in the words of Leon Wieseltier, the literary editor of The New Republic, the official mortuary photographer of Eastern European Jewry.

title: A New Examination of Roman Vishniac
description: A gallery of the photographer's published and unpublished work.

description: Never mind the celebrities and the television studios, which house Saturday Night Live, the Today show, 30 Rock and Late Night With Jimmy Fallon. Rockefeller Center remains the star of its own universe. Embodying John D. Rockefellers vision of a city within a city, the 19-building complex has its own post office (for outgoing mail only), postage stamp (issued in 2001, a 10-cent depiction of Atlas) and, according to the 2000 census, a lone resident (a man). As one of Manhattans most conspicuous areas, the complex may astonish tourists, but a closer look also reveals hidden corners. To discover them, take the B, D, F or V train to the complexs namesake subway station, 47th-50th Streets/Rockefeller Center.Here is a suggested itinerary, which will be in Sundays Metropolitan section. Share your own suggestions for things to do and places to shop in Washington Heights in the comments box below.

title: The iPad Consumer Case #6: A Hole in the Sky and on Your Screen
description: You are in a Wi-Fi hot spot and want to catch up on some news. You check your usual traps, scanning headlines, and you begin to notice holes everywhere. Youve read about how the iPad doesnt play Flash, the main video application on the Web, but youve never realized how much of your news now comes in video form. You realize that even though the future is here, for the time being, much of it will not be televised.

title: An Aerial Town House
description: IF you had $15 million to spend in one place, where might you look? You could pop by a fancy art auction. There probably are some very nice jets for sale.

title: A Devastating Takedown
description: Wow. Read Nate Silvers takedown of a study thats been making the right-wing rounds, claiming that stimulus funds have been funneled to Democratic districts. It turns out that most of the districts receiving big funds are Democratic, but thats because  most of them are districts that include state capitals (usually urban, and typically Democratic), and a lot of the aid is funneled through state governments.

title: Patient Voices: Autism
description: From social awkwardness to a complete inability to communicate verbally - six men and women speak about life with autism.

title: Tennis Stars Widow Sheds Duplex
description: JEANNE MOUTOUSSAMY-ASHE, a photographer and the widow of the tennis player Arthur Ashe, recently sold a three-bedroom duplex on the Upper East Side. It closed last month for $2.125 million.

title: He Let the Sunshine In
The iPad Consumer Case #7: Built for Watching, Not Working
description: You are taking a short trip for work and decide that you dont want to lug the office-issued laptop, taking the iPad instead. Then word comes from the boss that the all-signed-off-on planning memo needs major revisions. Stat. You download document and begin working on touchpad keyboard against tight deadline. Sweat begins dripping on beautiful screen as you realize that the keypad, sufficient for Tweeting, emailing and IMing, is not the app you want when you catch a red ball from work.

title: Mint Milano
description: If you follow furniture, you know that unlike fashion its less about trends than about style and innovation. Every April at the Salone Internazionale del Mobile in Milan, the most established designers  whose impeccable, minimalist works are mainstays of producers like Cassina and Kartell  set the tone for the industry, and this year is no exception. Heres a glimpse of what to expect when the furniture fair opens on April 14.

title: For Private Exhibitionists
description: TO live in a glass building in Manhattan is to hone the urban art of the close-proximity-ignore  the real estate version of pretending that the stranger next to you on the subway doesnt have an elbow buried in your neck.

description: The ABCcomedy Modern Family featured an unusual guest star Wednesday: the Apple iPad.
