title: A Bold Vision, Still Ahead of Its Time
description: IT is perhaps inevitable that we are still catching up with Rainer Werner Fassbinder, who worked practically at the speed of thought and who died of a drug overdose in 1982 at 37, leaving behind more than 40 films. World on a Wire, an obscure two-part television movie he made in 1973, is a textbook example of a film that was ahead of its time. Head-trip cinema about virtual-reality immersions, its an analog-age Avatar, a movie that anticipates Blade Runner in its meditation on artificial and human intelligence and The Matrix in its conception of reality as a computer-generated illusion.

title: Excerpt: 'Miami Medical'
description: The new CBS medical procedural drama is produced by Jerry Bruckheimer.

title: Wyndham at National Harbor
description: WHAT Urban time-share development.

title: A Composer at Ease With Conflicts
description: THE Dutch composer Louis Andriessen has a gift for embracing conflicting values, musical and otherwise, and making it seem as if they fit together naturally. He has, for example, written 12-tone works and Minimalist scores, and has no problem using elements of both  along with rock rhythms, quotations from Bach, Mozart or Sweelinck and occasional jazz harmonies  in the same piece. He considers himself influenced by the French Romantics and staunchly anti-Germanic, yet he describes Bach as the real god in the house and says he plays and studies something from The Well-Tempered Clavier or Bachs organ works every day.

title: London Olympic Tower Plan Is Unveiled
description: Hours after the design for the tower that Anish Kapoor and Cecil Balmond will create for the 2012 Olympic Park in London was revealed on Wednesday, the plan had already earned a few not-so-flattering nicknames, The Guardian reported, including the Hubble Bubble and the Colossus of Stratford, after the London neighborhood. But the official name of the 377-foot, $29 million red steel structure, right, is the ArcelorMittal Orbit; and when it is finished, it will stand taller than Big Ben or the Statue of Liberty (though it will be several hundred feet shorter than its Parisian ancestor, the Eiffel Tower). Lakshmi Mittal, the chief executive of the steel company ArcelorMittal, is providing about $24 million for the cost of the structure, with the remaining amount coming from the Greater London Authority. Boris Johnson, the citys mayor, told The Guardian that while some people will say we are nuts, we are barmy in the depths of a recession to be building Britains biggest ever piece of public art, Olympic Park needed it to spark peoples curiosity and wonder.

title: BBC News and WNET Are Together Again
description: Nearly two years after a nasty split, BBC World News and WNET.org have made up. The weeknight newscast will return on Monday to WNET, Channel 13 in New York, where it will air at 5:30 p.m., and to its sister station, WLIW, Channel 21, which will broadcast it at 11 p.m. WNET.org, the parent company of the two public stations, announced in April 2008 that it planned to drop the BBC newscast, which WLIW also distributed to public stations nationwide, in favor of an in-house-produced international news program called Worldfocus. At the time Neal Shapiro, the president and chief executive of WNET.org, criticized the BBC program for not presenting enough context for American viewers. But Worldfocus, which had its debut in October 2008, was unable to find enough financing to keep going, despite strong viewer support. A WNET spokeswoman, Kellie Specter, said that Mr. Shapiro, who was not available for comment, still firmly believes in the Worldfocus goal to make foreign news less foreign to the audience, but with that show being canceled, we are still committed to international news and analysis and thats the reason he brought BBC World News back.

title: The Illusion Is Added to Kushner Lineup
description: What, a new play by Tony Kushner and the first New York revival of his epic Angels in America arent enough to constitute a full-on, yearlong celebration of his work? Well, theres still one more component to the Signature Theater Companys Kushner-theme 2010-11 season. On Thursday the company said it would present The Illusion, Mr. Kushners adaptation of LIllusion Comique by Pierre Corneille, to be directed by Michael Mayer (Spring Awakening, American Idiot) and performed in the spring of 2011. The play, about a lawyer in search of his son and a magician who conjures up visions of the lost child, joins Signatures previously announced repertory productions of Angels in America, planned for the fall, and the New York debut of The Intelligent Homosexuals Guide to Capitalism and Socialism With a Key to the Scriptures, which it is producing with the Public Theater next spring. The season will also feature a reading series of Mr. Kushners other plays; casting for these productions has not been announced.

title: Bye-Bye to Didi
description: Will you ever win? In the case of Didi Benami, above, the answer is no, not this season. With a bittersweet performance of the Fleetwood Mac song Rhiannon, Ms. Benami, 23, an American Idol contestant from Knoxville, Tenn., bid farewell to the competition on Wednesday night. She received the fewest votes this week from Idol viewers, but the results show was, as usual, the nights most-watched program, drawing an audience of just under 20 million people, according to Nielsens estimates. Fox placed first for the night, and NBC was second with a lineup that included Law & Order: SVU (10 million). ABC saw a slight uptick for an episode of its comedy Modern Family (9.3 million) that prominently featured the Apple iPad, but the network was fourth over all. CBS was third with repeats.

title: Library Names New Fellows
description: The Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers at the New York Public Library announced its 2010-11 fellows, who include the novelist Mary Gaitskill; the historian Annette Gordon-Reed, author of the Pulitzer Prize winner The Hemingses of Monticello: An American Family; and the New Yorker writer Larissa MacFarquhar. Others include the fiction writers David Bezmozgis, Maile Chapman and Wells Tower; David Sandlin, a graphic novelist; Geoffrey Brock, a poet; David Hinton, an essayist and translator of classical Chinese poetry; Michael Meyer, who is writing a book about a familys organic rice farm in China; and Matthew Stewart, who is writing a book about the role of deism in the founding of the United States. Scholars chosen are Sara Lipton, who teaches medieval history at the State University of New York, Stony Brook; James Romm, a professor of Classics at Bard College; and Andrew McConnell Stott, who teaches English at the State University of New York, Buffalo. The fellowship lasts from September to May. Each fellow gets an office in the librarys Stephen A. Schwarzman Building at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, full access to the librarys research collections, and a stipend of $60,000.

title: The iPad and Consumer Case #8: Back-Seat Driver
description: Hour Three in the car and you are stuck on an interstate that has turned into a very slow-moving meat grinder. Your son and daughter have begun to play something called the hitting game. You hand back the iPad and they pounce on it like feral animals, working their way though Topple 2, Scrabble, Tap Tap Revenge Three. Hour Four they begin arguing about whose turn it is. You wait for the right moment and snatch it back.

title: Charles W. Colsons House of Worship
description: Charles W. ColsonAge: 78Occupation: Commentator and prison activistNext Project: Writing a book with his daughter about her autistic son.

title: Mail Call for Marines in Marja, Afghanistan
description: Yes, it is a moment of calm in Afghanistan. And it is set in Helmand Province, in Marja, the Taliban stronghold that was the objective of a major air assault in February. Lens has been following the operation, from the standpoint of Tyler Hicks, who was embedded with Company K, Third Battalion, Sixth Marines (Into the Maw at Marja), and Moises Saman, who was getting around on his own (A Perilous Route to Marja.) This photograph was taken by Asmaa Waguih of Reuters.

title: Longtime M.L.B. Spokesman to Retire
description: Richard Levin, Major League Baseballs chief spokesman for the past 25 years and a close adviser to Commissioner Bud Selig, said Thursday that he would retire at the end of the year.

title: New York Auto Show: As Mileage Rules Go Into Effect, the Green Tour
description: In his speech at the New York auto show on Wednesday, Dave McCurdy, president and chief executive of the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers, praised the rules regulating auto fuel economy and tailpipe greenhouse gas emissions that were completed on Thursday. And on the floor of the show, Jim Kliesch, senior engineer at the Union of Concerned Scientists, praised them, too.

title: The Janitor, It Seems, Always Rings Twice
description: Quirky goes a surprisingly long way before stalling out in Don McKay, an oddball comedy with the knowing, festering heart of a neo-noir. Thomas Haden Church, lips flat-lining, voice droning, plays the title character, a school janitor in a lonely place whose life takes a detour after he receives a blast out of the past. Somewhere in the night a phantom lady beckons. Suddenly Don heads down mystery street, unaware that hes about to tread dangerous ground alongside the writer and director Jake Goldberger. In the reckless moment the damned dont cry: they kiss tomorrow goodbye and pile on the movie allusions.

title: Ferrets, Tasty Ink and a Nastier Gordon Brown
description: LONDON  For some odd reason, Prime Minister Gordon Brown emerged relatively unscathed earlier this year when a book depicted him as a volatile bully who swears at underlings, destroys office supplies and jabs his pen compulsively into the upholstery of his car in a bad-tempered manner at times of stress.

title: Roundabout Picks a Replacement Play
description: Patton Oswalt wont have his Broadway debut this season, but Sherie Rene Scotts Everyday Rapture will. On Thursday, Roundabout Theater Company said it would replace a planned production of Lips Together, Teeth Apart with Everyday Rapture, confirming the rumblings that surfaced soon after Lips Together collapsed. Roundabouts production of that Terrence McNally play was postponed in late March when the actress Megan Mullally quit, amid accounts of a conflict over whether Mr. Oswalt, her co-star, had the experience to perform his part. Everyday Rapture, which Ms. Scott, above, wrote with Dick Scanlan and in which she plays a semi-fictionalized version of herself grappling with a half-Mennonite upbringing and struggling to break into New York theater, was widely acclaimed when it ran last year at Second Stage Theater. Roundabout said the production would begin previews at the American Airlines Theater on April 19 and open on April 29. Its limited engagement is scheduled to end on July 11.

title: Jeff Jacobson: The Last Roll
description: Photographer Jeff Jacobson confronts his own mortality in this stunning selection of images.

title: Dry Heat: Early Innings in the Cactus League
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

title: Selfridges in London Gets New Restaurant
description: If there werent enough options at Selfridgess flagship store in London, you can add one more: high-end dining. Mark Hix, the British chef, restaurateur and fervent proponent of locavore fare, opened his fourth restaurant, Hix Restaurant and Champagne Bar, in the upscale department store in early March.

title: Popcast: The Bieber Phenomenon
description: This week: a review of the latest album from the country music stalwart Alan Jackson and a roundtable discussion about Justin Bieber, the 16-year-old pop music star. Ben Sisario is the host.

title: The iPad Consumer Case #9: This Is Your Grandmas Oldsmobile
description: Your mother-in-law hates computers. Hates. Them. Too old, too stupid, she says. She comes for a Christmas visit and you show her pictures from your daughters kindergarten graduation. She watches with increasing interest as you scatter and scan the photos with a flick of the finger. She takes a turn and it goes well. Then you show her the YouTube video of the fall pageant. The satellite map of your childhood home. She takes a turn and this time she does not give it back. You leave her alone for an hour and come back to find her scanning recipes on Epicurious. This isnt really a computer, she says. It cant be. I actually might like having one of these around. Is that so? Merry Christmas, beloved, Luddite mother-in-law. We bought it for you.

title: Iran Plays Host to Delegations After Iraq Elections
description: BAGHDAD  Iran may seem an unlikely place to turn for guidance when it comes to putting together a democratic government, but that is exactly what most of Iraqs political class did immediately after last months parliamentary elections.

title: Scenes From Reality TV and Other Madness
description: With a sure idea of how much or how little it takes to fill a stage with madness  in the sense of euphoria, hysteria, desperation and rage  the choreographer Faye Driscolls new work explores extreme states, from those found in actual wars to the sort of battles waged on television shows like Jerry Springer.

title: Courtesy of Brahms, Some 19th-Century Pop
description: The English tenor Ian Bostridge commented recently in a radio interview that the lieder tradition is closer to pop music than to opera. Mr. Bostridge certainly avoids the decorous stage presence adopted by most lieder singers for a more pop-star approach, his lanky frame swaying and twisting as he clutches the piano and staggers unpredictably around the stage.

title: Judge Throws Out Suit Against Moodys and S.&P.
description: A federal judge in Manhattan threw out a class-action lawsuit accusing the ratings agencies Moodys Investors Service and Standard & Poors of defrauding investors about the safety of $63.4 billion of mortgage debt, Reuters reports.

title: Formalism and Boasts
description: The point of actual overlap came and went quickly for the rappers KNaan and Wale at the Fillmore at Irving Plaza on Wednesday night. It happened during KNaans half of a double bill, on a boast track that appears on Wales most recent album. And the lyrical particulars of the tune, TV in the Radio, invited easy comparison. Wales verses spoke to a frisky formalism, studded with internal rhymes and winking pop-culture references. KNaan went more for the jugular, pledging to draw blood from any challenger, though he had his own sly twists. Ive been on more red carpets than Ryan Seacrest, he cracked.

title: Demystify the Lehman Shell Game
description: Making unattractive assets disappear from corporate balance sheets was one of the great magical tricks performed by accountants over the last few decades.

title: Dreamy Fantasies of Femininity and Nature
description: Too small for crowd-pleasing spectaculars, the Frick Collection has specialized in what you might call the un-blockbuster: miniature shows of old masters carefully selected and borrowed from other museums. That any of the nine works in the current sweet dream of an exhibition, Masterpieces of European Painting From Dulwich Picture Gallery, could easily be mistaken for works from the Fricks incomparable collection tells you all you need to know about the quality on display.

title: Upward With the Arts | The Louvres Cy Twombly Ceiling
description: Last week, the Muse du Louvre introduced its newest acquisition, a 3,750-square-foot ceiling painting created by Cy Twombly to hang in the Salle de Bronzes.

title: For Theater Troupe Without a Home, All the Worlds a Stage
description: Are you content the bard once asked, to make a virtue of necessity / And live, as we do, in this wilderness?

title: Father Did the Math; The Maid Solved Problems
description: James Newman (1907-1966) was the kind of bad father who makes for good reading. He was a mathematical genius, the man who popularized the terms googol and googolplex in a 1940 book, written with Edward Kasner, called Mathematics and the Imagination. (The notion of a googol provided the name for Google, the internet search behemoth.) His friends included Albert Einstein and I. F. Stone, and he was a noisy opponent of nuclear proliferation. During the McCarthy era his phones were often tapped, and G-men loitered on the stoop across from his house, watching.

title: Visual Diary: The Drawdown From Iraq
description: So it ends where it began, a juggernaut of American armor sitting in the Kuwaiti desert waiting to move. This video, filmed in Kuwait, Iraq and Afghanistan, shows the scale of the logistical exercise that Stephen Farrell and Elisabeth Bumiller describe in When Military Moves a War, There Are No Shortcuts.

title: Local Paper Creates iPhone App
description: Thursdays Phone Smart column is partly dedicated to apps thatll help you spoof your friends with texts and calls sent to your phone.

title: Theater Listings: April 2  8
description: THEATER

title: Police Shoot and Kill Man in Brooklyn During Struggle
description: The police, searching for a robbery suspect in Brooklyn, fatally shot a man on Thursday when he walked up to a car with three plainclothes officers inside and waved a gun, the authorities said.

title: British Libel Laws Challenged by Journalist Who Called Chiropractic Treatments Bogus
description: On Thursday, a British court denounced the chilling effect on public debate of the countrys expansive libel laws by ruling that a journalists comment that certain chiropractic treatments are bogus may not be libelous.

title: Apple Adds iPad Apps to Its Store
description: Big-screen applications are going to be a big selling point for the iPad. But it has largely been unclear what most of those applications would be, since Apple has asked developers to keep quiet about the programs they are creating.

title: Fabulous Dead People | Mark Hampton
description: In Interior Decoration, as far as anyone knows the only play ever written about a decorator, the characters Gerald and Phillipa Detweiler (rhymes with Rottweiler) are at a job site waiting for a client when Phillipa reminds her husband what he owes his success to.

title: The Voices of Autism
description: The latest installment in the Patient Voices series offers a fascinating glimpse into the often silent world of autism.

title: The iPad Consumer Case #10: A Mousetrap for Old Tech
description: You spend a night surfing, answering e-mail messages, checking your Twitter on Twitterific, the Tweets arrayed in glorious colors according to origin. It is all a scrolling wonder as you marvel at how wicked fast it browses, how quickly you move across content, how natural it is to touch and manipulate stuff you want to learn about.

title: Beware of Greeks Bearing Buzz Cuts
description: Clanging swords, thundering gods, shrieking monsters  about all thats missing from the self-consciously kitsch retread of Clash of the Titans is Laurence Olivier pitching a fit in a toga. Released in 1981, the first Clash starred Sir Larry as Zeus alongside titans of the stage and screen like Claire Bloom (as Hera), Maggie Smith (Thetis) and Ursula Andress (Aphrodite). Harry Hamlin, wearing the dry look and robes so voluminous he could have rigged the entire Greek fleet, played Perseus, the half-human son of Zeus, whose adventures and pillowy lips pushed this mythic tale straight into the realm of cinematic camp.

title: Lucille Lortel Nominees Announced
description: Theatergoers, time to start predicting who should win and who will win awards for the best shows of the season. Nominations for the Lucille Lortel Awards recognizing Off Broadway achievement were announced on Thursday, with the productions of The Glass Menagerie, The Pride and When the Rain Stops Falling each receiving six nods, the highest number.

title: Two Methods to Evoke Soul Sounds That Shrug
description: What must it have been like when the xx met jj? Did they feverishly chat as if theyd known each other for years? Immediately start trading MP3s of their favorite 1990s R&B songs?

title: Sarah Staveley-OCarroll and Michael Matthews
description: ON a spring morning in 2002, Michael Kerry Matthews, a history major and an aspiring filmmaker, watched as a beautiful young woman walked across a cafeteria at Brown University and put two pieces of bread in the toaster on her way to the omelet line. Mr. Matthews felt an overwhelmingly urgency to act.

title: Tax Burdens by State
description: Just ahead of April 15, the Tax Foundation, an organization that promotes lower tax rates, released its annual report on state and local taxes. It shows cigarette, gas and alcohol excise tax rates by state; lottery ticket sales per capita in each state; and state debt per capita, among other interesting statistics.

title: Jenniemae & James
description: Chapter 1

title: The Greening of the Waterfront
description: The mayors office was in such a rush to showcase the completion of the first phase of its new Brooklyn Bridge Park in Brooklyn that it opened it too soon. Construction crews are still installing handrails. Walkways remain unpaved. Only a few early buds are showing on the freshly planted trees.

title: E.P.A. to Limit Water Pollution From Mining
description: The Environmental Protection Agency issued tough new water quality guidelines on Thursday that could curtail some of the most contentious coal mining techniques used across Appalachia.

title: Obama, in Maine, Needles Republicans Over Calls to Repeal Health Care Overhaul
description: PORTLAND, Me.  President Obama continued on Thursday what might be called his Go-for-It Tour, traveling to this Northeastern state  represented by two moderate Republican senators who balked at his health care overhaul  to dare the opposition party to run against it this fall.

title: Ska Revivalists Enjoy a Revival
description: LONDON

title: They Treat Trauma but Not Oddballs
description: Shock trauma units like the one depicted in Miami Medical, Jerry Bruckheimers new drama on CBS, follow the rule of the golden hour, the 60 or so minutes doctors have to treat injuries before shock does fatal damage.

title: Another Bloomberg Aide Exits City Hall
description: Another day, another high-profile departure from the Bloomberg administration.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: New Works to Celebrate a Flutists Influence
description: You might think that in celebrating a four-decade concert career, the flutist Carol Wincenc would opt to anthologize past achievements. To the contrary, in two previous concerts during what she has termed her Ruby Anniversary Series, Ms. Wincenc has emphasized her lasting involvement with contemporary music. The final event, presented on Wednesday night in the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at the Juilliard School, followed suit: playing for a full house, Ms. Wincenc offered two substantial premieres and two further works of recent vintage.

title: Scottsboro Boys Not Moving to Broadway, for Now
description: The producers of the Off Broadway musical The Scottsboro Boys said on Thursday that they will not try to pursue a transfer to the two Broadway theaters that are going to be vacant beginning next week, Circle in the Square Theater and the Henry Millers Theater, because neither were a good fit for the John KanderFred Ebb show.

title: Obama to Boehner: Wheres the Armageddon?
description: At a rally inMaine, President Obamapushed back a bit on Republican assertions that the newhealth care legislation would herald the end of days.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Seen and Not Heard
description: I was at a party at the home of a semiprofessional artist. Her paintings covered the walls, and the guests oohd and ahhd over them. I thought the work was terrible, but kept my mouth shut. (Later, I showed her Web site to different artists, who all agreed with me.) But Im wondering: Was I obliged to join the chorus of praise, just to be polite? Is it ever acceptable to be truthful in these circumstances?

title: Finding the Musical Hidden in a Punk Album
description: AS they assessed the pre-Broadway tryout of the new musical American Idiot in California last fall, the director, Michael Mayer, and his creative team kept coming back to the same question: Should they add more dialogue to flesh out the tormented journeys of the three main characters or continue to rely on the songs  by the band Green Day  to do the storytelling?

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

title: Ash Wednesday, New Orleans
description: In the first installment of Continental Picture Show, the photographer Alec Soth explores cycles of sin and redemption in the aftermath of Mardi Gras.

title: Dance Listings
description: Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

title: F.T.C. Role Seen in Exit at Amazon
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Last month, John Doerr, one of Americas most celebrated venture capitalists, announced that he would step down from the board of Amazon.com, a company that he helped to finance and build. At the time, Amazon said Mr. Doerr has decided not to stand for re-election and will focus more of his time on new ventures.

title: Movie Listings
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Frank Bans Ex-Adviser From Dealing With Panel
description: 6:53 p.m. | Updated The New York Timess Sewell Chan provides more details in this article about Barney Franks rebuke of a former committee adviser.

title: Lawmaker Rebukes Aide Who Left Work on Finance Bill to Be Lobbyist
description: WASHINGTON  A leading House member issued a stern rebuke on Thursday of a former aide who had become an industry lobbyist after working on legislation to overhaul the nations financial regulations.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: A New York City Pillow Fight
description: Prepare to release your inner child this weekend, and not only because the Easter Bunny is coming. Hundreds of people are expected to swarm the area around Union Square on Saturday for the fifth-annual New York City Pillow Fight, promoted by Newmindspace, an interactive public art group based in New York and Toronto.

title: Teenager Dies, Leaving Love, and a Life, Behind
description: The Greatest, an earnest, high-minded, would-be sobfest about grief and healing, left me dry-eyed and squirming with impatience. The first feature written and directed by Shana Feste, this study of a familys emotional devastation after the death of a perfect teenage son, whom everyone remembers as the greatest (awful title!), wants to be a contemporary Ordinary People.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO  (Friday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series Dora the Explorer and Go, Diego, Go! have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Childrens Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diegos Animal Rescue Center and Doras Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (until 8 p.m. this Friday); Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street , (212) 721-1223, cmom.org; free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members; free to all this Friday from 5 to 8 p.m.20100401

title: The Velveteen Rabbit
description: Toward the end of Margery Williamss 1922 childrens book, The Velveteen Rabbit, the title character is about to be consigned to a rubbish fire. Its not a pleasant fate for a much-loved stuffed animal, but a doctor has declared him infested with germs from his young owners bout of scarlet fever. Before the dreaded burning a fairy transforms the shabby toy into a real rabbit. Later he exchanges a brief look of near recognition with the boy who cherished him.

title: Obama Is Briefed on Floods
description: PORTLAND, Maine  President Obama made an unscheduled stop at a Massachusetts emergency center to meet with Gov. Deval Patrick and receive an update on floods that have been plaguing New England in recent days.

title: John Bunch, Pianist With Goodman and Bennett, Dies at 88
description: John Bunch, a jazz pianist whose elegant style led to prominent sideman posts with Benny Goodman and Tony Bennett as well as an accomplished solo career, died on Tuesday in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 88.

title: Subway Nudity Possibly O.K. With Everyone.
description: Update, 7:40 a.m. | So of course, whaddya know, as we suspected, it was a hoax, our supposed friend Charlie lied right into our ears, and we will never trust him again. Happy April 2.

title: Ash Wednesday, New Orleans
description: In the first installment of Continental Picture Show, the photographer Alec Soth explores cycles of sin and redemption in the aftermath of Mardi Gras.

title: Slatkin Withdraws From Mets Traviata
description: I do not know whose fault it was, Verdi wrote after the first performances of La Traviata were panned in 1853. It is best not to talk about it. Fingers were pointed, however, after the troubled opening-night performance on Monday of La Traviata at the Metropolitan Opera, conducted by Leonard Slatkin.

title: Apple iPad Town Meeting
description: David Pogue answers questions about the Apple iPad.

title: How to Improve the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Critics have long complained that the selection process in the N.C.A.A. tournament favors big-conference teams and excludes smaller colleges. The huge amounts of corporate money involved, they say, turns the tournament into a pre-packaged commercial event. This year, though, fans have been treated to some real drama.

title: How Fat Was Your Envelope?
description: This evening, applicants to Harvard, Yale, Princeton and a handful of other highly selective colleges will anxiously log on to the institutions Web sites to learn whether they have been admitted, denied or invited into limbo with an offer to join the waiting list.

title: In Fields of Art, Snapping Photos
description: If you want to subject your eye and brain to a stimulating exercise in frustration, see Haunted: Contemporary Photography/Video/Performance at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. Next read the shows catalog. Then try to fit them together in a cohesive way.

title: After Traveling the World, Hunting for Bugs in Central Park
description: He survived malaria in the Amazon, burned leeches off his body with cigarettes in Nepal, infiltrated the cricket-fighting underworld in Shanghai, and ate fried locusts in Niger.

title: For Pizza, Thomas H. Lee Goes to Papa Murphys
description: The billionaire private equity executive Thomas H. Lee is betting that he can deliver fat returns to his investors by acquiring Papa Murphys, a pizza chain that doesnt even offer delivery. Mr. Lees firm, Lee Equity Partners, announced Thursday that it had acquired the take and bake fast-food chain from Charlesbank Capital Partners, another private equity firm, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Memories of a Family, With a Few Detours
description: Watching the work of the French fabulist Michel Gondry can be an intoxicating yet frustrating experience. Few directors share his ability to make images that seem to plug directly into our feelings, particularly those of nostalgia, melancholy and childhood joy.

title: A Tale of Two Japanese Pitchers
description: Appearing on consecutive days for the first time, the Mets Hisanori Takahashi faced two batters in Thursdays 9-3 loss to the Nationals and got two ground balls as he ended an impressive spring.

title: Eames Experts Selling Their Singular Trove
description: John and Marilyn Neuhart, designers and historians in Southern California, have devoted much of their careers to documenting the life and work of Mr. Neuharts former employers: the mid-20th-century masters Charles and Ray Eames, known for contouring plywood and fiberglass sheets into lightweight chairs.

title: Picasso Leads the Way Through a Maze of Cubism
description: PHILADELPHIA  Size alone does not a blockbuster make. Thats the lesson of Picasso and the Avant-Garde in Paris, at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Rethinking the museum blockbuster isnt necessarily a bad idea, even if its a budgetary necessity. Exhibitions of Vermeer and van Gogh at the Metropolitan and the Modern have shown that the mini-blockbuster, an intimate exhibition focused on a single masterpiece, is a viable option. The Philadelphia Museum of Art has done this too, with last summers show of works surrounding Duchamps tant Donns.

title: An Airborne Afghan Folktale
description: It was pretty much a normal day in Afghanistan on Monday.

title: Lacking Shelter at Home and Abroad
description: Its all in the eyes. Remember that as you watch Teza.

title: Countries Blame China, Not Nature, for Water Shortage
description: BANGKOK  In southern China, the worst drought in at least 50 years has dried up farmers fields and left tens of millions of people short of water.

title: 19th-Century Battles, Epic and Personal
description: A potent mix of war, wuxia and male bonding, The Warlords uses a large canvas  the Taiping Rebellion in 19th-century China  as the backdrop for a small personal drama.

title: As A.I.G. Gets Good Marks, Benmosche Beams
description: Over the past month, the American International Group has raised more than $51 billion to pay back government financing by selling off two units, and another major subsidiary sold $750 million worth of bonds. And on Thursday, Standard & Poors upgraded its outlook for the insurer.

title: The Vietnam Wars: Matterhorn
description: Every war novel must at some point confront a central contradiction. Only the truth has any real value, but the truth about war is that it contains nearly unbearable levels of repetition, boredom and meaninglessness. To write honestly about war, you should make readers feel they have endured those things as well. Yet no sane novelist wants to inflict that much discomfort on the audience. And so we read novels (and watch movies) filled with the kind of bravery and drama that make war look at least entertaining, if not admirable. Many of those works are tremendous artistic achievements. But theyre not war.

title: The Vietnam Wars: The Lotus Eaters
description: It is April 1975. The North Vietnamese are marching into Saigon, the Americans are fleeing in helicopters. And in Tatjana Solis splendid first novel, The Lotus Eaters, a group of Western journalists sip liberated Champagne on the roof of the Caravelle Hotel as they reflect on all that has been lost. For Helen, a veteran photographer who made her name covering the war, the resounding absence of planes and artillery has transformed Saigon into an eerie place of nostalgia and history and failure. Failed dreams and failed ambitions may be the very stuff from which Vietnam narratives are fashioned; but although Helens war is over, there is no guarantee she will be on a plane home. As one of her colleagues says ominously, The war doesnt ever have to end for us. For the interpreters of violence there will always be another war zone with new treasures of heartbreaking stories.

title: Dissecting the Relationship of Self-Aware Urbanites
description: Separation anxiety proves tough to manage in Breaking Upwards, a thoroughly charming romantic comedy that takes a fresh look at a spoiled relationship.

title: Up Front: Vietnam
description: April 30 will mark the 35th anniversary of the fall of Saigon, the event that ended the Vietnam War and with it the belief in the inevitability of American victory in wars fought on foreign soil.

title: Whats Left?
description: In his 1977 Inaugural Address, Jimmy Carter called the United States a purely idealistic nation and expressed the hope that his presidency would be one of competent and compassionate government, even as he had to allow for diminished expectations. We have learned, he explained, that even our great nation has its recognized limits. Nixon, Vietnam and Watergate had exhausted our political spirits. As the 1970s gave way to the 1980s, we waited for the cold war to catch fire, the oil shortage to become utter depletion, the Iran hostage crisis to end in disaster. Potential spies and traitors could be anywhere, but optimism was hard to find.

title: The Parent Problem in Young Adult Lit
description: It took a surprisingly long time for bad parents to show up in childrens books. Did you ever notice how few there are, compared with, say, the self-centered and murderous parents in Greek mythology or the Bible? In American literature, childrens and adult books didnt sharply diverge as categories until the 20th century, so its not clear whether we should even include that mean, kidnapping drunk, Pap Finn.

title: Journeys End
description: Weve all met Kevin Quinn, the 50-year-old protagonist of James Hyness fourth novel, Next; indeed, a fair number of us actually are Kevin Quinn, caught at midlife somewhere between jaunty and defeated, living with one foot in the present and one foot firmly in the past. In some ultimately perilous way, as we should be warned by the novels title, Kevin isnt very good at thinking about whats next.

title: As I Am Egypts Queen
description: The name Cleopatra calls up cheap flashes of Hollywood glitz, a diva in jewels, not a regal eminence invested with the power to drive armies. Those who think they know anything about her at all can do little more than recall some nebulous fame as a beautiful, cunning seductress of mighty men in togas. Shes more the stuff of fable for us than a real person who inhabited her own square of time and space. But inhabit one she did, and with a good deal more intelligence, lan and tact than exercised by most of her male allies and enemies in the Roman world.

title: Thine Is the Kingdom
description: It is only a brief moment, a seemingly inconclusive exchange in the midst of one of the most significant interviews in human history. In the Gospel of John, Jesus of Nazareth has been arrested and brought before Pontius Pilate, the Roman governor of Judea. Improbably polite, reflective and reluctant to sentence Jesus to death (the historical Pilate was in fact brutal and quick-tempered), Pilate is portrayed as a patient questioner of this charismatic itinerant preacher. So you are a king? Pilate asks, and Jesus says: You say that I am a king. I was born for this, and I came into the world for this: to testify to the truth. Everyone who is committed to the truth listens to my voice. Then, in what I imagine to be a cynical, world-weary tone, Pilate replies, What is truth?

title: Culture Clash
description: Its a long way from Park Avenue: the beautiful, desolate, casually despoiled landscape of the Pyrnes-Orientales in southernmost France, where Fernanda Eberstadt moved with her husband and children in 1998 and where she has set her latest novel. Eberstadt grew up in a fancifully ornate Upper East Side apartment with pistachio-green velvet walls, ancient statuary and a gold Marilyn by Andy Warhol in the living room, as she reminisced in The New York Observer in 2007. It was a childhood studded with glamour: in 1962 (little Fernanda was just 2 at the time) her parents  the photographer and psychotherapist Fredrick Eberstadt and the novelist Isabel Eberstadt  gave a legendary costume party at which Jacqueline Kennedy, flanked by Secret Service escorts, danced to a reggae band till dawn.

title: Under the Dome
description: One of the paradoxes of punk is that a movement based on nihilism led to such a wealth of creativity. This dichotomy is at the heart of Peter Bognannis first novel, The House of Tomorrow, which unexpectedly pits the teaching of R. Buckminster Fuller, architect, philosopher and futurist, against the misanthropy of punk. Theres only going to be one winner, but it is a measure of Bognannis empathy that his narrators decision is never an easy one.

title: Swept Away
description: The Dutch author Margriet de Moor, a classical singer turned novelist, writes fiction that is musical, even when it doesnt star castrati (The Virtuoso) or suggest a four-part fugue (First Gray, Then White, Then Blue). Her epigraphs cite musicians (Schoenberg, Schubert); her prose is shot through with recurring leitmotifs and song; and her sensitivity to sound and tempo permeates her new novel.

title: We Three Kings
description: In July 1917  the point at which Miranda Carter opens this enterprising history of imperial vicissitudes and royal reversals  George V, king of Great Britain and emperor of India, resolved to change his name. In that scorching summer, King George was a worried man. His Russian cousin, Czar Nicholas II, had recently lost his throne and was under house arrest. In Germany, another imperial cousin, Wilhelm II, had been stripped of his proudest title, supreme warlord. Deprived of power, Wilhelm discovered a hitherto absent sense of humor. Hearing that the English king had decided to bury his German connections by proclaiming himself a member of the newly formed House of Windsor, the emperor pondered the possibilities for a forthcoming Shakespearean production: The Merry Wives of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha.

title: Ratings Fall on Newscasts at 2 Networks
description: With buyouts and layoffs in progress, the mood at ABC News cannot be good. It was probably not enhanced by the ratings report for the first quarter of the year showing that the networks evening newscast, World News, had sunk to the lowest numbers the program has had in a first quarter since the People Meter was introduced by Nielsen in 1987.

title: Adaptation
description: Heres one idea for what not to do if youre young, unsure of yourself and burdened with unresolved grief: Take your mess to a foreign culture for a year and try to dump it there.

title: Seized
description: About midway through Siri Hustvedts memoir, she tells the story of a 50-year-old embarrassment: As a young child visiting relatives in Norway, she tried to comfort an older cousin whod begun weeping, by reaching up and patting her on the back. When the adults laughed, the little girl was seized by burning humiliation. This sense of powerlessness in a grown-ups world may bring to mind similar incidents for readers of The Shaking Woman; Or, A History of My Nerves. Yet Hustvedt, who grew up to become an accomplished novelist and essayist, stresses the moments particularity. I now understand, she writes, that the adults laughter wasnt malicious, but the assault on my dignity has lasted, and it shaped my motherhood with my own daughter.

title: Dance Dance Revolution
description: Most of the lingering images of the disco era arent pretty: strobe-lit suburbanites doing the hustle, John Travoltas white polyester suit and campy preening in Saturday Night Fever, mobs pushing and screaming to get into Studio 54. The music itself is easy to snicker at. Set to a clockwork thump, it ordered you to boogie-oogie-oogie or to shake, shake, shake your booty. Disco stormed the charts from 1973 through 1979, but many critics see it as the soundtrack of a vapid decade  a time in which self-indulgence replaced the lofty striving of the 60s.

title: Paperback Row
description: HOW IT ENDED: New and Collected Stories,  by Jay McInerney (Vintage, $15.95.) The short fiction collected here spans the nearly three decades of McInerneys career, beginning with early stories like Its Six A.M. Do You Know Where You Are?, which grew into his first novel, Bright Lights, Big City. This book, his 10th, reminds us how impressively broad McInerneys scope has been, our reviewer, Sam Tanenhaus, said, adding that McInerneys prose seems free of self-consciousness and of mannerism, at once postmodern and naturalistic.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: MAKING TOAST  A Family Story.  By Roger Rosenblatt.  Ecco/HarperCollins, $21.99.

title: Reading Tim OBrien in Hanoi
description: Last month, on a typically dull, gray late-winter Hanoi day, I stopped in at the citys sole respectable foreign-language bookstore, the Bookworm, for a conversation with a Vietnamese fan of Tim OBrien. The Things They Carried, OBriens celebrated collection of linked stories about the Vietnam War, has just been reissued in a 20th-anniversary edition, and I was interested in gathering a Vietnamese perspective on OBriens work. But it took me days of calls and e-mail messages to find anyone in Hanoi who had read any of it. Finally the manager of the Bookworm suggested I speak with Tran Ngoc Hieu, a lecturer at Hanois Pedagogical University. I needed a while to track him down, as he is perhaps the only person in the city who does not use a mobile phone. Hieu, 30, looks young for his age, and compensates by wearing a sport jacket and speaking a careful, deliberate English with an exceptionally rich vocabulary, interrupting himself frequently to apologize for not speaking English well.

title: Georgia: Award in Reverse Discrimination Suit
description: A jury awarded more than $180,000 in damages Thursday in a reverse discrimination case against DeKalb County and its first black chief executive, Vernon Jones. Three white former managers in the countys Parks and Recreation Department claimed they were victims of an attempt to replace whites with blacks. A fourth former employee, who is black, claimed he suffered retaliation when he refused to dig up dirt on his white colleagues. Mr. Jones, who served from 2001 to 2009, is running for Congress. He denied he had discriminated based on race and compared himself to President Obama. According to trial testimony, the county had 33 black and 61 white top managers when Mr. Jones took office and 60 blacks and 57 whites five years later.

title: Marketing to a Problem That Needs a Polite Name
description: IN a television commercial for Poise, the bladder protection brand made by Kimberly-Clark, Whoopi Goldberg, the actress and co-host of The View, depicts historical figures including Helen of Troy and Joan of Arc suffering from weak bladders. I dont want to be painted, says Ms. Goldberg, dressed as Mona Lisa. I want to be dry. As Cleopatra, she says, I have a problem  Ive been leaking for years.

title: What Were Reading: The April Fools Edition
description: Thursdays installment is a mixture of the fake and the real, but the tech editors and reporters of The New York Times sorted it out.

title: Court Ruling on Wiretap Is a Challenge for Obama
description: WASHINGTON  As a presidential candidate, Senator Barack Obama declared that it was unconstitutional and illegal for the Bush administration to conduct warrantless surveillance of Americans. Many of his supporters said likewise.

title: With Reyes Out, Mets Tejada Could Get a Shot
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  With Jose Reyes starting the season on the disabled list, the Mets will need a backup for Alex Cora. Jerry Manuel said the 20-year-old Ruben Tejada and the veteran Russ Adams were the top two candidates, and that Tejada, who was hitting .344 despite never playing above Class AA, was the front runner.

title: The Times Company Sells Part of Its Boston Red Sox Holdings
description: The New York Times Company said on Thursday that it had sold a small slice of its minority ownership of the Boston Red Sox and related properties.

title: For the Birds
description: Video | Theatrical trailer for Birdemic, the cheesy cult horror flick being ranked right up there with Plan 9 From Outer Space:

title: Massachusetts Insurance Regulators Reject Most Requests for Higher Rates
description: With the encouragement of Gov. Deval L. Patrick, Massachusetts insurance regulators took the extraordinary step Thursday of rejecting nearly 9 out of 10 rate increases requested by the states health insurers.

title: Quake Survivors Freed From Immigration Jails
description: More than three dozen Haitian earthquake survivors were released from Florida immigration jails on Thursday after more than two months in the custody of Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

title: Fordham Student Has His Sights Set on Nascar
description: Chase Mattioli, a 20-year-old sophomore business administration major at Fordham, reached under the bed in his dormitory room and pulled out a large blue plastic tub. He pried open the lid to reveal its contents: a steering wheel, a set of pedals and a gearshift.

title: Discharges From Service Still Possible, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Army secretary, John M. McHugh, said Thursday that he had incorrectly stated that there was a moratorium on the discharge of gay members of the military.

title: Put This on a Billboard: Droopy Pants Can Kill
description: Hector Quinones didnt amount to much in life, but he managed in death to make a powerful fashion statement. The statement boiled down to this: Dont be a jerk like me.

title: Top European Clerics Defend Benedict
description: ROME  Several prominent European churchmen on Thursday denounced suggestions that Pope Benedict XVI was anything but a vigorous defender of victims of priestly sexual abuse, arguing that the pope should not be criticized for his oversight of such cases.

title: Clijsters Outlasts Henin to Advance to Key Biscayne Final
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Kim Clijsterss and Justine Henins closely intertwined careers converged again in another captivating semifinal clash between two Belgian champions.

title: A City Struggles to Make Room for Its Children
description: SEATTLE  Jennifer Piper was at the Olympic Sculpture Park with her family the other day and the art did what art can do: it got her thinking. With the waterfront park bustling with bicyclists and joggers, with children playing hide and seek behind Richard Serras abstract sculpture  Wake,  why did so many signs instruct people not to touch anything?

title: Despite Few Hunters, Seal Pups Face Threats
description: OTTAWA  The annual hunt for harp seals off the coast of eastern Canada will barely take place this year. But this is not good news for the seals.

title: Kerry Tries to Nudge Syria to Re-engage With the U.S.
description: CAIRO  Senator John Kerry met Thursday with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria in Damascus, another indication that the United States is moving to re-engage with Syria as the Obama administration works to resuscitate Middle East peace talks.

title: Health Care for All, With Obama Down the Street
description: PORTLAND, Me.

title: How a Molesting Case Emerged Decades Later
description: ESSEN, Germany  The case that has raised questions about the future popes handling of a pedophile priest in Germany came to light three decades after it occurred, and then almost by chance. It happened when Wilfried Fesselmann, an early victim, said he stumbled on Internet photographs of the priest who sexually abused him, still working with children.

title: From Lithuania, a View of Austeritys Costs
description: VILNIUS, Lithuania  If leaders of the worlds many indebted countries want to see what austerity looks like, they might want to visit this Baltic nation of 3.3 million.

title: Drought Along the Mekong River
description: A severe drought has dried up farmers fields and left tens of millions of people short of water in southern China and Southeast Asia.

title: For World Cup, Javier Hernndez Could Be Mexicos Next Big Thing
description: A little more than a year ago, Javier Hernndez sat down to breakfast at a restaurant with his mother, his father and his agent. What was supposed to be a discussion on how best to move his soccer career along instead turned into a counseling session.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,378 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Does Wall Street Need an Estrogen Injection?
description: One of the more intriguing  yet unanswerable  questions that has arisen in the wake of the financial crisis is whether all that alpha-male testosterone at the top of Wall Street firms helped to ratchet up the excessive risk-taking, inflating the housing and securitization bubbles, the bursting of which led to a credit freeze and the worst recession in generations.

title: J.F. terHorst, Ford Press Secretary, Dies at 87
description: J. F. terHorst, a reporter who in August 1974 was appointed White House press secretary by an old friend, President Gerald R. Ford, but who resigned less than a month later when Ford granted former President Richard M. Nixon an unconditional pardon in connection with the Watergate scandal, died Wednesday in Asheville, N.C. He was 87.

title: A Cellphone Fine, Billed as Small, Is No Longer That
description: What started as a quest for safer driving could soon turn into a new revenue stream worth tens of millions of dollars to state and local governments. A bill working its way through Sacramento could sharply increase the penalties for driving while using a handheld cellphone, fines that some say are already deceptively higher than had been expected.

title: Cameras for the Police
description: Some police departments in the Bay Area are expanding their use of crime-fighting technology, which can raise privacy questions. In some cases, the devices can be used to monitor the actions of police officers as well as the public. A number of these technologies can be additional useful tools for law enforcement, but none of them is a panacea, said David Onek, a senior fellow at the Berkeley Center for Criminal Justice and a member of the San Francisco Police Commission. We need to look at how effective each is and balance that against legitimate civil liberties concerns.

title: South Africa: Union Leaders Wife Under Scrutiny Over Financial Ties
description: Noluthando Vavi, the wife of the general secretary of the South Africas largest labor federation, is being paid $8,000 a month to market financial products to union members, according to an investigation by the newspaper The Mail and Guardian. Mrs. Vavis husband, Zwelinzima Vavi, above, has been calling for lifestyle audits of all senior politicians to root out the corrupt. Veon Bock, chief executive of the company involved, is said to have offered $16,000 to a reporter to withhold the story  the first payment of which was captured on a hidden video camera.

title: Gravely Ill Butler Alumnus Joins His Team
description: INDIANAPOLIS

title: Seeking to Help Budding Researchers With a Click of the Mouse
description: Jonas Ketterle, a top mechanical engineering student at Stanford University, and his colleague Mike Lin, a sustainable-design lecturer at Stanford and Yale, are studying how 150 million people in developing countries make do using electricity from hacked car batteries.

title: Pay Garnishments Rise as Debtors Fall Behind
description: PHOENIX  When the bank sued Leann Weaver for not paying her credit card balance, her reaction was typical for someone in that situation. Personal and financial setbacks weighed her down, and she knew she owed the $2,470. So she never went to court to defend herself.

title: 3 Relatives Dead, Child Feared Speaking Up, Police Say
description: CHARLOTTE  A 10-year-old girl ran out of her home with her 2-year-old brother to waiting police officers late Monday night. Leaving behind her father, who then fatally shot himself, the girl proceeded to help unravel a grisly murder-suicide, the police said. Two adults and two children were dead.

title: Kenya: Court Is Given Names of Suspects in Election Violence
description: The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court in The Hague said Thursday that he had presented judges with a list of 20 suspects who he believed were most responsible for financing or organizing the violence after the 2007 elections in Kenya. More than 1,100 people were killed, many in ethnic violence, as the two leading parties quarreled over election results. The prosecutor, Luis Moreno-Ocampo, said at a news conference that the suspects included political and business leaders from both parties and that he would soon open criminal investigations against them. He provided no names. On Wednesday, two judges in The Hague said the international court had jurisdiction in the case after Kenya had failed to start its own prosecutions.

title: On Bronx Stoops, a Highways Traffic Entertains
description: Watching traffic may not be a spectator sport, but Harriette Moore concentrates on the action before her as if she were in the front row at Wimbledon.

title: Financial Reform 101
description: Lets face it: Financial reform is a hard issue to follow. Its not like health reform, which was fairly straightforward once you cut through the nonsense. Reasonable people can and do disagree about exactly what we should do to avert another banking crisis.

title: After Traveling the World, Hunting Bugs in New York
description: He survived malaria in the Amazon, burned leeches off his body with cigarettes in Nepal, infiltrated the cricket-fighting underworld in Shanghai, and ate fried locusts in Niger.

title: Lead Vanishes for King of the Downturn
Lottery Numbers
description: April 1, 2010

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Good Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations

title: Girls! Girls! Girls!
description: "Christopher Owens's longing for simple pleasures belies his tumultuous adolescence (his mother belonged to the Children of God sect): "I wish I had a suntan, I wish I had a pizza and a bottle of wine," he opines, his voice androgynous and warped," writes Amanda Petrusich. "Girls's songs are sad, but also buoyant and shimmery in the spirit of the Beach Boys or Elvis Costello; they promise redemption and renewal, something we can all stand to be reminded of." The band will be at Webster Hall on Saturday with Dum Dum Girls.

title: Pillow Fight
description: It may not warrant a special designation from the United Nations, but Saturday is International Pillow Fight Day. Leave your jammies on, grab a soft, non-feather pillow, and head to Union Square for the fifth annual event. The fight, which is timed to coincide with other fights around the world, is hosted by Newmindspace, which produces "interactive public art, creative cultural interventions and urban bliss dissemination." Participants must swing lightly and clean up their mess. All leftover pillows will be donated to two Manhattan no-kill animal shelters to make bedding for puppies and kittens. The fight kicks off at 3 p.m.

title: Seeing Red
description: "Even before you see his eyes, you're aware of the force of his gaze. Portraying the artist Mark Rothko, Alfred Molina sits with his back to the audience at the beginning of 'Red,' John Logan's intense and exciting two-character bio-drama, which opened on Thursday night at the Golden Theater," writes Ben Brantley. "Yet the set of his neck and shoulders makes it clear that he is staring hard and hungrily, locked in visual communion with the object before him. That's an abstract painting, copied from Rothko, and it is indeed very red and very dramatic. But it is Mr. Molina's stare that invests it with real drama." The show, set in a New York studio on the Bowery in the late 1950s, follows a new assistant as he is initiated into the aesthetic of the artist. " 'Red,' which arrives as fresh, yes, as paint from its recent premiere at the Donmar Warehouse in London, initially registers as a visceral exercise in art appreciation. Fortunately though, it turns out to be more a study in artist appreciation, a portrait of an angry and brilliant mind that asks you to feel the shape and texture of thoughts."

title: Hayward Grows Into Stars Role for Butler
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Butler Coach Brad Stevens still gets giddy recalling the day Gordon Hayward committed to playing for him nearly three years ago.

title: Build America Bonds Will Save $12.3 Billion, Analysis Says
description: WASHINGTON  State and local governments will eventually save $12.3 billion from bonds issued in the first year of the Build America Bonds program, a Treasury Department analysis has found, compared with what they would have spent by issuing traditional tax-exempt bonds to finance projects.

title: Questions for School on Bullying and a Suicide
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass.  On one point, everyone here agrees: the high school students who taunted and threatened Phoebe Prince for three months, until she hanged herself, deserve to be punished.

title: Manhattan Surrogates Court Judge Is Acquitted
description: A jury decided on Thursday that a judge in Surrogates Court in Manhattan, along with her mentor and former boss, did not break the law by making transactions that ended with a $250,000 contribution to the judges campaign.

title: State Court Limits Scope of Warrants for Searches
description: New Yorks highest court ruled on Thursday that police departments cannot use general warrants that apply to a specific location to search every person they find there unless there is probable cause to believe that a particular person is involved in criminal activity.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Perfect Night for Rangers, Who Werent Even Playing
description: Seven games on Thursday night, including three with a direct impact on the race for the last Eastern Conference playoff spot. The 10th-place Rangers were idle but watching, you bet, and to their delight, every single result turned out their way. They go into Fridays game at Tampa Bay 4 points out of the playoffs with at least a game in hand on everyone. Home teams listed first:

title: Knicks McGrady, His Knee Healing, Says Wait Till Next Year
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  With a pristine Yankees cap pulled tight on his head and his athletic frame draped in matching navy sweats, Tracy McGrady looks as if he could have just stepped off the field at spring training.

title: Police Kill Man Wielding a Gun
description: The police, searching for a serial-robbery suspect in Brooklyn, fatally shot a man on Thursday after he walked up to a car with three plainclothes officers inside and waved a gun, the authorities said.

title: Man Arrested in Sunday Killings in Subway
description: The police arrested a suspect on Thursday in the subway stabbing deaths of two men, saying he had implicated himself in the Sunday killings on the No. 2 train.

title: Mt. Sinai Vetoes Partnership With Struggling St. Vincents
description: Another potential savior has decided to pass on St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan, leaving the struggling Greenwich Village institution without a feasible rescue plan as it tries to stave off closing.

title: Certain Fricassee
description: Im kind of pretty, and pretty damn smart,I like romantic things like music and art,And as you know I have a gigantic heart!So why dont I have a boyfriend?It sucks to be me! Kate Monster

title: In Pinched Times, a Frugal Winery Builds
description: As guests of last months World of Pinot Noir  Californias premier pinot noir conference  filed off the bus at Foxen Vineyards, the site of afternoon tastings and panel discussions, they were greeted with a surprising sight: a brand new winery complex, almost sparkling in the sun.

title: Doing the iPad Math: Utility + Price + Desire
description: If the much-promoted iPad is going to be a mainstream consumer hit, Apple is going to have to change the minds of people like Jon Byron.

title: To iPad, or Not to iPad
description: In the days leading up to the arrival of Apple's iPad, New York Times reporter Claire Cain Miller hit the streets of New York City to find out if consumers are willing to carry yet another gadget.

title: Keeping the Family Plot
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.

title: If All Sports Are Local, So Is ESPN
description: A year ago, ESPN started going local. For an empire devoted to conquering the United States and the world on its multitude of media platforms, Web sites focused on major cities offered a way to fulfill its manifest destiny.

title: Apps for iPad From Some TV Networks, Not All
description: Television networks are taking sharply different approaches to the iPad.

title: For Minaya, Mets Glass Is Always Half Full
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  On the first day that pitchers and catchers reported to spring training, closer Francisco Rodriguez arrived with pinkeye, the result of an eye infection. Six weeks later, as the Mets broke camp, General Manager Omar Minaya tried to look ahead through rose-colored lenses. What other choice did he have?

title: Sharp Increase in March in Personal Bankruptcies
description: More Americans filed for bankruptcy protection in March than during any month since the federal personal bankruptcy law was tightened in October 2005, a new report says, a result of high unemployment and the housing crash.

title: Without Rancor, Palin Show Has Debut on Fox
description: Sarah Palins new television special debuted on Fox News on Thursday evening and, despite the early controversy that preceded it, appeared relatively tame.

title: Girardi Makes It Official: Granderson in Center and Gardner in Left
description: DUNEDIN, Fla.  In the Yankees first post-World Series championship spring training in nine years, Manager Joe Girardi had two major decisions to make. The first was tough. The second appeared obvious, especially to Brett Gardner.

title: In Europe, a Call for Tighter Caps on Greenhouse Gas Emissions
description: BRUSSELS  Climate advocates called for tighter caps on greenhouse gas emissions in the European Union after figures released on Thursday showed that some of the dirtiest industries benefited from a surplus of permits.

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column on Thursday, about the Apple iPad, misstated the top-level domain name of Slashdot, a technology news site, in some copies. It is Slashdot.org, not Slashdot.com.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the Passover Seder at the White House misspelled, in some editions, the surname of one attendee at the dinner. He is Herbie Ziskend, not Ziskind.

title: Basketball 101, Through Jaded-Colored Glasses
description: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: The Pulse: Charity Is Fined Over Fencing Rule
Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a detailed defense of Pope Benedict XVIs handling of sexual abuse cases given by a Vatican official, Cardinal William J. Levada, in which he criticized The Timess coverage as unfair, misstated the cardinals former role with the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops. He was a member and served on panels, but never served as the head of the group or in another leadership post. The article also misstated the top position in the organization. It is president; there is no chairman.

title: The Church Abuse Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: This Time, Listen
description: The New York State Legislature made a much-needed change when it reauthorized the law that gave Mayor Michael Bloomberg direct control of New York City schools. It required him to confer more closely with parents, community groups and other stakeholders before closing schools. We have long been concerned about Mr. Bloombergs commitment to that process  and a recent ruling by the State Supreme Court made us worry more.

title: Everybody Wins
description: The new automobile fuel economy standards formally adopted by the Obama administration on Thursday will yield a trifecta of benefits: reduced dependence on foreign oil, fewer greenhouse gas emissions, and consumer savings at the pump.

title: Serbias Honest Apology
description: London

title: Someone New Is Watching
description: Ever since the semi-independent Office of Congressional Ethics was created two years ago to vet allegations against lawmakers, cynics wondered how soon it would fall into the find-no-evil track record of the House ethics committee it serves. The new office showed encouraging initiative this week when it released a report that would have been buried from public notice under the old way of doing business.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday that detailed the chronology of the case of the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy, who was accused of molesting as many as 200 deaf boys at a school in Wisconsin over many years, misstated the date of his death in 1998. It was Aug. 21, not. Sept. 2.

title: Who Froze the Mideast Peace Process?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ecstasy of Fiscal Policy
description: Lets say youre a political consultant. Youre sitting there in your West Hollywood bondage-themed strip club with party donors picking up the tab, and, of course, youre thinking about what a great country this is. Swept up in the spirit of gratitude, you decide youd like to give back. Youd like to solve the countrys looming fiscal catastrophe.

title: The Myth of Mean Girls
description: IF nine South Hadley, Mass., high school students  seven of them girls  are proved to have criminally bullied another girl who then committed suicide, as prosecutors have charged, they deserve serious legal and community condemnation.

title: On the Front Line
description: Passing health care reform was only half of the job. It is just as important  likely just as politically difficult  to quickly and smoothly carry out the reforms. Republican critics have made clear that they are not going to stop fighting just because comprehensive reform has become the law of the land.

title: Cash Incentives for the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Boys Who Are Lagging in School
description: To the Editor:

title: Video Gambling in Bars Holds Promise of Handsome Revenues
description: On Chicagos gritty far southeast corner, which in the past few decades has seen factories rust and grandiose plans for a Lake Calumet airport fizzle, a couple of dozen neighborhood bar and restaurant owners gathered at the Knights of Columbus hall on a late winter evening to learn about the latest big-ticket plan: video gambling.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Thursday with an article about record rains causing flooding in Rhode Island misspelled the name of a dam along the Pawtuxet River in West Warwick. It is the Artic Dam, not Arctic.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about reports by the Internal Affairs Bureau of the New York Police Department that detail crimes by police officers over the years misstated the year that the Lexow Commission investigated payoffs to officers by operators of brothels and gambling dens. It was 1894, not 1884.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the continuing debate over menthol flavorings in cigarettes misstated the position of Dr. Mark S. Clanton, who was appointed by the Food and Drug Administration to a new scientific committee that will examine the issue. He is the chief medical officer of a division of the American Cancer Society, representing six states, not of the entire society.

title: Dayton Wins N.I.T. and May Become Trivia Answer
description: On one end of the Madison Square Garden court Thursday night were the words College basketballs beginning ...

title: Amid Signs of Spring, Hints of Green
description: FOR decades, the crowds expected flashy supercars and futuristic design studies from any self-respecting auto show. But between the still-shabby economy and the specter of new fuel economy and carbon-dioxide regulations, the 2010 New York International Auto Show is the biggest eat-your-peas auto affair of recent memory, offering next to nothing in high-zoot style, speed or concept cars that hadnt already been seen elsewhere.

title: Shooting the Shows Stars
description: A LUSCIOUS yellow Ferrari sits front and center in the companys display at the auto show, a blond draped over the front fender. Its a natural snapshot for anyone who loves cars, or blonds, or both.

title: Monthly Film Festival Designed to Be Bad
description: Like many excellent ideas, Bad Meaning Good was born over a late-night round of beers. Unlike so many others, BMG, a monthly film series celebrating the worst in movie making, survived to see the light of day.

title: Aldermen Come Close to Blow at Mayor
description: Chicago aldermen have to take their victories where they can. A special session of the City Council on Wednesday called by Aldermen Joe Moore (49th Ward), Ricardo Munoz (22nd) and Willie Cochran (20th ) to override Mayor Richard M. Daleys proposal to centralize control over city street sweepers attracted just 25 aldermen, one shy of a quorum.

title: Finding Hope and Family in the Discipline of Hip-Hop
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on March 1 about the American Symphony Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall, where it played Alexander Lokshins Symphony No. 4 among other works, referred incompletely to program information about Lokshin, a Russian composer who ran afoul of the Stalin regime. In addition to noting that former gulag prisoners had accused Lokshin of being an informer, the program said that it was unclear if the accusations were true, and that Lokshin had denied them. (Lokshins son raised the issue on Saturday, in an e-mail message.)

title: Absences Worsen L.P.G.A.s Headache
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  The 10th group off the first tee Thursday at the Kraft Nabisco Championship was technically a single.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about research into the way the brain processes literature misstated the name of the university where Lisa Zunshine, who is investigating the subject, is a professor of English. It is the University of Kentucky, not Kentucky University. The article also misidentified the school where Ms. Zunshine was a graduate student. It is the University of California, Santa Barbara  not Stanford.

title: Corrections
description: A music column on Thursday about William Schuman, the composer who also served as president of the Juilliard School and Lincoln Center, misidentified the borough of New York City in which he was born. It was Manhattan, not the Bronx.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Janet Cardiff & George Bures Miller
description: Few artists work with sound more inventively and with a cannier sense of theater than Janet Cardiff and George Bures Miller. The main attraction here is The Carnie, a carousel in a dark room that looks and sounds like something youd encounter in a Twilight Zone episode. In addition to Disney-esque plastic riding figures  including a giraffe, a deer, a cow and a frighteningly animated crescent moon  it has an arched, vertical framework dotted by blinking lights from which effigies of children dangle like angels. It is also outfitted with a drum kit that plays itself. As the whole merry-go-round revolves, speakers broadcast ominous, cacophonous modern music by the electronic composer Freida Abtan.

title: John Bock
description: John Bocks Maltreated Frigate, a video and sculptural documentation of an ambitious performance work involving himself and two actors, is one of the standouts in Skin Fruit at the New Museum. In his fifth solo show in New York (and at Kern), he demonstrates his ability to pare down, lighten up and also diversify.

title: Lyle Ashton Harris
description: The New York artist Lyle Ashton Harris has spent a fair amount of time in Africa. For two years in the 1970s he lived in Tanzania. He later made extended trips to South Africa. Since 2005 he has spent part of every year teaching at the New York University extension in Accra, Ghana. His solo show at CRG is inspired by contemporary Ghana, and like much of his art, its a knotty fusion of seductive beauty and sharp sociopolitical observation.

title: Amar Kanwar
description: Although the filmmaker Amar Kanwar is highly regarded internationally, hes not much seen on the biennial glamour circuit. He continues to live in New Delhi, where he was born in 1964. And his documentary-based art is unswervingly grounded in what he once called issues of justice, meaning social justice. At the same time, however dark the content of his work, he is a vivid shaper of narratives, as two ambitious pieces at Marian Goodman attest.

title: Nari Ward
description: Is the art world having its own referendum on health care? Theres an ambulance at the Whitney Biennial, by the Bruce High Quality Foundation, and another in Nari Wards first solo exhibition at Lehmann Maupin.

title: Security Checks on Flights to U.S. to Be Revamped
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has signed off on new security protocols for people flying to the United States, establishing a system that uses intelligence information and assessment of threats to identify passengers who could have links to terrorism, a senior administration official said Thursday.

title: Slight Rise in Manhattan Apartment Prices in First Quarter, Data Show
description: Apartment prices in Manhattan rose modestly in the first three months of this year compared with the previous quarter, but they were well below the peak of 2008, according to sales reports to be released on Friday by four major brokerage firms.

title: Letter: A Trek in Nepal
description: To the Editor: Regarding Last Footfall in Nepal (March 21): I trekked in Nepal last October, and I enjoyed the article about the Annapurna Circuit. Trekking in the Himalayas is wonderful, but you need to be prepared. Anyone planning such a trek should consider the problem of contaminated water (use filters or purification tablets or boil drinking and cooking water), the possibility of unsanitary food preparation practices and the lack of easily available medical help.

title: Letter: Preserving Macao

title: Warming Trend
description: There is perhaps no better symbol of the Southern California lifestyle than the heat lamp, that industrial, propane-fueled pillar that magically appears on every restaurant terrace the moment the mercury dips below 70. As ubiquitous as cellphone towers  and as grimly utilitarian  the lamps are a not so subtle reminder that even L.A. is prone to the change of seasons. Sort of, anyway. Kindle Living aims to give the heat lamp an image makeover by reimagining it as an actual lamp. The three models currently in production come complete with pleated shades, curvaceous bases (to hide unsightly propane tanks) and an array of colors, like black  perfect for that post-Oscar bash  or pale pink for a poolside sweet 16. And true to form, the Kindle Glow, with its translucent shell, offers not just warmth but mood lighting. Now if only it provided cellphone reception.

The two had climbed the 14,050-foot summit, but bad weather moved in and Mr. Bennett started experiencing the effects of altitude. On Thursday, five days after Mr. Thomas left, rescuers found his friends body. If Id stayed with him any longer, I would likely be up there with him, he said. [The San Francisco Chronicle]
