title: Houses of Their Dreams
description: Even in 3-D, Alice in Wonderland has nothing on the Surrealists, who imagined spaces far trippier than any rabbit hole. Max Ernst drew a maiden trapped inside a giant zoetrope; Alberto Giacometti created rooms strung with a spinal column and other oddities; and Salvador Dals famous Dream of Venus installation, at the 1939 Worlds Fair, was an aquatic funhouse filled with topless women and a rubber cow udder. For the exhibition The Surreal House, which opens June 10 at Londons Barbican gallery, the curators have worked with the architects Carmody Groarke to bring these dreamscapes to life, constructing a labyrinth of rooms and corridors that immerse visitors in the art, films and furnishings of the movements original and contemporary practitioners. The idea is to radically alter the space so that youre not sure whats up, whats down or where it finishes, says Alona Pardo, an assistant curator at the Barbican. Rather than imagining surreal interiors, the sculptors Claude and Franois-Xavier Lalanne furnished them. Their zoologically inspired pieces are now on view at the Les Arts Dcoratifs in Paris, including hippo-shaped bathtubs and a bed that resembles a can of sardines. The retrospective also includes pieces designed for Yves Saint Laurents apartment, exhibited here for the first time.

title: Best-Selling Graphic Books: Even the Losers Get Lucky Sometimes
description: Say hello to The Losers, at No. 10 on our paperback list. That series, written by Andy Diggle and illustrated by Jock (no last name  think Madonna), is about members of a special forces group who are betrayed by their handler and find themselves hunted by the C.I.A. The series ran 32 issues, from 2003 to 2006, but the run was long enough to garner interest from Hollywood. A film version of the comic is to open on April 23. Jeffrey Dean Morgan, Zo Saldana and Chris Evans are part of the elite team, while Jason Patric plays their renegade handler, Max. The Losers are a reinvention of a group of DC Comics characters from the 1960s who had many adventures in World War II.

title: Master Glass
description: A few years ago, Ted Muehling journeyed to Viennas venerable glassworks J. & L. Lobmeyr to research the butterfly-etched drinking set he was in the midst of designing for them. There he found an archive of flat files, filled with the stuff of a designers dreams: pencil sketches on graph paper by Josef Hoffmann, graceful charcoal drawings of glassware by Oswald Haerdtl and renderings of complicated patterns and engraved borders by Adolf Loos. These rich supporting materials by Viennas early-20th-century masters will be on view at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, alongside their delicate three-dimensional counterparts, beginning April 23 as part of Ted Muehling Selects: Lobmeyr Glass From the Permanent Collection. From a baroque, leaf-cut decanter by Ludwig Lobmeyr to the thin, attenuated muslin glass forms that have dominated the past half century, Muehling primarily chose pieces meant for celebration and ritual; the great thing about Lobmeyr, he says, is they may be opulent and insanely expensive, but for the most part the pieces are useful and functional drinking glasses.

title: Hes Not That Into You
description: In August 1852, Theresa Longworth, not yet out of her teens, met and fell in love with a 28-year-old Irish aristocrat and soldier named William Charles Yelverton on a steamer crossing from France to England. Theresa, the daughter of a Manchester silk manufacturer, and William, the son of the Viscount of Avonmore, talked through the night. Nothing clandestine happened, but seven months later Theresa picked up her pen and wrote to this attractive stranger. From the beginning, her exchange with William followed a troublesome pattern: Theresa passionately throwing herself at a man who remained reluctant and evasive. Although he often failed to write, Theresa somehow managed, as Chlo Schama writes in Wild Romance, her portrait of this willful woman, to turn his apathy into a sign of his commitment.

title: London Dance Journal: MacMillans Judas Tree
description: Plenty of artists are controversial in their lifetimes, but in most cases the dust settles. The choreographer Kenneth MacMillan died in 1992. Some of his ballets remain controversial for their subject matter: abusive sexuality, abnormal psychology and social dissidence were regular themes of his. Some of his ballets remain controversial for their style, which could include aspects of exaggerated and repetitious expressionism, sexual imagery in nonsexual contexts, acrobatic hyperextension, over-manipulative partnering and jerkily mechanical pure-dance routines. And almost every ballet he ever made remains controversial for its deficiencies of construction: individual dances are too long or too irrelevant, certain scenes are expressively unclear, overall organization has too many loose ends.

title: This Was Her Story: S. Epatha Merkerson Leaves Law & Order
description: Is there a way to make the Law & Order donk-donk sound in a sad way, to indicate a bittersweet transition? S. Epatha Merkerson, who for nearly two decades has played that crime dramas hard-charging police lieutenant, Anita Van Buren, will leave the show at the end of its current season, The Hollywood Reporter said. Ms. Merkerson, an Emmy Award-winner for the HBO adaptation of Lackawanna Blues (not to mention the performer who played Reba the mail lady on Pee-wees Playhouse), appeared in an episode of Law & Order in its first season, back when George Dzundza and Chris Noth were still the lead cops. She then joined the show as Lt. Van Buren in its fourth season in 1993. Since then Ms. Merkerson has appeared in more than 375 episodes of Law & Order, and been on the show longer than any other cast member. The Hollywood Reporter said a deal to return Law & Order to NBC for its 21st season was not yet in place.

title: Married? A Bit Bored? See a Shootout
description: TWO evenings or so every month, the director Shawn Levy and his wife arrange a sitter for their three daughters and drive to Giorgio Baldi, an Italian restaurant in Santa Monica, Calif. Its our date night, Mr. Levy, whose films include Cheaper by the Dozen and the Night at the Museum series, said by phone recently. The couple, who have been married for 14 years, always order the same thing: ravioli, sole, langoustines. Out at dinner a few years ago, Mr. Levy recalled, it occurred to us as we were talking that we were just checking off boxes  which gift we had to buy for some kids birthday, what plans we had to get done, what happened with our daughter at school that day.

title: The Bun Report | Hot, Cross and Sticky
description: Lately, buns  sometimes holy  have been on everyones minds, bodies and menus. As a nod to Good Friday, with apologies to anyone whos off leavened items this week, heres a guide to the Big Apples best buns: sticky, cinnamon, hot cross and otherwise:STICKY BUNSLets start at the very beginning with a small bakery on Madison Avenue at 83rd Street, William Greenberg Jr. Desserts. When I was a child, my father went here for schnecken. The German word for snail, its reference is the spiral shape of the thing. In fact, while I identify schnecken with this particular rich-doughed, cinnamon-filled, raisin-laden, pecan-topped, caramelized breakfast staple, the label is as generic as danish, and can be used to describe any flattened, coiled, cinnamon-raisin pastry. Sadly, William Jr. sold his bakery a number of years ago and the goods dont taste the same. If you want to experience a sticky bun as I knew it, you can go two blocks down to E.A.T., where Eli Zabar has created something that rivals the Greenberg classic. Or else call Scarsdale, where Williams son Seth continues to bake (and sell) his fathers schnecken. Seth uses the same ingredients as his dad and has the original 1930s recipe cards to prove it. You can taste the sour cream and butter in the dough; the perfectly burnt brown sugar in the thick glaze.

title: Great Expectations
description: When I first told my son, Charlie, about the Easter Bunny and described his duties  distributing and hiding colored eggs  my logical 3-year-old would have none of it. But rabbits dont have any hands, he said. Since I never believed in the Easter Bunny, either, I didnt apply further pressure on the issue. Next to the Crucifixion itself (whose violent details I spared my son and daughter until age 7 or so), the image of a man-size rodent that lurches around peoples houses late at night, clutching fragile treats in its curled paws, strikes me as one of the most appalling nightmare visions that adults can inflict on tender minds.

title: High-School Redux
description: Paul was one of my best friends in high school, but we drifted apart after graduation. We werent good about staying in touch, and it had been years since wed seen each other. I blew off my 20th reunion two years ago. Dont get me wrong: I love witnessing the ravishing effects of time on bodies that arent mine; its just that you have to go through so much lame small talk to see the train wrecks. But I really wanted to know how Paul was doing. We were close once. It felt wrong that wed gone through 22 years of life experiences without talking. If we reconnected, I wondered, could we still be friends? Does the raw material for friendship remain intact despite decades of separation?

title: Vatican Priest Likens Criticism Over Abuse to Anti-Semitism
description: ROME  A senior Vatican priest, speaking before Pope Benedict XVI at a Good Friday service, compared the worlds outrage at sexual abuse scandals in the Catholic Church to the persecution of the Jews, prompting angry responses from victims advocates and consternation from Jewish groups.

title: Setting a Curfew  or Not  for Your Child

The film has generated a lot of buzz with packed pre-release screenings throughout the East Bay, the Peninsula and in Marin, where The Pacific Sun said it resonated with parents, students and teachers.

title: Some Comments on DealBooks Comments
description: DealBook is rolling out a new comments system that is similar to the one used on articles and most other blogs on NYTimes.com, so you will probably notice some changes. And as we introduce the new system, we would like to remind readers about our guidelines for acceptable comments.

title: U.S. Urges Homeowners to Remove Chinese Drywall
description: The federal government on Friday instructed families with certain Chinese-made drywall to rid their homes of the material and replace electrical wiring, gas pipes and sprinkler systems.

title: Twins Head to a New Stadium and Take Mauer Along
description: An interested observer in a Vancouver Canucks cap raised his hand at Joe Mauers news conference last month in Fort Myers, Fla. The moderator called on him, and, following the lead of reporters, he stated his name and affiliation.

title: G.M. and Toyotas Joint Venture Ends in California
description: 7:00 p.m. | Updated

title: Protect Your Art With More Than a Handshake
description: DEALINGS in the art world have long been conducted with a decorum that belies the money at stake. Handshake agreements are still commonplace. But every so often, something happens that wakes even top collectors to the risks of conducting business as usual.

title: Wild Romance
description: Chapter Four: The Dublin Trial

title: Kenya Lawmakers Pass Draft Constitution, Limiting Presidency
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenyan lawmakers late Thursday night passed a new draft constitution that would curtail the sweeping powers of Kenyas imperial-like presidency, enhance individual rights and give more power to local governments.

title: Shusters CNN Dalliance May Bring MSNBC Response
description: David Shuster, an anchor on MSNBC, recently participated in a test of a new show. But not for his own network.

title: The Storm
description: Chapter 1: On a Raw Morning They Said Good-bye

title: Leaving a Studio for a Home
description: Galia Solomonoff and Fabian Marcaccio decided it was time to stop living in Mr. Marcaccio's studio when they had their son.

title: Answers for the Unemployed and Uninsured
description: Todays Patient Money column offers a useful primer of the various health insurance options available to people who have recently lost their jobs or who dont have insurance.

title: When Live-Work No Longer Works
description: FOR more than a decade, Galia Solomonoff and Fabian Marcaccio lived happily in Mr. Marcaccios studio, a 2,500-square-foot loft in a Chelsea co-op building.

title: Finding Themselves in Lost
description: THE action on Lost takes place in the wilds of adventure reels and pulp paperbacks, racing through island jungles and in and out of submarines, caves, an underground lair beneath a heavy hatch and the torch-lit temple of the Others. But The Transmission, despite its place among many fans as the definitive weekly podcast about Lost, plays out in the far less exotic  if still dangerous  toy room of the Ozawa family in Honolulu.

title: Same Party, Similar Bills. Let the Fighting Begin.
description: State legislators A, B and C want to wipe out immigration fraud. They are all Democrats. An easy equation for intraparty harmony, right?

title: A Painter's Six-Room Canvas
description: Catharine Warren, a painter, lives with her husband, Bradley Geist, a semi-retired patent lawyer, in a luxuriously furnished apartment on East 80th Street.

title: Obama to Meet With 11 European Leaders
description: President Obama will meet with leaders of Central and Eastern Europe when he travels to Prague next week to sign a new arms control treaty with Russia, the White House said on Friday.

title: Riding the Cylcone
description: A trip on Coney Island's Cyclone roller coaster, from start to finish.

title: A Painters Six-Room Canvas
description: THE third-floor apartment on East 80th Street where Catharine Warren, a painter, lives with her husband, Bradley Geist, a semiretired patent lawyer, is almost preternaturally quiet. The walls are so thick that the traffic is not even a whisper. Town houses sit snugly on either side, yet the nearest neighbor might be miles away.

title: Interview: Xavier Dolan
description: Xavier Dolan, the writer and director of "I Killed My Mother," discusses his role in the film and his directing method.

title: A Blogger Signs Off but Mini-Rants Go On
description: It started in earnest in October with the Bay Bridge eyebar failure.

title: Travel Deals: Book Early to Save on Amtrak
description: Amtrak, which has been offering up to 25 percent off Northeast Regional fares since February 2009, is making the discount fares permanent for travelers who book 14 days in advance.

title: Halladay Is Closer to Seeing Playoffs From a Dugout
description: Some players do not watch postseason baseball unless they are playing it. Maybe they are busy. Maybe they are not interested. Maybe it hurts too much to watch instead of play.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Kim Cattrall, A.O. Scott, Ellen DeGeneres and More
description: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: L.O.L.s from the B.L.S.
description: Looking for tips on landing a job? Curious about the outlook for manufacturing in Indiana? The answers are now just a click way.

title: White House Calls Karzai Speech Troubling
description: The White House expressed unhappiness Friday with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan after a harsh anti-Western speech in which he accused foreigners of manipulating last years election and warned that American and NATO troops risked being seen as invaders.

title: Problems Spring Up for 2003-6 Saab 9-3s
description: General Motors is offering an extended warranty on about 66,000 20036 Saab 9-3s to cover the cost of replacing front springs that break due to corrosion.

title: We Three Things | Slumber Party
description: We Three Things is a roundup of three items from the current visual landscape that share a common theme. Shapton, a former art director of the New York Times Op-Ed page as well as an author (Important Artifacts and Personal Property From the Collection of Lenore Doolan and Harold Morris, Including Books, Street Fashion, and Jewelry), illustrator and publisher, connects the dots.

title: John Forsythe, Debonair Dynasty Star, Dies
description: John Forsythe, the debonair actor whose matinee-idol looks, confident charm and mellifluous voice helped make him the star of three hit television series, including ABCs glamour soap Dynasty, died on Thursday in Santa Ynez, Calif. He was 92.

title: John Forsythe, Debonair Dynasty Star, Dies
description: John Forsythe, the debonair actor whose matinee-idol looks, confident charm and mellifluous voice helped make him the star of three hit television series, including ABCs glamour soap Dynasty, died on Thursday in Santa Ynez, Calif. He was 92.

title: In Turkey, Proposed Changes Aim at Old Guard
description: Turkeys governing party moved this week to further reduce the power of the countrys staunchly secular old guard, submitting a series of amendments to Turkeys military coup-era 1982 Constitution, but passage is far from assured.

title: John Forsythe, Dynasty Actor, Is Dead at 92
description: John Forsythe, the debonair actor whose matinee-idol looks, confident charm and mellifluous voice helped make him the star of three hit television series, including ABCs glamour soap Dynasty, died on Thursday at his home in Santa Ynez, Calif. He was 92.

title: What Were Reading
Alex Rodriguez Denies Taking Drugs
description: Alex Rodriguez told investigators and lawyers for Major League Baseball on Thursday that he was treated by a Canadian-based doctor now under investigation by federal authorities but that he did not receive performance-enhancing drugs from him, according to two people in baseball with knowledge of the meeting.

title: One and a Half Men
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: Reeling in the Benefits of Fish
description: In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman cooks up new ways to enjoy the health benefits of fish. Fish typically is a good source of healthful omega-3 fatty acids, and studies show that eating fish regularly is associated with better heart health. She writes:

title: Walls, Real and Imagined, Surround the Roma
description: OSTROVANY, Slovakia  The gray barrier evokes the West Bank or cold war Berlin: a 500-foot-long, 7-foot-high concrete wall that separates a Roma ghetto from the neatly manicured homes of gadzos, or white people, on the other side.

title: Signs of Life in Sand-State Real Estate
description: SAND is not a good foundation for a house, and it certainly wasnt a good foundation for a housing boom. But now home prices are starting to recover in some so-called sand states.

title: Help Paying Mortgages Elicits Anger
description: The angry comments flooded in after the federal government announced it was expanding its program to assist unemployed homeowners, as well as borrowers who owe more on their mortgages than their homes are now worth.

title: Virtuosity Flows From Street to Piano
description: If you have spent time on the East Side of Manhattan around the United Nations, there is a good chance you have seen a man walking around looking a bit like Elton John circa 1977.

title: Want a Cheaper 3G iPad Now? Heres How.
description: The price of a new 3G-connected iPad just dropped.

title: Ivorian With a Game to Match His Brazilian Name
description: Few African national soccer teams in recent years have supplied as many impact players to Europe as Ivory Coast. Sven Goran Eriksson, the teams new manager, is no doubt familiar with the Ivorian stars of the Premier League like Didier Drogba, Salomon Kalou and Emmanuel Eboue. But many of the countrys best players began their European careers in France, and it is in Ligue 1 where Eriksson might find the next name for his World Cup roster this summer: Gervais Yao Kouassi, known as Gervinho.

title: An Enclave Passed Down to Generations
description: ON certain afternoons in Country Club, a small waterfront neighborhood near the Throgs Neck peninsula in the Northeast Bronx, small groups of men congregate in kitchens for the beloved ritual of the sauce. After the tomatoes and the seasoning are wedded together, the mixture is poured into jars and wrapped in a blanket to cool  an essential step on its way to the top of many a pasta dish.

title: Friends With Different Parenting Styles
description: A reader, JK, from Queens, has a question  a variation on the Motherlode discussion a few weeks ago about friendships. Back then we talked about staying close with childless friends once you become a parent. What JK is wondering about is how to stay close with others who have children but whose parenting style is somewhere on the spectrum of irritating to alarming.

title: After 9 Forgettable Years, Reds Could Be on the Move
description: For the Cincinnati Reds, the last decade began with so much promise. They were coming off a 96-win season and had just added baseballs premier star, Ken Griffey Jr., with a new ballpark starting to rise.

title: Liberty Tower: A Storied Skyscraper With Much to Celebrate
description: ITS a big birthday for a co-op with an eventful history.

title: Film Director Pays for Supporting Iran Protests
description: One month after he was arrested, Jafar Panahi, an internationally celebrated Iranian director who openly sided with opposition protesters last year, is still being held without charge and interrogated in a Tehran prison, the opposition Web site Jaras reported on Friday.

title: A New Look at Urban Life
description: A look at the first phase of the new Brooklyn Bridge Park.

title: New Directors/New Films Video: Xavier Dolan
description: On Sunday, New Directors/New Films will close this years series with a film by a director who very well couldnt be newer. I Killed My Mother was written and directed by the 21-year-old French-Canadian Xavier Dolan. The film, which explores the strained relationship between a mother and her teenage son, also stars Mr. Dolan. In the past year, I Killed My Mother received raves from audiences at the Cannes Film Festival and became Canadas submission for the best foreign language film Oscar. Mr. Dolan spoke about casting himself in his first feature (an excellent way to land a role) and the spontaneous nature by which the scenes in the film were developed:

title: Houses That Hang Around
description: ANOTHER spring, another home-selling season under way, and another chance to wonder about houses that are listed now, just as they were last spring, and in some cases the spring before that.

title: Donald J. Trump Jr.
description: Mr. Trump, 32, is an executive vice president at the Trump Organization, a title he shares with his sister Ivanka and his brother Eric. His father, Donald J. Trump, is the chairman and chief executive.

title: Lenders Loosen Reins on Jumbo Mortgages
description: IT may be too early to announce a thaw of the mortgage market, but some early signs have emerged, at least in one important category: jumbo loans.

title: Dream Realized, Now Its Time to Wake Up
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Womens Professional Soccer in the leagues first season. Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, will be filing to the Goal blog as the defending champions prepare for the opening of their 2010 season on April 11.

title: What Do You Think of the Program for Distressed Homeowners?
description: In this weeks Your Money column, I wrote about the wave of angry reader comments on The New York Timess Web site after the government announced plans to expand its program to help troubled homeowners.

title: Rays Look to Rise Again in the East
description: Three teams in the American League have it all, and their identities are no secret. The Yankees, the Boston Red Sox and the Los Angeles Angels have lots of money, deep reservoirs of homegrown talent and passionate fans who seem to scrape up every ticket every night.

title: Charmed Obsolescence
description: MARIA BERMAN was hopelessly smitten with the working fireplace in her first New York apartment, a third-floor walk-up in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.

title: In New Jersey, Holding the Line at Nine-Foot Ceilings
description: CEILINGS that soar to 9, 10 or even 15 feet, a hallmark of the construction boom in the last decade, have managed to survive the recession even as home builders and buyers are moving toward smaller living spaces.

title: Builders Ponder a Housing Mandate
description: AS Westchester tries to comply with a federal settlement mandating the creation of affordable housing in mostly white, well-to-do communities, the construction of low-cost units continues in low-income, racially mixed areas.

title: Inspirational Stories on Fox? You Betcha!
description: When Sarah Palin made her debut as the host of a Fox News show on Thursday night she didnt reload, she retreated into canned television formula. Fans who thought that having her own cable program would allow the former Alaska governor to be her true spontaneous and unfettered self had to feel let down by the debut of Real American Stories.

title: Reaching Out, Pushing Back and Holding Tight
description: Around the world, people and nations are constantly pushing, pulling, testing and embracing one another.

title: E-Book Dodge
description: I bought an e-reader for travel and was eager to begin Under the Dome, the new Stephen King novel. Unfortunately, the electronic version was not yet available. The publisher apparently withheld it to encourage people to buy the more expensive hardcover. So I did, all 1,074 pages, more than three and a half pounds. Then I found a pirated version online, downloaded it to my e-reader and took it on my trip. I generally disapprove of illegal downloads, but wasnt this O.K.? C.D., BRIGHTWATERS, N.Y.

title: Nefarious Doings in a World of Sunlit Decay
description: THE ICONS OF SUSPENSE COLLECTION: HAMMER FILMS

title: In Queens, a Civic Group Flexes Its Muscles
description: All manner of politicians have made it a point to show up at meetings of the Juniper Park Civic Association in Queens: City Council members; Representative Anthony D. Weiner, who represents parts of the borough; and even George E. Pataki when he was governor of New York.

title: Good Friday Links
description: Peggy Noonan on the scandal, the press and the Popes.

title: Off the Menu: Quattro Gastronomia Italiana
description: The twins Fabrizio and Nicola Carro, from the Piedmont region of Italy, have been cooking together at Quattro Gastronomia Italiana in Miami Beach since 2006. Now they are splitting up, and Fabrizio will be running the kitchen at a branch opening on April 9 in the Trump SoHo.

title: Where Everyone Knows Your Twitter Handle
description: Some people want to go to a bar where everybody knows their name. And some people want to go to a bar where no one will judge them if they put their iPhones on the table, compulsively text while chatting and talk social media marketing long after the workday is done.

title: On Cable, Some Run but Hiding Is Tougher
description: Its a wonder that anyone stays missing in this country. On Monday, Runaway Squad arrives on A&E, joining The Locator on WE as cable shows dedicated to the tracking down of loved ones who may or may not want to be found.

title: Construction Damages Day Care Center Next Door
description: A day care center on the Lower East Side was displaced Thursday evening when excavation work on the building site next door caused the day care centers building to crack, the Department of Buildings said. No one was evacuated  the day care center, Action for Progress at 255 East Houston Street near Suffolk Street, was not in session when the order was issued.

title: A Cheese Factory to Open in Manhattan
description: Beechers Handmade Cheese, which has been in Seattles Pike Place Market since 2003, will open a cheese factory in the Flatiron district in February. The factory will be similar to the one they have in Seattle, where the entire operation can be viewed through a plate-glass partition. They also make and sell excellent mac-and-cheese and other products. Theyll add a wine bar and cheese cave on the lower level of the space at 900 Broadway (20th Street), in the same Stanford White building where Craftbar is located.

title: Hot Cross, and Other, Buns
description: At the time of year when hot-cross buns may be of interest, the Moment blog has a guide to great buns of all sorts in New York.

title: Country Grief, Soulful Gospel and Gay Lust
description: Gary Allan

title: Lettuce Soup
description: Mark Bittman makes a chilled soup with romaine lettuce.

title: 2010 American League Predictions
description: Heres the post to clip-n-save (or bookmark, I guess) for Oct. 3, the day the regular season ends. Feel free to taunt all you want about picks that go horribly wrong, like last years prediction that the Royals would win the A.L. Central. As the season begins, this is my best guess for what will happen  understanding that much of it could look foolish in six months.

title: Sunday Preview
description: The island nation of Mauritius, known as the Pearl of the Indian Ocean, was once the province of jet-setters, offering white beaches, world-class diving and tea plantations. But as the writer Seth Sherwood discovers new air service and affordable hotels now makes it possible to visit on a budget.

title: Black Is the New Black
description: The 27-year-old Jordan-born, Paris-based designer Rad Hourani is known for his unwavering commitment to aggressively modern androgyny and to his all-black palette. T asked the roi du noir for his take on a new exhibition devoted to his favorite color.

title: Shane Dawson, YouTubes Comic for the Under-30 Set
description: MIGHTYLIONS1 says hes crude. WorldWalker calls his videos disgusting.

title: Ricky Martins Personal Spin on His Own News
description: LAST week the Latin pop star Ricky Martin  to the surprise of perhaps almost no one  came out of the closet. Did he give the exclusive to People? Nope. Whisper it to Page Six? Nuh-uh. Submit to a tearful interview with Barbara Walters? Not a chance.

title: Take a Little Trip and See
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Governors Receive Threats From Extremist Group
description: WASHINGTON  Governors around the country said Friday that they had received letters from an extremist group warning that they might be forcibly removed from office if they did not step down within three days.

title: The Charms of the Loser Lettuces
description: FOR many people, the world of lettuce has changed enormously in the last decade. The standard is no longer head lettuce, but mesclun, or baby lettuce mix, or whatever you choose to call the omnipresent pile of variably colored leaves, tissue-thin and textureless. (Im aware theres sometimes a bit of radicchio thrown in there for color and flavor, but the amount is insignificant.)

title: Bank of America Grants New Credit Card Protections to Small Businesses
description: From John Tozzi at BusinessWeek we learn that Bank of America will extend to small-business accounts the protections recently granted to individual consumers by the Credit Card Accountability Responsibility and Disclosure Act of 2009. Between May and July, Bank of America will implement new policies for its two million small-business account holders that will end rate increases on existing balances, provide at least 45 days advance notice on rate changes for future balances, eliminate the over-limit fee, and set a grace period of at least 25 days between the statement closing date and the payment due date.

title: Keeping Score: Which Team Is Built to Win?
description: After analyzing the championship games or series of the N.F.L., N.B.A., Major League Baseball and N.H.L., and the major finals in golf and tennis, we identified 50 championships characteristics in our book, Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method. Based on similar research, we focused on several championship characteristics that might help predict the winner of this years N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament.

title: Lupone Names Winner of Book Title Contest
description: In February, when Patti LuPone announced on her Web site (pattilupone.net) that she was asking her fans to suggest potential titles for her coming memoir, readers of The New York Timess ArtsBeat blog (nytimes.com/artsbeat) were invited to join in the competition, too. And frankly, our commenters came up with some pretty good ones, including A Little Touch of Star Quality, I, Eva and Being LuPone. On Friday, Ms. LuPone announced that she had chosen a title. The winner? Its Patti LuPone: A Memoir, submitted by Precilla Ng of Toronto. Runners-up included An 11 OClock Life; Entrances, Exits and Everything in Between: A Life, by Patti LuPone; and Eight Times a Week. Among the submissions that Ms. LuPone said made her laugh was Mein Kampf, suggested by Ginny Brazier of Chicago. So apparently things could have been worse. Harmony Books will release Patti LuPone: A Memoir on Sept. 14.

title: TV Dramas Yield Plenty of Ratings Agita
description: April Fools Day did not give the networks much to smile about as many dramas saw ratings decline on Thursday night, according to Nielsens estimates. Among those taking the hardest hits were the Fox series Bones (8.4 million) and Fringe (6 million viewers), which ran their first new episodes since February, and ABCs struggling science-fiction series, FlashForward (5.1 million), which had some of its worst ratings to date. CBS won the night, but its hit investigation show The Mentalist drew an unusually low 13.9 million viewers after switching time slots for the evening with CSI (13.2 million). At 8 p.m., Survivor: Heroes vs. Villains attracted 11.1 million viewers. ABC was in second place with Greys Anatomy (9.8 million) and Private Practice (7.8 million), which also experienced declines. Fox ranked third, and NBC was fourth with repeats of The Office, followed by The Marriage Ref (5.3 million).

title: Debut Is Announced for Tales of the City
description: The musical Tales of the City, adapted from two books by Armistead Maupin, will have its world premiere next spring at the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco, the theater has announced. Drawing on the exploits of the characters Mary Ann, Mouse, Anna Madrigal and others from Tales of the City and More Tales of the City, set in 1970s San Francisco, the musical has a score and lyrics by Jake Shears and John Garden of the rock band Scissor Sisters and a book by Jeff Whitty (a Tony Award winner for Avenue Q). It will be directed by Jason Moore (Shrek the Musical, Avenue Q). The production is scheduled to run May 17 to July 10, 2011. According to a statement from the theater, the creative team has been working on the musical for more than two years, with Mr. Maupins blessing. Ive always believed that a theatrical version of Tales should be homegrown in San Francisco, just the way the story itself was back in 1976, Mr. Maupin said in the statement. I trust this company to be faithful to the spirit of the material and to transfer it to another medium with charm and inventiveness.

title: Can the Ipad Do What a Comics Store Can?
description: Sure, the Apple iPad has the power to run all kinds of applications and make you the envy of your friends. But can it help you to imagine that youre Captain America, brandishing your shield and fists against the ruthless Red Skull? Yes, it can do that, too. On Friday, Marvel Comics, the publishing home of heroes like Spider-Man and the X-Men, said it was introducing a free application for the iPad that will give readers access to a digital library of more than 500 comics from its 70-year history. The software program, Marvel Comics App, developed by the digital comics distributor comiXology, offers free access to the first issues of titles like New Avengers and The Invincible Iron Man. Other recent and vintage issues can be downloaded for $1.99 each. Marvel says it sees the app as being complementary to the experience of buying and reading physical comics, not supplanting it. That Wednesday, when people go to the stores, I call it a mini Comic-Con, Ira Rubenstein, the executive vice president of Marvels global digital media group, said in a telephone interview. Its where fans gather and talk about the books and they argue about the books and speculate about the books. That experience isnt going to change.

title: Jones Cancels Shows, Citing Vocal Problems
description: For Tom Jones, below, this is unusual: the singer has canceled several concerts in Asia in recent days on the advice of his doctors, who say he could risk injuring his vocal cords, Reuters reported. Last Friday, Mr. Jones, the 69-year-old Welsh crooner of Whats New Pussycat? and Its Not Unusual, began a concert at a casino in Sentosa, the Singapore island resort, but stopped the show after two songs. He rescheduled the performance for Thursday, citing laryngitis, but canceled that show as well as a subsequent concert scheduled for Saturday in Seoul, South Korea. A statement on his Web site, tomjones.com, said the cancellations were due to doctors orders. It added that though Mr. Jones has been resting his voice all week, his doctors warned him that he could risk serious permanent damage to his vocals if he performed. The singer has additional concerts scheduled l this month in Cape Town and Johannesburg, as well as in Oman and the United Arab Emirates.

title: S. Epatha Merkerson to Leave Law & Order
description: Is there a way to make the Law & Order donk-donk sound in a sad way, to indicate a bittersweet transition? S. Epatha Merkerson, right, who for more than 15 years has played that crime dramas straightforward police lieutenant, Anita Van Buren, will leave the show at the end of its current season, The Hollywood Reporter said. Ms. Merkerson, an Emmy Award winner for the HBO adaptation of Lackawanna Blues, appeared in an episode of Law & Order in its first season, back when George Dzundza and Chris Noth were still the lead cops. She joined the show as Lt. Van Buren in its fourth season in 1993. Since then Ms. Merkerson has appeared in more than 375 episodes of Law & Order, and been on the show longer than any other cast member. The Hollywood Reporter said a deal to return Law & Order to NBC for its 21st season was not yet in place.

title: Resounding Schuman, Rebounding Slatkin
description: From its inception, the concert that the Juilliard Orchestra presented at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night was meant to celebrate the centenary of William Schuman, the former president of the Juilliard School and of Lincoln Center who died in 1992, an American composer of originality and lasting significance. The event was a late complement to Juilliards 2010 Focus! festival in January, devoted to so-called mainstream American composers.

title: Powerful Top Notes Paired With Theatrical Conviction
description: The best came last during a concert by the American soprano Sondra Radvanovsky and the Siberian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening.

title: Larger Than Life
description: The Colombian artist Fernando Botero is back at the Nassau County Museum of Art, where more than 70 of his sketches, drawings and paintings were exhibited five years ago. The museum is now showing a small but significant collection of figure paintings, drawings and monumental sculptures; one of the sculptures, a plump female nude, enlivens the plaza fronting the museum.

title: Growing Conversion of Movies to 3-D Draws Mixed Reactions
description: LOS ANGELES  For weeks, Hollywood has sat in judgment of a last-second decision by Warner Brothers to convert its two-dimensional Clash of the Titans into 3-D after filming was finished. James Cameron cried sacrilege, Michael Bay said such quickie conversions resulted in fake 3-D and fanboy bloggers lambasted Warner and urged people to skip it.

title: Chic in Review | Move Over, Imelda
description: Aniston, JenniferBusts out in a hot pink Lacroix haute couture dress.  Demonstrates why she tends to only wear simple black and nude dresses.

title: Book Review Podcast: New Vietnam War Novels
description: This week: A look at two new novels about the Vietnam War, with Tatjana Soli, the author of The Lotus Eaters, and Sebastian Junger, who reviews Karl Marlantess Matterhorn; the Book Reviews childrens books editor Julie Just discusses bad parents in young adult fiction; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Asked to Declare His Race, Obama Checks Black
description: It is official: Barack Obama is the nations first black president.

title: In Pursuit of Sounds Delicate and Eerie
description: The Miller Theater at Columbia University was packed on Thursday night for the concert celebrating the 75th birthday of the visionary, idiosyncratic German composer Helmut Lachenmann, the last of this seasons popular Composer Portraits programs. As always with this series, the audience was mostly young. For 10 years now, the Composer Portraits have enticed young people who are curious about all kinds of extreme contemporary music to take chances on living classical composers.

title: Rock Band and Traditional Brass, Marching From Brazil to Broadway
description: Its been a while since a band from Pernambuco, the state in the northeastern promontory of Brazil, made a deep impression in the United States. People will tell you about the singer Chico Science, who died in 1997, and his fantastic band, Nao Zumbi. Theyre still missed. Their aggressive, guitar-and-drum-centric Brazilian rock burst with sound and imagery about the complexity of Brazilian cultural identity, about limited resources and technological curiosity. It also sounded good on a beach.

title: Need a Cab? New Analysis Shows Where to Find One
description: It is a question that taxi-seekers in New York often ponder: Is there some kind of secret formula for where to find a cab in this town?

title: Will the iPad Cause the End of Innovation?
description: On a day in which the majority of tech news consists of breathless examination of the first round of iPad Apps, Cory Doctorow writes on the blog Boing Boing that the iPad will discourage innovation.

title: At Couples Reunion, Laughs, Then Grief
description: Tyler Perry likes to give full value for the entertainment dollar, and Tyler Perrys Why Did I Get Married Too? is two movies for the price of one.

title: Inventing Tahini Soup
description: IT all started when I began obsessing over how to turn hummus, my toddlers favorite snack, into more of a complete and vegetable-rich meal. Dipping carrot sticks into hummus doesnt work, as she simply licks it right off.

title: Book Review Podcast: New Vietnam War Novels
description: This week: A look at two new novels about the Vietnam War, with Tatjana Soli, the author of The Lotus Eaters, and Sebastian Junger, who reviews Karl Marlantess Matterhorn; the Book Reviews childrens books editor Julie Just discusses bad parents in young adult fiction; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Rebuilding in Haiti
description: The federal government recently agreed to sell most of the 120,000 formaldehyde-tainted trailers it bought nearly five years ago for Hurricane Katrina victims for pennies on the dollar. How could it not have anticipated that the sale of those units  perhaps the most visible symbol of the governments bungled response to the hurricane  would result in outrage? And how can they sell them cheaply to middlemen who will then turn a profit selling them back to those who still remain without housing, post-Katrina?

title: Trustees Find Board Seats Are Still Luxury Items
description: Like Prada handbags and Herms scarves, a spot on one of New York Citys most prestigious cultural boards never goes on sale, even in a recession.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 2
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Reading Up on Gutenberg as the iPad Drops
description: With the iPad, which arrives in stores on Saturday, Apple is joining Amazon and other makers of e-readers in an effort to overturn the 500-year-old model of book publishing.

title: Financial Tuneup: Remember to Rebalance
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: Letters on a Modern Love Essay About a Woman in Prison
description: Prisons Untold Tales

title: At Prospect Park Lake, Graceful Swans and Chicken Feet
description: By the banks of Prospect Park Lake in Brooklyn, a handful of young children stood watching the geese and swans in the warm sunshine on Friday. A few feet away, Anne-Katrin Titze knelt over the banks edge and poked at the murky water with a stick until two dismembered chicken feet and some small pieces of loose, rotten flesh floated to the surface.

title: Honoring Dizzy Gillespie With a Mix of Many Styles
description: Twenty years ago the pianist Danilo Perez was a precocious member of Dizzy Gillespies United Nation Orchestra, a clutch of musicians from the Americas and the Caribbean. That appointment, which ended with Gillespies death in 1993, was formative: Mr. Perez has said it gave him the conviction to seek out his own personal amalgam of jazz and Latin music, and in particular the folk music of his native Panama. From Gillespie, bebops peerless trumpet ambassador, he also learned a few things about the art of engaging an audience, even (or especially) when presenting them with a challenge.

title: What It Takes to Fight Obesity
description: A Room for Debate forum last week discussed the effectiveness of public campaigns to promote healthy eating and reduce obesity. Many readers wrote in about their own struggles with weight, what worked for them and how public policy might be changed to help Americans keep the pounds off. Here are excerpts from their comments.

title: What Did You Think of the New York Auto Show?
description: Yes, after tramping the New York auto show floor for two long days and posting our opinions, we want to hear your thoughts. Did you enjoy the show? What was your favorite car at the show? Which companies are building the cars that matter? Which companies are not?

title: The Week in Pictures for April 2
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York region. Subjects include mountain climbers, the last homeless person in Times Square, and a bug safari in Central Park.

title: Confronting a Stranger, for Art
description: At 20 minutes to closing time, Matthew Koopersmith was next in line. There was no telling if the clock would run out.

title: Cars Starved (or Stuffed) for Attention
description: THE Tango electric commuter car is a conversation piece wherever it appears, including the Detroit auto show in January, and last fall Jay Leno took one for a highly publicized test drive.

title: A Cure for Cabin Fever
description: TESTED 2010 Nissan 370Z Roadster

title: Cures for Balky Gearshifts
description: TROUBLE with Acura timepieces and Jaguar gearshifts are among the problems cited in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: Shedding Light on Safety
description: MONTVALE, N.J.

title: An 82-Year-Old Star of the New York Auto Show
description: Again this year at the New York auto show, the LeMay Museum of Tacoma, Wash., has brought together an impressive group of classic cars that will be on display through this weekend on the lower level of the Javits Center. None has a stronger New York connection than a vintage black-and-green Packard roadster.

title: Drill, Obama, Drill
description: We all know that people running for office make promises that they either cannot or will not fulfill when in office, and its hard to accuse them of hypocrisy when they yield to political realities. Thus candidate Barack Obama promised to quickly close the interrogation centers at Guanatnamo Bay, but President Obama, facing an attack of

title: In Call, Karzai Tries to Clarify a Diatribe
description: WASHINGTON  A day after he delivered a scorching attack on the West for its conduct in Afghanistan, President Hamid Karzai telephoned Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday to express surprise that his comments had caused such a stir, administration officials said.

title: On the iPad, Gilt Is for All Kinds of Shoppers
description: Shopping on Gilt, the site with private, limited-time sales, can be a blood sport, with shoppers competing against others for a pair of gold Calvin Klein heels in a size 8.

title: 2010 National League Predictions
description: Weve brought you the American League picks. Heres the fearless forecast for the National League.

title: A Tour of the Census Form
description: A guide to the 2010 census form, which the Census Bureau claims you can fill out in less time than it takes to cook a hard-boiled egg.

title: Mom and Pop, Scraping By
description: JOHN Scanlon pushed up the grate on his store, Pelham Bay Home Center, one recent frosty morning and hauled onto the sidewalk a pageant of products  bathroom sinks, cabinets, countertops and a refrigerator  in the unlikely hope of catching a passer-by in need of a large appliance.

title: Details Help Michigan States Izzo Channel Inner Football Coach
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The day before Tom Izzos first game as Michigan State coach, he had his assistant Tom Crean go to an office supplies store to purchase small plastic sheets on which he could draw the first six plays of the game.

title: No Need for Hunting
description: DRIVE down almost any of Connecticuts back roads and you are likely to see nearly as many Fresh Eggs placards as those advertising homes for sale. Seemingly overnight, the availability of farm-fresh eggs has become a sign of the times, an indication that more and more people, having taken the locavore notion to heart, are raising their own eggs  and raising money by selling off the extras.

title: A Rematch Worth Slapping the Floor About
description: INDIANAPOLIS  West Virginia guard Joe Mazzulla made his name in the Mountaineers 73-67 victory over Duke in the N.C.A.A. tournament two years ago.

title: The Unpaid Intern, Legal or Not
description: With job openings scarce for young people, the number of unpaid internships has climbed in recent years, leading federal and state regulators to worry that more employers are illegally using such internships for free labor.

title: Healthy in a Hurry
description: Its not unusual for food and drink establishments to use a symbol to highlight low-fat or vegetarian choices on the menu. At Mango Mix, a juice bar that also serves salads, sandwiches and omelets, the concept is taken to a new level.

title: A Touch of Tex-Mex, and a Whole Lot More
description: THE photographs of chili peppers that adorn the walls of Roasted Peppers, Mamaronecks charming new restaurant, suggest a Mexican theme, but in practice, the kitchen adheres more to its claim to offer casual American dining. Mole and chilies occasionally appear on the menu, but there is no one-note garnish here, like overcooked rice and refried beans, the mainstay of many Tex-Mex spots.

title: Lawyer Sues Ex-Wife of Steven Cohen Over Fees
description: Patricia Cohen, who sued her ex-husband, Steven A. Cohen, the founder of SAC Capital Advisors, over money involved in their divorce, has in turn been sued by a lawyer in the case for unpaid fees.

title: $14 Million for Stanford Victims Fund
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission obtained more than $14.2 million for Stanford Financial Group investors in a Panamanian asset sale, the agency said Friday.

title: Atheists Collection Plate, With Religious Inspiration
description: ALPHARETTA, Ga.

title: Apollo Made Him Do It
description: Cute, young, tousle-haired Orestes has good reason to curl up in a ball on a stone bench and sleep as much as he can. He has murdered his mother and her lover, and now hes just waiting to find out what horrible way he is going to be executed. Probably along with his sister, Electra, who aided and abetted.

title: School Where Acting Is a Hard Sell
description: When I first saw Nilaja Sun perform No Child ...  four years ago in a small theater in New York City, the audience included a large number of teachers. Ms. Sun was obviously multitalented, and her story was both inspiring and deeply sad, but this was a classic case of preaching to the choir. That segment of the audience was presold on any work of art that showed just how tough and unappreciated a job teaching was.

title: John Malkovich Seeks Bigger Madoff Return
description: John Malkovich, the actor, is seeking to recover $2.3 million from an account he had with the securities firm of Bernard L. Madoff. Irving H. Picard, the trustee liquidating Mr. Madoffs firm, approved a claim in August for $670,000 for the actors pension plan and trust, more than $1.5 million short of the value of the securities listed on the November 2008 final statement of Mr. Malkovichs account, lawyers for the actor said in a filing Thursday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. Mr. Picard told Mr. Malkovich he was not entitled to the full amount because no securities were purchased for his account and the approved claim reflects what he deposited with Mr. Madoffs firm, according to the filing. The actors lawyers said Mr. Malkovich was owed the full amount on his final statement.

title: As Expected, Bryant Signs Extension With Lakers
description: Scratch one big name from the star-studded 2010 free-agent class. It is not as if many expected Kobe Bryant to lend an ear to potential recruiters, but Bryant made official what had been expected, signing a three-year contract extension with the Lakers on Friday.

title: Renewing Memories of a Big Hit
description: PEEKSKILL

title: Tracking Taxi Flow Across the City
description: Information from millions of taxi trips provides a telling record of the city's vital signs.

title: From California to Cambodia, Fighting for Women
description: MAK PRAING, Cambodia

title: Airline Screening Plan Wins Tentative Praise
description: WASHINGTON  Aviation security experts and industry officials said Friday that new screening protocols for air passengers coming to the United States were a marked improvement over an emergency plan that has required extra screening of every passenger from 14 countries since the attempted bombing of an airliner on Christmas Day.

title: Bagels, With a Southern Twist
description: After more than two decades in the bagel business, Dennis Pariti, 53, of Levittown, decided to add barbecue to the menu. So last May he put a hickory-burning smoker in the kitchen of the Garden City Park deli he has owned for six years and rechristened it Bagels and BBQ.

title: From Italian Roots, a New American Palate
description: SUGO sounds like an Italian restaurant, and indeed thats what it was when it opened in Long Beach in May 2007. Though its Web site calls its fare Italian food with an urban edge, the owner, Alan Adams, told me on the phone after my visits: Were not that anymore, adding, Were now New American with world influences.

title: Readers Questions Answered
description: Church Holdings

title: Urge to Help That Became a Lifes Work
description: TO answer a question about its complex homeless services system, Bloomberg administration officials can ask their experienced bureaucrats, call a high-priced consultant or tap into their sophisticated computerized data programs.

title: Acorn Says It Continues Its Work
description: After months of budget problems and criticism from the right, the community organizing group Acorn plans to release a letter next week clarifying its path forward and stating that its local chapters may be closed, but the national organization is alive and well.

title: Harlem Arts School Shuts Over Financial Problems
description: For nearly 50 years, the Harlem School of the Arts has given generations of mostly black and Latino children entree into worlds often otherwise out of their reach. It put violins and other orchestral instruments in their hands, ballet slippers on their feet and Shakespeare on their tongues.

title: Food From the Farm, and Far Beyond
description: WHATEVER advantage a bucolic setting bestows on the appreciation of food, the restaurant Ninety Acres at Natirar uses it well.

title: A Race to Reap Energy From the Ocean Breezes
description: As New Englanders await a decision in Massachusetts on a bitterly contested proposal to build the nations first offshore wind farm, the State of Rhode Island is forging ahead with its own project in the hope of outpacing  and upstaging  its neighbor.

title: Plans for a Synagogue Upset a Town
description: Millburn, N.J.

title: When a Papered Wall Acts Like a Web Site
description: MANY people hustle right past the wall pasted with paper fliers on Forsyth Street, in the shadow of the Manhattan Bridge. But others make pilgrimages to this easternmost reach of Chinatown, where scores of advertisements, most handwritten in Chinese, are posted, their phone-number strips curling like beckoning fingers.

title: Paterson Deputy Is Questioned in Case Involving Another Aide
description: ALBANY  Clemmie L. Harris Jr., a top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson, appeared in Manhattan on Friday before investigators for Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomos office in their inquiry into the Paterson administrations handling of a domestic violence matter, people with knowledge of the case said.

title: Tales of Obsessions and Battles That Shaped the City
description: Ready to be beguiled? Two new collections of nonfiction detective stories will help.

title: Before the Rush, a Bite for the Staff
description: This muscular grand cafe in Greenwich Village may be famous for its towering architectural dishes, but you  the paying customer  will never get to taste what may be a more indicative meal: the free dinner that is fed each night to the staff. Just as a nation can be judged by how it cares for its least fortunate citizens, a restaurant can be judged by what it feeds its servers, barkeeps, busboys, line cooks and dishwashers before their shifts. The verdict? Pretty good  at least according to the half-dozen workers who gathered for the meal at 4 p.m. one day last week at their typical spot, in the back at Table 35.

title: 3 Germans Die in Afghan Clash
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three German soldiers were killed on Friday during a firefight with insurgents while on patrol near the city of Kunduz in northern Afghanistan, a spokesman for the German military said.

title: For Pro Athletes, Practice Thats All in the Thumbs
description: Video games like Nintendos Wii Fit or Electronics Arts Madden N.F.L. series arent just for armchair athletes.

title: She Makes the Best Waf-Cakes
description: Sisterhood has made for a prolific collaboration between the writer Delia Ephron and her writer/director sister, Nora. Their play Love, Loss, and What I Wore is running Off Broadway with a fresh cast each month, and their screenwriting credits include the comedy Youve Got Mail. Delia Ephrons latest novel for young adults is The Girl With the Mermaid Hair, which explores a dysfunctional family and its dysfunctional relationship with cosmetic surgery. She lives in Greenwich Village with her husband, Jerome Kass, also a writer, and their multinamed Havanese, Honey Pansy Cornflower Bernice Mambo Kass. ROBIN FINN

title: Urologist Posts His Politics on His Florida Office Door
description: MIAMI  Doctors take the Hippocratic oath promising to do no harm, but once that requirement is fulfilled, do they have a right to choose patients based on politics?

title: Insurance Pool to Offer Reduced-Rate Coverage
description: WASHINGTON  In one of its first steps to carry out the new health care law, the Obama administration announced Friday that it was establishing a temporary insurance pool where uninsured people with medical problems could buy coverage at reduced rates.

title: Thrilling Reminder of Old Coney Island
description: From 85 feet up, the view of Coney Island is so good you can almost see the future. You can get the Boardwalk, but also a sense of the crowds that will soon fill it. The sun peeking through the clouds, but also an image of the beachgoers who will soak it in. The familiar attractions like the Parachute Jump, and the new development that after years of controversy will make its debut in May.

title: Pakistan: A Raft of Amendments
description: The Pakistani government on Friday introduced a package of constitutional changes in Parliament that would shift the balance of power from the president to the prime minister. Under the proposed changes, the president would no longer have the powers to dismiss the prime minister, dissolve Parliament or appoint the powerful military chiefs. The package also includes the lifting of a ban on two-time prime ministers running for a third term, essentially paving the way for a campaign by the opposition leader Nawaz Sharif. Another measure would change the name of the North-West Frontier Province to Khyber-Pakhtoonkhwa.

title: New Health Care Law Does Not Help Democrats in Poll
description: The legislative wrangling over the health care reform bill that became law last week has not translated into improved poll ratings for any of the principal participants.

title: A Long Chat for Obama and Hu
description: President Obama spoke by phone on Thursday night with President Hu Jintao of China for about an hour  so long that Air Force One had to be held for 10 minutes on the tarmac at Andrews Air Force Base after landing. Chinese television reported that Mr. Hu expressed a desire for healthier ties while emphasizing Beijings positions on Taiwan and Tibet, and the White House said Mr. Obama stressed for China to press Iran on its nuclear ambitions. Their conversation, which reportedly also touched on trade, did not appear to address the issue of Chinas currency, the renminbi, and whether China would loosen the tight link between it and the dollar  a policy that keeps the renminbis value depressed and makes Chinese exports more competitive in global markets.

title: Pension Funds Still Waiting for Big Payoff From Private Equity
description: Private equity deal-makers, those kings of corporate buyouts, made billions for themselves when times were good. But some of their biggest investors, public pension funds, are still waiting for the hefty rewards they were promised.

title: Judge Dismisses Suit Seeking to Keep A.I.G. Assets in Place
description: A judge in California dismissed a lawsuit on Thursday that would have barred the American International Group from moving any assets out of that state until an independent audit could verify the companys financial condition.

title: Battle of $50 Bill Splitting Republican Ranks
description: CINCINNATI  It is a battle that is pitting Republican against Republican.

title: A Cancer Survivor and His Kodachrome
description: Jeff Jacobsons new book project, The Last Roll, emerged from a low point in his life. Recovering from lymphoma and the chemotherapy used to treat it, he faced his own mortality in 2005. Then he faced the end of Kodachrome 200, a medium hed used for more than 20 years.

title: Report Faults Training of Local Officers in Immigration Enforcement Program
description: State and local police officers who enforce federal immigration laws are not adequately screened, trained or supervised, and the civil rights of the immigrants they deal with are not consistently protected, according to a report released Friday by the Department of Homeland Security inspector general.

title: A Pfizer Whistle-Blower Is Awarded $1.4 Million
description: A federal jury has awarded $1.37 million in damages to a former Pfizer scientist who claimed she was sickened by a genetically engineered virus at a company laboratory and then fired for raising safety concerns.

title: Exiled Pedophile Priest May Have Continued Abuse
description: BOULDER JUNCTION, Wis.  The modest clapboard cottage projects a sense of simple rural peace, nestled amid tall pines on quiet Trout Lake. The house, in the Northwoods of Wisconsin, had been in the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphys family for years, his getaway in the summer months and his sanctuary where he was sent to retire in 1974, at age 48, after victims of sexual abuse demanded he be removed from work at a school for the deaf near Milwaukee.

title: On the Street | Spring Shift
description: The heavy rains end, and New Yorkers show their colors.

title: In SoHo Burglaries, a Case of a Taste for the Luxurious Things in Life
description: He has a taste for luxury  Michael Kors gold leather satchel bags, hand-constructed Japanese denim jeans that start at $260 and about $23,000 worth of designer sunglasses.

title: H. Edward Roberts, PC Pioneer, Dies at 68
description: Not many people in the computer world remembered H. Edward Roberts, not after he walked away from the industry more than three decades ago to become a country doctor in Georgia. Bill Gates remembered him, though.

title: After a 20-Year Mapping Effort, Hoping to Save Dozens of Native Plants
description: American colonists once watched for the spring bloom of the Nantucket shadbush, a sign that it was warm enough to bury the winters dead.

title: In Baseball, Power Matters, but Not Absolutely
description: Among baseball people it is a reflex to praise the little things. The games greatest virtues are said to be situational hitting, taking the extra base and, most of all, pitching and defense. To suggest that games are won with power is like saying pizza tastes good. Everybody knows it, but most people would rather say they eat health food.

title: New Vessels for New Perils
description: THE New York Police and Fire Departments often boast about their cutting-edge capabilities on the streets of the city. Rarely, though, do they discuss their capabilities on the water.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Thursday about Albanys failure to complete a budget on time, using information from the state comptrollers office, referred incorrectly to a law enacted in 1998 to help spur lawmakers toward agreement. It prohibits only legislators from being paid until a budget is approved  not the governor or other statewide elected officials.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 2, 2010

title: IPad Apps Have Ignition
description: The rush is on to dissect and analyze the multitude of iPad-aimed applications that have emerged on the day before the tablets release. In the Technology section of The New York Times online, youll find articles about apps from National Public Radio, Netflix, ABC, the Walt Disney Company and many others.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about millions of heart patients receiving nitroglycerin tablets never approved by the Food and Drug Administration misstated the year the F.D.A. was established. It was in 1927, when it was spun off from the Bureau of Chemistry, not in 1938. (Its powers to require new drugs to demonstrate safety before being marketed came in 1938 with passage of the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act.)

title: Health System Bears Cost of Implants With No Warranties
description: In January, William R. Morriss artificial hip, just three years old, was failing so badly that it had to be replaced during an extensive procedure that cost about $50,000.

title: Japanese Food Companies Seek Growth Abroad
description: TOKYO  Until he moved to Japan three years ago, Arturo Vega, a Spanish-language teacher, had no idea that the Sofyl brand of yogurt that he had bought in his native Mexico was made by Japanese company named Yakult Honsha.

title: What Were Reading: Sorry, a Little More iPad
description: Just a few more thoughts on the iPad. Forgive us.

title: Once Uniforms, They Are Now Works of Art
description: THE traditional place for a retired soldiers uniform is, perhaps, in a trunk in the attic. But a more creative option begins in a portable pulping machine belonging to Drew Matott, an artist who makes paper.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the impact of a court decision that invalidated patents on two genes misstated the role of the American Civil Liberties Union in the case. It acted as a lawyer for the plaintiffs; it was not a plaintiff itself.

title: Breaking Down the NYTimes.com Bracket Pool
description: About 40,000 brackets were submitted to the nytimes.com mens bracket tournament, and users selections reveal the contrast between heavy favorites and underdogs. About 70 percent of brackets had Kansas in the Final Four, for example, while just over one percent put Butler there.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a charity game between alumni of teams that were supposed to meet in the 1989 New Jersey high school hockey championship game but did not because of a measles outbreak misidentified the channel that will show it. The game, scheduled for today in Morristown, N.J., will be taped and shown on Cablevisions MSG Varsity, not on the MSG Network.

title: Apparently Floored
description: In German, a young lady has no sex, while a turnip has.The Awful German Language by Mark Twain

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Friday about General Manager Omar Minayas optimism for the Mets chances this season misstated the day that shortstop Jose Reyes, who has been told he will begin the season on the disabled list, would be eligible to play again. It is next Saturday, not Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: Schedule information on Thursday with a theater review of August Wilsons Women, at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe in the East Village, misstated the cafes phone number. It is (212) 780-9386.

title: Brothers From Duke Arrive After a Detour
description: WARSAW, Ind.  When Duke forwards Mason and Miles Plumlee transferred from the public high school in this town of hay bales and basketball hoops, their father, Perky, was treated like a pariah. When he went to grab a cup of coffee after church, he said, people would disperse as if I had poured scalding hot water on a dog.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Friday about the bands xx and jj, at Webster Hall, misidentified the hit by Lil Wayne that jj reimagines in its song Ecstasy. It is Lollipop, not A Milli.

title: Bloggingheads: Expand the Bracket?
description: Will Leitch, left, of Deadspin and Hampton Stevens of The Atlantic debate expanding the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about mental health coverage under the new federal health care law, using information from the American Psychological Association, overstated one provisions requirements for covering Medicaid recipients. Only those in Medicaid managed-care plans must be offered the same mental-health and substance-abuse benefits as medical and surgical benefits; the new law does not require all Medicaid coverage to include equal benefits.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about David Mills, a television writer who explored racial issues in scripts for NYPD Blue, Homicide and other dramas, referred incorrectly to the HBO series The Wire, for which he also wrote. It was an urban drama that explored various aspects of Baltimore and its institutions; it was not a taut prison series.

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: For Butlers Stevens, Run Began in the Driveway
description: INDIANAPOLIS  When Brad Stevens was 5 years old, he spent each morning watching videotapes of basketball games before attending afternoon kindergarten. For his eighth birthday, his mother bought him a basketball hoop and hurried home from work early to see the look of excitement on his face.

title: How to Stop Bullying in the Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: The End of History (Books)
description: TODAY, Apples iPad goes on sale, and many see this as a Gutenberg moment, with digital multimedia moving one step closer toward replacing old-fashioned books.

title: Of Jets, Voyeurs and Back Wax
description: Our challenge today is to discuss politicians who get in trouble for extravagant spending, and to do it without mentioning the Republican National Committees expense-account party at the bondage club.

title: President Karzai Lashes Out
description: The rambling speech of President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Thursday was alarming. His delusional criticism of the United Nations and governments whose troops are risking their lives by fighting the Taliban complicates the difficult effort to stabilize Afghanistan.

title: About That Webcam
description: A Pennsylvania town has been roiled by a local high school using cameras in school-issued laptops to spy on students. Almost as shocking is the fact that the federal wiretap law that should prohibit this kind of surveillance does not cover spying done through photography and video in private settings.

title: An Alternative to Statins
description: To the Editor:

title: Promises for and From Haiti
description: This weeks donors conference for Haiti at the United Nations was strikingly hopeful, in good part because of what participants pledged not to do.

title: We Still Dont Hear Him
description: The great man was moving with what seemed like great reluctance. He knew as he climbed from the car in Upper Manhattan that he was stepping into the maelstrom, that there were powerful people who would not react kindly to what he had to say.

title: An Article of Faith
description: Since signing the health care reform bill, President Obama has been traipsing about the country trying to sell it. Its not really working for him.

title: A Diagnosis of Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: A Deal at Ground Zero?
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg and other politicians are celebrating a deal to finally finish the major buildings at the World Trade Center site. Lets hope they are right to break out the confetti. Larry Silverstein, who is developing office towers on the site, and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the 16 acres, need to make sure that the agreement does not fall apart yet again, as they fill in the remaining details.

title: After-School Programs
description: To The Editor:

title: Huggins Focused on a Title, Not Redemption
description: INDIANAPOLIS  West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins has carried a mottled reputation for having players with off-the-court problems, having had zero percent graduation rates and using profane language.

title: Mountaineers and Bulldogs Play to Their Strengths
description: Zach Hillesland, a contributor to The Quad, is a former Notre Dame forward who is now an academic adviser in the universitys athletic department.

title: Previewing Williams-Clijsters Final
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  It has been nine years since Venus Williams reached the final of the Sony Ericsson Open, but for the first time since 2001 she will be there Saturday at 12:30 p.m. to play an old rival.

title: Loyalty Is Paramount in Woodss Inner Circle
description: Tiger Woods, a self-acknowledged control freak, insists on loyalty as a fundamental quality in employees, associates and friends. Just how much Woods values allegiance was summed up by his father, Earl, in an interview shortly before he died.

title: Mets Cut Six, Including Four Pitchers
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Mets intended to wait until Saturdays exhibition final against Baltimore in Sarasota to make their final cuts. Instead, they let six players go after Fridays 4-2 loss to Tampa Bay, cutting pitchers Nelson Figueroa, Bobby Parnell, Kiko Calero and Elmer Dessens; infielder Russ Adams; and outfielder Chris Carter.

title: Ochoa Has Hard Day on the Course, but a Good One
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Life is like a long par-3 to Lorena Ochoa, the top-ranked womens golfer. There are hazards galore, but all too soon the adventure will be over.

title: Roddick Overcomes Nadal as Risk Is Rewarded
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Even though he knew he would be facing one of tenniss top defensive players in Rafael Nadal, Andy Roddick felt comfortable enough in the way he had been playing to continue with what had been working.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Rangers Just 2 Points From Playoff Spot
description: Seven games on Friday, including two huge ones in the East and one in the West. Home teams listed first:

title: Seth Curry Turns Heads Since Transferring to Duke
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Stephen and Seth Curry played seven grueling games of one-on-one last summer at the Jewish Community Center in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Stephen Curry Brings Hope to Beleaguered Warriors
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  In the semi-charmed life of Golden States golden rookie, the television serves as both ego amplifier and modesty meter.

title: Alexander McQueens Final Bow
description: AT approximately 10:20 a.m. on Feb. 11, a London taxi stopped at the entrance to Green Street, a normally quiet block of drab red brick houses in Mayfair  drabber on this bone-chilling Thursday  and the passengers, a man and two women, hastily got out.

title: Yankees and Mets Get Together, Almost, in a Split Spring Doubleheader
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  After the Yankees moved their spring training base from Fort Lauderdale to Tampa in 1996, and Major League Baseball instituted interleague play in 1997, exhibition games in Florida between the Yankees and the Mets lost their attraction. The Yankees have no interest in busing two and a half hours to Port St. Lucie, and the Mets show little inclination to come over to Tampa.

title: Rangers Roll Over the Lightning, Inching Closer to a Playoff Position
