description: TAMPA, Fla. The Rangers took a big step closer to the playoffs Friday, crushing a Tampa Bay team in disarray and gaining ground on postseason contenders.

title: Kit Horn, Pioneer Surfer, Dies at 80
description: Kit Horn, a skilled surfer whose exploration of new surf spots along the California coast in the 1940s and 1950s  and later Oahus famed North Shore  helped the sport grow from a small subculture to an international pastime, died March 25 at his home in Encinitas, Calif. He was 80.

title: Friends Reflect on Alexander McQueens Death
description: In this weekends cover story in Sunday Styles, Cathy Horyn reports on the events leading up to the suicide, at age 40, of the designer Alexander McQueen on Feb. 11. She writes movingly on his life and death, based on interviews with his closest friends, most of whom have not spoken publicly before. Among them are the fashion muse Daphne Guinness, who recalls being in a Paris hotel room with Mr. McQueen a few months earlier, celebrating a triumphant runway show earlier that day: I had never seen him happier or so full of ideas.

title: Alexander McQueen: A Designer's Story
description: The designer was known for some of the most controversial collections and fashion shows of the last two decades. Here is a timeline of his life and career.

title: Looking Ahead: The Mens Final Four
description: Michigan St. vs. ButlerSaturday, 6:07 p.m.TV: CBS

title: Man, 18, Is Fatally Stabbed Near Prospect Park
description: An 18-year-old man was chased and stabbed to death near Prospect Park early Friday evening after a confrontation with a group of men over a girl, the police said.

title: 6 Afghans Die as Their Unit Is Hit in Error by Germans
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A contingent of Afghan reinforcements delivering supplies to a German military base was mistakenly fired on by German troops, and six Afghan soldiers were killed, officials said Saturday.

title: Classic Ad: Datsun 240Z
description: In this Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the Nissan 370Z Roadster, the latest incarnation of the first Japanese sports car to win a widespread following in the United States. The original Z-car, the 1970 Datsun 240Z, was an instant sensation when it arrived in North America in October 1969, winning fans for its combination of strong performance, responsive handling, reasonable price and intelligent packaging.

title: Best Right Tackles in the N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
description: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely  but not strictly  by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, though the future isnt utterly ignored. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. Thats why most of you will have no trouble finding ways to disagree about what youre about to read.

title: American Stars May Sit Out World Championships
description: As Team USA dropped from its basketball perch, many pointed to a lack of desire in representing the country from the N.B.A.s star players as a prime component. The losses and prodding from USA Basketball managing director Jerry Colangelo helped firm up flimsy commitments, a reason the United States won the gold medal at the Beijing Games.

title: An Agonizing Wait Yields Tough, but Enviable, Choices
description: And so it has finally come, nearly bringing with it the crashing musical accompaniment and jarring mental edits of a scene straight from the Transformers movies  April 1 has arrived, and now passed.

title: A Wild, Rainy Qualifier in Malaysia
description: Malaysia delivered a flood of rain again as a qualifying session turned into a massive free-for-all at the Malaysian Grand Prix. And it was Mark Webber in a Red Bull who came out on top with the third pole position of his career after he was the only driver in the top 10 to finish out the session on intermediate wet tires, instead of full-wet tires.

title: The Final Four and Baseballs Champions
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: 25 Members of Sunni Family Killed Near Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  The killers came at night, speaking passable English and wearing uniforms and carrying weapons that resembled those of the American military.

title: Urban Forager | A Bitter Green Bouquet
description: In the spirit of Passover (still not too late to sneak in that Third Seder), heres a list of wild edibles fit for a free-range Seder plate, including dandelion, garlic mustard, and common mugwort. This foragers fantasy of bitter herbs grows freely throughout the city, and, who knows, may even be flourishing in front of your stoop or in thy neighbors yard.

title: The iPads Big Day
description: Since the word iPad entered the collective consciousness back in January, there has been plenty of punditry about what Apples new device means for the future of technology, media and life as we know it. On Saturday, people will finally be able to start making up their own minds about it. The iPad went on sale this morning at Apple and Best Buy stores around the country. Check back here for updates from Times reporters and from the Web at large. Please share your thoughts and experiences in the comments, especially if you are diving into the frenzy yourself.

title: Saturday Word: Easter Address
description: As the country continues to split over the administrations health care bill, President Obama tried to build unity among Jews and Christians, Muslims and Hindus, believers and nonbelievers alike in his national address the day before Easter.

title: Sarah Weeks, Edward Daniels
description: Sarah Elizabeth Weeks and Edward Frost Daniels were married Saturday evening in Brooklyn. The Rev. Lynell H. Carter, a Lutheran minister, officiated at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios, in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Marian Westley, David Pinkus
description: Marian Bohanna Westley, an oceanographer, and David Steven Pinkus, a high school physics teacher, were married Saturday at a fusion energy research laboratory, where the couple met, at Princeton University in Plainsboro, N.J. Mayor H. Frances Enright of Spring Lake Heights, N.J., officiated.

title: Christopher Heywood, Nicholas Tomasetti
description: Christopher Charles Heywood and Nicholas Roy Tomasetti were married Saturday evening at the Wequassett Resort and Golf Club in Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Jim F. David, a priest of the Ecumenical Catholic Church of Christ, officiated.

title: A Popcorn Law
description: Monologue |  Friday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Under President Obamas new airport security plan, anyone traveling to the U.S. will be stopped if they match the description of a potential terrorist. Wait, we werent doing this already?

title: New Tiny Cars
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Oh, you know what they do every Monday after Easter at the White House? They have the hunt, on the White House lawn. And they canceled it this year. You know why? I was stunned. I didnt know about this. Last year a couple of kids accidentally stumbled into Dick Cheneys underground torture chamber.

title: Elizabeth Schwartz, Matthew Coleman
description: Elizabeth A. Schwartz, the daughter of Jeanne E. Mixon and John Schwartz of Millburn, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Matthew M. Coleman, a son of Carol A. Coleman and William H. Coleman of Dexter, Mich. Rabbi Alan Freedman officiated at an outdoor ceremony at the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center at the University of Texas at Austin.

title: Criticism of Chvez Stifled by Arrests
description: LOS TEQUES, Venezuela  When Judge Mara Lourdes Afiuni issued a ruling in December that irked President Hugo Chvez, he did little to contain his outrage. The president, contending on national television that she would have been put before a firing squad in earlier times, sent his secret intelligence police to arrest her.

title: Mark Cubans Grudge Match With the S.E.C.
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to securities law and white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Rejoice, Muffy and Biff: A Preppy Primer Revisited
description: Just when you thought it was safe to get back in your khakis.

title: Yolon Jambor, Jeremy Vellon
description: Yolon S. Jambor, a daughter of Suzanne L. Bauch of Pinckney, Mich., and the late David F. Jambor, was married Monday evening to Lt. Cmdr. Jeremy E. Vellon, a son of Maria D. Vellon and Herbert G. Vellon of Brooklyn. Renate Anne Daversa, a Universal Life minister, officiated at Cuvier Park in San Diego.

title: Vivienne La Borde, Kaddu Luyombya
description: Vivienne Ceri La Borde and Kaddu Kibuuka Luyombya were married Saturday at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York. The Rev. Daisy M. Barnum, an African Methodist Episcopal minister, officiated.

title: Puns and Anagrams
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Mel Taubs PandA puzzles might seem tricky at first. You can finish them if youre patient. Think of every clue as ending with a question mark, and then its just like any old Thursday puzzle, only even more fun.

title: At 89, Stevens Contemplates Law, and How to Leave It
description: WASHINGTON  There are still pros and cons to be considered, Justice John Paul Stevens said in his Supreme Court chambers on Friday afternoon, reflecting on his reluctance to leave a job he loves after almost 35 years. But his calculus seemed to be weighted toward departure, and he said his decision on the matter would come very soon.

title: Burden of Paying for Wedding Bells Shifts
description: WHEN it comes to paying for a wedding while remaining financially afloat, todays rule is all hands on deck.

title: Anglican Archbishop Rebukes Irish Church
description: LONDON  At a time when his relations with Pope Benedict XVI are already strained over the popes offer to dissatisfied Anglicans of fast-track conversion to Roman Catholicism, the archbishop of Canterbury has plunged into the crisis over cases of abuse by Catholic priests, choosing the Easter weekend to describe the Catholic Church in Ireland as losing all credibility because of its poor handling of the crisis.

title: Violence Helps Taliban Undo Afghan Gains
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  Since their offensive here in February, the Marines have flooded Marja with hundreds of thousands of dollars a week. The tactic aims to win over wary residents by paying them compensation for property damage or putting to work men who would otherwise look to the Taliban for support.

title: Hijacking Too Big To Fail
description: This AP report illustrates perfectly why Im worried about emphasizing the too-big-to-fail problem rather than the need for tighter regulation:

title: Changeups in the Pastime
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  In the world of sports, change is not necessarily a complicated process. Brett Favre is denied a trip to the Super Bowl, perhaps by the flip of a coin, and voil, the owners vote to change the rules of overtime. A few months after the N.C.A.A. floats the idea of expanding its mens basketball tournament to 96 teams, it appears to be close to a fait accompli.

title: We Are Not Mirror Images
description: Jon Chait has a post about a conservative misinformation campaign involving a truncated quote from Barney Frank  something to which I can relate. In this case, the estimateestimable Mr. Frank was saying that we need to expand regulation of runaway financial institutions, and this was clipped to make it seem as if he was calling for bigger government across the board.

title: Why Has Greece Dropped From The Headlines?
description: It suddenly occurred to me that I wasnt reading much about Greece the last few days. Was the situation stabilizing?

title: Palestinian, 14, Emerges Unharmed
description: GAZA  A 14-year-old boy thought to have been killed either by Israeli gunfire or from internal Palestinian violence last week turned up unharmed at his familys house after trying to sneak into Egypt via smuggler tunnels and being held by Egyptian security officials, his parents said Saturday.

title: Yankees Set 25-Man Roster
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees completed the 25-man roster Saturday morning. All the injured guys seem to be better, so there were no surprises.

title: Rites of Spring Offer Lessons for Everyone
description: Indianapolis

title: Ride That Pony
description: Donald Frey, the man behind the Ford Mustang, died last month at age 86.

title: Prime Number
description: 31.2: The average length of time, in weeks, that the jobless were out of work in March, the longest span since the government began collecting that data in 1948. But the news was not all bad. Employers added 162,000 jobs last month, the biggest gain in nearly three years and the latest indication that the economy is turning around. Still, the unemployment rate remained at 9.7 percent, and the government predicts that rate will average 9.8 percent next year.

title: Contesting Jobless Claims Becomes a Boom Industry
description: WASHINGTON  With a client list that reads like a roster of Fortune 500 firms, a little-known company with an odd name, the Talx Corporation, has come to dominate a thriving industry: helping employers process  and fight  unemployment claims.

title: A History of Complaints
description: Wisconsin officials have long complained that the Talx Corporation causes errors and delays in processing unemployment claims. The complaints were spelled out in a 2004 letter from the unemployment insurance administrator to the president of Talx. Years of subsequent e-mail messages, from front-line staff members and their supervisors, suggest that many of the problems have persisted.

title: Fighting Words
description: "Real American Stories," a new series hosted by Sarah Palin on Fox News, announced in an ad that LL Cool J would be a guest.

title: Correction: When Does Political Anger Turn to Violence?
description: An article last Sunday about political anger turning to violence misstated part of the name of the college where Clark McCauley, who has studied the psychology of violence, is a professor of psychology. It is Bryn Mawr College, not University.

title: For Mets, Gloom and Doom Instead of Sunshine and Smiles
description: Abandon hope, all ye who enter here.

title: Sex Business Backs the Party Animal
description: Bondage-gate, as its been called  the unfortunate convergence of Republican Party donors and a Hollywood sex club with a lesbian theme  has led to the dismissal of a party staffer, an inquiry into the use of donor money and gleeful late-night television jokes (Me likey, Jon Stewart quipped), but, really, is it such a big deal?

title: Yankees vs. Red Sox Will Be Without Its Regular Rhythm
description: The Yankees and the Red Sox will play each other 18 times this season. The rivalry will be renewed each game as they move from Fenway Park, where they start their season Sunday night, to Yankee Stadium.

title: In Maine, Last Sardine Cannery in the U.S. Is Clattering Out
description: PROSPECT HARBOR, Me.  The women in their smudged aprons here at the sardine cannery work together in mesmerizing synchronization. Their hands flying, they fill the empty tins that clatter along the conveyer belt, packing in pieces of cut herring like, well, so many sardines.

title: The Writers Room at 24
description: The following takes place in real time:

title: For Woods, Exemptions No Longer in Play
description: When Tiger Woods, the face of golf for more than a decade, returns to public life at the Masters, what face will we see?

title: School Law Clinics Face a Backlash
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  Law school students nationwide are facing growing attacks in the courts and legislatures as legal clinics at the schools increasingly take on powerful interests that few other nonprofit groups have the resources to challenge.

title: For the Battle-Scarred, Comfort at Leashs End
description: WASHINGTON  Just weeks after Chris Goehner, 25, an Iraq war veteran, got a dog, he was able to cut in half the dose of anxiety and sleep medications he took for post-traumatic stress disorder. The night terrors and suicidal thoughts that kept him awake for days on end ceased.

title: There Is More to Baylors Griner Than Viral Videos on the Internet
description: SAN ANTONIO

title: Protesters Block Heart of Bangkoks Shopping Area
description: BANGKOK  Antigovernment protesters who have camped out on the streets of Bangkok for the past three weeks raised the stakes in their mass demonstrations on Saturday, converging on the heart of Bangkoks shopping district and vowing to remain until new elections are called.

title: UConn Needs Game Plan for Brittney Griner
description: SAN ANTONIO  Asked if he relished facing Baylors 6-foot-8 Brittney Griner at the Womens Final Four on Sunday, Connecticut Coach Geno Auriemma said sure. He would be on the bench, not on the court.

title: Where Are You When the Going Gets Tough?
description: This interview with Andrew Cosslett, chief executive of InterContinental Hotels Group,  was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: U.S. to Delay Chinese Currency Report
description: The Obama administration said Saturday that it would delay a decision on whether to declare China a currency manipulator, but it vowed to press Chinese leaders on the politically charged issue of its currency valuation during a series of meetings through June.

title: A Primer on the Great Proton Smashup
description: For those whose physics knowledge was a bit rusty, the news about the Large Hadron Collider, the world's biggest physics machine, might have been puzzling.

title: Weighing Benefits of 96 Teams
description: The magical run by Butler Universitys fifth-seeded basketball team this month has amplified talk of expanding the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament to as many as 96 teams, ostensibly so that more colleges can participate. N.C.A.A. officials are expected to decide whether to take that step in the coming weeks.

title: Expansion Is Tough Call for the Interim Boss
description: INDIANAPOLIS  If a theme song were to be played in the background of this Final Four, R.E.M.s Its the End of the World as We Know It would be most appropriate.

title: Another Cousteau Working to Save the Waters
description: I FIRST went on an expedition with my father, Philippe Cousteau, and my mother when I was 4 months old. He had outfitted an amphibious plane, named the Flying Calypso, as a base of operations, and it became our home away from home. By the time I was 4, I had traveled to over a dozen countries.

title: In Russia, Putin Escapes Blame for Terror Attack
description: MOSCOW  The Moscow subway, which is usually so punctual and sparkling that it makes New Yorks seem like a third world also-ran, was slowly getting back to normal late last week. But passengers kept looking over their shoulders, casting uneasy glances at others (Could he be one? Could she?) and silently cursing terrorisms return to their lives.

title: Clijsterss Win Is Like a Day in the Park
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  In less time than it might take to accompany her 2-year-old daughter to the playground, Kim Clijsters was dominant in her other job Saturday, dismissing Venus Williams in less than an hour to win the Sony Ericsson Open.

title: When a First Pick Isnt the Best Pick
description: AS March Madness winds down, its time to turn our attention to the next major sports event on the calendar. Thats right, the National Football League draft, now a three-day extravaganza with the first round broadcast in prime time on April 22.

title: Coming to Terms With My Sabbatical
description: I NEED a sabbatical from my sabbatical, I recently confided to a friend. I wasnt joking. For some time, I had been feeling exhausted from being on work-leave. And this got me to thinking: if the word sabbatical derives from Sabbath, meaning rest, why was I so restless and worn out?

title: When Stocks Stop Moving Like a Herd
description: AMID all the market uncertainty of the last two years, investors have had a hard time knowing when to jump in. But once they have, theyve at least known that their stocks stood a good chance of moving in the same direction as the broad market  until the last few months, that is.

title: The Iraqi Voter Rewrites the Rulebook
description: BAGHDAD  Quite a few of the candidates in Iraqs national election did so poorly they didnt even get the votes of their wives (assuming the sole vote these candidates got was their own).

title: At CVB Financial, Praise and Questions
description: THE plaudits are piling up at CVB Financial, the holding company for Citizens Business Bank, a midsize institution with $6.7 billion in assets based in Ontario, Calif.

title: Packing to Leave
description: An inside look at the Stinson Seafood Company, the last sardine cannery in the United States.

title: For Knicks, New Season Will Start on April 16
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  When the schedule has been emptied and there are no more games to lose, or shots to clank, or defensive assignments to ignore, when the Knicks have scattered across the country, Mike DAntoni will be left alone with his thoughts.

title: The Last Sardine Cannery
description: The Stinson Seafood Co., the last sardine cannery in the United States, will close its doors this month. This multimedia was produced by Compass Light Productions for the Penobscot Marine Museum.

title: Is President Obama Fulfilling Clintons Promise?
description: WASHINGTON  For years, Bill Clinton tried to negotiate an arms control treaty for the post-cold-war era. He and Boris Yeltsin even agreed on a framework for a new Start treaty in Helsinki. But it never came to be. So when President Obama flies to Prague this week to sign a New Start treaty with Russia, it will culminate Mr. Clintons unfulfilled aspiration.

title: Cowboys Cut as N.F.L. Spins
description: Quick takes on five N.F.L. news items: COWBOY RELEASES

title: Across the Country, Fans Gather for iPad
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apples most devoted fans congregated on Saturday morning at stores around the country to pick up their latest object of desire: the eagerly anticipated iPad.

title: Words as Weapons: Dropping the Terrorism Bomb
description: WASHINGTON  Words can be weapons, too. So after nearly every new report of political violence, whether merely plotted or actually carried out, there is a vocabulary debate: Should it be labeled terrorism?

title: Bargain Rates for a C.E.O.?
description: LAST year may have been unnerving for chief executives accustomed to all of the familiar ornaments of corporate life: eight-figure pay packages, corporate jets, memberships in select clubs, and on and on.

title: Another Talented Teenager Gets in the Swing
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  On her left hand, Alexis Thompson is wearing a golf glove with the word Tempo written in her girlish scrawl. It is there to remind her not to be in such a rush, to take her time with her swing.

title: Calculating the Pay Figures
description: TO measure the amounts that executives were paid last year, Sunday Business asked Equilar, an executive compensation research firm, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings.

title: Green Gone Wrong: Can Capitalism Save the Planet?
description: IT may seem quaint to recall this now, but on the eve of the financial crisis, one of the biggest business stories was how large corporations were going to save the planet and make billions of dollars for their shareholders at the same time.

title: 16-Year-Old Italian Is Set to Make History at the Masters
description: ALPHARETTA, Ga.  Matteo Manassero found himself in a hazardous place among the pine needles behind the second green at the Golf Club of Georgia. His predicament raised a couple of questions: Are there pine trees in Italy? Could he play under pressure, as well as under pine trees?

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu: April 4
description: Sunday may be a holiday for some, but there should still be a lot of chatter about jobs on the morning talk shows.

title: Striking Gold in Stock Options
description: WERE they smart, or just lucky?

title: European Leisure
description: I see that Ryan Avent has been sparring with Scott Sumner over the question of whether lower European GDP per capita compared with the United States  mainly the result of lower working hours rather than lower productivity  can be attributed to higher taxes.

title: Court Rules for Woman and Against Public Course
description: Elaine Joyce, a champion amateur golfer, made a federal case of being barred from playing in a 2007 mens tournament at Dennis Pines Golf Course, where she is a longtime member. She sued the town of Dennis, Mass., and others in 2008. Last week, the United States District Court in Boston, in a rare federal ruling involving a town, its public golf course and an accusation centering on sex discrimination, told her she had won.

title: More Than Enough Hours in Every Day
description: My mother-in-law, Dorothy, is showing me the red spiral notebook thats almost as precious to her as my husbands baby pictures. Inside, in Dorothys distinctive script, is a list of every book she has read since 2007. For some people waking up in the middle of the night is a terrible curse; unable to drift back to sleep, theyre confronted with a big gaping hole that represents hours of lost time. For my mother-in-law, that time is a gift. At 87, she is acquiring the education she never had by working her way through the canon of great literature. She has now read close to 100 books, including every single novel by Anthony Trollope, Charles Dickens, Jane Austen, Edith Wharton, Henry James and Thomas Mann.My mother-in-law discusses her newfound passion with the enthusiasm of a young girl, although she can also be a very tough critic, writing VG for very good in the margins next to her favorites. Thus far, only a handful of books have received the top prize. Though she loves Mr. Darcy, especially after seeing the Masterpiece Theater version with the dashing Colin Firth, she didnt award Jane Austen a single VG. I cant explain it, she says. I like her a lot and I wish shed written more  was she sickly? I cant remember  but she just doesnt hold a candle to Thomas Mann (three VGs). Everybody should read Buddenbrooks. Where were those books when I was growing up?

title: The Debut of the iPad
description: After months of anticipation, Apples iPad finally went on sale. Eager customers had been lining up outside Apple stores to be among the first to buy one.

title: I Saw the Crisis Coming. Why Didnt the Fed?
description: Cupertino, Calif.

title: Splitting Hairs
description: There are two kinds of people in the world. You know how it goes. Northerners and Southerners. Realists and dreamers. People with curly hair and people with straight hair. Every classification throws light on something, said Isaiah Berlin, the political philosopher and elucidator of the distinction between fox people, who know many things, and hedgehog people, who know one big thing.

title: Social
description: In our Web-driven era of social media and social networking, we are all learning more sophisticated ways to socialize that go far beyond cocktail-party chatter. But being social in the 21st century can sometimes be downright unsettling.

title: Slightly Used
description: In each episode of the fascinating BBC Radio 4 series A History of the World in 100 Objects, Neil MacGregor, the director of the British Museum, uses one item from that institutions collection as a jumping-off point to discuss humanitys long relationship with made things. The journey starts, as you would expect, with something useful: a stone chopping tool, believed to be about 1.8 million years old, suggests the dawning of a relationship between humans and the things they create, which is both a love affair and a dependency, MacGregor says. From this point on, we cant survive without the things we make.

title: How Washington Abetted the Bank Job
description: A FEW weeks ago, two Republican House members asked Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, whether the Fed knew  before Lehmans bankruptcy examiner revealed it  about the bookkeeping scam at Lehman known as Repo 105. This scam allowed Lehman to disguise how much debt it was carrying, right up until it collapsed. Lehman got new loans to pay off old loans, pretended the new loans were sales, and through a complicated series of steps made both the old and new loans disappear just in time for its quarterly reports.

title: Yankees Set Roster
description: The Yankees completed their 25-man roster Saturday morning. All the injured players appear to be better, so there were no surprises.

title: New York Denies Indian Point a Water Permit
description: In a major victory for environmental advocates, New York State has ruled that outmoded cooling technology at the Indian Point nuclear power plant kills so many Hudson River fish, and consumes and contaminates so much water, that it violates the federal Clean Water Act.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Hundreds of Drug Cases Are at Risk in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Hundreds of drug cases have been dismissed and hundreds more are being examined here by prosecutors who are scrambling to deal with the fallout from accusations that a technician in the Police Departments crime laboratory was stealing cocaine for personal use.

title: Rhymes and Reasons for Father-Daughter Bonding
description: Daddy, what rhymes with Pierzynski?

title: Start-Ups, Not Bailouts
description: Heres my fun fact for the day, provided courtesy of Robert Litan, who directs research at the Kauffman Foundation, which specializes in promoting innovation in America: Between 1980 and 2005, virtually all net new jobs created in the U.S. were created by firms that were 5 years old or less, said Litan. That is about 40 million jobs. That means the established firms created no new net jobs during that period.

title: Coach Walks the Dress Codes Fine Line
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees require jackets, but not ties, on their charter flights. So technically, the bullpen coach Mike Harkey did not violate the dress code. But Manager Joe Girardi enjoyed ragging him for an embarrassing oversight.

title: Its a Bird, Its a Plane, Its Obama!
description: NOT since Clark Kent changed in a phone booth has there been an instant image makeover to match Barack Obamas in the aftermath of his health care victory. He went from Jimmy Carter to F.D.R. in just a fortnight, said one of the Game Change authors, Mark Halperin, on MSNBC. Look at the steam in the mans stride! exclaimed Chris Matthews. Is it just me, or does Barack Obama seem different since health care passed? wrote Peter Beinart in The Daily Beast, which, like The Financial Times, ran an illustration portraying the gangly president as a newly bulked-up Superman.

title: After Word
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Bob Klahn is taking it easy on us today. Hes known for his clever cluing but even more for his tough puzzles. Even top solvers know theyre in for a challenge when Will Shortz announces his name at the A.C.P.T. as a tournament constructor. A collective gulp trickles across the room. The Wrath of Klahn.

title: Live Updates From the Mens Final Four: Butler Beats Michigan State
description: Live coverage and analysis from the Final Four. Kevin Armstrong and Thayer Evans will provide updates from Indianapolis, along with the the longtime Quad contributor Zach Hillesland, who played in the tournament with Notre Dame. You can also follow Pete Thamel on Twitter throughout the Final Four.

title: Mets Make Final Moves
description: The Mets completed their 25-man roster Saturday after they lost to the Orioles, 11-0, in their final spring training game.

title: You, Too, Can Bankroll a Rock Band
description: EVEN early in their careers, the Beatles led charmed lives. Sure, they spent hundreds of nights playing the clubs of Hamburg before their inherent talent and practiced skill were discovered. But once they were waved into the privileged sanctum of the signed recording artist, they commanded the worlds attention.

title: Does Merck Agreement Pave a Road Toward Change?
description: SHAREHOLDERS of Merck sued in 2004, contending that current and former company officers and directors had breached their fiduciary duties in the marketing of the painkiller Vioxx, causing investors to lose billions.

title: Suns Go Back to Doing What They Do Best
description: Last year, the Phoenix Suns fired their coach, and missed the playoffs for the first time since 2004. This year, the Suns have ridden a late-season hot streak back to their customary place near the top of the Western Conference and could make some noise come playoff time.

title: Harriet Shetler, Who Helped to Found Mental Illness Group, Dies at 92
description: Harriet Shetler, whose experience as the mother of a son with schizophrenia led her to help start a national organization to address mental health needs, died Tuesday in Madison, Wis. She was 92.

title: Burton Joseph, Lawyer in First Amendment Cases, Is Dead at 79
description: Burton Joseph, a civil liberties lawyer in Chicago who took on tough First Amendment causes, notably the right of Nazis to march through Skokie, a Chicago suburb with a large Jewish population, died on Wednesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 79 and maintained his primary residence in Evanston, Ill.

title: Stamkos Up, Ovechkin Down
description: TAMPA, Fla.  There will be no playoffs for the Tampa Bay sophomore Steven Stamkos, certainly not after he and the Lightning were so emphatically beaten by the Rangers on Friday, 5-0. But Stamkos is still a big part of the hockey conversation this spring as an unforeseen contender for the Maurice Richard Trophy, awarded to the N.H.L.s top goal scorer.

title: Factory Food
description: No country has embraced the movement toward commercialized, prepackaged food as much as the United States.

title: David Slivka, a Sculptor and Painter, Dies at 95
description: On the morning of Nov. 11, 1953, David Slivka, a well-known sculptor, slipped into a Manhattan funeral parlor to pay his respects to a friend. It was no ordinary visit.

title: A Place With Good Vibrations
description: Alonzo King is the choreographer and artistic director for Alonzo King LINES Ballet, a contemporary dance company he founded in 1982. Decades ago when Mr. King was new to San Francisco, a friend took him into Golden Gate Park, where he was captivated by a roadside stand of Australian tree ferns. (His remarks have been edited and condensed.) MALIA WOLLAN

title: Richmonds New Priority: Taking Health Seriously
description: Daniel Weintraub has reported on California politics and policy for more than 20 years.

title: City Endorses New Policy for Treatment of H.I.V.
description: In a major shift of H.I.V. treatment policy, San Francisco public health doctors have begun to advise patients to start taking antiviral medicines as soon as they are found to be infected, rather than waiting  sometimes years  for signs that their immune systems have started to fail.

title: Why Hurling Rotten Fruit Is Good for Theater
description: When audiences threw rotten vegetables at actors in the old days, it generally meant they werent having a good time. But the San Francisco-based theater company PianoFight has been resurrecting that Shakespearean tradition in the hopes of inducing the opposite effect.

title: City Endorses New Policy for H.I.V. Treatment, and Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Report
description: A Major Shift | San Francisco public health doctors have begun to advise H.I.V. patients to start taking antiviral medicines as soon as they are found to be infected, rather than waiting  sometimes years  for signs that their immune systems have started to fail. The controversial city guidelines, to be announced next week by the Department of Public Health, may be the most forceful anywhere in their endorsement of early treatment against H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Tiny Knox College Stands Tall at Commencements
description: All things considered, the graduation speaker who drones on before the mortarboards are sent skyward typically rates low on the college seniors list of concerns.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article last Sunday about coming elections in Britain, where the opposition Conservatives hope to end the Labour Partys 13 years in power, misstated the age of Labours leader, Prime Minister Gordon Brown. He is 59, not 57.

title: For Some Aspiring Political Broadcasters, Breaking the Law Does Pay
description: When James Laski finished serving his 11-month prison stint on corruption charges in 2008, he knew his political career was over. But the former Chicago city clerk had every reason to believe his rap sheet was no barrier to another coveted, high-profile job: Chicago radio broadcaster.

title: Problem of Vacant Houses Resists Easy Solution
description: The 2900 block of Washtenaw Avenue is a quiet street in the Avondale neighborhood, where women stroll with baby carriages and parents watch their children play on the seesaw in Algonquin Park, a small playground.

title: Taking a Different Look at Chicagos Cultural Assets
description: In the middle of North Lawndale, now one of Americas most shamefully impoverished neighborhoods, theres a boarded-up apartment building where Golda Meir, the former Israeli prime minister, lived briefly when she was a young librarian.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about the Composers of the Future program for children, held in a school behind St. Gabriels Roman Catholic Church in New Rochelle, N.Y., misidentified the entity that runs the program together with the Westchester Chamber Orchestra. It is Songcatchers, an after-school music group, not the church itself.

title: Helping Patients Face Death, She Fought to Live
description: By the time she was 38, Dr. Desiree Pardi had become a leading practitioner in palliative care, one of the fastest-growing fields in medicine, counseling terminally ill patients on their choices.

title: We Cant Tell You
description: For more than 20 years, it was settled law, born of bitter experience, that the government may not eavesdrop on people in the United States without a warrant.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Charedim Shmurah Matzah Bakery in Borough Park, Brooklyn, which makes its matzo by hand, misstated part of the Web address where a photographer, Judah S. Harris, has posted pictures of the bakery. It is judahsharris.com/matzah-bakery.

title: Live Updates From the Final Four: Duke Beats West Virginia
description: Live coverage and analysis from the Final Four. Kevin Armstrong and Thayer Evans will provide updates from Indianapolis, along with the the longtime Quad contributor Zach Hillesland, who played in the tournament with Notre Dame. You can also follow Pete Thamel on Twitter throughout the Final Four.

title: Pension Funds Fail to Reap Private Equitys Rewards
description: Private equity deal makers, those kings of corporate buyouts, made billions for themselves when times were good. But some of their biggest investors, public pension funds, are still waiting for the hefty rewards they were promised, The New York Timess Jenny Anderson reports.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about houseplants that do well in New York City apartments misidentified the genus of one plant, known as the ZZ plant. It is Zamioculcas zamiifolia, not Zamia zamiifolia.

title: Already Home, Butler Rounds Third
description: INDIANAPOLIS  All week, the Final Four has been a homecoming celebration of Butler basketball.

title: The Waning of Private Medical Practice
description: To the Editor:

title: Censored in Singapore
description: LAST month, on the same day The New York Times praised Google for standing up to censorship in China, a sister newspaper, The International Herald Tribune, apologized to Singapores rulers and agreed to pay damages because it broke a 1994 legal agreement and referred to them in a way they did not like.

title: Intervening to Stop Bullying
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweet Honey on the Roof
description: Heres the best news we have heard in a while: keeping honeybees is now legal in New York City. The old rule was based on a misunderstanding. It lumped honeybees into a long list of wild animals that may not be kept in the city  outside a zoo  including the hippopotamus and elephant.

title: Hedge Funds Make Hay
description: Riding high on the bank bailout, hedge fund managers posted record paydays in 2009, according to an annual survey by AR: Absolute Return +Alpha magazine.

title: Rebuilding Haiti: Getting It Right This Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Tattered Right to Counsel
description: New York States dysfunctional, underfinanced public defender program is a problem of constitutional dimensions. It is the subject of a class-action lawsuit, which argues credibly that indigent criminal defendants are regularly deprived of their right to effective counsel. The suit, filed by the New York Civil Liberties Union, focuses on five counties, but the problem is far broader. A commission appointed by Judith Kaye, then the chief judge, concluded in 2006 that the states defender system failed to provide effective representation to a large portion of those entitled to it, citing bloated caseloads and inadequate training and supervision.

title: Lapse in Jobless Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Devil of a Scandal
description: WASHINGTON

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about Americas Kitchens, an exhibition of seven period kitchens at the Long Island Museum in Stony Brook, gave an outdated name for the organization that owns the three dozen historic homes from which the kitchens were borrowed. It is now Historic New England, no longer the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities.

title: Queasy Before Her Round, Leader Is All Smiles After It
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Her mouth was drier than the desert, her stomach was churning and she could not feel her legs. As nervous as Karen Stupples was Saturday, she knew she was poised for a good round on moving day at the Kraft Nabisco Championship.

title: Nearing Record, Warriors Nelson Prefers Not to Talk About It
description: Don Nelson had one warning for the news media.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on March 14 about an automobile show at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta, which includes cars once owned by Clark Gable and Steve McQueen, referred incorrectly to the actors preferences in cars. They both owned Jaguars; it was not the case that they had completely different tastes in cars. (As the article noted, Mr. Gable owned a big, lavish 1935 Duesenberg and Mr. McQueen owned the sleek Jaguar XKSS  both of which are in the Atlanta show. But Mr. Gable was one of the first Americans to own a Jaguar XK120, a predecessor to Mr. McQueens XKSS.)

title: White Supremacist Is Killed in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG  The white supremacist Eugene TerreBlanche, who sought to rally Afrikaners to resist the end of apartheid, was killed Saturday on his farm by workers there, police officials said.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Brian Distelberg and Ryan McAuliffe misstated the middle name of Mr. McAuliffes father. He is Kenneth Joseph McAuliffe, not Kenneth Jay.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about low-profile attractions in Paris referred incorrectly to Louis XVs connection to the Louvre in describing  Chateau, which offers wine tastings in that monarchs private cellar. Louis XV lived at Versailles, not at the Louvre. (He oversaw additions to the Louvre.)

title: Lookin at Lucky Falters; Eskendereya Cruises
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  Shortly after Eskendereya pulled away from an overwhelmed Wood Memorial field in New York and established himself as the early Kentucky Derby favorite, 10 horses edged into the starting gate here for the Santa Anita Derby in a race that was supposed to sort out who was the best 3-year-old in the West.

title: Six Arrested After Girl, 7, Is Gang-Raped in New Jersey
description: New Jersey officials announced on Saturday six arrests in connection with the gang rape of a 7-year-old girl who investigators believe was sold for sex by her 15-year-old stepsister at a party in a Trenton high-rise last weekend.

title: Correction
description: The Evening Hours column last Sunday misidentified a guest shown at the Asia Society reception on March 22. She is Chiu-Ti Jansen, not Elizabeth Han.

title: Correction
description: The In the Region article in New York and New Jersey copies last Sunday about redevelopment efforts in East Orange, N.J., misstated the street number on Evergreen Place for the sales office of a new development called Evergreen Crossings. It is at No. 33 Evergreen Place, not No. 22.

title: Swimsuit Model and Tar Heels Fan
description: Brooklyn Decker has appeared in the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue the past five years and graced the cover in 2010, a streak of success unequaled by her beloved North Carolina Tar Heels.

title: Shaquille ONeal: The N.B.A.s Salary King
description: In his 18-year career, Shaquille ONeal has put up plenty of big numbers. He has scored 28,255 points, grabbed 12,921 rebounds, won 4 N.B.A. championships and made 5,862 free throws (though it took him 11,121 attempts.) But the biggest number of all for ONeal is $290,846,146, his career earnings according to Basketball-Reference.com.

title: For a Storied Coach the Ultimate Accolade
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Tom Konchalski, the editor and publisher of High School Basketball Illustrated, called St. Anthony High Coach Bob Hurley in his apartment Thursday to wish him a Happy Easter. Before speaking with Hurley, whom he has known for more than four decades, Konchalski reached his wife, Chris, who informed him that Bob would be inducted into the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame on Aug. 13.

title: For Butler, No Such Thing as Irreplaceable
description: INDIANAPOLIS  He does not have the mustache of his teammate Matt Howard or the baby face of Gordon Hayward, but Butler guard Shelvin Mack managed to make himself unmistakable in Butlers run to the national championship game Saturday night.

title: N.C.A.A. Photo Replay: April 3
description: Butler and Duke won at the Final Fourand will play for college basketballs national championship. Butler beat Michigan State, 52-50. Duke topped West Virginia, 78-57.

title: Late Rally Lifts Rangers Closer to Playoff Spot
description: SUNRISE, Fla.  Less than two weeks ago, the Rangers were 7 points out of a playoff spot. Now they are a hairbreadth away.

title: Vows: Vivienne & Kaddu
description: Vivienne La Borde and Kaddu Luyombya met at a party, at which he judged her to be too thin and she found him to be arrogant. All would change three years later.

title: A Many-Faceted Star
description: Ellen DeGeneres has established herself as one of Americas most popular entertainers.

title: In Chicago, a Tournament That Turns Out Grandmasters
description: In 1993, Laszlo Nagy began organizing monthly tournaments in Budapest that give players a chance to earn the norms needed to gain the grandmaster and international master titles. Called the First Saturday tournaments, the events have attracted many of the worlds best players.

title: Duke Returns to Final, but With a Different Style
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski acknowledged that the criticism had bugged him. He resented a reporters question last month about his teams melting down in recent N.C.A.A. tournaments. Duke had lost to lower seeds in six consecutive seasons.

title: Showing Softer Side, Huggins Comforts Butler
description: INDIANAPOLIS  With West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins kneeling inches from his face to comfort him, DeSean Butler feared that he had torn the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 3, 2010

title: N.B.A. Gives Fans a Voice, Albeit a Small One
description: This season the N.B.A. is giving fans a chance to actually vote for the leagues M.V.P. award. Before people bring up the fact that the fans almost voted Tracy McGrady into a starting spot on the All-Star team despite the fact that he had played a mere 45 minutes all season leading up to the game, its worth noting that the fan vote will not actually count for much.

title: Paris Show Puts Spotlight on New York
description: American artists have had a long-standing attraction to Paris: John Singer Sargent, Ellsworth Kelly and Edward Hopper are among the prominent names who have turned to the city for inspiration. Now a show in the French capital is returning the favor, focusing specifically on New York.

title: Best Right Guards in the N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
description: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely  but not strictly  by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, though the future isnt ignored. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. Thats why most of you will have no trouble disagreeing about what youre about to read.

title: David Waldsteins 2010 Predictions
description: David Waldstein is in his first season covering the Mets for The Times. Here are his picks for the playoffs and major award winners. Tyler Kepners A.L. picks can be found here, his N.L. picks here.

title: A Sheaf of Rejections, But Still Fabulous
description: Ive been rejected and Im still fabulous.

title: Ben Shpigels 2010 Predictions
description: Ben Shpigel, who covered the Mets for the Times from 2005 to 2009, is in his first year as the Yankees beat writer. Here are his predictions for the playoffs and major award winners. Tyler Kepners A.L. picks can be found here, his N.L. picks here.

title: Bombs Hit Hub of Diplomacy in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi capital echoed with explosions on Sunday as insurgents sought to exploit political uncertainties created by painstakingly slow talks on forming a new government, with three suicide car bombings at diplomatic targets killing dozens of people and other scattered attacks disrupting areas across Baghdad.

title: Finally, Vettel Wins a Race
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  After scoring pole position at the first two races and dropping from the lead with a technical problem each time, Sebastian Vettel of Germany leaped from third on the grid at the Malaysian Grand Prix here on Sunday to take the lead from his Red Bull teammate by the first corner. He never dropped it.

title: Protesters Turn Up Heat in Thailand
description: BANGKOK    Dancing jubilantly in the streets to the beats of blaring pop and country music, anti-government demonstrators on Sunday defied calls by the government to disperse from Bangkoks affluent commercial hub in a major escalation of three weeks of mass demonstrations.

title: State Media Dispute Report That Kim Went to Beijing
description: SEOUL   The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, was the host of a weekend party in his countrys capital, Pyongyang, for the new Chinese ambassador, both countries state media reported Sunday, disputing a South Korean news report that Mr. Kim visited China on Saturday.

title: The Sunday Word: Resurgent Taliban
description: A resurgent Afghan Taliban is neutering the American effort to win over militants and would-be fighters in Marja, where money meant to win over residents is ending up in the hands of anti-Western forces, The Timess Richard Oppel reported from Baghdad.

title: Easter Support for Pope, and Some Apologies
description: VATICAN CITY  A prominent cardinal, in a marked departure from tradition, stood near Pope Benedict XVI at Easter Mass in St. Peters Square on Sunday and delivered pointedly public support in the face of growing anger over the Catholic Churchs sex abuse scandal  a topic untouched by the pope in his Easter appearances.

title: La Traviata, Take 2: Same Cast, Different Conductor
description: The cast of Verdis Traviata at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night looked much relieved to have the conductor Marco Armiliato in the pit instead of Leonard Slatkin, who had conducted on Monday, the opening of the run.

title: Zuma Seeks to Calm South Africa After Killing
description: JOHANNESBURG  South Africas president, Jacob Zuma, called for calm on Sunday, warning that agents provocateurs might try to incite racial hatred after the brutal killing of the white supremacist Eugene TerreBlanche.

title: 'Lend Me a Tenor'
description: Anthony LaPaglia and Jan Maxwell in a scene from the Broadway revival of Ken Ludwig's play. (Video courtesy of the production)

title: Greenspan Cites Economic Momentum
description: Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve and a self-described Republican libertarian, on Sunday reinforced increasingly confident assessments by the Obama administration that the nations latest job numbers reveal a resurgent economy.

title: Fuel Leak Threatening Great Barrier Reef
description: HONG KONG  Salvage experts and a tugboat crew struggled on Monday to save a large Chinese freighter that slammed into the Great Barrier Reef off Australia over the weekend, trying to prevent the vessel from breaking apart as some of the 1,075 tons of engine fuel in its tanks began oozing from the hull, threatening the worlds largest collection of coral.

title: Does Merck Agreement Pave a Road Toward Change?
description: Shareholders of Merck sued in 2004, contending that current and former company officers and directors had breached their fiduciary duties in the marketing of the painkiller Vioxx, causing investors to lose billions.

title: BB&T Whistle-Blower Ordered Rehired
description: The BB&T Corporation must rehire a former company investigator who said she was fired after exposing a $100 million North Carolina development scam, a federal administrative law judge said in a ruling released Friday, according to The Associated Press.

title: Bid to Keep A.I.G. Assets in California Is Dismissed
description: A judge in California dismissed a lawsuit on Thursday that would have barred the American International Group from moving any assets out of that state until an independent audit could verify the companys financial condition, The New York Timess Mary Williams Walsh reported Saturday.

title: Some Claims Dismissed for Ex-Qwest Officials
description: A federal judge has thrown out some claims in a civil lawsuit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission against former Qwest executives, including Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive, The Associated Press reported Saturday.

title: Stanford Victims Fund Gains $14 Million
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission obtained more than $14.2 million for Stanford Financial Group investors in a Panamanian asset sale, the agency said Friday, according to Bloomberg News.

title: Easter in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD At first, I mistakenly thought that the sound was caused by the rattle of two iron rods. This is the Stone Age method still used ironic, in a land considered one of the wealthiest in resources to alert residents that the gas cylinder mans cart is in their neighborhood.

title: Alan Greenspan: Still Not A Mensch
description: Until now Ive managed to avoid reading Alan Greenspans Brookings Paper (pdf). But I finally took the plunge  and discovered that hes still not a mensch, a person of integrity willing to take responsibility for his own actions.

title: WWS 543, April 5
description: Readings (doc)

title: Clash of the Titans Rules Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  Clash of the Titans sold $61.4 million in tickets in North America over the weekend, enough for first place. But that strong showing was powered less by 3-D screenings than by traditional ones.

title: Gods Are in Their Heaven, but Alls Not Right With World
description: What does a writer do when he has already won the Man Booker Prize and can make copacetic use of words like preterite, spalpeen, goitrous and phthistic? In the case of John Banville, whose accolades also include the Guinness Peat Aviation award, the answer has been to take a pseudonymous flight of escapism into genre fiction.

title: Karzais Words Leave Few Choices for the West
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As President Hamid Karzai made more antagonistic statements over the weekend toward the NATO countries fighting on behalf of his government, the West was taking stock of just how little maneuvering room it has.

title: Verdi Chops Are Tested by Traviata
description: It is hard not to feel sorry for Leonard Slatkin in the aftermath of his withdrawal from the Metropolitan Operas revival of La Traviata. True, he has much to answer for. He had never performed this popular Verdi opera when he accepted the engagement to conduct it at the Met. By his own admission he was insufficiently prepared.

title: Its Not Over Till the Zonked Guy Flings
description: One, two, three, four, five. Yes, thats five doors on the stage of the Music Box Theater, where a revival of Ken Ludwigs Lend Me a Tenor opened Sunday night. Five doors, primed for slamming, in a single hotel suite. All but incontrovertible physical evidence that farce is on the bill.

title: Grants Nurture Arts Spaces and Housing
description: As part of an effort to increase the impact of its giving, the Ford Foundation is to announce a plan on Monday to dedicate $100 million to the development of arts spaces nationwide over the next decade. The plan is by far the largest commitment the foundation has ever made to the construction, maintenance and enhancement of arts facilities.

title: Take It to the Limit
description: In middle school my friends and I enjoyed chewing on the classic conundrums. What happens when an irresistible force meets an immovable object? Easy  they both explode. Philosophys trivial when youre 13.

title: Whats True in Art Studios and Onstage
description: Painful experience has taught me to approach movies or plays about artists and their art with low expectations. For someone like me  an art critic for longer than she cares to recall who before that held various small-time jobs around the art world  these dramatic forays into the studio tend to fall gratingly wide of the mark.

title: Ballet Stars, Up Close and Personal
description: There is something almost overwhelming about seeing dancers like Marcelo Gomes and Ashley Bouder in a space as small as the Alvin Ailey Citigroup Theater. Artists of this caliber, so accustomed to projecting in cavernous houses, offer vertiginous, sometimes surprising thrills when seen on a human scale.

title: More Surgery for Levine Means Met Cancellations
description: In need of surgery for a lower-back problem, the conductor James Levine, right, will not be on the podium for the Metropolitan Operas coming productions of Tosca and Lulu, the company announced on Sunday.

title: Juilliard Student Group Attuned to Baroque Pitch
description: The Juilliard School  which, together with Carnegie Hall and its Weill Music Institute, concocted an inscrutable name for the performing arm of their academy, the Ensemble ACJW  has come up with another puzzler: Juilliard415. The logo highlights the A in Juilliard and the 415, slipping a hint to specialists. But is an average listener (or for that matter, a typical Juilliard student) supposed to intuit that this is a group that tunes to an A of 415 cycles per second (as opposed to the modern 440 or so), a standard now thought to have been widespread in Baroque precincts, and that it must therefore be an early-music ensemble?

title: New CDs
description: SHARON JONES & THE DAP-KINGS

title: What, Me Solve?
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  We have another guest solver with us today, the art director of Mad magazine, Sam Viviano. Well get to his report after my brief notes (in Mad terms, Ill be the letters section, with Mr. Viviano serving as the climactic fold-in).

title: Prelude to Championships Advances Players Education
description: The main events at every North American Bridge Championships start on a Friday. But on the preceding evening there is a charity duplicate for the American Contract Bridge Leagues Education Foundation. This is a nonprofit organization with the goal to make bridge a game played by people of all ages and walks of life.

title: Featuring Iphigenia, Videos and In-Jokes
description: The news that the Ohio Theater, the SoHo home of adventurous drama for almost three decades, is closing in August is not a good sign, but lets not get carried away. Off Off Broadway remains dynamic, and its no surprise that theater makers are moving away from expensive neighborhoods of Lower Manhattan. Would it be so terrible if the occasional rumor that Performance Space 122 might move to Brooklyn became true? I dont think so.

title: Tea Party Groups Make Harry Reid Target No. 1
description: LAS VEGAS  The television cameras went 60 miles south, to where Sarah Palin kicked off the Showdown in Searchlight.

title: Handels Women Mean Business
description: Female operatic characters are so often victims  of murder, consumption, suicide and their own messy emotions. But in Handels Partenope the women come out on top. Its gender-bending plot and wondrous music are vividly realized in Francisco Negrins production, which returned to New York City Opera on Saturday evening.

title: Boundaries Shift in Mixing and Matching of Artists and Images
description: The program handed out to those arriving for Body Maps at Galapagos Art Space in Dumbo, Brooklyn, on Friday night succinctly stated the events premise, an evening of music and film featuring artists who have crossed oceans. That what transpired hardly seemed so clear cut was to be expected given the events architects: the composer Paola Prestini, a founder of the interdisciplinary collective VisionIntoArt, and Beth Morrison, a producer who specializes in facilitating ambitious avant-garde collaborations.

title: Singler vs. Hayward Is the Matchup to Watch
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Mondays championship game between Duke and Butler is full of intriguing matchups, but the most intriguing will be Kyle Singler versus Gordon Hayward.

title: A Cuban Company Taking on Its Traditions and Ballets
description: LONDON  The National Ballet of Cuba came to fame as the project of the ballerina Alicia Alonso, who founded it in 1948. During her exceptionally long stage career and despite the presence of other good dancers, she often eclipsed her own company. Now that she has retired from performing, her company and school have gone on producing dancers of note, including Carlos Acosta, one of the schools most celebrated alumni. He and other dancers have become better advertisements for their alma mater than Ms. Alonso herself.

title: Bartering Art for Taxes
description: With tax returns due this month in the United States, Americans might be interested to learn how one unidentified citizen of Britain got out of paying up there: he contributed a bronze statue by Edgar Degas to the nation instead, BBC News reported. Dancer Looking at the Sole of Her Right Foot was donated in place of ponying up more than $265,000 of inheritance tax the person owes, one of many items taken as payment under the Acceptance in Lieu program. The program, administered by the Museums, Libraries and Archives Council on behalf of the British government, allows those who owe inheritance tax to donate items deemed to be of historical or artistic importance. The Degas statue will be added to a collection of French 19th-century paintings, sculptures and drawings at the Courtauld Gallery. The British government accepted almost $30 million in artwork through the program last year.

title: The Tour, It Is A-Changin
description: Bob Dylan canceled a leg of his Asian tour after the Chinese government refused him permission to play scheduled performances in Shanghai and Beijing this month, Agence France-Presse reported. Brokers Brothers Herald, Mr. Dylans Taiwan-based promoter, said the Chinese culture ministry gave Mr. Dylan no alternative but to cancel subsequent shows in Hong Kong and Taiwan. The chance to play in China was the main attraction for him, Jeffrey Wu, Brokers chief of operations, told The South China Morning Post of Hong Kong. When that fell through, everything else was called off. The ministry did not respond to telephone calls from Agence France-Presse on Sunday, but Mr. Wu said that the Chinese government had become more selective about performances by foreigners after Bjorks 2008 concert in Shanghai, where she shouted Tibet, Tibet! while performing her song Declare Independence. Later that year China imposed rules on such concerts, including one that said, Those who used to take part in activities that harm our nations sovereignty are firmly not allowed to perform in China.

title: Footnotes
description: The avant-garde director, choreographer, artist and playwright Robert Wilson, known for his epic experimental works The Civil Wars and Einstein on the Beach will receive this years Jerome Robbins Award, Playbill reported. Robbins befriended Mr. Wilson in the 1960s, often attending open houses at Mr. Wilsons loft to see his early works, like The Life and Times of Sigmund Freud, and A Letter for Queen Victoria. The $100,000 prize from the Jerome Robbins Foundation, as well as a bronze statue, will be awarded at a ceremony in December. ... Stephen Daldry, who directed the musical Billy Elliot to acclaim on Broadway, has been hired to direct the film adaptation of Jonathan Safran Foers novel Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close, according to The Hollywood Reporter. But Mr. Daldry is no stranger to book adaptations, having directed two other popular film versions, The Hours and The Reader. Paramount and Warner Brothers will co-produce the movie. Production dates have not been announced.

title: Two Dance Groups Negotiate Merger
description: A merger of two New York dance organizations would combine the 28-year-old Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company and the 45-year-old presenter Dance Theater Workshop, Crains New York Business reported. The groups are in final negotiations on the merger, which would combine the staff and boards of both groups into one with a new name and a new mission. Dance Theater Workshops executive director, Andrea Sholler, told Crains that the specifics of the agreement were still being worked out, including who would run the new group. Were very excited about the model were working on, she said. According to Crains, the merger will help Dance Theater Workshop, which as of last year had accumulated $4.2 million in debt. Mr. Jones, above, plans to move his company into Dance Theater Workshops space at 219 West 19th Street in Chelsea.

title: A Match for Emma
description: A rare copy of Jane Austens Emma, signed by the author, has sold for almost $500,000, according to the BBC News. This three-volume first edition, below, published in 1816, was one of 12 presentation copies that the publisher, John Murray, allotted to Austen for friends and family. Austen originally gave this copy to Anne Sharp, her friend and the inspiration for the character of Mrs. Weston in the novel. In 2008 Jonkers Rare Books in Henley-on-Thames, England, bought the book for a little more than $273,000 at the Bonhams auction house in London. Last week Jonkers announced that it had sold the book to a British collector it did not identify. The important thing is the signature of Jane Austen to her best friend, Christiaan Jonkers, director of the booksellers, told The Henley Standard. Thats what moves it from being a 20,000 book to a 300,000 book.

title: Fine for Public Nudity at Dealey Plaza, Dallas
description: Erykah Badu will receive a citation for disorderly conduct for stripping naked while filming a video in the Dallas plaza where John F. Kennedy was assassinated, The Associated Press reported.

title: Turning Tides in Afghanistan
description: Compensation helped turn the tide of insurgency in Iraq. But in Marja, where the Taliban seem to know everything, they have already found ways to thwart the strategy.

title: Andy Roddicks New Plan Results in a Title
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Now that he is 27, which is middle age in mens tennis, and plays with increased savvy and finesse, Andy Roddick is considered more sophisticated. He grudgingly accepts the compliment.

title: Strong Mexico Quake Shakes Buildings and Nerves in California
description: LOS ANGELES  A powerful earthquake southeast of Tijuana shook Southern California on Sunday afternoon, damaging buildings in northern Mexico and border cities in California and Arizona and rattling a seismically sophisticated population as far north as Los Angeles and Las Vegas as chandeliers swayed, homes shook and the earth seemed to slide under the feet of people emerging from Easter church services for well over a minute.

title: Mike Cuellar, Star Pitcher for Orioles, Dies at 72
description: Mike Cuellar, a Cy Young Award-winning left-hander whose brilliant screwball helped the Baltimore Orioles win three consecutive American League pennants, died Friday at a hospital in Orlando, Fla. He was 72.

title: Dozens Rescued From Chinese Mine
description: BEIJING  Thirty-four miners were freed early Monday from a flooded coal mine in northern China where they had been trapped for more than week, and Chinas state-run media said rescuers were close to saving 61 more later Monday. There was no word on the fate of 58 others trapped in the watery pit in Shanxi Province.

title: Can CNN Be Saved?
description: Listening to Jon Stewart helped destroy CNN. Now imitating him might be the networks only hope of salvation.

title: New Health Initiatives Put Spotlight on Prevention
description: WASHINGTON  Amid all the rancor leading up to passage of the new health care law, Congress with little fanfare approved a set of wide-ranging public initiatives to prevent disease and encourage healthy behavior.

title: U.S. Admits Role in February Killing of Afghan Women
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After initially denying involvement or any cover-up in the deaths of three Afghan women during a badly bungled American Special Operations assault in February, the American-led military command in Kabul admitted late on Sunday that its forces had, in fact, killed the women during the nighttime raid.

title: Obama Misses the Big Oil
description: Amherst, Mass.

title: Red Sox Beat Yankees in Season Opener
description: Nearly five months after the Yankees Mark Teixeira closed his glove on the 2009 World Series, the 2010 Major League Baseball season opened Sunday night with a game that always has Series-level passion: Yankees-Red Sox.

title: Drilling Plan May Buoy Efforts on Energy Policy
description: Ever since he ran Bill Clintons Its the Economy, Stupid presidential campaign in 1992, James Carville has held a reputation for common-sense Democratic strategy.

title: Colonial-Era Dispute Agitates South Koreans
description: TONGYEONG, South Korea  A nondescript post office here provides an appealing footnote to the history of Korean literature. From 1945 until his death in 1967, the poet Yu Chi-hwan strolled in almost daily, mailing thousands of letters to a widowed poet, his muse in one of the countrys most celebrated literary love affairs.

title: Throw Out Skybox Tax Subsidies
description: UNTIL the 1970s, Major League Baseball was a populist sport. Bleacher seats cost as little as a dollar, meaning middle- or even working-class fans could afford to take their families to a game a few times each season.

title: Mentally Disturbed Man Attacks Bishop in Germany
description: BERLIN  A mentally disturbed man ran amok in the Mnster Cathedral during the Easter service on Sunday, attacking the bishop with a broom handle, the police said.

title: Officer Hurt in Traffic Stop on B.Q.E.
description: A police officer suffered two broken legs just after stopping a driver he suspected was drunk, when he was struck by a second drunken driver on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway early Sunday, the authorities said.

title: A Store Kept Afloat by the Generosity of Customers
description: POINT LOOKOUT, N.Y.

title: Do-It-Yourself Dining at the Grand Hyatt
description: Wedged between the bell desk and an antiques store in the lobby of the Grand Hyatt New York hotel on East 42nd Street is an elegant new market offering designer pastries, salads of baby greens and hot meals to go. With sleek, dark wood floors, white stacked-tile walls and pillars bathed in sky-blue light, the space  designed by the architectural team behind the restaurants Craft, Gramercy Tavern and the Modern  feels more like a specialty food shop than an alcove in a chain hotel.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Presidents Features Reunited After 176 Years
description: Finding a politicians mouth has rarely been a problem  unless it has been missing since 1834.

title: In Hate-Crime Case, a Teenager Finds Himself Caught in 2 Worlds
description: PATCHOGUE, N.Y.  Hundreds stood in the rain next to the railroad tracks, around a shrine made of flowers, balloons and a mural of the man who had been killed there. Someone arranged purple and white votive candles into the shape of a heart.

title: Branding Comes Early in Filmmaking Process
description: LOS ANGELES  Jordan Yospe had some notes on the script for The 28th Amendment, a thriller about a president and a rogue Special Forces agent on the run. Some of the White House scenes were not detailed enough, Mr. Yospe thought. And, he suggested, the heroes should stop for a snack while they were on the lam.

title: For Haitian-American Doctors, a Call to Return
description: As she struggled with junior high algebra at SS. Joachim and Anne School in Queens, Marie-Dominique Toussaint knew where it was all supposed to lead: she would be a doctor, an ambition inspired by her father, a physician she rarely saw, and fueled by her mother, a nurse who immigrated from Haiti.

title: Drones Batter Al Qaeda and Its Allies Within Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A stepped-up campaign of American drone strikes over the past three months has battered Al Qaeda and its Pakistani and Afghan brethren in the tribal area of North Waziristan, according to a mid-ranking militant and supporters of the government there.

title: Red Bulls: Road Warriors
description: The Red Bulls had just arrived at Newark Airport on Sunday after an early-morning flight from Seattle.

title: Spring Harvest of Debt for Parched Farms in Southern China
description: WANGZHI, China  Odds are that the drought that is parching southwest Chinas Yunnan Province and its neighbors will break sometime in the next month, as the regions usually dry winter gives way to an abundance of summer rains.

title: States Skeptical About Race to Top School Aid Contest
description: A dozen governors, led by Bill Ritter Jr. of Colorado, sat with Secretary of Education Arne Duncan in a hotel ballroom in Washington a few weeks back, praising his vision and gushing with enthusiasm over a $4 billion grant competition they hoped could land their states a jackpot of hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Without Title in Tow, McNabb Sent to Redskins
description: From the moment fans booed when Philadelphia made him the second pick in the 1999 draft, Donovan McNabbs time with the Eagles was marked by the undercurrent that he might never be engulfed by brotherly love unless he led the Eagles to a championship. Over and over, the Eagles came close, only to fall short, fueling one off-season pledge after another that McNabb was still Andy Reids man.

description: The Eagles must think Donovan McNabb is finished.

title: Corrections

The official, Carlos Lupi, is the labor minister of Brazil, not the secretary of labor for Rio.

title: Corrections

Christie, to take on the states police and teachers unions in the face of a budget crisis, misspelled the surname of the director of a poll showing that Mr. Christies approval rating declined after his first budget address. He is Peter J. Woolley, not Wooley.

She was Alice Roosevelt Longworth, not Alice Longworth Roosevelt.

description: INDIANAPOLIS  Butler Coach Brad Stevens is 33, and less than 10 years ago was one day from starting training at Applebees when he landed a job as Butlers director of basketball operations.

title: First Time in Months Woods Makes His Game Semipublic

The sticky cloud of pollen that had clung to the Augusta National Golf Club like a yellow haze since midmorning Sunday began to clear by 2:15 p.m., just as Tiger Woods ambled from the practice putting green to the 10th tee to join his friend Mark OMeara for a nine-hole practice round.

The senator denounced the letter as a grotesque and inappropriate mistake when it was reported by Politico. But the V.I.P. access tab was not that unusual a symptom of political moneys abominable grip on the Capitol.

But when it is opening day (or night, as was the case on Sunday), when all teams start out equal, and the air is unseasonably warm, and the opposing team is Bostons fiercest rival, and that rival happened to have won the World Series last year, there is barely room to stand.

After attending John Updikes funeral in Massachusetts in February of last year, he stopped by Harvard Law School to interview some of President Obamas old professors. Despite the exhaustive newspaper coverage of the 44th president, Mr. Remnick suspected he had something to add.

But Congress should at least make certain that whatever lands on those cafeteria trays is nutritious and safe to eat. Every day it delays doing so is another mealtime when millions of students are cheated of programs that could help relieve hunger and reduce obesity.

title: Using an Electronic Device to Break in a New Violin
description: No one knows how the violins of Antonio Stradivari sounded when they first left his workbench in Cremona, Italy, hundreds of years ago. But those fabled instruments probably did not reach their full potential until they were played. And played. And then played some more.

title: Channel Surfing While Surfing the Net
description: Last year, people vastly increased the amount of time they spent watching television and browsing the Internet simultaneously, according to Nielsen. Looking only at people who used the technologies together at least once a month, Nielsen found that the amount of time such people spent on simultaneous use had shot up 34.5 percent from December 2008 to December 2009. Such users represent about 59 percent of the total population.

description: ECONOMIC REPORTS This week, reports include the ISM service index for March and pending home sales for February (Monday); F.O.M.C. minutes for March (Tuesday); Consumer credit for February (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims (Thursday).

description: INDIANAPOLIS  Matt Howards arrival at Butler three years ago was as ballyhooed as any in the universitys history.
