title: Mars on Demand
description: The High Resolution Imaging Science Experiment aboard NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter is nicknamed "the people's camera." Here are the first eight images of areas on Mars chosen by the public.

description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

description: lithe \lith, lith\ adjective

title: UConn Teeters in Semifinal, but Its Baylor That Falls
description: SAN ANTONIO  The legend of Brittney Griner is just beginning. The Connecticut winning streak just keeps growing. After defeating  but not destroying  Baylor on Sunday night in the national semifinals, it is on to another championship game for Geno Auriemmas team.

title: Girardi Still Setting Up Yankees Relief Roles
description: BOSTON  In the last game of last season, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi turned to Joba Chamberlain and Damaso Marte as his bridge to Mariano Rivera. That tandem was good enough to clinch a World Series title, and it may be good enough this season as the Yankees try to defend it.

title: Canada  Oil Sands  Are Still a Gamble
In Mexico, Resuming Life After Quake
description: MEXICALI, Mexico  The day after one of the strongest earthquakes to strike the region in nearly two decades, residents on both sides of the border marveled that damage was relatively light even as waves of mild aftershocks troubled nerves.

title: For Schoeneweis, Baseball Is the Easy Part
description: BOSTON  Eleven pitchers took the mound at Fenway Park in Sundays season opener. Only one of them was perfect: the Red Sox left-hander Scott Schoeneweis, who struck out the Yankees Curtis Granderson in the fifth inning, and then retired Nick Swisher and Brett Gardner in the sixth.

title: Hard Times for Chess
description: Early last week, Silvio Danailov, the manager of Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria, said in an interview that the M-Tel Masters would not be played this year because the main sponsor, after which the tournament is named, had pulled out. (The interview, which was with Trud, a Bulgarian newspaper, was reported by the Web site Chessdom, which has a translation.) Instead, the company decided that it would get more for its money by sponsoring Topalov in his upcoming world championship match against Viswanathan Anand of India, the titleholder.

title: News Quiz | April 5, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: SandRidge to Buy Rival Arena Resources
description: SandRidge Energy, an oil and gas exploration company, on Sunday said it agreed to buy a rival, Arena Resources, for about $1.55 billion. The move will help SandRidge increase its investments in oil, Reuters reported.

title: Where 'Slap Shot' Was Shot
description: The Johnstown Chiefs, one of the original five teams in the East Coast Hockey League, played their final game in Pennsylvania on Saturday night and will be moving to South Carolina next season.

title: Forns Fest
description: As part of the 2010 New York Forns Festival, presenting an array of work by the playwright, director and theatrical pioneer Mari Irene Forns in honor of her 80th birthday, there will be a rare revival of her play "And What of the Night?" at the Cherry Lane Theater tonight. Ms. Forns, the theater historian Marc Robinson wrote recently on the ArtsBeat blog, "is among the most important contemporary playwrights, with more than 40 plays that helped establish an American version of absurdism (in her plays of the 1960s) and that codified a spare, lyrical form of realism (in her work of the 1980s). Through her influential teaching, she has also been the godmother to an enormous number of other Hispanic playwrights."

title: Get Romantic
description: The important American baritone Thomas Hampson, artist-in-residence with the Philharmonic this season, presents "A Guide to German Romanticism," part of the orchestra's Insights series tonight at 6:30 at the Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center. "Mr. Hampson will discuss iconography, metaphor and imagery in German lieder," writes Anthony Tommasini. "He knows what he is talking about, having sung the repertory throughout his career, lived for an extended period in Vienna and done important scholarly work on the songs of Mahler. His comments will be illustrated with music, for which he will be joined by the pianist Craig Rutenberg."

title: Plumb Funny
description: "Shannon Plumb," Ken Johnson writes, is a "terrific comic performer. She makes mock television commercials in a flickering, silent-movie style and adds rousing soundtracks of jazz, rock, folk and country music. Portraying a student with attention deficit disorder, an absurdly bewigged model for a shampoo ad, a patient suffering side effects from a stop-smoking pill and other characters, Ms. Plumb is hilarious. Comparing her to Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton might sound like a stretch, but it's not." Tonight IFC Center is presenting "An Evening with Shannon Plumb." The artist and filmmaker will be there to present a sampling of her films and participate in a discussion.

title: Burry: I Foresaw the Crisis. Why Didnt the Fed?
description: Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, proclaimed last month that no one could have predicted the housing bubble. Everybody missed it, he said, academia, the Federal Reserve, all regulators.

title: Krugman: Fool-Resistant Finance Reform
description: The White House is confident that a financial regulatory reform bill will soon pass the Senate. Im not so sure, given the opposition of Republican leaders to any real reform, Paul Krugman writes in an Op-Ed column in The New York Times. But in any case, how good is the legislation on the table, the bill put together by Senator Chris Dodd of Connecticut?

title: Does Wall Street Need an Estrogen Injection?
description: From William D. Cohan at Opinionator:

title: Fischer May Still Not Be Able to Rest in Peace
description: Bobby Fischer, the former world champion, died in January 2008, but the fight over his estate is still not resolved. In the latest macabre twist, a court in Iceland will soon rule whether his body must be exhumed so that a D.N.A. test can be performed to determine if Jinky Young, an 8-year-old Filipino girl, is really his daughter.

title: Brown Said to See Bank Levy Accord Closer
description: Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain said the worlds large economies were close to agreeing a global tax on banks to help prevent another financial crisis, The Financial Times reported on Monday.

title: Wilbur Ross Backing Virgin Money in RBS Bid
description: Wilbur Ross, the billionaire investor, said on Sunday he is prepared to commit up to 500 million ($760 million) to support Virgin Money in its bid to buy the branch network of the Royal Bank of Scotland, Reuters reported.

title: Accel Invests in Personal Finance Site for Women
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: Goldman Said to Invest in Level Global Fund
description: A Goldman Sachs Group buyout firm bought a minority stake in David Ganeks $4 billion Level Global Investors, adding a hedge fund that can bet on rising as well as falling stock prices globally, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Crowds Cited in Times Sq. Shootings
description: Four people were shot in three episodes in Midtown Manhattan, and the police said they arrested 33 people as rowdy crowds roamed the area in the waning hours of Sunday and early Monday in what has become something of a violent Easter Night ritual.

title: Afghan Investigators Say U.S. Troops Tried to Cover Up Evidence in Botched Raid
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan officials investigating the deaths of five Afghan civilians gunned down in February during a bungled raid by American Special Operations forces believe that troops tampered with evidence at the scene, the lead investigator said Monday. NATO officials disclosed that they were looking into the allegations.

title: Kingdom Holding Sells Stake in Raffles
description: Kingdom Holding, Prince Alwaleed bin Talals investment vehicle, is selling a stake in Raffles Holdings International to a group of investors, including an affiliate of Qatars sovereign wealth fund, in a deal worth $847 million, according to press reports.

title: Qlik Technologies Eyes $100 Million I.P.O.
description: Qlik Technologies, a maker of business analytics software, is hoping investors will provide as much as $100 million when it goes public, peHUB reported.

title: Bombers Kill Policemen in Russia
description: MOSCOW  A suicide bomber killed at least two police officers in the restive North Caucasus region of Russia on Monday, officials said, the latest in a spate of such attacks, including a double bombing on the Moscow subway, that have killed more than 50 people in the last week.

title: With Hope Dwindling, 115 Chinese Miners Are Saved
description: BEIJING  From the start, Chinas latest coal mine disaster seemed likely to end as so many others had in a country where an average of seven miners die every day: a failed rescue effort, grieving relatives, few if any survivors.

title: Going to the Dogs

title: Do Saggy Pants Mean Disrespect?
description: What do you think of the saggy pants trend and the efforts of some communities and politicians to make young men pull their pants up? State Senator Eric Adams of Brooklyn has sponsored a billboard campaign with the slogan Raise your pants, Raise your image! Do you think such a campaign will work? Why do you think this fashion trend  at least a decade old  has hung on so long?

title: Canada Oil Sands Are Still a Gamble
description: Energy investors are showing their short memories, Reuters Breakingviews says. The stampede to the initial public offering of Athabasca Oil Sands is a tribute to the allure of Canadas extra-heavy oil. Last week Athabasca priced at the high end of its range and raised $1.35 billion, twice its goal.

description: Jonas Ketterle, a top mechanical engineering student at Stanford University, and his colleague Mike Lin, a sustainable-design lecturer at Stanford and Yale, are studying how 150 million people in developing countries make do using electricity from hacked car batteries, Victoria Schlesinger writes in The New York Times.

description: From Todd Woody at  Green Inc.:

title: U.S. Consulate in Pakistan Attacked by Militants

title: Boost for U.S.-China Clean Energy Research
description: From Sindya N. Bhanoo at Green Inc.:

title: Jogging in Paris When Spring Has Sprung
description: As blue skies finally replace wintery gray and the first spring bloom is in the air, runners start hitting the Paris streets in numbers. Whether youre training for the city marathon, scheduled for April 11, or are just working off those croissants, Pariss many parks, gardens and waterways make it a great place to get your heart rate up. Here are some spots to get you started. (Share your suggestions below.)

title: Extended Stay Said to Back New Offer
description: Extended Stay Hotels is favoring a new plan for a bid for it from investment companies Centerbridge Partners and Paulson & Company over a one from a group led by Starwood Capital Group, Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with the situation.

title: Chipotle Bites the Hand It Used to Feed
description: One of the most popular trends in advertising is to make a campaign about the ad-making process, a meta approach that speaks to how savvy contemporary consumers are about the ways products are sold to them. Chipotle Mexican Grill is climbing aboard the ads-about-ads band wagon, beginning on Monday, with a campaign that mocks the advice given to the restaurant chain by Madison Avenue.

title: Crestview and MidOcean Lead Deal for Insight Stake
description: A consortium of investors led by Crestview Partners and MidOcean Partners snapped up a large stake in Insight Communications, in a deal that will give the group a 42 percent holding in the regional cable outfit when the deal closes.

title: Charlie Bites Big Media
description: Todays idea: Big-media business models collapse the way highly sophisticated civilizations do  of their own irreversible complexity, a professor of new media writes.

title: No Big Returns Seen at Macro Hedge Funds
description: Despite criticism of speculation by hedge funds in the currency markets, funds that focus on such bets have failed to deliver significant returns since the start of the year, The Financial Times reported, citing new industry data.

title: Sino Polymer Aims for $433 Million I.P.O.
description: Sino Polymer New Material has applied for an initial public offering in South Korea to raise up to $433 million, the countrys main bourse said Monday.

title: Sampler: Pacific Gas and Electric Rates Might Hurt Solar, and Cats Prowl Amid Evidence
description: New Rates Could Slow Adoption of Solar | The proposed rate structure announced last week by Pacific Gas and Electric would replace the current five tiers with three. Most customers bills would rise, but those using the most electricity would see significant reductions, to about 30 cents per kilowatt hour from the current level of nearly 50 cents. The existing rates have been a boon to Californias residential solar industry, but these incentives would be reduced under the new plan. P.G.&E. has asked state regulators to rule on the proposal by years end. If approved, the rates would go into effect in May 2011. David Hochschild, a vice president for external relations at Solaria, a solar manufacturer in Fremont, said, You cant have one foot on the gas and one foot on the brake at the same time. [The San Jose Mercury News]

title: V.C. Valuation: The Great Debate
description: Marc Andreessen, Tom Conway and David Hornick gathered to debate hot start-ups like Quora, Foursquare and Blippy with Michael Arrington from TechCrunch.

title: More Talking Babies, This Time in a New Ad for Diapers.com
description: E*Trade has commercials with talking babies. Zappos has commercials that offer a fanciful look at its customer service center. So can you guess the approach being taken in a campaign for Diapers.com?

title: Tax Payback Year
The View From Philadelphia on the McNabb Trade
description: Enrico Campitelli of the 700 Level put it starkly in the opening of his blog post: Donovan McNabb was the most polarizing figure in Philadelphia sports over the past decade.

title: NHN Said to Win Auction for Livedoor
description: NHN, the parent company of South Korean search leader Naver.com, won a bid to buy Japanese portal Livedoor, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Gadget Impresses Cat
description: Video | The iPads out of the bag:

title: Yamaha Set for $810 Million Share Issue
description: Yamaha Motor, the worlds second-largest motorcycle maker, plans to raise 76.1 billion yen ($810 million) from a public sale of new shares to fund research and development, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Morgan Chief Sees $15 Million Pay Day
description: The recently installed chief executive of Morgan Stanley, James P. Gorman, took home $15 million last year serving as the investment banks co-president, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing the firms proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday.

title: Motorcycle Training Does Not Reduce Crash Risk, Study Says
description: Courses designed to make new motorcyclists safer are not decreasing crashes, according to a new study by the Highway Loss Data Institute, an affiliate of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. However, research also shows that helmets and antilock brakes on motorcycles are life savers.

title: A Cab Outside Manhattan. What a Concept.
description: Recently, David Yassky, the erstwhile Brooklyn city councilman and candidate for comptroller, was confirmed as the chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission. He will be czar of the citys livery and yellow cab industry  a steward of this icon, in his words.

title: Shuttle Lifts Off for Space Station
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  Lighting up the predawn sky, the space shuttle Discovery climbed out of darkness and into the glare of the rising sun early Monday, putting on a spectacular sky show as it thundered away on a mission to resupply the International Space Station.

title: O.K., Who Thought
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: Q.&A.: The Benefits of Blu-ray
description: Q.

title: Submit Your Funny Caption
description: Bog n Bogey | Tell us whats going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned images were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. The most recent funniest captions are at right.

title: Speed Read for Monday, April 5
description: Here are some highlights from Mondays edition of The New York Times:

title: Bargain Rates for a C.E.O.?
description: Last year may have been unnerving for chief executives accustomed to all of the familiar ornaments of corporate life: eight-figure pay packages, corporate jets, memberships in select clubs, and on and on.

title: Is Movement Near for Financial Reform?
description: 7:58 a.m. | Updated Fresh off the Democrats victory on overhauling health care, some key Republicans are moving toward compromises on the next big item on the Washington agenda, financial regulatory reform, The New Republic reports.

title: Media Equation: How Sarah Palin Became a Brand
description: In his Media Equation column, David Carr writes about how former Alaska governor and Republican vice presidential nominee Sarah Palin has defied all the experts  who told her after her 2008 defeat to go back to being governor and study up so shed do better in future national contests  to become a one-woman national media empire. The first episode of Real American Stories on Fox News last week only underscored her achievement. He writes:

title: Video Shows Attack on U.S. Consulate in Pakistan
description: Updated | 4:33 p.m. As my colleagues Ismail Khan and Sabrina Tavernise report, on Monday Pakistani television showed footage shot during a militant attack on a government checkpoint near the American consulate in the city of Peshawar.

title: After 176 Years, Mouth Returns to Face
description: Finding a politicians mouth has rarely been a problem  unless it has been missing since 1834.

title: Of Biofuels, Land Grabs and Food Prices
description: ActionAid, an antipoverty group, has stepped up a campaign against European Union policies aimed at encouraging consumers to use fuels grown from crops to power their cars.

title: The View From Washington on the McNabb Trade
description: The Donovan McNabb trade created something of a partisan divide in Washington, at least in the aisles at The Washington Post:

title: Get Ready for Blizzards in April
description: International Dairy Queen is readying two firsts for its advertising efforts, one to take place in the traditional media and the other in the new media.

title: Youre on the Waiting List. Now What?
description: When some of the nations most selective colleges announced their decisions last week, thousands of applicants found themselves neither accepted nor rejected. Like passengers bumped from an overbooked flight  as one commenter on The Choice put it this weekend  they were instructed to sit tight in a crowded, virtual lounge, and wait to see if an opening presented itself over the next few weeks.

title: Wanda Sykes Nabs Erykah Badus Window Seat
description: Last week was not an easy one for the R&B singer Erykah Badu, as tempers flared over the video for her song Window Seat, in which she disrobes at Dealey Plaza, the site in Dallas where John F. Kennedy was assassinated. She was later cited for disorderly conduct after the Dallas police said a witness had complained.

title: Save the Receipt
description: Is there anyone alive not conflicted about getting and spending? Even at the height of the bubble, when Americans wallowed in an orgy of things, there were always people like Kate Bingaman-Burt, for whom the daily acquisition of stuff resulted in a pang or two. Obsessive Consumption (Princeton Architectural Press) is her sweet act of contrition. A graphic design professor from Portland, Ore., Bingaman-Burt drew three years of everyday commerce, from pizza to toothpaste, ballet slippers, zippers, tweezers, DVDs, moving boxes, airline tickets, fly swatters, diet soda, etc. She annotates where necessary  Serta Mattress, Queen $500 No More Futon for Us!  and were also treated to credit card bills, recreated in her own innocent hand, which somehow (maybe not for her) takes the sting out of owing MasterCard $5,522.62. Read from beginning to end, Obsessive Consumption reveals a happy (if somewhat guilty) grasshopper who likes a good bargain as much as she likes a good burrito. Bingaman-Burt engages in the same name-brand culture as the rest of us, but in her life, at least, its art.

title: Ask a Hip-Hop Veteran
description: This week, Jorge Pabon, a performer and choreographer known as Pop Master Fabel, responded to questions about the history and culture of hip-hop.

title: Blagojevich Hears a Familiar Phrase: Youre Fired
description: Once again, Rod R. Blagojevich finds himself out of a job. On Sunday night, the disgraced former governor of Illinois was sent packing from The Celebrity Apprentice, the NBC reality series hosted by Donald J. Trump, after an improbable one-month run.

title: Gay Cruise to Hawaii
description: RSVP Cruises, a gay-friendly cruise company, is celebrating its 25th anniversary with a new sailing expedition to Hawaii.

title: Tickets-for-Children Charity Branches Out
description: At this time last year, the tiny charity Donate A, was in a bind. The group collects tickets to sporting events from companies and season-ticket holders and donates them to children in Hackensack University Medical Center Hospital, Memorial Sloan Kettering and other hospitals.

title: Student Challenge | Create a New York Times Found Poem
description: Its National Poetry Month, and were celebrating by inviting students to create found poems using The New York Times.

title: Apple Sold 300,000 iPads on Day One
description: Apple said Monday that it sold more than 300,000 iPads on Saturday, the day the product was released across the country.

title: Sharp Rise in Home Sales in February
description: The wobbly housing market showed a rare sign of strength in February: pending home sales were up significantly, a report released on Monday said, suggesting that Americans took advantage of a tax credit for home buyers.

title: The Flavor Chameleon: Broccoli
description: Last week I prepared pickled broccoli stems for a big party. The leftover broccoli crowns took up an entire shelf in my refrigerator  and the desire to do something with them pretty much determined this weeks subject.

title: Tee Off With On Par
description: As the eyes of the golf world turn to Augusta, Ga., where this afternoon the scandal-scarred Tiger Woods is expected to face the assembled news media for the first time in more than four months, The New York Times invites readers to weigh in on the Woods saga and all things golf on On Par, the latest addition to the stable of sports blogs from The New York Times.

title: Some First Impressions From Fenway
description: BOSTON  The first game I covered for The Times was on Aug. 2, 2005. That night at Shea Stadium, Victor Zambrano allowed four homers to the Brewers in a five-batter span. The Mets went on to overcome a four-run deficit, give up the go-ahead run in the ninth inning, tie the score in the bottom half and then win in the 11th on Mike Piazzas bases-loaded walk. The game lasted 4 hours 28 minutes, and it was a thrilling night.

title: Finding a Way In to Augusta National
description: Because the Augusta National Golf Club limits media credentials for covering the Masters, news agencies are unable to increase staffing inside the gates to report on developments related to Tiger Woodss return. (As for the TMZs and E! Entertainments of the world, dont even bother asking the club for entry.)

title: Broccoli With Chile and Garlic
description: This is a simple way to dress up broccoli. It makes a great side dish, or you can toss it with pasta.

title: Broccoli Gratin With Red Pepper and Parmesan
description: Red peppers always brighten up a dish, and they make a particularly compatible partner for broccoli.

title: Now and Then
description: If you could never quite picture Philippe Starcks machine-gun lamp in your own home, try picturing it in the architect Piero Portaluppis 1935 rationalist masterpiece, the Villa Necchi Campiglio; it has just taken up a seven-week residence in the houses entry, alongside Konstantin Grcics Kanu chair, with Portaluppis elaborate ceiling tableaus overhead. The villa, which reopened to the public in 2008, is one of four house museums that will host more than 200 pieces of 21st-century design for Unexpected Guests, one of the headline exhibitions of Milans design week. Among other interventions are a Nacho Carbonell chair and Steven Holl credenza in the Museo Bagatti Valsecchi; ceramics by the upstart Toms Alonso in the Casa Museo Boschi Di Stefanos Lucio Fontana gallery; and at the Museo Poldi Pezzoli, Gaetano Pesces La Michetta modular sofa for Meritalia (above) and Fronts horse-shaped lamp for Moooi, which displaced an armored steed. The Italians may have invented design, but they still have a sense of humor about it. Go to casemuseomilano.it.

title: Monday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Broccoli Chickpea Pure
description: This is very much like a green hummus. Serve it with pita bread, make sandwiches with it, or use it as a dip or a spread for crostini.

title: Fried Rice With Tofu and Broccoli
description: I like to use brown rice for this dish, though you can make it with white rice, too. Use the same pot in which you blanch or steam the broccoli to cook the rice.

title: Strict Deadlines, Disabled Veterans and Dismissed Cases
description: WASHINGTON

title: New York Auto Show: 2011 Bentley Supersports Convertible
description: Introduced last Thursday: 2011 Bentley Continental Supersports Convertible

title: All About Snopes, Uncovering Untruths on the Web
description: In Mondays Business section, Brian Stelter profiles David and Barbara Mikkelson who, for more than a decade, have devoted themselves to fact-checking the Web. Their conclusion: There are a lot of people out there posting items that have only a glancing relationship with the truth.

title: Concern for Detained Iranian Filmmaker
description: On Friday The Lede discussed the continuing detention of Jafar Panahi, a leading Iranian filmmaker who was arrested over a month ago, apparently while working on a film that, rightly or wrongly, the authorities understood to be anti-state.

title: Crowds Growing After a Dozen Malaysian Grands Prix
description: This was the 12th time the Sepang International Circuit had hosted the Malaysian Grand Prix, and I had the distinct impression that the locals were starting to flock to the race. There has been much chatter over the years about how Bernie Ecclestones idea of setting up races in far flung countries with no racing tradition is nothing more than a cynical effort to rake in the money these venues will pay for the races.

title: Buffalo Millionaire to Join Governors Race
description: Carl A. Paladino, a real estate developer from Buffalo, will announce later on Monday that he is joining the Republican race for governor.

title: Q.&A.: Transportation Secretary on Biking, Walking and What Americans Want
description: The United States transportation secretary, Ray LaHood, recently caused a stir when he proclaimed that bicycling and walking should be given the same consideration as motorized transport in state and local transit projects.

title: Cause Marketing Leader Joins Edelman
description: Carol Cone, who pioneered in the field now known as cause marketing, is getting a new cause: a senior post at the Edelman public relations agency.

title: Book Tells of Undercover Operation to Recover Stolen Gardner Artwork
description: Was an effort by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to recover Vermeer and Rembrandt works stolen more than 20 years ago from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston undone by infighting at the bureau? That is the assertion made by Robert K. Wittman, a retired F.B.I. special agent, in a coming book titled Priceless: How I Went Undercover to Rescue the Worlds Stolen Treasures, which details his efforts in 2006 and 2007 to retrieve the heisted paintings, The Boston Globe reported.

title: Greek Official Warns Portugal May Falter Next
description: As Greece presses its case for a bailout by the European Union, one of its controversial government officials warned that Portugal may be the next in line for debt troubles, Reuters reported, citing the Portugese newspaper Jornal de Negocios.

title: Gillibrand Picks Up Key Support
description: Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York on Monday picked up the endorsement of an influential Democratic Party leader who has tacitly encouraged a primary challenge against her over the last few months.

title: Vettel Wins the Malaysian Grand Prix
description: From our colleagues at the Formula One blog:

title: Kraft Said to Trip on Cadbury Pension Plan
description: Kraft Foods has asked about 3,600 people at Cadbury, the British confectioner it recently acquired, to choose between their present pension plan or possible pay increases, The Financial Times reports.

title: At Peter Lugers, Breaking Bread and Talking Money
description: In July, Richard Ravitch was working his way through a steak dinner at Peter Lugers when an aide to Gov. David A. Paterson unexpectedly arrived to swear in Mr. Ravitch as lieutenant governor. It was not long after the governor had announced his selection of Mr. Ravitch.

title: Marlins Ace Had an Early View of a Champion
description: BOSTON  The day I interviewed Josh Johnsons brother, Ryan, for this feature article on the ace of the Florida Marlins, I also attended the news conference announcing Joe Mauers $184 million contract extension with the Minnesota Twins.

title: I.B.M. Needs to Do Deals, Some Investors Say
description: With I.B.M. lagging rivals like Hewlett-Packard and Oracle in growth, some investors and analysts told Bloomberg News that Big Blue needs to start up its deal machine.

title: London Dance Journal: Pure British Dance, From Other Countries
description: LONDON  The comedian Anna Russell used to adopt sniffily congealed tones as she said, The British style is known for its utter purity. Todays Royal Ballet is led by dancers from Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Cuba, Denmark, France, Italy, Japan, Romania, Ukraine, the United States and other countries, but you can see how they have all adopted the characteristics that the British find so pure.

title: Better Birth Weight for Babies of Exercisers
description: Regular exercise during pregnancy doesnt change a mothers body weight but does lead to a small reduction in the babys weight, a new study shows.

title: Christina Kims Candid Look at Life on Tour
description: The cover of Christina Kims account of her 2009 season, Swinging From My Heels: Confessions of an L.P.G.A. Star, which comes out next week, seems all wrong. Instead of the full-length color shot of Kim reacting to a putt, it should have been a plain brown wrapper, so bawdy are some of her anecdotes about life on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: Saving CNN, Cont.
description: Sticking with the theme of todays column, heres Jay Rosens proposed prime-time lineup for a revamped CNN:

title: The Claim: For Better Muscle Tone, Go Lighter and Repeat
description: THE FACTS

title: Damons True Value: Consistency
description: On Sunday night Tyler Kepner wrote about the missing player in the Yankees-Red Sox rivalry. When that player, Johnny Damon, makes his debut for the Detroit Tigers on Monday afternoon, it will be with lowered expectations from his previous contract, in which he had starred for the Yankees for four seasons, winning a World Series championship.

title: Bloggers Discuss Race and the Census
description: Updated | 5:25 p.m. Last week, CNN hosted an interesting, if brief, discussion of race and the census with three bloggers who deal with race in their work: Raquel Cepeda, a filmmaker and native New Yorker by way of the Dominican Republic who blogs at djali rancher; Baratunde Thurston, a comedian who brings a Black bourgeoisie perspective to the discussion of American politics on the blog Jack & Jill Politics; and Christian Lander, a Canadian living in the United States who started the comic blog Stuff White People Like.

title: Thai Protesters Defy Order to Disperse
description: BANGKOK  Convoys of anti-government protesters coursed through Bangkok on Tuesday afternoon as thousands more demonstrators remained in the commercial heart of the city, where they continued to defy government orders to disperse.

title: How to Make Checking a Bag a Little Better
description: I rarely ever wait in line to check a bag. Whats my secret? If I have to check a bag, I always check it curbside with a skycap before entering the airport.

title: Vollis Simpson
description: Images of works by the artist.

title: Breaking Up After a Miscarriage
description: Loss brings some couples closer, their bonds strengthened by grief. More often, though, loss seems to act as a wedge and a divider, and a study released today by researchers at the University of Michigan and published in the journal Pediatrics finds that couples are more likely to break up after the loss of a pregnancy than couples whose pregnancies go to term.

title: Obsessions | Fear and Clothing
description: Ive recently noticed a proliferation of tote bags, T-shirts, fridge magnets and other motivational paraphernalia emblazoned with the phrase Do one thing every day that scares you.

title: Mike Zwerin, Jazz Critic and Author, Is Dead at 79
description: Mike Zwerin, a jazz trombonist and bass trumpeter who became a prominent jazz critic and author, died on April 2 in Paris, where he lived, after a long illness. He was 79.

title: Chefs Lead New Rome Walking Tours
description: Context, a company that organizes walking tours led by experts and scholars, said in a statement that it has expanded its program to Rome with walks designed and led by chefs and food writers.

title: Former Executive Buys Publishers Weekly
description: 6:20 P.M. Updated with comment from Mr. Slowik.

title: People and Accounts of Note in Advertising
description: Tracey Altman joined Parade, New York, in a new post, senior vice president for food development, working with departments like editorial, advertising sales and research on alternative revenue sources in the food category like event marketing and custom publishing as well as on additional products to raise Parades profile with food marketers. Ms. Altman had been vice president and group publisher of Readers Digest magazine, New York, part of the Readers Digest Association. Parade is part of the Parade Publications unit of Advance Publications.

title: Q & A With Stuart Elliott
Up Next From Apple, a Preview of iPhone Software
description: Even before the dust has settled after this weekends iPad bonanza, Apple is ready to announce a new iPhone operating system.

title: Clinton Family Attends Next to Normal Matinee
description: Former President Bill Clinton and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton have attended Broadway shows from time to time during their last decade living in New York, but given Mrs. Clintons duties and travel schedule, they havent had much free time to visit the Rialto over the last year. On Saturday afternoon, however, the couple, along with their daughter, Chelsea, her fianc, Marc Mezvinsky, and a few Secret Service agents took in the matinee of the musical Next to Normal at the Booth Theater, according to an attendee and confirmed by the shows management.

title: Couples Provides Cover for Woods
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Fred Couples was no incidental bystander to Tiger Woodss much anticipated practice round Monday. First of all, he hit a succession of outstanding shots. Straight drives, pin-seeking approach shots and calm, steady putting Freddie put on a clinic.It was Couples, who has won three Champions Tour events this season, who looked like the worlds top-ranked golfer, not whats-his-name walking alongside him.

title: New Glue for You? True.
description: The rotten economy has revived an old saying from thriftier days: Use it up, wear it out, make it do or do without. So this may be a good time to reintroduce a familiar product that is being reformulated to help consumers repair a wide variety of household items.

title: Corridor Of Evil
description: So Sarah Palin is insulting my home region:

title: David Meets Goliath, With Tiger Standing By
description: Sports fans could make a convincing argument that the first Monday in April should be a national holiday. Honestly, how can anyone be expected to work as we get our good-versus-evil vibes going for the N.C.A.A. championship tonight, while absorbing all those lovely afternoon opening day baseball games while rolling our eyes at the television while Tiger Woods performs in his first actual news conference since becoming Tabloid Tiger? Really, we should get Tuesday off, too. Thats only fair considering CBSs insistence on starting the championship game so late it stretches almost into Tuesday.

title: Olbermann Pays a Visit to Citi Field
description: Hard to imagine better weather for a baseball opening day in this part of the country. About an hour before first pitch at Citi Field Monday between the Mets and the Florida Marlins, the temperature was 68 with low humidity and a gentle breeze blowing out to the right-field corner. (Might it help fly balls travel farther than they did in home-run deprived 2009?) The skies were partly cloudy but milky sunshine prevailed as the fans filed in.

title: From Taft to Obama, Ceremonial First Pitches
description: BOSTON  When President Obama throws out the ceremonial first pitch at Nationals Park on Monday, he will continue a tradition that dates to 1910, when President Taft tossed the first pitch in Washington on April 14, 1910.

title: TimesCast | April 5, 2010
description: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and the stories being covered Monday.  Today's edition includes the attack on a U.S. Consulate in Pakistan and what factors are driving the Dow over 11,000.

title: Repos Clarified
description: My Friday column on abuses of repo accounting sparked more mail than usual, and makes me think I should have gone into more mind-numbing detail.

title: McQueen: The Backstory and Beyond
description: Despite the number of very thoughtful tributes to Alexander McQueen that ran after his death on Feb. 11, the reality is very few people really understood him. A private man who also had difficulty switching off the creativity and finding balance in his life, he may have preferred it that way. His friends were the same, small close-bound group that went back 20 years, and of course, as we know, two of women who were integral to his life, his mother, Joyce, and his friend and mentor, Isabella Blow, had died.

title: Stick a Fork in the Name Game
description: Southfork. That was the first name I had in mind way back when I was searching for space. I was surprised that no restaurant had gobbled up that easy play on words since the Hamptons are located on the South Fork of Long Island and the name lends itself naturally to various logos. Southfork. Sweet and simple.

title: Supertaskers
description: People who are able competently to perform more than one task at a time.

title: Weekend Action, Above Ground and Under
description: Despite the holiday (and the sudden proliferation of pillows), there wasnt a lot of resting going on over the weekend. Maybe it was all the iPad lust and backlash, or the nice weather. Or the fact that Easter reportedly  and strangely  has become a kind of gang initiation day, at least around Times Square.

title: Me And The Bubble
description: Some readers have asked for evidence that I saw the housing bubble; others are using that out-of-context remark about the Fed needing to create a housing bubble. So some backward looks:

title: Edie Falco and Alison Pill to Star in Off Broadway Play
description: The actresses Edie Falco (HBOs The Sopranos, Broadways Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune) and Alison Pill (The Miracle Worker, Blackbird) will star in the American premiere of the play This Wide Night later this spring at Off Broadways Peter Jay Sharp Theater.

title: European Teams Vie for Champions League Semis
description: 4:14 p.m. |Messi Lifts Bara Over Arsenal

title: Finding Activities for Parents With Memory Loss
description: Ive invited the clinical psychologist Cynthia Green, an assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York and the author of several books on memory (including Through the Seasons: An Activities Book for Memory Challenged Adults and Caregivers), to join the conversation today. Ive been hearing laments about the difficulties of visiting relatives with dementia; people yearn to make that time together enjoyable and meaningful, but they cant always figure out how to connect. Dr. Green has some thoughtful suggestions.

title: What a World: Wicked Producers Address Piracy
description: What would Glinda do? The executive producer for the London production of Wicked said that a recent warning to fans that they faced a lifelong ban from the show if they were caught recording it was prompted by one eager theatergoer who pirated the entire musical.

title: A Few Bronx Cheers at Citi Field
description: The first robin of spring depends on location and weather. But the first boo birds of spring could be heard at Citi Field during the introductions Monday. Among those hearing the mixed reactions from the home fans were pitcher Oliver Perez, Manager Jerry Manuel and Luis Castillo, the second baseman.

title: With Draft Looming, Butler Prepares for Surgery
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The West Virginia star DaSean Butlers father, Ira Puryear, said that his son would prepare for surgery on his left knee after tearing his A.C.L., sustaining two bone bruises and spraining the same knee in the Mountaineers 78-57 Final Four loss to Duke.

title: Obama and the Ceremonial First Pitch
description: President Obama stepped up to the pitchers mound at Nationals Park today, where he threw the ceremonial first pitch before the Washington Nationalss season opener against the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Citigroup Hires Technology Banker From Merrill
description: Citigroup has hired a longtime technology banker, Paul Phillips, from Bank of America Merrill Lynch, according to an internal memo obtained by DealBook. A Citigroup spokesman confirmed the appointment.

title: Laugh It Up, Fuzzball: Lucas Plans Star Wars Comedy Series
description: 3:16 p.m. | Updated If you know the scene in Star Wars where a storm trooper accidentally bonks his head on a Death Star doorway, or you stuck around with the franchise through Hayden Christensens performances in the last two prequels, you have probably laughed at George Lucass movies for reasons he never intended. Now you have his permission to laugh at the Star Wars universe.

title: Volcanic Eruption in Iceland Draws Sightseers
description: Tourists and hikers are thronging to the area near a volcanic eruption in southern Iceland despite the opening of a second fissure and lava flows headed in two directions, according to officials.

title: Elmer's Glue-All
description: A new ad campaign for Elmer's Glue-All.

title: Archbishop of Canterbury on Catholic Abuse Scandals
description: As my colleague John Burns reported on Saturday, the archbishop of Canterbury said in an interview with the BBC that sexual abuse scandals in the Catholic Church in Ireland had led to an institution so deeply bound in to the life of the society suddenly becoming  suddenly losing all credibility.

title: Woods Begins Busy Day at Augusta With a Quiet Practice Round
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Tiger Woods walked softly to the first tee for his practice round on Monday, and the throng of spectators on hand at 8 a.m. silently parted to let him pass, their reception as cool as the dew that sparkled on manicured grass.

title: Case Will Test N.F.L. Teams Liability in Dementia
description: VAN NUYS, Calif.  The five paper-clipped sheets that were slipped into a wire basket at the Van Nuys State Office Building looked no different from the other workers compensation claims filed by welders and cashiers. But this packet was different: it will almost certainly become a test case in considering National Football League teams liability for the dementia experienced by retired players.

title: Insurance Costs Keep Arena League Out of State
description: After lying fallow for one season, the Arena Football League resumed operations last weekend with 15 teams  none of them in California. This is no accident.

title: First Pitch: Pants 1, Hat 0
description: Forget about the Easter egg roll and the nuclear posture review. The big news at the White House on Monday involved a far more important question: Would he or wouldnt he?

title: Financial Tuneup: Reconsider Your Retirement Investments
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: Woods Faces Questions
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Tiger Woods got the tough part of this Masters week out of the way Monday, getting in front of the public in the morning and the news media in the afternoon. After engaging fans who came out for his practice round, Woods took aim at winning over a national television audience by taking on tough questions  about his personal life, his behavior and treatment he received from a Canadian doctor  without rancor.

title: Style Map | Jerusalem
description: The newest chapter of the ancient city begins with a face-lift for the Israel Museum, the Chords Bridge, and the construction of the Waldorf-Astoria hotel. More

title: Brittney Griner, Basketball Star, Helps Redefine Beauty
description: TALLER than 99.35 percent of all Americans, the basketball player Brittney Griner has the wingspan of an albatross, wears sneakers more than twice as large as the average womans foot and, more saliently, perhaps, can dunk. It was the latter fact that turned her into a YouTube phenomenon when she first appeared on the scene a few years ago as a high school phenomenon in Houston.

title: Artists and Vendors Bristle at Proposed Limits in Parks
description: At 11 a.m. on Friday, more than 90 vendors selling art packed Union Square Park, creating a colorful gauntlet for visitors. But the scene could be drastically altered if the Department of Parks and Recreation is allowed to amend its regulations for people selling printed texts and visual arts. If that happens, just 18 vendors will be approved.

title: Childhood: In Most Holiday Injuries, Everyday Causes
description: Childrens injuries spike on holidays like Halloween and the Fourth of July, but pumpkin carving and fireworks are among the least likely culprits, a new study finds. Most of the injuries are caused by everyday activities, like riding bikes or just playing.

title: Brian C. Bose | Part 2
description: Brian C. Bose and five other high school seniors are blogging their college admissions experience on The Choice.

title: Conservatives, Maddow and MSNBC
description: Glenn Greenwald and others have objected to a passage in todays column in which I suggest that conservatives only show up on Rachel Maddows show when they have something nasty to say about the Republican Party. Greenwald has a point: I intended a touch of hyperbole about MSNBCs biases, but, taken literally, the line reads as an anti-Maddow exaggeration, which I did not intend. She does, in fact, have conservatives on her show as conservatives, and its possible (as Greenwald suggests) that any seeming imbalance in her guest list is mainly the result of Republicans turning her invitations down.

title: Travel Deals: $100 off Disney Vacations
description: Orbitz is offering $100 off Disney World hotel stays and vacation packages of three nights or more.More than 20 Disney accommodations are on sale, including the Polynesian Resort and the Animal Kingdom Lodge.

title: Ninth Avenue and 50th Street, 2:15 P.M.
The Morning Skate: Burkes Bear Hug Idea Turns Back the Clock
description: Many eyes are focused on the bottom of the playoff races, and that includes the Rangers, now two points behind the Flyers in ninth, having passed Atlanta. The Rangers have four games left, the Flyers three and that includes a home-and-home to finish the season next weekend.

title: Artifacts | Kruger World
description: Barbara Kruger is not just an artist who understands the manipulative power of seductive images when combined with a few pointed words. She uses them to hold a mirror to our entire culture  a hotbed of passive aggression if ever one was. At least, thats the way it looks in The Globe Shrinks, an immersive new multichannel video installation that is challenging the presumptions of all who dare to enter the Mary Boone Gallery in Chelsea.

title: Worlds Tallest Tower in Dubai Reopens
description: The observation deck of the worlds tallest skyscraper has reopened in Dubai, two months after an elevator malfunction that left visitors trapped more than 120 stories above the ground forced it to close.

title: New York Auto Show: 2011 Kia Sorento SX
description: Introduced last Thursday: 2011 Kia Sorento SX

title: Gazing Into the Crystal Ball for April
description: April is alternatively described as cruel, a rebirth or a time for vigor. But for me, April will bring a break from writing for DealBook. I will be taking some needed time to work on academic projects.

title: Airlines Look to Limit Bumping
description: Ryan Kingsbury is the rare flier whos actually looking to be bumped from a flight.

title: Connecticuts Run Reaches Final Game
description: Thirty-eight wins down this season, one more to go for Connecticut for the N.C.A.A. title.

title: Off the Menu: M Pche
description: Hotel dining has become increasingly unbuttoned but nothing like M Pche, where David Chang will be bringing his Momofuku brand to Midtown when it opens for lunch in the Chambers later this week.

title: Seeking Emotional Clues Without Facial Cues
description: MEDFORD, Mass.  The woman was afraid and alone, a fragile soul in a wheelchair who had managed to stuff a few possessions into a plastic garbage bag before being evacuated.

title: Sartorial Advice From John Daly
description: AUGUSTA, Ga  While Tiger Woods, golfs most reclusive player, was engaged in a practice round Monday inside Augusta National, his polar opposite was peddling souvenirs that bore his name outside the gates on a busy street corner.

title: Priest Charged in U.S. Is Still Serving in India
description: A Catholic priest who has been criminally charged with sexually assaulting a 14-year-old girl in Minnesota six years ago is still working in his home diocese in India despite warnings to the Vatican from an American bishop that the priest continued to pose a risk to children, according to church documents made public on Monday.

title: U.S. Is Seeking a Fine of $16.4 Million Against Toyota
description: DETROIT  The Transportation Department said Monday it would seek a $16.4 million fine against Toyota, the largest allowed, because the company had failed to promptly notify the government about potential problems with accelerator pedals.

title: Tech M.&A. Shows More Signs of Rebounding
description: The number of technology mergers and acquisitions announced in the first quarter of the year rose to its highest level since the financial crisis first gripped the market, according to the 451 Group, a technology investment research firm. But the aggregate value of the transactions fell from the previous quarter as there were only a handful of big-ticket deals announced.

title: NBC Renews Seinfelds Marriage Ref
description: NBC got Jerry Seinfeld back onto television again this season  and the network definitely wants to keep him around.

title: The Hamlet of Hip-Hop
description: A 2010 audio slide show narrated by the playwright Michael Oatman, who talks about the legacy of the rapper Tupac Shakur.

title: McNabb Gone, Kolb Takes the Reins in Philadelphia
description: As the fallout from the Eagles shocking trade of Donovan McNabb to the Redskins continued Monday - now coupled with reports that the under-new-management Redskins are looking to unload Albert Haynesworth and the mega-contract the previous regime lavished on him just a year ago - Kevin Kolb spoke at a news conference, his first public comments since becoming the starter.

title: More on the Parents of Bullies
description: During my Monday parenting segment on PRIs Takeaway this morning, the host, Celeste Headlee, and I spoke with Fran Bell Baruch, who has an important perspective on how it feels to learn your child is the bully.

title: At a Toxic Site, Shovels and a Promise of Fresh Air
description: Decades after a Staten Island landfill was shut down after a federal inquiry into illegal dumping of toxic waste, the city broke ground Monday on a big cleanup there.

title: Seeking Solid Ground and Returning to Flight
description: The earth shook all around on Sunday and Monday. In some cases, these movements wounded and killed. In others, they merely sent hearts racing.

title: A Child of the Clubhouse Knows Opening Day
description: 10:58 p.m. | Updated Gary Matthews Jr. speaks to his father before every opening day, he said, and at the end of their conversations, the father tells the son the same thing each year.

title: Seeing What the Hubble Sees, in Imax and 3-D
description: What goes through an astronauts head when things go wrong, and he is floating in space 350 miles above the Earth?

title: Looped to Close on Sunday
description: The new Broadway play Looped, starring Valerie Harper (Rhoda) as the actress Tallulah Bankhead, will close this Sunday at the Lyceum Theater, the producers announced on Monday, after failing to draw much audience interest over its six weeks of performances.

title: Subway Station Gets Makeover, Light and Glass Included
description: A few minutes after 11 a.m. on Monday, with little fanfare and a few inches of police tape, one of the most despised frustrations of the New York City subway system came to an end.

title: Lifting Heavier Weights to Slim Down
description: Most people think the best way to tone up and slim down is to lift lighter weights more often. But in todays Really? column, Anahad OConnor debunks that notion, suggesting youll get better results with heavier weights. He writes:

title: In Syria, a Prologue for Cities
description: Archaeologists have embarked on excavations in northern Syria expected to widen and deepen understanding of a prehistoric culture in Mesopotamia that set the stage for the rise of the worlds first cities and states and the invention of writing.

title: April Is the Drunkest Month
description: April is National Poetry Month. What better excuse to get sloshed?

title: The (Teen) Insider | Nicklas Skovgaard
description: Its no secret that fashion bloggers are turning younger by the day, especially thanks to Tavi Gevinson. Now,in Scandinavia, another wunderkind is giving grown-up journalists a run for their money. The 15-year-old Danish blogger Nicklas Skovgaards site documents his fashion fixations and aspirations from a small village near Copenhagen. His take on fashion shows and customized garments, as well as his emo-style self-portraits, have won him a local cult following.

title: Oracle Co-President to Leave Morgan Stanleys Board
description: Charles E. Phillips Jr., the Oracle co-president who acknowledged an affair after being displayed with an ex-girlfriend on New York billboards, is stepping down from Morgan Stanleys board and will not seek re-election, Bloomberg News reports, citing a regulatory filing.

title: Gluten and Gluttony
description: Q. Other than celiac disease, is there any reason to avoid gluten in the diet?

title: What Were Reading
That Old Equation: Dad + Son = Clash
description: Dont expect to watch all of I Never Sang for My Father. There are times when youll want to look away, uncomfortable, as if you were intruding on this family and its private, painful struggles. Indeed, 42 years after its premiere, Robert Andersons script still elicits genuinely heartbreaking moments by having its characters grapple with questions of guilt and regret and by leading you to ask similar questions of yourself.

title: Documenting the Chechen Struggles
description: After suicide bombers set off two huge explosions, killing dozens in the Moscow subway system last week, attention turned toward Chechnya  the troubled republic in North Caucasus where the Russian government has sought to suppress a violent Muslim uprising since the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991.

title: Diners Journal  New and Improved
description: The Diners Journal blog began in 2006 as a way to keep up with restaurant news and the dining experience in New York. Our view has expanded over the years and now our focus will become even broader.

title: The Pain of Losing a Spouse Is Singular
description: As my husband of 43 years approached the end of his life and the anguish within me welled like a dam ready to burst, I realized something both simplistic and profound  losing a spouse is nothing like losing a parent.

title: Where to Reach Me in the Future
description: Mother of mercy, is this the end of The Pour?

title: An Elite Team of Sleuths, Saving Lives in Obscurity
description: Millions of people know what C.D.C. and F.D.A. stand for. Far fewer recognize E.I.S., though they may owe their lives to it.

title: The Anguish of Losing a Spouse
description: In todays Science Times, Personal Health columnist Jane Brody writes about the recent death of her husband Richard. She writes:

title: Water: World Bank Report Recommends Ways to Improve Access to Clean Water
description: Ethiopia, Haiti and Niger are facing the worlds worst water shortages, but 700 million people in 43 countries are under water stress, according to a new report released by the World Bank last month.

title: Critics' Picks: 'The Seventh Seal'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Ingmar Bergman's meditation on death and life.

title: Kissing in Public, a Touchy Subject for Readers
description: If our critical attitude toward politicians, athletes and their illicit lovers are any indication, it seems we here in the United States suffer from what some may call a repressed sense of sexual freedom. Not unrelated, Americans traditionally have a low tolerance for public displays of affection, perhaps a vestige of our Puritanical heritage.

title: Grand Canyon Staging Site to Get Face-Lift
description: A Grand Canyon icon is getting new plumbing. The Bright Angel Lodge, the historic 1935 hub of the South Rim, is set to undergo renovations this spring including new public bathrooms, repaved concrete sidewalks and a new roof.

title: Seeking Identity, Shaping a Nations
description: The Bridge, the title of David Remnicks incisive new book on Barack Obama, refers to the bridge in Selma, Ala., where civil rights demonstrators were violently attacked by state troopers on March 7, 1965, in a bloody clash that would galvanize the nation and help lead to the passage of the Voting Rights Act. It refers to the observation made by one of the leaders of that march, John Lewis, that Barack Obama is what comes at the end of that bridge in Selma  an observation Congressman Lewis made nearly 44 years later, on the eve of Mr. Obamas inauguration. And it refers to the hope voiced by many of the presidents supporters that he would be a bridge between the races, between red states and blue states, between conservatives and liberals, between the generations who remember the bitter days of segregation and those who have grown up in a new, increasingly multicultural America.

title: He Shoots! He Scores! He Sells!
description: Sidney Crosby is making what may be his first big advertising appearance since he helped win the gold medal for Canada in hockey at the Winter Olympics.

title: Tiger Woods, at the Virtual Tee First
description: The first time I met Tiger Woods, in 2005, I was shocked to find myself talking to a real person.

title: Looped to Close
description: The new Broadway play Looped, starring Valerie Harper as Tallulah Bankhead, will close on Sunday at the Lyceum Theater, the producers announced on Monday, after failing to draw much audience interest over its six weeks of performances. For its eight performances last week, for instance, Looped grossed $168,351, only 26 percent of the maximum possible amount. At such a low percentage, Looped was probably not covering its weekly running expenses, let alone turning a profit. (The weekly expenses have not been made public.) Moreover, the show was not on an upward trajectory; last weeks gross represented a decline from the previous weeks amount, $176,622. Written by Matthew Lombardo (Tea at Five) and directed by Rob Ruggiero, Looped will have played 27 preview performances and 25 regular performances when it closes. A spokesman for the show did not immediately reply to questions about the total cost for mounting the production and whether it will close at a complete loss for investors. The play is a portrait of Ms. Bankhead at the end of her film career, as she arrives, apparently drunk, at an editing studio to rerecord a line of dialogue for a movie  setting the stage for a colorful showdown between the actress and an uptight film editor. Ms. Harper drew generally positive reviews for her bravura turn as Bankhead, though the reviews for the overall production were mixed to negative.

title: Blagojevich Loses Another Job
description: Rod R. Blagojevich has been fired once again, but this time it was Donald Trump who terminated the former governor of Illinois. The latest dismissal for Mr. Blagojevich, who was impeached and removed from office in January 2009 and is expected to stand trial this year on corruption charges, came on Sundays episode of The Celebrity Apprentice, which drew an average of 7.1 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. The NBC reality show finished second in its time period behind CBSs combination of Undercover Boss (12.9 million) and Cold Case (10.1 million). CBS placed first on Sunday over all, with a lineup that included 60 Minutes (8.3 million) and The Amazing Race (9.1 million). ABC ranked second for the night with Extreme Makeover: Home Edition (7.7 million) and a rerun of Brothers & Sisters (3.7 million). NBC finished in third place with Dateline (4.1 million) and Minute to Win It (5.4 million), while Fox, in fourth place, broadcast mostly repeats of its comedy lineup.

title: Laugh It Up, Fuzzball: A Star Wars Comedy
description: If you know the scene in Star Wars in which a storm trooper accidentally bonks his head on a Death Star doorway, you have probably laughed at George Lucass movies for reasons he never intended. Now you have the permission of Mr. Lucas, above, to find the Star Wars universe funny. On Monday Lucasfilm Animation said it was preparing a new series that would offer a comedic perspective on Star Wars, with creative help from Seth Green and Matthew Senreich, who have often satirized that science-fiction franchise on their Adult Swim animated show Robot Chicken. The new series, for which a title and a broadcaster have not been announced, will be produced by Jennifer Hill (The Backyardigans) and directed by Todd Grimes (Back at the Barnyard). Brendan Hay, who has written for The Simpsons and produced for The Daily Show, will also be a writer for this series, Lucasfilm said.

title: Wicked Pirates
description: What would Glinda do? The executive producer for the London production of Wicked said that a recent warning to fans that they faced a lifelong ban from the show if they were caught recording it was prompted by a theatergoer who taped the entire musical. In a post at the official Facebook page for the West End production of Wicked, its producers wrote: The posting of film and audio recordings from performances is ILLEGAL and strictly prohibited. All such posts will be removed and the FANatic banned from future performances. Michael McCabe, the executive producer of the London production, said the message was posted at the behest of the Ambassador Theater Group, which owns the Apollo Victoria Theater where Wicked is presented, after an incident in which a fan recorded the entire performance and posted it on YouTube. A representative for the shows Broadway production, which is at the Gershwin Theater, said it did not have a formal policy banning audience members who are caught recording or pirating the show. The posting of Wicked recordings on the Internet is usually dealt with by Universal Pictures, a producer of the show.

title: Holiday Week Helps Boost Some Broadway Shows
description: Easter, Passover and school vacations contributed to strong tickets sales for many Broadway musicals last week, yet several plays struggled to fill seats in spite of what appeared to be a surge in theater-going on Broadway, according to box office grosses of musicals and plays published on Monday afternoon.

title: Coordinated Bombings in Northwestern Pakistan
description: Militants mounted coordinated attacks on the United States Consulate in Peshawar, Pakistan, killing at least six Pakistanis and wounding 20.

title: New Book Says F.B.I. Infighting Hindered Efforts to Recover Stolen Art
description: Was an effort by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to recover stolen Vermeer and Rembrandt works undone by infighting at the agency? That assertion is made by Robert K. Wittman, a retired special agent, in a coming book titled Priceless: How I Went Undercover to Rescue the Worlds Stolen Treasures, which details his efforts in 2006 and 2007 to retrieve the paintings, The Boston Globe reported. In Priceless Mr. Wittman writes that French middlemen with ties to a criminal gang in Corsica offered to sell the stolen paintings to him, believing that he was a rich collector. The works were among more than $500 million in art stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston on March 18, 1990, in what is regarded as the biggest art theft in American history and which remains unsolved after two decades. The Globe reported that Mr. Wittman wrote that his efforts were sabotaged by a superior, called Fred in the book, who micromanaged his work and tried to have him thrown off the case. The F.B.I. told The Globe that it was reviewing the manuscript to see if it revealed any secrets that could damage its investigations or national security. Representatives for Crown Publishing, which is releasing Priceless, said Mr. Wittman would not comment until the book was published in June.

title: Surprisingly, Family Time Has Grown
description: Working parents perpetually agonize that they dont see enough of their children. But a surprising new study finds that mothers and fathers alike are doing a better job than they think, spending far more time with their families than did parents of earlier generations.

title: Rams Part Ways With Bulger, Clearing Way for Bradford
description: In the strongest signal yet that they intend to make Oklahoma quarterback Sam Bradford the first overall pick in the N.F.L. draft later this month, the St. Louis Rams released quarterback Marc Bulger on Monday.

title: Even Among Animals: Leaders, Followers and Schmoozers
description: I recently tried taking a couple of online personality tests, and I must say I was disappointed by the exercise. I was asked bland amorphisms like whether I was someone who tends to find fault with people (duh), is generally friendly and agreeable (see previous response), and always does a thorough job (can I just skip this question?).

title: Is Dementia an Occupational Hazard?
description: Ralph Wenzel, a retired football player, has dementia that his wife believes was caused by hits he sustained during his N.F.L. career.

title: BlogTalk: Of Mavericks, Justices and Counts
description: Not so long ago (in fact, less than two weeks ago), Sarah Palin was calling her former running mate  or rather, the person whose running mate she was  a maverick. For the sake of your state, for the sake of our country, send a maverick back to the United States Senate, Ms. Palin told a rally audience at the Pima County Fairgrounds in Arizona, according to our colleague Jeff Zeleny.

title: Goodbye, Hello
description: After two years of Bitten-izing, Im moving my Times blogging over to Diners Journal to join the rest of the section in a new, improved, all-in-one New York Times Dining blog that will be unveiled on April 7. Look for me there, along with Sam Sifton, Eric Asimov (hes moving too), Kim Severson, Julia Moskin, Florence Fabricant, Glenn Collins, Nick Fox, Pete Wells and others.

title: A Tax to Combat Americas Sugary Diet
description: How sweet it is! The American diet, that is.

title: Stories From the Automat Machines, in a Harlem Basement
description: They were once gleaming, efficient dispensers of comfort food, all shiny chrome and beveled milky glass. They were the heralded automat vending machines - drop in some coins and get a piece of pie! - and now they lie heaped ingloriously in a dank basement at 131st Street and Broadway in Harlem.

title: Precious Echoes
description: While visiting Long Island in 1791, Thomas Jefferson, below, collected a list of words in the Unkechaug language. His list will be a building block in an effort by scholars to revive the dead language. Following is a sampling of the vocabulary Jefferson gathered:

title: Indian Tribes Go in Search of Their Lost Languages
description: As far as the records show, no one has spoken Shinnecock or Unkechaug, languages of Long Islands Indian tribes, for nearly 200 years. Now Stony Brook University and two of the Indian nations are initiating a joint project to revive these extinct tongues, using old documents like a vocabulary list that Thomas Jefferson wrote during a visit in 1791.

title: Video: Excerpts From Woods News Conference
description: Tiger Woods, looking sober but professing to be cheerful about his return to golf, broke little new ground in his first news conference since a Nov. 27 car accident that sent his image on a downward spiral and interrupted his career, but he did deny performance-enhancing drug use when asked about his treatment by Dr. Anthony Galea.

title: Seoul Survivor | A Front-Row Report From Korean Fashion Week
description: I think theyre confused, says the blogger Hong Sukwoo as he slowly drinks his strawberry juice with a straw in the ornate Las Vegas-meets-grandma marble lobby of Seouls Imperial Palace Hotel. Sukwoo is talking about Koreas younger generation, the K-pop kids now in their late teens and early 20s who have plenty of disposable cash and a burning desire to be unique, but who barely have a clue who they are. Sukwoo, at the ripe age of 28, already considers himself part of an earlier not so beautiful, but perhaps more thoughtful generation. For the past four years, he has been filling his Your Boyhood blog (yourboyhood.com) with the photos he takes of Seouls jeunesse dore and essays that read like sad, disjointed poems (at least when you try to decipher them with your computers instant translator). For him the blog is still in the early stages of a project he imagines will take him about 10 more years: to record the passing youth of one of Asias  and the worlds  speediest fast-track cultures. Young Koreans havent found their own style yet, so theyre copying images they find on the Internet, he says. Its a form of stylish cosplay.

title: Trailer: Tiger Woods PGA Tour Online
description: This online version of the popular Electronic Arts golf game is the first new, post-scandal Tiger Woods product to be released.

title: Dan Hurley to Wagner, Bob Hurley to Hall of Fame
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Bob Hurley, the boys basketball coach at St. Anthony High School, was on his way to noon mass, which he attends daily near his Jersey City condominium, with his wife and grandson when a representative from the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame called on Wednesday. It was then that he learned he would be inducted as a member in August.

title: Strong Ties With India Goal of Trip by Geithner
description: NEW DELHI  Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, arrives in New Delhi on Tuesday for a two-day trip to inaugurate a new economic and financial partnership between two of the worlds largest and oldest democracies.

title: Junkyard Poet of Whirligigs and Windmills
description: LUCAMA, N.C.  Just when you think youve traveled too far down Wiggins Mill Road, and you start to look for a spot to turn around, the rusting masterworks of Vollis Simpson loom into view.

title: Searching for Sept. 11 Victims, Again
description: The search for the remains of the victims of the World Trade Center attacks has begun anew.

title: A Rare Tasting of Conterno Barolos
description: THE Barolos of Giacomo Conterno are among the most beautiful wines in the world: gorgeously pure and packed with flavors that feel almost three-dimensional. Despite the intensity, the texture is sheer, almost delicate, like silken threads that can suspend bridges.

title: The Return Address on the Envelope Was N.Y.U.
description: I was a bit of a nervous wreck on April 1. It seems as if Ive been waiting for New York Universitys decision forever: from the time I clicked submit on the Common Application on Dec. 27, to the time I auditioned on Feb. 10th, to last Thursday.

title: Digg Founder Kevin Rose to Replace Jay Adelson as C.E.O.
description: Jay Adelson, chief executive of Digg, the user-driven social news Web site, announced on Monday that he would step down as head of the company. Kevin Rose, Diggs original founder, will be taking over as the new chief executive.

title: Choosing Gay Identity in Old Hollywood
description: In some other theater season, Looking for Billy Haines might have been welcome as a pleasant, lightweight entertainment. Its about a dashing gay 1920s movie star who is run out of the business when he refuses to pose as straight by marrying some starlet and giving up the man he loves. Its also about a young aspiring actor auditioning for a part in a movie telling Hainess story and fretting over his closeted boyfriend.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Seventh Seal
description: This week in Critics Picks, A. O. Scott looks at Ingmar Bergmans classic meditation on life and death, The Seventh Seal. The film tells the story of a knight who returns from the Crusades to find his homeland ravaged by the Bubonic Plague. In spite of its reputation as a bit of a downer, Mr. Scott says, The Seventh Seal is actually kinda fun. Some of the films supporting characters embody [Bergmans] belief in the importance of art as a response to mortality, Mr. Scott says. Please share your thoughts on The Seventh Seal and what it means to you.

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this article misstated the name of the state where a priest abused deaf children in the 1970s. It was Wisconsin, not Minnesota.

title: More Surgery for Levine, Leaving Met in a Bind
description: Two of the most important classical music institutions in America were scrambling again this weekend because of the fragile health of a stocky 66-year-old man with a baton.

title: U.S. Sued Over Nuclear Waste Fees
description: WASHINGTON  Sixteen utilities and a trade association sued the Energy Department on Monday to halt the governments collection of nuclear waste disposal fees, arguing that the country no longer had a disposal plan after ruling out Yucca Mountain, Nev., as a repository.

title: Support for Irish Who Arent So Lucky
description: In real life, theres an excellent chance that you will never encounter five men sitting in a room earnestly discussing their penises. Joking or lying about their penises, sure. Talking about other mens penises  at a urologists convention, for instance  sure. But analyzing their own the way some men dissect the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament? Never. Wed sooner pluck our eyes out.

title: Autism Is Another Thing That Families Share
description: Normally, when you reach the end of a documentary and say to yourself, Im not sure which character that film was about, its a bad thing, a sign of unclear writing and poor execution. But in the case of Dads in Heaven With Nixon, Tuesday night on Showtime, its a testament to how rich this bittersweet tale is.

title: Sun and Santana Gives Mets Fans a Warm Feeling
description: No one can know for certain what fortunes await the Mets in 2010, but for one game, one significant game, things could not have gone much better.

title: Breeden Capital Names Research and Trading Head
description: Breeden Capital Management, the activist hedge fund, said on Monday that it had named Joshua W. Fenton, a veteran investment professional, as its director of research and trading.

title: Tools and Trinkets of the First Cities
description: Gil Stein of the University of Chicago discusses excavations in northern Syria in search of new clues about a prehistoric culture that gave rise to the first cities and the invention of writing. (National Science Foundation)

title: Hooters Patrons Not Focused Entirely on Woods
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  All but two television sets at the Hooters on Washington Road  the one with the putting green out front, a few blocks from the Augusta National gates  were tuned Monday afternoon to Tiger Woods news conference.

title: Gossip and Golf, Pollen and Scalpers in Augusta
description: The marquee outside a musical instruments store greets motorists with Welcome to Augusta, golf fans, pollen and TMZ.

title: Weekend of Triumphs on Track Offset by Turmoil Off It
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  You have to love the color and pageantry of horse racing. Here in Southern California, a horse owned by the weight-loss queen Jenny Craig and tenderly named for her late husband ran off with the Santa Anita Derby on Saturday. Heartwarming? Heck, yes.

title: Moelis & Co. Hires a Senior Adviser
description: Moelis & Company, the boutique investment bank, said on Monday that it had hired John T. Grady, a longtime asset management executive, as a senior adviser.

title: Zebra Finches
description: Researchers have decoded the genome of the zebra finch, whose males learn a single love song from their fathers that they repeat through life.

title: No Access Is No Problem for Some Media
description: With interest in the Masters ratcheted up by Tiger Woodss presence, media organizations that do not normally staff the tournament have been lured to Augusta even if they lack credentialed access to the golf course.
