title: From a Songbird, New Insights Into the Brain
description: Researchers have gained new insights into the brain by decoding the genome of the zebra finch, a songbird whose males learn a single love song from their fathers that they repeat through life.

title: After Attacks in Russia, Fears of Xenophobia
description: MOSCOW  Lilya Paizulayeva descended into the subway anxiously, trying to keep her distance from the crowds and the newly deployed and heavily armed police officers. She cringed at the trains loud metallic shriek, pressing herself to the wall.

title: A New Signal of the Recessions End
description: Many have suggested that the recession probably ended last summer. But the positive jobs report released last Friday is most likely the clincher, says the Harvard economist Jeff Frankel.

title: More Upheaval at R.N.C.
description: 7:26 p.m. | Updated There is more upheaval at the offices of the Republican National Committee as it struggles to recover from fallout from the disclosure that it had paid a $1,946 tab for staffers and contributors to go to a West Hollywood bondage and strip club.

title: Can Neuro Lit Crit Save the Humanities?
description: A recent Times article described the use of neurological research  and cognitive science in the field of literary theory.

title: What Were Reading: Tear Down, Return or Blend the iPad
description: The mood toward the iPad, at least reflected in Mondays reading list of the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times, is a bit less kindly. Luckily, there are smartphones and Facebook.

title: Live Updates: Duke Wins the National Title, 61-59
description: Live coverage and analysis from the mens championship game between Duke and Butler. Kevin Armstrong and Thayer Evans will provide updates from Indianapolis, along with the the longtime Quad contributor Zach Hillesland, who played in the tournament with Notre Dame. You can also follow Pete Thamel on Twitter throughout the Final Four.

title: Rangers Are Playing Their Best, but Time Is Running Out
description: BUFFALO  Last year at this time, the Buffalo Sabres were in the same position the Rangers find themselves as the last week of the regular season begins, trying to claw their way up to a playoff position before time runs out.

title: Toll Mounts in West Virginia Coal Mine Explosion
description: At least 12 miners were killed and 10 were unaccounted for after an explosion ripped through a West Virginia coal mine on Monday, mining officials said.

title: A Town Says Yes, in Our Backyard to Nuclear Site
description: OSTHAMMAR, Sweden  Twelve years ago, fearing for her health, Inger Nordholm quit her job as a hairdresser in this seaside Swedish community, one of several that have been competing for the right to become the countrys permanent storage site for radioactive waste. I was sick of the chemicals for the hair treatments, said Ms. Nordholm, 45.

title: Financial Crisis Inquiry Wrestles With Setbacks
description: WASHINGTON  The panel established by Congress to investigate the causes of the financial crisis has been hobbled by delays and internal disagreements and a lack of focus, according to interviews with a majority of its members and government officials briefed on its work.

title: Israeli Rights Groups View Themselves as Under Siege
description: JERUSALEM  Leaders of some of Israels most prominent human rights organizations say they are working in an increasingly hostile environment and coming under attack for actions that their critics say endanger the country.

title: The Health Care Law (5 Letters)
description: The Health Care Law

title: For Weight Watchers, Jennifer Hudson Wins a Losing Battle
description: THE previous campaign for Weight Watchers featured a furry critter that tempted dieters with high-calorie foods. Now, the company has decided to get real: its new campaign will star the actress and singer Jennifer Hudson, who will talk about what she has experienced in her quest to lose weight.

title: On First Day, Apple Sells 300,000 iPads
description: Apple said on Monday that it had sold more than 300,000 iPads on the devices first day on the market, a figure that included preorders. That met the expectations of financial analysts who were keeping tabs on the release of the companys highly anticipated tablet computer.

title: South Africa: Pay Dispute Led to Killing, Mother Says
description: The white supremacist Eugene TerreBlanche was killed by two workers in a dispute about unpaid wages, according to the mother of a 15-year-old arrested for the crime. In an interview with the mother, The Associated Press reported that her son had said that some of Mr. TerreBlanches final words were, I will kill you and throw you to hell. Some white supremacists have attributed the killing to the renewed singing of an anti-apartheid song by Julius Malema, the head of the governing partys youth league.

title: E-Reader vs. Printed Book: Which Is Greener?
description: To the Editor:

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,021 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: African Fossil Changes Ideas of Ant Origins
description: The first fossil ant from Africa, found in amber dating back 95 million years, challenges a previously held theory that ants originated in North America or East Asia.

title: For Nuclear Reactors, Metals That Heal Themselves
description: A nuclear reactor is a tough place for metals. All those neutrons bouncing around wreak havoc with the crystalline structure of steel, tungsten and other metals used in fuel rods and other parts. Over time, the metals can swell and become brittle. (They become radioactive, too, but thats another story.)

title: Caterpillars That Thrive in Water and on Land
description: Plenty of animals can live equally well in air or water. They dont call frogs amphibians for nothing, after all. But insects  whoever heard of an amphibious insect?

title: A Woman With Her Own Tools? Call Security
description: I CANT even begin to estimate how many times Ive flown during the last several years. I feel like Im always in an airport. The way I figure it is that if Im not traveling, Im not doing any business. And that wouldnt be good.

title: Fans Voice Frustration, but Mets Leave It Behind
description: Tough crowd. Before the season even began, Mets fans booed the poor trainers, who were first to be introduced in the pregame ceremony on opening day.

title: Visual Diary: Shooting by Car in Kandahar
description: Kandahar is currently bracing itself for a major operation by Afghan and NATO forces against Taliban fighters that have been infiltrating the city.

title: A Nudge in the Ribs for Sleepy Travelers
description: MY worst experience with travel fatigue occurred about 10 years ago, when I impulsively bought a theater ticket in London after a sleepless flight from New York that was followed by a day of meetings.

title: Video Shows U.S. Killing of Reuters Employees
description: WASHINGTON  The Web site WikiLeaks.org released a graphic video on Monday showing an American helicopter shooting and killing a Reuters photographer and driver in a July 2007 attack in Baghdad.

title: Obama Limits When U.S. Would Use Nuclear Arms
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Monday that he was revamping American nuclear strategy to substantially narrow the conditions under which the United States would use nuclear weapons.

title: Group Releases Classified Video of 2007 Baghdad Attack
description: An online whistle-blowing group has circulated online classified U.S. military video showing a 2007 attack by Apache helicopters that killed a dozen people in Baghdad, including two members of Reuters news staff. The group, WikiLeaks.org, told a news conference at the National Press Club that it acquired encrypted video of the July 12, 2007, attack from military whistle-blowers and had been able to view and investigate it after breaking the encryption code, Reuters reported.

title: What Are iPad Owners Downloading?
description: Although it remains to be seen whether or not mainstream consumers will latch onto the iPad with the same ferocity as they did the iPhone, its clear that theres no lack of appetite for apps. On Monday, Apple revealed that iPad owners were voraciously consuming applications. More than one million were downloaded before the weekend was over.

title: Turning Our Backs on Heroes
description: Arlington, Va.

title: Renewal, Without Sanctuary
description: For New York sports fans, the last few months have embodied lyrics from a well-worn Beatles song: Little darling, its been a long cold lonely winter.

title: Ayatollah Supports Bid to Sharply Cut Iran Subsidies
description: Irans supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, offered a crucial gesture of public support Monday for President Mahmoud Ahmadinejads effort to enact a sweeping economic reform plan that would sharply curtail the countrys long-established system of state subsidies.

title: Side Taken by Giuliani in Florida
description: MIAMI  Rudolph W. Giuliani showed once again on Monday that for him, politics is personal. Two years after Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida passed over him to endorse Senator John McCain for president, Mr. Giuliani paid back the snub by supporting Marco Rubio for the Republican nomination in Floridas open Senate seat.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the eighth day of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Why New Yorkers Dont Donate Organs
description: When I started thinking about writing about New York States exceptionally low number of registered organ donors  13 percent of people 18 and older  I remembered that I had never signed up on the official registry to designate myself a donor. So I went online, assuming I would be able to click somewhere quickly, and was delighted at the prospect. How many virtuous impulses can you act on in the amount of time it takes to order staples from Fresh Direct?

title: Problem Child Becomes Complete Player
description: SAN ANTONIO

title: A Haitian Family Reunites in Miami, by Video
description: MIAMI  It was a Haitian reunion unlike any other: the 9-year-old boy mostly healed after coming to Miami for surgery, talking to his relatives via video teleconference with a hip-hop band and an N.F.L. star in the background.

title: Relax, Well Be Fine
description: According to recent polls, 60 percent of Americans think the country is heading in the wrong direction. The same percentage believe that the U.S. is in long-term decline. The political system is dysfunctional. A fiscal crisis looks unavoidable. There are plenty of reasons to be gloomy.

title: In California, Louder Calls to Prepare for Quakes
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As residents on both sides of the Mexican border cleaned up after Sundays earthquake, the authorities warned that many Californians remained unprepared for a serious quake, and emergency officials said that budget cuts have strained their ability to handle a disaster.

title: When a Lawyer Is Wrong
description: Immigration laws have changed over the years to make it easier to deport noncitizens convicted of crimes, even nonviolent crimes. But that does not mean they should be treated unfairly in court  a point the Supreme Court drove home last week by ruling that lawyers for noncitizens must advise their clients if a guilty plea would put them at risk of being deported.

title: Does Money Talk in the Marketplace of Ideas?
description: Supreme Court Justice Benjamin Cardozo once said that metaphors in law are to be narrowly watched, for starting as devices to liberate thought, they end often by enslaving it. Cardozos warning would seem to have been heeded by a group of A-list first amendment scholars who met on March 27 at New York Universitys Brennan Center for Justice to consider the Courts recent campaign-funding decision, Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission.

title: Citigroups Chief Shrinks Company, Eyeing Growth
description: Citigroup is getting smaller, and maybe even better.

title: Salvagers Struggle With Shipwreck at Great Barrier Reef
description: HONG KONG  Salvage experts and a tugboat crew struggled on Tuesday to save a large Chinese freighter that slammed into the Great Barrier Reef off Australia over the weekend.

title: Returning Prospect Park to the People
description: Drugs were sold at the carousel. Muggers used the cover provided by the parks shrubs and foliage. One year, near the skating rink, a man was found shot to death, and another year, the acting supervisor of the zoo was arrested and charged with shooting animals.

title: Excerpts From Obama Interview
description: Following are excerpts of a New York Times interview with President Obama conducted Monday by David E. Sanger and Peter Baker in the Oval Office, about the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty:

title: Lollapalooza Lineup Announced
description: Last week the Lollapalooza festival teased fans by slowly revealing this summers lineup Wheel of Fortune-style, filling in the name of each band one letter at a time. First, on Wednesday, came O, followed by R, I and S. By Monday morning the festivals Web page was filled with clues like SO_I___ _IS_OR_IO_ and S_OO_. It only took a day or two  an O here, a couple of Rs there  for the online hive to piece it all together and come up with plausible guesses for most of the names, like Social Distortion and Spoon.

title: After a Shooting, Cooperstown Searches for Answers
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  On Main Street, the signs of police activity had all but disappeared by Monday. The State Police cars were gone, the yellow police tape removed. Order, at least outside the National Baseball Hall of Fame, had been restored.

title: We Call That Double-Dipping
description: Republican critics are continuing to pummel health care reform. Their newest charge is that the elimination of one generous tax deduction for retiree benefits would take such a bite out of corporate profits that companies may have to cut back on hiring, drop that retiree benefit, and shift added costs onto the taxpayer.

title: Showdown at Indian Point
description: In a very welcome decision for the health of the Hudson River, New York States Department of Environmental Conservation has ruled that the obsolete cooling system at the Indian Point nuclear power plant violates the federal Clean Water Act by polluting the river with heated water and needlessly killing vast numbers of fish. The agency has now left the Entergy Corporation with a choice between spending many millions of dollars to install a system that recycles cooling water or shutting down the plant.

title: Detective Testifies Long Island Teenager Confessed to Fatal Stabbing of Latino Man in 2008
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  The Long Island teenager accused of killing a Hispanic immigrant in 2008 confessed to the police that he had stabbed the man after he and a group of friends agreed to go looking for a Mexican to beat up, the lead homicide detective in the case testified on Monday.

title: Facing Suit, Pipe Maker Extends Guarantee
description: JM Eagle, fighting to retain sales amid allegations that it knowingly sold defective pipe to municipal water systems, said on Monday that it would guarantee its products for 50 years.

title: Bloggingheads: Bailout Outrage
description: Glenn Loury, left, and Ross Levine, both of Brown University, discuss whether the Wall Street bailout was inevitable.

title: An Unwelcome Easter Custom in Times Square: Violence
description: In the waning hours of Sunday, what has become something of a violent Easter night ritual began to unfold. Hundreds of people filled Times Square, some pouring out of the subway, howling and unruly. By nights end, four people had been shot, and the police had arrested 33 people.

title: Womens Final Renews Stars Friendly Rivalry
description: SAN ANTONIO  They met as sprouting pre-adolescents already on the competitive fast track and the early college scholarship prowl. Tina Charles of Queens took on Jayne Appel of Pleasant Hill, Calif., on neutral ground, at the Amateur Athletic Union nationals in Florida.

title: Mets Replay: April 5
description: The Mets opened the season hearing boos for its training staff, then cheers for a 7-1 victory over the Marlins.

title: Excerpts from Obamas New Nuclear Strategy
description: The Nuclear Posture Review to be released by the Obama administration on Tuesday will renounce the development of new nuclear warheads and the use of nuclear weapons against non-nuclear states that adhere to treaty commitments. The following are excerpts from the new strategy:

title: For Inspection Help, Restaurateurs Turn to Consultants
description: The inspection was not going well for Doma, a cafe in the West Village. The visitor with the clipboard, Mark Nealon, noted that the front door had been left wide open  grounds for a two-point violation and a $200 fine  and that trash was bundled on the stairs leading from the street to the basement kitchen.

title: Allergy-Free New York
description: San Luis Obispo, Calif.

title: Performance Art That Would Make Any College Proud
description: Indianapolis

title: Researchers Trace Data Theft to Intruders in China
description: TORONTO  Turning the tables on a China-based computer espionage gang, Canadian and United States computer security researchers have monitored a spying operation for the past eight months, observing while the intruders pilfered classified and restricted documents from the highest levels of the Indian Defense Ministry.

title: 29 Down: Icicle Feature
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Do you start by looking through the clues to see if one might reveal the theme? Or jump ahead part way through? I tend to wend my way down the grid, taking things as they come, but today, after getting SPACE BAR and TRAFFIC CONE, I got curious and scanned ahead.

title: Meet the Mets Memorabilia
description: With their 7-1 victory over the Marlins on Monday, the Mets officially opened their 49th season. With just two championships to their name, the Mets are eons beyond the Yankees, the Cardinals and the Dodgers.

title: Rancher's Death Brings Attention to Illegal Border Crossings
description: The death of Robert N. Krentz, a rancher in southeast Arizona, has led residents and politicians to call for tighter border enforcement.

title: John G. McCoy, Innovator in Banking, Dies at 97
description: John G. McCoy, who transformed the smallest bank in Columbus, Ohio, into the national powerhouse Banc One, died Sunday at his home in New Albany, Ohio. He was 97.

title: Now to Explain the Party Favors
description: On Thursday, two of the biggest  and among the most tarnished  names on Wall Street will testify in front of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission in Washington: Charles O. Prince III, the former chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, and Robert E. Rubin, a former top adviser and director of the bank. On the watch of these men, Citigroup lost more money than almost any company in history, requiring an extraordinary government bailout.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 5, 2010

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about potential offshore wind projects under study off the coast of Rhode Island misstated the nature of a megawatt-hour in describing one projects potential to generate electricity. A megawatt-hour is a unit of energy, not a unit of power. And an accompanying map reversed the location of Nantucket and Marthas Vineyard. (Nantucket is southeast of the Vineyard.)

title: Bays Hit: Citi Field Triple a Fenway Single?
description: Jason Bays line drive to the gap in left-center field leading off the sixth inning Monday had him heading for extra bases. The only question was whether he would settle for a double or race for a triple.

title: Working With Posada, Burnett Hopes to Tame Fenway
description: BOSTON  A. J. Burnett was just standing there, on the mound at Fenway Park last Aug. 22, with his arms spread, his back to the plate and one thought and one thought only careening through his head. The thought did not stay in there very long, though. It left his mouth, a self-indictment captured by television cameras.

title: Conservative Developer Joins Race for Governor
description: BUFFALO  Carl P. Paladino, a blunt multimillionaire developer with Tea Party political leanings, announced his campaign for governor on Monday, becoming the third Republican to enter a race that is quickly becoming a scramble for conservative support.

title: A Successful Bond Program in These Economic Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Medications Safe
description: To the Editor:

title: The Value of After-School Programs
description: To the Editor:

title: How the Church Is Confronting a Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ball in Flight
description: It is practice day at the start of a junior tennis tournament in Southern California. And because its a warm Sunday afternoon, the ball is in play all across the region  any ball, on every patch of grass, every field and diamond and pitch. At the clink of an aluminum bat and the convergence of female softball players, two boys under a nearby hoop stop facing off to see how the play turns out. So do some casual soccer players just over the fence. I feel for a moment like an alien, entranced by our fondness for small representations of the spheroid on which we live. How we love to test gravity and admire the trajectory of a spinning orb!

title: Silence Yields to Ovation for Woods at Practice
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  In the back corners of Augusta National Golf Club, it is possible to be so sheltered by the loblolly pines, dogwoods and azaleas that the setting seems soundless. Occasionally on Monday, Tiger Woods stood in these surroundings transfixed by the simple task of hitting a little white ball.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the rise in pay garnishments misstated the portion of a persons wages that is exempt from being garnished by court order to repay debts. The maximum that is exempt under federal law is 75 percent of a persons take-home pay or 30 times the minimum wage per week, whichever is more  not whichever is less. The law thus exempts a minimum of $217.50 per week from seizure, not a maximum of that amount.

title: Helping Others See the Real World
description: Claire Azzam, 28, became an optometrist after deciding she did not have the stomach for medical school, and despite the fact that her first visit to the optician made her cry. Born in Southern California to a Palestinian father and a Mexican mother, she earned an undergraduate degree in psychobiology from the University of California, Los Angeles. That was followed by four years at the SUNY College of Optometry, from where she graduated in 2008. She lives in Hoboken, N.J., and works at Cohens Fashion Optical on West 72nd Street, and at DC 37, a union for the citys public workers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article Saturday about the awarding of damages to a workplace safety whistle-blower at Pfizer described an initiative by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration incorrectly. OSHA is considering new requirements on employers to identify and fix potential safety problems in the workplace  not new requirements on workers.

title: Corrections
description: The Media Equation column on Monday, about Sarah Palins television career, erroneously included, in some copies, one television host among several who worked in politics before working in the media. The host, Sean Hannity, did not start in politics.

title: A Family That Reads and Reviews Together
description: Like most parents, Mara and Dave Lateiner wanted their two children to love reading. The couple, from Millburn, N.J., did the usual library outings, as well as daily read-alouds, sometimes for as long as two hours. But the usual evolved into something more when last July the family went live with its own book-review blog, the Lateiner Gang Family Book Review Spot.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Monday about the marketing of a forthcoming program on the National Geographic Channels Explorer series referred incorrectly to the program. While the marketing campaign borrows from reality television, the program itself is a documentary, not a reality show.

title: New Deal for Beckett Puts Red Sox Years Ahead
description: BOSTON

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Itineraries pages last Tuesday about business travel in the armed services misstated the name of an online service that many military travelers use to make travel arrangements. It is the Defense Travel System, not the Defense Transportation System.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about professional athletes use of realistic video games to sharpen their skills, misstated the device that Joey Logano, a Nascar driver, uses to prepare for his races. It is his PC, not his Xbox.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the release of the Apple iPad misspelled, in some editions, the given name of one customer waiting in line in San Francisco to purchase the device. He is Mathieu Thouvenin, not Mathiew.

title: Massachusetts: Insurers Sue
description: Six Massachusetts health insurers and an industry trade group filed suit Monday to challenge last weeks denial by the state of nearly nine out of 10 rate increases requested by the companies. The lawsuit, filed in state court, where a hearing is scheduled for Thursday, objects to the decision by Gov. Deval Patricks administration to reject 235 out of 274 proposed premium increases. The increases, some as high as 34 percent, were scheduled to take effect April 1. The complaint charges that the denials were not based on a sound actuarial review. The filing said the companies would lose more than $100 million in revenues, losses that will deplete their individual reserves, weaken their financial stability, and in some instances threaten their near-term solvency.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about the Rangers victory over the Florida Panthers on Saturday misstated the number of points they have earned in their last six games. It is 11, not 13. And because of an editing error, it misidentified, in some copies, the franchise the Panthers tied for most seasons without a playoff appearance. It was the Colorado Rockies/New Jersey Devils franchise, not the Colorado Avalanche.

title: A Daring Proposal to Rescue Greece
description: Forget about Greece for a moment. Just think about country X, which has lived well beyond its means for years thanks to loans from inattentive or foolishly optimistic lenders. When the financial crisis comes, the people of the country will have to cut back on spending. And the countrys lenders will generally suffer from the famous rule of banking: Cant pay, wont pay.

title: Corrections
description: A question in the 30 Seconds With ... column on Sunday with the model Brooklyn Decker, a fan of the University of North Carolina mens basketball team and the wife of the tennis player Andy Roddick, misstated the last year, before this one, that the Tar Heels did not play in the N.C.A.A. tournament. It was 2003, not 2004.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Monday about James Levines withdrawal from productions at the Metropolitan Opera because of back surgery referred incompletely to the conductors for the coming performances of Tosca. Fabio Luisi will replace Mr. Levine on April 14, 17, 20 and 24. The performances on April 29, May 5, 8 and 13 will be conducted, as originally scheduled, by Philippe Auguin.

title: Corrections
description: The Deal Professor column in the special DealBook section on Thursday, about the initial public offerings of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and Apollo Global Management, misstated Apollos goals for its offering. It is planning to raise $50 million through the share sale; it is not simply listing shares without seeking to raise new capital.

title: Cameras Keep Joy Confined to Schedule
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.

title: Yelp Makes Changes in Response to Small-Business Owners
description: Small business owners have been loud and vocal in their criticism of Yelp and its reader reviews. On Tuesday, Yelp will make two significant changes to its pages to address those complaints.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Mexicali After the Quake
description: Despite some damage to buildings and belongings, a 7.2 earthquake near Mexicali in Mexico caused only a limited number of injuries.

title: Duke Holds Off Butler to Win 4th N.C.A.A. Title
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The dark sky, tornado warnings and pelting rain here Monday night portended something ominous. The backdrop all week at the Final Four had been one of change, a feeling that the tournament as it has existed for the past quarter-century could be forever altered.

title: Word of the Day | barrage
description: barrage \br-ij\ noun and verb

title: Threesome Captures Title It Was Missing
description: INDIANAPOLIS  All season, Jon Scheyer, Kyle Singler and Nolan Smith carried Duke.

title: More Foreign Students Applying to Graduate Schools
description: International applications to graduate programs in the United States increased by 7 percent this year, according to a report to be released Tuesday by the Council of Graduate Schools. Applications from abroad decreased sharply in 2003, 2004 and 2005. China, India and South Korea accounted for the majority of applications, and applications from China, India, the Middle East and Turkey grew by double-digit figures over last year. Applications to private institutions were up by 12 percent and applications to public institutions rose by 5 percent.

title: Clifford Hardin, Who Cut Subsidies at Agriculture Dept., Dies at 94
description: Clifford M. Hardin, who as the first secretary of agriculture in the Nixon administration succeeded in limiting subsidy payments to the nations largest farmers, died Sunday at his home in Lincoln, Neb. He was 94.

title: Deaths at West Virginia Mine Raise Issues About Safety
description: MONTCOAL, W.Va.  Rescue workers began the precarious task Tuesday of removing explosive methane gas from the coal mine where at least 25 miners died the day before. The mine owners dismal safety record, along with several recent evacuations of the mine, left federal officials and miners suggesting that Mondays explosion might have been preventable.

title: Duke Wins N.C.A.A. Championship
description: Duke held off Butler, 61-59, to win the N.C.A.A. men's national basketball title.

title: News Quiz | April 6, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Now to Explain the Party Favors
description: On Thursday, two of the biggest  and among the most tarnished  names on Wall Street will testify in front of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission in Washington: Charles O. Prince III, the former chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, and Robert E. Rubin, a former top adviser and director of the bank, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

title: Financial Crisis Inquiry Wrestles With Setbacks
description: The panel established by Congress to investigate the causes of the financial crisis has been hobbled by delays and internal disagreements and a lack of focus, according to interviews with a majority of its members and government officials briefed on its work, Sewell Chan and Eric Dash report for The New York Times.

title: Looking Ahead: Womens Final
description: Connecticuts march toward the N.C.A.A. title has seemed inevitable for months. Maybe it is: UConn has never lost in the final (6-0), and it hasnt lost to anyone in two years. But Coach Geno Auriemma says his undefeated 2002 team  a group that, unlike this years, had a win over Tennessee on its rsum  was better, and Stanford is hoping to prove him right. Stanford lost at UConn by 12 points on Dec. 23, but it led by 2 at halftime.

title: Citigroups Chief Shrinks Company, Eyeing Growth
description: Citigroup is getting smaller and maybe even better.

title: Miracle Rescue in China
description: HOW many coal miners, on average, die every day in China? HOW many were trapped underground at the Wangjialing mine? HOW many were pulled to safety?

title: Lehmans British Unit Objects to Post-Bankruptcy Plan
description: The administrators of Lehman Brothers British unit are objecting to a plan by the collapsed American investment bank to create an asset manager that would continue to oversee its illiquid assets post-bankruptcy, Reuters reported.

title: S.E.C. Doubts Usefulness of Pushing Back of Traders Servers
description: Banning traders from placing their servers close to an exchanges trading system would not solve anything, a top securities regulator said on Monday, Reuters reported.

title: Redgate Media Shelves I.P.O.
description: Redgate Media Group, the Chinese advertising company, has postponed an initial public offering scheduled for this week after cutting its asking price for shares, a lead underwriter for the deal told The Associated Press Monday.

title: Brunswick Capital Sues Annie Leibovitz for Fees
description: A New York investment firm sued Annie Leibovitz on Monday, saying the celebrity photographer owes it more than $800,000 in fees as part of its role in securing a new financing deal to sort out her debts, Reuters reported.

title: Nexsan Aims to Bring $55 Million in I.P.O.
description: Nexsan, the digital storage company, hopes to raise about $55 million this week in an initial public offering.

title: Greece Said to Seek to Avoid I.M.F. Limits
description: Greeces government, concerned that the International Monetary Fund would impose tough conditions in exchange for aid, wants to amend a deal struck at an European Union summit last month to bypass a monetary fund financial contribution, senior government sources in Athens told Market News International, Reuters reported.

title: Brightcove Nabs $12 Million
description: Online video has been sucking in millions of capital with very little to show for it. And Brightcove, the online video management start-up, is a perfect example. It just raised another $12 million in fourth-round venture funding, now nearing the $100 million mark, but is still barely breaking even, with just $50 million in annual revenue.

title: Shareholders Seek Examiner For Visteon Bankruptcy
description: Shareholders of auto parts maker Visteon asked a judge to appoint an examiner to determine if it is possible to craft a plan of reorganization more favorable to equity investors, Reuters reported, citing court documents.

title: Britains Prime Minister Announces May 6 Election
description: LONDON  Confirming what he called the worst-kept secret in British politics, Prime Minister Gordon Brown on Tuesday named May 6 as the date for Britains general election, setting the scene for what promises to be one of the most competitive and consequential ballots in modern British history.

title: Should Greece Be Allowed to Default?
description: Forget about Greece for a moment. Just think about country X, which has lived well beyond its means for years thanks to loans from inattentive or foolishly optimistic lenders. When the financial crisis comes, the people of the country will have to cut back on spending. And the countrys lenders will generally suffer from the famous rule of banking: Cant pay, wont pay.

title: Noble and Peabody Move on Australia Coal
description: Noble Group, the Hong Kong-based firm with a controlling stake in Gloucester Coal, said Tuesday that it was bidding 12.60 Australian dollars per Gloucester share to buy the rest of the company, an offer the directors of Gloucester voted to recommend.

title: Best Centers in the N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
description: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely  but not strictly  by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. title: Sampler: Lack of Attention for Earthquake Preparations, and More Attention for Story of Stuff
description: Prepared for the Big One? Not Exactly | As residents on both sides of the Mexican border cleaned up after Sundays earthquake, the authorities warned that many Californians remained unprepared for a serious quake, and emergency officials said that budget cuts have strained their ability to handle a disaster. The budget challenges faced by firefighters and other first responders have probably affected preparedness, fire officials say, particularly in remote or lightly populated areas that often depend on larger cities or agencies for help in emergencies. Sundays quake registered 7.2 and centered in a largely unpopulated area of northern Mexico. But a recent study by the California Emergency Management Agency found a majority of the states households failing to meet recommendations for many basic emergency needs, like stockpiling water (a minimum of three gallons per person), reinforcing their homes and making disaster plans. We know that theres going to be an earthquake, and we know its going to be a major natural disaster, said Lou Paulson, president of the California Professional Firefighters and a captain in the Contra Costa County fire protection district. And I dont want to be one of the people who stands in front of the state of California and says, We told you so.  [The New York Times]

title: The Resurrection and the Life
description: Newsweek has an Easter-time excerpt from Lisa Millers forthcoming book Heaven, which looks at the apparent decline of a belief in the physical resurrection of the dead among contemporary religious believers. The number of Americans who believe in the literal resurrection of Jesus Christ has dropped 10 points in the last decade; only 26 percent of Christians believe that they will have bodies in the next life; and almost a third of Americans (including one in five self-identified Christians) now believe in reincarnation. Pondering these trends, Miller argues that some kind of immortality of the soul is simply easier to swallow than a physical resurrection; the latter, she suggests, presents all sorts of credibility problems that the more reasonable belief in purely spiritual afterlife lacks.

title: Nicollette Sheridan Sues Desperate Housewives Producers
description: A working environment where colleagues are perpetually stabbing each other in the back and occasionally inflict bodily harm on one another would seem to be de rigeur at Desperate Housewives, at least when the cameras are rolling. But it is those same conditions that Nicollette Sheridan, a former star of that ABC prime-time serial, says went on behind the scenes at the show, whose producers she is suing for assault and wrongful termination, The Associated Press reported. In her lawsuit, Ms. Sheridan, who played Edie Britt on the first five seasons of Desperate Housewives, says that the shows creator, Marc Cherry, hit her during an incident in September 2008. When Ms. Sheridan asked Mr. Cherry about a line in the script, he took her aside and forcefully hit her with his hand across her face and head, the suit said, according to The A.P. When Ms. Sheridan complained to ABC, she says she was ignored and her character was later killed off in retaliation. ABC and Cherry Alley Productions, Mr. Cherrys company, have not yet responded to the suit, which was filed on Monday in Los Angeles County Superior Court.

title: Berlin Staatsoper Prepares for a Temporary Move
description: After more than 160 years in its Berlin home, the Staatsoper Unter den Linden will move to a smaller space for three years while its longtime theater undergoes renovations, The Associated Press reported. At a news conference on Tuesday, the opera company said it was preparing to move west to Berlins Schiller Theater as the Staatsoper building, which opened on the Unter den Linden boulevard in 1844, begins a $321 million restoration project. Rehearsals in the Schiller Theater, which is contending with its own renovations, are to begin Aug. 19, and the Staatsopers 2010-2011 season will open there on Oct. 3 with the world premiere of Jens Joneleits Metanoia, directed by Christoph Schlingensief. Other conductors who are scheduled to lead the Staatsoper during the season include James Levine and Pierre Boulez. At the news conference, Daniel Barenboim, the music director for the Staatsoper, said, Moving for three years can be seen as a calamity or as a challenge, and we have decided to see it as the latter. Its artistic director, Jrgen Flimm, said it would be difficult for operagoers to follow the company to its new home, adding: I hope there will be sufficient curiosity. Thats why we are doing so much.

title: I Want My MCM
description: As far as symbols of 80s excess go, its hard to beat Cindy Crawford (she of big hair and voluptuous  by model standards, anyway  body) and MCM (Mode Creation Munich), the Euro leather goods brand, whose flashy logoed caramel-colored bags gave even Gucci and Louis Vuitton a run for their money. (Did we mention this was the 80s?) The MCM ads were equally flashy, featuring Crawford perched on a pile of suitcases or posing wearing nothing except a giant MCM logo. (If that werent enough, they were signed I want my MCM and The beginning of a beautiful friendship. Awwww.) And while you might think that such naked consumption went the way of the world economy, you would think wrong. Not only has the brand been on a store opening spree with 15 new Saks Fifth Avenue boutiques and a Beverly Hills Rodeo Drive boutique scheduled for later this year, but it has signed on as a sponsor for New York fashion week. MCM is even recreating its Cindy Crawford campaign, this time around with the model Coco Rocha. Under the circumstances, the images are a bit more modest  Rochas mane is tamed down, and shes wearing a bustier dress  but the message is not lost.

description: WASHINGTON  Continued low inflation has strengthened the hand of Federal Reserve officials who believe that monetary policy should not be tightened anytime soon, minutes from the Feds latest policy meeting show.

title: Properties for $350,000
description: Homes in New Orleans, Minneapolis and Manchester, Md.

title: Teams Dispute Workers Comp Rights
description: Reinard Wilson knew something was up last March when he opened an envelope from the Cincinnati Bengals, unfolded a check and noticed its amount: $0.00.

title: Australian Leader Angry Over Chinese Freighter
description: HONG KONG  Anger rose in Australia on Tuesday, including some blunt language from Prime Minister Kevin Rudd, over the off-course Chinese coal freighter that beached on the Great Barrier Reef last weekend and threatens to befoul its pristine corals with leaking fuel oil.

title: Broadway Opening Delayed for Phantom Sequel
description: 5:30 p.m. | Updated The Broadway production of Andrew Lloyd Webbers new musical Love Never Dies, a sequel to his Phantom of the Opera, will be delayed several months, until spring 2011, as Mr. Lloyd Webber deals with postoperative problems from his treatment for prostate cancer, according to a statement given to The New York Times on Tuesday by the Broadway producers.

title: Inside Out | More Is More
description: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

title: The Morning Skate: Anxious Times in N.H.L. Playoff Race
description: These are anxious times for fans of the Rangers and the Flyers as their teams battle for the final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference. The Rangers (who Jeff Z. Klein says in The Times are playing their best hockey of the year  or at least since their seven-game winning streak in October) are in Buffalo tonight while the Flyers are in Toronto. The Rangers play their game in hand against the Maple Leafs at the Garden tomorrow and then the Rangers and the Flyers play a season-ending home-and-home series, starting Friday in New York and ending Sunday in Philadelphia.

title: 'Bellona: Destroyer of Cities'
description: Tanya Selvaratnam and Sarita Choudhury in a scene from a show based on Samuel  R. Delany's book "Dhalgren." (Video courtesy of Jay Scheib)

title: Qantas Has More Engine Malfunctions
description: According to Bloomberg News, Qantas reported its fifth aircraft malfunction since March 30 as a power surge in an engine on a Boeing 747 forced a London-bound flight to turn back to Bangkok on Tuesday.

title: Scientists Discover Heavy New Element
description: A team of Russian and American scientists has discovered a new element that has long stood as a missing link among the heaviest bits of atomic matter ever produced. The element, still nameless, appears to point the way toward a brew of still more massive elements with chemical properties no one can predict.

title: Ernst & Young Said to Face Inquiry Into Lehman Role
description: 4:34 p.m. | Updated A spokeswoman for the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board clarified that the overseer did not say no comment to Fox Business, but that the boards investigations were not public.

title: AOL Plans to Sell or Close Bebo, a Social Network
description: 3:43 p.m. | Updated  Added more information about AOLs plans for Bebo.

title: G.O.P. Ad Aims at Flip-Flops in Florida
description: Flip-flops are an essential part of the Sunshine State wardrobe, but Republicans are trying to give them a negative connotation when it comes to Representatives Suzanne M. Kosmas and Allen Boyd, two Democrats from Florida who supported the final health care legislation after voting against the original House bill back in November.

title: Outsourced Grades
description: Heres a novel way to help professors and teaching assistants resist the temptation to inflate their students grades: outsource the grading to Bangalore. Thats what one instructor did at the University of Houston.

title: Which States Work the Longest Hours?
description: Nevada residents work the longest hours, according to a new report from the Labor Department.

title: Debate in Israel on Gag Order in Security Leak Case
description: A young Israeli journalist is scheduled to go on trial in Israel in mid-April on accusations of serious security offenses, possibly including espionage, according to Israelis familiar with the case.

title: Anne Paik | Part 2
description: Anne Paik and five other high school seniors are blogging their college admissions experience on The Choice.

title: Study Says U.S. Waterways Are Warming
description: Many streams and rivers in the United States are getting warmer, with the greatest increases in urbanized areas, according to research to be published in an upcoming edition of the journal Frontiers of the Ecology and the Environment.

title: On Track | Indias Maharajas Express
description: Taking the train in India is usually best left to locals or seasoned adventure travelers. It takes a certain skill, and stomach, to negotiate the hordes of bodies jampacked into every available square foot, and the overwhelming sensations of sight, sound, smell and, yes, touch that are part of a typical journey. As of last month, however, an entirely new breed of locomotive has landed on the countrys tracks.

title: Holy Wishful Thinking
description: Sight Gag | Image found here.

title: After Years, M.T.A. Cracks Down on Sign Dealer
description: Update, 6:01 p.m. | An earlier version of this post misstated the Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys policy on old subway signs. The authority instructs its contractors to save them for possible resale, not throw them away.

title: How This Half Lives
description: In the hippest new design publications, life is, well, messy. Mark Rozzo explores a new world of interiors.

title: Ancient Indian Village in Rhode Island Pits Preservation Against Property Rights
description: NARRAGANSETT, R.I.  Long before this town existed, there were Indians of that name who lived, camped, hunted, fished and grew maize in the woods and fields along the shoreline.

title: Developers See Possibility (and Value) in Old Steel
description: As commercial real estate development nearly comes to a halt in the economic downturn, some well-capitalized investors are focusing instead on sprucing up existing properties. The process has various names: retrofitting, renovating, repurposing, even repositioning. But the underlying idea is to wring out more value at a time when rents will not support new construction.

title: Bringing You a Signal Youre Already Paying For
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Faced with withering criticism for its spotty iPhone service, AT&T blames in part a shortage of cellphone towers near homes and businesses. But it has a solution: put a miniature cell tower in your living room.

title: The Ice Cube Theory of Why Studio Deals Are Struggling
description: Both Miramax and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer are struggling to find attractive-enough bidders, despite the purported lucrativeness of their biggest assets: their film libraries.

title: Financial Tuneup: On Making an Extra Mortgage Payment
description: A few weeks back, I wrote a column about the wisdom of making extra mortgage payments each year. Then, in a video for our Financial Tuneup interactive checklist, we ran through the math on the amount of interest you might save by paying that little bit extra each year.

title: Images of Conflict Abound
description: Scenes of war and tension dominate our show for Tuesday.

title: Hornets Rookies Contribute Early and Often
description: Zach Lowe writes for CelticsHub.com. He grew up in Connecticut watching the Bird-era Celtics with his father and hating Chuck Person. He now lives in Manhattan and dreams of a day in his adult lifetime when the Celtics and Knicks are both elite teams.

title: Update: The Continuing Mystery of a Newsweek Columnist vs. Apple
description: What, if anything, did Apple try to do to Daniel Lyons, Newsweeks technology columnist?

title: The Visual Thing
description: There are lots of things I miss about the late, great graphic designer Alan Fletcher, but the thing I miss the most is arguing with him about design. Some of our most enjoyable arguments involved how to explain design to the 99 percent of the population that Alan pityingly described as civilians  in other words, those of us who arent lucky enough to be designers.

title: Drawing Crowds in the West Coast Venice
description: TRUE, Abbot Kinney Boulevard, a few blocks in from the beach in Venice, Calif., is hardly off the radar and has long drawn people from outside the neighborhood. But the streets spark never seems to dim; instead, it jumps around, alighting on one new spot after another. And, despite some tough times, the past year or so has brought a fresh crop of worth-a-visit places.

title: Farm Fresh Down Under
description: IT seems as if everyone is releasing an iPhone application nowadays, so why not a butcher? Vics Premium Quality Meats, one of the fanciest meat purveyors in Sydney, Australia, now offers Ask the Butcher, which enables users to request information on everything from how to cook a particular cut to diagrammed references of animal bodies.

title: The Texas Border Draws Frequent Fliers
description: ELEVEN in the morning is not the best time of day to start birding. But when my plane landed at that hour in the Rio Grande Valley, reputedly one of the best places for bird-watching in the country, I just couldnt wait.

title: Floyd, a Year After His 45th Masters, Announces His Retirement
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Raymond Floyd played his 45th and final Masters last year but waited an entire year to announce it, telling a small gathering of reporters a 9 a.m. news conference Tuesday that he would not be competing in this years event and that his competitive days are over on the Champions Tour as well.

title: Relishing the Waves, Not the Crowds, in Mexico
description: IT was a blazingly bright afternoon on Cerritos Beach just outside Todos Santos, Mexico. The air was hot and dry and smelled like frying fish. Neighborhood children jumped up and down in the shoreline ripples as their parents lingered at picnic tables with tacos and icy beer. Out in the water, a dozen surfers were lying on their boards, waiting to paddle as the next swell approached.

title: Confusion, Chairs and Charters Helped Doom Bid for Grant
description: In the hectic rush to finish New York States Race to the Top grant application last January, much of the spotlight fell on the State Legislature, as lawmakers wrangled over a bill that would increase the number of charter schools permitted in the state.

title: 36 Hours in Sydney
description: SUNNY, fashion-forward and multiethnic, Sydney is an animated city bent on making its mark. But with its skyline already crowded with skyscrapers, and its place on the world stage firmly set, the city seems to be in the midst of a historical revival. Traditional Australian cuisine like meat pies is being remade in the locavore age. Sports like surfing are being celebrated in their national birthplace. And older buildings are enjoying an architectural second act as salons for the citys cognoscenti, who cant seem to get enough of Sydneys homegrown charms.

title: Store Review: GaleriAmaznica in Manaus, Brazil
description: Its one of those only-in-the-Amazon tourist dilemmas: you want to bring home a 12-foot blowgun, but dont know how to tell the genuine article from tourist schlock. And how do you know if a fair share of your money will get to the indigenous group that made it? Or if the tortoise shells used for adornment were responsibly obtained?

title: Common Ground on Autism
description: Liane Kupferberg Carter got your attention back in February with her guest post here on Motherlode comparing those who would claim a cure for autism to snake-oil salesman. What got her attention was the furor that other parents hurled her way after the piece appeared.

title: Hotel Review: Art + Hotel in Tel Aviv
description: THE BASICS

title: Tastes of India, by New Delhi Taxi
description: WITH its fluorescent lights and laminate tables, the little restaurant near the shuttered Chanakya Cinema looked like any no-frills canteen found throughout the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu. Diners bought copies of the Daily Thanthi newspaper, written in the curlicue script of Tamil. A small statue of Balaji, a deity worshiped in southern India, sat snugly on the counter. And the food was rich with the crepe-like dosas for which the region is known.

title: Mangia, Mangia!
description: NICOLA DE THOMASIS, a round-bellied, bearded, bespectacled man from the rough-hewn hills of Abruzzo, stood near the head of his dinner table, holding a pair of tongs  and my fate  in his hand. He had already placed on my plate an almost lethally large portion of spaghetti alla chitarra, dressed with the regions traditional tomato-and-lamb rag, and his tong-bearing hand kept inching closer and closer to the communal pasta platter until, at last, he dove in with the instrument, scooped up a final, fatal tangle of noodles and added them to my dish. I was done for.

title: Saving by Tying the Knot at Sea
description: CRUISES have long been popular with honeymooners looking for a romantic getaway after the wedding. Now, a growing number of brides and grooms are tying the knot on cruise ships and sailing off into the sunset with their entire wedding party in tow.

title: Notes From the 2010 Campaign Trail
description: Tuesday on the trail:

title: Now Shopping | Ralph Lauren Kids
description: Its in my blood: all the men in my family are dressed-up rowdy Texas boys at heart  my brother, our father and his father are all just a little bit taller than shotguns, and wear suits as tight as barbed wire, sharp edged as bullet holes. The fact that I shattered the family height record doesnt stand for much: Im 5-foot-9-ish on a really good day. Im not one for the Napoleon complex, and anyway, there are perks to being, lets say, compact. But there is one big difference between my forebears and me: those bastards had crazy cash, and Im a broke scribe struggling in this sick city. So hows a bred-for-bespoke fella supposed to pay for fancy garb without two dimes to rub together?

title: Old Hickory, Rock Star President
description: Ladies and gentlemen, the seventh president of the United States is here to take a firsthand look at you the people, and he thinks youre really hot. You feel the same way about him, right? Youre going to shake, rattle and roll when he makes you the ultimate promise, the one you truly want to hear from anyone who aspires to lead your nation: He solemnly swears to give you the best sex youve ever had.

title: On Trial, Ex-Oil Magnate Finally Speaks
description: MOSCOW  For a year, Russias most famous prisoner, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, sat in a glass cage in a dingy, third-floor courtroom and listened while prosecutors sought to prolong his time behind bars by charging that he embezzled billions of dollars worth of oil. On Tuesday, Mr. Khodorkovsky finally got a chance to speak in his own defense in the politically tinged case.

title: Fee-Based People Search Site Takes Heat
description: Amended 4/21/2010, to clarify the amount of Intelius business in February

title: Winter. Summer. Is a Season Missing?
description: April is the cruelest month, the noted meteorologist T. S. Eliot once wrote. But Eliot was not sitting on the sun-drenched Brooklyn waterfront taking in a hazy Manhattan skyline in 78 degree warmth on Monday afternoon. Had he been around to join New Yorkers enjoying the unseasonably good weather, he might have otherwise assessed the months and their comparative cruelty.

title: 3 Check In at Airport; 1 Departed Beforehand
description: LONDON  Something was not right about the elderly man in the wheelchair, the check-in agents at Liverpool John Lennon Airport thought when he showed up with his wife and stepdaughter for a flight to Germany on Saturday.

title: Mercedes Says S-Class Could Become a Hybrid Line
description: The flagship V-12-powered 2010 Mercedes-Benz S600 gets only 11 miles per gallon in the city, and the well-heeled buyers of this $149,700 car probably shrug when they pay $3,000 in gas-guzzler taxes. But fuel economy that low does little for the companys efforts to meet the stringent fuel economy and greenhouse gas standards pending in Europe and the United States, and thats why Mercedes is considering an out-of-left-field plan to turn its entire S-Class line into full hybrids.

title: A Brazilian Home Out of Hardwoods
description: The home was designed by the Brazilian architect Severiano Mario Porto in the 1970s andconstructed using many types of Amazonian hardwoods.

title: Arrest Follows Threat to Kill Senator
description: 9:39 p.m. | Updated Federal agents on Tuesday arrested and charged a man with threatening to kill Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, because he was angry about her vote in favor of the major health care legislation.

title: What You Get for... $350,000
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: Lots of Vocal Firepower for Mendelssohn Work Despite an Absence
description: Elijah may or may not have graced your Passover Seder last week, but he put in a vivid appearance at Carnegie Hall on Monday night. Or at least the trappings were vivid, as Rafael Frhbeck de Burgos conducted the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the Tanglewood Festival Chorus and a formidable cast of vocal soloists in Mendelssohns grand oratorio Elijah.

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this article misspelled the name of Bishop Arulappan Amalraj.

title: First At-Bat Home Runs
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: Park for Special-Needs Children to Open in San Antonio
description: Morgans Wonderland, which bills itself as the worlds first ultra-accessible family fun park designed specifically for children and adults with special needs, is scheduled to open April 10, just northeast of San Antonio.

title: In Eastern Europe, Pact With Russians Raises Old Specters
description: KARLOVY VARY, CZECH REPUBLIC  As President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia and President Barack Obama prepare to arrive in Prague on Thursday to sign a landmark arms control treaty, Marcela Balounova, like many Czechs, remains haunted by her memories of 1968, when nearly one million Warsaw Pact troops invaded Czechoslovakia, ushering in a period of political repression.

title: Special Counsel Requested in Polanski Case
description: In a new California appeals court filing, lawyers for Roman Polanski on Tuesday asked for the appointment of a special counsel to investigate claims of official misconduct in the sex-crime case against him. The defense respectfully suggests that it is now necessary for this court to recommend the appointment of special counsel to investigate and take appropriate action through a grand jury and referral to state agencies charged with addressing and disciplining cases of professional misconduct within the criminal justice system, the lawyers wrote in reply to the Los Angeles County district attorneys earlier brief opposing Mr. Polanskis appeal.

title: A Thinker Finds His Funk
description: Rhythm ruled the music of Atoms for Peace, the band Thom Yorke led at Roseland on Monday night. Its a side project with unspecified goals for Mr. Yorke, who also leads Radiohead, but one effect was immediate: he danced through nearly the whole set. Twitching, strutting, pivoting, hopping, jittering and gesticulating, he let the music propel him in ways that were anything but cerebral, even in songs for which he sat at the piano. Where Radioheads music is the triumph of thinking much too hard, Mr. Yorke on his own got sweaty and physical.

title: Joness Versatility Shown in Two Swings
description: After hitting 21 home runs in 82 games last season, many wondered if Garrett Jones, the Pirates outfielder, was a fluke. He did his best on opening day to quiet that talk with home runs in his first two at-bats. But what may be most interesting about the home runs is how different they were.

title: New Kid at Large on Urban Chessboard
description: Adaptations are tricky monsters; where do you begin when making theater out of something like Dhalgren, Samuel R. Delanys classic science-fiction novel about the ravaged, metaphoric city of Bellona? How do you please devotees and guide the uninitiated (this reviewer is 95 percent in the uninitiated category, having just begun the book) while forging a self-sufficient artistic vision?

title: When Local Control Fails
description: Todays priestly sex abuse story features a South Asian cleric accused of assaulting a teenage girl (and robbing his diocese into the bargain) while serving temporarily in Minnesota. He had already returned to India by the time the allegations surfaced, at which point the Minnesotan bishop wrote to the Vatican suggesting that the priest might need to be removed from ministry. The priests bishop in India, however, ordered him to undertake a year of prayer in a monastery, rather than seeking to have him defrocked, even as further accusations surfaced in Minnesota, and the county attorney began pursuing extradition. A Vatican spokesman says that the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith recommended laicization, but (per canon law) deferred to the Indian bishop on the matter. However, the documents suggest that at least initially, the C.D.F. only recommended that the priest be monitored and kept away from minors.

title: BlogTalk: Dr. No, Nancy Pelosi and Fox News
description: When the health bill was being debated in Congress, there was no stronger opponent to it than Senator Tom Coburn, the physician and Republican from Oklahoma who is known in some circles as Dr. No. In December he said that seniors would die faster because of cuts in Medicare in the version of the health care measure then being considered.

title: In Brazil, a Jungle Home
description: MANAUS, Brazil  It wasnt the snakes and scorpions that horrified Sandra Santos back in 1996 when her husband, Edson Costa, first showed her the potential weekend getaway, a wooden home on stilts on two acres of Amazonian rainforest. It was the dark, gloomy, off-the-grid structure itself.

title: Inspiration From Tiger: Get Out of Jail Card, Though Its Far From Free
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Pulled a Tiger lately? begins a handmade sign crafted by Christian Seklecki on a street corner just outside Augusta National Golf Club. Of all the unusual money-making schemes that invoke Tiger Woodss name, this one is the leader in the clubhouse.

title: What Were Reading
City Fined for Ignoring Court Orders in Crane Lawsuit
description: Updated, 6:09 p.m. | A judge fined the Bloomberg administration $5,000 Tuesday for repeatedly ignoring court orders to provide the families of two construction workers who died in a fatal 2008 crane collapse with documents, e-mail messages and other information concerning equipment inspected by the city.

title: Questions to Ask Former Citi Executives
description: As several former Citigroup executives prepare to testify on Wednesday and Thursday about their onetime employers near-implosion, we started thinking about what the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission should ask them.

title: Diligence Is a Factor in Controlling Risks From Methane
description: Coal mines will always have methane, often in explosive concentrations, geologists and engineers say. The only question is how diligently miners and mining companies will work to avoid explosions.

title: App Mashes Up Social Network Functions
description: Do we need yet another social interaction app? The developers of Friends Around Me think so.

title: For Sale in ... Panama
description: A THREE-BEDROOM THREE-AND-A-HALF-BATH LAKEFRONT HOME NEAR PANAMA CITY

title: Lilly Pulitzer: Fashion With a Colorful Narrative
description: WES ANDERSON movies and J. D. Salinger novels both portray hyper-colorized worlds of civilized affluence. The characters are all a little too wonderful, attractive and brilliant to be believed  and theyre all a bit unstrung by their passions for sport or religion or art or each other.

title: AOL Plans to Sell or Close Bebo Social Network
description: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

title: Hedge Fun
description: Rake in the cachet with new designs for the great indoors. More

title: Suspect Arrested After Threats to Senator Murray
description: Federal agents on Tuesday arrested and charged a man with threatening to kill Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, because he was angry about her vote in favor of the major health care legislation.

title: Dancing to Feature City Ballet Principal
description: The former astronaut Buzz Aldrin is among the celebrities who have been roundly criticized for their technique on the ABC television competition Dancing With the Stars, but the judges will have a hard time finding fault with one dancers skills next week. Tiler Peck, near left (with Gonzalo Garcia), a principal with New York City Ballet, is scheduled to appear on the show on Tuesday as part of the Macys Stars of Dance performance during the live results episode. According to ABC, Ms. Peck, the first City Ballet dancer to appear on the show, will perform along with 12 other dancers in a piece choreographed by Travis Wall.

title: Nicollette Sheridan Sues Housewives Producers
description: A working environment where colleagues are perpetually stabbing one another in the back and occasionally inflicting bodily harm would seem to be de rigueur at Desperate Housewives, at least when the cameras are rolling. But Nicollette Sheridan, below, a former star of that ABC prime-time serial, says those same conditions existed behind the scenes at the show, whose producers she is suing, asserting she was assaulted and wrongfully terminated, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Sheridan, who played Edie Britt on the first five seasons of Desperate Housewives, said the shows creator, Marc Cherry, hit her during an incident in September 2008. When Ms. Sheridan asked Mr. Cherry about a line in the script, he took her aside and forcefully hit her with his hand across her face and head, the suit said, according to The A.P. When Ms. Sheridan complained to ABC, she was ignored and her character was later killed off in retaliation, she said. ABC and Cherry Alley Productions, Mr. Cherrys company, have not yet responded to the suit, which was filed on Monday in Los Angeles County Superior Court.

title: Broadway Opening for Love Never Dies Is Delayed Until 2011
description: The Broadway production of Andrew Lloyd Webbers new musical, Love Never Dies, a sequel to his Phantom of the Opera, will be delayed several months until spring 2011 as Mr. Lloyd Webber deals with post-operative problems from treatment for prostate cancer, according to a statement on Tuesday from the shows Broadway producers. While Mr. Lloyd Webbers cancer has been eradicated, the statement said, his doctors have asked him to avoid long airplane flights, which apparently have aggravated his condition, according to the statement. The producers did not provide details about the health of Mr. Lloyd Webber, 62, though they said he was well enough to continue appearing on a new BBC television series about his search for an actress to play Dorothy in a new production of The Wizard of Oz. Asked why Mr. Lloyd Webber did not postpone the television show and instead base himself in New York to work on the musical, executives involved in the Broadway production said he had a commitment to the BBC show. Mr. Lloyd Webber was not available for a telephone interview, a spokesman for the Broadway production said, though he said in a statement that he was extremely frustrated by the limitations on his travel. Two Broadway theater executives who met with Mr. Lloyd Webber in London in March, when Love Never Dies opened there, said that he reported feeling well and did not complain of post-treatment problems. Love Never Dies drew mixed reviews from critics in London, including a tough critique from The New York Timess chief theater critic, Ben Brantley, prompting speculation that the Broadway run would be delayed so Mr. Lloyd Webber could overhaul it. The musical had been scheduled to open in November at the Neil Simon Theater.

title: More Legal Woes for Annie Leibovitz
description: The photographer Annie Leibovitz, below, whose protracted legal troubles had seemed to be behind her, is back in court. Brunswick Capital Partners has filed a suit against her in New York State Supreme Court, saying that she owes the firm several hundred thousand dollars in fees for its role in finding investors who have helped her restructure her debt, Reuters reported. Ms. Leibovitz fell into financial trouble, according to friends, after years of incautious spending and expensive home renovations. Last month she reached an agreement with Colony Capital, a Los Angeles firm: it became her only creditor and agreed to help her concentrate on her career and earnings. She averted a foreclosure last summer after she missed a deadline to repay $24 million in loans to Art Capital Group, a lender that used the rights to her photographs and her real estate as collateral. In the new lawsuit, filed on Friday, Brunswick Capital says that Ms. Leibovitz has failed to pay fees for its services and a 2 percent commission on the $40 million loan that Colony made to consolidate her debt. Representatives for Ms. Leibovitz and Colony declined to comment, saying that they had not had a chance to review the suit.

title: Dancing vs. Duke
description: A two-hour Dancing With the Stars carried ABC to the top of the ratings on Monday night as an average of 20.9 million viewers tuned in to the reality show from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. The celebrity dancers earned the largest audience of the night and gave a lift to ABCs 10 p.m. show Castle (12.3 million), but CBS ranked a very strong second place, broadcasting a repeat of The Big Bang Theory at 8 (10.8 million) and a new episode of Rules of Engagement at 8:30 (10.2 million), followed by live coverage of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball championship game. Preliminary estimates show that the game between Duke and Butler universities, won by Duke 61-59, garnered a larger audience than last years championship game, which drew 17.7 million viewers when final ratings were released. Fox finished third with a two-hour episode of 24 (7.3 million), while NBC placed fourth.

title: Smoke at the Met but No Fire
description: Ambroise Thomass Hamlet was not the only drama at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night: partway through that 3-hour-18-minute production was the 10-minute subplot of the smelly lighting gel. Shortly after 9 p.m. patrons in the upper balconies smelled smoke, and some headed for the door. At 9:16 one called the New York City Fire Department, which soon arrived and found that the gel on a stage light had burned, sending an odor through the ventilation system. No fire was detected and the whole incident was closed in 9 minutes and 45 seconds, a fire department spokesman said. A Met spokesman said that the performance, conducted by Louis Langre and starring Simon Keenlyside as Hamlet and Jane Archibald as Ophlie, was not interrupted and that ticketholders who walked out were reseated.

title: Footnote
description: The Metropolitan Opera said that Steven White would conduct the performance of La Traviata on Wednesday night in his Met debut. Mr. White was already scheduled to conduct the opera on Saturday, replacing Leonard Slatkin, who withdrew.

title: Tree-mendous
description: The garden outside my window is home to an enormous and beautiful tree. I gave it a hug the other day, but the trunk is so huge I could barely get my arms round a quarter of its girth. For now, the branches are bare of leaves, so you can see its form in all its majesty, a triumph of natural architecture. And if you half-close your eyes and dream a little, you can also see its roots, stretching deep beneath the grass, much as its branches and twigs stretch outwards towards the buildings and upwards towards the sky.

title: How the F.B.I. Identified Murrays Caller
description: As the F.B.I. moved in on a man who allegedly threatened Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, because of her support for health care legislation, law enforcement agents faced a challenge: they needed to confirm that Charles A. Wilson, the man whose phone number was used to leave menacing messages on her office voicemail, was in fact the man who made the threats.

title: When Corporate America Comes Calling
description: Out of the blue a couple of weeks ago, I got a call from a headhunter on my mobile phone. I happened to be walking across a parking lot at the time. I glanced over my shoulder  like a refugee in the witness-protection program  and wondered, How did they find me?

title: Funds Sought to Continue Restoration at Ellis Island
description: Save Ellis Island, a nonprofit charged with restoring that historic immigrant gateway to America, may not be able to save itself.

title: Ticket Broker Sees Sudden Interest in Woodss Return
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  At least one licensed ticket broker has detected a spike in demand for tickets to Thursdays first round of the Masters. Igniting the escalation is media frenzy over Tiger Woodss return, according to TicketCitys chief operating officer, Zach Anderson.

title: Ample Optimism, Defiant Dreams
description: The headwaters of the protean talent that is Allan Harris, a baritone crooner with a husky edge, may be Nat King Cole and his trio. But to describe this pop-jazz singer, composer and guitarist as a gifted Cole acolyte doesnt take into account the winding tributaries that bring in the blues, folk, pop-soul, light funk, Americana and Broadway flavors. Together they flow into a fertile musical delta that reflects Mr. Harriss unfashionably hopeful vision of multicultural America.

title: Reed Attacks Lobbying Efforts by Ratings Agencies
description: 7:35 a.m. | Updated Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island, on Tuesday criticized efforts by the credit ratings agencies to ward off proposed new rules, and rejected efforts to woo Republican legislators support as cynical.

title: Bilton on ABC: Test-Driving the iPad
description: On Monday I sat down with Dan Harris, a correspondent based in new York for ABC News, to discuss some of the features of Apples iPad. Mr. Harris asked about the weight of the device, which is a concern for some users, along with the typing features on the device and some of the interesting games and other applications that are available. I specifically talked about Flight Control 3-D.

title: Music Surely Soothes; Can It Also Heal?
description: When presenting concerts devoted to contemporary music in a variety of styles, an overarching theme can provide context. You regularly encounter programs bundled according to historical period, ties to other art forms or more fanciful notions. For this years Cutting Edge Concerts New Music Festival, an annual series presented by the composer and conductor Victoria Bond, Music & Health: Can Music Heal? is the banner notion.

title: 16 Years after the Genocide, Rwanda Continues Forward
description: Josh Ruxin is the director of Rwanda Works and a Columbia University expert on public health who has spent the last few years living in Rwanda. Here he reflects on the anniversary of the genocide in Rwanda.

title: Illuminating Princes Path That Led to Enlightenment
description: David Grubin, a prolific maker of television documentaries, specializes in profiles of American presidents and other prominent Westerners: Lincoln, both Roosevelts, Truman, Napoleon, Freud. For his latest PBS project, making its debut on Wednesday night, he has headed East, offering a two-hour introduction to an Asian with a large Western fan base.

title: Less Baggage, Big Savings to Airlines
description: Airlines in the United States started charging for luggage in 2005 by instituting a fee for passengers with more than one bag to check. Soon, even the first bag wasnt free. Now, Spirit Airlines says it will charge as much as $30 each way for carry-on bags that are too big to fit under the seat.

title: Contrasting Percussion, From Streets Near and Far
description: For thousands of years groups of people around the world have played music on percussion instruments  for rituals, dances, ceremonies, and just for fun. But as the percussionist Daniel Druckman wrote in a program note for a concert by the Juilliard Percussion Ensemble at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, the concept of a percussion ensemble as an independent musical entity in Western music, that is, as a group for giving concerts, is usually traced to 1933, when Nicolas Slonimsky conducted the premiere of Varses audacious Ionization at Carnegie Hall.

title: Automaker Pensions Underfunded by $17 Billion
