description: DETROIT  The pension plans at General Motors and Chrysler are underfunded by a total of $17 billion and could fail if the automakers do not return to profitability, according to a government report released Tuesday.

title: Malone Reduces Control of DirecTV
description: Updated 2:50 p.m. Tuesday: DirecTVs single largest shareholder and the chairman of its board of directors, John C. Malone, is reducing his control of the satellite television company.

title: Tenderness and Flair for British Composers
description: The superb British mezzo-soprano Alice Coote has been justly acclaimed for her operatic trouser roles. So it seemed fitting that for her recital at Zankel Hall on Monday evening she wore tight black trousers, a long, glittery silver top and killer heels  abandoning both sartorial and repertorial tradition in her unusual program.

title: Novartis Bias Suit to Begin
description: A class-action lawsuit alleging that Novartis Pharmaceuticals practiced sex discrimination against female employees is set to go to trial on Wednesday in federal court in New York.

title: Health Secretary Warns of Insurance Scams
description: The secretary of health and human services, Kathleen Sebelius, wrote to state officials on Tuesday to urge that they take action against scam artists reportedly marketing fake insurance policies to exploit the new law overhauling the health care system.

title: The iPad in the Eyes of the Digerati
description: Apple said it sold more than 300,000 iPads on Saturday, the devices first day on the market. Apple iPad users downloaded more than one million apps from the companys App Store and more than 250,000 electronic books from the iBookstore. Some reviewers said the iPad could challenge the primacy of the laptop. But others said the device, though gorgeous, simply doesnt fill an obvious need.

title: Edginess Over the Yankees Payroll
description: The Yankees paid around $150 million last season in luxury taxes and revenue sharing, the majority of it on the latter. When other teams complain about the Yankees high payroll, it can strike a nerve with club officials.

title: Web Luddite No More: OBrien Hits Internet
description: LOS ANGELES  When Conan OBrien wanted to start a Web site last winter, he was reminded that he did not own his dot-com name, ConanOBrien.com.

title: From the West Coast, a Punk Bronx Tale
description: After a decade spent grinding through the Los Angeles punk scene, a handful of talented, tattooed musicians formed a new band, one that promised an end to the indignities of begging promoters for shows and paying nightclubs for gigs.

title: Say Cheese
description: For the last few years, Nora Sherman has photographed at least half of her meals and uploaded the pictures to her blog.

title: Mourning in the Mountains
description: Charleston, W.Va.

title: Iris Cafe, Bakeri and Culture Espresso Bar
description: A GREAT cup of coffee is enough to make any place a neighborhood favorite. And if that place also serves good food, with a couple of standouts, it could become a local institution.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Delicious Words

title: Is Induction Cooking Ready to Go Mainstream?
description: LISA SIMPSON had been a professional cook, so when she remodeled her kitchen she was counting on a big, powerful gas range. But that would have meant installing a huge propane tank on her rural property outside Seattle. It would have been expensive, ugly and, in an area prone to earthquakes, nerve-racking.

title: Midtown Extension of Momofuku to Open This Week
description: IN one sense, the wait will be over soon for M Pche, David Changs Midtown extension of his Momofuku brand and one of the more anticipated recent restaurant openings. It is expected to begin serving lunch later this week in the Chambers Hotel.

title: Faustina
description: JEAN-CLAUDE IZZO wrote a terrific series of French noir novels, a Marseille trilogy of sun-baked bad guys and beautiful women, smart cops and mean situations. Mr. Izzo was a marvelous food writer in addition to being a poet of violence and regret. His books are filled with winning descriptions of Provenal meals run through with the flavors of north Africa, Italy, Greece. Also, violence. Of life in Marseille, Mr. Izzo wrote, Even to lose, you have to know how to fight.

title: Ginger Ale From Bruce Cost Is Now in Stores
description: Bruce Cost, a partner in the Big Bowl Asian restaurant chain, is having the lip-smacking fresh ginger ale he sells in the restaurants bottled in Brooklyn for retail sale.

title: London Meat Makes Products for Its Own Label
description: London Meat, a wholesaler that produces sausages and cured meats for store brands, now has its own line, Milano Suino dOro, or golden pig. Hot and sweet soppressata, rosemary-scented lardo (both above) and guanciale are highlights. Its all made in the meatpacking district, though the pork, from Duroc pigs, is from Iowa.

title: A Toaster With Glass Sides for Viewing
description: A new stainless-steel toaster has see-through insulated glass walls and a button that allows you to stop the toasting at any time, like reality TV at breakfast. It is designed in France by Robot-Coupe, which originated the food processor and first sold the toaster in Europe. This latest appliance has one-sided toasting for bagels, a button for defrosting and toasting simultaneously and a reheat button to warm the toast without further browning. A lever makes it easy to remove small pieces of toast, the ones that often require a fishing expedition in a regular toaster, and the glass walls tip out for cleaning.

title: Heirloom Apple Crops Increase
description: Spring does not bring to mind apples, but with the start of the growing season a nonprofit group called Renewing Americas Food Traditions (RAFT), which works with Slow Food, has declared this the year of the heirloom apple.

title: A Week With an Induction Burner
description: I SPENT a week with an All-Clad portable induction burner, a heavy silver and black unit that takes up about as much counter space as a Costco-size box of cereal.

title: Off the Menu
description: Openings

title: The Wild, Improbable Ride of the Last Mrs. Mailer
description: When Barbara Jean Davis  the future Norris Church Mailer  met Norman Mailer at a party in Russellville, Ark., in 1975, she was a high school art teacher and divorced single mother. Shed never flown in an airplane. She had a closet full of polyester clothes. When she took Mailer back to her house that first evening, she poured him a glass of Boones Farm apple wine.

title: Checking in at Faustina
First Camera, Then Fork
description: JAVIER GARCIA, a 28-year-old neuroscientist at the University of California, Irvine, was in the campus pub recently having a grilled cheese sandwich. But before he took a bite, he snapped a digital picture of it, cheese artistically oozing between toasted white bread, just as he has photographed everything he has eaten in the last five years.

title: Lawsuit Filed Over Eames Archives
description: One of the largest private archives documenting the mid-20th-century furniture designers Charles and Ray Eames has been withdrawn from an auction scheduled for Thursday because of a lawsuit contesting ownership. The paperwork, which fills more than 100 binders, was to be the top lot at a sale at Wright auction house in Chicago focused on furniture by the Eameses, known for their mass-produced contoured plywood and fiberglass chairs.

title: Visual Artists to Sue Google Over Vast Library Project
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As Google awaits approval of a controversial settlement with authors and book publishers, the companys plan to create an immense digital library and bookstore may face yet another hurdle.

title: A Ticket to the Circus
description: Chapter 1

title: What Are You Eating Right Now?
description: We want to see whats for breakfast, lunch or dinner. Send us a photo and description of what you are eating, using this form or by e-mailing pix@nyt.com. The pictures will be posted throughout the day at nytimes.com/dining.

title: How to Take Photos of Food
description: Andrew Scrivani, a freelance photographer and food stylist for The New York Times, is taking questions on how to photograph food. Andrew writes the food and photography blog Making Sunday Sauce. Post your question in the comments below and he will respond throughout the week. In the meantime, here are five basic tips on creating a successful food portrait.

title: What Were Reading: Videos, Design and Health Records
description: The tech editors and reporters of the New York Times were enjoying videos of a childs encounter with an iPad and Hewlett Packards encounter with its slate computer as well as articles on health information and analysts wild estimates.

title: AOL Plans to Sell or Shut Bebo Social Networking Site
description: Two years after AOL acquired the social networking site Bebo for $850 million, the company plans to sell or shut it.

title: They Cant Imagine
description: Jonathan Chait seems puzzled by a Michael Barone column in which Barone cant imagine that a key part of the Obama stimulus plan, aid to state governments, had any purpose other than to reward unionized government workers. Chaits puzzlement made me think of Ezra Kleins somewhat similar puzzlement over a column by Shelby Steele, in which Steele attributed Obamas push for health care reform to grandiosity and narcissism  never once mentioning that Obama might have, well, wanted to cover the uninsured.

title: Pakistan Weighs Changes to Revise Constitution
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans Parliament opened debate on Tuesday on a set of amendments intended to refurbish the Constitution after decades of distortions inflicted by a series of military autocrats.

title: G.O.P. Squirms as Spotlight Focuses on Its Leader
description: WASHINGTON  Michael Steele was hardly the consensus choice to become chairman of the Republican National Committee, scrambling to the top early last year after surviving multiple ballots in a crowded field.

title: A Regions Wounds Fester on Russias South Border
description: VLADIKAVKAZ, Russia  If anyone is still wondering why Russia finds itself entangled deeper and deeper in its attempt to pacify the Caucasus, Aslan Aushev, for one, would be happy to explain.

title: Winfrey to Interview Rielle Hunter
description: Oprah Winfrey has arranged for the first televised interview with Rielle Hunter, the woman with whom John Edwards admitted to having an extramarital affair.

title: Debt Rising in Europe
description: Greece is not the only country in Europe with problems with credit and debt.

title: Immaculate Transfer Strikes Again
description: Oh, dear. Via Mark Thoma, I see that Joe Stiglitz has fallen victim to the doctrine of immaculate transfer:

title: For Malone, a Much Smaller Piece of DirecTV
description: From Brian Stelter at Media Decoder:

title: In Medicine, the Power of No
description: WASHINGTON

title: Remembering Namir Noor-Eldeen
description: Updated, Wednesday, 4 p.m. | The writer, Michael Kamber, feels that some of his meaning may have been lost in the editing process. There is an addendum by him at the end of this blog post.

title: Analysis of California Pensions Finds Half-Trillion-Dollar Gap
description: An independent analysis of Californias three big pension funds has found a hidden shortfall of more than half a trillion dollars, several times the amount reported by the funds and more than six times the value of the states outstanding bonds.

title: Safety Issues at W.Va. Mine (NBC)
description: A video report highlighting the record of safety violations at the Massey Energy mine.

title: Stanford Pushes, but Not Far Enough
description: SAN ANTONIO

title: On Bench, a Link to Auriemmas Past
description: SAN ANTONIO  Bud Gardler would like to say that he always knew Geno Auriemma had what it took to be a legend in his own time, but such unmitigated praise would require suppressing his acerbic side. And as Auriemma, a chip off the old coach, said, Hes not exactly Mr. Sentimentality.

title: Finding the Strength of Super Wonder Woman in Rejection
description: In a video blog post, Anne Paik, a high school senior in Los Angeles who was rejected by 11 of the 15 colleges and universities to which she applied (and wait-listed by a 12th), reflects further on the emotional fallout from that experience. Her previous post  in which she wrote, Ive been rejected and Im still fabulous  has drawn nearly 150 reader comments.  Jacques Steinberg

title: Matsui Keeps His Production and His Following Rolling Out West
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  It was a quarter past 11 p.m., and the home dugout at Angel Stadium resembled a Tokyo subway car. Four dozen Japanese journalists  some standing, some sitting and almost all of them dressed in suits and ties  were waiting patiently to interview the former Yankee Hideki Matsui after his triumphant regular-season home debut.

title: Latino to Lead Los Angeles Diocese
description: The Vatican has chosen Archbishop Jose H. Gomez  who was born in Mexico and became an American citizen while serving in Texas as a priest for the conservative Catholic organization Opus Dei  to become the next leader of the Archdiocese of Los Angeles, the largest Roman Catholic archdiocese in the country.

title: Palestinians Try a Less Violent Path to Resistance
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Senior Palestinian leaders  men who once commanded militias  are joining unarmed protest marches against Israeli policies and are being arrested. Goods produced in Israeli settlements have been burned in public demonstrations. The Palestinian prime minister has entered West Bank areas officially off limits to his authority, to plant trees and declare the land part of a future state.

title: Paris Prosecutor Investigating French Oil Firm
description: PARIS  The Paris prosecutors office confirmed on Tuesday that Total, the French oil giant, was being investigated in a corruption case linked to its role in the scandal-plagued oil-for-food program in Iraq.

title: Whos Up for Building Bridges?
description: Im no expert on American politics, but I do know something about holes. And watching the way the Republican Party is reacting to the passage of health care, it seems to me the G.O.P. is violating the first rule of holes: When youre in one, stop digging.

title: In Australia, Interest Rate Is Raised a Fifth Time
description: HONG KONG  The Australian central bank raised its key interest rate Tuesday by a quarter of a percentage point to 4.25 percent, in a sign that it thought that the Australian economy was on solid enough footing to be weaned off the low rates.

title: Mines Fight Strict Laws by Filing More Appeals
description: Armed with tougher federal mining laws passed in 2006, federal investigators had new powers to crack down on mines with persistent violations.

title: From a Seat of Power to One on Greyhound
description: ABOARD GREYHOUND BUS No. 1026  A half-hour north of Richmond, Va., Sharpe James fell asleep. His eyes were closed, his lips puckered open. His blue-and-silver tie was undone. If this had been a portrait, it might have borne the title Disgraced Politician at Ease.

title: U.S. and Brazil Reach Agreement on Cotton Dispute
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and Brazil have reached an agreement aimed at settling a long-standing trade dispute over American subsidies to cotton growers, officials in both countries said Tuesday.

title: Tupper's Prospect Park
description: As Tupper Thomas retires, her legacy in Prospect Park continues.

title: A Red Sox Lineup With Less Power, but More Patience
description: BOSTON

title: Iraq Video Brings Notice to a Web Site
description: Three months ago, WikiLeaks, a whistleblower Web site that posts classified and sensitive documents, put out an urgent call for help on Twitter.

title: No Problem, Say Golfers in the Group With Woods
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Hunter Mahan stood beneath the large oak tree adjacent to the Augusta National clubhouse Tuesday as the playing groups for the first two rounds of this weeks Masters were revealed. With a reporter holding the pairings sheet in his hand, Mahan leaned over to read from it.

title: At the Masters, Two Favorites Confront Obstacles
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The two golfers who have won combined to win half of the Masters tournaments played since the turn of the century are  surprise!  the two top favorites entering the 74th rite of spring starting Thursday at Augusta National Golf Club. But if either Tiger Woods, who has won three Masters since 2000, or Phil Mickelson, who has won two, is to win this years event, they will have significant obstacles to overcome.

title: Greek Bond Yields Soar in Sell-Off
description: Investors fled Greek bonds on Tuesday, pushing up the cost of new borrowing for the debt-stricken nation and calling into question a joint rescue plan by the European Union and the International Monetary Fund.

title: Why Tiger Matters
description: Every week I learn something from writing this column. Last weeks column taught me that if you want to bask in the adulation of your readers, you should avoid sounding like you disapprove of Tiger Woodss off-the-course behavior.

title: Ensnared by Error on Growing U.S. Watch List
description: Rahinah Ibrahim, a Stanford University doctoral student, arrived at San Francisco International Airport with her 14-year-old daughter for a 9 a.m. flight home to Malaysia. She asked for a wheelchair, having recently had a hysterectomy.

title: Now Abloom on Staten Island: Flora, Potholes and Complaints
description: One month ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg helped fill what city officials said was the two millionth pothole repaired on the mayors watch.

title: Abuse Crisis Strains Vaticans Ancient Ways of Management
description: ROME  The sexual abuse scandal engulfing the Roman Catholic Church is by far the most tenacious and complex crisis Pope Benedict XVI has faced. And it is a crucial test for a papacy that many Vatican observers say has a deep internal flaw: its management.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 6, 2010

title: City Fined Over Documents on Fatal Crane Collapse
description: A judge fined the Bloomberg administration $5,000 on Tuesday for repeatedly ignoring court orders to provide the families of two construction workers who died in a 2008 crane collapse with documents, e-mail messages and other information concerning equipment inspected by the city.

title: U.S. Approves Targeted Killing of American Cleric
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has taken the extraordinary step of authorizing the targeted killing of an American citizen, the radical Muslim cleric Anwar al-Awlaki, who is believed to have shifted from encouraging attacks on the United States to directly participating in them, intelligence and counterterrorism officials said Tuesday.

title: Mets Lead Majors in Flags but Would Prefer a Pennant
description: In the Mets opening day victory over the Florida Marlins, the Venezuelan starting pitcher Johan Santana threw six strong innings. He was replaced by his countryman Fernando Nieve, who shut down the Marlins in the seventh and eighth, and then Nieve gave way to Francisco Rodriguez, another Venezuelan, who tossed a perfect ninth.

title: Obamas Nuclear Strategy Intended as a Message
description: WASHINGTON  At the heart of President Obamas new nuclear strategy lies a central gamble: that an aging, oversize, increasingly outmoded nuclear arsenal can be turned to the new purpose of adding leverage to the faltering effort to force Iran and North Korea to rethink the value of their nuclear programs.

title: 27 Down: Rodeo Specialist
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  When I see a Richard Silvestri byline on a puzzle, theres a 97 percent chance laughs will follow. Not necessarily knee-slapping pig-snorters, but a dose of chuckles and grins at the very least. Todays puzzle didnt disappoint.

title: Off-Menu Goods Attract the Polices Attention
description: The sign outside Chris Restaurant in Brooklyn listed some staples of Caribbean cuisine among its offerings: homemade fried chicken, jerk chicken and stew fish. But according to the authorities, there was one item that it apparently did not advertise, at least not openly  marijuana.

title: An Idol Ratings Loss, but Not in Its Pocketbook
description: THE hit show American Idol has been the playground bully of prime time for so long that its not surprising that long-suffering competitors relish every opportunity to tweak its sky-high nose.

title: Another Twist in a Connecticut Triple-Murder Case
description: NEW HAVEN  Steven J. Hayes is charged with killing a mother and her two daughters in the town of Cheshire, Conn., in 2007. He faces the death penalty. And on Tuesday, he told a courtroom here that he would fight the charges.

title: Man Gets at Least 20 Years in Murder on Nightclub Roof
description: Ingrid Estrada has had problems sleeping at night for more than a year and a half. She is sometimes listless at work, unable to get anything done. It hurts when she hears her 9-year-old son, Joshua, who has Down syndrome, ask for his sister. She cannot look at the roof of a building without horrific images flashing through her mind.

title: South Africa Energy Needs Collide With U.S. Policy
description: JOHANNESBURG  The Obama administration, caught in an awkward bind between its own ambitions on climate change and Africas pressing energy needs, is facing the first test of its new guidelines discouraging coal-fired power projects in developing nations.

title: Fire at Shoeshine Stand Seemed Random, the First Time
description: Three weeks ago, a shoeshine stand outside Bryant Park burned down in the night. There seemed to be no motive or suspect, suggesting that the fire was a random act of violence.

title: St. Vincents Votes to Shut Hospital in Manhattan
description: The board of St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers voted on Tuesday night to close its flagship hospital in Greenwich Village, ending its long struggle to stay afloat despite millions of dollars of debt.

title: Wilma Mankiller, Cherokee Chief and First Woman to Lead Major Tribe, Is Dead at 64
description: Wilma Mankiller, who as the first woman to be elected chief of a major American Indian tribe revitalized the Cherokee Nations tribal government and improved its education, health and housing, died Tuesday at her home near Tahlequah, Okla. She was 64.

title: Underground Fire Disrupts Midtown
description: A buildup of carbon monoxide under a Midtown street caused an underground fire and a manhole explosion Tuesday afternoon, prompting the evacuation of four buildings near Times Square, the authorities said.

title: Corin Redgrave, Actor and Activist, Dies at 70
description: Corin Redgrave, a versatile actor and ardent left-wing political activist who, as the son of Michael Redgrave and the brother of Vanessa and Lynn Redgrave, was the prince of the royal family of English theater, died on Tuesday in London. He was 70.

title: Rangers Stumble in Their Run to Playoffs
description: BUFFALO  All those victories and all those points, and now one defeat may have undone everything.

title: Mexico: 25,000 Affected by Quake
description: The earthquake that struck Baja California on Sunday has affected an estimated 25,000 people, the states governor said Tuesday. The governor, Jos Guadalupe Osuna Milln, said that the 7.2-magnitude quake caused the worst damage in the rural area south of the city of Mexicali, and that more than 5,000 families had reported that their homes were destroyed or damaged. The earthquake killed two people and injured more than 200.

title: Malone Trims DirecTV Stake
description: John C. Malone, DirecTVs single largest shareholder and its board chairman, is divesting most of his voting shares in the satellite television company.

title: Robinson Still Trying to Settle in With Celtics
description: For two seasons, the Knicks have slashed, purged and repeated in order to trim payroll in an attempt to attract star players through free agency. How does a center who can haul in 18 rebounds and score 17 points against the playoff-bound Boston Celtics resonate?

title: Thamess Start in Left May Be the First of Many
description: BOSTON  On Tuesday night, in their second game of the season, the Yankees started a player in left field who joined the team in February on a minor league deal.

title: Philippe Braunschweig, Prix de Lausanne Founder, Dies at 82
description: Philippe Braunschweig, the heir to a Swiss watchmaking fortune who founded the innovative and prestigious Prix de Lausanne ballet competition for young dancers, died on April 3 in Vevey, Switzerland. He was 82 and lived in Vevey.

title: Taxpayer Could Have Kept the $600, but He Put His Country First
description: A flaw in the most recent version of TurboTax, the nations most popular tax-preparation software, may have caused thousands of retired federal employees to overstate their medical deductions and unwittingly underpay the Internal Revenue Service, according to federal officials.

title: Inside the West Virginia Mine Explosion
description: Mondays explosion at the Upper Big Branch mine in West Virginia killed 25 miners, injured two and left four missing.

title: What Are You Eating Right Now?
description: Readers submitted photos of whatever happened to be on their plate.

title: Nonprofit Group Will Prod Companies to Report Their Water Use
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Carbon Disclosure Project, an investor-backed nonprofit organization that has persuaded some of the worlds largest corporations to disclose their greenhouse gas emissions, will announce on Wednesday that it is asking 302 global companies to begin issuing detailed reports on their water use.

title: Moore Leads Connecticut to Womens Title
description: SAN ANTONIO  Sometimes, the best coaching tactic is a desperate plea to a teams best player. Stand up. Do something. Show us the way.

title: Expensive Language Lessons? Doesnt Translate
description: At the beginning of this year, I made a resolution to learn to speak Spanish and Mandarin Chinese, two of the most commonly used languages on the planet and the keys to travel over a great swath of the world.

title: The Churchs Judas Moment
description: WASHINGTON

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about an apparently coordinated hacking assault on the Yahoo e-mail accounts of a dozen rights advocates, academics and journalists who cover China included three errors. A 2005 transaction between Yahoo and Alibaba, a Chinese e-commerce company, that gave Alibaba control of Yahoos China operations was a sale  not a merger. The year that Yahoo turned over data that Chinese officials used to help prosecute several dissidents was 2004, not 2006. And local Chinese service providers  not Yahoo  maintain the servers in China used to store e-mail sent through Yahoos Chinese domain, which are considered relatively vulnerable to intrusions and have driven privacy-conscious Chinese away.

title: Another Mining Tragedy
description: Representative Nick Rahall II, a Democrat from the district in West Virginia where disaster struck deep in the Upper Big Branch mine, summed up the mixture of sorrow and suspicion that followed the worst American mining catastrophe in a quarter-century.

title: Mean Girls Arent a Myth. Theyre All Too Real.
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Obamas Nuclear Policy
description: President Obama has spoken eloquently about his vision of a world without nuclear weapons. It is a lofty goal that will not be achieved during his presidency  or for years after that. But in a very dangerous time, he is taking important steps to make the world safer and bolster this countrys credibility as it tries to constrain the nuclear ambitions of Iran, North Korea and others.

title: We Wont Bet on OTB
description: After years of mismanagement, a work force padded with patronage employees and a dwindling public interest in wagering on the horses, the corporation that runs New York Citys off-track betting parlors filed for bankruptcy protection late last year. Unless something is done, the betting parlors could start closing next week. Some lawmakers in Albany are calling for a taxpayer bailout. That is a bad idea. The New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation must find a way to pay its operating costs or the state will have to pay to close it down.

title: It Happened on Wall St. and Main St.
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Board Appointee
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Save Afghanistan From Karzai
description: IN February, the Taliban sanctuary of Marja in southern Afghanistan was attacked in the largest operation of the war. Last week, President Obama flew to Afghanistan and declared, Our troops have pushed the Taliban out of their stronghold in Marja .... The United States of America does not quit once it starts on something.

title: The Labor Department Wakes Up
description: The Department of Labor has begun a long-overdue campaign to protect workers rights, a core part of its job that was sorely neglected in the fiercely antiregulatory Bush era. The campaign, We Can Help, uses public-service announcements, a Web site and a phone hot line to encourage workers  particularly those in construction, janitorial fields, hotels, food services and home health care  to report employer abuses. It also adds 250 investigators, a one-third increase, to the departments wage and hour division.

title: Man Charged in Shooting of 2 in Times Sq. Melee
description: A 20-year-old man was arrested Tuesday afternoon on charges that he shot two women during the sprawling melee near Times Square on Sunday night, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about an effort to replace the likeness of President Ulysses S. Grant on the $50 bill with that of President Ronald Reagan referred incorrectly to Parker Poling, whose boss, Representative Patrick T. McHenry, Republican of North Carolina, is leading the effort. Parker Poling, Mr. McHenrys chief of staff, is a woman.

title: A Case for Annual Stress Tests
description: Improving bank regulation may call for a little more stress. The disclosure and discipline imposed by the Federal Reserves stress tests of big banks a year ago drew a line under the crisis. The tests separated sheep from goats and led to tens of billions of dollars of new capital being raised. Its a shame that stress tests arent becoming an annual event.

title: Corrections
description: The Seattle Journal article on Friday, about efforts by officials to make the city more welcoming and conducive to children, misstated part of the name of a waterfront park that posts Please Dont Touch signs. It is Olympic Sculpture Park, not Seattle Sculpture Park.

title: This Time, Bullpen Holds as Yankees Get Win No. 1
description: BOSTON  About 1,400 miles from here, Phil Hughes was sitting in his condominium in Tampa, Fla., on Sunday night watching the Red Sox throttle the Yankees bullpen. Hughes used to be part of that group, a big part, but he has moved on.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about information gathered by New York City showing the most popular places to find a cab at any hour during the week referred incorrectly to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. It is the busiest train station in the United States, not the world.

title: California: City Offices Will Go Dark
description: With Los Angeles teetering toward a major fiscal crisis, Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa on Tuesday asked the city administrative officer to shut down all city agencies  except for public safety and those that generate revenue  for two days per week beginning next week. Mr. Villaraigosas order comes on the heels of the city controllers warning that the city might be unable to pay employees and vendors within four weeks. The city has been pressing the Department of Water and Power for its $73.5-million contribution to the treasury, which the agency has declined to pay after the City Council recently rejected its proposed electricity rate increase.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the rise in drama programming on cable channels erroneously included an ABC drama on a list of shows that have failed in the 10 p.m. prime-time slot on network television. The show, The Deep End, was shown at 8 p.m.

title: California: If Its Monday, Its Veggies
description: Tuesday was a good day for vegetables  and San Franciscans who love them  as the citys Board of Supervisors passed a nonbinding resolution declaring every Monday as meat-free. The resolution, sponsored by Supervisor Sophie Maxell, a vegetarian, urges restaurants, stores and schools to offer plant-based options every Monday to improve the general civic health. Ms. Maxwell tied the measure to the fight against global warning and said it would encourage citizens to choose vegetarian foods as a way to protect the planet and their health. The board also passed a nonbinding resolution commending businesses that use only cage-free eggs. Ms. Maxwell invited the entire board to her office for a vegetarian treat.

title: Illinois: The Obamas New Neighbors
description: The Obamas will soon have new next-door neighbors in Chicago: the 6,000-square-foot house at 5040 South Greenwood Avenue, a 17-room, century-old, fixer-upper next to the Hyde Park residence of the Obamas, sold Tuesday for $1.4 million. Matt Garrison, the listing agent, and the owners, Bill and Jacky Grimshaw, had not put an asking price on the property when it went on the market in September because they were not sure what the Obama effect would be. They had hoped to get a record-breaking price. But the effect proved less powerful than anticipated. At the end of the day, the property traded to a local buyer for what we felt was a very fair price, Mr. Garrison said. The buyers were not publicly identified. The propertys estimated value in 2009 was $1.19 million, according to the Cook County Assessors Office.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Tuesday about Dukes victory on Monday in the championship game of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament erroneously included one Duke player among those on past teams who were high first-round N.B.A. draft picks. The player, Carlos Boozer, was a second-round pick, in 2002.

title: Massachusetts: Not-Guilty Pleas in Bullying
description: Lawyers entered pleas of not guilty Tuesday for three students who face charges related to the bullying of Phoebe Prince, a 15-year-old student at South Hadley High School who committed suicide. Sean Mulveyhill, 17, and Kayla Narey, 17, are charged with violation of civil rights, criminal harassment and disruption of a school assembly, all felonies. Mr. Mulveyhill and Austin Renaud, 18, are charged with statutory rape. The students did not appear in court on Tuesday. Prosecutors said Ms. Prince was subjected to relentless taunts and physical threats before she killed herself on Jan. 14. Three other students will appear in court on Thursday to face felony charges.

title: Those Melodic Sounds, From Mysterious Spaces
description: Walking through the streets in and around New York City, you hear all sorts of sounds: cars, footsteps, the occasional argument, and, of course, music.

title: Corrections
description: The On Basketball column on Tuesday, about the push-pull relationship between Tara VanDerveer, the Stanford womens coach, and one of her players, misspelled the players surname in some editions. She is Rosalyn Gold-Onwude, not Gold-Owunde.

title: N. Korea Sentences American to Hard Labor
description: SEOUL, South Korea  An American man who was arrested in North Korea for illegal entry was sentenced to eight years of hard labor, the Norths state-run news agency reported on Wednesday.

title: How to Turn Your Blogs Readers Into Paying Customers
description: We already know that everyone from Ashton Kutcher to Don Draper, the slick ad man on Mad Men, could build a loyal following on Twitter, Facebook, blogs and other social sites.

title: Upbeat Signs Revive Consumers Mood for Spending
description: American consumers are finally coming out of hiding.

title: Study Finds More Woes Following Foster Care
description: Only half the youths who had turned 18 and aged out of foster care were employed by their mid-20s. Six in 10 men had been convicted of a crime, and three in four women, many of them with children of their own, were receiving some form of public assistance. Only six in 100 had completed even a community college degree.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Bats roundup in some editions on Saturday about the Mets final cuts before the new baseball season misstated the given name of a pitcher who was let go on Friday. He is Kiko Calero, not Kiki.

title: Deadly Blasts in Baghdad
description: Bombings shook Baghdad for the second time in three days, killing 35 people and wounding more than 140.

title: Word of the Day | curmudgeon
description: curmudgeon \()kr-m-jn\ noun

title: Two Rough Games for Ortiz
description: BOSTON  Everybody in the stands, the press box and the dugout understands that the season is two games old. It is far, far too early to make snap judgments on anybody. But this is all the baseball weve seen in 2010.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Friday about Miami Medical, on CBS, misspelled the surname of the actress who plays Dr. Eva Zambrano. As a listing of credits with the review noted, she is Lana Parrilla, not Parilla.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on a capsule summary in some editions on Monday about Chinas new ambassador to North Korea misidentified the location of a weekend party welcoming him to the country. It was in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang  not, of course, in the South Korean capital of Seoul. (The article, which noted the correct location, was written from Seoul.)

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: News Quiz | April 7, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Greek Bond Yields Soar in Sell-Off
description: Investors fled Greek bonds on Tuesday, pushing up the cost of new borrowing for the debt-stricken nation and calling into question a joint rescue plan by the European Union and the International Monetary Fund.

title: See No Evil
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs elections were a photographers dream. Millions of people turning out to vote, long lines at the ballot boxes, and everywhere photogenically purple fingers being held aloft for camera and television lenses.

title: S.E.C. to Push for Disclosure on Mortgage-Backed Paper
description: Remember mortgage-backed securities? They were the go-go house of cards that collapsed and nearly brought down the financial system, helping usher in the recession. In response, lawmakers and government agencies have been trying to lay down stricter rules for asset-backed securities, The Associated Press reported.

title: High-Speed Trading May Soon Be Regulated
description: United States securities regulators may formulate a plan to improve oversight of high-frequency trading by keeping track of executed transactions, The Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: Google Deal for AdMob Under the Gun at F.T.C.
description: Lawyers at the Federal Trade Commission plan to recommend that the government try to block Googles proposed acquisition of mobile advertising firm AdMob on antitrust grounds, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters.

title: Film Department Tweaks I.P.O. Size Again
description: The Film Department cut the expected price range for its initial public offering Tuesday, as the company continued its effort to raise funds by selling stock to investors.

title: Fact-Checking the Web
description: WHO are David and Barbara Mikkelson?

title: Union Expresses Concern Over Salaries
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association is considering, among a number of options, filing a grievance accusing owners of conspiring to suppress player salaries this past winter.

title: Raymond James Settles With Wells Fargo
description: Raymond James Financial said on Tuesday that it had reached a confidential settlement in a brokerage raiding case with Wells Fargo, Reuters reported.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about tomatoes grown in giant greenhouses misidentified a variety that Backyard Farms in Maine produces. It is a cocktail tomato on the vine, not a cherry tomato on the vine.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report last Wednesday in the Off the Menu column about the opening of the restaurant Zengo referred imprecisely to its menu. It serves a fusion of Asian and Latin American food, not Asian and Mexican food, and its tequila bar serves Mexican street food, not just tacos.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the Irish food writer and cooking teacher Darian Allen misspelled the surname of a chef who has studied with Ms. Allen. She is Abra Berens, not Behrens.

title: What Are You Doing This Summer?
description: Though the economy may be improving, job prospects for young people remain dim. What do you plan to do this summer? What summer options for work, education, entertainment or other kinds of enrichment are there in your area? What would you consider a summer well spent?

title: Cohens Ex-Wife Says Shes Owed a Piece of SAC
description: The ex-wife of Steven A. Cohen, already suing her former husband for millions of dollars in damages, now claims the trader cheated her out a piece of his $12 billion hedge-fund empire.

title: Making a Case for Annual Stress Tests
description: Improving bank regulation may call for a little more stress, Breakingviews says. The disclosure and discipline imposed by the Federal Reserves stress tests of big banks a year ago drew a line under the crisis. The tests separated sheep from goats and led to tens of billions of dollars of new capital being raised. Its a shame that stress tests arent becoming an annual event, the publication says.

title: How to Save the World Wins Web Video Contest
description: How to fight climate change? Well, you could start by just saving some electricity. Or saying no to plastic bags. Or turning off the tap while you brush your teeth.

title: Wall Street Turns Mixed at the End of Day
description: Wall Street traders were cautious on Tuesday amid worries that the European Unions plan to help Greece might unwind. But signs that the Federal Reserve would keep interest rates low helped give stocks some support, The New York Timess Javier C. Hernandez reported.

title: How This Half Lives
description: On a recent Monday afternoon in the East Village, the 32-year-old upstart photographer Todd Selby  more commonly known as the Selby  was entertaining a guest in his modest ground-floor studio. One of the two monitors on which he creates his teeming online gallery, The Selby Is in Your Place, was tuned to a Web site called Unhappy Hipsters. The idea behind the site  which that week was reaching something of a viral mass  is pretty straightforward: cut and paste a selection of those placid, sparsely populated house shots from magazines like Dwell and run the snarkiest captions imaginable beneath them. Hed become a caricature of what it meant to be a young, monied follower is a typical entry. Oh, my God, Selby said, scrolling through the site with what appeared to be a mixture of astonishment and appreciation, as if meeting a fellow traveler. After all, Selbys vrit approach to photographing personal spaces is precisely in tune with the urge to skewer those magazines that celebrate sleek minimalism while scorning clutter like the long-suffering mother of a teenage son.

title: Thai Protesters Storm Parliament
description: BANGKOK  Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva of Thailand declared a state of emergency in the Bangkok area on Wednesday after antigovernment demonstrators broke into the Parliament building, forcing government ministers to flee by helicopter.

title: Goldman Denies Conflict of Interest on Subprime
description: Goldman Sachs, in its annual letter Wednesday, denies the charge that it bet against its own clients at the height of the subprime mortgage crisis.

title: Tengion Seeks to Pocket $44.4 Million in I.P..O
description: Tengion, a regenerative medicine company, plans to raise as much as $44.4 million in an initial public offering of stock this week.

title: Stitcher Sews Up $6 Million
description: Stitcher, a service that allows listeners to stream radio shows and podcasts on mobile devices, has received $6 million in a second round of funding, PaidContent reported.

title: Automaker Pensions Underfunded by $17 Billion
description: The pension plans at General Motors and Chrysler are underfunded by a total of $17 billion and could fail if the automakers do not return to profitability, The New York Timess Nick Bunkley reported, citing a government report released Tuesday.

title: Infogroup Investor Blasts Proposed Sale Price
description: An investment firm that holds nearly 6 percent of the stock of Infogroup, a database provider, says the proposed sale of the company to the private equity firm CCMP Capital Advisors is priced too low, The Associated Press reported, citing documents released Tuesday.

title: Metals USA Aims for $200 Million in I.P.O.
description: Metals USA Holdings is hoping to raise as much as $200 million in an initial public offering this week, The Associated Press reported.

title: American Idol: Growing More Like a Circus
description: Casey James > Michael Lynche > Crystal Bowersox > Tim Urban > Lee DeWyze > Katie Stevens > Siobhan Magnus > Andrew Garcia > Aaron Kelly

title: JAL Said to Plan 16,500 Layoffs to Save $870 Million
description: Japan Airlines plans to reduce its work force by a third within the fiscal year to lower labor costs by 81.7 billion yen ($870 million) a year, The Nikkei, a business daily, said.

title: Son of Venture Capitalist Gets Foursquare Badge for Polar Trip
description: Normally if youre the teenage child of a multimillionaire, you might expect a nice car or designer clothing as a present, VentureBeat reported.

title: Blockbuster Agrees to Payment Terms With Studios
description: Blockbuster, the indebted video retail chain, agreed to payment terms with two movie studios that will allow it to rent DVDs on the same day they go on sale, the company said in a statement Tuesday, Reuters reported.

title: R.B.S. Kicks Off Bond Restructuring Scheme
description: Royal Bank of Scotland on Tuesday started its planned bond exchange and buyback to restructure up to 15.8 billion ($24 billion) of debt, hitting prices of a few lower ranked bonds, Reuters reported.

title: Macarthur Coal Cool to Peabody Energys Bid
description: Macarthur Coal discouraged its shareholders on Wednesday from taking action on Peabody Energys increased takeover bid, worth 3.56 billion Australian dollars, and instead to wait for a board vote on an acquisition attempt by Macarthur.

title: Upheaval in Kyrgyzstan Could Imperil Key U.S. Base
description: MOSCOW  The president of Kyrgyzstan was forced to flee the capital, Bishkek, on Wednesday after bloody protests erupted across the country over his repressive rule, a backlash that could pose a threat to the American military supply line into nearby Afghanistan.

title: Jets Executive Chef Has Personal Touch
description: Jets tight end Dustin Keller, who is a budding restaurateur, will write a food column once a month for the Fifth Down. Hell also answer football questions from readers. Post your question in the comments section.Playing in the N.F.L. is awesome. Im very grateful that its something I get to do for a living. I know a lot of people would love to have this job, and I dont ever take it for granted. You get a lot of perks playing in the league, and one of my favorites is the food. Which is why I hired the Jets executive chef, John Canniezaro, to come to my house to prepare my meals during the off-season.

title: Prado Pairs Las Meninas With American Masterpiece
description: This spring at the Prado Museum (museodelprado.es), an exhibition pays homage to that institutions  and perhaps Spains  most treasured painting, Las Meninas (1656) by Velzquez. In what is likely to be a true once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has lent John Singer Sargents famous painting The Daughters of Edward Darley Boit (1882), which many art historians call the American Meninas to be displayed next to the Velzquez painting. The loan is part of the Prados series of Invited Work exhibitions, which bring individual works of special importance or resonance to the museum, to be seen in proximity to the Prados collection.

title: Automakers Unveil Partnership
description: Renault, Nissan Motor and Daimler said on Wednesday that they would swap stakes and jointly develop cars in a tie-up to gain scale and share costs, Reuters reported.

title: Sears and Lampert Win Dismissal of Kmart Fraud Suit
description: A federal appeals court said that Sears Holdings was not liable to former Kmart Holding shareholders who accused the retailer of trying to drive down Kmarts stock price to let executives buy shares cheaply.

title: The Plunge Into Poverty That Wasnt
description: Todays idea: The global economic downturn was supposed to throw masses of people in the developing world back into poverty. It didnt, says a columnist.

title: Masters Offers a Glimpse of 3-D Internet
description: In movies, 3-D has certainly come of age. There is the record-setting Avatar, of course, and only last week Clash of the Titans and Alice in Wonderland delivered the biggest Easter weekend box office on record.

title: Putin Marks Soviet Massacre of Polish Officers
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Wednesday became the first Russian or Soviet leader to join Polish officials in commemorating the anniversary of the murder of thousands of Polish officers by the Soviet Union at the beginning of World War II.

title: Ford Gets $1.75 Billion in High-Yield Bond Sale
description: Ford Motors finance arm sold $1.75 billion of five-year debt, taking advantage of investor demand for high-yield bonds, on pace for the longest rally since 1996, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Barclays Seeks Lehman Assets Despite Trustee Disputes
description: Barclays has asked a court to let it keep billions of dollars in Lehman Brothers Holdings assets, even though the trustee of the bankrupt investment bank says the remaining Lehman customers should probably get them, Reuters reported.

title: I.M.F. Meeting With Greek Officials Over Reforms
description: Inspectors from the International Monetary Fund will meet Greeces finance minister to find ways to speed up fiscal reforms, as the debt-plagued country continues to grapple with volatile borrowing costs, The Associated Press reported.

title: Verizon Chief Sees No Appeal in Vodafone Merger
description: The top executive of Verizon Communications dismissed speculation his company would merge with wireless venture partner Vodafone Group, saying such a deal would offer little benefit, Reuters reported.

title: Buyout Shops Said to Circle R.B.S Unit
description: While the sale of hundreds of Royal Bank of Scotland branches has gotten the most attention in recent days, a slew of bidders are also reportedly lining up for another asset the government-owned bank has put on the block.

title: Roadside Assistance in an App, From Mazda
description: Take that, OnStar.

title: Q.&A.: The Best Option for Road Tunes
description: Q.

title: Will Greece Reverse Course on Hedge Funds?
description: As investors fled Greek bonds on Tuesday, pushing up the cost of new borrowing for the debt-stricken nation, the country may now be forced to reverse its policy of shutting out hedge funds when it starts its upcoming bond offering, The Telegraph reported.

title: High and Outside
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: As Rescue Efforts Continue for Miners, Officials Press for Answers
description: MONTCOAL, W.Va.  As rescue workers waited anxiously on Wednesday to re-enter the Upper Big Branch mine where at least 25 people were killed in a deadly blast this week, federal officials said two safety citations were made against the mines operator on the day of the explosion.

title: Transgender Film Draws Protests at Festival Site
description: Transgender and transsexual women and men and their supporters gathered outside Tribeca Cinemas Tuesday evening to demand the removal of what they called a transphobic film from the Tribeca Film Festival lineup.

title: Cabrera Goes From Pauper Caddie to Prince of the Greens
description: Reluctant to embrace the spotlight, particularly if English is being spoken there, ngel Cabrera has been well served this week as he has prepared to defend his Masters title.

title: Comeback Dj Vu, or One of a Kind?
description: No longer master of the universe or even of his own image, Tiger Woods has succeeded in remaining the talk of the Masters in this season and situation unlike any other.

title: Sampler: Sex Abuse by a Swim Coach, and Engineers Create Towel-Folding Robot
description: Half-Trillion-Dollar Shortfall in State Pension Funds | An independent analysis of Californias three big pension funds has found a hidden shortfall of more than half a trillion dollars, several times the amount reported by the funds and more than six times the value of the states outstanding bonds. The analysis was commissioned by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, who has been pressing the State Legislature to focus on the rising cost of public pensions. Graduate students identified the shortfall in the three funds serving more than 2.6 million people  the state-run employees pension fund, known as Calpers; a second large fund for teachers, known as Calstrs; and the University of California Retirement System. The researchers offered recommendations for closing the gap, including revamping the benefit structure. [The New York Times]

title: Countries Urged to Plan for End of Stimulus
description: PARIS  An international financial organization urged advanced economies on Wednesday to begin laying the groundwork now so that next year they could start removing economic stimulus measures.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, April 7
description: Here are some highlights from Wednesdays edition of The New York Times:

title: For Corzine, a Second Act Took Just 7 Days
description: So just how much will Jon S. Corzine, who spent more than three decades at Goldman Sachs before using his vast fortune to start a career in politics as a New Jersey senator and governor, get for his return to Wall Street?

title: WikiLeaks Draws Attention for Iraq Video
description: WikiLeaks, a Web site with offices across the globe that specializes in uncovering information that governments and other powerful interests would rather keep hidden, has drawn sudden attention because of its release Monday of a startling and graphic video showing a United States Army assault in Baghdad in 2007 that left 12 people dead, including two employees of the Reuters news agency. Noam Cohen and Brian Stelter write in The New York Times that while the group uses digital technology to uncover its scoops, it offers a mix of fact and advocacy that some find troubling. They write:

title: Beurgeois
description: Middle class French Muslims of North African descent who are fueling demand for halal products  i.e., those permitted under Islamic law.

title: Labor, Losing Influence?
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: CKE Gets Higher Takeover Bid
description: CKE Restaurants said on Wednesday that it has received a new takeover bid, one that the restaurant chain operator said is reasonably expected to lead to a superior proposal to THL Partnerss existing $928 million offer.

title: He Was Pining For The Fjords
description: From todays Times:

title: I.B.M. and Saudi Researchers Collaborate on Solar-Powered Desalination Technology
description: I.B.M. and a Saudi Arabian research institute are collaborating to develop a desalination plant powered by a new type of solar technology.

title: From Trains to Planes, Europe Faces Strikes
description: Work stoppages are in the news. Bloomberg News is reporting, French train drivers began their third strike this year. Network Rail signal workers considered reviving a strike plan blocked by a British court. Deutsche Lufthansa pilots may strike this month. And British Airways could face another round of stoppages by flight attendants.

title: The Early Word: The Bandwidth Plays On
description: The chief appeals court that oversees federal regulations delivered a body blow to the Federal Communications Commission by ruling that the agency lacks the explicit statutory authority to require that Internet service providers treat all customers and Web sites equally, regardless of how much or what kind of information they download or deliver.

title: Toyota Canada Says It Learned of Pedal Repair Procedure Later Than Europe
description: OTTAWA  Toyota Canada and the United States Transportation Department are at odds about when the Canadian unit was first told to repair pedals on several models to avoid unintended accelerations.

title: Martin And The Austrians
description: Martin Wolf asks for a discussion of Austrian economics.

title: Rental Vouchers in Jeopardy
description: What were reading this morning:

title: Best Left Guards in the N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
description: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely  but not strictly  by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, although the future isnt utterly ignored. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. Thats why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what youre about to read.

title: A Call for the Fed to Raise Rates Unsettles Investors
description: Wall Street investors were rattled on Wednesday by the prospect of higher interest rates and new signs that consumers were reluctant to spend again.

title: Met, Where Is Thy Sting? (Hes Coming in July.)
description: 11:20 a.m. | Updated If you thought you saw a familiar, nattily attired Englishman poking around Lincoln Center in recent days, you might well have spotted Sting inspectingthe Metropolitan Opera as he prepares to perform there as part of an orchestra tour this summer.

title: The Visual Thing
description: There are lots of things I miss about the late, great graphic designer Alan Fletcher, but the thing I miss the most is arguing with him about design. Some of our most enjoyable arguments involved how to explain design to the 99 percent of the population that Alan pityingly described as civilians  in other words, those of us who arent lucky enough to be designers.

title: Fed Reviews Find Errors in Oversight of Citigroup
description: WASHINGTON  Citigroup ran into trouble under the noses of federal regulators. But even after taxpayers rescued the financial giant, regulators failed to monitor the company adequately, according to reviews by the Federal Reserve.

title: One Museum Tour, With Everything!
description: Dan Rossi, the lone survivor of the notorious hot dog wars outside the Metropolitan Museum of Art, takes a break from his grill, to give his own inimitable take on the art inside.

title: Building a Green Economy
description: If you listen to climate scientists  and despite the relentless campaign to discredit their work, you should  it is long past time to do something about emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases. If we continue with business as usual, they say, we are facing a rise in global temperatures that will be little short of apocalyptic. And to avoid that apocalypse, we have to wean our economy from the use of fossil fuels, coal above all.

title: Kobe Bryants Contract Extension
description: The Lakers took Kobe Bryant off the market last week, signing their franchise player to a three-year extension on Friday. Bryant had the option to become an unrestricted free agent this summer and join players like LeBron James on the open market. Instead he chose to lock in with the Lakers through the 2013-14 season.

title: Speaking at the Alcohol Convention
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: You know what happened in Las Vegas today? Sarah Palin, former governor of Alaska, was speaking at the alcohol convention in Las Vegas, Nev. Because, I mean, lets face it, nothing says family values like gambling and liquor.

title: 162,000 Jobs
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: Well, the Labor Department reported that the economy added 162,000 jobs last month, all of them bodyguards for Tiger Woods.

title: G.M.s $4.3 Billion Loss Masks Progress
description: DETROIT  The first detailed financial report from General Motors since its bankruptcy showed a company that has largely stanched the hemorrhaging in its day-to-day business, but is still cleaning up problems left over from its collapse last year.

title: Decoder Online Interview: Ad Age Columnist Bob Garfield Types a Final -30-
description: For the past 25 years, Bob Garfield has written the AdReview column for Advertising Age, buton Monday he filed for the last time. AdReview was a witty and sometimes withering deconstruction of all manner of advertising campaigns that had many fans. But Mr. Garfield said he was hanging it up, in part, because, if my grand apocalyptic theories about advertising and media are correct, thats a lot of my eggs in a couple of quickly disintegrating baskets.

title: Blackstone Invests in Worlds Most-Read Paper
description: Talk all you want about the structural decline of the industry, at least somebody thinks newspapers are a good investment.

title: How Buying a Truck Can Create Cash Flow
description: April 15 is drawing closer, and somehow it doesnt seem as scary as usual  at least not to those of us who werent very profitable last year. But if youre planning to make money this year, you might want to think ahead.

title: Building Webs of Support for People With B.D.D. and Eating Disorders
description: Overview | What do you know about psychiatric disorders that cause people to obsess over a physical feature? How can a community of parents, peers, teachers, doctors and psychiatric professionals best help and support someone with one of these disorders? In this lesson, students reflect on stories of teenagers with body dysmorphic disorder, or B.D.D., and eating disorders. By drawing and discussing support webs around each story, groups investigate the disorders from the perspectives of the individual affected and the people in their lives.

title: Video | The Making of Hedge Fun
description: Those beautiful photos in the cover story of the April 11th Spring issue of T Design, Hedge Fun, didnt take themselves. As this exclusive video demonstrates, behind the scenes and on-set, a small army of creative people, including the photographer Ilan Rubin and the set designer Stefan Beckman, worked away to create just the right composition, backdrop and lighting, among other things. But if the photos themselves look effortless, thats exactly the point. See our cover story here.

title: Net Neutrality: Not Just a Nerd Issue
description: The U.S. Court of Appeals ruled that the FCC overstepped its bounds in telling Comcast it could not regulate bandwidth use. So what if your Internet provider could charge you for what you use?

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Lost Watch: Desmond Agonistes
description: Warning: This post contains spoilers.

title: On Eating Sustainable Fish
description: Casson Trenor, who works with Greenpeace on seafood issues, dropped by the Times the other day, and we sat and chatted for a while. My main question for him was, What are people supposed to do? Servers in restaurants and clerks in supermarkets are usually ignorant of what theyre serving and selling.

title: G.M.s $4.3 Billion Loss Masks Progress
description: General Motors said Wednesday that it lost $4.3 billion in the six months after emerging from bankruptcy protection, but that it had positive cash flow of $1 billion in that period, The New York Timess Nick Bunkley reported.

title: Pressure Builds on Greece as Europe Delays Details on Crisis Aid
description: With investors becoming increasingly worried about the failure so far of European officials to agree on the terms for loans to Greece, the main banks in Athens added another concern Wednesday by turning to the Greek government for more financial support.

title: Court to FCC: Back Off on Net Neutrality
description: As Edward Wyatt wrote on Wednesday, a federal court ruled that the F.C.C. overstepped by telling Comcast it could not limit the amount of broadband available to certain heavy users.

title: Atlanta Symphony and Dallas Opera Appoint New Leaders
description: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and the Dallas Opera have appointed new executive leaders, the organizations announced Wednesday.

title: For Writers, a Less Lonely Life
description: Remember when book writing used to be a solitary experience? If you needed feedback, youd e-mail (or fax or mail) a few pages to a trusted friend and hope that he or she wouldnt trash your efforts.

title: New Tools to Build Your Own Credit Card
description: In late 2007, Capital One introduced a card customization tool it called Card Lab, where customers could chose certain combinations of rates, fees and rewards and customize the look of their cards.

title: Toyota Chief Blames Communication for Crisis
description: Toyotas chief executive, Akio Toyoda, told investment analysts on Wednesday the company felt communication was to blame for the crisis surrounding the company, not defects on its cars.

title: Madman, Perhaps; Survivor, Definitely
description: DENNIS HOPPER  actor, filmmaker, photographer, art collector, world-class burnout, first-rate survivor  never blew it. Unlike the villains and freaks he has played over the decades  the psycho with the mommy complex in Blue Velvet, the mad bomber with the grudge in Speed  he has made it through the good, the bad and some spectacularly terrible times. He rode out the golden age of Hollywood by roaring into a new movie era with Easy Rider. He hung out with James Dean, played Elizabeth Taylors son, acted for Quentin Tarantino. He has been rich and infamous, lost and found, the next big thing, the last man standing.

title: Herald Square, 8:38 A.M.
Video of Protests in Kyrgyzstan
description: Updated | 10:30 p.m. As my colleague Clifford Levy reports, opposition protesters appear to have overthrown the government of Kyrgyzstan for the second time in five years after riot police officers fired on demonstrators on Wednesday.

title: Elles Carol Smith Jumps Ship to Cond Nast
description: Carol Smith, the star senior vice president and chief brand officer at Elle who helped wedge the magazine into shows like Project Runway and The City, is jumping ship for Cond Nast. There, she will oversee Bon Apptit and what is left of the Gourmet brand as vice president and publishing director for the epicurean group, a newly created position.

title: New Clancy Thriller Contains the Sum of All Characters
description: Super groups: They worked for Blind Faith, the Avengers, Them Crooked Vultures and the 1992 mens United States Olympic basketball team, so why not Tom Clancy? On Wednesday, Penguin Group said it would publish a new thriller by Mr. Clancy that would bring together many of his best-known characters from his last-quarter century of literary output. The new novel, called Dead Or Alive and written with his frequent collaborator Grant Blackwood, will feature the characters Jack Ryan, the C.I.A. analyst-turned-American president; his son and fellow analyst, Jack Ryan Jr.; the C.I.A. operative John Clark; his apprentice, Ding Chavez; and the agency executive Mary Pat Foley. In a statement, Penguin said the novel will pit them against The Emir, a sadistic killer who has masterminded the most vicious terrorist attacks on the West and who has eluded capture by the worlds armed forces and law enforcement agencies. Dead Or Alive will be released by the G. P. Putnams Sons imprint of Penguin on Dec. 7.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by David Shields
description: David Shields is the author, most recently, of Reality Hunger: A Manifesto.

title: Greenspan Hearing Goes Dark
description: From Sewell Chan, a DealBook colleague in Washington:

title: MSNBC Returns to Satellite Radio
description: Finally, MSNBC is back on satellite radio.

title: How Much Will the High-Risk Pools Cost?
description: As attention shifts from passage of health care legislation to its implementation, we will take the next few weeks to answer readers questions here in Prescriptions. Submit your question to health_feedback@nytimes.com. You may also submit videos. Please remember that we cannot respond to all questions and that we cannot offer personal advice.

title: Tupac Shakur, Immortalized Again
description: CLEVELAND

title: Quote Unquote | Cache and Carry
description: Olivia Palermo describes the exhilaration of purchasing her first Herms Birkin to Vogue UK. Mean girls alert!

title: I.M.F. Says West Bank Economic Growth Is Imperiled by Israel and Arab States
description: JERUSALEM  The International Monetary Fund is preparing a report on the Palestinian economy that praises the actions of the West Bank government and the large donations of Western countries, especially European ones, but argues that healthy recent growth rates are imperiled by the parties that claim to have the most at stake  Israel and the Arab states.

title: The Proper Place for Fights and Song
description: It seems as though there was a time when, if someone started performing or making a scene on the subway, you could be sure that he or she wanted you either to move to another car, or to part with a few dollar bills.

title: Not a Morsel for Vegans at Cabreras Masters Feast
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  It is an annual dinner at a very long rectangular table, a custom begun in 1952, when Ben Hogan suggested it might be fun to get all the living Masters champions together for dinner before the tournament. So at a famously exclusive golf club, a more selective society, one based on golf achievement, meets on the Tuesday of the first fullweek of each April.

title: The Complications of Measuring Water Use
description: In The New York Times on Wednesday, I reported about the Carbon Disclosure Projects new campaign to get global corporations to report their water use.

title: Greenspan Again Defends Tenure as Fed Chairman
description: Alan Greenspan on Wednesday defended his record as chairman of the Federal Reserve, testifying that any notion of inadequacy within the regulators actions in the run-up to the subprime mortgage crisis was unverifiable.

title: Behind Obamas Cool
description: In 2004, Congresswoman Jan Schakowsky of Illinois attended a White House event wearing the campaign pin of her states candidate for the United States Senate. When she saw President Bush do a double take at the one word on her pin, she assured him that it spelled Obama, not Osama. Bush shrugged: I dont know him. She answered, You will. Not long after this, Barack Obama gave the keynote address at the Democratic National Convention, and many people suddenly knew him. It happened so fast that he seemed to come out of nowhere. The truth was more intriguing  he had come out of everywhere.

title: Weighing an Obama Plan to End a Mideast Logjam
description: WASHINGTON  Two weeks ago, Gen. James L. Jones, the national security adviser, was holding a meeting at the White House with a high-powered array of his predecessors when President Obama dropped in.

title: UConn and Messi, a Level Above
description: That the two shows of dominance came on the same day, in two vastly different sports and in two distinct parts of the world, was nothing but a coincidence, but at least we can sit back and appreciate the spectacle of the soccer phenomenon Lionel Messi and the Connecticut womens basketball team with the same part of our brains. Its the part that forms the word wow.

title: Bernanke Says Nation Must Take Action Soon to Shape Fiscal Future
description: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned Wednesday that an aging American population posed fiscal challenges for the United States.

title: Updated: Classroom Resources on Mining Disasters
description: Weve updated yesterdays post by adding more resources, and by quoting a teacher from North Carolina who wrote to us with a simple but powerful idea for how to help kids connect this news with their own lives.

title: Concrete Executive Gets Jail Time; Suicide Attempt Delays Sentencing of Owner
description: Updated, 12:50 p.m. | The sentencing of two executives of Testwell Laboratories, once the leading concrete testing company in New York, was reduced to one on Wednesday, after the disclosure that one of the officials again tried to kill himself.

title: Mad Men Say a Boozy Bye Bye
description: How badly are we jonesing for new episodes of Mad Men? Bad enough that we sat through almost all of this video (which we were pointed to by the good folks at Vulture) in which that shows cast and crew  many with beer bottles in hand  say farewell to their third season by singing along to Ann-Margrets performance of Bye Bye Birdie, which played a crucial role on the series last year.

title: Back to the Future
description: The early chapters of Brian Lutzs Knoll: A Modernist Universe (Rizzoli) read like a portrait of the Greatest Generation, only with really cool furniture. Hans Knoll, an entrepreneur from a well-known German furniture-manufacturing family, and Florence Schust, an architect whose education brought her in contact with greats like Eliel Saarinen and Mies van der Rohe, married in 1946 and quickly turned Hanss small company into a design powerhouse. They recruited people like Harry Bertoia and Eero Saarinen to design groundbreaking furniture, reintroduced classics like Miess Barcelona chair and started the Knoll Planning Unit, which under Florences direction revolutionized office interiors. Hans died in a car accident in 1955, but Florence stayed for another 10 years. Knoll after the Knolls became a more corporate place, concentrating heavily on office systems but still caring enough about furniture to commission pieces from a whos who of design and architecture.

title: Pressed to Act, Karzai Fires Election Monitors
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Under enormous pressure from Western governments, President Hamid Karzai ousted Afghanistans top two elections officials, who were seen as sanctioning the widespread fraud that favored him during last years presidential race.

title: TimesCast | April 7, 2010
description: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Wednesday.  Today a look at antigovernment protests in Kyrgyzstan and Thailand, and the strategy behind Eliot Spitzer's comeback.

title: What Were Reading
A Man, a Guitar, a Lap in a Ferrari F10 Formula One Car
description: If you divide the time I spend on YouTube into a pie chart, the two largest slices would represent Formula One videos and videos of guitar theatrics. At long last, the twain have met. In the above video (via 0-60mag.com), a man replicates a Ferrari F10 engine with his Gibson Explorer guitar. And he doesnt just bust out a few revs. He actually performs a lap  matching the gear changes with a video of Fernando Alonso doing a lap in his Ferrari. It might not be as impressive as the Renault team playing God Save the Queen or We Are the Champions on its Formula One engine, but its pretty close.

title: Jersey Boys Matinee Canceled
description: The Wednesday matinee of the Broadway musical Jersey Boys at the August Wilson Theater has been canceled, a spokesman for the show said, in the aftermath of an electrical fire that took place on West 52nd Street on Tuesday. A buildup of carbon monoxide caused the underground fire and a manhole explosion, prompting the evacuation of several buildings in the area and causing Tuesday nights performance of Jersey Boys to be canceled. According to a statement from the spokesman, the Jersey Boys producers were notified by authorities that it would not be possible to have a performance on Wednesday afternoon. The problem should be solved this afternoon to make sure there is a performance tonight, the statement said. Exchanges for the matinee performance can be arranged at the point of purchase.

title: Americans Still Not Confident in Banks
description: Even as the economy, and the financial sector, have shown rapid recovery, Americans confidence in banks remains at a historic low, according to Gallup.

title: Graphic Content | The Designer as Activist
description: Steven Heller, a former art director at The New York Times, is a co-chair of the MFA Design Department at the School of Visual Arts and a blogger and author.

title: Comeback Deja Vu, or One of a Kind?
description: No longer master of the universe or even of his own image, Tiger Woods has succeeded in remaining the talk of the Masters in this season and situation unlike any other.

title: A Boom Box for Your Phone, Minus the Boom
description: Livespeakr, a popular portable speaker system for the iPhone, is expanding its portfolio. It is now claiming to the be the first and only such system compatible with the Google Nexus One, Palm Pre and Pre Plus and Droid smartphones.

title: Raiding the Refrigerator, but Still Asleep
description: Shirley Koecheler, 54, has been a sleepwalker for as long as she can remember. But it wasnt until she got married that she started eating in her sleep, too. Shed wander into the kitchen  eyes open but asleep  and binge on junk food.

title: Binge Eating During Sleep
description: Most people have heard of sleep disorders and eating disorders. But what about an eating disorder that shows up while youre asleep?

title: Mayor Frets as New Yorkers Ignore Census
description: New York is a city of procrastinators.

title: Director and Choreographer Caught Between Phantom Sequel and Catch Me if You Can
description: Now that the Broadway production of Andrew Lloyd Webbers musical Love Never Dies has been delayed until spring 2011, the director Jack OBrien and the choreographer Jerry Mitchell appear to face a logistical dilemma in balancing that show with their other new Broadway-bound musical, Catch Me if You Can.

title: When the Bullys Victim Fights Back
description: One of the points several of you made during the Motherlode discussions about bullying is that sometimes the lines become blurred. What counts as bullying? Is the threat of physical violence required? Or are sniggering and teasing more than enough? How young is too young to be considered a bully? Is excluding a child from a social circle bullying? Do all classmates have to be friends?

title: Mapping the Dark Heart of Strindberg
description: LONDON
