title: Freighter on Great Barrier Reef Has Punctured Fuel Tank
description: HONG KONG  A Chinese coal freighter aground on the Great Barrier Reef has at least one punctured fuel tank, prompting a delicate effort to transfer oil within the ship to tanks that are still intact, Australian officials announced on Wednesday.

title: Coaching in the Best of All Worlds
description: SAN ANTONIO

title: Squeaky (Bicycle) Wheels Heard on Proposal to Raise Cellphone Fines
description: A California State Senate committee approved a bill on Tuesday to increase the fines for driving while using a hand-held cellphone, but a provision that would have held cyclists equally accountable for following the law was scaled back in the wake of cyclist complaints. Distracted driving is already against state law; distracted bicycling is not. Yet.

title: Wi-Fi Woes for iPad?
description: Some owners of the new Apple iPad reported problems with its Wi-Fi connection right out of the box.

title: Soft Treatments in Tough Times
description: A SOFT WEEK  In these dial-it-back times, perhaps youve gone ages without a facial or a massage. Starting April 12, Spa Week, a twice-a-year nationwide event, features $50 treatments. Eight hundred spas are onboard, up from 25 a decade ago. Perhaps the recession is to thank for the addition of luxury spas like Exhale and Clarins Skin Spa. A list of participants is at spaweek.com.

title: Tanning Bed Hygiene
description: Repeat visits to tanning beds can lead to cancer and premature aging, the same way that overexposure to ultraviolet light in the sunlit world can. But lying in a tanning bed may also lead to skin infections, according to a study published in the Journal of American Academy of Dermatology.

title: Awake for Breast Implants? If You Wish
description: SOON after Jane Z. had her B-cup breasts augmented for the first time, she realized she hadnt gone big enough. So the second time, Jane Z., who preferred to not have her last name mentioned, was thrilled that she could choose her implant size during surgery.

title: Usher Knocks Justin Bieber From Top of Chart
description: The upper ranks of the Billboard chart this week belong to Usher. His new album, Raymond vs. Raymond (Jive)  his real name is Usher Raymond IV  is No. 1, and Justin Bieber, his 16-year-old protg, is standing strong at No. 2. Raymond vs. Raymond sold 329,000 copies in its first week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Mr. Biebers album My World 2.0 (Island), which was No. 1 on last weeks chart, fell one spot in its second week out, with 290,000 sales. (Mr. Biebers EP, My World, released in November, fell three spots this week to No. 8, with 63,000.)

title: Its Always Sunny on Our Channel, FX Tells Advertisers
description: The FX cable channel is reaching out to advertisers ahead of the 2010-11 season with a pitch centered on ratings growth as well as changes to its program lineup intended to help ratings growth.

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: British Airways Strikes on Hold, in Latest Talks
description: The union representing British Airways 13,500 flight attendants said Wednesday that talks with the airlines management this week had made serious progress toward resolving differences over wage cuts and changes to in-flight staffing. As a result, it is putting off plans for any further strikes following two costly walkouts last month.

title: Now Showing | Hooray for Nollywood
description: The photographer Pieter Hugo is no stranger to shocking and peculiar sights. His horrifying, arresting 2007 portrait series The Hyena & Other Men showcased Nigerian street performers posing alongside their exotic prey. In Nollywood, his latest body of work, currently on view at the Yossi Milo Gallery, Hugo once again focuses his camera on performers, only this time his subjects are actors from Nigerias surprisingly robust film industry, which is apparently the third largest in the world. The photographs dont allude to any films in particular, but rather explore some of the industrys more popular themes, like mysticism, war and the supernatural. The results are often menacing if not grotesque, and they blur the line between documentary and fiction. In one photo, a trio of zombielike children await their next cue, and, in another a well-dressed man proudly stands, camera ready, holding the entrails of a slain ox.

title: U.S. Soccer Puts Youth Development in Reynas Hands
description: Claudio Reyna is coming back, not as a player but as the youth technical director for the United States Soccer Federation. The former captain of the national team will coordinate the development of young players in the U.S., from the recreational to the promising.

title: Now Playing: The Little Big Screen
description: The new HTC HD2 says it has the biggest screen of any phone in the United States, 4.3 inches measured diagonally. It has given the phone cinematic aspirations.

title: How Lenders Overlook the Warning Signs of ID Theft
description: Despite all the new fraud alert tools and increased awareness of the perils of identity theft, incidence of the crime remains at 2003 levels, with about 10 million Americans falling victim every year.

title: Redefining What It Means to Work Hard
description: David Brooks: Gail, to wrench me out of my fiscal funk last week, you allowed me to talk about sports and sex, in the person of Tiger Woods. I want you to know how much that helped.

title: Theater Company Gets $800,000 for Traveling Classics Project
description: The New York-based Aquila Theater Company has received $800,000 from the National Endowment for the Humanities to support new productions of classic Greek works that will be performed for veterans groups and in rural and urban locales, the theater group announced on Wednesday.

title: 2010: Lamb Tagine With Green Olives
description: By Andrew Carmellini, the chef and an owner of Locanda Verde in Manhattan. If you can get your hands on ras el hanout, you can use it instead of making the spice mixture. And no worries if you dont have a tagine  a covered Dutch oven will work just fine.

title: 1980: Spicy Orange Salad, Moroccan Style
description: This recipe appeared in an article in The Times by Craig Claiborne.

title: April in Virginia
description: 9:43 p.m. | Updated Gov. Robert F. McDonnell has apologized for his major omission of any mention of slavery when he revived Aprils designation as Confederate History Month in Virginia.

title: A.N.C. Issues Caution in Singing Polarizing Songs
description: JOHANNESBURG  The governing African National Congress on Wednesday told its members to be circumspect in singing songs from the anti-apartheid struggle, retreating from its earlier defense of a contentious song  Shoot the Boer  that in recent days has become associated with the killing of a white supremacist leader.

title: Mens Suits for Under $1,000
description: Stylish upgrades are giving the cost-conscious suit new appeal.

title: No Rubber Stamp for the Mayor
description: If you assumed that the new commission to revise the city charter would be a mere rubber stamp for the wishes of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, think again  at least for now.

title: 2010: Moms Florida Avocado and Orange Salad (Adjusted)
description: By Andrew Carmellini, the chef and an owner of Locanda Verde in Manhattan. 2 Valencia or navel oranges1 Florida avocado or 2 regular avocadosJuice of 1 lime1/2 small red onion, thinly sliced 1 scant tablespoon dried oregano, preferably Mexican1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil, plus some for sprinkling1/4 teaspoon salt1 teaspoon of your favorite hot sauceHandful cilantro leaves. 1. Segment the oranges by slicing off the ends with a sharp knife. Put the orange on one end and, with a small, sharp knife, cut off the peel and white pith. Segment the orange by slicing between the membranes. Remove the segments and drop into a bowl. Squeeze the juice out of the remaining membranes into the bowl with the segments. Reserve the juice. 2. With a dinner knife (not the sharpest knife in your kitchen), cut each halved avocado half lengthwise into segments, cutting through the meat to (not into) the skin. Then cut around the outside of the avocado meat and, using the knife, push the pieces out of the skin and into the bowl with the oranges. 3. Add the lime juice, red onion, oregano, olive oil, salt, hot sauce and the reserved orange juice. Using a large spoon, mix all the ingredients together so that everything is coated and well combined. 4. Remove to a serving bowl. Garnish with cilantro leaves and drizzle with more olive oil. Serves 4 as an appetizer or antipasto.

title: Recipe Redux: Spicy Orange Salad, Moroccan Style, 1980
description: I have never seen an orange salad on a menu or been served one at someones house. And now that I have tasted one, Im outraged. Moroccan orange salad is one of the best salads in the world  sweet citrus juices countered with pungent onion and dueling kicks of spices and acidity.

title: Why Identity Theft Is Still a Big Problem
description: Here is one possible reason why the incidence of identity theft remains at 2003 levels: Lenders are too willing to extend credit to just about anybody, according to a new report covered by the Bits blog in this post, How Lenders Overlook the Warning Signs of ID Theft.

title: Still Searching for West Virginia Miners
description: Gov. Joe Manchin III of West Virginia speaks with The Today Show about the families of the lost coal miners and their hope despite poor odds.

title: Mercedes Deal With Renault-Nissan Gets Mixed Reviews
description: It was a case of competing quotes when Daimler and the Renault-Nissan Alliance announced a strategic partnership in Brussels on Wednesday morning.

title: Abuse Case Forced Bishop in Norway to Quit in 09
description: ROME  In May, the leader of central Norways small Roman Catholic population unexpectedly resigned with little explanation. The Vatican on Wednesday said why: He sexually abused a boy in the early 1990s.

title: April 11  17
description: Dance

title: Will We Get a V.A.T.?
description: Everybody on the right seems convinced that a value-added tax is on its way. Sometimes this conviction is framed in alarmist, look what the Democrats are going to do next terms: See, for instance, this Allahpundit post today, following up on this Charles Krauthammer column from last month. Sometimes its couched as advice to President Obama, delivered more in sorrow than in anger, explaining what hell have to do if he wants to pay for the new entitlement hes created: See Glenn Hubbard in The Wall Street Journal, for instance, or Greg Mankiw in the Times. And sometimes its presented as an idea that the right-of-center should learn to live with, provided that its part of a grand bargain of some sort: See James Pethokoukiss ideal scenario, or Mankiws thoughts on the fiscal commission, or Tyler Cowens provocative case for a V.A.T.

title: The Concierge | The Kiddie Classics
description: Christine Muhlke, T Magazines food editor and de facto concierge, is at your service. Have a dining or imbibing quandary for her? Leave your question in the comments section below.
Correction: An earlier version of this article misstated President Reagan's middle initial. It is Ronald W. Reagan, not Ronald R. Reagan.

title: Alcott Recalls Her Augusta Moment, Kept Quiet
description: If ever the lords of Augusta National were going to add a woman to their membership ranks, this week might have been their idea of perfect timing, when they could have snuck her in under everyones Tiger-centric radar.

title: China Is Eager to Bring High-Speed Rail Expertise to the U.S.
description: BEIJING  Nearly 150 years after American railroads brought in thousands of Chinese laborers to build rail lines across the West, China is poised once again to play a role in American rail construction. But this time, it would be an entirely different role: supplying the technology, equipment and engineers to build high-speed rail lines.

title: Reaction on Military Blogs to the WikiLeaks Video
description: As much as in the general public, military blogs have reacted with passion to the released Wikileaks video of a 2007 Apache attack in Iraq. With more expertise than most viewers  as well as more empathy, even among those who felt the pilots acted improperly  they explored a range of issues: Were the people in the video carrying weapons? Is Wikileaks a security risk? Did the military fail in not explaining the video more fully to the media? Should journalists operate so closely to insurgents?

title: Big Hair Is Everywhere
description: Both Hillary Clinton and Snooki sport the voluminous hairstyle.

title: Financial Tuneup: The Home Equity Loan as Emergency Fund
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: Payne, Augustas Chairman, Chastises Woods
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The annual address at the Masters by the chairman of Augusta National Golf Club is usually a routine, even humdrum, affair. The principal topic of conversation is often something like turf management or the speed of the greens. But on Wednesday, Billy Payne, who has led the club since 2006, did something unprecedented. Without prodding, he singled out Tiger Woods in a harsh rebuke.

title: Is Dancing Showing That Idol Has Feet of Clay?
description: The chops-licking over the declining performance of Foxs American Idol may grow more intense in the wake of that perennial powerhouses ratings Tuesday night.

title: Can You Hear Me Now?
description: We live on a quiet suburban street. We hear birds and the rushing water of a creek. We leave eggs out after breakfast and watch foxes come by and snatch them in their jaws. Creatures of modernity, we do occasionally hear a jet overhead or a distant car. A neighbor's children play in their backyard. This is all good.

title: Travel Deals: Marriott Sale in the Carolinas
description: Dreaming of a weekend in Chapel Hill or a budget getaway to Charleston?

title: Ellen Degeneres: Out of Place on Idol
description: To the editor:

title: Inspiring a New Generation
description: To the Editor:

title: Movie Criticism: A Film Shows Demise
description: To the Editor:

title: City Shelters to Stop Sending Homeless to Boarding Houses
description: The Bloomberg administration promised on Wednesday to end its longstanding practice of encouraging homeless people to move to crowded, illegal boarding houses once they leave the shelter system.

title: Thumbs Up!
description: To the Editor:

title: Unlikely R.I.T. Skates Among Redwoods in Frozen Four
description: HENRIETTA, N.Y.  Some players meet weekly for meals at a Mexican restaurant, then engage in spirited bouts of Golden Tee Golf, a video game. And everyone wears some sort of playoff beard, from sparse and patchy to thick and scratchy.

title: Rooney Returns but Manchester United Falters
description: 4:39 p.m. |Update

title: Eliot Spitzer: Milestones in an Ambitious Career
description: An interactive timeline of Eliot Spitzer's rise to power and his turbulent term as governor.

title: Spitzers Long Road to Redemption
description: HERE is Eliot Spitzer on MSNBC with the host Ed Schultz, railing against fallen Wall Street titans who regain power (absolutely insane). There he is on Foxs Good Day New York, taking swipes at Andrew Cuomo (he has to answer the hard questions) and Senator Kirsten Gillibrand (I dont like politicians who vacillate). Hes lunching regularly at power restaurants like Michaels (telling the waiter, Silda wants me to have the salad), holding hands with his wife at charity galas, attending a private salon at Tina Browns. Writing his twice-monthly Slate column, The Best Policy. Teaching undergraduates at the City College of New York, lecturing at Harvard about ethics, parsing the meaning of love on BigThink.com.

title: A New Twist: Hockey on an Indoor Football Field
description: DETROIT  It has been a big deal to move hockey games outside, like the N.H.L.s Winter Classic or various college games played in football stadiums.

title: When Mom Says a Bad Word
description: Vivian Manning-Schaffel is an editor for Momlogic.com and blogs at TheMadMom.com, which means she has spent a lot of time thinking about good and responsible parenting. She also is the mother of a 1-year-old daughter and a 5-year-old son and has vowed not to make certain mistakes that her own mother made decades ago.

title: On Dance: From Broadway to the Met
description: The final new production of the Metropolitan Opera season, Rossinis Armida, opens on Monday. The sorceress of the title seduces men, including the crusader Rinaldo, but the story is essentially about a powerful woman who chooses revenge over love. There are powerful women involved in the production too. The director is the theater veteran Mary Zimmerman, Rene Fleming is the star, and, also crucial, the choreographer is Graciela Daniele.

title: In Focus | Skye Parrott
description: The photography exhibition Younger Than Ill Be opens today at BAMart in Brooklyn and runs through May 23. Curated by Skye Parrott, it includes works by Jack Pierson, David Armstrong, Larry Clark and Weegee, to name but a few. Parrott is a photographer in her own right, as well as the creative director of Dossier Magazine, Dossierjournal.com and a woman about town. I caught up with Parrott  who is as lovely as she is busy  to talk about the new show, the new iPad and New York when she was young.

title: Two Ex-Players Leverage Connections in N.F.L. Workers Comp Cases
description: As workers compensation lawyers go, Ron Mix and Mel Owens understand their clients problems better than most.

title: A Tale of 2 Courses  Both in Augusta
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Since 1928, the Augusta Municipal Golf Course has been the Masters host citys affordable venue for 18 holes.

title: Modernist Dollhouses
description: Miniature modern furnishings created by two enthusiasts.

title: Mr. Broadway Storms Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON

title: Rethinking High School Education in Oakland
description: Its almost deadline, and Christopher Scheers journalism class at Skyline High in Oakland is working feverishly on the upcoming issue of The Oracle, their school paper.

title: More On The Exchange Rate And The Trade Balance
description: A bit more on the fallacy  which both Steve Roach and, Im a bit shocked to say, Joe Stiglitz  have fallen into: the belief that appreciating the renminbi cant reduce the US trade deficit unless US savings increase.

title: From Apex of Hot Dog World, Even Pyramids Look Small
description: In the long-simmering hot dog wars outside the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the grill smoke has cleared and  for the moment, and probably not much longer  Dan Rossi is the last vendor standing.

title: Three for the Price of One (And Still Free!)
description: Welcome to the new Diners Journal. Look around, make yourself at home. The first thing you might notice is that we spruced up the place a bit. Diners Journal has been around since early 2006 and to tell the truth, it was starting to look a little worn around the edges.

title: Turmoil in Kyrgyzstan
description: Our show opens with fierce images from the protests that appear to have overthrown the government of Kyrgyzstan, an important American ally in Central Asia (Slides 1, 2, 3 and 4). Violence between riot police officers and opposition demonstrators on Wednesday killed at least 17 people. The countrys president, Kurmanbek Bakiyev, left the capital, Bishkek, on his plane, and the opposition declared that it was forming its own government.

title: Debating CNN
description: Slates Troy Patterson has a rejoinder to my column on CNN in which he argues that the network is basically doing the best job it can, and we should all appreciate its fine work as a newsgathering institution rather than asking it to be something it isnt:

title: In Sleepless Nights, a Hope for Treating Depression
description: Is there anything good about insomnia? Could there possibly be any upside to a long, torturous sleepless night?

title: Theater Talkback: Politics and Show Tunes
description: Were politicians born to sing and dance? I dont mean the old song-and-dance that this breed is regularly said to perform, but stuff-strutting, spotlighted numbers that involve high kicks and high notes.

title: Austrian Followup
description: As predicted, many of the comments to my Austrian economics post are of the form Well, of course employment rises when investment is expanding, and falls when the investment is falling  in the first case the economy is booming while in the second its slumping.

title: Scrabble Trickster? Challenge!
description: The news that proper nouns were going to be allowed in Scrabble (no!) was enough to distract some of us from our deadlines today.

title: Birds And Bees Blogging
description: There have been many stories about the decline of the birth rate in 2008, with almost all attributing it to the recession. But James Trussell raises an interesting point: doesnt it take nine months from conception to birth? Abortion aside, to reduce births in the first three quarters of 2008 in response to a recession that started in Dec. 2007 would have taken pretty impressive rational expectations.

title: Twitter Needs More Filters
description: Twitter users only really have one kind of filter: people. You follow someone, or you un-follow them.

title: Second Attempt to Put School Back on Chopping Block
description: Two weeks after a judge said the citys Department of Education could not close 19 schools as planned, one of the schools is back on the citys agenda to be shuttered.

title: It Isnt Easy Building Green
description: Michelle Kaufmann, an architect, remembers leading Laura Bush, the first lady, on a personal tour of one of her prefabricated homes, pointing out its on-demand water heater and explaining how the graywater system recycled waste water. It was May 2006, and a full-scale model of Ms. Kaufmanns Glidehouse design had been erected at the National Building Museum in Washington. It was, Ms. Kaufmann said, one of the high points for her design-build company, mkDesigns.

title: Profile in Style | Jeanne Greenberg Rohatyn
description: The New York art mavens taste runs the gamut from bohemian to glam. More

title: Five Questions for Donna Murphy
description: Anyone Can Whistle is to musical theater what Tron is to film: a beloved, misunderstood work with merits that have been revealed with time.

title: April Showers Extend Ski Season Out West
description: While much of the country is basking in summerlike weather, snow country is celebrating April showers  the snowy sort  with extended ski seasons.

title: That Term Paper Might Be Graded in Bangalore
description: With all the services that are being transferred overseas, should we be surprised that an enterprising company has sought to tantalize university professors with the prospect of having the grading of their students term papers outsourced?

title: H.P. Sees a Revolution in Memory Chip
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Hewlett-Packard scientists on Thursday are to report advances in the design of a new class of diminutive switches capable of replacing transistors as computer chips shrink closer to the atomic scale.

title: With Arms Pact, Disarmament Challenge Remains
description: PRAGUE  President Obama came to this medieval city last spring to lay out an audacious vision of a world without nuclear weapons. A year later, he arrives back here on Thursday to sign a treaty with Russia that envisions a world with thousands of nuclear weapons.

title: United and US Airways Said to Be in Merger Talks
description: 7:36 p.m. | Corrected The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, and US Airways are in talks to merge, in a potential deal that would create one of the worlds largest airlines, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

title: Q & A With Andrew Scrivani (Round 1)
description: Q.

title: Unhappy Medium Searches for Clarity
description: Whida Peru, the flamboyant figure in the lace bodysuit and flowery silk wrap, is having serious boyfriend trouble. Her beloved Juannie is not communicating as he used to. Despite Whidas effusive endearments and desperate entreaties  not to mention the new outfit she just bought him  Juannie shows marked signs of wanting to leave Whida altogether. You must let me go, he cries, again and again.

title: Stripping Down the Web for a Slow Connection
description: Dealing

title: Facade of Garage Wall Collapses on West Side
description: A facade of a parking garage wall on Freedom Place at West 68th Street, near Riverside Drive, fell onto the sidewalk Wednesday afternoon, a city official said. There were no reports of injuries.

title: Paper Magazine Editor Is Powerful, but No Power Snob
description: DOES anyone remember that, long before Madonna was a zillionairess with a fake British accent, she used to dance at the Roxy with a posse of Latino b-boys? Kim Hastreiter does. Are there many who recall when Jean-Michel Basquiats paintings, created in a basement on manic cocaine binges, were being sold for $200 on the street at what his dealer termed a fire sale? Well, there is Ms. Hastreiter. Are there two people alive who celebrated the bicentennial by driving cross-country from California in a Dodge truck called the Dragon Wagon to storm New York City with Joey Arias riding shotgun? There is just one.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: iPad Apps and Casual Gaming
description: In this weeks Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein catches up with Jenna Wortham, the Times technology reporter whos been covering app development, to discover how the people who create iPad apps reacted to finally getting their hands on the new device. Most of them had to design their apps without seeing the iPad or testing on it. While some rushed their products to Apples App Store before the iPads release, others decided to wait it out.

title: Pause: Bristol Palin and Teen Pregnancy
description: Bristol Palin, the daughter of former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska and herself a mom, has made a public service announcement for the Candies Foundation that asks teens to think twice before they have sex.

title: Looking Good in Three Figures
description: BACK in the day, there were many choice slurs to run a fellow down, but somehow nothing was more damningly dismissive than to sneer that he wore a cheap suit. Then, of course, there came a new generation for whom the very term suit, cheap or no, was an even worse insult: a middle-management man who couldnt think outside the boxy garb of Big Business.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. The Museum of Modern Art has added the @ sign to its architecture and design collection; the iPads apostrophe key is difficult to find. Punctuation is going all diva on us.

title: Answers From a Hip-Hop Veteran
description: Following is the first set of answers from Jorge Pabon, a performer and choreographer known as Pop Master Fabel, who responded to questions about the history and culture of hip-hop.

title: Paul Sevignys Next Act
description: THIS is what we dont need, Paul Sevigny said, groaning as he glanced up at a queue of honking taxis clogging the street in front of his new restaurant, Kenmare, in a quiet stretch of NoLIta.

title: In This Electronic War, Momentum Shifts to the Underdog
description: Battlefield: Bad Company 2 is a better game than Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2.

title: Second School Building of Day Is Evacuated
description: On the first day back after along spring break, school officials at Public School 115 on West 177th Street in Washington Heights found that water damage had caused part of the ceiling in a couple of classrooms to tumble down. School officials were concerned about a potential asbestos contamination, so just after noon, the school was evacuated(making it the second school evacuation on Wednesday.)

title: Disappointment Is Rarely Kind, but It Makes for Catchy Tunes
description: Whoever the boys were, they did a number on Bethany Cosentino. Ms. Cosentino is the singer and steering force behind Best Coast, an offhandedly charming no-fi indie rock band focused almost exclusively, and talmudically, on the ones that got away.

title: Garment District Hothouse
description: IM going to have fun walking down the hall yelling, Bibhu! Bibhu! said Waris Ahluwalia, the designer of the jewelry collection House of Waris, on his first day in his new office at 209 West 38th Street in the heart of the garment district last Tuesday. Bibhu Mohapatra, an evening-wear designer, had moved into a space down the hall a week earlier, from where he could wave hello. Bibhu! This has the potential to get annoying.

title: For Designer Bargains, Step Into Their Closet
description: ON a recent foray for new spring clothes  a sundress, slouchy pants, a nautical-inspired top or two  I was determined not to break the bank.

title: Big Hair Returns, via New Jersey
description: SHOULD it be interpreted as a sign of the apocalypse, or just a really big trend, that both Hillary Clinton and Snooki have been accused of wearing Bumpits of late?

title: 19th-Century Classics, and Then a Little Samba
description: LONDON  Springtime in London has become a smorgasbord of world-class dance in recent years. This years range of visiting and resident companies is remarkable: Pina Bausch Tanztheater Wuppertal was at the Barbican Theater, Akram Khan will be seen at Sadlers Wells, the Royal Ballet is in residence at Covent Garden, and at the London Coliseum the succession of troupes will include the Mark Morris Dance Group, Birmingham Royal Ballet and Ballet Nacional de Espaa.

title: Navratilova Says She Has Breast Cancer
description: The retired tennis champion Martina Navratilova, who remains a remarkably active 53-year-old, said Wednesday that she was found to have noninvasive breast cancer in February and had undergone a lumpectomy, with radiation treatment to come in May.

title: Hot Spot Shortcut, in the Weeds
description: You want to hear a really scary statistic? Twenty-five percent.

title: Why Francona Is Sticking With Ortiz
description: BOSTON - The Red Sox have a left-handed hitter with a .212 average against left-handers since the start of the 2008 season. They also have a right-handed hitter with a .307 average against left-handers in the same time frame.

title: Hollywood Unites to Block Trading on Movie Box-Office Performance
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywoods advice for financial players who expect to start speculating on movie box-office receipts: Dont bet on it.

title: The Art of the Straddle: A Saxophonist Ranging at Will
description: The alto saxophonist David Binney upholds an agenda of indeterminacy. He doesnt swim in the jazz mainstream, but neither is he sworn to an established avant-garde. His music accommodates elements of funk and electronic music, but rarely accepts the known artifice of fusion. To some degree his in-betweenness is a signature, characteristic since his arrival in New York more than 20 years ago. Increasingly its also a common ideal among up-and-coming musicians, which attests to his stealth influence on the scene.

title: A Digital Camera That Swaps Lenses, Priced to Please
description: Any serious photographer can quickly point out the benefit of a digital camera with a large image sensor. Simply put, bigger sensors  not more pixels  yield better photos.

title: American Idol Ratings Hit a Low Mark
description: The chops-licking over the declining performance of Foxs American Idol may grow more intense in the wake of the Tuesday night ratings for that perennial powerhouse. Fewer people watched Idol on Tuesday (when the contestant Crystal Bowersox performed with the didgeridoo player Ernie Fields, both left) than watched ABCs Dancing With the Stars on Monday. (Dancing runs performance episodes on Mondays, with results on Tuesdays; Idol generally has performance on Tuesdays with results on Wednesdays.) And for a second consecutive week, in the category Fox cares most about  viewers between the ages of 18 and 49  Idol, if the Tuesday overnight ratings hold, will post its lowest number ever for a two-hour edition of the show. It will also be the lowest-rated Tuesday edition of the show since an hourlong episode on Aug. 13, 2002, in its first season, when the series played in the summer. Idol had a total audience of about 20.4 million on Tuesday, below the 21.2 million that Dancing averaged for its performance show on Monday. (The Dancing results on Tuesday averaged a total audience of 12.3 million.) But the Idol 7.1 rating among viewers 18 to 49 is what will be most noticed. That is down from a 7.7 a week ago and down from the 8.1 the show averaged for the three previous weeks. Of course, Idol is still the dominant show on television with those younger adults advertisers love. And the success of Dancing has to be tempered by its skew toward older viewers. This weeks Dancing results episode, when the astronaut Buzz Aldrin was blasted off the show, faced the Idol performance on Tuesday night and scored a modest 2.4 rating in the 18 to 49 group. More tellingly, almost 70 percent of its audience was over 50.

title: New Clancy Thriller Has All-Star Cast
description: Super groups: They worked for Blind Faith, the Avengers, Them Crooked Vultures and the 1992 mens United States Olympic basketball team, so why not Tom Clancy? On Wednesday Penguin Group said it would publish a new thriller by Mr. Clancy that would bring together many of his best-known characters from his last-quarter century of writing. The new novel, called Dead or Alive and written with his frequent collaborator Grant Blackwood, will feature Jack Ryan, the C.I.A. analyst turned American president; his son and fellow analyst, Jack Ryan Jr.; the C.I.A. operative John Clark; his apprentice, Ding Chavez; and the agency executive Mary Pat Foley. Penguin said the novel would pit them against the Emir, a sadistic killer who has masterminded the most vicious terrorist attacks on the West. Dead or Alive will be released by the G. P. Putnams Sons imprint of Penguin on Dec. 7.

title: Usher Tops Pop Chart
description: The upper ranks of the Billboard chart this week belong to Usher, below. His new album, Raymond vs. Raymond (Jive)  his real name is Usher Raymond IV  is No. 1, and Justin Bieber, his 16-year-old protg, is standing strong at No. 2. Raymond vs. Raymond sold 329,000 copies in its first week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Mr. Biebers album My World 2.0 (Island), which was No. 1 on last weeks chart, fell one spot in its second week out, with 290,000 sales. (Mr. Biebers EP, My World, released in November, fell three spots this week to No. 8, with 63,000.) Also on the chart, Vol. 33 in the pop compilation series Now Thats What I Call Music! holds at No. 3 with 123,000, and New Amerykah Part Two: Return of the Ankh (Universal Motown), the latest by Erykah Badu, opens at No. 4 with 110,000. Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville) fell one spot to No. 5, with 87,000. Monicas Still Standing (J) fell four spots to No. 6 in its second week out, with 81,000, and Freight Train (Arista Nashville), the latest album by the country star Alan Jackson, opened at No. 7 with 72,000 sales.

title: A Police Man Is Preparing to Play at the Met
description: If you thought you saw a familiar, nattily attired Englishman poking around Lincoln Center in recent days, you might well have spotted Sting, right, inspecting the Metropolitan Opera as he prepares to perform there as part of an orchestra tour this summer. On July 13 and 14, Sting, the Police man and solo pop star, will perform at the Met with the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra of London, it was announced on Wednesday. While Sting said, in a telephone interview, that he was stoked for the full orchestra tour, which begins June 2 in Vancouver, British Columbia, his dates at the Met have him feeling both excited and anxious. I think one needs to take this seriously, Sting said. Its quite something to be sitting in front of the Royal Philharmonic on the Met stage. I think Im suitably anxious. Sting played orchestral concerts with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in May 2009 and the Philadelphia Orchestra in January.

title: Theater Company Gets Aid for Classics Project
description: The New York-based Aquila Theater Company has received $800,000 from the National Endowment for the Humanities to support new productions of classic Greek works that will be performed for veterans groups and in rural and urban areas, the theater group announced on Wednesday. The grant for Aquilas new Ancient Greeks/Modern Lives program is the largest in the theater companys 19-year history, an Aquila spokesman said. The performances will begin in May and run through April 2013, taking place at 100 public libraries and arts centers in communities from Harlem and Washington Heights in New York to Miami, Houston, Seattle and several other cities and small towns in at least 20 states. The productions will include scenes based on Homers Odyssey and from Sophocles Ajax, Euripides Herakles and The Trojan Women and Aeschylus Persians, the spokesman said. In its award, the endowment said the money was intended to begin a national program series exploring classical literature. Aquila regularly tours America with classics.

title: Backwoods Design and the Art of a Doo Nanny
description: A look at Butch Anthonys home, part of an 80-acre compound in the Alabama woods, and his micro folk-art festival.

title: Design Archives Auction Is Canceled
description: One of the largest private archives documenting the mid-20th-century furniture designers Charles and Ray Eames has been withdrawn from an auction scheduled for Thursday because of a lawsuit contesting their ownership. The archives were to be the top lot at a sale at Wright auction house in Chicago focused on furniture by the Eameses, known for their mass-produced contoured plywood and fiberglass chairs. The archives were put up for sale by the design historians John and Marilyn Neuhart, who are in their 80s and had collaborated with the Eameses on exhibitions and books. But on Monday Lucia Eames, the designers daughter, filed suit in an Illinois state court asserting that the family owns the material. The lot was estimated to bring $150,000 to $200,000. Richard Wright, the auction house owner, said, Trying to sell these items with a cloud over the title doesnt make any sense. He said he would still offer a four-foot-wide model that the Neuharts built of the Eames office in Los Angeles (estimated at $10,000 to $15,000).

title: Exploring the Cocoon
description: The Cocoon, part of the Darwin Center at the Museum of Natural History in London, puts the focus on scientific exploration itself as well as on its results.

title: 'Moving in Place'
description: The exhibition of work by Susan Rothenberg at the Georgia OKeeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M., makes comparisons between the two artists hard to avoid.

title: Hubris of a Man Who Thought He Was Napoleon
description: War, Thomas Hardy once wrote, makes rattling good history. If you would like an example of exactly what Hardy meant, I commend Russia Against Napoleon by Dominic Lieven.

title: Enjoy the Bugs, but Dont Feed the Scientists
description: LONDON  There is something daring, almost provocative, about the Cocoon. This eight-story-high egg-shaped structure, which contains major new exhibition space along with scientific-research facilities, is housed in an enormous glass-and-steel box. It is annexed to the Natural History Museum here as if it were a gigantic specimen brought back by 21st-century heirs to the collectors, entomologists and zoologists who created that great institution.

title: Jane Has a Really Big Closet Now
description: JANES CLOSET, the Internet retailer for the woman in touch with her inner Gossip Girl, has transitioned from Web site to pop-up outlet to permanent store. In February, the bricks-and-mortar location opened in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, for what was to be three months. When traffic proved promising, Jane Rim, the owner, signed an extended lease.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS Isabel Marants much-anticipated SoHo boutique opens on April 9. The store features Corinthian columns, poured concrete floors and, of course, the French designers chic collection, including her iconic slouchy boots, which are worn both in winter and summer. The Dana, below, is $1,160. Other key items are the Hola embroidered jacket ($1,370) and Xacala fur vest ($1,490). The center of the boutique is a jewelry display constructed of timbers stretching from floor to ceiling; 469 Broome Street (Greene Street), (212) 219-2284. . . . Masgaschoni has moved its store on Main Street in East Hampton, N.Y., into a 2,000-square-foot boutique nearby, just in time to stock up for summer. The store offers the brands trademark vibrant kaleidoscope of colors in knits, sportswear, home designs and accessories. Simple tops start at $178, cashmere coats go to $1,000; 2 Newtown Lane, East Hampton, (631) 329-8139.

title: Clogs Get Up on Their Toes
description: BANISH all thoughts of nurses, aging hippies and potbellied, globe-trotting chefs. The lowly clog has been updated this season by designers including Michael Kors and Karl Lagerfeld.

title: Bags Worth Celebrating
description: HAYDEN-HARNETT, the Brooklyn fashion company best known for its stylish, functional and not insanely priced handbags, is celebrating its fifth anniversary with a sale at its stores in NoLIta and Greenpoint through April 26.

title: Kiton, but Cheaper
description: WANT a Kiton suit but get sticker shock every time you glance at the sales tag? The Bergdorf Goodman Mens Store is now selling a lower-priced collection from this high-end Italian designer (the term lower-priced being relative, of course).

title: What Were Reading: Murdoch and Collapsing Business Models
description: The tech editors and reporters of the New York Times were reading about business deals and business models as much as gadgets.

title: Three Classes of Digital Cameras
description: A guide for those choosing which type of digital camera to buy.

title: Speak Easy | Laura Marling
description: Laura Marling is the most prominent member of a loose community of young London-based performers, including Johnny Flynn and Mumford and Sons, playing acoustic music inspired by British and American folk traditions. Her debut album, Alas I Cannot Swim, was recorded when she was 17 and nominated for the 2008 Mercury Prize. This week her follow-up, I Speak Because I Can (Astralwerks), was released in the United States. The album has been greeted by a sweep of five-star reviews in British newspapers, earning comparisons to Joni Mitchells Court and Spark. In a warm, dusty voice and accompanied by her intuitive guitar playing, Marling sings of being perched between adolescence and womanhood, between the rural England where she was raised and the anxious metropolis she has made her home, between despair and freedom. Marling spoke with The Moment during her recent American tour.

title: HCA Said to Plan I.P.O. for This Year
description: HCA, the big hospital operator whose $33 billion takeover in 2006 heralded a slew of giant leveraged buyouts, is planning an initial public offering that may raise more than $3 billion, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

title: Russia Against Napoleon
description: There are usually three stages in the creation of empires, though these stages often overlap. First comes the conquest of empire and the elimination of foreign threats. This is generally a question of military power, diplomatic craftiness, and geopolitical context. To survive, however, an empire needs institutions, otherwise it will disintegrate with the death of the conqueror and his charisma. Establishing these institutions is the second stage in creating an empire and is often harder than the first stage, particularly when huge conquests have occurred in a short period. The third stage requires the consolidation of imperial loyalties and identities in the subject populations, and above all, in the pre-modern world, in their elites.

title: Another Painter in OKeeffe Territory
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  When the painter Susan Rothenberg moved to New Mexico from New York City in 1990 at the age of 45, she didnt give a lot of thought to the parallels between herself and Georgia OKeeffe, another woman who gained fame in New York and began spending a lot of time here at around the same age.

title: S.E.C. Moves to Tighten Rules on Bonds Backed by Consumer Loans
description: WASHINGTON  Credit rating agencies would lose their formal role in evaluating certain bonds backed by consumer loans, like home mortgages, under rules proposed on Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Instead, the companies issuing these bonds would have to vouch for their soundness.

title: Maestros Pay Hangs on Unsigned Deal
description: As the conductor James Levine prepares to undergo lower-back surgery, his employers at the Metropolitan Opera and the Boston Symphony Orchestra are nervously hoping that he will recover and resume his extremely busy schedule.

title: Man Arrested in Threat Against Pelosi
description: Federal agents on Wednesday arrested a San Francisco man in connection with threats against the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, over her role in winning adoption of landmark health care legislation, officials said.

title: Lyon-Bordeaux Exposes Frances East-West Divide
description: Win or lose, France knew it would qualify a team for the semifinals of the UEFA Champions League on Wednesday. Bordeaux won the game, 1-0, but Lyon got the ticket through to the next round. Lyon had an edge of course, having won 3-1 in the first leg the week before at Lyons Gerland Stadium. But Bordeaux was playing on home turf and worked hard to please the home crowd.

title: Plot Twists
description: In Bruges: The influential Belgian garden designer Jacques Wirtz, now in his 80s, is best known for bold landscapes with strong perspective lines, sweeping hedges, swaths of grass and geometric topiary. (His sons Peter and Martin are now in charge of the family firm, Wirtz International.) Its a signature thats apparent even in projects with limited space.

title: Jets Are Courting Jason Taylor, a Fan Nemesis
description: The Jets courted the free agent defensive end Jason Taylor on Wednesday. They showed off their new stadium. They offered a tempting role.

title: Soul Man
description: By age 12, I had a rote reply for grown-ups quizzical looks when they heard I went to a Waldorf school: Its based on the ideas of Rudolf Steiner. Blank stare. He was an Austrian philosopher who believed in teaching the whole student  mind, body and soul. Luckily no one ever asked me to elaborate, because Id have been at a loss for words  except to say that we students got to do lots of drawing and painting, which I loved, but we couldnt skip eurythmy class (yuck). Any serious discussions of pedagogic method and what Steiner called his spiritual science, anthroposophy, took place out of earshot in the teachers room. My only mental picture of Steiner (1861-1925) came from a dim black and white photo showing a stern mouth and X-ray eyes that made me glad this guy wasnt our headmaster. Oh, well, I reasoned, as soon as I enter the real world after graduation, its Goodbye, Dr. Steiner.

title: The Tapping Looked Good, but Happened to Backfire
description: You are on defense. Declarer ruffs your opening lead in his hand. You get back in immediately. Should you continue to tap declarer, hoping that he will lose trump control, or should you shift in order to stop him from scoring his trumps separately and aiding what might turn into a dummy reversal? (In a dummy reversal, declarer does a lot of ruffing in his hand and uses dummys trumps to draw those of the opponents.)

title: Toyota E-Mail Noted Pedal Trouble
description: DETROIT  A senior official in Toyotas American operations urged his colleagues to come clean and admit it had mechanical problems with sticking accelerator pedals three days before the company met with federal authorities to discuss a recall, documents showed Wednesday.

title: With Select Apps, iPad Is More Than a Pretty Face
description: Lets set aside the question of whether you should get an iPad and suppose you already bought one last weekend. You probably floated home and loaded it with a few whiz-bang apps and maybe even passed it around to your friends.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,023 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: Cano Picks and Chooses
description: BOSTON  According to the Yankees charts, Robinson Cano swung at more pitches out of the strike zone last season than any of his teammates.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about school nutrition legislation now in the Senate omitted one type of milk the bill would allow in cafeterias. Besides skim, 1 percent milk could be sold.

title: Wisconsin: Schools Warned Against Sex Education
description: A prosecutor is urging schools not to follow a new state law that requires districts with sex education programs to tell students about the proper use of contraceptives. In a letter to school districts, Scott Harold Southworth, Juneau Countys district attorney, warned that teachers face possible criminal liability for teaching youths how to use contraceptives. The law allows districts to opt out. State lawmakers who wrote the bill, pushed through this year by Democrats, said the warnings were incorrect, irresponsible and political. Hes trying to make it sound as if teaching a comprehensive sex education curriculum is somehow illegal, said Tamara Grigsby, a Democratic state representative. Mr. Southworth was unavailable for comment.

title: Spanish Judge Indicted for Inquiry Into Franco-Era Abuses
description: MADRID  Baltasar Garzn, the Spanish judge who attained international fame for pursuing leaders like Augusto Pinochet of Chile and Silvio Berlusconi of Italy, was himself indicted Wednesday on charges of abusing his powers to investigate Spanish Civil War atrocities.

title: California: Man Accused of Threatening Pelosi
description: Federal agents arrested a San Francisco man on Wednesday in connection with threats against Speaker Nancy Pelosi for her role in winning adoption of health care legislation, officials said. Charges were not disclosed. The man, Gregory Guisti, 48, is scheduled to appear in court Thursday. On Tuesday, a man was charged with threatening to kill Senator Patty Murray of Washington.

title: Arkansas: Probation for Ex-Aide to Bill Clinton
description: Betsey Wright, chief of Bill Clintons staff as governor and a senior member of his presidential campaign in 1992, was fined $2,000 and placed on a years probation after pleading no contest on Wednesday to two misdemeanor charges involving prohibited items that were taken from her at a state prison where she visited death row inmates in May. Security guards seized a box cutter, a pocket knife and needles from Ms. Wright, a vocal opponent of capital punishment.

title: Ex-Citi Executives Take Fire at Crisis Hearing
description: A group of former high-ranking Citigroup executives defended the firms management of risk in its credit derivatives business on Wednesday, telling an investigative panel that the firms multibillion-dollar subprime mortgage losses arose from unprecedented global events beyond their control.

title: Hollywood Tries to Block Market for Movie Bets
description: LOS ANGELES  In a show of solidarity, many of the film industrys major players, and some sympathetic lawmakers, have aligned in an 11th-hour push to block new financial instruments that would allow traders to swap contracts tied to box-office results.

title: Trailer: Bad Company 2
description: The Electronic Arts game is the latest in the Battlefield series.

title: Meb Keflezighi to Defend Title
description: Meb Keflezighi will be back to defend his New York City Marathon title Nov. 7, trying to become the first American since Alberto Salazar to win back-to-back titles in New York. The American womens record-holder in the marathon, Deena Kastor, also entered, officials with the New York Road Runners announced during a drawing for the marathon lottery.

title: Frozen Four From a Basketball Prism
description: DETROIT  The N.C.A.A. Final Four has gone Frozen, with interesting parallels between the basketball and hockey versions of the 2010 mens tournaments.

title: Summer Overtakes Spring; Confusion Reigns
description: When you thought about it, while mopping the dripping sweat off your brow, it was kind of absurd. What was August doing here in April?

title: Evercore Plans a Deal and High-Level Hires
description: April 8, 8:18 a.m. | Updated Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank, announced Thursday morning that it has bolstered its commercial real estate and mining and metals advisory businesses with an acquisition and two high-level appointments.

title: State Panels Prove Resilient to Budget Pruning
description: Financially ailing states seeking to cut bureaucratic sprawl have zeroed in on what might seem a vulnerable target: the countless advisory, advocacy and regulatory boards and commissions that ripple out from their capitals into infinite niches of human need and pursuit.

title: Poet and Anti-Poet
description: At a reading I attended in the Smith College science lecture hall a few years ago, Charles Bernstein, famous as a poet and anti-poet, pointed to the giant poster on the wall behind him and said, I want to thank the Poetry Center for putting up my poem The Periodic Table of the Elements.  He then proceeded to give a mock-dramatic rendition of the symbols, left to right, down the page. H, He, Li, Be! he panted, growled and spluttered. Why!? he complained when he got to yttrium (Y). I! he declared solemnly for iodine, as if toasting his own ego. He slowed down, sped up. No! he bellowed for nobelium, then finally whispered Lr, the last chemical symbol. He turned to face the audience. Ive always wondered if I should have ended with No rather than putting that Lr on the end. I think it was a mistake. I think it would have been more emphatic with the negation. This was the funniest, most impromptu-brilliant, serious moment Ive ever witnessed at a poetry reading  and very much about sound, language, expression and communication.

title: For an Obama Mentor, a Nebulous Legal Niche
description: WASHINGTON  On a recent Saturday morning in a hardscrabble neighborhood here, a stocky man who could not afford a lawyer attended a legal clinic to ask a question about his mothers will.

title: In a Tour for Visitors, Baghdads Past Is Present
description: BAGHDAD  A group of foreign visitors went on a tour of Baghdad recently. Such an event, almost anywhere else, would have passed unnoticed. But this is Baghdad, where the rumblings of a passing thunderstorm recently had people convinced that insurgents had unleashed a string of synchronized bombings.

title: Up Front: Barbara Kingsolver
description: In this issue, Barbara Kingsolver reviews Anthill, the first novel by the distinguished biologist E. O. Wilson, who turns 81 this year.

title: In Cuomos Corner, a Pugnacious Aide Emerges
description: When members of the painters union heckled Andrew M. Cuomo as he arrived at a debate during the race for attorney general, Joseph Percoco, a burly aide to Mr. Cuomo, walked over to the unions political director with a warning:

title: Free Report on Credit? No Longer
description: The credit report you get from freecreditreport.com is no longer free, no matter what that Web address promises.

title: A Tentative Contract Deal for Washington Teachers
description: Capping two years of rancorous bargaining, the Washington schools chancellor and the citys teachers union on Wednesday announced an agreement on a tentative contract that would increase teacher salaries, establish a voluntary merit pay system and give the authorities clearer powers to move teachers out of the system based on their effectiveness rather than seniority.

title: Suspense Builds Over Census for New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  Nobody really knows how many people live here.

title: Stepping Gingerly Into the Heat
description: In the old economy, a furnace blast of heat would have brought out the latest spring clothes. Fueled by big spending, stores had the goods early, and one of the discombobulating aspects of spring dressing was how suddenly spiffed-up everything looked in New York, as if all the citys doormen had hosed the sidewalks clean of winter garments.

title: Psychologists Explain Iraq Airstrike Video
description: The sight of human beings, most of them unarmed, being gunned down from above is jarring enough.

title: Decommissioned Boards
description: Here is a sample of boards and commissions that have been eliminated as part of state government streamlining efforts.

title: Augustas Chairman Rebukes Woods
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The annual Masters address by the chairman of the Augusta National Golf Club is usually a routine, even humdrum, affair. The principal topic of conversation is often the speed of the greens, and the closest thing to controversy is the yearly refusal to discuss whether the club will some day include a woman as a member. On Wednesday, Billy Payne, who has led Augusta National since 2006, did something unprecedented.

title: Uprising in Kyrgyzstan
description: Opposition leaders declared Thursday that they had seized power in Kyrgyzstan, a crucial ally to the U.S. and strategic staging ground for the war in Afghanistan. (Video: NBC)

title: A Charge That When Funds Crumbled, a Firm Deceived Its Brokers and Clients
description: WHEN the subprime credit structure began to shake and then to crumble, money managers who had invested in it were faced with hard decisions.

title: Chinas Censors Tackle and Trip Over the Internet
description: This article was reported by Michael Wines, Sharon LaFraniere and Jonathan Ansfield and written by Mr. Wines.

title: Skip the South of France. Try Zimbabwe.
description: So what are the great places to visit in Africa? It surprises people to hear it, but Zimbabwe is very high on the list  and now that Ive just returned from a week there with my family, I feel that more strongly than ever.

title: AT&T Image Campaign Accentuates the Positive, Not Products
description: THINGS are starting to look up on Madison Avenue, or so it seems, as more advertising takes on the type of upbeat tone that had been noticeably missing during this recession.

title: Texas Oil Firms Oppose California Climate Law
description: WASHINGTON  Several Texas oil companies are bankrolling a petition drive to suspend Californias path-breaking climate change law in a move that may prove a bellwether for national efforts to address global warming.

title: Cash For Carbon
description: That was my working title for my piece published in Sundays NYT Magazine, under the title The Green Economy.

title: Bloggingheads: WikiLeaks Blowback
description: Henry Farrell, left, of George Washington University and Brink Lindsey of the Cato Institute discuss the video of American soldiers killing a journalist in Iraq.

title: Its Not a Foul Until the Next Day
description: If Kevin Durants maiden playoff voyage is cut short this month, he might look back to one play and one officiating mistake as the cause.

title: Nike Ad Features Voice From Tiger Woodss Past
description: Nike, which stood by Tiger Woods when AT&T and Accenture dropped him, began running a new 30-second commercial on Wednesday that uses the recorded voice of his father, Earl, who died in 2006.

title: City Orders End to Sending Homeless to Illegal Houses
description: For years, homeless people were sent by the city to illegal boarding houses, places with crowded conditions, rows of bunk beds and vermin. For many of the buildings landlords, it was an easy way to turn a run-down house into a fairly lucrative operation  tenants were charged hundreds of dollars each month for little more than a mattress.

title: Third Officer Pleads Guilty in Shooting
description: NEW ORLEANS   A third police officer pleaded guilty in federal court on Wednesday to covering up evidence in a police shooting that left two dead and four others wounded in the days after Hurricane Katrina.

title: Shopping With Susanna Salk
description: The author of  Room for Children: Stylish Spaces for Sleep and Play, looked for children's bedding.

title: Earthquake  Roulette
description: SEATTLE  The real triumph of hope over experience is not a second marriage, as the saying goes, but the fact that millions of us continue to live atop some of the most fragile ground on the planet, knowing full well it could crack, shatter, splinter and heave at any moment.

title: Legal Threats and Bike Rides by the Hudson
description: You might think, as Glen Goldstein did, that if you organized a bike ride that crossed the Hudson River, you would be able to use the word Hudson in its name.

title: Harringtons Knicks Career Likely Ending With Shoulder Surgery
description: Al Harringtons Knicks career probably ended Sunday night in Los Angeles, though he didnt know it at the time.

title: The Lenox Hill Neighborhood House Gala
description: THE taxidermied swans at P. Allen Smiths table had come all the way from Arkansas. They had been in his freezer, explained Mr. Smith, the public television garden show star, who keeps swans of the live variety on his 600-acre organic farm there, awaiting their 15 minutes.

title: U.S. Tries to Mend Rift With Karzai
description: WASHINGTON  Seeking to quell an increasingly vitriolic and public dispute, the Obama administration said Wednesday that President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan was a figure that we respect, and it sharply countered claims by a former United Nations official that the president might be a drug user.

title: Silk Trading Company Relocates
description: Silk Trading Company has moved out of ABC Carpet & Homes basement and has opened its own store nearby. With the new location come many changes: new fabrics, furniture and accessories, and a new name  Wolf Home by Silk Trading. We felt it was time to come out into the light, said Warren Kay, the owner, who made the move after splitting with his business partner, Andrea Kay (Ms. Kay retains ownership of the Silk Trading Company store in Los Angeles). The concept for the store, he said, was a place where shoppers can have a coffee, talk to designers, look at fabrics, think about color and be in a creative environment. Products range from sofas (starting at $3,100) and limited-edition throw pillows ($59 to $150) to Molton Brown scented candles ($74). Wolf Home by Silk Trading, 936 Broadway (22nd Street), (800) 220-1893, wolfhome-ny.com.

title: Facing Cuts, Stony Brook Will Close Programs
description: Four years after taking over an 81-acre campus in Southampton, N.Y., from Long Island University, Stony Brook University announced on Wednesday that it would close most programs at the site and stop accepting undergraduate applications.

title: Why Do We Still Have Mining Disasters?
Newspaper Finds Its Way Onto the Wall
description: Newsworthy, the latest wallpaper from Lori Weitzner, a textile and product designer, is made from strips of recycled newspaper woven together to create a textural surface. Its similar to grass cloth, which is a very popular wallcovering where they weave grass on a loom and layer it on paper, Ms. Weitzner said. Replacing the grass with newspaper (you can still make out some of the text) was a way to create something beautiful and interesting, she said. The strips are woven with nylon thread to make the paper more durable and finished with a water-based topcoat that helps protect against yellowing and staining. Newsworthy is 47 inches wide and $125 a yard (to the trade). Information: (888) 609-5551, weitznerlimited.com.

title: Geithner to Visit China, in Sign of Warming Relations
description: MUMBAI, India  In a sign of improving economic relations between the United States and China, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner will meet the Chinese vice prime minister in Beijing on Thursday on his way back to the United States from India, a Treasury spokesman said here on Wednesday.

title: Scrutinizing Woodss Game, and His Sportsmanship
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Shortly after Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer reunite on Thursday morning to hit the honorary opening tee shots in the Masters, 96 golfers will begin battling their own jangling nerves and a firm and fast Augusta National golf course.

title: Bright New Bowls From Paul Smith
description: Paul Smith Dot, a new line of stainless-steel-and-enamel bowls, was designed to complement an update of Arne Jacobsens 1967 Cylinda pitchers and pots  given a shot of characteristic Paul Smith color with bright new handles in pink, yellow, blue, purple and green  and Jacobsens Cylinda cocktail set, reinterpreted in black titanium alloy.

title: Cano, New No. 5 Hitter, Exhibits New Approach
description: BOSTON  According to the Yankees charts, Robinson Cano swung at more pitches out of the strike zone last season than any of his teammates.

title: Carolina Plantation Extends Tours
description: Richard Jenrette, a retired Wall Street financier, bought Millford Plantation in Pinewood, S.C.  an antebellum house he calls the Taj Mahal of my dreams  in 1992. He already owned five other grand old homes, but Millford, he said, was the finest example of pre-Civil War Greek Revival architecture in America.

title: Sales at Artemide, Angela Adams and Others
description: Angela Adamss colorful, graphic wool rugs are 30 percent off while supplies last (Pooky/Blue, above, originally $1,950 for a 9-by-12-foot rug, is $1,365); 273 Congress Street, Portland, Me., (800) 255-9454 or angelaadams.com.

title: A Mine Boss Inspires Fear, but Pride, Too
description: MONTCOAL, W.Va.  Since Mondays mine explosion, Don L. Blankenship, the chief executive of the Massey Energy Company, which owns the Upper Big Branch mine, has appeared several times before the cameras. But he has said very little, his face seeming almost expressionless as he quietly answers questions about his concern for miner safety.

title: Lung Function of 9/11 Rescuers Fell, Study Finds
description: Rescue workers exposed to thick clouds of dust after the attack on the World Trade Center had large drops in lung function lasting at least seven years, a study of nearly 13,000 workers has found.

title: Thanks for the Tasteless Sermon
description: They are worse than we knew.

title: Investigators Want to Talk to Rodriguez Assistants
description: Federal agents have reached out to several people who have worked for Alex Rodriguez in an effort to learn more about his relationship with Anthony Galea, the Canadian-based doctor under investigation by various federal authorities.

title: United Is in Merger Talks With US Airways
description: United Airlines and US Airways are in merger talks that, if successful, would create the nations second-biggest airline. It is the third time in a decade that they have tried to make a deal.

title: Job Creation Basics
description: President Obama recently noted that, by itself, government cannot replace the 8.2 million jobs lost over the past two years. What government can do, he said, is help to create the conditions for renewed hiring.

title: A Ride Home
description: Former Mayor Sharpe James of Newark was released from federal prison and boarded a Greyhound bus for home.

title: Rwanda: 6 Drown on Their Way to Genocide Memorial
description: Six people drowned after a boat taking them to a genocide memorial service capsized Wednesday in heavy winds on Lake Kivu off the coast of Rwanda. According to the provincial governor, at least 10 were still missing, and more than 50 were rescued from the waters near the city of Kibuye where services were being held to observe the 16th anniversary of the Rwandan genocide. He said that genocide survivors were among the missing. The governor said that the boat had been overloaded and that the mourners drowned within eyesight of the memorial services on the mainland.

title: Postcard From Zimbabwe
description: HWANGE, Zimbabwe

title: Before It Ends, Schools Race Is a Success
description: Critics of the Obama administrations signature education initiative have been breathing fire since it was announced that only Delaware and Tennessee had won first-round grants under the program, known as Race to the Top. Politicians from some losing states have denounced the well-designed scoring system under which the 16 finalists were evaluated. Others have thrown up their hands, suggesting that retooling applications for the next round is more trouble than its worth.

title: Bystanders and Bullying
description: To the Editor:

title: The Work Interns Do, and the Pay They Dont Get
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Nuclear Policy Gets a New Look
description: To the Editor:

title: H1N1 Vaccine, Still Available
description: Just a few months ago, nervous Americans were clamoring for access to vaccines that could protect them against the swine flu. Now there is a glut of vaccine available, and American health officials are renewing their calls for more people to get vaccinated  just in case the virus resurges in coming months.

title: Send In the Professors
description: Harrisonburg, Va.

title: A Confederacy of Dunces
description: April is the cruelest month. Or, if you live in Virginia, Confederate History Month.

title: How Fast Is Your Broadband?
description: There are many ways for marketing professionals to bamboozle customers into believing they are getting a better deal than they actually are  notable among them as low as pricing come-ons and offers that promise to deliver up to some standard of service.

title: Modern Design, in Miniature, Is Growing
description: CHRISTINE FERRARA, a 39-year-old public affairs director for the Institute for Advanced Study, a research center in Princeton, N.J., has a passion for modern architecture and design. It began in 2008, when her husband, Steven Birnbaum, a technology consultant, bought her an airy modern home with floor-to-ceiling windows.

title: Art Shapes a Rural Alabama Compound
description: SEALE, Ala.

title: Searching for Childrens Bedding
description: AROUND the time she began working as special projects editor for House & Garden in 2003, Susanna Salk noticed that childrens rooms were being featured in shelter magazines, something that would have been almost unthinkable a decade earlier.

title: For Executives in Concrete Testing Case, a Sentencing and a Suicide Attempt
description: The sentencing of two executives of Testwell Laboratories, once the leading concrete testing company in New York, was reduced to the sentencing of one on Wednesday, after one of the defendants made his second attempt to kill himself.

title: Nancy Paterson, Who Aided in Milosevic Investigation, Dies at  56
description: Nancy Paterson, an international war crimes prosecutor who played a leading role in building the case linking the former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic to massacres, mass rape and ethnic cleansing in the Balkans in the 1990s, died on March 27 at her home in Bethesda, Md. She was 56.

title: 24 Down: Vintners Concern
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Twas frabjous. Twas frumious. Twas uffish. The adjective you use to describe todays solve might likely depend on how familiar you are with a 44 Across creation.

title: Coots Matthews, Cantankerous Hellfighter, Dies at 86
description: A joke has it that St. Peter was showing a Texan around heaven, with the Texan claiming that everything he saw was better in Texas. St. Peter tired of the routine and pointed to the fire of hell. Do you have anything like that in Texas? he asked. The Texan said no, then added, But there are a couple good old boys in Houston who can put it out for you.

title: Morris Jeppson, Airman Who Flew on the Enola Gay, Dies at 87
description: Morris R. Jeppson, an Army Air Forces electronics specialist who helped arm the atomic bomb aboard the Enola Gay as it flew to Hiroshima, died March 30 at a hospital in Las Vegas. Mr. Jeppson, who was 87 and lived in Las Vegas, was the next-to-last survivor of the 12 men who carried out historys first atomic strike.

title: Video Hints at Mind of Man Accused in a Killing
description: The detectives were about to leave the room after informing David Tarloff that he would be charged with murdering an Upper East Side therapist, but Mr. Tarloff would not let them go without some parting words.

title: Before and After in Washington Heights
description: A couple reinvents their living room, adding a work space, with the help of the interior designer Kimberly Hall.

title: A Writer Gets a Home Office of Her Own
description: AFTER spending several months looking for a three-bedroom apartment in Washington Heights, Emily Raboteau and Victor LaValle, novelists who are engaged to be married this summer, finally accepted that all they could afford was a two-bedroom  which meant that only one of them would have a home office for writing.

title: Iona Hires Cluess From C.W. Post
description: Iona College players met with their new coach, Tim Cluess, in the teams locker room Wednesday night. Cluess, formerly the coach at C.W. Post, accepted the job of replacing Kevin Willard, who departed recently to take the same position at Seton Hall. Ionas sports information director, Brian Beyrer, said a news conference would be scheduled for Friday.

title: A Ranger Rises to His Coachs Challenge
description: Coach John Tortorella admitted Wednesday that the clubs hopes of qualifying for the playoffs were growing dim. Theres no more time, he said. No more time.

title: On the Energy Gap and Climate Crisis
description: Its worth beginning Dot Earths new iteration with a few straightforward points about humans and their planet that I feel are powerfully established. Below, I start with several thoughts on energy and climate. In coming days, along with a regular flow of news-driven posts, Ill add similar foundation-building pieces on relations between people and Earths other inhabitants and on ways to mesh humanitys infinite aspirations with life on a finite planet.

title: Bosh to Miss at Least Rest of Regular Season
description: Chris Bosh will miss at least the rest of the regular season after sustaining a facial fracture, the Toronto Raptors announced on Wednesday. The injury will cause Bosh to miss at least the final five regular-season games and probably the playoffs if the Raptors qualify.

title: Nearby Hospitals to Fill Gap When St. Vincents Closes
description: A day after St. Vincents Hospital in Greenwich Village announced it was closing its inpatient facilities, other Manhattan hospitals said Wednesday that they were making plans to accommodate its patients, doctors and employees at their own institutions.

title: Guilty Plea in Death of N.Y.U. Professors Daughter
description: A man charged with murdering the daughter of two New York University professors pleaded guilty Wednesday to manslaughter as part of an agreement under which he will be sentenced to 25 years in prison.

title: White House Presses Japan to Reopen Market to U.S. Beef
description: TOKYO  The Obama administration is stepping up pressure on Japan to reopen its market to American beef, in hopes of helping ranchers and meatpackers gain full access to what was once their most lucrative market.

title: After One More Minor League Game, Mets Reyes Is Set to Play Saturday
description: Barring unexpected complications, Jose Reyes will be in the Mets lineup Saturday for their home game against the Nationals. The plan is for Reyes to play one more minor league game Thursday in Port St. Lucie, Fla., then travel to New York, where he will join the team Friday.

title: At Last Allowed, Muslim Scholar Visits
description: A federal appeals court had ruled in his favor. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton had issued an order that paved the way for a visa. And so, on Wednesday afternoon, Tariq Ramadan stepped off a plane at Newark Liberty International Airport for his first visit to the United States since 2004, when the Bush administration barred him from entering, asserting he had contributed money to terrorist enterprises.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 7, 2010

title: Newcomers Provide Pitching and Punch
description: BOSTON  Brian Cashman had concentrated on acquiring Curtis Granderson, the first new member of the 2010 Yankees, before last years World Series even started. Chan Ho Park, the last player to join the retooled team, did not arrive at spring training until the final day of February, two weeks into spring training.

title: Teenager Charged in L.I. Hate Crime to Testify
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Jeffrey Conroy, the Long Island teenager charged with a hate crime in the  fatal stabbing of a Hispanic immigrant, will most likely testify on Thursday in his murder trial. But it remains unclear if he will be allowed to tell the jury what he has told his lawyer  that someone else stabbed the immigrant.

title: Air Marshals Intervene in Incident on Plane
description: Federal officials were investigating an incident aboard a Washington-to-Denver flight on Wednesday involving a passenger who caused a disturbance.

title: Corrections
description: A headline and an article on March 30 and another article on April 2 about the bullying and suicide of Phoebe Prince, a freshman at South Hadley High School in Massachusetts, reported that nine students had been charged with crimes including harassment, violating civil rights and statutory rape. The number of students was taken from a March 29 statement by Elizabeth D. Scheibel, the district attorney, in which she named six students who were charged with felonies, including an 18-year-old, two 17-year-olds and three 16-year-olds. Ms. Scheibel said that in addition, delinquency complaints for similar crimes had been filed in juvenile court against three unnamed females. Her office refused to comment further, citing strict rules on the confidentiality of juvenile proceedings.

title: Nike Rolls Out Woods Ad With More Questions Than Answers
description: Nike could not wait to package the contrition of Tiger Woods in a 30-second ad.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about a meeting between President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela and visiting Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia reversed their identities in some copies. Mr. Putin was shown at the left and Mr. Chvez at the right.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a powerful earthquake that shook Southern California on Sunday afternoon misstated, in some editions, the distance between Yuma, Ariz., and the quakes epicenter just south of Mexicali, the capital of Baja California, Mexico. It is about 60 miles, not 1,600. And an accompanying map showed an incorrect location for Mexicali.
