description: The nuptials of Anthony Angelo Nunzio and Valentina Lynne Vitale, more than 20 years in the making, will proceed on Saturday as planned. Actors Equity Association said on Friday that the producers of Tony N Tinas Wedding, the Off-Broadway show, had agreed to recognize the contract of its actors who are represented by the association and that performances of the show would continue. On Thursday, the association said it had filed an unfair-labor-practice charge with the National Labor Relations Board against Broadway Entertainment, which produces Tony N Tinas Wedding, saying the company had closed and re-opened the show in less than eight weeks without negotiating with the union  violating a union rule  and was offering employment to its cast on the condition they resign from Equity or work without its representation. Broadway Entertainment said on Friday afternoon that it had come to an oral agreement with Actors Equity and that the union had committed to talks next week to resolve other matters.

title: Venus Volcano
description: 360-degree views of a volcano on Venus. (Created by Ryan Ollerenshaw and Eric DeJong of the Solar System Visualization Group, JPL.)

title: Looking, or Just Looking
description: SUNDAY after Sunday, a ritual is repeated throughout Manhattan and other parts of the city: Owner of a property for sale straightens up and clears out for a couple of hours. Broker comes in, tidies up some more. At scheduled time, the door opens and an urban apartment is transformed into the residential equivalent of a suburban mall, serious shoppers mingling with those who are just looking, all of them out enjoying a great American weekend activity.

title: Nurses and Stanford Hospitals Are at Loggerheads
description: When representatives of Stanford Hospital and Clinics and Lucile Packard Childrens Hospital submitted their Last, Best, and Final Offer to its nurses on March 30, their gesture seemed to be an ultimatum of sorts.

title: With Family Built In
description: IF by magic you could slice off the facade of Jennifer Acostas red- and cream-colored house in Woodhaven, Queens, as if it were one of those dollhouses that open to reveal what lies within, you would find most of the people she feels closest to in the world.

title: Seeking Moderns, to Save Them
description: WESTON

title: Live First Shot Provides Ratings Bump to ESPN
description: ESPNs heavily promoted live airing of Tiger Woodss first tee shot at the Masters Thursday at 1:42 p.m. Eastern generated a substantially higher rating for SportsCenter than it usually gets in that part of the afternoon.

title: On Long Island, Competing Brokers Become Comrades
description: PLANDOME MANOR

title: For the Best of the Best, Determination Outweighs Nature and Nurture
description: IVE always been considered a good writer and a terrible singer. I pick up sports quickly but draw like a 2-year-old. My talents, such as they are, seemed pretty set by the time I was in my late teens.

title: Whoosh! The Trash Can as a Pneumatic Tube
description: Underneath the 40-block strip of land between Queens and Manhattan known as Roosevelt Island is a complex system of pneumatic tubes that connects the islands 12,000 or so residents. But its not mail thats hurtling through them at at 30 miles an hour. Its garbage. Vacuum cleaners, Christmas trees and last nights unfinished dinner have all passed through the intestines of the Automated Vacuum Assisted Collections facility, a pneumatic trash system built in 1975 that seems forever ahead of its time.

title: Deeply Offensive
description: To the Editor:

title: Multiple Bids, but Not Exactly a War
description: DID you hear? There were 17 bids on a $1 million house in Short Hills late last month. In a slowly recovering housing market, that kind of activity tends to cause a stir.

title: Out in Italy With Bertolli
description: A giant marketer is again sponsoring a campaign for one of its mainstream food brands that is aimed at gay and lesbian consumers.

title: The Country, However You Define It
description: ROBERT A. MCCAFFREY, who has lived all of his 67 years in Garrison, across the Hudson River from the United States Military Academy at West Point, can recount stories of buyers who moved in, lured by the astonishing beauty of the area, and then within a year sold their homes and left for someplace closer to supermarkets and other suburban amenities.

title: Aspen Festival Music Director Quits
description: Early this week the Aspen Music Festival and School released its schedule of programs for the summer. It should have included a blue pencil. The festival announced on Friday that David Zinman, its music director since 1997 and the director of the American Academy of Conducting at Aspen, which he founded in 2000, had resigned effective immediately.

title: Working Financial Literacy in With the Three Rs
description: Most Americans arent fluent in the language of money. Yet were expected to make big financial decisions as early as our teens  Should I take on thousands of dollars of student debt? Should I buy a car?  even though most of us received no formal instruction on financial matters until it was too late.

title: How Will Microsoft Explain Its Pink Phones to Partners?
description: Come Monday, Microsoft will need to apply some of its most sophisticated public relations and marketing maneuvers.

title: Sunday Preview
description: A culinary group in Italy called Home Food seeks out exceptional home cooks, puts them through a training course and dubs them Cesarinas  little Caesars, emperors of the kitchen. Then a few times a month, the Cesarinas open their homes to paying guests. Matt Gross, who writes the Frugal Traveler column, grabs a fork and dives in.

title: Its History: Audio, Video and Live Performance
description: In 1969 Vivian Perlis, then working as a reference librarian at the Yale School of Music, started doing tape-recorded interviews with people who had known and worked with Charles Ives, a Yale graduate. That project culminated in Ms. Perliss landmark 1974 book, Charles Ives Remembered: An Oral History.

title: Bertolli Ad by Logo
description: Charlie David of "Bump" on Logo appears in a commercial for Bertolli created by the cable channel.

title: Andrew C. Florance
description: Mr. Florance, 46, is a founder and the chief executive of the CoStar Group, a provider of data, marketing and analytic services to the commercial real estate industry.

title: How Would You Teach Personal Finance in School?
description: The economic crisis has provided a reminder that many Americans lack financial savvy. So in this weeks Your Money column, I make the case for adding a subject to Americas course load: personal finance.

title: Dear God: A Young Boy Needs a Cure. Please Help.
description: Heres the pitch: A child with brain cancer writes letters to God and thereby touches the heart of an embittered, hard-drinking postal carrier. Even an untrained eye can see right away that a story with that much emotion in its central plotline would require restraint and subtlety to be brought credibly to the screen.

title: Chickpea Tagine With Chicken
description: Mark Bittman cooks a one-pot meal with Moroccan flavors.

title: Room to Grow
description: Its one thing to commission a sumptuous landscape design to go with your impressive house design. But you know that a homeowner is serious about greenery when theres a greenhouse involved. That was the case when B Five Studio, the New York design firm, was asked to design a greenhouse and utility sheds to go with the comfortably elegant house that it had designed in northern Westchester County, N.Y. (The extensive landscape around the house was designed by Reed Hilderbrand, a firm based in Watertown, Mass.)

title: A Show Born in a Garden, but Not Garden Variety
description: A disclaimer before I review Paige Martins Panorama: I left 25 minutes before the shows conclusion.

title: An Expedited Tagine
description: TAGINES, the slow-cooked, deeply aromatic stews of North Africa, are traditionally made and served in distinctive clay pots, often with lamb, and usually over couscous.

title: Deadline Extended to Rule on Box-Office Futures Trading
description: The federal commission that oversees futures trading said on Friday that it had extended to April 16 the deadline for deciding whether to approve a proposal to create a market for futures contracts based on movie box-office receipts.

title: For Couples, a Day Makes a Big Difference
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  It seemedas ifthings were all set up for Fred Couples on Friday. He had a nice tee time, just before 10 a.m. The weather at the start of the day even matched his age and demeanor  50 and breezy.

title: Doctors Remove Ammunition From Soldiers Head
description: WASHINGTON  The patient arrived in critical condition last month at the Bagram Air Base hospital in Afghanistan, with what American military doctors at first thought was an all too typical war injury: metal shrapnel from an improvised bomb lodged in his head.

title: Revisiting Adolescence in the Secret Annex
description: A new adaptation of Anne Franks diary arrives on Sunday night on PBS, and it stars the unedited Anne: harshly critical of the people sharing her cramped hiding place (including her mother), self-dramatizing, sexually curious. We see her in a bra, we see her making out in the attic, we hear her talking about her period and her urge to explore her body.

title: Crispy Duck Thats Light Enough for Spring
description: WITH so many false starts, when spring finally sprang, it caught me by surprise. But there it was, complete with trees blossoming and tiny green shoots inching out of pots.

title: In Fight for Art Vendors, a Look to the Past
description: Art vendors in and around the citys parks who oppose the parks departments proposal to limit their numbers echo a common refrain: that the city is trying to clear them out  the art vendors are protected under the First Amendment and do not have to pay  to make space for vendors who will pay permit fees.

title: The Week in Pictures for April 9
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York region. Subjects include the Twittering crowd at Tom & Jerrys bar in NoHo, summertime weather in April and the release of the Mayor Sharpe James of Newark from prison.

title: A Weeknight Tagine
description: I love tagines  the warmly- and sweetly-spiced North African stews. But theyre not exactly weeknight fare for most people. My adaptation, featuring chicken, bulgur, chickpeas, and apricots, is more like it.

title: On the Street | Blooms
description: Early April's weather was a cyclone of change, from spring coats to stripping down to the essentials for the heat. The quick turn provided a preview of summer style.

title: Chic in Review | Gaga Worst Dressed
description: American ApparelHas a rummage sale,  hipsters freak out, fight.

title: Mr. Lagerfeld Gives a History Class
description: Some of you may remember The Story of Fashion, a three-part series that was first shown in 1987 on the A&E channel and was narrated by Karl Lagerfeld. The films have been reissued as a DVD set, and they are still pretty interesting and informative, if dated in places. Of course, the designers look astonishingly young. Mr. Lagerfeld, without his many rings, discusses everything from French court clothes to Mary Quant, and there are some fascinating bits with people such as the late illustrator Antonio Lopez. Produced by Arthaus Musik, the set is $49.99.

title: The Scull Collection
description: Robert and Ethel Scull amassed one of the worlds most impressive collections of Pop Art before selling most of it. A portion is currently on view at Acquavella Galleries.

title: Milan Designers Say Basta
description: For the past few seasons the main talking point during the Milan shows was how tight the calendar was to accommodate American editors and buyers who felt that Italian designers could get the job done faster so travel budgets werent blown. Personally, I liked the tight schedule  four days of shows, a little crazy, but doable. I know that the schedule was difficult for some editors, and I also thought that if the Italian designers really wanted to put their foot down and claim a certain number of days  just as the French do  then they should do that.

title: Jersey Shore Meets South Beach
description: Despite the hopes of paleoanthropologists that the second season of Jersey Shore would send the shows cast to Cradle of Humankind, South Africa, to search for two-million-year-old hominid fossils, the dreams of the scientific world will have to wait until at least Season 3. When the hit MTV reality series returns with new episodes in the summer, it will split its time between the Seaside Heights, N.J., setting that gave the show its name and a more urban location, Miami. On its Remote Control blog, MTV said that shooting for Season 2 of Jersey Shore began this week in Miami, and would reunite the original cast members, including Jenni Farley, known as Jwoww, left; Nicole Polizzi, a k a Snooki; Michael Sorrentino, known as The Situation; and Angelina Pivarnick (who bailed early on Season 1), before they return to their Jersey beach house later this year (i.e. when the Jersey weather gets warmer, MTV said). Season 2 of Jersey Shore will have its premiere on July 29, so expect the protest letters to start arriving at MTV on July 30.

title: Comedy Central Series Chooses New Lead
description: He may not have the name recognition of, say, Napoleon Dynamite, but Chris Gethard, a writer, performer and veteran of the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater, will soon be a familiar face on Comedy Centrals schedule. On Friday, the cable channel said Mr. Gethard would replace Jon Heder, the Napoleon Dynamite star, in a new series, confirming an Internet report on the Comics Comic (thecomicscomic.typepad.com). The series, tentatively titled Big Lake, was announced in July and is being made by Gary Sanchez Productions, the company of Will Ferrell and Adam McKay; it was to star Mr. Heder as a former financial whiz who returns to his hometown. Last month representatives for Mr. Heder said he was leaving the show because of creative differences. In addition to Mr. Gethard, who has written for Saturday Night Live and the Onion News Network, the shows cast includes the S.N.L. veterans Chris Parnell and Horatio Sanz.

title: Tony and Tina Can Still Get Married
description: The nuptials of Anthony Angelo Nunzio and Valentina Lynne Vitale, more than 20 years in the making, will proceed on Saturday as planned. Actors Equity Association said on Friday that the producers of Tony n Tinas Wedding, the Off Broadway show, had agreed to recognize the contract of its actors who are represented by the association and that performances of the show would continue. On Thursday the association said it had filed an unfair-labor-practice charge with the National Labor Relations Board against Broadway Entertainment, which produces Tony n Tinas Wedding, saying the company had closed and reopened the show in less than eight weeks without negotiating with the union  a violation of union rules  and was offering employment to its cast on the condition they resign from Equity or work without its representation. Broadway Entertainment said on Friday afternoon that it had come to an oral agreement with Actors Equity and that the union had committed to talks next week to resolve other matters.

title: Wheel of Fortune and Jeopardy! Go On
description: Powerhouse game shows for $1,000, Alex. Two classic game shows, Wheel of Fortune and Jeopardy!, will stay on television through 2014 in a renewal deal with stations owned by ABC, TheWrap.com reported. Their deals were expected to expire next year. The Web site said that Pat Sajak, the co-host of Wheel of Fortune (above, with Vanna White), and Alex Trebek, the host of Jeopardy!, had also renewed their own contracts. The distributor of the shows, CBS, is working on renewals with other local stations, but the new contracts with the ABC stations mean the shows are virtually certain to continue through the 2013-14 television season.

title: Aspen Director Quits
description: Early this week the Aspen Music Festival and School released its schedule of programs for the summer. It should have included a blue pencil. The festival announced on Friday that David Zinman, above, its music director since 1997 and the director of the American Academy of Conducting at Aspen, which he founded in 2000, had resigned, effective immediately. Mr. Zinman was scheduled to conduct five concerts this summer as well as to direct the academy. Alan Fletcher, the president and chief executive of the festival, said that it would begin a two-pronged search, to find replacements for the events this summer and to find new permanent directors for the future. Mr. Fletcher said he was unable to comment on the reasons for Mr. Zinmans sudden resignation, and Mr. Zinman was in Zurich and the festival said he could not be reached immediately. Mr. Fletcher, who was fired by the festival in October and rehired in November, said that he and Mr. Zinman had disagreed about certain faculty cuts made in response to the recession last year. But he added: I have never had any problems with David. He raised the level of everything here and left a great legacy.

title: Ozawa Cancels More Performances
description: Seiji Ozawa, below, the Japanese conductor and musical director of the Vienna State Opera, said on Friday that his recovery from cancer was proceeding well even as he announced that he was canceling more dates to focus on getting better, Agence France-Presse reported. In January Mr. Ozawa announced that he had esophageal cancer and was canceling performances for at least six months while he underwent treatment. On Friday he said that he was canceling additional dates, including an opera in Matsumoto, Japan, in August, on the advice of his doctors. In a statement, he said: Im really sorry for troubling and worrying everyone. I myself feel great regret but I want to take all possible measures to ensure recuperation by listening to my chief doctors instructions.

title: Good Night for Bones but Not for Romance
description: The 100th episode of Bones, in which Brennan (played by Emily Deschanel) and Booth (David Boreanaz) appeared to throw cold water on their long-simmering potential romance, showed some muscle for Fox, drawing 9.8 million viewers on Thursday and helping the network to second place for the night, according to Nielsens estimates. There was no love lost between the teams of Heroes and Villains on Survivor on CBS, which won the night over all; the Villains coped with the loss of Boston Rob Mariano, the Heroes handily won a game of Survivor Bowling and the reality show drew 12.2 million viewers. The CBS lineup included CSI (15 million) and The Mentalist (16.1 million). ABC was third with a new episode of the fading FlashForward (5.4 million). NBC finished fourth as the nuptials experts Nathan Lane, Kathy Griffin and Tracy Morgan sat on the celebrity panel of The Marriage Ref (4.8 million).

title: Ruin With a View
description: Books molder on library shelves. A vial of blood from a murder investigation, sealed in a plastic bag, lies in a jumble of old evidence at the former police headquarters. Shirts hang in a hotel closet. A hair dryer, typewriters, a switchboard, pianos, lamps  all left behind. At first glance, Detroit looks more like Pompeii than, say, Buffalo  like a city whose demise arrived overnight rather than over decades, whose residents fled en masse, midsentence, instead of drifting away as the jobs ran out and prospects dwindled.

title: Actors Equity Withdraws From Come Fly Away
description: Responding to a dispute with a sister union, Actors Equity Association made the unusual announcement on Friday evening that it would withdraw as the collective bargaining unit for the cast of new Broadway musical Come Fly Away in order for the other union to seek that bargaining role with the shows producers.

title: Graceful Movements in a Fog, or Just an Illusion
description: Trisha Brown has always been interested in the boundaries of vision. In her early work, in the late 60s and 70s, she famously suspended dancers off the sides of buildings, obliging spectators to observe from odd angles below. In later pieces, like Set and Reset and Foray Fort, dancers  or parts of their bodies  would pop unpredictably out of the wings, suggesting that the world of the onstage dance extended well beyond what we could see.

title: Laura Begley and Jonathan Bloom
description: Laura Elizabeth Begley and Jonathan Alexander Bloom were married Saturday evening at the Rockhouse Hotel in Negril, Jamaica. Oliver Ramsay, a licensed marriage officer affiliated with Faith in Christ Ministries, officiated at a ceremony led by David A. Stein, a friend of the bridegroom.

title: Elizabeth Robilotti, Rit Aggarwala
description: Dr. Elizabeth Victoria Robilotti and Rohit Thomas Aggarwala were married Saturday at St. Patricks Cathedral in Manhattan. The Rev. David P. Dwyer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Gentle Singer-Songwriter Revives His Rocking Side
description: At 67, Caetano Veloso still has a boyish grin, a kindly voice and mischief in his eyes. None of them should be mistaken for mellowing with age. On Thursday night at Terminal 5, his music was typically tuneful and smart. It was also obstinate, flinty, sometimes raunchy and laced with noise.

title: Elise Baran and Neil Canfield
description: Elise Jett Baran and Neil Richard Canfield were married Saturday at Holy Trinity Catholic Church in Washington. The Rev. William C. McFadden, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. He also officiated at the wedding of the brides parents in 1979.

title: Sloan McClure, Alexander Overstrom
description: Charlotte Sloan McClure, a daughter of Katherine W. McClure and D. Bryan McClure of Figure Eight Island, N.C., was married Saturday evening to Alexander Edward Cadwell Overstrom, a son of Margery Larus Overstrom of Vero Beach, Fla., and the late Gunnar S. Overstrom Jr. The Rev. Craig D. Townsend, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Jamess Church in New York, where he is the vicar.

title: Stacey Frank, Robert Tessaro
description: Stacey Rochelle Frank and Robert Victor Tessaro were married Saturday evening in New Orleans. Dennis J. Waldron, a retired judge of the New Orleans Criminal District Court, officiated at the Bourbon Orleans Hotel.

title: Jane Keltner, Giancarlo Valle
description: Jane Rowntree Keltner, a daughter of Paula S. Keltner and Thomas N. Keltner Jr. of Manhattan, was married Saturday evening to Giancarlo Devin Valle, a son of Maria Seibt de Valle and Jaime W. Valle of Chicago. The Rev. Gerald R. Blaszczak performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.

title: Hadley Hosea, Jeffrey Olsen
description: Hadley Elizabeth Hosea and Jeffrey Michael Olsen were married Saturday in Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. Aidan Hynes, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Christ Memorial Chapel on Jupiter Island, with the Rev. David C.L. Prior, an Episcopal priest, participating.

title: Masha Korsunsky, David Fisch
description: Masha Korsunsky and David Fisch were married Saturday evening at Studio 450, an event space in New York. Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz officiated.

title: Alison Grossman, Gil Baron
description: Alison Kate Grossman and Gil Alexander Baron are to be married Sunday evening by Rabbi Sheldon Pennes at Marvimon, an event space in Los Angeles.

title: Rebecca OConnell, Scott Franco
description: Rebecca Ruth OConnell and Scott Daniel Franco were married Saturday. The Rev. Diana Carroll, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Trinity in Philadelphia.

title: Joy Nesbitt and David Sajous
description: Joy Annemarie Nesbitt and David Joseph Sajous were married Saturday evening at the Boathouse in Central Park in New York. The Rev. Violet L. Dease, a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Jerrlyn Iwata and Michael Lee
description: Jerrlyn Shelley Iwata and Michael Jen-Howe Lee were married Saturday in a nondenominational ceremony at the Acqualina Resort and Spa in Sunny Isles Beach, Fla. The Rev. Eddie Rodriguez, a minister affiliated with the Universal Brotherhood, an interfaith ministry, officiated.

title: Erika Bekeny and Alexander del Nido
description: Erika Rae Bekeny, a daughter of Judith A. Bekeny and Frank S. Bekeny of Erie, Pa., was married Saturday evening in New York to Alexander Sixto del Nido, a son of Martha V. del Nido and Dr. Pedro J. del Nido of Lexington, Mass. Rabbi Jeffrey Gale officiated at the Harvard Club, with the assistance of the Rev. Angelo Gambatese, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: David Lucking and Franco Destro
description: David Graham Lucking and Franco Destro, lawyers, were joined in civil partnership Saturday in London. Alison Cathcart, the Westminster superintendent registrar, officiated at Claridges, the hotel.

title: Devon McBride, Michael Skehan
description: Devon Powell McBride, the daughter of Barbara L. McBride and David F. McBride of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married Saturday to Michael Brendan Skehan, the son of Eileen M. Skehan and William M. Skehan of Plandome, N.Y.

title: Elizabeth Fox, Karim Mouzannar
description: Elizabeth Ruth Fox and Karim Mouzannar were married Friday at Our Lady of Lebanon Maronite Catholic Cathedral in Brooklyn. The Very Rev. James A. Root, a Maronite Catholic priest and the cathedrals rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Jordan Heitz, Charles Hurd
description: Jordan Michelle Heitz, the daughter of Janette and Michael E. Heitz of Lexington, Ky., was married Saturday evening to Navy Lt. Charles Raymond Hurd, the son of Dr. Beverly W. Hurd and Charles F. Hurd of New York. The Rev. Michael L. Ward, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Walnut Hill Church in Lexington.

title: Katherine Barringer, Peter Bahouth
description: Katherine Moreau Barringer and Peter Anthony Bahouth were married Friday at their home in Atlanta. Tyler Thigpen, a minister ordained by the Grace Fellowship Church, a nondenominational congregation in Snellville, Ga., officiated.

title: Maura Myers, Jared Bisogni
description: Maura Frances Myers, the daughter of Marie Robinson Myers and Raymond Andrew Myers of McLean, Va., was married Saturday to Jared John Bisogni, a son of Carole A. Bisogni and James J. Bisogni Jr. of Ithaca, N.Y. The Rev. Lydio F. Tomasi, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Holy Rosary Church in Washington, where he is the pastor.

title: Melissa Griffin, Antoine Munfakh
description: Melissa Ann Griffin and Capt. Antoine Nasri Munfakh were married Saturday at the Church of the Assumption in Peekskill, N.Y. The Rev. John J. Higgins, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Rachel Sandweiss, Ross Gourvitz
description: Rachel Lili Sandweiss and Ross Lane Gourvitz were married Saturday evening at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Rabbi Benjamin H. Spratt officiated.

title: Theyre Chicanos and Artists. But Is Their Art Chicano?
description: Is it time to retire the identity-based group show? Back in the 1970s, exhibitions devoted to the work of women, blacks, gay people, American Indians and other disenfranchised groups brought into the mainstream all kinds of new styles and ideas. They changed the course of modern art history.

title: Internet Polls Found to Be Unrepresentative
description: Most Internet polls should be avoided as measures of the opinions of the general population, according to a report released last month by the American Association of Public Opinion Researchers (AAPOR).

title: Which Justice Will Prevail?
description: In one of the least surprising surprise announcements in Washington history, Associate Justice John Paul Stevens, leader of the liberal wing of the Supreme Court, announced on Friday that he would retire at the end of this term, reports The Timess Charlie Savage. So, who ya got?

title: In Florida, Crist Caught Between Teachers and His Party
description: MIAMI  First Marco Rubio announces a fund-raising haul of $3.6 million for the first quarter, tripling what Gov. Charlie Crist pulled in. Then, on Friday, Floridas Republican-controlled legislature handed the governor an education bill that forces him to choose between alienating teachers or the Republican base.

title: Hiding in Plain Sight as Chef, Nanny, Author
description: FOR more than three decades, Kurt Seidl worked as a chef, cook, bartender and, most recently, nanny. He wrote in his spare time, self-publishing collections of short stories under the name Gerald Conteh.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Rio Tinto Goes to Quarterly Pricing on Iron Ore
description: SHANGHAI  Rio Tinto, the British-Australian mining giant, said Friday that it had joined two other global mining companies and decided to sell iron ore based on quarterly prices, a move that effectively ends a decades-old benchmark annual pricing system.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE WORLDS FAIR CAFE AND GAS DOCK is a quiet little shack at the end of a pier at the Worlds Fair Marina that sells fast food and cheap beer, along with gas for boats at $3.95 a gallon. It has the feel of a walk-through bait shack, but when the Mets are home, it swings. A five-minute walk from CitiField, the dock has grown as a pre- and post-game hangout for fans in the know. From the outdoor seating area, you can watch boats bobbing, jets from La Guardia ascending and the CitiField scoreboards looming. Opening day for the Mets is opening day for us, said the manager, Jack Carneiro. The offerings are basic  $3 beers (Heineken, Corona, Budweiser, Coors) and $3 hot dogs. On game days, the specials beat the heck out of stadium prices: $10 for a burger, fries and a beer; $6 for two dogs, fries and beer.

title: Regulators May Pursue More Fines Against Toyota
description: DETROIT  Federal safety regulators are considering more fines against Toyota on top of a $16.4 million penalty sought this week for taking too long to notify them of defective accelerator pedals.

title: Showing a Couples Eye for Art (and Money)
description: A half-century ago, before the phrase Pop Art was even coined, a taxi tycoon named Robert C. Scull started buying up dozens of works by artists like Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg and Andy Warhol.

title: Evan Williamss Message to Twitter Developers
description: The romance between Twitter and its outside developers has hit a rough patch, one that Chief Executive Evan Williams, along with many Twitter developers, saw coming.

title: Singing at Mass, Then on Broadway
description: Vanessa Williams has received recurring Emmy nominations for her portrayal of the glamorous, viperish magazine editor Wilhelmina Slater on the series Ugly Betty, which ends a four-year run on April 14. A chanteuse since childhood, Ms. Williams, 47, was the first African-American woman to be crowned Miss America in 1984, but resigned when nude photos of her surfaced in Penthouse magazine. She is currently on Broadway in the musical Sondheim on Sondheim. Twice divorced, she lives in a renovated 1905 farmhouse in Chappaqua with the two youngest of her four children.

title: For New York Runners, a White House Stop
description: The New York Road Runners, the organization that sponsors the New York Marathon and supports the citys public school running programs, made a stop at the White House Childhood Obesity summit today.

title: Obama Nominee to Legal Office Withdraws
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas choice to lead the powerful Office of Legal Counsel at the Justice Department withdrew from consideration for the post on Friday, ending a troubled but high-profile nomination that had dragged on for more than a year.

title: Struggling in Zimbabwe
description: Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof shares his photographs taken on a recent trip to Zimbabwe, where bad governance has left the country a shambles.

title: Stupaks Abortion Deal and His Exit
description: Representative Bart Stupak, the anti-abortion Democrat from Michigan who was central to negotiating a compromise with the Obama administration in passing the health care bill in March, announced on Friday that he would not seek re-election. He said that his main legislative goal  health care reform  had been accomplished and that he was ready to do other things. Even so, he has been under intense pressure from Tea Party supporters who opposed the health care overhaul and abortion opponents who said he betrayed their cause.

title: Notable Opinions by Justice Stevens
description: A selection of major cases during Justice John Paul Stevens's term on the Supreme Court.

title: Bloggingheads: The G.O.P.'s Race Problem
description: Matthew Yglesias, left, of the Center for American Progress and David Weigel of The Washington Post discuss Republicans and race.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 9
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: U.S. Reviews New York Police Dealings With People Who Dont Speak English
description: The Justice Department has begun reviewing how the New York Police Department interacts with New Yorkers who do not speak English, focusing on whether language barriers play a role in matters like car stops, emergency calls, arrests, crime prevention and the filing of complaints.

title: Unleashing Operatics Hidden in Brahms
description: Antonio Pappano, the music director of the Royal Opera House, has devoted most of his career to opera, and when he conducted the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, his operatic instincts  a penchant for shapely lines and dramatic contrasts  were fully in control.

title: A Park With a Different Sort of Opening Day
description: Under clouds of rain and dust, bulldozers picked through the shrinking ruins of the old Yankee Stadium on Friday. Across the street, at the gleaming new stadium festooned with huge banners, preparations continued for Opening Day next week.

title: Challenging Iran, With YouTube Views
description: VIENNA, Va.

title: Many Filers Confused by Stimulus Tax Credit
description: As the deadline approaches for filing tax returns, the process of claiming a tax break created by the stimulus package has proved to be more work than millions of people had bargained for.

title: Pakistan Begins to Ease Backlog of Visas for American Diplomats
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A logjam blocking visas for United States diplomats in Pakistan has been broken, a senior American official said during a visit here on Friday.

title: A Sondheim Tribute to Politics and Other Craziness
description: Its not as if New York hasnt known its share of power-addicted, egomaniac mayors. But theres something special about Cora Hoover Hooper, the impeccably coiffed basket case who runs the broken-down little town in Anyone Can Whistle, Stephen Sondheim and Arthur Laurentss muddled musical from 1964, which is stylishly exploring its own identity crisis at City Center this weekend.

title: If You Know, but Shouldnt, You Cant Act on It
description: What is a normal winning percentage for a duplicate pair event?

title: Where Musicals Can Dare to Be Different
description: For those who dismiss musicals as the theatrical equivalent of cheerleading, the Bay Area arts scene is demanding that they be taken seriously.

title: Canada: Honors at an Eras End
description: Canada marked the death of its last living World War I veteran on Friday with solemn ceremonies at the National War Memorial in Ottawa and at a Canadian memorial near Vimy, France. John Babcock, 109, died Feb. 18 at his home in Spokane, Wash. Canada originally planned to hold a state funeral, an event normally reserved for prime ministers and governor-generals, to observe the last veterans death. But when it became apparent that Mr. Babcock was the final survivor, he asked that any ceremony honor all Canadians who fought in the war. To enlist, Mr. Babcock lied about his age. When it was discovered in Britain that he was only 15 at enlistment, he was kept from the battlefields. In 1946, he became an American citizen. His Canadian citizenship was restored in 2008.

title: Sri Lanka: Governing Party Wins Large Majority in Vote
description: The governing party won a large majority in parliamentary elections held Thursday, cementing President Mahinda Rajapaksas control over a nation struggling to recover from a quarter century of civil war. Mr. Rajapaksa was re-elected in January in a landslide after delivering on his promise to defeat the Tamil Tiger insurgency. His main opponent, a retired army general, Sarath Fonseka, was arrested soon after the election, raising fears that the country was headed toward autocracy. The size of the governments victory will not be known until voting is held again in two districts where results were annulled because of election day violence. Mr. Rajapaksa has pledged to unite the country after the polls, but his critics say he is a divisive figure who will only exacerbate the countrys deep ethnic and religious divides.

title: Meinhardt Raabe, Famous Munchkin, Is Dead at 94
description: As coroner, I must aver I thoroughly examined her. And shes not only merely dead, Shes really most sincerely dead.

title: Harems, Villagers and Advancing Armies
description: Theres nothing like sitting down to see a performance for the first time and feeling as if youd seen it all before. Craft can be learned, and honed. But artistic voice? Thats another matter.

title: For Whom the Bridge Toll Ends a Trip Thats Free
description: ZIP code 11693 in southeastern Queens spans two communities divided by water and a half-mile-long toll bridge. One of them is Broad Channel, a narrow island in Jamaica Bay with cottages on stilts and a quaint business district that has a nail salon, a bar, a pizzeria, a deli and little else.

title: Pumping Wine, With Flair
description: In what was once a gas station, Derek and Carol Todd are offering fill-ups of a different sort: whites, reds and sparkling pinks. Heavy on small producers, with an emphasis on organic and biodynamic wines, Wine Geeks  the couples shop, which retains many of the buildings cool concrete-block and cement surfaces  offers fun for aficionados and neophytes alike.

title: A Touch of France, on a Shoestring
description: IN this season of shad runs and early tag sales, a sweet little restaurant called Juniper in Hastings-on-Hudson is causing diners to take notice. Just three months old, this tiny place is often fully booked for dinner on weekends. I cant think of anywhere else in Westchester where you can eat like this at these prices.

title: Republicans Weighing Partys Message
description: NEW ORLEANS  Should Republicans be the party of no? Or the party of yes?

title: In Search of Flavors That Go Beyond the Deli Counter
description: LIKE many of his customers, Allin Tallmadge fell in love with cheese in Europe.

title: For the Senses: Food, Lights and Sounds
description: WE follow our hostess, a slight young woman with high-heel, knee-high black boots pulled over tight black jeans, to a table at the edge of the cavernous, futuristic space. Techno rock blares and booms; one wall is a light show, colors shifting with the beat. Its hip. Its loud. And it works.

title: Judge Rules for Lehman in Sale Case
description: A federal judge on Friday rejected a bid by Barclays to throw out a motion by Lehman Brothers Holdings to recover an $11 billion windfall the bank supposedly made on the purchase of the bankrupt firms North American brokerage.

title: Reshaping the Art of Nature
description: In the last few decades, quite a few sculptors and installation artists working with materials scavenged from nature have risen to the forefront of the international art world.

title: Paintings Meant for Each Other
description: No, its not a still from How to Train Your Dragon. The dark-haired woman encircled by a fearsome monster, her deep red cloak clearly caught between its jaws, is St. Margaret, and she has just escaped from the belly of the beast, thanks to the miraculous cross she holds with four fingers. The fifth, her slender pinky, pokes daintily into the air.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about the increasing numbers of college students taking unpaid internships, using erroneous information from a report by the Economic Policy Institute, misstated the results of a 2008 survey by the National Association of Colleges and Employers and also the results of a Northwestern University study in 1992 . The NACE survey found that 50 percent of graduating students had participated in internships, not 83 percent. The university study found that of graduating students in 1992, 17 percent  not 9 percent  had held internships.

title: More Awesomeness, or John Wayne Part 2
description: Ive been reminded that, in my earlier column on what to me were three glorious days spent in the company of John Wayne, I said that there is more to the story. Heres what I meant:

title: Off the Leash
description: A.R. Gurney certainly knows his WASPs. In plays like The Dining Room and The Cocktail Hour, he wields his stiletto pen to dissect the breed with the precision of a surgeon.

title: Views of Maos China, and What It Became
description: With just over a dozen artists, State of the Dao, at the Lehman College Art Gallery, is smaller than many of the Chinese contemporary art shows that have come to the New York region over the past decade. But it is just as politically attuned.

title: Pope Put Off Punishing Abusive Priest
description: The priest, convicted of tying up and abusing two young boys in a California church rectory, wanted to leave the ministry.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about an e-mail exchange in January between two Toyota officials who were discussing problems with accelerator pedals misstated the sequence of the messages. According to the e-mail time stamps, a message from a Toyota communications coordinator that advised colleagues not to mention mechanical failures came before  not in response to  a message from a Toyota executive in the United States urging the company to acknowledge such a problem.

title: What Were Reading: Privacy, Revolution and a Touch-Screen Stylus
description: A light reading day as the workweek comes to a close. The tech reporters and editors of The New York Times suggested these:

title: Amid the Attention, Woods Is Right at Home at the Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  When Tiger Woods completed his second round Friday, after a workmanlike two-under-par 70 put him squarely in contention for his fifth Masters title, he was asked if he liked where he was.

title: Need a Spot? Give One
description: New York parking stinks, but its like the weather  and I dont mean last weeks weather  what can you do about it? Why, you can build an iPhone tool, of course. Or tweet. Or text message. Two very different new parking ventures use a combination of these media: one in hopes of saving you time, the other in hopes of saving the world.

title: OConnor on the Court
description: This week I was invited to a lunch at which former Justice Sandra Day OConnor of the Supreme Court was the speaker. With the rumbling about Justice John Paul Stevenss impending departure, I just had to go.

title: Canadian State Minister Facing a Police Investigation Resigns
description: OTTAWA  Prime Minister Stephen Harper asked the Royal Canadian Mounted Police to investigate Helena Guergis, his minister of state for the status of women, before she resigned Friday from his cabinet as well as the Conservative Party Caucus.

title: Twitter Acquires Atebits, Maker of Tweetie
description: Twitter, which has flourished thanks to tools built by outside developers, is taking more of those tools under its own wing. In a move that is sure to rattle its developers, Twitter has agreed to acquire Atebits, the start-up that makes the Tweetie apps for using Twitter on Mac computers and iPhones. The acquisition price was not disclosed.

title: A Sinkhole Offers Plenty of Nothing to Talk About
description: Jose Fonseca considers himself something of a pothole connoisseur.

title: Corrections
description: Two captions for three pictures on Page 22 this weekend with an article about the band MGMT are reversed. The band members in the top photograph are Andrew VanWyngarden, gesturing, and Ben Goldwasser. In the picture at the bottom, showing the two of them at the 2008 Bonnaroo festival in Tennessee, Mr. Goldwasser is at the left and Mr. VanWyngarden at the right. (Mr. VanWyngarden and Matt Asti are correctly identified in the center photograph.)

title: Corrections
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: The Urgency of Bearing Witness
description: He has been telling the story for more than 60 years: expelled from school at 13 for being Jewish; arrested at 16; sentenced to labor in the service of Nazi Germany until an SS guards blow landed him, at 20, on the doorstep of death  an infirmary at Auschwitz.

title: Mitt Romney on Health Care: A Particular Spin
description: BEDFORD, N.H.  When it comes to health care, Mitt Romney is hoping to have it both ways, even as he accuses the White House of doing the same.

title: The East End Comes West
description: Late winter is not the most popular time for visits to vineyards on the East End, so 25 producers brought their wines to New York City on March 18 for a tasting, A Vacation in a Glass.

title: With the Closing of a Hospital, Womens Childbirth Options Diminish
description: Its not a sales pitch that would work for most businesses: Well let you endure excruciating pain for as long as you want. You have our word!

title: Old Tuscan Favorites and New Roman Ones
description: TRATTORIA DIANE in Roslyn has taken a new turn. Again. It was originally Dianes Restaurant, opened in 1992 by John Durkin and his wife, Diane Margaritis, next door to their 10-year-old bakery. The menu was predominantly French. Five years later, after falling in love with the food of Tuscany, the couple turned the restaurant into Trattoria Diane.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 9, 2010

title: Veracity of the Defendant Is Key in Hate-Killing Trial
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  By Wednesday, when the prosecution rested its case against the Long Island teenager accused of killing a Hispanic immigrant as part of a hate crime, the jury had listened to testimony from 23 witnesses since March 18 and had seen scores of exhibits, including surveillance video, maps, blood-stained clothes and a picture of a swastika tattoo on the teenagers leg.

title: The Well-Off Are Spending Again  but Carefully
description: The wealthy are cautiously opening their wallets again.

title: Republicans Pose Test for Treaty With Russia
description: PRAGUE  As President Obama headed home on Friday with a freshly inked arms control treaty in hand, he faced a new challenge that may be every bit as vexing as negotiating with Russians: making common cause with Republicans.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Magazine Advertising Pages Declined 9.4% in Quarter
description: The ad-page retreat isnt over yet.

title: Abel Muzorewa, African Cleric and Politician, Dies at 85
description: Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa, once a central player in white minority plans to blunt black majority rule in what is now Zimbabwe, died on Thursday in Harare, the capital, the state-controlled Herald newspaper said Friday. He was 85.

title: Mohsen Sazegara's Green Revolution
description: A prominent Iranian dissident produces a nearly daily Web video from his basement in suburban Virginia.

title: Tight N.B.A. Scoring Race Comes Down to James and Durant
description: In the waning days of a breakout season, Kevin Durant will be confronted with thorny decisions. Shoot or pass. Lead or defer. Attack or hang back. His mentor will not be there to guide him. But he knows exactly what he would say.

title: A Psychologist Steeped in Treatment of Sexually Active Priests
description: Leslie Lothstein has seen them all: priests sexually active with adult men, others with adult women, others with adolescents, others with children. By his own count, Dr. Lothstein, a psychologist at the Institute of Living, in Hartford, has treated about 300 Roman Catholic priests, not only those with sexual problems, but also those with alcoholism, depression and other mental illnesses.

title: Wife Who Hired Cousin to Kill Husband Appeals Conviction
description: In a last-minute decision, the judge ordered defense lawyers to cram overnight and deliver closing arguments the next morning, but gave prosecutors the weekend to write theirs.

title: Manhattan Prosecutors Dispute Jurors Account in Astor Trial
description: A holdout jurors claim that another jurors threats caused her to cave in and convict Brooke Astors son of fraud was exaggerated and inaccurate, Manhattan prosecutors argued in a brief filed on Friday.

title: 45 Across: Turning Up on the Farm?
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  The one thing that really jumps out at me when looking at this grid is the abundance of less-common letters, in many cases two, three or even four of them in the same word. I can almost hear Kevin Der giving some sort of cruciverbal speech for this puzzle: I couldnt done it without the valuable contributions of J, Q, W, B, X, C, Z and two letters that have been with me from the very beginning, K and V.

title: Fathers, Brothers, Husbands, Sons: Mining Towns in Mourning
description: They were novices of barely 20, and veterans in their 60s; beaming first-time fathers, and papaws who coddled their grandchildren. Despite those differences, they were all members of the same proud and self-reliant tribe  West Virginia coal miners. Every day, they carried their lunch buckets and tool belts into a world whose dangers were a fact of life, a fact made stark when an explosion at the Upper Big Branch mine in Montcoal on Monday killed these eight men and 21 others. Their families say these men, wedded to the mountains and hollows of the coal country where many were born and raised, would never have considered doing anything else. SHAILA DEWAN

title: As a Hiring Filter, Credit Checks Draw Questions
description: In defending employers use of credit checks as part of the hiring process, Eric Rosenberg of the TransUnion credit bureau paints a sobering picture.

title: Little Job Security for Basketball Coaches in New York City Area
description: Bob Hurley, the St. Anthony High School coach and recent Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame inductee, has been a model of stability in his 38 years at the small Jersey City school. By his standards of stillness, the coaching changes among colleges in the New York City area have been dizzying.

title: My Boss, Justice Stevens
description: On Friday, John Paul Stevens, the longest-serving Supreme Court justice on the bench, announced that he would retire at the end of the term. The Op-Ed editors asked six of his former clerks to share their memories of working for him.

title: Reyes Is Ready, Not a Moment Too Soon
description: Jose Reyes jogged across the Mets clubhouse in Citi Field late Friday afternoon and sat down in front of his locker  a star-status location in the front-left corner of the room, with extra berths on one side and cupboard doors on the other.

title: Zenyatta, Now 16-0, Secures Share of Record
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark.  Zenyatta bowed twice  deep, head-bobbing, theatrical flourishes that telegraphed to an adoring audience that it was about to see something special. Her groom, Mario Espinoza, smiled as the more than 44,973 fans crammed into Oaklawn Park, a cozy racetrack beneath the Ouachita Mountains, roared in delight Friday night.

title: Greenspan Criticized for Characterization of Colleague
description: WASHINGTON  In the summer of 2007, as he was dying from blood-cell cancer, Edward M. Gramlich, a former member of the Federal Reserves board of governors, sent a handwritten note to Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman under whom he had served.

title: California Labor Dept. Revises Guidelines on When Interns Must Be Paid
description: Californias labor department has issued updated guidelines on whether internships should be paid or unpaid, with the new rules giving employers slightly more latitude not to pay them.

title: California: Union Wins Damages
description: A federal jury in San Francisco awarded more than $1.5 million in damages to the Service Employees International Union on Friday in a lawsuit that accused a breakaway union local and its leaders of illegally undermining the S.E.I.U. The jury ordered the breakaway unit, the National Union of Healthcare Workers, to pay $724,000 and ordered several of its leaders, including Sal Rosselli, its president, to pay $30,000 to $74,000 each. The S.E.I.U., which put its large Oakland health care local into trusteeship 15 months ago, prompting the breakaway, said the verdict showed that the Rosselli group had illegally used union money and salaries to finance the breakaway. Saying it would ask the judge to overturn the verdict, Mr. Rossellis group noted that 12 defendants had been cleared of all charges and that the jury award fell far short of the $25 million the S.E.I.U. was seeking.

title: Rangers Top Flyers to Set Up Showdown
description: The Rangers fell behind in the very first minute. They blew a 3-1 lead and then withstood a withering Flyers barrage near the end to prevail, 4-3, in a virtual win-or-go-home game Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: New York State Backs Remorseful Buyers at Rushmore Tower
description: Call it the multimillion-dollar typo.

title: Third-World Brain Drain
description: To the Editor:

title: Heres Why Im So Glum
description: To the Editor:

title: Running in Circles in Kyrgyzstan
description: Fairfax, Va.

title: A Better Way to Protect Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Place to Live
description: The spring weeds are up again behind the fences in the empty field at Larkfield and Pulaski Roads in East Northport, N.Y. In the world of not-in-my-backyard suburbia, this is ground zero.

title: Justice Stevens
description: President Obama might be tempted to replace Justice John Paul Stevens with someone bland enough to slip through the Republican chain of opposition in the Senate. If he is, we recommend he read a few of the opinions that Justice Stevens wrote in the last 34 years.

title: Name That Revolution
description: We have become depressingly accustomed to the wilting of revolutions in former Soviet republics, whether Orange in Ukraine, Rose in Georgia or, now, the Tulip Revolution in Kyrgyzstan.

title: Redoing the City Charter
description: To help quiet the uproar about changing New York Citys term-limits law so he could run for a third term, Mayor Michael Bloomberg promised to set up a commission to rethink the City Charter from top to bottom. The mayor has said every issue will be on the table, and every voice will be heard, which is appropriate for what amounts to the first major review of the citys governing constitution since 1989.

title: The Race to the Top of the Education Peak
description: To the Editor:

title: A Voice of Reason
description: The Republican Party is not simply the just-say-no party. Its also a shameless advocate of the free lunch. Ronald Reagan famously told us he could jack up defense spending, cut taxes and balance the federal budget all at the same time.

title: The Curse of the Wow Factor
description: In the middle of 2008, Hillary Clinton transformed herself from a perfectly-fine-but-slightly-boring presidential candidate to a really terrific campaigner. This all happened too late to help her candidacy. But some of us hoped that it might be the beginning of a new era. Women in politics had always had a reputation for being honest and steady and hard-working. Maybe some of the next generation would also have a wow factor.

title: The Palestinians Use of Nonviolence
description: To the Editor:

title: Return of Vazquez Leads to Humbling of Yankees
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Joe Girardis strides were long and purposeful as he approached the mound in the sixth inning Friday night, as if he were late for an appointment. Javier Vazquez placed the ball in Girardis hand and walked toward the dugout, his pace slow and deliberate, as if he had bad news to deliver.

title: City Leader in Fight on Terror Will Resign
description: The New York Police Departments top counterterrorism official, a former National Security Council staff member who has led the citys anti-terror efforts for nearly four years, will leave the department in the coming weeks, several people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

title: Europe Acts to Ensure Its Imported Timber Is Legal
description: TEMERLOH, Malaysia  Huge meranti tree trunks, many of them destined for faraway shores, are piled high along the road in this town about a two-hour drive northeast of Kuala Lumpur, awaiting their date with the saw.

title: Only 16 and Enjoying His Success at Augusta
description: He seemed like the kid who was whistling his way past the graveyard. You know, the one trying to ignore the bogeyman and maybe it would not leap out and eat him.

title: If This Is April, Teixeira Must Be Eager for May
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  As a 22-year-old rookie with Texas in 2003, Mark Teixeira went hitless in his first 16 major-league at-bats. The dry spell seemed to foreshadow his performance in April for the rest of his career. Every season, it seems, Teixeira starts slowly, and after the Yankees first three games in 2010, he is 0 for 12.

title: Pelfrey Plus Four Homers Adds Up to a Mets Rout
description: Before the Mets beat Washington, 8-2, on Friday night, the excitement in the clubhouse in Citi Field was over the return of shortstop Jose Reyes, who will probably play Saturday.

title: China Sees First Trade Deficit in Years
description: HONG KONG  China announced on Saturday that it had a trade deficit of $7.24 billion last month, its first monthly trade deficit in nearly six years, as imports jumped along with a surging domestic economy while exports grew more modestly.

title: Bay Area Emerges as Center of Nonprofit Journalism
description: In its ten months of existence, California Watch, an offshoot of the Center for Investigative Reporting, which is located in Berkeley, has placed 21 stories with the San Francisco Chronicle. One of those stories, on seismic safety in Californias public colleges and universities, was distributed to more than 80 news outlets, Robert Rosenthal, the centers executive editor, said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit in some editions last Saturday with the National Hockey League roundup misspelled the surname of the photographer. The picture, of Devils goalie Martin Brodeur making a second-period save, was taken by Jim McIsaac, not McIssac.

title: Classic Ad: Pontiac Tempest
description: Richard S. Changs profile of Jackie Saril and her 1961 Pontiac Tempest, which appears in this Sundays Automobiles section, gives us an opportunity  or better yet, an excuse  to marvel at this strange carnival-themed ad for the 1963 Tempest.

title: Polish President Dies in Jet Crash in Russia
description: This article was reported by Nicholas Kulish, Ellen Barry and Michal Piotrowski, and written by Ms. Barry.

title: Is Kevin Kolb Ready? He Had Better Be
description: Repeat: Kolb can play. McNabb would still be here if the Eagles didnt believe that to be true. Rich Hoffman, The Philadelphia Daily News, in a recent column

title: Kaczynski Often a Source of Tension Within E.U.
description: Lech Kaczynski, who died Saturday in a plane crash in western Russia, rose from childhood fame as an actor to become president of Poland. He was 60.

title: Urban Forager | Dont Compost That Weed
description: I love chickweed, the delicate, sprawling ground cover that tastes like corn. So when I attended Volunteer Day at East New York Farms in Brooklyn last Saturday and had to weed out giant handfuls of it, it was a little like I could hear Janis Joplin singing, Take another little piece of my heart, now baby.

title: World Leaders, Especially Merkel, Express Sadness
description: BERLIN  World leaders expressed sadness on Saturday after an airplane crash in Russia killed President Lech Kaczynski of Poland and some of his countrys leading military, banking and foreign policy experts.

title: From Darfur to a Corner of Brooklyn
description: SOME arrived as early as 1987, others as recently as this year. Many came by way of Fort Wayne, Ind., where they originally landed as refugees but could not find enough work. Now, more than 300 immigrants from the war-torn Darfur region of Sudan live in Kensington, Brooklyn, according to the leaders of the Darfur Peoples Association of New York, a community group.

title: The Most Radical President
description: Monologue |  Friday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Yesterday, Newt Gingrich called Barack Obama the most radical president in American history. You cant really read into that until you know how he said it. Did he say it like Newt Gingrich, or did he say it like Donatello from the ninja turtles? Hes the most radical president in American history, dude. Bodacious pizza!

title: A Great Day to Be Old
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Its a great day for old people. A 96-year-old man in South Africa became the worlds oldest bungee jumper. It is a great day to be old  one because of the bungee jump guy and the new trend sweeping the fashion world is gray hair. It was in The New York Times. Actually the only people who still read The New York Times have got gray hair.

title: Mad at America
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: Hamid Karzai is mad at America. He said we said his government is riddled with corruption, bribes, kickbacks and payoffs. So, looks like theyre trying to pass health care over there, too.

title: Saturday Word: Tax Breaks
description: President Obama this morning highlighted the tax breaks that 100 million Americans can use to save hundreds or even thousands of dollars when they file their income tax returns, including a credit for families with children in college, for first-time homebuyers and for those who weatherized their homes.

title: Iran Wants Sunnis in Iraqi Politics
description: BAGHDAD  Iran, which has acted as a major power broker in Iraqi politics, called Saturday for Iraqi leaders to include Sunnis in the long-overdue new government and said Shiites would have to form an alliance with them for that to happen.

title: What Is, and Isnt, Appropriate Deficit Spending?
description: WASHINGTON  To Senator Tom Coburn, the idea of providing extended unemployment pay to the nations long-term jobless without finding money elsewhere in the federal budget to cover the added benefits amounts to a crime.

title: Violence Erupts in Thai Streets
description: BANGKOK  Antigovernment protesters repulsed an attempt by the military to disperse them on Saturday in fierce running battles filled with tear gas, gunfire and explosions in the worst political violence in nearly 20 years.

title: Acrostic Jeopardy!
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Our last acrostic post had a Wheel of Fortune spin to it, so to speak. Not one to leave well enough alone, Ive decided to continue in a similar vein today by revealing some answers  er, questions  Jeopardy! style. To see them, highlight the space between the brackets.

title: S. Africa President Rebukes a Disciple
description: JOHANNESBURG  President Jacob Zuma of South Africa reprimanded his most outspoken and often outrageous disciple on Saturday, issuing a statement that Julius Malema ought to button his lip.

title: In Brooklyn, Hope for a Home Far Away
description: On Sunday, April 11, Sudan will hold its first multiparty election in more than 20 years. The more than 300 Sudanese immigrants who live in a tight-knit community in Kensington, Brooklyn, will be able to vote in the election. Some of them are not sure their vote will count.

title: Redirecting the Discussion of Brain Trauma
description: Six women from diverse backgrounds have redirected the discussion of brain trauma and former N.F.L. players.

title: Vatican Defends Handling of a Case in California
description: ROME  The future Pope Benedict XVI, dealing with a request to defrock a child-molesting priest in California, was handling it as a dismissal from the priesthood  not an abuse case  and acted expeditiously by the standards of the time, a lawyer for the Holy See said in a statement released Saturday.

title: In Mine Safety, a Meek Watchdog
description: This article was reported by Michael Cooper, Gardiner Harris and Eric Lipton, and written by Mr. Cooper.

title: The Other Augusta
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The geographic divide between the two golf courses measures 4.3 miles. They share similar proximity in the Yellow Pages.

title: G.O.P. Weighs Political Price of Court Fight
description: WASHINGTON  The retirement of Justice John Paul Stevens presents a test for Republicans as much as it does for President Obama as they weigh how much they want to wage a high-profile battle over ideological issues in the months before crucial midterm elections.

title: In N.F.L. Fight, Women Lead the Way
description: Those who have followed the debate over the risks of sports concussions nodded knowingly Monday when its most significant legal action to date was brought by a woman.

title: Clinton Calls Acting Leader of Kyrgyzstan
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  The United States made its first high-level contact with the interim government of Kyrgyzstan on Saturday, getting assurances that the new leadership would live up to previous agreements and allow American use of an airport that plays an important role in supplying the war effort in Afghanistan.

title: Pakistan Begins Its Largest Military Exercises in 20 Years
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A month of military exercises began in Pakistan this weekend, the countrys biggest drills in 20 years, in what analysts said was a show of military muscle meant mainly to impress a domestic audience.

title: Staff Dispute Shuts Gorilla Coffee
description: Its been a bleary-eyed Saturday in Park Slope: Gorilla Coffee is closed because of dispute between the staff and the owners.

title: At Long Last, Reyes Is Back
description: For the first time since May 20, 2009, Jose Reyes was in the starting lineup, leading off and playing shortstop for the Mets.

title: Basketball Grad School for 3 Ivy League Stars
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va.  One month after finishing an exceptional basketball career at Harvard, Jeremy Lin was playing for a team sponsored by a water sealant company.

title: As Families Gather at Dover, Efforts to Ease Pain
description: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del.  Shortly after 4:20 a.m. on Easter Sunday, a pair of flag-covered cases with the remains of two Marines, both killed the previous week in Afghanistan, were carried out of the belly of a C-17 into the sight of their waiting families.

title: Westwood and Mickelson on Top at the Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  It was a Saturday like few others in the history of the Masters, a tournament that has just about had it all. It was a civilized brawl, a donnybrook with the top players in the game knocking down flagsticks, trading stunning shots, swapping the lead and coming back for more.

title: A Treadmill in Afghanistan on the Road to Boston
description: The knees. Thats where Paul Zeizel feels it most after an hour on the treadmill in the morning and maybe another hour on machines in the evening. Ice and medication for the knees, from all that repetition.

title: Correction: The Great Proton Smashup
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the Large Hadron Collider referred incorrectly to the cooling effect of the Big Bang. It was the universe  not the Earth  that the Big Bang caused to coolfrom billions or trillions of degrees to superfrigid temperatures today.

title: Tribes of Amazon Find an Ally Out of Avatar
description: VOLTA GRANDE DO XINGU, Brazil  They came from the far reaches of the Amazon, traveling in small boats and canoes for up to three days to discuss their fate. James Cameron, the Hollywood titan, stood before them with orange warrior streaks painted on his face, comparing the threats on their lands to a snake eating its prey.

title: Rangers Are Hoping to Complete the Surge
description: For the Rangers, the season has come down to one game, Sunday afternoon in Philadelphia. Win, and they are in the playoffs after the most astonishing late-season surge since the club was founded in 1926. Lose, and the surge will have been all for naught.

title: The Dixie Walker She Knew
description: Innocently, then tentatively, Susan Walker would tell a friend or an acquaintance that she happened to be the daughter of a major league baseball player. Which one, she would be asked. After a while, she knew the mere mention of the name might draw a furrowed brow or a sideways glance.

title: Aim for the Fence, Dont Hit the Roof
description: A new baseball season is an expressionof possibility. And so it was on April 9, 45 years ago, when the Yankees traveled to Houston for a game at the new Astrodome. The Times was there:

title: When Cupid Strikes at the Cubicle
description: Q. You are interested in dating someone you work with. You cant help thinking that had you met this person outside of work, you might not have been as attracted. Why is that?

title: Prime Number
description: 47: The percentage of households in the United Statesthat will pay no federal income taxes for 2009, according to projections by the Tax Policy Center, a research group. The group said incomes in those households were too low, or the households qualified for enough credits, deductions and exemptions to eliminate their liability.

title: Worlds Without Women
description: WASHINGTON

title: Workers Strike Over Beer Ban
description: Hundreds of workers at the Danish brewer Carlsberg walked off the job in Copenhagen last week to protest a new policy restricting beer drinking at work to lunch breaks. Warehouse workers used to be able to help themselves to beer throughout the day  provided they didnt get drunk. There has been free beer, water and soft drinks everywhere, Jens Bekke, a Carlsberg spokesman, told Reuters. The worlds fourth largest brewer, Carlsberg had been considering the restrictions for years. Carlsbergs truck drivers joined the strike in sympathy, Mr. Bekke said, even though they are exempt from the new rules. Drivers are permitted to drink three beers a day outside of lunch hours. No worries, says the company. Carlsbergs trucks are equipped with alcohol ignition locks.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 11
description: The Obama administrations nuclear policy dethrones health care at the top of the ticket Sunday as Hillary Clinton, the Secretary of State, and Robert Gates, the Secretary of Defense, team up on the talk shows ahead of the Nuclear Security Summit beginning Monday in Washington.

title: Drawn to the Music
description: MY first memory of loving music was listening to Eine kleine Nachtmusik by Mozart on my Victrola when I was 4. At elementary school, I wanted to play the flute. by the time it was my turn to choose, all the flutes were taken. I picked the violin instead but was not particularly diligent in my practicing.

title: The Youngest Does Not Mean Cant Miss
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Matteo Manassero, 16, is piling up some impressive designations, many of them prefaced by two words that cut both ways: the youngest. The youngest player in Masters history, the youngest to make the cut in Masters history, the youngest (by two years) to win the 124-year-old British Amateur Championship. And Manassero, a pleasant, soft-spoken teenager from Verona, Italy, already has veteran Masters watchers comparing his short game to the wizardry of Seve Ballesteros and saying he is a more polished player than Tiger Woods at the same age.

title: Quotations of the Week
description: Theres going to be a whale of a fight if he appoints an activist to the court. Thats not good for him, its not good for the Senate, its not good for the country. Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, on President Obamas yet-to-be-announced nominee to replace the retiring Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens.

title: Does Dixie Walker Deserve Scorn or Sympathy?
description: Forgiveness is one of the most prominent and continuous narratives in the American sports culture. Famously successful athletes break laws or commit socially reprehensible sins, deal with the consequences and ultimately throw themselves before the court of public opinion.

title: Young Superheroes in a Hut
description: VICTORIA FALLS, Zimbabwe

title: From Embattled Pope, Praise for a Predecessor
description: ROME  As the Roman Catholic Church continued to battle a sexual abuse crisis, Pope Benedict XVI spent Friday evening watching a movie. And not just any movie: a biopic about wartime Pope Pius XII, one of the most contentious figures to haunt his five-year-old papacy.

title: Is Disneys Chief Having a Cinderella Moment?
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Waiting Continues for Garcia
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  There was a time when people thought Sergio Garcia might win the Masters tournament some day, along with a bunch of other major golf championships. In 2004, he finished in a tie for fourth at the Masters. In 2002, when he was 22, he was the only player in the world to finish in the top 10 in all four majors. Garcia turned 30 in January and he is still waiting for that major championship victory.

title: Where Running for Cover Is Part of the Job
description: In an age of robotically assembled automobiles and pilotless drones, extracting coal remains a stubbornly labor intensive and dangerous enterprise. But there are even riskier ways to earn a living, like logging or commercial fishing.

title: No One Is to Blame for Anything
description: I was right 70 percent of the time, but I was wrong 30 percent of the time, said Alan Greenspan as he testified last week on Capitol Hill. Greenspan  a k a the Oracle during his 18-year-plus tenure as Fed chairman  could not have more vividly illustrated how and why geniuses of his stature were out to lunch while Wall Street imploded. No doubt he applied his full brain power to that 70-30 calculation. But the big picture eludes him. If the captain of the Titanic followed the Greenspan model, he could claim he was on course at least 70 percent of the time too.

title: Innovation, by Order of the Kremlin
description: MOSCOW

title: Rethinking a Gospel of the Web
description: FOR about a decade now, ever since it became clear that the jungle of the World Wide Web would triumph over the walled gardens of CompuServe, AOL and MSN, a general consensus has solidified among the otherwise fractious population of People Who Think Big Thoughts About the Internet.

title: Taking a Chance on Thames in the Outfield
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  When Jason Bartletts liner to left evaded the outstretched glove of the Yankees Marcus Thames on Friday night, Im sure more than a few of you were thinking that Brett Gardner would have caught it. Manager Joe Girardi thought so, too.

title: The Choices, When Death Is Near
description: To the Editor:

title: Rah-Rah Isnt for Everyone
description: This interview with Jilly Stephens, executive director of City Harvest,  based in New York, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Inventors Wanted. Cool Tools Provided.
description: Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Turnaround of India State Could Serve as a Model
description: PATNA, India  For decades the sprawling state of Bihar, flat and scorching as a griddle, was something between a punch line and a cautionary tale, the exact opposite of the high-tech, rapidly growing, rising global power India has sought to become.

title: Grabbing Gracefully, With Replacement Fingers
description: ERIC JONES sat in a middle seat on a recent flight from the New York area to Florida, but he wasnt complaining. Instead, he was quietly enjoying actions that many other people might take for granted, like taking a cup of coffee from the flight attendant or changing the channel on his video monitor.

title: The Danger of Always Being On
description: THE Times introduced a regular video newscast on its Web site late last month. TimesCast shows scenes from the morning meeting where planning starts for the next days paper, and it features editors and reporters discussing the top stories that are developing, often with compelling video and photography from world hot spots.

title: Hidden Explosives Are Found at a Hospital Run by an Italian Charity in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Suicide vests and grenades hidden in boxes of medicine were found Saturday in a hospital run by an Italian charity in the capital of Helmand Province, Lashkar Gah, and three Italian citizens were detained along with six Afghans who worked at the hospital, according to the provincial governor and Interior Ministry officials in Kabul.

title: Do Popes Quit?
description: VATICAN CITY  He is elected for life, by a group of elderly men infused with the will of God. People address him as Holy Father, not Mr. President. After bishop of Rome, his second title is vicar of Jesus Christ.

title: Dont Bet the Farm on the Housing Recovery
description: MUCH hope has been pinned on the recovery in home prices that began about a year ago. A long-lasting housing recovery might provide a balm to households, mortgage lenders and the entire United States economy. But will the recovery be sustained?

title: In Currency Games, the Prize May Be a Trade War
description: THE United States and China have edged away from a trade war, but both sides are keeping their powder dry.

title: No Regulation? No Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: A Consumption Tax, Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: Healthy Incentives at Work
description: To the Editor:

title: One Man, Two Courts
description: New Haven

title: Another Dead Child-Bride
