description: 6:18 p.m. | Updated The New York Timess Miguel Helft provides more details of Palms efforts to sell itself.

title: Airline Mergers Are Necessary, I.A.T.A. Chief Says
description: Further mergers among airlines are essential in order to cut costs and improve competitiveness in an industry seen sustaining combined losses of $2.8 billion this year, the head of the airline industry body, the International Air Transport Association, said Monday.

title: Not Yet Athens on the Potomac
description: Greece may be enviable as the ancient cradle of democracy, but no country wants to emulate its contemporary fiscal troubles. Markets are exacting a heavy price for Greeces budget woes. Yet it is hardly the only country that would fall into crisis if creditors lost faith, Breakingviews notes. Indeed, the United States government is running a deficit of Greek proportions, although its total debt load is much less frightening, the publication says.

title: Judge Who Worked on Hate-Crime Cases Is Shot to Death in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  A brief audio clip posted on an ultranationalist Web site was enough to evoke an angry argument in a Moscow courtroom early this year, when a federal judge challenged a teenage skinhead to justify murdering migrants selected at random on city streets.

title: Male Studies vs. Feminism
description: Todays idea: Feminism gets in the way of the study of men, some scholars say  hence the new Male Studies Foundation, which sets the subject apart from feminist theory.

title: Tax Audits of Big Business Are Declining, Study Says
description: Despite the federal governments repeated pledges to crack down on big businesses that underpay their taxes, the Internal Revenue Service has in recent years decreased the time it spends auditing the returns of the nations largest corporations, The New York Timess David Kocieniewski reported, citing a new study.

title: Markets Rise on European Bailout for Greece
description: Stocks rose in Europe and Asia on Monday and the euro gained more than a cent against the dollar, as markets cheered the European Unions offer of concrete financial aid to the beleaguered Greek government, David Jolly reported in The New York Times.

title: With Eye on Asia, Investindustrial Plans Asset Sale
description: Investindustrial, the European investment group, plans to boost sales in Asia by two-thirds in three years to $1 billion and aims to sell its portfolio companies to Chinese firms eager to expand overseas, its president, Filippo Aleotti, said.

title: Free Museums During Romes Culture Week
description: Culture is everywhere in Rome: museums, ancient sites, art of all sorts  you name it. But for one week, it will be that much easier for visitors to access all that history. From April 16 to 25, Italy will celebrate its 12th annual Settimana della Cultura, or Culture Week.

title: Bringing a Smarter Search to Twitter, With Fees
description: Bill Gross, the serial entrepreneur who pioneered search advertising, is unveiling a venture on Monday that aims to make money by allowing people using Twitter to bid on key words to give their posts top ranking, The New York Timess Todd Woody reported.

title: Innovation, by Order of the Kremlin
description: Around the time that Apple Computer was making it big in California, Andrey Shtorkh was getting a first-hand look at the Soviet approach to high tech: he guarded the fence keeping scientists inside Sverdlovsk-45, one of the countrys secret scientific cities, deep in the Ural Mountains.

description: 10:25 a.m. | Updated California Pizza Kitchen on Monday confirmed that its looking at financial and strategic alternatives and that it has hired Moelis & Company as an adviser.Is California Pizza Kitchen cooking up an auction?

description: When it comes to global equities, hedge funds have begun opening their wallets again, with spending on stocks by funds at its highest level since 2007, The Telegraph reported, citing new research from UBS.

description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  The provisional government that took power in Kyrgyzstan last week has drawn up plans to detain the countrys ousted president, a leader once close to the United States who fled a bloody riot in the capital to his ancestral homeland in the south of the country.

title: Roberta Flack Meets a Big Yellow Taxi
description: One rainy day last month, Roberta Flack, the smooth voice of 1970s soul ballads, stepped out of her recording studio in Chelsea, hailed a yellow taxi and threw a suitcase of CDs into the back seat. Arriving at the Dakota, her longtime home, Ms. Flack got out and hurried past the wrought-iron entrance gate, seeking cover from the downpour.

title: No Hybrid Limo for President Obama

description: Reports are spreading across the Internet that the inaugural Korean Grand Prix, which was scheduled to run Oct. 24, but which always was slightly in doubt, is likely to be called off this year. The construction of the new circuit is not only behind schedule but apparently has other problems.

title: Army Routs Taliban in Gunfight in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  More than 100 Taliban militants attacked a checkpoint in a tribal region in northwest Pakistan early Monday, Pakistani military and security officials said, firing rockets and mortars before being repulsed in a long gun battle.

title: Heist to See You: Stolen Vermeer Resurfaces on The Simpsons
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation isnt the only group thats still focused on the 1990 heist at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston. The crime, in which more than $500 million worth of art was taken from the museum, got a shout-out Sunday on The Simpsons when Vermeers Concert  one of the works stolen in the unsolved crime  turned up in the collection of the plutocrat C. Montgomery Burns. (How he got his hands on the plundered painting remains a matter between Mr. Burns and the F.B.I.)

title: Media Equation: What Happens in Philly
description: In todays Media Equation column, David Carr writes:

title: U.S. Economist Dissents, Saying Recession Is Over
description: WASHINGTON  In a rare public dissent, a member of the committee that officially dates the turning points in the nations business cycles said on Monday that he thought that the recession ended last June and that the panel should have said so.

title: Ruin With a View
description: Books molder on library shelves. A vial of blood from a murder investigation, sealed in a plastic bag, lies in a jumble of old evidence at the former police headquarters. Shirts hang in a hotel closet. A hair dryer, typewriters, a switchboard, pianos, lamps  all left behind. At first glance, Detroit looks more like Pompeii than, say, Buffalo  like a city whose demise arrived overnight rather than over decades, whose residents fled en masse, midsentence, instead of drifting away as the jobs ran out and prospects dwindled.

title: Ask About Child-Friendly New York
description: This week, Alison Lowenstein, the author of City Kid New York: The Ultimate Guide for NYC Parents With Kids Ages 4-12 (Rizzoli/Universe 2010), responded to readers questions about child-friendly activities in the city, and other related questions.

title: Staying Alive: How I Got Myself Into This
description: My company makes custom furniture. I started the company shortly after graduating from the University of Pennsylvania in 1985. I had intended to go to graduate school and become an architect, but I wanted a break from school. I was working that summer as a carpenters helper, thinking that some construction experience would serve me well when designing buildings.

title: Shazam Moves Into the TV Room
description: Shazam, the mobile application that can identify the songs you hear, has enjoyed tremendous success on the iPhone and iPod Touch. More than 15 million users have downloaded the application since it first became available in 2008, and the company that created it recently secured more money from investors.

title: Cerberus to Buy DynCorp for $1.5 Billion
description: DynCorp International, the private military contractor, said on Monday it has agreed to sell itself to Cerberus Capital Management for $1.5 billion, as the private equity industry continues to return to its core business of deal-making.

title: Those Youve Known: Lea Michele and Jonathan Groff Reunite on Glee
description: For nearly two years, Lea Michele and Jonathan Groff shared a stage in the Off Broadway and Broadway productions of Spring Awakening as Wendla and Melchior, the German youths who share feelings, a beating and many more intimate acts duringan ill-fated romance. After enduring that for eight shows a week, Ms. Michele and Mr. Groff did not get sick of each other, and instead forged a friendship that, as youll shortly see, is unusual, even for theater people.

title: Treme: Built on Reporting
description: Treme goes right after the man-made disaster that followed Katrina, a story that was well-told in newspapers as well.

title: Mehrlings Idea: Let the Fed Back Default Swaps
description: Amid the more daring proposals to avert the next financial crisis is an idea put forth by Perry Mehrling, a speaker at the Institute of New Economic Thinking.

title: Twins Ready to Move Outdoors
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The Metrodome, it must be said, was a friend to the Minnesota Twins. They won all eight World Series games they played there, riding the sound waves of raucous fans to titles in 1987 and 1991. And, of course, you knew you could always watch the team in comfort.

title: Lightning Clean House, Firing Coach and General Manager
description: The Tampa Bay Lightnings new owner, Jeff Vinik, has not wasted any time in changing his team, which finished 12th in the Eastern Conference. This morning he fired both General Manager Brian Lawton and Head Coach Rich Tocchet the day after their season ended.

title: Such Tweet Sorrow: Shakespeare Gets the Social Media Treatment
description: Since Sunday, a new Twitter user who goes by the screen name @julietcap16 has been excitedly firing off posts about her typical teenage life, her frustrations with school and the birthday party she hopes her family will throw for her. But shes not just any social-media savvy teen: shes the online avatar for Juliet Capulet in a 21st-century update of Romeo and Juliet that the Royal Shakespeare Company has started online. BBC News reported that duringthe project,which is called Such Tweet Sorrow and will run for five weeks, actors playing Shakespeares star-crossed lovers (who had their disagreements about the chirping of birds) and other characters from that tragedy will play out the story on Twitter and react to real-life events. Charlotte Wakefield, a actor in the Royal Shakespeare Company who is playing Juliet, has already tweeted about her new bed and her beloved deceased mother  not to mention the Robert Pattinson cutout she keeps in her bedroom.

title: Monday Puzzle: Birdbath
description: Hi folks. Ive returned from my vacation, and the Monday Puzzle resumes today with a challenge to welcome the coming of Spring. It has been designed by our graphical maven, Justin Thyme. This puzzle continues on the theme of balance and slippage that characterized his previous contribution which became our most popular puzzle ever, the Slippery Slope Puzzle. Justin has also come up with an interesting game of strategy and suspense that hinges on guessing the number of comments this post will attract.

title: Monday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Do Smarter Workers Work Less?
description: Last week, we summarized a Labor Department report on hours worked and earnings by state, which found that Nevadans work the longest hours and workers in the District of Columbia had the highest hourly wage. Over at The Atlantic, Richard Florida has parsed the data to focus on what makes a states labor force more or less likely to work longer weeks and get higher pay.

title: Adding Up Baseballs First Week
description: The 2010 baseball season is only a week old, but in a sport where numbers tend to pile up fast, plenty has already happened. Over seven days of games there were 1,596 hits, 842 runs, 1,265 strikeouts and 673 walks. While no accurate statistical analysis can be done of such a small sample, that doesnt mean there isnt fun to be had.

title: Send Us Your Island Fantasies
description: Its all yours now, people. The mayor has wrested control of Governors Island, all 172 pathetically underdeveloped acres of it, from the state and plans to turn much of it into a city park while adding commercial buildings at the south tip.

title: Why You Should Fill Out Hotel Surveys
description: Last December, my husband had a particularly bad experience at the Omni Berkshire Place Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Jack Kirbys Characters
description: A leading illustrator left a few characters in the vault.

title: Forty Years On, Vatican Tells The Beatles They Passed the Audition
description: At a time when the Vatican could use a little positive notice in the news media, the Holy See has momentarily turned attention away from the helter skelter it has lately faced by offering its enthusiastic praise for the Beatles. In its weekend editions, LOsservatore Romano, the official newspaper of the Vatican, paid tribute to the Beatles on the 40th anniversary of that groups breakup, and endorsed the Fab Fours music without quite giving its thumbs up to the band members lifestyles, The Associated Press reported.

title: Treading a Path With Little Ivy in Sight
description: Im definitely not checking right now, I said jokingly to a friend.

title: A Hedge Fund Show Tune
description: In the tradition of Dirty Rotten Scoundrels and The Producers, NPRs Planet Money presents a new show tune about Americas latest, lovably scandalous businessmen: the hedge fund crowd.

title: In-Flight Food Tries to Be Tasty
description: Those bland sandwiches sold by airlines to economy-class passengers? Theyre on the way out.

title: Lip Shtick
description: At first glance, Vincent Olinets mixed-media sculptures of pretty, frilly things like pastel layer cakes, four-poster fairy beds and glossy lipsticks are seductive, but upon closer inspection they reveal a subversive side. The cakes have collapsed in a gooey mess on their plates, the beds have been left outside to rot in the rain, and the lipsticks have rough edges and are sloppily varnished. I like to make shiny, colorful art pieces that appeal to our dreams and urges but actually deal with decay or disillusion, says the Brussels-based Olinet. Apply with caution. An exhibit of his work is at Galerie Laurent Godin in Paris through May 15. Go to laurentgodin.com.

title: Sampler: Abuse Scandal, Palo Alto Cuts, Tenderloin for Tourists
description: More on Father Kiesle | Melinda Costello was a 7-year-old parishioner in the late 1960s in Fremont, Calif., when the Rev. Stephen Kiesle first playfully invited her to sit on his lap. Ms. Costello, now 48, recalled that as the tickling and touching quickly progressed to fondling her chest and genitals, Mr. Kiesle justified his behavior as exorcism and told me the devil was inside me, she said in an interview with The New York Times. Emerging accounts like Ms. Costellos in California churches have intensified pressure on the pope. As Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, then a top Vatican official overseeing clergy, he sent a letter in 1985 to Bishop John S. Cummins of Oakland, who had repeatedly voiced concerns about Father Kiesle, saying that the case needed more time and that the good of the universal church should be considered before moving to discipline the priest.

title: A Look at Challenges Facing Independent Theater
description: The Bleecker Street Theater Company will hold a Playwrights Symposium Benefit on Tuesday evening to explore the artistic and financial challenges facing Off Off Broadway theaters and artists.

title: Powell Says He Will Challenge Rangel
description: Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV announced on Monday that he would challenge Representative Charles B. Rangel in this falls Democratic primary, setting the stage for a deeply personal battle between two of Harlems biggest political names and oldest foes.

title: Mickelson Writes His Own Masters Script
description: Perhaps the most amazing thing about an amazing Masters tournament was this: for all the outsized hype and attention it received before it started (ESPN running constant ticker updates like, Tiger Woods approaches first tee is off-the-rails territory), it actually ended up earning it. There was a bit of everything in four days: from the honey-hand-me-the-TiVo-remote shots, to the breathless Woods watch, to the comeback of the A.A.R.P. set to the final, tear-jerking scene on the 18th green when Phil Mickelson won.

title: SAS Seeks to Improve Data Mining of Social Media
description: No one doubts that social media  all the stuff on Facebook, Twitter and other online forums  provides a rich lode of user sentiment that companies ought to be able to exploit. And not just to sharpen their marketing, but also to improve their products and services  potentially, the ultimate source of customer views and a crowd-sourced suggestion box.

title: New Collaborative Google Docs Unveiled
description: Google is continuing its assault on Microsofts dominance of the multibillion dollar market for productivity software.

title: Media Decoded: HBOs Treme Builds on Pulitzer Prize Reporting
description: Treme, another remarkable outing from David Simon on HBO, reflects some of the great reporting that went on before, during and after the storm.

description: 12:23 p.m. | Updated

title: Bingo! Playing a Game With The Times to Improve English Language Skills
description: Overview | How can students improve English language skills by reading The New York Times? In this lesson, students first compile lists of their personal grammar, punctuation, spelling and usage demons, then play a bingo game to find examples of correct usage in The New York Times; finally, they track particular words, marks of punctuation or elements of grammar or usage through a weeks worth of The Times to view examples.

title: The Background Beat of the Senate
description: ALBANY  Change comes slowly to the New York State Senate. It took Democrats four decades to win control of the chamber, which they finally did in 2008. It took more than a year for Democrats to institute some of the rules changes they had promised upon taking power. The state budget, due on March 31, is late again.

title: Frustrated? Try Life on the No Fly List
description: I USUALLY take traveling in stride. But Ive been on the no fly list for about a year now. So that puts all of the other travel hassles into perspective.

title: How Long Will Taiwan Love Its Internet Star? Not Always.
description: So much for the next Susan Boyle. A week after his pitch-perfect rendition of I Will Always Love You made him an online sensation, Lin Yu-chun, a 24-year-old contestant on the One Million Star show, a Taiwanese talent competition, was voted off the program, Agence France-Presse reported.

title: Figueroas Love for His Son Trumps His Love for the Mets
description: Nelson Figueroa, Sr., is a true-blue Mets fan. Its a love affair that was cemented when his son, Nelson Figueroa, Jr., pitched for the Mets at Shea Stadium in 2008.

title: Steelers Patience Has Its Limits
description: How badly did the Pittsburgh Steelers want to get rid of receiver Santonio Holmes, whom they traded to the Jets late Sunday night?

title: The Claim: Milk Makes You Phlegmy
description: THE FACTS

title: Ailing Chinese Dissident Is Denied Early Release
description: BEIJING  One of Chinas best-known dissidents has been denied early release from prison despite being seriously ill, members of his family said Monday.

title: Study Sees a Slant in Articles on Drug
description: A new analysis of reviews and articles about the controversial diabetes drug Avandia has found that experts who were paid by its manufacturer have been significantly more likely than others to draw positive conclusions about the drugs safety and efficacy.

title: The Climate Path From Copenhagen Through Cancun
description: Its always been hard to get a clear view of the intentions of the 193 countries embroiled for nearly 20 years in climate negotiations, which is one reason I captured some video of a CBS radio correspondent in the cacophonous and cavernous press hall in Copenhagen last December. (Im trying to recall his name; please remind me in a comment!) Somehow, his use of a shroud to muffle the noise of colleagues as he recorded his dispatches reflected the challenges facing anyone trying to get to bedrock on climate diplomacy.

title: What Were Reading: Analyzing Bond Girls
"I Could Have Saved This One"
description: Stanley Steemer, the carpet-cleaning company, introduces two Penn-and-Tellerish characters in a new, humorous campaign.

title: Conan OBrien Will Do a Late-Night Show on TBS
description: In a move that qualifies as a shocker, Conan OBrien has made a deal to return to television in a new late-night show on cable  not network  television.

title: Characters Welcome to Cut a Rug (or Clean One)
description: The USA cable channel, in promoting series like Burn Notice, Psych and White Collar, proclaims, Characters welcome. That could be a motto for Madison Avenue, too, as more commercials feature recurring characters who can help spots stand out amid the clutter.

title: Q. & A. With Stuart Elliott
description: A question here last week, asking why light beer commercials always make their customers appear to be so stupid, drew more comments than usual. What follows below are e-mail messages on the subject from a couple of agency creative executives.

title: TimesCast | April 12, 2010
description: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Monday.  Topics include a nuclear summit  in Washington, an exclusive look at bootlegging in Pakistan and more.

title: People and Accounts of Note in Advertising
description: Samantha Allen, who founded and ran Pulse Communications, Sydney, Australia, part of the Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide network, is moving to New York to become managing director for the global consumer marketing practice at Ogilvy Public Relations. She succeeds Barby K. Siegel, who left to join the Zeno Group, part of Daniel J. Edelman Inc., as chief executive. Ogilvy Public Relations is part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP.

title: Conan OBrien Will Do a Late-Night Show on TBS
description: 2:17 p.m. | Updated  In a move that qualifies as a shocker, Conan OBrien has made a deal to return to television in a new late-night show on cablenot network television.

title: Fed-Up Messiah Tells Followers That the Shoe Doesnt Fit
description: A San Francisco economist who was unwillingly declared the messiah is taking believers to task in a pointed, first-person essay published in one of his hometown newspapers, The Guardian.

title: The Doctor Is In
description: Trading in her stethoscope and the trappings of Hollywood for an Off Broadway debut, the actress Kate Walsh (Dr. Addison Montgomery on ABCs Private Practice) will play one of the lead roles in Stephen Belbers new play, Dusk Rings a Bell, at the Atlantic Theater Company this spring.

title: Pre-Failed State
description: Bleak description of southern Sudan, which is expected to vote for independence in a referendum scheduled for January 2011.

title: ConocoPhillips to Sell Syncrude Stake to Sinopec
description: ConocoPhillips announced Monday that it had agreed to sell its 9 percent stake in Syncrude Canada to the Sinopec International Petroleum Exploration and Production Company of China for $4.65 billion.

title: Donatella Arpaias Next Step
description: Donatella Arpaia wont reveal the location of her newest restaurant. Or the identity of the executive chef. Or even the name. But wait, naming-opportunity fans: readers who work their way through 248 pages of recipes in her forthcoming cookbook, Donatella Cooks: Simple Food Made Glamorous, might note a phrase on the back-cover book flap, announcing that she is planning the opening of her new restaurant, Donatella, in summer 2010.

title: Quote Unquote | Sweet Talk
description: Alexander Wang tells Teen Vogue Karlie Klosss secret to being a supermodel. The real secret? Not eating the peanut butter cookies.

title: Marinated Vegetables and Quick Pickles
description: I often extend the shelf life of the vegetables in my refrigerator by keeping them in marinade. Vinegar, an ingredient in all of this weeks marinades, acts as a preservative, as does olive oil.

title: All in All, Its Just a Live Tour of The Wall
description: After more than two decades of making us eat our meat, Roger Waters is finally giving us the pudding: on Monday Mr. Waters, the onetime Pink Floyd singer, songwriter and bassist, gave in to the demands of ornery students everywhere and announced a concert tour version of The Wall, his former bandsclassic album about post-World War II disillusionment, rock stardom and the anguish of being pursued by groupies. Billboard reported that Mr. Waters will begin the 36-date tour on Sept. 15 in Toronto and conclude it on Dec. 13 in Anaheim, Calif.Concerts, which will, of course, feature a 35-foot-tall, 240-foot-wide wall on stage, are also scheduled for Madison Square Garden (Oct. 5) and the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J. (Nov. 3). Billboard said that The Wall has been performed live only 31 times by Pink Floyd or Mr. Waters, who left the group in the mid-1980s: in a series of concerts the band played in 1980 and 1981, and by Mr. Waters in 1990 to mark the fall of the Berlin Wall.

title: Why You Should Fill Out Hotel Surveys
description: The next time you have a bad experience at a hotel, dont just rant about it on TripAdvisor. Instead, make sure to also fill out the hotel feedback survey. Heres why.

title: Why Life Insurance Is Not an Investment
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Clearwater Asset Management. He answered questions from Bucks readers in November.

title: Off the Menu: Walle
description: Wally Chin, who owns Chin Chin restaurant in Midtown with his brother, Jimmy Chin, plans to open his own restaurant next month at 251 East 53rd Street in the space that had long housed Il Nido.

title: Dissent on Recessions End
description: Earlier on Monday, the National Bureau of Economic Researchs Business Cycle Dating Committee  the group that determines the start and end dates of recessions  said that it could not yet declare an end to the recession that began in December 2007.

title: South Could Benefit From a Little Efficiency
description: That the American South is both a voracious consumer of energy and a laggard on implementing efficiency measures has long been a matter of some concern for policymakers and energy analysts.

title: Skakel Loses Appeal for a New Trial
description: Michael C. Skakel, who was convicted in 2002 of having killed a 15-year-old Greenwich, Conn., neighbor in 1975, lost an appeal on Monday in which he had sought a new trial.

title: First Impressions of Target Field
description: MINNEAPOLIS - Its the first day at a new ballpark, and there are so many new things to see that your mind is bouncing a thousand different directions. At least mine is. So as I sit in the press box here at Target Field, Ill share a few stylistic observations, rapid-fire:

title: On Ingesting KFCs New Product, the Double Down
description: KFC, the fast-food company based in Louisville, Ky., introduced its newest product on Monday, a chicken, cheese, bacon, and mayonnaise sandwich called the Double Down.

title: Design Olympics | Next Stop, Milan
description: The annual Salone Internazionale del Mobile (International Furniture Fair) opens this week in Milan, and T Magazine asked some design luminaries to tell us what they are looking forward to in and around the fair.

title: A Top-Heavy Field Shapes Up for the Derby
description: The field for the 136th running of the Kentucky Derby is finally taking shape, and the most obvious conclusion so far is that it is going to be a rich bunch. Spots in the starting gate are determined by graded stakes earnings, and right now, Homeboy Kris holds the 20th spot with $250,500 in eligible purse money  the highest total ever for the last spot in the field.

title: Fort National, Haiti: Choosing to Stay
description:
After the devastating earthquake in Haiti on January 12, most residents of Fort National fled their homes. 
Todd Heisler, a staff photographer, documented the ones who stayed behind.

title: Senator Warns of Populist Fervor Against Wall St.
description: Senator Judd Gregg, the ranking Republican on the Senate Banking Committee, asserted Monday that Senate Democrats were approaching the overhaul of the nations financial regulations with a harmful populist fervor, but he said he still hoped a compromise could be reached between both parties in the coming weeks.

title: Powell to Challenge Rangel
description: Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV announced on Monday that he would challenge Representative Charles B. Rangel in this falls Democratic primary, setting the stage for a deeply personal battle between two of Harlems biggest political names and oldest foes.

title: The Mourning Skate: Rangers Season Dies in Shootout
description: After the their game had ended and the Rangers had lost, 2-1, to be eliminated from playoff contention by the Flyers (Jeff Z. Kleins Times story here), Devils game analyst Chico Resch bemoaned during the Devils broadcast the manner in which the Rangers season ended  via the shootout. This is not the right way to have a playoff spot decided, the former goalie said.

title: Questioning International Adoptions
description: There seems to be plenty of blame to go around in the sad and sobering tale of Justin Hansen (Artyom Savelyev), who landed unaccompanied in his native Russia last week, sent back by his adoptive mother and grandmother, who describe the boy as psychologically damaged and say they can no longer care for him.

title: New Microsoft Phones Aim at a Younger Crowd
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft is trying to home in on a younger, chattier demographic with two new cellphones centered on social networking.

title: An Easy Way to Buy Sustainable Seafood
description: After I spoke with Casson Trenor a couple of weeks ago, we both became aware of Martin Reed, who has just started a business called I Love Blue Sea. Mr. Reed is a retailer whos doing the work for you, buying and selling seafood he has verified as sustainable.

title: Travel Deals: JetBlue Spring Sale
description: JetBlue is offering one-way fares starting at $29 to destinations throughout the United States and the Caribbean. Book by April 21 for travel between April 22 and June 16. The sale is not valid for flights around Memorial Day weekend.

title: How the Conan OBrien-TBS Deal Happened
description: Conan OBriens manager, Gavin Polone,said that awhirlwind negotiation of only about 10 days led the late-night star to leave network television and jump to the cable network, TBS.

title: The Further Empowerment of Anthony Kennedy
description: It tells you something about the remarkable power our system has vested in 5-to-4 Supreme Court decisions that the most interesting piece Ive read about the post-John Paul Stevens court involves the swing-voting Anthony Kennedy, rather than any of Stevens prospective liberal replacements. On Scotusblog, Lyle Denniston argues that Stevens retirement will only increase Kennedys already-enormous influence on American jurisprudence. For one thing, Kennedy will be moving up in seniority, meaning that hes more likely to be the assigning justice on a case that divides the Court. Denniston explains what this means:

title: A Stroll Through the City of Numbers
description: It appears that some residents of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, may be too cool to fill out the 2010 census. As the National Public Radio correspondent Robert Smith narrates from the enclave of hipsters  or, as some prefer, fauxhemians or trustafarians  that boasts the citys lowest return rate for census forms:

title: UBS Client Pleads Guilty To Tax Fraud
description: A wealthy client of the Swiss bank UBS pleaded guilty on Monday to tax fraud, the ninth American caught up in an investigation of the banks offshore private banking services.

title: Titans Conquers Date Night at the Box Office
description: It may not seem to matter much now in a post-Conan-OBrien-goes-to-TBS world, but a winner has been declared in the box-office showdown between Clash of the Titans and Date Night. After all the drachmas or denarii or whatever currency an ancient warrior might carry were counted, Clash of the Titans remained No. 1 for the second weekend in a row, according to the entertainment site Hollywood.com, with a three-day gross of $26.6 million; in its opening weekend Date Night had to settle for second place with ticket sales of $25.2 million. Date Night stars Tina Fey, Steve Carell and a parade of celebrities in cameo roles. But Clash of the Titans has the Kraken.

title: Failure Is A Failed Strategy
description: One thing that keeps coming up in comments, both here and on my column, is the widespread belief that all we need to do on the banking front is (a) break up the big banks, so that none of them are too big to fail (b) promise not to bail out any banks in the future. That way, the claim goes, bankers will know that they will face dire consequences if they misbehave, and market discipline will do the rest.

title: British Prime Minister Proposes Tougher Takeover Rules
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain proposed changes to the countrys takeover rules on Monday that could make it more difficult to acquire British companies.

title: Israeli Stores Stop Selling Book That Denounces Settlers
description: Updated | Tuesday | 8:23 a.m. An Israeli bookstore chain announced on Sunday that it would stop selling The National Left, a political manifesto by two Israeli authors who compare settlers living on occupied Palestinian land to brainwashing, hypnotized zombies transforming Israel into an apartheid state.

title: Does Milk Make You Phlegmy?
description: In an article last year about health myths, I wrote about research showing that drinking milk does not increase nasal secretions, cough or congestion.

title: Because Bread Is for Wimps
description: Quick, what kind of sandwich goes calorie-for-calorie with the Big Mac without resorting to bread? KFCs new chicken-bacon-cheese three-bagger, the Double Down, thats what kind. Our colleague Sam Sifton, after lining his stomach with wax paper and titanium, tried one at Broadway and 33rd Street on Monday morning. All he got for his troubles (other than some unasked-for face time online) was a slimy and unnaturally moist thing. Read all about it here.

title: A Google Tablet Could Be Good News for Adobe
description: As Ashlee Vance and I report in a Monday article, Hewlett-Packard, Acer, Microsoft and a suite of other companies are hard at work on products that they hope will be iPad killers.

title: The Moviegoer | Bette Gordons Handsome Harry
description: The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

title: Washington Post Wins 4 Pulitzers, New York Times Gets 3
description: The Washington Post won four Pulitzer Prizes on Monday for its work in 2009, and The New York Times won three, while ProPublica became the first of the new breed of online, nonprofit news organizations to win the most prestigious award in print journalism.

title: 2010 Pulitzer Prizes for Letters, Drama and Music
description: The Pulitzer Prizes were announced on Monday.

title: Europe Finds Clean Energy in Trash, but U.S. Lags
description: HORSHOLM, Denmark  The lawyers and engineers who dwell in an elegant enclave here are at peace with the hulking neighbor just over the back fence: a vast energy plant that burns thousands of tons of household garbage and industrial waste, round the clock.

title: Some, but Not All, Savor Silence in the Stacks
description: The library may be one of the last bastions of quiet in this pinball machine world, but some of these community institutions have broken the no-shushing laws that once ruled the land.

title: Complicated Emotions, Spurred by a Visit to Cuba
description: Its the spring of 2004, and Ruth is angry and tired. Ruth, a Columbia University professor teaching fiction writing to graduate students she dismisses as the cowardly children of Republicans, rages against them and President Bush even as she rages against herself, a onetime radical, for hiding in her job. Now in her 70s, she seethes with longing: for a student with talent; for her ex-lover; and for a late-in-life show of meaning.

title: In India, Wal-Mart Goes to the Farm
description: HAIDER NAGAR, India  At first glance, the vegetable patches in this north Indian village look no different from the many small, spare farms that dot the country.

title: Apps Wed Like to See: Bright Light to Night Light
description: Everybody seems to have some idea for an app, and heres mine. I think it might be worth something; it is designed to increase domestic bliss.

title: Where Auto Insurance Is Most Expensive
description: Louisiana has the highest average auto insurance rates in the United States, while Maine has the lowest, according to new data from Insure.com that ranks the states according to their average insurance rates (see the full ranking below).

title: Wade Plays Down Free Agency Buzz
description: Every thing LeBron James does comes under scrutiny for clues by those trying to divine where the soon-to-be free agent could be headed.

title: 2010 Pulitzer Prizes for Journalism
description: The Pulitzer Prizes were announced on Monday. Following are the winners in Journalism.

title: China Pledges to Work With U.S. on Iran Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama secured a promise from President Hu Jintao of China on Monday to join negotiations on a new package of sanctions against Iran, administration officials said, but Mr. Hu made no specific commitment to backing measures that the United States considers severe enough to force a change in direction in Irans nuclear program.

title: Roethlisberger Isnt Charged, but the N.F.L. Could Act
description: Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger will not face criminal charges stemming from an incident in which he was accused of sexually assaulting a 20-year-old college student, but the N.F.L. has a broadly worded personal conduct policy that gives Commissioner Roger Goodell plenty of latitude to determine its own discipline.

title: Data on Fees to Doctors Is Called Hard to Parse
description: Pfizer recently became the latest big drug maker to start disclosing payments to doctors who act as consultants or speakers. But many followers of the pharmaceutical industry are still finding it far too difficult to follow the money.

title: No Makeup Required
description: Oh, the irony! Have you ever noticed how many women in fashion refuse to embellish their faces? Here are five trendsetters whose daily regimen consists mostly of soap and water.

title: In Reporting Symptoms, Dont Patients Know Best?
description: About six years ago, my doctor gave me some samples of a drug to treat pain from an injury. I took it for a few days and then woke up one morning with a big red blister on my tongue. Id never had anything like it before, and I wondered if the pills might be to blame. They werent helping much anyway, so I quit taking them. The blister went away. I mentioned it the next time I saw the doctor, but he said it must have been a coincidence.

title: A New Lizard? Well, New to Science
description: The number of lizard species in the world  by most counts, around 4,000  has just increased by one, with the announcement of a new species found on Luzon island in the Philippines.

title: A Grid of Wind Turbines to Pick Up the Slack
description: Like most other sources of alternative energy, the wind can be intermittent. It does not blow uniformly, so power output from wind turbines rises and falls. And when the wind doesnt blow at all, output drops to zero.

title: Rare Bird, Alive and Well and Living in Colombia
description: The mountainous area around Santa Marta, on Colombias Caribbean coast, is a biological hotspot of sorts, filled with bird species that are found nowhere else.

title: Sentences Get Harsher in White-Collar Cases
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Farming Fish
description: Q. Why do ecologists seem to give the nod to farmed catfish and tilapia but not salmon?

title: At Target Field, Pucketts Memory Lives On
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Downstairs in the press dining room at the new Target Field on Monday, five people sat at a table in the back. It was about as exclusive a table as you could find around here: Harmon Killebrew, Rod Carew, Tony Oliva, Kent Hrbek and Kirby Puckett Jr., who is 17. The four players, and Pucketts father, all have their numbers retired by the Twins.

title: Nuggets Sign Karls Son to Contract
description: Coby Karl wants to be seen as just another member of the Denver Nuggets.

title: Tinkers by Paul Harding: The One That Got Away
description: Every now and then a good book completely passes us by: we dont get a copy, for whatever reason, and we dont request one because the books not on our radar. Thats what happened with Paul Hardings first novel, Tinkers, which was published at the beginning of 2009 by the Bellevue Literary Press, a small publisher that had only been in business for a couple of years. Now Tinkers has gone and won the Pulitzer Prize  the first novel from a small press to win that award since A Confederacy of Dunces did it for Louisiana State University Press in 1981.

title: Tinkers by Paul Harding: The One That Got Away
description: Every now and then a good book completely passes us by: we dont get a copy, for whatever reason, and we dont request one because the books not on our radar. Thats what happened with Paul Hardings first novel, Tinkers, which was published at the beginning of 2009 by the Bellevue Literary Press, a small publisher that had only been in business for a couple of years. Now Tinkers has gone and won the Pulitzer Prize  the first novel from a small press to win that award since A Confederacy of Dunces did it for Louisiana State University Press in 1981.

title: Pertussis, 1913
description: Whooping cough has been a well-known disease for hundreds of years, and the term pertussis has been in use since the 18th century. Its symptoms are vivid: severe coughing spells ending with a whooping gasp for breath and a face that turns red or purple, often followed by vomiting and then a return to feeling fine until the next episode. But until the early 20th century, no one knew what caused it.

title: Cancer Survival Demands Steady Progress
description: I continue to find reasons to be hopeful that one day, though probably not within my lifetime, medical researchers will overcome the challenges that thwart efforts to cure or at least contain most cancers, especially the more common ones.

title: Pictures of the Day: Voting in Sudan
description: Sudans first multiparty elections in more than 20 years began on Sunday. They have been hampered by accusations of fraud and a boycott by some opposition parties. Although the incumbent president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, has been vilified in the West and charged by the International Criminal Court with crimes against humanity, he is expected to win. Across the country, thousands of candidates are competing for state, regional and national positions (Slides 1, 2 and 3). Elsewhere, leaders converged in Washington for an international nuclear security summit meeting (Slide 4).

title: Could Health Overhaul Incentives Hurt Some?
description: The new health care law promises to extend coverage to millions of Americans and to cut costs by cultivating healthy habits and preventive care. But could its emphasis on wellness undermine one of its central achievements: putting an end to the practice of charging sick people more for health insurance?

title: Research Reactors a Safety Challenge
description: In Cambridge, Mass., at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a nuclear reactor emits an eerie blue glow 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Its fuel is 93 percent uranium 235  the high-purity uranium it takes to energize an atom bomb and exactly what the West fears that Tehran wants to produce.

title: Jack Kirbys Heroes in Waiting
description: The characteristics of a Jack Kirby illustration are easily distinguished: extravagantly costumed heroes and nefarious villains locked in titanic struggles; foreshortened fists, feet and muscles that seem to pop off the page; intricately detailed settings meant to conjure the ancient past or suggest the distant future.

title: Fed Picks Chief of Monetary Affairs Division
description: WASHINGTON    The Federal Reserve Board on Monday named William B. English director of its division of monetary affairs, one of the most powerful staff positions at the central bank.

title: The Sandcastle Worm
description: Russel J. Stewart of the University of Utah is studying the sandcastle worm's ability to glue minerals underwater in order to create a synthetic version for use as a medical adhesive.

title: For Pediatricians in the Military, Duty Always Calls
description: In the mid-1960s, Dr. Eve Kimball was the first female intern in the Army. She started her residency in pediatrics at Madigan Army Medical Center in Tacoma, Wash., while her husband did his residency there in internal medicine. She was honorably discharged after one year for disability  she was pregnant with their first child  and has worked as a civilian pediatrician in practices that serve military families.

title: Technology: For Nations That Lack the Expertise, an Automated System for Detecting TB
description: One of the difficulties of diagnosing tuberculosis is that there is no simple blood or urine test. Instead, a laboratory technician must take a sample of sputum coughed up from the lungs, stain it and inspect it under a microscope for the telltale bacteria, which resemble long-grain rice. It takes expertise that is often rare in poor countries.

title: Two Media Analysts Weigh In on Conan OBrien Deal
description: Steve Sternberg, alongtime media analyst who now blogs on The Sternberg Report, offered this opinion on Conan OBriens new show on TBS in an e-mail message:

title: London Cab, Now Made in China
description: The black cab, as much a part of Londons cityscape as Big Ben and Harrods, will get an update and a new manufacturer when the Geely version makes its debut later this month at the Beijing auto show.

title: Interview Transcript: Justice John Paul Stevens
description: The following is an edited transcript of an interview with Justice John Paul Stevens conducted by Jeffrey Rosen for The New York Times Magazine article "The Dissenter," published on Sept. 23, 2007. The interview was conducted on June 22, 2007.

title: Morgan Stanley Chief Not Satisfied With 2009 Results
description: James P. Gorman, the new chief executive of Morgan Stanley, says he is not satisfied with the firms financial results for last year, which included a loss of 93 cents a share, Bloomberg News reports.

title: 11,000, Almost 11 Years Later
description: Wall Street is excited that the Dow Jones industrials closed over 11,000 today, for the first time since just after Lehman Brothers failed.

title: Expert Answers on Multiple Myeloma
description: In Tuesdays Science Times, the Personal Health columnist Jane Brody explores the progress being made in the treatment of cancer patients like Janet Battaile, a former reporter for The New York Times who has multiple myeloma, the second most common blood-based malignancy:

title: Studying Sea Life for a Glue That Mends People
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Along one wall of Russell J. Stewarts laboratory at the University of Utah sits a saltwater tank containing a strange object: a rock-hard lump the size of a soccer ball, riddled with hundreds of small holes.

title: The High Low | Eryn Brini Trench, $198
description: What: Eryn Brini Spring Trench

title: Chicago Restaurant Opens on Four Floors
description: This is no misnomer. Epic, as the name of this new Chicago restaurant in River North suggests, has grand ambitions. Spread across four floors including a roof deck, it spans some 14,000 square feet and has a 190-seat dining room highlighted by 24-foot-high windows.

title: White House Dashes Chatter of Clinton as Supreme Court Nominee
description: To the list of candidates President Obama is considering for the Supreme Court, strike this name: Hillary Rodham Clinton. But add these: Sidney Thomas, Janet Napolitano, Jennifer Granholm and Leah Ward Sears.

title: For Sky Blues Dutch Defender, Pay and a Platform
description: Daphne Koster was the epitome of a free agent.

title: A Brief Sensation on TV in Taiwan
description: So much for the next Susan Boyle. A week after his pitch-perfect rendition of I Will Always Love You made him an online sensation, Lin Yu-chun, above, a 24-year-old contestant on the One Million Star show, a Taiwanese talent competition, was voted off the program, Agence France-Presse reported. Video of Mr. Lin, a shop worker who has been nicknamed Little Fatty, singing that Whitney Houston-by-way-of-Dolly Parton love ballad, was widely circulated on the Internet and was viewed more than four million times on YouTube. But those numbers apparently meant nothing to the shows viewers and judges, who criticized Mr. Lins performance of a Mandarin song on the next weeks broadcast. (You rarely hit a wrong note, one judge said. But you did today. Whats wrong with you?) Stella Teng, an agent for Mr. Lin, told Agence France-Presse: Despite the failure he still keeps a positive attitude. He feels that success cannot possibly come without failure. Ms. Teng said that Mr. Lin would be invited back on One Million Star as a guest performer next week, and may give interviews or concerts in other territories, including the United States.

title: Gotti on 60 Minutes: Who Can Refuse?
description: Were afraid to be the ones to tell him this, but John Gotti Jr. got a boost for his first interview with 60 Minutes from CBSs afternoon coverage of the Masters on Sunday. After Phil Mickelsons victory at Augusta National, CBS was No. 1 for the night, according to Nielsens estimates, with a lineup that included 60 Minutes (which garnered over 15 million viewers) and the season finale of its hit reality show Undercover Boss (14.1 million). ABC ranked second overall, benefiting from a two-hour episode of Brothers & Sisters (8.8 million). NBC was third with Dateline (3.7 million) and a rerun of Minute to Win It (4.5 million), followed by The Celebrity Apprentice (6.6 million), while Fox placed fourth with its comedy lineup including The Simpsons (5.6 million) and Family Guy (6.9 million).

title: Such Tweet Sorrow: Posts by Shakespeare
description: Since Sunday a new Twitter user with the screen name @julietcap16 has been excitedly firing off posts about her typical teenage life, her frustrations with school and the birthday party she hopes her family will give her. But shes not just any social-media-savvy teenager; shes the online avatar for Juliet Capulet in a 21st-century update of Romeo and Juliet that the Royal Shakespeare Company has started online. BBC News reported that during the project, which is called Such Tweet Sorrow and will run for five weeks, actors playing Shakespeares star-crossed lovers (who had their disagreements about the chirping of birds) and other characters from that tragedy will play out the story on Twitter and react to real-life events. Charlotte Wakefield, an actor in the Royal Shakespeare Company who is playing Juliet (above, with the actor James Barrett), has already tweeted about her new bed and her beloved deceased mother, as well as the Robert Pattinson cutout she keeps in her bedroom. Michael Boyd, the artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, told the BBC that the project tries to bring performers and theatergoers closer together. Mobile phones dont need to be the antichrist for theater, he said.

title: All in All, Its Just a Tour of The Wall
description: After more than two decades of making us eat our meat, Roger Waters is finally giving us the pudding. On Monday Mr. Waters, the onetime Pink Floyd singer, songwriter and bassist, gave in to the demands of ornery students everywhere and announced a concert-tour version of The Wall, his former bands concept album about post-World War II disillusionment, rock stardom and the anguish of being pursued by groupies. Billboard reported that Mr. Waters would begin the 36-date tour on Sept. 15 in Toronto and conclude it on Dec. 13 in Anaheim, Calif. Concerts, which will, of course, feature a 35-foot-tall, 240-foot-wide wall on stage, are also scheduled for Madison Square Garden (Oct. 5) and the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J. (Nov. 3). Billboard said that The Wall had been performed live only 31 times by Pink Floyd or Mr. Waters, who left the group in the mid-1980s: in a series of concerts the band played in 1980 and 1981, and by Mr. Waters in 1990 to mark the fall of the Berlin Wall.

title: The Doctor Is in (an Off Broadway Play)
description: Trading in her stethoscope and the trappings of Hollywood for an Off Broadway debut, the actress Kate Walsh (Dr. Addison Montgomery on ABCs Private Practice), above, will play one of the lead roles in Stephen Belbers new play, Dusk Rings a Bell, at the Atlantic Theater Company this spring. She will star as a CNN executive who unexpectedly encounters a man with whom she had an adolescent fling years earlier, and the two find that their romanticized memories of youth are complicated by adult realities. Her co-star is Paul Sparks, above, who played Ejlert Lovborg in last seasons Broadway revival of Hedda Gabler and has acted Off Broadway most recently in Pumpgirl and Essential Self-Defense. Ms. Walsh, who trained at the Piven Theater Workshop and Oxford School of Drama, starred in several plays in Chicago and elsewhere before taking television roles on The Drew Carey Show, Karen Sisco and Greys Anatomy, on which she created the character she now plays on Private Practice. The play by Mr. Belber (Match, Geometry of Fire) will be directed by Sam Gold (Circle Mirror Transformation) at the Atlantics Stage 2 at 330 West 16th Street in Chelsea. The production is to begin previews on May 19 and open on May 27, running through June 20.

title: Vatican Gets Around to Praising the Beatles
description: At a time when the Vatican could use a little positive notice in the news media, the Holy See has momentarily turned attention away from the helter skelter it has lately faced by offering its enthusiastic praise for the Beatles. In its weekend editions, LOsservatore Romano, the official newspaper of the Vatican, commemorated the Beatles on the 40th anniversary of that groups breakup, and endorsed the Fab Fours music without quite giving a thumbs-up to the band members lifestyles, The Associated Press reported. Its true, they took drugs; swept up by their success, they lived dissolute and uninhibited lives, LOsservatore Romano wrote. But, the newspaper added, listening to their songs, all of this seems distant and meaningless. Their beautiful melodies, which changed forever pop music and still give us emotions, live on like precious jewels. Giovanni Maria Vian, the editor in chief of LOsservatore Romano, told The A.P. that he is a fan of the Beatles, and he minimized John Lennons notorious 1966 remark that the band at that time was more popular than Jesus. In reality it wasnt that scandalous, Mr. Vian said, because the fascination with Jesus was so great that it attracted these new heroes of the time.

title: Does Obama Have the Right Stuff for Space?
description: Will President Obamas plan for space exploration bring us closer to Mars  or is it a step backward for those who favor human exploration of the solar system?

title: From Life of Pi Author, Stuffed-Animal Allegory About Holocaust
description: Yann Martels 2001 novel, Life of Pi, was a charming, eccentric fable  part philosophical meditation on God, part childrens adventure story about a boys voyage across the ocean on a lifeboat with a tiger named Richard Parker.

title: Apache to Buy Oil and Gas Assets from Devon
description: The Apache Corporation said Monday that it would acquire Devon Energys oil and gas assets in the Gulf of Mexico for $1.05 billion, an amount that is about $250 million more than some analysts had expected. The deal expands Apaches presence in the region and gives Devon the cash it needs to concentrate on its land drilling operations.

title: Where Auto Insurance Is Most Expensive
description: From our colleagues at the Bucks blog:

title: Like, We Are a Lost Generation, You Know
description: I mean, wouldnt you think, its a bit, you know, begins a typical exchange of ideas in Enjoy, Toshiki Okadas clever portrait of the comically desperate part-time employees of a cafe in recession-racked Japan. A co-worker (Alex Torra) responds, What do you mean, you know?

title: When a Doctor Plays Down Your Symptoms
description: Do doctors have a tendency to play down the symptoms and complaints of their patients?

title: No, Minister
description: BAGHDAD  Sometimes its the little things that tell you all you really need to know about the big ones.

title: Samurai Shopper | Slip Tease
description: This is the era of exhibitionism, when everybody reveals everything to everybody, like it or not. Marilyn Monroe standing over a subway grate way back when is hardly indecent now. Her giggly joy  oooh goody, Im aerating my nether parts  was sweet, and without air conditioning on a blistering summer night, she was just being sensible.

title: As His Health Struggles Continue, James Levine Faces Difficult Choices
description: No one is more frustrated over the serious health problems James Levine has struggled with since 2006 than Mr. Levine himself, as he has indicated in numerous interviews and news releases. For six years he has been juggling demanding music directorships at the Metropolitan Opera and the Boston Symphony Orchestra. But because of various surgical procedures and injuries requiring long recuperative periods, he has missed months of accumulated performances at each institution, not just in Boston and New York but on American and international tours.

title: New Force Behind Agency of Wonder
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency is different from other federal agencies. For one thing, the agency, known as Darpa, created the Internet (really). For another, it is probably the only agency ever to offer a $40,000 prize for a balloon hunt, a contest that was inspired by Regina Dugan, a 47-year-old expert in mine detection, who took over last summer as its director.

title: Channel 13 Is Putting Lincoln Center on the Set
description: It may not be the same as Matt Lauer interviewing movie stars on Today, but Channel 13 is betting that some people will want to press their noses to the glass to see Paula Zahn, the former CNN anchor, or Philippe de Montebello, the former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, interview curators in its new storefront studio at Lincoln Center.

title: Percentage of Animals Put to Death in Shelters Reaches Low
description: Theres never been a better time to be a dog in New York City, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proclaimed Monday morning. As usual, he had statistical proof. The percentage of dogs and cats put to death at the citys shelters hit an all-time low last year  33 percent, down from 69 percent in 2003.

title: A Bike for Abel
description: My Sunday column was about an amazing set of kids living in a Zimbabwe hut together after their four parents died of AIDS. The kid in charge, a high school student, wants a bicycle to reduce his three-hour commute to school each way  and now it looks as if hell get it. Several readers are trying to send him money for that bike (I didnt want to post his contact information for fear of getting him in trouble with the Zimbabwean government, and aid organizations were wary of being intermediaries for similar reasons).

title: Bank Woes Haunt Illinois Democrat in Senate Race
description: CHICAGO  With pressure mounting over the possible demise of his familys bank, Alexi Giannoulias, a Democrat who hopes to fill President Obamas former seat in the United States Senate, on Monday blamed his Republican opponent for talking too much about the whole bank situation.

title: This Week Is Adding Online Fact Checks
description: WASHINGTON  ABCs Sunday morning public affairs program, This Week, is adding an online feature that its political guests may not appreciate: fact checking.

title: NASA, Weve Got a Problem. But It Can Be Fixed.
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.  During his trip to the Kennedy Space Center this week, President Obama will be confronted with an awkward political reality: when it comes to space exploration, sometimes even Republicans can be passionate advocates for the public option.

title: Hotel Talk | The Pritzker Conundrum
description: Days after the announcement that Sanaa would receive the Pritzker Prize (considered architectures highest honor), the Tokyo firm  a partnership of Kazuyo Sejima and Ryue Nishizawa  was asked to design a hotel. As part of a larger foray into the hospitality business, the international luxury goods maker LVMH plans to turn the Samaritaine department store in Paris into chic accommodations. (The company acquired the store, in a landmark building overlooking the Seine, in 2001, and closed it four years later.)

title: Teixeira Honors a Cancer Patient
description: During his seven-plus years in the major leagues, Yankees first baseman Mark Teixeira has visited numerous childrens cancer wards and spoken to hundreds of patients. But Teixeira said none of those experiences touched him as much as the encounter he had in February with 19-year-old Brian Ernst.

title: Lukes Lobster Spreads Uptown
description: Luke Holden has done so well selling lobster rolls hes quitting his day job and heading to the Upper East Side.

title: UBS Client Pleads Guilty to Tax Fraud
description: A wealthy client of the Swiss bank UBS pleaded guilty on Monday to tax fraud, the ninth American caught up in an investigation of the banks offshore private banking services, The New York Timess Lynnley Browning reports.

title: The Long Story of a Long Revolution
description: Invictus isnt the only recent film to look at apartheid and the complicated legacy it left in South Africa. But unlike Clint Eastwood and his cast, Connie Field has taken the documentary route in Have You Heard From Johannesburg, a series of seven films that will have its world premiere this week at Film Forum in Manhattan.

title: Fed Names New Chief for Monetary Affairs
description: The Federal Reserve Board on Monday named William B. English as director of its division of monetary affairs, one of the most powerful staff positions at the central bank.

title: Jersey Boys File Suit Against The Boys
description: Oh, what a headache: the producers of Jersey Boys have filed suit against the producers of a touring show called The Boys in Concert, saying that it is trying to confuse audiences into thinking the two musicals are related, Reuters reported. Jersey Boys, which tells the story of Frankie Valli and his rock group, the Four Seasons, has remained a popular and lucrative show since it opened on Broadway in 2005 (and won the Tony Award for best musical), spawning several regional productions and a national tour. The Boys in Concert, whose cast and creators include the Jersey Boys alumni Christian Hoff, Michael Longoria and Daniel Reichard, features the music of several pop acts of the 1960s and 70s, including the Four Seasons. The lawsuit, which The New York Post reported was filed by Mr. Valli, as well as his band mate Bob Gaudio and the playwrights Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice, says that The Boys in Concert copies many elements of Jersey Boys and that its promotional materials represent a deliberate and willful attempt to create public confusion and foster the misimpression that the shows are associated or connected. The Jersey Boys producers are seeking damages and an injunction against performances of The Boys in Concert that use copyrighted or similar materials. Representatives for The Boys in Concert did not immediately respond to Reuters or The Post.

title: An Amen From the Press Box
description: The back end of Augusta Nationals challenging Amen Corner proved to be a propitious place for the Masters champion Phil Mickelson last weekend. His eagle on No. 13 on Saturday was the first of consecutive eagles that vaulted him into contention. And on Sunday, after driving into the pine needles to the right of the fairway on the par-5 510-yard hole, he opted not to lay up, but instead gambled on threading the needle between the trees. The ball landing a few feet from the hole. Though he missed the eagle, his subsequent birdie set him firmly on the path to his third Masters title.

title: Governors Island Vision Adds Hills and Hammocks
description: When the federal government sold Governors Island to the City and State of New York for one dollar in January 2003, it wasnt clear who had gotten the short end of the stick.

title: Reports That Palm Is to Be Sold Lift Its Stock
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Last year Palm, a pioneering maker of hand-held devices that was lagging far behind its competitors in the phone market, bet its future on a slick new smartphone called the Pre.

title: Versed by Rae Armantrout: California Poet, National Recognition
description: Rae Armantrout has won the 2010 Pulitzer Prize for poetry for Versed, her 10th collection.

title: Artful Way to Expand a Museum
description: To expand downtown or not to expand downtown, this is the nagging, seemingly unanswerable question facing the Whitney Museum of American Art. The museum wont know the right answer for sure until it tries it; if it doesnt, it will never know. But it is right in asserting that it must do something to remain viable in what has become a cutthroat competition for museum visitors in New York.

title: Judge Sees No Progress on Ground Zero Settlement
description: The federal judge who rejected a settlement last month of lawsuits filed by rescue and cleanup workers at ground zero said on Monday at a hearingthat no progress appeared to have been made in renegotiating the accord.

title: Prokhorov Group Denies Links to Sanctioned Firms in Zimbabwe
description: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, who is close to being approved by the N.B.A. as the majority owner of the New Jersey Nets, denied a New York Post article published Sunday that said that his company might be in violation of economic sanctions imposed on Zimbabwe.

title: Unshaven Women: Free Spirits or Unkempt?
description: SOME grooming choices are so brazen that not even an A-lister can make them palatable.

title: Social Skills and Animals (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Loss of a Loved One (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Navigating a Course Among 4 Composers
description: The Henschel Quartet, from Germany, made news last month when it performed for Pope Benedict XVI at his residence in Vatican City. Since then it has returned to more conventional concert spaces, though on Sunday afternoon the quartet turned up at a bona fide New York mansion, the Frick Collection, for a demanding, stylistically varied program. Its musicians performed early-20th-century scores by Erwin Schulhoff and Samuel Barber, and standard repertory works by Haydn and Schumann.

title: Studying Expressions (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Schumann Songs, Uncut, on the Lovesick Man
description: It is unclear why four songs from Schumanns Dichterliebe (A Poets Love) ended up on the cutting-room floor, but according to the baritone Thomas Hampson, Schumann was not the one wielding the knife.

title: Quantifying Quality Time (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Gluten-Free Diet (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Phillys Newspapers Are on a Hitting Streak
description: Last week, the current ownership of the newspapers in Philadelphia won an improbable series of legal victories at the Third Circuit in an effort to keep the properties out of the hands of the lenders, and then today, The Philadelphia Daily News, the underdog newspaper owned by an underdog owner in an underdog market, won a Pulitzer for investigative reporting. (The New York Times also won a Pulitzer for investigative reporting, in conjunction with ProPublica, for a magazine article by a freelancer, Sheri Fink, about the after-effects of Hurricane Katrina on a hospital in New Orleans.)

title: An All-Day Concert, but Only One Piece Was Performed
description: Morton Feldmans String Quartet No. 2 is hardly standard fare for a housewarming. Composed in 1983, the work runs more than six hours when played complete. But somehow it seemed ideally suited for the first public event mounted by Issue Project Room, a vital avant-garde performing arts presenter, in its future home at 110 Livingston Street in downtown Brooklyn on Sunday. A string quartet drawn from the fine new-music ensemble Ne(x)tworks did the honors.

title: Philips Changes Policy on Fitness Monitor
description: In December, I reviewed the Philips DirectLife  a tiny, plastic, waterproof/crushproof motion sensor. You wear it around your neck or in your pocket, and it tracks your physical activity over the days, weeks and months. In conjunction with a human coach who studies your uploaded data, the device is supposed to encourage you to be more active and become healthier.

title: Tribune Files Bankruptcy Plan; Lenders Protest
description: The Tribune Company filed its bankruptcy reorganization plan on Monday, setting the newspaper publisher up for a showdown with a large group of lenders that called the terms unfair and demanded the right to propose a rival plan, Reuters reports.

title: Europe Urged to Share Power Across Continent
description: BRUSSELS  Renewable energy in Europe should be generated and distributed on a continental scale to make the greatest contribution toward reducing greenhouse gases, according to a report that raises significant challenges for a fragmented region.

title: Why Do Educated People Use Bad Words?
description: California state legislators have long pushed self-improvement schemes on their constituents. Remember the State Task Force to Promote Self-Esteem (1986)? The latest such effort was a Cuss Free Week designated last month aimed at reducing profanity in public places.

title: Hedge Funds Get $16.6 Billion in New Money
description: Hedge funds took in $16.6 billion in new money in February as pension funds and wealthy investors raced to capture a piece of the industrys recent strong returns, Reuters reports, citing data released on Monday.

title: A German Riesling That Embodies Spring
description: WITH so many grapes grown in so many places around the world, even experts may be forgiven for mistaking, say, a South African sauvignon blanc for a Chilean sauvignon blanc. But a good German riesling from the Mosel region is like no other riesling in the world. It is simply one of wines singular glories.

title: Kuwait Deports Critics of Egyptian President
description: 17 Egyptian residents of Kuwait were deported last week for a meeting to discuss political change in Egypt, where Mohamed ElBaradei, the former head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, has emerged as a potential presidential candidate.

title: Critics' Picks: 'The Breakfast Club'
description: A.O. Scott revisits John Hughes's ode to adolescence.

title: Lions Gate Urges Shareholders to Reject Icahns Bid
description: Lions Gate Entertainment appealed directly to shareholders on Monday to thwart a hostile takeover attempt by the billionaire activist investor Carl C. Icahn that it calls inadequate, opportunistic and coercive, The Associated Press reports.

title: Senators End Impasse on Extending Unemployment Benefits
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Monday agreed to consider a temporary extension of unemployment benefits after four Republicans joined Democrats in voting to debate the proposal, which has become the focus of an intensifying fight over deficit spending.

title: Kabinett Rieslings
description: Ive always wanted to go to Michigan. Seriously. Its one of six states Ive never been to (since you insist, the others are South Carolina, North Dakota, Nebraska, Iowa and Hawaii). But, most important, Michigan has what I imagine to be a thriving wine country.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Breakfast Club
description: This week in Critics Picks, A. O. Scott looks at the 1985 film The Breakfast Club, an exploration of suburban teen angst  and detention  directed by John Hughes, who died last year.

title: Beatrice and Virgil
description: (Virgil and Beatrice are sitting at the foot of the tree. They are looking out blankly. Silence.)

title: That Corporate Jet Sometimes Makes Sense
description: AFTER two years, business jet no longer sounded disreputable.

title: Bootlegging in Tribal Pakistan
description: In Pakistan's tribal areas, alcohol bootleggers, lured by enormous profits, have created clandestine delivery services to evade recent crackdowns by the Taliban and the police.

title: Where Professors Make the Most
description: The average salary of a full-time faculty member rose 1.2 percent over the last year. That is the smallest increase professors have received in at least 50 years, according to the latest annual study from the American Association of University Professors.

title: Bootlegging, Pakistan-Style
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Even the threat of death cannot deter one 30-year-old entrepreneur here from his appointed rounds supplying the Pakistani elite with expensive contraband Scotch.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,381 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,026 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: Italian Judge Cites Profit as Justifying a Google Conviction
description: ROME  An Italian judge convicted three Google employees in February of violating privacy laws because the Internet company had sought to profit from a video of an autistic boy being bullied by classmates, according to a judicial reasoning in the case released on Monday.

title: Vatican Publishes Procedures for Sex Abuse Cases
description: ROME  Fending off accusations that it covered up abuse and obstructed justice, the Vatican on Monday spelled out for the first time that it now strongly urges bishops to report abuse cases to civil authorities if required by local law.

title: Jets Say Rewards Outweigh Risks With Holmes
description: Jets General Manager Mike Tannenbaum said Monday he understood the risks of making receiver Santonio Holmes part of the off-season makeover, one that already added a player of questionable character, cornerback Antonio Cromartie. But when he discovered Holmes could be had from the Pittsburgh Steelers for a fifth-round draft pick, Tannenbaum said the upside of adding a dynamic, potentially game-changing 26-year-old receiver made those risks palatable.

title: Baffled by Health Plan? So Are Some Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  It is often said that the new health care law will affect almost every American in some way. And, perhaps fittingly if unintentionally, no one may be more affected than members of Congress themselves.

title: Naming a New Chief, MasterCard Signals It Is Open to Changes
description: MasterCard named a onetime star at Citigroup as its next chief executive on Monday, a widely expected move that could nonetheless shake up the giant payment company. The appointment of the executive, Ajay Banga, is to take effect on July 1, the company said. MasterCard hired Mr. Banga as president and chief operating officer last August and signaled early that he would succeed Robert W. Selander, who has held the top job since 1997.

title: French and German Ties Fray Over Greek Crisis
description: PARIS  France and Germany traditionally have been the motor of the European Union, but relations between the two countries are badly strained over the Greek debt crisis, which is just the latest example of a new German willingness to resist the demands of Europe and assert its self-interest under Chancellor Angela Merkel.

title: Thrilling Rounds Whet Appetites for Rematch Between Mickelson and Woods
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.

title: Footage of Chinatown Fire
description: A resident captured the seven-alarm fire in Chinatown. (Courtesy of Adam Levy)

title: Kazakhstan to Permit Military Overflights to Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  Kazakhstan has agreed to let the United States fly troops and weapons over its territory, a deal that opens a direct and faster route over the North Pole for American forces and lethal equipment headed to Afghanistan.

title: Before Citys Worst Fire in Years, History of Neglect
description: The building in Chinatown where an enormous blaze started late Sunday night had more than two dozen open violations for hazardous conditions, including missing smoke detectors, lead paint and other problems that signified a history of neglect, city records show.

title: Gathering to Watch Their Citys Star Turn
description: NEW ORLEANS  In the family center of the Charbonnet-Labat-Glapion Funeral Home on St. Philip Street, the local historic neighborhood association came together for a meeting on Sunday night. After a few mentions of beautification issues, they got down to the matter at hand: in a few minutes time, the citys Trem neighborhood, unknown to most and mispronounced by many, was about to become very, very famous.

title: 4 Pulitzers for Washington Post; 3 for The Times
description: The Washington Post won four Pulitzer Prizes on Monday for its work in 2009, and The New York Times won three, while ProPublica became the first of the new breed of online, nonprofit news organizations to win the most prestigious award in print journalism.

title: Rangers Top Need? An Identity
description: On Tuesday, the Rangers will assemble at their practice rink one last time before breaking up for the summer and yet another rebuilding job. They missed the playoffs because of a single shot in the season-ending shootout Sunday in Philadelphia, but there are no illusions. If they are to be considered contenders in 2010-11, their off-season to-do list will have to be a long one.

title: OBrien Will Move to TBS
description: EUGENE, Ore.  In a move that has shocked much of the television world, Conan OBrien will make his comeback on a cable  not a network  channel.

title: Democrats Push to Require Campaign Disclosure
