description: WASHINGTON  The White House and leading Democrats in Congress are close to proposing legislation that would force private companies and groups to disclose their behind-the-scenes financial involvement in political campaigns and advertising, officials involved in the discussions said Monday.

title: What Were Reading: Technology to Help Journalism
description: Considering how distracted the New York Times tech reporters and editors were today, they did a fair amount of Web searching for other worthwhile news. Mondays reading list includes:

title: Their Childrens Children, as Holocaust Witnesses
description: Toby Edelstein, 9 years old, stood Sunday evening before a synagogue audience of about 350 to talk about his grandmother. The details were few, but they were enough.

title: Old Ads That Wont Die or Fade Away
description: MADISON AVENUE is coming up with a digital variation on an Irving Berlin standard: The campaign has ended, but the advertising lingers on.

title: Trump and Bondholders Gain Control of Casinos
description: Donald J. Trump is hoping the third time will be the charm.

title: Imagine the Bailouts Are Working
description: What if, after all that panting over Washingtons bailout of the financial system, we learned that it actually worked?

title: Does Reason Know What It Is Missing?
description: The German philosopher Jrgen Habermas has long been recognized as the most persistent and influential defender of an Enlightenment rationality that has been attacked both by postmodernism, which derides formal reasons claims of internal coherence and neutrality, and by various fundamentalisms, which subordinate reason to religious imperatives that sweep everything before them, often not stopping at violence.

title: In Canadian Case, Filings Say Toyota Knew of Risk
description: OTTAWA  Documents filed in a Canadian civil case against Toyota complaining of accelerator problems with a Lexus sedan show that the company viewed the problems as a serious threat to its reputation, even as officials publicly played down their importance.

title: In a Diplomatic Limbo While Waiting to Adopt
description: Randy Wills received the long-awaited call from his adoption agency last Thursday: a 10-month-old girl from eastern Russia was available for adoption. He and his wife, Magdalena Kleczkowski Wills, who live in Southington, Conn., could plan to travel to Russia in two weeks.

title: Behind the Curtain, Cuomo Runs His P.R. Machine
description: ALBANY  Press conferences called by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo have a Wizard of Oz feel: They are routinely done by conference call, with Mr. Cuomo remaining invisible, a booming authoritative voice sticking carefully to his chosen subject.

title: Apple Places New Limits on App Developers
description: Apple is tightening its already firm grip on what software can run on the iPhone and its other mobile devices, as shown by its recent changes to the rules that outside programmers must follow.

title: Sun Shines on Twins in Their New Ballpark
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The Minnesota Twins take pride in details. From the minor leagues on up, they implore their players to execute fundamentals. For a team that for years had one of baseballs lowest payrolls, and was nearly contracted out of existence, the approach was a matter of survival.

title: Bloggingheads: Christians With Guns
description: Anthea Butler, left, of the University of Pennsylvania and Michelle Goldberg of The American Prospect discuss Christian militias.

title: Lehman Channeled Risks Through Alter Ego Firm
description: It was like a hidden passage on Wall Street, a secret channel that enabled billions of dollars to flow through Lehman Brothers.

title: A Sailor First Ventures to Motherhood at Age 73
description: One friend told her she was too old to raise a child. Another promised it would keep her young.

title: Political Graffiti
description: Government-financed brigades of graffiti artists and muralists are blanketing the walls of Caracas, Venezuela, with politicized images, ranging from crude, semi-anonymous graffiti tags to bold, colorful works.

title: Child in Adoption Case Is an American Citizen, Not Russian, Experts Say
description: Russian officials and the sheriff in Shelbyville, Tenn., have both raised questions about whether the 7-year-old boy sent back to Moscow by his adoptive mother and grandmother last week is really a United States citizen.

title: Win a Meeting With the President
description: WASHINGTON  For President Obama, the first three days of this week are the diplomatic equivalent of speed dating. Every few minutes, it seems, another foreign leader is escorted into the room. They sit, they talk, they pledge mutual cooperation. And then it is on to the next one.

title: A Campaign Shows Signs of Progress Against Polio
description: JOHANNESBURG  A decade after the worlds original deadline for eradicating polio, the most tenacious bastions of the crippling virus  Nigeria and India  have recently shown remarkable progress in halting its spread, giving even some of the antipolio campaigns severest doubters hope that it may yet largely achieve its goal.

title: On Call When the Paint Chips Are Down
description: While Paul Mutimear arrived in New York from London in 1987 with dreams of rock n roll fame, these days he makes his living helping people decide between Drop Dead Gorgeous and Bed of Roses (both shades of red). Mr. Mutimear, 59, has been a paint guru for 23 years, first as a contractor specializing in decorative finishes for clients including Bobby Flay. For the last three years, he has worked as a senior color consultant for the Janovic home-design chain, most recently at the store at 888 Lexington Avenue on the Upper East Side, offering advice to high-strung customers choosing colors for their apartments.

title: Yankees Moment to Cherish
description: Before he takes the mound to pitch the Yankees home opener against the Los Angeles Angels on Tuesday, Andy Pettitte will be handed a World Series championship ring, his fifth. He will feel the joy of achievement that comes with ceremonial ritual. He will take a moment to admire the jewelry. Then the ring will go back in the box on its way to enshrinement at his family home in Houston.

title: Deaths Draw Attention to Dangers of Oil Tanks
description: CARNES, Miss.  When an oil tank exploded on a neighboring property early on the morning of Halloween last year, Phillip White immediately raced through his house, checking on his familys safety. But he could not find his 18-year-old son, Wade.

title: SUNY to Focus on Revitalizing the State
description: The State University of New York wants to expand its online offerings and capitalize on changes in health care and education over the next five years in an effort to turn the system into an economic engine for the state, according to a strategic plan to be unveiled on Tuesday by its chancellor, Nancy L. Zimpher.

title: Classic Miles
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Do you suppose Alex Boisvert loves music? Weve got Jimi Hendrix, Natalie Cole, Britney Spears, Sade and, of course, Miles Davis to supply the hint that ties the theme answers together and has us singing the blues.

title: D-League Attendance Tops 1 Million
description: Below the radar, the N.B.A.s Development League has gone from an underdeveloped asset to a key tool for N.B.A. franchises.

title: Somali Man Accused in 09 Piracy May Plead Guilty
description: A Somali man who was accused of piracy last year in the hijacking of an American-flagged cargo ship off Somalia appears to be in negotiations to plead guilty, according to a government letter filed on Monday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Memos Show Risky Lending at WaMu
description: WASHINGTON  New documents released by a Senate panel show how entrenched Washington Mutual was in fraudulent and risky lending, and highlighted how its top executives received rewards as their institution was hurtling toward disaster.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 12, 2010

title: Six Games In, and the Spotlight Is on the Mets Manuel
description: DENVER  It was in this city nestled, appropriately enough, in the Rocky Mountains, that Bobby Valentine, then the manager of the Mets, had an epic, emotional outburst in his office at the end of a 12-game losing streak in a deteriorating 2002 season.

title: On a Magazines List of the Citys Most Livable Neighborhoods, a Few Surprises
description: Ah, Greenpoint, Brooklyn. A neighborhood at once blessed and cursed.

title: Appeals Court Nominee Ignites a Partisan Battle
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama nominated Goodwin Liu to be an appeals court judge earlier this year, some on the left cheered. Mr. Obama had previously picked a succession of nominees who they believed were too centrist to counter the conservatives appointed during the Bush administration, they said, but finally he had selected a liberal legal rock star.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Personal Tech pages on Thursday about Micro Four-Thirds cameras misstated the genesis of the name of the camera standard. Four Thirds refers to the size of the image sensor measured diagonally (4/3-inch, in a sizing system derived from video camera tubes, now obsolete). The name does not stem from the 4:3 aspect ratio of the sensor.

title: Nets Are Looking Ahead to a Fresh Start in a New Home
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Larry Brown coached the Nets first N.B.A. game here, long before it was named Izod Center and long before it was named Continental Airlines Arena.

title: Sudan: Voting Period Is Extended After Problems
description: Election authorities extended voting on Monday to five days from three after election observers complained that polling stations were unprepared for the nations first national multiparty vote in more than two decades. Voting started Sunday.

title: United Arab Emirates: 2 Convicted in Chechens Killing
description: A Dubai court convicted two men for their roles in the assassination of a former Chechen general and sentenced both to 25 years in prison. The men were accused of aiding and abetting in the murder of Sulim B. Yamadayev, who was shot dead in the garage of an apartment complex in Dubai with a Russian-made handgun in 2009. They were identified as Mahsoudjan Asmanov of Tajikistan and Mahdi Tagi Dhurnia of Iran. Mr. Yamadayev, a former Chechen general who had fallen out of favor with Chechnyas Kremlin-backed president, Ramzan Kadyrov, had been living in Dubai under an assumed name. The Dubai police have accused four other suspects, including Adam Delimkhanov, an adviser to Mr. Kadyrov, who they say organized the killing.

title: Garden Says Farewell to the Knicks Impending Free Agents
description: All goodbyes are not created equal. Some are more meaningful than others, and for suffering Knicks fans, none was more poignant than the one they delivered Monday night.

title: Hungary: New Leader Assails Far-Right Partys Rise
description: The incoming prime minister, Viktor Orban, left, vowed Monday to defend Hungary from the ascent of a far-right party and its black-clad paramilitary branch, which have railed against the Roma community and called the capital Jewdapest. Mr. Orban, 46, the leader of Fidesz, the party that defeated the incumbent Socialists in first-round parliamentary elections on Sunday, said he was unhappy over the rise of the far-right party, Jobbik, which won 16.7 percent of the vote. No radical party will be allowed to get rid of law and order in this country, he said. Democracy in this country is strong enough to defend itself.

title: Mayor Bloombergs Island
description: Unable to carry its share of the costs, the New York State government has ceded responsibility for revitalizing Governors Island to New York City  which is exactly where the responsibility belongs.

title: A Different Creature
description: Nancy Pelosi, at lunch, was making the point that this latest recession was not a typical cyclical downturn.

title: What We Learned From H1N1s First Year
description: Richmond, Va.

title: Arts School in Harlem
description: To the Editor:

title: The Changing Face of the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Updating Internet Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Tomorrows Menu at School
description: To the Editor:

title: A Wrong Way and a Right Way
description: While Congress was on spring break the past two weeks, federal unemployment benefits expired for an estimated 200,000 jobless Americans. Each day, another 30,000 join the ranks of those who are both out of work and out of benefits. It did not have to come to this.

title: Politics 1, Rule of Law 0
description: The struggle between President Obama and Republicans on Capitol Hill has claimed a fresh victim  Dawn Johnsen. She was Mr. Obamas choice to lead the Office of Legal Counsel at the Justice Department. Ms. Johnsen withdrew her nomination after more than a year. It was clear that the White House was not going to fight to save her from Republicans who were refusing to allow a vote on her confirmation.

title: Palestinian Tactics, Through a Historical Lens
description: To the Editor:

title: Gao Zhisheng, Hu Jia, Liu Xiaobo
description: Washington and Beijing are, rightly, eager to lower tensions. After President Obama met President Hu Jintao of China at the White House on Monday, officials said they had agreed to work together to come up with new sanctions on Iran. That is good news.

title: History Is Hardly on Greeces Side
description: The International Monetary Fund is back at the peak of its power and relevance. But with Greece it has taken on a novel challenge: helping to repair a sovereign governments finances with neither a default nor a currency devaluation. No bailout in modern history has managed such a feat.

title: Massachusetts: Setback for Health Insurers
description: Gov. Deval L. Patrick won the first round Monday in a legal dispute with health insurers over the states recent rejection of rate increases requested by the companies. Ruling in a lawsuit brought by the companies, Judge Stephen E. Neel of Suffolk Superior Court in Boston said he would not block the state from denying the increases because the insurers had not exhausted their right to appeal administratively. Mr. Patricks insurance commissioner announced on April 1 that the state was rejecting 235 of 274 requested increases as excessive. Some were as high as 34 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the demographics of the audience for The Tonight Show on NBC after Jay Lenos return misstated the median age of Jon Stewarts audience on the Comedy Central channel. It is 40, not 49.

title: Lenos Longtime Music Director Moves On
description: Kevin Eubanks, the music director for The Tonight Show With Jay Leno, has confirmed that he will be leaving the show after 18 years. The decision was announced during the taping of Monday nights show.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about an increase in spending by well-off consumers misstated the surname of a pilot with XOJet, a jet-leasing company in San Francisco. He is David Kinser, not Kinsner.

title: Corrections
description: Schedule information on Wednesday with a theater review about Bellona, Destroyer of Cities misidentified the Web site of the Kitchen, the Chelsea performance space where the play was staged. It is thekitchen.org  not kitchen.org, a Web site guide to kitchen and bath remodelers.

title: Last Place? Mets Have Been There, Done That
description: It is early in the 2010 season, but for the Mets, of course, it may already be too late. To no great surprise, they have staggered through their first seven games and find themselves in last place in the National League East as they proceed through what could be a disastrous six-game trip to Colorado and St. Louis.

title: Anna Walentynowicz, Polish Provocateur Who Spurred Communisms Fall, Dies at 80
description: Anna Walentynowicz, a labor leader whose firing as a crane operator at the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk in 1980 touched off the strike that led to the founding of Solidarity and the unraveling of Communism in Poland, died on Saturday in the plane crash in Russia in which Polands president and dozens of Polish leaders were killed. She was 80.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on April 3 about the actor John Forsythe, using information provided by a family spokesman, referred incorrectly to Mr. Forsythes marital history. His marriage to Parker McCormick lasted from 1939 to 1943, not from 1938 to 1940, and he married Julie Warren the year they divorced, not three years later.

title: Andrew Stern, Head of S.E.I.U., Plans to Step Down
description: Andy Stern, president of the politically potent Service Employees International Union, has told colleagues he plans to step down, two members of his unions board said Monday.

title: Bill Would Allow Layoffs of Teachers With Seniority
description: When the Bloomberg administration raised the prospect of teacher layoffs this year, administration officials complained that they would be forced to get rid of the youngest newest teachers, and called on legislators to rewrite the seniority rules.

title: Corrections
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Different Takes on Top Defenders
description: Ballots are due this week for the N.B.A.s postseason awards. Although The New York Times does not permit its reporters to vote, the N.B.A. reporters Howard Beck and Jonathan Abrams are making their picks in Off the Dribble.

title: Jeffrey Katzenberg Goes to NAB to Talk 3-D
description: The NAB Show  the annual National Association of Broadcasters convention  has unexpectedly become the next 3-D battleground for the movie business.

title: Gates Foundation Stops Grant to Canadian Research Center
description: The Gates Foundation has withdrawn a $5.2 million grant to a Canadian research center for planned tobacco control work in Africa, after learning that the chairwoman of the centers board was also a board member for a unit of one of the worlds largest tobacco companies.

title: Leg Lost, Dancer Is Caught Between Caregivers
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Fabienne Jean, a professional dancer who lost her right leg in the earthquake, hopped on her slim left leg through the dusty General Hospital compound on her way to a very important X-ray.

title: Son of Former Congressman Enters Race to Take Rangels House Seat
description: Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV announced on Monday that he would challenge Representative Charles B. Rangel in the Democratic primary in the fall, setting the stage for an intensely personal rematch between two of Harlems biggest political names and oldest foes.

title: Man Is Sentenced in Sex Abuse Case
description: A Brooklyn man convicted of molesting a 16-year-old boy was sentenced on Monday to up to 32 years in prison, the maximum, for sexual abuse.

title: 3,500 at St. Vincents Get Termination Notices
description: St. Vincents Hospital handed out termination notices on Monday to all 3,500 of its employees, further sealing the fate of New York Citys last Catholic general hospital.

title: Defense in Hate Crime Trial Says Killing Was Unintended
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  In his closing argument, the lawyer for the Long Island teenager accused of fatally stabbing an Ecuadorean immigrant struck two themes seemingly at odds with each other  that the teenager was innocent, but that even if he were guilty, he did not intend to kill or seriously hurt anyone.

title: Racist E-Mail Tied to Candidate for Governor
description: ALBANY  Carl P. Paladino, a Republican candidate for governor from Buffalo, drew fire on Monday for racist and sexually explicit e-mail messages that a left-leaning Web site claimed he had sent to friends and business associates in recent years.

title: Twitter Unveils Plans to Draw Money From Ads
description: Twitter will unveil on Tuesday a much-anticipated plan for making money from advertising, finally answering the question of how the company expects to turn its exponential growth into revenue.

title: George Nissen, Father of the Trampoline, Dies at 96
description: One by one, the trapeze artists topped off their routines by dropping from their high-swinging bars into the net stretched below, then rebounding into somersaults  to the roar of the crowd at the traveling circus in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. And one kid in the stands began to wonder: Hey, what if there was a contraption that made it possible to keep on bouncing and flipping?

title: Wal-Mart Farms in India
description: Wal-Mart is trying to establish an agricultural beachhead in India as part of its global growth strategy.

title: Word of the Day | austere
description: austere \o-stir also -ster\ adjective

title: Crunching the Numbers From the Masters
description: One of the more memorable moments from Phil Mickelsons victorious final round in the Masters on Sunday also provided a prime example of how Mickelson and many of the other leading finishers navigated Augusta National.

title: News Quiz | April 13, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Twitter Unveils Plans to Draw Money From Ads
description: Twitter will unveil on Tuesday a much-anticipated plan for making money from advertising, finally answering the question of how the company expects to turn its exponential growth into revenue, Claire Cain Miller reports in The New York Times.

title: Imagine the Bailouts Are Working
description: Every couple of months the Treasury Department takes a moment to strategically leak some good news about the bailouts. It happened again on Monday, when a Treasury official told The Wall Street Journal that Americas coffers would be only $89 billion lighter after all accounts were settled from the rescues, down from an earlier estimate of $250 billion.

title: Common Sense About the Web
description: WHAT was the first wave of parental anxiety about the Internet focused on? WHAT, according to this article, do parents fear now?

title: Lehman Channeled Risks Through Alter Ego Firm
description: It was like a hidden passage on Wall Street, a secret channel that enabled billions of dollars to flow through Lehman Brothers, Louise Story and Eric Dash write in The New York Times.

title: Brazilian Rancher Convicted in Murder of Catholic Nun
description: A jury in the Brazilian city of Belm has sentenced a rancher to 30 years in prison in a retrial for the murder of an American-born nun, news agencies reported.

title: Woods Raises Ratings
description: Tiger Woodss return to competitive golf helped CBSs fourth-round Masters rating rise substantially over last year, but it did not set a record. The 12.0 preliminary overnight rating for Phil Mickelsons victory represented a 46 percent increase from an 8.2 last year, when ngel Cabrera won. By comparison, the highest rating for a final round at the Masters was 15.8 in 1997, when Woods won his first green jacket.

title: UBSs U.S. Brokerage Unit Still Losing Assets
description: Six months after Merrill Lynch veteran Bob McCann came on board to revive the United States wealth management business of UBS, the Swiss banks investors were reminded that a full recovery is still a ways away, Reuters reported.

title: Deposed Kyrgyz Leader Offers Deal to Step Down
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  The deposed president of Kyrgyzstan said Tuesday that he would formally step down if there were guarantees of safety for him and his family, speaking after the interim government that took power after bloody riots last week stripped him of immunity and threatened to send special forces to arrest him.

title: Sticking With UBS
description: UBSs worst days may be behind it, Reuters Breakingviews says. The Swiss bank said on Monday that it expected to make a pretax quarterly profit of at least 2.5 billion Swiss francs ($2.3 billion). With two profitable quarters under its belt, the turnaround appears to be under way.

title: Conan OBrien Back On Stage, but Away From TV
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Conan OBrien thrilled a sellout crowd of frenzied fans here Monday night, putting on a two-hour, highly energized show that referred at several points to his widely publicized departure from NBC and reached back to many of his best-loved moments from his days with the network.

title: Israeli Troops Kill 2 Militants in Gaza
description: GAZA  At least two Palestinian militants were killed and two others were wounded Tuesday when Israeli troops shot at them as they tried to plant explosives near the border, according to an Israeli military spokesman in Tel Aviv and Palestinians in Gaza.

title: How Much Do You Curse? Why?
description: The Room for Debate blog asks a similar question, Why do educated people use bad words?, that was inspired by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.s overheard use of an expletive during the signing of the health care bill. Do you think peoples attitudes have changed about what is socially acceptable language? Has the Web made it easier to curse? How much do you, personally, use bad words? When, where, and why do you use them? What is your reaction when others curse?

title: The Insider | Rachel Comey
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Rachel Comey is a downtown New York designer whose namesake brand includes a womens collection of clothing, shoes and accessories as well as a mens collection of shoes and accessories. Comey moved to New York to pursue life as an artist, and her collaboration with the band Gogol Bordello garnered her and the group a place in the 2001 Whitney Biennial. She started her clothing collection, inspired by the New York music scene, shortly thereafter and has developed a loyal following. She recently introduced an e-commerce site for her coveted mens shoes.

title: New Chief at MasterCard Signals Its Open to Change
description: MasterCard named a onetime star at Citigroup as its next chief executive on Monday, a widely expected move that could nonetheless shake up the giant payment company, The New York Timess Andrew Martin and Eric Dash reported.

title: Tencent to Invest $300 Million in Facebook Backer
description: Tencent Holdings, Chinas leading Internet provider, said Monday that it was investing about $300 million in Digital Sky Technologies, the Russian Internet holding company that acquired a stake in Facebook last year.

title: Greece Sells $1.6 Billion in Debt Sale
description: Greece raised 1.2 billion euros ($1.6 billion) in a heavily oversubscribed auction for 26- and 52-week government bonds Tuesday, the first debt sale since details were announced of a euro-zone and International Monetary Fund rescue package over the weekend, The Associated Press reported.

title: Dow Finishes Above 11,000
description: A few little points was all it took.

title: Phillys Newspapers Are on a Hitting Streak
description: From David Carr at Media Decoder:

title: British Prime Minister Wants Tougher Takeover Rules
description: Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain proposed changes to the countrys takeover rules on Monday that could make it more difficult to acquire British companies.

title: Apple Places New Limits on App Developers
description: Apple is tightening its already firm grip on what software can run on the iPhone and its other mobile devices, as shown by its recent changes to the rules that outside programmers must follow, The New York Timess Jenna Wortham reported.

title: Red Cross Staff Kidnapped in Congo
description: PARIS  The International Committee of the Red Cross said Tuesday that an armed group had kidnapped eight of its staff members in the South Kivu region of the Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: A Hedge Fund Show Tune
description: From Catherine Rampell at Economix:

title: White House Still Fighting for Financial Overhaul
description: The Obama administration vowed Monday to push for even tougher financial regulation, as legislation heads for the Senate floor as soon as next week, Reuters reported.

title: Trump Beats Out Icahn for Control of Casinos
description: Donald J. Trump is hoping the third time will be the charm.

title: GMAC Sells European Mortgage Arm to Fortress
description: GMAC, the bailed-out former financial service arm of General Motors, said Monday that it had sold its residential mortgage operations in Europe to the American hedge fund and private equity group, Fortress Investment.

title: A Bidding War for Arsenal?
description: One of Arsenal Football Clubs biggest shareholders decided to sell her stake in the English Premier League club on Monday, raising the possibility of a takeover bid for the north London team, Reuters reported.

title: The Styles of Grace at Londons V&A
description: At a time when it can be difficult to find that rare quality known as class, it is refreshing to see Grace Kelly back in the limelight. The late actress and her inimitable fashion sense are the focus of Grace Kelly: Style Icon, an exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum (Cromwell Road; 44-20-7942-2000; vam.ac.uk; free admission) through Sept. 26.

title: Creditors to Respond to Dubai World Debt Talks
description: Creditors of state-owned Dubai World will give their response to the indebted conglomerates debt restructuring proposal within weeks, one of its main lenders said Monday.

title: Obama Vows Fresh Proliferation Push as Summit Ends
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama completed a first meeting of world leaders on combating nuclear terrorism with a list of specific commitments from dozens of nations to eliminate or lock down nuclear materials, in what he called a bold and pragmatic program to finish the task in the next four years.

title: Iceland Investigators Issue Scathing Report on Banks
description: A former prime minister and central bank head and five other former officials acted with gross negligence in failing to prevent Icelands banking collapse in 2008, an official investigation found Monday, Reuters reported.

title: Should the N.F.L. Suspend Roethlisberger?
description: Commissioner Roger Goodell has wide latitude in punishing players under the personal conduct policy.

title: Virus as the New Axis of Evil
description: Todays idea: Venezuela, Iran and Russia together pose a serious threat to American objectives worldwide, a foreign affairs scholar writes, dubbing the combined peril the Virus.

title: Pimco Shuns Greek Debt Offerings
description: The Pacific Investment Management Company will not be buying new Greek debt, as it believes a euro-zone rescue package fails to tackle the countrys longer-term solvency challenges, the chief executive of the bond fund told Reuters.

title: Lowes Prices $1 Billion of Debt
description: Lowes Companies said Monday that it will sell $1 billion of debt in two parts and will use slightly more than half of the net proceeds to pay off notes coming due in June, Reuters reported.

title: F.D.I.C. Chief Says Banker Pay Can Still Pose Risk
description: Sheila C. Bair defended the move by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to clamp down on excessive banker pay on Monday, saying the stability of the financial system was at stake, Reuters reported.

title: Short Sales Fall at N.Y.S.E., but Rise at Nasdaq
description: Short sales on the New York Stock Exchange declined at the end of March, while those same positions rose on the  Nasdaq in the same period, Reuters reported.

title: Halliburton Strikes Deal for Boots & Coots
description: Halliburton has agreed to buy the oilfield services company Boots & Coots for $240.4 million, or $3 a share,in cash and stock, The Associated Press reported.

title: A Twitter Guide to the N.F.L. Draft
description: Sigmund Bloom, Cecil Lammey and Matt Waldman of Draftguys.com will help preview and analyze the draft for the Fifth Down. Bloom and Lammey host the always informative podcast at FootballGuys.com, and Waldman writes the  Rookie Scouting Portfolio, weighing in at a Kris Jenkins-like heft this year, with 740 pages.

title: New Hope Says Its in Talks With Macarthur Shareholders
description: New Hope, the coal producer which has offered $3.45 billion for its Australian rivalMacarthur Coal, has begun talks with Mccarthur shareholders, it said Tuesday.

title: Carlyle Closes Asia Fund With $2.55 Billion
description: Carlyle Group, the American private equity firm, said Tuesday that it had raised $2.55 billion for its Asia fund, Carlyle Asia Partners III, giving it a total of $5 billion for three such funds in the region.

title: Morningstar Buys British Fund Researcher
description: Morningstar said its British subsidiary had acquired Old Broad Street Research in Britain for about $18.3 million, The Associated Press reported.

title: Google Plunks Down for Plink
description: As Google continues its shopping spree, the search giant has picked up Plink, the maker of an Android application that can recognize and identify artwork, The Guardian reported.

title: Bootlegging in Tribal Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Adam Ellick writes in The New York Times about the hazards of selling alcohol in the Pakistani frontier town of Peshawar, in defiance of both the Taliban and Pakistani police.

title: Will Twitter Twist the Timeline?
description: Twitter has become more useful as it has ballooned to more than 50 million posts a day. But it has also become harder than ever to dig through all those posts to find the most useful ones.

title: Ford Explorer to Get 4-Cylinder EcoBoost Engine
description: Ford Motor announced that it will expand its line of EcoBoost engines by launching three new power plants before the end of the year. EcoBoost is Fords brand name for an engine technology package that optimizes engine efficiency through turbocharging, direct fuel injection and variable camshaft timing.

title: A 1917 Flying Boat Goes on the Auction Block
description: Updated, 1:43 p.m. | The Curtiss MF Flying Boat sold for $506,000 on Tuesday afternoon, a Bonhams spokesman said. The buyer bid by telephone, competing against two other phone bidders and one in the auction room.

title: Billionaire Will Try to Buy Rest of Rams
description: Stan Kroenke has decided to exercise his matching rights and try to buy the remaining 60 percent share of the St. Louis Rams, he said late Monday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Of Hedge Fund Managers and Campaign Contributions
description: As the spotlight on hedge funds has become increasingly hotter, industry executives have increasingly poured money into politicians campaign coffers.

title: Tip of the Week: Chemistry in Word
description: Chemistry students and teachers might want to check out the new Chem4Word add-on for Microsoft Word. The free software, which was developed by Microsoft Research and the Unilever Center for Molecular Science Informatics at the University of Cambridge, allows Word users to insert chemical symbols, formulas and even 2-D models of molecules into documents. Chem4Word works with Word 2007 and the current beta version of Word 2010, and is listed as a beta version itself. More information and a demonstration video are also available for scientists, aspiring scientists and those who have chemistry papers due soon.

title: Speed Read for Tuesday, April 13
description: Highlights from todays New York Times:

title: The Oy of Yiddish, Part 1
description: In March, co-vocabularists were invited to revel in the delights of Yiddish and pose questions to Michael Wex  author of the bestselling Born to Kvetch, and, most recently, How to Be a Mentsh and Not a Shmuck.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Arroz de Verduras
description: Arroz de Verduras, or vegetable rice, is an intensely flavored dish of many colors. It is rice cooked in a sofrito, a base of garlic, onions, sweet paprika, fresh tomato and saffron, and then studded with corn, edamame, peas and olives and baked until the edges are crisp and golden. It is a dish with Portuguese roots that George Mendes, the 37- year-old chef and a co-owner of Aldea, in Manhattan, introduced at his restaurant. As a first-generation American, he grew up in Danbury, Conn., surrounded by 30 relatives, all of whom had emigrated from Portugal. My mom, and my aunts, all cooked, he said.

title: Prosecutors Name Targets of More Galleon Trades
description: Goldman Sachs Group, AT&T and Cisco Systems are among stocks bought and sold illegallyby the Galleon Group hedge fund founder Raj Rajaratnam and others involved in a sprawling insider trading case, federal prosecutors said.

title: Why Humanity Loves, and Needs, Cities
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.For much of its early existence, our species spread out.

title: Book Reveals Unheard Interviews With Jacqueline Kennedy
description: Nearly seven hours of previously unreleased interviews with Jacqueline Kennedy, recorded just months after the death of President John F. Kennedy and intended for deposit in a future presidential library, will be released as a book, the publisher Hyperion said on Tuesday. The original interviews with Mrs. Kennedy were conducted in the spring of 1964 with the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. as part of an oral history project intended to preserve memories of Kennedy and his administration. In the seven interviews, Hyperion said, Mrs. Kennedy discusses various subjects including her husbands election campaigns, his handling of challenges like the Cuban Missile Crisis, her role as a wife, mother, and first lady; and what her husband would have done in a second term as president.

title: Bill Would Permit Layoffs of Teachers With Seniority
description: What were reading this morning:

title: Ex-Northern Rock Executives Fined and Banned
description: Britains financial regulator has fined and banned two former executives of the mortgage lender Northern Rock  the countrys first major casualty of the global credit crunch  for misreporting figures on loan arrears, The Associated Press reports.

title: Trading Ends With a Modest Gain as Investors Digest Earnings Reports
description: Wall Street traders took in the first batch of quarterly earnings reports on Tuesday, but nobody seemed quite sure what to make of the numbers.

title: The Early Word: More Nuke Talks
description: Its time for Day Two. President Obama heads back over to the Washington Convention Center today for more action at the nuclear security summit.

title: Imports Rose in February, Building Hope for Recovery
description: Trade data on Tuesday provided another piece of evidence that spending by consumers and businesses was picking up, bolstering hopes that the recovery was gaining momentum.

title: Today in Business Travel
description: In-Flight Food, No Longer Free, Tries to Be TastyAirlines are abandoning free in-flight food, and looking closely at what the paid options might be.Frustrated? Try Life on the No Fly ListHes not supposed to be on the list. Theres a way to get off the list, but thats not working either.

title: Book Reveals Interviews With Jacqueline Kennedy
description: Hyperion announced this morning that nearly seven hours of previously unreleased interviews with Jacqueline Kennedy, recorded just months after the death of President John F. Kennedy and intended for deposit in a future presidential library, will be released as a book. Caroline Kennedy is editing the book, which is planned for publication in September 2011 as part of the 50th anniversary commemoration of the Kennedy presidency.

title: Will There Be Annual Caps in the High-Risk Pools?
How We Try to Get Buy-In, Part 1
description: On the morning of June 22, 2009, all 78 associates of SRC Power Systems, which makes custom-engineered power units and is based in Springfield, Mo., filed onto the shop floor to hear an hour-long presentation about the companys latest sales-and-marketing plan. People grabbed folding chairs where available while others sat on wire containers or floor baskets near their tools and workstations. There was a dark mood in the air. One guy leaned up against an engine crate, his arms folded across his chest and his jaw set. It was as if he already didnt like what he was about to hear.

title: Consumer Reports Says Lexus GX 460 Is Unsafe
description: 7:07 p.m. | Updated

title: Pedaling for Nepal
description: When we last wrote about Apolis Activism, the socially minded clothing company had teamed up with the American heritage brand Filson to make a messenger bag using fabric sourced from Uganda. Its latest offering  a sweater produced in collaboration with the cycling outfitters at Rapha  originates from another unlikely spot: a small wool cooperative in Nepal staffed entirely by women.

title: Smithsonian Names Director of Education
description: The Smithsonian Institution has named Claudine Brown as its first director of education. Ms. Brown, 60, who since 1995 has been the director of the arts and culture program at the Nathan Cummings Foundation, will oversee the National Science Resources Center and the Smithsonian Center for Education and Museum Studies, and coordinate the efforts of the education offices in all of the Smithsonians museums and science centers.

title: Pulitzer Juror Criticizes Choice for Drama Prize
description: How did Next to Normal end up winning the Pulitzer Prize for drama on Monday when the five-person drama jury  responsible for evaluating the entries of plays and musicals  did not include Next to Normal among its three nominees for the prize?

title: A Spy Takes the Spotlight
description: When Michael Garin, who plays the piano at Elaines on Sunday nights, started Secret Agent Man, few patrons noticed as the man in the blue blazer and gray slacks at the front table pulled off his shoe and did his best Maxwell Smart.

title: Growth and Greenhouse Gases
description: So Ive gotten some pushback from environmentalists on the proposition in my mag piece that we can afford, at real but modest cost, to limit greenhouse gas emissions. Oddly, it comes from two directions. On one side, there are those who insist that greening the economy is win-win: more jobs, more growth, as well as less carbon. On the other, those who insist that you can only be serious about protecting the planet if you admit that we have to give up on economic growth.

title: A Womans Place Is in the Home  er, House
description: The May issue of Good Housekeeping, celebrating the magazines 125thanniversary, salutes 125 women who changed our lives and who changed the world. At an event on Monday night to celebrate the milestone, it seemed that most of them were there  and then some.

title: A Rumor Going Around
description: Monologue |  Monday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Theres a rumor going around that Hillary Clinton could be Obamas choice for the next Supreme Court justice. Thats a lifetime appointment that would take up all of her time, or as Bill Clinton calls it, Shell take it.

title: Financial Ruin
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: Well, according to the Pentagon, Al Qaeda is in financial ruin. You know why theyre broke? Health insurance premiums.

title: Paging Larry Kudlow
description: Larry Kudlow, 2007.

title: Andrew Ross Sorkin Owes Several People an Apology
description: He writes:

title: Ring Around the Rosy
description: The artist Anish Kapoor is known for his large-scale, often highly polished and mind-bending sculptures, many of which are currently on view at the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao, where he is having a major solo exhibition. The ring he recently designed for Bulgari would make the ultimate souvenir. The concave stainless-steel band capped in pink gold is like one of the artists works  pocket size rather than park size  and will serve as the inspiration for a larger piece to be auctioned off later this year to benefit Save the Childrens Rewrite the Future program.

title: Tuesday Reading: Unemployment Benefits
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Sharp Adds Yellow to 3-D TV
description: The new 3-D televisions are barely out of the box, and the one-upmanship among manufacturers has begun.

title: Dr. Deepak Chopra on Reinventing the Body
description: If you are looking for inspiration and motivation to improve your health, Dr. Deepak Chopra is a good place to start.

title: Conan OBrien, On the Road Again
description: The last time we saw Conan OBrien on stage, he was bidding farewell to his Tonight Show tenure with an all-star singalong of Free Bird. On Monday night, he commenced his Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television tour at the Hult Center for the Performing Arts in Eugene, Ore., with a set that included this appropriate Willie Nelson number. Bill Carter has a report on the nights show on Media Decoder, and at Variety, Michael Schneider has posted more video from the show (which may be yanked from the Web faster than you can say The Jay Leno Show).

title: Bank Failure: Two Brief Notes
description: 1. Some commenters on this blog have argued that lots of small banks failed in Georgia, without systemic consequences. But these banks werent allowed to collapse; they were seized by the FDIC  in effect, nationalized  and their depositors were protected. That is, in effect they were rescued, although the stockholders were cleaned out.

title: Unplaced Students Go Back to Square One
description: It did not matter if the envelope was thick or thin  for thousands of eighth graders around the city, whether rejected or accepted, it ended the strange state of limbo they had been in for months. The high school admissions process, normally nerve-wracking, was even longer this year because a lawsuit over the citys plans to shutter some high schools delayed the letters several days.

title: With Broadway On Hold, Patton Oswalt Pivots to TV
description: However the theater world may feel about Patton Oswalt, hes still got a home on television. Weeks after the demise of the Lips Together, Teeth Apart revival that would have marked his Broadway debut, Mr. Oswalt, the comedian and actor (Big Fan, Ratatouille, The King of Queens) has been cast in a new television pilot that puts him opposite the Broadway veteran Matthew Broderick. Publicists for Mr. Oswalt said in a statement that he would star in a comedy pilot called Beach Lane, created by Paul Simms (NewsRadio), in which he will play a well-to-do if not well-educated man who is put in charge of a local newspaper in fictional Dockhampton, N.Y. Mr. Broderick will play an established journalist whom Mr. Oswalts character hires to help him keep the presses rolling. The cast will also feature Kristen Johnston (Third Rock From the Sun) and its producers include Lorne Michaels and Marci Klein (of Saturday Night Live and 30 Rock).

title: Ringo Unmoved by Vatican Praise for Beatles
description: Updated | 12:59 p.m. While newspapers in many countries continue to report on how the Roman Catholic Church has responded to the sexual abuse of children by priests, the Vaticans daily, LOsservatore Romano, found space in its pages over the weekend to deal with an older controversy: John Lennons offhand statement in 1966 that the Beatles were more popular than Jesus.

title: G.O.P. Takes Aim at Plans to Curb Finance Industry
description: WASHINGTON  Drawing the lines for a fierce election-year battle over regulating the nations financial system, Senate Republicans on Tuesday insisted that legislation proposed by Democrats and the White House would only encourage future taxpayer bailouts of big banks.

title: Study Says Overuse Threatens Gains From Modified Crops
description: Genetically engineered crops have provided substantial environmental and economic benefits to American farmers, but overuse of the technology is threatening to erode the gains, a national science advisory organization said Tuesday in a report.

title: Mapping World Debt
description: This map, by Benjamin Hennig of the University of Sheffields SASI Research Group, shows the debt load around the world. The size of each country represents the total external debt of that nation (using 2010 World Bank estimates). The color of each country, on the other hand, shows the size of national debt relative to the size of each countrys economy.

title: The Slowly Fading Cult of the Messenger
description: The immortal class is looking a little more mortal these days.

title: Obamas Opening Remarks
description: Following is a transcript of remarks by President Obama and the president of South Korea, Lee Myung-bak, at a plenary session ofthe 47-nation nuclear security conference on Tuesday, as released by the White House:

title: Matsui Returns to Yankee Stadium
description: A few hours before the Yankees received their 2009 World Series rings, Hideki Matsui, the most valuable player of the Series, was in the spotlight.

title: Grammys Will Return to Mid-February in 2011
description: The Grammy Awards will return to its usual mid-February date in 2011, the Recording Academy announced Tuesday on its Web site, Grammy.com.

title: The New Features in Your 401(k)
description: Employers arent just reinstating 401(k) matches. They are also adding investment advice and target date funds and are increasingly automatically enrolling employees, according to new data from Charles Schwab.

title: Obama Seeks Local Action for Earth Day
description: President Obama today urged Americans to honor the upcoming 40th anniversary of Earth Day by acting to improve the environment around them and launched a Web site, Whitehouse.gov/EarthDay, compiling citizens success stories.

title: 36 Hours in Munich
description: MUNICH is a major destination for beer lovers, history buffs and music fans, but lately the Bavarian capital has been recognized as a great place to live. Monocle magazine ranked it the worlds most livable city in 2007, citing its high-quality housing, low crime and general feeling of Gemtlichkeit. Its public transportation was recently deemed Europes best by a leading automobile club. And its storied beer culture is so ubiquitous that Lufthansa just installed its own beer garden at Munich airport.

title: CNN Fights Back With Objectivity Arguments
description: In a presentation to advertisers and agencies on Tuesday morning, executives of CNN indicated how they plan to counter the growing ratings of  and buzz about  the rival Fox News Channel: play up their channels identity as an objective source of news.

title: Williamsburg Waterfront Concerts Announced
description: Its looking to be a big summer of music at East River State Park, on the waterfront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Modest Mouse will play on July 23, in a benefit for the Open Space Alliance of North Brooklyn, a nonprofit group that runs the concert series there. Faith No More has added a second date there for July 2, after its season-opening concert on July 5 sold out, and in February Senator Charles E. Schumer declared, enthusiastically, that the free pool parties would return this summer, but no details about those shows have been announced. Tickets for Modest Mouse go on sale Friday, and for Faith No Mores July 2 concert on April 23, both through Ticketmaster.

title: Barney Frank Joins Talk Schedule at The Temperamentals
description: Its not often that a politician makes it known in advance when hell be attending a theater event, but in this case, Representative Barney Frank not only wants you to know hell be at a performance of The Temperamentals, he hopes youll stick around afterward and ask him questions. Mr. Frank, the outspoken Democrat of Massachusetts, will participate in a postperformance discussion on May 3 at New World Stages, the plays press representatives said on Tuesday. The congressman will appear with Jon Marans, the author of The Temperamentals, a play about forerunners of the gay rights movement in the early 1950s. Other guests planned for the talk series in future weeks include the playwrights Charles Busch and Terrence McNally, and James E. McGreevey, the former governor of New Jersey.

title: Robert Bohr Leaves Cru
description: Robert Bohr, who was a partner and wine director at Cru since it opened in 2004, has left the restaurant. While continuing the wine consulting company he runs with Crus owner, Roy Welland, he has also stared working with Tom Colicchio to oversee some of the wine programs at Mr. Colicchios restaurants.

description: Several Pulitzer Prize board members went to see the Broadway musical Next to Normal last Thursday, the night before the board made its surprise vote to award this years drama Pulitzer to the musical, according to two people with firsthand knowledge of the boards deliberations.

title: G.O.P. Leader Faults Democrats Finance Overhaul
description: The Democratic proposal to overhaul financial regulations would perpetuate government bailouts of big Wall Street banks rather than end them, the Senates Republican leader said Tuesday.

title: The Incinerator as Eye Candy
description: The waste-to-energy plants I visited in Denmark this year for an article look like, well, power plants. Each has a prosaic smokestack dating from the days when all they had were old-fashioned incinerators. Twenty years ago, an important form of pollution control was to build a very, very tall smokestack so that dirty emissions dispersed far and wide.

title: Sampler: Union Leader Steps Down, and Residents Fight Over Trees
description: Labor Leader Steps Down | Andrew Stern, the leader of the Service Employees International Union, signaled Monday that he would step down at the end of this week, Politico reported. Over the past year, Mr. Stern has confronted bitter resistance as he steered the union through the fastest period of growth in its history. He has been locked in a fierce struggle with a splinter S.E.I.U. health care workers local in the Bay Area. He has also been fighting the hotel and restaurant workers union Unite Here, whose leader in San Francisco, Mike Casey, is a prominent national labor figure. [Politico, The New York Times]

description: -The director Vincent Gallo explains why he is selling a portrait of himself by Julian Schnabel on eBay. We dont know why someone would want a portrait of Vincent Gallo in their home, but we do understand the need for more shoes!

Now, hes complaining of partisan politics when it comes to documents concerning the carmakers recall of 6 million vehicles.

title: Michelle Obama and Jill Biden Stop in Haiti

title: Marinated Carrots With Fresh Mint

description: PEARL RIVER, N.Y.  It has long been a rite of passage for teenagers here to hit the Manhattan clubs or make a road trip to the Jersey Shore after prom.

description: Heres a way to preserve those mushrooms you didnt get around to using when they were at their best. Serve these as hors doeuvres, snacks or a side dish, or slice them up and throw them into a salad.

title: Thai Protesters Revel, the Government Reels and the Army Wavers
description: BANGKOK  With soldiers back in their barracks three days after a convulsion of political violence, antigovernment demonstrators took up squirt guns in central Bangkok on Tuesday to dedicate themselves to the start of the annual water festival.

description: These arent like any cucumber pickles Ive ever tasted. The cucumbers are marinated in seasoned rice vinegar with a small amount of sesame oil. Theyre great on sandwiches or with cottage cheese, and go well with fish and with Asian dishes.

description: MEXICO CITY  In her first solo trip overseas as first lady, Michelle Obama made an unannounced visit to Haiti on Tuesday, flying in an Army helicopter over Port-au-Prince, the earthquake-damaged capital, meeting with Haitis president and first lady in the ravaged National Palace and dancing with young children trying to get beyond the destruction of their homes.

description: Dont despair if you realized your eligibility for certain tax breaks (like those we covered in this recent Bucks post) only after you had already filed your federal taxes. You can still file an amended return.

title: 92nd Street Y Announces 2010-11 Season
description: The 92nd Street Y plans to focus largely, but not exclusively, on thematic programming in its 2010-11 season. Among the highlights is a three-concert Schubert series by the Takcs Quartet (Oct. 16, Feb. 26, April 9), with a new work by Daniel Kellogg, based on Schuberts Death and the Maiden Quartet, on the first program. The Chamber Music at the Y series, with the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio, and guests, celebrates Schumanns bicentenary with three programs devoted to music of Robert and Clara Schumann, Brahms and Chopin (Oct. 27 and 28, Dec. 15 and 16, April 6 and 7).

title: Driving While Demented
description: You might hope that when the American Academy of Neurology reviews and updates its decade-old guidelines on driving and dementia, the experts would come up with clear-cut recommendations: a specific score on a specific test means someone can head for the mall without much concern, or a particular behavior means its too risky to be on the road, so hand over the keys.

title: New Flip SlideHD Has Bigger Screen
description: Flip pocket camcorders have always made it a snap to share video through online social networking and e-mail. The new Flip SlideHD makes it easier to share face t0 face with a pop-out 3-inch widescreen LCD for sharing videos with friends and family.

title: Scent Notes | Chandler Burr
description: Unlike the old masterpieces, which cloaked the wearer in scent, new fragrances are lighter and more transparent, engineered to show you off. Some of the best. ...

title: Marinated Beets
description: A little sugar softens the edge of the vinegar here and complements the natural sweetness of the beets. Keep these on hand for healthy snacks, or add to salads.

title: Union Brandishes Banker Pay in Fight With Wall St.
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O., the nations largest labor union federation, is taking aim at the big banks in its annual survey of chief executive compensation, highlighting the efforts by Wall Streets leaders to fight against tougher financial regulations.

title: Pittsburgh Company Cuts Ties With Roethlisberger
description: Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger was to meet with N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell on Tuesday, one day after a Georgia district attorney said he would not bring sexual assault charges against Roethlisberger. But Roethlisberger is far from in the clear. He could be suspended either by the league or by the Steelers, and the estimated $2.5 million he makes in endorsement money could dry up, too.

title: To Get Ring, Hairston Flies All Night
description: Hideki Matsui wasnt the only former Yankee at the Stadium on Tuesday collecting his World Series championship ring. Jerry Hairston Jr., who now plays for the Padres, surprised his old teammates by taking a red-eye flight after his game Monday in San Diego to take part in the ceremony.

title: Pulitzers for Distracted Driving
description: The Pulitzer Prizes were announced Monday, and two journalism awards went to stories on distracted drivers.

title: Anti-American Demonstration in Najaf
description: NAJAF, Iraq  Earlier this week, on the seventh anniversary of the American fall of Baghdad, Shiite demonstrators held a protest in the holy city of Najaf, burning effigies of President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., and stamping on the flags of the United States and its allies. Many were supporters of Moktada al-Sadr, and carried posters of the Shiite cleric and his father, Mohammad Sadeq al-Sadr, who was assassinated during Saddam Husseins regime.

title: Police Investigating Death of a Lighting Designer
description: The police are investigating the death of a 26-year-old man whose body was discovered on Monday lying on the kitchen floor, his hands cuffed behind his back, in his apartment in Lower Manhattan, the authorities said.

title: Ex-Chief Claims WaMu Was Not Treated Fairly
description: WASHINGTON  The former chief executive of the largest United States bank ever to fail told a Senate hearing on Tuesday that his company had been treated unfairly and should have been given a chance to survive the crisis that engulfed the financial system in September 2008.

description: Q.

title: Steinbrenner Makes Room on His Hand for Another Ring
description: The Major League Baseball season is six games old, but as far as Yankees fans were concerned, the 2010 campaign started today, when the Yankees received their 2009 World Series championship rings before their home opener.

title: High and Low Dining: Amsterdam
Milan Report | Fornasetti Remix
description: Its the start of design week here in Milan, and our first event was an off-site exhibit at one of our favorite galleries: Nilufar. Run by Nina Yashar, the gallery-cum-high-end-design-boutique specializes in antique design masterpieces as well as newly commissioned works by young designers. The standout at this years exhibition, however, was a bit old and a bit new. The designer Barnaba Fornasetti, son of the legendary Piero Fornasetti, has made newly commissioned pieces out of some of his fathers classic collaborations with the famed designer Gio Ponti. Instead of making these pieces in the high-gloss lacquer that is a Fornasetti trademark, these new works are covered in the original zinc lithographic plates that papa Fornasetti used to print his famous designs. The matte gray zinc is embellished in a black etched patchwork of flowers, trompe loeil books, faux bois and more. The zinc plates are attached to the wooden construction of the furniture by way of utilitarian yet decorative nail heads. The collection consists of two desks, a tall secretary desk, a chair, a chandelier and a wardrobe (in which Barnaba has even placed some of his own idiosyncratic Fornasetti printed suits, vests and shirts). All of the pieces are unique and are destined to become instant, if remixed, classics.

title: Senators Invited to White House for Supreme Court Talks
description: President Obama has invited top Democratic and Republican senators to the White House next Wednesday to consult on his next pick for the Supreme Court  a move that means, in effect, there will be no announcement of a candidate for at least the next eight days.

title: Pimentn: Its Spanish for Better Than Paprika
description: DONT you hate paprika? O.K., maybe thats too strong, but isnt it at least puzzling?

title: Oven-Barbecued Pimentn Brisket
description: Time: 8 to 10 hours, mostly unattended

title: South Bronx, 10:51 A.M.
The Morning Skate: Danger Looms in the First Round
description: The first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs, which starts on Wednesday, can be a danger zone for favorites. Scotty Bowman, who coached more Stanley Cup championships than anyone, told listeners of Toronto radio FAN 590 this morning (audio) that he was very aware of the possibility of first round upsets and there are no sure things. I look at all the different TV shows and everyones always picking the favorites, its the easy thing to do. You wonder how a team thats 20 or 30 points behind another can even have a competition.

title: Talking in Depth About Adoption
description: My in-box has been filling with emotion over the past few days, as I hear from parents of adopted children, would-be parents of adopted children, parents having second thoughts and those hoping that Russian officials will reconsider. This morning I am posting a sampling of what I am hearing, as a way of continuing the conversation.

title: The Power of Pimentn
description: Paprika a power ingredient? That tasteless powder that your great-aunt sprinkled over potato salad to give it some color? Well, no. But in a fertile valley in the Spanish equivalent of the Wild West, they make a paprika with a sneaky heat and deep smokiness that takes the spice to a whole different place. Called pimentn, its a nearly effortless way to add complex flavor to all kinds of dishes, like barbecued brisket, or barbecue sauce, or a Spanish lamb stew, or this quick and easy kale recipe.

title: Red Bulls May Be Close to Signing Notts County Striker (or Not)
description: 11:25 a.m. | Updated A Red Bull official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to speak publicly about Luke Rodgers, said the reports that the player has been denied a work permit were false.

title: Former WaMu Chief Defends Loan Practices
description: The former chief executive of Washington Mutual, the biggest American savings and loan ever to fail, defended on Tuesday the banks actions to reduce risks from the looming housing bust, The Associated Press reports.

title: Flowers, Bikes and Other Signs of Spring
description: Move over, D.C.  the cherry blossoms of New York are pretty impressive as well. It could even be argued that ours are more stunning, blooming as they often do near towering buildings or alongside highways rather than in manicured parks, as Found in Brooklyn and others appreciate.

title: Yankee Stadiums Second Season
description: Yankee Stadium opened to much fanfare last season, with the superlatives to match the teams record number of championships. With a $1.5 billion price tag, it is the most expensive baseball stadium. The $2,500 tickets behind home plate were also the priciest in the league. And when many of them went vacant, they became the most scrutinized as well.

title: Q. and A. on Food Safety with Michael Moss
description: Michael Moss, who won the Pulitzer Prize on Tuesday for his reporting on contaminated hamburger and gaps in federal oversight of food safety, will be taking questions from readers on Diners Journal this week.

title: Random House Merges Two of Its Imprints
description: In a move to streamline its family of imprints, Random House, the worlds largest trade publisher, consolidated two of those imprints within its Random House Publishing Group, merging Bantam Dell with Ballantine Books.

title: High and Low Dining: Barcelona
The Latest Web Hit: Spoofs of Nikes Tiger Woods Ad
description: The parodies of Tiger Woodss recent ad for Nike are now more popular online than the original ad.

title: U.S. Institutions Join International Museum Day
description: Dozens of American art museums will offer free or discounted admission, store discounts and special programming on May 18, for the first time collectively joining other institutions around the world by participating in International Museum Day.

title: Civil Rights Groups Fight Oakland Gang Injunction
description: The proposed Oakland gang injunction  introduced in February by Oaklands city attorney, John Russo  has garnered praise from those seeking aggressive anticrime measures and wary disapproval from others concerned about racial profiling. The issue has generated considerable back-and-forth debate about the best ways to balance public safety and civil liberties.

title: High and Low Dining: Berlin
Berlins Terror Exhibition Gets New Home
description: For years, only a simple sign indicated the location of what was once the Nazi secret police headquarters in Berlin. You are standing on the grounds of the former torture chambers of the Gestapo, it read. More recently, an outdoor exhibition, called The Topography of Terror, has marked the spot. On May 7, the exhibition is scheduled to get a new home: a glass and concrete museum and documentation center built on same site.

title: Financial Tuneup: Automate Your Debt Payments
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: Interesting Choices for N.B.A.s Overseas Tour
description: The Knicks do not have a superstar (yet), a winning record or even a full roster for next season, but the N.B.A. is sending them on a good-will tour of Europe in October. Call it an official leap of faith in their rebuilding plan.

title: FAQs on Style
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: High and Low Dining: London
Lane Departure Warning Systems for the Rest of Us
description: Sophisticated driver assistance safety technologies, like beeping lane departure warning systems and dashboard lights that flash when you follow another car too closely, have generally only been available as a factory-installed option on new cars. Drivers of older vehicles have had to make do without it. But now at least one company hopes to make such systems more readily available to those who arent in the market for a new car.

title: N.E.A Chairman Testifies on Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, Rocco Landesman, delivered his first budget testimony before a House subcommittee on Tuesday, arguing for the arts as a source of jobs and an economic stimulus.

title: More People Choosing Kosher for Health
description: An ancient diet has become one of the hottest new food trends.

title: Man Who Spread H.I.V. May Be Held
description: ALBANY  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomos office is moving to block the release of Nushawn J. Williams, the Brooklyn man who was believed to have knowingly infected a number of young women and girls in upstate New York with H.I.V. in a highly publicized case more than a decade ago.

title: High and Low Dining: Moscow
Now Skewering | Jean Philippe Delhomme
description: In the hands of the illustrator Jean Philippe Delhomme, the unbearable lightness of being hip, rich and polished has never seemed so disarmingly down-to-earth. For more than 25 years, the artist has chronicled the in-crowd by quizzical strokes through advertisements and editorials for the likes of Barneys, Interview and Glamour. His signature is a rainfall of lifelike impressions that glitter until they prickle. Know thyself, he seems to say to a beau monde unwittingly silly in its distractions. Words to heed in frugal times? Recognize yourself in his world and you may feel better about being so terribly with it.

title: I.M.F. Supports Charging Banks for Risks
description: Requiring the largest banks to pay surcharges based on the risks they pose to the global financial system could help provide stability, but the fees would have to be handled very carefully, the International Monetary Fund said Tuesday.

title: Obama to Attend Funeral for Polish President
description: President Obama will travel to Krakow, Poland, this weekend to attend the funeral of Polish President Lech Kaczynski, who was killed last weekend in a plane crash.

title: Tower on 40th St. Is Named a Landmark
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday bestowed landmark status on the Springs Mills Building, a tower clad in green glass at 104 West 40th Street, just west of Avenue of the Americas, which was built in 1963 and named for a pillowcase maker.

title: Dressed for Success, or a Yankees Game
description: Opening day is a day for fans to wear their teams colors. Yankees fans are no different  home white pinstripe jerseys, navy blue fitted caps and T-shirts saying, Got rings?

title: High and Low Dining: Prague

description: WASHINGTON  Representative Barney Frank publicly rebuked a former aide this month for taking a job with a big Wall Street firm right after drafting a regulation that could affect the way the firm does business. Mr. Frank described it as an unusual transgression, one that embarrassed others working on the legislation and created at least the appearance of a conflict of interest.

title: High and Low Dining: Rome

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is still popular. Or so recent polls suggest. But he shouldnt let those numbers get to his head just in case hes toying with higher office, or is considering trying to renew his lease on City Hall.

title: A Crusade of Seduction and Sorcery
description: Rene Fleming has always made very particular and personal choices of operatic roles. Over the years, the managers of the Metropolitan Opera, fully appreciative of Ms. Flemings vocal artistry and star power, have been ready to accommodate her. The company has mounted house premiere productions of three strikingly diverse operas  Carlisle Floyds Susannah, Bellinis Pirata and Handels Rodelinda  specifically for Ms. Fleming.

title: The Apolitical Evangelicals

Bush is no longer president, but anyone who remembers those wearying debates will find Mark Chaves analysis of political activism in American churches illuminating. It turns out that evangelical congregations, despite all the exertions of the Moral Majority and the Christian Coalition, tend be less politically engaged on many fronts than their mainline Protestant, black Protestant and Catholic counterparts:

title: High and Low Dining: Istanbul
Hesitation Complaints on Lexus ES in U.S., Too
description: As reported earlier, internal Toyota Canada documents released as part of a Canadian lawsuit indicated that many 2004 Lexus ES 330 models experienced a problem that was the mirror image of the automakers current acceleration issues. Rather than accelerate out of control, these Lexus sedans hesitated or slowed.

title: HBO Orders Second Geaux-Round for New Orleans Series Treme
description: Dont play any blues for Treme, HBOs much promoted (if not easily pronounced) series about life and music in post-Katrina New Orleans. On Tuesday, just two days after the shows premiere, the cable channel announced that it had ordered a second season. The series mixes actors like Steve Zahn, Wendell Pierce and Clarke Peters with real-life musicians like Elvis Costello and Allen Toussaint; the pedigree of David Simon, who created Treme with Eric Overmyer, and who also produced The Wire and The Corner for HBO, probably didnt hurt, either.

title: Super Modeling | T by Greg Lynn
description: Voluptuousness may be back in fashion for the fall, but as usual, the architectural designer Greg Lynn is ahead of the curve. With everything that I design, from a church to a plate to skyscraper to a spoon, he says, I am always thinking about voluptuous volumes and spaces. Add to that list Lynns soft-serve riff on the T logo, which he created for the spring design issue. Its as intriguing coming as it is going. Lynn was inspired by the Ts combination of hard lines and curvilinear flourishes and scrolls. This is something I have a great affinity for, he says. The combination of the hard-edged and the curvaceous. View interactive >>

title: Opening Day Homecoming for Matsui
description: The old place is just a shell now, on its way down. The new place is acquiring its own character, its own history. Yankee Stadium never lacks for great moments.

title: The Jingle of Change in Europe
description: IF youve searched for a flight to Europe this summer and gasped at all the four-digit fares on your screen, there is some good news to report: the favorable exchange rate should help you save money once you land.

title: Cuomo Ally to Lead States Democrats
description: It is Andrew M. Cuomos state Democratic Party, now more than ever.

title: Different Angles on the Portrait
description: While putting together the catalog that accompanies his current show at Team Gallery, Ryan McGinley asked another photographer, Catherine Opie, if she would interview him. In some ways it was a strange choice. Ms. Opie, 49, is best known for studio portraits that are as static and deliberate as the 32-year-old Mr. McGinleys photographs are hyperkinetic. And while both artists explore queer identity, theyre separated by gender, geography and nearly a generation.

title: Series Rings, and Familiar Ring, at Stadium
description: The final game at Yankee Stadium last season ended with Mariano Rivera saving a victory for Andy Pettitte. The Yankees returned on Tuesday to collect their championship rings, and three hours later Rivera secured another win for Pettitte. The Yankees are trying to move past their accomplishments from 2009, but days like this recall the glory they hope to sustain.

title: Calling All Carnivores in Portland, Ore.
description: Olympic Provisions, a new restaurant in Portland, Ore., may occupy a restored cereal mill inand industrial neighborhood in the citys southeast. But its meat-heavy menu reminds you more of a slaughterhouse.

title: The Pulitzers in Drama: Expecting the Expected
description: Ive never put much stock in artistic prizes. I enjoy the Academy Awards for much the same reason I imagine most of you do: being able to make fun of the tedium, the clothes and the fatuity the day after the presentation. (Of course, Hollywood on Oscar night has become so circumspect and airbrushed in recent years that those pleasures aint what they used to be.) But its become a self-evident truth that the correlation between Oscars and actual merit is arbitrary at best. And dont get me started on the Tonys.

title: For Tech Bidders, Data Recovery Seems Alluring
description: The data recovery industry received a bit of a jolt this week when Double-Take Software disclosed that an unidentified bidder had made an unsolicited offer to buy it for a premium price. Double-Takes stock jumped about 20 percent on Monday on anticipation that a larger company was eager to acquire Double-Takes technology to add data recovery to its list of services.

title: More Changes for David Bouley
description: David Bouley is shrinking his holdings. On April 14, he will close Bouley Bakery and Market on the corner of Duane Street and West Broadway and he has canceled his plans for a commissary and market in SoHo.

title: Banks Making Big Profits From Tiny Loans
description: In recent years, the idea of giving small loans to poor people became the darling of the development world, hailed as the long elusive formula to propel even the most destitute into better lives.

title: A Fiery Scholar on the Trail of Genocide and Its Causes
description: Daniel Jonah Goldhagen, the controversial scholar who has specialized in the study of mass murder in books like Hitlers Willing Executioners and A Moral Reckoning, has a reputation for combativeness. Worse Than War, Wednesday night on PBS, wont change that.

title: Segal Awards Are Given
description: This years winners of the Martin E. Segal Award, the baritone Quinn Kelsey and the dancer Daniel Ulbricht (above, with Misa Kuranaga) received their prizes on Tuesday  $7,500 each to be used for career advancement and study. The chairman of Lincoln Center, Frank A. Bennack, and its president, Reynold Levy, presided over the event. The awards namesake, Martin E. Segal, also participated. Nominations are submitted by two of Lincoln Centers 12 resident arts constituents on a rotating basis. This years winners were chosen by New York City Opera and New York City Ballet. The awards were established by the board of Lincoln Center and by a group of Mr. Segals friends and colleagues when he retired as Lincoln Center chairman in 1986.

title: 92nd Street Y Announces Season
description: The 92nd Street Y plans to focus largely, but not exclusively, on thematic programming in its 2010-11 season. Among the highlights is a Schubert series by the Takacs Quartet (Oct. 16, Feb. 26, April 9), with a new work by Daniel Kellogg, based on Schuberts Death and the Maiden Quartet, on the first program.
