The Chamber Music at the Y series, with the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio and guests, celebrates Schumanns bicentenary with programs devoted to music of Robert and Clara Schumann, Brahms and Chopin (Oct. 27 and 28, Dec. 15 and 16, April 6 and 7). The pianist and lecturer Charles Rosen will give a talk on Chopins final year (Nov. 14) and play an all-Chopin recital with the cellist Fred Sherry (Nov. 20). The pianist Leon Fleisher, above, is the focus of three evenings: a recital on Nov. 13, a chamber concert on Dec. 11 and an onstage interview with a showing of the film Two Hands: The Leon Fleisher Story, on Dec. 12.

title: Smithsonian Names Director of Education
description: The Smithsonian Institution has named Claudine Brown as its first director of education. Ms. Brown, 60, who has been the director of the arts and culture program at the Nathan Cummings Foundation, will oversee the National Science Resources Center and the Smithsonian Center for Education and Museum Studies, and coordinate education offices in all Smithsonian museums and science centers. Before joining the Cummings Foundation, Ms. Brown worked for the Smithsonian to develop plans for the National Museum of African American History and Culture, which is to open in 2015. In an interview, Ms. Brown said she was interested in exploring how to use technology, including video games and hand-held devices, to engage young people. We want to be pretty aggressive about reaching young people where they are, she said. In the K-through-12 audience, a lot of learning is being done online, outside of the school environment.

title: N.E.A. Chairman Testifies on Capitol Hill
description: Rocco Landesman, left, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, delivered his first budget testimony before a House subcommittee on Tuesday, arguing for the arts as a source of jobs and an economic stimulus. The Obama administration has requested a $161.3 million budget for the endowment for fiscal year 2011, the same as its request for 2010, but less than the $167.5 million budget that Congress ultimately passed. Mr. Landesman has put his stamp on the budget, cutting a program known as American Masterpieces (though sparing one of its most popular components, the Big Read) and devoting $5 million to a pilot program, Our Town, that will support the creation of local arts districts. When Representative Mike Simpson of Idaho, the ranking Republican on the subcommittee, asked what he would do if Congress gave him $180 million, Mr. Landesman replied that Our Town could be expanded to reach more than the 35 communities currently planned. The chairman of the subcommittee, Jim Moran, Democrat of Virginia, who was in a jocular mood, congratulated Mr. Landesman several times on having hit the trifecta at the Kentucky Derby in 2001. (Ive been married three times, Mr. Moran said, but it was hardly the trifecta.)

title: Interviews With Jacqueline Kennedy to Be Published
description: Nearly seven hours of unreleased interviews with Jacqueline Kennedy, recorded just months after the death of President John F. Kennedy and intended for deposit in a future presidential library, will be released as a book, the publisher Hyperion said on Tuesday. The original interviews with Mrs. Kennedy took place in the spring of 1964 with the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. as part of an oral history project intended to preserve memories of Kennedy and his administration. In the seven interviews, Hyperion said, Mrs. Kennedy discusses various subjects including her husbands election campaigns; his handling of challenges like the Cuban missile crisis; her role as a wife, mother and first lady; and what her husband would have done in a second term as president. The book, still untitled, is planned for release in September 2011 to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Kennedy presidency, and is being edited by the Kennedys daughter, Caroline. In a statement, Caroline Kennedy said: My mothers passion for history guided and informed her work in the White House. She believed in my father, his vision for America, and in the art of politics. She felt it was important to share her knowledge and excitement with future generations.

title: Dancing Soars
description: For the second consecutive week, the figure skater Evan Lysacek topped the leader board on Dancing With the Stars, and the reality competition won the night with 20.3 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. ABC won the night as well, as its crime series Castle (13.2 million) outperformed CSI: Miami (10.8 million) on CBS and Law & Order (4.1 million) on NBC. CBS was runner-up with its comedies, including How I Met Your Mother (6.9 million), Rules of Engagement (7.4 million), Two and a Half Men (13.5 million) and The Big Bang Theory (13.1 million). Fox placed third with an episode of House (10.5 million), directed by that seriess star, Hugh Laurie, and the winding-down 24 (8.3 million). NBC finished a distant fourth.

title: Museums Join Program
description: Dozens of North American art museums will offer free or discounted admission, store discounts and special programming on May 18, for the first time collectively joining other institutions around the world in International Museum Day. The annual event, which began in 1977, has been widely celebrated in Europe and elsewhere, but participation among art museums in the United States has traditionally been low. The Association of Art Museum Directors, which represents 193 museum leaders in the United States, Canada and Mexico and has organized the participation of its members this year, said that as many as 75 institutions would participate (though some, because of their schedules, will celebrate the day on alternate dates). Among the museums joining are the Art Institute of Chicago, the Cleveland Museum of Art, the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the National Gallery of Canada.

title: From Laundry to a Home in Berlin
description: Stephan Landwehr lives in a two-story, 2,695-square-foot building that had been used as a laundry for almost 100 years.

title: One Reason U.S. Health Care Costs So Much
description: At a recent conference, David Cutler, a Harvard economics professor and health care adviser to Barack Obamas presidential campaign, presented a version of the following chart:

title: Milan Report | On the Design Trail
description: First stop this morning: B&B Italia on Via Durini, where Patricia Urquiolas Bend sofa represented the high-end companys first foray into more affordable furniture. Also at B&B, Naoto Fukasawas Grande Papilio wing chair now comes in a more human-, and more New York-apartment-scaled Piccolo version.

title: Rebuilding a Town, One Piece at a Time
description: PERRY, Iowa  Just days after the last of the winter snow melted here last month, workers descended on the corner of Second Street and Otley Avenue. In a matter of weeks, they had finished installing water, electric and sewer lines for the Perry Career Academy, a campus of Des Moines Area Community College that will train 450 adults and high school students in the vocational arts.

title: The 3% Drag on a Nascent Recovery
description: With some indicators pointing to a slight rebound in the moribund commercial real estate market in New York City, transfer taxes have emerged as a threat to the few deals now in the works.

title: In Berlin, a Life Worth Framing
description: BERLIN  For years Stephan Landwehr, owner of the Berlin framing company, Bilderrahmen Landwehr, popular with galleries and artists in Berlin, would drop off his shirts at the dry cleaners across from his framing studio in Kreuzberg, a central neighborhood in Berlin.

title: Some Respite for Greece in Successful Debt Sale
description: Investors enthusiastically snapped up Greek short-term securities on Tuesday after European Union leaders pledged to stand behind the countrys debt.

title: Apple Lets Opera Browser Use Own Software on iPhone
description: The Norwegian company that makes the Opera Internet browser said on Tuesday that its software had been approved for use on the iPhone, making it the first browser that competes with Apples own software to gain full access to the device.

title: Pregnant and Despondent
description: We have discussed postpartum depression here often on Motherlode, but the subject of depression during pregnancy comes up less frequently. I received an e-mail from a reader who is grappling with the problem  her daughter is pregnant and despondent. They are speaking with medical experts but the grandma-to-be is hoping that readers might have some advice. Have you struggled with depression during pregnancy? Has someone you loved? What might this reader do to help her daughter?

title: If Your Name Is Powell, Take a Number
description: Here are some things you may not know about Adam Clayton Powell IV. He has considerable expertise in metallurgy and thin films. He has written widely on polymer membranes, solder wetting and electron beam melting.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs Possibilities
description: Hows this for a fantastic finish? As of Tuesday morning, only five N.B.A. teams had locked in their seeding for the playoffs, leaving most of the postseason bracket in flux. It will be settled over the next two nights. There is much at stake:

title: A Canal Home in Bruges,  Belgium
description: A two-bedroom duplex apartment in central Bruges is on the market for 625,000 euros ($850,500).

title: House Hunting in ... Belgium
description: A TWO-BEDROOM DUPLEX APARTMENT IN CENTRAL BRUGES

title: An Insurers New Approach to Diabetes
description: This could be one glimpse of the future of health insurance.

title: Dining Calendar
description: A Restaurant Collection

title: New Rings for the Yankees
description: The Yankees were given their 2009 World Series rings before their home opener at Yankee Stadium.

title: Michael Moss on Food Safety (Round One)
description: Michael Moss responds to the first batch of readers questions.

title: The Makeover of the Delicatessen
description: New delis are going above and beyond the traditional Jewish model, bringing a high set of culinary standards to once-plebeian food.

title: Next to Normal and the Voters
description: Several Pulitzer Prize board members went to see the Broadway musical Next to Normal last Thursday, the night before the board made its surprise vote to award this years drama Pulitzer to that musical, according to two people with firsthand knowledge of the deliberations. They requested anonymity because they said they were not authorized to discuss Pulitzer decisions.

title: Apple Refreshes MacBooks
description: Hard on the heels of iPad-mania and a new update for the iPhone operating system, Apple continues to ride the product wave this month (and its only half gone) with the introduction of upgraded MacBook Pro notebook computers that the company says will run at faster speeds and with longer battery lives.

title: A Diplomatic Dance
description: A time-lapse of images of President Obama's many greetings before a dinner at the 47-nation nuclear security conference in Washington.

title: Properties for $250,000
description: A cottage in Bradenton, Florida, a carriage house in Columbus, Ohio, and a historic home in Keokuk, Iowa.

title: Riddle? Yes. Enigma? Sure. Documentary?
description: Is there an art-world equivalent of crying wolf? If so, Banksy has probably done it.

title: What You Get for ... $250,000
description: BRADENTON, FLORIDA

title: Should the U.S. Burn or Bury Its Trash?
description: Updated, April 14, 3:30 p.m. |  Neil Seldman of the Institute for Local Self-Reliance joins the discussion.

title: OBrien, Unbound, Hits the Road
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Conan OBrien thrilled a sell-out crowd of frenzied fans here Monday night, putting on a two-hour, high-energy show that touched on his widely publicized and contentious departure from NBC, but at the same time reached back to many of his best-loved moments from his days at that network.

title: Tracing Muriel Sparks Road From Slender Means to Her Own Prime
description: In a perfect world, a biography of Muriel Spark (1918-2006) would share some of the qualities of her best novels, among them Memento Mori, The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie and The Girls of Slender Means. That is, it would be sinister, comic and ruthlessly slim, a jar that holds a scorpion.

title: British Politicians Confront YouTube, Warily
description: Despite the British Parliamentary tradition of freewheeling political debate, expectations are low for a series of televised debates among the leaders of Britains three major parties that begins on Thursday, three weeks before election day. As Britains Channel 4 News explains, it seems a fear of gaffes has led the parties to insist on such a long list of rules for the encounters that they are likely to be far less dramatic than the Question Time sessions that British prime ministers have to endure on a regular basis.

title: Muriel Spark
description: Chapter 1: Night and Day1962  1918

title: McDonalds Board Rejects Move Toward Cage-Free Eggs
description: The board of directors of McDonalds has recommended that the companys shareholders vote against a proposal to require that 5 percent of the eggs purchased for the chains restaurants in the United States be the cage-free variety, the Green, Inc., blog reports.

title: Schumer Sees Move to Raise Taxes at Buyout Firms
description: The Senate is for the first time considering adopting a House proposal that would more than double the tax rates on executives at private equity firms, Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, has told Bloomberg News.

title: Fassbinders Vibrating Sci-Fi Questions About Reality
description: What if everything we think is real is just an illusion? This is not a new question  at least one character in Rainer Werner Fassbinders World on a Wire traces it back to Plato  and the version of it that this curious film presents will certainly be familiar to fans of The Matrix.

title: Denim for a City That Takes a Tough Hide
description: AS the water line crept higher and higher in the bathtub, it was hard not to think I had been hornswoggled.

title: N.C.A.A. Council Approves Testing for Sickle-Cell Trait
description: Members of the N.C.A.A.s Division I Legislative Council have approved a measure that requires all athletes to be screened for the sickle-cell trait unless they can show results of a previous test or they sign a release to decline testing.

title: A Fight Against Bigotry and Violence, Lasting 45 Years and 8  Hours
description: When documenting racist atrocities, one proven tactic is to go long, matching the gravity of your subject with sheer duration. Joining Shoah (about 9 hours) and Eyes on the Prize (14 hours) in this category is Have You Heard From Johannesburg, Connie Fields seven-film, eight-and-a-half-hour documentary series about apartheid.

title: Lexus Stops Selling S.U.V. That Was Called Unsafe
description: Toyota quickly suspended sales of its 2010 Lexus GX 460 sport utility vehicle on Tuesday after Consumer Reports magazine warned buyers that the model had a dangerous handling problem that could lead to a rollover and possibly serious injury or death.

title: Laboratory Life
description: Heres a problem: evolution never stops.

title: Dear Professor Krugman
description: Dear Professor Krugman,

title: A Man of Pinter ... Sings in a Wig
description: AT a rehearsal of the Broadway musical La Cage aux Folles this month the British actor Douglas Hodge paused during the number The Best of Times to hash out a detail with the director, Terry Johnson. Mr. Hodge asked if he could improvise where to sit on the lip of the stage as he banters with the audience midway through the song. There will be people who are too embarrassed to talk back to me, Mr. Hodge explained. Mr. Johnson said he trusted the actor to choose his spot; nodding, Mr. Hodge began silently conversing with invisible theatergoers, feigning delight at their imagined responses.

title: Ahmadinejad Asks U.N. to Investigate 9/11
description: Updated | Wednesday | 10:24 a.m. Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, who said last month that the terrorist attacks in the United States on Sept. 11, 2001, were a big fabrication, wrote to the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, on Tuesday to ask him to open an investigation into the events of that day.

title: Cilantro Haters, Its Not Your Fault
description: FOOD partisanship doesnt usually reach the same heights of animosity as the political variety, except in the case of the anti-cilantro party. The green parts of the plant that gives us coriander seeds seem to inspire a primal revulsion among an outspoken minority of eaters.

title: Spcialits de la Maison, a Vintage Celebrity Cookbook, Gets a New Life
description: Turn back the calendar to the days of the Colony  creamed vegetables, sherry in sauces and patrons like Mrs. Charles H. Marshall, before she became Brooke Astor (below, top left)  and you have the era reflected in Spcialits de la Maison (Collins Design, $19.99), first published in 1940 to support the American Friends of France, a war-relief organization. It has been reprinted, thanks to the efforts of Christine Schwartz Hartley, who found a copy in a used-book store.

title: Breezy Hill Orchard Joins Essex Street Market
description: The Lower East Side Girls Club has sold brownies, cookies and cupcakes at a booth in the Essex Street Market for some time. Now the display also includes apples, cider, fruit pies, fresh pasta, eggs and tamales, from a new partner, Breezy Hill Orchard in the Hudson Valley. The stand is called Fresco del Rancho (fresh from the farm). Elizabeth Ryan (above), the owner of Breezy Hill and a founding board member of the club, will also sell produce from other upstate farms. The girls club benefits from the sale of its own baked goods.

title: St. Anselm in Brooklyn Serves Up Organs and Bones
description: The idea for St. Anselm was a glorified hot dog stand, but the brick-walled space that Joe (above right) and Kim Carroll leased in Brooklyn next to their bar, Spuyten Duyvil, was too capacious, so theyve stretched the menu to fill it.

title: Nello
description: NELLO BALAN was standing on Madison Avenue in front of his restaurant, smoking a cigar. It was after 10 on a Tuesday night, and the dining room was empty save for a table of four people finishing a collection of wan Italian food that, with a few glasses of wine, would cost them $593.37 before tip.

title: Off the Menu
description: Chefs on the Move

title: Sarah Ruhls Sunday School Lessons
description: TWO years ago, at the urging of its pastor, David Dyson, Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church welcomed a resident theater company into the largely unused interior of what was once its Sunday school. Named the Irondale Center after its new tenant, the Irondale Ensemble Project, the soaring space now serves as a home to a wide array of performances and community events in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: Print
description: In the Ink48 Hotel, 653 11th Avenue (48th Street), Clinton; (212) 757-2224.

title: Bistro Vendme
description: 405 East 58th Street (First Avenue), Upper East Side, (212) 935-9100, bistrovendomenyc.com

title: Can the Jewish Deli Be Reformed?
description: WHEN a Jewish deli decides to stop serving salami, something is wrong in the cosmos.

title: Minting Bank Lobbyists on Capitol Hill
description: Representative Barney Frank publicly rebuked a former aide this month for taking a job with a big Wall Street firm right after drafting a regulation that could affect the way the firm did business. Mr. Frank described it as an unusual transgression, one that embarrassed others working on the legislation and created at least the appearance of a conflict of interest.

title: A Spanish Vermouth Makes a Splash Overseas
description: Lately, some unfamiliar European vermouths have been making their way to American bars, notably Dolin, which came over from France last year, and now, from Spain, Vermouth Perucchi, made in Catalonia since 1886 but available in the United States for less than a year.

title: Nebraska Law Sets Limits on Abortion
description: Gov. Dave Heineman of Nebraska signed a law on Tuesday banning most abortions 20 weeks after conception or later on the theory that a fetus, by that stage in pregnancy, has the capacity to feel pain. The law, which appears nearly certain to set off legal and scientific debates, is the first in the nation to restrict abortions on the basis of fetal pain.

title: Why So Glum, Indeed
description: Much of the commentary on last Fridays column has focused on the headline  which began, Why So Glum?  rather than on the column itself. Some readers, and some people who actually get paid to comment, seem to think that any sign of pessimism out there provides evidence that there is good reason to be glum.

title: Nello: In the Club
Airstrike by Pakistanis Against Militants in Border Area Is Reported to Kill Civilians
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  An airstrike by Pakistans military killed as many as 75 civilians in northwestern Pakistan over the weekend, according to a government official and villagers from the area. A military official confirmed some civilian deaths, but said the toll had been far lower.

title: Obama Goes Dancing With the Heads of State
description: Updated, Wednesday, 3:50 p.m. | In a time-lapse of 1,338 images, the photographer Luke Sharrett of The New York Times captured President Obamas many greetings before a dinner at the 47-nation nuclear security conference in Washington on Monday night.

title: Bill Clinton to Speak on 1995 Bombing
description: Former President Bill Clinton will give the keynote speech Friday at a symposium marking the 15th anniversary of the Oklahoma City bombing, a tragedy drawing renewed attention in light of increasing concern about the tone of todays political dialogue.

title: With Time Running Out, Swingman Plays for His Future
description: The twin scars running parallel on Bill Walkers knees represent what could have been. More important, they stand for what is.

title: Hospital Infection Problem Persists
description: The nagging and largely solvable problem of hospital-acquired infections remains as resistant to cure as the germs that contribute to an estimated 100,000 deaths a year, according to an annual government study issued Tuesday.

title: Yes, 47% of Households Owe No Taxes. Look Closer.
description: Forty-seven percent.

title: Designer, 26, Found Dead in Apartment in Manhattan
description: Alejandro Bulaevsky was an accomplished lighting designer whose paths around the nation and world were well chronicled. On Tuesday, the New York police spent the day trying to learn how Mr. Bulaevsky, 26, ended up dead on the floor of his Lower Manhattan apartment  his body wrapped in a latex suit, his hands cuffed behind his back, his face covered by a gas mask.

title: Stephen Curry or Tyreke Evans? Dont Ask Dell Curry
description: A fantastic rookie of the year race between Stephen Curry and Tyreke Evans could come down to a single vote. Could the deciding ballot be cast by Currys father?

title: Revising the New York City Charter
description: To the Editor:

title: What Were Reading: Cellphone Wars
description: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times recommend articles on the cellphone wars and how Twitter may be eating its own dog food. And just for fun: another robot video and a way to create a parody of the Google search ads.

title: Report: For Palin Speeches, Luxury Rooms and Bendable Straws
description: Sarah Palin apparently has some pretty specific requirements when she agrees to give a speech.

title: Love the Telenovela, Buy the Product
description: FOR decades, the logo As seen on TV has appeared in advertising to indicate that the product in question is promoted in television commercials. Now the logo is taking on another meaning: the product may be incorporated into the plot line of a show.

title: A Less Imperious U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Mideast Land Conflict Now Includes Street Signs
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  A city project marking every street name and house number in this temporary Palestinian capital has stirred an international dispute and exposed yet again how the Israelis and Palestinians live in sealed narrative bubbles and seem almost incapable of hearing one another.

title: The Price for Building a Home in This Town: $300,000 Water Meter
description: BOLINAS, Calif.  Marc Dwaileebe would like to build a house for his family on land he owns in this bucolic town just 20 miles north of San Francisco. But he cannot hook up to the water main that runs right past his property unless he has a water meter. And a water meter, in Bolinas, could cost more than $300,000.

title: Dodgers Promising Despite Distraction
description: LOS ANGELES  During the winter, the Los Angeles Dodgers gave a facelift to their cramped, nearly 50-year-old clubhouse, installing brighter lights, posting quotations and photographs of famous Dodgers and putting up cubbyholes above the players lockers that appeared to be straight out of an Ikea catalog.

title: British Election Issues: Frugality and Afghanistan
description: LONDON  Has a penny pinching approach to defense spending by Prime Minister Gordon Brown kept British troops in Afghanistan disastrously short of the helicopters and other equipment their commanders have long demanded, causing unnecessarily heavy combat losses to the Talibans most devastating weapon, roadside bombs?

title: The Loss in the Closing of St. Vincents Hospital
description: To the Editor:

title: Polands Unity Is Disrupted by Plans for Presidents Interment
description: KRAKOW, Poland  Public discontent has begun to emerge in the grievous aftermath of the plane crash that claimed the lives of Polands president and dozens of top politicians and military leaders, as people here protest the decision to inter the president and his wife in a crypt holding the remains of many Polish kings.

title: Roethlisberger Is Facing Fallout for His Behavior
description: The fallout has begun for Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, who met with Commissioner Roger Goodell for two hours Tuesday regarding his involvement last month with a 20-year-old college student in a Georgia bar.

title: W.W.E.s Smackdown Is Moving to Cable TV
description: World Wrestling Entertainment is moving one of its weekly TV shows to cable from broadcast.

title: When an Adoption Goes Awry
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Devils and Brodeur, Another Shot
description: NEWARK  A bad memory in Martin Brodeurs world lasts about as long as a fresh sheet of ice. The Devils have lost in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs the last two years  last year in about the worst way imaginable  and now face a team that has their number.

title: Two Torahs, Two Holocaust Stories and One Big Question
description: One Torah, said to have been in Auschwitz, has been in the ark at one of New Yorks most prominent synagogues since 2008. A second Torah joined it on Monday night, as the synagogue, Central Synagogue in Manhattan, observed Holocaust Remembrance Week.

title: Who Doesnt Pay Taxes?
description: What percentage of Americans pays no federal taxes?

title: Confidence Anchors Twins Amid Change
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Two quotations are inscribed above the main doors of the Minnesota Twins locker room at its new home, Target Field. One is from Kirby Puckett, a Hall of Fame outfielder, who said: Live for today. Tomorrow isnt promised to anyone.

title: Taxing the Rich, Over Time
description: My column this week notes that tax rates on the affluent have fallen more in recent decades than tax rates on other groups. Here are the details:

title: Bill Would Require Derivatives Trading to Occur on Exchanges
description: WASHINGTON  The Democratic chairwoman of the Senate Agriculture Committee said on Tuesday that she would propose legislation requiring nearly all users of derivative contracts to trade on centralized exchanges and possibly ordering banks to segregate their business in derivatives into separate subsidiaries.

title: Deadly Scene at Angels Hotel
description: The Anaheim Angels knew something was amiss when they were about to board their team bus Tuesday morning to take them to Yankee Stadium. The street in front of their hotel, the Le Parker Meridien on West 56th Steet,was closed. The bus had to be rerouted.

title: Plan Would Require Homeless to Work to Qualify for Rent Subsidies
description: The Bloomberg administration is planning to require more homeless families to get jobs in order to qualify for rent subsidies, city officials said Tuesday.

title: For Now, the Coyotes Know Where They Are
description: After an N.H.L. season dominated by the Olympics and by a debate over head injuries, the playoffs are here, as usual, to supersede any off-ice issues. Except that this spring, one of the eight opening-round matchups stands out for its behind-the-scenes questions as well as for what it offers in the rink.

title: Mine Effort Turns Next to Inquiries
description: Recovery workers finished the bleak job of removing bodies from a West Virginia coal mine early Tuesday, but federal and state officials said it might be two weeks before investigators enter the Upper Big Branch mine, where 29 people were killed in an explosion last week.

title: Local TV Stations in Venture for Mobile Programming
description: Determined not to get left behind as television migrates to mobile devices, a formidable group of local television stations is forming a joint venture for what it calls a national mobile content service.

title: Chipping Away at the Corporate Debt Wall
description: A looming wall of debt can be a scary thing. Nearly $830 billion of risky dollar-denominated corporate debt comes due from 2012 to 2014, according to JPMorgan Chase.

title: Time to Stop Giving Free Pass to Roethlisberger
description: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell summoned Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger to league headquarters on Tuesday, and the question is: what took so long?

title: Critics May Rant, but Addams Family Rakes It In
description: The new Broadway musical The Addams Family opened Thursday to the sort of scathing reviews that would bury most shows in the graveyard next to the Addamses forbidding mansion.

title: For Students, a Waiting List Is Scant Hope
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Ashley Koski, ranked third in the senior class at Thomas Dale High School in Chester, Va., has wanted to attend Duke University since she was 12.

title: Visas and Censorship
description: Claiming that it was part of the fight against terrorism, the George W. Bush administration revived the loathsome cold war practice of denying visas to foreign intellectuals, artists and others because of their views.

title: Advice From the Keeper of a Long Waiting List
description: For many college admissions officers  to say nothing of the high school seniors pursuing them  this has been the season of the waiting list. M.I.T., Dartmouth and Yale are among the institutions that have offered more applicants spots on their waiting lists this spring, as a means of making sure the colleges have deep benches from which to draw the final members of the incoming freshman classes, if needed.

title: Requiem for a Nice Person
At the End, Tortorella Has Plenty to Criticize
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  While Rangers Coach John Tortorella acknowledged the ton of mistakes he made during the season, he also criticized some of his players, notably Marian Gaborik, and raised questions about the teams lack of character two days after the Rangers season ended in a shootout loss in Philadelphia.

title: They Should Know Better
description: We were disturbed to learn that health care workers shunned the swine flu vaccine in droves. Their training and skills will be essential if there is a dangerous flu outbreak. They, of all people, should know how important it is for them to get vaccinated  and that the risk of serious side effects is negligible.

title: The Price of Assassination
description: I wouldnt have believed you if youd told me 20 years ago that America would someday be routinely firing missiles into countries its not at war with. For that matter, I wouldnt have believed you if youd told me a few months ago that America would soon be plotting the assassination of an American citizen who lives abroad.

title: Lessons From the Big Branch Tragedy
description: It is still not known what set off the West Virginia mine explosion that killed 29 workers  the nations worst mining disaster in four decades. What is clear is that federal oversight of the industry must be greatly strengthened.

title: One Last Place to Get Fleeced on a Mortgage
description: One day last year, many people in trouble with mortgages got e-mail messages announcing that Sal Pane Jr., acclaimed expert on their exact problems, would be appearing on the CBS Evening News.

title: Obama Puts His Own Mark on Foreign Policy Issues
description: WASHINGTON  When he took office last year, President Obama told his foreign policy advisers that he had two baskets of issues to deal with. The first would be the legacy issues left from his predecessor, like Iraq, Afghanistan and Americas image in the world. The second would be his own agenda for the future.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 13, 2010

title: Obama Goes Dancing With the Heads of State
description: Over at the Lens blog, the photographer Luke Sharrett of The Times captured President Obamas many greetings before a dinner at the 47-nation nuclear security conference in Washington on Monday night in a time-lapse of 1,338 images. Go to Lens

title: Mr. Obama and Mr. Hu
description: We think President Obama made the right decision  for now  not to pick too public of a fight with China over its currency manipulation.

title: Iraqs Forces Prove Able, but Loyalty Is Uncertain
description: CAMP HABBANIYA, Iraq  Iraqs security forces, once mocked for deserting firefights and feared as a sanctuary for rogue death squads, crossed a crucial line of competence during the recent parliamentary elections: With little American help, they kept the nation overwhelmingly safe for voting.

title: Jury to Begin Deliberating in L.I. Hate Crime Case
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  The jury in the murder trial of a Long Island teenager accused of stabbing a Hispanic immigrant in 2008 will begin deliberations Wednesday morning, after listening on Tuesday to a prosecutors nearly two-hour rebuttal to the teenagers own testimony that he was innocent of the hate crime.

title: 2-Year-Old Boy Left on School Bus for Two Hours
description: A 2-year-old Brooklyn boy was left on a school bus for two hours on Tuesday after the driver and the bus matron forgot to drop him off at day care, then went to their homes for a break, the police said.

title: Its a Relief in Athens
description: I never saw a flying camel,I never hope to see one

title: At Yurcak Field, in the Same Place at a Different Time
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Womens Professional Soccer in the leagues first season. Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, will be filing to the Goal blog during the defending champions 2010 season.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies on Tuesday about Chinas position on possible sanctions against Iran if it does not curb its nuclear program overstated a promise that President Hu Jintao of China made to President Obama in a meeting in Washington on Monday. As the article noted, Mr. Hu said that his country would join negotiations over the sanctions. He did not say that China supports such sanctions.

title: Couple Move Toward Lawsuit Over Episode in Police Station
description: A retired police officer and his wife who were involved in an altercation inside a police station in Harlem last month after their 13-year-old son was detained for disorderly conduct have taken the first steps toward filing a lawsuit against the city and the Police Department.

title: No Matter Coast or Cost, Hairston Wasnt Going to Miss Ceremony
description: Hideki Matsui was not the only former Yankee at the Stadium on Tuesday collecting his World Series championship ring. Jerry Hairston Jr., who now plays for the San Diego Padres, surprised his old teammates by taking a red-eye flight after his game Monday in San Diego to join in the ceremony.

title: Top Sixth Man: Instant Offense or Well-Rounded Game?
description: Ballots are due this week for the N.B.A.s postseason awards. Although The New York Times does not permit its reporters to vote, the N.B.A. reporters Howard Beck and Jonathan Abrams are making their picks in Off the Dribble. Todays debate is about the Sixth Man Award.

title: Our Fill-in-the-Blank Constitution
description: Chicago

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Lehman Brothers relationship with a smaller company, Hudson Castle, referred incorrectly to the status of a California property developer, SunCal, which had joint investments with Lehman. SunCals and Lehmans investments collapsed; SunCal itself did not.

title: After Another Dismal Loss, Its Getting Late Early for Mets and Manuel
description: DENVER  A strong start to the season was considered vital for the Mets, particularly Manager Jerry Manuel, but any hope of that happening is quickly slipping away.

title: Maternal Deaths Decline Sharply Across the Globe
description: For the first time in decades, researchers are reporting a significant drop worldwide in the number of women dying each year from pregnancy and childbirth, to about 342,900 in 2008 from 526,300 in 1980.

title: Corrections
description: The Osthammar Journal article on April 6, about efforts by the town of Osthammar, Sweden, to win a competition to host a permanent storage site for the countrys nuclear power plant waste, which proponents say would create jobs and keep townspeople from leaving, misstated Swedens unemployment rate. It is 9.1 percent, not around 2 percent.

title: Attention: Baby on Board
description: There are many differences between Iraq and Afghanistan, but they do resemble each other in one critical way. In both countries, the bad guys, the violent jihadists, are losing. And in both countries, it still is not clear if the good guys will really turn out to be good.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column on Wednesday about the fiscal crisis in Los Angeles, using information from the mayors office, referred incorrectly to the Fitch Ratings for bonds issued by the citys Department of Water and Power. The ratings have remained unchanged; they were not downgraded recently.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Twitters plan to make money from advertising omitted the name of one of its co-founders. In addition to Evan Williams and Biz Stone, who continue to work at the company, Jack Dorsey was a co-founder and remains as nonexecutive chairman.

title: Negotiations Seek to Avert a Strike by Doormen Next Week
description: With a strike deadline looming, contract negotiations between the owners of apartment buildings and the union that represents doormen and other workers have been complicated by very different views on whether the citys economy has turned a corner.

title: To Save Millions, M.T.A. Simply Asked Vendors for a Break
description: When officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority asked a team of consultants for tips on how to save money, the advice was simple: just ask.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about efforts by a committee of the National Bureau of Economic Research to determine the end date of the recession that began in December 2007 misstated the day of the committees meeting. It was Thursday, not Friday.

title: An Affordable Sitter in a Foreign Land
description: First, you have to believe that I love my daughter, Sasha. Shes cute, amusing and, although shes only 16 months old, a good companion at a bar. When I come home from a long trip, Sasha is the one Im most excited to see (followed immediately by my wife, Jean, of course). Feeding her, playing with her, taking care of her  this is whats important, above all.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the large turnover of Division I mens basketball coaches in the New York metropolitan area omitted one of the area teams that played in the National Invitation Tournament this year. Besides Stony Brook and Seton Hall, St. Johns played, losing to Memphis. The article and an accompanying chart also omitted one university in assessing the likelihood of coaching changes. Long Island University is one of five teams expected to keep their coaching staffs intact.

title: Georgia Insurance Commissioner Balks at Request on New Health Law
description: ATLANTA  The insurance commissioner of Georgia has chosen not to comply with a federal request to create a state pool for high-risk insurance plans, opening a new front in the resistance by state Republican officials to the new federal health care law.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Monday, about Tiger Woodss fourth-place finish at the Masters golf tournament, misstated his score on the final hole on Sunday in some copies. He had a birdie, not par.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the wider use of induction cooking referred imprecisely to regulations for venting restaurant kitchens. While in some cases, venting and fire-suppression requirements are not as extensive as they would be for kitchens with gas stoves, using an induction stove doesnt always eliminate the need for elaborate venting or fire suppression.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 31 about an Irish food writer and cooking teacher misspelled the surname of a chef who studied with the teacher, and a correction in this space last Wednesday misstated the given name of the teacher. The chef is Abra Berens, not Behrens. And as the article correctly noted, the teacher is Darina Allen, not Darian.

title: China: Leader to Visit Indonesia
description: A powerful earthquake in northwest China killed at least 67 people and left many others buried under debris early Wednesday, the official Xinhua news agency said. The quake, which struck at 7:49 a.m. in Qinghai Province, was reported as having a magnitude of 7.1 by Chinas earthquake administration. The U.S. Geological Survey recorded it as 6.9. Xinhua said the earthquake had struck 240 miles southeast of Golmud, a town of about 130,000 on the Tibetan plateau. Golmud is perhaps best known as the site of the worlds largest salt lake. Soldiers have been dispatched to save the people buried in the collapsed houses, Huang Limin, a local official, told Xinhua. He said phone service, briefly cut off by the quake, had been restored. The Geological Survey reported three aftershocks, with magnitudes of up to 5.8. Last August, Golmud was hit by a 6.2 magnitude earthquake that destroyed dozens of homes but caused no deaths. Qinghai is an ethnic melting pot of Tibetans, Mongols and Han Chinese.

title: Long Recovery for Barrier Reef
description: It could take up to 20 years for a section of the Great Barrier Reef to regrow after the damage done by a Chinese coal carrier that ran aground and leaked oil, an Australian government scientist said Tuesday. The recovery could take longer depending on the toxicity of the ships exterior paint, which is designed to prevent the growth of barnacles and other marine life. The Shen Neng 1 crashed onto a shoal near the southern end of the reef on April 3, then ground back and forth against the nearby coral until it was refloated late Monday. The scar on the reef is 1.9 miles long and up to 820 feet wide. About three tons of engine fuel were spilled.

title: The Hague: First Witness Speaks in Karadzics War Crimes Trial
description: The first witness, a man disabled from the nightly beatings by his Serbian captors, appeared at the war crimes trial of the Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic on Tuesday, but he never looked at him in the dock. The witness, Ahmet Zulic, wearing gloves to hide his damaged hands, testified about the killings he saw after Serbs attacked non-Serbs in his ethnically mixed village in 1992. Mr. Karadzic, who acts as his own lawyer, conducted a long-winded cross-examination that was several times cut off by the bench.

title: President to Outline His Vision for NASA
description: President Obama will seek to promote his vision for the nations human space flight program on Thursday, just two days after three storied Apollo astronauts  including Neil Armstrong, the first human to walk on the Moon  called the new plans devastating.

title: Middlebury to Develop Online Language Venture
description: Middlebury College, a small Vermont college known for its rigorous foreign-language programs, is forming a venture with a commercial entity to develop online language programs for pre-college students. The college plans to invest $4 million for a 40 percent stake in what will become Middlebury Interactive Languages.

title: Banks Resist Plans to Reduce Mortgage Balances
description: In a rebuff to the Obama administration, two big banks on Tuesday drew a line in the sand on cutting the mortgage balances of beleaguered homeowners, saying that the tool would be applied sparingly.

title: 'Armida'
description: Images from Mary Zimmerman's production of Rossini's opera, starring Rene Fleming.

title: A Whisper Room of Her Own
description: Claire Daly describes her practice studio and plays Roland Kirks composition Theme For The Eulipions.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,027 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American:

title: Word of the Day | pallid
description: pallid \pa-ld\ adjective

title: Obama on Nuclear Security
description: President Obama spoke about securing nuclear weapons at a 47-nation summit.

title: Earthquake Kills Dozens in Northwest China
description: BEIJING  A powerful earthquake in northwest China killed at least 67 people and left many others buried under debris early Wednesday, the state said.

title: Nina Bourne Is Dead at 93; Catapulted Sales of Catch-22
description: Nina Bourne, a publishing executive whose unfussy advertisements, peppered with understated but punchy copy, helped propel Joseph Hellers Catch-22, Kay Thompsons Eloise books and Robert Caros Robert Moses biography The Power Broker to the top of the best-seller lists, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 93.

title: H. G. Stever, Who Advised Leaders on Science, Dies at 93
description: H. Guyford Stever, the chief science adviser to Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford, a former president of Carnegie Mellon University and the head of the committee that monitored the redesign of the space shuttles booster rockets after the Challenger disaster, died on Friday at his home in Gaithersburg, Md. He was 93.

title: Fred Ascani, Who Flew Supersonic Jets, Is Dead at 92
description: Maj. Gen. Fred Ascani, an Air Force test pilot, a record-setting air racer and the overseer of a highly publicized supersonic aircraft project of the 1960s, died March 28 at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 92.

title: Tennessee: Interview With Adoptee
description: Law enforcement authorities in Shelbyville said Tuesday that they were arranging an interview with the boy who was sent back to Russia alone by his adoptive parents. Chuck Crawford, the district attorney for Bedford County, where Torry Hansen and her mother, Nancy Hansen, were raising the boy they named Justin, said he had directed local and state police to continue investigating the Hansens for possible charges. Because the Hansens have refused to speak with the police, Mr. Crawford said, it is imperative that law enforcement be allowed to communicate with the child.

title: California: Democrats Balk Over Scouts
description: Faced with a $20 billion deficit and its own plummeting popularity, the California Legislature cannot even agree on the Boy Scouts. On Tuesday, Republicans complained after the majority-holding Democrats blocked a resolution to honor the 100th anniversary of the Boy Scouts of America, citing the groups ban on gay or atheist leaders. Assemblyman Mike Feuer, the West Hollywood Democrat who heads the Judiciary Committee, which rejected the resolution, said that while individual scouts have done some great things, the state cannot be on the record endorsing the Scouts membership policy. Republicans, who have tried to pass similar resolutions in the past, called the action extreme. The Scouts did not reply to a request for comment, thus missing a chance to earn a Party Politics merit badge.

title: News Quiz | April 14, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: A Commitment to Haiti
description: WithWHOM did the first lady meet when she made an unannounced visit to Haiti on Tuesday? WHO accompanied her? WHO served as her translator?

title: Banks Resist Plans to Reduce Mortgage Balances
description: In a rebuff to the Obama administration, two big banks on Tuesday drew a line in the sand on cutting the mortgage balances of beleaguered homeowners, saying that the tool would be applied sparingly.

title: Shinsei Bank Said to Suffer $1.1 Billion Loss
description: Shinsei Bank is likely to tumble to a net loss of about $1.1 billion for the year just ended due to bigger provisions against property loans, and the head of the struggling Japanese lender will resign, two sources with knowledge of the matter told Reuters.

title: Death Toll in China Quake Rises to 617
description: BEIJING  The death toll from the powerful earthquake that struck western China Wednesday rose to at least 617 people on Thursday, with 10,000 more injured as many remained buried under debris, Chinese state media reported.

title: Father Wont Have Say In Rookie Race
description: The rookie of the year race between Stephen Curry of the Golden State Warriors and Tyreke Evans of the Sacramento Kings could come down to a single vote, but on Tuesday, the N.B.A. pulled the ballot from Dell Curry, a Charlotte Bobcats broadcaster and Stephens father. Dell Curry should not have received a vote for rookie of the year, said Brian McIntyre, the N.B.A. senior vice president for basketball communications. We dont want to put Dell in such a position.

title: Morgan Stanley Fund Said to Risk $5.4 Billion Loss
description: Morgan Stanley has told investors that its $8.8 billion real estate fund may lose nearly two-thirds of its money due to bad investments, according to The Wall Street Journal, which reviewed fund documents.

title: Opel Behind It, Magna Itches Again for Deals
description: Magna International will tap its strong cash position to acquire companies that could support its expansion in emerging markets and key growth areas such as electric vehicle technologies, its co-chief executive said Tuesday.

title: What Would Your Favorite Fictional Character Tweet?
description: The Royal Shakespeare Company has started a project online called Such Tweet Sorrow in which actors will tweet a 21st-century update of Romeo and Juliet. (The screenshot above shows a tweet by the actress playing Juliet Capulet.) If you were to choose a fictional character, whether from literature, comics, television, the movies or elsewhere, what do you think he or she (or it) would tweet? Tell us who the character is and supply one or two typical tweets, below.

title: Macquarie Buys $2 Billion in Planes From I.L.F.C.
description: Macquarie Group, the largest investment bank in Australia, said Wednesday that it would pay $2 billion to acquire 53 airplanes from International Lease Finance Corporation, a unit of the bailed-out insurer American International Group.

title: London Real Estate Said to Boom With Tower 42 on Sale
description: Londons commercial real estate market is thriving again, and the Square Miles tallest worked-in skyscraper, Tower 42, is to be put up for sale, The Financial Times reports.

title: Some Respite for Greece in Successful Debt Sale
description: Investors enthusiastically snapped up Greek short-term securities on Tuesday after European Union leaders pledged to stand behind the countrys debt, The New York Timess Jack Ewing and David Jolly reported.

title: The Oy of Yiddish, Part 2
description: In March, co-vocabularists were invited to revel in the delights of Yiddish and pose questions to Michael Wex  author of the bestselling Born to Kvetch, and, most recently, How to Be a Mentsh and Not a Shmuck.

title: Greycroft Closes Modest $131 Million Fund
description: From Camille Ricketts at VentureBeat:

title: Bill Would Force Derivatives Trades Onto Exchanges
description: The Democratic chairwoman of the Senate Agriculture Committee said on Tuesday that she would propose legislation requiring nearly all users of derivative contracts to trade on centralized exchanges and possibly ordering banks to segregate their business in derivatives into separate subsidiaries, The New York Timess Edward Wyatt reported.

title: Robot From NASA and G.M. Heading to Space Station
description: NASA and General Motors announced on Tuesday that they planned to send a robot to the International Space Station, with the eventual goal of having it help the astronauts there.

title: Yes, Theyre Poor. But They Can Make Banks Rich.
description: In recent years, the idea of giving small loans to poor people became the darling of the development world, hailed as the long elusive formula to propel even the most destitute into better lives, The New York Timess Neil MacFarquhar writes.

title: U.S. Signals Support for New Kyrgyz Leaders
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  The Obama administration signaled its support for the new leadership of Kyrgyzstan on Wednesday, sending a senior diplomat here to meet with the head of the countrys interim government.

title: Winning Plans to Displace Disposables
description: From Lora Kolodny at Youre the Boss:

title: Palm Is Said to Discuss Sale to Huawei
description: Money-losing smartphone maker Palm tapped Huawei Technologies for preliminary acquisition talks, a move that would give the Chinese telecommunications equipment maker a foothold in the premium mobile phone market, Reuters reported.

title: A Modest Gain as Investors Digest Earnings Reports
description: Wall Street traders took in the first batch of quarterly earnings reports on Tuesday, but nobody seemed quite sure what to make of the numbers, The New York Timess Javier C. Hernandez writes.

title: Goldman Dropped Bid for Liverpool, Report Says
description: The owners of Liverpool Football Club have missed out on a major investment from a consortium including Goldman Sachs and owners of two American sports teams, The Associated Press reported, citing a person involved in the negotiations.

title: Berlin Shopping Stretch Is Reborn
description: Coming from Berlins Hackescher Markt and heading northwest, the initial stretch of Rosenthaler Strasse has been a shoppers heaven at least since the first wave of post-Communist Berlins urban renewal in the mid-1990s. But beyond the streets second block or so, the pickings got pretty thin. Empty lots alternated with gray, Communist-era housing and a few surviving old buildings to create an uneven and unappealing streetscape. That is, until recently. Just last year, several attractive, affordable hotels opened, and they have now been joined by some promising new shops.

title: N.F.L. Draft: The Fine Points of Game Film
description: Matt Waldman is a staff writer at Footballguys.com, where he pens The Weekly Gut Check and authors The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a 740-page film evaluation of 170-plus rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

title: F.D.I.C. Weighs Changes in Fees for Big Banks
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is proposing changes to the way it determines how much it charges big banks to insure their deposits, with the aim of having large, higher-risk institutions pay bigger premiums, The Associated Press reported.

title: In Europe, Pension Funds Return to Hedge Funds
description: It seems that European pension funds are once again showing hedge funds the love. While many investors, including pension funds, fled or cut back on their exposure to hedge funds during the financial crisis, this swath of institutional investors is coming back in force in Europe, HFM Week reported, citing research from the investment consultant Mercer.

title: Usmanov Not Ruling Out Arsenal Bid
description: Red & White Holdings, the investment vehicle of Uzbeki steel magnate Alisher Usmanov, has left the door open for a takeover of the English Premier League football club Arsenal, Reuters reported.

title: Chinese Dairy Backed by U.S. Banks Collapses
description: Taizinai, a Chinese maker of dairy products maker, is unable to pay its debts and will be liquidated, sources familiar with the matter said Wednesday. The companys lenders include Royal Bank of Scotland and Citibank, with Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley among its investors.

title: Volvos Chief Sees No Problems if Renault Sells Stake
description: Volvo would have no trouble relying solely on its Swedish investors if Renault decided to sell its stake in the company, the automakers chairman, Louis Schweitzer, told a Swedish newspaper on Wednesday.

title: Whats Wrong With Shyness?
description: Todays idea: Enough about you. What the self-promoting world needs now is shyness, more shyness, an essay says.

title: Big Brazilian Retail Groups to Review Deal
description: Grupo Po de Acar, Brazils largest retail group, said Tuesday that it would review the terms of its planned acquisition of a majority stake in the countrys leading appliance and furniture chain at its request, The Associated Press reported.

title: In Emirates, Builder and Fund Scrap Deal
description: A Dubai construction company that helped build the worlds tallest tower and an Abu Dhabi investment firm say they have abandoned plans for the fund to take a controlling stake in the builder, The Associated Press reported.

title: Wall Street Ramps Up Hiring as Profits Rebound
description: Wall Street is hiring again.

title: The Upside of an Impenetrable Tax Code
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Katie Crouch
description: Katie Crouch is the author of the novels Men and Dogs, which has just been published, and Girls in Trucks.

title: Through Baseball Cards, a Meditation on Life
description: Josh Wilker, in his Web site, Cardboardgods.net, has garnered a cult following from his lyrical autobiographical musings inspired by his 1970s-era baseball card collection.

title: In Germany, Legal Challenge Planned Over Greek Aid
description: A German economist plans to launch a legal challenge at the Constitutional Court against the euro zone aid package for Greece agreed upon by finance ministers over the weekend, a German newspaper reported on Wednesday.

title: Mexico Embraces Michelle Obama
description: MEXICO CITY  Moved by their singing and dancing as well as their difficult lives, Michelle Obama hugged student after student at a humble Mexico City elementary school on Wednesday. Just to let you know  today you did your country proud, she told the youngsters on the second day of her first solo foray out of the United States as first lady, a trip in which she surrounded herself with young people of all ages and backgrounds and attempted to offer them inspiration.

title: JPMorgan Earns $3.3 Billion in 1st Quarter
description: 7:29 a.m. | Updated The New York Timess Eric Dash has more on JPMorgan Chases earnings here.

title: End Celibacy for Priests
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: Weve Got Company
description: Video | Its a dramatic clich, and heres proof:

title: JPMorgan Upbeat as It Posts Profit
description: For big banks, the good news just keeps coming.

title: WaMu Chief Didnt Trust Goldy, E-mails Show
description: The former chief executive of Washington Mutual expressed doubts about the reliability of advice fromGoldman Sachs in 2007, as WaMu headed toward collapse, Bloomberg News reported, citing e-mail documents released by congressional investigators.

title: Australia Arrests Chinese Crew of Ship in Reef Accident
description: SYDNEY  Australian police on Wednesday arrested two senior crew members in charge of the Chinese coal vessel that ran aground on the Great Barrier Reef last week, causing serious damage to one of the worlds most famous coral outcroppings.

title: K.K.R. Said to Kick Deutsche Off of NXP I.P.O.
description: Deutsche Banks decision not to renew a credit line to NXP, the Dutch semiconductor company,has cost the investment bank a spot on the list of underwriters for the upcoming initial public offering, according to press reports.

title: BofA Names Outsider as Chief Financial Officer
description: 12:58 p.m. | Updated Bank of America announced Wednesday that it had named Charles H. Noski, an executive from outside the bank, to be its chief financial officer.

title: Soros Says Bank Oligopoly Should Be Broken
description: George Soros, the billionaire financier, called for the oligopoly formed by the four biggest U.S. banks to be broken up, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Citi Sells Fund of Funds Unit to SkyBridge
description: Citigroup agreed on Wednesday to sell a $4.2 billion hedge fund unit, including its fund of funds business, to SkyBridge Capital. Terms werent disclosed.

title: Smart Car Sharing Service Plans Expansion
description: Car2go, Daimlers car-sharing service that began operating pilot programs in Germany and Texas last year, will soon be going public in Austin, Tex., where the project had been offered exclusively to city and state officials.

title: The First Meal of Spring
description: It is still asparagus season. (Actually if youre strictly local, and you live where I live, it isnt even really asparagus season yet. But close enough.) It is also leek season. Like other members of the allium family, these grow through the winter, and along with spring onions, are among the first to be ready.

title: Angry Borrowers Mob JPMorgans Mortgage Chief
description: David Lowman, the mortgage chief at JPMorgan Chase, was mobbed by angry borrowers on Tuesday after he invited customers to speak to him if they feared foreclosure of their homes, Reuters reported.

title: Correcting Christopher Hitchens
description: I do not usually respond to Christopher Hitchens attacks on the Catholic Church, but since he begins his latest column with a reference to yours truly, I will make an exception, and examine one of the pieces more dubious claims:

title: Lost Watch: Hurley in Charge
description: Warning: This post contains spoilers.

title: An Android Phone for Fat Fingers
description: Fat-fingered Android phone fans may be frustrated by the crowded keyboard of the Motorola Droid, but there is an alternative, the Droids little brother, the Motorola Devour.

title: The Early Word: Financial Bills
description: With the nuclear summit over, the White House and President Obama turn to the next big domestic item on the agenda  financial regulatory changes.

title: Deal Outlook Is Rosy Ahead of Tulane M.&A. Conference
description: Deal-makers are feeling good about their business again ahead of Tulane University Law Schools annual Corporate Law Institute in New Orleans, which begins Thursday. (DealBook will be on the ground to give you an inside look.)

title: Rios Christ the Redeemer Closed After Rains
description: Rio de Janeiros iconic Christ the Redeemer statue will be closed indefinitely because of damage to access roads caused by heavy rains last week, the authorities said.

title: American Idol': The Top 9 (Again) Battle Elvis and the Weight of History
description: Siobhan Magnus > Michael Lynche > Crystal Bowersox > Lee DeWyze > Tim Urban > Casey James > Andrew Garcia > Aaron Kelly > Katie Stevens

title: U.S. Forces Close Post in Afghan Valley of Death
description: KORANGAL OUTPOST, Afghanistan  The last American soldier left here Wednesday, abandoning a base surrounded by tall cedar trees and high mountains, in a place that came to be called the Valley of Death.

title: Body Building: The Props of 'Dr. Oz'
description: Diann Duthie, the show's art director, reveals how tongues and tapeworms are made for TV.

title: Sue Sylvester Strikes a Pose: Glee Does Vogue
description: In what is almost certainly a pre-emptive strike against television bloggers who cant resist leaking it to the Web themselves, Fox has released an authorized clip of its remake of the music video for Madonnas hit Vogue, as performed by the cast of Glee.

title: Broad Group of Retailers Had Big Gains in March
description: Sales rose robustly in March across a wide range of retail stores, another sign that American consumers were beginning to spend more freely even as the job market remained weak.

title: Pragues Vital Gay Scene
description: ITS Friday night at Termix, a nightclub in Pragues affluent Vinohrady district, and the dance floor is clogged with unseasonably tanned Czech men in well-laundered shirts (Trebizskeho 4a; 420-222-710-462; club-termix.cz). Mirror-plated wine bottles hang from the ceiling, and the front half of a cartoon-pink sedan juts out over the bar, where three husky patrons shout over vintage Madonna.

title: A District Is Reborn in Budapest
description: FOR years, the eighth district was considered one of the worst in Budapest. Decimated during World War II and still pocked by bullets from the 1956 Hungarian revolution, the district  also known as Jozsefvaros or Joseph Town  was synonymous with theft and prostitution.

title: Hotel Review: Dean Street Townhouse in London
description: THE BASICS

title: A Work Requirement for Rent Subsidies
description: What were reading this morning:

title: Where Paris Chefs, Not Prices, Rise
description: THIS is not how I envisioned my first meal in Paris, I thought as I stood in front of LAgrume. I did not take a three-chapter-long Mtro ride to a boring part of the Fifth Arrondissement to eat at a place with a banner in the window advertising a 14-euro lunch menu.

title: Must Self-Insured Employers Extend Coverage to Adult Children?
There Is Nothing Easy About Advertising
description: Slowly but surely things are getting better, and I have decided that it is time to get back to investing in the future rather than just trying to survive.

title: Apple Delays Global Release of iPad
description: Responding to strong demand in the United States for its iPad, Apple said Wednesday that it would delay the worldwide release of the tablet computer for a month.

title: Video of Earthquake Damage in China
description: Last Updated | 4:47 p.m. As my colleague Andrew Jacobs reports, a powerful earthquake in western China has killed at least 400 people, injured 10,000 and left many others buried under debris on Wednesday, according to Chinese state media.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, April 14
description: Highlights from Wednesdays editions of The New York Times:

title: A Little Dog Touches Off a Big Search
description: This is the story of a dog with his own Facebook page and newsletter who slipped away from his collar and spent hours and hours wandering the streets of Jackson Heights, Queens, until a stranger took him home. It is also the story of the speed of modern communications, lots of posters, a few coincidences, and two dog owners with more than your average connections.

title: Going to the Matte
description: Dry shampoos are the new shine.

title: Simon Unveils New General Growth Offer
description: The Simon Property Group on Wednesday made a new offer to General Growth Partners, offering to invest $2.5 billion along the lines of the bankrupt mall operators already announced reorganization plan.

title: S.&P. at Highest Level Since 2008
description: Strong earnings reports excited Wall Street on Wednesday, pushing the Standard & Poors 500-stock index above the 1,200-point threshold for the first time since the beginning of the financial crisis.

title: Relief Messengers
description: A check for $1 million was given last night to Bill Clinton, proceeds from a $25 T-shirt created by designers to help raise money for Haiti earthquake victims. At an event at the Pierre Hotel, Diane Von Furstenberg, president of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, along with Tory Burch and Andrew Rosen, the chief executive of Theory, made the donation to the Clinton Bush Haiti Fund. The Fashion for Haiti T-shirt went on sale Feb. 16. In a tweet last night, Ms. Burch mentioned that President Clinton said that the actor Sean Penn had basically not left Haiti since the earthquake. He has stayed to help.

title: U.S. Must Start to Rein In Deficit, Fed Chief Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman said Wednesday that the government had to make difficult choices to address its gaping deficits and warned that postponing them will only make them more difficult.

title: Another Oprah on Our Hands
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: We may have another Oprah on our hands. Since leaving her job as the governor of Alaska, Sarah Palin has made more than $12 million. That is a lot of money for someone who cant say words that end in g.

title: South Park and Avenue Q Guys Bringing Book of Mormon to Broadway
description: Oh my God: theyre going to Broadway. A long-gestating musical from the South Park creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone, and Robert Lopez, a co-creator of Avenue Q, is bound for the Great White Way in March 2011, its producers announced on Wednesday. Continuing Mr. Parker and Mr. Stones tradition of satirizing every organized religion from Catholicism to Scientology, the musical, called The Book of Mormon, will juxtapose a tale of two young Mormon missionaries with the story of Joseph Smith, who founded Mormonism in the 19th century (a topic that the South Park guys have covered previously on the show). Mr. Stone and Mr. Parker wrote the book, music and lyrics with Mr. Lopez, a Tony Award winner for Avenue Q, and Mr. Parker will direct with Jason Moore (Avenue Q, Shrek the Musical). Scott Rudin and Anne Garefino will produce The Book of Mormon; no cast or theater has been announced.

title: A State-Run Comedy Show
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: President Obama announced that in 2012 hes going to hold his next nuclear security summit at a site in South Korea, right near the North Korean border. Seriously? Thats like if you held a biker chick rally right across the street from Jesse Jamess rehab facility. Youre asking for trouble.

title: Arizona Endorses Immigration Curbs
description: While pressure increases on the Obama administration for a long-anticipated and much-promised overhaul of the nations immigration laws, Arizona is moving ahead with anti-illegal-immigrant legislation widely considered among the most stringent in the states. It would hand the police in the state broad power under state law to check the legal status of people they reasonably suspect are illegal immigrants.

title: Chinas Ag Bank Said to Choose Underwriters
description: Agricultural Bank of China has chosen the roster of banks to handle its initial public offering, sources with direct knowledge of the matter told Reuters on Wednesday, in an offering expected to raise as much as $20 billion.

title: Now Showing | Carol Bove
description: The first sculpture  that greets you upon entering Carol Boves solo exhibition at Kimmerich Gallery is a frondlike piece of rusty metal mounted on an armature and set atop a brass pedestal. There is nothing inherently important about any of its elements. It is possible, this piece (and the show as a whole) seems to argue, to experience the distinction in detritus, to dignify the pleasures of collecting from nature and memory.

title: Ambushed for an Interview
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Its a great day for America, everybody. Yes, it is! But not a great day for former Vice President Al Gore. He was ambushed for an interview by Fox News. Whats wrong with you, Fox News? You dont ambush him. If you want to get Al Gore for an interview, you dont have to ambush him. Just leave a trail of ham into the studio.

title: Barter With Your Doctor
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: Well, the big story is the president of China, Hu Jintao, I believe his name is pronounced, is in Washington this week. Boy, its causing some controversy. You may have heard about this. President Obama was seen bowing to the Chinese leader. Well, he has to. I mean, the rent is going to be late again next month.

title: U.S. Must Start to Rein In Deficit, Fed Chief Says
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Wednesday that the government must begin to make difficult choices to address its gaping deficits, and warned that postponing them will only make them more difficult, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

title: Thai Official Broaches Taboo Topic: Role of the Monarchy
description: BANGKOK  The government here distanced itself on Wednesday from remarks by the Thai foreign minister that portrayed the countrys current upheaval as evidence of a society moving toward greater inclusion but that also broached what he called the taboo subject of considering changes to Thailands monarchy.

title: Wednesday Reading: A Ban on Carry-On Bag Fees?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: The Estrogen Dilemma
description: Here we are, two fast-talking women on estrogen, staring at a wall of live mitochondria from the brain of a rat. Mitochondria are cellular energy generators of unfathomably tiny size, but these are vivid and big because they were hit with dye in a petri dish and enlarged for projection purposes. Theyre winking and zooming, like shooting stars. Oh, my God, Roberta Diaz Brinton said. Look at that one. I love these. I love shooting mitochondria.

title: Pause Here
description: Toby the Lab is in that familiar morning zone called Completely Out of It. So I wont disturb him. But you should know, dog and cat people, that John Bartlett is having an adoption event this Saturday at his store, at 143 Seventh Avenue near Charles Street. The North Shore Animal League is helping out. There will be cats and dogs, young and grown, for adoption. The event is from noon to 5 p.m.

title: Kiva, MicroPlace and 3-Digit Lending Rates
description: When I last wrote about Kiva and MicroPlace, I discussed the issue of whether individuals who loan money through such microfinance institutions were truly investing in a particular entrepreneur in a developing country. The answer? Not exactly.

title: The Mental Chaos of Menopause
description: When people talk about menopause, its usually about the discomfort of hot flashes. But in this weeks New York Times Magazine, a contributor, Cynthia Gorney, explores the mental and emotional challenges that can be set off by the hormonal chaos of midlife.

title: Answers About Child-Friendly New York
description: Following is the first set of responses from Alison Lowenstein, the author of City Kid New York: The Ultimate Guide for NYC Parents With Kids Ages 4-12 (Rizzoli/Universe 2010).

title: I.B.M. Suppliers Must Track Environmental Data
description: 2:19 p.m. | Updated  Corrected spelling of John Patersons last name.I.B.M. said on Wednesday that it will require its 28,000 suppliers in more than 90 countries to install management systems to gather data on their energy use, greenhouse gas emissions and waste and recycling.

title: The Addams Family, a Critic-Proof Smash? Readers Respond
description: As Patrick Healy writes, The Addams Family sold $851,000 in tickets last weekend  a huge figure for a new Broadway run  despite the negative response to the show from critics. After five months of well-publicized creative difficulties for the show, this seeming paradox amounts to a theater world version of the golden fleece: the critic-proof smash, writes Mr. Healy. Readers responded with their own take on the musicals success, with some dismissing the role of critics and others suggesting audiences are just looking for an escape. Here is a selection of their comments. Read below and add your own.

title: Sampler: Earthquake in China, Sarah Palin and Crime Labs
description: Earthquake Kills Hundreds in Western China | An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 7.1 struck Qinghai Province in western China on Wednesday morning, leaving at least 400 dead and 10,000 injured, Chinese state media reported. Chinese officials said the quake struck in a poor and sparsely populated area near the mountainous border with Tibet. The circumstances echo the devastating earthquake that rocked neighboring Sichuan Province almost two years ago, killing 87,000 people. [The New York Times]

title: Thrashers Become Second Team to Clean House
description: Two days after the Tampa Bay fired its general manager and coach, the Atlanta Thrashers have made similar changes.

title: Broncos Trade Brandon Marshall to Dolphins
description: The Miami Dolphins had sat mostly quiet through much of the off-season, their surprise American Football Conference East championship of little more than a year ago fading quickly. The Patriots reclaimed the spot atop the division with the return of Tom Brady, and the Jets stockpiled a roster of big names after a shocking run to the A.F.C. championship game in January.

title: Drag and Drop Dead Gorgeous
description: Before and after photos of Douglas Hodge in costume for the Broadway revival of "La Cage aux Folles."

title: Chanos Sees Unfounded Euphoria in China
description: James S. Chanos, head of the New York hedge fund Kynikos Associates, has made a pretty good living calling bubbles, and he sat down with Business Insider to explain what he is shorting now.

title: Which Part of Werner Herzogs 3-D Cave Painting Movie Dont You Understand?
description: Can there be a 3-D movie about a work of art that predates the discovery of perspective? If anyone can make such a film, surely Werner Herzog can. The Guardian reported that Mr. Herzog, the director of Grizzly Man and Fitzcarraldo, is working on a movie that will take audiences inside a French cave containing drawings that are more than 30,000 years old. In a video interview on the blog of Roger Ebert, the film critic of The Chicago Sun-Times, Mr. Herzog said that he had been given permission to film inside the Chauvet cave in the southeastern Ardche region of France, whose walls are decorated with more than 300 images of rhinoceroses, bison and other animals. (Due to the risk of damage to the drawings, the site is usually restricted to visitors.)
