description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Moments after a judge excused four alternate jurors from the courtroom, one of them did something that would ease the mind of any defense lawyer whose client was on trial for murder: She mouthed the words good luck to the defendant.

title: Russian Authorities Search H.P.s Offices
description: Hewlett-Packard said on Wednesday that Russian authorities searched the companys offices in Moscow, but it did not disclose the reason for the raid.

title: Wheels With Women in Mind
description: THE graphic designer Julie Hirschfeld had a simple manifesto for Adeline Adeline, her bicycle boutique for women: No spandex! The result is a store aimed at fashionistas who wouldnt consider Lycra bike shorts, or ditching their Louboutins just because they are on two wheels. Each bike is a work of art, from the simplistically beautiful Pashley at left ($995), to the curvaceous Abici Sveltina Donna ($1,850).

title: Just for You, Sarah Jessica, but ...
description: THE azure front-pleated Calvin Klein Collection dress that Sarah Jessica Parker wears on the May cover of Vogue was supposed to be a one-off, a modification of a dress that Francisco Costa had created for this fall.

title: Top Hats, Bottom Prices
description: EUGENIA KIM is selling a limited-time hat collection at Target, starting April 18, all under $20. Ms. Kims hats, spotted on celebrities like Cameron Diaz, usually go for up to $300. The easy, breezy toppers come in cloche, fedora, sun hat, bucket hat, newsboy and pillbox silhouettes.

title: Old Is Good, Cheaper Is Better
description: NEW WORLD ORDER, an East Village store beloved by fashion editors, is having a sale of its lush vintage clothes from designers like Oscar de la Renta, Thierry Mugler and Balenciaga. The store owner, Renee Bejil, a fashion stylist and serious collector, said that he is clearing out the old old to bring in the new old.

title: Immigration Officer Guilty in Sexual Coercion Case
description: A federal immigration officer who was caught on tape demanding sex in exchange for a green card pleaded guilty to all the charges against him in Supreme Court in Queens on Wednesday in expectation of a prison sentence of one and a half to four and a half years.

title: City in Oregon Considers Beacon for the Big One
description: CANNON BEACH, Ore.  Well before recent earthquakes shook Haiti, Chile and the California border with Mexico, this corner of the West Coast was trying harder than many places to prepare for the Big One. It has upgraded its warning signs and sirens, refined evacuation routes and reassessed bridges and buildings.

title: After the Summit
description: President Obamas nuclear security summit meeting drew long overdue attention to the terrifying danger that terrorists could buy or steal the makings for a weapon from the worlds far-too-vulnerable nuclear stocks.

title: Celebrating the Joys of April 15
description: The Internal Revenue Service needs to get way better at marketing.

title: Denzel Washington and Viola Davis
description: The actors, who star in the Broadway revival of August Wilson's "Fences," talk about the playwright's legacy and their early days as theater actors.

title: Ladies Man
description: Aht Uh Mi Hed Shuggie Otis

title: Wall Street Must Recover Before City Can Overcome Recession, Economists Say
description: The recession may be ending in the New York metropolitan area, but if history is any guide, no substantial recovery can begin until Wall Street stops shedding jobs and starts hiring again.

title: Is Marriage Good for Your Health?
description: In 1858, a British epidemiologist named William Farr set out to study what he called the conjugal condition of the people of France. He divided the adult population into three distinct categories: the married, consisting of husbands and wives; the celibate, defined as the bachelors and spinsters who had never married; and finally the widowed, those who had experienced the death of a spouse. Using birth, death and marriage records, Farr analyzed the relative mortality rates of the three groups at various ages. The work, a groundbreaking study that helped establish the field of medical statistics, showed that the unmarried died from disease in undue proportion to their married counterparts. And the widowed, Farr found, fared worst of all.

title: Health and the Happy Marriage
description: When people think of marriage they often think of love, companionship and family. But what many dont realize is that the health of your marriage is inextricably linked to the health of your body.

title: St. Vincents Files for Bankruptcy
description: St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan filed its long-expected petition for bankruptcy on Wednesday, indicating that its largest unsecured creditor was a federal pension insurance agency.

title: Extension of Unemployment Benefits Advances
description: Senate Democrats on Wednesday cleared the way for final approval of additional unemployment pay for out-of-work Americans who are exhausting their standard benefits. The Senate voted 60 to 40 to exempt the legislation from budget challenges and Democrats said they hoped to finish the now $18 billion measure as early as Thursday night. Senator George Voinovich of Ohio was the sole Republican to break ranks, joining Democrats and providing the crucial 60th vote. Democrats failed in their first attempt to waive the budget rules, coming up one vote short since Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, was away at a funeral. The Senate held the vote open Wednesday night to allow Mr. Leahy time to return and cast his vote.

title: Expiring Tax Cuts Fate Has Parties Strategizing
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats for years have vowed to let the Bush administrations tax cuts for the wealthiest taxpayers expire as scheduled after this year, but election-year politics and the economys fragility could complicate matters in Congress.

title: Fund Proposed to Prevent Some Teacher Firings
description: Senator Tom Harkin, an Iowa Democrat, introduced legislation on Wednesday to create a $23 billion jobs fund to prevent teachers from being fired because of budget shortfalls. Job losses at public schools and colleges may top 100,000 in the next school year, Mr. Harkin said. The legislation needs to be passed now because school districts are making budget decisions this month, he said. The fund would supplement the $100 billion for education in the $862 billion stimulus package.

title: Groups Protest Segregation of Inmates With H.I.V.
description: In Alabama, prisoners infected with H.I.V. must wear white armbands and live in special units. In South Carolina, infected men have blue dots on their badges and are housed in a maximum-security prison; female prisoners carry the name of the H.I.V./AIDS dorm on their uniforms. The two states are the last to segregate and put blanket restrictions on H.I.V.-positive inmates and on Wednesday, rights groups called for change, saying the policies violate federal and international guidelines. Infected prisoners chances of early release and help in re-entering society are harmed as well, according to a report issued by the American Civil Liberties Union and Human Rights Watch. South Carolina bars them from participating in work-release, for example, and Alabama limits such opportunities. Prison officials in the two states say that segregation is necessary to prevent the spread of H.I.V. and provide specialized medical care.

title: The K.S.M. Files
description: Watching Attorney General Eric Holder struggle on Wednesday to answer senators questions about the detention and trial of terrorism suspects made us nostalgic for the old days  back in 2009  when the United States was making progress toward cleaning up the mess President George W. Bush made with his detention policies.

title: Book Details Spitzers Fall and His Wifes Anguish
description: ALBANY  Last month, an insiders account of Eliot Spitzers turbulent career hit bookshelves. Next week, a journalistic take on Mr. Spitzer will debut, Rough Justice: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer, by Peter Elkind, an editor at large at Fortune magazine.

title: John Schoenherr, Childrens Book Illustrator, Dies at 74
description: John Schoenherr, a Caldecott Medal-winning illustrator who for a half-century produced painterly, exquisitely detailed images of creatures from this world and others, died on April 8. He was 74 and lived in Delaware Township, N.J.

title: Army Corps of Engineers Said to Err on Flooding Risk
description: An attempt by the Army Corps of Engineers to correct old data on water flows in the Mississippi may have led to underestimates of the current risk of flooding along the river, scientists argue in a new study.

title: Helen Ranney, Pioneer in Sickle Cell Research, Dies at 89
description: Dr. Helen M. Ranney, a hematologist whose experiments in the 1950s elucidated the genetic basis of sickle cell disease, an inherited form of anemia that affects one in 500 African-Americans, died on April 5 in San Diego. She was 89.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 14, 2010

title: Prosecutors Offer Blagojevich Evidence
description: CHICAGO  Just as Barack Obama was elected president, Rod R. Blagojevich, whose job it was as governor of Illinois to appoint Mr. Obamas replacement to the United States Senate, began a frenetic, dizzying campaign to get something  an administration post, more than a million dollars, a high-paying job  in exchange for the appointment, a document released Wednesday by federal prosecutors suggests.

title: Amputee Wins Sullivan
description: The ultramarathoner and amputee Amy Palmiero-Winters has won the Sullivan Award as the United States top amateur athlete.

title: Fathers Tied to Deaths of 2 Babies
description: Two men in Queens have been arrested in recent days in connection with the deaths of their baby sons.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Whitney Museum of American Art, using information from a publicist for the Whitney, misstated the museums policy on endowment spending. The museum restricts the use of its endowment fund to cover yearly operating expenses to 5 percent of the funds value, not 5 percent of the interest income generated by the fund.

title: Indonesia: Protests After Rumor That Tomb Would Be Moved
description: Hundreds of protesters clashed with riot police on Wednesday in northern Jakarta after rumors spread that the city planned to remove the tomb of a Muslim cleric from the area. Two people were killed in the clashes and the death toll could increase, a deputy national police spokesman, Col. Zaenuri Lubis, said, according to the Associated Press. Dozens of others were injured, including a police officer whose hand was cut off and another whose stomach was slashed, according to local television stations. The violence erupted near the city's biggest port, away from the city center. The A.P. also reported that a city spokesman Cucu Kurnia said: "We did not intend to demolish the tomb, but we want to evict the illegal settlers. In fact, the local government wanted to preserve or restore the tomb."

title: Tense School Meeting After Charges
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass.   Three parents were removed by the police on Wednesday after speaking at a tense meeting of the South Hadley School Committee, which assembled for the first time since six students were indicted in the bullying of a 15-year-old girl, Phoebe Prince, who committed suicide Jan. 14.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a listing on Tuesday of the winners of the Pulitzer Prizes omitted, in some copies, a finalist for editorial writing. Besides Marie Dillon of The Chicago Tribune and John G. Carlton of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, John McCormick, also of The Tribune, was a finalist.

title: Arrest but No Motive in Strangling of Queens Woman
description: The victim, who went by the name Amanda, was a 29-year-old transgender woman, born male, who had yet to undergo a sex change operation. She advertised her services as a prostitute, a law enforcement official said.

title: Congo: Rapes by Civilians Rise Sharply, Study Says
description: Rapes by civilians sharply rose in recent years in the conflict-racked eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, where armed groups have been preying upon women for years, a new study shows. According to research commissioned by Oxfam and conducted by the Harvard Humanitarian Initiative, the total number of sexual assault cases handled by a major Congolese gynecological hospital decreased between 2004 and 2008. But the number of rapes committed by civilians increased 17-fold. "Sexual violence has become more normal in civilian life," said Susan Bartels, one of the researchers. "The scale of rape over Congo's years of war has made this crime seem more acceptable." The researchers interviewed more than 4,000 women who had been raped and sought treatment at Panzi Hospital in Bukavu. The study will be made public Thursday, and Oxfam officials said total rape cases likely were on the rise again in 2009 and 2010.

title: Brazil: Judge Suspends Awarding of Dam Contracts
description: A federal judge on Wednesday suspended an auction scheduled for April 20 to award construction contracts for a huge hydroelectric dam in the Amazon that environmentalists say would devastate indigenous communities along the Xingu River, according to a court Web site. The judge, Antonio Carlos Almeida Campelo, agreed with a federal prosecutor in Para State, who argued that awarding the contracts would violate environmental laws. The project has attracted worldwide attention from nongovernmental organizations and celebrities, including the director James Cameron, who have tried to draw attention to the dams potential negative impact. Mr. Cameron said Wednesday that he remained committed to stopping the dam.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the oral antics in a hearing by the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission misidentified the witness to whom the panels vice chairman, Bill Thomas, directed the question What made you walk away? The witness was Richard Bitner, a former subprime lender  not Richard Bowen III, a former Citigroup mortgage lending officer.

title: Critics Turn Out at Open House on N.Y.U. Expansion
description: At an open house in Greenwich Village on Wednesday evening that at times resembled a somewhat raucous cocktail party sans alcohol, New York University formally unveiled its 25-year expansion plan, giving the public a look at how it would grow by six million square feet.

title: The Tables Turn
description: On many weeknights last year, in the depths of the recession, Tursis Latin King restaurant in Des Moines closed one of its three dining rooms and pared its kitchen to a skeleton crew.

title: Arrest in Bryant Park Shoeshine Arsons
description: A 71-year-old shoeshiner, apparently angry that he was not permitted to work at a stand outside Bryant Park, set fire to it on two separate occasions in recent weeks, fire officials said Wednesday.

title: Withholding Water Meters, Slowing Growth
description: Bolinas, Calif., is auctioning off that rarest of commodities: a water meter.

title: Corrections
description: A Rebounds note in some editions on Tuesday about Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the prospective majority owner of the Nets, quoted incorrectly from a statement by the N.B.A. In addressing a report that a company owned by Mr. Prokhorov might be in violation of economic sanctions imposed on Zimbabwe, the statement said, U.S. companies are not prohibited from doing business in Zimbabwe; rather, they are prohibited from conducting business with specifically identified individuals or entities in that country. The statement did not say, U.S. companies are not prohibited from conducting business with specifically identified individuals or entities in that country.

title: Carriage-Horse Vote
description: The City Council passed a bill on Wednesday that increases the fare for horse-drawn carriage rides and improves some conditions for the horses.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies on April 5 with the Sports Briefing column misidentified the cyclist cheered at the Wall of Geraardsbergen in Meerbeke, Belgium, during the Tour of Flanders. The photograph showed Fabian Cancellara, who won the race, not Tom Boonen.

title: With End of the Season, the Knicks Future Begins
description: TORONTO  Through no merit of their own, the Knicks played a game that had playoff intrigue in the season finale before the Summer of Their Future.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Saturday about the careers of the three top-class thoroughbreds who have won 16 consecutive races misstated, in some editions, the age of one horse when she won in her debut, at Hollywood Park, in 2007. Zenyatta was a 3-year-old, not a 2-year-old.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a study on financing of research into the diabetes drug Avandia referred incorrectly to a scientist who reported findings favorable to the drug. The scientist, Dr. Mark W. Stolar, an associate professor of medicine at Northwestern, has received payments from Takeda Pharmaceuticals, which makes diabetes drugs, but not from GlaxoSmithKline, which makes Avandia. (A co-author with Dr. Stolar did receive financing from Glaxo.)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about preventive-care provisions in the new federal health law misstated the surname of the president of the American Heart Association, an advocate of comprehensive wellness programs for employees. He is Dr. Clyde W. Yancy, not Hancy.

title: Word of the Day | canter
description: canter \kan-tr\ noun and verb

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about Fred Ascani, an Air Force test pilot and the overseer of a supersonic aircraft project, referred incorrectly to the fatalities aboard the XB-70A supersonic plane involved in a midair collision in 1966. One of the two pilots aboard that plane was killed, not two of the XB-70A pilots.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: With Oil Deals, Merger Advisers Rejoice
description: Wall Street has always loved the fees generated by deal-crazy oil companies. But the recent flurry of activity in the energy industry  $130 billion so far this year and counting  is once again making them the most valuable clients for the worlds merger advisers.

title: A Program to Certify Electronic Waste Recycling Rivals an Industry-U.S. Plan
description: The Basel Action Network, an American watchdog group that has sought to curb the export of toxic electronic waste from the United States, plans to begin a new certification and auditing program on Thursday for both recyclers and companies that generate electronic refuse.

title: Unleash Your Inner Gleek on the iPad
description: Fans of Glee, Foxs campy comedy about the misadventures of a high school show choir, now have one more way to gleek out: Using their iPhones and iPads.

title: New Bandleader For Tonight Show
description: After years of practice NBC is finally addressing the abrupt departure of one of its signature late-night personalities with a plan for a smooth transition. (It may be only the bandleader for The Tonight Show, but hey, its a start.) On Tuesday the network said that Rickey Minor, the music director of American Idol, would succeed Kevin Eubanks , who announced on Mondays broadcast that he was stepping down after 18 years of chuckling amiably at Jay Lenos gags, 15 as the shows musical director. Mr. Minor, who was nominated for an Emmy as the music director of the 2008 Grammy Awards, will make his Tonight Show debut on June 7 and continue to work with the American Idol creator Simon Fuller on other projects, NBC said.

title: Bieber Knocks Usher From Top Billboard Spot
description: Last week Usher bumped his young protg Justin Bieber from the top spot on the Billboard album chart, and this week Mr. Bieber returns the favor. My World 2.0 (Island) by the 16-year-old Mr. Bieber  seen on Saturday Night Live last week  returned to No. 1 with 102,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Ushers Raymond vs. Raymond (Jive) fell to No. 2, with 92,000. Slash, once the guitarist of Guns N Roses, is at No. 3 with his new, self-titled album, released by EMI, which sold slightly more than 60,000 in its first week out. Down the chart Madonna opened at No. 10 with her live album Sticky & Sweet Tour (Warner Brothers), which sold 28,000; it is her 19th album to reach the Top 10. Sharon Jones & the Dap-Kings have officially become Brooklyns biggest retro-soul band: their latest, I Learned the Hard Way (Daptone), sold 23,000 copies in its first week out to land at No. 15.

title: News Quiz | April 15, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: My Life in Food
A Set-Up Man Emerges for the Mets
description: DENVER  Jerry Manuel saw a few positive things come out of Wednesdays 6-5 loss to the Rockies in 10 innings, not the least of which was the performance of reliever Ryota Igarashi.

title: Former Banker for UBS Seeks Shorter Sentence
description: The former UBS private banker in prison after helping to uncover tax evasion by wealthy Americans is asking President Obama for a shorter sentence, Lynnley Browning reports in The New York Times.

title: Rescue of Greece Faces Test in Germany
description: The German Parliament would probably need to approve the countrys contribution to a Greek rescue package, a spokesman for the German finance minister said Wednesday. It was another indication of the complexities that would be involved in the first bailout of a country in the euro zone, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

title: The Waiting Game
description: WHAT college currently has a waiting list of 3,383 students? WHAT other colleges are hedging their bets this spring?

title: Euro Zone Needs Tougher Rules, Official Says
description: The European Commission said Wednesday that the euro zone needed tougher rules to require national governments to stick to economic pledges in the aftermath of the Greek debt crisis, Stephen Castle reported in The New York Times.

title: The Day Lehman Got a Love Note From a Hedgie
description: In spring 2008, Lehman Brothers didnt have too many friends on Wall Street, Reuters says.

title: FLO TV Isnt Giving Up
description: How do you keep them paying, now that theyve seen free TV?

title: Volcanic Ash to Curtail Air Traffic Into  Midday Friday
description: PARIS  A dark and spectacular volcanic cloud shrouded much of northern Europe on Thursday, forcing airlines to cancel thousands of flights as it drifted at high altitude south and east from an erupting volcano in Iceland. The shutdown of airspace was one of the most sweeping ever ordered in peacetime, amid fears that travel could continue to be delayed days after the cloud dissipates.

title: S.E.C. Looks for Hedge Funders to Track Their Peers
description: Hedge fund managers may soon face a new regulatory nemesis: Their peers.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Thursday with an article about Eliot Spitzers re-emergence as a public figure misstated the year that Newsweek published a cover article about him. It was April 27, 2009  not 2008.

title: Corrections
description: The Skin Deep column last Thursday, about breast-enhancement operations performed without general anesthesia, referred imprecisely to the ability of the anesthetic lidocaine to ward off infection. While it has antibacterial properties, they are present only in high concentrations.

title: Corrections
description: The Seen column last Thursday, about the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House spring gala, misidentified the distributor of the television show P. Allen Smiths Garden Home. It is American Public Television, not the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Corrections
description: The Seen column on April 1, about a fragrance symposium, misspelled the name of a participant. She is Yuka Hiyoshi, not Yoko Hiroshi.

title: Peabody Lifts Macarthur Bid to $3.8 Billion
description: Peabody Energy raised its bid for Macarthur Coal of Australia to $3.8 billion in cash Thursday, calling it a definitive offer, a day after Macarthur rebuffed an improved bid from Peabodys rival in the takeover effort, New Hope.

title: Magnetars Big Subprime Trade
description: We can add another culprit in the bursting of the subprime mortgage lending bubble  the Illinois-based hedge fund Magnetar  The Financial Timess John Gapper writes in a lengthy profile.

title: VIP Passenger Syndrome
description: The theory that certain high-profile passengers may have a deleterious effect on airline pilot safety  controversially associated with the crash that killed Polish president Lech Kaczynski and 95 others.

title: Images of Icelands Vast Landscapes, in Icelands Vast Landscape
description: Updated, Thursday, 10:30 a.m. | When Icelands Eyjafjalla volcano exploded on March 21, the photographer Ragnar Th. Sigurdsson boarded a Cessna and flew to the scene  one he said was so beautiful you cant imagine.

title: Democrats Press on Finance Controls
description: The White House and Democratic Congressional leaders said Wednesday that they would press forward with legislation to tighten regulation of the nations financial system. Rebuffing Republican criticism, the Democrats effectively dared the minority party to side with Wall Street by opposing the measure, The New York Timess David M. Herszenhorn and Sheryl Gay Stolberg reported.

title: Wall St. Must Recover Before N.Y.C. Can, Economists Say
description: The recession may be ending in the New York metropolitan area, but if history is any guide, no substantial recovery can begin until Wall Street stops shedding jobs and starts hiring again.

title: Local TV Stations in Venture for Mobile Programs
description: Determined not to get left behind as television migrates to mobile devices, a formidable group of local television stations is forming a joint venture for what it calls a national mobile content service.

title: Dennys Slams Investors Leading Proxy Fight
description: Dennys hit back at a group of investors waging a proxy battle against the company, telling shareholders that the hedge funds are doing so for their own personal gain and dont have the companys interest in mind, The Associated Press reported.

title: Dollar General Prices Shareholder Offering
description: Dollar General on Wednesday priced 26 million shares at $27 each in a secondary public offering that allowed certain shareholders to sell their stock, the company said in a statement.

title: Kyrgyz President Leaves Country
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  The deposed president of Kyrgyzstan resigned and left the country for neighboring Kazakhstan on Thursday under an agreement brokered by Russia, regional leaders and the Obama administration. Within hours, security forces swooped in to arrest one of his brothers and a political ally.

title: Is Prom Just an Excuse to Drink?
description: To try to curb post-prom partying, an upstate New York school is holding its junior and senior proms on school nights and requiring next-day attendance. What do you think about this plan as a way to reduce prom-night drinking?

title: Lehman Sets Payouts to Exit Bankruptcy
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings laid out a plan Wednesday to repay creditors a portion of some $1 trillion in expected claims, under a proposal that could resolve the largest United States bankruptcy in history.

title: Twitter Talks Money
description: Twitter, the microblogging sensation that has now signed up more than 100 million users, outlined on Wednesday several revenue-generating initiatives, declaring that making money was now a primary goal, Reuters reported.

title: For Name Players in the N.F.L., Try the Bob Smith Test
description: Next time youre evaluating an N.F.L. player, be sure to run a Bob Smith Test. To do this, simply ask, If this players name were Bob Smith, would I still notice him? How would my opinion of him differ? The answer could surprise you.

title: Best Baguette Prize Awarded in Paris
description: The baguette, the French cultural symbol par excellence, has been part of French life for more than a hundred years. It is also, of course, part of day-to-day life in Paris. Last month, the mayor of Paris organized the Grand Prix de la Baguette, an annual contest in which more than 160 baguettes and their crispy crusts were tested by a jury. Judged on their taste, texture, look, smell, size and weight, the best baguette prize was awarded to Djibril Bodian, the Senegal-born baker at Le Grenier  Pain Abbesses in the picturesque district of Montmartre.

title: Obama to Order Review of Troubled Mines
description: President Obama on Thursday will order federal mine safety regulators to review mines with checkered safety records, after a preliminary federal review found a deeply troubling safety record at a coal mine where 29 miners were killed in an explosion last week, a senior White House official said.

title: Lehman Examiner Sees Possible Grounds for Suit
description: In a portion of the Lehman examiners report unsealed Wednesday, Anton Valukas, appointed to investigate the circumstances surrounding Lehman Brothers collapse and liquidation, says that the failed investment bank might have cause to sue Goldman Sachs and Barclays for what might be a fraudulent transaction.

title: Twitter Hints About What Developers Should Build
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: With Oil Deals, Merger Advisers Rejoice
description: Wall Street has always loved the fees generated by deal-crazy oil companies, Breakingviews says. But the recent flurry of activity in the energy industry  $130 billion so far this year and counting  is once again making them the most valuable clients for the worlds merger advisers, the publication says.

title: The Next Global Problem: Portugal
Standard & Poor at Highest Level Since 2008
description: Strong earnings reports excited Wall Street on Wednesday, pushing the Standard & Poors 500-stock index above the 1,200-point threshold for the first time since the beginning of the financial crisis, The New York Timess Javier C. Hernandez reported.

title: Financial News Site Says It Is Imperiled by Judges Ban
description: Theflyonthewall.com, a financial news service,has urged a Manhattan federal judge to lift a ban barring it from quickly reporting hot news about analyst research from three Wall Street banks, saying the ban has cost it subscribers and could threaten its survival, Reuters reported.

title: Racism and Obamas Census Form
description: Todays idea: In checking off black on his census form, Barack Obama confirmed an enduring legacy of American racism, a commentator says  that the peculiar logic of blackness still matters.

title: Zell Sees Political Risk to Investing in U.S.
description: The policies of the current U.S. administration have created political risk to investing in the United States, Sam Zell, who took over Tribune Company and then rode it into bankruptcy, said Wednesday.

title: 2 Philippine Candidates Killed in Election Violence
description: MANILA  Election violence erupted again in the Philippines on Thursday as a grenade attack killed two people and injured a dozen during a meeting of local candidates.

title: TD Ameritrade Said to Consider Acquisitions
description: TD Ameritrade Holdings chief executive said it had lots of cash to make a possible acquisition and, eventually, it would absolutely make sense for the big online brokerage to offer a dividend.

title: John Malone Back in Europe and Looking to Buy
description: Two decades ago, the 69-year-old billionaire John Malone tried and failed to replicate his U.S. cable TV success in Europe by buying up and consolidating local carriers. Now, undeterred by losses in his international operations in 14 of the past 16 years, including in 2009, hes ready to try again, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Soros: Germany Needs to Pay Up if E.U. Is to Survive
description: George Soros, the billionaire financier, says he thinks the euro and the European Union itself are at risk of breaking up if Germany refuses to play its traditional role and make concessions, Reuters reported, citing an interview conducted with Italian newspaper.

title: Goldman Director Examined in Galleon Case, Report Says
description: Add another name to the long list of companies reportedly tied to the federal prosecutors continuing investigation into the Galleon Group: Goldman Sachs.

title: P.I.C.C.s Chief Says A.I.G. Is Committed to Its Stake
description: The American International Group remains a long-term investor in the Peoples Insurance Company of China, Chinas top non-life insurer said Thursday, even as the embattled American firm unwinds its holdings in other assets to repay the United States government, Reuters reported.

title: Lagardre to Sell Stake in Vivendis Canal+
description: Lagardre, the French media company, is selling its 20 percent stake in pay-TV group Canal+ France in a move to streamline the group, which has come under fire from activist shareholder Guy Wyser-Pratte, Reuters reported.

title: Agricultural Bank of China Announces Underwriters
description: Agricultural Bank of China announced the roster of 10 banks it has picked to handle its initial public offering, which is expected to raise as much as $20 billion, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Carlyle Said to Shop United Components
description: The Carlyle Group is shopping United Components and has tapped Goldman Sachs to help it find a buyer for the auto-parts maker, Bloomberg News reported, citing three people familiar with the plans.

title: Surprise Visit
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: Russia Seeks Ways to Keep Its Children
description: MOSCOW  Russia would like to stop giving away its babies.

title: Q.&A.: Increasing Bit Rates in Windows Audio
description: Q.

title: Apache Buying Mariner Energy for $2.7 Billion
description: The Apache Corporation said Thursday it would buy Mariner Energy for $2.7 billion, just days after Apache said it would acquire Devon Energys Gulf of Mexico oil and gas assets for more than $1 billion.

title: Betty White and a Cadillac Named Parakeet
description: Betty White is known for her timeless charm and quick wit, but when the 88-year-old comedian and veteran of television series like The Mary Tyler Moore Show and The Golden Girls mentioned her beloved parakeet, I thought the joke was on me.

title: Deadly Storm Strikes Eastern India
description: NEW DELHI  Rescuers spread across eastern India on Thursday, searching for survivors of a deadly storm that killed at least 122 people and left an estimated 100,000 homeless.

title: Apache Makes Second Energy Deal
description: The independent energy company Apache announced Thursday that it would buy rival Mariner Energy for $2.7 billion, its second acquisition this week.

title: Speed Read for Thursday, April 15
description: Highlights from todays New York Times:

title: The Early Word: Tax and Tea
description: Its Tax Day, perfect timing for those who plan a protest.

title: Cold, and Contrast, in Shanghai
description: If Day One in Shanghai is an indication of what is to come, then Formula One can add to its list of firsts: Weve had the first night race in Singapore; weve had the first evening races in Australia and Malaysia. Now we have the winter race in Shanghai.

title: U.S. Industrial Production Rose in March
description: An energetic rebound for manufacturers continued in March, a report showed on Thursday, bolstering hopes that the nations factories could help lead the American economy out of its deep downturn.

title: Film Fest Is on Police Radar, Anarchists Say
description: Update, 11:13 a.m. Friday | An earlier version of this post mistakenly listed one of the venues for the Anarchist Film Festival as St. Marks Church-in-the-Bowery. The festival is not playing there. It is playing at Theater 80 St Marks and at Judson Memorial Church.

title: Views of Volcanic Ash Plume Over Europe
description: Updated | 6:23 p.m. As my colleagues Nicola Clark and Liz Robbins report, a high-altitude cloud of ash drifting south and east from an erupting volcano in Iceland has closed airports in northern Europe. Flights have been canceled because volcanic ash contains silicates, or glass fibers, which can melt inside jet engines, causing them to flame out and stall.

title: Is Health Coverage for Domestic Partners Still Taxed?
description: Q.

title: Can You Write a Business Plan With Fewer Than 140 Characters?
description: The Twitter business idea pitch, also known as a biztweet, twitpitch or twitch, has arrived. Yes, that means entrepreneurs have 140 characters, tops, to explain their start-up ideas  making the classic elevator pitch, which can take a couple of minutes (sometimes in an actual elevator, as with Wake Forest Universitys annual event), feel downright dilatory.

title: Hair Over There: The Broadway Revival Unfurls in London
description: Five months after the surprising announcement that the cast of the Broadway revival of Hair would pack up their bell-bottoms and patchouli and head to London, the transplanted American production had its official opening at the Gielgud Theater on Wednesday night. Though the Broadway production, directed by Diane Paulus, won the Tony Award for best musical revival, success in the West End wasnt guaranteed for Will Swenson, Gavin Creel and company; a previous Hair revival was not well-received went it played there 15 years ago.

title: After Quake in China, Cold and Altitude Hinder Relief
description: JIEGU, China  Rescue teams joined shovel-wielding monks in this devastated county seat on Thursday, a day after an earthquake that killed more than 700 people, as frigid temperatures threatened to claim hundreds more who remained missing, trapped beneath debris for more than a day.

title: Charges in Bryant Park Shoeshine Arsons
description: Heres what were reading this morning:

title: Dream Girl
description: Much as we might rag on it, the awful truth must be looked at head-on: Reality TV, that fiction of verisimilitude, is, even for people who read W. G. Sebald and enjoy grim Scottish films with subtitles, supernally addictive. Not always and (lets hope!) not forever, but in the right now of it. Sure, sometimes one is simply not in the mood for all that virtual id, the jawing and bitching, the glaring white teeth and the faux familiarity. And it is possible to envision a day in the not-too-far-off future when one might return to an old-fashioned pastime, like doing ones nails, over the vicarious pleasures of comparing and contrasting the suntans and blown-out blondness that beset the Real Housewives of Orange County. Meanwhile, though, one stays tuned, fascinated by the mindless commotion, caught on the hook of the souped-up dramas that barge into every episode, unsure whether one is watching a version of oneself or a counter-version or perhaps an alternate version. Which brings me to the question: Who might one be if one were to be played by a reality-show star? Who might one want to be?

title: Sit-In Grows in Central Bangkok
description: BANGKOK  Thai commandos staged a raid on Friday to capture some leaders of the anti-government protests that have gridlocked parts of Bangkok for more than a month, a senior government official said.

title: Cannes Festival Will Show Film About Plame Affair
description: A film by Doug Liman (The Bourne Identity, Mr. & Mrs. Smith) adapted from the memoir of Valerie Plame Wilson, a formerly covert C.I.A. employee, whose identity was unmasked amid the dispute over the Iraq war, will be among the 16 movies shown in competition at the Cannes Film Festival in May, and among the 46 features chosen for the festival, The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. Limans film, called Fair Game, stars Naomi Watts as Ms. Plame and Sean Penn as her husband, Joseph C. Wilson IV, the former ambassador. Other directors with films showing in competition include Mike Leigh (Another Year) and Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu (Biutiful). The features making their Cannes debut out of competition include Ridley Scotts Robin Hood, starring Russell Crowe and Cate Blanchett; Oliver Stones Wall Street 2: Money Never Sleeps; Woody Allens You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger; and Stephen Frearss Tamara Drewe. The festival, whose jury will be led this year by Tim Burton, runs from May 12 through 23.

title: Who Should Have Custody of Baby Emma?
description: John Wyatt says he tried to see his newborn daughter the moment he realized that his 20-year-old girlfriend gave birth, but the Virginia hospital lied to him and told him that neither the mother nor the baby was there. By the time he located them, the newborn had been given up for adoption, and while Virginia courts have recognized his right to custody, the state of Utah, where she has been living for more than a year now with her adoptive parents, say he has no claim on the girl.

title: Best Cornerbacks in the N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
description: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely  but not strictly  by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, although the future isnt ignored. Statistics werent acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally dont sneak onto Top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. Thats why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what youre about to read.

title: With Greece Calmer, Eyes Turn to Portugal
description: From Peter Boone and Simon Johnson at Economix:

title: Live from Tulane: Deal-Making Returns
description: NEW ORLEANS  What a difference a year makes.

title: Nelson Gets by With Fewer and Fewer Warriors
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  The regular season came to a bizarre end here Wednesday night, in a game between the leagues two most injury-depleted teams. As the playoff-bound Trail Blazers mostly rested their key players in a game that had no consequence for their postseason positioning, the low-run Golden State Warriors brought just eight players. Two of them (Ronny Turiaf and Anthony Morrow) were declared unfit to play by the teams trainer during warmups. Midway through the first quarter, center Chris Hunter aggravated his knee. So Coach Don Nelson, who recently became the career victories leader, used five players for the rest of the game.

title: Shanghai Exchange Sets Plans for Foreign Listings
description: The Shanghai Stock Exchange is finishing up plans to create an international board this year, which would allow foreign companies to sell shares to Chinese investors on the mainland for the first time, David Barboza reports in The New York Times.

title: From the Sea to a Sushi Plate, a Trail of DNA
description: One element of negotiations now under way to try to reduce the number of whales killed is the proposed creation of a central registry of whale DNA to improve efforts to track whale populations and monitor the international trade in whale meat.

title: Saturday Night Live': The Will Ferrell/George W. Bush/Tina Fey/Sarah Palin Decade
description: If you watched the more than 200 episodes of Saturday Night Live that have been shown over the past decade, and could still see straight afterward, what story would you tell? Would it be about how NBCs 35-year-old late-night comedy institution dealt with the departure of homegrown stars like Will Ferrell while generating new talents like Tina Fey and Jimmy Fallon? Would it be about how the show dealt with news events like the 9/11 attacks, and helped reflect opinions on political figures like George W. Bush, Al Gore, John Kerry and Sarah Palin? Or, like Shimmer, the floor polish thats also a dessert topping, would it be both?

title: Benjamin L. Hooks, Civil Rights Leader, Dies at 85
description: Benjamin L. Hooks, who for 15 years led the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People as it struggled to remain an effective champion of minorities in an era of rising political conservatism, died Thursday at his home in Memphis. He was 85.

title: The Dumbest Tax Mistakes Ever
description: As I was sealing the envelopes last night, I had an unpleasant flashback.

title: Head Man
description: Guido Palau performs hair-raising feats for the fashion elite. Sandra Ballentine gets the back (combed) story. More

title: Tulane: JPMorgans Braunstein Sees Good Signs Ahead
description: NEW ORLEANS  The recovery in deal-making may appear slow, but in the view of Douglas L. Braunstein, JPMorgan Chases head of investment banking, it is real.

title: Thursday Reading: The Extension of Jobless Benefits
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: A Killing in Zambia
description: Im late turning to Jeffrey Goldbergs mammoth New Yorker story on Mark and Delia Owens, a pair of celebrated conservationists who apparently went vigilante in their struggle against poachers in Zambias North Luangwa National Park, but I wanted both to recommend the piece (its the fastest-moving 17,000 words youll read this month), and to remark on how surprised I was, all things considered, to find myself feeling sympathetic toward its off-the-reservation subjects. The tenor is appropriately prosecutorial: Goldberg builds an extensive, persuasive case that the Owenses much-lauded environmental activism in the Zambian hinterland led to at least one murder, and maybe more. The victim was a poacher; the killers were probably game scouts who were trained by the Owenses as a kind of private army (and encouraged to take the fight to hunters)  and the fatal gunshots, Goldberg plausibly contends, may have been fired by Mark Owens own son, Christopher. (Remarkably, the murder was captured on camera by an ABC documentary crew sometime in 1995; even more remarkably, it was then broadcast, on an episode of the newsmagazine show Turning Point in 1996.)

title: Off the Menu: BLT Food Truck
description: The BLT Restaurant Group will inaugurate a restaurant on wheels the weekend of April 17 and 18 when its new Go Burger truck heads out to street fairs around the city. It will have a menu of burgers, hot dogs, a breakfast frittata, a salad, sweets and milk shakes, $3 to $9.

title: Brutal Truths About Violence
description: EVEN before it opened in theaters on Friday, Kick-Ass had achieved a degree of notoriety thanks to a scene in which Hit-Girl, a pint-size masked vigilante played by Chlo Grace Moretz, unleashes a barrage of obscenities against a room full of foes. Both the provocation and the published responses to it  more or less evenly split between shock and exhilaration  had a somewhat ritualized quality. Weve been here before: A movie pointedly tests what seems to be an established boundary of propriety, and rhetorical battle lines are drawn. How dare they! faces off against Oh, lighten up.

title: What Tea Party Backers Want
description: The latest  New York Times/CBS News poll focusing on Tea Party supporters found most of them very angry, generally well-educated, financially secure and deeply pessimistic about the direction of the country. We asked political analysts and historians what they found most illuminating about the polls findings, and whether the views of the Tea Party backers have commonly run through American politics.

title: On the Blank Slate Of Governors Island, Imaginations Run Wild
description: First things first: The name. No one suggested Gilligan's, Fantasy or Treasure. Of the 147 readers who answered City Room's call on Monday for ideas about Governors Island, the 172-acre former military outpost that New York City is taking over, one suggested Trump Island.

title: Imaginations Run Rampant on Governors I.
description: First things first: The name. No one suggested Gilligans, Fantasy or Treasure. Of the 147 readers who answered City Rooms call on Monday for ideas about Governors Island, the 172-acre former military outpost that New York City is taking over, one suggested Trump Island.

title: Icelands Volcanic Ash Halts Flights Across Europe
description: The plume of ash from a volcano in Iceland forced aviation authorities to order the restrictions, affecting thousands of flights in a wide arc from Ireland to Scandinavia. Read more.

title: Quadrangle Settles Pension Fund Case
description: 3:23 p.m. | Updated The Quadrangle Group, the private equity firm, has agreed to settle a corruption investigation with the New York attorney general and the Securities and Exchange Commission, Louise Story of The New York Times reports.

title: Investment Firm Agrees to Settle Kickback Inquiry
description: The investment firm founded by Steven L. Rattner, the politically connected financier who went on to lead President Obamas auto task force, has agreed to pay $12 million to settle allegations that it paid kickbacks to win lucrative business from the New York State pension fund.

title: Auditing the I.R.S.
description: If you struggled with some of the complicated new changes in your tax return this year, youre not alone. The Internal Revenue Service also had problems.

title: Final Sales Phase for World Cup Tickets Begins With a Frenzy
description: The fifth and final phase of World Cup ticket sales began Thursday with a little more than the requisite enthusiasm. Thousands of fans lined up at retail locations in South Africa overnight to buy some of the 500,000 remaining match tickets. Some 300 tickets to the final, which was reportedly sold out, were to be made available on a first-come, first-served basis, according to The Associated Press.

title: Eminem Album Isnt Canceled, Just Renamed and Reinvented
description: Every so often, it pays not to jump all over a potentially contentious celebrity tweet immediately after it appears. Eminem briefly sent his followers into a tizzy when he posted a message on Twitter Wednesday morning on his Twitter feed that read: There is no Relapse 2. Most readers took this to mean that the rapper would not release a follow-up to his 2009 album Relapse, the first he had put out since Encore in 2004. But a few hours later, Eminem set his loyal fans straight, posting a second message that said only RECOVERY, and directed followers to his Web site, eminem.com. There, the rapper said that his new album, Recovery, will be released on June 22 by Aftermath/Interscope Records, and will feature contributions from producers including DJ Khalil, Just Blaze, Jim Jonsin and Boi-1da.

title: Pope Urges Repentance in Homily
description: ROME  In his most direct reference to the sexual abuse crisis that has reached the Vatican, Pope Benedict XVI said Thursday that it was necessary for Christians to repent in light of the attacks of the world, which speaks to us of our sins.

title: Solar Growth Slows, With Homes a Glaring Exception
description: A new report from a solar industry group found that the pace of solar installations slowed last year amid the economic downturn.

title: A Song About Forgetting
description: Cynthia Scotts voice came wafting out of my car radio on a Sunday morning. Shes a lovely singer, a veteran of jazz clubs and international festivals and, back when, one of Ray Charless Raelettes.

title: They Had Some Controversy
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Here in California, our attorney general said hes going to investigate whether a university foundation that hired Sarah Palin to give a speech violated public disclosure laws. They had some controversy. Some students found her contract rider in a dumpster. That is a list of demands a performer has when they appear somewhere. Usually you see them for, like, rock stars, but Sarah Palin has one, I guess. Among other things, Palins rider requires two first-class tickets from Alaska or a private jet from Alaska, nothing smaller than a Lear 60, and it has to have a window she can shoot out of.

title: Deeper Space Exploration
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: President Obama is launching a new $6 billion space policy that will ultimately take astronauts to Mars. Of course, its $6 billion and $45 if the astronauts have a carry-on.

title: No. 1 in Science
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: The Obama administrations top science and technology official has warned the United States cannot expect to be No. 1 in science and technology forever. Did you know we were No. 1 now? If were No. 1 in technology, why do I have to call India for tech support, O.K.?

title: 42 Just One of Robinsons Numbers
description: When future generations go to ballparks, they will see the number 42 written on outfield walls or on a teams list of retired numbers and will be told that the number was retired by all teams to honor Jackie Robinson, the man who broke baseballs color barrier. They may even see the number worn by all major leaguers on Jackie Robinson day, like they will in todays games. What they wont see is that there are plenty of other numbers that could represent Robinsons time as an athlete, and 42 represents just his time with the Brooklyn Dodgers.

title: In the Future, Everyone Will Be a Piata for 15 Minutes
description: 1:13 p.m. | Updated  This 20-foot-tall piata representation of the head of Andy Warhol, designed by the food artist Jennifer Rubell, will make its debut at a gala for the Brooklyn Museum on April 22. In answer to your next questions: Yes, you will be allowed to hit it with bats, and yes, it is filled with desserts. (In a telephone interview, Ms. Rubell said it will contain the vernacular of American treats, which will remain nameless for the moment.) If you have complicated feelings about Warhol, his impact on the art world or his pairing of the Velvet Underground with Nico, this could be your opportunity to release them in an appropriate forum.

title: Educating Viewers
description: To the Editor:

title: Movie Criticism: Even Earlier Commentary
description: To the Editor:

title: All About Plot
description: To the Editor:

title: Alan Rickman: An Earlier Villain
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Broadway Storms Capitol Hill
description: An article last Sunday about Rocco Landesman, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, referred imprecisely to the production of Rent that he attended in Peoria, Ill. The show was put on by the Eastlight Theater in a high school auditorium; it was not a high school production.

title: On Military Awards and Perceptions of Them
description: It seemed an unlikely issue for a presidential race, perhaps especially when the nation was fighting two wars, but Senator John Kerrys campaign in 2004 got bogged down over the long contentious question of military awards.

title: Popcast: New Releases from Dr. Dog and Sam Amidon
description: This week: Jon Pareles reviews Shame, Shame, the new release from the psychedelic rockers Dr. Dog; Ben Ratliff on the folk singer Sam Amidons third album I See the Sign; and the Oscar-winning film composer Dave Grusin performs live. Ben Sisario is the host.

title: Madison Square to 34th Street
description: A set of distinctive structures along Madison Avenue are up for landmark designation.

title: Video: Denzel Washington and Viola Davis
description: In a year in which Hugh, Sienna  and Jude appeared on Broadway, the last  and perhaps most anticipated  celebrity sighting of the season is happening at the Cort Theater, where Denzel Washington is playing a former Negro League baseball player in the revival of August Wilsons Fences, which won the Tony Award for best play and the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1987.

title: For Pre-existing Conditions, Separate and Unequal Coverage?
description: They may all get coverage through their states high-risk insurance program, but some participants may have better and cheaper coverage than others starting in July.

title: Q&A: A Base for Exploring Scotland
description: Q.

title: Legally Allowing Illegal Parking
description: Last year, the Police Department formed a new unit within its corruption-busting arm, the Internal Affairs Bureau, to zero in on any officers misusing parking placards.

title: A Three-Story Home in Hong Kong
description: Adrian and Jessica McCarroll bought a house in Hong Kong's New Territories in 1999 and completely renovated the three-story structure.

title: University of California System Assembles First Waiting Lists
description: The University of California system, which said in the midst of fiscal belt-tightening in January that it planned to compile its first waiting lists, announced on Wednesday that it had placed more than 10,000 applicants on at least one such list. The lists, long used at selective private colleges, are being employed by several U.C. campuses to insure that enrollment targets are not exceeded.

title: What a Debut, What a Goal
description: What a Premier League debut and what a golazo.

title: Sampler: Warding Off Disaster, and Out-of-State Admissions
description: Oregon Town Considers Beacon for Big One | Cannon Beach, Ore., a seaside town of 1,500 tucked in the northern corner of Oregon, has tried harder than most places to prepare for a devastating earthquake and subsequent tsunami. It has upgraded warning signs, sirens, evacuation routes, and seismically reappraised bridges and buildings. Now, the community is trying to become the first to build a $4 million seismically sound evacuation tower that could rise over the crest of even 18-foot tsunami waves. While California is often seen as the epicenter of earthquakes in the country, new studies show that parts of the Pacific Northwest, stretching from Northern California to British Columbia, are at even greater risk of a catastrophic earthquake lasting as long as five minutes. [The New York Times]

title: Happy Tax Day
description: In honor of this sacred occasion, heres Jon Stewarts take on one of our favorite subjects of late: Who pays taxes?

title: Title Season Seems Long Ago for Celtics
description: Looks as if there may be some serious trouble brewing with the Boston Celtics.

title: The Insider | Tien Ho
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Tien Ho, the executive chef of M Pche  Momofuku Inc.s new French-Vietnamese restaurant in the Chambers Hotel  got downtowners addicted to Bentons ham and spicy brussels sprouts while cooking at Ssm Bar. It looks like hes on track to make snails with pork sausage and frise with tripe and jowl croutons the dishes of summer. Here, he shares a few of his favorite things.

title: What You Wont See in Tosca This Time Around
description: The individual performances are so arresting I didnt much notice Mr. Bondys convoluted staging. And actually, with Mr. Bondy himself absent from the scene for these return performances of Tosca, it was clear on Wednesday night that the singers have taken charge of some things. More power to them!

title: Outliers
description: Barack Obamas more nuanced version of rogue states  used to describe Iran and North Korea.

title: What Were Reading: Free Ice Cream at I.R.S. Building
N.F.L. Memo Calls on Teams to Act
description: In the days before a Georgia district attorney announced he would not pursue criminal charges against Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, the National Football League sent a memo last week to all teams emphasizing that it is not enough to avoid criminal behavior and encouraged teams to be vigilant in reinforcing the message.

title: Tea Party Express Targets Candidates
description: Tea Party activists not only rolled into Washington for protests on Tax Day, but also released a list of Congressional seats that theyve set their sights on for the November elections.

title: Through African Eyes
description: Images from a new exhibit at the Detroit Institute of Arts.

title: Threat of Fake Antivirus Software Grows
description: Fake antivirus scams are growing as an online menace, Google says. And in a post on its security blog Wednesday, the company said that the people running them were aggressively using spam, online ads and schemes to manipulate search engine results to get a grip on Web users.

title: The Girl Whos Going to U.C.L.A.
description: Hey, remember me? Its Anne, the girl whos going to U.C.L.A!

title: N.B.A. Playoffs Q. and A. With Jonathan Abrams
description: Jonathan Abrams, who covers the N.B.A. for The Times, will answer readers questions on Friday.

title: Instant Refunds, Karmic and Otherwise
description: Before braving the rush at James A. Farley Post Office  the one that used to be open 24 hours and remains much loved  to get that 4/15 postmark, take heart: tax day is also freebie day around the city, and there will be plenty of opportunity for protest.

title: The Making of the iPad Town Hall Video
description: Every week, I write and star in a goofy 3-minute video about whatever I reviewed in The Times that week. It airs on CNBC at around 1:40 p.m. Thursday, and then it goes online-to nytimes.com, YouTube, iTunes, TiVo, JetBlue and so on.

title: Obama Steps Up Mine Safety Reviews
description: Updated: President Obama, in ordering a fresh round of mine safety inspections, said Thursday that the federal government was partly to blame for the disaster that claimed 29 lives in West Virginia last week.

title: DiNapoli Ensnared in Pension Fund Inquiry
description: Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli became enmeshed in the sprawling investigation of the state pension fund on Thursday, with Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomos office announcing a settlement with a political consultancy firm that facilitated a meeting between Mr. DiNapoli and a prominent investment executive.

title: TimesCast | April 15, 2010
description: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Thursday.  Topics include Russia's suspension of American adoptions, the nuclear terrorism threat and paying teachers not to teach.

title: Making Your Wishes Known at the End of Life
description: Tomorrow is Health Care Decisions Day, part of a national campaign to encourage Americans to complete their advance directives or living wills and document their desires regarding medical treatment at the end of life.

title: Do Living Wills Really Make a Difference?
description: In this weeks Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen shares the story of a personal loss, the recent death of her father-in-law.

title: Theater Talkback: Odd-Man-Out Syndrome
description: Am I missing something?

title: New York City Carriage Rides to Increase in Price
description: Concluding, for now, a debate that brought vivid responses from both sides, the City Council passed a bill Wednesday to increase the fare for horse-drawn carriage rides while improving some conditions for the horses.

title: Continental Reopens Talks With United
description: 1:22 p.m. | Updated Continental Airlines has reopened merger talks with the UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday.

title: Rescue Efforts Continue After China Quake
description: Workers and relief supplies reached the remote county of Yushu the day after it was struck by an earthquake with a magnitude of 7.1

title: Obama and Biden Tax Returns Made Public
description: 5:12 p.m. | Updated President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. have to pay taxes just like the rest of us. Unlike (most of) the rest of us, they make their returns public.

title: Rupert Murdoch and Family Find Faith and Fame at the River Jordan
description: As a newspaperman with an ear for his audience, Rupert Murdoch, the chief executive of the News Corporation, has long expressed his distaste for elites and royals. But plenty of both were in attendance recently as Mr. Murdoch and his wife Wendi celebrated the christening of their two daughters, Grace and Chloe.

title: Teachers Set Deal With City on Discipline Process
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the citys teachers union have agreed to do away with rubber rooms full of teachers accused of wrongdoing or incompetence and speed up hearings for them, reforming a disciplinary system that has made both City Hall and the teachers union subjects of ridicule.

title: MySpace to Offer New Service for Concertgoers
description: MySpace is getting into the calendar business. The social networking company introduced a new service on Thursday that would allow individuals to manage their upcoming events within the site and to buy concert tickets through links on artist pages and elsewhere on the site.

title: Fifteen Nights of Midsummer Swing
description: True to its name, there will be plenty of swing music this summer at Midsummer Night Swing, Lincoln Centers annual series of al fresco dancing. Its 22nd season opens on June 28 with a battle of the big bands between the George Gee Orchestra and the Bill Elliott Swing Orchestra, and the 15 nights in Damrosch Park also include various species of jazzy swing by the Time Jumpers (Western swing, July 1), the New Orleans Moonshiners (New Orleans jazz, July 6), the Wycliffe Gordon Sextet (straight-up jazz, July 10) and the Harlem Renaissance Orchestra on closing night (yet more big-band swing, July 17).

title: 15 Minutes of Piata Fame, 20 Feet Tall
description: That expressively expressionless visage gazing down from the exterior of the Brooklyn Museum, in case you were wondering, is Andy Warhol, reincarnated this time in 20-foot-tall piata form. In a few days, gala attendees suffering from anxiety of influence will have the opportunity to hit it with bats. Read all about it on ArtsBeat.

title: Some at MoMA Show Forget Look but Dont Touch
description: A few Fridays ago, a young contemporary dancer named Will Rawls was working at his current production, the Marina Abramovic performance art retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. Specifically, he was standing naked in a gallery entrance, facing a naked woman, as museumgoers passed through the narrow space between them. It was a re-enactment of Imponderabilia, a well-known piece originally performed by Ms. Abramovic and a partner in the 1970s.

title: At Internet Conference, Signs of Agreement Appear Between U.S. and Russia
description: GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany  For the 140 computer network specialists, law enforcement agents and diplomats from eight countries who met in this German ski resort this week for a Russian-sponsored conference on Internet security, the biggest challenge was finding a common ground to discuss their differences.

title: Milan Report | Paola Navone for Barovier & Toso
description: Last year, the designer Paola Navone created a striking installation for Richard Ginori, turning an old warehouse into a fantasy china factory with palettes of stacked white ware surrounding an island of lounge seating where visitors could relax and sip an espresso while they admired a 40-foot-high wall of china plates, all hand-painted in different bright patterns. It was a coup de theatre.

title: Tips on Shooting Video With a D.S.L.R.
description: A few weeks ago, I attended a hands-on class on shooting pro-level footage with a video-capable D.S.L.R. camera. The all-day session was led by Bruce Dorn, a professional photographer and videographer who champions the use of D.S.L.R.s for creating sophisticated video. It was sponsored by Canon to showcase the 1080p video capabilities of its new EOS Rebel T2i.

title: N.B.A. Career Full of Moves for Ollie: 11 Teams in 13 Years
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Kevin Ollie was in one of the N.B.A. cities that he has not called home. When on the road, it is nearly a 50-50 proposition whether he once dressed in the home locker room rather than the visiting one.

title: Of Meter and Money
description: Who says poetry doesnt pay? On April 26 and 27, there will be 53 high school students from around the country reciting verse from memory before a panel of judges, vying for the title of Poetry Out Loud Champion and a total of $50,000 in prize money. The competition, a partnership between the Poetry Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts, began last month with contests in all the states (and the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands). The winners of those competitions will go to Washington for the semifinals on April 26; nine students will advance to the finals on April 27. Thenational champion will get $20,000, the second- and third-place finalists $10,000 and $5,000. Other finalists and semifinalists will also win cash prizes, and the finalists schools will each receive $500 to buy poetry books. The judges include Garrison Keillor, the poet and critic Adam Kirsch, and last years national champion.Both the semifinals and the finals will take place at the Lisner Auditorium at George Washington University and are free and open to the public.

title: The Tea Partys Political Favorites
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll of Tea Party supporters reveals a new movement that has yet to coalesce around any one political figure.

title: A Case for and Against Electric Cars
description: LA JOLLA, Calif.  A panel of scientific experts, looking into various sustainable mobility solutions for the auto industry here on Tuesday, came up with some unexpected conclusions.

title: Black Boxes Yield Data on Crash of Polish Jet
description: MOSCOW  For a few terrifying seconds before a Polish jet crashed in western Russia on Saturday, its crew members knew they were about to die, Polands chief prosecutor said on Thursday, as investigators in both countries analyzed the contents of the planes black boxes.

title: Idiot Gets Some Smart(phone) Marketing
description: Until recently, most new Broadway musicals got marketing campaigns that would not have seemed strange or different to Rodgers and Hammerstein, Lerner and Loewe or Adler and Ross. Print advertising, some television commercials, a promotional event or two  there rarely was anything new along the Rialto.

title: Hyatt to Open New Hotels in India
description: Hyatt Hotels plans to expand its presence in the Indian cities of Delhi, Goa, Calcutta and Mumbai, as well as move into 15 new Indian markets  including Bangalore, Chennai, Hyderabad and Pune  over the next five years. The company said it would open Hyatt Regency Pune, Hyatt Regency Chennai and Grand Hyatt Goa this year.

title: Eleventh Times the Charm: Meet Your New Doctor Who
description: It was just three months ago that science fiction fans everywhere held their breath as Doctor Who said goodbye to its star David Tennant, the actor who portrayed the energetic, enigmatic adventurer known only as the Doctor. Not only did Mr. Tennant depart the BBC series in January  so, too, did Russell T Davies, the writer and producer who revived the dormant Doctor Who franchise in 2005, and helped restore an aura of wonder to the Doctor, his time-traveling phone booth-slash-spacecraft, the TARDIS, and his mechanical alien foes, the Daleks.

title: Eruption Wasnt That Powerful, but Effects May Linger
description: The volcanic eruption in Iceland that disrupted air travel in Europe on Thursday was not a particularly powerful one, experts said, but they cautioned that its effects  both on travel and on the regional climate  might linger.

title: Former N.S.A. Official Is Charged in Leaks Case
description: WASHINGTON  In a rare legal action against a government employee accused of leaking secrets, a grand jury has indicted a former senior National Security Agency official on charges of providing classified information to a newspaper reporter in hundreds of e-mail messages in 2006 and 2007.

title: Compartmentalizing Life and Work
description: As the word flexibility returns to the national work/life conversation, USA Today reporter Sharon Jayson asks whether working from home really means spending more time with your kids. That is the theory, of course, and the reason that telecommuting and flexible hours that allow employees to do some of their tasks at home have become the holy grail, for some, of a balanced life.

title: The Power of Place: Doing Ethnographic Studies of Local Sites
description: Overview | How do writers create or defy popular images of settings? What is ethnography, and how can it be used to reveal the meanings of places? In this lesson, students consider the power of place in their own lives, and then execute an ethnographic research project that dispels clichd notions about where they live.

title: 2 Charged in International Tax Evasion Scheme Said to Involve HSBC
description: Federal authorities arrested two property developers, a father and son, on Thursday and charged them with participating in a multimillion-dollar tax evasion scheme through a large international bank.

title: The Morning Skate: Night One, and Fans History Will Be Made Videos
description: And with that goal, credited to Chris Stewart (and accompanied by the typically strangled-voiced histrionics of the Avs announcer Mike Hayes), the Avalanche finished an evening of upsets on the first night of Stanley Cup play, defeating San Jose, 2-1, in the last minute.

title: Support Voiced for Plan to Increase S.E.C. Budget
description: April 16, 9:59 a.m. | Corrected Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, joined with four former chairmen of the S.E.C. on Thursday to voice their support for a proposal in the Senates financial regulatory bill that would considerably increase the budget for the agency in order to combat securities fraud and other violations.

title: A Student Lenders Broken Promise
description: If youve ever taken out a student loan, youre probably familiar with the perks that lenders offer for making payments on time, like an interest rate reduction.

title: Justice Thomas Laughs at His Silent Streak
description: In the age of television cameras, perhaps silence is golden.

title: Answers About Child-Friendly New York, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of responses from Alison Lowenstein, the author of City Kid New York: The Ultimate Guide for NYC Parents With Kids Ages 4-12 (Rizzoli/Universe 2010).

title: Jessica Bram and Robert Cooper
description: FOR a long time, Jessica Bram never thought of herself as the remarrying kind, and the book she wrote about her post-marriage years was called Happily Ever After Divorce.

title: Courtney Loves Music Therapy
description: COURTNEY LOVES room at the Mercer Hotel in SoHo was a study in chaos. Racks of clothing, from 1920s vintage to this seasons Miu Miu, lined two walls. The floor was littered with boxes of photos. Empty coffee cups, half-finished bottles of juice, opened bags of candy, overflowing ashtrays and stacks of books on Buddhism and psychology were seemingly everywhere. And at the center of it all, at once manic and serene, brash and vulnerable, sat Ms. Love, watching on a battered laptop YouTube videos of her duet with the Irish singer Gavin Friday at a benefit for Red, an African AIDS charity, at Carnegie Hall.

title: Hamas Executes Two Accused of Aiding Israel
description: GAZA  Hamas authorities on Thursday executed two Palestinians who were convicted in a Hamas military court of collaborating with Israel. The executions, carried out by a firing squad at dawn, were the first since the Islamic group Hamas seized control of Gaza after routing forces loyal to the president of the authority, Mahmoud Abbas, in 2007.

title: Grass Fed | Relishing Gramercys Pickles
description: Do you pickle?

title: Michael Moss on Food Safety (Round 2)
description: The Timess Michael Moss, who has won a Pulitzer Prize for his reporting on contaminated beef and food safety issues, responds to a second batch of readers questions.

title: Militants Ban School Bells in a Town in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The Shabab, Somalias most powerful Islamist insurgent group, outlawed school bells in a southern town on Thursday after deciding that they conflicted with Islam, residents said.

title: Thompson Wont Run for Senate
description: Former Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin said Thursday that he would not run against Senator Russ Feingold this year, giving Mr. Feingold a much clearer advantage.

title: Photo of the Week
description: A farmer harvests a wheat crop on the outskirts of Amritsar, India.

title: Art-Themed Hotel to Open in Mumbai
description: Indias luxury hotel scene  long dominated by opulent palaces and converted mansions  is joining the arty boutique craze with Le Sutra, a 16-room property in Mumbais posh Bandra neighborhood, billed as the first Indian art hotel.

title: Fake Race Vehicle Seized With Nearly a Ton of Cocaine
description: The Spanish police have stopped what appears to have been a daring strategy by an enterprising band of drug smugglers, who the police say tried to use the Dakar Rally in January to cover up their tracks.

title: Lobbyist Was Paid for Pension Fund Deals, Cuomo Says
description: Last year, when The New York Times was scrutinizing a deal between the state pension fund and InterMedia Partners, a spokesman for Roberto Ramirez, a lobbyist and former assemblyman who facilitated the deal, insisted that his company, the Mirram Group, was not paid for his work.

title: Boos Become Bravos at the Met
description: What a difference a cast can make.

title: Honoring the I.R.S.
description: Thats from a column by E.J. Dionne Jr. in todays Washington Post, on some public servants who get a bad rap, especially this time of year.

title: Former Israeli Leader Is a Suspect in New Corruption Case, Media Says
description: JERUSALEM  The former prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, who resigned after being accused in several corruption cases, is now a chief suspect in a major bribery investigation involving a West Jerusalem building project that was advanced during his years as mayor of the city, Israels state radio and other Israeli news media reported on Thursday.

title: The Robots Are Coming to Town
description: If you live in New York and dont like giant robotic muffin bicycles or fire-breathing robots, you might want to skip town in September.Maker Faire, the fair for geeks from all walks of geekiness, is heading to New York, and is likely to bring along these and other oddities.

title: Senate Climate Bill to Be Unveiled April 26
description: The three Senate sponsors of climate and energy legislation now plan to unveil their proposal on April 26, aides said, a few days later than expected, but in time for potential floor debate before the Senate adjourns for its annual summer recess.

title: Couple Honored for Years of Loyalty to Theater
description: Ever since they helped found Primary Stages in 1985 and took seats on its board of directors, Marvin and Anne Einhorn have also volunteered five days a week as the receptionists manning the phones at the Off Broadway theaters offices. On Friday, Mr. Einhorn, 89, and Mrs. Einhorn, 86  who have been married for 67 years  will receive an honor that usually goes to a millionaire donor: Primary Stages will name its theater school on their behalf in recognition of their longtime commitment.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE
