title: British Leaders Debate on Domestic Issues
description: Original Post | 3:28 p.m. The leaders of Britains three largest parties are meeting for the first of three 90-minute debates on British television on Thursday in Manchester. Readers in the United Kingdom can watch live video of the debate on the Web site of the British broadcaster ITV.

title: Q.&A.: Lincoln Makes Her Case for Derivatives Rules
description: Senator Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas, the Democratic chairwoman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, is expected to introduce derivatives legislation on Friday that is far stricter for banks than Wall Street had anticipated. The measure includes a number of provisions that Ms. Lincoln believes are necessary to curb systemic risk and bring much needed transparency to this opaque corner of the financial world.

title: Financial Tuneup: Find a Better Rewards Card
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: Movie Listings
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Tulane: S.E.C. Official Urges Caution on Regulation
description: NEW ORLEANS  Just because calls have grown louder for the government to increase its regulation of companies doesnt mean that it should, a commissioner at the Securities and Exchange Commission said here on Thursday.

title: Senate Climate Bill Debut Set for April 26
description: At our Green Inc. blog, The Timess John Broder outlines the rollout for the climate change legislation in the Senate:

title: Hazards: Metal Shavings From Swings a Danger to Children With Autism
description: Children with autism are often calmed by riding on a swing; some do it for hours every day. But doctors are warning of a danger that can occur when wear and tear causes small metal fragments to peel from the suspension apparatus and fall into childrens eyes.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music.

title: Jazz Listings
description: Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.

title: Clog Posting
description: Among the clognoscenti, a visit with the Portland, Ore.-based Clogmaster, aka Cecilia Tidlund, is the stuff of legend. Not only can you custom-design clogs from candy-colored, patent and metallic leathers, youll also receive a custom fitting  maybe even a customized dressing-down about your appalling footwear habits. (Silly me, I wore flip-flops.) Tidlund, a native of Sweden and the founder, in 1976, of one of Americas first bespoke clog companies, is an orthopedic-wellness militant  la the Soup Nazi. Which is why, when I phoned Tidlund to solicit her (withering, I was certain) take on one of springs big trends  the befeathered, begrommeted, open-toed, high-heeled clog (see Miu Miu, above left; Louis Vuitton, above right; and Chanel)  I was surprised that she wasnt entirely negative. First she reminded me that weve seen them before. Then she added, Id rather people get into a bad fashion clog than a ballet flat or flip-flop. Flimsy shoes are ruining peoples feet. Ive seen 12-year-olds with bunions.

title: Jobless Rate Continues to Fall
description: New York Citys unemployment rate declined again in March, falling to 10 percent, its lowest rate since last November, and lending support to the view that the recession caused by the financial crisis is winding down.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

title: As U.S. Tests the Lexus GX 460, Toyota Ceases Selling It Worldwide
description: DETROIT  Toyota said on Thursday that it was testing the safety of all its sport utility vehicles and had suspended sales of the Lexus GX 460 in markets beyond the United States, where sales were halted this week.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

title: Q. & A. With Sam Sifton (Round One)
description: Response to my article for the Sunday magazine, about eating for a living and how to stay healthy while doing it, has been fascinating. Turns out there are some number of people in the world who struggle with their weight, and who are fascinated with the business of keeping it off while, if possible, continuing to eat lustily. Who knew?

title: He Tested the Market
description: CAN you hear me now? Good. How about now that Ive sold my apartment? Lets hope so!

title: Outside of the Blue and Yellow Box
description: The Brooklyn neighborhood of Red Hook may be most famous these days for affordable Swedish design, but a group of artists is giving the once rough-and-tumble peninsula a softer, more creative edge. Their fondness for turning salvaged objects into objets dart makes the area feel like a small town of misfit toys, in one residents words, which might also serve to describe much of the creative class that now lives there. To reach these somewhat inaccessible streets, take the B61 bus to the Red Hook Ikea; the bus runs between Queens Plaza and Red Hook, stopping in Downtown Brooklyn near the Jay Street-Borough Hall subway stop (A, C, F lines) and near the Borough Hall stop (2, 3, 4, 5, M, R). Or take the water taxi to Ikea from Pier 11 near Wall Street.

title: Earth Day Events
description: In a city where green space has grown by 570 acres in the past eight years, every day could be considered earth day. This is especially true in April, when the events leading up to the formal Earth Day, April 25, could fill every page of your calendar (no doubt made from recycled materials).

title: Immigration Raids Focus on Shuttle Vans
description: PHOENIX  With sweeps on both sides of the border Thursday, American and Mexican authorities delivered what they called their most serious blow toward dismantling human smuggling organizations that have brought thousands of illegal immigrants to the United States.

title: Anchor Casts Off Home
description: ITS been an eventful two years on Wall Street. Perhaps youd heard? And as CNNs chief business correspondent, Ali Velshi has been busy.

title: The Pepsi Will Flow at the Move-In Party
description: ROGELIO M. REBOLLEDO, a man who made his fortune in snacks and sodas, and now sits on the board of the Kellogg Company and Best Buy, has bought a three-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side for $3.1 million. Now, one wonders: what will go in the pantry? Rice Krispies, for sure.

title: Workaday Buildings That Arent
description: THE Historic Districts Council, a preservation advocacy group, has surveyed the blocks from Madison Square to 34th Street for potential landmark designations.

title: Next Stop for Woods Is Quail Hollow
description: Tiger Woods will be back among golf fans in two weeks, according to his Web site, choosing to make the regular PGA Tour stop at the Quail Hollow Championship in Charlotte, N.C., his second appearance of 2010.

title: Aerialists, Athletes And Arpeggios
description: When the Little Orchestra Society performs on Saturday, some of the most carefully planned moments will go right over the young audience members heads  and thats exactly what Dino Anagnost wants.

title: A Beer Marketer Is Painting the Town, Literally
description: One of the hottest trends in marketing is for brands to commission the creation of content  sometimes chock full of product placement, sometimes low-key in trying to peddle their wares.

title: Credit Suisse Hires Proxy-Fight Expert
description: Credit Suisse has hired Chris Young, the director of mergers and acquisitions and proxy-fight research at Institutional Shareholder Services, to head the investment banks takeover defense practice. Mr. Young, who is considered a leading authority in contested M.&A. transactions and shareholder activism issues, was with I.S.S. for six years where he advised large shareholders on how to vote.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO  (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series Dora the Explorer and Go, Diego, Go! have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Childrens Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diegos Animal Rescue Center and Doras Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street , (212) 721-1223, cmom.org; free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members.20100415

title: Googles Profit and Revenue Rise, but Analysts Wanted More
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google may be fighting a multifront war against Apple, Microsoft, federal antitrust regulators and the government of China, but its online advertising business continues to hum along nicely.

title: Dueling Columnists
description: A surprising disagreement has broken out between two Times columnists, with Paul Krugman demanding an apology from Andrew Ross Sorkin and Sorkin so far refusing to back down.

title: Senegal Urged to Rein in Religious Schools
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Thousands of children in Senegal are forced to beg on the streets under the pretext that they are receiving religious instruction, Human Rights Watch said in a report Thursday that urged the government to crack down on the long-established phenomenon.

title: Pictures of the Day: Devastation in China and Volcanic Ash in Europe
description: Rescue efforts continued in western China a day after the 7.1-magnitude quake that devastated a county seat on the Tibetan plateau (Slides 1, 2, and 3). Government teams joined shovel-wielding monks as frigid weather threatened to claim hundreds more who remained missing. In Europe, a drifting cloud of smoke and ash from a volcano in Iceland (Slide 4) grounded air traffic. The situation left passengers stranded and mostly resigned (Slides 6 and 7) at some of the worlds busiest airports.

title: Chinese Premier Offers a Tribute to a Reformer
description: BEIJING  He was the reformist party leader whose death 21 years ago helped inspire the pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square. To a large extent, both the protests and the leader  the former Communist Party general secretary Hu Yaobang  have been missing from Chinas official political lexicon ever since.

title: Anger and Frustration in Tea Party Voices
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll offers an in-depth look at the 18 percent of Americans who consider themselves supporters of the Tea Party movement.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: As Churchs Windows Come Down, So Do Hopes for Restoration
description: Workers for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn have removed the dozen towering stained-glass windows from a beloved church built a century ago by Italian immigrants, prompting protests from preservationists who consider the building an important artifact  and who consider demolition imminent.

title: Milan Report | Shopping With Stella
description: Stella McCartney just opened her first store in Milan, on via Santo Spirito in the heart of the citys fashionable shopping district. Housed in an 18th-century building, the store  which was designed by the architects APA in London and J&R Studio in Milan  has a sustainable oak parquet floor, in McCartneys signature color palette, that was designed by Yael Mer and Shay Alkalay of Raw Edges for Established & Sons (www.establishedandsons.com), the furniture company headed by Alasdhair Willis, McCartneys husband. While the stores ground floor is full of decorative touches, the second floor is a study in white on white with accents of bright color like the organic felt cubes that display shoes, and a painted ceiling that is original to the building. Moreover, the design doesnt just look good; it does good, too  McCartney is aiming for LEED certification.

title: Low Rates Good for Banks, but Pity the Saver
description: Arent low short-term interest rates wonderful?

title: The Exotic in the Eyes of African Beholders
description: DETROIT  For centuries Euro-American eyes have been trained on Africa. Weve scanned it from afar, surveyed it up close, put it behind glass; looked and looked, wonderingly, acquisitively, disdainfully, fearfully. But we rarely seem to be aware that during all that time Africans have been looking back at us  wonderingly, acquisitively, disdainfully, fearfully. A remarkable exhibition called Through African Eyes: The European in African Art, 1500 to Present, which opens Sunday at the Detroit Institute of Arts, gives a vivid hint of what theyve seen.

title: Cold War Nuclear Fears Now Apply to Terrorists
description: WASHINGTON  The top secret National Intelligence Estimate did not mince words. The United States faced an enemy with no scruples about employing any weapon or tactic, it said, and nuclear weapons smuggled across porous borders threatened to devastate American cities. Sleeper cells, the document warned, might already be inside the country.

title: All About the Obamas Charitable Giving
description: Even the president has to file taxes. And so he did today, as noted by our colleagues over at the Caucus blog. In addition to paying $1.8 million in federal taxes, the Obamas donated $329,100 to charity plus the full amount of the $1.4 million he won for receiving the Nobel Peace Prize in 2009.

title: Practice Swing Should Imitate Your Shot
description: Maybe youre heading out to play for the first time this season. Now is a great time to break old habits that arent helping you. Case in point: the common, often useless practice swing.

title: Rangers Manager Has a Season of Work After a Moment of Weakness
description: CLEVELAND  Ron Washingtons home in New Orleans is made of brick. Hurricane Katrina gutted its insides in 2005. Some of his relatives moved away, their homes totaled. Washington stayed. He has steadily restored almost everything, with only the living room and a bedroom to finish.

title: New York City Pays Teachers Not to Teach
description: Carolyn Ryan, the Deputy Metro Editor of The Times, speaks to the reporter Jennifer Medina about the ridiculed "rubber rooms," where teachers receive pay for doing nothing.

title: The Resurrection of a Gothic Mansion
description: The Resurrection of a Gothic Mansion

title: From Mr. Clean to Luv Gov
description: The Eliot Spitzer story plays like a novel that might have been plotted by Theodore Dreiser and peopled with characters by Tom Wolfe. The governor of New York, a k a Mr. Clean, a k a the Sheriff of Wall Street, is transformed by a prostitution scandal into the Luv Gov and Client 9. The tireless reformer compared to Batmans alter ego, Bruce Wayne; the moralistic square, who carried a briefcase in junior high, finds his much ballyhooed future as a possible presidential contender smashed to pieces, and the word disgraced seemingly permanently stapled to his name like a Homeric epithet.

title: Fox News Cancels Hannitys Tea Party Broadcast
description: Update, 11:19 P.M.: Sean Hannitys plan to broadcast from a Cincinnati Tea Party rally were canceled late Thursday.

title: Epics and Erotica From a Grandfather of Anime
description: Todays comic book artists and graphic novelists owe a huge debt of gratitude to Hokusai, Hiroshige and other Japanese artists who, with wonderful formal and technical ingenuity, illustrated tales of martial conflict, high seas adventure, travel and erotica, and sold them cheap in vast quantities to the pre-20th-century equivalents of manga and anime fans.

title: President Obamas Remarks on the Space Program
description: Following is the text of President Obama's speech on Thursday outlining his plans for space exploration at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida:

title: Tracking Airport Status
description: A list and map of airports that have been affected by the ash cloud.

title: Appetite for New and Next New
description: Maybe we dont need to be reminded that the American art of the late 1950s and 60s moved with ferocious speed. Those were the glory days, weve been taught, repeatedly and indelibly.

title: A Turn in the Sun for the Cello, Equal Orchestral Partner
description: The cello is now so firmly established as a solo instrument that its easy to forget that it was mostly a bit player until the 19th century.

title: Happily Settling for a More Modest Country Getaway
description: BUYERS looking for a country house in the Hudson Valley or the Catskills in New York State have settled on a more modest ideal: between $200,000 and $250,000 for a home on a few acres, with a picturesque town not too far away.

title: Daniel Radcliffe to Star in How to Succeed Revival on Broadway
description: How do you succeed on Broadway without really trying? It doesnt hurt when you have a star from one of the most successful film franchises in history in a leading role. Daniel Radcliffe, the Harry Potter star  who, in fairness, works hard in all his endeavors, were sure  will play the ambitious window washer J. Pierrepont Finch in a revival of How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying that is planned for Broadway in the spring of 2011, its producers announced on Thursday. The musical revival, with music and lyrics by Frank Loesser and book by Abe Burrows, Jack Weinstock and Willie Gilbert, will be Mr. Radcliffes first Broadway role since the revival of Equus that ran at the Broadhurst Theater in 2008 and 2009. Rob Ashford, (Promises, Promises; Curtains) will direct How to Succced, and it will be produced by Broadway Across America (John Gore, Thomas B. McGrath, Beth Williams), Craig Zadan and Neil Meron. The original production (with a cast that included Robert Morse and Charles Nelson Reilly) opened in 1961 and ran for more than 1,400 performances; a film version was released in 1967, and a previous Broadway revival, starring Matthew Broderick and Megan Mullally, was mounted in 1995.

title: Visiting Audubons Still-Fine Feathered Friends
description: ST. FRANCISVILLE, La.

title: Whitney Heads for the High Line
description: Even before a final decision on whether the Whitney Museum of American Art will build a $680 million downtown museum in the meatpacking district, the institution is planting its flag on the site  a parcel of land at Gansevoort and Washington Streets  in a series of outdoor exhibitions.

title: Familiar Names Return to Madison Avenue Under New Moniker
description: Two well-known agency executives, Bill Berenter and Marty Greenhouse, are returning to advertising with a new agency.

title: The Palm Orchard
description: WHAT Oceanfront residential resort.

title: Icahn Raises His Bid for Lions Gate to $7 a Share
description: 5:59 p.m. | Updated The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn is not ready to be thwarted in his hostile bid for Lions Gate Entertainment.

title: Film About Plame Affair to Be Shown at Cannes
description: A film by Doug Liman (The Bourne Identity, Mr. and Mrs. Smith) adapted from the memoir of Valerie Plame Wilson, the covert C.I.A. employee who was unmasked in a dispute over the Iraq war, will be among the 16 movies shown in competition at the Cannes Film Festival in May, and among the 46 features chosen for the festival, The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. Limans film, Fair Game, stars Naomi Watts and Sean Penn, above, as Ms. Plame and her husband, Joseph C. Wilson IV, a former ambassador. Other directors with films showing in competition include Mike Leigh (Another Year) and Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu (Biutiful). The features making their Cannes debut out of competition include Ridley Scotts Robin Hood, starring Russell Crowe and Cate Blanchett; Oliver Stones Wall Street 2: Money Never Sleeps; Woody Allens You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger; and Stephen Frearss Tamara Drewe. The festival, whose jury will be led this year by Tim Burton, runs from May 12 through 23.

title: Theater Prizes Awarded
description: The playwright Dan LeFranc and the musical theater songwriters Peter Mills and Barry Wyner have won major awards recognizing promising new talent in American theater, the sponsors of the prizes announced. Mr. LeFranc has won the 2010 New York Times Outstanding Playwright Award for his play Sixty Miles to Silver Lake, about a divorced father and his teenage son on an emotionally exacting car ride together. The prize comes with $5,000 award. The downtown theater Soho Rep produced Sixty Miles to Silver Lake last year. The prize will be presented on May 13 at a ceremony held at TheTimesCenter in Manhattan. Mr. Mills, meanwhile, is the winner of the 2010 Kleban Prize for most promising musical theater lyricist, and Mr. Wyner is the Kleban recipient for most promising musical theater librettist. Those awards each come with a cash prize of $100,000 from the Kleban Foundation, established in 1988 under the will of Edward L. Kleban, the Tony Award and Pulitzer Prize-winning lyricist of A Chorus Line. The Kleban prizes will be presented June 21 at a ceremony hosted by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

title: Night of Goodbyes
description: It was a night of farewells as Andrew Garcia and Katie Stevens failed to make the cut on a double-elimination episode of American Idol, and Ugly Betty showed its final original episode. American Idol was the nights big winner, drawing 20.6 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates and leading Fox to a first-place finish. On third-place ABC the finale of Ugly Betty (5.4 million) was up slightly over recent episodes of the series. CBS was the nights runner-up as its Criminal Minds (12.2 million) had no problem holding off Foxs Human Target (7.2 million). NBC ranked fourth for the night with a line-up of repeats.

title: Lincoln Center Plans a Musical Candida
description: A musical based on a George Bernard Shaw play? Its worked in the past. To a 2010-11 schedule that already includes a musical adaptation of Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown, the transfer of the life-size-puppet play War Horse and John Guares long-awaited Free Man of Color, Lincoln Center Theater has added a new musical based on Shaws Candida, the theater company said. The musical, called A Ministers Wife, tells the story of a minister and his wife, Candida, whose marriage is upended by a young poet; the adaptation is by Austin Pendelton (Orsons Shadow), with music by Josh Schmidt (Adding Machine) and lyrics by Jan Tranen (Night in Sarajevo). It will be directed by Michael Halberstam, the artistic director and a co-founder of the Writers Theater in Glencoe, Ill., where the musical had its debut last year. The Lincoln Center Theater production will begin previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater next April 7. A cast has not yet been announced.

title: Midsummer Swing Adds New Sounds
description: True to its name, there will be plenty of swing music this summer at Midsummer Night Swing, Lincoln Centers annual series of al fresco dancing. Its 22nd season opens on June 29 with a battle of the big bands between the George Gee Orchestra and the Bill Elliott Swing Orchestra, and the 15 nights in Damrosch Park also include various species of jazzy swing by the Time Jumpers (Western swing, July 1), the New Orleans Moonshiners (New Orleans jazz, July 6), the Wycliffe Gordon Sextet (straight-up jazz, July 10) and the Harlem Renaissance Orchestra on closing night (yet more big-band swing, July 17). But continuing the ever-more multicultural evolution of Lincoln Centers summer series, this years lineup also includes some notable new sounds, like the electronic tango of the Argentinean band narcotango (June 30), the Orchestre Septentrional dHaiti (July 2), a bhangra night with D.J. Rekha (July 8) and Afrobeat with Femi Kuti and Positive Force (July 12); the J C Hopkins Biggish Band will be joined by the drag virtuosos Justin Bond and Joey Arias as well as the comedian Lea DeLaria (July 7). Each show is preceded by a dance lesson.

title: Eminem Album Isnt Canceled, Just Renamed
description: When Eminem posted a message on Twitter Wednesday morning that read, There is no Relapse 2, most readers took it to mean that he would not release a follow-up to his 2009 album Relapse, the first he had put out since Encore in 2004. But a few hours later Eminem, right, set his loyal fans straight, posting a second message that said only RECOVERY, and directed followers to his Web site, eminem.com. There he said that his new album, Recovery, will be released on June 22 by Aftermath/Interscope Records and will feature contributions from producers like DJ Khalil, Just Blaze, Jim Jonsin and Boi-1da. In a statement Eminem said: I had originally planned for Relapse 2 to come out last year. But as I kept recording and working with new producers, the idea of a sequel to Relapse started to make less and less sense to me, and I wanted to make a completely new album. The music on Recovery came out very different from Relapse, and I think it deserves its own title.

title: S.B.A. Faces Potential Discrimination Trial
description: The Small Business Administration could be headed to court to defend itself against accusations of discrimination in its investment financing programs. On March 29, a federal judge in Washington ruled against the S.B.A.s motion for summary judgment in a lawsuit filed by a would-be venture capital fund. The fund, Diamond Ventures, which is based in Atlanta and run by two African-American men, planned to invest in poor, largely black communities in the Southeast.

title: Seeing Things | An Absolute Stitch
description: Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, a design writer and curator based in Los Angeles.Over the years I have amassed a small collection of vintage crewel kits designed by Erica Wilson, and have long wanted to meet the needlework legend. Last weekend, on a visit to Miami, I invited myself over to the 1960s apartment complex in Palm Beach, Fla., where Wilson spends the winters with her husband, the renowned  and charming  furniture designer Vladimir Kagan.

title: Outside of the Blue and Yellow Box
description: The Brooklyn neighborhood of Red Hook may be most famous these days for affordable Swedish design, but a group of artists is giving the once rough-and-tumble peninsula a softer, more creative edge. Their fondness for turning salvaged objects into objets dart makes the area feel like a small town of misfit toys, in one residents words, which might also serve to describe much of the creative class that now lives there. To reach these somewhat inaccessible streets, take the B61 bus to the Red Hook Ikea; the bus runs between Queens Plaza and Red Hook, stopping in Downtown Brooklyn near the Jay Street-Borough Hall subway stop (A, C, F lines) and near the Borough Hall stop (2, 3, 4, 5, M, R). Or take the water taxi to Ikea from Pier 11 near Wall Street.

title: Genzyme Drug Shortage Leaves Users Feeling Betrayed
description: Because of a drug factory shutdown, Jeannine Lipez of Lock Haven, Pa., says she can no longer even walk across the street without getting spasms in her left leg and will probably need an operation to replace an artery.

title: Raising the Bar
description: Anyone out there remember soap? The Samurai Shopper does, and admits a sentimental affection for soaps plain-Jane properties. Soap may not be the most voluptuous product youve ever used, but it is efficient, disposable, a marvel of minimalism. I, like many others, traded up to fancy-pants facial gels, foams and creams that smell expensive  and are. But washing with emulsions of Meyer lemon or fig makes me think: what do figs smell like anyway, and should I smell like one?

title: Decorative and Functional, Artistry From a Female Viewpoint
description: The American Folk Art Museum has an edge over other museums when it comes to collecting art made by women. Because many of its holdings fall outside the narrow scope of professional creativity, the usual biases of art history dont always apply.

title: Journal of the Plague Year
description: Prologue

title: Precious Drugs That Come at a Cost Few Can Afford to Meet
description: Genzymes close relationships with its patients has helped the company during the current product shortage, as many have considered switching to alternate drugs from Shire and Protalix Biotherapeutics that were made available even before they had regulatory approval.

title: How to Draw Time
description: Its only April, and my vote for the most beautiful book of the year may be all sewn up.

title: Tour-Worthy Milestone for Brazils Pop King
description: ROBERTO CARLOS has been so large a pop music presence for so long that when he first emerged he was nicknamed the Elvis Presley of Brazil and once opened a show there for Bill Haley and His Comets. But 50 years, 120 million records and various stylistic shifts later, he is more often described as the Frank Sinatra of Latin America.

title: Reach for the Song, You No-Good Lousy Varmint!
description: A little more garlic in the Bolognese would be a definite boon to Bloodsong of Love, a new musical subtitled The Rock n Roll Spaghetti Western. This small-scaled show at Ars Nova, with book, music and lyrics by Joe Iconis, isnt as pungent as its ripe title would suggest, and cant seem to decide whether to favor sincere homage or flippant parody.

title: Once Told He Would Never Play Again, Young Violinist Is Now a Star
description: Even under the best circumstances, it can be difficult for a prodigy to become a successful adult musician. When the violinist Augustin Hadelich, who had given his first concert at 7, was 15, he also had to contend with a terrible accident: he was badly burned when tractor fuel caught fire on his familys vineyard. Some doctors told him he would never play again, but he surmounted the odds to win the International Violin Competition of Indianapolis in 2006 and has become one of the most distinctive violinists of his generation.

title: Name of Driver in Pedestrian Death Matches That of Furniture Executive
description: As we reported earlier, a 65-year-old motorist named Harley Greenfield, of York Avenue on the Upper East Side, was charged with driving while impaired by alcohol after he struck and killed a man who was crossing the Whitestone Expressway in Queens on Wednesday night.

title: 12 Days, 132 Films, 38 Countries
description: Dont imagine that because its subject is 9/11, Alex Gibneys documentary My Trip to Al-Qaeda, is merely the latest in a long list of depressing films about the aftermath of that catastrophe. My Trip to Al-Qaeda, which exemplifies the loftiest ambitions of the Tribeca Film Festival, beginning its ninth year on Wednesday, is an utterly compelling (dare I say entertaining?) personal history lesson, filled with insights that come as little jolts.

title: Theater Listings: April 16  22
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Scenes From the Night Shift
description: As a photographer, I work the night shift  when daylight gives way to moonlight, neon, and street light. In cities, especially New York, the darkness awakens me in a way the light of day never can. Gradually, my insomniac wanderings have taken me to the more ambiguous, transitional zones of the city. And I am seeing these not in black and white, as I used to, but in color  as if the visual noise of daytime were transforming itself into haunting nocturnal tonalities.

title: New Taxes for Peggy Noonan
description: PEGGY NOONAN, a columnist at The Wall Street Journal, just bought an apartment on the Upper East Side for $1.72 million.

title: Taliban Seen Behind 2 Car Bomb Attacks in Downtown Kandahar
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Militants exploded two car bombs in downtown Kandahar on Thursday evening, killing at least 2 people and wounding 23, local officials said.

title: Strong Outing by Pelfrey Ends the Mets Losing Streak
description: DENVER  In the somber moments after another depressing defeat Wednesday night, David Wright stood at his locker and declared that the Mets had better start winning games soon, and it didnt matter how it happened. The Mets had just lost their fourth consecutive game and the fifth in their last six, and a hint of early desperation was noted.

title: A Historic Remodel
description: Nancy Smith and John Casey live in a red brick town house on 12th Street in the West Village with their daughters.

title: On Jackie Robinson Day, a Met Reflects
description: DENVER  When Gary Matthews Jr. was growing up at his fathers side in ballparks around the National League, he saw role models everywhere. There was his father, of course, and teammates and opponents such as Bobby Bonds, Joe Morgan, Dusty Baker and Willie McCovey.

title: Charter Extension Denied to Low-Scoring Stanford School
description: A charter school created and overseen by Stanford Universitys School of Education was denied an extension of its charter on Wednesday night after several members of the school board labeled it a failure.

title: Say Cheese to the Droid Incredible
description: HTC has designed a phone for people who like to take pictures with a phone. It has just announced the modestly named Droid Incredible, which pairs an 8 megapixel camera with a bright 3.7-inch AMOLED screen.

title: Trio Arrested in H.P. Case on Kickbacks
description: FRANKFURT  Authorities in Germany have arrested three people who worked for the Hewlett-Packard Company as part of an investigation into accusations that kickbacks were paid in connection with a contract to supply equipment to Russian law enforcement agencies, a prosecutors office said Thursday.

title: Cold Case, Warm Hearts: Death Leads to Romance
description: The past continually forces its way into the present in The Secret in Their Eyes, an attractive, messy drama riddled with violence and edged with comedy that comes with a hint of Grand Guignol, a suggestion of politics and three resonant, deeply appealing performances. Set primarily in contemporary Argentina with intermittent flashbacks to the 1970s when the country was descending into a military dictatorship, the film is by turns a whodunit (and why), a romance and something of a ghost story. A young dead woman lies at the center of the mystery, but shes scarcely the only thing here haunting the living.

title: Tulane: In M.&A. Talk, Strine Steals the Spotlight
description: 11:02 a.m. | CorrectedNEW ORLEANS  At Tulane Universitys Corporate Law Institute, its a fair bet that if Leo E. Strine Jr. is on your panel, he will inevitably make a few memorable remarks.

title: Former Clinton Counsel Forms Own Law Firm
description: Lanny J. Davis, a high-profile Washington lawyer who was the special counsel to President Bill Clinton in the 1990s, is leaving McDermott Will & Emery to form his own law firm. The new firm, Lanny J. Davis & Associates, will specialize in general litigation issues, media crisis and public policy issues.

title: Before the Doors Close, Delivering One Last Baby
description: It appears that little Abigail Yael Jancu will be able to claim her place in history from birth: the last baby born to the last Catholic hospital in New York City.

title: Geographical Me
description: My talk for the Association of American Geographers. (pdf)

title: Smurf House? Chinese Hat? Museum Intrigues
description: METZ, France  From afar, the new Pompidou museum in this postindustrial landscape resembles an enormous snow-white toadstool rising out of a wasteland.

title: River Surfing, Rugby Bonding and Bicycle Soaring
description: The connection between the Tribeca Film Festival and the sports cable network ESPN, now four years old, has brought the premieres of movies like David Mamets Redbelt and Spike Lees Kobe Doin Work to New York. This year the partnership is more noticeable than ever, as ESPNs 30 for 30 series of original documentaries has raised sports films to a new prominence.

title: Inside the List
description: YES HE CAN: The Bridge, David Remnicks biography of Barack Obama, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 3. Its Remnicks first appearance on the hardcover list, though he did notch one week on the paperback list in 1994 with Lenins Tomb, his Pulitzer Prize-winning account of the fall of the Soviet Union.

title: Weaknesses in the Strongest Teams
description: Zach Lowe writes for CelticsHub.com. He grew up in Connecticut watching the Bird-era Celtics with his father and hating Chuck Person. He now lives in Manhattan and dreams of a day in his adult lifetime when the Celtics and Knicks are both elite teams.

title: How to Prevent Adoption Disasters
description: Updated, April 16, 1:30 p.m. | Cynthia R. Mabry, a professor at Howard University School of Law, joins the discussion.

title: Details on the Tribeca Film Festival
description: The 2010 Tribeca Film Festival will begin on Wednesday and run through May 2, with screenings of 85 features and 47 short films at locations in Lower Manhattan. The festival will also include postscreening panel discussions and conversations with directors and actors, as well as free events like the Tribeca Drive-In, with outdoor screenings at the World Financial Center Plaza, North Cove, at 200 Vesey Street (Thursday to April 24, beginning at sundown with activities beginning earlier, at 6 p.m.). On May 1 there are several special events from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.: the Family Festival Street Fair, on Greenwich Street, between Chambers and Harrison Streets, and at the Tribeca Performing Arts Center, Borough of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street; and the Tribeca/ESPN Sports Day, on Duane Street, between Greenwich and Hudson Streets; and a display of contemporary artwork, at the Chanel Boutique, 134 Spring Street, SoHo.

title: Keep Your Team Out of My Book
description: Not long ago I began reading David Benioffs City of Thieves. The novel had come highly recommended to me by several friends, and as I had already seen Spike Lees excellent film 25th Hour, which is based on Benioffs first novel, I was really looking forward to reading the book.

title: Its a Bird, Its a Plane, Its a Blood Bath
description: A story about a teenager who yearns to be a superhero, and a little girl whos the star of her own splatter-happy head trip, the big-screen comic Kick-Ass could not be more calculating, or cynical. Fast, periodically spit-funny and often grotesquely violent, the film at once embraces and satirizes contemporary action-film clichs with Tarantino-esque self-regard  its the latest in giggles-and-guts entertainment.

title: Egypt: Mubarak Back at Work After Surgery
description: egyptbrf President Hosni Mubarak resumed his duties on Thursday, almost six weeks after undergoing an operation in Germany to remove his gallbladder and a benign growth. He led a meeting with several government ministers in Sharm El Sheikh, where he has been recuperating since his return to Egypt about three weeks ago. Mr. Mubarak, who turns 82 next month and has ruled Egypt for almost three decades, did not announce whether he planned to run for another term in the presidential election next year.

title: Up Front: Virginia Postrel
description: In this issue, the journalist Virginia Postrel reviews Sheena Iyengars book The Art of Choosing.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE BRIDGE: The Life and Rise of Barack Obama,  by David Remnick (Knopf, $29.95.) This study of Obama before he became president, by the editor of The New Yorker, has many important additions and corrections to make to our reading of Dreams From My Father.

title: France: Bin Laden Son Is Denied Visa
description: Omar bin Laden, the fourth son of Osama bin Laden, has been denied a visa to promote his new book in France and elsewhere in the European Union, his French publisher told Agence France-Presse on Thursday. The book, Osama bin Laden: A Family Portrait, denounces his father. The book was written with his mother, Najwa, 51, the first of Osama bin Ladens five wives, and the American journalist Jean Sasson, said a spokesman for the publisher, Denol.

title: Israel: Former Premier Is Suspect in New Inquiry
description: Former Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, who resigned after being accused in several corruption cases, is now a chief suspect in a major bribery investigation involving a West Jerusalem building project when he was mayor of the city, Israeli news media reported Thursday. Mr. Olmert denied any wrongdoing. I was never offered a bribe and have never received a bribe from anybody for anything in any way, either directly or indirectly, he said in a televised statement.

title: Obamas Report Earnings of $5.5 Million in 2009
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and his wife, Michelle, reported earnings of $5,505,509 in 2009, more than double their 2008 income of roughly $2.6 million, according to tax returns made public on Thursday by the White House.

title: Cuomos State Pension Inquiry Extends to the Current Comptrollers Office
description: The sprawling investigation into the state pension fund has reached the office of the current state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, the attorney generals office acknowledged on Thursday.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,029 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Truth, Fiction and Tribeca
description: Stephen Holden narrates a look at some of the films appearing in the 2010 Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Tax Day Outside New Yorks Main Post Office: Now, Thats Entertainment
description: In The Hunchback of Notre Dame, Victor Hugo had his cour des miracles, the courtyard of miracles. It was a gathering place for all sorts: musicians, mendicants, hucksters and peddlers, including some whose stock in trade was salvation.

title: Lawyer to Put $2 Million Into Attorney Generals Race
description: Sean Coffey, a prominent trial lawyer who is one of the many Democratic candidates for state attorney general, will invest $2 million of his own money in his campaign, he said in an interview on Thursday.

title: More Households Getting Federal Help
description: One in four households received government benefits in the third-quarter of 2008 because their income and assets fell below the federal threshold during the economic downturn, the Census Bureau said Thursday. Between May and November 2008, the percentage receiving any so-called means-tested benefit rose to 24.7 percent from 23.2 percent. The share collecting food stamps climbed to 8.8 percent from 7.6 percent and the proportion receiving Medicaid increased to 18.5 percent from 17.5 percent.

title: Graying in a Home, Not an Institution
description: BALDWIN, N.Y.

title: Paperback Row
description: COLUMBINE,  by Dave Cullen (Twelve, $15.99.) Everything you think you know about the Columbine High School massacre of April 20, 1999, is wrong. The shooters, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, were not victims of bullying. They did not belong to a goth Trench Coat Mafia. They did not single out blacks or Christians or athletes. Eric Harris was a psychopath, simple as that, our reviewer, Jennifer Senior, reported. Dylan Klebold was a suicidally depressed kid who yoked his fate to a sadist. This book by Cullen, who as a reporter in Denver covered the story for Salon and Slate, is a fine example of old-fashioned journalism, Senior said.

title: Truths and Parables
description: To the Editor:

title: New Normal as Woods Sends Early R.S.V.P.
description: By announcing his return to a PGA Tour event two weeks beforehand, Tiger Woods appears to be sending a message that he is serious about sorting out the problems in his game  and is ready to face golf fans at an event that is open to the ticket-buying public  well before the United States Open in June at Pebble Beach.

title: Massachusetts: Expansion of Gambling Advances
description: In an about-face from two years ago, the Massachusetts House voted Wednesday to expand gambling, arguing that building two casinos and adding slot machines at four racetracks could create jobs. It is not clear whether the Senate and Gov. Deval Patrick, a Democrat, will go along with what would be the biggest expansion of gambling since the state introduced the lottery in 1971; Senate leaders and the governor oppose slot machines. The House vote is a sharp reversal from its vote in 2008 under a different House speaker. Wednesdays vote was the result of a tour-de-force by Speaker Robert A. DeLeo, who has two racetracks in his district.

title: Vietnam Novels
description: To the Editor:

title: Wyoming: Ex-Radical Sues Over College Speech
description: William Ayers, the 1960s radical and current professor of education at the University of Illinois at Chicago, filed a federal lawsuit on Thursday against the University of Wyoming over its decision to bar him from speaking there. Mr. Ayers, a founder of the Weather Underground, was invited by the universitys Social Justice Research Center, which canceled his appearance last month. Tom Buchanan, university president, cited controversy over Mr. Ayers planned appearance and also safety concerns. A student tried to reserve a campus site for Mr. Ayers, but the university rejected that idea as well.

title: Wisconsin: Ex-Governor Wont Face Feingold
description: Former Gov. Tommy G. Thompson said Thursday that he would not run against Senator Russ Feingold this year. My family didnt want me to run, Mr. Thompson, a Republican, told The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel just before he gave a speech to Tea Party supporters gathered at the State Capitol in Madison. Mr. Thompson, who served from 1987 to 2001, had been a popular governor, and talk of his potential candidacy had bolstered Republicans hopes of taking the seat from Mr. Feingold, a Democrat seeking his fourth term.

title: Perception and Distortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Subpoenas Sought for Information on Shootings
description: Top-ranking senators on the Homeland Security panel said Thursday that they would subpoena the Pentagon and the Justice Department if they did not provide more information by Monday on the shootings that left 13 people dead last year at Fort Hood in Texas. A Pentagon spokesman said the department recognized the committees interests, but had a responsibility to investigate and prosecute the shooting suspect, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, in a way that preserves the judicial process.

title: Twitter Loses Its Scrappy Start-Up Status
description: Twitters first developer conference, held this week in San Francisco, served as a coming-out party for the four-year-old service. Twitter the start-up is becoming Twitter the big company, with more polish, controversy, competition and revenue.

title: Indecision-Making
description: Sheena Iyengar is the psychologist responsible for the famous jam experiment. You may have heard about it: At a luxury food store in Menlo Park, researchers set up a table offering samples of jam. Sometimes, there were six different flavors to choose from. At other times, there were 24. (In both cases, popular flavors like strawberry were left out.) Shoppers were more likely to stop by the table with more flavors. But after the taste test, those who chose from the smaller number were 10 times more likely to actually buy jam: 30 percent versus 3 percent. Having too many options, it seems, made it harder to settle on a single selection.

title: A Portrait of the Tea Party Supporters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Endless Prom, and an Attempt to Curb It
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Crisis Panel
description: To the Editor:

title: Waiving Oil Royalties
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank Troubles in Georgia
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviewing Mine Safety, Obama Faults Company and the Government
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday ordered a fresh round of coal mine inspections and a far-reaching review of mine safety, and said the federal government was partly to blame for the explosion that claimed 29 lives at the Upper Big Branch mine in West Virginia this month.

title: A Baseball Story
description: The Perfect Game, about a ragtag Mexican team that improbably wins the Little League World Series, is so overwhelmed by its own based-on-actual-events tale that it cant find the tone to tell it effectively. From start to finish you can almost hear William Dear, the director, and W. William Winokur, the first-time screenwriter, screaming: Wow! Isnt this a dandy story? So lets throw in every gimmick we can think of  coldhearted father, tentative romance, tidy lessons in racism and sexism, cruel authority figures, labored catchphrases  to make sure everyone realizes what a dandy story it is. Just let the kids play, for cryin out loud.

title: And Now, a State Microbe
description: There it was, amid the long list of crucial bills that state legislators in Wisconsin were racing to vote on before their session ends next week: A bill to select the states official microbe. Yes, microbe.

title: Imam and Informant Tells Why He Lied
description: He had built a life in this country. He grew up in Queens, attended high school there, and became a religious leader in his community. He would marry and marry again, have children, and buy a plot nearby where he planned to be buried.

title: Interview: Bahman Ghobadi
description: Bahman Ghobadi discusses the legal perils of shooting a party scene in his film about rock musicians in Iran.

title: Ohio Lawmakers Have Tax Day Tussle
description: Tax Day has been known to make people cranky. And relations between members of the two parties in Washington can get a bit tense.

title: Arrested in Shoeshine Arsons, and Back Out Shining Shoes
description: The gentlest-looking person on an otherwise sharp-elbowed stretch of 42nd Street on Thursday seemed to be a short, sweet-faced man of 71 years, hunched over a little wooden shoeshine box.

title: Obama Vows Renewed Space Program
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  Pointing to Mars and asteroids as destinations, President Obama on Thursday forcefully countered criticisms that he was trying to end the nations human spaceflight program.

title: Where Historys March Is a Funeral Procession
description: Wroclaw, Poland

title: Attacks on Military Computers Cited
description: WASHINGTON  Computer networks essential to the Pentagon and military are attacked by individual hackers, criminal groups and nations hundreds of thousands of times every day, according to the officer nominated to lead a cyberwarfare command.

title: Polish Heroes, Polish Victims
description: Warsaw

title: Walsh and Knicks Cannot Wait for Summer Sales Pitch
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The payroll is clear, the roster is nearly empty and the pain is subsiding. All the Knicks need now is a clever sales pitch and a willing savior.

title: The Devastating Legacy of Thalidomide
description: How rare is it to discover a documentary about disability that scorns differently abled euphemisms and rhapsodies of inner beauty? Rare enough to make NoBodys Perfect an exemplar of fresh-air filmmaking that addresses the devastating legacy of the drug thalidomide with acidic wit and grumpy honesty.

title: With Tax Day as Theme, Tea Party Groups Demonstrate
description: WASHINGTON  Tea Party groups used Tax Day Thursday to stage rallies around the country where they pledged to turn their nascent movement into a powerful force to root out politicians they do not consider fiscally responsible.

title: A Reprieve for Some Who Receive Housing Aid
description: Some of the 10,000 low-income families in danger of losing the rental assistance they get through a voucher program will probably keep receiving it, thanks to $23.5 million that the New York City Housing Authority is to receive from the federal government, officials said Thursday.

title: Schools Out! (Temporarily); The Auditorium Collapsed
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y.  Students were expecting a tough week here at Mount Vernon High School, trying not to fall apart as they slogged through third-quarter exams and prepared for Advanced Placement exams and Regents tests.

title: A Tale of Two Volcanoes
description: Sandisfield, Mass.

title: 3 Tales on Disappearance of Gay Porn Star
description: The title alone should guarantee an audience of the curious, but despite marvelously moody visuals and a tantalizing setup, Pornography: A Thriller finally puzzles more than it pleases.

title: Continental and United Resume Talks to Merge
description: When the music stopped on Thursday in the airline industrys game of musical chairs, Continental Airlines and United Airlines were back in talks again, and US Airways was still trying to grab a seat.

title: Obama Widens Medical Rights for Gay Partners
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday ordered his health secretary to issue new rules aimed at granting hospital visiting rights to same-sex partners.

title: U.N. Report Finds Faults in Pakistani Bhutto Inquiry
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A United Nations investigation into the assassination of the former opposition leader Benazir Bhutto has concluded that the failure of Pakistani authorities to effectively investigate the killing was deliberate and had been severely hampered by the countrys powerful intelligence agencies.

title: The Fire Next Time
description: On Tuesday, Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader, called for the abolition of municipal fire departments.

title: Blackhawks Enter N.H.L. Playoffs With Many Stars, Just Not in Goal
description: The Chicago Blackhawks have spent a great deal of money locking in some of the leagues best young talent, but they enter the playoffs having to rely on an untested goalie they acquired on the cheap.

title: In a First, 2 British Leaders Vying to Be the Premier Debate, but a Third Face Shines
description: LONDON  The Times of London described it as the moment when presidential politics arrive in Britain, and ran a grainy front-page photograph of John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon in Chicago in 1960 in the first televised American presidential election debate.

title: Children Left Behind
description: A mind-numbing barrage of random television clips and trash-talking heads, The Cartel purports to be a documentary about the American public school system. In reality, however, its a bludgeoning rant against a single state  New Jersey  which it presents as a closed loop of Mercedes-owning administrators, obstructive teachers unions and corrupt school boards.

title: Recalling 95 Bombing, Clinton Sees Parallels
description: WASHINGTON  With the 15th anniversary of the Oklahoma City bombing approaching, former President Bill Clinton on Thursday drew parallels between the antigovernment tone that preceded that devastating attack and the political tumult of today, saying government critics must be mindful that angry words can stir violent actions.

title: C.I.A. Document Details Destruction of Tapes
description: WASHINGTON  Porter J. Goss, the former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, in 2005 approved of the decision by one of his top aides to destroy dozens of videotapes documenting the brutal interrogation of two detainees, according to an internal C.I.A. document released Thursday.

title: Fighting Foreclosures
description: From the start, the central concern about President Obamas antiforeclosure effort has been that it would postpone foreclosures but ultimately not prevent enough to ease the economic strain from mass defaults. That concern seems increasingly justified.

title: Fifth Avenue and the Pent-up Urge
description: Wall Street analysts, commenting on positive retail sales numbers, have lately used the term that theyve beat expectations. This is a little like a mother saying of her new son-in-law, Hes not the handsomest, but hes nice. Yes, most department stores and specialty retailers like H & M saw decent sales gains for March. In Paris, LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton reported an 11 percent quarterly increase. But this was after a not-so-pretty 2009. And several luxury companies, including LVMH, continue to express caution about the rest of the year. Many people are still out of work, or finding work that pays less.

title: Florida Governor Splits With G.O.P. on Teacher Pay
description: MIAMI  Gov. Charlie Crist has been jawboned and buttonholed as he has traveled around the state in recent days, and his office was deluged with 120,000 messages. Passions have not run so high in Florida, the governor said, since the controversy over ending the life of Terri Schiavo in 2005.

title: Spying, Civil Liberties and the Courts
description: Succumbing to the politics of fear during the 2008 campaign, Congress seriously diluted the First and Fourth Amendment rights of Americans by changing the 1978 law that governs electronic surveillance.

title: City Unemployment Rate Dropped to 10% in March
description: New York Citys unemployment rate declined again in March, falling to 10 percent and lending support to the view that the recession caused by the financial crisis is winding down.

title: Housing Plan Survives For St. Vincents Site
description: As officials and physicians plod through the logistics and heartache of closing one of the citys major hospitals, preservationists and developers are preoccupied with another issue: Will the St. Vincents Hospital campus be turned into luxury apartment buildings?

title: After Their Arrival
description: More than half of the working immigrants in the St. Louis area hold higher-paying white collar jobs  Here, four men and women from across the world and the economic spectrum tell their stories coming to this metropolitan area.

title: The Gun Lobbys Colony
description: Cravenness and horse trading are too often the political reality in Washington, but a deal now in the works is particularly cruel.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 15, 2010

title: Work Force Fueled by Highly Skilled Immigrants
description: ST. LOUIS  After a career as a corporate executive with her name in brass on the office door, Amparo Kollman-Moore, an immigrant from Colombia, likes to drive a Jaguar and shop at Saks. It was a good life, she said, a really good ride.

title: Another Trump Hopes What Glitters Will Be Gold
description: OF all the shiny things in Donald and Melania Trumps dining room on the 66th floor of Trump Tower  the gold panes on the floor-to-ceiling windows, the gold candelabra, the gold-toned mirrors etched with gold  the most distracting may be Mrs. Trump herself. Wearing black J Brand skinny jeans, a white Dolce & Gabbana blouse and select items from her soon-to-be-introduced jewelry line, Mrs. Trump is every bit the lithe, shimmering beauty that her modeling photos suggest.

title: Band on the Run, Filmed on the Fly
description: Negar and Ashkan are two young people  its possible that theyre a couple, but you cant quite be sure  who want to start a band. The style they favor is what they call indie rock, an apt enough designation for the sweet, moody songs they perform together, which would not sound out of place on the soundtrack of a movie at the Sundance Film Festival.

title: A Newspaper Leaves Behind Its City Roots
description: ATLANTA  When The Atlanta Journal-Constitution moves into its new home next week, its employees will have access to free parking, more natural light and a wide variety of retail, service and dining options at Perimeter Mall, according to a memorandum from the newspapers publisher, Michael Joseph.

title: In Playoffs, Even the Best Have Room to Improve
description: No N.B.A. team is perfect. Even the best struggle with elements of the game, either because they de-emphasize them or because theyre just not very good at them. This can be magnified if it costs a team a victory during the playoffs. So here are elements the top four teams may want to work on now that the postseason has arrived.

title: Women Who May Make People Break Up
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  I love clues like Company with the stock symbol DPZ. Im sure there are a few day traders out there who knew that answer immediately but for most of us, its the kind of clue that seems impossible at first. Hmmm. It probably starts with D. But what is that PZ all about? I bet it only took you a few seconds. Same with the 2006 Rihanna song ___ Been the One. I dont know who Rihanna is but by applying a little standard crossword logic, I was able to fill the blank from just the first letter. How about that novel with the chapter Farming in Polynesia? Youve never read that book but if youve been doing crosswords for a while, you filled in that four-letter answer immediately. Does this mean crosswords are making us smarter? Or just filling our heads with useless trivia? Either way, its fun.

title: Now Its the Presidents Plan
description: When it was unveiled  in budget documents  in February, we thought President Obamas new approach to human space flight made good sense. But it drew immediate, fierce opposition from states that feared they would lose jobs and from Congressional boosters of the traditional space program.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with the continuation of a news analysis article about a shift in the Obama administrations Middle East policy referred incorrectly to Ramat Shlomo, the name of a Jewish housing development that Israel says it is expanding despite objections by the United States and the Palestinian Authority. It is a neighborhood in East Jerusalem, not a settlement in the West Bank.

title: President Signs Bill to Extend Jobless Aid
description: WASHINGTON  Congress on Thursday approved legislation that would keep unemployment checks flowing to jobless Americans, and President Obama immediately signed it.

title: B.Y.U. Womens Rugby Team Will Forfeit if It Reaches Sunday Game
description: The women on Brigham Young Universitys club rugby team had every reason to expect that they would make it to the quarterfinals of the national college playoffs this weekend in Florida and California.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about high interest rates and fees on small loans to poor people misstated the annualized interest rate paid by Rosa Gonzalez Abad, a borrower in Mexico City shown in the photograph. While analysts have calculated that Compartamos, Ms. Abads lender, charged an average of nearly 82 percent in interest and fees in 2008, the most recent year available, Ms. Abad said she was not sure that was her own annualized rate.

title: Chinas Recovery Keeps Focus on Interest Rates and Currency
description: BEIJING  Chinas accelerating economic recovery without signs yet of a surge in inflation may give the government some leeway in making two crucial decisions: raising interest rates and revaluing the Chinese currency.

title: Debt Worries Shift to Portugal, Spurred by Rising Bond Rates
description: LONDON  Next target: Portugal.

title: Genteel Lives Unsettled in Uruguay
description: The City of Your Final Destination is as pure an example of the Merchant Ivory brand of upscale literary cinema as devotees of Howards End, A Room With a View and The Remains of the Day could ask for. But times have changed. Partly because the rarefied aesthetic climes conjured by the film barely exist anymore, its story feels as quaint as the once-vital Merchant Ivory ethos of hothouse nostalgia  with its antique-shop sensibility and Anglo-European snob appeal  does.

title: Back (Way Back) to Drinkings Basics
description: Theres no greater confirmation that the age of the byzantine cocktail and its apron-clad ministers has mellowed than the fact that the long-awaited bar from the mix maestros Jeff Hollinger and Jonny (Flash) Raglin will de-emphasize cocktails.

title: Despite Budget Woes, University Still Has Money for Bottled Water
description: Times are tough at the University of California. The states budget crisis has led to cuts, layoffs and higher student fees.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 2 about Irans influence on the political groupings in Iraq that emerged after the March 7 elections misidentified the holiday celebration in Tehran attended by top officials of three major Iraqi political alliances on March 27. As noted elsewhere in the article, it was for the Persian new year, which always begins on the first day of spring  not the Islamic new year, which follows a lunar calendar and shifts each year. (The most recent Islamic new year holiday was on Dec. 18, 2009.)

title: Rooney Says Steelers Are Prepared to Issue Roethlisbergers Discipline
description: As more troubling details about Ben Roethlisbergers encounter with a 20-year-old college student in a Georgia bar emerged Thursday, the Pittsburgh Steelers president, Art Rooney II, said the Steelers would move forward with Roethlisberger at quarterback and would prefer to discipline him themselves.

title: Being Forced to Make Do
description: Most of the Bay Areas nine counties and their major cities are wrestling with multimillion-dollar deficits and draconian cuts. The required reductions come at a time when they have been hit by revenue losses and the state has contributed many millions less.

title: Remaking an Ancient Farce From 2007
description: An effective farce is a comic contraption that largely runs on its own crude mechanics. The surprises and sight gags, however they are discharged, are more important than the actors and the direction.

title: Washington, With Few Options, Signs New Jets Deal
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Leon Washington, the electrifying back who looked as if he might make an off-season getaway from the Jets, let everyone know on Thursday that he wore Jets gear as he worked out in Florida while he recovered from a leg injury that ended his 2009 season.

title: Postscript
description: NATIONAL

title: Air Travel Chaos Deepens Into Weekend
description: This article is by Alan Cowell, Liz Robbins and Nicola Clark.

title: F.D.A. Again Warns a Generic Maker About Conditions at Its Plants
description: Federal regulators have raised another red flag about the quality of generic drugs, sending a warning letter to a leading maker about manufacturing violations.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Days Of Tea And Wine
description: I just had dinner in DC with a bunch of geographers, at a cute French bistro near Dupont Circle. And who should walk in but about eight tea partiers, still carrying their protest signs. They marched in, then upstairs, and sat down for dinner.

title: On the Street, at the Corner of Art and Trash
description: There is something indescribably odd about Thierry Guetta, the antic Frenchman and Ron Jeremy lookalike who guides our experience  and would like to guide our perceptions  of Exit Through the Gift Shop.

title: On Robinson Day, a Namesake Is the Star
description: Like every player in the major leagues on Thursday, Robinson Cano wore on his back the number 42 to honor Jackie Robinson, who broke baseballs color barrier in 1947.

title: For Bulls, the Playoffs Are Just a Band-Aid
description: A general managers going for his coachs throat is pretty radical behavior, even by the laissez-faire standards of a league that includes gun-carrying Gilbert Arenas and the unfailingly bizarre Ron Artest, among others.

title: Agencies Are Stretched in Efforts to Aid Refugees
description: The hum of sewing machines echoed through the basement of the United Church of Rogers Park on a recent Friday morning. Refugee women from Bhutan, Iraq, Myanmar, Somalia, Eritrea and Ethiopia sat at the machines, exchanging smiles and nods, but few words.

title: City Treasurer Threatens Defamation Suit Over Policemans Articles
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley grudgingly bears the news medias tendency to scrooten him constantly. Stephanie D. Neely, the first-term city treasurer, is taking a different approach to dealing with scrutiny from at least one pen-wielding critic. She retained a lawyer and is threatening a defamation suit against a Chicago police officer who repeatedly criticized her in the F.O.P. News, a union newsletter published by the local Fraternal Order of Police.

title: A Lawmakers Vacation, Learning by Doing
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: A Sexual Advance, a Savage Beating, Years of Guilt
description: The protagonist of Handsome Harry, Bette Gordons pungently didactic critique of the masculine mystique among American men of a certain age and generation, is an electrician in his early 50s who still has a roguish glint in his eye. The divorced father of a grown son with whom he has a distant relationship, Harry Sweeney (Jamey Sheridan) still walks with the swagger of an aging rou who knows he is catnip to women over 40 and has no need for Viagra. But in a confessional moment, he candidly admits he has been very busy being a failure.

title: Big Leveraged Buyouts May Soon Make a Comeback
Now G.I. Jane Is Somebodys Mom
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, CALIF.

title: Buy, Buy, Buy, to Keep Up With the You-Know-Whos
description: As glossy and golden-tinged as a magazine advertisement spread, The Joneses proposes itself, at least at first, as a satire of modern consumerism. Members of the titular family, a foursome with perfect teeth, lithe bodies and limitless sex appeal, dont just embody a sleek and seamless ideal of material comfort and aesthetic perfection. They also sell that ideal, with an aggression that is no less ruthless for being invisible.

title: A.M.D. Posts Profit as Sales Rise by 34%
description: Advanced Micro Devices, the microprocessor maker, reported first-quarter sales on Thursday that beat analysts predictions, adding to evidence that personal computer demand was increasing.

title: Reyess Moving Problem
description: DENVER  Jerry Manuel said on Thursday that he basically cant wait to put Jose Reyes in the third spot in the batting order, but at least one player is skeptical about the Mets plan, and its not even Jose Reyes.

title: Central Bank in Europe Sees a Crisis Returning
description: The European Central Bank warned Thursday that a resurgence of enormous trade imbalances and growing government debt were creating a volatile mix that could ignite new economic turmoil.

title: Veteran Experiences His First Yankees Roll Call
description: Randy Winn played as a substitute in seven of the Yankees first eight games but made his first start Thursday night in the third game of a three-game series against the Los Angeles Angels at Yankee Stadium.

title: Paroled Murderer Shoots His Parole Officer at His Desk in Brooklyn
description: A paroled murderer walked up to his parole officer in a state office in Downtown Brooklyn on Thursday evening and shot him in the shoulder, the authorities said.

title: U.S. Clears Boston Scientific to Resume Defibrillator Sales
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation said Thursday that the Food and Drug Administration was allowing it to resume defibrillator sales after a one-month halt caused by the companys failure to notify regulators about manufacturing changes to the devices.

title: What Were Reading: Opera on the iPhone
description: The tech reporters and editors of The New York Times watched the sales of a rival to Apples Safari and saw a backlash against Apples ad strategy begin to brew. Then there was that warning about a solar flare and electronic equipment. Our reading list:

title: Critics' Picks: 'Brazil'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Terry Gilliam's sprawling dystopian science fiction film about repression.

title: Venture Capitalists Continue to Take It Slow
description: The venture capital industry seems to need a bit longer to recover after last year, when Silicon Valley froze in response to the economic uncertainty.

title: Word of the Day | mote
description: mote \mot\ noun

title: Senate G.O.P. Leader Calls on Party to Stop Fiscal Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, labored on Thursday to unite his caucus in opposition to legislation to tighten regulation of the nations financial system, as Democrats expressed dismay that Republicans were threatening not only to vote against the bill but to block the start of floor debate.

title: Viewing Baseball Through a Prism of the Numbers
description: Sean Forman is the creator of Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues.

title: U.S. Nuclear Threat
description: Conventional wisdom is that the Cold War danger nuclear missile strikes has given way to a new threat: nuclear devices in the hands of terrorists.

title: Finance Bill Consensus on a Point: No Bailouts
description: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration and Senate Republicans clash over the future of the nations financial regulatory system, there is one principle on which they agree: Taxpayers should never again have to bail out giant financial institutions.

title: Eve of Destruction
description: Eighteen months after the failure of Lehman Brothers, writers seeking to make sense of the debacle have had their say: the first responders and e-booksters, the polemicists and shoe-leather reporters, the boardroom whisperers and I-told-you-so scolds, the would-be screenwriters and former policy makers. For those fortunate enough to be on the receiving end of publishers entreaties, a certain amount of Panic of 2008 fatigue has set in. Ive read at least five times that the JPMorgan Chase chief executive Jamie Dimons 52nd-birthday dinner at the midtown Greek restaurant Avra was interrupted by a call about Bear Stearnss travails.

title: Charter Extension for Stanfords School Denied and Highlights from Fridays Bay Area Pages
description: Stanford Charter School Faces Closure | A charter school created and overseen by Stanford Universitys School of Education was denied an extension of its charter on Wednesday night after several members of the school board labeled it a failure. Last month, the state had placed the charter school, Stanford New School, on its list of persistently lowest-achieving schools.

title: Human Orbits
description: According to the perverse aesthetics of artistic guilty pleasure, certain books and movies are so bad  so crudely conceived, despicably motivated and atrociously executed  that theyre actually rather good. Solar, the new novel by Ian McEwan, is just the opposite: a book so good  so ingeniously designed, irreproachably high-minded and skillfully brought off  that its actually quite bad. Instead of being awful yet absorbing, its impeccable yet numbing, achieving the sort of superbly wrought inertia of a Romanesque cathedral. Theres so little wrong with it that theres nothing particularly right about it, either. Its impressive to behold but something of a virtuous pain to read.

title: Oscar Tuazon: My Flesh to Your Bare Bones
description: Oscar Tuazons latest solo is really a duet, in the key of postminimalism. Mr. Tuazon, a sculptor who tends to evoke collapsed or ruined architecture, has come up with a fine-tuned and personal response to a piece by Vito Acconci. It combines sound with fragmentary sculpture, both haunting.

title: Self-Fulfilling Prophecies
description: Self-Fulfilling Prophecies, a group show of 18 artists ranging in age from the high 20s to the low 60s, broadcasts an undeniable cheer about arts current condition. An in-house job organized by Leo Koenig along with Elizabeth Balogh and Nicole Russo, the gallerys directors, it is selective without being narrow, inclusive without being lax. It doesnt attempt to account for everything, but it also doesnt make whats missing feel left out. Irony abounds, and language is often a primary weapon, but strong emotions surge beneath. Parodies are parried; homage is paid, differences illuminated.

title: Eva Hesse
description: Eva Hesses name still has magic, because of her radical and influential art and because of the short time she was given to make it, about a decade before her death in 1970 at the age of 34.

title: Shirley Jaffe: Selected Paintings 1969-2009
description: Freud contended that everything means something or nothing does, and Shirley Jaffe, an American painter in her 80s who has lived in Paris since 1949, would seem to agree.

title: Freddie Brice
description: Using wide brushes and mostly black and white house paint on thin pieces of plywood, Freddie Brice made paintings notable for their spontaneity, economy of means and comical, enigmatic imagery. Born in South Carolina in 1920, he moved to Harlem at 9, and he began painting in his early 60s at an art workshop after years of incarceration and psychiatric institutionalization. There is a childlike immediacy and simplicity about his self-taught style, a directness that appeals to eyes trained by Modernist painting. One magical picture is nothing but a white-spotted black snake about to bite its own tail. It seems unlikely that Mr. Brice would have known that this image  the uroboros  is frequently encountered in antique, mystical tomes.

title: News Quiz | April 16, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Navigating the U.C. Budget, Without Maps
description: For this weeks column, I ventured into the labyrinth of the University of Californias budget. Or, to be more accurate, I tried to do so. I couldnt get very far on my own, which raises questions about the transparency of the universitys finances.

title: Macarthur to Hold Talks With Peabody
description: The Australian mining company Macarthur Coal, which for weeks has been the object of an intensifying takeover battle, on Friday said it would enter discussions with one the bidders, Peabody Energy, a United States company that earlier this week sweetened its offer to $3.8 billion, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

title: Rare Finance Bill Consensus: No Bailouts
description: As the Obama administration and Senate Republicans clash over the future of the financial regulatory system, there is one principle on which they agree: Taxpayers should never again have to bail out giant financial institutions, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: Protest Leaders Elude Capture by Thai Commandos
description: BANGKOK  In a new humiliation for the Thai government, several leaders of the red-shirt protest movement escaped from a hotel on Friday after it had been surrounded by security forces  even as a deputy prime minister was announcing the raid live on television.

title: Senate G.O.P. Leader Calls on Party to Stop Fiscal Bill
description: The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, labored on Thursday to unite his caucus in opposition to legislation to tighten regulation of the nations financial system, as Democrats expressed dismay that Republicans were threatening not only to vote against the bill, but to block the start of floor debate, David M. Herszenhorn reports in The New York Times.

title: A Sacred Bath
description: WHO bathed in the Ganges river in India this week?

title: Twitter Loses Its Scrappy Start-Up Status
