description: Twitters first developer conference, held this week in San Francisco, served as a coming-out party for the four-year-old service. Twitter the start-up is becoming Twitter the big company, with more polish, controversy, competition and revenue.

title: Towns in Europe Learn About Swaps the Hard Way
description: The worst global financial crisis in 70 years arrived in Saint-tienne, France, this month, as embedded financial obligations began to blow up, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Venture Capitalists Continue to Take It Slow
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: Norris: Low Rates Good for Banks, but Pity the Saver
description: Arent low short-term interest rates wonderful? If you are a bank, the answer is yes, particularly because the low rates are accompanied by somewhat higher longer-term rates. If you are a saver, however, your view might be very different, Floyd Norris writes in his latest column in The New York Times.

title: Polish Insurer May Set Price Near $3.5 Billion
description: PZU Group, Polands largest insurer, will set on Monday the maximum price for individual investors in what is expected to be Europes largest initial public offering worth up to $3.5 billion, Reuters reported.

title: The Ermintrude Effect
description: The fear of looking like a ruminant when eating watercress.(Ermintrude is a cow in the psychedelic childrens television animation, The Magic Roundabout.)

title: U.S. Team Is Named
description: Two Rangers and two Islanders were among 12 players named to the United States team for the I.I.H.F. world championships in Germany next month. Forwards Brandon Dubinsky of the Rangers and Kyle Okposo of the Islanders and defensemen Matt Gilroy of the Rangers and Jack Hillen of the Islanders were among the selections.

title: N.F.L. Wins Ruling Over Revenue Sharing
description: The N.F.L. won a labor skirmish when the special master Stephen Burbank upheld the implementation of the supplemental revenue-sharing program adopted with the 2006 collective bargaining agreement.

title: What is Your Reaction to the News About International Adoption?
description: Russia has suspended international adoptions by Americans in response to the case of a 7-year-old boy who was sent back to Moscow alone last week by his adoptive mother in Tennessee. Have you been following this news? What is your reaction?

title: At Coachella, California and Veteran Musicans Provide Roots
description: INDIO, Calif.  Even in the age of YouTube and Webcasts, a rock festival is the essence of a site-specific event, a convergence of geography, demographics, weather, booking and people bumping into you. The 11th Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, here at the Empire Polo Field this weekend, flaunts its location in the California desert  its small stages are named Gobi, Mojave and Sahara  and usually has a well-styled Hollywood contingent in the V.I.P. zone.

title: Idex Nabs Seals Ltd. for $54 Million
description: Idex, a maker of pumps and metering products, said Thursday it bought Seals Ltd., a provider of seals for a broad range of industries like semiconductor and solar technologies, for about 35 million ($54 million), The Associated Press reported.

title: Trio Arrested in H.P. Case on Kickbacks
description: Authorities in Germany have arrested three people who worked for the Hewlett-Packard Company as part of an investigation into accusations that kickbacks were paid in connection with a contract to supply equipment to Russian law enforcement agencies, The New York Timess Jack Ewing reported.

title: Are Big L.B.O.s Set for a Comeback?
description: The next $10 billion leveraged buyout may be just around the corner, Reuters Breakingviews says.

title: Citic Suspends Shares for Important Talks
description: Citic Securities, Chinas largest brokerage by market value, suspended trading of its shares in Shanghai, saying it is holding important discussions, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Pension Corp., a British Insurer, Is Said to Diversify
description: Pension Corporation, the specialist insurer, is making a first foray into real estate and has raised its exposure tohedge funds as part of a broad effort to diversify a largely fixed-income and cash-oriented strategy, Reuters reported.

title: China Bank Thinks It Can Get $30 Billion in I.P.O.,
description: Agricultural Bank of China, the nations third-largest lender by assets, plans to attempt what could be the biggest initial public offering in history by July, people with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News.

title: 2 Charged in Tax Evasion Scheme Involving HSBC
description: Federal authorities arrested two property developers, a father and son, on Thursday and charged them with participating in a multimillion-dollar tax evasion scheme through a large international bank, The New York Timess Lynnley Browning reported.

title: In Tajikistan, Women Fill a Void
description: Mashid Mohadjerin was 8 years old when she and her family left their home in Iran after the revolution. She still remembers the sadness of leaving and the awkwardness of learning life in a new country. First, it was adjusting to Pakistan. Then, a year later, it was acclimating to Belgium. Now, at 33, Ms. Mohadjerin says she feels as if she has found her place as a resident New Yorker.

title: Goldman-Backed Whitehall Said to Lose 98 Percent
description: Whitehall Street International, the real estate investment fund that counts Goldman Sachs as its largest investor, has seen almost all of its $1.8 billion of equity go up in smoke, The Financial Times reported.

title: Reader Photos: Print Mixing, Worn Well
description: We asked readers for photos of examples of mixed prints, done well. Heres a gallery of submissions.

title: Some Funds Unwind Short Bets on Wheat
description: Wheat prices are getting a break from hedge funds, as some investors unwind short bets on the futures, Bloomberg News reported.

title: ONeal Foiled Twice in 2007 Effort to Sell Merrill
description: Stan ONeal, former chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch, saw his firms liability to $45 billion worth of collateralized debt obligations (C.D.O.s) a year before the crisis hit, but was blocked twice in 2007 when he tried to negotiate to sell the bank, Fortune reported.

title: Thomas Cook Raises $1 Billion Through Bond Issues
description: Thomas Cook, Europes second-biggest travel firm, said on Friday it had raised over $1 billion through new sterling and euro bond issues with the proceeds to be used for general corporate purposes, Reuters reported.

title: Book Review: The Big Short and The End of Wall Street
description: From Daniel Gross at the Sunday Book Review:

title: Credit Suisse Names Head of India Investment Banking
description: Credit Suisse is hiring Vedika Bhandarkar, a veteran investment banker at rival JPMorgan Chase, as head of investment banking for India, the Swiss investment bank said on Friday.

title: A Business Plan in Fewer Than 140 Characters?
description: From Lora Kolodny at Youre the Boss:

title: BofA and Symphony Team Up for C.L.O., Reports Say
description: Bank of America Merrill Lynch and Symphony Asset Management have joined forces on a new $500 million collateralized loan obligation, Bloomberg News and The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: In Sickness and in Wealth, Sweethearts in Crime
description: At one time, the idea of a husband and wife team working in tandem to orchestrate a securities fraud might seem like a Wall Street novelty act. But thats not the case any more, Reuters writes.

title: Thomas Jones, Coal Miners Son
description: I caught up with Thomas Jones, the former Jets running back who signed this off-season with Kansas City, in Manhattan recently. He was there to talk to a literary agent about a book, and also pursuing other entertainment-related projects. More details will be available in coming months.

title: Street Art Goes Mainstream in Rome
description: For years, the Roman street artist was written off as a vandal who worked under the cover of night to prevent being apprehended by police. Slowly, this reputation has evolved and now many artists are featured in private galleries, awarded corporate sponsorships, and even granted public spaces by city authorities. This spring, three Roman neighborhoods will host street art exhibitions in which once anonymous artists will produce their work in public view for the first time.

title: Will Write-Offs for Retiree Health Care Kill Jobs?
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton and a trustee or director of various health care companies and funds.

title: Qatar Fund Takes 5 Percent Stake in Veolia Unit
description: Qatar state-owned investment firm Qatari Diar agreed to take a 5 percent stake in Veolia Environnement in a partnership to pursue infrastructure and utilities projects in the Middle East and North Africa, Reuters reported.

title: Cuomos Pension Inquiry Extends to DiNapoli
description: The sprawling investigation into the state pension fund has reached the office of the current state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, the attorney generals office acknowledged on Thursday.

title: Telenor Says Its Close to Closing With Alfa
description: Telenor of Norway said it was very close to closing a deal with Russias Alfa Group to merger their Russian and Ukrainian mobile operators following a successful share exchange and the withdrawal of a court suit.

title: N.Y. Democrats at Odds With Wall Street Backers
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York has always been known as a savvy politician: a reliably liberal Democrat, never camera-shy, and a defender of his hometown industry, Wall Street.

title: Lehman is Dead  Long Live Lehman!
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings, which filed the largest bankruptcy in U.S. history, won a federal bankruptcy judges approval on Thursday to create a new asset management company, Reuters reported.

title: Only 60% of C.D.S.s Should Clear Centrally, Analysts Say
description: Around 60 percent of the $24.8 trillion credit derivatives market can rapidly move to central clearing and reduce systemic risk, but moving much beyond that could be counterproductive, Reuters said, citing market experts.

title: In Defense of Pit Bulls
description: Todays idea: Summary seizures and killings of pit bulls around the country are unjustified canine profiling and flout the legal due-process rights of owners, an article argues.

title: Analyst Raises Possibility of German Exit From Euro Zone
description: Germany might consider exiting the European monetary union in coming years to protect price stability as the Greek crisis threatens to turn the euro area into a region of fiscal profligacy, Morgan Stanley said.

title: Tebow and Other Draft Enigmas: Where Will They Land?
description: Sigmund Bloom of Draftguys.com will help preview and analyze the draft for the Fifth Down. He and Cecil Lammey host a podcast at FootballGuys.com,  and you can follow him on Twitter here. Today he looks at the biggest mysteries of this years draft.

title: Income Falls, but G.E. Tops Forecasts
description: General Electric, reassured by signs that a global recovery was gaining momentum, said on Friday that its profit for the year might exceed expectations.

title: Stray Questions for: Tom McCarthy
description: Tom McCarthy is the author of Tintin and the Secret of Literature and two novels, Remainder and the forthcoming C.

title: Goldman Director Decided to Leave After Notice
description: Rajat K. Guptas decision, announced last month, not to seek re-election to Goldman Sachss board came after he received notice from prosecutors that they were looking into recorded conversations Mr. Gupta held with the Galleon Group founder Raj Rajaratnam, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people close to the matter.

title: A Private Plan for a Hydrogen Highway
description: Many alternative-fuel companies are cash-poor, which means they spend a lot of their time chasing government loans and private capital. SunHydro, a start-up founded by Tom Sullivan to establish a solar-powered fuel-cell car refueling network on the East Coast, doesnt have that immediate challenge. In 1993, Mr. Sullivan founded Lumber Liquidators, a hardwood flooring retailer that now boasts more than 200 stores and, according to Reuters, had $544 million in net sales last year.

title: BofA Earns $3.2 Billion in 1st-Quarter Profit
description: 7:46 a.m. | Updated The New York Timess Andrew Martin has more here.

title: Boy Scouts Add a New Digital Badge
description: I wasnt a very good Boy Scout when I signed-up at 6 years old.It wasnt that I didnt have fun traipsing around the woods  instead, I spent most of my time daydreaming about my brand newcomputer, a 1982ZX Spectrum.

title: Bank of America, With Merrills Help, Returns to Profit
description: Bank of Americas acquisition of Merrill Lynch, a marriage made under the storm cloud of the financial crisis, has been the subject of government investigations and shareholder lawsuits ever since it became official in early 2009.

title: Debating the Tax Burden
description: Tony Fratto, the former White House spokesman for the Bush administration, offered some polite criticism of my column this week, in a blog post for CNBC. I want to try to respond to one point that he made in a similar way.

title: South Korea Says Ship Sank After External Explosion
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Officials investigating the mysterious sinking of a South Korean warship in waters disputed by North Korea believe that the ship was hit and torn apart by an external explosion, the government announced Friday.

title: What Clark Hoyt Said
description: Here.

title: The Worst of Times
description: A question for the history-minded, related to todays column: has there ever been a time in US political history when one of the two major political parties was so addicted to doublethink, so committed to pretending that its advocating the opposite of its actual agenda?

title: Tip of the Week: WordPad in Windows 7
description: Often used for short notes or for word-processing by people who dont own Microsoft Word, the humble little WordPad program has gotten a update in Windows 7.

title: Flight Chaos Sends Businesses Scrambling
description: PARIS  Businesses around Europe were scrambling to make contingency plans Friday as a cloud of volcanic ash from Iceland kept airports closed, while insurance companies were hoping to avoid having to cover any losses.

title: Sampler: Lawsuit Seeks Suede Nightclub Closure, and Palm Fronds For Oakland Elephants
description: 10,000 Turn Out for Pleasanton Tea Party Rally | Political candidates like Carly Fiorina, the Republican who is trying to unseat Senator Barbara Boxer, went to the Alameda County Fair Grounds to rally Tea Party followers to their campaigns. But most of the talk during the five-hour rally focused on general discontent with the Obama administrations economic policies and the recently passed health care legislation. This is great timing for us, said Bridget Melson, the president of the Pleasanton T.E.A. (Taxed Enough Already) Party and the events organizer. The passing of the health care bill has incensed and fired people up. Among the slogans visible at the event was: Vote the traitors out in November. A New York Times poll shows that Tea Party supporters are wealthier than the general public, tend to be Republican and classify themselves as angry. [The Contra Costa Times, The New York Times]

title: Chinese Premier Visits Tibetan Quake Survivors
description: JIEGU, China  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao spent Friday in the Tibetan high country, comforting survivors of this weeks devastating earthquake in a prominent display of concern by the countrys Han leadership for one of Chinas most troubled ethnic minorities.

title: Miss Liberty From Every Angle
description: Late Thursday morning, Katherine Dolgy Ludwig parked herself on a sun-drenched wooden bench on the High Line, took her red, yellow and blue watercolors from a canvas lunch bag and began to paint.

title: After the Housing Bust, Construction Shows Life
description: In a modest sign that the housing market is moving toward more normal conditions, the pace of home building is finally picking up from its near-death levels.

title: The Early Word: Visitation Rights
description: President Obama has ordered new rules that give visitation rights to same-sex partners of patients at any hospital that participates in Medicare or Medicaid.

title: Will Premium Subsidies Be Based on Personal Assets?
description: Q.

title: Toyota Passes Test Its Lexus Cousin Failed
description: ON the same day that Consumer Reports tested the 2010 Lexus GX 460 sport utility vehicle and found what it considered a dangerous handling problem, it also tested a related vehicle, the 2010 Toyota 4Runner. The Toyota did just fine.

title: Return of a Rock Star That Didnt Cross Over
description: A PLUME of pale-beige dust half a mile long trailed behind a vehicle racing across El Diablo Dry Lake. Ivan Stewart, a legendary off-road racer known as the Ironman, was driving flat-out at triple-digit speeds. He was at the wheel of a new Toyota 4Runner and, man, I wanted one.

title: Italian Model Goes on a High-Carbon Diet
description: SantAgata Bolognese, Italy

title: European Airports Close for Second Day as Ash Spreads
description: With no prospect of a return to normal before the weekend, travel chaos across the globe deepened on Friday as a vast, high-altitude plume of volcanic ash from Iceland spread farther across northern and central Europe, forcing authorities to close airspace and ground airplanes to forestall potentially dangerous damage to jet engines. title: Speed Read for Friday, April 16
description: Highlights from todays media coverage:

title: Shoe Shiner Arrested for Arson Keeps Shining
description: What were reading this morning:

title: Reading, Riding, Wristmanship
description: FOR enthusiasts who believe that motoring fun rides on two wheels, not four, here is a handful of short reviews, all related to motorcycles. The four books range from a history of the late and lamented English motorcycle industry to road tests of both classic and new bike designs. And there's even a DVD on precision cornering. CHARLES McEWEN

title: Samurai Shopper | Raising the Bar
description: Anyone out there remember soap? The Samurai Shopper does, and admits a sentimental affection for soaps plain-Jane properties. Soap may not be the most voluptuous product youve ever used, but it is efficient, disposable, a marvel of minimalism. I, like many others, traded up to fancy-pants facial gels, foams and creams that smell expensive  and are. But washing with emulsions of Meyer lemon or fig makes me think: what do figs smell like anyway, and should I smell like one?

title: Should You Tell the Employees?
description: The issue of what you tell your employees when youre trying to sell your business is a tricky one that requires careful thought. Maintaining confidentiality surrounding the sale typically takes precedence over other concerns, yet it may be impractical  or even impossible  to keep employees in the dark.

title: Wall Streets Win Streak Ends at 6
description: Wall Street seemed headed for another strong weekly finish on Friday  and then the news hit.

title: Complaint Box | Lunches and Landfills
description: I work in the financial district, and when its lunchtime, the decision to be made is: polystyrene, No. 6 plastic or real plates?

title: Mr. Softee Fill-In
description: Go to related article

title: Updates on the Volcanic Ash Cloud
description: As my colleagues Alan Cowell, Nicola Clark and Liz Robbins report, global air travel continues to be disrupted on Friday as the high-altitude plume of volcanic ash from Iceland spreads farther across northern and central Europe. The Lede will provide updates on the movement of the ash cloud throughout the day.

title: Graphic Book Best-Sellers: A Big Piece of the Pie for One Piece
description: Of the eight new books on the manga list on Friday, five are volumes of One Piece. The series follows the adventures of Monkey D. Luffy, a 17-year-old adventurer and his ragtag crew on the search for One Piece, a pirate treasure. One Piece is incredibly popular in Japan: The Anime News Network reported that Volume 56 had a print run of 2.85 million copies. The publication schedule put forth by VIZ Media in the United States is an aggressive one. From January through June, the company plans to publish five installments a month, taking the series from volume 24 to 53. This week, Volumes 39-43 sit on the manga list. Previews of the first eight chapters are available here. The site also includes character bios and motion comics.

description: Weekend Notes From (Sunny) Shanghai:

title: In China, Loan Regulations Without a Loophole
description: Chinese banking regulators have tried a new tactic in their fight to curb lending: cutting their computers connection, Caijin magazine reported.

description: Q.

description: Q.

description: ARE we postracial yet? Not as long as the whole country looks over President Obamas shoulder to see what race he checks off on his census form.

description: Film

title: Theater Prizes Are Awarded
description: The playwright Dan LeFranc and the musical theater songwriters Peter Mills and Barry Wyner have won awards recognizing promising new talent in American theater, the sponsors of the prizes announced.

title: Rough Justice for Eliot Spitzer, in Book and Movie Form
description: If any publicity is good publicity, then this has been an excellent week for Eliot Spitzer, the former governor of New York. In Fridays New York Times, Michiko Kakutani reviews Peter Elkinds Rough Justice: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer, which chronicles the disgraced politicians trajectory from Sheriff of Wall Street to Client 9. For several days, the Internet has been aflame with chatter generated by a Playboy interview and photo shoot with Ashley Dupr, the woman whose 2008 encounter with Mr. Spitzer led to his downfall (dont look for any links here). Now, via the good folks at Flavorwire, were led to the above clip for the documentary film version of Rough Justice, directed by Alex Gibney (Taxi to the Dark Side), a version of which will be shown at the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: U.A.W. President Says Things Are Turning Around
description: Ron Gettelfinger has had a rather bumpy ride as president of the United Auto Workers union, but he brought a message of hope with him to a meeting of the International Motor Press Association on Thursday in New York.

title: Truth and Consequences
description: If its true that traits like novelty-seeking and risk-aversion are genetic in origin, then Mary Beth Lathams biological makeup appears to be tilted toward safety and security. Mary Beth, the narrator of Anna Quindlens engrossing new novel, Every Last One, values stability and sameness, finding quiet contentment in her long, amiable marriage to an ophthalmologist and in her flourishing career as a landscaper. But her most intense feelings and greatest concerns are centered on her three teenage children: lovely Ruby, nearing her last year of high school, and the twins, Max and Alex, who will be freshmen next year.

title: Oracle to Buy Phase Forward for $685 Million
description: Oracle said Friday that it had agreed to buy the drug data management software company Phase Forward for about $685 million in a deal aimed at bolstering its health sciences business, Reuters reports.

title: Upstart With the Marks of Experience
description: THERE is something ridiculous about asking Stephen Petronio how he wants his dances to live on when hes no longer around to look after them. This svelte, handsome choreographer is only 54. Vibrant tattoos snake along his arms, an enduring stamp of his rebellious punk roots.

title: Mayor John Lindsay
description: A selection of images from "Americas Mayor: John V. Lindsay  and the Reinvention of New York," an exhibit at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: I Exam
description: Over the last 25 years, the memoir  or The Story of My Life, as Vivian Gornick calls it  has become one of the major gestures of American writing. In direct opposition to the literal-minded, linear and epistemologically nave nature of many such works, there has emerged in the last dozen years a vital countertradition, what John DAgata labels the lyric essay. Its a form with ancient roots. Heraclitus, anyone?

title: S.E.C. Accuses Goldman of Fraud in Housing Deal
description: Goldman Sachs, the Wall Street powerhouse, was accused of securities fraud in a civil lawsuit filed Friday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which claims the bank created and sold a mortgage investment that was secretly intended to fail.

title: Those Who Wait
description: In Olga Grushins second novel, The Line, hundreds of citizens spend several hours a day, every day for a year, waiting to buy tickets to a concert that may or may not take place. The premise is loosely based on Stravinskys 1962 concert in Leningrad, which was likewise preceded by a yearlong ticket line.

title: Flexible Spending, a Little Less So
description: THANKS to the sweeping new health law, your flexible spending plan is about to become a bit less flexible.

title: New Law Lowers Flex-Spending Benefit
description: In Fridays Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad writes about one of the casualties of health reform: flexible spending benefits for health care costs are being cut.

title: Newspaper Advertising Decline is Slowing Markedly at Gannett
description: 1:05 p.m. | Updated Looks like Moodys Investors Service was paying attention to that Gannett quarterly report, too. Moodys on Friday changed its outlook on the newspaper industry from negative to stable. Which could be like a hospital patient being critical but stable.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Goldman of Fraud in Mortgage Deal
description: 1:56 p.m. | Updated Goldman Sachs, which emerged relatively unscathed from the financial crisis, was accused of securities fraud in a civil suit filed Friday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which claims the bank created and sold a mortgage investment that was secretly devised to fail, The New York Timess Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson report. (Read the S.E.C.s lawsuit after the jump.)

title: Friday Reading: Getting More for Your Money in Europe
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Overextended Family
description: Ostensibly, the central characters in The Bradshaw Variations, Rachel Cusks seventh novel, are a husband and wife named Thomas Bradshaw and Tonie Swann. Also ostensibly, the novels plot follows the year Thomas leaves the work force to take care of their daughter and his wife returns to a full-time job. But it soon becomes apparent that the novel is not exactly about these two individuals, nor is it overly concerned with the Mr. Mom circumstances newly introduced into their lives. What The Bradshaw Variations is about, however, is hard to say.

title: And Now for Something Completely Different: Terry Gilliams First Opera
description: As long as his production doesnt go exorbitantly over budget, abruptly run out of funds, get ruined in a flash flood or drowned out by NATO aircraft drills  all calamities that have befallen him in the past  the director Terry Gilliam is scheduled to make his operatic debut with the English National Opera next year, The Guardian reported. Mr. Gilliam, the Monty Python alumnus whose films include Brazil and The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus, and whose disaster-plagued shoot for an aborted film, The Man Who Killed Don Quixote, was the subject of the documentary Lost in La Mancha, will direct a production of Berliozs Damnation of Faust that is planned for May 2011.

title: We Three Things | Lip Reading
description: If the eyes are window to the soul, then the mouth is window to the gut, revealing anxieties, turmoil and hidden appetites. My partially deaf step-aunt lip-reads, and she understands me better than any other member of my family. The way a person smiles clues us into their disposition and emotional state, and whether painted, bitten or sealed, lips are constantly speaking volumes.

title: Fashion Hotel Opens in New York City
description: New hotels continue to pop up in New York City. Fashion 26-A Wyndham Hotel, opened this week in the citys garment district, a block away from the Fashion Institute of Technology on West 26th Street.

title: The Making of the iPad Town Hall Video
description: Every week, I write and star in a goofy 3-minute video about whatever I reviewed in The Times that week. It airs on CNBC at around 1:40 p.m. Thursday, and then it goes onlineto nytimes.com, YouTube, iTunes, TiVo, JetBlue and so on.

title: Weighing the Evidence on Exercise
description: How exercise affects body weight is one of the more intriguing and vexing issues in physiology. Exercise burns calories, no one doubts that, and so it should, in theory, produce weight loss, a fact that has prompted countless people to undertake exercise programs to shed pounds. Without significantly changing their diets, few succeed. Anecdotally, all of us have been cornered by people claiming to have spent hours each week walking, running, stair-stepping, etc., and are displeased with the results on the scale or in the mirror, wrote Barry Braun, an associate professor of kinesiology at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, in the American College of Sports Medicines February newsletter.

title: An Unnecessary Law
description: To the Editor:

title: My Daughter, the User
description: To crudely paraphrase Tolstoy, all addicts families are alike, and when it comes to teenage drug abusers theyre unnervingly alike, right down to the last battering detail. So I was fewer than 30 pages into Anne Lamotts powerful and painfully honest novel when a chill of recognition shot through me. Rosie  17, bright and sweet and anticipating the summer before her final year of high school  has come to realize how maddeningly easy it is to deceive her mother and stepfather, Elizabeth and James. So preoccupied are they with her alcoholic mothers faltering recovery that they forget to notice whether Rosie herself is drinking (she is). In fact, theyre so clueless about her real life that when James picks a moment for an honest chat he has no idea Rosie is coming down off Ecstasy, so tweaked she has to struggle not to grind her teeth into paste as she listens.

title: Loyal Alumni
description: To the Editor:

title: View From the Corner
description: Over the years, various gyms have emerged as the Sorbonne of the sweet science. In the 1930s and 40s, there were Stillmans and Gleasons in New York, and much later the Kronk in Detroit. But during the late 50s and early 60s, the Fifth Street Gym in Miami Beach became one of the grand hubs of pugilism. It was out of that cocoon of combat that the young Cassius Clay was transmogrified into Muhammad Ali.

title: London Dance Journal: Mark Morris Makes a Visit
description: LONDON  Pastoral is a rare genre anywhere these days. Artists still celebrate nature but seldom the tranquil harmony between nature and civilized man. In dance, the two greatest extant pastoral masterpieces are Frederick Ashtons La Fille mal garde and Mark Morriss LAllegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato. When Mr. Morris first made LAllegro in Brussels in November 1988, it was just three months after Ashton had died. To some of us, connections between the two were immediately powerfully apparent: most obviously in the imagery in each work of horses, carriages and riders, of landscapes and people gazing into them, and of workers in the fields. In both, the world is young, its population innocent.

title: What Happens to All Those No. 42 Jerseys?
description: Now that the calendar has turned past April 15, the question arises: What happens to all those No. 42 jerseys worn this week in honor of Jackie Robinson Day?

title: Daryl F. Gates, L.A.P.D. Chief in Rodney King Era, Dies at 83
description: Daryl F. Gates, whose aggressive approach to law enforcement as chief of the Los Angeles Police Department was both admired for its innovation and criticized for the racial unrest it provoked, died Friday at his home in Dana Point, Calif. He was 83.

title: Syllabus Sampler
description: Courses by some of the worlds foremost scholars are online, free for the viewing. Browse a selection of lecture videos.

title: The Paper Debate
description: Before each tournament, Sam Crichton, a senior on the Wake Forest debate team, meticulously stocks a half-dozen Rubbermaid tubs with computer printouts. Each sheet of paper  perhaps 5,000 total  summarizes the argument in, say, a presidential speech or op-ed piece. These cards have been sorted into manila files, grouped into brown accordion folders, stacked into the tubs and labeled by argument type: affirmatives, disadvantages, counterplans, critiques, case arguments/negatives, backfiles.

title: Postmodernspeak
description: Stupidity is neither ignorance nor organicity, but rather, a corollary of knowing and an element of normalcy, the double of intelligence rather than its opposite.  Stupidity is always the name of the Other, and it is the sign of the feminine.

title: Elementary: Quiz Answers
description: 1. 30 years old

title: Training Teachers Pe(s)ts
description: Back in the Paleolithic period, when men and women wore their Sunday best, classroom decorum was unquestioned; the relationship between professor and student was based on a set of unspoken rules. One wonders what their reaction would be to an e-mail message I received from a student: hey prof, owt late last nite .... am sic today. pls emal cls notes. yah thatd b great. thx see u.  I teach a course in public speaking at Borough of Manhattan Community College, part of the City University of New York, in which students give speeches ranging from how to clean a trumpet to solar energy. My job is to show them how to arrange their thoughts, use language to its best advantage and, most important, perform in front of an audience without fear.

title: Finding a Gay-Friendly Campus
description: The scene was similar to one that plays out thousands of times a year in gyms and auditoriums around the country: a college fair. The folding tables, the school banners, the admissions officers with a student representative or two, and the brochures and tchotchkes laid out. The only thing that might have made this one appear out of the ordinary was the preponderance of handouts with rainbow designs, and the fact that the fair was being held at the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Community Center in Greenwich Village. This college fair, and several like it around the country, was devoted to recruiting gay students.

title: F.A.Q.
description: Whats an externship?

title: The Long-Haul Degree
description: Law students get a diploma in three years. Medical students receive an M.D. in four. But for graduate students in the humanities, it takes, on average, more than nine years to complete a degree. What some of those Ph.D. recipients may not realize is that they could spend another nine years, or more, looking for a tenure-track teaching job at a college or university  without ever finding one.

title: My Teacher Is an Index
description: ECOMOMICS 252: FINANCIAL MARKETS

title: If You Go
description: It's one of the biggest adjustments to college life: showering, brushing hair and applying pimple cream with everyone else on the dorm floor, men and women alike.

title: Asian Culture Through a Lens
description: VISUALIZING CULTURES

title: The Matrix
description: MATHEMATICS 18.06: LINEAR ALGEBRA

title: Exactly How Personal Is That Personal Statement?
description: Talk about chutzpah. The admissions director for Penn States M.B.A. program, Carrie Marcinkevage, recalls that the school once received a student essay with three of four paragraphs taken directly from an article online. It was, ironically, in our Principled Leadership admissions essay, she says.

title: Audit This
description: WHY homeschool? Maybe to brush up for an exam, get a sense of what a college is like, or just to learn. Diana E. E. Kleiner, who runs Open Yale Courses, knows of users who take open classes with friends, or who want to bone up on, say, art history before a trip to Italy. Yales open courses are probably the most accessible for the general consumer. Fewer casual students might be hankering to dip into the junior year of aeronautics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Still, technical courses like classical mechanics and linear algebra are consistently among the top viewed among M.I.T.s extensive list of offerings. On the following pages, writers who know the fields weigh in on some of the highlights of free education. Fittingly, open classes have many homes on the Internet, including university Web sites and professors personal home pages. Access seems to be easier through big sites like YouTube and iTunes, which work in conjunction with the institutions.

title: Are Business Schools Failing?
description: The aftermath of a historic financial crisis seems an appropriate time to take stock of graduate business education. What are we teaching these people before they head off to the executive suite?

title: How to Learn Something for Nothing
description: Thousands of pieces of free educational material  videos and podcasts of lectures, syllabuses, entire textbooks  have been posted in the name of the open courseware movement. But how to make sense of it all? Businesses, social entrepreneurs and "edupunks," envisioning a tuition-free world untethered by classrooms, have created Web sites to help navigate the mind-boggling volume of content. Some sites tweak traditional pedagogy; others aggregate, Hulu-style.

title: Why We Go Cuckoo for
description: PSYCH 123: THE PSYCHOLOGY, BIOLOGY AND POLITICS OF FOOD

title: Atoms and Antimatter
description: PHYSICS 10: PHYSICS FOR FUTURE PRESIDENTS

title: Voil! A Better e-Course
description: FRENCH II

title: The Inner Body
description: INTEGRATIVE BIOLOGY 131: GENERAL HUMAN ANATOMY

title: An Open Mind
description: At 83, Marian C. Diamond has been teaching anatomy at the University of California, Berkeley, for 50 years. Her class is so popular that its difficult for students to get in, though she holds court at the campuss largest lecture hall, with room for 736.

title: Decoding DNA
description: HONORS COLLEGIUM 70A: GENETIC ENGINEERING IN MEDICINE, AGRICULTURE AND LAW

title: They Have a Class for That
description: COMPUTER SCIENCE 193P: IPHONE APPLICATION PROGRAMMING

title: Elementary
description: George Freeman, a vice president and assistant general counsel of The New York Times, is an avid Pop Quiz taker. But, he admonished us the other day, "Make it easier!" And so we turned to the syndicated game show "Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?," which challenges adults with questions from textbooks and curriculums from first grade through fifth. The producers agreed to share some of the toughies. Only two contestants have made it through the low grades and correctly answered fifth-grade-level and bonus questions like the ones below to win $1 million. One winner was a Nobel-laureate physics professor from the University of California, Berkeley (by answering No. 32); the other was schools superintendent of Georgia (with No. 33). And how did Mr. Freeman fare? Without any test prep, he got 21 right, including a million-dollar question.

title: The Examined Life, Age 8
description: A few times each month, second graders at a charter school in Springfield, Mass., take time from math and reading to engage in philosophical debate. There is no mention of Hegel or Descartes, no study of syllogism or solipsism. Instead, Prof. Thomas E. Wartenberg and his undergraduate students from nearby Mount Holyoke College use classic childrens books to raise philosophical questions, which the young students then dissect with the vigor of the ancient Greeks.

title: The Music Lesson
description: VARIOUS MUSIC COURSES

title: Living With the Boss
description: If you want to find out what its like to be Gail Hochman, a New York literary agent, it wouldnt be enough to merely follow her around during the workday. Youd have to follow her home for the night and back to the office the next morning  because it is during her daily commute that Ms. Hochman, 56, goes about the business of poring over unpublished manuscript after unpublished manuscript.

title: Smiles, Sex and Object Permanence
description: PSYCH 110: INTRODUCTION TO PSYCHOLOGY

title: Paying for College on Your Own
description: THE REALITY

title: What Theyre Watching
description: YouTube, with its view-count ticker, has become a useful tool for determining the popularity of an online video  whether it has gone viral, as the kids say. Atop YouTubes list of most-popular course lectures (as of April 1) is  Justice,  Michael J. Sandels legendary philosophy class. The courses videos also happen to be the only ones produced for public television. The Top 10 videos are the first lecture in a series, except No. 6, which is smack in the middle of a course on search engines. That lecture may have been boosted by a guest  Sergey Brin, the co-founder of Google.

title: The Marvel of Science
description: PHYSICS 21: SCIENCE FROM SUPERHEROES TO GLOBAL WARMING

title: Acura Recalling 2010 ZDX for Air Bag Problem
description: 6:00 p.m. | Updated

title: How a Roth I.R.A. Conversion Can Hurt Financial Aid
description: If you think youre going to be eligible for federal financial aid, you may want to think twice about converting a traditional I.R.A. to a Roth I.R.A. while your child is still in college.

title: Budget Ax Falls in Vances Office
description: With the Manhattan district attorneys office facing a 25 percent budget cut from the city this year, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the offices newly elected chief, is cutting a handful of staff members.

title: Tocqueville: The Novel
description: Peter Careys 11th novel is announced by its publisher as an improvisation on the life of Alexis de Tocqueville, a figure perhaps a bit cerebral for one of this authors brass-band burlesques of literature and history. But Parrot and Olivier in America grabs its subject and marches down Main Street playing full out, provoking a readers delighted applause and  as is often the case with this exuberant novelist  a small measure of exasperation.

title: Living in a Commercial Space
description: New Yorkers sometimes wind up living in places that never before saw bed, sofa or stove.

title: Born a Store
description: IN a city where the hot hangout changes by the minute, and people move to neighborhoods that are just starting to shed a commercial or industrial past, it is little surprise that New Yorkers sometimes wind up living in places that never before saw bed, sofa or stove.

title: Youth, Fossils and Planetary Progress
description: Im on the road to a big conclave of college students, professors and administrators trying to build a better planet and society  organized by former President Bill Clinton through his Clinton Global Initiative. Ive moved to a university. My third book on the environment, a project of The New York Times, was for middle school kids. Theres a pattern here. Youth matters.

title: McCann Erickson Sues Kirshenbaum Bond Senecal Over Senecal
description: The hiring by one agency of a top executive from another agency is often fraught with potential pitfalls, particularly when it comes to the delicate subject of whether the executive is wooing clients and co-workers to join him or her at the new agency.

title: Did I Mention the Graves Out Back?
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn.

title: Tocqueville: The Life
description: Glimpsing the human side of major historical figures is endlessly fascinating. As Melville noted, Shakespeare in his own day wasnt Shakespeare. He was Master William Shakespeare, the harried writer  mocked as an upstart crow by a critic  who churned out plays for the proprietors of the Globe Theater.

title: Josh Hamiltons Perspective on Ron Washington
description: Josh Hamilton will always have a connection with the original Yankee Stadium, where his flurry of majestic home runs was the highlight of the All-Star Game home run derby in 2008, the final year of the ballpark. Speaking in Cleveland on Wednesday, Hamilton said he was curious to see what was left of the old Yankee Stadium - and the answer is: not much.

title: Halfway Between New York and Philadelphia
description: DONNA NEJAD began thinking of Branchburg Township as a hidden gem 12 years ago, when she and her husband, Peter, chose it from the numerous central New Jersey towns they explored after deciding to leave Staten Island.

title: Dr. Does-It-All
description: As one of the most accomplished cardiothoracic surgeons of his generation, Mehmet Oz has transplanted lungs and repurposed hearts; implanted mechanical devices to provide the pump and pulse for patients that cannot manage that on their own; and otherwise pressed, pulled, cut and stitched inside bodies where a seconds lapse of attention or a millimeter of miscalculation could kill.

title: The Step-by-Step Four-Story Renovation in the West Village
description: BACK in the mid-1990s, when John Casey and his wife-to-be, Nancy Smith, were looking for an affordable place to live in Manhattan, Mr. Casey chose an unusual approach to house hunting. Day after day, he prowled the citys streets in search of rundown properties. Then he pored over records at the offices of various city agencies, hoping to come across an owner who was on the ropes financially and desperate to sell.

title: An Apartment With Laundry on the Premises
description: THOUGH Samantha Slater was glad to be starting graduate school in New York, she was concerned about living on a students budget.

title: Christopher Albanese
description: Mr. Albanese, 44, is a principal of the Albanese Organization.

title: Sales Pace Moves From Walk to Trot
description: WESTCHESTERS real estate market has benefited from what sales agents like Marcene Hedayati, a managing partner at Legends Realty Group in Sleepy Hollow, describe as a perfect confluence: House prices finally dropped. Interest rates remained low. And first-time buyers were able to take advantage of a federal tax credit.

title: Luxury Condos for Princeton
description: PRINCETON BOROUGH

title: Bucks, Thunder Got Their Biggest Lift From the Top
description: Ballots were due this week for the N.B.A.s postseason awards. Although The New York Times does not permit its reporters to vote, the N.B.A. reporters Howard Beck and Jonathan Abrams are making their picks in Off the Dribble. Todays debate is about the Executive of the Year Award.

title: Forecasts for Underwater Owners
description: FOR the New York City area's underwater homeowners - that is, those whose mortgage debt exceeds the value of their homes - this could be a very long decade.

title: Playing the Ball Correctly From Damaged Ground
description: Aftera difficult winter, spring has finally arrived and Arnie, Bill, Charlie and Doug prepare for the first round of the year. At their home course, officials have marked a large area damaged by heavy snows as ground under repair (G.U.R.) in the fairway and rough. All four players play their tee shots and all four balls come to rest in the G.U.R.

title: Contractors on Call to Prepare Houses for Sale
description: NERVOUS about the economy last fall, Victor Mora of Roslyn Harbor contacted a real estate broker. If I lost my job, he remembers thinking at the time, I would have to sell my house.

title: Google Battles Bad Spellers
description: Finishing your sentences, correcting misspellings  Google is either coming to resemble a spookily sentient computer intelligence, or an annoying spouse.

title: Middle East Boyhood
description: When playing the conquer the world board game Risk as an adolescent growing up in a well-to-do Cairo suburb, Kai Bird avoided occupying the Middle East. So did his American friends. Their very surroundings schooled them in the difficulty of holding the crossroads of three continents.

title: Weekend Competition: Whelmed by Outunendo
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to create necessary neologisms by monkeying with prefixes and suffixes.

title: Dear FloFab: My Boyfriend Was Raised by Wolves
description: Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: A Ripe Old Age
description: Heres how precocious Adam Thirlwell is: In 2003, when he was 24 years old, Granta named him one of Britains best young novelists  before his first novel had even been published. (He made the cut on the strength of the manuscript.) Once the book, Politics, did appear, discussions about it had one common denominator: sex. Readers and reviewers, pro and con, sought the precise location of the line demarcating smut from smart. Translated into 30 languages, Politics told the story of three young Londoners involved in a mnage  trois. Though few explicit descriptions were spared, the novel was ultimately less concerned with the foibles and fumblings of sexual misadventure than with what they could reveal about human nature that more conventional narratives could not.

title: Magic Monsters
description: Images from an exhibit of Japanese prints by Utagawa Kuniyoshi.

title: Dont Have a Nice Day
description: Anyone who loves the short story, that perennially marginalized and disrespected form, should rejoice in the appearance of a writers collected stories. Its simply good for the team. (Recent proclamations that the novel is over and done with take aim at the bigger target for a change. Welcome, novels, to the realm of the unquiet dead.) When the short-story writer in question is as innovative and idiosyncratic as Deborah Eisenberg, its an opportunity for both celebration and appraisal, a chance to explore our expectations of narrative in contentious times. As if there were any other times worth writing about.

title: Obama Pushes for D.C. Voting Rights
description: President Obama called Friday for Congress to pass legislation giving voting representation to residents of the nations capital.

title: Collateral Damage
description: On the opening page of The Sandbox, David Zimmermans gripping first novel about the Iraq war, Pvt. Toby Durrants convoy comes across a dead girl in the road, her body a small white mound, like a fallen bird. Tobys response is to put this child in the small cigar box I keep hidden in the back of my head, close its cardboard lid and snap a couple of rubber bands around it to keep it tightly shut. Just like Ive done with the rest.

title: Milan Report | Saved By Droog
description: Its impossible not to be charmed by the exhibition Saved By Droog, for which the Dutch design brand scoured online liquidation auctions for caches of unwanted objects  like 720 soda glasses and 50 neon-orange safety vests  and then invited 14 designers to use them as raw materials. Nearly everyone here at the furniture fair did more with less this year, but few so overtly made an asset of the crisis, the business-killing tendencies of which inspired Droog to come to the aid of all those orphaned goods. Reclamation can also apparently benefit the bottom line, considering that 125 euros ($170) will net you one of 448 wallets stamped Money does not make me happy by the graphic designer Stefan Sagmeister. And silicone-coated wooden spoons by the Dutch food designer Marije Vogelzang are only 29.50 euros ($40). Everything is for sale on-site, and the designers get half the profits.

title: Shes Come Undone
description: The latest incarnation of the Patti Smith, straggly-hair, no-makeup makeup look. (See: Bettina Rheims.)

title: Spitzer Antagonist Advises Ex-Madams Campaign
description: Roger J. Stone Jr. has more than a bit of a thing for Eliot Spitzer.

title: An Unexpected Death
description: Early on in Sue Millers new novel, The Lake Shore Limited, a middle-aged woman loiters in a dark street, peeping into the window of a bar. Inside, a much younger woman  vivid in a crimson suit, flanked by men, her long legs on display  throws her head back to laugh, either in pure pleasure or in the wish to convey pure pleasure. The moment is quintessential Miller, touching on the themes that have animated her fiction for the past quarter-century: the potency of sex; the failure of men and women to understand each other; the hunger for a different life. Here too is the hyper-self-consciousness that afflicts her characters, who are forever questioning the authenticity of their feelings.

title: Experts Seek Clues to How Long Eruption Will Go On
description: The volcanic eruption that has disrupted air travel in Europe for two days shows no signs of abating, an Icelandic geophysicist said Friday.

title: Pride and Popularity
description: Jane Austens best-known phrase describing her own writing appears in a letter to her nephew, James Edward Austen-Leigh, an aspiring novelist and student at Winchester College. When she heard hed lost some draft chapters, she jokingly announced that she couldnt be accused of purloining his pages: What should I do with your strong, manly, spirited Sketches, full of Variety & Glow?  How could I possibly join them on to the little bit (two Inches wide) of Ivory on which I work with so fine a Brush, as produces little effect after much labour? The little bit of Ivory, frequently quoted to describe Austens virtuosic miniaturism, started out as a self-deprecating remark to a much younger, less talented relative who would later become her biographer.

title: Is YouTubes Safety Mode Safe? Not Very.
description: Parental warning: This post contains descriptions of videos that may make you blush, cringe or turn away from your screen. And each can be viewed with YouTubes Safety Mode feature turned on.

title: Five Ways to Marinate Vegetables
description: Marinades are a great way to make vegetables last longer, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: TimesCast | April 16, 2010
description: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories covered Friday.  Topics include widening effects of the volcano,  U.S. accusations against Goldman Sachs, Obama mandates gay visitation rights.

title: Icelandic Volcano Casts a Shadow Over Indio, Calif.
description: 6:32 p.m. | Updated

title: Travel Deals: European Flight and Hotel Sale
description: Airfares are expected to jump this summer, but for now, Lufthansa and Air France are having spring flight sales to Europe, good for departures through mid-May. And for lodging once you get there, Hotels.com is offering 30 percent off hundreds of European hotels.

title: Let the Playoffs, and the Hand-Wringing, Begin
description: It is tempting to wonder what on earth is going on in the first round of the N.H.L. playoffs. Two No. 1 seeds, Washington and San Jose, lost the openers and Capitals superstar Alex Ovechkin was held without a shot on goal for the first time since before birth. The defending champion, Pittsburgh, lost at home to  gasp  Ottawa and the Red Wings fell to Phoenix, which wasnt even sure it still had a team. This is crazy stuff, hockeys equivalent of a solar eclipse.

title: Gomez Finds Scoring Touch With Puebla
description: In the annals of Major League Soccer, the 2005 season seems like ages ago.

title: For Oil Sands Project,  a Step Forward
description: A pipeline that would carry crude oil extracted from Canadian tar sand fields to refineries in Texas has edged a bit closer to approval with the State Departments release of a draft environmental impact statement this month. It concluded that the projects construction and operation would have limited adverse environmental impacts.

title: The Fat Trap
description: Food is never just food. Food is love. Food is solace. It is politics. It is religion. And if thats not enough to heap on your dinner plate each night, food is also, especially for mothers, the instant-read measure of our parenting. We are not only what we eat, we are what we feed our children. So here in Berkeley  where a preoccupation with locally grown, organic, sustainable agriculture is presumed  the mom who strolls the farmers markets can feel superior to the one who buys pesticide-free produce trucked in from Mexico, who can, in turn, lord it over the one who stoops to conventionally grown carrots (though the folks who grow their own trump us all). Let it slip that you took the kids to McDonalds, and watch how fast those play dates dry up.

title: Taxes on the Rich vs. the Merely Affluent
description: A few readers wondered whether I was referring to only a very small slice of the highest-income households when I said tax rates on the wealthy had fallen more than on any other group over the last three decades. The short answer is no.

title: Everybodys Doing the Co-opting a Name Thing
description: Whats in a name?

title: Body Talk
description: As the founder of the first World Fitness Day, which will be held in Atlanta on May 1, you will be leading what might be called the biggest gym class ever.  Were taking over the Georgia Dome, which is home of the Atlanta Falcons. It can hold 3,000 people on the floor and other people in the stands. A friend of mine e-mailed and said that with all that music and fun it sounds like Woodstock without the drugs and the rain.

title: Wellness
description: Wellness,   intoned Dan Rather in November 1979, introducing a 60 Minutes segment on a new health movement known by that name. Theres a word you dont hear every day.

title: Weinsteins Get Exclusive Window to Close a Deal to Reclaim Miramax
description: The Walt Disney Company has granted Harvey and Bob Weinstein an exclusive negotiating window to close a deal for Miramax Films, according to two people with knowledge of the matter but who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the talks were private.

title: Charles Schwab Stops Offering 2 Percent Credit Cards
description: Back in December, I warned that Charles Schwabs generous 2 percent cash rebate credit card was in jeopardy. And sure enough, the company pulled the plug two weeks ago. Its not accepting new applications for the card, though the company isnt currently making any changes to the rewards structure for existing cardholders.

title: The Anatomy of Desire
description: The two mannequins stood side by side in the back of the white van. Johan Karremans, a psychologist at Radboud University in the Netherlands, along with his student and collaborator, Sander Arons, clothed the plastic women identically in tight black tops and dark skirts. Arons then drove the van around the country to the homes of blind men.

title: McMillan, Adelman Did More With Less
description: Ballots were due this week for the N.B.A.s postseason awards. Although The New York Times does not permit its reporters to vote, N.B.A. reporters Howard Beck and Jonathan Abrams are making their picks in Off the Dribble. This is the coach of the year discussion.

title: Vanderbilt or Yale?
description: I feel like Jake Pavelka.

title: Chart: MGMTs Congratulations
description: The artist Andrew Kuo charts his take on Congratulations (Columbia/Sony), the controversial new album by the Brooklyn rock band MGMT, where it sheds its radio-friendly electro-pop sound for psychedelia.

title: Apple Invites Pulitzer Winner to Resubmit His Rejected iPhone App
description: Update: Apples chief executive apparently believes that his company made a mistake when it rejected an iPhone app from a cartoonist who is now a Pulitzer prize winner. Steve Jobs, the Apple chief executive, responded by e-mail message to a customer who asked about Mark Fiores rejected app on Friday.

title: Healthy Talk About Food With Kids
description: In the Sunday magazine this weekend, Peggy Orenstein muses about how food is never just food.

title: Unhappy With Your Looks? Or Is It a Disorder?
description: When is it ordinary unhappiness about the way you look, and when is it a psychological disorder? Thats the question explored by Dr. Katharine A. Phillips in this weeks Consults blog. Dr. Phillips, a professor of psychiatry at Brown Medical School, recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers questions about body dysmorphic disorder, or B.D.D., an unusual condition in which people become obsessed about perceived body flaws. To learn more about B.D.D., see Personal Health columnist Jane Brodys story When Your Looks Take Over Your Life. Dr. Phillips writes:

title: New Yorkers Get Average Grade on Census
description: New Yorkers seem have done a slightly better job doing their homework than they did a decade ago.

title: Do You Love Your Freedom?
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: At a Tea Party rally in Boston yesterday, Sarah Palin praised the crowd for winning that Senate race in Massachusetts. She said: Shoot, look at what you did in January. You shook up the United States Senate. Unfortunately, no one heard the Senate thing, because after she said shoot, 300 guns went off.

title: Calculating Your Tax Bill, on the Go
description: Ever sit in line somewhere and think, hey, I wonder how much federal income tax Ill owe this year?

title: Your Playoff Theme? Amazing is
description: In the last few years, the N.B.A. has marketed the playoffs under the slogans Win or Go Home, There Can Only Be One, and I Love this Game.

title: A Lot of Dependents
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: It is April the 15th. This is a day we all curse like Joe Biden.

title: Lessons in 20th-Century History
description: Mammy

title: Baghdad: The Traffic Is Murder
description: I heard a thud, but did not think much of it. The car picking me up arrived on time that morning, so everything was normal, I thought.

title: Talking About the Roman Catholic Church and the Sex Abuse News
description: Please note: In this post we present several classroom ideas for addressing and contextualizing the current news about sexual abuse and the Roman Catholic Church. As always, we assume you will adapt our suggestions to fit your curriculum, but also to make sure the content is appropriate for your students.

title: Naked Ambition
description: "Look for the woman in the dress, Coco Chanel once decreed, meaning that her customer, not her clothes, should draw the eye first. With the current vogue for blush- and flesh-colored fashion, following this directive is at once easy and difficult. Easy when the palette is deployed in transparent fabrics (like the Rochas nude lace top that made it impossible not to look at the model . . . or at least at her instantly discernible nipples). Difficult when the individual and the outfit share the exact same coloring  a problem exemplified at this years Oscars by actresses from Demi Moore (whose apricot Versace gown blended seamlessly with her spray-on tan) to Anna Kendrick (all but invisible in pasty pink Elie Saab). Just last week, I myself decided not to buy a peach suede jacket by the Row because the saleswoman told me, It looks like youre wearing your own skin. She seemed not to find this notion creepy.

title: Naked Ambition
description: Nude fashion is not an oxymoron. Caroline Weber bares all.

title: Financial Tuneup: Check Your Credit Reports Free
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: Advertisers Line Up for Sex and the City Sequel
description: The film version of Sex and the City was not only a hit with moviegoers two years ago, it was also one of the more successful recent examples of a film studio assembling a phalanx of brands and products to help market the movie. With Sex and the City 2 coming out on May 27 from the New Line unit of Warner Brothers, the marketing tie-ins are already on their way.

title: Another Casting Change for Patton Oswalt
description: Hey, remember that silly blog that said a few days ago that even if Patton Oswalt didnt have a place on Broadway, he would still have a home on television? Wait a minute  that was us. Well, never mind.

title: A Wire Star Redirects His Electricity
description: IDRIS ELBA is a businessman. In fact, he might remind viewers of Stringer Bell, the no-nonsense Baltimore drug lord Mr. Elba memorably played on the HBO series The Wire. You got to think about what we got in this game for, Stringer once admonished a colleague, his soft, deep voice studded with emphatic profanity (here deleted): Was it the rep? Was it so our names could ring out on some ghetto street corner? Naw, man. Theres games beyond the game.

title: Must See: And the Awards Go To
description: Tainted Meat (09:15)

title: Excerpt: 'Friday Night Lights'
description: The small-town drama returns for its fourth season on NBC.

title: Book Review Podcast: Anna Quindlen
description: This week: A conversation with Anna Quindlen about her novel Every Last One; The Timess Larry Rohter tells us about this years Pulitzer Prize winners; Daniel Gross talks about two excellent new books about the Wall Street implosion; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Good News for the Young Gay Applicant
description: The forthcoming edition of The Timess Education Life quarterly, which is previewed online here, includes an article by my colleague John Schwartz under the headline, Finding a Gay-Friendly Campus.

title: No Gold, but Something Better: Going Home
description: Near the end of last year, Kevin Pearce was one of the best snowboarders in the world. He had visions of winning more halfpipe contests, making the United States Olympic team and returning home to Vermont, perhaps with a medal.

title: Answers About Child-Friendly New York, Part 3
description: Following is the third and final set of responses from Alison Lowenstein, the author of City Kid New York: The Ultimate Guide for NYC Parents With Kids Ages 4-12 (Rizzoli/Universe 2010).

title: Book Review Podcast: Anna Quindlen
description: This week: A conversation with Anna Quindlen about her novel Every Last On; The Timess Larry Rohter tells us about this years Pulitzer Prize winners; Daniel Gross discusses two excellent new books about the Wall Street implosion; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Q. & A. With Sam Sifton (Round Two)
description: The questions have been coming fast and occasionally furious since Diners Journal posted my food diary on Thursday  an accounting of all that I consumed over the course of seven days eating, and what I expended in purposeful exercise during it.

title: Goldmans Stock Loss Dwarfs Possible Penalty
description: Shares of Goldman Sachs fell as much as 15 percent on Friday, pulling down other financial stocks, after the Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil fraud charges against the firm, accusing it of creating subprime mortgage securities that were designed to fail. The banking sector declined as much as 2.6 percent on the news.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry May Widen, Khuzami Hints
description: NEW ORLEANS  The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking closely at other mortgage security deals made in cooperation with investors betting against the housing market in the wake of its civil lawsuit against Goldman Sachs, the agencys enforcement director said Friday.

title: PharmVille: Dr. Bobs Web Site
description: Say you start to find social encounters terrifying. Your doctor proposes a medication called phenelzine. Now you have a question: What does phenelzine feel like?

title: The Cecil B. DeMille of Movie Lists
description: IF Brad Bourland were a movie character he might be T. E. Lawrence in Lawrence of Arabia, embarking on a small project yet ending up on an epic quest; perhaps hed be Jake Gittes in Chinatown, relentlessly digging, following what he finds even if it takes him someplace disagreeable; or maybe Jefferson Smith in Mr. Smith Goes to Washington, an outsider and novice who shows the establishment a thing or two.

title: Kanes Twist on Playoff Hair: Its in Back
description: Its the time of the year when normally clean-shaven N.H.L. players start turning into clones of Grizzly Adams.

title: Bringing Up Baby, Dirt and All
description: My husband and I have a crawling baby who puts everything he finds into his mouth. So we dont allow shoes in our home. A friend came over to watch a movie with me and began picking dead skin from her lip and scratching her scalp, flicking what she collected under her nails onto the floor. I didnt want my son ingesting this! I asked if she needed a tissue, but she missed my point. Should I just keep her out of our house?

title: Treating a Sons O.C.D.
description: Our 12-year-old son has obsessive-compulsive disorder. His psychiatrist recommended a medication, but our son fears its potential side effects and refuses to take it. We could sneak a liquid version into his meals, but his physician said this could be considered child abuse. Yet under the circumstances, not doing so seems worse, considering that our sons condition prevents him from making a self-healing decision. What to do? NAME WITHHELD, PENNSYLVANIA

title: The Lake Shore Limited
description: Because it was still afternoon, because she was in a strange room, because she was napping rather than sleeping ("I'll just lie down for a bit and see what happens," she'd told Pierce)  because of all this, she was aware of herself as she dreamed, at some level conscious of working to subvert the dream she was having, to make it come out another way, different from the way it seemed to be headed.

title: History From Unexpected Characters
description: THE first clue that America: The Story of Us isnt your typical PBS-style documentary comes five minutes in. After actors re-create the early travails of the settlers at Jamestown and their eventual success building a tobacco business, the very first expert who comes on camera to put it all in context is not an eminent Harvard historian or noted archaeologist, but the businessman Donald J. Trump.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Courtney Love, Demi Moore, Idris Elba and More
description: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Weinsteins Get Window for Miramax Deal
description: From Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply at Media Decoder:

title: Toyota Admits Lexus Safety Problem
description: Updated 4:10 p.m.

title: The Morning Skate: Whats Wrong with Ovechkin and Other Cup Mysteries
description: Why do some hockey observers doubt the Washington Capitals, owners of the leagues best regular-season record, can be Stanley Cup champions? For all their offensive flair and charisma, especially that of Alex Ovechkin (who was well profiled last week in The Times Sunday Magazine by Charles McGrath), they dont play a good defensive game.

title: Face Booking | Benetton Casts a Wide Net
description: Diversity is a catchword thats often used in fashion but pretty rarely employed. Since 1982, United Colors of Benetton has been putting its money where its mouth is through its award-winning if controversial ad campaigns. Now the Italian brand has taken the message a step further with a democratic online casting, Its My Time. Candidates uploaded a profile with photos of themselves, and the community  yes, thats regular folks like you and me  voted on its favorites. The top 20, which included men and women from Iran, Belgium, Kazakhstan and India, were flown to New York City for a campaign shoot by the photographer Josh Olins. Its the first time Ive been here. I want to stay! one winner, Lorenzo, a k a Plastic is Fantastic, gushed last night at the a party in their honor at the Standard Hotel. (Plastic, he explained, is the name of my favorite disco in Milano.)

title: From Natalie Merchant, a Literary Tour
description: A FEW weeks ago Natalie Merchant was pondering what the promotional sticker should say on the package of her new album, Leave Your Sleep. She was worried that the P-word, as she put it, might deter potential listeners.

title: Parrot and Olivier in America
description: Chapter 1

title: British Leaders Debate in 60 Seconds
description: As The Lede explained on Thursday, polling after the first televised debate among the leaders of Britains three largest parties revealed that the public was most impressed by Nick Clegg, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, who is extremely unlikely to become the countrys next prime minister but may end up holding the balance of power if neither of the other parties wins a clear majority of seats on May 6.

title: Community Advocate to Challenge Espada
description: State Senator Pedro Espada Jr., the Bronx politician who staged a coup last summer and seized the Democratic majority leaders seat in Albany, will have some challengers of his own to fend off.

title: Media Decoder: Apple Invites Pulitzer Winner to Resubmit Rejected App
description: On Media Decoder, Brian Stelter writes about a digital-age perk of winning a Pulitzer Prize: Apple might invite you to resubmit your formerly rejected iPhone application.

title: In Global Unemployment, a Sea of Young Faces
description: The global recession has caused unemployment rates to rise almost everywhere, and for almost every group. But it was particularly hard on young people, whose unemployment rates rose much faster than those of adults.

title: Exploiting Kids on YouTube?
description: Remember David After Dentist? The video, recorded by his father, showed 7-year-old David DeVore in his car seat after minor oral surgery when he was still a bit loopy. The dads original goal was just to forward the few minutes of footage to his wife, who was at work, to show her that their son was O.K. But then he posted it on YouTube because, well, it was just so darn adorable, launching a debate over whether it is exploitation to forever immortalize online your child making a fool of himself.

title: In Bear Times, a Bull Market for Sitcoms
description: BURBANK, Calif.

title: What Goldmans Conduct Reveals
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil lawsuit against Goldman Sachs for securities fraud on Friday, charging the bank with creating and selling mortgage-backed securities that were intended to fail.

title: Poland Grieves, but With Few Tears
description: Adam Lach, a Polish photographer on assignment for The New York Times, has wandered through crowds and memorial events this week capturing images of a nation in shock.

title: Sun Setting on Duncans Dominance
description: One of the more fascinating first-round N.B.A. playoff series is the all-Texas matchup between Dallas and San Antonio, mainly because it could mark the beginning of the end of the Tim Duncan era.

title: Trusted Adviser, or Counterparty?
description: The S.E.C. civil suit against Goldman Sachs essentially accuses the bank of putting together a really bad investment so a hedge fund client could short it, and then selling that investment to clients without disclosing why the investment was created. Goldman says it did nothing wrong.

title: Theres a Theorbo in the Rock Bin
description: SHOPPING for recordings was so much easier back when genre distinctions seemed more concrete. When you hit the record store in search of Ravel or Radiohead, you had a good idea where to look. But when classically trained artists make music suited for both concert hall and nightclub (and play it in both), conventional categories become useless. Whither Clogs? Slow Six? Where does Redhooker reside?

title: After Strong Year for Hedge Funds, Investors Return
description: WHILE the stock market was surging back last year, so, too, were hedge funds.

title: Europe Moves Toward Tougher Bank Supervision
description: Banks operating in the European Union will have to accept stricter external supervision and be required to set aside more funds to prevent another crisis under a regulatory proposal to be presented by the European Commission in June, The New York Timess Raphael Minder reports from Madrid.

title: Coming Back to Hedge Funds
description: In this weeks Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan points to high returns in hedge funds of late and evidence that wealthy investors are creeping back in again.

title: Q. & A. With Sam Sifton (Round Three)
description: Got a lot of questions just now from a guy who calls himself NYTourist, from New York. Im going to break them apart because theyre good questions, and answer his queries as best I can. If the answers arent very good, and they very well might not be, it might be partly because I had lunch today  a dozen clams on the half shell followed by a salad and half a turkey club sandwich, followed by a coffee  and Im feeling a little dazed. I went to the gym in the morning and just hammered the weights and the stair-climbing machine, and by the time I got to lunch I was ravenous. Ruh-oh. Should have gone to the gym after lunch and written in the morning instead. Either way, I would have liked to have walked about 10 more blocks than I did in advance of returning to this hot seat to write. Also because: I have a dinner reservation in a couple of hours. Welcome to my life!

title: Milan Report | Rossana Orlandi Presents
description: Over the last few years Spazio Rossana Orlandi has become a must on the the Milan design circuit. The eight-year-old charmingly ramshackle former factory is not only a showcase for everything from high-end sofas to plastic forks but also a laboratory for emerging designers.

title: Is Deutsche Bank in, or Out of, Trouble?
description: The Goldman case today had a devastating impact on investors in Deutsche Bank, which is said to have packaged similar securities as the one in the Goldman case. But maybe todays action indicates Deutsche is in the clear.

title: Sunday Preview
Republicans Grill Appeals Court Nominee
description: Republican members of the Senate Judiciary Committee spooled out lines of attack on Friday that may well signal the themes for the Supreme Court confirmation battle looming ahead. In a more immediate way, their criticisms and concerns portend trouble for Goodwin Liu, the appeals court nominee who testified before them today.

title: Iceland Volcano Spews Consonants and Vowels
description: New Yorkers with suddenly dashed European travel plans were not the only ones in town inconvenienced by the eruption of a volcano 2,800 miles away.

title: Pictures of the Day: Rescue Efforts in China and Frustration in Europe
description: It happened in Concepcin, Chile, and in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, before that: dust-covered earthquake victims rescued against all odds from graves of rubble and twisted metal. We see it now in Chinas Qinghai Province (Slide 1), where a girl was rescued 50 hours after being buried by a 7.1-magnitude quake. The chances of survival are dimming, but rescuers keep clambering over the remnants of schools, hotels and mud-brick homes looking for signs that a few of the hundreds of people still missing might be alive (Slide 3).

title: Chatting Up the Trophy Girl, Toddler Style
