description: THE future of love revealed itself to me one morning two autumns ago as I zipped up my toddlers sweater outside a popular cafe in Boerum Hill in Brooklyn, one that played a role in my amorous past.

title: Chic In Review | The Book on Alexander McQueen
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: The Deft Dance of the Critic and Artist
description: Musicians never read reviews. Just ask them.

title: Letters: The Love That Dare Not Squawk Its Name
description: Jon Mooallem nicely encapsulates for the general reader a broad panorama of observation, research and interpretation concerning a relatively little-known and probably somewhat hidden aspect of biology. Absent from the discourse, however, is any mention of the simple notion of pleasure or of the more complicated emotions. The animal kingdom at its higher levels is suffused with not only reproductive survival drives but also with pleasure-seeking drives, an area covered by the science of hedonics, a discipline with a name itself suffering the moralistic denunciations engaged to suppress much about sexual behavior. It is interesting to note that there seems little of what we would call prejudice among animal societies toward nonstandard behavior, and yet there was no discussion of this judgmental and too-often-punitive activity that emerges in nominally more advanced human animals. There is much more to this subject; the author barely mentioned things likethe cavorting of dolphins, the pansexuality of bonobos and the same-sex mating behavior seen in deep-sea octopuses.THOMAS W. FILARDOEvendale, Ohio

title: Airline Merger Talks Renew Skepticism of Tie-Ups
description: Ever since the airline industry was deregulated more than three decades ago, the nations top carriers have operated under a basic premise: bigger is better.

title: Letters: A Closer Reading of Roman Vishniac
description: The problems of veracity in what is termed documentary photography go well beyond the work of Roman Vishniac. Persuasive voices have cast doubt on the authenticity of other famous images of the Leica era: The Falling Soldier [in the Spanish Civil War], by Vishniacs friend Robert Capa Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima, by Joe Rosenthal; and many others.

title: Letter: Questions for Rand Paul
description: Dismissive statements by the Kentucky Senate candidate Rand Paul to Deborah Solomon on federal regulations concerning seat-belt use and public smoking are vacuous. It is simply irresponsible for anyone, least of all a physician like Paul, to tout personal freedoms at any cost. It is deplorable that anyone would openly advocate that the only thing that really matters is the personal choices of the indulgers of unsafe behavior. Im shocked, really, that Paul would choose to make such ill-informed statements. If he cant look at the human cost of rolling back seat-belt or antismoking legislation, perhaps he can take a look at the cold bottom line. It costs every citizen-taxpayer a fortune to support emergency assistance for traffic fatalities, and we all pay in increased health-insurance costs when smokers are ill.GEORGE C. VILLARREALLexington, Ky.

title: Behavior: Few Young Men Counseled on Sexual Health, Study Finds
description: Despite repeated recommendations to provide reproductive health services to teenage boys and girls, few adolescent males are getting the information they need to protect themselves from H.I.V. and other sexually transmitted diseases, a new study reports.

title: Letter: Cooking With Dexter
description: Thanks to Pete Wells for his homage to Laura Ingalls Wilders wonderful food scenes throughout her books (Little House in the Hood). When my children were young, I read Farmer Boy aloud to them  it was to become our favorite of the Little House series. When the books characters started to prepare their meals, the kids would say, Oh no, theyre going to eat again! and we would all laugh while enjoying the detail of hearty meals described so vividly that we could almost taste every bite.DEBORAH KNOXPittsburgh

title: Aging: Diet May Be Linked to Lower Alzheimers Risk in Older People
description: Older adults appear to be at lower risk for Alzheimers disease if they eat a diet rich in fish, poultry, fruit, nuts, dark leafy greens, vegetables like broccoli and cauliflower, and oil-and-vinegar dressing, a new study has found.

title: The Man in the Grey Flannel Dishdasha?
description: Edicoo, the name of a new member of Icom, a worldwide network of independent advertising agencies, is odd, but certainly not unusual in an industry whose players bear names like Anomaly and StrawberryFrog. But where Edicoo is located may seem unusual: in Erbil, in the autonomous Kurdistan region of Iraq.

title: Formerly Unsober
description: The very first time I got drunk, I was 10. Id gone to some event with my father, who was in A.A. Some bigger kids thought it would be funny to get me tipsy. I dont remember how it felt. I just remember my dad, more scared than angry, yelling as the Volvo lumbered along and my head lolled against the seat: You cant drink! Im an alcoholic. My father was an alcoholic!

title: In Some Adoptions, Love Doesnt Conquer All
description: At times, Kelly Lytle Baehr wondered how they would all get through it. Two years ago, she and her husband adopted three boys from Ukraine  two of them 8, the other 16  and brought them back to their home in Omaha. She knew assimilation into a family life would not be easy; all had come from troubled backgrounds, including one who had spent the first five years of his life in a prison orphanage back in Ukraine, and had a mother who drank while she was pregnant.

title: From the Left Flank, Pearce Eyes World Cup Roster
description: Heath Pearce brings a soccer fans enthusiasm and the deliberation of a graduate student to the F.C. Dallas back line. If all goes well for the 25-year-old Pearce, he will do the same for the United States national team at the World Cup in South Africa.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 16
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Next Up: A Smarter Streetlight
description: The light-emitting diodes that are now common in traffic lights seem poised to move into more streetlights  and to get smarter.

title: Now Booking | Boca Chica in Acapulco
description: Old Acapulco is finding inspiration these days in its glittery past. The latest retro revival is the Hotel Boca Chica, a 50s era hideaway that gave birth to the margarita and sheltered John Wayne and his Hollywood cronies. Reopened a few weeks ago by Grupo Habita  the ultrahip owners of the Condesa DF in Mexico City, among other culty hotels  the Antonio Pelez-designed property has 36 minimalist rooms tucked away in a quiet cove beneath pink and white modernist bungalows that spill down the seaside cliffs where Rita Hayworth shot scenes for The Lady From Shanghai (1947) and Elvis filmed Fun in Acapulco (1963).

title: Katzenberg Talks Up 3-D at Broadcasters Convention
description: Despite the media attention given Jeffrey Katzenbergs recent negative comments about the poor-quality 3D conversion of Clash of the Titans, the DreamWorks Animation chief executive is convinced that 3-D production is real, and will soon overtake standard 2-D fare in quantity.

title: Ford Eco-Route: The Most Fuel-Efficient Path From A to B
description: Fords new map-based navigation system has three options: the fastest route, the shortest route and also the Eco-Route.

title: Goldman Fraud Case Holds Risks for Both Sides
description: Professors Peter J. Henning and Steven M. Davidoff examine the stakes in the securities fraud case against Goldman Sachs.

title: Comments of the Week: Robots, Nerds and Adobe Flash
description: This weeks rumblings of a Google slate PC stirred up the blogosphere and the Bits comments. The post A Google Tablet Could Be Good News for Adobe asked if Google could be a white knight for Adobe and its struggling Flash platform and generated a healthy debate about the future of both companies battle against Apples iPhone operating system. An anonymous commenter summed up Googles goals:

title: The Enduring Relevance of a Gold-Rush Tycoon
description: In 2001, T.J. Stiles, a writer now living in San Francisco, embarked on a biographical project as uncompromising and ambitious as its subject. For seven years, he holed up in an archive or wrote and rewrote in his Presidio home. The long hibernation has now been well rewarded.

title: Steve Jobs Says Apple Made a Mistake in Rejecting Pulitzer Winners App
description: Apples chief executive apparently believes that his company made a mistake when it rejected an iPhone app from a cartoonist who is now a Pulitzer Prize winner.

title: South African Judge May Be Kept From Grandsons Bar Mitzvah
description: JOHANNESBURG  For the past few days, many South African Jews have concerned themselves with a question perhaps better put to Talmudic scholars: Is it ever right for protesters to keep a grandfather from his grandsons bar mitzvah?

title: Footnote
description: The choreographer Bill T. Jones is this years recipient of the annual Jacobs Pillow Dance Award. Mr. Jones will accept the award, which carries a $25,000 cash prize, in person at the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival opening gala on June 19.

title: Daniel Radcliffe to Star in How to Succeed
description: How do you succeed on Broadway without really trying? It doesnt hurt when you have a star from one of the most successful film franchises in history in a leading role. Daniel Radcliffe, right, the Harry Potter star  who, in fairness, works hard in all his endeavors, were sure  will play the ambitious window washer J. Pierrepont Finch in a revival of How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying that is planned for Broadway in the spring of 2011, its producers announced on Thursday. The musical revival, with music and lyrics by Frank Loesser and book by Abe Burrows, Jack Weinstock and Willie Gilbert, will be Mr. Radcliffes first Broadway role since the revival of Equus that ran at the Broadhurst Theater in 2008 and 2009. Rob Ashford (Promises, Promises; Curtains) will direct How to Succeed, and it will be produced by Broadway Across America (John Gore, Thomas B. McGrath and Beth Williams), Craig Zadan and Neil Meron. The original production (with a cast that included Robert Morse and Charles Nelson Reilly) opened in 1961 and ran for more than 1,400 performances; a film version was released in 1967, and a previous Broadway revival, starring Matthew Broderick and Megan Mullally, was mounted in 1995.

title: Terry Gilliam Takes on His First Opera
description: As long as his production doesnt go far over budget, abruptly run out of funds, get ruined in a flash flood or be drowned out by NATO aircraft drills  all calamities that have befallen him in the past  the director Terry Gilliam, right, is scheduled to make his operatic debut with the English National Opera next year, The Guardian reported. Mr. Gilliam, the Monty Python alumnus whose films include Brazil, and whose disaster-plagued shoot for an aborted film, The Man Who Killed Don Quixote, was the subject of the documentary Lost in La Mancha, will direct a production of Berliozs Damnation of Faust planned for May 2011. The English National Opera, which previously recruited the director Anthony Minghella to stage a successful production of Madame Butterfly, acknowledged that there were risks when anyone directs opera for the first time. (It can be like a car crash coming at you from every angle, John Berry, the opera companys artistic director, told The Guardian.) But Edward Gardner, the companys music director, said Mr. Gilliam has a real grip on what needs to be done, adding, I cant wait to tap into his crazy world and artistry. Other works on the 2010-2011 calendar of the English National Opera include a production of Donizettis Lucrezia Borgia directed by Mike Figgis, who is also making his opera debut, and a new opera by Nico Muhly.

title: Of Meter and Money
description: Who says poetry doesnt pay? On April 26 and 27, there will be 53 high school students from around the country reciting verse from memory before a panel of judges, vying for the title of Poetry Out Loud Champion and a total of $50,000 in prize money. The competition, a partnership between the Poetry Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts, began last month with contests in all the states (and the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands). The winners of those competitions will go to Washington for the semifinals on April 26; nine students will advance to the finals on April 27. The national champion will receive $20,000; the second-place finalists $10,000; and the third-place, $5,000. Other finalists and semifinalists will also win cash prizes, and the finalists schools will each receive $500 to buy poetry books. The judges include Garrison Keillor, the poet and critic Adam Kirsch and last years national champion. Both the semifinals and the finals will take place at the Lisner Auditorium at George Washington University and are free to the public.

title: Couple Honored for Years of Loyalty to Theater
description: Ever since they helped found Primary Stages in 1985 and took seats on its board of directors, Marvin and Anne Einhorn have also volunteered five days a week as receptionists manning the phones at the Off Broadway theaters offices. On Friday, Mr. Einhorn, 89, and Mrs. Einhorn, 86, received an honor that usually goes to a millionaire donor: Primary Stages named its theater school on their behalf in recognition of their longtime commitment. The Einhorns, who have been married for 67 years, did not make a financial gift to the theater in return for naming rights, as is often the case with such tributes; rather, a Primary Stages spokesman said, they have given their time freely to handle phone calls  though they leave a bit early, at 2 p.m., on Fridays  and work on the board. The couple has long been retired; Mr. Einhorn worked for years in television, including as a director of NBCs Today show.

title: A Brand-New Time Lord, but He Sounds Familiar
description: They got rid of the high-tops, and for that alone we should be grateful. There was something profoundly irritating about watching David Tennant, the 10th Doctor Who, run around last season saving the world in a suit and sneakers.

title: MySpace Offers Service for Concertgoers
description: MySpace introduced a new service on Thursday that would allow individuals to manage their coming events within the social networking site and to buy concert tickets through links on artist pages and elsewhere on the site. Events chosen by a user will appear on the persons profile page and will be shared with their friends. The company hopes to expand the service beyond music and concerts, to movie and video game releases and other events, and onto mobile apps. Advertisers will be able to sponsor events, and if a ticket is sold through MySpace, the company could get a fee from the ticketing provider if there is a formal arrangement, as it has with LiveNation Entertainment. MySpace has struggled to maintain and add users in recent years, while Facebooks popularity has continued to rise. In March 2010, the site had a little over 70 million unique users, 6 million fewer than in October 2008, according to comScore, which measures Web traffic.

title: SNL Shines Brightly as FlashForward Dims
description: A special about the most recent decade of Saturday Night Live was a successful substitute for NBCs Thursday night comedies, but it was a Debbie Downer kind of night on ABC as its science-fiction series FlashForward continued to erode. The NBC documentary, Saturday Night Live in the 2000s: Time and Again, drew 6.7 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, following reruns of The Office. On ABC, FlashForward dwindled to 5 million viewers. CBS was the No. 1 network for the night with Survivor (12.1 million) and CSI (13 million), while Fox placed second with Bones (9.7 million) and Fringe (6.7 million).

title: Pad Thai
description: Mark Bittman makes the noodle dish Pad Thai with shrimp.

title: Pad Thai, an Easy Stir-Fry
description: IN the last 20 years or so, pad Thai has gone from being virtually unknown in this country to being a restaurant and takeout staple. Its easy to see why: the tangy, crunchy, slightly sweet noodles are irresistible. But its difficult to understand why more people dont make it at home, since pad Thai is essentially a stir-fry (in Thailand they refer to it as a Chinese noodle dish). It requires little more than chopping and stirring, and comes together in less than a half-hour.

title: A Pulitzer Winner Gets Apples Reconsideration
description: Heres a digital-age perk of winning a Pulitzer Prize: Apple might be a whole lot nicer to you and your work.

title: Dantes Unearthly Story Updated for the Stage
description: La Commedia, Louis Andriessens operatic dissection and reconstruction of Dantes Divine Comedy, is the centerpiece of a series of concerts devoted to the composer at Carnegie Hall this month and next. The opera, heard in a concert version at Carnegie on Thursday evening, was created as an elaborate production in which important musical and dramatic elements take place on film, projected on multiple screens. It occupied Mr. Andriessen from 2004 to 2008, and when Carnegie offered him its Richard and Barbara Debs Composers Chair this season, La Commedia was the first work he said he wanted to present.

title: Lawsuit Describes Art Blacklist to Keep Some Collectors Away
description: Imagine a market for highly sought-after items in which the makers and sellers work hard to ensure that the items go only to certain buyers, even if other buyers might be willing to pay more. The favored buyers are then expected not to resell the items for many years, even if the values skyrocket. Ideally, in fact, the buyers are expected to give these items away eventually, for the public good. And if the buyers dont abide by these expectations, they risk being cut off, cast out with the other unwashed wealthy who can afford to buy but have no access.

title: A Lively Celebration of the Power of No! No!
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  O.K., Im just going to say it, Patrycja Kujawska announces at the start of Charlotte Vincents If We Go On.

title: A Magazine, Long Gone, Is Given Digital CPR
description: A few months ago Robert Whiteman dashed off an e-mail message to Warren Buffett reminding that investor that he reportedly earned his first nickel selling Liberty Magazine in the 1930s. He told Mr. Buffett that he planned to resurrect the old publication for the digital age.

title: Pad Thai Doesnt Have to Be Takeout
description: Pad Thai has become a takeout staple in the United States, but there is no reason to fear making it at home. This recipe is fast enough, and easy enough, that it should become a from-scratch favorite.

title: Slow-Cooking Asparagus in Paper Packets
description: THE last thing I needed was another way to cook asparagus. What with steaming, grilling, braising, roasting, broiling and the various subgenres of frying  pan-fried, stir-fried and deep-fried  I practically had more cooking methods than weeks in the brief asparagus season. Why add another technique to the list?

title: Next Up, Abso and Smirnie?
description: Brands have long encouraged consumers to refer to them by nicknames or diminutives. Coca-Cola is Coke. Chevrolet is Chevy. Stolichnaya is Stoli. Now, in that same vein, Belvedere vodka is introducing a campaign that suggests calling the brand as Belve, pronounced Bell-vee.

title: What Were Reading: More Cellphones Than Toilets
Reviving Liberty
description: Robert Whiteman hopes to rekindle interest in the once-popular magazine, which stopped publishing in 1950.

title: Demi Moore, Then and Now
description: Clips and trailers from a selection of Demi Moore's films.

title: Detroit Seeks Exit From Doom Highway
description: Theres a war going on in Detroit, but not the one that immediately comes to mind, between drug dealers and the police, or corrupt politicians and prosecutors. This war is more abstract than those very real battles and more David-and-Goliath. At issue is whether seemingly overwhelming sociological and economic forces of decay can be reversed by a few individuals determined to fight the good fight, no matter how quixotic their efforts seem.

title: Park Guide Is Equally Bright Eyed and Bushy Tailed
description: Ladies, gentlemen and park users of all ages, meet Pearl. Shell be your cartoon squirrel.

title: Europes Cloud of Ash Casts Pall Over World of Music
description: Ticket holders worldwide, beware. That violinist onstage this weekend may be addled by a 14-hour drive. That pianist may not be the one you expected to see. The concert hall doors may even be locked because of a cancellation.

title: Goldman Fraud Case Weighs on Financial Bill
description: The securities fraud case against Goldman Sachs found its way into the Senates debate over the financial regulatory bill on Friday as senators from both parties tried to use it to their advantage, although the Democrats seemed more vocal.

title: A $30 Cable and an iPad on a Television
description: Last year in an effort to cancel my Time Warner cable, I bought an Apple TV. I came home with my new fancy sleek white packaging, tore open the box and plugged the Apple TV into my television. It took about 15 minutes before I went from excited to utterly frustrated.

title: No American Left Inside
description: President Obama  about the most urban president I can recall  today urged Americans to reconnect with the great outdoors.

title: Iceland Volcano Disrupts Air Travel
description: Clouds of volcanic ash blanketed parts of rural Iceland as a vast, invisible plume of grit drifted over Europe, emptying the skies of planes.

title: The Conservative Mind, Circa 2010
description: Here are a few thoughts on the conversation that Julian Sanchez started with a post on the American rights epistemic closure problem (i.e. the closing of the conservative mind), and which has subsequently been taken in all sorts of interesting directions by Matt Yglesias, Noah Millman, Megan McArdle, Sanchez again, Jonah Goldberg, and Conor Friedersdorf, among others.

title: Great Tax Expectations
description: More than 6 in 10 Americans expect their taxes to go up in the next year, according to Gallup. Even a majority of low-income taxpayers foresee an increase in their taxes:

title: Zimbabwe: Activists Honored by Obama are Jailed Again
On Being an Island in a Sea of Laughs
description: Am I missing something?

title: Senate Republicans Band Together in Opposing Financial Bill
description: Updated:  All 41 Senate Republicans have signed a letter urging the majority leader, Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, to adopt a more bipartisan approach in developing legislation to tighten regulation of the nations financial system.

title: Sunday in the Park, Feeling Natures Call
description: The birds and the bees are in full view across New Yorks parks these days, but when it comes to another fact of life, the signs can be a little less obvious. In Central Park, where a generous conservancy has attended to every landscaped inch, many maps posted along the way say nothing about any of the 19 free restrooms scattered across its 843 acres.

title: Good News from the Childbirth Front
description: One of the great tragedies of the developing world is the number of women who die in pregnancy and childbirth. But what is that number? Several studies had put it at somewhat more than 500,000 a year, while a new and apparently more rigorous study suggests that it has dropped to less than 350,000 a year.

title: No Ordinary Teachers in These Schoolrooms
description: No matter how much you enjoyed or are enjoying high school, your experiences are no match for the ones being savored by the students in Masterclass, a nine-part documentary series that starts Sunday on HBO.

title: Call and Response on the State of the Black Church
description: In the first decade of the American nation, a former slave turned itinerant minister by the name of Richard Allen found himself preaching to a growing number of blacks in Philadelphia. He came to both a religious and organizational revelation. I saw the necessity, he later wrote, of erecting a place of worship for the colored people.

title: Bove: Time to Clean House at Goldman
description: Leave it to Richard X. Bove, the outspoken banking analyst at Rochdale Securities, to call for the leaders of Goldman Sachs to fall on their swords.

title: Other Lonely Shores
description: A version of this column originally ran online. More than 130 readers shared their tales of being in the minority opinion on a show or movie. Here is a sampling. More comments are at nytimes.com/artsbeat.

title: Is the W.P.S. the iLeague?
description: Womens Professional Soccer, now in its second season, will not only Webcast a live game this Sunday, it will also provide a stream to users of Apples iPhone.

title: The Last of the Asian Godfathers
description: IT was 1994  the Year of the Dog  and Frank Ma was in a quandary.

title: In Narrow Win, Perfect Timing
description: The Vanderbilt and Spingold knockout team events feature 64-board matches. But even then a result can hang on a thin thread.

title: Watching the News, Not Reporting It
description: Gabe Pressman, 86, began working in 1954 for WNBCs radio station and then its television news. He has numerous Emmy Awards and is currently the senior correspondent for WNBC-TV, mostly as a blog writer on New York City news. He keeps working, he said, because the news is his lifeblood and because hanging around the apartment (at Central Park West and 92nd Street) would drive his wife, Vera, crazy.

title: Super-Powered Pride
description: Photos from a recent superhero costume party and leading gay and lesbian comic characters.

title: Weinstein Brothers Said to Be Near Deal to Buy Miramax From Disney
description: LOS ANGELES  Harvey and Bob Weinstein are on the brink of regaining control of Miramax Films, a move that would mark a triumphant and unexpected return by the pair to the independent film spotlight.

title: Meat, and the Men Who Deal in It
description: Meat  locally grown, wickedly smoked and unapologetically fatty  is the point of this Asian-flavored, neo-Confederate barbecue joint that sits at 91 South Sixth Street in Brooklyn, literally in the shadow of the Williamsburg Bridge. Out back in the yard are two Ole Hickory smokers, imported directly from Cape Girardeau, Mo. (It dont get more South than that, said the owner, Zak Pelaccio, not referring specifically to geography.) Inside are hipsters, chopstick wielders, wandering uptowners and, on a recent night, a table of dudes in the business.

title: Google Takes Printing to the Cloud
description: When Google began discussing Chrome OS, its new approach to an operating system that places all applications in the cloud, one question that wasnt answered was how the new OS would handle printing.

title: Revisiting Carnage and 39 Steps in New Incarnations
description: As that great cultural arbiter American Idol likes to remind us, theres more than one way to sing a song. Two charming new quartets of performers have joined shows that might be regarded as Broadway equivalents of pop-chart toppers: God of Carnage and Alfred Hitchcocks The 39 Steps, accessible comedies with nigh-irresistible hooks. And with these latest casts, interpretations that might have been merely dutiful or imitative have instead a sprightly freshness that makes you smile both at whats familiar and whats new.

title: Sale of Texas Rangers Is Delayed by Owners Dispute With Banks
description: The pending sale of the Texas Rangers has become a deepening standoff between the owner of the team, who says he has lost enough money on the franchise and will keep a portion of the proceeds from its sale, and creditors, who say they stand to lose many millions even if his full amount is turned over to them.

title: Adopting With Care, and for Good
description: A decade ago, the doctor peered at grainy videos, trying to glean a sense of the future from an out-of-focus present. Now, shes more likely to sit at her computer, click on an e-mail message, and view crisper footage taken on a Flip camera: a toddler waving a stuffed animal, a baby lying passively in a crib.

title: The Week in Pictures for April 16
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include a sinkhole in the Bronx, plans for New York University expansion, and a shoeshine man.

title: Nights at the Museum, When Fun Trumps Art
description: Its hard to talk about museums after-hours programs without getting confused. Differentiating among Nightlife (at the California Academy of Sciences), After Dark (the Exploratorium) and L@TE (Berkeley Art Museum)  in name, and in concept  is not easy.

title: As Cellular Service Expands in Subways, Thefts Rise
description: BOSTON  Nashira Muniz was sending a text message on her cellphone the other day when the phone rang. I just texted you! she said to the caller. Nothing unusual about that, except Ms. Muniz, 25, was deep underground, riding the subway.

title: What Were Reading: Improving Twitter
description: The tech reporters and editors of The New York Times were provoked by these thoughts:

title: Lets Just Indict the Deficit
description: I dont know how youre spending your spring, but here in New York we are all busy waiting for Andrew Cuomo.

title: Tough Times for Givers and Receivers
description: Grant making by foundations plunged last year, dropping an estimated 8.4 percent to $42.9 billion as the economic downturn hit even those wealthy institutions. The decline was the largest since the Foundation Center, a research group, began collecting such data in 1975. Still, it was not as severe as the center predicted last year, based on the sharp loss in the value of foundation assets. Some foundations pared expenses and reduced staffs. The Ford Foundation, for example, found $40 million in cost savings that it used for grants. Ford and other foundations also increased the portion of assets they gave away in hopes of ameliorating problems caused by the poor economy. While assets at the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation declined about 20 percent, the foundation increased the amount it paid out to 7 percent of the lower value of its assets, around $3.8 billion. Without the Gates spending, the decline in spending by foundations would have been 9.4 percent.

title: A 30-Pack of Charmin, but Where to Store It?
description: WHEN Costco opened its first Manhattan outpost last November, in a soaring East 116th Street shopping complex with river views, management did not know precisely who or what to expect: Would customers stream in from East Harlem and Washington Heights? Or would the aisles be flooded with Upper West Siders stocking up on San Pellegrino? How much demand would there be for kosher meat? Costcos nationwide sell some 57 million rolls of Charmin per month: would people living in cramped apartments go for those 30-roll packages?

title: Rookie From New Jersey Is Skating for the Enemy
description: NEWARK  Frans van Riemsdyk did not see his son, James, score his first N.H.L. goal live, so there was no way he was going to miss Jamess first Stanley Cup playoff game Wednesday. He bumped up a few appointments and caught an earlier flight.

title: Man Is Arrested in Shootings From a Crown Heights Rooftop
description: The police said Friday that they had arrested a man they accused of firing on a busy street in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, last week, wounding four teenage boys and sending crowds fleeing for cover. The authorities said the shooting was gang related.

title: Silly Bandz, the Bracelets That Spring Off Shelves
description: At Michael Casarens toy store in South Orange, N.J., children from elementary to high school are coming in every day with their wrists and forearms wrapped in a jumble of silicone bracelets, desperate to buy more.

title: Girls in Private Schools Ask, Thin Mints or Samoas?
description: Two dozen fourth graders from the Chapin School, all in regulation green vests that were dotted with badges, popped up from their chairs to recite the Pledge of Allegiance and the Girl Scout promise: On my honor. ...

title: Iraqi Sunnis Expect Allegiance Shift to Bear Fruit
description: TIKRIT, Iraq  As he sits in his palatial homes reception hall, Sheik Munaf Ali al-Nidah denounces the governments of both Iraq and the United States and shakes his head over the vilification of the Baath Party. Above his mantel is a photograph of a smiling Saddam Hussein. A Saddam Hussein watch is wrapped around his wrist.

title: 10 Years After a Mea Culpa, No Hint of a Me, Too
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon

title: When Pizza Becomes Predatory
description: By 9 oclock each morning, the arithmetic of debt jams the courthouses of New York City, the far end of a trail that begins on Wall Street and is paved with securitized bonds and chits for appliances bought on credit.

title: Excerpt: 'America: The Story of Us'
description: This sweeping history of America includes celebrity commentators and lots of CGI.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: In Hospital Decision, Obama Finds Safe Ground on Gay Rights
description: ATLANTA  President Obama has found a way to support gay rights that least offends those who oppose them.

title: New York Seeks Limits on Art Vendors in Parks
description: Street vendors who have become fixtures at some of Manhattans busiest parks  hawking paintings, kitschy souvenirs and all sorts of ephemera  may find themselves a lonelier crowd, as the Bloomberg administration proposes to cut their numbers by 75 percent.

title: Veto Threat Raised Over Derivatives
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama threatened on Friday to veto the financial overhaul bill making its way through Congress if it failed to include strong restrictions on derivatives, which were at the heart of the financial crisis two years ago.

title: Events on Long Island
description: Comedy

title: On the Street | Eggwear
description: The Fifth Avenue Easter Parade attracts visitors from around the world, eager to see the still-stylish stroll.

title: Volcanic Eruptions Affect Hundreds of Runners Travel to Boston
description: The Boston Marathon is one of the most famous tests of endurance. For runners coming from Europe this year, getting to the event may be even more difficult than running the 26.2 miles.

title: Voters Concerns on Immigration Spin British Campaign
description: LONDON  Few people in the working-class neighborhood of Barking seem willing to proclaim unalloyed enthusiasm for the ultra-right-wing, anti-immigration British Nationalist Party. But get past hello in any conversation and their feelings come spilling out.

title: Amazon Dam Project Pits Economic Benefit Against Protection of Indigenous Lands
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The indigenous leaders had a plan. They would unite for a last, desperate stand against the mammoth dam threatening their lands in the Amazon, vowing to give their lives, if necessary, to prevent it from being built.

title: New Look and Flavors at an Old Standby
description: FOR almost 30 years, Crabtrees Kittle House has been a destination for all occasions, from friends meeting for a drink or casual supper to large formal groups celebrating one of lifes milestones.

title: China Starts New Bureau to Curb Web
description: BEIJING  China has quietly formed a new bureau expected to help to police social networking sites and other user-driven forums on the Internet, which are proving harder for the government to monitor and control than ordinary news portals.

title: Fox Canceled Hannitys Attendance at Tea Partys Tax Day Rally in Cincinnati
description: For more than a week on his Fox News show, Sean Hannity promoted his planned Tax Day attendance at a Tea Party rally in Cincinnati. But as hundreds of Mr. Hannitys fans lined up for a pre-rally book signing there on Thursday, he was whisked back to New York, his plans scrapped by his bosses at the last minute.

title: Goldmans Stacked Bet
description: From Government Sachs to guest of the government? Goldman Sachs, which emerged relatively unscathed from the financial crisis, was accused of securities fraud in a civil suit filed Friday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which claims the bank created and sold a mortgage investment that was secretly devised to fail, report The Timess Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson. Release the schadenfreude!

title: For Burgers, Try Ostrich
description: Ramzey Rizk, 31, of Westbury said he opened the Fuel Your Body Cafe last May because it was cheaper to open my own place than to keep driving into the city for this kind of food.

title: A Taste of the South (Many, Many Tastes)
description: THE restaurant LL Dent calls its food American cuisine with a Southern flair. The Southerner at our table, digging into collard greens and grits, called it a taste of home.

title: Web Coupons Know Lots About You, and They Tell
description: For decades, shoppers have taken advantage of coupons. Now, the coupons are taking advantage of the shoppers.

title: Cafeteria Fare, Korean-Style
description: School Zone in Fort Lee is a playful restaurant that takes its inspiration from school cafeterias in Korea. This kind of food is memory food for Korean students, said the owner, Dong Kang, 51.

title: The Soul of a Bistro in the Form of a Diner
description: THE Skylark Diner is one strange bird. Perched on the traffic-choked flyway that is U.S. 1, its multicolored neon plumage poised for liftoff, it looks garish, flamboyant, possibly radioactive.

title: Faces of Health Debate Point to Laws Complexity
description: WASHINGTON  They were the human faces of the nations wrenching, yearlong health care debate.

title: Congo: Red Cross Aides Are Freed
description: Eight Red Cross staff members kidnapped in the Democratic Republic of Congo last week were released unharmed on Friday, the International Committee of the Red Cross said. The staff members, seven Congolese and one Swiss citizen, had just completed an assessment mission in a war-racked pocket of eastern Congo when they were abducted by a local militia.

title: Record Audience Tuned In for British Debate
description: LONDON  An independent audience survey conducted for Britains main television networks said about 9.4 million people watched the first-ever televised election debate on Thursday night among the three candidates bidding to become prime minister after the May 6 election.

title: In the N.F.L., an Amorphous Standard for Character
description: The Jets are excited about their prospects for the new campaign. They reached the A.F.C. championship game last season and have been reloading for a Super Bowl run. They made two bold moves in the off-season  bringing in Santonio Holmes, the troubled but talented wide receiver, and Antonio Cromartie, a great cornerback talent whose work ethic was questioned last season.

title: The Morning Glory of Lobster
description: With dinner hours limited to two nights a week, the Village Cafe and Bistro would seem to be more cafe than bistro. Yet the knotty pine floor, varnished wood counter, expressionist oils on the walls, and ample number of tables inside and out endow the place with a handsome feel that goes well beyond your basic diner.

title: Infusing Indian Recipes With Western Touches
description: RESTAURANT row in downtown Stamford  Summer Street between Broad Street and West Park Place  is home to about 10 restaurants, most of them relatively upscale. But the Indian restaurant Tawa, the newest arrival on the block, offers several satisfying dishes at more moderate prices.

title: A Mighty Pale Tea
description: GRAND PRAIRIE, Tex.

title: Paltry Tribute to a Yankee Lost Too Soon
description: ON a lonely block in the South Bronx, beyond the reach of Yankee Stadiums shadow and the championship trophies shine, a forgotten memorial to a fallen baseball demigod sits hidden in plain sight.

title: What Haiti Needs Right Now
description: Haiti has an oceans worth of problems, but money shouldnt be one of them. The worlds response to the Jan. 12 earthquake was swift, with more than 150 countries and organizations promising to send hundreds of millions of dollars for emergency relief and billions more for long-term rebuilding.

title: A Hit Parade for a Pop-Hungry Set
description: When the curtain goes up on Smokey Joes Caf at the Paper Mill Playhouse, four guys are standing casually around a jukebox. They begin singing Neighborhood (Faded pictures in my scrapbook/Just thought Id take one more look) as the other five cast members stroll onstage and join in. If that setup is a playful reference to the term jukebox musical, no show has a greater right to use it.

title: Watch This Case
description: Months ago, Gretchen Morgenson and Louise Story of The Times exposed Goldman Sachss practice of creating and selling mortgage-backed investments and then placing financial bets that those investments would fail. While appalling, it wasnt clear whether the practice was also fraud. The Securities and Exchange Commission has now decided that it was, charging Goldman on Friday.

title: U.S. Indicts 5 Blackwater Ex-Officials
description: WASHINGTON  Federal prosecutors charged the former president of Blackwater Worldwide and four other former senior company officials on Friday with weapons violations and making false statements in the first criminal inquiry to reach into the top management ranks of the private security company.

title: Justice and Comfort
description: The cause of equal rights for gays and lesbians, which is advancing in hard-won increments, moved forward on two important fronts this week.

title: In Tom Sawyer, Homage to Childhood
description: There is a dead cat in Hartford Stages Tom Sawyer. Huckleberry Finn carries it around for a while for no good reason. But the animal (fake, of course) is strangely cute, like one of those puppets Craig Ferguson plays with on The Late, Late Show.

title: The Whole Ravitch Rescue
description: New York States lawmakers remain deeply divided over how to balance a $135 billion budget with a $9.2 billion hole in it  before the state runs out of cash in June.

title: Troopers Role in Helping Roethlisberger Is Investigated
description: The Pennsylvania state police are investigating whether one of their officers violated regulations on off-duty work last month when  Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger was accused of sexually assaulting a 20-year-old woman at a rural Georgia nightspot.

title: Outpost of Economic Cheer in a Borough Weary of Recession
description: Worlie Steven Moore spent much of his working life selling stylish mens suits in luxury stores like Saks Fifth Avenue. But in February 2009 he was laid off and spent nearly a year out of work, mostly catching up on reading because looking for employment in his field during a recession seemed futile.

title: Filling in the Blanks
description: When is a painting finished?

title: Reverse Mortgages Still Costly, but Less So
description: The adage that you cant take out a loan to pay for retirement is not entirely true.

title: Do Price Cuts Make Reverse Mortgages More Attractive?
description: This weeks Your Money column looks at the recent price cuts in reverse mortgages, which allow older homeowners to essentially take a cash advance against their home equity  without having to make any payments.

title: Pushing the Boundaries of Dance
description: PURCHASE

title: 104 Are Arrested in Connection With Crips-Bloods Alliance
description: The Flocc street gang had an unusual mix of members. It formed out of an alliance, law enforcement officials said, between two groups that have traditionally been rivals: the Crips and the Bloods.

title: Frustration May Have Led Parolee to Shoot Officer
description: He had fired a bullet into his parole officers upper chest on Thursday evening, the police said, and now Robert Morales was aiming at the officers face and trying to pull the trigger again to kill the officer, which would probably send him back to prison for good.

title: Oom the Omnipotent Was Here
description: Yoga enthusiasts in Nyack can shop for classes in styles like anusara, vinyasa, iyengar and bikram. But the scene seems almost quaint compared with 90 years ago, when Dr. Pierre Bernard (right) introduced the rich and eccentric to the joys of the tantric tradition. The media called him Oom the Omnipotent; his devotees said he was a pioneer. To others, he was trouble.

title: John Jay College Accused of Bias Against Noncitizens
description: The Justice Department filed a lawsuit on Friday against John Jay College of Criminal Justice, alleging that the school engaged in a pattern of job discrimination against noncitizens who were authorized to work.

title: Obama Weighs Supreme Court Nominees, and Each Potential Battle
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obamas advisers consider Supreme Court nominees, White House officials and political activists are focusing on the vulnerabilities that conservatives could exploit to portray them as so-called liberal judicial activists, according to interviews and a review of documents.

title: At Upstate Campus, Saving Energy Is Part of Dorm Life
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  The Energy Star label, the federal governments nod of approval for energy-efficient products, usually calls to mind household appliances like refrigerators and air-conditioners. But at Ithaca College, a campus known for its embrace of all things sustainable, two dormitories proudly wear the Energy Star label, too.

title: Watercolors From the Kenyan Wild
description: Shelly Malkin is no stranger to the extremes of the natural world. Ms. Malkin, an artist who lives in Greenwich, is an avid rock climber, which comes with a pretty much endless supply of breathtaking vistas.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 16, 2010

title: Dispute Revives Battle Between Rafters and Property Owners
description: GUNNISON, Colo.  For years, Mark Schumacher has guided white-water rafts up and down the Taylor, a swift moving river that cuts through the canyons and cliffs outside Gunnison.

title: Meteorites in Them Thar Fields
description: CHICAGO  On the first day, there was light. On the third day, land  strewn with meteorites.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about state-of-the-art incinerators in Europe that cleanly convert waste to energy referred incorrectly to the ownership status of Covanta, a New Jersey company that processes some trash from New York City at older incinerators in Newark and Hempstead, N.Y. It is a publicly traded company, not a private one.

title: Put Vendors in Their Place
description: JUST in time for summer, proposed Department of Parks and Recreation regulations would designate  and limit  where artists may sell their works in and around New York Citys major parks. Art vendors would be able to set up shop, with table or easel, in city parks, but in certain heavily congested areas under the Parks Departments jurisdiction their numbers would be limited. No doubt some champions of individual expression will cry censorship. Indeed, the leader of the largest art vendor group is already preparing a legal attack on the new regulations.

title: Bloggingheads: Tea Party Anger
description: James Poulos, left, of Postmodern Conservative and James Pinkerton of Fox News discuss Tea Partiers politics.

title: Toyota Agrees Lexus S.U.V. Has Problem With Handling
description: Toyota said Friday that its engineers had duplicated the errant slide that prompted Consumer Reports to issue a dont buy warning on the 2010 Lexus GX 460 and acknowledged that the vehicle had a safety problem.

title: 1 in 3 Americans Failed to Return Census Forms
description: Nearly one in three Americans failed to return their census questionnaires by Fridays official deadline, the Census Bureau said.

title: Strip in a Bar
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Youre right, thats a purposely salacious blog post title. Let me atone by tackling the bible clues first because theyre both terrific. Biblical spot ought to be EDEN but thats not enough letters. Theres a lot of complex geography in those testaments but fortunately we dont need to know any of it here as long as were reading the right translation. Spot is a verb. Thou SEEST? What about Fall cuisine? Yes, thats biblical too but APPLE is wrong. I laughed when the answer finally came to me like MANNA from heaven.

title: Out of the Closet and Up, Up and Away
description: DIM lighting. Rendezvous-friendly nooks. Muscled bartenders. Pulsating dance music. At first glance, it could be any Saturday night in any gay bar in New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the scheduled expiration of tax cuts for wealthier taxpayers included several imprecise or incorrect references. If Congress does not change current law, the following tax rates will be in effect after this year:

title: Sale of Texas Rangers Is Delayed by Dispute With Banks
description: The pending sale of the Texas Rangers has become a deepening standoff between the owner of the team, who says he has lost enough money on the franchise and insists on keeping some of the proceeds from its sale, and creditors, who say they stand to lose many millions even if his full amount is turned over to them.

title: In a Rush to Judge Goldman?
description: The market wasted little time in rushing to a particularly harsh judgment against Goldman Sachs on Friday, slicing some $12.4 billion off the companys market value after the Securities and Exchange Commission filed a blockbuster civil suit against the firm and a vice president who works there. The commission says Goldman failed to disclose to investors how a complicated mortgage-backed security was made and the conflicts that resulted from it.

title: Yankees Granderson Honored for His Off-Field Work
description: After less than two weeks as a Yankee, Curtis Granderson will get his first award Saturday before a game against Texas at Yankee Stadium.

title: The Past Is Never Dead. Its Not Even Past.
description: To the Editor:

title: Investor Who Made Billions Is Not Target of Suit
description: Three and half years ago, a New York hedge fund manager with a bearish view on the housing market was pounding the pavement on Wall Street.

title: Antony Flew, Philosopher and Ex-Atheist, Dies at 87
description: Antony Flew, an English philosopher and outspoken atheist who stunned and dismayed the unbelieving faithful when he announced in 2004 that God probably did exist, died April 8 in Reading, England. He was 87 and lived in Reading.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Timothy M. Dolans first year as archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York misstated part of the Latin terms for two types of Catholic bishops, the outward-looking and the inward-focused. The terms are ad extra and ad intra  not ad estera and ad intera. (A reporter writing a book about Archbishop Dolan describes him as ad extra.)

title: Rain Shortens Game but Does Little to Slow Sabathia or the Yanks
description: C. C. Sabathia, the ace of the Yankees pitching staff, is a large man who wears a big, baggy uniform that fits him like comfortable old pajamas.

title: Colleges Wait to Hear Their Name Called by Elite Recruit
description: BALTIMORE  Last Friday evening, Josh Selby, the nations most explosive high school guard yet to commit to a college, walked out the back door of Lake Clifton High School here with the Tennessee assistant Steve Forbes. The two kept chatting as they approached a light-blue Mercedes-Benz with tinted windows. Selby, keys in hand, popped the trunk, threw sneakers in it and joked with Forbes. Selby said goodbye, and drove away. It was Selbys last visit from a coach before making his college decision.

title: A Wall Street Invention Let the Crisis Mutate
description: Can it get any worse?

title: At Coachella, Rap-Rock Returns
description: INDIO, Calif.  The afternoon theme du jour is that rap goes with everything  no surprise, perhaps, when the nights headliner is Jay-Z, who has become the man for all festivals. But the more improbable corollary is that rap-rock, the widely derided late-1990s fusion that dominated FM rock radio for a few tedious years, is recovering some of its early promise. The days first blast of it was by P.O.S., a Minnesota rapper who details setbacks, struggles, contradictions and small, hard-won successes: I can never be what I want to be/Nothing but a man, he rapped. His rhymes are fast, with jagged rhythms; his band pounds without steamrollering him, and he keeps his shoutalongs simple enough to keep the crowd with him: Yeah right! went one, Yeah, went another.

title: Best Advice for Travelers: Rebook Your Flight
description: Still trying to figure out whether you can get to Europe this weekend in spite of all the chaos caused by the cloud of volcanic ash that has virtually shut down air traffic there? Youre out of luck but not out of options.

title: Europe Plan Would Put Tighter Rein on Banking
description: MADRID  Banks operating in the European Union will have to accept stricter external supervision and be required to set aside more money to prevent another crisis under a regulatory proposal to be presented by the European Commission in June.

title: Movie Futures Exchange Can Open, but It Cant Trade Yet
description: The commission that oversees futures markets approved on Friday a proposal by Veriana Networks to open a futures exchange, but expressed concerns about the companys plans to trade contracts on that market tied to the box-office receipts of forthcoming films.

title: Andrew Cuomos Message, Delivered Offstage
description: To the Editor:

title: Men, Women and the Catholic Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Obamas Failure to Fight for a Nominee
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Mine Disaster, a Question for the Regulators
description: To the Editor:

title: Igarashi Bolsters His Bid for Setup Job With Mets
description: ST. LOUIS  On a slow day toward the end of spring training, Ryota Igarashi finished a bullpen session and was approached by the Mets pitching coach, Dan Warthen, who was looking for something.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Reuters Breakingviews column on Friday about Americas lack of appetite for Greek bonds misstated the size of an aid package for Greece being assembled by European countries and the International Monetary Fund. The package is valued at 45 billion euros, not $45 billion.

title: The Cap Room Just Got a Little Bigger
description: With one unexpected and seemingly benign statement on Friday, Commissioner David Stern may have altered this summers free-agent landscape.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about new treatments for multiple myeloma, included an outdated reference to the insurance coverage of a patient, Janet Battaile. After she was interviewed for the column, but before the section went to press, Ms. Battaile learned that her insurer, United Healthcare, would cover her participation in a trial of the experimental drug pomalidomide; she is no longer battling her insurance company.

title: Two Men Found Shot, One Fatally, in the Bronx
description: One man was killed and another critically injured Friday evening when they were shot on a dead-end street in an industrial neighborhood in the Bronx, the police said.

title: L.I. Victims Family Criticizes Judge for Keeping Jury Late
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  On their third day of deliberations, the jurors determining the fate of a Long Island man accused of fatally stabbing a Hispanic immigrant in 2008 began deliberating at 9:45 a.m. Friday. By 9:30 p.m., nearly 12 hours later, they were still at the courthouse here, sitting in the courtroom listening to a court reporter read, line by line, the transcript of a lawyers detailed cross-examination of a witness.

title: Leading Gay and Lesbian Comic Heroes
description: A look at the most prominent gay and lesbian comic-book superheroes.

title: For Free Agents, Playoffs Could Be a Tipping Point
description: Dwyane Wade wants a parade in June, but he will probably be home by May Day. Chris Bosh wants a simple playoff victory, but he is firmly planted on his couch. Joe Johnson wants validation, Amare Stoudemire wants recognition and LeBron James wants something resembling world domination.

title: Perez Delivers, but One Pitch Is Enough to Upend Mets
description: ST. LOUIS  All Manager Jerry Manuel wanted from Oliver Perez was for him to pitch better than he did against the Cardinals in spring training, and to last six or seven innings with the Mets in a close game. It was not an extravagant request, even for Perez, a mercurial left-hander, and he did everything Manuel asked.

title: A Sorority of Three, and Counting
description: TWO weeks ago in Minneapolis, when Sarah Palin (the half-term Alaska governor) and Michele Bachmann (the Minnesota Republican congresswoman) took the stage to rally support for Ms. Bachmann for the midterm elections, they seemed to draw power from their proximity, like the Wonder Twins in the 1970s cartoons. But with their coordinating outfits  Ms. Palin in a shiny black jacket, glittery cross pendant and Madonna-in-the-80s pearl strands; Ms. Bachmann in a  Dynasty  -bright yellow jacket  they strongly evoked another retro duo, the stars of the 1997 film  Romy and Micheles High School Reunion.

title: Chipmaker in the Netherlands Plans to Sell Shares
description: NXP Semiconductors, the Dutch chipmaker owned by KKR & Company and Bain Capital, filed to raise $1.15 billion in what would be the biggest initial public offering in the United States this year. NXP did not disclose the number of shares it intends to sell or at what price range in its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday. The chipmaker, which is based in Eindhoven, The Netherlands, and has reported losses for three straight years, plans to use the proceeds to repay debt. NXP, with 27,000 employees, makes computer chips for a broad range of electronic device makers such as Nokia Oyj and Apple, according to the filing.

title: Thats How He Rolls
description: WILL FORTE walked into a Santa Monica, Calif., bowling alley on a recent evening carrying bowling shoes and flashing the boyish grin that makes him arguably the most crushable bachelor on Saturday Night Live.

title: Internal Report Faults S.E.C. In Stanford Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission did not conduct a meaningful investigation of the indicted money manager R. Allen Stanford until 2005 even though examiners suspected him of operating a Ponzi scheme eight years earlier, a report by the S.E.C.s inspector general, H. David Kotz, disclosed Friday. The S.E.C. sued Mr. Stanford in February 2009, claiming his Antigua-based firm, the Stanford International Bank, defrauded investors by selling billions of dollars in bogus certificates of deposit. He is jailed awaiting a January trial on related criminal charges that he oversaw a $7 billion Ponzi scheme.

title: Philosophical Waxing Eases the Ouch
description: A CLIENTS giggles bubbled up from a treatment room at the J. Sisters Salon in Midtown, which would be nothing remarkable were the client undergoing a regular salon treatment. But the laughter came over the rip-rip-rip of muslin strips covered in hot wax that were pulling hairs from her bikini area: the woman was in the midst of a Brazilian wax.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Two Marathoners Head to Boston, Each With an Eye on His Neighbor
description: A week ago, while Ryan Hall was running around sunny Walden Pond, Meb Keflezighi was back home in Mammoth Lakes, Calif., navigating through a foot of snow.

title: Message From Union Says Upper Deck Owes Players
description: Major League Baseballs players union told agents in an e-mail message on Friday that the trading card company Upper Deck was experiencing financial difficulty and had not paid a large number of players money it owed them.

title: U.N.s Bhutto Report Says What Pakistanis Already Know About Spy Agency and Army
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The long-awaited United Nations report on the assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto did not answer the central question of who killed her, but did put its finger directly on what remains the most troubling part of Pakistans reality, the dominance of its military and intelligence services over civilian leaders.

title: Air Travel Crisis Deepens as Europe Fears Wider Impact
description: PARIS  As an increasingly large part of European airspace was shut down for the third day on Saturday and the towering fountain of ash from an Icelandic volcano showed no signs of letting up, questions about the long-term impact of the eruption were being raised in a continent trying to recover from recession.

title: North Korea Denies Sinking Navy Ship
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea on Saturday denied involvement in the mysterious sinking of a South Korean warship in waters disputed between the two Koreas.

title: Photographs From Coachella, Day 1
Submit Your Questions for Clarence Seedorf
description: With five games remaining in the Italian Serie A season, A.C. Milan is in third place behind Inter Milan and Roma. Its final matches will test players will to challenge city rival Inter through the end of the season.

title: Biden Gave Only 1.44 Percent
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: Obama Vows to Move on Regulation
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Saturday accused Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, of waging a cynical and deceptive attack against a measure to tighten regulation of the nations financial system, and vowed to move ahead on the bill with or without the minority partys support.

title: N.F.L. Draft: The Road Back for Ryan  Perrilloux
description: Cecil Lammey of Draftguys.com will help preview and analyze the draft for the Fifth Down. He and Sigmund Bloom host the podcast at FootballGuys.com. You can follow him on Twitter here.

title: Urban Forager | Dandelion Wine? No, Jelly
description: Last weeks sudden 90-degree spell spurred a pageant of early flowering across the five boroughs that went far beyond the usual spring bulbs  see the magnolias, cherry blossoms and dogwoods in fervent bloom  but perhaps none more prominent than the ubiquitous yellow blossom that gardeners love to hate: the common dandelion.

title: The New Yorker Explains Resolution Authority
Every Mode but Silly Walks to Get Around
description: LONDON  For the man who worked at the Ministry of Silly Walks, travel chaos across the Continent was only a modest hurdle.

title: Time to Reread Akerlof and Romer
description: Looting: The Economic Underworld of Bankruptcy for Profit.

title: The Schumacher Question
description: The tension was palpable at the Mercedes team this afternoon after qualifying. Nico Rosberg had set the fourth fastest time and will therefore start fourth on the grid. His illustrious teammate, Michael Schumacher, could manage only ninth fastest  at .7 seconds slower than Rosberg.

title: The Saturday Word: Regulate
description: President Obama used his weekly national address to rally support for his plan to regulate Wall Street, saying that tighter restrictions on the financial industry would have prevented the economic meltdown. He also chastised the Senates top Republican for criticizing the Democrats efforts.When he returned to Washington, the Senate Republican Leader came out against the common-sense reforms weve proposed, Mr. Obama said, referring to Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the minority leader. In doing so, he made the cynical and deceptive assertion that reform would somehow enable future bailouts  when he knows that it would do just the opposite.

title: Aprils Poli-Book Best Seller List
description: The Big Short by Michael Lewis debuts at No. 1, providing further evidence of sustained reader interest in the failings of Wall Street. In fact, several books on this months Caucus list of political best sellers continue to mine the reasons for the nations financial downturn and collapse of big Wall Street institutions.

title: Fallon: New Comic Book
description: Monologue |  Friday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Jimmy Fallon: In an interview with GQ magazine, Lou Dobbs said hes considering running for president. Hey, stranger things have happened. Lou Dobbs in GQ magazine being one of them, I think.

title: The Shaky Planet
description: With news last week of yet another devastating earthquake, a 6.9-magnitude jolt in western China that killed at least 700, many wondered if the earth was in an especially volatile phase.

title: Prime Number
description: 125: The approximate number of former Congressional aides and lawmakers who are lobbying for Wall Street and the financial services sector as part of a multibillion dollar effort to shape, and often scale back, federal regulatory power over the industry, according to analyses by Public Citizen and the Center for Responsive Politics, two nonpartisan watchdog groups.

title: When an Invention Reached New Heights
description: George Nissen, inventor of the trampoline, died on April 7 at 96, but not before the acrobatics he first tried on the bouncing rig he built as a 16-year-old in 1930 (a canvas sheet stretched across a steel frame) became an Olympic event. Nissen was 86 and still capable of executing somersaults on his invention when he traveled to Sydney to watch the newly recognized sport. The Times was with him.

title: Fighting Words
description: Senate Republicans took a hard line against a Democratic proposal to regulate the financial system.

title: Correction: Stevens, the Only Protestant on the Supreme Court
description: A picture last Sunday with an article about Justice John Paul Stevenss being the only Protestant on the Supreme Court was printed in mirror image. While Justice Stevens was correctly identified in the photograph, of the justices on the Court in 1976, he should have been shown on the far right of the second row.

title: Video of Volcano Spewing More Ash
description: As my colleagues Julia Werdigier, Alan Cowell and Nicola Clark report, an Icelandic geologist, Magnus Tumi Gudmundsson of the University of Iceland, told The Associated Press on Saturday that activity was increasing at the Eyjafjallajokull volcano that has grounded flights across Europe.

title: At G.W.U., Commencement Competition
description: Call it the jitter room.

title: Copenhagen to Paris? Join the Crowd, Drink a Beer
description: The Times correspondent John Tagliabue recounts his three-day journey from Copenhagen to his home in Paris. Use the comments below to tell us how you or someone who know, besides John Cleese,  who improvised travel because of the volcanic plume over Europe.

title: Spiral
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Wait a sec, did I read that right? Did Will Shortz just announce his retirement? The third clue today reads Former New York Times crossword editor Will. Former?

title: Marine Stayed Faithful to Dream of Playing Football
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Even when the days were longest at his North Carolina Marine base, when he went to the weight room three times a day to fill the hours between the 4 a.m. physical fitness test and when he went to bed, Brandon Crawford would not join the unit football teams.

title: The Shy Life, Sniffing Bears, Oysters Away
description: Living Quietly

title: Fleeing Drug Violence, Mexicans Pour Into U.S.
description: FORT HANCOCK, Tex.  The giant rusty fence of metal bars along the border here, built in recent years to keep illegal immigrants from crossing into the United States, has a new nickname among local residents: Jurassic Park Gate, a nod to the barrier in a 1993 movie that kept dangerous dinosaurs at bay in a theme park.

title: N.F.L. Draft Travels Far for a Two-Night Stay
description: No longer pro footballs off-season daytime soap opera, the N.F.L. draft will have its premiere as a two-night prime-time special this year. Under the elegant gold stage curtain of Radio City Music Hall, the 32 franchises will select more than 200 rookies over three days. Few will be instant starters, some will make the team. Many will disappear during training camp.

title: Ferguson: Send Someone to Mars
description: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: President Obama went to NASA headquarters, where he said he wants to send someone to Mars. Theyre still deciding who to send. It was an awkward moment when Bill Clinton went, We could send Hillary.

title: For Goldman, a Bets Stakes Keep Growing
description: For Goldman Sachs, it was a relatively small transaction. But for the bank  and the rest of Wall Street  the stakes couldnt be higher.

title: Ski Team Pinched Everywhere but Top
description: The United States Ski and Snowboard Association continues to revel in its record-breaking success at the Vancouver Olympics, where 17 Americans took home 21 medals, the biggest haul in the organizations 100-year history.

title: Monica Youn and Whitney Armstrong
description: Monica Youngna Youn and Whitney Brewster Armstrong were married Saturday evening at St. Thomas Church in New York. The Rev. Jonathan M. Erdman, an Episcopal priest and the churchs curate and youth minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Wheres Bob Barker When You Need Him?
description: Ever been out playing with your buddies and thought it would be fun to try a Happy Gilmore swing on the tee? Come on, be honest.

title: Inquiry Faults S.E.C.s Handling of Stanford Case
description: Securities regulators suspected as early as 1997 that the Texas financier R. Allen Stanford was running a Ponzi scheme, a government investigation found, but they did nothing to stop it until late 2005.

title: Jennifer Ku and Peter Rubin
description: Jennifer Eunmi Ku and Justice Peter Jason Rubin were married Saturday evening at the Charles Hotel in Cambridge, Mass. Rabbi Jonah D. Pesner officiated.

title: Russia and Poland: A Blood Feud Rooted Deep in the Past
description: MOSCOW  Until very recently, President Lech Kaczynski of Poland was seen here as an especially disagreeable strain of Eastern European leader, one of those Slavic turncoats who demonized Russia and toadied up to its rivals. Then Mr. Kaczynski was killed in a plane crash on Russian soil this month, and Russia choked up.

title: Julie Horowitz, Ian Wallace
description: Julie Heather Horowitz and Peter Ian Wallace were married Saturday in New York. Michael S. Davidson, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated at the home of the brides parents, Barbara and Lawrence Horowitz.

title: Anne Leader, Richard Guether Jr.
description: Anne Conyers Leader and Richard Charles Guether Jr. were married Saturday by the Rev. William R. Heston at the First Presbyterian Church in Houston.

title: Why Newer Appointees Offer Fewer Surprises
description: WASHINGTON  The last two justices to leave the Supreme Court, David H. Souter and Sandra Day OConnor, were nominated by Republican presidents and then drifted left. So did Justice John Paul Stevens, who announced his retirement last week.

title: The Benefits of a Sabathia-Cervelli Partnership
description: On the morning of an A.J. Burnett start, the concept of a personal catcher was a topic in Joe Girardis pregame interview session. For a change, it had nothing to do with Burnett, who is making his third straight start Saturday with Jorge Posada behind the plate. C.C. Sabathia pitched brilliantly Friday night for the second consecutive outing, and both have come with the backup, Francisco Cervelli, catching him.

title: Jessica Shapiro, Gregory Cavic
description: Jessica Frances Shapiro and Gregory George Cavic were married Saturday at St. Stevens Serbian Orthodox Cathedral in Alhambra, Calif. The Very Rev. Radomir Chkautovich performed the ceremony with the assistance of the Rev. Serge Veselinovich. Both are Serbian Orthodox priests.

title: After Quake, Tibetans Distrust Chinas Help
description: JIEGU, China  The Buddhist monks stood atop the jagged remains of a vocational school, struggling to move concrete slabs with pickax shovels and bare hands. Suddenly a cry went out: An arm, clearly lifeless, was poking through the debris.

title: For Cash-Strapped  States, Sin Is Sure Lucrative
description: In tough fiscal times, everything needs to be monetized. Including morality.

title: New York Offers Costly Lessons on Insurance
description: When her small executive search firm in New York City canceled its health insurance policy last year because of the recession and rising premiums, April Welles was able to buy her own plan and still be covered for her cancer and multiple sclerosis.

title: Ann MacRae, Winthrop Ruml
description: Ann Cameron MacRae, a daughter of Ann Bedell MacRae and Cameron F. MacRae III of New York, was married Saturday to Winthrop Jordan Ruml, a son of Doriane Carter Ruml of Lexington, Mass. The Rev. Jonathan C. Page, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Jupiter Island Beach Club in Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. David C. L. Prior, an Episcopal priest, assisted.

title: Usha Pinninti and Geoffrey Kaung
description: Dr. Usha Rani Pinninti and Dr. Geoffrey Kaung were married Saturday at the Meridian House in Washington. Pandit Narayanachar Digalakote, a Hindu priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Katherine Susman, Zachary Baylin
description: Katherine Temma Susman and Zachary Jones Baylin were married Saturday evening on Pier 46 at Hudson River Park in New York. Jonathan F. Baylin, the bridegrooms father, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: No Planes, Waiting for Trains
description: For a third day, travelers in Europe scrambled to get around as the volcanic ash plume grounded flights over much of the Continent.

title: Hard-Luck Trail Blazers Trying to See the Basket as Half Full
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Nate McMillan could win the N.B.A.s coach of the year award because he not only Lewis-and-Clarked the Portland Trail Blazers through the leagues strangest season to reach the playoffs, but ruptured his Achilles tendon in the process.

title: For Giddyup, Give a Horse a Holiday
description: Mister Ed knew what he wanted out of a vacation. He once stowed away on a cruise ship bound for Honolulu, took up surfing and announced that he liked the Hawaiian life so much he wouldnt be returning home.

title: After Teams Collapse, Fans Enjoy Final Surprise
description: PORTSMOUTH, England  Through the dourest of winters, some of Englands most ardent soccer fans winced and vented, for their cherished Portsmouth team not only dwelled in the Premier League dungeon but also moved closer to relegation for next season. The club also typified the global recession when its debts threatened the whole enterprise with extinction.

title: A Fight to Save the House That Built Ruth
description: BALTIMORE  The hardscrabble field where George Herman Ruth Jr. learned baseball from a Xaverian brother is now a lovingly landscaped diamond. The little trees that he saw when he looked uphill from the field have grown into tall, graceful oaks.

title: Measuring Wall Street Apologetics
description: The parade of bankers called to account for the financial crisis continued last week when Kerry K. Killinger, head of Washington Mutual, the largest bank ever to fail, apologized, sort of, as have many before him. But he also said that his firm should have been given a chance. Here are some of those mea culpa moments.

title: Tea Party Supporters Doing Fine, but Angry Nonetheless
description: It makes sense that people would take to the streets to protest government spending and enormous deficits during the Great Recession, when they are feeling economic pain most acutely.

title: After Strong Year for Hedge Funds, Investors Return
description: While the stock market was surging back last year, so, too, were hedge funds, Paul Sullivan reports in his Wealth Matters column in The New York Times. This recovery may anger the average investor who equates hedge funds with the bad deeds of Wall Street. And the funds quick return may surprise sophisticated investors who are still smarting from the money they lost in their rush to move their portfolios to cash.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 18
description: President Barack Obamas financial regulatory overhaul and the approaching midterm November elections are the talk of the town  Washington, that is  this Sunday.

title: Uniform Number Is Just a Bit Low
description: Ever since he was 8 years old, Clay Buchholz said, he wore No. 11 on his jersey. But when Buchholz joined the Boston Red Sox in 2007, at age 23, he was given No. 61, typical for a rookie.

title: Best Safeties in the N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
description: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely  but not strictly  by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, although the future isnt ignored. Statistics werent acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally dont sneak on to Top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. Thats why most of you will have no trouble finding something to disagree with:

title: Castroneves Leaves Worries Behind and Finds He Is Smiling Again
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. (AP)  Hlio Castroneves is chatting with crew members outside his race hauler when fans call out his name.

title: Confident Burton Is Gaining Speed but Not Victories
description: FORT WORTH (AP)  Jeff Burton had been running some of the fastest laps at Phoenix before he was penalized for an improper pit stop.

title: Out of the Loop in Silicon Valley
description: San Francisco

title: Stalking a Saltwater Trophy in Belize
description: TURNEFFE ATOLL, Belize  Less than 20 minutes from the dock at Turneffe Flats Lodge, my angling buddy Geoff Roach and I beheld a sight that would set any saltwater fly anglers heart aflutter: the thin dorsal fins of a school of permit, slicing like a scythe through the clear Caribbean. Our guide, Michael Anderson, killed the motor, climbed onto his poling platform and began pushing us slowly toward the fish.
