Moving onto the skiffs casting deck, I nervously peeled line off my reel and tried to steady my nerves.

title: Drug War Refugees Seek Asylum at the Texas Border
description: Fort Hancock, a small Texas town on the border with Mexico, is struggling to take in an influx of people seeking asylum from drug violence.

title: In Caucasus, Two Leaders Vie for Loyalty
description: MAGAS, Russia  Yunus-Bek Yevkurov, the president of the Russian republic of Ingushetia, was sitting in his gold-domed palace, a warren of cool, empty marble halls surrounded by rings of gunmen.

title: John A. Paulson Is Not Target of S.E.C. Inquiry
description: Three and half years ago, a New York hedge fund manager with a bearish view on the housing market was pounding the pavement on Wall Street, The New York Timess Gretchen Morgenson and Louise Story report. Eager to increase his bets against subprime mortgages, the investor, John A. Paulson, canvassed firm after firm, looking for new ways to profit from home loans that he was sure would go sour.

title: In Los Angeles, the Saucer Is Ready to Land Again
description: LOS ANGELES  Before they face traffic on the 405 freeway, grab an In-N-Out burger or zip off to Rodeo Drive to see whatever they think is there, visitors who arrive here through LAX first stare up at the futuristic spider-shaped building at the center of the airport, welcoming them to the edge of America.

title: N.H.L. Teams Fight to Keep Gloves On in Playoffs
description: No one complains when the fighting stops.

title: Coachellas Capitalist and Its Naysayer
description: INDIO, Calif.  Coachellas two head-to-head headliners on Friday night, blasting away simultaneously on adjacent stages, were opposites in some ways. Jay-Z was the triumphal capitalist, touting his business savvy and long-term success with a big band, a full stage production  complete with a video backdrop and an entrance via lift  and a glamorous cameo from Beyonce, his wife, that was topped with fireworks. Public Image Ltd. (PiL on its logo), playing John Lydons pioneering post-punk songs for its first tour in 18 years, was the unglamorous naysayer, sneering at capitalism (in its opening tune, This Is Not a Love Song) and singing about death, antisocial thoughts and lifelong trauma.

title: Carolyn Montrose, Adam Dub
description: Carolyn Heather Montrose and Adam Craig Dub were married Saturday evening at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Cantor Henry Weintraub officiated.

title: Vikeena Bonett, Matthew Wolfe
description: Vikeena Kimberly Bonett, a daughter of Edna M. Bonett and Victor L. Bonett of Elmont, N.Y., was married in Manhattan on Saturday morning to Matthew Alan Wolfe, the son of Judy A. Wolfe of Avon, Ohio, and Robert A. Wolfe of Amherst, Ohio. The Rev. Randolph Weber performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, where he is associate minister.

title: Graft Probe Heats Up Bingo Issue in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  On the first day of April, Zeb Little was sitting down to a barbecue luncheon when he was summoned to a meeting at the State Department of Public Safety. For around 10 minutes, Mr. Little, the majority leader in the Democratic-controlled State Senate, waited at the office with several other senior Republican and Democratic lawmakers.

title: Jen Rogers, Alex Taylor
description: Jen Lacey Rogers and Alex Bernick Taylor were married Saturday evening at the Galapagos Art Space, a performing arts and event site in Brooklyn. Brian J. Hashimoto, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated.

title: Songs to Accompany an Air Horn
description: The time had finally come for the Washington Capitals to take a bold step. Fueled by their captain, Alex Ovechkin, the Capitals assembled a fast, young, aggressive team that scored often this season.

title: Virginia Iglesia, Steven Weber
description: Virginia Iglesia and Steven D. Weber, lawyers, were married Saturday evening at the Westin Colonnade Hotel in Coral Gables, Fla. Judge Alan S. Gold of the United States District Court in Miami officiated.

title: Allison Bailey, Douglas Blais
description: Allison Elizabeth Bailey and Douglas Wheeler Blais were married Saturday by the Rev. Michael L. Lindvall at Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Rebecca Sawyer, Kenneth Lin
description: Rebecca Ruth Sawyer and Kenneth Lin are to be married Sunday at Atlantis Marine World, an aquarium in Riverhead, N.Y. Jackson Gay, a Universal Life minister and a theater director, is to officiate.

title: Other Thoughts From Coachella on Friday
description: INDIO, Calif.  Kate Miller-Heidke, an Australian songwriter who can be tenderly folky or sly and wry, has a warm voice with a secret extension: a high, operatic flutter, that had the crowd whooping every time she unleashed it. She used it sparingly, and every time was a zinger.

title: Jessica Keefe, Brian Ryckman
description: Jessica Leanne Keefe and Brian Charles Ryckman were married Saturday evening in Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Stephen Williams, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Harper Fowlkes House, a 19th-century home and event space.

title: Lessons From the Gridiron
description: I GREW up in Toledo, in the Old West End neighborhood near the Toledo Museum of Art. It was a predominantly African-American neighborhood. My mother worked for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, finding temporary housing for residents whose apartments were being torn down. My father was a skycap for United Airlines and worked nights as a janitor at the local library.

title: Womens Rugby Surges, Especially on Campus
description: WAYNE, Neb. (AP)  Long denied the chance to compete in contact sports, women are now joining rugby clubs in record numbers and relishing the hard-nosed nature of what has been called a gentlemans game for ruffians.

title: Darria Long and Bryce Gillespie
description: Dr. Darria Elizabeth Long and Dr. Bryce Tinker Gillespie were married Saturday evening at First Presbyterian Church in Chattanooga, Tenn. The Rev. Ben Haden, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony with the assistance of the Rev. Mike Preg, also a Presbyterian minister.

title: Official Contends Greece Wont Face Further Restrictions
description: MADRID  Greeces finance minister dismissed on Saturday speculation that his government would be forced to introduce tougher austerity measures in return for securing a 45 billion euro loan package  even as he indicated that the countrys deficit had climbed higher than initially estimated.

title: Samantha Hill, Benjamin Brutlag
description: Samantha Ariel Hill, a daughter of Frances I. Hill and Philip S. Hill III of New York, is to be married Sunday to Benjamin Daniel Brutlag, the son of Simone Claude Brutlag and Douglas Lee Brutlag of Menlo Park, Calif. Joseph N. Gruber, a Universal Life minister, will officiate at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: Cant Cut Spending? Look Around the Globe
description: AMERICAS long-run fiscal outlook is bleak, mostly because of an aging population and rising health care costs. To close the gap between expenditures and revenue, well likely see a combination of revenue increases and spending cuts. And well need to focus especially on reducing spending, largely because that taxes on the wealthy can be raised only so high.

title: Natalie Guthrie, Alex Taylor
description: Natalie Fostel Guthrie and Alex Gregory Taylor were married Saturday evening in Charleston, S.C. Douglas L. Farmer, a minister of the International Fellowship of Chaplains, officiated at the Wickliffe House, an event space.

title: Letters to the Editor: A Pair of No. 42s for the Ages
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Alison Plenge, Colin Aitken
description: Alison Jo Plenge, a daughter of Jo Ann R. Plenge and Charles F. Plenge of Dallas, was married there Saturday to Colin Echeverria Aitken, the son of Lina M. Echeverria-Aitken and Bruce G. Aitken of Corning, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Fran T. Shelton, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Rosewood Crescent Hotel.

title: Kristen Scipione, Vincent Scorza III
description: Kristen Jennifer Scipione, the daughter of John A. Scipione of Fairfax, Va., and the late Karen G. Scipione, was married Saturday evening to Vincent Francis Scorza III, the son of Christine Scorza and Mr. Scorza Jr. of Patchogue, N.Y. The Rev. Elizabeth A. Bansavage, an interfaith minister, officiated at Le Parker Meridien Hotel in New York.

title: Every Million Counts for the Knicks
description: As reported in Off the Dribble, the Knicks got some good news on Friday when N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern provided an updated projection for the leagues salary cap. Revealing that the 2009-10 season is going better than originally thought, Stern indicated that the league was now projecting a 2010-11 salary cap of $56.1 million  although he acknowledged that maybe well have to hustle and get it.

title: Trench Warfare: Send In the Deputies
description: WASHINGTON

title: Obama v. Roberts: The Struggle to Come
description: WASHINGTON  They are two of the smartest men of their generation, both magna cum laude products of Harvard Law School, both cerebral and charming and ambitious. They vaulted to the highest offices in the land after just short stints at the next level down, and each was seen initially as a conciliator only to lead on the strength of his own majority.

title: This Bailout Is a Bargain? Think Again
description: ITS way too early to tally the costs of the governments various efforts to help our nations financial institutions survive the credit debacle. But that hasnt stopped anonymous Treasury officials from claiming in recent days that their Armageddon-avoidance will wind up costing far less than many feared.

title: Another Gerhart Stands Out at Stanford
description: STANFORD, Calif. (AP)  Teagan Gerhart is still regularly referred to as the younger sister of Toby Gerhart, a Heisman Trophy runner-up and former Stanford star.

title: Police Officer Arrested in Assault on Cabby
description: An off-duty city police officer was arrested after being accused of punching a cabdriver in the face on the East Side, the police said.

title: Obama Cancels Trip to Poland
description: The White House announced just a short while ago that President Obama has canceled his overnight trip to Krakow, Poland, for that countrys presidential funeral on Sunday, citing the ash spewing from the Icelandic volcano.Mr. Obama released this statement:

title: In North Korea, Juche Iron vs. American Crows
description: NEVER mind the chronic food shortage: North Koreas propaganda apparatus is partying like its 99  and over there, it is. Year 1 of the Juche Calendar (named after Juche Thought, the regimes official pseudo-ideology) was 1912, the birth year of the states founder, Kim Il-sung, whose birthday was celebrated last week. The new century will therefore be celebrated next year with all the requisite hoopla, which must then be outdone in 2012 for the 100th anniversary of Kims birth. The approach of back-to-back centennials, each symbolic of a national coming-of-age, puts great pressure on Kims successor and son, Kim Jong-il, to improve living conditions for the masses.

title: Painful Memory Returns to Mound Against Mets
description: ST. LOUIS  Perhaps the last thing Mets fans need is a reminder of one of their most painful memories in recent years, but they will get it if they watch the St. Louis Cardinals Adam Wainwright take the mound against their team on Sunday night.

title: Two Billion Laptops? It May Not Be Enough
description: ONE LAPTOP PER CHILD is a nonprofit group that thinks big. Since 2007, it has sold inexpensive but rugged laptop computers to the governments of less-developed countries. The goal is to equip each of the two billion children in the developing world with his or her own computer.

title: Churchs Woes Follow Pope on Trip to Malta
description: VALLETTA, Malta  In spite of the cloud of volcanic ash drifting south from Iceland, Pope Benedict XVI arrived in this Catholic nation on Saturday evening in his first foreign trip since a sexual abuse crisis began engulfing the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Rodriguez Hits First Homer of Year as Yankees Mix Power and Speed
description: To begin the 1995 season, Alex Rodriguez went 48 at-bats before hitting his first home run. He was 19 then, playing his home games at the gloomy Kingdome in faraway Seattle and backing up Felix Fermin at shortstop. Now that he is a prodigious slugger whose workplace is a $1.5 billion palace, Rodriguez is no less immune to a home run drought. It is just that, as a Yankee, he snaps it in style.

title: The System Is Broken: More From a Poll of Tea Party Backers
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll looks at the 18 percent of Americans who consider themselves supporters of the Tea Party movement.

title: Keep the Fed on Main Street
description: Kansas City, Mo.

title: Suicide Bombers Strike Refugees in Pakistan
description: KACHA PAKHA, Pakistan (Reuters)  Two suicide bombings at a center for people displaced by a Pakistani military offensive against militants killed at least 38 people and wounded 65 on Saturday, an official said.

title: Troubles Turn to Olympic Gold
description: At the Beijing Olympics in 2008, Henry Cejudo, then 21, became the youngest gold medalist in United States wrestling history. This completed a most improbable journey, one captured by Cejudo and Bill Plaschke, a columnist for The Los Angeles Times, in a book titled American Victory. In 223 entertaining pages, Plaschke told Cejudos story: life on the street and in a junkyard, in fear of immigration officials and his father, a career criminal, fighting for ice cream and survival. Cejudo took a break from his book tour to talk. GREG BISHOP

title: Cows on Drugs
description: Stanford, Calif.

title: Africa Reboots
description: I SPENT March with a delegation of activists, entrepreneurs and policy wonks roaming western, southern and eastern Africa trying very hard to listen  always hard for a big-mouthed Irishman. With duct tape over my gob, I was able to pick up some interesting melody lines everywhere from palace to pavement ...

title: Europe-Bound Travelers in U.S. Struggle to Cope
description: Thousands of travelers bound for Europe remained in limbo in the United States on Saturday, waiting for a volcanic ash cloud an ocean away to clear.

title: A Thanksgiving Meal, Then Charges of Jihad: A Mothers Tale
description: WASHINGTON  In the photograph from last November, Ramy Zamzam, 22, is a proud first-year dental student in his new white jacket, framed by his beaming parents.

title: The Scoreboard Cant Tell You Everything
description: This interview with Bill Carter, partner in and founder of Fuse, a youth marketing agency, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Blasts Rattle Cricket Fans in South India
description: NEW DELHI  At least 15 people were injured Saturday by two explosions near a crowded cricket stadium in Bangalore as thousands of spectators were arriving for a match in Indias popular professional league.

title: United Nations Endorses Afghan Presidents Choice to Lead Election Commission
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After months of pressure from Western leaders seeking to avoid another fraud-ridden election, President Hamid Karzai on Saturday chose a new head of Afghanistans election commission, who received the immediate endorsement of the United Nations.

title: From Dung to Coffee Brew With No Aftertaste
description: SAGADA, the Philippines  Goad Sibayan went prospecting recently in the remote Philippine highlands here known as the Cordillera. He clambered up and then down a narrow, rocky footpath that snaked around some hills, paying no heed to coffins that, in keeping with a local funeral tradition, hung very conspicuously from the surrounding sheer cliffs.

title: After Health Care Passage, Obama Pushes to Get It Rolling
description: WASHINGTON  Mindful that the new health care laws ability to slow rising medical costs will depend to a great extent on how it is put in effect, President Obama is assembling a high-level team to carry out key elements of the overhaul and is considering moving faster than the law requires to put them into action.

title: Philippines Drops Charges Against Two Brothers in Mass Killings
description: MANILA  The Philippine government on Saturday dropped charges against two prominent members of a powerful political family accused of the mass killing of 57 people in November, the single worst incident of political violence on record here.

title: This Rally Must Clear Some Tall Hurdles
description: WITH a profit recovery in full swing  and the first-quarter earnings reporting season under way  the bar on Wall Street is set high. Analysts forecast that profits for companies in the Standard & Poors 500-stock index soared by an average of 39 percent in the first quarter, versus the period a year earlier.

title: Whose Side Are They On?
description: Last month Democrats on the Senate banking committee passed a reasonably tough financial regulatory reform bill. Now Republican leaders have suddenly begun lashing out against it.

title: Whats-Its
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  When I first caught on to todays theme, I admit it seemed strange. Why is adding IT to the end of answers fun? I quickly warmed up to it, though, and I ended up loving the oddball humor of IT.

title: A Safe, Loving Home
description: The story of Artyom Savelyev, the boy who was sent back to Russia by his American adoptive mother, is heart-wrenching. It is also threatening the dreams of thousands of other children and prospective families.

title: When Marketing Becomes Almighty
description: SUPPOSE aliens landed on Earth today. What would be their main impression of our culture? Terry OReilly and Mike Tennant argue that theyd be struck by the omnipresent influence of advertising and marketing.

title: Arizona Goes Over the Edge
description: The Arizona Legislature has just stepped off the deep end of the immigration debate, passing a harsh and mean-spirited bill that would do little to stop illegal immigration. What it would do is lead to more racial profiling, hobble local law enforcement, and open government agencies to frivolous, politically driven lawsuits.

title: Debunking the Myths of the Telecommute
description: IM executive director of community operations at Edmunds.com, which provides information to car buyers, sellers and drivers. I lead the team that develops systems and policies for anyone submitting comments, reviews and questions to the site. My team also works with engineering to decide how parts of the site should appear to users  the forums, the car and dealership reviews, blogs and the question-and-answer area.

title: Columbine, 11 Years Later
description: Two rallies by gun rights celebrants and anti- government polemicists are planned Monday on both sides of Washingtons Potomac River. They will invoke the Second Amendment and the Battles of Lexington and Concord. A more apt, and tragic, anniversary to keep in mind is the Columbine school massacre of 1999. Eleven years later, and Congress has failed to close the gun show loophole that made the carnage possible.

title: Crme de la Cell: Six-Figure Phones
description: IN 2006, Frank Nuovo was 45  boom! he says, five more years to 50!  and at the top of his game. Except for one thing: Id kind of lost my soul.

title: Letters
description: The Trade Seesaw

title: Library Buys 14th-Century Book by Catholic Rebels
description: Denounced by the Vatican as heretical some seven centuries ago, the writings of an influential Franciscan dissident have found their way to the fourth floor of the Newberry Library.

title: Despite Progress, Police Chief Still Struggles
description: The next few months of warmer weather will be crucial for Jody Weis, whose job running the police department is as close as it gets to Mission Impossible in Chicago.

title: Using an Islamic View to Forge Connections
description: When Rami Nashashibi and a top aide ambled toward the entrance of Taft High School in a bright morning sun last week, I assumed the outside loudspeakers would break into the theme from Ghostbusters.

title: Welcome to Confederate History Month
description: It's kind of like that legendary stunt on the prime-time soap "Dallas," where we learned that nothing bad had really happened because the previous season's episodes were all a dream. We now know that the wave of anger that crashed on the Capitol as the health care bill passed last month  the death threats and epithets hurled at members of Congress  was also a mirage.

title: The Pulse: A Post With Little to Do, but Plenty of Money to Do It
description: The vice mayor of Chicago has few responsibilities, but a budget exceeding $100,000 a year.

title: The Pulse: Celtics Coach Sends His Regards to DePaul
description: Doc Rivers, the Boston Celtics coach, is still a Chicagoan at heart. Though he broke DePaul fans' hearts when he chose Marquette over the Blue Demons after graduating from Proviso East High School in 1980, he still follows all the Chicago-area teams, including DePaul, and applauds the hiring of Oliver Purnell as its basketball coach.

title: A Church Mary Can Love
description: I heard a joke the other day about a pious soul who dies, goes to heaven, and gains an audience with the Virgin Mary. The visitor asks Mary why, for all her blessings, she always appears in paintings as a bit sad, a bit wistful: Is everything O.K.?

title: Valentine at the Bat
description: With Jerry Manuel feeling the heat, Bobby Valentine has been mentioned as a possible successor. But some people remember that his first tenure with the Mets did not always go smoothly. Apologies to Ernest Thayer.

title: Carmel Lawmaker in Front Line on Health
description: It is difficult to say which life experience will come in handier for Assemblyman Bill Monning, the new chairman of the State Assemblys Health Committee.

title: Sweat | We Actually Get to Hit the Teacher
description: Mondays lesson for sixth graders at Archimedes Academy, a public school in the Southeast Bronx, was how to throw a left hook.

title: When Foreclosure Threatens Elder-Care Homes
description: In September 2009, Sgt. Rick Turini of the Santa Clara County Sheriffs Office drove to a house in San Jose to carry out a court-ordered eviction.

title: Outer Beauty and Inner Peace
description: Clifford Saron is a research neuroscientist at the Center for Mind and Brain at the University of California, Davis, and director of the Shamatha Project, a study on the impact of sustained meditation on behavior and brain function. Mr. Saron, 56, has spent time at the Spirit Rock Meditation Center in West Marin as a retreat participant, a researcher and a speaker. Hundreds of people attend classes and retreats there each week, with teachers that have included the Dalai Lama. Mr. Saron lives in Marin County with his family. (His words have been edited and condensed.)  KATHERINE ELLISON

title: Rasim Delic, Bosnian Army Commander, Dies at 61
description: Gen. Rasim Delic, who commanded Bosnias Army during much of the catastrophic ethnic war in the former Yugoslavia in the 1990s, died on Friday at his home in Sarajevo. He was 61.

title: Elder-Care Home Foreclosures, Without Warning
description: Headlines everywhere have described the foreclosure tsunami that continues to overwhelm the housing market. Less noticed has been the impact on single-family homes that are used as lucrative care facilities for the elderly.

title: Just Doing It
description: St. Louis

title: Unemployment Is Tied to Big Drop in Demand
description: The nations high unemployment rate is a result of a severe drop in demand for goods and services and is not a reflection of longer-term structural changes in the economy, a top adviser to President Obama said Saturday.

title: Gates Says U.S. Lacks a Policy to Thwart Iran
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has warned in a secret three-page memorandum to top White House officials that the United States does not have an effective long-range policy for dealing with Irans steady progress toward nuclear capability, according to government officials familiar with the document.

title: Unease at Wrigley While Soriano Struggles
description: CHICAGO  The whereabouts of Alfonso Soriano had been the most perplexing mystery confronting the Chicago Cubs two weeks into the season.

title: Capitals and Bruins Fall Behind, Then Win
description: WASHINGTON  Alex Ovechkin awoke from his one-game slumber ornery and powerful, and another Washington star, Nicklas Backstrom, completed a hat trick just 31 seconds into overtime, giving the Capitals a 6-5 victory over the Montreal Canadiens on Saturday and squaring their first-round Eastern Conference series at one game each.

title: David Simons, Who Flew High on Eve of Space Age, Dies at 87
description: David G. Simons, whose ascent more than 19 miles above the Earth in an aluminum capsule suspended from a helium balloon set an altitude record in 1957 and helped put the United States on the road to manned space flight, died April 5 at his home in Covington, Ga. He was 87.

title: Anonymous Sources Postscript
description: Unfortunately, there were more examples of anonymous sources that drew reader complaints than I could include in this weeks public editor column.

title: James Aubrey, Who Portrayed the Hero in Lord of the Flies, Is Dead at 62
description: James Aubrey, a British actor who had his first role when he was an untrained schoolboy, portraying Ralph, the right-minded boy who strove to ward off the savagery of his fellow castaways in the 1963 film Lord of the Flies, died on April 6 at his home in Cranwell, Lincolnshire, in central England. He was 62.

title: With ONeal Back, Cavaliers Strike First
description: CLEVELAND  There were many witnesses here. But Joakim Noah was the one who had the most interesting experience at Quicken Loans Arena on Saturday.

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: Squandered Trust
description: THE Times continues to hurt itself with readers by misusing anonymous sources.

title: For Campaign Disclosure
description: To the Editor:

title: Burning Trash: Solution or Problem?
description: To the Editor:

title: Street Trees and Allergies
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Sick Days
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Mary Kay Gallagher, 90, a real estate broker who specializes in the Victorian Flatbush section of Brooklyn, misidentified the formerly WASP-only club that she joined half a century ago. It is the Knickerbocker Field Club, a tennis club in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn  not the Knickerbocker Club, an all-male social club in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary in some editions last Sunday about Robert D. Franks, a former Republican congressman from New Jersey, misstated the length of his tenure in the House of Representatives. He was elected four times, but did not serve four terms. (He left the House before the end of his fourth term to run for the United States Senate in 2000.) The obituary also misstated the amount Jon S. Corzine, Mr. Frankss Democratic opponent in the Senate election, spent on his campaign. It was $63 million, not $62 million. (A corrected version of the obituary appeared in some editions on Monday.)

title: Michel Chartrand, Fiery Labor Union Leader in Quebec, Is Dead at 93
description: Michel Chartrand, a firebrand Canadian labor leader whose support of leftist politics and Quebec nationalism, including its most violent permutations, provoked the Trudeau government to summarily jail him in October 1970, died on April 12 in Montreal. He was 93.

title: Private Schools Welcome the Girl Scouts
description: Girl Scouts membership has risen sharply, and unexpectedly, in private schools in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: Fast Pace of Playoffs Is a Test for Kidd
description: After an 82-game season of teams grinding it out for position, the N.B.A. playoffs can seem like an entirely different game. A team can get away with an undersize player in the middle during the regular season, the way the 2006-7 Warriors did with Al Harrington, but that weakness is often highlighted in the playoffs, as when Harrington had to face the much larger Carlos Boozer in the second round.

title: The Other Catholic Church
description: My Sunday column is about the other Catholic Church, the one I have learned to admire for its work among the poorest people around the globe. It has tended to be the bishops and cardinals who have gotten the church in trouble, while its the amazing priests, nuns and lay-workers who do extraordinary work at home and around the world. And as I note in the column, Ive learned from meeting nuns in Africa, Asia and Latin America that the coolest and toughest people in the world are nuns. Their orphanages, hospitals and schools keep the world going.

title: Corrections
description: The 36 Hours column on April 4, about San Antonio, misstated the number, and status, of golf facilities at the new JW Marriott San Antonio Hill Country Resort & Spa. There are two courses at the resort, not one, and they have been open since January; they are not opening soon.

title: Mets Re-Fight Hundred Years War
description: As the Mets and the Cardinals head to the 20th inning, what is your favorite stat so far?

title: Ubaldo Jimenezs Moment
description: The fastest average fastball in the majors last season (minimum 162 innings) belonged to Ubaldo Jimenez of the Colorado Rockies. According to Bill James, it was 96.1 miles per hour. Jimenez also led the National League in pitches per start, with 108.2 (minimum 30 starts).

title: A Showdown in Bulgaria for the World Championship
description: A World Chess Championship match that begins on Friday in Sofia, Bulgaria, between Viswanathan Anand of India, the titleholder, and Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria, a former champion, should be a treat for fans.

title: Long Story Short: Mets Beat Cardinals in 20th
description: ST. LOUIS  In search of a solitary run, the Mets and the Cardinals played nearly seven hours of baseball Saturday, beginning on a warm, sunny afternoon and continuing into a chilly evening until finally the matter was resolved.

title: Cavaliers Depth Costs Hickson Minutes
description: CLEVELAND  Throughout the regular season, Cavaliers Coach Mike Brown considered J.J. Hickson one of the teams more pleasant surprises.

title: Correction
description: An article on April 4 about same-sex pairings in animals misspelled the surname of a director at the American Civil Liberties Union who works on gay issues and who commented about animal behavior as it appliesto the rights of humans. He is James Esseks, not Essex. The article also referred imprecisely to the referencing of a book about the subject in a 2003 Supreme Court case that overturned a Texas sodomy law. While the book, Biological Exuberance, by Bruce Bagemihl, was cited in a brief filed for the case, it was not cited in the decision itself. Also, the educational affiliation of a biologist mentioned in the article, David Featherstone, who discovered a protein mutation in the brain of male fruit flies that made them try to have sex with other males, was incomplete. It is the University of Illinois at Chicago, not simply the University of Illinois.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 17, 2010

title: Elite Recruit Picks Kansas, Then First Half Resumes
description: Kansas Coach Bill Self walked into the gym at Lake Clifton High in Baltimore last Friday and introduced himself to a man standing underneath one basket. Self joked that if the mans name were Josh Selby, he could probably score 40 points at any time.

title: Was Marathon Win a Highlight or a Lowlight for the Mets?
description: So here is the question that Mets fans can debate among themselves as their team proceeds through the final 151 games of the 2010 season: Was Saturdays 20-inning victory over the Cardinals exhilarating or a little bit embarrassing? Yes, the Mets won the game, but they scored all of two runs  two runs!  in the final three innings with first an infielder and then an outfielder pitching for St. Louis.

title: For Goldman, a Bets Stakes Keep Growing
description: For Goldman Sachs, it was a relatively small transaction. But for the bank, and the rest of Wall Street, the stakes couldnt be higher. Accusations that Goldman defrauded customers who bought investments tied to risky subprime mortgages have only begun to reverberate through the financial world, The New York Timess Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson report.

title: Feeling Cradled by Nature, and Other Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Report
description: A Neuroscientist Studies Meditation and Finds a Place to Meditate | Clifford Saron, 56, who does research at the Center for Mind and Brain at the University of California, Davis, directs a study on the impact of sustained meditation on behavior and brain function. In a valley in West Marin, he puts his theories into practice. Katherine Ellison reports.

title: Photographs From Coachella, Day 2
Deal for Coyotes Raises Eyebrows
description: Even as the Phoenix Coyotes amazing season continues before sellout crowds dressed in playoff white, the intrigue surrounding the N.H.L.-owned club persists.

title: Top Recruit Picks Kansas
description: Josh Selby, the highly recruited 6-foot-3 scorer from Lake Clifton High in Baltimore, announced at Madison Square Garden that he would attend Kansas. I think thats the best place for me to mature and get to the next level, said Selby, who also considered Tennessee, Connecticut, Kentucky and Arizona.

title: Airlines Press Europe to Ease Ban on Flights
description: As Europe grounded most airline flights for a fourth day on Sunday because of a volcanic ash cloud spreading from Iceland, increasingly desperate airlines ran test flights to show that flying was safe and pressed aviation authorities to loosen the flight ban.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 4 with the cover article about Mauritius, an island in the Indian Ocean, misstated the location of a small island off Mauritius. As the article and an accompanying map correctly noted, the island, le aux Cerfs, is off the east coast of Mauritius  not off Grand Baie, which is on the northwest tip of the island.

title: What to Pair With Monet? Try Classical Music.
description: How do you enhance the splendid Impressionist collection at the quaint and elegant Muse Marmottan Monet in Paris? How about adding the strains of equally classy tunes? On certain Tuesday nights during special exhibitions, the museum hosts classical music concerts; the next events are scheduled for April 20 and 27.

title: N.F.L. Draft: A Closer Look at Georgia Techs Jonathan Dwyer
description: Matt Waldman is a staff writer at Footballguys.com, where he writes The Weekly Gut Check and authors The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a 740-page film evaluation of 170-plus rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

title: Button Beats the Elements and Takes Victory in Chinese Grand Prix
description: SHANGHAI  As the world faced chaos in the skies due to a geological phenomenon, Grand Prix racing took a brief break from its own travel concerns to run a wild and challenging race, the results of which were also altered by the natural elements.

title: Poland Mourns, but Some Look Ahead to Elections
description: KRAKOW, Poland  About 150,000 mourners bade farewell to President Lech Kaczynski and his wife, Maria, on Sunday in an emotional funeral service here marked by solemnity and a determination never to forget.

title: The Sunday Word: Nuclear Warnings
description: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has warned that the United States does not have an effective long-range policy for dealing with Irans steady progress toward nuclear capability, The Timess David Sanger and Thom Shanker reported.

title: Pope Meets Victims Abused by Priests in Malta
description: VALLETTA, Malta  In his first such encounter since a sexual abuse scandal began to envelop the Catholic Church in recent months, Pope Benedict XVI met privately on Sunday with a small group of victims of sexual abuse by priests, expressing his shame and sorrow at their plight, the Vatican said.

title: The Mystery of the Missing Man of Steel
description: Look! Up on the wall! Its a painting! Of that strange visitor from another planet who came to Earth  well, you know how that goes.

title: The Ears Have It
description: With the playoffs underway, few N.B.A. players would dream of covering their eyes. Their ears? Thats another story  especially where music is concerned. Most players usually augment the thump-thump-thump of the basketball on the courts hardwood floor with the banging, reverberating bass from headphones tethered to their iPods. But flash headphones are an absolute must.

title: Vows: Jen & Alex
description: Jen Rogers and Alex Taylor met when they were working together at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Connecticut in summer 2007. Alex won her over at the end of the summer.

title: Flyers Boucher Ends Dry Spell
description: When Philadelphia Flyers goaltender Brian Boucher beat the Devils in Game 1 of their first-round series Wednesday, it was his first playoff victory since May 20, 2000. His gap between postseason victories of 9 years 329 days is the third longest in N.H.L. history.

title: Trendspotting | Fresh Paint
description: Student photographers rove their campuses for The Times. This issue: graffiti traditions. Text by Amanda M. Fairbanks

title: Government of Thailand Is Promised Support
description: BANGKOK  The pro-government yellow shirt movement added to Thailands tensions on Sunday with a threat to challenge the red-shirt protesters with a counterdemonstration if the government did not move quickly to crush them.

title: Q. & A. With Sam Sifton (Round Four)
description: Shawn in Los Angeles wrote in on Saturday to make a parliamentary point about this exercise, in which Ive been answering readers questions about the health and nutrition issues raised by my job as the restaurant critic for The Times.

title: City Critic: Park Bathrooms
description: Warm weather puts more strain on a park's facilities - including its bathroom facilities. The City Critic set out to investigate.

title: Tinkerman Takes Roma Back to the Top in Italy
description: A goal down and his team showing little signs of a pulse, Roma Coach Claudio Ranieri, derided in some circles as the Tinkerman, did what he appears to do best  he tinkered with his lineup.

title: Progressive Rock Day
description: INDIO, Calif.  Saturday was progressive-rock day at Coachella, headlined by Muse, the three-man English band with flying fingers and sci-fi fantasies, and by the reunited Faith No More, the San Francisco band that jump-cuts from screaming hardcore to arena pomp. Leading up to them were other bands that can count well above 4/4: the early Genesis-loving Porcupine Tree, the Rush-meets-emo band Coheed and Cambria and, best of all by far, Dirty Projectors.

title: New Video From Under the Volcano
description: Video shot on Sunday in Iceland for Britains Channel 4 News showed close views of the Eyjafjallajokull volcano, which continued to spew ash into the atmosphere, as my colleague Nicola Clark reports.

title: Matthews Arena Turns 100
description: Last Friday was the 100th birthday of Matthews Arena, the worlds oldest indoor hockey rink. The marvelous old building, home of Northeastern University hockey, is the cradle of the game in Boston.

title: Discussing Dating Woes Over Coffee
description: Little girls sketch their wedding dresses in crayon, and couples in their 90s still tell the story of how they met, which suggests that there is an appetite for romance even among those most removed from its sway.

title: Squint, and the World Is Beautiful
description: Their plumage is wilting, their wigs are askew, and their bustiers keep slipping south to reveal unmistakably masculine chests. Yet the ladies of the chorus from La Cage aux Folles have never looked more appealing than they do in the warm, winning production that opened Sunday night at the Longacre Theater.

title: Yankees Complete a Series Sweep
description: In the vast home clubhouse at Yankee Stadium, Derek Jeter commands a locker in the back next to the doorway that leads to an inner sanctum that is off limits to most visitors.

title: Poland Bids Farewell to President
description: Some 150,000 Poles bade farewell to their president and first lady in an emotional funeral service that capped more than a week of public mourning, with the shadow of a special presidential election looming in the background.

title: Battle Between the Decades
description: INDIO, Calif.  There was a secondary theme for Saturday: a scuffle between the 1970s and the 1960s, between the precise, impressive strategies of the 1970s and the looser, shaggier methods of the 1960s.Mid-afternoon there was a 1960s idyll, with the slowly swaying songs of Beach House and the wistful, guitar-strumming pop of Girls  who even reached back further, to 1958, for the Everly Brothers All I Have To Do Is Dream.

title: Rap-Rave From South Africa
description: INDIO, Calif.  Theres a nonstop dance beat at Coachella  on the four stages with live bands, and in the Sahara tent at the festivals far end, where D.J.s spin discs and poke laptops, day and night.

title: It Slices, It Dices
description: Mathematical signs and symbols are often cryptic, but the best of them offer visual clues to their own meaning. The symbols for zero, one and infinity aptly resemble an empty hole, a single mark and an endless loop: 0, 1, . And the equals sign, =, is formed by two parallel lines because, in the words of its originator, Welsh mathematician Robert Recorde in 1557, no two things can be more equal.

title: Drug Violence Along Mexican Border
description: Mexicans are coming to United States border towns as they flee gang violence in Mexico and their presence has changed the small towns along the border.

title: Junior Teams, High-Stepping Into the Big Leagues
description: For young dancers, a junior troupe is many things: a place to be noticed and to hone stagecraft and, barring irritating complications  like other, even better dancers  a steppingstone to a company contract. The 1.2.3. Festival at the Joyce Theater features three such groups in alternating performances: Ailey II, ABT II and Taylor 2.

title: 60 Across: Indy 500, e.g.
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  We have two distinguished guest solvers with us today, the husband and wife team of Stefan and May Kanfer. Hes the author of the recent Marlon Brando biography Somebody and was a writer and editor at Time magazine for 20 years, including five as its first bylined film critic. Shes a consultant at the Early Childhood Center of Sarah Lawrence College, where she taught for some 20 years.

title: What We Learned in Oklahoma City
description: FIFTEEN years ago today, the bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Building in Oklahoma City claimed the lives of 168 men, women and children. It was, until 9/11, the worst terrorist attack in United States history. But what emerged in its aftermath  the compassion, caring and love that countless Americans from all walks of life extended to the victims and their families  was a powerful testament to the best of America. And its lessons are as important now as they were then.

title: Monks Assist in Rescue Effort
description: Monks set ablaze piles of the blanket-wrapped bodies of Chinas earthquake victims on a mountaintop.

title: A Broadway Baritone Unplugged, Up, Down and Piano-Ready
description: Brian Stokes Mitchell was merrier than Santa Claus on Saturday evening at Town Hall, where he performed a program, mostly of theater songs, accompanied by a pop-jazz quartet. The joie de vivre that is a trademark of Mr. Mitchells stage demeanor can be a powerful mood elevator for an audience. But when his cheerleading enthusiasm is pushed too far it can start to cloy, as it did on Saturday, and you wish he would lean more to the dark side.

title: A Look at the Barely Victorious, and at Defensive Falsecarding
description: The column on April 10, about the 86.25 percent game at the Regency Whist Club, generated some correspondence.

title: Chvez Says China to Lend Venezuela $20 Billion
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chvez said over the weekend that China had agreed to extend $20 billion in loans to Venezuela, pointing to deepening ties between the two countries as China seeks to secure oil supplies here.

title: Minsky Conference
description: Ive been meaning to write up what I said at the Hyman Minsky conference on regulatory reformat the Ford Foundation, but have had too many balls in the air. Ill try to get to it soon; meanwhile, Ryan Avent has a few notes from the meeting.

title: Ex-Pat Paris as It Sizzled for One Literary Lioness
description: If the worlds dwindling independent bookstores have a patron saint, an exemplar to cling to in moments of duress, she is Sylvia Beach (1887-1962), the soulful and fearless owner of Shakespeare & Company, the English-language bookstore she founded in Paris in 1919 and operated on the Left Bank until the German occupation during World War II.

title: Mr. Cinderella: From Rejection Notes to the Pulitzer
description: IOWA CITY  Six years ago Paul Harding was just another graduate of the Iowa Writers Workshop with a quiet little novel he hoped to publish. He sent copies of the manuscript, in which he had intertwined the deathbed memories of a New England clock repairer with episodes about the dying mans father, to a handful of agents and editors in New York. Soon after, the rejection letters started to roll in.

title: Art Made at the Speed of the Internet: Dont Say Geek; Say Collaborator
description: When Robert Rauschenberg and a buttoned-down Bell Labs engineer named Billy Kluver began thinking, in the mid-1960s, about ways that people from the world of technology could help artists make art, Mr. Kluver surveyed the mighty gulf between the two groups and almost thought better of the idea. I was scared, he said once in an interview. The amazing thing was that its possible for artists and scientists to talk together at all.

title: A Terrorist, Plain-Spoken and Cold
description: Its hard to read faces, but voices are even harder to gauge. Timothy J. McVeigh, the anti-government extremist who killed 168 people in the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing, had a calm, almost reassuringly matter-of-fact way of speaking. He could have been a building inspector, a driving instructor or a Persian Gulf war veteran, which, of course, he was, having earned a Bronze Star before he went completely off his head.

title: Hoofers Pay Tribute to the Tapper Jimmy Slyde
description: To the man who gave me a name with wings, reads a line on a screen at the start of Roxane Butterflys film Hoofalogies, a homage to the great tap dancer Jimmy Slyde, who died in 2008 at the age of 80. Slyde was one of the most renowned tappers of his era, and Ms. Butterfly paid tribute to his heritage in a low-key show at Symphony Space on Friday night that included her fellow hoofers Rocky Mendes and Tamango.

title: A Cellist and Her Friends Explore Multicultural Harmonies
description: Spains Golden Age, an era of peaceable coexistence and cooperation among Jews, Muslims and Christians during the 9th through 15th centuries, has inspired projects by numerous prominent artists. Some, like the great Catalan viol player Jordi Savall (who will perform at Lincoln Center in May), have tried to recreate sounds of the period. Provenance, a program the cellist Maya Beiser presented at Le Poisson Rouge on Wednesday night, proposes a modern-day analogue with evocative modern works inspired by historical sources.

title: 3 Premieres Highlight New-Music Concert
description: The New York Philharmonics sold-out concert in its new-music series Contact! at Symphony Space on Friday evening had an air of excitement and a refreshing informality.

title: Yanks Head West, and So Do Rings
description: Since last Tuesdays championship ring ceremony at Yankee Stadium, the Yankees have started dispersing rings to the rest of the 2009 team. Everyone who appeared on the active roster during the season will get one  even those who barely played, like Anthony Claggett, or never got into a game, like Steven Jackson.

title: New CDs
description: MERLE HAGGARD

title: Dragon Edges Out Fake Superheroes
description: The much-hyped fake-superhero movie Kick-Ass brought in about $19.8 million at North American theaters over the weekend, a so-so performance that, by early estimates, was good enough only for second place. The film was probably hurt by its R rating and controversy about a violent and profane performance from its 13-year-old star. The No. 1 movie at the weekend box-office derby appeared to be the DreamWorks Animation holdover How to Train Your Dragon, above, which brought in about $20 million for a new total of $158.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles sales statistics. The comedy Date Night (20th Century Fox) was third with about $17.3 million ($49.2 million total). Death at a Funeral, a new comedy from Sonys Screen Gems unit, was fourth with about $17 million. And Clash of the Titans (Warner Brothers) chugged away in fifth place with about $15.8 million ($133 million total).

title: Coachella Festival, Under the Volcano
description: Entertainers, like thousands of other travelers, have been stranded since the cloud of ash from the Icelandic volcano prevented flights from taking off across much of Europe. Organizers of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif., tweeted that some acts were forced to pull out of the festival, held over the weekend, The Associated Press reported. British acts including the Cribs, Bad Lieutenant, Delphi, Talvin Singh, Gary Numan and Frightened Rabbit and the Chicago brass group Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, which was on tour in Europe, were unable to appear. Bad Lieutenant announced this weekend that it was also canceling concert dates through Wednesday in San Francisco, Chicago and New York because of flight disruptions. Whitney Houston, in the middle of her Nothing but Love world tour, had to take a boat across the Irish Sea to perform in Dublin because of airport closings.

title: Domingo Returns to Ovation at La Scala
description: In his first performance since surgery for cancer more than a month ago, Plcido Domingo, above, earned a 14-minute ovation and cheers on Friday at La Scala in Milan, singing the title role in Verdis Simon Boccanegra. Mr. Domingo, 69, blew a kiss to the crowd during the performance and called his return to the stage a great evening, The Associated Press reported. It was very emotional, he said during a backstage interview. I was happy to be in front an audience. The applause for Mr. Domingo, who was treated for colon cancer, was mixed with boos for the conductor, Daniel Barenboim, according to The A.P. But Mr. Domingo warmly embraced Mr. Barenboim as the curtain call continued even after most of the audience had departed. Mr. Domingo said in an earlier interview that his biggest triumph ever is the one over illness. He also said that despite singing the baritone role of Simon Boccanegra, which he performed at the Met this year, he remains a tenor. He is scheduled for six performances at La Scala before taking the role to the Royal Opera in London in June and the Teatro Real in Madrid in July.

title: A GLAAD Award for Foxs Glee
description: The Fox TV musical-comedy Glee, the actress Drew Barrymore, above left, and the comedian Wanda Sykes, above right, were among the winners at the 21st annual Media Awards ceremony of the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, held Saturday in Los Angeles. Ryan Murphy, the creator of Glee, said, We have a great responsibility with the show, adding that the character played by Chris Colfer, top, a gay glee-club member, would have a boyfriend next season. Ms. Barrymore received the Vanguard Award, which honors efforts to increase gay visibility and understanding. In a video shown before Ms. Barrymore accepted her trophy, she listed her dog, her stylist and her agent as among her inspirational gay colleagues. Ms. Sykes received the Stephen F. Kolzak Award, which goes to an openly gay entertainer who works to eliminate homophobia. Tom Ford, the director of the film A Single Man, was stuck in London and unable to accept a trophy for outstanding film.

title: Ontological Departs St. Marks Church
description: The Ontological-Hysteric Theater is leaving its performance space at St. Marks Church in the Bowery in June, the playwright and director Richard Foreman said in a news release. The Ontological, which has had a permanent home at St. Marks, in the East Village, since 1992, will wrap up operations there on June 30, the end of its 2009-10 season, according to the release. My aesthetic remains the same, Mr. Foreman said in the statement, but after many years of making theater theres been a thematic deepening of everything Ive been working towards that can now only be made possible through film. The Ontological-Hysteric Theater will continue to function, with the possibility of an occasional theatrical production, but will focus on film and video work.

title: Rolling Stones Song Gets a Hearing
description: An unheard Rolling Stones song, Plundered My Soul, recorded for a 1972 album but never released, was issued as a limited-edition single in honor of Record Store Day in Britain on Saturday, an annual event celebrating independent record stores. The song, recorded during sessions for the bands Exile on Main Street, was left to languish in the vaults, BBC News reported, but was rediscovered when the group was preparing for a May 18 reissue of the album. Plundered My Soul will be one of 10 bonus tracks on the deluxe edition of the reissue, Reuters reported, which will include the never-before-heard songs Dancing in the Light, Following the River and Pass the Wine.

title: Scandal Forces India Politician to Step Down
description: NEW DELHI  A former high-level United Nations diplomat who had become a prominent and flamboyant figure in the Indian government resigned Sunday amid accusations that he had wrongly used his official influence to help a female friend get an ownership stake in a new franchise in Indias lucrative professional cricket league.

title: Little Ships Rerun Finds Its Own Dunkirk
description: DOVER, England  Few moments in modern British history are more iconic than the evacuation of the British expeditionary force of nearly 340,000 troops in the spring of 1940 from the beaches of Dunkirk, 22 miles across the Channel from the white chalk cliffs that overlook this ancient port town. At the time, Winston Churchill called it a miracle of deliverance.

title: Radio Stations With No Music May Be Shut in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Radio stations in the capital of this near-anarchical country, still scrambling to comply with an Islamist ultimatum to stop playing music, were jerked in the other direction on Sunday when the government said that all broadcasters who had heeded that ultimatum faced closing.

title: Monks Bolster Chinas Quake Relief Effort
description: JIEGU, China  Long after the bulldozers have gone silent and the rescue workers have retired to their tents, the only sound in this earthquake-battered city is the plaintive barking of dogs that have lost their homes, and in many cases, their owners.

title: A Welcome Fall in Maternal Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Companies Slowly Join Cloud-Computing
description: SAN FRANCISCO  This year, Netflix made what looked like a peculiar choice: the DVD-by-mail company decided that over the next two years, it would move most of its Web technology  customer movie queues, search tools and the like  over to the computer servers of one of its chief rivals, Amazon.com.

title: Facebook Seeps Onto Other Web Sites
description: SAN FRANCISCO  With about half of Facebooks 400 million users checking in daily, the social networking company has established itself as one of the Webs most popular destinations.

title: The Speed of Broadband
description: To the Editor:

title: Ike Davis Era Is Approaching
description: ST. LOUIS  The Ike Davis era is approaching, and it could begin as soon as Monday, or at least in the next few days.

title: Its Not All About Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Indian Who Built Yoga Empire Works on Politics
description: HARIDWAR, India  The sun slumbered well beneath the horizon, but Swami Ramdev had been up for hours. Swathed in a saffron loincloth, he led his charges, a few hundred devotees in this holy city on the Ganges River and tens of millions more watching on television, through a rapid-fire series of yoga poses.

title: Law School Clinics vs. Corporate Interests
description: To the Editor:

title: MTV Not Involved With Jersey Shore Imitations
description: Success always breeds imitation. On television, there are three varieties of CSI, three of Law & Order, and at least four of Real Housewives. But in the case of MTVs Jersey Shore, the original network is not the one doing the imitating.

title: Modern-Day Apprentices
description: A day in the life: two externs in New York.

title: Microcredit Loans and Responsible Lending
description: To the Editor:

title: Fact-Checking the News
description: To the Editor:

title: For TBS and OBrien, a Match Made in Heaven
description: How did a channel like TBS  a cable channel without the prestige or marketing power of a broadcast outlet  manage to land Conan OBriens show?

title: James Masterson,  Narcissism Expert, Dies at 84
description: Dr. James F. Masterson, an internationally recognized psychiatrist who helped inaugurate a new approach to the study and treatment of personality disorders including narcissism, died April 12. He was 84 and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: Sky Above, Disaster Below
description: Oklahoma City

title: The Fluorescent Fairway
description: Annika Sorenstam shows Bill Pennington how to train for the golf season without leaving the office.

title: The Extremists Next Door
description: Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: How We Picked Ourselves Up
description: Tulsa, Okla.

title: When a Bag Speaks in Spring
description: It was a long winter. So on the first warm day this month, I charged into the garage and headed for my golf bag.

title: For Chinese, Web Is the Way to Entertainment
description: SHANGHAI  The daily Web habits of a typical 18-year-old college student named Li Yufei show why American Internet companies, one after another, have had trouble penetrating what is now the worlds most wired nation.

title: Six Doctrines in Search of a Policy Regime
description: Last week I gave a talk at the Levy Institutes 19th annual Hyman P. Minsky Conference, held at the Ford Foundation. The occasion forced me to clarify my thoughts about financial reform; so heres a version of what I said.

title: Before Kyrgyz Uprising, Dose of Russian Soft Power
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  Shortly before the uprising in Kyrgyzstan two weeks ago, online news sites posted a series of hard-hitting exposs accusing the family of President Kurmanbek Bakiyev of skimming money from the public coffers, an allegation that touched a nerve in this poor country and galvanized opposition to his government.

title: For Eddie Feibusch, a Life in Zippers
description: What, you need a zipper? O.K., Eddie Feibusch is going to sell you a zipper. Brass? Nylon? Swarovski rhinestone crystals? What color? Mystery orchid? Big or little zipper? For a purse? Or a hot-air balloon cover? How many? One? A thousand?

title: Saving the Neglected History of FM Radios Unsung Pioneer
description: The questions seemed simple enough: When and how did Edwin H. Armstrong, the father of FM radio, make the discovery that led to that invention?

title: Two Stabbed in Long Island University Campus Fight
description: Two people were stabbed and four others also injured in a fight early Sunday morning at a party on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University, the police said.

title: Reporter and Players Wearing Same Colors
description: Sharp-eyed readers might have noticed something truly unusual in Gannetts New Jersey newspapers. A new byline started appearing this month on articles about the New Jersey Devils hockey team, with a note under each piece stating that the author, Eric Marin, is employed by the Devils, not Gannett.

title: Gates Pushes Back on Report of Memo About Iran Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates acknowledged Sunday that he had written a classified memorandum to the White House in January raising significant questions about long-term Iran policy, but said his goal had been only to contribute to an orderly and timely decision-making process.

title: New Yorkers Brace for Doorman Strike
description: It has been nearly two decades since New Yorkers faced their last doorman strike, but as the deadline for a new contract for building workers approached, the questions being posed throughout the city remained largely unchanged on Sunday.

title: A First-Class Cabins Debut Diverted by Ash
description: Updated | 3:37 p.m. Until this morning, British Airways officials insisted that, ash or shine, the company would press on with its artsy debut of a new first-class cabin on Monday evening in London, even if volcanic dust prevents most of the guests from attending. It was too late, they said, to postpone.

title: Garnett Suspended, Richardson Fined for Game 1 Altercation
description: The N.B.A. suspended Kevin Garnett for Game 2 of the Boston Celtics first-round playoff series against the Miami Heat and fined Miami guard Quentin Richardson $25,000 for their altercation on Saturday.

title: Looters in Loafers
description: Last October, I saw a cartoon by Mike Peters in which a teacher asks a student to create a sentence that uses the verb sacks, as in looting and pillaging. The student replies, Goldman Sachs.

title: Alternate Path for Teachers Gains Ground
description: Not long ago education schools had a virtual monopoly on the teaching profession. They dictated how and when people became teachers by offering coursework, arranging apprenticeships and granting masters degrees.

title: The F.C.C. and the Internet
description: With the Internet fast becoming the most important communications channel, it is untenable for the United States not to have a regulator to ensure nondiscriminatory access, guarantee interconnectivity among rival networks and protect consumers from potential abuse.

title: A Case of Discrimination
description: Hastings College of the Law, part of the University of California, rightly prohibits student organizations from discriminating. A Christian group that bars non-Christian and gay students sued the school for denying it funding and access to its facilities. The Supreme Court hears arguments Monday in the case. It should rule in favor of Hastings.

title: The Icelandic Plume
description: When severe storms blow through, meteorologists can track their path and predict with considerable confidence when the disturbance will end. Volcanoes dont blow through. Even with all of the sophisticated monitoring technology and expertise, no one knows when the eruptions at Eyjafjallajokull  the Icelandic volcano now venting ash into the atmosphere  will subside.

title: Scrawled in the Margins, Signs of Twain as a Critic
description: By the end of his life, Samuel Langhorne Clemens had achieved fame as a steamboat pilot on the Mississippi, a globe-trotting lecturer and, of course, the literary genius who wrote The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn and other works under the name Mark Twain.

title: Cassandra, the Ignored Prophet of Doom, Is a Woman for Our Times
description: In Treme, HBOs new series about New Orleans, a college professor played by John Goodman railed against the needless tragedy of Hurricane Katrina. The storm was a natural disaster, he says, but the flooding that followed was a man-made catastrophe, decades in the making. Many people knew about the threat, but no one did anything about it.

title: Doctors Hear Many Questions About Health Law
description: Dr. Roger W. Evans, a cardiologist in Wichita, Kan., is used to answering patients questions about their hearts. But lately, he said, he has spent half his time answering a succession of different questions  about the health care law.

title: Mets Loss Has Its Roots in Marathon Victory
description: ST. LOUIS  A tired group of players and two managers with decision-overload hangovers arrived at the ballpark ready for yet more baseball Sunday night. Having played the equivalent of more than two games in a seven-hour period the day before, it was already time to play again.

title: Senior Executives at Goldman Had a Role in Mortgage Unit
description: Tensions were rising inside Goldman Sachs.

title: The Tory Challenge
description: American conservatives dont think terribly highly of the British Tories  if, that is, they think of them at all. With the exception of the sainted Margaret Thatcher, Britains Conservatives have acquired a reputation among their more populist American cousins for being aristocratic squishes: part Bertie Wooster and part Arlen Specter.

title: A Glare on Goldman, From U.S. and Beyond
description: Calls for increased scrutiny of Goldman Sachs emerged on Sunday as two congressmen pressed for investigations into possible taxpayer losses generated in securities sold by the firm, and the British prime minister also asked his nations securities regulator to investigate the Wall Street powerhouse because of losses suffered by a major British bank.

title: S.E.C. Puts Wall St. on Notice
description: WASHINGTON  In the last few years, the Securities and Exchange Commission seemed like the cop in the doughnut shop, sitting idly by while the likes of Lehman Brothers and Bernard L. Madoff ran amok.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Theater Theory: Restoring Downtown Bijou Is Sign of a Cool Place
description: Rosendale, N.Y.

title: In Iceland, Mostly Clear Consciences
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  Like the volcano that erupted last week, this once obscure island nation seems to have awoken from centuries of quietude with a determination to spread its fallout all over Europe.

title: Travel Disruptions Reach New York City
description: The plume of ash may be an ocean away, but New York City, too, has been rattled by the volcano that began erupting last week in Iceland.

title: Democrats Seize on Financial Oversight After Goldman Suit
description: WASHINGTON  With the Senate scheduled to begin debate on a financial overhaul bill this week, the fraud suit against the Wall Street titan Goldman Sachs has emboldened Democrats to ratchet up pressure on Republicans who oppose the Obama administrations proposal.

title: Small Vendors Left Out of Schools Book Purchasing
description: Even as recently as last year, the process by which books ended up in New York classrooms bore more resemblance to Avon than Amazon.

title: Nonprofit Groups Hopeful but Wary as City Aims to Cut Red Tape
description: From day care centers to food pantries to senior centers, thousands of nonprofit groups that depend on New York City for their livelihood are bracing for the most ambitious change in a generation as the Bloomberg administration prepares to dismantle the way it awards $4 billion in contracts every year.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,030 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 18, 2010

title: Mount Vernon High School to Resume Classes Tuesday
description: Students at Mount Vernon High School in Westchester County will be allowed to return to class on Tuesday, eight days after a wall collapsed and the school was closed for a safety inspection, school district officials said Sunday. Teachers and staff members are to return Monday.

title: White House Quietly Courts Muslims in U.S.
description: When President Obama took the stage in Cairo last June, promising a new relationship with the Islamic world, Muslims in America wondered only half-jokingly whether the overture included them. After all, Mr. Obama had kept his distance during the campaign, never visiting an American mosque and describing the false claim that he was Muslim as a smear on his Web site.

title: On a Dusty Mesa, No Water or Electricity, but Boundless Space
description: ALBUQUERQUE  Fermin Roman knew he was a pioneer when he bought his homestead on the Pajarito Mesa, a treeless plateau outside Albuquerque. But the seller assured him that water and power would arrive in a year or two.

title: What Would Daniel Ellsberg Do With the Pentagon Papers Today?
description: BEFORE Wikileaks, or even the Internet, there were just plain leaks.

title: Obama Health Team Turns to Carrying Out Law
description: WASHINGTON  The success of the new health care law depends to a large degree on a handful of Obama administration officials, who are scrambling to make the transition from waging political war on Capitol Hill to managing one of the most profound changes in social policy in generations.

title: The Canine as Canvas
description: There are few limits in creative grooming, and groomers spend months on their projects.

title: Reduction Is Theme Of Presidents Next Act
description: As President Obama approaches the end of his administrations opening chapter, his advisers have begun a backstage debate over Chapter 2, which will be fundamentally different in tone, aspiration and political complexity.

title: Evans, Curry Led the Freshman Class
description: Voting concluded last week for the N.B.A.s postseason awards. Although The New York Times does not permit its reporters to vote, the N.B.A. reporters Howard Beck and Jonathan Abrams are making their picks in Off the Dribble. This is the rookie of the year discussion.

title: People StyleWatch Gains as It Blurs Ad Lines
description: It may be a dreary time in the magazine business, but you wouldnt know it inside the offices of People StyleWatch, a bright spot in the industry. Here, on the 29th floor of the Time & Life building, it is girlie heaven, with flip-flops in pink patent leather, neon rubber lining the hallway, and a fashion closet that holds all the bronzing powder, chunky earrings and formal shorts (yes, its a thing) that shoppers daydream about.

title: How Do You Say Road Trip! in Catalan?
description: Like a college team heading to its conference tournament, Barcelona piled its multimillion-dollar roster onto a bus on Sunday afternoon and started on the road to its Champions League semifinal in Milan.

title: Where Creativity Wags Its Tail
description: SECAUCUS, N.J.  Once they finished shaving the cats, the glamour event of the dog grooming show began.

title: Toyota Is Expected to Pay $16.4 Million Fine
description: Toyota is expected to tell the Transportation Department on Monday that it will pay a $16.4 million fine, the largest government penalty ever against an automaker, for concealing information related to its sticking pedal recall.

title: Celtics and Heat Set Playoffs on Simmer
description: WALTHAM, Mass.

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS There will be reports this week on leading economic indicators for March (Monday); the Producer Price Index for March and existing home sales for March (Thursday); and durable goods orders for March and new home sales for March (Friday).

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Pressure Builds as Giants Stoic Architect Begins Repairs
description: Jerry Reeses first indication of what his new job was going to be like came when he was ensconced in the Giants general managers office for just a few months in 2007. In poured the letters, tons of them, he said, wondering what he was doing, why the Giants had barely made a peep. Reese treads quietly, anyway.

title: Accounts, People & Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Theres Very Little to Complain About in Yankees Start
description: In the first year of the new Yankee Stadium, every team in the majors had a flag atop the upper deck: a green one for the Oakland Athletics, a blue one for the Los Angeles Dodgers and so on, a subtle sign of welcome for the visitors.

title: 20 Innings of Insight, Without Substitutions
description: Near the end of the Mets 2-1, 20-inning win over St. Louis on Saturday night, Foxs Tim McCarver compared the 6-hour-53-minute game to a frat party, a beer-league game and a fairy tale. Does this game count? McCarver asked Kenny Albert in the 20th.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a Russian-sponsored conference on computer security misidentified the United States agency for which Stewart A. Baker, a panelist at the conference, once served as chief counsel. Is the National Security Agency, not the National Security Council.

title: Falling Sales for the Printed Word
description: Overall book sales in the United States dropped 1.8 percent in 2009, to approximately $23.9 billion not adjusted for inflation, according to the annual estimate released by the Association of American Publishers this month, though there is some hope for the beleaguered industry.

title: Devils Leave the Flyers an Opening
description: PHILADELPHIA  Devils left wing Ilya Kovalchuk participated in his first Stanley Cup playoff game in Philadelphia on Sunday night, and a full house of Flyers fans, most wearing orange T-shirts, booed him as lustily as if he were a mortal enemy, or Sidney Crosby.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a speech by President Obama on revamping the space program referred incorrectly in some copies to Representative Sheila Jackson Lee, Democrat of Texas, whose district includes parts of Houston close to Johnson Space Center. While Ms. Lee attended the presidents speech at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, she did not travel there on Air Force One with him.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: In New Mexico, a Frugal Existence
description: Residents of Parajito Mesa, a desolate area on the outskirts of Albuquerque, survive entirely off the grid  without running water, electricity, streets or mail.

title: Corrections
description: The Atlanta Journal article on Friday, about The Atlanta Journal-Constitutions relocating outside the city, misstated the newspapers decline in weekday circulation during a six-month period in 2009 and overstated the significance of that drop. Circulation was down 20 percent  not 13.6 percent, which was the decline during a similar period in 2007-2008. And the six-month decline in 2009 was the largest circulation drop among major newspapers, not all newspapers. (The Journal-Constitutions weekday circulation is about 211,000.)

title: Baffled by the New Law, Patients Turn to Their Doctors
description: After months of public wrangling and brinksmanship in Washington, the nations doctors now find themselves having to answer questions about the new health care law  a complex, many-staged program that many do not understand, or support, themselves. The politicians and pundits may have spoken, but the dialogue is just beginning in examination rooms around the country.

title: Capitals Ovechkin Snaps Out of Late-Season Funk
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  For anyone concerned that Alex Ovechkin was no longer himself, it is time to stop worrying. Ovie is back.

title: Flavored Tobacco Pellets Are Denounced as a Lure to Young Users
description: A research study and editorial to be published Monday in the medical journal Pediatrics takes direct aim at a novel tobacco product that some critics say too closely resembles Tic Tac breath mints.

title: New Razors Place Focus on Comfort, Not Blade Count
description: WHEN Gillette introduced the first three-bladed razor in the United States, the Mach 3, in 1998, it struck some as absurd, and Saturday Night Live at the time pitched a 14-blade razor in a parody commercial. But blade escalation continued: Rival Schick introduced the four-bladed Quattro in 2003, and Gillette struck back with the five-bladed Fusion in 2005.

title: Dede Allen, Pioneering Film Editor, Dies at 86
description: Dede Allen, an editor whose work in films like Reds, The Hustler and Bonnie and Clyde revolutionized images with a staccato style that gave a story a sense of constant motion, died on Saturday. She was 86.

title: Lakers Flip Playoff Switch and Outmuscle Thunder
description: LOS ANGELES  The good news, the Los Angeles Lakers discovered Sunday, is that the big switch they have been able to flip over the years whenever boredom or a feisty opponent requires it is still at their fingertips  even ones as achy as Kobe Bryants.

title: Carolyn Rodgers, Poet, Is Dead at 69
description: Carolyn Rodgers, a leading poet of the Black Arts Movement of the 1960s and 1970s whose work wove strands of feminism, black power, spirituality and writerly self-consciousness into a sometimes raging, sometimes ruminative search for identity, died on April 2 in Chicago. She was 69.

title: S.E.C. Charges Are a Distraction for Goldman
description: Were the investors who lost $1 billion buying a fearfully complex product sold by Goldman Sachs in the dying days of the credit boom fools or victims? That is the crucial distinction on which the Securities and Exchange Commissions fraud charges unveiled on Friday hinge.

title: Word of the Day | provisional
description: provisional \pr-vizh-nl, -vi-zh-nl\ adjective

title: At Open Qualifier, Youth Triumphs Over Experience, but Just Barely
description: Richard Bustamante has dedicated his life to tennis and, at 61, he was taking his best shot at qualifying for the United States Open.

title: Spurs Try Different Approach to Shutting Down Nowitzki
description: DALLAS  It is only a game into his playoff series, but San Antonio Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich tried a well-used ploy in the first-round Western Conference matchup against the Dallas Mavericks.

title: Harlem Centers Director to Retire in Early 2011
description: Howard Dodson, whose wide-ranging acquisitions and major exhibitions have raised the profile of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture and burnished its reputation as the premier institution of its kind, plans to retire as its director in 2011.

title: Eli Manning Raves About New Stadium and New Backup Quarterback
description: Just like a musician testing out the acoustics of an arena, Eli Manning went on a private tour of the new Meadowlands stadium a few weeks ago. And, after enduring an 8-8 season and no playoffs, hes already seeing the positive signs of playing in a $1.6 billion stadium.

title: What Course(s) Would You Like to Take Online?
description: This weekends edition of Education Life explores the world of free educational material available online via the open courseware movement, with an interactive Syllabus Sampler that features clips from six popular online lectures.
