What experiences do you have with learning online? What courses do you wish you could take online? If you could design an online course or lecture that would be useful for your current interests or needs, what would it be? Who might teach it?

title: News Quiz | April 19, 2010

title: A Glare on Goldman, From U.S. and Beyond
description: Calls for increased scrutiny of Goldman Sachs emerged on Sunday as two congressmen pressed for investigations into possible taxpayer losses generated in securities sold by the firm, and the British prime minister also asked his nations securities regulator to investigate the Wall Street powerhouse because of losses suffered by a major British bank, Gretchen Morgenson and Landon Thomas Jr. report in The New York Times.

title: Morgenson: This Bailout Is a Bargain? Think Again
description: Its way too early to tally the costs of the governments various efforts to help our nations financial institutions survive the credit debacle. But that hasnt stopped anonymous Treasury officials from claiming in recent days that their Armageddon-avoidance will wind up costing far less than many feared, Gretchen Morgenson writes in her latest column in The New York Times.

title: Buyout Shops in Emerging Markets Push, Study Says
description: More than half of private equity investors plan to put more money in emerging markets, expecting higher returns from deals in these economies than ones in sluggish western markets, Reuters reported, citing a new survey.

title: Amid Merger Talks, Airlines Eye 3-Way Alliance
description: United Airlines is continuing separate merger talks with US Airways and Continental Airlines, but it has also discussed the option of deepening a three-way marketing alliance among the carriers absent a merger, Reuters reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

description: United Chemical UralChem seeks to raise from $496 million to $642 million in an initial public offering of shares in London, not including an over-allotment option, the Russian chemicals company said Monday, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Surfacing History in Greenwich, England
description: It is hard to imagine, in current times, that a royal palace would be razed to make way for a hospital for injured seamen  but that is exactly what happened in Greenwich, England, at the end of the 17th century.In March, Discover Greenwich, a 6 million (about $9.2 million) cultural center, opened on the site of the Royal Hospital for Seamen (which in turn became the Royal Naval College), aiming to interpret over 500 years of both royal and maritime history.

title: Countrywide Criminal Probe Said to Move Ahead
description: Federal authorities are picking up the pace in a criminal investigation of Countrywide Financial, the former mortgage giant, and its role in the meltdown in 2007 and 2008 of the housing and finance industries, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

description: Todays idea: We should feel grateful to the unruly Icelandic volcano, a philosopher says, for allowing us briefly to imagine what a flightless future would envy and pity us for.

title: U.K. Buyout Market Begins to Revive
description: The appetite of buyout shops for British companies seems to be returning, with private equity firms closing just over 5 billion pounds ($7.6 billion) worth of deals in the United Kingdom in the first quarter, The Financial Times reported, citing new research.

description: Australias competition watchdog said Monday that it opposed National Australia Banks proposed 13.3 billion Australian dollar ($12.3 billion) acquisition of AXA Asia Pacific Holdings, opening the gates for a rival offer from the asset management firmAMP, The Sydney Morning Herald reported.

description: Chris Brown writes and edits SmartFootball.com

title: Sampler: Silicon Valleys Gender Trouble, and Nursing Home Neglect
description: Nursing Homes Cashed In While Cutting Staff | Californias nursing homes reaped $880 million from a 2004 state law designed to help hire more caregivers and boost wages. But thats not what all of them did, an investigation found. Some 232 homes took the money while cutting staff or wages. Cloverdale Healthcare Center in Sonoma County received a $1 million increase in state money, but staffing dropped 8 percent in 2008 compared with 2004. Regulators uncovered problems at the center, including a patient who had been left in a soiled diaper for five hours.[California Watch]

description: The GEO Group, a prison services provider, said on Monday that it would buy a rival, Cornell Companies, for cash and stock worth $685 million.

title: A Visit With a Surprise Pulitzer Prize Winner
description: Motoko Rich went to Iowa City to spend some time with Paul Harding, who teaches at the Iowa Writers Workshop and who was the surprise winner last week of the Pulitzer Prize for fiction. His debut novel, Tinkers, beat out a long list of books by much more established authors to take the prestigious honor. It had been a long, difficult road for Mr. Harding. Motoko Rich writes:

description: Q.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Lebanese Potatoes With Cilantro Sauce
description: Batata Harra is a Lebanese dish of twice-fried potatoes. The crisp, golden cubes are served with a sauce of cilantro, garlic, and olive oil. Its a poor mans dinner, eaten with eggs, or with tomatoes and scallions, said Philippe G. Massoud, the 39-year-old executive chef and co-owner of Ilili, a Lebanese restaurant near Madison Square Park.

title: Drop in Commodity Prices Pushes Major Indexes Down
description: Worries about the effect of government efforts to strengthen oversight of banks faded somewhat on Monday, helping Wall Street indexes to end the day mostly higher.

description: 8:33 a.m. | Updated  The New York Timess Eric Dash provides more details about Citigroups first-quarter results.

description: The only regulators in Asia that are focusing on the competitive impact ofPrudentials bid for American International Groups Asian life-insurance business are those in South Korea and Vietnam, Barry Stowe, Prudentials head of Asian operations, told The Wall Street Journal.

description: What were reading this morning:

title: Citigroup, in Turnaround, Reports $4.4 Billion Profit
description: Citigroup on Monday provided the strongest signs yet that it was beginning to recover after nearly two years of being drenched in red ink, reporting a $4.4 billion profit in the first quarter.

title: Five Airlines Pledge No Carry-On Fees
description: Sen. Charles Schumer of New York says five major airlines have agreed they are not going to charge passengers for their carry-on bags.

title: The Early Word: Financial Feuds
description: With the Senate preparing to debate an overhaul of the financial regulatory system soon, the federal lawsuit filed against Goldman Sachs on Friday may help Democrats  gain Republican support, The Timess Jackie Calmes reports.

title: Ke$ha, Reon$idered
description: The visually arresting musical performances by Ke$ha on Saturday Night Live raised a lot of questions over the weekend, like: Huh? And also: Whaaaa? Was her glow-in-the-dark body paint routine for Your Love Is My Drug a bit of stealth marketing for the DVD release of Avatar? Is she just a Britney Spears manque in a Lady Gaga world? How does one play drums and guitars while wearing bulky spacesuits? What if, in fact, we are the aliens?

title: Month of Unrest Hits Thailands Economy
description: BANGKOK  Thai troops patrolled Bangkoks financial district on Monday in a show of force as protesters threatened a march on Tuesday that could incite a new confrontation.

title: Greetings From Your New Bay Area Blogger
description: Hello.

title: The Eastern Stars: Q.& A. With Mark Kurlansky
description: By 2008, 79 men and boys from San Pedro de Macors, a small sugar mill town in the Dominican Republic, had gone on to play major league baseball. Of the 471 Dominicans who had played in at least one major league game, 1 in 6 came from San Pedro: Ozzie Virgil, Joaquin Andujar, Alfredo Griffin, George Bell, Sammy Sosa, Robinson Cano. Mark Kurlansky, who has written histories revolving around cod and salt, puts San Pedro under the microscope in his new book, The Eastern Stars: How Baseball Changed the Dominican Town of San Pedro de Macors (Riverhead).

title: The Perfect Excuse
description: If pulled over by a police officer for talking on my cellphone without a headset, or in one of those social situations where it takes a powerful reason for a last-minute cancellation, I never would have dared use my mothers illness as an excuse to get me out of a jam. Not while she was still alive.

title: Will Better Insurance Be Available to College Students?
description: Q.

title: Lexus to Recall GX 460 S.U.V.
description: DETROIT  Toyota on Monday added another model to its long list of recalls, hours after agreeing to pay the largest fine ever imposed by the government against an automaker.

title: Iraqi Court Sets Partial Recount in Tight Election
description: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi court on Monday ordered a partial recount of votes in last months national election, deepening the political turmoil that many here feared could turn violent when the United States begins to withdraw most of its combat troops this summer.

title: Ask About Transgender Issues
description: This week Dr. Laura Erickson-Schroth, who is working on Trans Bodies, Trans Selves, a resource guide for transgender and other gender-variant people, covering health, legal issues, cultural and social questions, history and theory, responded to readers questions about transgender life.

title: The Last Lost Roundup (Until the Next One)
description: With just over a month to go until the May 23 finale of Lost, TV Guide has published what are being called the last cast photos for the show (until its producers rewrite history, or the inevitable 10th anniversary reunion at Lost-Con 2020), and The Hollywood Reporter offers a look at the pictures.

title: Commissioner for Homeless Resigns
description: Robert V. Hess, the citys commissioner of homeless services, said on Monday that he will leave his post after four years of overseeing one of the Bloomberg administrations most demanding agencies.

title: Toward a Hung Parliament
description: Todays column on David Camerons Tories has been half-overtaken by events: I was writing as if the Tories were still clinging to a slight edge in the polls, but as of this morning that may no longer be the case. The Liberal Democrats have been surging since their leaders strong performance in last weeks debate; now theyve surged into a narrow lead. Thanks to the way the U.K.s Parliament apportions seats, a Lib Dem victory in the popular vote would leave either Labour or the Tories with a slight plurality in the House of Commons (not coincidentally, electoral reform is a major Lib Dem issue), but well short of the majority required to govern. For political observers, this would be a fascinating outcome: Think Florida in 2000 crossed with a brokered convention. For Britain, misgoverned and indebted and desperate for strong leadership, it would probably be a disaster.

title: The British Election and the Wars
description: If the voters of any country know that wars fought in foreign fields rarely win or lose elections, the British do; the most stunning election upset in modern British history came in 1945, when soldiers returning from World War II, or awaiting transportation from distant battlefields, combined with restive families at home to boot Winston Churchill and his Conservatives out of office less than three months after he led the country to victory over Nazi Germany. Then, as now, voters made their choices primarily on domestic issues, and they judged Labours Clement Attlee better equipped for the social and economic renewal the country needed than the man widely regarded, even then, as one of the greatest Englishmen who ever lived.

title: Jenson Button Calls Chinese Grand Prix My Best Victory
description: Jenson Button, the 2009 Formula One champion, may not have been on many pundits shortlist to repeat the title  especially after switching teams  but after four races, he is the lone driver with multiple wins. Sundays victory at the Chinese Grand Prix in Shanghai amid a light rain might have been one of his most impressive.

title: The Inches That Matter
description: C. J. Chivers reports from Marja, Afghanistan, where Marines face stiff resistance from Taliban fighters, including a rarity, a trained marksman.

title: Carrie Underwood and Michael Bubl Score at Music Awards Shows
description: Musicians from down South, up North and all points in between had reasons to celebrate as both the Academy of Country Music Awards and the Juno Awards, the Canadian equivalent of the Grammys, were handed out this weekend.

title: Android Tries Harder
description: Remember the old Avis car-rental slogan? Were Number 2. We try harder.

title: Cutting Back the Rain Forest in New York
description: Like many other municipalities, New York City has used durable rain forest woods to build pieces of public infrastructure like benches and boardwalks. And although Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has publicly promised to limit the use of such materials, some organizations have decided that the city is not moving quickly enough.

title: Monday Reading: Five Airlines Promise No Carry-On Bag Fees
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Obama to Confront Wall St. on Its Turf
description: President Obama will take his case for tougher financial regulation to Wall Streets backyard this week, the White House announced Monday.

title: Tacos: Health Food With a Kick
description: In the years before I began look closely at Mexican food, my concept of the taco was shaped by Tex-Mex restaurants and fast food chains. It was a deep-fried tortilla filled with ground beef and grated yellow cheese. Then I began to travel in Mexico, where tacos are only sometimes made with crisp-fried tortillas and rarely have greasy fillings. Wrap a warm tortilla around anything, it turned out, and its a taco. Taco fillings consisted of everything from fish and shellfish, to in-season vegetables and potatoes, to the fungus called huitlacoche that grows inside of cornhusks.

title: The Dangers of Buying Medicines Overseas
description: Millions will travel overseas this coming holiday season. But whether its at the Great Wall of China or the Taj Mahal, Victoria Falls or Iguazu Falls, there always exists the risk that one may become ill or hospitalized while abroad and require medicine from a local pharmacy or clinic. And as a tourist pops that pill into the mouth, he or she should be concerned about the safety and efficacy of those drugs.

title: Soft Tacos With Fish and Spinach
description: Friends who sampled all of this weeks tacos liked these the best. Theyre easy to make: I used frozen Alaskan cod fillets from Trader Joes, approved as sustainable by the Blue Ocean Institute. I liked them very much, especially since I found no bones when I flaked the fish.

title: Want a Higher G.P.A.? Go to a Private College
description: Update: Stuart Rojstaczer, the co-author of the grade inflation study summarized below, is taking reader questions. Submit them here.

title: Soft Tacos With Sauted Winter Squash and Chipotles
description: Pan-cooked, slightly caramelized winter squash contrasts beautifully with the spicy, rich-tasting chipotles that are canned in a sort of Mexican-style barbecue sauce and stocked by most supermarkets along with other Mexican ingredients. These tacos bring you lots of vitamin A, as well as vitamin C, potassium, manganese and folate.

title: Quote Unquote | Your Grandmothers Rodarte
description: Kate Mulleavy of Rodarte explains her current inspiration to the Wall Street Journal. Tavi is going to love this.

title: Soft Tacos With Potatoes and Greens
description: These tacos are comforting and filling, a great destination for greens. If you want to save time, use washed, stemmed greens that come packaged by the pound. Youll need a little less than half of a one-pound bag. This filling isnt spicy, so if you want spice serve it with salsa (my preference would be a green salsa).

title: Update on European Airports
description: As Europe grounded most flights for a fourth day on Sunday because of a volcanic ash cloud spreading from Iceland, increasingly desperate airlines ran test flights to show that flying was safe and pressed aviation authorities to loosen the flight ban.

title: How to Make Your Opera Mini Browser Sing
description: The Opera Mini Web browser for the iPhone was downloaded 1 million times on its first day in the iTunes store. So now that you have it, there are some tips and tricks to make it more useful. Some are pretty obvious, some are not.

title: No More Mystery Behind Savage History Reviews: The Authors Wife Did It
description: For weeks, the pseudonymous reviewer known only as Historian had been using the British book site amazon.co.uk as his or her personal shooting gallery, taking aim at the authors of works on Russian culture and history: Rachel Polonskys book Molotovs Magic Lantern was dismissed as dense, pretentious and the sort of book that makes you wonder why it was ever published; and Robert Services work was skewered as a dull read (for a book about Trotsky) and rubbish and an awful book (for a history of communism). Perhaps the only author to be spared the point pen of Historian was Orlando Figes, whose book The Whisperers was described as a beautiful and necessary account of Soviet history, written by someone with superb storytelling skills and of whom Historian said, I hope he writes forever.

title: Roundup: I.R.A.s and Financial Aid  New Avenues for Teacher Training  L.I. Quadruplets Decide
description: As the April 1 admission-decision deadline fades and the May 1 deadline for deposits looms at many colleges, The Choice has been taking a breather to catch up on other reading.

title: Top Qaeda Leaders in Iraq Reported Killed in Raid
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki announced Monday that two top insurgent leaders had been killed, including a somewhat mythic figure who has operated under the name Abu Omar al-Baghdadi. Mr. Baghdadi has been reported dead or detained several times previously, and his very existence had been called into question a few years ago by American military leaders.

title: Groups Urge Tax on Wall St. Bonuses
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson and the Legislature have spent weeks arguing over how to cut enough spending to close the states $9 billion budget gap, with little progress.

title: Mushroom and Poblano Tacos
description: This is inspired by a dish that Mexican chef Rick Bayless makes with huitlacoche, a black fungus that grows in lobes on ears of corn. Its a great delicacy in Mexico but not easy to get in the United States (though you can find mail order sources on the Internet). Mushrooms are a lot easier to find, and they make a delicious taco filling. Epazote is an earthy Mexican herb that you might be able to find in a Mexican market or a farmers market. If you cant find it, use cilantro.

title: Bomber Strikes Near Pakistan Rally; Police Officer Seen as Target
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A teenage suicide bomber struck near a protest rally in the northwestern frontier city of Peshawar on Monday, killing a prominent police officer and as many as two dozen protesters, the police said.

title: Twain's Bookshelf
description: List of 230 books from Mark Twain's personal collection.

title: Guilty Verdict in Killing of Long Island Man
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  The white teenager accused of killing an Ecuadorean immigrant in a racially motivated attack was convicted on Monday of manslaughter as a hate crime, in a case that put a spotlight on anti-Hispanic violence on Long Island.

title: Biden Books The View
description: What do you get when you put Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Elisabeth Hasselbeck at the same coffee table?

title: Schott Op-Chart: British General Election Briefing
description: Last Thursdays televised party leaders debate  the first in British history  injected new energy into a lackluster election campaign. The incumbent prime minister, Gordon Brown of the Labour Party, still faces a tough fight from his Conservative opponent, David Cameron  though with the polls swinging toward the third-party Liberal Democrats there is the real possibility of a hung Parliament.

title: Aziz Ansari to Host MTV Movie Awards
description: MTV has named the host of its annual movie awards, and its a sort of surprise if you dont keep up with industry chatter or were expecting the gig to go to Snooki. Aziz Ansari, a comedian and a co-star of the NBC comedy Parks and Recreation, will be the M.C. of the 2010 Movie Awards, the cable channel said on Monday, confirming longstanding reports (like this one from The Los Angeles Times in March) that he was in negotiations for the job. Mr. Ansari, who was a cast member of the MTV sketch series Human Giant and will appear this summer in the comedy Get Him to the Greek, seemed just as astounded as anyone that he was chosen over the stars of the channels best-known reality series. In a statement, he said, Im so happy Ronnie from Jersey Shore was unavailable and this exciting opportunity was able to come my way.

title: Obama Opens Deficit Panel Meetings Next Week
description: Next Tuesday, President Obama will open the first meeting of the bipartisan debt reduction commission he established in February, followed by what are certain to be dire fiscal warnings from economic authorities including Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke.

title: What Were Reading: Wall Street Doesnt Understand Wall Street
Revisiting the Lindsay Era
description: He was fresh when everyone else was tired.

title: Caption Contest: Walid-Pandit Edition
description: Kingdom HoldingsPrince Walid bin Talal, left center, praised Citigroups first-quarter performance on Monday.

title: Clinton Cancels Finland Trip
description: Icelands spreading cloud of volcanic ash is now disrupting American diplomacy: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has been forced to cancel a one-day visit to Finland on Wednesday, a senior State Department official said Monday.

title: Staying Alive: The Wipe Out
description: Two disadvantages of selling residential furniture are that the average sale is small and you have to work really, really hard to get it. The Partner and I both realized that it would be hard to build the business (you can see my previous posts here) selling only dining furniture. Residential clients want to sit in the chair, to feel the finish and to thump the table top before they buy. Which means we could only sell to clients who came to the shop, and thats a relatively small group.

title: The High Low | J. Crew necklace, $98
description: Good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant but affordable gets. In this column, Ts fashion team finds the cheap and the chic.

title: Classic AC Roadster Gets a Modern Touch and a Six-Figure Price
description: 10:54 a.m. | Updated

title: The Snake-Bit Sharks
description: The N.B.A. and N.H.L. playoffs are still young, the bandwagon-jumping having not even claimed its first pulled hamstring (that should come Tuesday), but it is hard not to be fixated by two California teams.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Both questions this week concern the campaign to encourage Americans to take part in the 2010 Census.

title: People and Accounts of Note in Advertising
description: AMJ Campbell Van Lines, Toronto, Canadas largest moving company, named Ariad Custom Communications, Toronto, as its agency of record. The company had previously handled advertising internally. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Comcast Denies Connection to RightNetwork
description: Comcast denied reports Monday that it is a partner in the RightNetwork, a red state start-up that promises content that reflects and reinforces their perspective and worldview.

title: A D'Agostino Commercial
description: A commercial to run on screens in the back of taxi cabs is part of a new campaign for D'Agostino supermarkets.

title: Web Buzzing Over Possible New Version of the iPhone
description: Technology bloggers were riveted over the weekend as photos of what might be a yet unannouncednext generation iPhone began circulating.

title: Magazine Covers Are Lousy Investment Signals
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Clearwater Asset Management. He answered questions from Bucks readers in November.

title: TimesCast | April 19, 2010
description: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories covered Monday.  Topics include the politics of the Goldman Sachs fraud suit, Europe's patchwork response to the ash cloud and a firefight in Afghanistan.

title: Armani Hotel Delays Dubai Debut
description: The opening of the Armani Hotel Dubai, in the Burj Khalifa, the worlds tallest building, has been delayed to April 27, as ash from volcanic eruptions in Iceland forced extensive flight cancellations from Europe

title: South Korea Vows to Find Culprit in Sinking of Warship
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Pausing to wipe away tears with a handkerchief, South Koreas president, Lee Myung-bak, vowed Monday to respond resolutely and unwaveringly to last months deadly sinking of a South Korean warship in disputed waters near North Korea.

title: What Changes Are Really Afoot at CNBC?
description: In a Page Six item in The New York Post on Sunday about changes coming to the business news network CNBC, a network representative said the information was 40 percent accurate.

title: A Final Minute of Mayhem for Malcolm McLaren
description: It wouldnt be a funeral for Malcolm McLaren if it didnt feature one last stunt. On Monday relatives of Mr. McLaren, the pop provocateur, sloganeer and former manager of the British punk band the Sex Pistols, asked that his mourners observe a minute of mayhem when he is buried on Thursday, Reuters reported. Mr. McLaren, a former proprietor of a clothing boutique (that went by the names Let It Rock and Sex) and a formerpartner of the fashion designer Vivienne Westwood, died of mesothelioma on April 8. He was 64.

title: According to DAg, Low Prices Are in the Bag
description: A supermarket chain once known for its quirky, light-hearted advertising is promoting itself again, this time with a humorous, make-believe battle between the boss and his senior management.

title: Treasury to End Paper Checks
description: The Obama administration is phasing out paper checks to people receiving federal benefits.

title: Photographs From Coachella, Day 3
description: A slide show of photographs from the music and arts festival in Indio, Calif.

title: Another Cheruiyot Wins the Boston Marathon
description: BOSTON  Robert Kiprono Cheruiyot arrived at the Boston Marathon with name recognition  just not his own. He then shook up the venerable race on Monday with a memorable performance that came so fast and so soon, leaving the familiar American favorites in his dust.

title: When It Pays to Plan Ahead
description: Looking for a new place to rent can be a stressful ordeal, a kind of ticking time bomb formulation with many moving parts  price, location, view, time frame, pets, etc.  that never seem to line up exactly right. Its a feeling approximated  metaphorically, of course  in this frustrating Tetris-like Web game inspired by a cartoon on XKCD, titled Hell.

title: Hello, Brooklyn
description: There was a dispatch from Kings County in The Financial Times over the weekend, a woman named Emily Stokes banging around Brooklyn on the F train and looking into the boroughs dining scene: the laid-back and hipstery crowds at Vinegar Hill House, Saraghina, Frankies Sputino, Prime Meats, the Vanderbilt.

title: The Goldman Defense: Caveat Emptor
description: 5:43 p.m. | Updated with both Goldman response documents Months before the Securities and Exchange Commission sued Goldman Sachs for securities fraud, the investment bank outlined its defense to potential charges related to its construction of a mortgage investment.

title: Daviss Honesty Was Refreshing, but Not Unexpected
description: Something seemed very wrong when Brian Davis of England summoned a rules official immediately after hitting his pitch from the hazard near Calibogue Sound in Sundays playoff with Jim Furyk for the Verizon Heritage title. Actually, something was very right.

title: In Blood, Lifes Ebb and Flow
description: When you are seriously ill, many of the transactions you make are rendered in blood.

title: The Claim: Alcohol Worsens Allergies
description: THE FACTS

title: With Flights Grounded, Kenyas Produce Wilts
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  When Kenneth Maundu, general manager for Sunripe produce exporters, first heard about a volcano erupting in Iceland, he was excited. I thought, Oh, wow, a volcano, he said.

title: Going Mobile: Debating and Using Cellphones in School
description: Overview | Can cellphones serve as effective instructional tools in the classroom? In what ways can the use of mobile technology support and strengthen curriculum? What are the drawbacks? In this lesson, students learn about innovative uses of cellphone technology and applications in the developing world, then explore how their phones can be used as learning tools.

title: Monday Puzzle: Thank You, John
description: The Monday Puzzle is on the move. TierneyLab is about to shut down (John explains here why hes closing the blog to concentrate on longer articles and his science column), but the math puzzles will continue at a new home, The Times WordPlay blog. The math puzzles by me with illustrations by Justin Thyme will appear there under the title Numberplay starting next Monday. This is the last puzzle here at the Lab, so it is time to take a stroll down memory lane . . .

title: Volcano Set to Cost Airlines Millions
description: As volcanic ash keeps European flights grounded, air carriers claim they are losing $200 million per day. NBC's Dawna Friesen reports from London.

title: Value-Added Taxes: A Primer
description: In recent weeks there has been lots of buzz  much of it preemptively negative  about value-added taxes. This post presents a short primer to help you get up to speed if youre unfamiliar with this policy tool.

title: Fabrice Tourre: Fabulous or Fatally Flawed?
description: Fabrice Tourre, the 31-year-old Goldman Sachs vice president cited by the Securities and Exchange Commission in its accusation of securities fraud against the firm, is a graduate of one of Frances oldest and best known engineering schools, the cole Centrale Paris, where he studied from 1998 through 2000.

title: A Baristas One Shining Moment, Again
description: On Sunday, Mike Phillips of Intelligentsia Coffee and Tea won at the United States Barista Championship, for the second consecutive year. He will represent the United States at the World Barista Championship, to be held in London in June.

title: Layoffs Announced at St. Vincents
description: Updated, 3:52 p.m. | More than 1,000 staff members were laid off on Monday at the bankrupt St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan, the hospital said in a statement.

title: Vain Glorious | Kiehls Earth Day Initiative
description: Who: Jeff Koons, Julianne Moore, Pharrell Williams and Malia Jones.

title: Greeces Uncertain Future Weighs on Bond Market
description: Yields on Greek bonds pushed to fresh highs on Monday and shares in Athens sank as investors continued to worry about the countrys near-term ability to finance its debt. Some raised the specter of default even if international aid arrived soon.

title: A Firsthand Look at Firefights in Marja
description: During the initial American-led assault earlier this year into Marja, the last large Taliban-dominated population center in Helmand Province, Marines in several companies encountered something unusual in the American experience of the Afghan war  insurgent snipers.

title: Paedophile Pound
description: The market for mainstream products that sexualize young children.

title: Wild Sharks-Avalanche Series Gets Even Wilder
description: The Sharks and Avalanche have only played three games in their first-round N.H.L. playoff series, but the amazing drama makes it feel like theyve played many more.

title: The Squeeze on the Middle Class
description: A combination of rising health insurance premiums and falling wages has hit middle-income people especially hard, causing them to lose health insurance coverage faster than workers both poorer and richer than they are, according to a recent report from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.

title: Travel Deals: Free Lonely Planet iPhone Guides
description: Thousands of travelers have been stranded by the eruption of Icelands Eyjafjallajokull volcano, which disrupted air traffic worldwide. But as Elisabeth Rosenthal reports, some stranded passengers are enjoying the forced leisure time.

title: Florida Voters: Its a Bad Idea to Sue Over Health Care Law
description: Bill McCollum, Floridas attorney general, has been crowing for months about the lawsuit he filed challenging the federal health care overhaul. His calculus, as the Republican candidate for governor, has been broadcast at every turn: Voters will love it!

title: Iron Man and Miley Cyrus vs. the Volcano
description: A cloud of volcanic ash has done what foes like the Mandarin, Modok and the Crimson Dynamo could not  it has forced Iron Man to yield. Paramount said on Monday that it was moving the world premiere of Iron Man 2, its much anticipated comic-book adventure movie, to Los Angeles from London as Europe contends with travel woes caused by the eruption of an Icelandic volcano, The Hollywood Reporter said.

title: Citi Distances Itself From Goldmans Troubles
description: Citigroup said Monday that it was not involved in the governments fraud investigation into Goldman Sachss subprime mortgage dealings, but the bank once again acknowledged that regulators were looking at its subprime business.

title: Iran Mutes a Chorus of Voices for Reform
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Iranian authorities on Monday suspended two prominent opposition political parties, banned a newspaper and handed down prison sentences to three reformist political figures, in the latest sign that the countrys hard-line rulers aim to crush any official political representation by the reformist movement.

title: Eyjafjallajokulls Scream Could Wake a Neighbor
description: As my colleagues Alan Cowell, Nicola Clark and Mark McDonald report, the disruption to air travel in Europe is easing as the eruption of the Eyjafjallajokull volcano in Iceland has weakened, spewing less ash into the skies.

title: Flood Insurance Program Is Back  for Now
description: The National Flood Insurance Program is back in business, at least until May 31.

title: Man Convicted for Driving Drunk in Barbie Car
description: A few months ago I wrote about a man in Minnesota who was charged with drunken driving after he crashed his homemade motorized recliner into a parked car, and I didnt think it got any weirder than that.

title: Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 12:55 P.M.
The Insider | Gordon Harrison Hull
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts.

title: Orchestra and Lincoln Center in Deal
description: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and the New York Philharmonic have decided to extend their operating agreement to give both parties more time to resolve questions about a renovation of the orchestras home, Avery Fisher Hall.

title: (Company Name Here) Presents: Martinez Schools
description: Just how much is the right to name a building at your childs school worth to a corporate sponsor? Parents of the 4,000 students in the Martinez Unified School District could soon find out.

title: Los Angeles Museum Board Members Ordered to Undergo Financial Training
description: The California Attorney Generals office has ordered the board members of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, which came close to a financial collapse in 2008, to undergo special fiduciary training after the office determined that the museum flouted state law in the way it managed its budget, The Los Angeles Times reported.

title: A Mischievous Convergence of Past and Present Jazz
description: Erimaj, a band led by Jamire Williams, the young jazz drummer from Houston, features a lot of information being knocked around. There are rising and falling vamps and solos; a bit of rock and pastoral-sounding, post-Pat Metheny guitar harmony; some careful falsetto R&B; and, from Mr. Williams, fluid narrative improvising, as well as beats like fragmented hip-hop.

title: Previous Airline Brushes with Ash Disaster
description: Here is a partial list of commercial airline flights that faced potentially disastrous problems when they flew into volcanic ash clouds. All were Boeing 747s.

title: In Event of a Strike, How to Open the Doors
description: Here at City Room we do our best to help New Yorkers in need. Lately weve been reading that more than 30,000 workers in the citys residential buildings  many of them doormen  are threatening to strike at 12:01 a.m. Wednesday.

title: The Morning Skate: An Entertaining Start to Stanley Cup Play
description: Poor Dan Boyle. Trying to clear the puck behind his own net to teammate Douglas Murray, the Sharks defensemans attempt deflected off the stick of Colorados Ryan OReilly and past Evgeni Nabokov for the only goal of the game in the first minute of overtime.

title: Auchincloss Co-op Is for Sale
description: A three-bedroom apartment on Park Avenue that was home to the author Louis Auchincloss has been put on the market for $3.9 million. Mr. Auchincloss wrote more than 60 books, most memorably about the upper echelons of society He also practiced law until 1987. He died in January at age 92. The co-op, at 1111 Park Avenue, is listed with Mary Rutherfurd and Leslie Coleman of Brown Harris Stevens.

title: Ash Clouds and Adoption Bans
description: Among the many disruptions caused by the volcanic eruptions in Iceland was a flight to Moscow by a U.S. delegation hoping to restart adoptions with Russia. While the details of the freeze are murky, what is clear is that nothing will be clarified until negotiations start. That was supposed to happen today, but was postponed until at least next week, according to a statement from the U.S. Embassy.

title: Good Brief | Underwear for Earth Day
description: Maybe your mother told you that you should always put clean underwear on in the morning in case you were ever to get hit by a bus. But what if every time you changed your skivvies, 20 trees would be planted in Africa? It could happen. PACT underwear [www.wearPACT.com], the pet project from the design celeb Yves Behar, donates 10 percent of its sales to an ever- increasing roster of nonprofits like Dave Eggerss writing program, 826 Valencia, and Oceana. Each organization gets its own print so you can wear your cause on your, er, oh never mind. The newest collaboration is with the architect David Adjaye and Wangari Maathai, whose Green Belt Movement works to empower women and fight deforestation, soil erosion and water scarcity in Kenya. For Earth Week only, 100 percent of the proceeds of Adjayes specially designed Green Belt print underwear will contribute to the planting of 10,000 trees. (After April 25, it reverts to 10 percent.) See? Change is good!

title: King Sunny Ad Cancels Tour After Two Deaths
description: Lots of musicians have been canceling international tour dates lately, mostly because of the hazards posed by the volcano eruption in Iceland. But concerns at once more tragic and more ordinary have forced King Sunny Ad, the legendary Nigerian bandleader, to call off his North American tour, which was scheduled to start in Canada last week and come to the Highline Ballroom in Manhattan on May 20.

title: Davis to Play, Reyes to Sit
description: 6:18 p.m. | Updated The Mets, off to a 4-8 start and slumping at the plate, promoted first baseman Ike Davis, their top prospect, from Class AAA Buffalo on Monday.

title: Columbine and Va. Tech Families Take On Gun Show Loophole
description: Updated: Family members of those killed or wounded in the shootings at Virginia Tech and Columbine High School signed advertisements running today that called on lawmakers to support closing the gun show loophole.

title: Acrobatic Ants
description: Q. Can the tiny ants that visit me every spring hop like a flea? Sometimes I look down and suddenly there one is, working its way across my anatomy.

title: Crist Faces New Pressure in Senate Race
description: Updated: Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida faced new pressure today to abandon his campaign to win the states Republican nomination for the United States Senate, with the head of the partys senatorial re-election committee declaring that Mr. Crist has zero chance to win.

title: Appliance Discounts, for the Swift
description: Whether it is newfound green consciousness ahead of Earth Day  or just the allure of a big discount on a new washing machine or air-conditioner  consumers across the country are snapping up government rebates for energy-efficient appliances.

title: Toyota to Recall 2010 Lexus Gx 460
description: Toyota said it will recall about 9,400 of its 2010 Lexus GX 460s to re-program the electronic stability control system, which it calls Vehicle Stability Control, to correct a handling problem that caused Consumer Reports magazine to issue a dont-buy warning.

title: Five Trades That Need to Happen During the Draft
description: Sigmund Bloom of Draftguys.com will help preview and analyze the draft for the Fifth Down. He and Cecil Lammey host a podcast at FootballGuys.com,  and you can follow him on Twitter here.

title: A Strange Set From the Reclusive Sly Stone
description: INDIO, Calif.  On Sunday night Sly Stones band was set up in one tent at 7 oclock, the show then postponed to 9:30 and the equipment dismantled and moved to a bigger tent, where a very small crowd that had gotten word finally saw him.

title: Fuld: I Had Never Heard of Repo 105 as C.E.O.
description: One of the biggest surprises to arise out of the court-appointed examiners report on Lehman Brothers was the emergence of Repo 105, an aggressive accounting trick that helped the investment bank look healthier than it really was.

title: Can You Have a Happy Birthday on April 19?
description: On the little block in Providence, R.I., where I grew up, three of us kids celebrated our birthdays on April 19. I thought that was pretty remarkable; April 19 must be pretty special, I concluded. Many years later I feel the same way, but for different reasons.

title: Luge Federation Says Olympic Track Not to Blame for Death
description: Two months after a Georgian luge athlete died in a crash on the Olympic track before the Vancouver Games, the sports international governing body has upheld its assertion that track design was not at fault in the racers death.

title: Kick-Ass Sneaks Ahead of Dragon in Box-Office Race
description: Kick-Ass slew the dragon after all. Lionsgate executives are doing cartwheels over final box office figures that show their R-rated superhero comedy was the No. 1 movie over the weekend after all, beating DreamWorks Animations How to Train Your Dragon by a whisker. Kick-Ass ended up selling $19.83 million in tickets; Dragon moved into second place, with $19.63 million. What does it mean? For Dragon, not much. The animated movie, propped up by sky-high 3-D ticket prices, continues to do solid business in its fourth week in theaters. So it fell to second place  it already got a boatload of free press out of appearing to take the top slot. As for Kick-Ass, the No. 1 crown is psychologically important to embattled Lionsgate, which promoted the movie heavily with hopes of discovering a franchise. Joe Drake, Lionsgates co-chief operating officer, appears to still have hope. Our marketing and distribution teams have brilliantly positioned it for a long and successful run, he said in a news release on Monday.

title: Sean Carroll Talks School Science and Time Travel
description: Q. When you go to a cocktail party, do you tell people that you are a physicist? Some physicists wont.

title: Brown Accuses Moodys of Blowing Off Inquiry
description: Attorney General Jerry Brown of California is taking Moodys Investors Service to court. Mr. Brown contends that the credit rating agency is blowing off the state of California in its seven-month investigation into whether Moodys and the two other leading credit-rating agencies, Standard & Poors and Fitch Ratings, acted improperly during the credit boom by assigning super-safe, triple-A ratings to mortgage-backed securities that later turned out to be extremely risky and in some cases worthless.

title: Bring Back My Cable
description: Ive had cable TV, but I went without without it for several months. I got all my shows online. Im currently back to a cable setup (FiOS, if you are keeping score at home). I think cable is better for one important reason.

title: Saturn Up Close
description: Images captured by cameras aboard the Cassini spacecraft on its mission to explore Saturn and its moons.

title: On Ash and the Global Aviation Boom
Chopin in All His Variety, Imaginatively Served
description: The Chopin bicentennial has brought an expected rush of celebrations, but for some performers this music is seldom out of mind. The brilliant Italian pianist Maurizio Pollini has a repertory that extends from Bach to Stockhausen, but Chopins music has always been a special cause, certainly since Mr. Pollini won the Chopin International Piano Competition in Warsaw in 1960.

title: Goldman Suit Affects Reform Prospects
description: Jeff Zeleny of The Times discusses how the Goldman scandal affects the administration's attempt to pass financial regulatory reform.

title: Critics Picks Video: Brazil
description: In this weeks Critics Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Terry Gilliams dystopian science fiction film, Brazil. Mr. Scott calls the film, which pits imagination against reality, extravagant, visionary and maybe just a little bit crazy. Please share your thoughts on Brazil and the career of Terry Gilliam.

title: Blockbuster First Week for Fences
description: The Broadway revival of Fences had a blockbuster first week of preview performances at the box office last week, grossing $703,724 for a six-show week  technically 105 percent of the potential maximum gross, a sign that some theatergoers are paying the $325 premium ticket price for the August Wilson play starring Denzel Washington and Viola Davis.

title: Suit Accuses USA Swimming of Negligence
description: A 21-year-old former competitive swimmer filed a civil suit Monday in Independence, Mo., against USA Swimming and her swim club, claiming they were negligent in protecting her and others from sexual abuse by a coach. Despite her complaints about his conduct, the suit said, the coach was able to move to a club in a different state.

title: A Saturn Spectacular, With Gravitys Help
description: When it comes to voyages of discovery, NASAs venerable Cassini mission is about as good as it gets.

title: Kyle MacLachlan Selling Chelsea Apartment
description: The actor Kyle MacLachlan and his wife, Desiree Gruber, an executive producer of Project Runway, have put their apartment up for sale. They are asking $2.875 million for a three-bedroom condo at the Chelsea Mercantile, located at 252 Seventh Avenue at 24th Street.

title: Apple Store Says 3G iPads to Ship by May 7th
description: Apples formal release date for the 3G version of the iPad is still up in the air, but information posted on the Apple Online Store site says the three 3G models will ship to purchasers by May 7th.

title: An Alcoholics Savior: God, Belladonna or Both?
description: In October 1909, Dr. Alexander Lambert boldly announced to a New York Times reporter that he had found a surefire cure for alcoholism and drug addiction. Even more astounding, he stated that the treatment required less than five days. The therapy consisted of an odd mixture of belladonna (deadly nightshade), along with the fluid extracts of xanthoxylum (prickly ash) and hyoscyamus (henbane). The result is often so dramatic, Lambert said, that one hesitates to believe it possible.

title: Australia Blocks a Deal for Unit of AXA
description: National Australia Banks ambitions to substantially increase its position in Australias wealth management and life insurance market were dealt a major setback on Monday, when the countrys competition authority blocked its $12.2 billion bid for the Asia Pacific operations of the French insurance giant AXA.

title: M2 Club Closed by the Police
description: An earlier version of this post said that M2 itself was accused of selling drugs. It should have said that M2 was accused of allowing the sale of drugs, and has been updated to reflect that correction.

title: Artifacts | Jeff Burtons Fantasy Life Beyond Porn
description: Jeff Burton was smitten with Stella Stevens the instant he saw The Poseidon Adventure. That was in 1972. He was 9. In the movie, Stevens played an ultrachic former call girl who had married a burly cop, Ernest Borgnine, and fell to her death shod in silver platform shoes. The young Burton developed a raging obsession with both Stevens and the film. Thirty-five years later, after working as a still photographer on porn movie shoots in Los Angeles, where he lives, Burton got to direct her himself  for a portrait now hanging in his seventh solo show at the Casey Kaplan Gallery.

title: Kenya: Pig Farmers Are Focus of Effort to Stop Spread of Parasite That Causes Epilepsy
description: Researchers in Kenya have been trying a seemingly unlikely tactic to prevent epilepsy: teaching farmers to tether their pigs.

title: Risks for Youths Who Eat What They Watch
description: Many factors influence childrens food choices: where they eat; what their friends and siblings eat; what parents eat and drink and bring into the house; what is served at school; and, of course, what they like.

title: MLB 10: The Show
description: A trailer for the video game.

title: Benefit for Uninsured May Still Pose Hurdle
description: William Mann of Pittsburgh earns just enough to get by. He is 46, doesnt own a car, hasnt taken a vacation in three years and hasnt had health insurance for most of his adult life.

title: With AIDS, Time to Get Beyond Blame
description: You dont hear much about AIDS in America anymore. The few new headlines are reserved for dispatches from the developing world, where the dying young still make good old-fashioned heart-wrenching copy.

title: Baseball Real Enough to Stink At
description: When it comes to sports video games, is there such a thing as too much realism?

title: For Same-Sex Couples, Equality in the Hospital
description: For people in same-sex relationships, aging carries an added burden of anxiety: the fear that in a health crisis their partner might be excluded from making medical decisions, even visiting their bedside.

title: BlogTalk: Birthers, Doctors and the Womens Vote
description: Tom Tancredo promotes the idea that President Obama was not born in this country and the White House reacts (sort of); more doctors are running for Congress; and a Las Vegas newspaper editorial calls for repealing the 19th Amendment, which gave women the right to vote. These are a few of the the political tidbits churning around the blogs today.

title: The Cassini-Huygens Mission to Saturn
description: A look back at four years of the Cassini mission to explore Saturn, its rings and moons.

title: Bracing for the End, Maybe, of Ginos
description: Every zebra has its day. The 314 zebras on the wallpaper in Ginos of Capri, an Upper East Side restaurant that was once a haunt for Ed Sullivan and Frank Sinatra, are not getting any younger. Their last day is May 15. Maybe.

title: Despite Advice, Many Fail to Breast-Feed
description: The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends breast-feeding exclusively for the first six months of life, and continued nursing for a year, but a national survey has found that less than 75 percent of women breast-feed at all, and by one year only about a fifth are still nursing their babies.

title: Global Strategy Stabilized I.B.M. During Downturn
description: I.B.M. wanted to sell its wares around the world since its early days, adopting the aspirational name International Business Machines Corporation, in 1924. And for decades, I.B.M. was the emblematic multinational with deep roots in foreign markets, mainly in the developed nations of Europe and Japan.

title: Aleppo, Syria, to Undergo Historical Restoration
description: In this ancient fortress city in northern Syria, one of the worlds oldest continuously inhabited settlements, an ambitious restoration project is near completion in the Old City. Bloomberg is reporting that a master plan for development has been laid out for the next 15 years.

title: A Magazine Master Builder
description: When Henry Luce graduated from the Hotchkiss School in Connecticut in 1916, he received not a single vote in the most likely to succeed category. That oversight remains amazing, not only because he would attain such eminence as Time Inc.s founder and long-reigning autocrat but also because of what Luce, at 18, had already accomplished.

title: Compulsory Education for a Museum Board
description: The California Attorney Generals office ordered the board members of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, which came close to a financial collapse in 2008, to undergo special fiduciary training last year after determining that the museum flouted state law in the way it managed its budget, The Los Angeles Times reported. The museum lost more than $30 million from its investment portfolio over several years, ending up with only $5 million on hand in 2008; it also broke state law when it paid general expenses from restricted endowment funds, according to the newspaper, which obtained a two-page letter sent to the museum by the attorney generals office in November. In December 2008 the museum negotiated a $30 million bailout from Eli Broad, Los Angeless leading cultural patron, which allowed it to maintain its facilities and avoid selling off artwork. As a result of that agreement and new giving by other donors, the museums investments have improved, with the value rising to more than $14 million. A museum spokeswoman said the museum and the board had complied with all the requirements for training and financial reform in the attorney generals letter.

title: Pacino and McEntire Deliver for CBS
description: The unlikely double act of Al Pacino and Reba McEntire led CBS to a ratings victory on Sunday night. A new installment of 60 Minutes, featuring a profile of Mr. Pacino, left, drew 10.7 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, and the Academy of Country Music Awards show, hosted by Ms. McEntire, roped in an average of 13.1 million viewers. ABC was runner-up on the night with its more traditional pairing of Desperate Housewives (10.4 million) and Brothers & Sisters (7.9 million), while NBC was third as Donald Trump fired the wrestler Bill Goldberg from his Celebrity Apprentice team (6.9 million). Fox was fourth with a lineup that included new episodes of The Simpsons (5.9 million) and American Dad (5.2 million).

title: A New Weekend Champ
description: Lionsgate executives are doing cartwheels over final box office figures that show that Kick-Ass, their R-rated superhero comedy that features Chloe Grace Moretz, above, was the No. 1 movie over the weekend, beating DreamWorks Animations How to Train Your Dragon by a whisker. Kick-Ass ended up selling $19.8 million in tickets; Dragon slipped to second place with $19.6 million. What does it mean? For Dragon, not much. Propped up by ticket prices at 3-D screenings, the film continues to do solid business in its fourth week in theaters. As for Kick-Ass, the No. 1 crown is important to the embattled Lionsgate, which promoted the movie heavily, hoping to build a franchise. Joe Drake, Lionsgates co-chief operating officer, apparently still has such hopes. Our marketing and distribution teams have brilliantly positioned it for a long and successful run, he said in a news release on Monday.

title: Underwood and Bubl Score Music Awards
description: Musicians from down South, up North and all points in between had reasons to celebrate as both the Academy of Country Music Awards and the Juno Awards, the Canadian equivalent of the Grammys, were handed out this weekend. Lady Antebellum was the biggest winner on Sunday at the Academy of Country Music Awards show in Las Vegas, The Associated Press reported. The trio, based in Nashville, picked up five trophies, including one for best vocal group as well as for song and single record of the year for Need You Now. But the spotlight shined brightest on Carrie Underwood, above, who became the first woman to win the academys entertainer of the year award twice, and was given a special trophy for her previous triple crown victories as entertainer of the year, top female vocalist and top newcomer categories. In St. Johns, Newfoundland, the pop singer Michael Bubl won four prizes at the Juno Awards, The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. Bubls Crazy Love won in the pop album and overall album categories, and his song Havent Met You Yet was named single of the year.

title: Readers Reduce, Reuse and Recycle
description: Across Berlin, color-coded domes and cans stand at at the ready to take in Berliners recyclables, one material at a time: glass, plastic, paper. But on New Yorks street corners, there is only one wide-lipped metal trash can that takes it all in, recyclable or not.

title: Minute of Mayhem for Malcolm McLaren
description: It wouldnt be a funeral for Malcolm McLaren if it didnt feature one last stunt. On Monday relatives of Mr. McLaren, the pop provocateur, sloganeer and former manager of the British punk band the Sex Pistols, asked that his mourners observe a minute of mayhem when he is buried on Thursday, Reuters reported. Mr. McLaren died of mesothelioma on April 8. He was 64. On the Web site of the charity Humanade, humanade.org.uk, Mr. McLarens son, Joseph Corr, wrote that he would be buried at Highgate Cemetery in London after a funeral procession through the city. In a statement Mr. Corr wrote: In celebration of Malcolms life we are asking people to observe a MINUTE OF MAYHEM at midday on 22nd April. Put on your favorite records and let it RIP!

title: King Sunny Ad Cancels North American Tour
description: King Sunny Ad, the legendary Nigerian bandleader, has called off his North American tour, which was to have begun in Canada last week and come to the Highline Ballroom in Manhattan on May 20. In late March, two percussionists in Mr. Ads 17-piece touring band, Gabriel Ayanniyi and Omo Olope, died in a car accident in Nigeria on the way to a music video shoot. With just a few weeks before the tour was scheduled to start, efforts to get American visas for replacement members of the band proved unsuccessful. Finding replacement players in the United States was next to impossible, said Andy Frankel, the bands manager, who is based in Philadelphia, for financial, logistical and, especially, musical reasons, given Mr. Ayanniyis key role as the lead talking-drum player. In Mr. Ads juju music  a Nigerian pop style rooted in Yoruba traditions  the talking drum is, Mr. Frankel said, equivalent to the lead guitar in a rock band. He added, After King Sunny, it does everything.

title: Iron Man and Miley Cyrus Wait for Dust to Settle
description: A cloud of volcanic ash has done what foes like the Mandarin, Modok and the Crimson Dynamo could not  it has forced Iron Man to yield. Paramount said on Monday that it was moving the world premiere of Iron Man 2, the much-anticipated sequel to its comic-book adventure movie, to Los Angeles from London as Europe contends with travel woes caused by the eruption of an Icelandic volcano, The Hollywood Reporter said. The high-wattage premiere, scheduled for next Monday at the Vue Westfield theater in London, was to have included the films stars Robert Downey Jr., above, Scarlett Johansson and Mickey Rourke. The Hollywood Reporter said that travel uncertainties had also caused Miley Cyrus and Liam Hemsworth to cancel planned appearances at a charity screening of their movie, The Last Song, in London. A-listers were no match for the relatively unknown Eyjafjallajokull volcano (whose name, were fairly certain, was not taken from an old Stan Lee-Jack Kirby issue of Tales of Suspense).

title: Corker Slams Both Sides in Financial Feud
description: Senator Bob Corker, the Republican of Tennessee who helped draft legislation to tighten regulation of the financial industry, criticized both Republicans and Democrats on Monday for politicizing the debate.

title: Newbies and the Reunited Gather in the Desert
description: INDIO, Calif.  Were Pavement, back from the dead, Scott Kannberg, Pavements rhythm guitarist, told thousands of people gathered on Sunday night at the main stage of the 11th Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival. A reunited Pavement, the epitome of disheveled 1990s indie-rock until it dissolved in 2000, wasnt the only re-emergent act at Coachella. The three-day rock festival, in the California desert, with more than 100 bands and D.J.s, also featured Faith No More, Public Image Ltd., the Specials and Sly Stone, whose set started four hours after it was scheduled and closed out the weekend as a funky mess.

title: The Few Who Founded Fantasy Baseball
description: A movie about the genesis of rotisserie baseball has a built-in audience. It also has a built-in, and almost equally passionate, nonaudience. Those of us who play roto know better than to bring it up at a party, let alone beat people over the head with it for an hour.

title: Ahead of Goldman Suit, a Tight-Lipped S.E.C.
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Love Your Dress. Really.
description: At the Matrix Awards luncheon at the Waldorf Astoria on Monday,Tina Fey and Sheryl Crow beamed for the cameras, their composure commendable  considering that each had committed the kind of fashion faux pas that often rates more attention than the event itself. Ms. Fey and Ms. Crow, both honorees at the event, which honors New York Women in communications, wore subtle variations of a nearly identical Dolce & Gabbana dress, a sleeveless jacquard embellished with overblown roses and vines.

title: Seeing Ourselves Through Our Childrens Eyes
description: A friend of mine famously decided to go back to work when her young daughter announced one morning: I go to school, Daddy goes to work. And Mommy goes to  gym.

title: Earth Week | The Moment Picks
description: Rough and Ready by Jill Singer

title: Voters Like Cuomos Aggressiveness, Poll Finds
description: Within the New York political circles that he has traveled since his 20s, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has a well-earned reputation as a hard-driving and occasionally bare-knuckled political operator.

title: A Return to the Scene of a Tragedy of Drama
description: A wispy breath of hope, an aftershock of anger, a lingering chill of regret. Thats about all of the ghosts of Tennessee Williams and Elia Kazan that materializes in The Really Big Once, an exploration of a failed collaboration between two one-time kings of American drama. But any lack of more full-bodied manifestations is not for want of wishing or willing by the spirit seekers who have gathered in the close quarters of the Ontological-Hysteric Theater.

title: Bloomberg for Prime Minister!
description: Andrew Stuttaford on the unexpected rise of Nick Clegg, leader of Britains Liberal Democrats:

title: In Deep Sea, Waves With a Familiar Curl
description: Scientists exploring the deep sea have discovered a distinctive kind of breaking wave. The finding reveals the presence of a subtle new force that can stir the dark seabed, and it helps to explain some of the nuances of planetary recycling and the provision of food to abyssal life.

title: He Gazed, She Gazed, and They Danced
description: The idea of the male gaze has played a prominent role in much of Maria Hassabis recent work, which deals with sculptural, often extreme poses. In Robert and Maria, that gaze is finally embodied, courtesy of her collaborator Robert Steijn. And Ms. Hassabi is looking right back.

title: Yes, This Manicure Is 12 Days Old
description: MANICURES arent known for being everlasting. They chip. They smudge. Sometimes a nail is ruined even before you get home from the salon.

title: For Some Birds, Its Not Always the Same Old Song
description: Songbirds are not born with songs in their heads, but learn them from others. And as in a game of telephone, it would seem natural that, over generations, the songs might change.

title: Overview of an Artists Work Helps to Explore His Sounds
description: Sometimes cooperation between arts organizations pays off in unexpected ways. When Carnegie Hall announced its current Louis Andriessen series, Ronen Givony, one of the music directors at Le Poisson Rouge, decided to present an all-Andriessen concert at that Greenwich Village club around the same time. Mr. Givony mentioned the idea to Carnegies director of artistic planning, Jeremy Geffen, who encouraged him and listed Le Poisson Rouges all-Andriessen concert on the halls Web site, carnegiehall.org, as a ninth event in what was originally an eight-concert series.

title: Sigh of Relief?
description: Inglot Cosmetics, a company from Poland, has a nail polish called O2M that it calls breathable, meaning that it allows oxygen and moisture to penetrate to the nail. This makes the polish something of an anomaly, since most brands dont make this claim.

title: Calculating Water Use, Direct and Indirect
description: How much water do you use every day?

title: Celebrating 45 Years of Preserving New York
description: One question that came to mind on Monday was: Where were you on April 19, 1965?

title: Composing Under the Radar for Orchestra and Imagination
description: Absolute declarations are a dangerous business, but it seems safe to say that Louis Andriessen is the worlds best-known living Dutch composer, maybe even the best-known Dutch composer, period. Mr. Andriessen, who now occupies the Richard and Barbara Debs Composers Chair at Carnegie Hall, has been one of the most influential figures in contemporary classical music since the mid-1970s, a point made by the American Composers Orchestra in a concert just over a week ago, kicking off a Carnegie Hall series in Mr. Andriessens honor.

title: Cheek to Cheek (and Tongue-in-Cheek)
description: In the realm of popular culture, there are few more terrifying circumstances than dancing on live television. On an episode of Dancing With the Stars this season, Aiden Turner, a chiseled soap-opera actor who was recently voted off the competition, threw up backstage.

title: Finding a Way to Stop Ricin in Its Deadly Path
description: Humanity has produced some lethal chemical weapons over the years, but nature is no slouch in that department, either. Among naturally occurring toxins, some of the most deadly are ricin, which is found in the beans of the castor oil plant, and Shiga-like toxins, which are produced from pathogenic E. coli bacteria. (With ricin the deaths have occasionally been intentional, which is why it is classified as a bioterror agent).

title: 'American Idiot'
description: An excerpt from the title number of the new Broadway musical based on the music of Green Day. (Video courtesy of the production)

title: Milans No. 10 on the Champions League Semis, Messi and Kaka
description: In his regular discussion with New York Times readers, Clarence Seedorf discusses the UEFA Champions League semifinals, some of the brightest stars of the international game, and whether or not he thinks doping is a major problem in international soccer. Read the AC Milan midfielders responses post your comments below.

title: Democrats Banking Bill Struggles to Get G.O.P. Support
description: WASHINGTON  Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner appealed on Monday to the centrist Republican senators from Maine for their support of legislation to tighten regulation of the nations financial system but came up empty-handed, leaving Democrats and Republicans on an apparent collision course.

title: G.M. Is Said to Be Ready to Pay Off Its Government Loans
description: DETROIT  General Motors, hoping to build confidence in its turnaround and move toward becoming an independent public company again, plans to repay the balance of its government loans this week, a person with direct knowledge of the plans said Monday.

title: Obama, Biden Will Attend Miners Memorial
description: President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will travel to West Virginia this weekend to mourn the 29 miners killed in an explosion earlier this month in the worst mining accident in the United States in four decades, the White House announced Monday.

title: Apollo Agrees to Cut Some Fees for Calpers
description: Apollo Management agreed on Monday to concessions for its oldest and largest investor, Calpers, cutting its fees for certain funds and dropping the use of placement agents to gain business from the California pension fund.

title: Doubts Grow About the Sale of Palm
description: Shares of Palm dropped 12 percent on Monday after analysts voiced doubts about the chances that the maker of smartphones and other hand-held devices would be able to sell itself its current market price. Palms stock price jumped last week after reports emerged that the company was seeking a buyer.

title: Recession Adds to Appeal of Short-Term Jobs
description: NORCROSS, Ga.  Michael Sinclair knows that in a few months, his stint in the marketing department of a health care manufacturing company here north of Atlanta is set to end.

title: Making It Easier to Eat Local Food
description: A recent Times article highlighted a growing problem for small farmers across the nation: too few slaughterhouses. Many farmers who have answered the demand for locally raised meat have been forced to scale back expansion plans because local processors cant handle any more animals and the cost of driving their livestock hundreds of miles for slaughter is too expensive.

title: A Candidate Makes an Asset of His Wall Street Past
description: ALBANY  Harry Wilson, a former hedge fund manager, has a novel idea for New Yorkers. Why not put a Wall Street veteran in the state comptrollers office to oversee the $129.4 billion pension fund?

title: Cleggmania Shakes Up British Election
description: Having stolen the show from the leaders of Britains two largest parties during a televised debate last Thursday, Nick Clegg, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, has seen his party surge in the polls to such an extent that he is suddenly at the center of what one British reporter is calling the hysterical condition known as Cleggmania.

title: For Earth Day, 7 New Rules to Live By
description: On the 40th anniversary of Earth Day, is the middle-aged green movement ready to be revived by some iconoclastic young Turqs?

title: Berkus Lines Up Across the Country
description: The Nate Berkus Show, hosted by an Oprah Winfrey protg, is cleared for a fall premiere.

title: Obama Raises Funds for Boxer, D.N.C.
description: 10:18 p.m. | Updated President Obama flew to Los Angeles on Monday for a political cash run to help out one of his most embattled Democratic allies, Senator Barbara Boxer of California, and warned that she was in danger of losing her seat after 18 years.

title: New Turkish Cypriot Leader Says Talks to Resume
description: ISTANBUL  The newly elected Turkish Cypriot leader, Dervis Eroglu, sought to quell fears on Monday that he would block United Nations negotiations to resolve the islands status, saying that talks could resume as early as mid-May.

title: What Were Reading: Zooey, Geeks and Hipster Nerds
description: What the tech editors and reporters of The New York Times wanted others to be certain to read:

title: 'Sondheim on Sondheim'
description: Vanessa Williams sings "Ah, but Underneath," a number written for the 1987 London production of "Follies," in an excerpt from the new Broadway musical about the work of Stephen Sondheim. (Video: Roundabout Theater)

title: Embracing Silence in a Noisy World
description: What is silence? I am profoundly deaf in my left ear (I have a cochlear implant). The ear is useless for hearing, though it makes a pleasant decorative ornament and serves as a place to display earrings and anchor glasses; no sound can penetrate it. You would think that profound deafness is as silent as it gets. And yet it is not quiet in there. I hear deep space sounds, a hollow hum that washes in and fades away, changes in pitch and volume.

title: New Ash Cloud Appears Headed Toward Britain
description: A new ash clouded appeared headed toward the United Kingdom, increasing the uncertainty about the return of air traffic to certain parts of the British Isles on Tuesday, the organization that controls air traffic in the area said.

title: A Similar Terrain for Ants and Men
description: As a former jockey, Dick Francis set all his novels at the racetrack, so it may not be surprising that the biologist Edward O. Wilson has made his newly published first novel revolve around an arena he is familiar with, that of ants. The novel is even called Anthill, though the title also refers to busy milling about of the human kind.

title: Pope Says He Faces Crisis With Cardinals Support
description: VATICAN CITY  Buffeted by a sexual abuse scandal that is quickly defining his papacy, Pope Benedict XVI marked the fifth anniversary of his election on Monday by telling a group of cardinals that he did not feel alone at the head of what he called a wounded and sinner church.

title: Never Too Late to Get Started on Reading
description: Jahara Drammeh first thought about coming to America while watching the 1988 Eddie Murphy film Coming to America. He liked what he saw.

title: Vaccines and Caregivers (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Mood Is Dark as Israel Marks 62nd Year as a Nation
description: JERUSALEM  Every year, Israelis approach the joy of their Independence Day right after immersing themselves in a 24-hour period of grief for fallen soldiers. Before the fireworks burst across the skies Monday night to celebrate the countrys 62nd birthday, the airwaves filled with anguished stories of servicemen and -women killed, the Kaddish prayer of mourning and speeches placing the deeply personal losses of a small country into the sweep of Jewish history.

title: The Patients Perspective (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The High Cost of Medicine (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Motivating Scientists (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Turning a Corner at Citigroup
description: How did Citigroup trounce JPMorgan and Bank of America? On Monday, Citi revealed that it earned $4.4 billion last quarter, its best showing in almost three years. The megabank headed by Vikram S. Pandit not only raked in more profit than its two closest competitors, it also generated a higher return on equity.

title: Cyberattack on Google Said to Hit Password System
description: Ever since Google disclosed in January that Internet intruders had stolen information from its computers, the exact nature and extent of the theft has been a closely guarded company secret. But a person with direct knowledge of the investigation now says that the losses included one of Googles crown jewels, a password system that controls access by millions of users worldwide to almost all of the companys Web services, including e-mail and business applications.

title: In the Mood to Clean? They Know
description: THE Madison Avenue marketing calendar is chockablock with holidays both official (Presidents Day, the Fourth of July, Christmas) and less so (St. Patricks Day, Cinco de Mayo, Halloween). Then there are commercialized occasions like back to school, during which consumers are encouraged to shop for more than a days worth of merchandise.

title: Lawmakers Subpoena Administration Over Fort Hood
description: Top senators on the Homeland Security panel subpoenaed the Obama administration for information they said they need for their investigation into last years Fort Hood shooting.

title: Turning to Teleconferencing as Air Travel Stalls
description: WITH air service still hobbled in Europe, government transport officials scrambled on Monday to hold an emergency meeting. But as anyone stranded in this mess knows well, its difficult to travel to, from or very far within Europe.

title: Albany Candidates Back Nonpartisan Redistricting
description: The four major-party candidates running or expected to run for governor of New York have pledged to support nonpartisan, independent redistricting of legislative and Congressional seats next year  a change that state lawmakers have resisted for decades.

title: Escape From the Jet Age
description: Chicago

title: Goldman Employees Rally Around Blankfein
description: The message went out from Lloyd C. Blankfein: circle the wagons.

title: President Nominates Professor to Health Job
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday nominated Dr. Donald M. Berwick, a health policy expert, to be administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, which runs health programs insuring nearly one-third of all Americans.

title:
A Finance Overhaul Fight
Draws a Swarm of Lobbyists
description: WASHINGTON  Assessing the battle to overhaul the nations financial regulations recently, Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, left no doubt about the consequences if Congress cracked down on his banks immense business in derivatives.

title: Green Ready for His Return, Whether His Game Is or Not
description: Ken Green will take a swing at getting back to a normal life on Friday in Savannah, Ga. Slightly more than 10 months after the traffic accident that killed his brother and his girlfriend and led to the amputation of his right leg below the knee, Green will try out his newly reconstructed golf game on the Champions Tour.

title: Gambling With the Economy
description: WHILE the Securities and Exchange Commissions allegations that Goldman Sachs defrauded clients is certainly big news, the case also raises a far broader issue that goes to the heart of how Wall Street has strayed from its intended mission.

title: Riders on the Storm
description: In 2001, Cass R. Sunstein wrote an essay in The Boston Review called The Daily We: Is the Internet really a blessing for democracy? Sunstein, a professor at the University of Chicago who now serves in the Obama administration, raised the possibility that the Internet may be harming the public square.

title: The Court, Money and Politics
description: Advocates for unlimited campaign contributions  especially corporate contributions  are hoping the Supreme Court will blow another huge hole in the campaign finance law.
