title: Before Gay Marriage Fight, Clashes on Free Speech
description: WASHINGTON

title: Airline Shuttles Smaller but Still Flying Hourly
description: The airline shuttles that operate between New York, Boston and Washington have been downsized, as fewer executives traveled those routes in the recession.

title: Verdict on Long Island
description: A jury in Suffolk County, N.Y., has found Jeffrey Conroy guilty of manslaughter as a hate crime, after he fatally stabbed an Ecuadorean immigrant, Marcelo Lucero. Whatever solace the conviction brings to Mr. Luceros family, the shame for Suffolk Countys law enforcement and political leadership remains.

title: Bloggingheads: How Risky Is Nuclear?
description: John Horgan, left, of the Stevens Center for Science Writings and George Johnson, author of The Ten Most Beautiful Experiments, debate the dangers of nuclear power.

title: If Doormen Strike, Residents Must Pick Up the Slack
description: A possible strike this week by the doormens union could impose  by necessity  a spirit of cooperation in New York Citys co-ops and other apartment buildings.

title: Final Report from the Lab
description: Theres time for one more debate here, about my Earth Day column, but first an announcement: After three years of experiments, TierneyLab is shutting down. Ill still be testing ideas in my Findings columns and in other articles for The Times, and you can keep up with them by following me on Twitter. You can also keep trying the weekly math puzzle at its new home starting next Monday at The Times Wordplay blog.

title: A Receiving Prospect Has His Mother in His Corner
description: AVENTURA, Fla.  One day during his sophomore season at the University of South Florida, Carlton Mitchell pulled on a pair of sweat pants that had once belonged to the boxer Antonio Tarver, a family friend.

title: Debate on Internets Limits Grows in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Displeased that a statue of a 10-year-old Barack Obama was installed in a park here, Indonesians took their protest not to this capitals most famous traffic circle but to Facebook. More than 56,000 online protesters later, city officials gave in to arguments that the park should be reserved to honor an Indonesian.

title: Justices Get Personal Over Privacy of Messages
description: WASHINGTON  The question in a case argued Monday in the Supreme Court sounded both irresistible and important: Did a California police department violate the Constitution by reading sexually explicit text messages sent by an officer on a department-issued pager?

title: Optimism, Then a Victory, After Arrival of Davis
description: If it had been a normal night, the highlight of the Mets game Monday would have been the two-run home run by Angel Pagan that broke a seventh-inning tie and sparked a 6-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: When Wall Street Deals Resemble Casino Wagers
description: The governments civil fraud case against Goldman Sachs raises so many provocative questions.

title: N.J. Voters Asked to Pay More for Less at Schools
description: EDISON, N.J.  School budget talks have become so contentious in this township that 700 people recently packed a school board meeting  and 100 of them stayed more than nine hours, until 4 a.m.

title: For Apple, Lost iPhone Is a Big Deal
description: For anyone who has ever lost a cellphone, remember this: it could be worse. You could be the person who left his phone in a bar in California. And it wasnt just any phone; it was a supersecret version of the next iPhone. That model is not expected to be formally unveiled for a couple of months.

title: Youre Welcome, Wall Street
description: In a 1964 concurring opinion deciding Jacobellis v. Ohio, Associate Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart wrote about hard-core pornography and his struggle to define it: Perhaps I could never succeed in intelligibly doing so. But I know it when I see it.

title: Europe to Ease Aviation Ban, Amid Criticism
description: PARIS  European transport ministers announced a plan to begin easing the ban on aviation traffic around the Continent by Tuesday, but only after a barrage of criticism that the European Union had failed a fresh test of leadership.

title: Two Dead in Tennessee Hospital Shooting
description: A gunman fatally shot a woman and injured two others before killing himself outside a hospital in Knoxville, Tenn., the police said.

title: Trial Opens for Ex-Officer Accused of Shoving Bicyclist
description: It was a clear evening two summers ago when two young men crossed paths in Times Square.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 19, 2010

title: Sleeping (or Not) by the Wrong Clock

Lehman Examiner to Testify That S.E.C.
Sat on Its Hands
description: WASHINGTON  The court-appointed examiner who dissected the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy is expected to criticize the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday for its decision to stand by idly as the investment bank veered toward collapse.

title: With Plenty of Problems, Mets Check One Off Their List
description: Jerry Manuel spoke Monday about the perils of promoting an acclaimed prospect after the season had begun. The more he talked, the more you wondered why the Mets ever held back Ike Davis.

title: A Difficult Path in Goldman Case
description: WASHINGTON  In accusing Goldman Sachs of defrauding investors, regulators are not only taking aim at a company with deep pockets and a will to fight  they are also pursuing an unusual claim that could be difficult to prove in court, legal experts said.

title: Do the Math
description: Last fall, Michelle Rhee, the tough-minded and creative schools chancellor in Washington, laid off 266 teachers, citing a budget crunch. She has since reported finding a budget surplus. The citys teachers union, which challenged the layoffs unsuccessfully last fall, has now asked a judge to review them again. The atmosphere has grown increasingly toxic.

title: Mexicos First Lady Quietly Takes Strong Stance
description: MEXICO CITY  When Margarita Zavala, the wife of Mexicos president, is reminded that newspapers here all ran front-page photographs of her attending a recent memorial service for two university students killed in drug violence, she frowns just slightly.

title: Cancer Fight: Unclear Tests for New Drug
description: Dr. Linda Griffith was at a conference in Singapore in early January when she felt a lump in her breast. She assumed it was nothing  a cyst. And anyway, she had no time for it. She was returning on a Sunday night and the next Tuesday morning was leaving for a conference in Florida.

title: Iran, Sanctions and the Memo
description: Sometime this spring, but still months later than President Obama predicted, Iran may finally face new United Nations sanctions for its illicit nuclear program.

title: Reyna Has Lesson Plan for U.S.
description: Lets clear up a couple of urban legends at once.

title: Small Child, but a Big Passport Headache
description: ON one of my very first business trips, I was fortunate enough to have my wife accompany me to Paris. We were young and didnt have a lot of money. So this was an incredible treat. My son was only 3 months old, and since he was nursing, he came along, too.

title: Insurers See Millions in Claims by Travelers
description: The travel insurance industry is generally paying claims to travelers stranded in Europe and elsewhere by the drifting Icelandic volcanic ash, treating it mostly as a weather-related event in their policies, industry officials said. Some said the claims were expected to total millions of dollars.

title: Two Stars to Stay on Comedy Central Through 2012
description: With Conan OBrien about to change the calculus of late-night cable programming, the Comedy Central channel has made a move to lock up its two dominant stars, Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert.

title: Obama Raises Money in California for Barbara Boxer
description: President Obama flew to Los Angeles on Monday for a political cash run to help out one of his most embattled Democratic allies, Senator Barbara Boxer of California, and warned that she was in danger of losing her seat after 18 years.

title: First Top Scorer Leaves Rutgers, Then the Coach
description: When Mike Rosario won a New Jersey state title with his St. Anthony High School teammates in March 2008, he ran off the court at the Louis Brown Athletic Center at Rutgers and past Scarlet Knights Coach Fred Hill.

title: Scary, Baby, Ginger, Posh and Sporty
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  The old joke at 1 Across put me in a good mood from the get-go, a feeling that lasted through the rest of the puzzle. Its a nice Tuesday theme and a good solve from a name weve been seeing a lot of recently, Paula Gamache.

title: College Conferences Ponder Expansion, and Their Extinction
description: With the 11 Football Bowl Subdivision conference commissioners gathering in Scottsdale, Ariz., on Tuesday for the annual Bowl Championship Series meetings, the prospect of significant change in the collegiate conference landscape is becoming increasingly likely.

title: When It Comes to Volcanic Ash, Airline Procedure Is Clear: Avoid
description: Last year, when the Mount Redoubt volcano blew up southwest of Anchorage, Alaska Airliness response was to ground its fleet, divert flights and wrap the engines in the parked planes in plastic.

title: Where a Greedy Wall Street Villain Would Feel Right at Home
description: Bankers who have spent two decades quoting Gordon Gekkos sayings  or what they remember Gekko saying  like Greed is good and Lunch is for wimps hope to lap up more of his insights when the sequel, Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps, comes out this fall.

title: Maternal Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond the Mining Tragedy: Safety for All Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Uproar Over Goldman Sachs
description: To the Editor:

title: Nude Art at MoMA
description: To the Editor:

title: In Effort to Limit C-Sections, Two Methods Yield Different Results on Staten Island
description: This is a tale of two hospitals.

title: Police Close Sister Clubs, M2 and Pink, in Chelsea
description: The thousands of party people who every night pack the M2 UltraLounge in Chelsea, one of the largest and busiest clubs in the city, will have to go somewhere else for a while: the Police Department shut it down on Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday with a Washington Memo article, comparing the concerns over nuclear attacks during the cold war with the fear of terrorist attacks today, reversed the identities of two of the three senators shown observing a Geiger counter demonstration in Washington in 1950. The senators, from left, were: John W. Bricker, William F. Knowland and Brien McMahon  not Brien McMahon and William F. Knowland. Numerous readers alerted The Times to the error, which was traced to the original picture in the newspapers archives. The incorrect identities also appeared in some copies on March 18, 1950.

title: Jefferson Has Yet to Pay Off for Spurs
description: DALLAS  Shortly before his playoff debut with the San Antonio Spurs, Richard Jefferson discussed his newfound serenity after a bumpy introduction to Spurs basketball. A critical factor, he said, was Coach Gregg Popovichs recent decision to allow him to play the entire first quarter.

title: Law Banning Blasphemy Is Upheld in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesias Constitutional Court ruled 8 to 1 Monday that a controversial 45-year-old law banning religious blasphemy was constitutional.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about ideas for travelers trying to cope with disruptions caused by a volcanic ash cloud from Iceland misstated the number of flights that pass over the North Atlantic in a 12-hour period. It is 900 to 1,200 flights  not 9,000 to 12,000.

title: Alan Cumming Drops Out of Spider-Man Musical
description: The actor Alan Cumming has withdrawn from the long-delayed Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark because of a scheduling conflict, a spokesman for the show confirmed on Monday night.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the rate of mail responses to the 2010 census referred incorrectly to a decades-long decline in participation by mail. It was reversed by the 2000 census, so this years could not do so.

title: Immigration Bill Reflects a Firebrands Impact
description: PHOENIX  The Arizona Senate passed one of the most stringent immigration laws in the country on Monday, marking a new level of influence for a Republican state senator who not long ago was seen by many as an eccentric firebrand.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about efforts to save Edwin H. Armstrong, the father of FM radio, from undeserved obscurity misspelled the surname of an emeritus professor at Columbia University who raised funds to get Armstrongs archives organized. He is Mischa Schwartz, not Schwarz.

title: Pressured in Senate Race, Crist May Leave G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida, facing pressure from fellow Republicans to abandon his Senate campaign, said Monday that he would not allow party leaders in Washington to push him from the race and declared that he was considering running for the seat as an independent.

title: U.S. Speaks to Syrian Envoy of Arms Worries
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Monday summoned the ranking Syrian diplomat in Washington to register concern about accusations that Syria transferred arms to the radical Islamic group Hezbollah. The Israeli government accused Syria last week of funneling long-range Scud missiles to Hezbollah militants in Lebanon, a charge the Syrian government has denied.

title: Corrections
description: The Critics Choice column on April 12, about new CDs, including Shame, Shame by Dr. Dog, misidentified the band member who sings, I do believe that theres no more tricks up my sleeve/The good old days are past, on the albums first song, Stranger. He is Toby Leaman, not Scott McMicken.

title: Corrections
description: A music review last Tuesday about a concert presented by Issue Project Room at the Old American Can Factory in Brooklyn misidentified the neighborhood in which the Factory is located. It is Gowanus, not Carroll Gardens.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit on Thursday with the Books of The Times review, about The Great Oom: The Improbable Birth of Yoga in America by Robert Love, using information from the publisher, misspelled the given name of the photographer who took the picture of Mr. Love. She is Nichol Hlinka, not Nicole.

title: Corrections
description: A jazz entry in the Listings pages on Friday about Apex, featuring Rudresh Mahanthappa and Bunky Green, at the Jazz Standard in Manhattan, misidentified Mr. Greens home base. While he lived in Chicago for nearly 30 years, he has been director of jazz studies at the University of North Florida in Jacksonville for the last two decades. Chicago is no longer his home base.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Corrections
description: A caption on March 16 for a grouping of four photographs with an article about new research on thalidomide described the bottom two photographs incorrectly. These pictures of a zebrafish and chick embryo showed the result of exposing the embryos to both thalidomide and a protein that blocked the creation of deformities. They did not show deformities induced by thalidomide and the protein. The error was pointed out by e-mail the day the article ran; this correction was delayed for research.

title: Pakistan: President Gives Up Expanded Powers
description: President Asif Ali Zardari signed into law legislation that would strip the president of expanded powers acquired under previous military governments, such as the authority to dissolve the Parliament and to appoint the head of the military. The legislation, known as the 18th amendment, gives many of the powers to the prime minister and restores Pakistan to a parliamentary democracy. Mr. Zardari retains extraordinary influence as the leader of the governing political party.

title: Wrongful-Death Lawsuit Over Rapper Is Dismissed
description: Adding perhaps a final twist to one of the longest-running and most contentious cases of celebrity justice, a federal judge in Los Angeles has dismissed an eight-year-old wrongful-death suit filed against the city by the family of the rapper Notorious B.I.G.

title: A State Holiday Tailored for Sports Fans
description: BOSTON  While most of the country went about business as usual on Monday, the third Monday in April here is an official state holiday, one that brings together a cacophonous mix of distance running, baseball and Revolutionary War role playing.

title: Alejandro Robaina, Grower for Top Cuban Cigars, Dies at 91
description: Alejandro Robaina, Cubas most revered tobacco grower, whose leaves wrap the countrys finest Habano cigars, died Saturday at his home near San Luis. He was 91.

title: Robert Pound, Physicist Whose Work Advanced Medicine, Is Dead at 90
description: Robert Pound, a Harvard physicist whose experiments provided the first laboratory confirmation of Einsteins general theory of relativity and helped pave the way for the age of magnetic resonance imaging, died on April 12 in Belmont, Mass. He was 90.

title: Mapping Out a Route to the Final in Europe
description: Iceland has no teams in the semifinals of the UEFA Champions League, the Europa League or the Womens Champions League, but all three competitions have been or will be affected by the torrent of ash and particles from the countrys Eyjafjallajokull volcano, which has disrupted travel and commerce in Europe for nearly a week. (Travel problems could also have an effect on a European futsal tournament and Thursdays scheduled Womens World Cup qualifier between the Netherlands and host Macedonia.)

title: Encouraging Start for the Ike Davis Era
description: After the first game of Ike Daviss career, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel said his new first baseman seemed unfazed, without the anxiety you sometimes see in first-time major leaguers.

title: Photographers Prepare for a Moment in May
description: Update, May 17 | It is now possible to search the Moment in Time interactive gallery by the name given in the photographers credit line (actual name, pseudonym or screen name, as the contributor chose). Youll find the search box in the upper right corner of the opening page. If you believe your picture wasnt posted, we urge you to give this a try.

title: Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert to Stay on Comedy Central Through 2012 Election
description: With Conan OBrien about to change the calculus of late-night cable programming, the Comedy Central channel has made a move to lock up its two dominant stars, Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert.

title: Rule Change Takes Aim at Loophole in Title IX
description: The Department of Education will no longer allow universities to rely solely on student surveys to prove they are meeting the requirements of the gender-equity law known as Title IX, a reversal of a Bush administration policy that had been opposed by the N.C.A.A. and womens sports advocates.

title: In M.V.P. Race, Theres No Debate
description: Voting concluded last week for the N.B.A.s postseason awards. Although The New York Times does not permit its reporters to vote, the N.B.A. reporters Howard Beck and Jonathan Abrams are making their picks in Off the Dribble. This is the most valuable player discussion.

title: Word of the Day | scaffold
description: scaffold \ska-fld also -fold\ noun and verb

title: Hoover Commercial
description: A commercial from a new campaign for Hoover aimed at consumers doing spring cleaning.

title: Fantasy Island
description: WHERE is Governors Island?

title: News Quiz | April 20, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Suit Charges Elderly Gay Partners Were Forced Apart
description: Clay M. Greenes story, as recounted in his recent lawsuit against Sonoma County, is a tale of loss, doubled and redoubled. For gay men and lesbians, the series of events outlined in the complaint hits very close to home.

title: When Wall Street Deals Resemble Casino Wagers
description: Why was Goldman Sachs, or any regulated bank, allowed to create and sell a product like the synthetic C.D.O. at the center of the governments case? What purpose does a synthetic C.D.O.  which is a bet on the value of a bundle of mortgages that the investors didnt even own  serve for the capital markets, and for society?

title: Britain Opens Its Airspace as Travel Crisis Begins to Ebb
description: LONDON  After six days of mostly closed skies, Britain abruptly lifted a ban on flights late on Tuesday as thousands of passengers stranded by a plume of volcanic ash began to make their way home after Europes worst peacetime aviation crisis.

title: Goldman Employees Rally Around Blankfein
description: The message went out from Lloyd C. Blankfein: circle the wagons.

title: For Former Thai Premier, Exile but Not Irrelevance
description: BANGKOK  Thaksin Shinawatra is angry. This is the worst political accusation I ever had, Mr. Thaksin, a former prime minister, said Tuesday in a message delivered by a spokesman  sent, as always, from an undisclosed location abroad.

title: A Finance Overhaul Fight Draws a Swarm of Lobbyists
description: Assessing the battle to overhaul the nations financial regulations recently, Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, left no doubt about the consequences if Congress cracked down on his banks immense business in derivatives, Edward Wyatt and Eric Lichtblau report in The New York Times.

title: In Harry Wilsons War, Wall St. Could Be an Asset
description: Harry Wilson, a former hedge fund manager, has a novel idea for New Yorkers. Why not put a Wall Street veteran in the state comptrollers office to oversee the $129.4 billion pension fund?

title: Generation R
description: British workers who kept their jobs during the recession but took on more responsibility for the same pay.

title: Lowenstein: Gambling With the Economy
description: From Roger Lowenstein at The New York Timess Opinion Pages:

title: Banking Bill Struggles to Get G.O.P. Support
description: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner appealed on Monday to the centrist Republican senators from Maine for their support of legislation to tighten regulation of the nations financial system but came up empty-handed, leaving Democrats and Republicans on an apparent collision course.

title: Here Come the L.B.O.s
description: Public companies have quickly become leveraged-buyout targets again. The five take private deals of at least $500 million announced since February outnumber the four completed in all of 2009. The surprise return of such acquisitions signifies a marked change from the acrimony that surrounded the last round of private equity deals, Reuters Breakingviews says.

title: SPS Commerce Eyes $26 Million I.P.O.
description: SPS Commerce is planning to raise $26 million in an initial public offering this week, The Associated Press reported.

title: A Difficult Path in Goldman Case
description: In accusing Goldman Sachs of defrauding investors, regulators are not only taking aim at a company with deep pockets and a will to fight  they are also pursuing an unusual claim that could be difficult to prove in court, legal experts said, Binyamin Appelbaum reports in The New York Times.

title: Whats Your Favorite Store? Why?
description: For Eddie Feibusch, a Life in Zippers tells the story of 86-year-old man who has owned a New York City store called ZipperStop since 1941. (Nobody makes them better, he says.) Whats your favorite store? Is it small and quirky and unique, like this one, or is it a store thats in every mall? Tell us what you like about it with as much colorful detail as you can.

title: Platinum Taps ING Portfolio Manager as President
description: A top portfolio manager at ING will be is set to become the new president of Platinum Partners, a $500 million boutique hedge fund, InvestmentNews reported.

title: Griffin to Quit Tisbury for GLG
description: GLG Partners, the London-based hedge fund, will soon be joined by Gerard Griffin, founder and manager of the former $2.75 billion fund, Tisbury Capital Management, which he is shutting down, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: DynaVox Aims to Raise $150 Million in I.P.O.
description: DynaVox, which makes special-education software and devices for people who are unable to speak, is looking to raise about $150 million in an initial public offering this week, The Associated Press reported.

title: Another $20 Million for BlackArrow
description: BlackArrow, a maker of advertising technology designed to target on-demand audiences, has landed $20 million in a third round of financing, led by NDS Group, Paid Content reported.

title: Big Brokerages Lost Market Share, Study Finds
description: The four biggest brokerage companies dominate the American wealth management space, but independent and regional firms have been catching up since they gained clients and assets after the 2008 downturn, Reuters reported.

title: Drop in Commodity Prices Pushes Indexes Down
description: Worries about the effect of government efforts to strengthen oversight of banks faded somewhat on Monday, helping Wall Street indexes to end the day mostly higher.

title: Groupon Gets $135 Million From D.S.T.
description: Groupon, the social commerce site, has landed a hefty $135 million round from Facebook backer Digital Sky Technologies.

title: Greek Bailout Unconstitutional, Report Says
description: The Greek bailout as currently proposed may run afoul of European Union rules, the Center for European Policy, a policy research organization, said Monday, as Greece struggles to refinance its mountain of debt despite European Union assurances of support.

title: Scientific Games Scores Sceptre Leisure Solutions
description: Scientific Games, the gaming equipment maker, said Monday that it had bought Sceptre Leisure Solutions assets, which include 751 server-based gaming terminals and related contracts for 3.8 million ($5.8 million), The Associated Press reported.

title: Calpers to Examine Goldman Practices
description: The chief investment officer of Californias giant pension fund said Monday he was disturbed by the allegations of wrongdoing against the investment firm Goldman Sachs, The Associated Press reported.

title: Paulson Said to Buy 13% of American Capital
description: 10:47 a.m. | Updated The billionaire investor John A. Paulson is buying about a 13 percent stake in American Capital, the business development company, as it gets a much-needed capital infusion to restructure debt, sending its shares up 14 percent, Reuters reported.

title: Turning a Corner at Citigroup?
description: How did Citigroup trounce JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America?

title: Terra Firma Said to Plan Asking More of Investors
description: Guy Hands, head of Terra Firma, has his feet on the ground  whether he wants them there or not  but hes got highflying plans.

title: Kirk Returns Goldman Cash in Example on Ethics
description: Goldman Sachss problems with the Securities and Exchange Commission are spilling over into the United States midterm elections.

title: The Real Problem? Wall Street Doesnt Get Wall Street
description: That most investors couldnt fully comprehend the the complex and exotic financial instruments Wall Street created and sold during the boom years is now considered a given.

title: F.S.A. Investigating Goldman Sachs
description: 6:03 a.m. | Updated The Financial Services Authority, Britains financial regulator, said Tuesday it had opened a formal investigation into Goldman Sachs in relation to recent accusations that the firm had defrauded investors, Julia Werdigier reports in The New York Times.

title: ABN Amros Path to Credit Derivatives, and Disaster
description: ABN Amro, one of two banks cited by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the Goldman Sachs case as buying credit derivatives that soon went sour, came to those bets late in the game, according to an in-depth article in Het Financieele Dagblad, the Dutch financial daily.

title: A Few Draft Sleepers Who Could Jolt the N.F.L.
description: Matt Waldman is a staff writer at Footballguys.com, where he writes The Weekly Gut Check and authors The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a 740-page film evaluation of 170-plus rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

title: Hong Kong Rappers to Reunite in Macao
description: Lilting Mandarin Chinese, the mainlands official language, is an ideal tongue for love songs. But the stop-start Cantonese dialect spoken in Hong Kong and neighboring Guangdong is perfect for another lyrical style  rap. One celebrated group that specializes in the latter is LMF.

title: Netflix Founder Acquires Online Education Start-Up
description: Reed Hastings, the founder and chief executive of Netflix, used the Web to make it easier for us to rent movies. Now Mr. Hastings, who is also a former high school math teacher, is using the Web for a less entertaining, more educational cause  teaching math to children.

title: A Home Librarys Educational Edge
description: Todays idea: Home libraries, and the fostering of learning they represent, correlate with extra years of educational attainment and better odds of finishing college, a study says.

title: British Regulator Opens Goldman Inquiry
description: LONDON  The Financial Services Authority, Britains financial regulator, said Tuesday that it had opened an investigation into Goldman Sachs in relation to recent accusations in the United States that the firm defrauded investors.

title: Goldman Posts $3.46 Billion 1st-Quarter Profit
description: 8:01 a.m. | Updated The New York Timess Nelson D. Schwartz provides more details about the financial results at Goldman Sachs.

title: A Tale of Many Cities
Goldmans Earnings Fail to Shift Focus From Case
description: On Wall Street, the numbers usually speak for themselves.

title: Nissan to Begin Firming Up Leaf Reservation List
description: More than 115,000 Americans have gone on the Internet and registered their interest in the 2011 Nissan Leaf battery electric car, and beginning Tuesday the company will begin trying to move those electronic tire-kickers onto the more select reservation list. The price to get on the waiting list for the first round of cars is $99, which is refundable if you buy a Leaf or opt out of the program.

title: A Killing Further Erodes Afghan Faith in Leaders
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Late on Monday night, Azizullah Yarmal, Kandahars deputy mayor, walked into a large mosque in his city and faced toward Mecca. He knelt down in unison with the others, leaning forward so his head touched the floor in ritual prayer.

title: Mayor Emanuel? He Hopes So
description: This is a title that Rahm Emanuel dreams about: mayor of Chicago.

title: A Clean, Fresh Mystery Beneath the Bridge
description: Whoever hung laundry under the Queensboro Bridge in Queens on Sunday morning: Your clothes are dry.

title: Magnetar Denies Creating Faulty C.D.O.s
description: Magnetar Capital, which until a few days ago was the biggest target of controversy over failed mortgage investments, told investors on Monday that it didnt help create collateralized debt obligations that were devised to fail in order to reap a profit.

title: What Do You Cook When Youre Sick?
description: I dont have much of an appetite. My taste buds are shot. My favorite beverage is hot water with honey.

title: Q.&A.: Recovering a Lost iBook
description: Q.

title: With Higher Passenger Revenue, Delta Narrows Loss to $256 Million
description: Delta Air Lines, the nations biggest carrier, said Tuesday that it had narrowed its loss in the first quarter, mostly because of higher passenger revenue as airline traffic begins to recover from the recession.

title: The Early Word: Regulatory Reins
description: Financial reform continues to take center stage in the Senate this week, as Democrats labor to get Republican support for their legislation that would increase regulation of the financial system.

title: A Refuge Fit for a Wall St. Villain
description: What were reading this morning:

title: Goldman Call: More on the S.E.C.s Case
description: 9:20 a.m. | Updated  The conference call is over.

title: How We Try to Get Buy-In, Part 2
description: In my last post, I discussed how we use what we call high-involvement planning at SRC and its subsidiaries to get every single associate in the company on board with our sales-and-marketing plan for the coming year.

title: Can Insurers Still Cap Physical Therapy Visits?
description: Q.

title: Survey Shows Madison Avenue Bonus Practices are Antiquated
description: A survey of bonus practices among agencies that specialize in advertising, marketing, media, public relations and related services criticizes much about the process last year  not the size of the bonuses, but rather how the money was allocated and distributed.

title: Furloughs Arent Forever: Career Advice for James Bond
description: You can call him Bond  James Bond  but dont bother calling him at the office, because Agent 007 is being suspended from duty. On Monday the producers of the James Bond film franchise, which since 1962 has yielded 22 movies adapted from or inspired by Ian Flemings novels, said they were halting work on a 23rd Bond film while they awaited the possible auction of MGM, the studio that releases the movies.

title: Europe to Ease Aviation Ban, Amid Criticism
description: A plan could begin to unravel the air travel disruption, but critics say the European Union has failed a test of leadership. Read more.

title: Lazard Hires Ex-Nassau County Executive as Adviser
description: 12:19 p.m. | Updated Lazard said on Tuesday that it had hired Thomas R. Suozzi, the former executive of Nassau County, N.Y., as a senior adviser for infrastructure assignments.

title: Energy and Banking Shares Lift Wall Street
description: Renewed confidence about an economic recovery helped a rally on Wall Street on Tuesday, with energy and banking stocks leading the way.

title: Shuttle, a Day Late, Lands Smoothly
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The space shuttle Discovery returned to Earth on Tuesday with a fiery dawn plunge across the heartland of America, closing out a complex space station resupply mission with a smooth Florida landing.

title: Timeless | 1,001 Nights
description: Sexy, mysterious, slightly dangerous: its the scent of Anjelica Huston.

title: Alcohol May Set Off Allergies
description: Allergy sufferers may have more than pollen and dust to blame for their symptoms. As explained by Anahad OConnor in Tuesdays Really? column, alcohol can also cause or worsen allergies. He writes:

description: A look at media coverage in The Times:

title: Consumers Can Snuggle With Lipton, Surf With Vaseline or Get Close Up With Lifebuoy
description: Another giant consumer marketer is turning to a company that specializes in crowdsourcing contests for advertising ideas.

title: Sampler: Breach of Google Passwords, and Cash for Old Appliances
description: Hackers Breached Googles Password System | Googledisclosed in January that Internet intruders had stolen information from its computers. Now, a person with direct knowledge of the investigation has told John Markoff of The New York Times that the companys password system was breached. The program, known as Gaia for the Greek goddess of the earth, allows users to sign in once to operate a range of services. It was attacked last December. The hackers do not appear to have stolen Gmail users passwords, and the company quickly beefed up security. But the theft leaves open the possibility that hackers can find other weaknesses, according to independent computer experts. [The New York Times]

title: Happy Christmas in July: Mad Men Returning This Summer
description: When we last saw the scheming, self-loathing advertising executives of Mad Men they had just orchestrated a Christmas coup, as Don Draper, Bertram Cooper, Roger Sterling and their newfound frenemy, Lane Pryce, bailed on their former agency to start their own shop. So whats in store for Season 4? Did Don and Betty pull the plug on their marriage? Have we seen the last of Sal Romano, and has little Sally Draper conquered her lisp? Will Pete and Trudy Campbell dance again?

title: Kimmel: Obama Had to Cancel His Trip
description: Monologue | Monday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: As you probably know, the volcano on the tiny island of Iceland has shut down air traffic. President Obama had to cancel his trip to Poland. President Obama said he hopes the volcano will stop smoking soon, and the volcano said the same thing about him.

title: Tuesday Reading: Goverment Rebates for Appliances
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: The Must Haves
description: Its all about hippie chic and flesh peddling. View interactive >>

title: Financial Tuneup: Paring Your Problem Areas
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: The First Motorcycle Heads to Auction
description: An original and unrestored 1894 Hildebrand & Wolfmller motorrad is one of the more interesting lots up for auction Sunday at the International Classic Motorcycle Show in Stafford, England.

title: F.D.A. Plans to Force a Salt Cutback
description: The Food and Drug Administration is planning a 10-year initiative to bring down sodium levels in processed foods, The Washington Post reports. Scheduled to begin later this year, the program would eventually lead to the first legal limits on the amount of salt allowed in food products, Lindsey Layton writes.

title: Abacus Casualty No. 2: IKB, of Duesseldorf
description: In the matter of the Securities and Exchange Commission v. Goldman Sachs, two European banks were burned: ABN Amro and IKB Deutsche Industriebank  well-known in Germany in 2007 as a Krisenbank, a bank in crisis.

title: Damages Watch: Freudian Twists
description: Warning: This post contains spoilers.

title: Another View: Peering Clearly at the Future
description: Mike Kwatinetz and Cameron Lester of Azure Capital Partners explain how they examine the the market dynamics of successful start-ups.

title: New Ash Cloud Adds to Uncertainty of Air Travel
description: A new cloud of volcanic ash was headed toward Britain on Tuesday, increasing the uncertainty about the prompt return of air traffic to parts of the British Isles, according to the organization that controls air traffic in the area.

title: Leno: I Made a Huge Mistake
description: Monologue | Monday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: I am so stupid. I made a huge mistake. I sent my taxes to Russia and my adopted kid to the I.R.S.

title: With Chorus Stuck in Russia, Philharmonic Amends Stravinsky Programs
description: 12:40 p.m. | Updated The rumblings of an Icelandic volcano continue to be felt as far away as New York, as the travel restrictions in Europe forced by volcanic ash have required the New York Philharmonic to make changes to its Stravinsky-themed programming that starts this week. The Philharmonic said on Tuesday that the Mariinsky Theater Chorus of St. Petersburg would be unable to perform in the Russian Stravinsky festival concerts planned for Wednesday and Thursday. As a result, the Philharmonic will offer all-orchestral programs on those nights, which will still be conducted by Valery Gergiev; Jeu de Cartes will be performed in place of Les Noces. The rest of the programs on those nights, including Symphonies of Wind Instruments and The Firebird, are not affected. The Russian Stravinsky festival runs through May 8.

title: N.F.L. Donates $1 Million for Brain Studies
description: Researchers at the Boston University School of Medicines Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy have decided that the National Football Leagues offer of support is what they had hoped: $1 million and zero strings.

title: Apple Removes Teaching App From App Store, and Educators Complain
description: Apple generally makes news by publishing new apps, not by unpublishing them. But last week, it made some educators upset when it removed an app, Scratch Viewer, from the iTunes App Store.

title: Letterman: The Only Reason
description: Monologue | Monday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: I am aware that the only reason you people are here tonight is volcanic ash. Thank God I still have my swine flu mask.

title: After Repairs, a Picasso Returns
description: To the untutored eye little is different about The Actor, the Metropolitan Museum of Arts rare Rose Period Picasso, other than that it is now safely behind plexiglass. Its virtually impossible to tell that on a January afternoon a woman taking an adult education class accidentally fell into the canvas, causing a six-inch vertical tear along the lower right-hand corner.

title: Are You the Favored Parent?
description: One of the books on my bedside table is The Favorite Child by the psychologist Ellen Weber Libby; an examination of the taboo subject. Parents are not supposed to love one child more, though every so often a survey comes along hinting that many do. Libby goes so far as to say that there are favorite children in every family with lifelong consequences for every family member.

title: At Schwab, Settlement of a Lawsuit on Securities
description: Charles Schwab, the brokerage firm, said Tuesday that it had agreed to pay $200 million to settle a federal class-action lawsuit claiming it had misled investors about the risks of a short-term bond fund.

title: A New Beginning for Spokes
description: Well, riders, Spokes is pedaling off to a new place. Were becoming a monthly feature in the Metropolitan section of the Sunday Times, and will continue to appear in City Room once a month on weekends, and we will continue to cover urban cycling news on the blog and in print as it breaks.

title: Video Supports, or Attacks, British Candidate
description: Updated | 12:54 p.m. Two British women who call themselves The Cameron Girls have released a musical tribute to David Cameron, the leader of Britains Conservative Party, that may do him more harm than good at the polls.

title: Green Thinking | A Loomstate State of Mind
description: A Barneys girl likes a sexy tee, so we wanted to give her an organic option, says the stores fashion director and eco-crusader, Julie Gilhart, of Barneys Earth Day collaboration with Loomstate. We wanted to do a blank T-shirt with a sexy fit like Alexander Wang or the Row, and we wanted to make it all organic but affordable, too. The deep-V design, which sells for $40 (for the 40th Anniversary of Earth Day), comes in your usual New Yorker hues  namely, black, white and gray  but also in the colors of the NBC peacock. Gilhart, it turns out, is also one of the headliners for Christies first ever green auction, A Bid to Save the Earth, and NBC has signed on as a media sponsor. The live auction on April 22, which benefits the N.R.D.C., the Central Park Conservancy, Oceana and Conservation International, includes such fashionable prizes as lunch with Vera Wang  plus a $10,000 shopping spree at her flagship store  and a fitting with Stella McCartney for bespoke his and hers suits. For Gilhart, creating such fashion synergy is all in a days work: We just thought, Hey were all on the same page, so lets get together.

title: Boshs Future in Toronto Is Uncertain
description: The five-time N.B.A. All-Star Chris Bosh and the Toronto Raptors seem like a good fit.

title: What Were Reading: Happy Equal Pay Day
Specter, Sestak Air Dueling Ads
description: Representative Joe Sestak, the Democrat running against Senator Arlen Specter in the May 18 Pennsylvania primary, has come out with his first TV advertisement, which is largely biographical and emphasizes his candidacy as the Democrat in the race.

title: Lebanon Rejects Israel Accusations About Scuds
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Lebanons prime minister has dismissed Israeli accusations that Syria had been providing Scud missiles to the Hezbollah militia in his country, comparing them to claims that Iraq had unconventional weapons before the American-led invasion in 2003.

title: Did Wall Street Blow It, Again?
description: Lobbying is fierce in Washington today on financial services reform, and Im not going to forecast anything.

title: Uwe Reinhardt: Reader Response
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton and a trustee or director of various health care companies and funds.

title: House Scraps Vote on D.C. Voting Rights
description: Updated The House wont vote this week  or even probably this year  on legislation that would grant the District of Columbia a voting representative in Congress, Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the House majority leader, said Tuesday.

title: Tune In for the Paperwork
description: Amid those minor distractions called playoffs  quaint little contests being staged by the N.B.A. and the N.H.L.  the N.F.L. will clear its throat and reassert its alpha maleness this week, instantly relegating everyone else (yes, you too, LeBron) to the kiddie table. And no, this has nothing to do with Commissioner Roger Goodells making an announcement in the Chinese water torture that has become the Ben Roethlisberger story. The Big League wouldnt want that to sound more important than the release of its (insert drum roll here) schedule (woo hoo!) or that behemoth draft that is about to take over the world.

title: Report Sees Corruption in State-Financed Institute
description: ALBANY  An obscure upstate theater group that receives far more state aid than any of New Yorks world-renowned cultural institutions is rife with corruption, mismanagement, nepotism and possibly illegal conduct, according to a scathing report released on Tuesday by the state inspector generals office.

title: Covering the Cost of a Hole in One
description: When a family friend recently made her first hole in one, she mentioned how she had hole-in-one insurance. For what exactly? Tradition calls for the ace golfer to treat everyone at the club to a round of drinks after the shot. Her insurance, however, didnt cover her because the shot didnt happen at her own golf club.

title: Justices Reject Ban on Videos of Animal Cruelty
description: WASHINGTON  In a major First Amendment ruling, the Supreme Court on Tuesday struck down a federal law that made it a crime to create or sell dogfight videos and other depictions of animal cruelty.

title: Danger! Danglers Everywhere!
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Danger! Danglers Everywhere!
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Savoring Moments of Laughter in the College Search
description: While sitting on a bench at his alma mater, Hank Herman reflected on his experience as a student years earlier at Penn.

title: Ousted President of Kyrgyzstan Finds Refuge in Belarus
description: MOSCOWThe deposed president of Kyrgyzstan, who was ousted following bloody antigovernment riots this month, is being harbored now in Belarus, that countrys president, Aleksandr Lukashenko, said Tuesday, though authorities in Kyrgyzstan said they would press for his extradition.

title: What Counts as a (Taxpayer-Subsidized) Human Right?
description: 12:56 p.m. | Updated

title: I, SuBo: The Susan Boyle Autobiography Is Coming
description: 12:04 p.m. | Updated  Her exterior masked a singing voice that took the Internet and the music industry by storm, so could Susan Boyle also be concealing a prose style to rival Jane Austens or Virginia Woolfs? The British publisher Transworld is willing to make that bet and has signed up Ms. Boyle, the reality television-turned-recording star, to write her autobiography, BBC News reported.

title: Buried by Paperwork, and Trying to Dig Out
description: Corporal punishment was banned in New York State public schools later than one might expect  in 1985. But there is still one vestige of that old policy that remains. Every year, each of the states 700 school districts must spend five minutes filling out a report recording whether there were any cases of physical punishment, and send it off to Albany.

title: Districts Warn of Deeper Teacher Cuts
description: School districts around the country, forced to resort to drastic money-saving measures, are warning hundreds of thousands of teachers that their jobs may be eliminated in June.

title: Espada Accused of Using Nonprofit for Personal Gain
description: ALBANY  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo filed a civil lawsuit against Senate Majority Leader Pedro Espada Jr. on Tuesday, alleging that Mr. Espada, his family and his political aides had siphoned more than $14 million from a health care nonprofit he founded to pay for meals, vacations and campaign expenses.

title: When Kids Eat What They Watch
description: In Tuesdays Personal Health column, Jane Brody writes about food advertising aimed at children.

title: Apple Will Replace Shuffle Headphones
description: If the inferior Apple headphones and remote that came with your third-generation iPod shuffle stop working, Apple will replace them with another inferior pair of headphones.

description: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

description: A time-based impedimentto career advancement, often faced by working mothers.

description: Aiming for the highbrow brilliant quadrant, the Bravo cable channel is developing a show based on New York magazines Approval Matrix, a grid that charts cultural moments based on the admittedly subjective tastes of its editors.

title: It Will Not Be Inter-Barcelona, It Will Be Inter or Barcelona
description: 4:54 p.m. |Update: Inter 3, Barcelona 1

title: Ferguson: Smoke and Ash
description: Monologue | Monday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Airports from London to Warsaw are on their sixth day of shutdown. The airports are closed because a volcano is erupting. Smoke and ash are spreading over Europe. The smoke cloud is big and thick. Meteorologists originally thought it was coming from Willie Nelsons tour bus.

title: Coyotes Are Making Hockeytown Sweat
description: Things could go from concerned to dire in a hurry in Hockeytown.

description: The Senate on Tuesday confirmed Lael Brainard to be Treasury undersecretary for international affairs as Democrats pushed to overcome Republican opposition to White House nominees.

title: Dorothy Height, Largely Unsung Giant of the Civil Rights Era, Dies at 98
description: Dorothy Height, a leader of the African-American and womens rights movements who was considered both the grande dame of the civil rights era and its unsung heroine, died on Tuesday in Washington. She was 98.

title: A Terminological Suggestion
description: Back in the Dark Ages, when kings of England were forced to pay ransom to Viking invaders, it came to be known as the Danegeld.

title: One for the Road? Bar Cars May Face a Last Call
description: The cocktails started early, before the train left Manhattan, and by 6 p.m. most of the passengers were already on the second round. Tiny vodka bottles and punched ticket stubs littered the floor. A game of dice by the bar was getting rowdy as a couple canoodled in the corner, beers in hand.

title: Schwab Settles Suit Over Mortgage Securities
description: 4:52 p.m. | Updated Charles Schwab, the brokerage firm, said Tuesday that it had agreed to pay $200 million to settle a federal class-action lawsuit claiming it had misled investors about the risks of a short-term bond fund, The New York Timess Javier C. Hernandez reports.

description: Talking Points Memo reports that Democrats are largely unprepared for the possibility that Republicans will filibuster financial reform.

description: Michael Jackson is getting the Cirque du Soleil treatment.

title: Men Like It Here, and So Do Young Optimists
description: Carrie Bradshaw may have made the city safe for cupcakes and Appletinis, but in spite of those nocturnal developments  or perhaps because of them?  men apparently love the nightlife here.

title: The Canadian Example
description: If you want to feel dispirited about Americas fiscal situation, read Tyler Cowens weekend column, which argues persuasively that the American publics mistrust of government and our cynicism about political elites will actually make spending cuts harder to achieve. If you want to feel really depressed, though, first ponder his example of how a more statist, socially cohesive country cut spending successfully, and then try to imagine the same scenario playing out in America:

title: Putting Taliban Sniper Fire in Context
description: A video and a blog post here on Monday presented a closer look at Taliban snipers, who were an unusual factor in the fighting in Marja this year. To understand the role that Taliban snipers have  or have not  played in the larger Afghan war, a look with more sweep is necessary. Afghanistan is a sprawling place, and the insurgency operates in some ways like a complicated syndicate, with varied groups and leaders in different parts of the country loosely collaborating with one another on some matters but not at all on others. So how significant have Taliban snipers been over all in the larger war? How much of a threat have they posed?

title: Media Cycle | Bikes We Like
description: Mayor Bloomberg has been so kind as to install 200 bike-lane miles in the five boroughs. Why not explore them on a snazzy new bike? The graphic designer Julie Hirschfeld was so inspired by beautiful handmade bicycles from Holland, England, Denmark, Italy and even Venice Beach, Calif., that she closed her studio to open Adeline Adeline, a design-oriented bike store.

title: A Location App That Cures Oversharing
description: The problem with popular apps that tell your friends where you are, like Foursquare, Brightkite and Latitude, is they also inform people who are not your friends where you are  or arent. A Web site called Please Rob Me republished such alerts to point out that telling a network of people where you are, tells burglars where you are not  protecting your home.

title: Ashes to Airlines: Examining the Effects of a Volcanic Eruption on Our Global Community
description: Overview | How can some local events have global consequences? What lessons can we learn from the eruption of the Eyjafjallajokull volcano in Iceland about the fragility of our interconnected world? In this lesson, students examine how the eruption has illuminated how connected we are and how fragile our global web may be. By collating stories of people, businesses and organizations affected by the eruption on a world map, students create a visual representation of the wide-reaching effects of the eruption.

title: Forgoing N.F.L. Now to Avoid Regrets Later
description: SEATTLE  It was less than a week before the N.F.L. draft, a night when some thought that Jake Locker would become the No. 1 overall pick and sign a contract worth something toward $50 million in guaranteed money.

description: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Tuesday.  Topics include a Supreme Court ruling on the First Amendment, the loss of of teaching jobs and a boom in North Dakota.

title: Wider Recount of Iraq Ballots Is Requested by Vote Leader
description: BAGHDAD  A day after an Iraqi court ordered a partial recount of ballots cast in last months national elections, the man whose political alliance won the most votes called Tuesday for a broader recount of ballots, a move that could deepen the countrys instability before the planned American military withdrawal.

description: The editor of Gizmodo.com talks about how they acquired an iPhone prototype apparently left in a bar. (Video: MSNBC)

description: The Pentagons long-running effort to buy aerial refueling tankers for the Air Force took another twist on Tuesday when a European company decided that instead of walking away, it would compete with Boeing for a contract worth at least $35 billion.

title: Twains Heavily Lawyered Last Words
description: The always quotable Mark Twain published millions of words in his 74-year lifetime, most quite delectable.

description: The end of the season couldnt have come soon enough for the Nets, who won just a dozen games to avoid setting a record for most losses ever.

description: Airports have begun to reopen in some parts of Europe after a deal to ease the flight bans, but a new ash cloud is moving south. (Video: NBC)

title: Privacy Commissioners Take Aim at Google
description: Google is being criticized for its privacy practices on the very day it is unveiling a site meant to show the extent to which governments are forcing it to hand over its users private data.

title: After Show Jumpers Disqualification, More Questions Than Answers
description: For two nights, Sapphire, a powerful liver chestnut mare, had jumped fast and clean, clearing courses with obstacles five feet tall and across. She and her rider, McLain Ward of the United States, were in the lead at the World Cup show jumping finals in Geneva.

title: Hungry Goats on Council Agenda in Oakland
description: The Oakland City Council will probably approve on Tuesday night a $250,000 payment to some goats and their human and canine herders. The financing, which is on the Councils consent calendar, is for fire-prevention services in 2008 and 2009 from a company based in Dixon called Ecosystem Concepts. The goats hope to be back chewing up the vegetation on the Oakland hills again this spring.

title: Larry David Searches Soul, Finds Nothing and Plans Return to Curb Your Enthusiasm
description: For his most recent run of Curb Your Enthusiasm Larry David performed the seemingly impossible and reunited the cast of Seinfeld. So what will he do for an encore? Recreate Andy Kaufmans notorious appearances on his short-lived 1980s comedy Fridays? Well find out in due time: on Tuesday, HBO announced that it was ordering another season of Curb Your Enthusiasm, on which Mr. David plays a dyspeptic fictionalized version of himself.

title: Young and Unemployed, Around the World
description: Around the developed world, young workers are nearly three times as likely to be unemployed as their older counterparts.

title: Travel Insurance and the Volcano
description: If you bought travel insurance before drifting Icelandic volcanic ash started disrupting international flights, you might be wondering what travel expenses it will cover. Meanwhile, if you havent bought it yet, you may be wondering whether you want insurance for next years trip and whatever natural phenomenon could strand you then (or keep you stuck at home).

title: Clegg as Bloomberg, Cont.
description: Ian Leslie compares Nick Clegg to Barack Obama:

title: Pulitzer Winners App Is Approved (Finally) by Apple
description: Mark Fiores cartoon application is now available through Apples iTunes Store.

title: Reds Pitcher Suspended for 50 Games
description: In 2008, Edinson Volquez emerged as a young star for the Cincinnati Reds, a hard-throwing right-hander who won 17 games and made the National League All-Star team. On Tuesday, Volquez was singled out in a far more unwelcome way, becoming the first major leaguer to be suspended this season for violating the sports testing program for performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Statoil Remains Committed to Oil Sands
description: If there is an oil company that environmentalists can learn to live with, if not embrace, it may be the Norwegian company Statoil.

description: As we noted earlier, Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania began broadcasting a new commercial today that attacks the military and congressional records of his opponent in the Democratic primary, Representative Joe Sestak.

title: I Want This Drug on the Market by the Time I Need It!
description: Rice Universitys Business Plan Competition held its finals over the weekend, granting $1.07 million worth of prizes in investments, cash and business services to 41 teams led by students from North America, China, England, India and Thailand. (The competition was co-sponsored by Fortune magazine.)

title: The Morning Skate: Canucks Get No Kick From Video Review
description: One of the N.H.L.s worst rules caused problems last night in the Kings 5-3 victory over the Canucks in Game 3 of their playoff series. Its Rule 78.5 (ii) which disallows a goal when the puck has been kicked using a distinct kicking motion.

title: Red Hook Lobster Moves South
description: Red Hook Lobster Pound, which has been bringing fresh lobsters south from Maine, will soon exhaust its drivers even more, offering lobster rolls in Washington, D.C., and its suburbs.

description: In "Food Jammers," one of shows on the upcoming Cooking Channel, Micah Donovan, Christopher Martin and Nobu Adilman build unusual cooking contraptions.

title: Local Food for Local Diners in Durham
description: In a part of North Carolina where tobacco was once king, the new focus is on area producers and restaurants.

title: Samurai Shopper | The Impossible Cream
description: In a perfect world, everything we eat would be clean, fresh, healthy and delicious. Every beauty product available would use extracts from the finest sources, formulated by artisans with profound botanical and pharmacological knowledge. We would never suffer the heartbreak of psoriasis, acne, or any dermatological catastrophe brought on by something ingested or applied.

title: Transit Cuts Are Protested in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA  When Danielle White boarded her bus to go to work on Tuesday morning, it was emblazoned from top to bottom with a giant, painted red X. Ms. White knew what that meant.

title: Shoved Cyclist Admits He Was Poor Driver
description: The man who was pushed from his bicycle by a police officer two years ago admitted in court on Tuesday that he had struck and killed a pedestrian with his car nearly a decade ago when he lived in North Carolina.

title: The Obamas Didnt Snub the Boy Scouts
description: Last week, we published a list of nonprofit groups that received donations from the Obama family in 2009. They gave to the Girl Scouts but not to the Boy Scouts.

title: Financial Tuneup: Walk Someone Through Your Files
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: McCains Tough Stance on Arizona Immigration Bill
description: Updated: PHOENIX  When Senator John McCain broke his silence Monday on his home states tough, new immigration enforcement bill, some immigrant advocates wished he had kept quiet and worried that he was backpedaling on what had been one of his signature bipartisan issues.

title: Travel Insurance and the Volcano
description: Some guidance on what volcano-related costs travel insurance will and wont cover from the president of the US Travel Insurance Association. Read more.

title: Making Noise
description: A London friend, his travels delayed by the cloud, noted this morning the remarkable blueness of the sky minus jet trails, and he wondered, too, if the city was less noisy. That may change on Thursday, when the funeral procession for Malcolm McLaren is expected to travel from Camden Town to Highgate Cemetery. Mr. McLarens son, Joe Corre, has asked that people create some mayhem for Malcolm at midday by playing something loud for one minute. The funeral should be a spectacle to observe. Among those planning to attend are Vivienne Westwood, who was Mr. McLarens partner during the 1970s, and her husband, Andreas Kronthaler.

title: Food Network Spinoff Announces Its Lineup
description: Allen Salkin has the details, and some background on the rationale for the new Cooking Channel. Although the Food Network has been a ratings powerhouse, even some insiders apparently feel it has become a little bland. One internal study from 2007 concluded that Food Network executives tend to see the current FN brand as friendly, approachable and middle of the road  though sometimes to a fault. Most would like to see the brand infused with more passion, excitement, drama and entertainment.

title: A Novel Argument for Girls Education
description: Greetings from South Sudan, where at the moment Im in Marial Bai, visiting the school started by a lost boy named Valentino Deng. Over the course of talking to local people about customs, I learned that people typically pay a huge bride price here to the parents of a girl whom their son marries. This is often 100 head of cattle  a huge sum in a poor area.

title: What Next, the Official Salad Dressing of Sex and the City 2?
description: It seems that not a day goes by without news of another marketing partnership for Sex and the City 2, due from the New Line Cinema unit of Warner Brothers on May 27. First, there was Skyy vodka. Last week, there was Mot & Chandon Champagne, followed by Lipton Sparkling Surprise tea.

title: Parenting an Autistic Adult
description: When we talk about autism (which we are doing often during Autism Awareness Month), we tend to talk about children and ways that their parents can help. But children grow, and the parents of autistic children become parents of autistic adults, a role that is less defined and less discussed. In a guest blog today, Laura Shumaker,  author of A Regular Guy:Growing Up With Autism, describes one weekend with her grown son Matthew, navigating the changing rules one interaction at a time.

title: Bush War Crimes Play Coming to Off Broadway
description: A new play that imagines President George W. Bush on trial for war crimes has been added to the lineup of the Americas Off Broadway festival at 59E59 Theaters in Manhattan, theater executives said on Tuesday. The festival runs from April 28 through July 3.

title: Did U.S. Miss an Early Warning on Toyota Acceleration?
description: Late in 2003, an investigator for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration concluded that the newly adopted drive-by-wire gas pedals of Toyota Camrys might be a cause of unintended acceleration.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iceland and Elsewhere
description: While the rest of the world concerns itself with the airborne residue of Icelands volcano, farmers there are trying to cope with the ground-level aftermath. As The Associated Press reported on Sunday, in Icelands Farmers Try to Save Herds From Toxic Ash, they are scrambling to protect their herds from inhaling or ingesting the ash, which can cause internal bleeding, long-term bone damage and teeth loss. On Monday, The Boston Globes Big Picture blog prepared a striking album, More From Eyjafjallajokull.

title: Goldman Fails to Shift Focus From Fraud Case
description: On Wall Street, the numbers usually speak for themselves. But for Goldman Sachs, even a blockbuster earnings report on Tuesday failed to shift attention away from the fraud accusations leveled last week by the Securities and Exchange Commission, Nelson D. Schwartz of The New York Times reports.

title: Your Jokes: Dont Trust Washington
description: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: Goldman Inquiry Comes at Key Time for British Regulator
description: LONDON  Hector Sants, the chief of Britains financial regulator, pledged last year to reverse his agencys reputation as a toothless tiger. He wanted to spread fear across the financial services industry by stepping up the aggressiveness of its inquiries and by pursuing more prominent fraud cases.

title: Eco Chic | Wasara Paper Bowls
description: Believe it or not, theres a line of disposable tableware that you wont want to throw away, let alone get wet. The Japanese company Wasara has a line of sculptural plates, bowls and cups made from a thin composite of bamboo, reed and sugarcane waste that looks and feels like something youd find at Ted Muehling.

title: Somali Pirates Hijack Vessels 1,200 Miles Offshore
description: A band of Somali pirates hijacked three Thai fishing boats and captured 77 sailors in an attack more than 1,200 miles offshore in the Indian Ocean, the European Union naval force said on Tuesday. The attack on Sunday was closer to India than Somalia, said John Harbour, a European Union spokesman, and was the furthest east we are aware of since we started operations in December 2008. The three fishing boats are now heading toward a notorious pirate den on the Somali shore. Somali pirates have made millions of dollars in recent years hijacking vessels and holding them ransom despite increased naval patrols. JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

title: Jets Sign Jason Taylor to Improve Pass Rush
description: Nearly three weeks after April Fools Day, Jason Taylor decided Tuesday to accept a two-year contract with the Jets. In related news, the Hatfields dealt for a McCoy.

title: War of Words Regarding the Financial Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  Hoping to seize on populist fury on a day when Goldman Sachs reported blockbuster earnings, Senate Democrats on Tuesday sought to portray Republicans as siding with wealthy Wall Street interests in opposing tougher financial regulations.

title: Testing the iPads Trip-Worthiness
description: IF you plan on vacationing in the near future, you should be ready to share an airplane ride with at least a few preening iPad owners. Whether you should succumb to gadget envy or not depends on just what type of traveler you are.

title: Son of Michael Douglas Is Sentenced
description: Cameron Douglas, the 31-year-old son of the actor Michael Douglas, was sentenced to five years in prison on drug-related charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Tuesday.
