description: The International Monetary Fund has proposed two new taxes to create a reserve for bank bailouts of the future, the BBC reported.

title: Search Continues After Oil Rig Blast
description: NEW ORLEANS  An explosion on an oil drilling rig off the coast of southeast Louisiana left at least 3 people critically injured and 11 others missing as of Wednesday night.

title: Obama and the Birthers in the Latest Poll
description: President Obama was born in Hawaii on Aug. 4, 1961. A scanned image of his birth certificate released during the 2008 presidential campaign says he was, and Hawaiis health director and its registrar of vital statistics have confirmed it.

title: Beyond Earth Day
Presidential Candidate Is Arrested in Rwanda
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Rwandan authorities arrested a top opposition politician on Wednesday and charged her with genocide ideology  a contentious crime that many critics say has been used to stifle dissent  and with cooperating with a notorious rebel group.

title: Change Is in the Air at B.C.S. Meetings
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  The fountains at the Royal Palms Resort trickled softly under the desert sun on Tuesday, providing a peaceful backdrop for what could be one of college sports most chaotic periods.

title: G.M. Repays U.S. Loan, While Chrysler Posts Improved Quarterly Results
description: DETROIT  General Motors repaid a government loan and Chrysler posted improved quarterly results on Wednesday  proof, the companies said, that they were turning their operations around.

title: Panasonic Cameras Most Reliable, Survey Finds
description: If youre looking for the most reliable point-and-shoot digital camera, you might do well to focus on a Panasonic. Thats the conclusion from a study of 60,000 warranties on cameras conducted by SquareTrade, a warranty provider for tech products.

title: EMCs Profit Rises as Executive Sees Rosy Outlook for Corporate Spending
description: An executive at EMC, the data storage giant, has offered some of the most positive language to date about the state of corporate spending on technology, saying customers were at last planning for the future rather than just battening down the hatches. And he uttered one of the most beloved phrases in the technology industry vocabulary  new innovative projects.

title: Once More, With Conviction: Oz Stars Are Coming to Primary Stages
description: Its not an official Oz reunion, but short of the cast members of that HBO prison drama getting thrown into a maximum-security penitentiary together, its as close as were likely to get. Primary Stages said that it would end its season with two stage readings of Godfather IV, an original work by Tom Fontana, the Oz creator, and starring Christopher Meloni, Lee Tergesen and Dean Winters, who all appeared on that eye-gougingly violent series. Godfather IV is not a sequel to Francis Ford Coppolas mafia movies, but a piece in which the Oz actors discuss the plausibility of a key scene in The Godfather, and Mr. Tergesen and Mr. Winters resolve to put a horses head in Mr. Melonis bed.

title: Is 15 a Better Rent-Ratio Cutoff?
description: Dean Baker, one of those economists who saw the housing bubble for what it was in real time, argues that Im wrong to use 20 as a rule of thumb for the rent ratio. He writes:

title: NATO Apologizes for Killing Unarmed Afghans in Car
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO apologized Wednesday for shooting to death four unarmed Afghan civilians this week in Khost Province and acknowledged that it had wrongly described two of the victims as known insurgents.

title: No Nail Clipping on the Platform, Please
description: First the Working Families Party riffed on them in a campaign against transit service cuts and fare increases last month. Now its an artist, frustrated with the behavior of some riders, who has taken the subways service change posters as inspiration, creating a series of 10 versions of his own that urge riders to  please!  show some proper etiquette on the trains.

title: Quote Unquote | The Under Maker
description: Erin Wasson tells Teen Vogue about her dream job: styling Britney Spears. Brit, we really think you should take her up on the offer.

title: Obama Promises No Litmus Test for Supreme Court Nominee
description: President Obama said on Wednesday that he has no abortion litmus test as he selects a replacement for Justice John Paul Stevens, adding that he wants to make sure any nominee he picks respects individual rights, including womens rights.

title: Piping Up
description: News Parody | From The Onion:

title: Drafted Late, but Made It Big
description: Andy Barall, who writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down, looks back at some late-round picks who made it to the Pro Football Hall of Fame. He wrote: This is by all means not an all-inclusive list. At least these guys got drafted. There are many other Hall of Famers who werent drafted at all. But thats another story for another time.

title: Greetings From Heathrow
description: About this letter from abroad: I know, it looks like Gmail, but in fact, Im typing on onionskin pages from a finger-pecked 1925 Smith Corona. Also Im smoking, without break or guilt. And wearing a fedora without irony.

title: Student Crossword | Earth Day
description: Celebrate the 40th anniversary of Earth Day with our new student crossword, and then find the answers here.

title: Agricultural Panel Starts Markup of Derivatives Bill
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee is taking the lead today on a piece of the legislation intended to overhaul financial industry regulations, starting with a markup on the derivatives bill that will probably become part of the overall Senate bill. The full bill could be brought to the Senate floor by the end of the week or by Monday.

title: Residents Grapple With Oaklands Violent Reputation
description: I walked south on Telegraph Avenue in Oakland at 4 p.m. on Tuesday. It was in the same place at about the same time on Friday  maybe an hour earlier  that a father and son had gotten out of their car nearby.

title: Quiet Sites Where Battles Once Raged
description: Photographing the battlefield of Gallipoli a few years ago  a place still carved by trenches and pocked by spent shells and human bones  the artist Nebojsa Seric Shoba found himself transported from Turkey to Bosnia, from World War I to the siege of Sarajevo, his hometown.

title: Elsewhere: Tech Words
description: Writing for Fox News, John Brandon enumerated 25 New Tech Words You Need to Know.

title: JetBlue and Hilton Partner on Points
description: JetBlue has teamed up with Hilton so that members of the airlines loyalty program can earn additional points when staying at any of Hiltons 3,500 hotels worldwide.

title: A C.E.O. Beauty Contest
description: Chief executives look more competent than the general populace, but that doesnt necessarily mean they are, a new study of facial features finds. From the abstract:

title: Deutsche Settles Over Firings in Espionage Case
description: Deutsche Bank said Wednesday that it had settled two lawsuits brought against it by former executives fired after they were tied to a corporate espionage case.

title: 2 Chinese Lawyers Are Facing Disbarment for Defending Falun Gong
description: BEIJING  Two Chinese lawyers who represented a follower of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement could have their licenses permanently revoked in an administrative hearing on Thursday. The action against the lawyers is the latest move in an increasingly harsh government crackdown on lawyers who take on human rights cases.

title: Ukraine Woos Russia With Lease Deal
description: MOSCOW  Swiftly carrying out his pledge to improve strained ties with neighboring Russia, the new Ukrainian president agreed to a landmark deal on Wednesday to extend the lease on a Russian naval base on Ukrainian territory.

title: Answers to Questions About Travel Insurance and the Volcano
description: In the Tuesday Bucks post Travel Insurance and the Volcano, Jim Grace, the president of the US Travel Insurance Association and president of InsureMyTrip.com, a Web site that aggregates travel insurance offers, provided some guidance on what volcano-related costs travel insurance will and wont cover depending on when you purchased it.

title: Its News to the Mayor, and From a Blog
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he only learned of President Obamas coming visit to New York City when he saw it on the blogs.

title: Looking to Bryant for Lessons
description: In sports time, it is as if whole eras have passed, but in geological time it was only about two minutes ago that Kobe Bryant was playing the role currently occupied by Ben Roethlisberger: sexual assault allegations having transformed him from star to reviled lout.

title: Red Wings Outlook Improves With Howard Shutout
description: Cancel the four-alarm red alert, for now, on the state of Detroit Red Wings.

title: Grassley Joins Democrats in Approving Derivatives Bill
description: Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa broke ranks with his fellow Republicans on Wednesday and voted in favor of a bill to tighten regulation of derivatives.

title: Lead Poisoning, a Stubborn Nemesis
description: Nothing prepared Veronica Rodriguez for the call she got from a New York City health official last October.

title: Loss Widens at American Airlines
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, said on Wednesday that it lost $505 million in the first quarter because of rising fuel costs and a sluggish economy.

title: Should You Join a Business Group?
description: Running a small business requires some level of expertise in many areas. There are management issues, marketing questions and financial realities. Trying to master all areas, or at least sort them all out, can be frustrating, exhausting and scary. Entrepreneurship differs from many other professions in that by definition you are on your own: no colleagues back at the office, no mentor or boss to show you the way. In addition, it is not just your paycheck that is at risk; it can be everything you have, not to mention money put up by friends and family.

title: The Pontiff and the Press
description: Heres John Allen, analyzing the Vaticans approach to the abuse firestorm in the wake of Benedicts private meeting with sex abuse victims on his trip to Malta:

title: University of California Trying Again on Museum Project
description: The University of California, Berkeley,decided last fall to scrap its ambitious designs for a new Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive, saying that it had been unable to raise enough money. Now it isconsidering proposals from 10 architectural firms for the conversion of an old printing plant in downtown Berkeley to become the museums new home, The San Francisco Chronicle reported. The university declined to identify the competitors for the job but the newspaper reported that three firms had confirmed that they were invited to take part: Bernard Tschumi Architects of New York, Tod Williams Billie Tsien Architects of New York and Will Bruder + Partners of Phoenix.

title: An Official Mourning in China for Quake Victims
description: BEIJING  In an elaborately orchestrated outpouring of grief, China on Wednesday mourned the victims of the earthquake in western Qinghai Province by printing monochromatic newspapers, shutting karaoke parlors and canceling sporting events across the country.

title: When the Meal Wont Go Down
description: When an older person regularly gags or chokes in the middle of a meal, its obvious that theres a problem. But what of the more subtle symptoms of trouble while eating?

title: The New C-Note
description: The $100 bill has gotten a makeover.

title: Sarkozy Wants Ban of Full Veils
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France told his cabinet on Wednesday that he would put forward a bill in May to ban the wearing of the full veil in public places in France, despite a warning from senior legal authorities that the bill may be unconstitutional.

title: Answers About Transgender Issues
description: Following is the first set of responses from Dr. Laura Erickson-Schroth, who is working on Trans Bodies, Trans Selves, a resource guide for transgender and other gender-variant people, covering health, legal issues, cultural and social questions, history and theory.

title: Vain Glorious | LOrals New Eco-Friendly Line
description: Who: LOral Professionnel

title: Chamberlain Settling Back Into Relief Role
description: All is well in Yankeeland, as Tyler Kepner detailed on Sunday, and the team continued its winning ways Tuesday night with a 7-3 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

title: Tribeca Film Festival: Where to Begin
description: From aggressive teenage journalists to expressive aged entertainers, from river surfers to falcon smugglers, this years Tribeca Film Festival has considerable variety to offer. In this video, Stephen Holden gives his assessment of some notable films. He has more to say here.

title: Why You Drink
description: Sight Gag | From GraphJam.com, found at The Daily Beast:

title: Bill on Finance Wins Approval of Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans and Democrats predicted on Wednesday that Congress would soon pass a far-reaching overhaul of the nations financial regulatory system, indicating a potentially swift resolution of the latest partisan firefight on Capitol Hill.

title: Lost Watch: Hes With Locke
description: This post contains spoilers.

title: Japan Stops Beef Exports in Possible Foot-and-Mouth Outbreak
description: The Associated Press reports that Japan suspended beef exports on Tuesday after three of 16 beef cattle at a farm in Miyazaki prefecture were found to have symptoms of foot-and-mouth disease earlier this month. The ban will last at least three months, the agriculture minister, Hirotaka Akamatsu, told The A.P.

title: Winfreys Channel Gets First Major Advertiser
description: Oprah Winfreys forthcoming cable channel has completed its first major advertiser deal. The consumer goods company Procter & Gamble is on board for what it calls a multi-year media deal with OWN, which is short for The Oprah Winfrey Network.

title: Income Falls, but Wells Fargo Sees Improvement
description: Wells Fargo said Wednesday that its first-quarter net income declined 16 percent, to $2.54 billion, as the bank dealt with continuing losses on consumer loans. However, the bank said it had turned the corner with its credit problems, The Associated Press reports. Income in the quarter a year earlier was $3.04 billion.

title: Muslim Group Says It Is Warning, Not Threatening, South Park Creators
description: 6:32 p.m. | Updated

title: How to Know Youre Headed to the Playoff Dustbin
description: While the Rangers didnt make the playoffs this year, theres some consolation on the way: Eight teams will be joining them on the sidelines over the next few days.

title: Mourning the Death of a Pet
description: Years ago, I had an orange tabby cat named Dave who was more person than pet. Sometimes when my husband and I were visiting our neighbors in Houston, we would hear a knock at the door. Its probably Dave, our friends would say, and sure enough, there he was on the step, waiting to be invited in with the rest of us.

title: Theodore Roosevelt, Empire Builder
description: These are books about men who wanted a war. Or at least the next best thing: a state of intimidation, fear, anxiety and excitement, which would produce the fruits of war, foremost among them order and peace. But what these men got was not always what they yearned for. And the price was not what they were ready  or even able  to pay.

title: TimesCast | April 21, 2010
description: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Wednesday.  Topics include plans to prevent homelessness, Politico's Washington coverage, the selection of a Supreme Court justice and more.

title: Why Take Our Children to Work?
description: Tomorrow is the fourth Thursday in April, which has always been a chameleon of a day, changing hue with the times. It started as Take Our Daughters to Work Day in 1993 and then officially became Take Our Daughters and Sons to Work Day in 2003.

title: Bieber Still on Top
description: Justin Biebers My World 2.0 (Island) is the top album in the United States for the second week in a row, with 92,000 sales, Nielsen SoundScan reported, and the Brooklyn band MGMT enters the chart this week in second place, with 66,000 sales of its second album, Congratulations (Columbia). Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville) is No. 3 with 65,000, Ushers Raymond v Raymond (LaFace) is in fourth place, with 64,000 sales, and the New York hard-rock band Coheed and Cambria opened at No. 5 with Year of the Black Rainbow (Columbia), which sold 51,000.

title: Livery Policy Fails Disabled Riders, Report Says
description: The vast majority of the citys livery and black cars cannot accommodate passengers who use wheelchairs, and those who do charge egregiously high rates, in violation of city rules, according to a report released Wednesday by Assemblyman Micah Z. Kellner of Manhattan.

title: A Bit of Good News From Harley-Davidson
description: Harley-Davidson, after two years of dismal sales and falling earnings, surprised Wall Street on Tuesday by posting a profit in the first quarter. The news sent Harleys stock price surging almost 10 percent immediately after the announcement.

title: MSNBC Pulls the Plug on Donny Deutschs Weeklong Anchoring Stint
description: A weeklong anchoring stint on MSNBC by Donny Deutsch ended abruptly on Wednesday, and four people briefed on the decision said the cancellation stemmed from an unflattering mention of that channels No. 1 anchor, Keith Olbermann, a day earlier.

title: Morgan Stanley Aims to Maintain Earnings Growth
description: Trading took center stage during Morgan Stanleys conference call to discuss its first-quarter earnings on Wednesday as analysts peppered senior management with questions concerning the firms ability to maintain its strong earnings growth in that division going forward.

title: Roethlisberger Suspended for 6 Games
description: In the waning moments of Super Bowl XLIII, Ben Roethlisberger lofted a pass to Santonio Holmes in the back of the end zone that won the sixth Super Bowl championship in Pittsburgh Steelers history.

title: A New PETA Ad Will Feature the Late Bea Arthur
description: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals is known for its attention-getting advertising stunts on behalf of furthering its cause. On Thursday, PETA leaders plan to run an ad that is novel even for them.

title: A Mothers Loss, a Daughters Story
description: ANDREW AVRIN sits on a beige couch in a nondescript room, a fruit still-life partly visible on the wall behind him, twisting his fingers while, off-camera, an unseen interviewer prompts him to talk about his sister, Melissa, who died last year at the age of 19 after a long battle with bulimia.

title: Trend in the Making? Woods Again Commits Early
description: For the third time in as many tournaments, Tiger Woods gave officials early notification of his commitment to play an upcoming event. Just as he did before the Masters and next weeks PGA Tour event, the Quail Hollow Championship, Woods committed early to The Players Championship, set for May 6-9 at TPC Sawgrass.

title: Senate Panel Approves Tougher Derivatives Rules
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee on Wednesday approved legislation to tighten regulation of derivatives trading, with a single Republican, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, joining Democrats in supporting the measure, The New York Timess Edward Wyatt and David M. Herszenhorn report from Washington. The vote was 13 to 8.

title: Brad DeLong Defends Robert Rubin
description: Brad DeLong, the liberal economist and blogger, argues today that Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury Secretary, has gotten a bad rap on derivatives regulation:

title: Late-Game Heroes Have Lifted Bayern Munich and Lyon
description: 4:29 p.m. |Final: Bayern Munich 1, Lyon 0

title: Boston Fans Discover Strange Feeling: Peace
description: Boston

title: Artist Uses the Subway, as Subject and Canvas
description: Hes the Rembrandt of 72nd Street! a yellow cab driver yelled at a man on the sidewalk sketching the 72nd Street subway station last Wednesday on the Upper West Side.

title: Decrying U.S., Iran Begins War Games
description: Irans supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, declared that President Obamas new nuclear strategy amounted to atomic threats against Iranian people, and Iranian state television reported Thursday that the military had begun a large exercise in the Persian Gulf, where the United States and Israel have both increased their presence in recent months.

title: Google Acquires Another Piece of the Tablet Puzzle
description: This week, Google took another step toward bringing its popular Web tools onto a myriad of nontraditional computing devices like tablet computers. It acquired a mysterious Silicon Valley start-up called Agnilux. PEHub first reported the acquisition on Tuesday; a price was notdisclosed.

title: A Rotisserie Baseball Re-Do
description: If you watched Silly Little Game, a documentary about the origins of rotisserie baseball, on ESPN on Tuesday night after reading The New York Times review, you may have noticed that one scene did not play out the way it was described. Discussing an imagined scene in which an actor portraying Neil Allen, a significant figure in the history of the original rotisserie baseball league, was shown downing a tall glass of beer, I wrote, Presumably everyone involved knew that Mr. Allens baseball career was ruined by alcoholism, but thought that the joke was worth it anyway.

title: Microsoft and W.N.B.A. Click With a Uniform
description: Microsoft is the latest company to buy space on the front of a W.N.B.A. jersey.

title: Germanys Secrets for a Steadier Job Market
description: The German labor market has been surprisingly bulletproof during the economic downturn, outperforming the United States and already beginning to tick downward, falling to 8.5 percent in March from 8.7 percent a year earlier.

title: Geological Society Presses on Climate Threat
description: The Geological Society of America, after some tussling last year, has updated its official statement on global climate change, strongly aligning with statements by the worlds scientific academies, the American Geophysical Union, and a letter to Congress from 18 American scientific associations last year. Heres the central conclusion from the geology group:

title: Karl Shares Cancer Fight Through Blog
description: Denver Nuggets Coach George Karl hasnt kept his battle with throat and neck cancer behind closed doors.

title: Elephant Show Will Go On
description: Three weekend performances of Elephant at the New Victory Theater are now back on, according to a statement from the theater.

title: Future Volcano Eruptions Remain a Threat
description: Airlines around the world began to confront a huge backlog of passengers on Wednesday, but threat remains for future volcano eruptions. (Video: NBC)

title: Ten Ways to Go Green and Mark Earth Day
description: April 22, 2010 is the 40th annual Earth Day celebration. Whether you teach about global warming and climate change or are just looking for a way to commemorate this anniversary with your students or children, here are 10 starting points, which well update as more Times resources become available.

title: Travel Deals: Up to 50% Off Hotels in Australia and Region
description: With cooler weather approaching in the Southern Hemisphere, IHG  which operates seven hotel brands including InterContinental, Crowne Plaza and Holiday Inn Hotels and Resorts  is offering up to 50 percent off stays throughout Australia, New Zealand, Fiji, French Polynesia and Papua New Guinea. Additionally, children under 12 stay free at Holiday Inn Hotels.

title: Dead? Again?
description: BAGHDAD The death of the two top leaders of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia one of whom was supposedly fictional did little to illuminate the secrets of their shadowy lives and the state of the insurgency in Iraq today.

title: Looking Back on the Bush Years
description: David Brooks: Recently Ive been thinking about the Bush family. I had dinner last night with a fellow who worked for George H.W. Bush and then I went home and watched two episodes of the fabulous HBO series, The Pacific. It got me thinking of what a really outstanding person H.W. is, whatever one thinks of his politics and so on.

title: Federal Plans to Prevent Homelessness
description: Peter S. Goodman discusses the Obama administration's new initiative to try to prevent homelessness before it starts.

title: Maintenance Therapy for Multiple Myeloma
description: Multiple myeloma, a cancer of the plasma cells of the bone marrow, causes no symptoms in some patients, while others suffer problems that may require aggressive treatment. Here, Dr. Philip Greipp, director of the Cancer Center Hematologic Malignancies Program at the Mayo Clinic, responds to one readers question about follow-up care for a patient who has had a stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Sigourney Weaver says James Cameron didnt win the Oscar because he didnt have breasts and that its fashionable to give the Oscar to a small movie nobody saw. Putting the rip back into Ripley.

title: U.S. Volcano Monitors Laugh Last
description: Last year, before everyone struggled to learn how to pronounce Eyjafjallajokull, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana told the nation that President Obamas economic stimulus package was larded with wasteful spending. He chuckled at the absurdity of it all as he listed his examples. Finally the governor arrived at this punch line:  and $140 million for something called volcano monitoring. Instead of monitoring volcanoes, what Congress should be monitoring is the eruption of spending in Washington, D.C.

title: Now Booking | Boutique Hotels in Joshua Tree
description: U2 and Lady Gaga videos notwithstanding, the lure of lonesome Joshua Tree has always been the desolation. Theres nothing like 25,000 square miles of Mojave wasteland to put things in perspective. But in those arid badlands of Southern California, accommodations  when you can find them  tend to be either motel-dismal or perfunctorily kitschy. Except for these two recent discoveries. Sacred Sands is a wisp of high-desert chic just one mile from the west entrance to Joshua Tree National Park. Here, at the base of a rocky ridge, Steve Pratt and Scott Cutler have fashioned a luxe eco-friendly retreat thats unapologetically open to the barrens. It has just two suites ($269 and $299 a night)  though two more are in the works  both with wraparound terraces. Each has an outdoor hot tub spiked with Dead Sea salts and tea tree oil along with a meditation platform, essentially a full-size bed where guests can sleep al fresco. And many do: For city dwellers, it might be a little frightening at first, Cutler says, but most people who doze off under the stars say its the best sleep theyve ever had. In the morning, fresh chilaquiles with homemade mole sauce, oven-baked pancakes and yam hash give incentive to rise.

title: U.S. Offers a Hand to Those on Evictions Edge
description: SAN MATEO, Calif.  Two years into a merciless downward spiral, Antonio Moore was threatened with living on the street.

title: Cattle Call: The Draft Through the Eyes of a Former Player
description: Nate Jackson was a tight end and wide receiver with the Denver Broncos from 2003-08.

title: BlogTalk: Friends With (Corporate) Benefits
description: In the debate about how to protect Main Street from the transgressions of Wall Street, members of both political parties have been trying to make the other one look like theyre kowtowing to corporate interests. Senator Mitch McConnell has said, for example, that the new financial regulations under consideration in the Senate will lead to endless taxpayer bailouts of Wall Street banks. (PolitiFact, by the way, rated that statement as false.)

title: Eliminating Lead Poisoning
description: Lead poisoning among children has decreased so sharply over the last decades that some view the problem as a thing of the past.  But federal health officials say that eradication may be years away.

title: President of Spirit Airlines Defends Fee for Carry-On Bags
description: The president of Spirit Airlines, Ben Baldanza, says no significant fallout has ensued from his new charge for carry-on bags, and he defended his business model in a televised interview.

title: Genzyme Expects a Fine of $175 Million
description: Genzyme, the beleaguered biotechnology company, said on Wednesday that it expected to be fined at least $175 million by the Food and Drug Administration because of manufacturing problems that have caused severe shortages of two of its best-selling drugs.

title: Gifted Letters Are in the Mail
description: Thousands of city parents have been anxiously checking their mailboxes since Monday to see whether their four- and five-year-olds have qualified for the citys sought-after gifted and talented programs.

title: Critics Challenge Safety of New Reactor Design
description: As Southern Company and its partners, armed with federal loan guarantees of $8.3 billion, move toward construction of two new reactors at a site near Augusta, Ga., opponents are taking aim at the design details.

title: Aid for Sanitation and Water Projects Lags
description: The world appears headed toward meeting, or even exceeding, the Millennium Development Goals target for safe drinking water, according to a recent United Nations report. But perhaps because of that success, the portion of foreign aid focused on water and sanitation has dropped over the past decade, according to a separate analysis  the United Nations Global Annual Assessment of Sanitation and Drinking Water.

title: Financial Tuneup: How to Find a Financial Planner
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: A California Museum Celebrating French Art Deco Cars
Timeline: 70 Years of Environmental Change
description: Environmental milestones over 13 presidential administrations.

title: Trooper Can No Longer Work for Roethlisberger
description: Edward Joyner, the Pennsylvania trooper who accompanied Ben Roethlisberger on the night of his alleged sexual assault in Georgia, can no longer work part-time for the N.F.L. quarterback because he was judged to have violated the terms of a supplementary employment application.

title: Daniel Goldstein, Last Atlantic Yards Holdout, Leaves for $3 Million
description: Updated, 4:53 p.m. | The last man standing in front of the Atlantic Yards bulldozer has stepped aside.

title: Underwater Camera Field Test
description: David Pogue looks at underwater cameras from Panasonic and Sony.

title: Do Overs | Recycled Chic, Paris-Style
description: Even if the idea of recycling is trs a la mode, it doesnt mean recycled fashion always hits the mark. But a number of Paris designers are taking old pieces and reworking them into new ones, earning points for being both eco- and fashion-friendly.

title: Green: A New Name, a Broader Mission
description: For the last 18 months, the Green Inc. blog has plumbed the fraught and increasingly fertile intersection of business and the environment. On topics as diverse as the debate over compact-fluorescent light bulbs, the carbon footprint of baby-making and the steady rise of the renewable energy industry, our team of contributors has kept you up to date on the high-stakes pursuit of a greener globe, as our mission statement put it.

title: Beverly Sills Award Winner Is Named
description: Susanna Phillips, a 28-year-old soprano from Huntsville, Ala., was named the winner of the Beverly Sills Artist Award, the Metropolitan Opera said on Wednesday. The award, for singers age 25 to 40 who have appeared in featured solo roles at the Met, has been given annually since 2006 and comes with a prize of $50,000. Its previous winners include the baritone Nathan Gunn, the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato, the tenor Matthew Polenzani and the bass John Relyea. Ms. Phillips made her Met debut last season in the role of Musetta in La Bohme; she has also sung Pamina in Die Zauberflte and will reprise the role in the Mets 2010-2011 season. The award was to be officially presented to Ms. Phillips at the Met by Dr. Agnes Varis, a managing director on the Met board who with her husband, Karl Leichtman, endowed the award, and Muffy Greenough, Ms. Sillss daughter.

title: Financial Debate Renews Scrutiny on Banks Size
description: A group of Senate Democrats introduced a bill on Wednesday that would require the nations three largest banks to shrink, in an effort to eliminate the problem of financial institutions being seen as too big to fail.

title: What Were Reading: New $100 Bill
Indian Tribe Wins Fight to Limit Research of Its DNA
description: SUPAI, Ariz.  Seven years ago, the Havasupai Indians, who live amid the turquoise waterfalls and red cliffs miles deep in the Grand Canyon, issued a banishment order to keep Arizona State University employees from setting foot on their reservation  an ancient punishment for what they regarded as a genetic-era betrayal.

title: Plane Carrying Tesla Officials Took Off at Own Risk, Tapes Show
description: The pilot in command of the plane that crashed and killed three Tesla Motors officials in February was told twice that limited visibility meant his takeoff from the Palo Alto Airport in California was at your own risk, according to a recording released by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Casting a Wider Net in the Galleon Insider Case
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Disney Names a New Marketing Chief
description: A five-month search for a marketing chief at Walt Disney Studios ended on Wednesday with the appointment of a Hollywood outsider: MT Carney, a Scottish-born and Sorbonne-educated communications strategist whose experience comes mostly from working with companies like Coca-Cola, Kraft, Google and American Express.

title: Pictures of the Day: Qinghai and Elsewhere
description: In an elaborately orchestrated outpouring of grief, China mourned the victims of the earthquake in western Qinghai Province by printing monochromatic newspapers, shuttering karaoke parlors and canceling sporting events across the country, Andrew Jacobs reports in An Official Mourning in China for Quake Victims.

title: The Flash, the Pan, the Complications
description: Its only their second time meeting, but the mismatched couple, Bruce (Dusty Brown) and Sue (DeAnna Lenhart), are already having the Talk. He looks nervous. She appears in pain. Who hasnt been there?

title: The $100 Bill Gets a Makeover
description: The $100 bill has gotten a new look intended to thwart counterfeiters.

title: Joe Allen: Where Flops Are Family
description: Joe Allen is known as a Broadway hot spot for hobnobbing. But its also a place where Broadways fattest flops can flower.

title: Roasted Pork With Red-Chili Corn Bread, Smoked-Bacon Broth and Fava Beans
description: For the corn bread:1 cup yellow cornmeal

title: Fresh Direction: A Farm-to-Table Restaurant
description: On a March morning at Coon Rock Farm  55 acres of just about everything you can grow and raise  in Hillsborough, N.C., Jamie DeMent is showing me a fallen tree thats being milled into tabletops for the farms biggest project to date: Eno Restaurant and Market.

title: Mets Put Igarashi on Disabled List
description: Within days of being proclaimed the Mets new eighth-inning set-up man, Ryota Igarashi has landed on the 15-day disabled list with what the team labeled a moderate injury to his left hamstring.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Distracted Driving and Green Gadgets
description: In this weeks episode of the Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein chats with Matt Richtel, the Times technology reporter who received a Pulitzer Prize, along with the Times staff, for his series about distracted driving. Despite efforts to curb talking and texting behind the wheel, use of tech gadgets in vehicles is still on the rise. Mr. Richtel discusses what he calls a disconnect between this behavior and its consequences, and how authorities are trying to address the problem.

title: When to Tell the Boss Youre Pregnant
description: When I was pregnant with my first child, I kept it a secret from everyone at work for the first three months. That was logistically simple  I was working in the Houston bureau of The Times at the time, and my editors and colleagues were almost all in New York. But it was physically and emotionally exhausting. I was spending as much energy pretending I wasnt pregnant as I was actually being pregnant, which adds up to an awful lot of energy.

title: British Candidate Egged by Teen Hoodie
description: Four years ago, after he became the leader of Britains Conservative party and set about rebranding it, David Cameron said his aim was to remake it in his image, as a modern, compassionate conservative.

title: Bloomberg Signs Willow Bay to Cover Milken Conference
description: Bloomberg Television has signed Willow Bay, the former CNN business anchor, as a special correspondent for next weeks Milken Institute Global Conference.

title: Quattrones Boutique Hires Ex-Colleague Boutros
description: Frank Quattrone has kept busy at his new boutique investment bank  busy enough, apparently, that its expanding.

title: Fluttering Along the Runway
description: ONE of the fondest childhood memories of Guillermo de Zamacona, a budding fashion photographer, was a visit to the mountains northwest of Mexico City, where millions of monarch butterflies migrate in the winter so that the boughs of firs appear to be dripping with flecks of orange.

title: A Touch-Screen Field Guide to the Birds, for Instant IDs
description: Buzzards.

title: Financial Debate Renews Scrutiny on Banks Size
description: A group of Senate Democrats introduced a bill on Wednesday that would require three of the nations largest banks to shrink, in an effort to eliminate the problem of financial institutions being seen as too big to fail, The New York Timess David M. Herszenhorn and Sewell Chan report from Washington.

title: Style Thats Created Show by Show
description: If you are hard-pressed to identify a stylistic signature for Lynn Ahrens and Stephen Flaherty, the gifted songwriting team behind Ragtime, Once on This Island and Seussical, it is probably the way they want it. As they explained to their sometime librettist Terrence McNally, who interviewed them at the 92YTribeca on Monday evening, they take pride in never repeating themselves.

title: Delta Resumes Nonstop Service to Valencia, Spain
description: This spring, Delta Air Lines resumes seasonal service to Valencia, Spain, with four weekly nonstop flights from New York City. This is the third year Delta has offered this route.

title: Is Indoor Tanning Addictive?
description: Many people think a bronzed tan gives them a healthy glow. But new research shows that people who regularly use tanning beds may be suffering from a form of addiction.

title: Leno: Volcanoes Are Caused by Women
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: The giant cloud of ash over Amsterdam is so bad that you cant even see the giant cloud of hashish.

title: Peripatetic Costume Parties in New York
description: About three years ago, Shien Lee conceived the Dances of Vice, a costume ball that, depending on its theme, may on any given evening be home to a kinky assortment of characters.

title: Letterman: No Place to Sleep
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Because of the volcano in Iceland, thousands of travelers are stranded with no place to sleep, eat or shower. This is the kind of thing that can really take the fun out of air travel.

title: Tips for Increasing Sales in International Markets
description: After Ethan Siegels wife, Lalenya, returned from her law office to their Manhattan apartment covered in soot from the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, the couple decided to find work that would let them spend more time together. And so, in 2003 Mr. Siegel and a friend started Orb Audio, a maker of high-end home theater systems.

title: Her True Colors
description: FOR much of her adult life, and perhaps none too fairly, Lisa Grunwald has been the Other Grunwald to a large swath of New Yorks media and political elite.

title: Kimmel: Iceland is Still Smoking
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Today is April 20, which is like Christmas for pot smokers. It all started in the 1700s, when St. Patrick drove the stoners out of Ireland with a pack of Twinkies.

title: Airliners Loss Is Ocean Liners Gain
description: A shipload of passengers due on Thursday in Southampton  the British port city, not the one in the, um, Hamptons  has a distinction that stranded airline passengers will envy (or curse): They crossed the Atlantic when the planes were not flying.

title: Low Information Voters
description: Via Matthew Yglesias, Gallup finds voters not that eager to crack down on large banks and financial institutions  but substantially more eager to crack down on Wall Street banks.

title: Making a Splash: The Kitchen & Bath Industry Show
description: Innovative tubs, toilets and more from the Kitchen & Bath Industry Show.

title: John Harwood Interviews President Obama
description: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC interviewed President Obama on economic policy, Wall Street, and new tax legislation.

title: At Home With Duane Hampton
description: The widow of Mark Hampton, the well-known decorator, lives in a sumptuous, antique-filled uptown apartment.

title: G.M. and Chrysler Show Progress After Bankruptcy
description: The two automakers saved from collapse last year by billions of dollars in government loans offered evidence Wednesday of what they and the Obama administration said was proof of their turnarounds, even as the market for new vehicles remained weak, The New York Timess Nick Bunkley reports from Detroit.

title: Stop Stop Too Big To Fail
description: Talking Points Memo:

title: To Be Young and Gay, Before Reality TV
description: Gay kids emerging from their cocoons these days can tune into any Bravo reality show to find an assortment of potential role models. But a few decades back, kinship ran thinner in popular culture.

title: Obama Denies Link to Timing of S.E.C. Case
description: President Obama denied categorically on Wednesday any political involvement or advance knowledge of the federal case against Goldman Sachs, saying he learned about the civil fraud suit from television.

title: Ever Active, Tannenbaum Reshapes Jets Roster
description: General Manager Mike Tannenbaum conducted this Jets off-season in typical fashion under atypical circumstances.

title: But Arent Home Prices Still Falling?
description: Ryan Avent, Ezra Klein and Annie Lowrey all question the idea that now may be a good time to buy a home in Phoenix, Las Vegas or some other place where prices have plummeted. They point out that these areas tend to have weak economies right now. As of February, Las Vegass unemployment rate was 13.9%, Mr. Avent writes on The Economists Web site. Should we be encouraging people to chain themselves to labor markets like this for at least five to seven years? Brett Barry, a real estate agent in Phoenix, makes a similar point here.

title: Taylor Ready to Let Bygones Be Bygones With Jets Fans
description: Jason Taylor is excited about the opportunity to play for Jets Coach Rex Ryan, but Taylor said in a conference call Wednesday that his original goal this off-season was to return to the Miami Dolphins, the team he played for during 12 of his 13 seasons in the N.F.L.

title: A Taste of Europe at Red Bull Arena
description: That gaping hole in the July schedule of the New York Red Bulls will be filled with the first New York Football Challenge, a tournament that will include Manchester City and Tottenham Hotspur of the English Premier League; and (tentatively, the Red Bulls said) Sporting Clube de Portugal, known widely as Sporting Lisbon. The tournament will be played from July 22 to July 25.

title: Case Study | Cocchi Americano: Waking the Dead
description: It is a universal truism, not to mention a bedrock commercial ploy, that when you tell someone they cant have something, theyll likely become obsessed with obtaining it. This is readily demonstrated by liquor fanatics, who will cross the globe for a bottle of the most obscure and often pointless spirits, just to say theyve tasted them. I am as guilty of this as anyone, and need only point to my several-year hunt for the elusive Cocchi Aperitivo Americano (pronounced co-key), for which Ive buttonholed friends heading to Italy and Oakland, Calif., where it was once rumored to have an importer, all in vain.

title: The Smart Way to Increase Your Exports
description: A lot of business owners stumble into exporting through serendipity. They happen to meet a distributor or they happen to get a a call from an intrigued customer in an overseas market. In a small-business guide to exporting weve just published, Ian Mount suggests that more small businesses should be going after foreign markets, that the Obama administration has taken some recent steps to make this easier, and that it helps to take a proactive approach.

title: How to Help the Young Superheroes
description: In response to Nicks April 10 column featuring a family of orphans in Zimbabwe, over 100 readers wrote in asking what they could do to make a difference. Many readers, for example, wanted to send a bicycle to the oldest brother to expedite his nine-mile trek to school.

title: Style Icon | Grace Kelly
description: For anyone raised on Madonna or Rihanna, its hard to fathom how a rich girl with a wardrobe full of shirtdresses, twin sets and pearls  and a firm disbeliever in women wearing trousers  could become the fashion idol of her generation. But Grace Kelly epitomized a time before rebellion was a virtue, and the forthcoming Grace Kelly: Style Icon exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London pays homage to the actress-turned-princesss sartorial legacy, from her rise to stardom in the 50s to her untimely death in 1982. She certainly didnt see herself as a style leader, liking such conservative clothes, says the shows curator, Jenny Lister. But audiences loved her kind of uncontrived, natural beauty. Highlights of the show include Kellys namesake Herms bag, dresses from her films High Society and Rear Window, and items from among the 80 pieces of luggage she carried to Monaco for her wedding to Prince Rainier in 1956. But perhaps more intriguing is what happened in the decades that followed, when Kelly found herself outside her comfort zone  amid all the tiaras and Dior ballgowns are the odd nods to rising hemlines and changing times, like her YSL Mondrian dress. In the end though, says Lister, she was always happier in a Chanel suit.

title: The Seas, and the Humans Who Could Drown Them
description: After wowing us in the skies with Winged Migration, the two Jacques (Perrin and Cluzaud) are back to entice us to gaze in the opposite direction. In Oceans, Disneynatures reconstitution of the 2009 French release Ocans, the filmmakers venture in, on and around our seas to discover photogenic oddities and endangered wonders.

title: A Sly Suggestion Is All It May Take to Kill a Marriage
description: In the world of August Strindberg, where everyone is always armed and dangerous, it takes only 90 minutes to destroy a marriage. Thats the time required to perform the thrilling new interpretation of Creditors, which opened Tuesday night at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. When this impeccably acted three-character drama has put the last of those minutes to cruel and careful use, youre likely to feel youve had the breath knocked out of you. Despite yourself, youll probably be smiling too.

title: Facebook Spreads Itself Across the Web
description: Call it Facebook to go.

title: All Creatures Great and Repulsive
description: Nature has taken up residence in your television set, and it wants to kill you. Happy Earth Day.

title: Pardon My French
description: Paris

title: Same Game, Other Side of Tracks
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: Despite Anxiety and Naysayers, Composer Wins Her Pulitzer
description: PHILADELPHIA  Jennifer Higdon wishes there were a 12-step program on how to deal with all the various stages of composing anxiety, she said, laughing, on Sunday in the spacious apartment here that she shares with her partner, Cheryl Lawson.

title: Ready, Shreddy, Go!
description: This past Saturday at Webster Halls grand ballroom, it all came down to two very different but equally impressive New York City shredders: Dylan Brenner, a 15-year old Les Paul-wielding prodigy from Long Island, and Lily Maase, a 27-year old guitarist who splits her time between Bushwick, Brooklyn, and Spanish Harlem. Both had out-rocked opponents in three previous rounds and were now facing off in the finals. Following two blistering 90-second solos, the judges were at an impasse and the audience was in an uproar.

title: 'The Sorter'
description: A video from the New York Public Library about the book sorting machine.

title: All Hail the Mighty Regis and Kelly Rolodex
description: David Letterman, near right, is rarely on television outside his own bailiwick, but when he does make a guest appearance, it is pretty much out of loyalty and friendship. Those are surely factors behind his decision to appear as a guest on Live With Regis and Kelly on the morning of April 30. Regis Philbin, above center, is a frequent guest on Mr. Lettermans Late Show on CBS, and Mr. Letterman has often expressed affection and admiration for him. (Mr. Letterman was last a guest on Live in April 2007, when Mr. Philbin returned to the show after heart surgery.) This visit helps kick off a big effort by Live during the next ratings sweeps period, which begins next Thursday. Besides Mr. Letterman, the show has booked stars including Robert Downey Jr., Gwyneth Paltrow (above right), Russell Crowe, Denzel Washington, Jimmy Kimmel and the Jonas Brothers.

title: Alabama Soprano Wins Sills Award
description: Susanna Phillips, below, a 28-year-old soprano from Huntsville, Ala., was named the winner of the Beverly Sills Artist Award, the Metropolitan Opera said on Wednesday. The award, for singers between the ages of 25 and 40 who have appeared in featured solo roles at the Met, has been given annually since 2006, and comes with a prize of $50,000. Ms. Phillips made her Met debut last season in the role of Musetta in La Bohme; she has also sung Pamina in Die Zauberflte and will reprise that role in the Mets 2010-11 season.

title: Curb Your Enthusiasm Gets Another Season
description: For his most recent run of Curb Your Enthusiasm, Larry David, below, performed the seemingly impossible and reunited the cast of Seinfeld. So what will he do for an encore? Well find out in due time: on Tuesday, HBO said it was ordering another season of Curb Your Enthusiasm, on which Mr. David plays a dyspeptic fictionalized version of himself. Mr. David said in a statement: After much soul searching  and by the way, it was nowhere to be found  I have decided to do another season of Curb. I look forward to the end of shooting, when I can once again resume the hunt for my elusive soul. I know its here somewhere, or perhaps in the rugged mountainous regions of Pakistan. Wherever Mr. David may find his vital force, HBO said that production of new episodes would begin this summer in New York and Los Angeles and would be shown next year.

title: Bieber Continues to Sell
description: Justin Biebers My World 2.0 (Island) is the top-selling album in the United States for the second week in a row, with sales of 92,000, Nielsen SoundScan reported, and the Brooklyn band MGMT enters the chart this week in second place, with 66,000 in sales of its second album, Congratulations (Columbia). Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville) is No. 3, with 65,000; Ushers Raymond v. Raymond (LaFace) is in fourth place with 64,000 sales; and the New York hard-rock band Coheed and Cambria opened at No. 5 with Year of the Black Rainbow (Columbia), which sold 51,000. For most music retailers it was a slow week; the sales for My World 2.0 are the fewest for a No. 1 album since last May, when Chrisette Micheles Epiphany sold 83,000.

title: Muslim Group Warns South Park
description: An Islamic group based in New York said that a recent episode of South Park, the satirical animated series, insulted the Prophet Muhammad, and compared the shows creators, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, to Theo van Gogh, the Dutch filmmaker who was killed in 2004 by an Islamic militant, CNN reported. The group, Revolution Muslim, published its post after a South Park episode last week that depicted the founders of various religions, including Moses, Jesus and Buddha, but declined to show the Prophet Muhammad, instead representing him as wearing a bear costume. The post, written by Abu Talhah Al-Amrikee, said that the episode had outright insulted Muhammad, adding: We have to warn Matt and Trey that what they are doing is stupid, and they will probably wind up like Theo van Gogh for airing this show. This is not a threat, but a warning of the reality of what will likely happen to them. Mr. van Gogh was killed in Amsterdam after making a film that discussed the abuse of Muslim women in some Islamic societies. A telephone message left at a number listed on the groups Web site, revolutionmuslim.com, was not immediately returned; on Wednesday the Web site was largely inaccessible. Comedy Central declined to comment on the groups remarks or say if it was taking any precautions because of them.

title: Fox Takes Tuesday
description: Foxs Glee continued to hit ratings high notes as its Madonna-theme episode finished second only to American Idol on Tuesday night. According to Nielsens estimates, 13.5 million viewers tuned in to Glee at 9 p.m., nearly matching the seriess record set last week (13.6 million). Although the audience for Idol was down somewhat at 8 (19.1 million), that show still dominated the night, surpassing ABCs Dancing With the Stars results episode in the hour (13.4 million), in which Kate Gosselin reached the end of her run. CBS placed third for the night with all reruns, while NBC finished fourth.

title: For the Magna Carta, an Extended Layover
description: The Magna Carta may have helped establish the right to protection against unlawful legal detention, but that doesnt mean it cant be held in New York a little longer than expected while Europe resolves its travel woes. The Morgan Library & Museum in Manhattan said a rare manuscript of the Magna Carta that it started showing on Wednesday would remain on display through May 30 while arrangements were made to transport it home to Britain. The original Magna Carta was sealed by King John of England in 1215 at Runnymede, putting limits on the kings power and laying the groundwork for legal principles like the writ of habeas corpus. The version at the Morgan, which comes from the Bodleian Library at Oxford University, dates to 1217 and is one of 17 surviving originals produced in the 13th century that bear the royal seal. Richard Ovenden, the Bodleians associate director and keeper of special collections, said this Magna Carta made its first visit to New York for a special event for Oxford alumni in the United States held on Saturday at the Waldorf-Astoria. As the ash from the eruption of an Icelandic volcano disrupted air travel, Mr. Ovenden said, transportation for the document became more perilous, and airlines, concerned with getting people home, were reluctant to carry it.

title: Cops Who Deliver a Bang for the Buck
description: DALLAS

title: Schapiro Hits Back at G.O.P. Critics of Goldman Case
description: Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, defended her agency on Wednesday against Republican critics who had accused the S.E.C. of playing politics by filing securities fraud charges against Goldman Sachs while the Senate was debating a sweeping overhaul of the nations financial regulations.

title: Oxygen Channel Founder Selling Co-op
description: Geraldine Laybourne, who had a long career in television and was founder of the Oxygen channel, has just put her Manhattan co-op on the market for $14.5 million.

title: 400-Year-Old Work Gets a Fresh Look
description: Many a conductor has muttered it at the start of an under-rehearsed performance: God help me. But Steven Fox sang it resoundingly at Park Avenue Christian Church on Monday evening  Deus in adjutorium meum intende, more formally translated as, O God, make haste to save me  and there was nothing undercooked about the performance to follow.

title: City Saves $50 Million in New Deal With Unions
description: Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco has struck a two-year deal with major unions representing city employees, staving off more than 1,000 planned layoffs, city officials said.

title: Music With and Without Musicians
description: The primary focus of the MATA Festival, a vital annual new-music series, is on fresh sounds fashioned by young creators. But not every piece requires live performers: sound installations and electronic music also factor into the mix. The first formal concert of MATAs 12th season was held on Tuesday night at Le Poisson Rouge, the Greenwich Village nightclub. But the festivities had actually started the night before, when Matt Wright, an English composer and improviser, activated his Totem for Gobi  New York in the clubs Gallery Bar.

title: Tracing Kings Killer in a World of Shadow
description: In writing Hellhound on His Trail, the hands-on historian Hampton Sides (Ghost Soldiers, Blood and Thunder) has undertaken a hugely risky proposition. He has pieced together a viscerally dramatic account of the last days of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and intercut Dr. Kings story with the maneuverings of James Earl Ray, the man tried and convicted as his assassin. The potential for exploitation is immense, especially in light of Mr. Sidess most visible literary influence. Here is the King assassination as imagined not only in the black and white of the civil rights movements era but in James Ellroys noir.

title: Robust Collection of Singing Visitors
description: In the great Anglican tradition, St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue has a superb men and boys choir, as well as a school for the training of its young singers. The choristers sing the church services and have an estimable concert series: their annual Messiah performances have long been the best in town.

title: Cant Stand to Sit Too Long? Theres a Desk for That
description: It takes courage to stand up at work. Im not talking about sticking your neck out, speaking truth to power or anything else so dramatic. I mean it literally; it is hard to find a way to work standing up at your desk instead of sitting down.

title: One Deceived by Experience, the Other by the Heart Queen
description: In the April 10 column I claimed  on the basis of personal experience  that it is easier to get a huge match-point score in a pair event that has many tables. But Richard Zeckhauser, the Frank P. Ramsey professor of political economy at the Kennedy School at Harvard University and twice a national bridge champion, points out that the fewer tables, the more likely you are to have a big score.

title: Nikes Women Problem
description: Is there anything creepier than a big, beer-breathed celebrity athlete exposing himself in a night club and hitting on underage girls, all the while protected by an entourage of off-duty cops? Well, yes. Its the big, corporate sponsor  Nike, in this case  that continues trying to sell product with the creep as their role model.

title: From Different Generations but on the Same Page
description: Rudresh Mahanthappa and Bunky Green are alto saxophonists born 36 years apart. The younger, Mr. Mahanthappa, matured in the 1990s in New York after studying at Berklee College of Music. Mr. Green played in clubs as a teenager in Milwaukee in the early 1950s, when jazz was still a vernacular language, then went on to New York and Chicago, working with Charles Mingus and Sonny Stitt.

title: That Mighty Sorting Machine Is Certainly One for the Books
description: A couple of years ago Salvatore Magaddino, who oversees the distribution of materials for the New York Public Library, complained at a meeting that he was having trouble recruiting book sorters, the people responsible for sorting the millions of books sent each year from one branch library to another.

title: Priestess of the Night
description: THERE are two Shien Lees: the schoolgirl, demure in a checkered frock and cardigan; and the siren, faintly dissolute in a lace-edged scarlet frock. Ms. Lee, a recent graduate of Columbia University, is fresh-scrubbed by day, pursuing a range of cultural interests that include the study of 1920s German art and 18th-century opera. By night, she is an events planner and the entrepreneurial force behind a series of monthly costume parties that are at the center of a thriving New York vintage scene.

title: Havasupai Case Highlights Risks in DNA Research
description: A settlement between 41 members of the Havasupai Indian tribe and Arizona State University highlights the risk researchers take when they fail to secure what is known as informed consent, fully informing research participants how their DNA may be used, legal experts and civil rights advocates said.

title: Timing the Delivery of Your E-Mail Messages
description: Timed Delivery

title: Goldman Executives Are Expected to Testify Before Senate Panel
description: The governments case against Goldman Sachs is about to get its first public airing, in what could be a gripping preview of the legal battle to come.

title: Q.&A.: Timed Delivery for E-Mail
description: Q.

title: Microcredit Is Still a Good Tool to Reduce Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: C. K. Prahalad, Proponent of Poor as Consumers, Dies at 68
description: C. K. Prahalad, a management professor and author who popularized the idea that companies could make money while helping to alleviate poverty, died Friday in the La Jolla neighborhood of San Diego. He was 68 and lived in San Diego.

title: Cuban May Try to Block Weinsteins on Miramax
description: Mark Cuban, the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks basketball team, told Bloomberg News that he might try to stop Harvey and Bob Weinstein from joining a buyout of Miramax films in a dispute over the performance of the The Road, a Weinstein movie.

title: Tough Cameras Make Underwater Photography Easier
description: When normal people hear that theyre going to the Bahamas, they think: Bathing suit! Sunscreen! Flip-flops!

title: Simon Lines Up More Investors for General Growth Plan
description: 10:03 p.m. | Updated The Simon Property Group said on Wednesday that it had lined up an additional $1.1 billion in new capital for its proposed investment in General Growth Properties, the bankrupt mall operator.

title: Hellhound on His Trail
description: Chapter 1: City of White Gold

title: What Were Reading: iPad Jokes
description: The tech editors and reporters of the New York Times had a varied reading list Wednesday:

title: Standouts at the Milan Furniture Fair
description: Fluid, lithe and angular pieces helped define this years Salone del Mobile in Milan.

title: LED Lamps With Porcelain Flowers
description: Frederick P. Victoria, who founded the Manhattan furniture shop that bears his name in 1933, was a huge pack rat, said Freddy Victoria, his grandson and the vice president for new development at the company, which is now in Long Island City, Queens.

title: The Conran Shop at ABC Carpet & Home
description: Fans of the Conran Shop, which for more than a decade resided in the distinctive  but painfully inconvenient  space underneath the Queensboro Bridge on East 59th Street, have every reason to be excited about the stores relocation to the lower level of ABC Carpet & Home.

title: A Collection of Felt Shades and Stools
description: Lily Latifi, an Iranian textile designer living in Paris, created her new collection of room dividers, shades and stools out of wool felt because its like sculpture, she said. Its very simple and minimalistic. And in Iran, Ms. Latifi added, people who cannot afford a Persian carpet often have a rug of felt instead.

title: Converting a Garage Outside Seattle Into a Tiny Home
description: SEATTLE

title: Slobproof Sofas and Chairs
description: Debbie Wiener once cared about keeping her home pristine. Then she got married.

title: Sales at John Robshaw and Others
description: At Armand Diradourians spring sale, which continues through May 1, cashmere throws and decorative pillows are 40 to 60 percent off (hand-knit pillows, originally $440, are $175; striped throws, originally $950, are $500); Armand Diradourian, 19 West 21st Street, (212) 924-5787.

title: At the Kitchen and Bath Industry Show, Bathrooms That Beckon
description: YOU need a little razzle-dazzle to pull in the crowd at a trade show, and from a showbiz point of view  lights! music! dance!  it was hard to beat Kohlers DTV II shower, set up prominently near the entrance to the Kitchen & Bath Industry Show at the McCormick Place Convention Center in Chicago last weekend.

title: How the Other Half Lives
description: DUANE HAMPTON is a clipper and a stacker, of New Yorker cartoons, theater reviews, newspaper and magazine articles, hardcover books from the best-seller lists. They stand in neat bundles  napoleons of inspiration, exhortation and whimsy  competing for space with the many side chairs, end tables and foot stools that patrol her Park Avenue apartment.

title: At the Milan Furniture Fair, a Fluid Design Emerges
description: MILAN

title: Brides Magazine Hosts a Newlywed Nest
description: ELIZABETH CROWLEY, 27, leaned deep into the mouth of a calla lily and took its photo. Purple is my color, explained Ms. Crowley, who is marrying soon and whose three bridesmaids, she said, will be wearing purple dresses.

title: Californias Solar Scorecard
description: California set an ambitious energy goal at the start of 2007: to have one million of the states households outfitted with solar roofs by 2018. Out of 7.7 million single family homes in the state, only about 50,000 homeowners (or 60,000, according to industry numbers) currently use solar panels, but advocates of the initiative in California say that the numbers have increased rapidly in the last year.

title: $3 Million Deal Ends a Holdout in Brooklyn
description: For the past six years, Daniel Goldstein has been at the center of just about every rally, house party, concert and lawsuit opposed to the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn.

title: A Family Gathering, but Not for Long
description: IT was never about the money, Joshua White said. It was about Can we make a happening? Can we make a scene?

title: Secret Baghdad Jail Held Sunnis From the North
description: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi security force under Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Malikis direct command held hundreds of detainees from northern Iraq in an undisclosed prison in Baghdad, torturing dozens of them, until the countrys human rights minister and the United States intervened late last month, Iraqi and American officials said.

title: Further Inquiries Into Former Rep. Massa
description: The House ethics committee announced Wednesday that it would open an inquiry into whether lawmakers or staff failed to pursue reports of misconduct by former Representative Eric Massa, a New York Democrat who resigned his seat last month after complaints of sexual harassment of male staffers.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,032 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: You Dont Hide Behind These
description: SELIMA OPTIQUES Bond Street boutique is host to a small pop-up for Cutler & Gross, the London eyewear line, which includes vintage specs. The most requested is the Cat Eye sunglasses that Kate Hudson wore with a swinging 60s fringed silver minidress in the movie Nine. The glasses, known by their style number, 866, come in turtle brown or black (below right, $425). The store is scheduled to be open until May, but since pop-up seems to be retail code for test run, the end date may be extended. Cutler & Gross Pop-up at Bond 07 by Selima Optique, 7 Bond Street, (212) 677-8487.

title: Just Call Them Edwardian
description: YES, the co-owner (along with Paul Birardi) of Odin New York is named Eddy, and the in-house collection by the design team Duckie Brown, which was started last fall, is named Edward. But the two have no connection, said Eddy Chai. I begged them not to do it, he insisted, saying that he was outvoted by the designers. We all have an Edward in our lives, so it seemed a good fit, he said, resignedly. No matter. The bottom line is that the stores recently arrived collection of short-sleeve plaid and checked shirts is a great way to embrace spring. Pictured above: Edward Blue Check, left, and Edward Blue Plaid, right, $185 each. The store also has plaid shirts from Eddy Chais brother, the designer Richard Chai (center, $169). Odin New York is at 328 East 11th Street, (212) 475-0666; 199 Lafayette Street, (212) 966-0026; and 750 Greenwich Street, (212) 420-8446; odinnewyork.com.

title: Many Feet Shall Be Shod
description: SHOE worshipers will be making a pilgrimage to the Sigerson Morrison Warehouse Sale next week. On sale will be shoes from many past seasons  flats, heels, boots and sandals. Among the offerings is the pointy black flat with gold-sequined toe (above), which retailed at $495 and will be $150. Boots that were $995 are now $295; booties, reduced from $695 to $225. The sister line, Belle by Sigerson Morrison, offers edgier shoes at lower prices.

title: Senate Hot Seat Awaits Goldman Officers and Trader
description: Fabrice P. Tourre, the Goldman Sachs trader accused of fraud by federal regulators, and at least three Goldman officers have agreed to testify before a Senate panel next week in an attempt to defend the firms dealings and reputation, Eric Dash of The New York Times reports, citing people briefed on the proceedings.

title: G.O.P. and Finance Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Needs a $100 Bill?
description: When was the last time you used a $100 bill?

title: At 40, Earth Day Is Now Big Business
description: So strong was the antibusiness sentiment for the first Earth Day in 1970 that organizers took no money from corporations and held teach-ins to challenge corporate and government leaders.

title: Animal Cruelty Videos: A Ruling on Free Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Spoil Your Wrist
description: THE centerpiece of the first American retail store for Girard-Perregaux, the Swiss watchmaking firm that dates back to 1791, is a workshop used by a skilled watchmaker, Yuriy Vasekevich, who sits in a slightly elevated enclosed glass space. But Mr. Vaskevich isnt a performance artist; hes actually there to answer customers questions about the watches on sale. His artistlike presence does feel appropriate, however: the store (above) is practically a museum, hushed and reverential, displaying the wares of the luxury brand with prices from $10,000 to $500,000. The boutique is a compact 900 square feet with 16-foot ceilings, and a combination of surfaces including wood, metal, glass, leather and stone. There are two limited-edition timepieces that are exclusive to the New York boutique. The womans watch  named Shopping Madison  is bejeweled and white, and it sells for $20,600; 701 Madison Avenue (at 63rd Street), (646) 495-9915; girard-perregaux.com.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: E-Playgrounds Can Get Vicious
description: LAST February, I wrote a piece for Salon about the Postpartum Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder I experienced after the traumatic delivery of my son. I was able to, unfortunately, write it from the first person: In the article, I discussed statistics, research and my initial ambivalence over a diagnosis that seemed reserved for war veterans and rape victims. My piece was not meant to evoke sympathy; it was meant to be informative. Besides, with the amount of antidepressants ultimately prescribed for my condition, I was far too numb to feel sorry for myself.

title: Trying to Save Wild Tigers by Rehabilitating Them
description: BALIMBING, Indonesia  The two wild Sumatran tigers, held in large, adjoining cages here, had killed at least eight people between them.

title: Settlement for a Grand Canyon Tribe
description: The Havasupai Indians received a settlement from Arizona State University's Board of Regents for wrongful use of DNA samples given to university researchers in 1990.

title: Leaders Start to Formulate Details of Greek Aid Program
description: PARIS  Talks over details of an international aid package for Greece began Wednesday as European leaders worked to reach a framework to help the troubled country.

title: Fashion Goes Farm to Table
description: WHAT do daughters of Russian billionaires and Williamsburg scenesters have in sartorial common? Curiously, a penchant for overalls. On the February cover of Russian Vogue, a tousled blonde wears Ralph Laurens bibbed denim version, neo-hippie accessorized with a gold woven bustier, a low-slung fringed belt and skin-baring provocative side curve.

title: How Judges See the Constitution
description: To the Editor:

title: Dalai Lama Mourns on Facebook for Earthquake Victims
description: As my colleague Andrew Jacbos reports from Beijing, China mourned the victims of last weeks earthquake in western Qinghai Province on Wednesday. Most of the more than 2,000 victims who were killed were ethnic Tibetans and the disaster devastated Jiegu, a high-altitude Tibetan city.

title: MSNBC Cancels Guest Anchors Show After a Controversial Segment
description: A television segment about angry media commentators created a furor inside MSNBC this week, one that extended outside the cable news channel after the segments host, Donny Deutsch, found himself dismissed as a guest anchor Wednesday.

title: Mets and Marines Share a Day
description: Bill Welyczko earned himself the nickname the Human Magnet over in Vietnam, for the way flying objects found their way to him, twice when his vehicles hit land mines, once from direct rifle fire.

title: Woods Commits to More Tournaments
description: Tiger Woods has again given tournament officials early notification of his commitment to play  this time naming two additional events for 2010. Just as he did before the Masters and next weeks PGA Tour event, the Quail Hollow Championship, Woods on Wednesday committed early to the Players Championship, set to begin May 6 at T.P.C. Sawgrass, and to the AT&T National, which will start July 1 at the Aronimink Golf Club outside Philadelphia.

title: Are You Ready for Some Picks at Night?
description: The popularity of the N.F.L. draft on television is proof that millions of people can be riveted by the sight of Commissioner Roger Goodell reading index cards and posing beside the men whose names he has announced.

title: Fouling to Protect a Lead: Debated but Rarely Done
description: The first-round playoff series last year between the Boston Celtics and the Chicago Bulls was a memorable montage of overtimes and clutch shots. Celtics Coach Doc Rivers remembers it for another reason.

title: Japan Tries to Face Up to Growing Poverty Problem
description: MEMURO, Japan  Satomi Sato, a 51-year-old widow, knew she had it tough, raising a teenage daughter on the less than $17,000 a year she earned from two jobs. Still, she was surprised last autumn when the government announced for the first time an official poverty line  and she was below it.

title: EBay Remakes an iPhone App Specifically for the iPad
description: The best eBay shopping experience  and one of the best shopping experiences on the Web  might just be on the iPad.

title: Gasping Devils May Be Finished Before Getting Started
description: NEWARK  The Devils gathered Wednesday afternoon for what might have been the last practice of an inconsistent season, and the chatter among the players barely drifted over the glass at Prudential Center. They seem to have a lot of things to fix, and they do not have much time.

title: U.S.O.C. Ends Plans for Its Own Olympic Channel
description: The United States Olympic Committee and Comcast have ended their plans to create an Olympic channel.

title: Mets Setup Man Sidelined by Hamstring Tear
description: After just seven games in the United States, the right-handed reliever Ryota Igarashi joined the fraternity of injured Mets when the team placed him on the 15-day disabled list Wednesday with a minor tear in his left hamstring.

title: Visa Buys CyberSource for $2 Billion
description: Betting that electronic payments will increasingly replace cash, Visa announced on Wednesday that it would pay $2 billion to buy CyberSource, which facilitates payments for big online merchants.

title: Scene Setter
description: Photos from a recent pop-up shop party inTriBeCa  part pop-up store, part gallery, part performance space where a full roster of readings, discussions and parties will go on through early May.

title: The World of Doormen Is Obvious, Yet Mysterious
description: The thing about doormen is, often they were doing completely unrelated work, like selling survival gear or bagging pork chops, when something random happened and suddenly they were doormen, tipping their caps and announcing that the in-laws were on the way up with a fruitcake.

title: At Least 6 People Abducted in Mexican Hotel Raids
description: MEXICO CITY  Armed men raided two hotels in the center of Monterrey, Mexicos industrial capital, early Wednesday morning, hauling away four guests and as many as three staff members and sending a wave of panic across a city that has experienced a spate of violent episodes in recent weeks, the authorities said.

title: Ruling for Plaintiff in Tobacco Case
description: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, one of the countrys biggest cigarette makers, must pay $46.3 million to the widow of a Florida man who died from lung cancer in 1995, a jury in Gainesville, Fla., decided Wednesday.

title: Earth Day, the Sequel
description: The genesis of the modern environmental movement was the subject of Earth Days, the most recent film by Robert Stone, an Oscar-nominated documentarian who has explored subjects ranging from the space race to the legacy of Lee Harvey Oswalds life and death. So I thought it worth having a Skype chat with Stone about the meaning of that era, and the crossroads confronting the environmental community now  which relates to the subject of his next film.
