description: Greeces attempts to get its economy back on its feet and to regain investor trust suffered another setback Thursday as the European Union increased its estimate of the countrys 2009 budget deficit.

title: Protecting the Street They Live On
description: Judging from their queasiness about federal efforts to get a grip on the casino aspects of Wall Street, it is plain what David A. Paterson and Michael R. Bloomberg would do if they were the governor of Iowa and the mayor of Des Moines. They would denounce the penny-per-ounce tax on soda that they now promote enthusiastically as vital for expanding New Yorks government revenues and shrinking its residents waistlines.

title: Dont Cry for Wall Street
description: On Thursday, President Obama went to Manhattan, where he urged an audience drawn largely from Wall Street to back financial reform. I believe, he declared, that these reforms are, in the end, not only in the best interest of our country, but in the best interest of the financial sector.

title: Backlash Builds in Japan to New Rules for Banks
description: TOKYO  As momentum grows in the United States and Europe for tighter regulations on banks, opposition is building in Japan.

title: A Routine Deal Became an $840 Million Mistake
description: LONDON  To the bankers here, it seemed like a chance to make a quick $7 million  risk free.

title: The Government War
description: In these columns I try to give voice to a philosophy you might call progressive conservatism. It starts with the wisdom of Edmund Burke  the belief that the world is more complex than we can know and we should be skeptical of handing too much power to government planners. It layers in a dose of Hamiltonian optimism  the belief that limited but energetic government can nonetheless successfully enhance opportunity and social mobility.

title: German Rail Operator Buys European Transportation Company
description: PARIS  Deutsche Bahn, the government-owned company that runs the German railways, said Thursday that it would buy Arriva, a transportation company based in Britain, as it looks to expand into new markets.

title: Chilean Abuse Case Tests Loyalty of a Parish
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  The Rev. Fernando Karadima is one of Chiles most respected and influential priests. Some go so far as to call him a living saint, who for half a century trained dozens of priests and helped mold thousands of young Catholics from Santiagos elite.

title: Appeals Court Judge and U.S. Attorney Are Confirmed
description: The United States Senate voted on Thursday to elevate Denny Chin, a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan, to a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Round 2 in Britain: Old Guard Rebounds
description: LONDON  When the three men vying to become Britains next prime minister met for a second of three televised election debates on Thursday night, the big question was whether Nick Clegg, the challenger from the Liberal Democrats, the smallest of the three parties, could repeat his show-stealing performance in the first debate last week.

description: The sign, with the little racks he designed to hold what he used to sell, sat in the foyer in his fourth floor walk-up. David Ferguson strapped it on for the first time in a long time.

description: PepsiCo said Thursday its first-quarter profit rose 26 percent after it acquired its two largest bottlers.

title: Privacy in a New World
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday in a case about the privacy rights of a California police officer who sent very personal text messages on a city-issued pager. description: Early this month, the International Maritime Organization  the United Nations agency that oversees maritime law  announced that large cruise ships will no longer be allowed to burn heavy fuel in Antarctic waters. This is a welcome step in protecting the harsh but delicate polar environment.

title: Credit Suisse Reports a 2 Percent Rise in Profit
description: LONDON  Credit Suisse reported Thursday that its first-quarter profit rose and that it had attracted more wealthy clients to its private bank. But shares fell after trading revenue failed to keep pace with that of American rivals.

title: Come Back, John McCain

title: State Teachers Union Urges More Oversight of Charters
description: A Buffalo charter school, run by a for-profit company, received $7.2 million in taxpayer money last year to educate about 500 elementary and middle school students. But at the end of the year, the audit it submitted to the state listed its expenses only in broad brushstrokes, including $1.3 million in rent for a building the company owned, $976,000 for executive administration and $361,000 in professional fees.

title: Ike Daviss Real First Name Has a History of Its Own

title: John Carl Warnecke, Architect to Kennedy, Dies at 91
description: John Carl Warnecke, the court architect of the Kennedy administration and the designer of John F. Kennedys grave site at Arlington National Cemetery, died on Saturday at his home in Healdsburg, Calif. He was 91 and also had homes in San Francisco and Manhattan.

title: Iraq: Navy Seals Member Cleared
description: A member of the Navy Seals was cleared Thursday of charges that he covered up the beating of an Iraqi prisoner suspected of leading the 2004 killings of four American security contractors. The Navy jurors who cleared Petty Officer First Class Julio Huertas said they heard too many differences in testimony by a sailor who said he saw the attack at a base outside Falluja and statements from other people who contradicted his account.

title: Buildings Superintendent Harassed Women, Suit Says

title: Polanski Fails to Block His Extradition
description: The director Roman Polanski failed in his latest attempt to block his extradition to the United States from Switzerland, where he is under house arrest, and end the 33-year-old case against him for having sex with a minor. In a decision on Thursday, a California appeals court denied a request to end the proceedings by sentencing him to time already served, despite Mr. Polanskis claims that new evidence showed hitherto undisclosed corruption in the case.

title: Jean Vergnes, Who Helped Open Le Cirque, Dies at 88
description: Jean Vergnes, a prominent chef who opened Le Cirque, one of New York Citys premier restaurants, with Sirio Maccioni in 1974, died Thursday at his home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 88.

Ivins, whom the F.B.I. has blamed for the anthrax letter attacks that killed five people in 2001, told a National Academy of Sciences panel on Thursday that he believed it was impossible that the deadly spores had been produced undetected in Dr. Ivinss laboratory, as the F.B.I. asserts.

description: As the Coast Guard was trying to assess the potential environmental effect of the oil rig explosion near Louisiana, industry officials said Thursday that they did not expect drilling in the Gulf of Mexicos deep waters to be curtailed.

description: Glamour took the top honor at the National Magazine Awards on Thursday, winning in a new category called Magazine of the Year that awards both print and digital efforts.

title: Green Day Makes Surprise Appearance at Musical
description: The Broadway show American Idiot turned into a rock concert with a supercharged encore: a surprise appearance by Green Day, the band that wrote the music.

title: Big Bamb
description: The twin artists Mike and Doug Starn are creating a monumental bamboo structure on the terrace of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a perpetual work-in-progress that will evolve over a six-month period.

title: New Lawsuit Shows Letters to Vatican on Sexual Abuse Earlier Than Previously Thought
description: Documents released in a lawsuit filed Thursday against Pope Benedict XVI show that the Vatican was informed more than a year earlier than previously thought about the case of a priest who molested deaf boys for two decades at a boarding school in Wisconsin.

title: A Marathon Just to Reach the Start Line in London
description: After an arduous week of ash-disrupted travel, running a mere 26.2 miles from Blackheath to Buckingham Palace on Sunday may be far smoother for some professional athletes running the London Marathon.

In fact, one of his former bosses joked recently that Ryan would stand on the interstate with a sign that read, I need corners.

title: For Better, for Worse

It alleges callous and unlawful behavior on the part of the officials who separated the men  Mr. Greene, 78, and Mr. Scull, who was 89 when he died nearly two years ago. It accuses the county and its employees of elder abuse and fraud.

After a few months of legal battles Mr. Gore and company won this past week, proving that Goliath can indeed beat David.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: News Quiz | April 23, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: To See the Boy King
description: WHO was King Tutankhamun, or Tut?

title: Can Debt Collectors Overuse the Courts, and More in Fridays Bay Area Report
description: The Wages of Debt | About $100 billion in credit card debt is sold annually in the United States, and debt collectors are increasingly turning to the courts to enforce payment of uncollected debts, which are sold and resold among debt collectors. Critics say the practice clogs the courts and turns corporate lists of debtors into free-fire zones that sometimes target the innocent. In the Bay Area, a loose-knit group of public-interest lawyers pools resources to fight what they see as a misuse of the court system. We found that these law firms count on a huge percentage of the people that they sue defaulting, or not responding to the legal actions, said Osha Neumann, a lawyer with the East Bay Community Law Center. Thats how the debt buyers make their money.

title: Rainer Ganahl: Language of Emigration & Pictures of Emigration
description: The latest exhibition from the veteran Conceptual artist Rainer Ganahl is a resonant feat of site-specificity, a fit of art and space so unforced yet so affecting as to be breathtaking. Basically Mr. Ganahl has used nearly every square foot of the fledgling Alex Zachary gallery, an empty brownstone garden duplex of 1980s rehab. (It is located on without being quite of the Upper East Side. It keeps Thursday-to-Sunday Lower East Side hours, and Mr. Zachary still has his day job at Gavin Browns gallery in the West Village.)

title: William Scott
description: There are obvious criticisms to be made of the canvases of the British painter William Scott (1913-1989), which are having their first solo in New York since 1992. His art can be seen as sentimental and timid, as abstract paintings for people who dont like abstraction. But what remains is some wonderfully solid, serenely formal images that refuse to banish reality. Their fusion of the mundane and exalted remains vibrant and may be especially useful at the moment, with so many painters exploring new ways of balancing meaning and form.

title: Dahesh Museum of Art: Becoming an Artist: The Academy in 19th-Century France
description: Unlike todays aspring artists, for those in pre-20th-century France the path to success was pretty clear. Becoming an Artist: The Academy in 19th-Century France explains the rigid system by which careers were made. (The show was organized by the peripatetic Dahesh Museum of Art, which is still seeking a home of its own.) The academy required three years of drawing, followed by painting under a recognized masters tutelage and, finally, winning the Prix de Rome. There is more to learn about the process from this compact show, but the main attraction is in the surprising number of mostly small, beautifully made paintings and drawings on display.

title: Corrections
description: An art entry in the Listings pages last Friday about Rome After Raphael, at the Morgan Library & Museum, misspelled the given name of an artist whose work appears in the exhibition. He was Annibale Carracci, not Anibale. (The error has appeared in the Listings pages each Friday since Feb. 12 and was pointed out in an e-mail message from a reader on Wednesday.)

title: Friend to Wall Street, Schumer Falls Quiet

title: A-Rod vs. Braden: Whos Right?
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  It was just a regular Thursday afternoon at Oakland Coliseum  a 2-hour-7-minute game, the Yankees first triple play in 42 years, that sort of thing  until Dallas Braden spoke. Some reporters from New York found him by his locker, and he was only too happy to take seven minutes out of his day to rip Alex Rodriguez for what he perceived as an unconscionable slight.

title: Abacus: From Routine Deal to Disaster
description: To the bankers at ABN Amro, it seemed like a chance to make a quick $7 million  risk free. Instead, their sweet deal turned into a $840.1 million debacle, Landon Thomas Jr. reports in The New York Times.

title: Belgium: Government Falls

The king did not accept the resignation, but began talks with key politicians. STEVEN ERLANGER

title: Turkey: Peace Process Hits Snag
description: Turkey reiterated its will to normalize relations with Armenia after a statement from Armenia's governing coalition said it had suspended the parliamentary ratification of peace accords with Turkey. President Serzh Sargsyan of Armenia confirmed the statement but said that his government remained determined to continue with the peace process, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency reported. The statement followed recent remarks by Turkey's prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, that diplomatic efforts could succeed only if Armenia settled its disagreement with Turkey over the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region. SEBNEM ARSU

This did not put an end to the conversation until he finally gritted his teeth and snarled, Im at Dr. Goldmans.

description: BART Fires Officer Involved in Oscar Grant Shooting |The officer who decided to arrest Oscar Grant just before a colleague fatally shot the unarmed man on Jan. 1, 2009, has been fired. The BART police department dismissed the officer, Anthony Pirone, on Thursday based on his actions on that night at the Fruitvale Station in Oakland. Officer Pirone, who had been on paid leave since Mr. Grants death, has never been charged with a crime but has been a focus of community outrage since the shooting. Earlier this month, protesters called for his firing during a demonstration at BART stations in San Francisco.[KTVU, The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: The National Agenda
description: IN THE DEAD of late January, the five members of the band the National were sprawled around a music studio in the attic of a weathered, gray Bridgeport, Conn., mansion. The studio belongs to the Nationals producer, Peter Katis, and after many long months of recording and rerecording their fifth album in Brooklyn, where the band members all now live, they had come to Connecticut for an efficient few weeks of mixing. Things were not turning out that way. The National is composed of the identical-twin guitar-playing brothers Bryce and Aaron Dessner; a second pair of brothers, Bryan Devendorf, the drummer, and Scott Devendorf, who usually plays bass; and Matt Berninger, the bands vocalist. Matt also writes the lyrics. He is tall, with a sturdy jib, cool blue eyes, a three-day reddish blond beard and enough lead-singer swagger to hold his own among all those siblings.

title: In the Health Bill, a New Focus on Elder Abuse
description: Tucked into the huge new health care law is a whopping $777 million, spread over the next four years, for programs to prevent and prosecute elder abuse. Advocates for these programs have been begging Congress for more money since 1978. Now they are celebrating as if they had won the lottery.

title: What About Home Prices and Incomes?
description: Before we get to some more good housing statistics, I want to emphasize that I am not trying to persuade people who now rent their home to become owners. If you rent now and youre happy, you probably should not move just for the sake of buying. Prices in most places are not that low yet. As I said in my column this week, renting still does not get enough respect in this country.

title: Surreal Reveal
description: Most beauty stories are about the latest makeup trends. For Surreal Reveal, the makeup artist Peter Philips and the photographer Richard Burbridge took a decidedly reductive, and ultimately seductive, route. Using photographs by Man Ray as a springboard, Philips, who is Chanels global creative director of makeup, stripped down the idea of a beauty image to its naked core. He didnt even use foundation on the models skin. After all, great skin is the ultimate luxury, he says. But bare doesnt mean you dont use any makeup at all, he stresses. When you pare it down to such an extent, every element you do wear has to be perfect  the perfect lipstick, the perfect eyeliner, the perfect nail polish. For Philips, the new bare lies somewhere between the overdone maquillage of the late 80s and the raw, unkempt look of the early 90s. I dont think women today feel the need to be so extreme, he says. Working on the shoot, Philips found the contradictions inherent in creating deconstructed beauty images to be both intriguing and modern. The iconic, formal poses in the photos are a reference to old fashion photography, and are completely at odds with how we played with the pristine, expensive objects in the shots, he says. (Its true that a lot of women might shudder at the idea of drawing on a quilted Chanel bag with eyeliner.) I love the fact that you can never see the models eyes, Philips continues. Makeup can be a mask that a woman hides behind. I compare it to a woman who overaccessorizes or wears over-the-top fashion  the accessories and clothes almost act as armor. Whether a woman decides to get away with a mere swipe of mascara or puts on a full face, Philips supports the idea that less can truly be more: You can wear the most dramatic red lipstick, but if you wear it with confidence, as if you own it, it will look completely natural.

title: Imagining a Jet-Free Europe
description: On April 15, the European Environment Agency in Copenhagen convened a two-day workshop on how to move toward a more sustainable transport system on the Continent by 2050. Since flying is by far the most highly emitting form of transportation, the central question was How would Europe look and function without aviation or with much less aviation than we have now? as Peder Jensen, the agencys transportation expert and the events organizer, put it.

description: Twice a week, Nocturnalist, our newest City Room feature, goes out at night so you dont have to.

title: Subway Terror Plotters Met Qaeda Leaders, Prosecutors Say
description: Updated, 4:13 p.m. | The failed Qaeda plan to bomb three New York City subway stations during the morning rush was ordered by two senior Qaeda leaders in Waziristan, who met personally with the admitted plotter Najibullah Zazi and his two co-defendants and urged them to conduct a suicide attack, a federal prosecutor said in court on Friday.

title: Stop the Presses! Historian Says He, Not His Wife, Is Savage Online Critic
description: The plot continues to thicken in the most exciting scandal to emerge from Britains historian community since  well, ever. Last week, a lawyer for Orlando Figes, an author and history professor at Birkbeck College in London, said Mr. Figess wife, Stephanie Palmer, a lawyer and lecturer at Cambridge University, was Historian, a pseudonymous commenter on the amazon.co.uk Web site who had been harshly criticizing books by Mr. Figess rivals while praising her husbands work.

title: Escaping the Crowds
description: BARBADOS

title: Weekend Competition: Peter Piper Picked a Peck of Woodchucks
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to submit tongue-twisters.

title: Screen Giant
description: She may be an ingnue, but at 5-FOOT-10, Rebecca Hall has legs.

title: When a Co-op Grows Taller
description: Q.

title: A Polish City Feels Its Future Has Arrived
description: ON one side of Tumski Bridge in Wroclaw, in southwest Poland, the Gothic Cathedral of St. John the Baptist hovers agelessly over Ostrow Tumski, the citys oldest quarter. Nearby, a boot-sized brass dwarf sits fishing over the rivers edge, one of more than 150 such statues placed throughout the city since 2001 in honor of the Orange Alternative, a Dada-influenced resistance movement that is widely considered to have had a hand in bringing down Polands Communist regime in the 1980s.

title: Caring for Hips and Knees to Avoid Artificial Joints
description: PROTECT your joints now, or pay later.

title: First a New Stove, Then Higher Rent
description: Q.

title: Friday Reading: Indulging the Urge to Divulge
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Taking Care of Knees and Hips
description: In todays Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman explores the steps men and women can take to protect their joints and keep arthritis at bay.

title: Subletting Your Co-op Can Cost You
description: Q.

title: When Pain Relievers Cause Bleeding
description: Millions take prescription and over-the-counter medicines to relieve arthritis pain, and all carry a long list of side effects. But how dangerous are these pain relievers? Dr. Neena S. Abraham, a gastroenterologist at the Michael E. DeBakey V.A. Medical Center and associate professor of medicine at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, recently took readers questions about ulcers, a potentially life-threatening condition increasingly tied to Nsaid pain relievers. Here, Dr. Abraham responds to a reader concerned about pain relievers and bleeding.

title: A New Character Is Arriving in Riverdale
description: A new man is moving into Riverdale, the home of comics perennial teenager Archie Andrews and his gang. His name is Kevin Keller and hes blond-haired, blue-eyed and gay. The property values in the fictional town will be sure to skyrocket. Kevin will be introduced in Veronica No. 202 in a story titled, Isnt it Bromantic? The inclusion of the character meets twin goals, one real world and one in-story.

title: Ford Is Recalling 33,000 Vehicles for Seat Problem
description: 2:43 p.m. | Updated

title: Cube Roots: Revisiting the Raiders and N.W.A. in Ice Cubes Straight Outta L.A.
description: As befits an actor-rapper multi-hyphenate like Ice Cube, his documentary Straight Outta L.A. is two stories in one: its the tale of how the Oakland Raiders owner Al Davis moved the team to Los Angeles in the 1980s, and how it helped inspire the city and bring it together, before the Raiders returned to Oakland in 1995. Its also the story of N.W.A., the gangsta rap group that included Ice Cube, Dr. Dre and Eazy-E, and how it made the Raiders clothing and sometimes ruthless spirit an essential part of its act. Straight Outta L.A. will have its premiere Friday at the Tribeca Film Festival, as part of the Tribeca/ESPN Sports Film Festival, and will be shown on ESPN as part of its 30 for 30 film series next month.

title: The Week Ahead: April 25  May 1
description: Film

title: Lufthansa Lounge in Munich Opens Beer Garden
description: According to Bloomberg, Lufthansa, Europes second-biggest airline, has opened a German beer garden at its business class lounge in Munich, the city that holds the annual Oktoberfest, as it seeks to lure full-fare customers.

title: How to Find Out if You Have Unclaimed Funds
description: My father recently sent me a New York State Office of Unclaimed Funds claim form in the mail that he had stapled to a partial list of names of people with unclaimed funds in New York. Among the names was mine (just a couple names down from a Susan A. Sarandon).

title: Mugabe Lends Ahmadinejad His Support
description: Video from Zimbabwe on Thursday showed Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Robert Mugabe, two presidents who remain in office despite claims from opponents that they engaged in electoral fraud, enter a news conference hand in hand at the start of a state visit by Iranian officials to a country with untapped uranium deposits.

title: Anatomy of an At-Bat: Braun vs. McCutchen
description: With two runners on in the third inning of Thursday afternoons game between Milwaukee and Pittsburgh, Pirates pitcher Daniel McCutchen seemed determined to pitch around Brewers slugger Ryan Braun. Unfortunately for McCutchen, no matter how hard you try to pitch around Braun, he just keeps swinging.

title: Screen Test | Rebecca Hall
description: The actress from "Vicky Cristina Barcelona" on her theatrical family, auditioning for Woody Allen and the ups and downs of being tall.

title: Stravinskys Identity: Dont Pin Him Down
description: To the Editor:

title: State Decision Blocks Drilling for Gas in Catskills
description: New York State environmental officials announced on Friday that they would impose far stricter regulations on a controversial type of natural gas drilling in the upstate area that supplies most of New York Citys drinking water, making it highly unlikely that any drilling would be done there.

title: Why Dwell on Race?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Diet of Brutality
description: To the Editor:

title: Movies and Violence: Rethinking Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Alexandra Lammers and Eric Hoyle
description: BY age 12, Alexandra Victoria Lammers knew how to bake bread from scratch, braid a horses mane, pin a kilt and set a dinner table correctly.

title: Real Violence vs. Fake
description: To the Editor:

title: From Natalie Merchant, a Literary Tour
description: The byline for an article last Sunday about the singer Natalie Merchant was omitted. It was by Jon Pareles.

title: A Value-Added Tax and the Poor
description: Bruce Bartlett is more worried about middle-class and poor families not paying taxes than I am. But his latest Forbes column  about a value-added tax, or VAT  makes an important point:

title: Relationships and Other Possessions
description: MORE than most title sequences, the opening shots in Nicole Holofceners Please Give forecast what kind of movie it will be. There they are: breasts.

title: A Tiny Piece of Hell's Kitchen
description: Jonathan Cerullo moved into a 348-square-foot apartment in a century-old tenement on West 47th Street in Hells Kitchen in 1985.

title: At City Ballet, Sweating Many Firsts
description: THE choreographer Christopher Wheeldon strode into a New York City Ballet studio one recent afternoon for the first rehearsal of a new work. As an accompanist played the opening melody, he read the young principal dancer Tiler Peck a few notes about the 1941 Ginastera score Estancia, involving romance, horse wrangling and ranch culture.

title: Drilling All but Ruled Out in New York Citys Watershed
description: New York state environmental officials have decided that new regulations governing a controversial method of natural gas drilling will not apply to the states only two unfiltered water supplies. Instead, far stricter ones will be in force.

title: Tinkering With Taco Night
description: A few years ago the satirical newspaper The Onion ran an open letter from a father to son, chiding him for making a mockery out of Taco Night.

title: Complaint Box | Horns and Drivers
description: I have a burning question for those clueless, self-absorbed troglodytes who honk their horns in residential neighborhoods. Why, because the person in front of you doesnt move within a millisecond of a green light, do you feel that slamming your jarring, piercing horn does anything other than upset everyone else in the vicinity  particularly those whose right to the quiet enjoyment of their residential premises is being violated?

title: Absent Grandparents
description: One of the many complicated questions raised by Abbie Dorns haunting story yesterday was what rights her parents have under the law. They are the grandparents in this case, asking for visitation on their daughters behalf. Lawyers for their former son-in-law argued that they had no legal standing, but a judge ruled otherwise.

title: Obama Slams Arizonas Immigration Bill
description: President Obama on Friday strongly criticized restrictive immigration legislation pending in Arizona, calling for a federal overhaul of the nations laws instead.

title: One Mans Trash . . .
description: Working with a patient he calls Debra, a compulsive hoarder, the psychologist Randy O. Frost tried a simple experiment. Frost proposed sending Debra a postcard, blank but for the name and address. Debras assignment was to throw it away.

title: Parent Hood
description: The set-up of Peter Hedges third novel, The Heights, is classic and promising. An attractive young couple, married with children, are roused from their quotidian rounds of diapers-and-drop-offs when a rich, beautiful stranger comes to town  town, in this case, being the mediacentric, well-heeled, aesthetically unbeatable Brooklyn Heights, where the husband teaches history at an exclusive academy a lot like St. Anns. Private school, real estate, a marriage at risk: what more could anyone want?

title: Tebows Draft Magic
description: Perhaps the best news from the first day of the N.F.L. draft Thursday was that Florida quarterback Tim Tebow was selected in the first round, sparing us from hearing about him for the next two days.

title: Dress Like You Care
description: These style-conscious pieces will make you feel pretty on the inside.

title: Zipcar Expands in Europe
description: Car-sharing companies, which sign up members who pay fees for access to strategically located fleets, are clearly on a roll.

title: On Our Radar: Tracking Asian Monsoons
description: Using tree rings, scientists chart Asian monsoons back to the Middle Ages and link the collapse of the Ming dynasty to drought.

title: Reclaiming the Blood of the Havasupai
description: Blood Journey (06:02)

title: Does H. Sapiens Need a New Tune?
description: The day after the 40th Earth Day is a good moment to revisit music of this sphere and ponder whether humans should start singing a new tune about forging a more durable relationship with their home planet. I love the music of the 20th-century environmental movement. No song captures the spirit of that era better than Tom Paxtons Whose Garden Was this?

title: Fleas Hither and Thither
description: On Saturday, fleas come to Manhattan.

title: McDaniels Has Great Faith in Tebows Talents
description: In 2007, Josh McDaniels was the prepubescent looking offensive coordinator who steered the New England Patriots offense, the most explosive the N.F.L. had ever seen. The Patriots dragged the spread into the N.F.L. spotlight, a scheme that McDaniels admitted he stole largely from the University of Florida, where his long-time friend Urban Meyer has dominated the college game.

title: Letter: Italys Home Cooks
description: To the Editor: Regarding Mangia, Mangia! (April 11): So good to see Italys home cooks  mostly women behind the scenes in Italys homes  finally getting the recognition they deserve! In a world where five-star chefs and celebrity chefs often get most of the attention, this is a refreshing article.

title: Letter: A Fictional Mauritius
description: To the Editor: Regarding Mauritius Dreaming (April 4): To transport oneself to the island of Mauritius, read The Prospector (Le Chercheur dOr), a novel by the Nobel laureate J. M. G. Le Clzio, who has dual French and Mauritian citizenship. (His French father was born on Mauritius.) The protagonist of the story grows up on Mauritius and later travels to the nearby island of Rodrigues in a quest for treasure.

title: A Mysterious Service From Cable, Part II
description: Yesterday, in my weekly e-mail column (sign up here: nytimes.com/email), and in this blog, I wrote about the explosion of free WiFi hot spots for home cable-Internet customers. I wrote that I love these developments, but just cant figure out why the cable companies are going to all this expense. Surely, I wrote, this must be a big preemptive move to ward off  something.

title: Correction: 36 Hours in Sydney
description: The 36 Hours column on April 11, about Sydney, Australia, misstated the location of a mens clothing store. As the article noted, Halfsleeve is at 133 Goulburn Street. But the store is in the basement of the Mark Foys Warehouse, now converted to apartments known as Sydney Mansions. It is not in the Griffiths Teas Building across the street. And because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to the airline service between Sydney and New York City. Some flights between the two cities require a layover, not a connecting flight.

title: Swapping Old Duds for a Good Cause
description: For years Orli Cotel, a spokeswoman for the Sierra Club and host of the nationally syndicated show Sierra Club Radio, hosted clothing swaps as a way to freshen up her wardrobe for free and recycle clothes among her friends.

title: Beijing Auto Show: Ford Start Concept
description: Ford introduced its Start Concept urban car Friday morning at the Beijing auto show. With China emerging as the worlds hottest and most congested automotive market, Beijing seems an obvious choice for the automaker to show off a vehicle that features its lightweight materials and EcoBoost engine technology.

title: A Euro-Style David vs. Minivan Goliaths
description: SOME cars just make sense. But that doesnt mean Americans will like them.

title: Smile on Your Face. Bugs in Your Teeth.
description: THE Ariel Atom 3 has the performance of a Ferrari, the style of a Formula racecar and all the luxuries of a Razor scooter.

title: A Modest Car for a Man of Means
description: THE glossy catalogs thunking into mailboxes in the weeks before a major collector-car auction have been known to reduce sober adults to drooling daydreamers. I know this from experience.

title: Spreading That Secure Feeling
description: FORD and General Motors arent the only automakers offering interactive entertainment and crash-reporting systems. In fact, G.M.s OnStar was initially licensed to other automakers, including Acura, Audi, Isuzu, Lexus, Subaru and Volkswagen, but it is now exclusive to G.M. and its former Saab brand.

title: Two Paths to Similar Ends for In-Car Data Systems
description: THE idea that the first call to a 911 operator after a traffic accident would be placed by one of the cars involved, rather than a witness, was once the stuff of science fiction.

title: M.I.T. Economist Wins John Bates Clark Medal
description: Esther Duflo

title: The First Coach
description: Your new memoir, A Game of Character, opens in a small apartment on Euclid Avenue on the South Side of Chicago, where you and your kid sister, Michelle, shared a bedroom until high school and indulged in a good deal of ribbing. You say she used to tease you about being a goody-two-shoes. She had some other stuff. She was always worried that I would go out and not know how to dance or talk to girls and that kind of thing, so she wanted to make sure I was schooled well from that standpoint.

title: Two Chicks Very Ready to Make Music
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: From Jameson to Fela Kuti, Preshow Rites of a Soul Band
description: SHARON JONES is, as the saying goes, the real deal. A 5-foot-1 vocal powerhouse who has been nicknamed the Queen of Funk, Ms. Jones, 53, grew up singing at home in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, in church and in local bands. But professional success in music eluded her; for a time she worked as a prison guard at Rikers Island, where the inmates would sometimes make requests. Now, as the leader of the Dap-Kings, the house band of the Brooklyn record label Daptone, Ms. Jones is the epitome of the soul revival. I Learned the Hard Way, the fourth album by Sharon Jones & the Dap-Kings, which entered the Billboard album chart at No. 15 this month, earned praise for staying true to the analog grit of its predecessors. Ms. Jones still lives with her mother in a public housing in Far Rockaway, Queens, a rough area she escapes by going fishing in the Delaware Water Gap. In an interview in the waiting room of her ear, nose and throat doctor  Ms. Jones needed a checkup before a European tour  she and Neal Sugarman, a Dap-King saxophonist and a founder of Daptone, talked about the musicians they draw inspiration from, like Otis Redding and Etta James, and their recently upgraded life on tour. After years of buying her own vintage dresses, Ms. Jones now has a stage wardrobe that comes courtesy of the designers Trina Turk and Minna. And the shoes she dances up a storm in? Payless, she stage-whispered. Dont tell anyone.

title: Ahab Sings! (The Whale Does Not)
description: SEEKING adventure may mean looking for trouble, but how much trouble did you have in mind? Five years ago, when the Dallas Opera began planning its move to the luxurious new Winspear Opera House, the companys artistic director, Jonathan Pell, approached the composer Jake Heggie to commission an opera for the inaugural season, with all the risks such a project entailed. Not missing a beat Mr. Heggie told him, I want to set Moby-Dick.

title: More Scrutiny of Lawyers in Deals Gone Bad
description: After the Securities and Exchange Commission accused Stephen J. Czarnik, a securities lawyer, of facilitating an illegal pump-and-dump investment scheme, Mr. Czarniks lawyer filed a vigorous defense brief in Manhattan federal court two weeks ago.

title: Anchors Dont Come in Pretty Boxes
description: DURING my wedding my best friends house burned down. Dylan and her boyfriend, Clay, had anticipated their homes combustion; wildfires had been raging for days in the mountains east of Tucson where they lived. As my wedding drew near, they packed their VW bus with Dylans bridesmaid dress, their dog, laptops and photographs, and drove cross-country to East Hampton, N.Y., where, during the festivities, they monitored events back home by phone.

title: Advice from Yale Mom for an Applicant with a Choice
description: Those of you who stumbled on The Choice soon after its inception last spring may remember Nicholas Geiser. He was a high school senior from San Francisco who wrote for our blog about a perfect batting average: he was accepted to all 12 colleges to which he applied, and ultimately chose Yale over Harvard and a prestigious Morehead-Cain Scholarship at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.

title: TimesCast | April 23, 2010
description: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Friday.  Topics include finding the votes for financial regulation, Jon Stewart takes on Fox and Hollywood wants a natural look.

title: Can Big Food Fight Fat?
description: Two articles in the current American Journal of Public Health (links via Marion Nestles piecehere) discuss the potentially constructive role of Big Food in improving global diet.

title: King Tut in New York
description: Images from two exhibitions of King Tut artifacts.

title: You Can Judge a Book by Its Movie
description: MADISON, Wis.

title: We Made It Ourselves | Mom-and-Pop Pop
description: Theres something comforting and delightful about a classic soda fountain. Thats what Anton Nocito thinks, and his dream is to open one in New York City. Hes starting small with homemade soda.

title: Draft Q.& A. With Mike Tanier (Questions)
description: Mike Tanier, an analyst for footballoutsiders.com and a contributor to the Fifth Down, took readers questions about the N.F.L. draft and answered them here. Look for his insight and analysis on Rounds 2 and 3 of the draft, delivered with a joke or two, Friday night on the Fifth Down. He wrote about Tim Tebow after he was picked by the Denver Broncos on Thursday:

title: Inside the List
description: POISON PEN: Oprah, the latest biography from the celebrity-slayer Kitty Kelley, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1. Readers scanning the lengthy index for dirt on Leo Tolstoy, William Faulkner and other authors featured in the classics phase of Oprahs Book Club will be disappointed, though there is an entry for Alice B. Toklas. Kelley also quotes the terse note that her subject sent to the publisher Nan Talese, after Talese endured a painful televised browbeating over the fabrications in James Freys memoir A Million Little Pieces. Dear Nan, the note read. Thanks for being on the show. Sincerely, Oprah. Apparently, she was following a tip from Bill Clinton, who likes to write single-page letters suitable for framing.

title: Editors Choice
description: SOLAR,  by Ian McEwan (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $26.95.) In McEwans funniest novel yet, a self-deluding physicist cheats on his wives, sends an innocent man to jail and tries to cash in on another scientists plans against global warming.

title: Levines Operation Deemed a Success
description: James Levines manager, Ronald Wilford, said his client was released from the hospital on Wednesday after lower back surgery and never looked better. He said the operation had been enormously successful and that despite a series of canceled performances recently, Mr. Levine still hoped to conduct at the Tanglewood Festival this summer. He wants to come back to conducting as quickly as possible, but he doesnt want to screw it up, Mr. Wilford said in a telephone interview. Hes really frustrated.

title: Letterman: Kind of Perplexing
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: You know, a lot of people were flying and got delayed by the Icelandic volcano, and everybody is upset. They lost billions of dollars in revenue. And I said, O.K., its kind of their fault. I mean to be flying during the volcano season, come on! Are you nuts? Really? Your own fault.

title: Bombings in Iraq Follow Killing of Militant Chiefs
description: Officials said 12 bombs killed dozens of people in a series of attacks in Baghdad and western Iraq that came days after two top insurgents were killed.

title: Leno: An Obama-Themed Nightclub
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: Happy Earth Day. To demonstrate their commitment, environmentalists all across the country risked their lives driving Priuses.

title: Tech Entrepreneurs Share Sentiments in Therapy That Arent Fit for Twitter
description: It was true confession time at Founder Therapy, a monthly support group for tech entrepreneurs in the new Silicon Alley, and a 27-year-old man in a red-striped T-shirt had a doozy.

title: Why Women Find Their Parents Unpleasant
description: I recently received a copy of Wellbeing: The Five Essential Elements in the mail. The book, published by Gallup Press, is a readable digest of survey data and academic research on what makes people happy and what makes them unhappy. To the uninitiated in this subject, you may find that the things you think make people happy are, in the words of the books authors, misguided or just plain wrong.

title: Adoption and Loss, From Three Angles
description: JUDGING from a quick spin through the adoption-related movies listed on the Internet Movie Database, where the roster includes titles like Broken Promises: Taking Emily Back and Dwarf Family Adoption, its easy to conclude that popular culture tends to approach the subject as either tragically sad or slightly weird.

title: When Over-Sharing Leads to Problems
description: 2:59 p.m. | Updated  Added Blippys explanation on its Web site of what went wrong.

title: Jorda Piskuloska, Christopher Eilert
description: Jorda Piskuloska and Christopher W. Eilert were married Friday evening at Most Sacred Heart of Jesus Church in Wallington, N.J. The Very Rev. Felix R. Marciniak, a Roman Catholic priest and the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Steven D. DAndrea, the churchs parochial vicar, taking part.

title: Not Afraid to Follow the Money
description: WHAT do Eliot Spitzer, Ken Kesey, Lance Armstrong, sumo wrestling, Al Qaeda and the imprisoned lobbyist Jack Abramoff have in common? Theyre all subjects of Alex Gibney films being released in 2010.

title: In Turf Battle, City Cedes to Ball Players
description: The tennis bubble at Queensboro Ovalwill be removed in May, paving the way for a return of the softball and baseball leagues that nearly lost their summertime fields.

title: Change in Experiment Will Delay Shuttles End
description: A $1.5 billion seven-ton cosmic-ray experiment scheduled to be carried aloft July 29 on the space shuttle Endeavour wont be ready until August, according to the experiments leader, Samuel Ting of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, delaying the end of the 29-year-old shuttle program.

title: Race Pays Off for Producers
description: The Broadway production of David Mamets play Race has earned back its initial investment of about $2.5 million after five months of performances this season, the producers announced this week. It is one of a handful of commercial plays this season to have recouped the investment spent on mounting the productions on Broadway.

title: Uncollected Poems': Subtitle as Oxymoron
description: We are easily amused. Thus, titles like James Schuylers Other Flowers: Uncollected Poems, reviewed this weekend in the Book Review, elicit chuckles. (Which is not to say anything bad about the book itself; Stephen Burt, our reviewer, has only high praise.)

title: Whaling Peace Plan Just Less of the Same?
description: On Earth Day, the leadership of the International Whaling Commission issued a long-discussed proposal for a peace plan aimed at reining in expanding whale hunts by Japan, Norway and Iceland that have, in various ways, skirted the longstanding moratorium on commercial whaling.

title: F.D.A. Steps Up Oversight of Infusion Pumps
description: Federal regulators say they are moving to tighten their oversight of medical devices, including one of the most ubiquitous and problematic pieces of medical equipment  automated pumps that intravenously deliver drugs, food and other solutions to patients.

title: Beijing Auto Show: BMW Gran Coup Concept
description: BMW introduced a new tweener sedan concept at this weeks auto show in Beijing, a design study that hints at how far the brand thinks it can push its styling without giving up its signature elements. Called the Gran Coup, it would slot into BMWs lineup between the 5 Series and 7 Series.

title: Book Review Podcast: Biographies of Henry Luce and Muriel Spark
description: This week: Alan Brinkley discusses the life of Henry Luce, creator of the Time-Life magazine empire; Charles McGrath talks about a biography of the author Muriel Spark; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: TimesCast: Financial Legislation
description: One day after President Obama addressed some of the nations most influential bankers on the need for a new financial regulatory structure, lawmakers in Congress are battling over the details of the overhaul bill.

title: Top Senators on Finance Bill to Meet  on Sunday Talk Show
description: The fate of the big financial regulation legislation is largely in the hands of two chief negotiators: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, the chairman of the banking committee, and Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, the panels senior Republican.

title: Divac Selected to Lead Serbian Olympic Committee
description: Former N.B.A. star center Vlade Divac has had many titles in his career: All-star, two-time Olympic silver medalist, two-time world champion, savvy flopper, basketball ambassador.

title: Milan Report | Pull Up a Chair
description: Last week, in spite of the volcanic ash cloud, Milan was abuzz with design, both at the furniture fair and at the many exhibitions outside it. There was plenty to see, and to sit on. Chairs were somewhat more restrained than in recent years, and there was a strong bent toward practicality, with a liberal sprinkling of eco-friendliness. But beauty, and even whimsy, was also on the menu. Here are a few of The Moments favorites.

title: Cleveland Groups Team Up to Offer Stravinsky and Vonnegut
description: The Cleveland Play House, the Cleveland Orchestra, and GroundWorks DanceTheater have undertaken an unusual collaboration this weekend to present a new production of Stravinskys Soldiers Tale, which includes a libretto by Kurt Vonnegut Jr. that sets the work during World War II.

title: Just a Moment: Photographing Ordinary Life
description: Overview | What if hundreds of people around the world took pictures at the same moment and uploaded them to one digital album? The New York Timess Lens blog has invited people to submit photos taken at the same time on Sunday, May 2, 2010. In this lesson, students look at and critique Times reader-submitted photos that capture a moment and/or express a theme. They then do a trial run for A Moment in Time, create a presentation of their images and prepare to participate in and/or view and assess the May 2 event.

title: Chelsea, 10:49 A.M.
The Amazing Jason Pierre-Paul
description: Youve probably read a lot about Jason Pierre-Paul and his amazing athletic ability. But if youve yet to witness it, heres the YouTube video everyone has been talking about.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Friday Night Lights, Peter Martins, Nicole Holofcener and More
description: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Financial Tuneup: Treat Giving Like Saving
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: China Asks Monks to Leave Quake Area
description: BEIJING  Chinese authorities confirmed Friday reports that they had asked Buddhist monks to end their relief work in Qinghai, the province in central Chinas highlands where an earthquake last week left at least 2,187 people dead.

title: What is the New Age of Travel?
description: The Icelandic volcano that disrupted global air travel last week raised a concern: should we be thinking of alternative ways to move masses of people and goods? Read more.

title: Global Culture: A Scholars View
description: To the Editor:

title: Donor Takes Aim at Espada
description: As investigators continue looking into the business and political dealings of Pedro Espada Jr., the Senate majority leader, a top Democratic donor announced Friday that he planned to direct as much as $250,000 toward defeating Mr. Espada in this years election.

title: For Jamie Dimon, a Sinking Feeling About Housing
description: Think the real estate bust has been tough for everyone? Just ask Jamie Dimon.

title: Former Officer Testifies in Bicyclist-Shoving Case
description: Ever since a videotape of a police officer knocking a man off of his bicycle in Times Square surfaced on the Internet two years ago, people have asked the same question: What was the officer thinking? The cyclist did appear, after all, to be veering away from the officer, trying to avoid a collision.

title: Forecast Says China Provides Opportunities and Competition
description: A new five-year forecast by J.D. Power and Associates anticipates a 55 percent growth for the automotive market in China by 2015, with sales of passenger vehicles  defined as cars, sport utility vehicles and minivans  expected to increase from 8.7 million in 2009 to 13.5 million in 2015.

title: Draft Q.& A. With Mike Tanier (Answers)
description: Mike Tanier, an analyst for footballoutsiders.com and a contributor to the Fifth Down, answered readers questions Friday afternoon about the N.F.L. draft. Look for his insight and analysis on Rounds 2 and 3 of the draft, delivered with a joke or two, Friday night on the Fifth Down.

title: Book Review Podcast: Biographies of Henry Luce and Muriel Spark
description: This week: Alan Brinkley discusses the life of Henry Luce, creator of the Time-Life magazine empire; Charles McGrath talks about a biography of the author Muriel Spark; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Bling Around the Collar
description: Something borrowed, something old, something new  the only thing missing from this one-off necklace ($2,900) by Marsha Chun-Matsubara (her fledgling label is called Abakus) is something blue. Unicorn Disco, inspired by a clients old necklace, is made of vintage aluminum disks from Germany, bubble pearls, antique copper mesh, fake coral, rhinestone buttons and snakeskin printed beads. It reminds me of something by Miriam Haskell, Chun-Matsubara says, but turbocharged. Go to abakuscollection.com for information.

title: Beamalot
description: Video | Now for something completely different with Kirk and Spock:

title: Living in Queens Plaza
description: Once known for its strip clubs, the area just over the Queensboro Bridge is slowly gaining an identity as a place to live and work.

title: Arizona Enacts Stringent Law on Immigration
description: PHOENIX  Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona signed the nations toughest bill on illegal immigration into law on Friday. Its aim is to identify, prosecute and deport illegal immigrants.

title: Lehman Moves to Disallow Nomura Claims
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings, the bankruptcy estate of the failed investment bank, moved to dismiss more than $1 billion worth of creditor claims by Nomura of Japan, arguing that they are vastly overstated.

title: Welcome to Queens. Please Stay Awhile.
description: QUEENS PLAZA has the distinction of being the gateway to Queens, a travelers first sight after alighting from Manhattan via the Queensboro Bridge. But that is not to say it has always been a sparkling example of a hospitable welcome.

title: A Popular U.S. Export: The $100 Bill
description: ONE of the most successful export businesses in the United States is run by the government, which produces a product for a small fraction of the price that people will pay for it.

title: Profiting From Distressed Homes
description: Upper Brookville

title: How to Opt Out of Facebooks Instant Personalization
description: This week, Facebook introduced the open graph, a giant expansion of the social graph concept on which Facebook is built. The word open alone should be a tip-off that there are significant new privacy issues to weigh.

title: Awake, Wall Street
description: Barry Ritholtz has a good post on the Goldman Sachs case. In it he describes Robert Khuzami, the former prosecutor now running the S.E.C.s enforcement division:

title: In Manhattan, Rents Are Creeping Back Up
description: ONE month free!

title: Fresh Pencils, Books, and Free Computers
description: Nearly 20,000 sixth graders who attend low-income schools will receive free computers beginning in September, thanks to a $22 million federal grant meant to increase broadband access in New York City.

title: With Impact Investing, a Focus on More Than Returns
description: The very phrase impact investing sounds rapacious, but it is an emerging hybrid of philanthropy and private equity that proponents say is about to become more widespread. It is also something that has some very rich people intrigued.

title: A New Crop of Rental Units Hits the Market
description: ROUGHLY 1,500 rental units are gradually being rolled onto the northern New Jersey market starting this spring. One large new building in Hoboken will start leasing this week; several other apartment complexes in both cities and suburbs have opened or are about to, and two tall rental towers are being readied to open early in 2011.

title: Now Online | T Womens Fashion Summer 2010
description: Its all about  undone beauty, starring our cover girl, the actress Rebecca Hall, who channels Horses-era Patti Smith to capture the seasons effortless style. Speaking of undone, we present a portfolio of beauties  from Karen O to Greta Gerwig  for whom messy is more, revisit Bettina Rheimss bare beauties, explore the history of nude fashion and bring you up to date on the latest in dry shampoos and wispy fragrances. Chanel makeup artist Peter Philips performs a surreal reveal, hair star Guido Palau picks his favorite products and Anjelica Huston talks about her favorite scent (hint: it isnt Joy). Susan Campos combs through Hollywoods secret hair-restoration club, Daphne Merkin dreams of life as a Real Housewife  complacent husband and all, and Guy Trebay reveals the naked truth about todays models.

title: For the Sweet-Toothed, Cocktails and Cake
description: UPON entering the Red Velvet Lounge on the Lower East Side, one cant help but notice a rather grave Marie Antoinette and Louis XVI watching over everyone  not exactly the usual faces seen out and about on a Saturday night. The hand-painted ceiling features the distinguished duos larger-than-life portraits hovering over the crowd in a let-them-eat-cake tribute to liquor-laced cupcakes.

title: Kenneth D. Levien
description: Mr. Levien, 58, is a founder and principal of Levien & Company, a real estate project manager based in New York.

title: Era Ends as Chevrolet Account Drives Off to Publicis
description: One of the longest relationships between an advertiser and an agency is ending after 96 years as the Chevrolet division of General Motors cuts its remaining ties with Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: N.F.L. Draft: What Were They Thinking?
description: A surprising number of teams spent their first-round pick on a position that, going into the draft, seemed already to be filled. These moves are always intriguing. Sometimes theyre a result of a team following the best player available drafting model. But usually, its a team saying, Fans might like the players we already have at this position, but we sure dont.

title: Tour of TECO
description: Coal mining carries inherent risks. But the TECO Coal Corporation, operator of the E3-1 mine in Hazard, Ky., places a high priority on mine safety.

title: Love and Writing
description: The great Marisa Silver, guest-blogging last week at The Elegant Variation, offered a short but valuable list of Advice for the Lovelorn  I Mean Writers, in which she applied relationship lessons to literature. Among her tips: Get lost. Be scared. Have no idea where youre headed.

title: Bias Accord as Harbinger
description: A DECISION this month by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to drop its racial-discrimination lawsuit against Wells Fargo in exchange for a say in reviewing its lending practices could set the stage for similar agreements with other big mortgage lenders, some experts say.

title: A Condo in the Thick of Things
description: AS soon as Joy and Brian J. Pape moved into their one-bedroom co-op in Manhattan, they wanted out.

title: Pocket-Sized on West 47th Street
description: SOME of the multitudes who saw an early touring production of Cats in the mid-1980s might remember an exuberant orange tabby called Skimbleshanks. The character was played by a 20-something dancer named Jonathan Cerullo, swathed from ears to tail in yak hair.

title: Sketching Lives Long Buried and Forgotten
description: The drawing is nearly devoid of detail. It shows a vague-faced man in a suit, ripped from context, leaning his hand up against nothing.

title: The Swimming Pool
description: I

title: Rural UConn Is a University in Want of a Town
description: STORRS

title: Durbin, Too, Gets Blagojevich Subpoena
description: Senator Richard J. Durbin told reporters on Friday that he has been subpoenaed to testify in former Illinois Gov. Rod R. Blagojevichs upcoming corruption trial, according to news media reports.

title: A Kitchen, and Filmmaker, With Soul
description: The name Fatih Akin is not likely the first that comes to mind when thinking of jovial movie comedies. His 2004 film Head On dealt with two strangers with suicidal tendencies, and 2007s The Edge of Heaven was a serious exploration of the generational and geographical distances between parents and children. Mr. Akin goes in a different direction with Soul Kitchen, a lighter look at the frenetic life of a restaurant owner in Hamburg, Germany.

title: The Morning Skate: Sympathy for the Devils
description: There is much talk around the Devils today of how disappointed players are (Rich Chere in The Star-Ledger quotes many of them), and how equally disappointed many of the fans are (like blogger John Fischer of In Lou We Trust), how much more everyone expected from a team whose cornerstones are Hall of Famers Lou Lamoriello and Jacques Lemaire and future Hall of Fame goalie Martin Brodeur.

title: Objects of Accumulation
description: People spend the first half of their lives accumulating stuff and the last half getting rid of it. Thats the story of eBay. And of my parents  except for the getting-rid-of-it part. If their life were a Frank Capra movie, it would be called You Cant Throw It Away. Or, in the language of reality TV: Hoarders: Rubber-Band and Rotary-Phone Edition. Which is great if you want to put your hands on that lifelike machine gun you had when you were 9. But not so great when it comes time to sell the house.

title: Mind Over Meds
description: One day several years ago, I was reaching the end of my first visit with a patient, J.J., who had come to see me for anxiety and insomnia. He was a salesman for a struggling telecommunications company, and he was having trouble managing the strain on his finances and his family. He was sleeping poorly, and as soon as he opened his eyes in the early morning, the worries began. I wake up with a list of things to worry about, he said. I just go through the list, and it seems to get longer every day.

title: Hitting Rewind on the Cassette Tape
description: Over the last couple of years, sales of vinyl records increased; the numbers arent huge, but they sparked a lot of public musing about the formats qualities. Cassette sales, meanwhile, steadily dwindled to a mere 34,000 last year through the retail venues tracked by SoundScan. Considering this not long ago, I concluded that the romance associated with vinyl doesnt apply to its longtime analog rival. I was wrong about that. In looking (and asking) around online, I realize now that there is extensive evidence of ongoing appreciation for the cassette  or at least the idea of the cassette.

title: Cracked Foundation: Reforming Housing Finance
description: Timothy Geithner, a man whose taste for Kierkegaard is usually kept under wraps, recently held forth to the House Financial Services Committee on the central, existential question that is facing America or, at the very least, that is facing its reform of housing finance. The Treasury secretary is bedeviled over what to do with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the bailed-out mortgage giants that have cost the taxpayers upward of $125 billion with as yet no end in sight. Shutting them down is not so easy because  get ready for this  since their bailout, in September 2008, Fannie and Freddie have become more, not less, important to the U.S. housing market. At present, 9 of every 10 new mortgages are sold to, or guaranteed by, arms of the U.S. government, the majority of them to Fannie and Freddie. Which is to say, without Uncle Sam, it is not clear that the private market for housing would even exist.

title: Lost in Translation
description: On a recent Tuesday, Twitter crackled with anticipation. A significant episode of Lost, the eerie long-running TV series about plane-crash survivors on a haunted island, was coming up. A Twitterer called dmaul53854 announced his plans to lift weights and get ready for some #Lost awesomeness! using the pound sign to create a tag to make his tweet easier to find. Happy #LOST day! wrote peterkz. Macarolribeiro tested her character allowance: #LOSTDAY!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!! Lost!!!

title: Existential Crisis of a Plastic Bag
description: An 18-minute film chronicling the life of a plastic bag has gone viral on the Internet.

title: Post-Debate Spin in British Newspapers
description: British newspapers are known for many things, but the impulse to hide their political views under a bushel of subtlety is not among them. For Americans taught that newspapers are supposed to be impartial in their news pages, a headline like The Cam Back Kid, which adorned the front page of The Sun on Friday  hailing the Conservative leader David Camerons victory in the tabloids own poll of viewers of Thursdays televised debate  might seem to err on the side of editorializing. On the newspapers Web site, readers were shown a huge photograph of Mr. Cameron downing a celebratory pint of beer, to celebrate bouncing back in style to win the second party leaders debate.

title: Now Screening | Take It Off!
description: The photographers Coppi Barbieri made this video, Nude, to coincide with the T Womens Fashion Summer 2010 issue, the theme of which is undone beauty. As youll see, model Adela Capova comes undone beautifully.

title: BlogTalk: Prayer and Immigration
description: Two topics buzzing through the blogs today concern the Armys decision to disinvite the Rev. Franklin Graham, son of the evangelist Billy Graham, to lead the services at the National Day of Prayer event at the Pentagon next month, and President Obama criticizing Arizonas pending immigration legislation.

title: 13 Bankers
description: Introduction

title: Ford Joins the App Generation
description: If you cant stop them, link to them. That is the approach Ford is taking to the use of smartphones in the car. Later this year, the automaker will introduce software that allows applications, like Pandora and Twitter, to be used with cellphones connected to its in-car Sync systems (a topic that is covered in an article in Sundays Automobiles section).

title: Cat Disposal
description: Our neighbor has 10 cats that live outdoors and make our yard a constant target for defecation (which is illegal). We often step in cat feces and fear our toddler will catch parasites. Our neighbor will not address this problem. The township will fine him but not remove the cats. We tried cat repellents, including coyote-urine powder and a motion-detecting sprinkler. None helped. We now plan to take the cats to a shelter (legally), where they will likely be euthanized eventually. This saddens us, but havent we done all we can? S. F., ARDMORE,PA.

title: Comments of the Week: iPhonegate, Privacy and Facebook
description: As the week comes to a closeiPhonegate continues to captivate the country; stores remain closed, truckers cant buygasoline, life is essentially at a standstill  O.K., it didnt really captivate the country, but the missing iPhone did make it onto almost every major media outlet, including Good Morning America and Late Show With David Letterman. Still, in the nerdosphere, the debate continues among technologist and gadget blogs. But what did commenters on The Times Web site think? Manybelieved that the entire production was just another Apple publicity stunt.

title: An Online Alias Keeps Colleges Off Their Trail
description: TO the list of the typical high school rites of passage  first crush, first kiss, first pimple  technology may be adding a ritual: changing your name.

title: The Moviegoer | At the Tribeca Film Festival
description: The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

title: Reyes to Bat Third in New Lineup
description: Manager Jerry Manuel unveiled his promised new lineup on Friday afternoon, and it has Jose Reyes batting third, the first time Reyes has not been in the leadoff spot since July 5, 2005.

title: Corrections
description: The Remarkable Creatures column on March 23, about sex determination in marine reptiles, referred imprecisely to sea snakes and their behavior. While true sea snakes, or Hydrophiidae, spend their entire lives in water and all bear live young, not all sea snakes do so. A few species return to land to lay eggs.

title: Zipcar Expands to London and Beyond
description: Zipcar members will soon be able to cross the Atlantic and unlock a fleet of cars parked throughout London and other cities in England.

title: What Were Reading: Recycled Toilet Paper
Omnivore Returns to New York
description: Last year, the French culinary organization Omnivore held its first festival in New York. On Friday, the group released details of an expanded and more ambitious event to be held June 4 and 5. This one is to be split between Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: Cool, Green or Both?
description: In this article, adapted from Sexy and Good: Sustainable Product Design, which appeared in the Fall/Winter 2009/2010 issue of the Harvard Design Magazine, the T columnist and International Herald Tribune design critic Alice Rawsthorn discusses the design and ecological pros and cons of nine products.

title: Nice Guy Eddie: 15 Years of Film Festivals With Edward Burns
description: Is it really a film festival if Edward Burns isnt there? Since his debut feature, The Brothers McMullen, broke through at the Sundance Film Festival in 1995, Mr. Burns has become a frequent presence at the Tribeca Film Festival, where his directorial efforts like Ash Wednesday, Looking For Kitty and Purple Violets have made their debuts. In the years between, hes also acted in films like Saving Private Ryan and as a fictional version of himself on the HBO comedy Entourage. This year hes back at Tribeca with Nice Guy Johnny, about a young man (Matt Bush) pulled between two paths in life and two women, and his miscreant uncle (Mr. Burns) trying to help his decision-making process.

title: Answers About Transgender Issues, Part 3
description: Following is the third and final set of responses from Dr. Laura Erickson-Schroth, who is working on Trans Bodies, Trans Selves, a resource guide for transgender and other gender-variant people, covering health, legal issues, cultural and social questions, history and theory.

title: Pictures of the Day: Baghdad and Elsewhere
description: Religious violence erupted in numerous places around the world on Friday, most grievously in Baghdad. Karim Kadim  a member of the Associated Press team that won the 2005 Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography  was on the scene and took the first three pictures in todays report; an unusual presence for a single photographer on any given day.

title: Pakistani Soldiers Killed in Ambush
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  Pakistani militants ambushed a military convoy in the North Waziristan area of northern Pakistan on Thursday, killing seven soldiers and wounding 16 others in the deadliest attack on the military in months.

title: Halston, the Life of the Party
description: Halston was the party monsters party monster, the Emperor of Studio 54, until the excesses of his life finally did him in. And now he is the subject of a new documentary, Ultrasuede: In Search of Halston, one of the most anticipated films at this years Tribeca Film Festival.

title: A Private Spat, With a Very Public Apology
description: Updated, Saturday, 8:19 p.m. | There is considerable evidence that this is a hoax. Jeff Ragsdale has worked as a comedian and actor, and his work sometimes involves blurring lines between reality and performance.

title: The Show-Book of the World': Henry Luces Life Magazine Prospectus
description: Below is a rather extraordinary document: Henry Luces prospectus for what would become Life magazine. According to Alan Brinkleys biography of Luce, The Publisher, which The Timess executive editor, Bill Keller, reviews in this Sundays Book Review:

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 23
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Brief Getaway in Asheville for the Obamas
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C.  Well, President Obama can check this campaign promise off the list at least. While running for president, he camped out in this scenic small city surrounded by the Blue Ridge Mountains in October 2008 to prepare for a debate, and the candidate liked it so much he vowed to come back.

title: The Firing Squad, Please, Says Prisoner
description: Ronnie Lee Gardner had a quarter-century to ponder his choice, whether to die by lethal injection or take four bullets in the heart.

title: A Yoga Manifesto
description: ZEN is expensive. The flattering Groove pants, Lululemons answer to Spanx, may set Luluheads, the devoted followers of the yoga-apparel brand, back $108. Manduka yoga mats, favored for their slip resistance and thickness, can reach $100 for a limited-edition version. Drop-in classes at yoga studios in New York are edging beyond $20 a session, which quickly adds up, and the high-end Pure Yoga, a chain with two outposts in Manhattan, requires a $40 initiation fee, and costs $125 to $185 a month.

title: Bright Falls: Episode 2
description: The second episode in the live-action prequel for the video game Alan Wake.

title: Domesticities | For a Mars Explorer, a Solar Studio
description: View Slide Show >>

title: Stanfords Charter Elementary School Is Suspended
description: The Ravenswood CitySchool District board voted on Thursday night to end grades K-4 at a charter school run by Stanford Universitys School of Education.

title: Bright Falls: Episode I
description: The first episode in the live-action prequel for the video game Alan Wake.

title: Creating a Video Games World With Real People
description: It has been five years since Microsoft and Remedy Entertainment of Finland announced that they were developing a mature psychological action thriller for the Xbox 360 called Alan Wake. The game isnt scheduled to hit stores until May 18, but its milieu  the disturbing, mist-shrouded Northwestern town known as Bright Falls  is first coming to life in a live-action suspense series.

title: Scrap Metal Radiation Raises Concerns in India
description: NEW DELHI  To walk through the squalor of Mayapuri, a grimy industrial area of hundreds of tiny scrap-metal shops, is to bear witness to the industrial detritus of the world: tons of rusted iron pipes, twisted steel poles, copper and other discarded metals from Europe, Russia, Japan and the United States, as well as from India.

title: A Little Too Ready for Her Close-Up?
description: IT took years for Hollywood to create the perfect woman. Now it wants the old one back.

title: Former Employees Criticize Culture of Rating Firms
description: WASHINGTON  Former executives at Moodys and Standard & Poors offered damaging critiques on Friday of the practices at the two credit rating agencies during the run-up to the financial crisis.

title: Report from a Pashtun Teen: Arranged Marriage
description: Sher Bano is a 17-year-old Pashtun girl from Pakistan who spent last year as an exchange student in Evanston, Illinois, as part of the Youth Exchange and Study (YES) Program. She is now back in the city of Peshawar in the northwest of Pakistan. As a guest blogger, shell be writing about life in Pakistan from the perspective of a teenage girl who has spent time in the West. This is her second post.

title: New Vantage for a Palestinian Photographer
description: Given the commotion outside his office in the West Bank one day in 2006  armed protesters, some of them firing into the air, were marching through the streets of Ramallah  Osama Silwadi, a well-known Palestinian photojournalist, naturally, went to the window to see what was going on.

title: A High-Minded Look at Electric Cars
description: The setting was the sun-dappled campus of Columbia University, so perhaps it wasnt surprising that todays forum on New York and the Electric Car, sponsored by the university and General Motors, took on a somewhat elevated tone.

title: Live Updates: Rounds Two and Three of the N.F.L. Draft
description: New York Times reporters will be providing updates and analysis of the second and third rounds of the N.F.L. draft. Paul Myerberg of The Times will be hosting the festivities, and Judy Battista is at Radio City Music Hall, Greg Bishop is with the Jets and Dave Caldwell with the Giants. You can also follow Judy on Twitter. You can catch up on last nights coverage here.

title: The Numbers Climb Online: A Score of 88.61
description: The record for the biggest game continues to be challenged. On Christmas Day last year, Meyer Kotkin and Marty Seligman of Philadelphia played in a 37-pair, 12-board event on Bridge Base Online (bridgebase.com).

title: Green Piece | Eco Luxe From Imitation and Disguise
description: Ecologically correct fashion can be more than hemp totes and Veja sneakers even more than vegan platforms from Stella McCartney. In the hands of the Franco-Brazilian designer Jean-Philippe Gawronski, its something you want to wear well beyond the yoga studio. The handsome 30-year-old designer, who honed his skills at Lanvin for a year, realized that there was something missing at the high end of the green market. In 2007, he launched Imitation and Disguise, a focused collection of luxurious clothing and accessories made with ecologically certified materials. I wanted to create clothes that make a woman look elegant, sexy and of the moment, he said from Paris.

title: A Long Way From Brooklyn
description: BARBARA STANWYCK must be one of the best represented classical-era stars on DVD. With its new boxed set  six films on three discs  Universal all but clears the shelves of any remaining Stanwyck titles in its library (which includes pre-1948 Paramount sound features).

title: Pesos, Ponzi, And Financial Sector Profits
description: Theres been an interesting exchange over my suggestion  which is by no means original  that the stability of banks between 1935 and 1980 or so had a lot to do with lack of competition, which gave banks a franchise value that executives didnt want to endanger with risky strategies.

title: Coney Islands Revival
description: A new amusement park on Coney Island will feature 22 new rides manufactured by Italy's Zamperla Group.

title: What You Get, Where.
description: Apartments from $1,300 to $3,000 in Manhattan.

title: Jon Stewarts Punching Bag, Fox News
description: George W. Bush and Dick Cheney are long gone. Fox News Channel is Jon Stewarts new enemy No. 1.

title: Give This Round to Icahn in Lions Gate Fight
description: Things are picking up for Carl C. Icahn in his takeover battle for Lions Gate Entertainment.

title: Sunday Preview
description: Luxury resorts at motel prices. Sugary beaches without crowds. In the weeks between spring break and the summer crush, travelers are few and deals abound.Lionel Beehner offers eight places to enjoy the off-season.

title: On the Street | In the Trenches
description: The pastel spring coat disappeared decades ago, replaced by variations of the between-season trench coat.

title: Layoff Anxiety Persists
description: Even though the job market appears to be turning around, more than one in five American workers still thinks the axe may be coming for them in the next year.

title: The Real Chicken-Checkup Fallacy
