description: Everyones having fun with the chickens for checkups story, in which Sue Lowden, the leading Republican Senate candidate in Nevada, expressed a desire to return to the good old days in which people who wanted a checkup from their doctor would offer a chicken in exchange. And shes not backing down!

title: That Fine Comedic Art of Hurling Pies at Faces
description: Perhaps some old TV shows are best left in the vault.

title: Fete Accompli | Food and Fashion at the Brooklyn Museum
description: Last night I gave some bum advice to Rachel Feinstein.

title: Bike Stolen? Check the Police Station
description: Updated, 7:07 p.m. | The crowds that lined East Houston Street on Thursday morning to watch Barack Obamas motorcade speed toward Cooper Union got a glimpse of the pomp and protection that accompanies the president. There were black sedans with tinted windows, S.U.V.s full of Secret Service agents and a brigade of motorcycle officers from the New York Police Department led by a high-ranking officer wearing a white shirt.

title: Escarole Soup With Rice
description: Mark Bittman prepares a pot of Italian spring soup.

title: A New Times Blog on All Things Green
description: My colleagues on the news side of The Times have expanded the focus of the great Green Inc. blog, which was reborn this week simply as Green. I hope youll track their work on environmental commerce, science, energy policy and related issues. You can contact the Green team with tips or feedback at greenblog@nytimes.com.

title: Birthday Party With Mexican Flair
description: For the venerable Anna Sokolow, who would have been 100 this year  she made it to 90  art wasnt an understated or passive act, but something meant to be a reflection and a comment on contemporary life. In a program celebrating her centennial from Sokolow Theater/Dance Ensemble, which opened on Thursday night at the Joyce SoHo, that expressive nature was on display.

title: Chinese Military Seeks to Extend Its Naval Power
description: YALONG BAY, China  The Chinese military is seeking to project naval power well beyond the Chinese coast, from the oil ports of the Middle East to the shipping lanes of the Pacific, where the United States Navy has long reigned as the dominant force, military officials and analysts say.

title: Green Day Surprises Broadway Audience
description: The Broadway show American Idiot turned into a rock concert with a supercharged encore on Thursday night: a surprise appearance by Green Day, the band that wrote the music. The three-man band, and an additional guitarist, took to the stage after the show as audience members screamed. This is my first night on Broadway, the singer-guitarist Billie Joe Armstrong, right, declared, then blared out the opening power chords of American Idiot, the shows title song. The cast was onstage, pogoing and singing along. One cast member tried crowd-surfing, traveling about three rows. Mr. Armstrong jumped around, stuck out his tongue and filled in the part of rock n roll thats absent from the Broadway show: audience participation, with singalongs of Heys and Day-Os from The Banana Boat Song. The drummer, Tr Cool, flung his drum sticks into the audience, as if the set were over. But it wasnt. Green Day went on to play an older song, Basket Case, which isnt part of the show. Audience members squealed anew and shouted the lyrics when the bassist Mike Dirnt pointed a microphone their way. Cast members knew them, too, cementing some punk-rock credentials. Afterward, a few of them lifted the grinning Mr. Armstrong off his feet.

title: Levines Back Surgery Is Deemed a Success
description: Ronald Wilford, the manager of James Levine, below, said his client was released from the hospital on Wednesday after lower back surgery and never looked better. He said the operation had been enormously successful and that despite a series of canceled performances recently Mr. Levine still hoped to conduct at the Tanglewood Festival this summer. He wants to come back to conducting as quickly as possible, but he doesnt want to screw it up, Mr. Wilford said in a telephone interview. Hes really frustrated.

title: Oz Breakout: Escape to Theater
description: Its not an official Oz reunion, but short of the cast members of that HBO prison drama getting thrown into a maximum-security penitentiary together its as close as were likely to get. Primary Stages said that it would end its season with two stage readings of Godfather IV, an original work by Tom Fontana, the Oz creator. It will star Christopher Meloni, Lee Tergesen and Dean Winters, who all appeared on that eye-gougingly violent series. Godfather IV is not a sequel to Francis Ford Coppolas mafia movies, but a piece in which the Oz actors discuss the plausibility of a key scene in The Godfather, and Mr. Tergesen and Mr. Winters resolve to put a horses head in Mr. Melonis bed. The readings, scheduled for May 2 at 59E59 Theaters, are being presented as a benefit for Primary Stages and the Writers Guild of America, East Foundation. They will be directed by Linda Laundra (Homicide: Life on the Street) and will also feature the Oz alumni Mike Doyle, Zeljko Ivanek, Terry Kinney, David Laundra, Kristin Rohde, Eamonn Walker and Catherine Wolf, as well as an appearance by Mr. Fontana.

title: Mentalist Wins for CBS
description: CBS led the ratings race on Thursday night, earning the most viewers during every hour of prime time. According to Nielsens estimates, The Mentalist attracted the largest audience, as 14.8 million viewers tuned into the CBS crime show at 10 p.m. CBSs Survivor was first in the 8 p.m. hour (11.8 million), while CSI, at 9, led with 13.3 million. Fox was the runner-up, drawing a modest 5.9 million viewers for Fringe at 9, but faring better at 8 with Bones (8.8 million). ABC ranked third with FlashForward at 8 (5.7 million), Private Practice at 9 (7.4 million) and a rerun of Greys Anatomy at 10 (4.4 million), while NBC placed fourth with its comedies.

title: A New Character in Archies Town
description: A new man is moving into Riverdale, the home of comics perennial teenager Archie Andrews and his gang. His name is Kevin Keller, and hes blond-haired, blue-eyed and gay. Kevin will be introduced in Veronica No. 202, right, in a story titled, Isnt it Bromantic? The inclusion of the character meets twin goals, one real world and one in-story. Riverdale has to reflect the diversity of the world today, said Jon Goldwater, co-chief executive of Archie Comic Publications. We want to be all inclusive. Mr. Goldwater also said hes not afraid of any repercussions. We think everyone is going to enjoy the story, he said. Its completely in the tradition of your typical Archie comic. Dan Parent will be writing and illustrating the story of Kevins introduction. He said his goal was simple: Veronica is always chasing guys and getting what she wants. Who could we introduce that she could not get? Mr. Parent said Kevin would be more than a one-off character with future stories already mapped out. The issue will hit newsstands on Sept. 1.

title: Polanski Fails in Bid to Block Extradition
description: The director Roman Polanski failed in his latest attempt to block his extradition to the United States from Switzerland, where he is under house arrest, and end the 33-year-old case against him for having sex with a minor. In a decision on Thursday, a California appeals court denied a request to end the proceedings by sentencing him to time already served, despite Mr. Polanskis assertions that new evidence showed hitherto undisclosed corruption in the case. The authorities in Switzerland have said they will not act on the request for Mr. Polanskis extradition to the United States until the courts in California clarify his status. The denial of his latest appeal makes clear that he is expected to appear in the United States to face sentencing.

title: Race Pays Off for Its Producers
description: The Broadway production of David Mamets play Race has earned back its initial investment of approximately $2.5 million after five months of performances, the producers announced. It is one of a handful of commercial plays this season that have recouped the investment spent on mounting the productions on Broadway. All of those plays had star performers in lead roles, a common box office strategy nowadays. Race stars James Spader (Boston Legal) as a lawyer who spars with two colleagues, played by David Alan Grier and Kerry Washington, about defending a white man facing ugly criminal accusations from a black woman. Other star-driven plays that recouped this season are A Steady Rain (with Hugh Jackman and Daniel Craig) and the revivals of Hamlet (Jude Law) and A View From the Bridge (Liev Schreiber and Scarlett Johansson). Directed by Mr. Mamet, Race opened at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Dec. 6, and is scheduled to run through June 13. Its lead producers are Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel.

title: Creating a World, if Not a Story
description: Gerald Casel must be tired of hearing that his choreography is reminiscent of the work of Stephen Petronio, whose company he danced with for seven years. But its true that choreographers with distinctive physical styles and dynamics tend to imprint those qualities on a younger generation. (Mr. Petronio was himself strongly influenced by Trisha Brown, with whom he too danced for seven years.)

title: The Latest Line, on a Desolate Racetrack
description: Bettors at Aqueduct racetrack, in Queens, N.Y., are devoted to their no-frills track, which is in for another lean season.

title: A Reason to Be Bitter in Spring
description: LIKE radicchio and other bitter, tough greens, escarole can survive the winter in many places and appear early in spring. But unlike radicchio, escarole is inexpensive. And its more versatile: it tastes better cooked than does its round, red cousin.

title: Ex-Employees Criticize Culture of Rating Firms
description: Former executives at Moodys Investors Service and Standard & Poors offered damaging critiques on Friday of the practices at the two credit-rating agencies during the run-up to the financial crisis, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

title: Add Gay Spirit to Taste, Then Stir
description: How at ease is Leslie Jordan with himself these days? Comfortable enough that when he was hired to perform on a recent Alaska-bound cruise, he invited his mother to take the extra stateroom he was offered.

title: The Week in Pictures for April 23
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York region. Subjects include showers for stranded travelers, the bar car on the Metro-North, and a party at the Hudson Hotel.

title: Government Says Al Qaeda Ordered N.Y. Plot
description: The failed plot to bomb three New York City subway lines during the morning rush last September was hatched in 2008 by two senior Qaeda leaders in the tribal areas of Pakistan, where they met personally with three would-be suicide attackers from Queens to urge them to carry out a strike, federal authorities said Friday.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 23
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Making a Flute Do Tricks in Pieces Old and New
description: New York is full of talented musicians, as well as artistic entrepreneurs who busily create their own opportunities to flourish. The flutist Claire Chase fits into each of those categories and then some. Both as a performer and as the executive director of the International Contemporary Ensemble, which she helped found in 2001, she has had a hand in some of the most memorable musical events of the last several years.

title: Chic in Review | Azzedine for H&M?
description: Alaa, AzzedineClaims he would love to design for H&M. Chic!

title: A Conductor Visits Before Moving In
description: NEWARK  The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra offered a glimpse of its future on Thursday afternoon at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here, when Jacques Lacombe, a fresh-faced conductor from the Trois-Rivires Symphony Orchestra in Quebec, led the ensemble for the first time since being chosen to be its next music director. Based on this initial encounter, a program featuring standard works by Brahms and Dvorak, the prognosis is decidedly positive.

title: Being the Tastemakers, and the Main Course
description: Much as you shouldnt judge a book by its cover  unless, say, its incredibly well designed or pockmarked with typos  its generally imprudent to judge a band by its opening acts. They might be friends of the promoter or the club owner, or have won a radio station contest, or be owed a favor.

title: Gunmen Ambush Police Officers in Ciudad Jurez
description: MEXICO CITY  When a police officer is killed in Mexico, as seven of them were Friday on the streets of Ciudad Jurez, the sad question that immediately arises is, Whose side were they on?

title: Its the Military, Undergraduate
description: On Dec. 16, 2009, I boarded a plane to Kabul, where I would spend five weeks as a research assistant.

title: Ruling Party in Nigeria Is Fractured by Infighting
description: DAKAR, Senegal  An outbreak of public infighting within Nigerias governing party this week has exposed how confused the countrys politics remain in the wake of the recent shaky transfer of power at the top, analysts contend.

title: A Man of Funks Straight-Ahead Groove
description: The saxophonist Pee Wee Ellis played just one original in his first set at Iridium on Thursday night, and it delivered the only dose of nonswinging groove. That ratio felt emphatic, like a statement of principle.

title: A Restorative Spring Dinner
description: This weeks Minimalist column uses escarole, one of the first spring greens and more affordable than other early offerings like radicchio. Its flavor is better cooked than raw, especially when mixed with creamy rice and the sweet mellow bite of garlic.

title: Chords Unfold and Soar, Evoking Birds and Bells
description: Works by two Pulitzer Prize-winning composers of similar aesthetic bents were featured in the first half of the Lark Quartets program at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening.

title: For the Fitzgeralds, the Ecstasy and Then the Agony
description: The beautiful and doomed Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald, those glittering emblems of the Jazz Age, are resurrected to do the Charleston once again in This Side of Paradise, a sadly limp new musical at the Theater at St. Clements.

title: Registering an Atom: Location Matters
description: AN Ariel Atom may be quick, but a buyer must wait four months to take delivery of an American-spec car.

title: Music Review: More of The Russian Stravinsky
description: 3:47 p.m. | Updated After many flights to New York were delayed because of the volcanic ash  clouds over Europe, the Chorus of the Mariinsky Theater finally arrived at Avery Fisher Hall in time for the second concert of The Russian Stravinsky: A Philharmonic Festival on Thursday night. The chorus was missed in Wednesdays opening-night program, conducted (as is the entire festival) by Valery Gergiev, which was to have included Les Noces, not heard at the Philharmonic since 1982.

title: Seeking the Best Financial Resources for Women
description: This weeks Your Money column discusses how women fare when it comes to money matters.

title: Doing Good and Making a Profit
description: In this weeks Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan writes about an emerging hybrid of philanthropy and private equity called impact investing.

title: Financial Advice by Women for Women
description: Several personal finance books aimed at women landed in my mailbox recently. They were hard to miss. The books had pink covers and the catchy, if cringeworthy, titles, Shoo, Jimmy Choo! and Hot (Broke) Messes. And then there was the one I found on Amazon, A Purse of Your Own.

title: Penny-Pinching Is Fine, but It Wont Save the Profligate
description: SOMETIMES I read about ways to pinch pennies and I feel good. We turn off lights, often buy in bulk, use compact fluorescent light bulbs and put tap water in our reusable bottles instead of buying disposable ones.

title: Answering the Call From iPhone Gamers
description: In video games, the best things rarely come in small packages.

title: Kerri Strug and Robert Fischer III
description: Kerri Allyson Strug and Robert William Fischer III are to be married Sunday evening at Skyline Country Club in Tucson. Rabbi Stephanie Aaron is to officiate.

title: Elizabeth Beaman, Philip Dizard
description: Elizabeth Bancroft Beaman, the daughter of Kathryn Rich Sherman and Peter H. Beaman, both of Pittsburgh, was married Saturday evening to Philip Ritz Dizard, the son of Darby Dizard and Stephen W. Dizard, both of New York.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,033 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Legal Victory Raises Profile of an Atheist Group
description: MADISON, Wis.  Annie Laurie Gaylor clicked through a flurry of e-mail messages warning her to repent or she would burn in hell.

title: An Artist Sings Her Goodbye to New York
description: Carnegie Hall was packed on Thursday night for the New York farewell recital of the beloved American mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade. Typically these events are occasions to celebrate an artists career, not to assess the actual quality of the performance.

title: Adding More Jewish Voices to the Discussion
description: Just starting a journal called The Jewish Review of Books invites a joke: Wait, dont we already have a Jewish review of books  or several?

title: Events in Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: S.E.C. Watchdog to Look at Timing of Goldman Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commissions inspector general said Friday that he would investigate why the agency filed securities fraud charges against Goldman Sachs on April 16 after several House Republicans questioned whether the timing of the case was aimed at swaying the Senates debate on the financial regulatory bill.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Mine Owner Defends Work and Pledges Accountability
description: The company that owns the Upper Big Branch mine in West Virginia, where 29 miners died this month, defended its safety record Friday and promised that there will be accountability if improper conduct took place.

title: Bright Falls: Episode I
description: The first episode in the live-action prequel for the video game "Alan Wake."

title: A Top Indonesian Lawyer May Be Honest to a Fault
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Will Wall Street Be Saved by Porn?
description: Goldman Sachs is in the federal dock, President Obama is in New York talking tough to Wall Street, regulatory packages are flying through Congress  what could possibly get in the way of the financial reform juggernaut? The Securities and Exchange Commission is the sheriff of the financial industry, reports Jonathan Karl of ABC News, but a new government report obtained by ABC News has concluded that some senior employees spent hours on the agencys computers looking at sites such as naughty.com, skankwire and youporn as the financial crisis was unfolding.

title: Amy Modi and Ketan Kulkarni
description: Dr. Amy Modi and Dr. Ketan Kulkarni were married Saturday at the Hanover Marriott in Whippany, N.J. Pandit Vijay Patwardhan, a Hindu priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Bright Falls: Episode 2
description: The second episode in the live-action prequel for the video game Alan Wake.

title: American Sprint Hope Has Youth, and Height
description: PHILADELPHIA  Usain Bolt, the mens world-record holder in the 100 and the 200 meters, will be the main attraction at the Penn Relays this weekend. But he will not be the only intriguing tall young sprinter at Franklin Field.

title: Kerry Shapleigh, Joseph Price
description: Kerry McIntyre Shapleigh and Joseph Fitzgerald Price were married Saturday by the Rev. William H. Roen, a Lutheran minister, at 91 Horatio Street, an event space in New York.

title: Persephone Harrington, Stephen Schneider
description: Persephone Constance Harrington and Stephen Corcoran Schneider were married Saturday at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York. The Rev. Robert G. Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony.

title: Lindsey Sichel and David Rubinstein
description: Lindsey Brooke Sichel and David Michael Rubinstein were married Saturday evening by Rabbi David Novak at Oheka Castle, the former Otto Kahn house in Huntington, N.Y.

title: Vanessa Matsis, Shaun McCready
description: Vanessa Giselle Matsis and Shaun Kevin McCready were married on Saturday at Our Lady of Mercy Church in Forest Hills, Queens. Msgr. Gerald J. Langelier, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: A Derby Hopeful, if He Can Keep His Head Straight
description: Gary Contessa knows that his starter in the Derby Trial Stakes is fast and gifted, maybe as talented as any 3-year-old in the country.

title: Caroline Lessing, Timothy Mullen
description: Caroline Melton Lessing, the daughter of Sandra Melton Lessing and Stephen M. Lessing of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., was married Friday evening in Hobe Sound, Fla., to Timothy Joseph Mullen, a son of Claire Cranwell Mullen and Patrick J. Mullen of Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. Luke L. Travers performed the ceremony at St. Christopher Catholic Church, with the Rev. Daniel K. Lahart participating. Both are Roman Catholic priests.

title: A Cacophony of Musical Playthings in the Desert
description: PHOENIX  There are complete skins of animals, dried, tied and knotted, their orifices fitted with hollow canes and reeds. Other hides are stretched taut over enormous gourds. Strings, spun from intestines, are pulled and pegged into the ends of long necks. Antlers, bones and horns are cut, carved and drilled. Elephant, goat, antelope, lizard, gazelle  the skins of all are used.

title: Cate Doty, Michael McElroy
description: Cate Doty and Michael McElroy were married Saturday evening in Charlottesville, Va. Deputy D. L. Duncan of the Charlottesville sheriffs office officiated at Ash Lawn-Highland, the former residence of President James Monroe.

title: Amanda LaFollette, Kevin Blackman
description: Amanda LaFollette and Kevin Blackman were married Friday at the DuPage County Courthouse in Wheaton, Ill. Judge Elizabeth W. Sexton of the 18th Judicial Circuit Court of Illinois officiated.

title: Robert Duffy and Alexis Cespedes
description: Robert Charles Duffy and Alexis Cespedes were married Tuesday evening at the Red Inn in Provincetown, Mass. James Mack, a chaplain with the Unitarian Universalist Meeting House of Provincetown, officiated.

title: Lauren Waterman, Andrei Kallaur
description: Lauren Anne Waterman and Andrei Kallaur were married Saturday evening in Brooklyn. Hubert J. McCabe, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Picnic House in Prospect Park.

title: Leah Threatte and John Bojnowski
description: Leah Ruth Threatte and John J. Bojnowski were married Saturday at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Albany. The Rev. James L. Reisner, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Amelia Erwitt, Kamil Kaluza
description: Amelia A. Erwitt and Kamil Kaluza were married Saturday at Bubbys, a restaurant in Brooklyn. Shauna Kanter, a minister of the Universal Brotherhood Movement, officiated in a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Twitter Buys a Text Messaging Company
description: Twitter was born as a text messaging service; tweets are 140 characters because that is the length of a text message, minus a few characters for the authors name.

title: Rachel Marcus, Rob Sales
description: Dr. Rachel L. Marcus and Rob B. Sales were married Saturday evening at the Old Field Club, an event space in Setauket, N.Y. Rabbi Marci Bellows officiated.

title: Erin Morrison, Patrick Flynn
description: Erin Elizabeth Morrison, the daughter of Corin C. Morrison and Robert R. Morrison III of Vicksburg, Miss., was married Saturday evening to Patrick Charles Flynn, the son of Barbara J. Flynn and Charles H. Flynn of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Geoffrey Joyner performed the ceremony at Crawford Street United Methodist Church in Vicksburg, with the assistance of the Rev. Cary Stockett, who also is a United Methodist minister.

title: Jane Morril, Benjamin Case
description: Jane Marion Morril and Benjamin Charles Case were married Saturday evening at the Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in New York. Cantor Mia Fram Davidson officiated. Sheldon A. Novek, a Hebrew tutor, took part in the ceremony.

title: What Were Reading: E Ink and iPhones
description: The tech reporters and editors of The New York Times are often too busy on Fridays to read much. But they spotted a few things:

title: Christine DelliBovi, David Cyr
description: Christine Marie DelliBovi and David Justin Cyr were married Saturday afternoon. The Rev. George W. Rutler, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Saviour in New York, where he is the pastor.

title: Margaret Fain, Evan Jenkins
description: Margaret Minton Fain, a daughter of Jennifer Nelson Fain and William H. Fain Jr. of Los Angeles, married Evan Andrew Jenkins, the son of David Atwood Jenkins of Middlefield, Mass., and the late Leigh Rand Jenkins, on Saturday at All Saints Church in Beverly Hills, Calif. The Rev. Carol Anderson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Maria Warman and Antoine Boulin
description: Maria Jean Warman and Antoine Boulin are to be married Sunday at the Smog Shoppe, an event space in Los Angeles. The Rev. Marvin P. Warman, the brides father and a minister of the Conservative Congregational Christian Conference, is to officiate.

title: Kathryn Murray, Jacob Cohen
description: Kathryn Elizabeth Murray, the daughter of Diana T. Murray and Dr. Henry W. Murray of New York, was married in New York Friday evening to Jacob William Cohen, a son of Carol J. Cohen and David J. Cohen of Westport, Conn. Former Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York officiated at Battery Gardens, a restaurant.

title: Heyward Is Living Up to the Hype
description: Braves closer Billy Wagner has been around professional baseball long enough to be able to differentiate the prospects who will develop steadily, the ones who will flame out, and the few who will live up to the promise of the extreme hype that surrounds them.

title: Brian Conroy, Christopher Harris
description: Brian Michael Conroy and Christopher Richard Harris were married Saturday at Binney Park in Greenwich, Conn. Elizabeth Bonsal, a justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Jean Limpert, Jon Burd
description: Jean Lindstrom Limpert, a daughter of Jean V. Limpert and John A. Limpert of Bethesda, Md., was married Saturday to Jon Walker Burd, a son of Helen K. Burd and Stanley L. Burd of North Brunswick, N.J. The Rev. DeeAnne L. Lowman, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Columbia Country Club in Chevy Chase, Md., at a ceremony that was led by Wesley Pippert, a former lay preacher and a friend of the brides family.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the work of the photographer Louis Faurer misstated the closing date of an exhibition at the Milwaukee Art Museum, Street Seen: The Psychological Gesture in American Photography, 1940-59, that features work by Mr. Faurer and other photographers. It is Sunday, not May 4.

title: The Man Baseball Loves to Hate
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  According to some of his peers, Alex Rodriguez is a hypocrite and a prima donna. He is not the Yankee type, either, and he has monopolized all the attention since arriving in the Bronx in 2004. Others have described his on-field conduct as bush league, a little cheap, an unsportsmanlike act of cheating and more typical of junior high school baseball. Tough crowd.

title: G-20 Split on the Need for a Global Tax on Banks
description: WASHINGTON  Proposals to establish a global tax on banks and charge them for the cost of government bailouts divided representatives of the Group of 20 countries during a summit meeting here on Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Escapes pages on Friday about the Old North Branch Inn in North Branch, N.Y., and the Bedford Post Inn in Bedford, N.Y., misstated the schedule of meditation classes at the Bedford Post. They are offered on Wednesday nights, not every night.

title: C.D.O. Days, S&M Nights at Derivatives Conference
description: SAN FRANCISCO  By day, they dealt with risk. At night, it got risqu.

title: Is All That Sitting Really Killing Us?
description: Yes, we all sit too much, but will our sedentary ways reduce our lifespans? Olivia Judson, in a recent online Op-Ed column in The Times, told readers to Stand Up While You Read This, and an article in The Timess business section reviewed different models of standing desks.

title: Hearing on Limits for Vendors Gets Creative Response
description: When the citys artists are fuming, they create. And when the focus of their rage is Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his efforts to crack down on selling art in parks, a new genre is born.

title: As Tower Rises, So Do Efforts to Buy In
description: The planned skyscraper once known as the Freedom Tower was scorned for years by urban planners, downtown residents and real estate executives who regarded it as an oversize and unnecessary exercise in waste and hubris.

title: Coney Island Getting a $30 Million Italian Makeover
description: ALTAVILLA VICENTINA, Italy  Alberto Zamperla sweeps through the cavernous workshop here where his amusement rides are manufactured while workers measure and bang and solder enormous platforms, oddly shaped beams and assorted fiberglass vehicles.

title: With a Push From Kevin Durant, the Thunder Steps Forward
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  The N.B.A.s elite can blame themselves for Kevin Durants evolution. He takes from here and there. He mimics and copies. At 21, Durant does not have much experience of his own to draw on. Instead, he copies Carmelo Anthonys rip move, Dwyane Wades craftiness in luring fouls and Kobe Bryants resilience.

title: A Top High Schools Move From a College Campus Prompts Anger
description: For over two decades, students at University Heights High School have attended classes on the leafy campus of Bronx Community College, a 50-acre haven that offers serene views of the Harlem River and a refuge from bustling Bronx streets.

title: Plan Gives Pedestrians a Plaza at Union Square
description: First the city repurposed Times Square, converting some of its streets to a pedestrian promenade. Similar plans are in store for 34th Street by the Empire State Building.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: $18.5 Million in Liability for Scouts in Abuse Case
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  The Boy Scouts of America were ordered Friday to pay $18.5 million in a lawsuit that has focused new attention on the secret files the Scouts keep to document claims of sexual abuse by troop leaders and volunteers.

title: A Tokyo Start, but Most at Home on 125th Street
description: Tommy Tomita walked past the red awning, down three concrete stairs, opened a gray door covered in duct tape and entered the jazz dive.

title: Dont Call It Pot in This Circle; Its a Profession
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Like hip-hop, health food and snowboarding, marijuana is going corporate.

title: Explosion in the Gulf
description: Nearly a dozen people are missing and presumed dead after the huge explosion aboard a deep-water oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico. The accident provides further evidence that despite advances in technology, oil drilling poses big environmental and human risks.

title: Against Trail Blazers, Suns Reap  Rewards of Playing Defense
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  As Amare Stoudemire sat at his locker stall Thursday night, he made a proclamation that drew a chuckle from several reporters  and probably outright laughter around the N.B.A.

title: Beautiful Brutes
description: Brutalism, a severe architectural style that came out of postwar Europe, is enjoying somewhat of a Renaissance.

title: Companies Feeling More Pressure to Cut Iran Ties
description: WASHINGTON  While President Obama struggles to negotiate United Nations sanctions with teeth against Iran, a parallel campaign to turn up the heat is gaining momentum by pressuring American and foreign corporations individually to cut their business ties there.

title: Rebellious Mood Takes Root in Rural Thailand
description: KHON KAEN, Thailand  Six weeks of demonstrations by red-shirted protesters turned violent this week in Bangkok, but the capital is not the only place with a whiff of insurrection in the air.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 23, 2010

title: Greece and Whos Next?
description: As Greece careened ever close to default this week, frightened investors also rushed to dump bonds from financially troubled Portugal, Spain and Ireland. But while the markets increasingly see this as a euro zone crisis, many European leaders are in denial.

title: Summer Crickets and College
description: Frank Calderon, an assistant district attorney in Albany, was 9 years old the first time he heard a cricket. He had left his familys small apartment in a housing project in Brooklyn for a two-week stay with a host family upstate, thanks to the Fresh Air Fund.

title: Running on Empty
description: The election season is starting in earnest, and already one thing is crystal clear. Both the Democrats and the Republicans are hopeless. It seems inconceivable that either party can possibly win anything. This may be the year when the Whigs finally get to make their comeback.

title: The New World Trade Center
description: Panoramic views of 1 World Trade Center show the progress of building.

title: For School Company, Issues of Money and Control
description: When the energy executive Dennis Bakke retired with a fortune from the AES Corporation, the company he co-founded, he and his wife, Eileen, decided to direct their attention and money to education.

title: Kyrgyzstan: A Promise to Stay Away
description: Kyrgyzstans ousted president said Friday that he would not try to return to the country, but he maintained that his resignation was not valid. In Belarus, where he arrived this week, the president, Kurmanbek Bakiyev, said that he had signed a letter formally stepping down, butsaid that it was no longer valid because the interim government had not kept its promise to safeguard his family.

title: Zimbabwe: Iranian President Opens Trade Fair
description: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran opened Zimbabwes international trade fair in Bulawayo on Friday. He and Zimbabwes president, Robert Mugabe, who both held on to power after violent, discredited elections  Mr. Mugabe in 2008 and Mr. Ahmadinejad last year  strongly criticized the West, according to The Herald, the state-owned newspaper in Harare controlled by Mr. Mugabe.

title: American (Judicial) Idol
description: Americans are justifiably proud of having given the world a model for the architecture of democratic self-government. Democracies old and new have emulated the separation of powers and the idea of a constitutional court with the authority to review and invalidate actions of the other branches.

title: China: Rare Public Protest Against an Official
description: Three protesters criticized a well-known propaganda official, Wu Hao, as he gave a speech at Peoples University in Beijing on Thursday, a rare instance in which a prominent official was humiliated in public. The protesters, graduates of the university, tossed currency notes worth five mao, or less than ten cents, onto the stage as Mr. Wu, deputy director of the propaganda department in Yunnan Province, spoke, many Chinese Web sites reported Friday. The notes were a reference to the five-mao party, a derogatory term for Chinese Internet users who are supposedly paid five mao per posting by officials to spread propaganda on the Internet.

title: Wide Receiver Welker
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Todays solve was a tale of two puzzles for me. The top went well. The bottom was slooow.

title: Pakistan: Military Convoy Ambushed
description: Pakistani militants ambushed a military convoy in the North Waziristan area Thursday, killing seven soldiers and wounding 16 others in the deadliest attack on the military in months. The convoy was carrying out a routine movement in the village of Boya, according to a statement on the Pakistani militarys Web site. The military carried out a campaign in South Waziristan last year, taking territory that once belonged to the leadership of the Pakistani Taliban. Many believe that the leadership fled to North Waziristan, where other tribes, as well as the Qaeda operative Sirajuddin Haqqani, an Afghan, are thought to be hiding.

title: Jets Make an Unlikely Selection
description: The Jets second-round pick is named Vladimir Ducasse, and if you hadnt heard of him before Friday night, dont worry, youre not alone. Turns out, Ducasse is a raw offensive lineman who played tackle in college at UMass, but more likely will play guard for the Jets, if he plays at all.

title: The Court and Free Speech
description: When the Supreme Court ruled 8-to-1 this week that a federal law banning the sale of animal-cruelty videos violates the First Amendment, it reaffirmed the right to engage in even highly unpopular speech. And it wisely declined to create another category of expression outside of the First Amendments protection.

title: Bloggingheads: Is Repeal for Real?
description: Timothy Noah, left, of Slate and Rich Lowry of National Review debate the G.O.P.s push to repeal health care reform.

title: Kyle Wilsons Cant-Miss Play for Attention
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The first time Kyle Wilson saw his familys new recreational vehicle, he cringed. He looked at the 34-foot beast and saw the gaudy decoration, the bright mixture of blue and orange, the three pictures, including one of him without a shirt splashed across the back of the vehicle.

title: Greece, Out of Ideas, Requests Global Aid
description: ATHENS  Describing his countrys economy as a sinking ship, Greeces prime minister formally requested an international bailout on Friday, creating the biggest test so far to the European monetary union.

title: Giants Gain More Weight in 2nd Round
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Rather than using their second-round pick in the N.F.L. draft on a middle linebacker to replace Antonio Pierce, the Giants took a 315-pound defensive tackle whom General Manager Jerry Reese unglamorously referred to as a human post.

title: Rating Agency Data Aided Wall Street in Deals
description: One of the mysteries of the financial crisis is how mortgage investments that turned out to be so bad earned credit ratings that made them look so good.

title: Search Ends for Missing Oil Rig Workers
description: NEW ORLEANS  Three days after an explosion on an oil rig off the southeast coast of Louisiana, an environmental disaster has been at least temporarily forestalled, but the search for 11 missing workers has ended, the Coast Guard said Friday evening.

title: Vivaldi, the Way He Wanted to Be Heard
description: Early music can bring out the pedant in a player, and Vivaldis The Four Seasons is, despite its popularity, no exception. But some musicians take a more passionate approach to the piece  none, perhaps, more than the members of the Venice Baroque Orchestra, a 13-year-old ensemble from Vivaldis hometown.

title: A New Bellisimo, Much Like the Old One
description: AFTER a year or more of hearing buzz on Bellisimo, an Italian restaurant in Hillsborough, I finally planned a visit last winter, only to learn that the place had closed. I had missed my opportunity by days. Instead, I later visited the new Bellisimo on the same premises, owned by Jim Nelson and his wife, Barbara, who opened it in early February.

title: A Film Fest, and Beyond
description: There are movies about music in the Connecticut Film Festival in Danbury this year, like The Wrecking Crew, focusing on studio musicians who backed up famous performers including Frank Sinatra and the Beach Boys. And there are movies about illness, from the deadly serious Still Here, about a man living with H.I.V. for 30 years, to the quirky Collecting Things, the story of a woman with a borderline hoarding disorder. But as far as I can tell, only one film on the festival schedule (May 4 to May 9) deals with the biggest issue of the decade: the economy. That is Matt Judges I Work in Public, about a laid-off administrative assistant who takes an unusual approach to entrepreneurship.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE LUCKY SKILL GAME AND LOUNGE, on 40th Road just off Main Street, has large Chinese characters outside advertising slot machines. Inside, there are dozens of computerized terminals resembling the kind of slots you see in Atlantic City or at Yonkers Raceway. But these are not slot machines  theyre games of skill  so theyre legal in New York State, said Joy Shyu, 35, who with her companion opened what they call the first casino in New York City. It is a sleek lounge with throbbing music and is open until 3 a.m. Snacks and a juice bar are available, since such places cannot serve alcohol, Ms. Shyu said. She said they hoped to open more outlets with these slot machines  er, games of skill  in the city. People come in and they say, Wow, we cant believe theres a real casino right here, she said.

title: Cheese and Yogurt, Fresh From the Sheep
description: Sheeps milk cheese is less well known in the United States than cheeses made with cows or goats milk, but a handful of farms are working to change that with some wonderful products. One of the best is in Columbia County: Old Chatham Sheepherding Company.

title: A New Theater Out of an Old One
description: For most of Bay Street Theaters 19 years, its directors have dreamed of having a second stage, a smaller theater where they could present edgier fare from fall through spring, said Murphy Davis, co-artistic director of the nonprofit theater, in Sag Harbor. But where to locate the new house presented a problem.

title: Where Musicians Are Seen and Heard
description: In its 21 years, the Raritan River Music Festival, which will present four intimate concerts at four different spots in western New Jersey next month, has earned its reputation as a destination series: Ticket holders have come from as far away as Chicago to places like the historic Prallsville Mills in Stockton, where the first show will take place May 1.

title: The OTB Parlors, Limping Along
description: The Off-Track Betting Corporation has just survived the latest of its many brushes with death, but on Monday at the Yankee Clipper, its South Street Seaport outpost, rumors of the institutions demise seemed, well, just about accurate.

title: Contemporary Twists on Indian Food
description: JUST inside the doorway at Orissa, a Dobbs Ferry newcomer, youll see a small stack of books prominently displayed. Modern Indian Cooking, by Hari Nayak and Vikas Khanna, with a foreword by the chef Daniel Boulud, is for sale, but its also a notice: This isnt your typical Indian restaurant.

title: Holding the Strings to the Heart and Soul
description: KATONAH

title: Getting the Royal Treatment
description: One of Prince Dimitris favorite family stories involves King Louis XIV of France. Louis, Dimitris great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-grandfather, was undergoing surgery so painful that he fell unconscious. When the Sun King finally awoke, his subjects gathered around his bed in the palace at Versailles and asked how he felt. Even as he lay in agony, by Prince Dimitris recounting, Louis XIV stammered: The man is suffering. But the king is all right.

title: A Concert With Students and Their Virtuoso Mentors
description: Bay Shore

title: Mysteries and Conspiracies, Over a Couple of Beers
description: The jukebox in the bar in Steven Dietzs Yankee Tavern doesnt work. It suddenly went dead on Sept. 11, 2001, at 8:46 a.m., just as the first hijacked plane rammed into the north tower of the World Trade Center. Right in the middle of the lyric Bye, bye, Miss American Pie.

title: A Real Housewife of the Upper East Side Takes a Break
description: Ramona Singer is among the five original housewives from the 2008 debut season of the Bravo reality series The Real Housewives of New York City. Shes still at it; she also sells her Art Deco-inspired jewelry on HSN and a skin care line called Tru Renewal. Ms. Singer, 53, lives on the Upper East Side and spends summers in Southampton with her husband, Mario, 56, a jeweler; their teenage daughter, Avery; and a Shih Tzu named Coco.

title: Merrily They Roll Along, Performing
description: WHEN the Arts Council of Greater New Haven began searching for a vehicle to transport arts programs around the city, it ran into a problem. We didnt have any money for the vehicle, said David Brensilver, a council spokesman.

title: From Common Food Carts, Exotic Tastes
description: BY 11 a.m. most weekdays, lunchtime aromas are already wafting up Cedar Street opposite Yale New Haven Hospital.

title: New Ambitions for an Old Standby
description: ROSLYN

title: Spreading His Gospel of Warm and Fuzzy
description: It was early in the class, in a nondescript room on Union Square, where more than a dozen business managers had gathered to learn the hospitality secrets that have made Danny Meyer one of the nations most successful restaurateurs. The moment to share had arrived.

title: Awash in $100 Bills That Add Up to Zero
description: For eight nights in March, the Allman Brothers played at the United Palace Theater in Washington Heights, and after the shows, their fans would come steaming along Broadway. One celebratory stop was at Cooganson 169th Street.

title: Learning How to Fight the Collector
description: Among debt collectors, Steven Katz is known as a credit terrorist. For years, he has run what he calls the Steven Katz School of Bill Collector Education, otherwise known as the credit terrorist training camp.

title: Health Care Cost Increase Is Projected for New Law
description: WASHINGTON  A government analysis of the new health care law says it will not slow the overall growth of health spending because the expansion of insurance and services to 34 million people will offset cost reductions in Medicare and other programs.

title: Carriage Horses Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: Government Lawyers Under Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: Regulating the Internet
description: To the Editor:

title: The Public Rage Against Wall Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Layoffs in New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Lehman Asks for Dismissal of Japanese Firms Claims
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings, the bankruptcy estate of the collapsed investment bank, asked a judge on Friday to dismiss more than $1 billion of creditor claims by Nomura of Japan, arguing that they were vastly overstated and that the firm instead owed millions of dollars.

title: A Tax Inquiry Jolts the World of Indian Cricket
Gorilla Coffee to Reopen Monday
description: Gorilla Coffee, the juggernaut Park Slope java-and-lifestyle dispensary that has been closed since April 9 after the entire staff quit  to protest a perpetually malicious, hostile and demeaning work environment, will reopen Monday. So said the smiling woman inside the half-rolled-up gate of the shop at Fifth Avenue and Park Place at 7 Friday evening.

title: Panthers End Clausens Wait at No. 48
description: One by one, the picks came and went. And Jimmy Clausen went nowhere.

title: Death by Firing Squad in Utah
description: Utah is the last state that still allows some condemned prisoners to choose to die by the bullet, as two did in 1977 and 1996, and a third chose in April.

title: On Night of Moves, Mets Find Stability
description: By juggling his batting order Friday night, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel added energy that helped forge a 5-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves and boost his teams momentum.

title: Strategizing Legalizations Pros and Cons
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As a longtime Democratic consultant, Chris Lehane has worked for presidents and managed scandals. But his current gig  as a strategist for the campaign to legalize, tax and regulate marijuana in California  is the one that has really caught the attention of his colleagues.

title: Bay Has Overcome Worse Slumps
description: The first time Jason Bay was mired in a serious slump, it almost changed the direction of his life. But instead of switching to a career in finance, as he nearly did, he stuck with baseball and became an All-Star.

title: Amid Cheers, Green Makes an Inspired Comeback
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  No one would have blamed Ken Green if the thought of quitting crossed his mind Friday. Partnering with his friend Mike Reid in the Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf, he was operating on one hours sleep and he looked it, playing in his first official round of a Champions Tour event since the motor home accident last June that turned his world upside down.

title: Purvis Young, Folk Artist Who Peppered Miami With Images, Dies at 67
description: Purvis Young, a self-taught painter who emerged from prison as a young man and by dint of his striking, expressionist vision of urban life and mammoth output over more than three decades transformed a forgotten Miami neighborhood into a destination for contemporary art aficionados, died on Tuesday in Miami. He was 67.

title: Sabres Lead Early and Dont Look Back
description: BUFFALO  For the fifth straight game, the Buffalo Sabres scored first in their opening-round series against the Boston Bruins. Only this time, on Friday night at HSBC Arena, Buffalo held on to win, 4-1.

title: Protests Erupt Over Immigration in Arizona
description: Hundreds of demonstrators descended on the Arizona Capitol after Gov. Jan Brewer signed a bill aimed at identifying, prosecuting and deporting illegal immigrants.

title: Nighttime Draft Is Attracting More Viewers
description: The N.F.L.s decision to move the draft from Saturday afternoon to Thursday evening paid off with an average of 7.3 million viewers, making it the sixth-most-watched program of the night.

title: Court Filing Sheds Light on Bin Laden Bodyguard
description: He was told that the question, posed through an intermediary, had come from Osama bin Laden: Will you be my bodyguard?

title: Moraless 2-Run Shot Off Chamberlain in the 8th Sinks Yankees
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Red is the dominant color at Angel Stadium. It is on the tops of the dugouts, the Angels uniforms, the Big A looming outside and the Not-As-Big A atop the left-field scoreboard. It is a cheery shade, but in their visits here the Yankees find little charm. Their memories, despite their success here last autumn, are overwhelmingly negative.

title: Tensions Rise Between the Koreas as Ship Is Raised
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea on Saturday salvaged the remaining half of a warship that sank near a disputed sea border with North Korea, as suspicion of a North Korean torpedo attack deepened and two former South Korean presidents urged the countrys leaders to punish Pyongyang economically.

title: Your Jokes: I Saved Energy
description: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: One Flew Over the Catchers Mitt
description: Video | The home-plate play that gave people a smile, went viral on the Web and, oh yes, helped Fordham come back to win the game:

title: Classic Ad: Mazda RX-3
description: Before there was zoom-zoom, there was boing-boing.

title: Big Draft Day for Rutgers and Piscataway
description: Rutgers finished 3-4 in the Big East last season but sent two of its players to the first round of the draft: offensive tackle Anthony Davis to the Niners at No. 11 and cornerback Devin McCourty to the Patriots at No. 27. The only other Big East player selected in the first round was defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul of South Florida (to the Giants at No. 15).

title: The Saturday Word: Autos and Finance
description: President Obama used his weekly national address to defend the governments decision to bail out and restructure the American auto industry, highlighting the progress the car companies have made since the depths of the recession.

title: Interview: Dana Adam Shapiro
description: Dana Adam Shapiro, the director and co-writer of "Monogamy," discusses the highs and lows of relationships.

title: Soupy, Explained
description: City Room has always had a soft spot in its heart for Soupy Sales while growing up, even if we never quite got him the way we did, say, Magic Garden. The puppets, the pies, the Dean-Martin-esque faux(?)-drunk diction - what was up with that? And what were we youngsters supposed to make of it? Even watching clips now, the main impression we get is that the 1960s were a very long time ago indeed. But Saturday at 6 p.m. on WLIW-TV (Channel 21 on all city cable providers), all will become clear, over the course of Soupy Sales: The Gangs All Here a one-hour survey of the mans oeuvre. It will be shown again Sunday at 4:30 p.m.

title: Goldman Cited Serious Profit on Mortgages
description: In late 2007, as the mortgage crisis gained momentum and many banks were suffering losses, Goldman Sachs executives traded e-mail messages saying that they would make some serious money betting against the housing markets.

title: Howard Is Only Half a Force Inside
description: On Tuesday, Dwight Howard was named the defensive player of the year for the second consecutive year. Two days before, in the series opener between the Orlando Magic and the Charlotte Bobcats, he showed why with nine blocks in an Orlando victory.

title: Republicans Look to 1994 Playbook
description: WASHINGTON  In the minds of many Republicans, Democrats never really won control of the House. Republicans gave it away.

title: Are S.B.A. Loans in Trouble?
description: The Reuters headline on Thursday was alarming: Weakness rife in US small business loans. The article reported on testimony at a hearing held by the House Small Business Committee. The U.S. Small Business Administrations inspector general found weakness in more than two-thirds of loans it examined in a program aimed at encouraging construction projects, Reuters reported. Some $255 million worth of these so-called 504 loans were made to borrowers who might not be eligible or might not be able to repay them.

title: Ferguson: Well Known in Britain
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: That volcano in Iceland is still causing problems! Planes are flying again, but thousands of people are stranded. I didnt think it would affect me, but now it has. Last night, I was supposed to go to a concert by my musical hero, Gary Numan, who couldnt get a flight here because of that volcano. Numan is well known in Britain, but only has one hit here. It was Cars. It was a hit in America. Here in my car, I feel safest of all. This was before Toyotas.

title: Letterman: Dont Worry About Him
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: John Paul Stevens, 90 years old, Supreme Court justice, is retiring. But dont worry about him. Hes getting his own show on T.B.S. Hell be fine.

title: Leno: Executives Were Shaking
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: Well, one good thing has come out of this volcano in Iceland. Economists say consumers can now expect a huge drop in the price of lava lamps.

title: From Twain, Turn-of-the-Century Twitter Posts
description: As they came and went  major dignitaries and minor deities, old friends and pint-size new ones, people who left too soon and people who showed up unannounced  Mark Twain recorded it all in a handsome brown guest book.

title: Former British Home Secretary Tries to Rebound
description: REDDITCH, England  When Jacqui Smith set out to knock on doors in this recession-hit English town on a chilly, gusting evening last week, the venture had the air of an itinerant penance, among a population reluctant to forgive.

title: From Jets Who Know, Life Lessons for Rookies
description: A year ago, Mark Sanchez was a rookie in waiting and the talk of the N.F.L. draft. Selected by the Jets fifth over all, he had an up-and-down season. There was the fast 3-0 start, then a steep descent. By the end of the season, Sanchez was a spark that carried the Jets to the A.F.C. championship game.

title: Greek Hero Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Todays quote is both very funny and seemingly true. Ive spent many a day here in the suburbs of New York discovering the very thing it mentions.

title: Vatican Seeks Transparency in Abuse Cases
description: ROME  As the Roman Catholic Church grapples with a widening sexual abuse scandal involving its clergy, it must show that it has nothing to hide, the Vatican spokesman said Saturday.

title: Football, Not Basketball, Could Determine the Future of the Big East
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  The commissioners and athletic directors from the 11 Football Bowl Subdivision conferences departed Friday, leaving more questions than answers

title: S. African Jews Relent on Bar Mitzvah
description: JOHANNESBURG  Richard Goldstone, the South African judge who had said threatened protests at his grandsons bar mitzvah would keep him from attending, has reached an agreement with Jewish groups here that will allow him to go to the ceremony after all.

title: A Graying Population, a Graying Work Force
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  One recent morning Antonia Antonaccio, a home care aide, got a call to help an elderly couple whose regular aide could not make it. The regular aide, who is 68 years old, had thrown out her back.

title: Raised to Hit Hard and Overcome the Blows
description: LAS VEGAS  The eccentric uncle reclines on a couch, shoes off, feet up. The father, once estranged from his famous son, naps in the corner. Children scurry around, boxing gloves covering their tiny hands.

title: TV Mystic Lingers in Saudi Jail
description: CAIRO  The sorcerer still has his head.

title: After a Coup, Niger Resumes Business as Usual With China
description: NIAMEY, Niger  For China, the transition seems smooth.

title: Last Teacher In, First Out? City Has Another Idea
description: Peter Borock, 23, is in his second year teaching history at Health Opportunities High School in the South Bronx. It could be his last.

title: Vegas Mob Museums, Set to Go to the Mattresses
description: LAS VEGAS  The people of Chicago debate the Cubs versus the White Sox. In Philadelphia, the cheese steak purveyors Pats and Genos have long divided the citizenry. Soon, the residents of Las Vegas  and the millions of people who visit  will be able to argue over which museum best depicts the moral turpitude of organized crime.

title: Spitzer on Cuomo: Hes Driven, Often by Politics
description: He questions whether the candidate has the will to stand up to powerful interests. He faults him for failing to aggressively take on Wall Street. And he is not sure that he will vote for him for governor this fall, saying he wants to see who else will be in the race.

title: Spitzer on Cuomo
description: Former Gov. Eliot Spitzer sat down with Sam Roberts of The Times for a conversation about Andrew M. Cuomo's career.

title: Stop the Presses! Harvey Weinstein Courts Controversy to Promote a Movie!
description: Oops, there he goes again!

title: G-20 Split on Need for Global Tax on Banks
description: Proposals to establish a global tax on banks and charge them for the cost of government bailouts divided representatives of the Group of 20 countries during a summit meeting in Washington on Friday, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports.

title: Feeling Warehoused in Army Trauma Care Units
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  A year ago, Specialist Michael Crawford wanted nothing more than to get into Fort Carsons Warrior Transition Battalion, a special unit created to provide closely managed care for soldiers with physical wounds and severe psychological trauma.

title: At the White House, It Is Often Good Politics to Play Ball
description: When the World Series champion Yankees visit the White House on Monday to meet President Obama, they will continue a tradition, stretching back a century and a half, of baseball players mixing with commanders in chief.

title: The Great One: Im Just Hanging Out
description: Wayne Gretzky, the N.H.L.s career leader in goals (894) and points (2,857), met his match in Viktor Ghamari of Sweden in a shootout on April 14. They were playing N.H.L. 10, part of the EA Sports Champions of Gaming Finals, staged by Gillette in Manhattan. (Ghamari was chosen from more than 350,000 online entrants to compete against a celebrity.)

title: Ochoa Says Goodbye to Golf and Hello to the Rest of Her Life
description: Lorena Ochoa walked away from competitive golf with grace and humility, the same way she walked in. For sure, as she might say, there were few regrets. None were important enough to mention to reporters on Friday, when she preferred to accentuate the positive, again, one of her endearing traits.

title: Rating Agency Data Aided Wall Street in Deals
description: One of the mysteries of the financial crisis is how mortgage investments that turned out to be so bad earned credit ratings that made them look so good, The New York Timess Gretchen Morgenson and Louise Story report. One answer is that Wall Street was given access to the formulas behind those magic ratings  and hired away some of the very people who had devised them.

title: Giants Focus on Defense but Grab a Spare Punter
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Compared with the team with which they will share a new stadium  that would be Rex Ryans noisy Jets  the Giants were downright dull during the three-day N.F.L. draft. Seven picks up, seven picks down, no trades of picks or players, not a whiff of controversy.

title: Topalov Wins First Game of Title Match
A Single-Minded Celtics Center
description: If there is one thing you can say for sure about Kendrick Perkins, the Boston Celtics center, it is that he knows how to do his job and then stay out of the way.

title: Lust and Marriage
description: To cheat or not to cheat? That is one of many questions proposed in Dana Adam Shapiros relationship drama/thriller Monogamy. The film stars Chris Messina as Theo, a photographer who shoots surveillance-style photos for his clients. One series of racy pictures sets off events that put a strain on Theos relationship with his fiance (Rashida Jones).

title: Maine Says Hes O.K., but Mets Will Wait and See
description: John Maine said his sore left (nonthrowing) elbow, which forced him from his start Friday, was feeling better Saturday morning and he was hopeful he would make his next scheduled start Wednesday against the Dodgers at Citi Field.

title: Perils Remain Despite Recoverys Pace, I.M.F. Head Says
description: WASHINGTON  The head of the International Monetary Fund said Saturday that the global economic recovery, while moving along faster than expected, was vulnerable to threats posed by long-term unemployment and unsustainable public debts.

title: For Greeces Economy, Geography Was Destiny
description: Stockbridge, Mass.

title: A Family Portrait of a Greek Tragedy
description: Washington

title: Unexpected Governor Takes an Unwavering Course
description: PHOENIX  One night last week, Grant Woods, the former state attorney general, spent more than an hour on the telephone with Gov. Jan Brewer, a fellow Republican who was considering whether to sign into law the nations toughest immigration enforcement bill.

title: Fighting Words
description: Alex Rodriguez may have breached an unwritten rule of baseball etiquette last week when, after making it to third base on a foul ball hit by a teammate, he wandered across the pitchers mound on his way back to first. Dallas Braden, the pitcher for the Oakland Athletics, was not happy.

title: Criminal Charges Possible in the Case of the Lost iPhone
description: 10:23 a.m. | Updated  Correcting name of the law enforcement agency involved, the Rapid Enforcement Allied Computer Team.

title: A Dream, Just Not That Dream
description: For as long as he could remember, Sergio Santos would dream about what his first day in the big leagues would be like.

title: Two-Wheeled Tribes
description: On New Yorks hurried streets, one passing cyclist can appear no different from another. But cyclists are hardly a monolithic subculture  more like a collection of finely divided sub-subcultures, each with its own uniform, lingo and attitude toward the bicycles place in the urban landscape.

title: In the Draft, Winners, Losers and the Patriots
description: If there is one thing that will resonate about the 2010 N.F.L. draft, it will not be the slides of quarterbacks Jimmy Clausen and Colt McCoy, who were this years reminders that serendipity plays nearly as big a role in where some players are drafted as evaluation does. It also wont be the fact that Day 3 turned into a fire sale of unwanted veterans like Leon Washington, LenDale White and Jason Campbell.

title: Stealth Salt in the Pantry
description: There are some foods that you expect to be generously salted.

title: Jets Subtract Two Veterans and Draft Two Backs
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets finished their latest roster remodeling with a striking flourish as the N.F.L. draft ended Saturday.

title: Troop Therapy
description: Haleiwa, Hawaii

title: C.D.O. Days, S&M Nights at Derivatives Conference
description: By day, they dealt with risk. At night, it got risqu. Financiers, lawyers, traders and accountants gathered this week at the annual International Swaps and Derivatives Association conference in San Francisco to discuss Collateralization and Netting  the Impact and Systemic Risk: Advances and Challenges in the Wake of the Crisis.

title: Prime Number
description: 3.3: The average grade point average at private colleges and universities, according to a study by Stuart Rojstaczer and Christopher Healy in the journal Teachers College Record, based on data collected from more than 160 schools. At public schools, the average G.P.A. is 3.0. The authors said that private schools are apparently conferring small but measurable advantages to their students by more generous grading. But whether public or private, colleges and universities are on average grading easier than ever before.

title: National Security and the Waistline
description: Terrorists. Nuclear weapons. Cyberattacks.Now a group of retired military leaders is warning of another risk to the nations security: overweight 17- to 24-year-olds. The Army estimates that 27 percent of those Americans, more than nine million in all, are too fat to enlist. The retired leaders  members of the group Mission: Readiness  urged Congress last week to remove junk food and high-calorie beverages from schools, increase financing for healthy school lunch programs and support efforts to encourage healthier life styles. When over a quarter of young adults are too fat to fight, we need to take notice, said James Barnett Jr., a retired Navy rear admiral.

title: Obama Marks Genocide Without Saying the Word
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C.  President Obama, who as a candidate vowed to use the term genocide to describe the Ottoman mass slaughter of Armenians nearly a century ago, once again declined to do so on Saturday as he marked the anniversary of the start of the killings.

title: Promises the Pill Could Never Keep
description: Minneapolis

title: A New Book Echoes Boutons Ball Four
description: The best way to describe Dirk Hayhurst is that he is in baseball, but not of it. Or maybe that is not quite right; technically, Hayhurst is out of baseball for now, recovering from shoulder surgery in Hudson, Ohio. He pitched 15 games for Toronto last season and 10 for San Diego in 2008.

title: Anatomy of a Benjamin
description: Last week, the Treasury Department introduced its new $100 bill, a redesign intended to frustrate high-tech counterfeiters when it goes into circulation Feb. 10.

title: Faking West, Going East
description: COMING in at No. 3 is MARGARET MITCHELL. Her Gone With the Wind captivated a huge international audience and brought her virtually unanimous literary acclaim, topped off by the Pulitzer Prize for 1937 and the ultimate accolade: a furious argument within the serious-lit hive over whether this was or wasnt that long-awaited elixir, the Great American Novel.

title: Dnt Txt N Drv
description: Chicago

title: New Orleans Tournament Has a Friend in Switzerland
description: Martin Senn, the new chief executive of the Zurich Financial Services Group, had his trip from Switzerland to New Orleans delayed a day because of ash in the atmosphere following the eruption of the volcano Eyjafjallajokull. But Senn, who took charge of the Zurich group in January, quickly made the earth move for tournament and PGA Tour officials in his first public on-site remarks as C.E.O.

title: At Each Stop, the Thunders Diligent Presti Learned Well
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  As a do-everything player at Emerson College in Boston, Sam Presti once took six charges in a game against Daniel Webster College. In the moments before body met body, Presti anticipated the bruises. He also understood that collecting them would help his team.

title: At 85, an Accomplished Marathoner Still Sees the Road Ahead
description: BEND, Ore. (AP)  Unlike age, which is measured precisely by years, vitality is not so easy to gauge.

title: Sabres-Bruins Is Battle of the Stingiest
description: BUFFALO  Consider two goalies. One was the most valuable player of the Olympic tournament in February and is a finalist for the Vezina Trophy, for the N.H.L.s best goaltender. When it comes to hockey in the United States, his is the closest to a household name.

title: Theyve Got It: Fixes for the Financial System
description: WASHINGTON  Congress is consumed by the proposed legislation to overhaul the financial system, with lawmakers clashing over the best ways to regulate derivatives, protect consumers and end taxpayer-supported bailouts.

title: Cup-Winning Goalies Are Rested Goalies
description: Can an N.H.L. goalie be overworked? Teams used to think so, but over the last decade or so, more No. 1 goaltenders are playing about 70 regular-season games each year.

title: Mallett Is Working to Lead Arkansas to New Heights
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP)  Ryan Mallett stood several yards behind the line of scrimmage, safely away from the action. He clapped his hands after a nice play and raised his arms after a touchdown. At one point, he took a quick break to throw short tosses of about 15 yards to a teammate.

title: For Now, a Refuge for the Catholic Church in Poland
description: BERLIN  When I think back on Polands period of mourning after the plane crash that claimed the lives of the countrys president and 95 other people, what stands out are flickering votive candles by the thousands and murmured prayers in unison from as many mouths; the priests sprinkling holy water on the presidents coffin; and the high pointed hats of bishops that seemed to tower above the crowds at every event.

title: Plunking Parallel: Steroid Use and Hit Batsmen
description: The so-called steroids era produced plenty of pumped-up statistics. Everyone talked about the home runs, but few noticed the soaring number of batters hit by pitches.

title: Faltering Cancer Trials
description: The nations most important system for judging the clinical effectiveness of cancer treatments is approaching a state of crisis. That is the disturbing verdict of experts assembled by the National Academy of Sciences to review the performance of clinical trials sponsored by the National Cancer Institute.

title: North Korea Appears to Tap Leaders Son as Enigmatic Heir
description: SUNGNAM, South Korea  The black-and-white photographs that were published last month in a North Korean newspaper appear no different from other propaganda coming from North Korea: they show the supreme leader, Kim Jong-il, touring a steel plant in a fur cap and his trademark sunglasses.

title: Why Should They Believe Us?
description: Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada, the host of this Junes Group of 8 summit meeting, said last week that if the G-8 is to remain credible, accountability is absolutely necessary. He is right. Leaders of the worlds wealthiest nations can start bolstering their credibility by explaining how they plan to fill the $20 billion gap between the foreign aid they promised to send to developing countries and what they are actually giving.

title: Afraid of the Sunshine
description: One, and only one, Congressional Republican has decided that unregulated money should not be allowed to swamp this campaign year. Representative Michael Castle of Delaware is daring to co-sponsor a bill to repair some of the damage from the Supreme Courts decision to give corporations and unions free rein to spend unlimited amounts on campaign ads and advocacy.

title: The Familys Ghosts
description: The playwright Horton Foote died last year, never to see theater lovers turned away nightly from his parting masterwork, Orphans Home Cycle. Rooted in his 1920s Texas boyhood, it is a canny celebration of life, its hopes and disappointments, in scenes that resonate with ordinary characters.

title: The Church, Seen in Another Light
description: To the Editor:

title: China Replaces Leader of the Restive Xinjiang Region
description: BEIJING  Chinese leaders announced Saturday that they had replaced Wang Lequan, the ruling official in the vast western region of Xinjiang, whose capital was engulfed last summer by the deadliest ethnic violence in China in decades.

title: To Mets, Reaching .500 Does Not Feel Half Bad
description: Less than two weeks ago, the Mets were among the worst teams in baseball, staggering to a 2-6 record to open the season as speculation raged over how long it would be before they might take drastic action, like firing the manager. Since then, the Mets have fought their way back to respectability with excellent pitching and fundamental play, even as many of the hitters have slumped.

title: An Existential View of the Tea Partiers Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: Drafted Together, Ending Up Well Apart
description: Giants defensive tackle Chris Canty  is entering the second of a six-year, $42 million contract that includes $17.25 million guaranteed. Like many professional athletes, he is in an enviable financial position at age 27.

title: Financial Reform: A View From the Electric Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Regulate the Internet?
description: To the Editor:

title: Questioning the Pope
description: A TOP Vatican official said The Times lacks fairness in its coverage of Pope Benedict. The archbishop of Brooklyn urged parishioners to besiege the paper and send a message that the Catholic Church will no longer be its personal punching bag. Writers in The Wall Street Journal and other publications have assailed the paper.

title: Writing the Book on Unwritten Rules
description: When Dallas Braden, the Oakland Athletics starting pitcher, criticized the Yankees Alex Rodriguez for running over the pitchers mound during last Thursdays game, it put the focus on baseballs unwritten rules, with many people unaware that Rodriguez had broken one.

title: Fight On, Goldman Sachs!
description: MAYBE Lloyd Blankfein was doing Gods work after all.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On the Sceptred Isle, Immigration Is an Issue Fit for Whispers
description: LONDON  In a general election where the unexpected surge of the Liberal Democrats has put all the usual calculations about the contest between Labour and the Conservatives in flux, there has been a morbid familiarity to the campaign of one party that cannot hope to be part of the jockeying for power many pundits foresee after the ballots are cast on May 6.

title: Tea Party With a Difference
description: Ive been trying to understand the Tea Party Movement. Sounds like a lot of angry people who want to get the government out of their lives and cut both taxes and the deficit. Nothing wrong with that  although one does wonder where they were in the Bush years. Never mind. Im sure like all such protest movements the Tea Partiers will get their 10 to 20 percent of the vote. But should the Tea Partiers actually aspire to break out of that range, attract lots of young people and become something more than just entertainment for Fox News, I have a suggestion:

title: School for Hope
description: MARIAL BAI, Sudan

title: Graham Pulls Support for Major Senate Climate Bill
description: WASHINGTON  In a move that may derail a comprehensive climate change and energy bill in the Senate, one of the measures central architects, Senator Lindsey Graham, has issued an angry protest over what he says are Democratic plans to give priority to a debate over immigration policy.

title: Rebuilding a Town Hub From a Stores Ashes
description: PUTNEY, Vt.  When residents saw flames shooting out of the Putney General Store in November, they were filled with an all-too familiar sense of dread.

title: States Warn of Obamacare Scams
description: In Illinois, a telemarketer recently sold an elderly woman a fraudulent health insurance plan that supposedly protected her against death panels, the state insurance director says.

title: CKE Restaurants Chooses Apollo Bid Over THLs
description: CKE Restaurants, the operator of the Hardees and Carls Jr. fast-food chains, said Saturday that it had accepted a $693.9 million takeover offer from Apollo Management, ending an earlier takeover agreement with THL Partners.

title: F.D.I.C.s Seizure of Senate Candidates Family Bank Further Complicates an Illinois Race
description: CHICAGO  Some Democrats had long worried that Alexi Giannoulias might not be their best hope of holding onto President Obamas former seat in the United States Senate, and then came word that federal regulators on Friday night had seized Broadway Bank, an institution here owned by Mr. Giannouliass family.

title: Monumental Achievement
