description: Note: When this puzzle is done, the seven circled letters can be arranged to spell a common word, which is missing from seven of the clues, as indicated by [ ]. Connect the seven letters in order with a line and you will get an outline of the object that the word names.

title: Whered You Go With My DNA?
description: The cultural gap between the impoverished Havasupai Indians who view their blood as sacred and the Arizona State University researchers who helicoptered in to their Grand Canyon home to collect it was at the heart of a lawsuit over the scope of a genetic study that ended last week with a settlement for the tribe.

title: Robert Hicks, Leader in Armed Rights Group, Dies at 81
description: Someone had called to say the Ku Klux Klan was coming to bomb Robert Hickss house. The police said there was nothing they could do. It was the night of Feb. 1, 1965, in Bogalusa, La.

title: Europe Under the Ash
description: Eyjafjallajokull, that unpronounceable volcano, prompted inevitable chatter about natures awesome fury and the inadequacy of human invention to deal with it. Few Europeans had even heard of the volcano before, and they marveled at, but mostly grumbled about, how such widespread havoc could be caused by such teensy particles of ash, adrift from Iceland. On the whole, Europeans tend to forget about Iceland until some fresh calamity compels their attention. The last was the banking implosion, and a line making the rounds in Europe has it that Icelands final wish after its economy kicked the bucket was to spread its ashes across Europe.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 25
description: The debate over financial regulation heats up on Sundays talk shows as the hosts and guests discuss the merits of President Obamas overhaul and the federal governments case against Goldman Sachs.

title: Calling Almost Everyones Tune
description: Its tough to handle this fortune and fame.

title: Dozens Ignored a Man Dying on a Sidewalk in Queens
description: Hugo Alfredo Tale-Yaxs last act may have been helping a woman who was having an argument with another man last Sunday morning in Queens. But his last hour or so was spent as a curiosity for people passing him on the street as he lay face down in blood after being stabbed several times.

title: Democrats Long-Held Seats Face G.O.P. Threat
description: ASHLAND, Wis.  Representative David R. Obey has won 21 straight races, easily prevailing through wars and economic crises that have spanned presidencies from Nixons to Obamas. Yet the discontent with Washington surging through politics is now threatening not only his seat but also Democratic control of Congress.

title: Do You Have Any Reforms in Size XL?
description: EVERY once in a while, Congress awakens from its lobbyist-induced torpor, realizes that the masses are cranky and sets out to appease them. Such a moment occurred last week when lawmakers finally got the message that Main Street is disgusted with Wall Street and wants them to do something about it.

title: Fierce Tornado Causes Deaths Across Mississippi
description: A tornado described by one Mississippi official as the worst in the area in decades swept through the state on Saturday, leaving at least 10 people dead in its path.

title: Oil Leaking Underwater From Well in Rig Blast
description: NEW ORLEANS  Robotic devices monitoring the deepwater well where a giant oil rig exploded and sank last week have discovered oil leaking from the well, a development that a senior Coast Guard official on Saturday called a game changer.

title: The Giants Critique the Giants Picks
description: Coach Tom Coughlin, General Manager Jerry Reese and other team officials discussed the Giants seven new draft picks on Saturday. (The days biggest news might have been the possible retirement of punter Jeff Feagles.) Here are some of their comments:

title: Bolt Draws Crowd and Delivers a Record at Penn Relays
description: PHILADELPHIA  Green and yellow were the colors of the 116th Penn Relays at Franklin Field on Saturday.

title: Whats Wrong With Saying I Dont Know?
description: This interview with Rachel Ashwell, founder of the home furnishings retailer Shabby Chic, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Reviewing the Jets Draft Picks
description: We break down the Jets busy day of picking and trading in this article, but heres a quick review of the teams selections in the draft itself. We encourage you to add your own critiques in the comments.

title: Yanks Provide Runs, but Pettitte Shows He Needs Little Help
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Already this month, Andy Pettitte has watched C. C. Sabathia and Phil Hughes take no-hit bids into the eighth inning. It is someone elses turn in the Yankees rotation to outdo them, though Pettitte does not think it will be him. He has never thrown a no-hitter and at 37, he figures his time has passed.

title: Last Days of the Dynamo
description: One of the greatest clubs in the history of hockey, Dynamo Moscow, announced last week that it was ceasing operations on April 30.

title: The Tax Hiding in Your Paycheck
description: EVERY year at tax time, libertarians indignantly denounce government income transfers from rich to poor. Societys income distribution, they argue, should reflect as closely as possible what people would earn in unregulated private markets.

title: The Rise of the Fleet-Footed Start-Up
description: ERIC RIES and Steven Blank think they have a better way to build a start-up, one that takes less time and money to try new ideas and find paying customers. They are leading proponents of the lean start-up  a fresh approach to creating companies that has attracted much attention in the last year or so among Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, technologists and investors.

title: Goldman E-Mail Cited Serious Profit on Mortgages
description: In late 2007, as the mortgage crisis gained momentum and many banks were suffering losses, Goldman Sachs executives traded e-mail messages saying that they would make some serious money betting against the housing markets, The New York Timess Louise Story and Sewell Chan report.

title: Rachel Alexandra May Return This Week
description: The connections for the horse of the year Rachel Alexandra are eying the $400,000 La Troienne Stakes on the Kentucky Oaks undercard Friday at Churchill Downs for her next race.

title: Correction
description: An entry on the paperback nonfiction best-seller list on Feb. 28 for A Patriots History of the United States, by Larry Schweikart and Michael Allen, misstated the books price. It is $25, not $21.95. (The error was repeated in successive issues through April 11; it was recently brought to editors attention by the publisher.)

title: Paul Schaefer, German Guilty of Chile Child Abuse, Dies at 89
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A former Nazi-era German soldier who founded a secretive German cult in southern Chile, where he sexually abused about 25 children, died of heart failure at a prison hospital early Saturday, Chilean officials said. He was 89.

title: In Luxury Watches, Beauty Is More Than Skin Deep
description: ADDING a diamond-studded dial isnt the only way to turn a wristwatch into a luxury item. Some buyers go for the clockwork inside the case  and the more intricate the mechanisms, the classier.

title: Your Comments on Valentinos School
description: My Sunday column is about the quite extraordinary school built by the equally extraordinary Valentino Deng. I highly recommend What is the What, the Dave Eggers best-selling book about Valentino  and buy it, since the royalties go to support the school!

title: Corrections
description: METROPOLITAN

title: How Much Do You Know About Transportation?
description: Electronic clickers in hand, the Chicago metropolitan areas most influential transportation officials gathered on Thursday morning and took a quiz. Try out some of the questions:

title: Pension Financing Shortfall Is a Threat on the Horizon for State
description: In this Tea Party age, when thousands of people demonstrate nationwide against high taxes, the 15,000 people who rallied in Springfield last week tried a change-of-pace chant. Raise My Taxes! they shouted at the television cameras and any lawmakers who happened by.

title: Educators and Parents Await News on Cuts
description: Principals, teachers and parents in Chicago will find out Monday what the $1.3 billion in proposed cuts to state education spending will mean to their schools.

title: Labs Where 3-D Is Just the Start
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Wal-Mart Expands Citys Lobbying Team
description: In its push for more stores in Chicago, Wal-Mart recently enlisted help from the brother of Cook County Sheriff Thomas J. Dart, as well as from a former aide to Mayor Richard M. Daley.

title: All I Wanted to Do Was Cancel
description: LETS start with two updates.

title: Slow Start and Some Controversy for the Sox
description: After a winter in which they retooled their roster and a spring interrupted by a series of nettlesome distractions, the White Sox could have used a strong start to the season.

title: Letter: Savers, Unrewarded
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberal Reputation Precedes Ninth Circuit Court
description: When President Obama earlier this year nominated Goodwin Liu, a liberal Berkeley law professor, to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, conservatives did not just criticize Mr. Liu  they also attacked the circuit court he hopes to join.

title: A Writer With a View to Share
description: Several times a week, Daniel Handler and his 5-year-old son, Otto, walk from their home in Ashbury Heights to the Randall Museum, which sits on Corona Heights with spectacular views of San Francisco. Mr. Handler, the author of the best-selling series of childrens books, A Series of Unfortunate Events (under the pen name Lemony Snicket), has also written three novels. His current projects include a fourth novel, a childrens picture book titled 13 Words, and the script for the second Lemony Snicket movie. His words have been edited and condensed. TRACEY TAYLOR

title: Community College Tax on Ballot in San Mateo
description: San Mateo County voters could soon become the first in California to approve a special parcel tax on property to help pay for community college education in the county.

title: Letter: Where Were the Jobs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jocks vs. Swans, in a Win-Win for Dance
description: The worlds of contemporary dance and college athletics rarely intersect. But performers from ODC/Dance in San Francisco and student athletes from the University of California, Berkeley, have been coming together annually since 2007 to match physical wits in an attempt to settle a longstanding debate: Which group has greater physical prowess?

title: Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Pages
description: Vistas: Corona Heights Park | Daniel Handler, the author of the best-selling series of childrens books, A Series of Unfortunate Events (under the pen name Lemony Snicket), enjoys the walk from his home in Ashbury Heights to the Randall Museum.

title: Inside the Ninth Circuit
description: The lead article for Sundays Bay Area pages is about the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, an institution that knows its reputation for being out in left field. But it can laugh about it, and even about itself.

title: Not the Retiring Type
description: I GREW up surrounded by mathematicians near the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Richland, Wash. At football games, cheerleaders carried a 4-foot-tall replica of a bomb with fins, painted in the school colors of green and gold. Our team name was the Bombers.

title: Rays of Hope for Job Hunters
description: FOR the first time in two years, many job seekers may have reason to feel hopeful. Employers are beginning to hire again  or at least think about it.

title: Tornado Sweeps Through Mississippi
description: A tornado described by one Mississippi official as the worst in the area in decades swept through the state, leaving at least 10 people dead in its path.

title: Better Options in Practice Golf Balls
description: There are a lot of types of practice golf balls. Theyve been around for decades. Some are pretty useless, like the hard white plastic ones with no holes. They do not mimic a true balls flight in any way. Here are some better alternatives:

title: Think Blankfein Will Resign? Want to Bet?
description: Goldman Sachs, if you listen to Congress, is little more than a casino where gamblers masquerade as traders and bet on the fortunes of the rest of us. Well, now the rest of us can bet on Goldman, Nelson D. Schwartz writes in The New York Times.

title: Time and Alice Neel
description: A look at how the artists work has influenced other realist painters.

title: Vows: Amelia & Kamil
description: Kamil Kaluza, an Australian, came to New York for graduate school, where he met and started dating Amelia Erwitt. As years went by, they became inseparable despite the greatest distance apart.

title: Ask About New York School Data
description: The New York Times has assembled an extensive database of New York education statistics that will help readers put the vast sea of information about schools into better context. Test out the widget by entering a schools name or your current ZIP code. The database includes all New York schools.

title: Obama to Speak at Memorial for W.Va. Miners
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C.  President Obama plans to fly to West Virginia on Sunday to pay tribute to 29 coal miners who died in an underground explosion earlier this month and to vow to work to save lives from being lost in another such tragedy.

title: Buika, Genre-Busting Artist, Plays Berlin
description: When Concha Buikas plaintive hit My Nia Lola began flooding European airwaves in 2006, listeners had a difficult time categorizing her sound  but they couldnt forget her distinctly husky voice and the tender tone of her songs. Like Billie Holiday and Nina Simone  both of whose names recur as influences  its not what she sings but how she sings. Audiences in Berlin will get a chance to hear those qualities for themselves on Thursday, April 29, when she performs at Passionskirche (Marheinekeplatz 1).

title: Still Time to Vote for Collectible Car of the Year
description: Are you passionate about purple Pacers? Do vintage Checker taxis set your meter running? Would you write a check for a Czech-built Tatra?

title: The Draft Match Game: The How and Why Behind the Picks
description: Matt Waldman is a staff writer at Footballguys.com, where he pens The Weekly Gut Check and authors The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a 740-page film evaluation of 170-plus rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver, and tight end.

title: Ship Attack Shows South Korean Quandary Over How to Respond to North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Koreas defense minister on Sunday said a torpedo attack was the most likely cause for the sinking of a South Korean warship that killed at least 40 sailors last month, a statement that inched the country closer to placing blame on North Korea and added urgency to the question of how the South might respond.

title: A Letter to a Distant Daughter
description: Good-byes loom this time of year. High-school seniors choose where they will spend their next chapter, often far from home, and begin taking leave of family and friends. New jobs beckon new graduates (if they are lucky), often farther from home. Its a favorite time for marriage, for moving, for change.

title: The Sunday Word: Energy
description: Lawmakers decided to delay the unveiling of their bipartisan climate change and energy bill, while tens of thousands of environmental activists will descend upon Washington today to rally for swift action on the measure.

title: Babson Competition Winners Sell Viral Videos, Healthful Foods
description: Babson College started the first ever business plan competition for undergraduates in 1984. That helped it achieve its status as a top United States college for aspiring entrepreneurs, especially at the undergraduate level.

title: Thai Premier Rejects Protesters Intimidation, but Seeks Peaceful End to Standoff
description: BANGKOK  Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva of Thailand said Sunday that he continued to seek a peaceful solution to the countrys tense political standoff, but that he would not give in to what he called intimidation by antigovernment demonstrators.

title: Like Kicking Back in Istanbul
description: Before the owners of AKCaf in Clifton had a restaurant, they owned a grocery store across the street, AKMarket, stocked with Turkish staples like yogurt, spicy soujouk (dried sausage) and spices.

title: Derby Favorite Scratched After Injury
description: Not that we needed it or wanted it, but thoroughbred enthusiasts received a heartbreaking reminder Sunday of how ephemeral Kentucky Derby dreams can be and how fragile an athlete they are built on. The 136th running of the Derby will be contested without Eskendereya, perhaps the best 3-year-old of his generation.

title: Till Debt Do Us Part
description: Robin Wells and I review Reinhart-Rogoff and the IMF.

title: What Start-Ups Can Teach Big Companies
description: My Sunday column, The Rise of the Fleet-Footed Start-Up, looks at a concept called the lean start-up.

title: Allison Stacey Cowles, Educational Advocate, Dies at 75
description: Allison Stacey Cowles, a longtime trustee of Wellesley College who was the wife of a newspaper publisher in Spokane, Wash., and, after he died, of a former publisher of The New York Times, died Saturday night in Spokane. She was 75.

title: Democrats, Pressuring G.O.P., Unite on Finance Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats said Sunday that they had bridged internal party differences and coalesced around a plan to tighten regulation of derivatives, the complex financial instruments that were a major factor in the 2008 economic crisis.

title: Seeking Cultural Subtlety in 10 Questions
description: The Vietnamese version of the 2010 census questionnaire used the words dieu tra to describe the population tally  but what the words really conveyed was something like a communist government investigation. On Korean forms, county was translated into nation. And the Chinese hot line offered information only in Mandarin at first, although elderly Chinese immigrants, who are less likely to be proficient in English, speak Cantonese.

title: Old Firm in the New World
description: The two most powerful teams (some would say the only two teams) in Scottish soccer  Glasgow Rangers and Celtic  are considering playing a preseason version of the Old Firm match at Bostons Fenway Park on July 21.

title: 90,000 Protest U.S. Base on Okinawa
description: TOKYO  More than 90,000 Okinawans rallied Sunday to oppose the relocation of an American air base on their island, adding to the pressure on Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama to resolve an issue that has divided Tokyo and Washington.

title: Cant Anybody Here Play This Game?
description: Bear with me while I vent for a moment. On financial reform, there are clear villains in the political process: Mitch McConnell, the US Chamber of Commerce, etc.. But at this point Im accustomed to that sort of thing.

title: Oil Leaks Could Take Months to Stop
description: NEW ORLEANS  Officials worked Sunday to try to stop oil leaks coming from the deepwater well drilled by a rig that sank last week near Louisiana, but they acknowledged that it could be months before they are able to stem the flow of what is now about 42,000 gallons of oil a day pouring into the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Obama Visits the Rev. Billy Graham
description: MONTREAT, N.C.  President Obama ventured to the mountaintop on Sunday to visit the Rev. Billy Graham, becoming the 12th commander in chief to meet the famed pastor to the presidents.

title: Israeli Rightists Stir Tensions in East Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  A small group of ultra-right-wing Israelis marched through a volatile neighborhood of East Jerusalem on Sunday, arousing passions over the future of the contested city as an American envoy wrapped up an inconclusive three-day visit aimed at getting peace talks under way.

title: Thousands Gather on the Mall for Earth Day
description: Tens of thousands of people gathered Sunday on the National Mall in Washington to observe the 40th anniversary of Earth Day and to urge Congress to pass climate and energy legislation.

title: At the Biltmore, McKinley vs. Obama
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C.  President Obama likes to boast that he runs the most transparent White House in history. But William McKinley gives him a run for the money in at least one respect.

title: Epistemic Closure In Macroeconomics
description: Theres been a huge outpouring of blogospheric discussion about epistemic closure on the right: a complete refusal to look at evidence or arguments that dont come from the like-minded. I dont have much to say about all that aside from the fact that its obvious, and has been going on for years.

title: The New Left at Red Bull Arena
description: The final stat sheet from the Red Bulls match Saturday night against the visiting expansion Philadelphia Union showed that Brian Nielsen had played 67 minutes, had two shots and was offside once. That said, Nielsen made an instant impression in the matchs early minutes when he sped down the left flank, latched on to a lead pass and slipped a dangerous cross into the Philadelphia goal box.

title: The Fresh Perspective of Dirk Hayhurst
description: When Dirk Hayhurst was growing up, he could never relate to friends who idolized major league baseball players.

title: Austrian President on Way to Landslide Victory
description: BERLIN  President Heinz Fischer of Austria appeared to be heading for a landslide victory in his bid for a second term on Sunday, winning nearly 80 percent of the vote, according to preliminary results that were not expected to change.

title: Chances Are
description: Have you ever had that anxiety dream where you suddenly realize you have to take the final exam in some course youve never attended? For professors, it works the other way around  you dream youre giving a lecture for a class you know nothing about.

title: Elite U.S. Units Step Up Effort in Afghan City Before Attack
description: This article is by Thom Shanker, Helene Cooper and Richard A. Oppel Jr.

title: Teams Choose Production Over 40 Times
description: Mike Tanier writes for Football Outsiders and is a contributor for the Fifth Down.

title: Reducing Pay for Cultural Executives in New York
description: For years chief executives at many major cultural organizations in New York City enjoyed salary growth that was buoyed by a booming economy and rivaled that seen in corporate America. Compensation increases of 25 percent to 50 percent over five years were not unusual, and in some cases packages nearly doubled.

title: United-Continental Talks Said to Snag Over Price
description: 6:17 p.m. | Updated Merger talks between United Airlines and Continental Airlines reached an impasse over the weekend over a disagreement about the price of a stock-for-stock deal, people involved in the negotiations told DealBook.

title: Anand Wins Game 2 to Square Title Match
A Dark Day That Still Resonates
description: The slaughter of hundreds of unarmed villagers in Quang Ngai Province, Vietnam, in March 1968  an event that came to be known as the My Lai massacre  is both an open wound in the American psyche and a cautionary tale at a time when we are once again fighting wars, and killing civilians, on foreign soil.

title: Assessing Jewish Identity of Author Killed by Nazis
description: The first novel of Irne Nmirovskys that most people read was the last one she wrote. Nmirovsky, the Russian Jewish author, died at Auschwitz in 1942 at 39 after completing two parts of a five-part novel titled Suite Franaise. Secreted away in a trunk carried by Nmirovskys daughters, Denise and Elizabeth, as they escaped from German-occupied France, the manuscript was not published for more than 60 years. It received stunning reviews that simultaneously announced the discovery and loss of an enormous talent.

title: Doing Something Risky
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Are you a crossword fan or, more generally, a puzzle aficionado? The former probably knows or at least might be pleased to learn that the word aficionado implies not just a devotee, but an enthusiastic amateur. The latter might then view that as the start of a logic puzzle. Will Shortz cant be an aficionado because hes a professional, therefore the man in the blue house must smoke Lucky Strikes, or however that old syllogism goes. Were going to do something a little risky, perhaps, by expanding the scope of Wordplay just a little. More on that further down.

title: A Roundabout Route Ending at the Met
description: The English pianist Paul Lewis faced the same travel problems as other Europeans who were grounded because of ash from the volcano in Iceland, but he had a recital to play at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday evening, and he was determined to be here. When his flight from London to New York was canceled on Tuesday, he first considered going to Paris, but there was no guarantee that flights to New York would leave from there either. Then it turned out that he could get to New York with a connection in, of all places, Reykjavik, which was close enough to the action not to be affected.

title: Behind Bryzgalov, Coyotes Force Game 7 Against Red Wings
description: DETROIT  The Phoenix Coyotes have already had a dream season, and they continued to follow that Cinderella script Sunday in Game 6 of their opening-round series against the Detroit Red Wings.

title: He Just Did What Came Naturally
description: In the days before the Internet and other electronic distractions, many people of all ages played bridge. Some of the young experts went on to become well known in the bridge world, winning national and international championships. But others chose different careers.

title: Let the Choir Sing (in Earthy, Idiomatic Voices)
description: After many flights to New York were delayed because of the volcanic ash clouds hovering over Europe, the Chorus of the Mariinsky Theater finally arrived at Avery Fisher Hall in time for the second concert of The Russian Stravinsky: A Philharmonic Festival on Thursday night. The chorus was missed in Wednesdays opening-night program, conducted (as is the entire festival) by Valery Gergiev, which was to have included Les Noces, not heard at the Philharmonic since 1982.

title: On the Good Ship Wagner, Some High Seas Looming
description: Wagners early milestone Der Fliegende Hollnder (The Flying Dutchman) returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday night after a nearly 10-year absence, and the timing was right. There is a devoted audience for this opera, a mythical tale of a satanically accursed ship captain condemned to sail the seas forever, allowed one fleeting chance every seven years to dock his vessel and find redemption through the love of a woman. And August Everdings engrossing 1989 production effectively combines realistic settings with starkly modern imagery.

title: New CDs
description: MELISSA ETHERIDGE

title: Obama Eulogizes Victims of Mine Accident
description: BECKLEY, W.Va.  Twenty days later and twenty miles away, they came to say farewell to the dead of Upper Big Branch on Sunday, the widows and orphans, the friends and neighbors, and a president of the United States.

title: In One Sad Day, an Old World Artisan Confronts a New World
description: In Market Day, by the cartoonist James Sturm, Mendleman, a Jewish rug maker in Eastern Europe during the early 1900s, experiences a momentous 24 hours. Mendleman, who fashions his wares by hand, realizes change is in the air (cheaply made goods are beginning to rule the day), and one of the many strengths of this graphic novel is its ability to convey the rug makers highs and lows during this transition.

title: New York City Subways: Mostly Fewer Riders
description: Job losses sent ridership down in 2009, especially in Manhattan, but some lines experienced growth.

title: A Two-Fold History Lesson, Courtesy of Four Midcentury Masters
description: In reviving little-known little gems by four leading mid-20th-century choreographers, as it did in the Signatures 10 program on Saturday at Gould Hall, New York Theater Ballet confirms its status as an invaluable company. Very few in the audience can have seen all these gems before; fewer can feel that they know even one well.

title: Kudrows Web Series Going to Showtime
description: The actress Lisa Kudrows online series, Web Therapy, has found a second life on television. Showtime said it would telecast at least 10 half-hour episodes starting next year. In the largely ad-libbed Web episodes, Ms. Kudrow, right, plays Dr. Fiona Wallice, a therapist who shows more interest in herself than her patients. This well-regarded series just began its third season and can be seen at lstudio.com and elsewhere. As the TV landscape continues to change, we really fell in love with the idea of taking something that has made so much noise on the Web and re-conceiving it with the original creators as a completely satisfying yet different experience for a half-hour audience on a television network, Robert Greenblatt, the president for entertainment for Showtime, said in a statement Friday. The channel said the TV version of Web Therapy would include new scenes yet to be shot.

title: Dragon Back in First Place
description: It was a slow weekend at the movies as two new wide releases, The Back-Up Plan and The Losers, aptly titled, stumbled at the North American box office. The Back-Up Plan, a $30 million romantic comedy starring Jennifer Lopez and released by CBS Films, came in second place with an estimated $12.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. (CBS Films, which aggressively interpreted its films opening as very solid, hopes a shortage of female-oriented pictures will eventually turn the heavily marketed Back-Up Plan into a winner.) The $25 million thriller The Losers became the latest in a string of flops from Joel Silvers Dark Castle Entertainment with about $9.6 million, putting it in fourth place. The No. 1 film was a holdover: DreamWorks Animations How to Train Your Dragon, with positive word of mouth and premium-priced 3-D tickets, brought in about $15 million and a new total of $178 million. The comedy Date Night from 20th Century Fox chugged away in third place with about $10.6 million ($63.5 million total). The violent superhero comedy Kick-Ass, No. 1 last weekend, sunk to fifth place with $9.5 million ($34.9 million total).

title: Departures at Carmen
description: The production of Georges Bizets Carmen at the Vienna State Opera that Ioan Holender planned as his farewell as the companys general manager seems to be turning into more of a farewell to the productions stars. Representatives of the opera house announced on Friday that the mezzo soprano Elina Garanca, who was to sing the title role, has withdrawn from next months five-show engagement for health reasons, Agence France-Presse reported. In a letter to the opera house Ms. Garancas management wrote that she was feeling exhausted and off-color after undergoing minor surgery this month. She is the third artist to withdraw from this production for health reasons. The tenor Rolando Villazn canceled his involvement last year after undergoing surgery to remove a cyst on his vocal cords. Then, a few days ago the conductor Mariss Jansons also withdrew because of ill health. Mr. Holender, who is stepping down as general manager at the end of this season and had scheduled Carmen as a parting gift, has not given up. He has replaced Ms. Garanca with Nadia Krasteva, Mr. Villazn with Massimo Giordano, and Mr. Jansons with Andris Nelsons.

title: Scottsboro Boys Finds a New Home
description: The Vineyard Theaters recent production of The Scottsboro Boys, above, the musical by John Kander and Fred Ebb, is not disappearing just yet. Producers for the show, which ended its Off Broadway run this month, announced Thursday that it would play for eight weeks at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, with previews beginning on July 31. This month producers canceled plans for a Broadway transfer, saying no available theaters were appropriate for the show. The run at the Guthrie may buy producers more time to find the right home in New York. The show, with direction and choreography by Susan Stroman and a book by David Thompson,  about a group of young black men who were falsely accused of raping two white women in the 1930s, opens on Aug. 6 and runs through Sept. 25. .... The Vineyards new season is beginning to take shape, opening with the world premiere of Will Enos Middletown on Oct. 6, the theaters directors announced. Ken Rus Schmoll (What Once We Felt) is to direct the play, which explores the universe of a small American town through the forging of a friendship between a longtime resident and a new arrival. Casting and an official opening date have not been determined.

title: Gervais and Merchant Plan a New Series
description: Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchant, creators of The Office and Extras, have been commissioned to write a new series for BBC2, BBC News reported. The 30-minute comedy, called Lifes Too Short, will revolve around Warwick Davis, right, an actor who has dwarfism. The show will follow Mr. Davis, best known for his performances in the Harry Potter and Star Wars films, in his daily life, with occasional appearances from Mr. Gervais and Mr. Merchant. Were having so much fun working with Warwick, Mr. Gervais said. Pound for pound he is one of the funniest men I know. The show is also being developed for HBO in the United States; broadcast dates for both networks have not been announced.

title: The Joyces New Season
description: Acclaimed local troupes and international companies are expected at the Joyce Theater for the coming season, running Sept. 18 through Feb. 6. Among the headliners are the dancer Cdric Andrieux, in a visual autobiography conceived and directed by Jrme Bel; the Israeli dance company Batsheva Dance, returning after a 27-year absence from the Joyce; Ballet Hispanico; and Garth Fagan Dance. The full schedule is at joyce.org.

title: Random House Cedes Some Digital Rights to Styron Heirs
description: After publicly staking a claim to the right to publish electronic versions of books that already have a long history in print, Random House appears to be letting go of digital rights to several works by one prominent author without a fight, potentially opening the way for other authors to take their e-books away from traditional publishers.

title: Iraqi Insurgent Group Acknowledges Killing of Two Leaders
description: BAGHDAD  The insurgent group that includes Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia acknowledged in a statement circulated Sunday that its two leaders were killed in a raid a week ago, but it vowed to continue to wage war against the Green Zone government of Iraq.

title: Back in the 60s: Lets Tryst Again
description: For a bunch of desk jockeys, the boys from Consolidated Life are surprisingly athletic. In Rob Ashfords revival of the 1968 musical Promises, Promises, which opened on Sunday night at the Broadway Theater, the male members of the chorus demonstrate that wearing skinny suits neednt keep corporate executives from playing leap frog, turning cart wheels, bouncing off desks or frugging like, well, mad men.

title: 'Promises, Promises'
description: Images from the new Broadway revival.

title: Spammers Pay Others to Answer Security Tests
description: MUMBAI, India  Faced with stricter Internet security measures, some spammers have begun borrowing a page from corporate Americas playbook: they are outsourcing.

title: To Preserve Whales
description: To the Editor:

title: A Futile War on Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Hospital Visiting Rights for Same-Sex Partners
description: To the Editor:

title: Coyote vs. Greyhound: The Battle Lines Are Drawn
description: ELGIN, Okla.  One morning in an otherwise quiet corner of the Great Plains, high-pitched yips and deep growls sprang from a cluster of trees. Two greyhounds were fighting a pack of coyotes.

title: When Human Rights Becomes a Political Football
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rebuilding Phase for Independent Film
description: Only five years ago, the center of the still thriving independent film universe lay behind the green doors of a converted TriBeCa warehouse from which the Weinstein brothers, Bob and Harvey, ran Miramax Films.

title: After Girardi Is Not Decisive, Moraless Homer Is
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  To Joe Girardi, one of the worst things anyone could say about him as a manager is that he was unprepared. He has a trusty binder that is loaded with trends, scouting reports, matchups, everything he could possibly want or need. When he makes decisions, he does so with conviction. He does not look back.

title: Fuel Trucks Attacked in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Twelve trucks, most of them carrying fuel to a NATO base in eastern Afghanistan, were burned by an angry crowd early Sunday less than 30 miles from Kabul, according to local officials and NATO reports. The attack was thought to be in retribution for two raids by a joint Afghan-American force over the weekend, Afghan officials said.

title: U.S. Extradition Effort Strains Relationship With Jamaica
description: MEXICO CITY  Christopher Cokes nicknames are numerous: General, President, Shortman, Dudus. But the one that American law enforcement officials say sums up his illicit activities best of all is simply Mr. Coke.

title: Monetizing an iPhone Spectacle
description: We all know that advertisers need to pay for clicks to keep the Web spinning. But what does it mean when publishers start paying for them as well?

title: Pressure Is Building on Disputed Wind Farm
description: BOSTON  Political pressure continues to build on Interior Secretary Ken Salazar as he prepares to announce his decision this week on the fate of a proposed wind farm off the coast of Cape Cod, Mass., that has been stalled for nine years.

title: Modernizing the Kodak Moment as Social Sharing
description: DESPITE the predictions of naysayers, the concept of the Kodak moment has endured into the 21st century, even if Kodachrome film is going the way of the Brownie Starmite camera. Now, Eastman Kodak, eager to sustain some recent momentum, is seeking to redefine the phrase for a new generation of picture-takers.

title: Ready for a Room Full of Fourth Graders?
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Ball State Walk-On Gets Tryout With Giants
description: Brandon Crawford, the 33-year-old former Ball State defensive end who held on to his hopes of reaching the N.F.L. through a high school arrest and a stint in the Marines, will get a chance to prove he belongs after all. Crawford was invited to try out for the Giants at their rookie camp this weekend.

title: Africas Role in the U.S. Slave Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Mississippi Assessing Damage by Tornado
description: YAZOO CITY, Miss.  Carolyn Veazey fought back tears on Sunday outside the remains of her home, hoping to find her missing cat and unsure of her next move, a day after a deadly tornado tore through town.

title: South Africa Redoubles Efforts Against AIDS
description: SOVANE, South Africa  South Africa, trying to overcome years of denial and delay in confronting its monumental AIDS crisis, is now in the midst of a feverish buildup of testing, treatment and prevention that United Nations officials say is the largest and fastest expansion of AIDS services ever attempted by any nation.

title: Socialists in Hungary Are Ousted in Elections
description: PRAGUE  Hungarys center-right Fidesz party secured a two-thirds majority in second-round parliamentary elections on Sunday, ousting the governing Socialist Party and giving it the authority to pass legislation, including crucial economic changes, without having to form alliances with the opposition.

title: Brooklyn School Scores High Despite Poverty
description: To ace the state standardized tests, which begin on Monday, Public School 172 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, finds money for coaches in writing, reading and math. Teachers keep detailed notes on each child, writing down weaknesses and encouraging them to repeat tasks. There is after-school help and Saturday school.

title: No Secrets in the Sky
description: Washington

title: Apple Allows a Cartoon App, and a Glimpse of Free Speech
description: Mark Fiores cartoon application is now available through the Apple App Store. But a group that represents cartoonists like him is now lobbying for the company to change its rules for humorous, politically charged apps.

title: Classical Musics Comeback, on Public Radio
description: In the last decade, public radio stations could not get rid of classical music fast enough, as station after station abandoned the format for news and talk, alienating classical fans.

title: Sex Scandal Is New Crisis for Troubled French Team
description: PARIS  Less than two months before the start of the World Cup in South Africa, the French national soccer team, its on-field reputation in decline, is dealing with a sex scandal involving several players and under-age prostitutes.

title: A Strong Woman Behind the Men of DreamWorks
description: Hollywoods index skimmers may want to jump past the big names  Steven Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg, David Geffen  in Nicole LaPortes new book on DreamWorks, The Men Who Would Be King, in favor of Terry Press.

title: Why Doormen?
description: JUST like everyone else, I was overjoyed that a doorman strike was averted last week in New York. But as I read the articles leading up to the resolution  an arc as dramatic as that of the Cuban missile crisis  I found myself asking a disturbing question: Are doormen necessary? Necessary? Why, the very thought could only be the product of a troubled mind. You might as well ask if the Holland Tunnel is necessary! You might as well ask if the Knicks are necessary! (Actually, never mind about that one.)

title: Foolish Memo on Popes Visit Spurs Apology by the British
description: LONDON  Britains Foreign Office has apologized publicly for a foolish internal memo circulated to government departments that suggested, with apparent sarcasm, that the ideal itinerary for Pope Benedict XVIs visit to Britain in September might include the popes opening an abortion clinic, blessing a gay marriage and introducing a Benedict brand of condoms.

title: Borrowing Our Way to Failure
description: Albany

title: Indian Justice Inches Closer to Chapters of Violence
description: NEW DELHI  On Oct. 31, 1984, two Sikh bodyguards gunned down Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in her garden. In the three harrowing days that followed, more than 3,000 Sikhs were killed by enraged mobs seeking to avenge her death.

title: Paying Tribute to Fallen Miners
description: Family members gathered at a memorial service for the victims of the Upper Big Branch mine disaster in West Virginia. President Obama and Gov. Joe Manchin III took part in the ceremony.

title: Sex Ads Seen Adding Revenue to Craigslist
description: Craigslist, one of the most popular Web sites in the United States, is on track to increase its revenue 22 percent this year, largely from its controversial sex advertisements. That financial success is reviving scrutiny from law-enforcement officials who say the ads are still being used for illegal ends.

title: W. Willard Wirtz, Labor Chief, Dies at 98
description: W. Willard Wirtz, an outspoken champion of the unemployed who was secretary of labor under Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson and was the last surviving member of the Kennedy cabinet, died on Saturday. He was 98.

title: Not Even in South Park?
description: Two months before 9/11, Comedy Central aired an episode of South Park entitled Super Best Friends, in which the cartoon shows foul-mouthed urchins sought assistance from an unusual team of superheroes. These particular superfriends were all religious figures: Jesus, Krishna, Buddha, Mormonisms Joseph Smith, Taoisms Lao-tse  and the Prophet Muhammad, depicted with a turban and a 5 oclock shadow, and introduced as the Muslim prophet with the powers of flame.

title: Investigation Links Critics Death to Top Chechens
description: VIENNA  Umar S. Israilov, a whistleblower living in hiding after accusing Chechnyas president of personally participating in torture, kidnapping and murder, was gunned down here last year as he stepped from a grocery store with yogurt, eggs and bags of M&Ms and Gummi Bears for his three young children.

title: From the Mall to the Docks, Signs of Rebound
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  The docks are humming again at this sprawling Pacific port, with clouds of golden dust billowing off the piles of grain spilling into the bellies of giant tankers.

title: All Bets Are Off in British Campaign
description: LONDON  With 10 campaigning days left until a general election that has seen a strong and unexpected surge by the left-of-center Liberal Democrats, Britain has been thrust into a complex new political calculus about which party  or parties  will govern after May 6.

title: United and Continental Merger Talks Said to Stall
description: Merger talks between United Airlines and Continental Airlines reached an impasse over the weekend over a disagreement about the price of a deal, people involved in the negotiations said on Sunday.

title: Stop by Stop, Subways Decline and Growth in 2009
description: Every year, New York City Transit releases a station-by-station breakdown of ridership in the biggest subway system in the nation. Shake-ups are rare; the usual suspects  Times Square, Grand Central Station  routinely top the list, and last year was no exception.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Friday about Sondheim on Sondheim, at Studio 54, referred incorrectly to a New York magazine article in 1994 that was the inspiration for God, a new Stephen Sondheim song that was performed. The article was featured inside the magazine; it was not the cover article.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: After the Storm
description: Hundreds of Mississippians were affected by violent weather that led to damaging winds and powerful tornadoes.

title: The Understated Elegance of the Yankees Rivera
description: He entered the clubhouse with the same purposeful stride with which he exits the bullpen. Into the big room came Mariano Rivera as if protecting a one-run lead in the ninth inning, the middle of the order due up.

title: An Uneasy Marriage of the Cultish and the Rumpled
description: When Bloomberg L.P. bought Businessweek in December, a group of the magazines writers, who were being transferred to the Bloomberg newswire, attended a two-week training session. They learned that the terminals, costing about $20,000 a year, drove Bloombergs business; they discovered that the main elevators stop only on the sixth and ninth floors, forcing a manic feeling in the building as employees dash up and down staircases.

title: Berating the Raters
description: Lets hear it for the Senates Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations. Its work on the financial crisis is increasingly looking like the 21st-century version of the Pecora hearings, which helped usher in New Deal-era financial regulation. In the past few days scandalous Wall Street e-mail messages released by the subcommittee have made headlines.

title: Strides, Often Painful, but Always, Always Forward
description: Hicksville, N.Y.

title: A Better Chance
description: Gov. David Patersons juvenile justice task force was on the mark when it advised him to stop sending low-risk young offenders to faraway lockups and place more of them in lower-cost community-based programs.

title: Cape Wind and Mr. Salazar
description: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar is expected to announce this week whether a controversial wind farm off the coast of Massachusetts can proceed. Given the countrys need for alternative energy sources  and the administrations commitment to promoting them  it would be dismaying if he did not give the go-ahead.

title: Questions Surround a Delay in Help for a Dying Man
description: It will probably never be clear how many people realized that Hugo Alfredo Tale-Yax was dying.

title: St. Vincents Is Putting Building on Market
description: Less than two weeks after St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan filed for bankruptcy, the hospital is officially putting on the market the first of many buildings in its valuable Greenwich Village real estate portfolio.

title: Poorer Nations Get Larger Role in World Bank
description: WASHINGTON  Members of the World Bank agreed on Sunday to support a $5.1 billion increase in its operating capital, the largest increase in general financing since 1988, and to give developing economies a greater say in running the antipoverty institution.

title: Growing Split in Arizona Over Immigration
description: MESA, Ariz.  They stood a few miles from each other, but as far apart as heat and cold.

title: When the System Works
description: Education Secretary Arne Duncan has vowed to press states to remake the 5,000 or so chronically failing schools that account for about half of the nations dropouts and usually serve  or more to the point fail to serve  the poorest children. A $4 billion school improvement fund is intended to give states the help and the incentive to turn these schools around.

title: Prosecutors Seek an 8-Year Term for Bruno
description: Federal prosecutors are seeking more than eight years of prison time for Joseph L. Bruno, the former Republican majority leader of the State Senate, as punishment for concealing hundreds of thousands of dollars in payments from a businessman who sought help from the Legislature.

title: New Yorkers Earn More, Early On, a Study Shows
description: New York City may be one of the best places for men with college degrees to seek their fortunes  at least until they reach their late 30s. After that, they might be better off in Atlanta or Dallas.

title: Praise for Reports on Hurricane Katrina
description: They are not winning trophies or plaques, but some journalists who write about New Orleans are unwittingly earning Seals of Approval from Levees.org, a group that educates people about why the city was so vulnerable.

title: God of Carnage to Close
description: After more than 400 performances and three different casts, Yasmina Rezas God of Carnage will close on Broadway on June 27, the producers announced. In a statement they said they were incredibly proud and thrilled with the success of the show but had decided to end the run with the completion of the current casts contracts. Carnage, a comedy about two couples who fight over an altercation between their sons, opened in March 2009 at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater with Jeff Daniels, Hope Davis, James Gandolfini and Marcia Gay Harden. It went on to win the 2009 Tony award for best play, as well as a best actress award for Ms. Harden and best director for Matthew Warchus. At the time it was one of the highest-grossing plays on Broadway. In November a second cast  Christine Lahti, Annie Potts, Jimmy Smits and Ken Stott  took over; then a third cast, with Janet McTeer, Lucy Liu, Mr. Daniels in a different role, and Dylan Baker, opened in March. The show continued to gain critical acclaim with each new cast, but it failed to sustain its original commercial success. Also, recent talks of a national tour ended after producers found that not enough theaters in major cities would be available for booking.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Charles River Said Close to $1.6 Billion Deal
description: 11:44 p.m. | Updated Charles River Laboratories, a laboratory services provider, is close to acquiring WuXi AppTec, a Chinese pharmaceutical outsourcing services provider, for about $1.6 billion, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 25, 2010

title: New Yorks Mayor, but Bermuda Shares Custody
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda  At Gregs Steakhouse, the power lunch spot on this sun-soaked island, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is such a regular that he has his own booth, with a view of the Parliament building. The waiters have memorized his order: coffee-rubbed New York strip steak.

title: What Are They Doing?
description: So tell us again why we are paying their salaries? New Yorks Legislature was supposed to approve a state budget before April 1. Nearly a month later, the leaders still cant come up with a plan to close a $9.2 billion deficit. Meanwhile, the other 210 senators and Assembly members are mostly sitting on their hands.

title: Accounts, People and Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Governor Christie vs. the Teachers: Nastiness in New Jersey
description: Even given the current decibel level in politics, the nasty din surrounding the customarily snore-inducing rubber-stamping of local school board budgets in New Jersey last week was something to behold.

title: In Court Nominees, Is Obama Looking for Empathy by Another Name?
description: WASHINGTON  Empathy is out. Understanding ordinary lives is in. Is there a difference? President Obama is about to find out.

title: From New York Harbors Depths, Muck to Restore Islands in Jamaica Bay
description: For generations, the islands of Jamaica Bay, the 26-square-mile natural sanctuary off the Brooklyn and Queens shoreline that is home to hundreds of species of migratory birds and marine life, have been disappearing, victims of environmental neglect.

title: For Gardener, Love of a Park Comes With the Job
description: First the man, with a ponytail and fraying green pants, started picking up the trash. Then he planted a purple plum tree and a garden with hydrangeas. By the time he put up a sign in Coffey Park requesting banana peels, the neighborhood was paying attention.

title: Girardi Cant Decide, but You Can
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Three weeks into my first season covering the Yankees, I dont have a frame of reference to say just how indecisive Joe Girardi was during the seventh inning of Sundays 8-4 loss to the Angels. But I asked Tyler Kepner, who covered the Yankees for years, and he said nothing similar immediately came to mind.

title: Urban Forager | Wilds of the Rooftop
description: The weeds are welcome here, said Anasa Scott as we walked across a gravel rooftop at the City College of New York on a sunny day in Harlem, making our way around a solar panel and a satellite receiver to check out a series of south-facing soil beds that comprised the green roof.

title: Mets May Have Musical Edge on Yankees
description: Ruth Roberts and Lou Stallman own musical pieces of New York baseball history.

title: Longtime Hollywood Hand Is Joining Boutique Bank
description: LOS ANGELES  Skip Paul, the video game pioneer, pal of Steven Spielberg and all-around Hollywood power broker, is headlining a push into the movie capital by one of New Yorks fastest-rising investment banks.

title: After 15 Months in Office, Policy vs. Politics for Obama
description: Inside Washington, President Obama is savoring a springtime resurgence: signs of economic recovery, victory on health care, the upper hand in the financial regulation debate.

title: Best Hope for Greece: Minimize the Losses
description: Only a few weeks ago, the idea that Greece might restructure its debt seemed like the nuclear option. Now restructuring  a polite alternative to outright default  is not only thinkable, but even likely.

title: Baseball Songs for New York: Write the Lyrics
description: New Yorks two major league teams have their own signature songs. Meet the Mets was first played at the Polo Grounds in 1963 and continues to be played at Citi Field. A short, instrumental version of Here Come the Yankees, which was written in the late 1960s, is played before and after each game on WCBS Radio. But do either of the songs still reflect the image of the teams?

title: Cavaliers Overwhelm the Bulls, With James Providing the Muscle
description: CHICAGO  These days, LeBron James speaks often of goals and destinations, dialing it in and turning it up, being mentally prepared and on the same page, remaining focused and taking care of business.

title: Major Earners in the Cultural World
description: A list of the culture world's major earners.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the Standard & Poors Case-Shiller home price index for February and consumer confidence for April (Tuesday); and first-quarter gross domestic product and the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer confidence index for March (Friday).

title: Charles River Said to Be Near a Deal for Drug Research Firm in China
description: Charles River Laboratories is close to acquiring WuXi AppTec, a Chinese pharmaceutical outsourcing services provider, for about $1.6 billion, people briefed on the matter said Sunday.

title: A Milestone for Internet Ad Revenue
description: For the first time, marketers spent more in 2009 on Internet advertising than in magazines, according to a report from ZenithOptimedia, which said online ad spending would rapidly close ground on newspapers. Despite a record-setting $6.3 billion fourth quarter, online advertising revenue declined 3.4 percent for the year from 2008, the first year-over-year falloff since 2002. The loss in ad spending across all media was an even steeper 12.3 percent for the year and 2 percent for the fourth quarter.

title: Quake Strikes Off Coast of Taiwan
description: A 6.9-magnitude earthquake struck off the southeast coast of Taiwan Monday morning, the United States Geological Survey said.

title: Too Much Risk in Film Futures
description: Markets allowing bets on movie ticket sales have gotten a regulatory thumbs-up  most recently Cantor Fitzgeralds proposal last week. Trading box-office futures could provide studios a new way to hedge and to raise money. But such speculation also risks encouraging all sorts of risky behavior. For Hollywood, Wall Streets antics are better left on-screen.

title: Alan Rich, Los Angeles Music Critic, Dies at 85
description: Alan Rich, a critic whose eloquent and passionate writing about classical music in both New York and Los Angeles made him an important voice in the American musical world over a long career, died on Friday at his home in West Los Angeles. He was 85.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: New York, New York, New York, New York
description: Hiroyuki Ito, a freelancer for The New York Times, was born in Tokyo in 1968. He moved to New York 18 years ago, studied at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University and began his freelancing career at The Village Voice. He now lives in Astoria, Queens. In Camera Obscura, Mr. Ito described his practice of storing exposed film rolls in the vegetable compartment of his refrigerator. Every few months, I need to develop all these films so that the vegetables can reclaim their space.

title: Word of the Day | ignoble
description: ignoble \ ig-no-bl \ adjective

title: At the Range, Drive Less and Practice More
description: I have seen you at the driving range. Wherever you play, I have seen you.

title: A Mets Mystery That Might Solve Itself
description: Through the first three weeks of the season, the Mets right-hander John Maine has been vexed, perplexed and maybe a little hexed. His latest problem  pain in his left elbow  caused him to leave Friday nights game early, and left him muttering the word frustrating amid phrases like its one thing after another.

title: Alan Sillitoe, Angry British Novelist, Dies at 82
description: Alan Sillitoe, a British writer whose two early works  a novel, Saturday Night and Sunday Morning, and a short story, The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner  drew attention to the seething alienation of the postwar working class in England, died on Sunday in London. He was 82.

title: Melvyn Zerman, Publisher of Performing Arts Books, Dies at 79
description: Melvyn Zerman, whose Limelight Editions gave a second life to neglected classics on the performing arts by bringing them back in paperback, and who published an eclectic list of hardcover titles as well, died on April 19 at his home in Manhattan. He was 79.

title: Hertz to Buy Dollar Thrifty for $1.2 Billion
description: Hertz Global Holdings said late on Sunday that it has agreed to buy the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group for $1.2 billion in cash and stock, uniting two of the biggest names in the rental car business.

title: Buyout Firms Said to Prepare a Nielsen I.P.O.
description: The private equity owners of Nielsen, best-known for its expansive television and Internet ratings research, are preparing to stage an initial public offering for the company, The Financial Times reported Monday, citing unnamed sources.

title: Pelfrey, Then Cloudburst, Close Out the Braves
description: Mets starter Mike Pelfrey has four victories in four starts this season, but Sunday nights quirky triumph  1-0 over the Atlanta Braves  merits an asterisk for at least two reasons.

title: Longtime Hollywood Hand Is Joining Centerview
description: Skip Paul, the video game pioneer, pal of Steven Spielberg and all-around Hollywood power broker, is headlining a push into the movie capital by one of New Yorks fastest-rising investment banks, The New York Timess Brooks Barnes reports.

title: News Quiz | April 26, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Encountering Kyoto
description: WHERE on a world map is Kyoto?

title: Democrats Unite on Finance Bill, Pressuring G.O.P.
description: Senate Democrats said Sunday that they had bridged internal party differences and coalesced around a plan to tighten regulation of derivatives, the complex financial instruments that were a major factor in the 2008 economic crisis.

title: The Rise of the Fleet-Footed Start-Up
description: Eric Ries and Steven Blank think they have a better way to build a start-up, one that takes less time and money to try new ideas and find paying customers. They are leading proponents of the lean start-up  a fresh approach to creating companies that has attracted much attention in the last year or so among Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, technologists and investors.

title: What Do You Think About the New Arizona Immigration Law?
description: Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona signed the nations toughest bill on illegal immigration into law on Friday. Aiming to identify, prosecute and deport illegal immigrants, it will make the failure to carry immigration documents a crime and give the police broad power to detain anyone suspected of being in the country illegally. What do you think of this law? Why?

title: Pressure Is Building on Disputed Wind Farm
description: Political pressure continues to build on Interior Secretary Ken Salazar as he prepares to announce his decision this week on the fate of a proposed wind farm off the coast of Cape Cod, Mass., that has been stalled for nine years.

title: Babson Winners Sell Viral Videos and Healthy Foods
description: From Lora Kolodny at Youre the Boss:

title: Rich: Fight On, Goldman Sachs!
description: From Frank Rich on The New York Timess Op-Ed Page:

title: Krugman: Berating the Raters
description: From Paul Krugman on The New York Timess Opinion page:

title: Dow Ends Week Up, Extending Streak to 5 Days
description: Stocks pushed higher on Friday as the Dow Jones industrial average rose for a fifth consecutive day, and analysts saw little economic news on the horizon that would upset market sentiment next week.

title: Twitter Snaps Up a Text-Messaging Company
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: Suicide Attacker Misses British Ambassadors Convoy Traveling in Yemeni Capital
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The British ambassador in Yemen survived an attack on Monday morning by a lone suicide bomber who detonated his explosive belt as the ambassadors armored convoy was passing, witnesses said.

title: A Marriage of the Cultish and the Rumpled
description: When Bloomberg L.P. bought BusinessWeek in December, a group of the magazines writers, who were being transferred to the Bloomberg newswire, attended a two-week training session. They learned that the terminals, costing about $20,000 a year, drove Bloombergs business; they discovered that the main elevators stop only on the sixth and ninth floors, forcing a manic feeling in the building as employees dash up and down staircases, The New York Timess Stephanie Clifford writes.

title: More Than 200,000 a Day Now Cycling, Data Suggests
description: Build it and they will ride. Thats the message conveyed in the latest annual estimate of the number of bicyclists in New York City by Transportation Alternatives, which found roughly 236,000 New Yorkers riding each day in 2009, up 28 percent from 185,000 daily riders the year before.

title: Too Much Risk in Film Futures?
description: Markets allowing bets on movie ticket sales have gotten a regulatory thumbs-up  most recently, Cantor Fitzgeralds proposal last week. Trading box-office futures could provide studios a new way to hedge and to raise money. But such speculation also risks encouraging all sorts of risky behavior. For Hollywood, Wall Streets antics are better left on-screen, Reuters Breakingviews argues.

title: Snipping Zithers With Scissors
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have tirelessly tied our tongues with a tonnage of tongue twisters.

title: Review: Your Money, Their Pockets
description: Seldom in our 230-odd years as a country have Congress and the White House had the fortitude to impose on American bankers and financiers a set of regulations sufficiently stringent to prevent them from pushing us into destructive panics and recessions. And once again Washington may be demonstrating its lack of backbone, The New York Timess Louis Uchitelle writes.

title: Sears Buys Stake in Canadian Unit From Ackman
description: The Sears Holdings Corporation said on Friday that it was buying a stake in Sears Canada from the hedge fund manager Bill Ackman for $560 million, taking a step toward full ownership of its Canadian unit.

title: Morgenson: Got Any Reforms in Size XL?
description: From Gretchen Morgensons latest Fair Game column:

title: Bank of Ireland to Raise $4.5 Billion
description: Bank of Ireland, the countrys biggest bank by market value, plans to raise as much as 3.4 billion euros ($4.5 billion) to bolster capital as real-estate losses surge, Bloomberg News reported.

title: With Impact Investing, Not Only Returns Matter
description: From Paul Sullivans latest Wealth Matters column:

title: South Korea Mourns Victims of Warship Sinking
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Politicians, soldiers and citizens lined up in the rain on Monday to pay tribute to at least 40 sailors killed in the sinking of a warship, as the country inched closer to placing blame on North Korea and faced the urgent question of how it might respond.

title: Former Official in Kyrgyzstan Is Extradited From Russia
description: MOSCOW  Kyrgyzstans provisional government said Monday that Russian special forces had seized and extradited Kyrgyzstans former interior minister, who had been convalescing in Moscow after being severely beaten during bloody antigovernment riots this month.

title: In Hong Kong, One Chefs Private Dinners
description: Many of the most interesting meals in Hong Kong are being served behind closed doors. Private kitchens are all the rage  and help chefs skirt the citys strict licensing on restaurants.

title: New Tourre E-mails Show Trader Under Duress
description: The Senates Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations released a number of Goldman Sachs e-mails this weekend in preparation for their hearing Tuesday on the causes of the financial crisis, and reported in detail here.

title: Do Nice Gals Finish Last?
Emerson Electric Bids $1.1 Billion for Chloride
description: Emerson Electric said Monday it has made a hostile 723 million ($1.1 billion) offer to acquire Chloride Group, a British competitor in providing back-up power supply systems, The Associated Press reported.

title: Obama Fulfills Pledge With Entrepreneur Summit
description: President Barack Obama on Monday will begin a new effort to build business and social ties to the Muslim world, Reuters reported.

title: E.On Said to Shortlist 3 Bidders For U.S. Business
description: Germanys E.On, the worlds largest utility by sales, has shortlisted three bidders for the multibillion-euro sale of its United States business, Reuters reported, citing three people with knowledge of the matter.

title: UBS-U.S. Deal Tied to Bank Bonuses?
description: Switzerlands economy minister said she hoped Parliament would not link a deal between UBS and the United States on disclosing secret bank accounts with questions such as bankers bonuses, the newspaper Sonntag reported on Sunday.

title: Summers on Goldman E-Mails and Transparency
description: E-mail messages sent by Goldman Sachs executives describing the money the firm made by betting against risky mortgage securities highlight the need for transparency in financial markets, Lawrence Summers, a senior White House adviser, said on Sunday.

title: Vue Said to Eye Possible Sale
description: Vue Entertainment, which controls more than 600 movie screens in the U.K., is planning a strategic review which might lead to a sale, The Financial Times reported. The move comes as Lloyds Banking Group is reportedly gearing up to sell a portfolio of equity stakes, which includes a 29 percent stake in Vue.

title: BofA Said to Near Decision on Chairman
description: Bank of America has narrowed the contenders for chairman to the directors Frank Bramble and Charles Holliday, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: The Trouble With College Costs
description: Todays idea: Because universities lock away objective information about how well they teach, consumers obsess on college reputation rather than true quality and drive up costs astronomically, a critic says.

title: Geithner Resents Wall Streeter Tag
description: Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner would like you to know that hes no Wall Streeter, thank you very much.

title: Hong Kong Landlord Plans $2.7 Billion I.P.O.
description: Swire Properties, landlord to Time Warner and Societe Generale in Hong Kong, plans to raise as much as HK$20.8 billion ($2.7 billion) in an initial public offering, said four people with knowledge of the plan, Bloomberg News reported.

title: A New Blog on Climate and Energy Choices
description: I first got to know Michael A. Levi, a talented young analyst of the interface between science, technology, economics and policy, while reporting on the unnerving prospect of dirty bombs in the wake of the 2001 World Trade Center attacks. Since then, as a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, hes dived in deep on climate and energy policy, and Ive found him consistently able to cut through the confounding layers of the super wicked world of climate diplomacy (or the lack of it).

title: Buffett Wants Grandfather Clause for Derivatives
description: As Democrats moved closer to an overhaul of financial regulations Sunday, The Wall Street Journalreported thatWarren Buffett  the man who once branded derivatives as financial weapons of mass destruction  has been fighting against the deal.

title: Hong Kong Regulator Seeks Trading Ban on Tiger Asia
description: Hong Kongs securities regulator is asking a court to impose a trading ban on Tiger Asia Management, amid new allegations of insider trading at the New York-based firm seeded by hedge fund veteran Julian Robertson, according to press reports.

title: Why Small-Business Owners Raid the College Fund
description: I have been following with great interest the trials and tribulations of Paul Downs and his woodworking business as he navigates troubled waters (Ill get back to business groups in my next post). Ive also been following the comments that Pauls posts have been getting.

title: Q. and A.: Getting Ready for a Close-Up
description: Q.

title: Senate Braces for Financial Showdown
description: Its a question of who will blink in the Senate this week as Democrats and Republicans head for a showdown over new rules to rein in the nations financial institutions.

title: Best Hope for Greece: Minimize the Losses
description: Only a few weeks ago, the idea that Greece might restructure its debt seemed like the nuclear option. Now restructuring  a polite alternative to outright default  is not only thinkable, but even likely.

title: Charles River Buys Chinese Drug Research Firm
description: Charles River Laboratories said Monday that it had agreed to acquire WuXi Pharma Tech, a Chinese pharmaceutical outsourcing services provider, in a cash and stock deal worth $1.6 billion, David Barboza and Michael J. de la Merced reported in The New York Times.

title: Sampler: San Francisco City Salaries Soar, and Pot Goes Corporate
description: One in Three San Francisco Employees Made $100,000 | Almost one in three of 27,000 city workers in San Francisco made six-figure salaries last year, more than one in three of all city employees. Its a pay club whose membership has grown steadily over the past decade, even without counting health insurance or pension benefits. Overtime and payouts for unused vacation days sent many of those city workers 2009 compensations over the $100,000 level. The retired deputy police chief, Charles Keohane, who left the force in mid-2009, led the pay pack, receiving $516,118 because of stored-up vacation, sick days and comp time. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: When Good Is Better Than Best
description: Lets say a subway station had peeling paint, decaying ceilings, cracked tiles. And lets say you would be happy to see just one of those problems go away.

title: Harbinger Continues to Trim Times Co. Stake
description: One of The New York Times Companys largest shareholders, Harbinger Capital Partners, said last week that it cut its stake to 9.4 percent, as the firm continues to pare its holdings in the newspaper publisher.

title: Faneca Is Upset With Jets Decision? Are You?
description: Youre going to stay the same, get better or get worse. Were getting better. Thats why we made the move we made. Coach Rex Ryan, on the decision to break up one of the best offensive lines in the league

title: Speed Read for Monday, April 26
description: Here are some highlights from Mondays edition of The New York Times:

title: Hertz to Buy Dollar Thrifty for $1.2 Billion
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: Media Equation: The Case of the iPhone Prototype
description: Just how much is a scoop worth? David Carr writes in his Media Equation column about the prototype iPhone that someone found in a California bar and sold to Gawker Media, which doled out the juicy details last week on its Gizmodo Web site. Was Gawkers chief, Nick Denton, right to pay for it? Mr. Carr writes:

title: Your Jokes: New Slogan for Tab
description: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Healthy Eggplant Parmigiana
description: Michael Scelfo, the 36-year-old executive chef at both the Temple Bar and the Russell House Tavern in Cambridge, Mass., invented this variation on eggplant parmigiana three years ago.

title: Off to the Races
description: Welcome back to The Rail, where for the next six weeks or so we unapologetic horseplayers and horse lovers will dissect and prognosticate, analyze and bloviate about all things thoroughbred racing. Ive come to think of this space as one of those cozy bars off the paddock, where trainers and owners come to watch the replays of the races as soon as their horses are off the track, and where handicappers divine genius between busting each otherschops.

title: In Defense of Giants Pick of Pierre-Paul
description: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down.

title: Treasury Prepares 1.5 Billion Citi Shares for Sale
description: The Treasury Department said on Monday that it was preparing to sell 1.5 billion Citigroup shares, the next step in its efforts to withdraw from its big ownership position in the bank.

title: Submit Your Funny Caption
description: Big Ben? | Tell us whats going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned images were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. The latest funniest captions are at right.

title: Dollars and Daggers in Californias Energy Battles
description: In California, where government-by-ballot-proposition has been raised to a high art, energy companies are pouring millions of dollars into efforts to protect their interests. The one that has gotten the most attention is a push to derail the states landmark 2006 law to combat global warming.

title: The Team That Built the S.E.C.s Goldman Case
description: What kind of team do you assemble when youre trying to catch an investment bank?

title: New Yorks Indie Film Scene Struggles Toward Resurrection
description: Hollywood correspondent Michael Cieply digs into the indie film scene in New York, and finds that a new group of moviemakers are attempting to revitalize the movement with a mix of low production costs, penny-pinching marketing and an eagerness to distribute through any platform available. For more than a decade, New York dominated the indie film scene, but the financial collapse and credit crisis has decimated it. He writes:

title: The Early Word: Financial Forays
description: Democrats will press ahead with their plan to overhaul the nations financial regulatory system this week, amid mounting pressure to tackle climate and immigration legislation before the midterm elections.

title: High Rates of Poverty, and High Test Scores
description: What were reading this morning:

title: Stifel Financial and Thomas Weisel Merge
description: Stifel Financial, the brokerage house based in St. Louis, said Monday that it had reached a merger agreement with Thomas Weisel Partners worth about $300 million.

title: Girls Just Want the Day Off
description: If you have a case of the Mondays and would prefer to be anywhere but your place of work, why not try the 11th-hour excuse that Cyndi Lauper broke out Sunday night on The Celebrity Apprentice? The degree of difficulty is extremely high if youre not a rock star, but if you have an alibi to match hers, we say you deserve the day off. (Note: We tried this on our boss. He didnt buy it.)

title: Must Self-Insured Companies Cover Adult Children?
description: Q.

title: In Bermuda, Bloombergs Construction Woes
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda  In New York City, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has taken a harsh line against builders whose work is not up to code, beefing up inspections and levying hefty fines for violations.

title: Ex-Leaders Twin Declares Run in Poland
