description: BERLIN  Despite facing long odds against a victory, Polands former prime minister on Monday declared his candidacy for president in a special election to replace his twin brother, who was killed in a plane crash earlier this month.

title: Bush Memoir Coming in November
description: Former President George W. Bushs memoir,Decision Points, will be releasedby Crown Publishers, a division of Random House,on Nov. 9, the publisher said Monday.Mr. Bushwill write about political and personal challengesand discuss his handling of events including the 9/11 attacks and Hurricane Katrina, as well as his embracing of his faith amid his effort to quit drinking. In a news release, Crown said that Mr. Bush would focus on 14 critical decisions in his life and share his reflections on subjects including the closely fought 2000 presidential election and the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: Q.&A.: Sanders Looks at Financial Bill From the Left
description: Senator Bernard Sanders, the Vermont independent, has won a reputation for being one of Wall Streets toughest critics. Mr. Sanders has been pushing hard to secure a strong financial regulatory bill that would keep banks from being too big to fail in an effort to eliminate the need for future government bailouts. The Senate is expected to take a key procedural vote on the bill by Monday evening.

title: Strong Earnings but Little Direction
description: Stocks ended mixed on Monday, wavering between optimism over strong corporate earnings and persistent concerns in the financial sector about regulation and Greeces debt troubles.

title: Smog in a Rural Valley? Mystery Is Solved
description: The smog in Californias San Joaquin Valley has puzzled scientists for years. Even though the region is largely rural and agricultural, its smog levels exceed those of densely populated cities like Los Angeles.

title: Celebrated Spanish Matador Survives Goring
description: Over the weekend, doctors in Mexico struggled to save the life of Spains most celebrated matador, Jos Toms Romn Martn, after a bull tore a six-inch gash in his left thigh on Saturday in the Mexican city of Aguascalientes. The bullfighter, who is known to fans and the media simply by his double-barreled first name, Jos Toms, needed 17 pints of blood and three hours of emergency surgery after being gored by an 1,100-pound bull named Navegante on Saturday afternoon.

title: The Morning Line: Eskendereyas Defection
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

title: Sauces for Grains and Vegetables
description: Lately Ive received several requests from readers for sauces to serve with cooked grains and vegetables. One reader cited an item called simply a bowl at a vegan restaurant in Southern California. The bowl, it turns out, is only a generous serving of whole grains accompanied by vegetables and a sauce.

title: The Novelists and the Candidates: A Campaign Finance Survey
description: Thanks to the Supreme Court and Ronald Dworkin, Ive been thinking lately about campaign financing and free speech. So just for fun the other day, I searched an online database of contributors for the 2008 election, to see which novelists had ponied up for which candidates. (I limited my search to self-described novelists, because expanding it to authors and writers returned more than 2,500 pages.)

title: Orange Aioli With Grains and Roasted Beets
description: Beets and their greens go well with a garlicky sauce. This twist on a Mediterranean classic pairs them with a garlic mayonnaise flavored with toasted orange peel. Serve the greens with cooked bulgur, wheat berries, quinoa or barley. The mayonnaise is delicious with roasted or steamed vegetables and makes a great condiment for a sandwich.

title: More Steep Circulation Declines at Newspapers
description: The reality facing American newspaper publishers continues to look stark, as figures released Monday show deep circulation declines, with average weekday sales down almost 9 percent since last year.

title: Beet Tzatziki
description: In the Eastern Mediterranean, the familiar tzatziki is made not just with thick yogurt and cucumbers, but also with grated cooked beets. The combination is quite wonderful, though the bright pink color may give you pause. Serve the tzatziki with rice or bulgur and steamed or blanched beet greens.

title: Peanut and Chile Salsa
description: This Mexican sauce, traditionally made with de arbol chiles, is quite spicy. Small, narrow de arbol chiles are available from plenty of online sources. Im offering two types of salsa here, a mild version that requires only chili powder and the authentic one. Whichever you choose to make, youll find it irresistible; the salsa is great with brown rice and any number of vegetables, grilled or steamed, or with a mixture of brown rice and edamame. The salsa is also wonderful with fish and shrimp.

title: Hot and Sour Peanut Sauce
description: Buckwheat noodles are my favorite food to serve with this pungent, spicy, rich-tasting sauce. It also goes well with any number of grains and with raw and cooked vegetables.

title: Election Ruling in Iraq Favors Prime Minister
description: BAGHDAD  Seven weeks after Iraqis went to the polls, a special elections court disqualified a winning parliamentary candidate, most likely reversing the narrow defeat of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Malikis alliance and possibly allowing him the first chance to form a new coalition government.

title: Brodsky Makes His Case for Attorney General
description: Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky of Westchester is one of potentially half a dozen Democrats running for attorney general this year. Mr. Brodsky, 63, has made his name in the Legislature as chairman of the Assembly Committee on Corporations, Authorities and Commissions, using his post to undertake investigations on everything from the financing of Yankee Stadium to corruption at the Canal Corporation. This is his second race for attorney general.

title: Obama Asks Supporters to Return to the Polls
description: President Obama delivered a fresh appeal today to the millions of new voters who helped send him to the White House two years ago, saying that the Democratic majority in Congress  and his agenda  depended on their roles in this years midterm elections.

title: Too Popular: Justin Bieber Concert Canceled in Australia
description: With his floppy bowl haircut and adorable lisp, the teenage pop star Justin Bieber may not seem like a dangerous figure. But make no mistake: his public appearances can be battlegrounds. On Monday the Australian police shut down a free performance that Mr. Bieber, 16, was to give in Sydney as his fans began injuring one another at the crowded concert site, Agence France-Presse reported. More than 4,000 fans, some who camped out overnight, showed up to hear Mr. Bieber sing three songs at Sydney Harbor, but the plug was pulled on the event hours before showtime when attendees started pushing and shoving. I am so sorry that it got out of control, Mr. Bieber said later in an Australian television appearance. We dont want anyone to get hurt. It gets crazy sometimes. Last November, an appearance by Mr. Bieber at the Roosevelt Field Mall in Garden City, N.Y., resulted in a fan stampede after which the singers manager, Scott Braun, was arrested on charges of reckless endangerment and criminal nuisance. The Australian police said that fans atSydney Harborhad sustained only minor injuries and were treated at the scene.

title: Too Fancy? Too Long? How to Name a Co-op
description: The world of Manhattan co-op boards is rich with infighting over issues like cigar smoke spilling into hallways, mammoth dogs that take up the whole elevator or Verdi recordings played at Carnegie Hall volume. So it would have seemed that residents at one pet-loving high-rise on East 56th Street had been blessed with a minor task: choosing a building name.

title: Monday Reading: Do Blondes Have More Financial Success?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Teammates Gordon and Johnson Feuding?
description: For the second straight Sprint Cup race, Jeff Gordon and Jimmie Johnson, teammates at Hendrick Motorsports, got together as they fought for position.

title: Does Conservatism Need Fox News?
description: Amid a long commentary on last weeks Jim Manzi-Mark Levin dust-up (and related matters), Jonah Goldberg made the following observation:

title: Robots Work to Stop Leak of Oil in Gulf
description: NEW ORLEANS  Oil continued to pour into the Gulf of Mexico on Monday as the authorities waited to see if the quickest possible method of stopping the leaks would bring an end to what was threatening to become an environmental disaster.

title: GTCR to Buy Protection One
description: 2:24 p.m. | Updated GTCR, a private equity firm, has struck a deal to buy Protection One, an electronic surveillance company, in a deal valued at about $828 million, including Protection Ones debt.

title: Bush Memoir Coming in November
description: At our sib-blog ArtsBeat, colleague Dave Itzkoff offers up a few choice details on the release later this year of the memoir, Decision Points, by former President George W. Bush.

title: Swiss Hold 3 in Plot Against I.B.M.
description: GENEVA  Three people suspected of planning an attack against a Swiss branch of I.B.M. were arrested this month, the Swiss authorities said Monday.

title: Hold the Advice, However Well-Intended
description: I have never been quite sure what to make of the usual you should go to this college comment. Usually it comes from former classmates  those a year ahead of me, enjoying their freshman year at any one of many exciting colleges.

title: The Artist at Work and Play
description: Bobby Sheehan, the director of the documentary "Arias With a Twist," describes what the performer Joey Arias represents in the contemporary art scene.

title: Tweezer Food
description: High-end restaurant cuisine that is delicately prepared and presented  often literally with tweezers.

title: Found Poem Favorite | A Ball of Yarn Saved Her Life
description: We received nearly 200 imaginative and interesting submissions to our April Found Poem Challenge for students, and, though it was difficult to choose among them, weve selected 10 favorites.

title: Fools Gold: An Oral History of the Insane Clown Posse Parodies
description: Even for guys who paint their faces with clown makeup and rap about brutality, thuggishness and dead bodies they took in off the streets, the past few months have been strange ones for Insane Clown Posse. Though that hip-hop act, consisting of the Detroit natives Shaggy 2 Dope and Violent J, has been a proud representative of the horrorcore rap scene for nearly two decades, the group is enjoying a resurgence in attention, if not popularity, from a wave of Internet comedy videos poking fun at their music and their legions of harlequin-faced fans, who call themselves Juggalos.

title: Gorilla Coffee Reopens, With New Workers
description: It was not until about 9:45 the morning of its reopening that the Gorilla coffee shop in Park Slope, Brooklyn, began to look a little like its old self: a few patrons lined up at the cash register, waiting for lattes and Balthazar pastries; several others sitting at red Formica tables, drinking coffee and tapping away at their laptops.

title: The High Low | Alice Park Wallet, $65
description: What: Alice Park kidskin wallet

title: Rent vs. Buy in Nine More Areas
description: A few readers noticed that I said last week that The Times had analyzed house prices and rents in 54 metropolitan areas but that our chart included only 45. Space constraints were the reason.

title: Report: 2010 College Budget Deficits = 2025 State Work Force Deficits
description: At a time when public colleges and universities in California are scaling back, a report released last week argues that state-funded higher education should expand to the tune of $1.6 billion annually to meet the needs of the states economy by 2025.

title: Thai King Avoids Talk of Unrest in Address
description: BANGKOK  Thailands ailing king spoke on national television on Monday night, his first remarks since his nation descended into a political crisis, but he made no reference to the conflict that now threatens to spin out of control.

title: On Our Radar: Lessons From a Deep Current
description: A huge Antarctic deep-water current has been discovered that sheds light on the workings of an ocean conveyor belt.

title: Director of Crude Will Resist Chevrons Request for Footage
description: 4:13 p.m. | Updated A documentary filmmaker says he will fight a request byChevron to turn over hundreds of hours of footage he shot for a documentary about pollution in the Amazon rainforests of Ecuador, film the company says may be useful in lawsuits it faces accusing it ofdamaging the environment there.

title: Financial Tuneup: Reread Your Will
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: Buildings Named Badly
description: It may seem like only neurotic New Yorkers would need 18 months and a team of professionals to choose a new name for an apartment building. But building naming is serious business in this city: It is perceived as helping drive up real estate values.

title: Draft Is Over; We Now Resume Our Regularly Scheduled Programming
description: Now that the N.F.L. draft has freed us from its grasp (although is it possible we all napped through the announcement that it would be extended to 93 rounds and last until June?) all thats left is three months of analysis, Brett Favre-watching and placing bets on when the risk-happy Jets will implode, with the over-under currently at Week 5.

title: Seavers Tales of Wine and Roses
description: Tom Seaver has never lacked for words, confidence or enthusiasm. With little prompting, he can launch into stories about pitching to Henry Aaron, winning it all with the 1969 Mets or any of a thousand other moments in his Hall of Fame career.At 65, Seaverhas not lost that passion, only now he has rechanneled it into wine making and his Seaver Family Vineyards. After several years of planting, pruning and planning, Seavers two cabernets  GTS and Nancys Fancy  are coming into their own.

title: Confronting the Mire on 34th Street
description: The Bloomberg administration has announced that it will create a new Midtown pedestrian mall, this one running on 34th Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues  that is, between Macys and the Empire State Building.

title: Icelands Main Airport Reopens
description: Keflavik International Airport, the main international airport in Iceland, reopened on Monday after a three-day shutdown because of ash from the Eyjafjallajokull volcano. The airport was closed Friday after easterly winds began blowing volcano ash toward the capital, Reykjavik.

title: In Portugal, Train Drivers Begin Rush-Hour Strikes
description: A morning rush-hour strike by train drivers caused widespread travel disruption in Portugal on Monday as the workers protested a government pay freeze at publicly owned companies.

title: Downtown Performance Art, Aliens Included
description: Arias With a Twist: The Docufantasy,  which examines the theatrical collaboration between the performance artist Joey Arias (best known for his vocal style that channels Billie Holiday) and the puppeteer Basil Twist as a way to explore the history of New Yorks downtown art and club scene. Traversing the 70s until today, the film includes interviews with several artists who were a part of the scene. But its most intriguing subject is Mr. Arias himself, who has spent more than 30 years at his craft.

title: Which Android Platform Is Netflix Working On?
description: When Netflix opened its doors for business in 1998 it offered one product: DVDs by mail. Since then the video company has plastered itself everywhere.

title: The Wheel Thing
description: Laugh all you want, but the name Design Within Reach was never meant to be about affordability. When Rob Forbes founded the high-end modern furniture retailer in 1999, he was throwing open the doors to a realm that was  at least in this country  maddeningly difficult for the average civilian to penetrate without the help of an interior designer. With his new company, Public, hes taking the pain out of acquiring another elusive design object: the stylish, practical city bike, the kind that the Dutch and Danish ride. A longtime urban cyclist himself, Forbes watched as places like New York, San Francisco and even Louisville, Ky., spent the last decade opening bike lanes and encouraging alternative transportation, and yet, he argues, most American bike stores still cater primarily to athletes. Bicycle technology here is centered on lightweight performance, so theyre not as interested in a customer that wants a kickstand, rack and fenders, he says. The Public M (left) is a lightweight update on classic French models from the 60s and 70s,  la Jules et Jim. And at $600 to $1,200, Publics bikes are more or less within reach. Forbes still believes in living a well-designed life, but this time around hes taking his gospel to the streets. Go to publicbikes.com.

title: What to Watch at Senates Hearing on Goldman
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Electric Cabs Begin 90-day Trial in Tokyo
description: Three electric cabs began a 90-day trial in Tokyo on Monday that officials and the company involved said could eventually lead to the electrification of the entire taxi fleet.

title: TimesCast | April 26, 2010
description: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Monday.  Topics include a new release of Goldman Sachs documents, a battle over a Cape Cod wind farm and saving sharks in Belize.

title: Thumbs Up:  Ferrari Combines P.R. With Whimsy
description: A Ferrari sponsor, Banco Santander, held an event in Spain today to promote the brand, and they made Fernando Alonso available to the invited media. I was not there, but the team put up a whimsical press release on the event, talking about how Fernando Alonso has had his thumbs insured by Banco Santander.

title: Shake-Up in Top Schools Posts
description: Theres another changing of the guard coming at the Education Departments Tweed Courthouse. Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein is poised to announce what is, by our count, the fourth administrative overhaul in his eight-year tenure.

title: Wall Street Journal Says Its Up to You, New York, New York
description: The Wall Street Journals much-anticipated New York edition hit the doorsteps of the city and brought with it the first broadsheet newspaper competition in decades.

title: Presidential Yankees and Mets
description: The Yankees visit to the White House on Monday and the flurry of I Like Ike signs at Citi Field welcoming Ike Davis, the Mets new first baseman, got us thinking about other presidential names from the Yankees and the Mets.

title: 'The Actor' Returns
description: Images of paintings from Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, including The Actor.

title: The Art Is Instrumental
description: Images from the Musical Instrument Museum.

title: Eskendereyas Scratching Highlights Fragile Nature of Sport
description: Steve Zorn, who writes the Business of Racing blog, is the racing manager for Castle Village Farm thoroughbred partnerships. He is also a board member of the New York Thoroughbred Horsemens Association and the Backstretch Employees Service Team, the health program for workers at NYRA tracks.

title: Current TV Reporters to Discuss Imprisonment in N. Korea
description: Laura Ling and Euna Lee, the two journalists who were imprisoned in North Korea, have spent the better part of a year out of public view.

title: G.O.P. Blocks Debate on Financial Oversight Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans, united in opposition to the Democrats legislation to tighten regulation of the financial system, voted on Monday to block the bill from reaching the floor for debate. As both sides dug in, the battle has huge ramifications for the economy and for their political prospects in this years midterm elections.

title: Odette Fada Leaving SD26
description: After 14 years with the restaurateur Tony May, Odette Fada is leaving SD26 on May 3. She was executive chef of San Domenico on Central Park South, which closed in 2008, then at SD26, the relocated, updated version of the restaurant that opened last year on Madison Square Park. Her replacement, Matteo BerganiniBergamini, who is from Lake Garda in northern Italy, has been the chef de cuisine and also worked for two years with Daniel Boulud.

title: BlackRocks Shares Drop as Results Disappoint
description: Shares of BlackRock fell sharply on Monday after the giant money management firm reported weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings as its funds businesses saw outflows and customers shifted to passive funds over more actively managed ones.

title: Memphis and The Royal Family Lead Outer Critics Circle Awards Nominations
description: The Broadway musical Memphis and the recent revival of The Royal Family were the most recognized productions at Mondays announcement of the nominations for the Outer Critics Circle awards, edging the John Kander and Fred Ebb musical The Scottsboro Boys and the critically reviled Addams Family.

title: Encouraging Older Volunteers
description: Evidence of the benefits that volunteering can bring older people continues to roll in. Volunteers have improved physical and social functioning, said Fengyan Tang, an assistant professor at the University of Pittsburgh School of Social Work, who has studied older volunteers. They report better well-being and greater life satisfaction. Theres a reduced risk for mortality compared to non-volunteers.

title: Lemaire Steps Down as Devils Coach
description: The Devils announced (first on their Twitter pge) that Jacques Lemaire is stepping down as their coach and retiring.

title: The Curious Politics of Immigration
description: Just a quick note: my take on the politics of immigration is that it divides both parties, but in different ways.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: The Moore the Merrier, Paint Marketer Proclaims
description: Forget about painting the town red. A leading brand of paint wants you to paint the town read, as in, I read about it on Facebook.

title: Whirling Bull
description: It is an article of faith in some circles that consumer spending cannot really recover, because so many of us are over-indebted and underemployed.

title: People and Accounts of Note in Advertising
description: Andy Bateman joined Leading Edge, Sydney, Australia, part of the Photon Group, as chief executive. He assumes those duties from Nigel Long, chairman at Leading Edge, who had been filling the post temporarily after Mark Sundquist left last year. Mr. Bateman had been chief executive of the New York office of Interbrand, part of the Omnicom Group, where a search for a successor is under way. Mr. Bateman, who will be based in Sydney, will oversee the planned opening of an office for Leading Edge in New York.

title: Thunder, a Young Team Learning Fast, Outrunning Lakers
description: Perhaps it took two games for the young Oklahoma City Thunder to get a hang of this N.B.A. playoff thing.

title: The Future May Not Resemble the Last 6 Months
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Clearwater Asset Management. He answered questions from Bucks readers in November.

title: Time Is Running Out on Daviess Comeback
description: Five months ago, Charlie Davies could not stand on his own. His once sculptured legs shook under the strain of his own weight. His girlfriend pushed him around in a wheelchair because he could not walk.

title: Fading Ads, Pickled in Pixels
description: Today, as on many days, Ephemeral New York is taken by that charming and most visible symbol of the changing city: the fading painted advertisement.

title: The Well-Dressed Chair
description: Artek, the Finnish company that was co-founded by the architect Alvar Aalto to produce his furniture designs, is celebrating its 75th anniversary by asking designers and artists to reinterpret its classic armchairs in a program called Dress the Chair! For the opening of Arteks new Stockholm showroom earlier this year, the British designer Ilse Crawford covered Aaltos chunky 1936 Armchair 400  better known as the Tank chair  with reindeer fur, in a nod to its Finnish roots. And the Swedish textile designer Fanny Aronsen covered Aaltos chairs in her own colorful fabrics. The second stop was Milan, where the fashion house Missoni dressed the Tank chair in its graphic textiles (above) during last months furniture fair. New York, Sydney, London and Tokyo come next, with more guest designers, before a final stop back home in Helsinki.

title: Two Dance Visions in a Creative Pas de Deux
description: A theater merging with a choreographers company? As the New York dance world puzzled over the unusual prospect of a union between the downtown presenter Dance Theater Workshop and Bill T. Joness company  one surprised former staff member of the workshop likened it to a merger of a museum and an artist  new details have emerged about the proposal.

title: Numberplay: Surreal Hat Tricks
description: Greetings folks, and welcome to the new Numberplay section of the Wordplay blog, the reincarnation of the TierneyLab Monday Puzzle. I extend a hearty welcome to both old friends and new. TierneyLab regulars, you will find the same suite of mathematical, logical and scientific puzzles that brightened up your Mondays, complete with Justin Thymes stunning illustrations and graphical hints. Wordplay faithfuls, it might surprise you to learn that the TierneyLab Monday puzzle suite had a word challenge of its own every week. Today, in your honor, Ive expanded that portion to feature a mini-crossword with a twist. I hope you enjoy it.

title: G.O.P. Readies a Rival Bill on Financial Rules
description: 3:10 p.m. | Updated Senate Republicans are working to complete their own version of legislation to tighten regulation of the nations financial system, and aides said their version could be put forward as a rival to the Democrats proposal if a bipartisan deal is not reached before an important procedural vote later on Monday, The New York Timess David M. Herszenhorn reports from Washington.

title: Nick Clegg Is (Not) the British Obama
description: As my colleague John Burns reports from London, a strong and unexpected surge by the left-of-center Liberal Democrats ahead of the general election in Britain on May 6 has thrown the spotlight on the partys youthful leader, Nick Clegg.

title: The Biker Who Took Big Air to the Big Time
description: If you associate Jackass with outrageous, over-the-top feats, know that the guys behind that hit MTV stunt show appreciate athleticism, too. In his new documentary The Birth of Big Air, Jeff Tremaine, the Jackass co-creator and director, pays tribute to Mat Hoffman, the freestyle BMX biker who ushered the sport from backyard ramps in the 1980s to the two-story-tall half-pipes of the modern-day X Games. The eerily mature film is also a grown-up endeavor for the Jackass star Johnny Knoxville, who is one of its producers.

title: Bashir Wins Election as Sudan Edges Toward Split
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Sudans incumbent president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, handily won the countrys first multiparty election in more than 20 years, according to results released Monday, offering a glimpse into the kind of lopsided contests that may continue if the nation splits in two next year as expected.

title: Now Booking | English Countryside Hotels
description: If you thought Britains country house hotels  usually dilapidated and ennui-inducing throwbacks to Olde England  had remained comfortingly formulaic, think again. A new generation of clued-in hoteliers are sprucing up some of the once-forgotten countryside piles, turning them into stylish getaways with impeccable interiors, haute cuisine and, more often than not, spectacular spas  all amid a pastoral panorama dotted with horses, foraging sheep and darting deer.

title: After Doubts About Pastors Project, Council Members Resign
description: A group of pastors and advisers have resigned as the executive council of a faith-based social service start-up in Brooklyn after saying it has been plagued by incongruities and lies and concluding that it could not even vouch for the projects veracity.

title: Sally on Her 75th Birthday
description: Facing dementia, one woman celebrates her 75th birthday.

title: Jones Says Hes Sorry for Off-Tone Joke
description: Just when it looked like the Obama administration couldnt get into any more trouble with the pro-Israel lobby, Gen. James L. Jones, the national security adviser, had to issue a formal apology Monday for possibly offending Jews with a joke he told to start a speech last week.

title: Scarborough and Brzezinski to Revamp, Expand Their Radio Show
description: Citadel Media put The Joe Scarborough Show on an immediate hiatus on Monday and said it was developing a longer version of the radio show featuring Mr. Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski.

title: Obama, Leno and a Low-Carbon Menu
description: The White House Correspondents Dinner, an annual black-tie festival of schmoozing, preening and source-greasing, is taking steps this year to reduce its carbon footprint. From decorations to menu choices to recommended modes of transport, the association is trying to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions generated by its 2,600 revelers.

title: Whats the Difference? Writing to Compare and Contrast
description: Overview | What are the purposes of doing a written comparison? How can a writer execute a well-developed and meaningful comparison? In this lesson, students explore sound topics and strategies for a written comparison as well as its authentic purpose, and then write their own compare/contrast essays, based on and inspired by models from The Times.

title: TimesCast: A Key Vote on Financial Regulation
description: TimesCast, a daily look inside The New York Times newsroom and articles planned for coverage, begins with a segment on the debate in Congress on the overhaul of financial regulations, and why the battle for a bipartisan bill may not be as difficult as the one surrounding health care.

title: Homeownership Falls Further
description: The homeownership rate fell further last quarter, and is now at its lowest level in a decade, according to a Census Bureau report released today.

title: Book Offers View of the Motoring Future
description: Last month, General Motors introduced its new Electric Networked Vehicle, or EN-V, a two person, podlike device created jointly with Segway.

title: Special Teams Lifting Coyotes
description: It should be pretty easy for the Phoenix Coyotes to figure out what they need to do to beat the Detroit Red Wings:

title: Travel Deals: Tuscan Castle Vacation
description: If staying in a Tuscan villa is not luxurious enough, how about sleeping in a castle?

title: Deep in December, Its Nice to Remember: Tom Jones Returns to The Fantasticks
description: At 82, the musical-theater lyricist and actor Tom Jones does not need to do much to make himself look like an elderly character on stage, he volunteered in a recent conversation. But on Monday night, he willuse makeup to add sags to his face and bulges to his eyes and an eyebrow pencil to make his teeth look rotted as he returns to the role of Henry the old actor in the Off Broadway production of The Fantasticks to recognize its 50th anniversary on May 3.

title: Hertz Aims to Push Forward With Dollar Thrifty
description: Hertz Global Holdings appears confident the that government will approve its $1.2 billion acquisition of the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, a rival rental car company, noting that it could be forced to carve out operations in some smaller markets.

title: Its No More Mr. Nice Guy for This Everyman
description: When Denzel Washington talks about challenging death to a wrestling match, you suddenly sense that everythings going to be all right. Not for Troy Maxson, the character portrayed by Mr. Washington in the vibrantly acted Broadway revival of August Wilsons Fences, which opened on Monday night at the Cort Theater; Troy might as well have Warning: Explosives tattooed across his forehead, with Breakable stamped on his back.

title: Gowanus, Brooklyn, 11:13 A.M.
description: A metal gleaner named Lucky pushed his load of scrap to Benson Scrap Metal near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn in the rain on Monday.

title: Edward P. Jones and Nam Le Win PEN/Malamud Award
description: The short story is not so small that it cant accommodate two winners for one of the more prestigious prizes in that genre. On Monday, the organizers of the PEN/Malamud Award for Excellence in the Short Story, which in recent years has recognized a veteran author and a writer at the start of a career, announced that Edward P. Jones and Nam Le were the winners of its 2010 prize. Mr. Jones, a Pulitzer Prize winner in 2004 for his novel The Known World, was cited for short story collections like Lost in the City (from 1992) and All Aunt Hagars Children (2007). Mr. Le, a Vietnamese-born writer who splits his time between the United States and Australia, was honored for his debut collection, The Boat, which was published in 2008. Mr. Jones and Mr. Le will a share a prize of $5,000 and take part in the 2010-11 PEN/Faulkner Reading Series at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington.

title: The Claim: Lack of Sleep Increases Weight
description: THE FACTS

title: Less Sleep Linked With More Eating
description: People who sleep less appear to eat more the next day.

title: Identifying Students With the Most Debt
description: The College Board, in a new report, found that bachelors degree recipients who graduated with the most student debt tended to be those who went to for-profit institutions or were independent  meaning they generally did not get support from their parents.

title: Cape Cod Project Is Crucial Step for U.S. Wind Industry
description: More than 800 giant wind turbines spin off the coasts of Denmark, Britain and seven other European countries, generating enough electricity from strong ocean breezes to power hundreds of thousands of homes. Chinas first offshore wind farm, a 102-megawatt venture near Shanghai, goes online this month, with more in the pipeline.

title: To Beat the Heat, Drink a Slushie First
description: Its no surprise that its hard to exercise on a hot day. You go slower. An easy workout is grueling. You have no endurance.

title: The Slushie Workout
description: Exercisers are always looking for ways to boost their energy, particularly during hot weather. Now Personal Best columnist, Gina Kolata, offers this advice for keeping your cool during a workout: drink a slushie.

title: 'Learning How to Learn'
description: Rosie O'Donnell speaks about auditory processing disorder and the therapy that has helped her son.

title: On Tour, Conan OBrien Gets Some Super Assistance
description: Conan OBrien got a little help from an old friend in a couple of boisterous stage shows on his Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television Tour in Los Angeles onSaturday and Sunday nights:

title: Who Will Build the First Offshore Wind Farm in North America?
description: Back in December, I had an opportunity to take a helicopter ride low over the North Sea, about 13 miles off the western shores of Denmark, to view an offshore wind farm.

title: Body After Baby
description: On the one hand we have all those breathless magazine covers, celebrating Body After Baby, and making it seem as if baby weight is something that can, nay, should, melt off in six weeks, leaving Heidi Klums body behind.

title: Advice for New Head of Homeless Services
description: Monday is the first day on the job for Seth Diamond, the citys new homeless services commissioner.

title: The Morning Skate: A Dramatical Turn, an Ironic Ending, a Confused Aftermath
description: When the Blackhawks take the ice in Nashville tonight for Game 6 of their opening-round series and try to close out the Predators, they will have Marian Hossa in the lineup.

title: Thomson Reuters CEO Has a Sympathetic Ear for Goldman Sachs
description: Thomson Reuters chief executive Tom Glocer has taken an unusual step for a media executive, issuing a blog post defending Goldman Sachs.

title: Viola Davis on 'Fences'
description: The actress talks about performing with Denzel Washington in the Broadway revival of August Wilson's play.

title: Coyote vs. Greyhound: One Man's Sport
description: John Hardzog uses trained greyhounds to hunt coyotes, a common pest for farmers. It's a practice that goes back generations, but is also opposed by some animal rights groups.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Glengarry Glen Ross'
description: A. O. Scott takes a look back at the 1992 film adapted from David Mamet's play about the real estate world's culture of unfettered selling.

title:
Mortgage Deals
Under Scrutiny as Goldman Faces Senators
description: WASHINGTON  The legal storm buffeting Goldman Sachs continued to rage Tuesday just ahead of what is expected to be a contentious Senate hearing at which bank executives plan to defend their actions during the housing crisis.

title: Isnt It Surreal? | Dorothea Tanning at the Drawing Center
description: Dorothea Tanning, the last of the Surrealists, has always been something of a fashion plate. A long-limbed beauty and a piquant dresser, Tanning scoured vintage shops and played dress-up with extravagant 19th-century pieces. Her eclectic style sense is celebrated in the 1942 self-portrait Birthday in which the bare-breasted artist sports an Elizabethan-style jacket, a draped skirt and what appears to the be the entire root system of a very large tree.

title: Roethlisberger Apologizes and Accepts His Suspension
description: In his first public comments since he was suspended for up to six games by the N.F.L. last week, Pittsburgh quarterback Ben Roethlisberger emphasized Monday that he committed no crime during an incident with a 20-year-old college student in a Georgia bar, but added that he was sorry he let his teammates and Steelers fans down. Roethlisberger said he would not appeal the suspension, which could be reduced to four games  or lengthened beyond six games  depending on Roethlisbergers compliance with a behavioral evaluation ordered by the league.

title: Milan Report | A Forest of Coat Trees
description: Every year at the Milan furniture fair, there is a stand-out, seemingly ubiquitous object; this time around we couldnt help but notice the abundance of cool coat trees. For those who dont have an entry hall closet, or, for that matter, an entry hall, the coat tree stands as the perfect design solution. One of the best was the 25 Liter Coat Stand by the design darling Peter Marigold for Skitsch. The quasi-ready-made is anchored by a 25 liter plastic tank  filled with water for stability  and has a metal tube with hooks extending out of the spout. At Japanese furniture manufacturer Karimoku, the Swiss design trio Big-Game came up with the Signs coat tree. Made in natural or gray stained wood, this coat stand has movable arms which pivot out from the frame when you place your coat on it or snap back in place with hidden magnets when not in use.

title: The Search for Genes Leads to Unexpected Places
description: Edward M. Marcotte is looking for drugs that can kill tumors by stopping blood vessel growth, and he and his colleagues at the University of Texas at Austin recently found some good targets  five human genes that are essential for that growth. Now theyre hunting for drugs that can stop those genes from working. Strangely, though, Dr. Marcotte did not discover the new genes in the human genome, nor in lab mice or even fruit flies. He and his colleagues found the genes in yeast.

title: Caveat Emptor Is Not a Business Plan
For Kennedys Tribute, Torch Is Passed to Three A-Listers
description: With more than 240 credits among the three of them (but surprisingly only three Academy Awards), it was merely a matter of time before Robert De Niro, Morgan Freeman and Ed Harris found the right project to appear in together. In this case, it is the debut performance of the multimedia work The Dream Lives On: A Portrait of the Kennedy Brothers, which will take place as part of the Boston Pops 125th anniversary season, the orchestra said on Monday. The work, which will have its premiere on May 18 at Symphony Hall in Boston, will have the actors narrating as three of the Kennedy siblings: Mr. De Niro as John F. Kennedy, Mr. Harris as Robert F. Kennedy and Mr. Freeman as Edward M. Kennedy. Composed by Peter Boyer with lyrics by Lynn Ahrens, The Dream Lives On will also feature the Boston Pops Orchestra conducted by Keith Lockhart and the Tanglewood Festival Chorus, as well as original texts and videos. The work will receive additional performances May 19 through 22 and July 3 and 4. It will also be performed on July 18 at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., with Alec Baldwin narrating, and on Aug. 1 at the Hyannis Village Green in Hyannis, Mass., where it will be narrated by Chris Cooper.

title: Hope for Sharks and Reefs in Belize
description: Glover's Reef in Belize is a Marine Protected Area where strict limits on fishing have helped shark populations.

title: How Do Lawyers Get Away With This Stuff?
description: At my company, we try so hard to provide great customer service that I sometimes forget that bad customer service exists. And then I hired a lawyer.

title: Cancer Patient Dies Despite Daring Surgery
description: They seemed like a formidable team. The surgeon was skilled and daring, the patient fiercely determined to live. But talent and grit were not enough. Robert Collison, 59, died on Friday at a hospital in Milwaukee, four months after undergoing 43 hours of surgery in New York to remove a huge cancerous tumor from his abdomen.

title: Fish Versus Flax
description: Q. How does flaxseed oil compare with fish oil in nutritional benefits?

title: 17 Years Later, Stage 4 Survivor Is Savoring a Life Well Lived
description: Each year on a day in January  the 15th, to be precise  I go to a Web site and post a message to hundreds of women Ive never met, saying, essentially, Im still here.

title: What Were Reading: New York Landmarking
Targeting a Shepard Fairey Mural
description: Its par for the course in the world of street art: getting painted over. But by the unwritten code of the scene, most artists leave others work alone; business-owners and antigraffiti activists are usually the ones brandishing the whitewash.

title: The Unspoken State of the Judiciary
description: The first State of the Judiciary message by New Yorks new chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, was presented Monday. And no one came.

title: Inquiry Says Health Care Charges Were Proper
description: WASHINGTON  When major companies declared that a provision of the new health care law would hurt earnings, Democrats were skeptical. But after investigating, House Democrats have concluded that the companies were right to tell investors and the government about the expected adverse effects of the law on their financial results.

title: Obama Welcomes Yankees, Chides Their Long Wait
description: President Barack Obama welcomed the Yankees to the White House on Monday, lauding them for the franchises 27th championship, and poking a bit of fun at how long it took to win this one.

title: Wheres My Car?
description: If theres one thing thats guaranteed to make me feel like a dope, its when I cant remember where I parked my car. And based on the number of products that are designed to help in this situation, Im not the only one with the problem.

title: Save Emergency Rooms for Emergencies
description: One of President George W. Bushs most injudicious statements was his suggestion in 2007 that anyone who could not afford private medical care could always go to the emergency room.

title: Protected Reef Offers Model for Conservation
description: GLOVERS REEF, Belize  As Alex Tilley powers his 15-foot skiff over the turquoise surface, a dark form slips across the white sand floor below. Sting ray, Mr. Tilley says.

title: Little-Known Disorder Can Take a Toll on Learning
description: Parents and teachers often tell children to pay attention  to be a good listener. But what if your childs brain doesnt know how to listen?

title: In Response to Car Horns, Readers Sound Off
description: It can be a satisfying experience to lay on your cars horn. Some people do it so frequently, they may believe the sound will part the cars ahead, or maybe even get that old lady to cross the street a little faster. But the cacophony can drive pedestrians and residents to distraction.

title: Traveling a Primeval Medical Landscape
description: The world was young, leafy green and overrun with dinosaurs so many eons ago that stories from prehistoric times are mostly fantasy and supposition. But the medical world was exactly that young, primitive and full of unusual creatures barely a century ago, giving historians ample fodder for true stories stranger than any fantasy.

title: Putting a Compliment in Context
description: One leftover item from President Obamas weekend break in Asheville, N.C., by way of the  Asheville Citizen-Times, which reports that Mr. Obama ran into some local residents at the 12th hole of the golf course at Grove Park Inn.

title: A Closer Look at the Derby Crop
description: Mike Welsch of the Daily Racing Form, who watches all of the Kentucky Derby horses work out and train leading up to the big race, shared some of his thoughts on the best workouts hes witnessed and this years crop of top 3-year-olds.

title: China in the Drivers Seat
description: The Chinese dont understand us, Amedeo Felisa, Ferraris global chief executive, told me in a recent interview. They dont understand why we make only two-door cars. They dont understand why we dont make a limousine.

title: The Other Great Divide | Posterior Lifting 101
description: Products to lift your posterior. Read related article.

title: With Expanded Coverage for the Poor, Fears of a Big Headache
description: Of all the changes wrought by the new health care law, none is more sweeping than the transformation of Medicaid  from the governments health insurance plan for poor families into a much wider program for millions of the poorest Americans who cannot afford insurance on their own.

title: Exploring the Complexities of Nerdiness, for Laughs
description: BURBANK, Calif.  Shudders and groans went around the blogs and coffee rooms of the physics world back in the summer of 2007, when CBS announced plans for a new comedy series about a pair of nerdy physicists and their buxom blonde waitress neighbor.

title: Dont Wait for an Emergency
description: Savvy health care consumers do some advance checking before selecting a personal physician or seeing a specialist. But how many check out the emergency room in advance of a medical crisis?

title: Mixed Smoke Signals in San Francisco
description: Last weekend, San Franciscos newantismoking ordinancewhich bans smoking in public places like bus stop shelters, outdoor dining areas and A.T.M. lines  went into effect.

title: Ambinder on the Conservative Mind
description: As a former colleague of Marc Ambinder and a longtime admirer of his work, Im genuinely distressed to learn that he believes this:

title: For $520 Million, AstraZeneca Will Settle Case Over Marketing of a Drug
description: AstraZeneca has completed a deal to pay $520 million to settle federal investigations into marketing practices for its blockbuster schizophrenia drug, Seroquel. The Justice Department plans a news conference on Wednesday to disclose details of the case, according to two people close to the negotiations who were not authorized to discuss it publicly.

title: No Closure in the Epistemic Closure Debate
description: The Great Epistemic Closure debate is still raging.

title: Is the M.T.A. Down Another $72 Million?
description: For the financially troubled Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the numbers seem to keep getting worse.

title: Obama Welcomes Yankees to the White House
description: President Obama welcomed the Yankees to the White House today, lauding them for the franchises 27th championship, and poking a bit of fun at how long it took to win this one.

title: Critics Picks Video: Glengarry Glen Ross
description: A. O. Scott learns his ABCs (Always Be Closing) with the film adaptation of David Mamets play Glengarry Glen Ross. The film looks at a group of aggressive salesmen who jockey for the top position in a cutthroat real estate office. Mr. Scott praises the films dialogue, saying that nobody but David Mamet can write with this kind of hard-boiled, lyrical mysticism. Mr. Scott also says the film points to the origins of the current economic crisis, looking at a culture of relentless buying and selling that muddled the true value of things. Please share your thoughts on Glengarry Glen Ross.

title: Recognized for Risk, Ortmeyer Is Among Masterton Finalists
description: After the final faceoff, when most players are thinking about postgame plans, Jed Ortmeyer is giving himself a shot in the stomach  a daily reminder of the risks he takes to play the sport he loves.

title: A Filly Is Entered in the Derby
description: Todd Pletcher may have lost three starters for the Kentucky Derby in recent days, including the favorite, Eskendereya, but he gained one starter with the entry of the filly Devil May Care.

title: Eager to Rebuild Willets Point, City Faces Legal Fight From Property Owners
description: It is one of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs signature projects  the sweeping transformation of Willets Point, a slice of Queens that has long been among the citys most neglected pieces of real estate. And a little over a year ago, it seemed like a done deal.

title: Authorities Seize Gizmodo Editors Computers
description: 10:21 a.m. | Updated Correcting name of law enforcement agency involved, the Rapid Enforcement Allied Computer Team.

title: Child Health Director Has Background in Genetics
description: Dr. Alan Guttmacher, a Harvard-trained geneticist and pediatrician, is the new acting director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, the federal agency that finances research into child and maternal health. Dr. Guttmacher, 60, previously worked with Francis Collins on the Human Genome Project and then as the deputy director of the National Human Genome Research Institute of the National Institutes of Health. We spoke for three hours in his Bethesda, Md., offices and then later by telephone. An edited version of the conversations follows.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
description: Jerry Lampen of Reuters photographed an anti-government red-shirt protester being arrested by soldiers of the Thai army. With Thailands political crisis worsening, King Bhumibol Adulyadej spoke on national television Monday from the hospital. Though he did not explicitly address the situation, his remarks could have been construed as indirect criticism.

title: Computers Seized at Home of Gizmodo Reporter Who Wrote About iPhone, Gawker Media Says
description: Gawker Media said on Monday that computers belonging to one of its editors, Jason Chen, were seized from his home on Friday as part of what appeared to be an investigation into the sale of a next-generation iPhone.

title: The Bachelor Shaw Woos With His Wit
description: Theres great fun in watching witty people fall in love. While some of us sputter in shyness, the well-spoken are infinitely more appealing as they bat bons mots back and forth. Engaging Shaw is just such a matchup, a charming romantic comedy featuring four razor-sharp tongues. If theres a minute of the play thats less than clever, youll be hard pressed to find it.

title: Conciliatory Tone Expected From Blankfein
description: 5:15 p.m. | Updated Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, plans to tell lawmakers on Tuesday that the day the Securities and Exchange Commission accused his firm of securities fraud was one of the worst days in his life, The New York Timess Louise Story reports.

title: Home From One War, Walking Into Another
description: Playwrights know what evil lurks in the hearts of American families: the homely, petty kind. In Frank D. Gilroys 1964 work The Subject Was Roses, the Clearys  mom, dad and Timmy, just back from the war  are the specimens under the microscope, their battles and shifting alliances the stuff of kitchen-sink (or perhaps waffle-iron) drama.

title: The Attack Coming From Bytes, Not Bombs
description: Blackouts hit New York, Los Angeles, Washington and more than 100 other American cities. Subways crash. Trains derail. Airplanes fall from the sky.

title: Peter Carey: At Home in Australia, New York and Writing
description: The novelist Peter Carey, whose new book, Parrot and Olivier in America, came out last week, likes to call himself a Marshian, which is another way of saying hes from Australia.

title: G.O.P. Blocks Debate on Financial Oversight Bill
description: Senate Republicans, united in opposition to the Democrats legislation to tighten regulation of the financial system, voted on Monday evening to block the start of floor debate, The New York Timess David M. Herszenhorn reports from Washington.

title: The Unfortunate Salesman
description: Just in time for wedding season comes the unfortunate tale of David Goldberg, a young salesman who, 109 years ago today, sued his fiance, Yetta Wolman, of the Upper West Side, for certain untoward matters that occurred during what The New York Times, in an article on the case, referred to as a courtship that was fraught with nothing but heartache and unceasing expense to him.

title: Three-Spined Stickleback Proves a Purposeful Cannibal
description: Its a fact of life in the animal world that some fish (and birds, mammals, reptiles, insects, crustaceans  you name it) eat their young.

title: Insect May Make Moves to Survive the Harvest
description: One thing about evolution  you never know whats going to influence it. Take the European corn borer, for instance. Researchers have just made a strong case that a certain aspect of its behavior has evolved because of human harvesting of corn.

title: Like Origami, Pollen Grains Fold Just So
description: After it is released from a flowers anther, a pollen grain walks a humidity tightrope. It dries up a bit as it travels through the air, the cellular material inside becoming dormant so it survives until it reaches the humid environment of another flowers stigma. But it cant become so dry that the material dies.

title: Vaccinations: A Hot Debate Still Burning
description: The Vaccine War, a look at the debate that has been raging for years over the safety of, and necessity for, childhood vaccinations, has only a few moments that might be illuminating to those who have been following this now familiar controversy.

title: Beneath a Bower, Passions of a Lovelorn Trio
description: Lawrence Goldhubers choreography has tended to revolve around his onstage persona: a fat man in the skinny world of dance. Mr. Goldhuber was an actor before joining the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, and when he began to create his own work, he frequently focused on the effects of his 350-pound body in both choreographic and comedic terms.

title: Pop Songs Exhibiting a Measure of Mortality
description: A mash-up, a conceptual exercise, an amateur talent show, a pop critique, piano-bar karaoke and a meditation on mortality: thats End of the Road, the production of the Young@Heart Chorus by No Theater, at St. Anns Warehouse through May 1.

title: Orchestra Celebrates 25th With Beethoven No. 9
description: For any artistic organization of independent means to survive and flourish for 25 years is a real achievement. But the feat seems even more impressive for a period-instrument ensemble based in the New York area, where several such groups have arrived with a bang and ended with the proverbial whimper. It was cause for celebration, then, that the American Classical Orchestra, founded by Thomas Crawford in Fairfield, Conn., had reached the quarter-century mark. Celebrate it did on Saturday night at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

title: Wal-Mart Gender Case Divides Court
description: In a closely watched case, a sharply divided federal appeals court on Monday ruled 6-5 that a sex discrimination lawsuit against Wal-Mart could proceed as a class action for more than a million women. The suit is the biggest employment discrimination case in the nations history.

title: Cracking Orcas Code: It Comes in Several Types
description: Imagine you are a killer whale, or orca, as you probably prefer to be known. You are thinking about lunch, specifically a nice fat penguin, and there on that ice floe is a whole flock of flippered lunch units.

title: A Morphing Mural
description: Shepard Faireys latest street-art piece, a freshly installed mural on Houston Street near the Bowery in Lower Manhattan, includes Mr. Faireys signature Andre the Giant, Communist propaganda-tinged images and, perhaps presciently, a target. Hours after the mural went up last week, the graffiti writer known as NAW added his tag to it; a security guard tried to apprehend NAW, but he escaped, apparently by wriggling out of his shirt, according to the blogger Bucky Turco. The tag was quickly removed. More recently, someone punctured the piece, perhaps with a rock or a brick, leaving several small holes and a gaping one through which a previous mural, by the twins known as Os Gemeos, is visible. The piece is a prelude to Mr. Faireys exhibition at Deitch Projects, the gallerys final show before it closes. Andrea Cashman, a spokeswoman for Deitch, said the puncture and tagging were a natural occurrence for any large outdoor project. She said that members of Mr. Faireys team would be filling the punctures soon. Mr. Fairey said in a telephone interview that he hadnt seen the damage, but that if critics wanted to express themselves by vandalizing the mural, thats fair. He added, I assume that they think that putting a bullet hole through it is a clever interactive addition, which I actually agree with.

title: While Contestant Ails, Apprentice Thrives
description: Amid a weekends outpouring of support for Bret Michaels, the rock musician and Celebrity Apprentice contestant who was hospitalized with a brain hemorrhage on Thursday, ratings for that NBC reality show hit their highest level in six weeks on Sunday night. According to Nielsens estimates, Celebrity Apprentice earned an average of 7.9 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., its best finish since this seasons premiere and enough to beat CBSs Hallmark movie, When Love Is Not Enough: The Lois Wilson Story (7.1 million). CBS still won the night, with a lineup that included 60 Minutes (11.2 million) and The Amazing Race (10.6 million). ABC was runner-up with Desperate Housewives (11.1 million) and Brothers & Sisters (8.4 million), while NBC ranked third and Fox was fourth.

title: Chevron Vs. Filmmaker
description: A documentary filmmaker says he will fight a request by Chevron to turn over hundreds of hours of footage he shot for a documentary about pollution in the Amazon rainforest in Ecuador. Chevron says the material may be useful in lawsuits accusing it of damaging the environment there. The filmmaker, Joe Berlinger, whose documentaries include Paradise Lost and Metallica: Some Kind of Monster, said he had been served with a request from Chevron for more than 600 hours of unused footage for his 2009 documentary Crude. The movie, seen in a scene above, chronicles Ecuadoreans who sued Texaco, which is now owned by Chevron, saying the companies practices at the Lago Agrio oil field resulted in the contamination of their drinking and bathing water. Mr. Berlinger, who is scheduled to appear in United States District Court in Manhattan on Friday, said Chevrons request violated his First Amendment rights. If Chevron obtained his footage, he said, It would have a serious chilling effect on these kinds of investigative films. Randy M. Mastro, a lawyer representing Chevron, said the company simply seeks here outtakes relating to the access this filmmaker was given to film the plaintiffs and their lawyers, government officials and supposedly independent experts meetings with the plaintiffs and their lawyers.

title: George W. Bush Memoir Coming In November
description: Former President George W. Bushs memoir, Decision Points, will be released by Crown Publishers, a division of Random House, on Nov. 9, the publisher said on Monday. Mr. Bush will write about political and personal challenges and discuss his handling of events, including the Sept. 11 attacks and Hurricane Katrina, as well as embracing his faith amid an effort to quit drinking. In a news release, Crown said that Mr. Bush would focus on 14 critical decisions in his life and share his reflections on subjects including the closely fought 2000 presidential election and the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. Crown said that Mr. Bush had given few speeches or interviews since leaving office. Instead, he has spent almost every day writing Decision Points, the release said, adding, He writes honestly and directly about his flaws and mistakes, as well as his historic achievements. The book will be released in hardcover and in audio and e-book formats. Mr. Bush will also go on a national book tour.

title: Bieber Concert Canceled After Fans Go Wild
description: With his floppy bowl haircut and adorable lisp, the teenage pop star Justin Bieber, below, may not seem like a dangerous figure. But make no mistake: his public appearances can be battlegrounds. On Monday the Australian police shut down a free performance that Mr. Bieber, 16, was to give in Sydney as some fans were injured at the crowded concert site, Agence France-Presse reported. More than 4,000 fans, some who camped out overnight, showed up to hear Mr. Bieber sing three songs at Sydney Harbor, but the plug was pulled on the event hours before showtime when attendees started pushing and shoving. I am so sorry that it got out of control, Mr. Bieber said later in an Australian television appearance. In November an appearance by Mr. Bieber at the Roosevelt Field Mall in Garden City, N.Y., resulted in a fan stampede after which the singers manager, Scott Braun, was arrested on charges of reckless endangerment and criminal nuisance. The Australian police said that fans at Sydney Harbor had sustained only minor injuries and were treated at the scene.

title: Privilege Pulls Qatar Toward Unhealthy Choices
description: DOHA, Qatar  For such a small country, a finger of sand poking into the Persian Gulf from the eastern side of the Arabian Peninsula, Qatar is a land of big numbers.

title: Two Authors Win Pen/malamud Award
description: The short story is not so small that it cant accommodate two winners for one of the more prestigious prizes in that genre. On Monday the organizers of the PEN/Malamud Award for Excellence in the Short Story, which in recent years has recognized both a veteran author and a writer at the start of a career, announced that Edward P. Jones, above left, and Nam Le, above right, won its 2010 prize. Mr. Jones, a Pulitzer Prize winner in 2004 for his novel The Known World, was cited for story collections like Lost in the City (1992) and All Aunt Hagars Children (2007). Mr. Le, a Vietnamese-born writer who splits his time between the United States and Australia, was honored for his debut collection, The Boat, published in 2008. Mr. Jones and Mr. Le will share a prize of $5,000 and take part in the 2010/11 PEN/Faulkner Reading Series at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington.

title: Old-Time Jazz Swing, but Modern Metabolism
description: The New York jazz landscape has always been defined partly by its underground, with the tacit understanding that such a region is usually zoned for experimentation. Thats as true as it ever was, but its an incomplete truth because of all that it overlooks. One case in point would be the Ear Regulars, the traditional jazz cohort led by the trumpeter Jon-Erik Kellso and the guitarist Matt Munisteri every Sunday night at the Ear Inn, on the westernmost edge of the South Village, near the entrance to the Holland Tunnel.

title: A Change of Topics for Pandit: World Growth
description: Vikram S. Pandit, the chief executive of Citigroup, must have welcomed the chance on Monday to talk about something other than the challenges facing his bank and the overall financial industry.

title: A Man Who Stopped Time to Set It in Motion Again
description: WASHINGTON  Technology moves fast, art slower. You could say that art is still catching up to Eadweard Muybridge (1830-1904), a pioneer of stop-motion photography and early filmmaking.

title: Architecture of Dance
description: Images from rehearsals of the new works in New York City Ballets spring season.

title: Folding Pollen Grain
description: Researchers studied pollen from lilies and other flowers, and their work could have implications for engineers.

title: Obama Talks to Muslim Entrepreneurs
description: President Obama vowed to continue to press for a comprehensive peace deal between Israelis and Palestinians, exhorting young entrepreneurs from Muslim majority countries on Monday to look for ways to work with their American counterparts on a wide range of issues.

title: Will Arizonas Immigration Law Survive?
description: Arizonas tough new immigration enforcement law, which was signed on Friday, will face many legal challenges before it goes into effect this summer. Some opponents of the law, the toughest in the nation,  predict that it will suffer the same fate as Californias Proposition 187, which was passed in 1994 but never carried out because of legal setbacks and political opposition.

title: Living With Tinnitus (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Couples and Caregiving (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: What Were Reading: Android Gains
description: Whats on the reading list of The Timess tech editors and reporters Monday:

title: 'Enron'
description: An excerpt from the new Broadway play. (Video courtesy of the production)

title: Making Healthy Choices (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Earth as Greenhouse (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Chatter of Swindles and Scams at Auction House
description: PARIS  In a warren of side streets not far from the stately Boulevard Haussmann is a squat concrete building that contains another world.

title: Grass-Roots Choice Leads Race for Top Union Post
description: Mary Kay Henry, a dark-horse candidate who is a leader of the health care division of the Service Employees International Union, has locked up the votes to succeed Andy Stern as the union president, several top union officials said Monday.

title: Justices to Consider Law Limiting the Sale of Violent Video Games
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether California may forbid the sale of violent video games to children.

title: Beacon to Hollywood Stays Alive in the Hills
description: LOS ANGELES  The landmark Hollywood sign will stand, unobscured, on scrub-covered slopes overlooking production studios and palm trees here, thanks to a $900,000 donation by Hugh Hefner in the ninth inning of a yearlong effort by conservationists to protect the hilltop around the sign from developers.

title: Newspaper Circulation Falls Nearly 9%
description: The reality facing many American newspaper publishers continues to look stark, as figures released Monday show deep circulation declines, with average weekday sales down almost 9 percent since the same time last year.

title: Russian Adoptees Get a Respite on the Range
description: EUREKA, Mont.  Hundreds of adopted children, most of them Russian, have come here to northwest Montana to live and perhaps find healing grace with the horses and cows and rolling fields on Joyce Sterkels ranch. Some want to return to the families that adopted them, despite their troubles.

title: McDaniels and Tebow Know How to Adapt
description: Josh McDaniels and the Denver Broncos have inextricably linked their futures to Tim Tebow, which seems like a dicey decision considering how raw Tebows talent is. But this is not the first time there have been questions about how well Tebow can adjust to a new system.

title: ESPN Cant Seem to Get Enough of the Mets
description: ESPNs early-season Sunday night schedule reveals one inescapable fact: the network loves the Mets.

title: Russias Power (and Strictly Platonic) Couple
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia made clear on Monday that he and his protg, President Dmitri A. Medvedev, were just friends. Really.

title: Franklin Mieuli, Offbeat N.B.A. Owner, Dies at 89
description: Franklin Mieuli, the unconventional and popular owner of the Golden State Warriors for nearly a quarter century who in 1975 brought the franchise its only National Basketball Association championship in 48 years on the West Coast, died Sunday. He was 89.

title: The Comfort of Having a Nurse on Board
description: I mostly fly to Seattle or Washington, D.C., for business. Im on the board of a small pharmaceutical company working on drugs to treat late-stage cancer. Its based in the state of Washington. I enjoy going there since its very interesting work and my son lives in Washington. And I always manage to squeeze in some mom time when I travel there.

title: Meet the Real Villain of the Financial Crisis
description: TODAY, we will have the pleasure of watching outraged members of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations fire questions at a half-dozen executives from Goldman Sachs. The firm first attracted anger for its return to making billions, and paying its employees millions, right after the financial crisis. And since the Securities and Exchange Commission this month charged Goldman with fraud over an investment tied to subprime mortgages, politicians have turned the firm into the arch-villain of the economic collapse.

title: Encouraging the Text Generation to Rediscover Its Voice
description: Julia Sokoloff, 14, woke up around 8 on Sunday morning and reached for her phone the way hard-core smokers reach for their cigarettes, before theyre even fully conscious. She sent a text, something about a play rehearsal, and then it hit her.

title: A Better Chance at Justice for Abuse Victims
description: LAST week, Pope Benedict XVI told victims of sexual abuse by priests in Malta that the Catholic Church was doing all it could to investigate abuse accusations and find ways to safeguard children in the future. With the popes pledge, and the resignation in recent days of three European bishops involved in the sex abuse scandal, it might appear that the church is finally taking responsibility for failing to protect children against molesters for hundreds of years.

title: Reed Colleges President Is Told to Crack Down on Campus Drug Use
description: After the heroin overdose death of a Reed College student last month, law enforcement authorities in Portland, Ore., told Reeds president, Colin Diver, to rein in drug use at his campus.

title: Future Popes Role in Abuse Case Was Complex
description: VIENNA  As Pope Benedict XVI has come under scrutiny for his handling of sexual abuse cases, both his supporters and his critics have paid fresh attention to the way he responded to a sexual abuse scandal in Austria in the 1990s, one of the most damaging to confront the church in Europe.

title: Breathing While Undocumented
description: Im glad Ive already seen the Grand Canyon.

title: Army Officers Defend Units From Critics
description: WASHINGTON  Army officers on Monday defended a program intended to help service members with physical wounds and severe psychological trauma, saying recent criticism of the program by soldiers and their families was not representative.

title: Home Tax Credit Called Successful, but Costly
description: Realtors, home buyers and sellers are rushing to complete sales agreements before the tax credit for home purchases expires this week.

title: Instead of Falling, Sky Is Now Limit for the Mets
description: Chicken Little was taken out of context. He would have us believe that he did not say, The sky is falling, but rather, The sky could still fall if certain things happen.

title: Noriega Extradited to France to Face Charges
description: MEXICO CITY  Two decades after United States troops invaded Panama and arrested Manuel Noriega, the countrys dictator, Mr. Noriega left federal prison in Miami on Monday and was extradited to France.

title: A Dangerous Squabble
description: Among the Senates most important tasks this year are fashioning a rational, humane immigration policy and a rational, comprehensive energy policy to address climate change and oil dependency. Unless Lindsey Graham and Harry Reid can patch up a needless feud, the Senate could end up doing neither. That would be a terrible outcome, since nobody knows what the appetite for either task will be after the November elections.

title: Is China Chortling at Senate Climate Stasis?
description: Senator John Kerry is trying to tamp down the advance obituaries on his effort, with two colleagues, to cobble a passable Senate energy and climate bill. He just listed three reasons for climate optimism on Talking Points Memo. The first was that he and Senators Joseph Lieberman and Lindsey Graham had invested enormous amounts of time and effort; the second, that a very variegated coalition (from oil companies to environmental groups) was behind the effort; and the third, that everyone recognized China would celebrate if the effort failed.

title: Midwest Trip With Political Fortunes on the Line
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, Iowa  President Obama is making an appeal to the legions of new voters who sent him to the White House, imploring them to preserve the Democratic majority in Congress. But party leaders have an even more pressing wish: that he help himself before he helps his fellow Democrats.

title: Listen to the Families
description: There are two tragic anniversaries this month. It is 11 years since two Colorado students gunned down 12 of their fellow classmates and one teacher at Columbine High School and three years since 32 students and faculty members were gunned down at Virginia Tech.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,384 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,036 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: Tribal Genes and a Fair Settlement
description: A bitter seven-year legal struggle between an impoverished Indian tribe and scientists at Arizona State University reached a reasonable settlement when the universitys regents agreed to pay $700,000 and to collaborate on other forms of assistance dealing with health, education and economic development. Left unresolved was the underlying question of how scientists can best obtain informed consent from patients whose education and command of English may be limited.

title: The First Amendment and Kittens
description: To anyone who has been following First Amendment jurisprudence in the past 40 or 50 years, the recent Supreme Court decision (United States v. Stevens, April 20) striking down a statute criminalizing the production and sale of videos depicting animal cruelty in a manner intended to satisfy a particular sexual fetish will come as no surprise.The proverbial ordinary citizen, however, may be surprised to learn that, according to Chief Justice John Roberts majority opinion, the First Amendment must be read to allow the production and dissemination of so called crush videos, videos (and I quote from Roberts opinion) that feature the intentional torture and killing of helpless animals often by women wearing high-heeled spike shoes who slowly crush animals to death while talking to them in a kind of dominatrix patter as they scream and squeal in great pain. How has it come to this?

title: Pakistan's Power Crisis
description: Adam Ellick reports from Lahore, Pakistan, about the worst power shortages the country has been facing in decades.

title: The White Houses G.O.P. Mainstay? Maybe Not
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Lindsey Graham makes no pretense about it. He wants to be where the action is.

title: Computers Seized From Home of Blogger in iPhone Inquiry
description: Gawker Media said Monday that computers belonging to one of its editors, Jason Chen, were seized from his home on Friday in an apparent investigation into the sale of a next-generation Apple iPhone. Gawker suggested the action violated Californias shield law for journalists.

title: View of the Sun
description: There has always been something miraculous about transmissions from space  those thin datastreams trickling toward Earth from research spacecraft. Over the years, the transmissions have grown more and more robust, richer in information, giving us dazzling and detailed panoramas of Saturns moons and rings and the surface of Mars. But there has never really been anything like the Solar Dynamics Observatory. Launched in mid-February, it is shipping a torrent of data our way from its orbit above the Sun.

title: Q. & A. With United States Forward Charlie Davies
description: The American striker Charlie Davies fractured the tibia, fibula and femur in his right leg in a car accident last October. He broke his elbow, his nose and his eye socket. His bladder was lacerated and he had a serious head trauma. Doctors estimated a 6- to 12-month recovery period, which would have ruled out his participation in this summers World Cup. But after seven operations and more than six months of grueling physical rehabilitation, Davies is making a feverish, last-ditch effort to make the American team that will travel to South Africa. Last month, Jeffrey Marcus had several telephone conversations with Davies while he was at CERS, a sports rehabilitation center in Capbreton, France, and when he returned to Montbeliard and resumed training with his club team, Sochaux. Here are edited excerpts from those conversations.

title: Russian Billionaire Is White Knight for the Nets
description: Mikhail D. Prokhorov has a net worth of $17.8 billion, enough to buy every team in the National Basketball Association, stock them with All-Stars and take them on a world tour aboard his 200-foot yacht.

title: Pakistanis Living on Brink, and Often in the Dark
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  The Taliban may be plotting bombings, and the economy is on the brink. But these days, the single biggest woe tormenting Pakistanis is as basic as an electric light bulb.

title: We Have Met the Enemy and He Is PowerPoint
