description: WASHINGTON  Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the leader of American and NATO forces in Afghanistan, was shown a PowerPoint slide in Kabul last summer that was meant to portray the complexity of American military strategy, but looked more like a bowl of spaghetti.

title: Off Wall St., Worries About Financial Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Mars, the maker of M&Ms and Snickers, wants to make sure it can continue dabbling in the derivatives market to protect the price of sugar and chocolate for its candies.

title: Islamist Death Threats Arent a Cartoon Joke
description: Lets see. A mobster warns that you will wind up like Paul Castellano, the crime boss who was gunned down outside a Midtown steakhouse in 1985. Maybe the guy is merely a blowhard. But maybe he is a sociopath. Youre not really sure. Either way, youve been handed a death threat. Shouldnt you count on his being arrested?

title: Words of Wisdom From the Mavericks Cuban
description: Mark Cuban, who bought the Dallas Mavericks in 2000, is one of the most passionate, outspoken and accessible owners in professional sports. He is a vivid example of how an owners personality can be just as important as his largesse. With the Russian billionaire Mikhail Prokhorov on the verge of taking control of the Nets, Cuban spoke about his insights on ownership.

title: The Goldman Drama
description: Between 1997 and 2006, consumers, lenders and builders created a housing bubble, and pretty much the entire establishment missed it. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and the people who regulate them missed it. The big commercial banks and the people who regulate them missed it. The Federal Reserve missed it, as did the ratings agencies, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the political class in general.

title: Howard Slims Down, Cashes In
description: The evolution of Ryan Howards game has been striking. To watch him against the Atlanta Braves last week  stretching to make a catch, diving to spear a sharp grounder, nimbly executing a flawless slide at the plate  was to see a player who has reinvented himself.

title: Inspector Says He Faked Data in New York Building Tests
description: A safety inspector licensed to make critical assessments of asbestos and lead risks in buildings and at construction sites across the city made a stunning admission in federal court: Despite filing hundreds of reports saying his tests had found no danger, he had not performed a single one of the tests.

title: Boozy, Bawdy Reality TV, With a Few Wrinkles
description: SURPRISE, Ariz.  Pedal to the metal, baby! shouted Joanne Hauncher, 63, as she swerved wildly through traffic on a busy street in this Phoenix suburb. A truck driver slammed on his brakes and stared  she was driving a golf cart, after all  as Ms. Hauncher completed an illegal U-turn.

title: Dugout to Derby: Torres Interest Grows
description: Don Zimmer decided to sneak out to the racetrack one day in 1996 and asked Joe Torre if he wanted to come along. Torre could not get away, but he gave his longtime friend a few hundred dollars and asked Zimmer to invest it for him at the betting windows at Baltimores Pimlico Race Course. Zimmer must have had one of those days at the track where every horse he picked ran like a champion. Torres bankroll grew exponentially.

title: In Wake of Immigration Law, Calls for an Economic Boycott of Arizona
description: A spreading call for an economic boycott of Arizona after its adoption of a tough immigration law that opponents consider racially discriminatory worried business leaders on Monday and angered the governor.

title: Bloggingheads: Blame Wall Street!
description: Jesse Eisinger, left, of ProPublica and Mike Konczal of the Roosevelt Institute discuss responsibility for the housing crisis.

title: Corrections
In Shake-Up, Principals May Get More Say Over What Is Taught
description: The schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, said Monday that he was reshuffling the top jobs at citys Education Department headquarters and eliminating the division that oversees school curriculum and teacher training programs.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits on Monday with a theater review of Promises, Promises, at the Broadway Theater, misstated the surname of the music coordinator. He is Howard Joines, not Jones.

title: Brewing Coffee Again in Brooklyn After a Barista Walkout
description: Not until about 9:45 a.m. on Monday, the morning of its reopening, did Gorilla Coffee in Brooklyn begin to look a little like its old self. A few patrons lined up at the cash register, waiting for lattes and Balthazar pastries; a smattering of others sat at shiny red tables, tapping away at laptops.

title: Street Weapon
description: Obi-Wan Kenobi. Obi-Wan  Now, thats a name Ive not heard in a long time. A long time. 23 Across

title: Democrats, Republicans and the Role of Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Air Force Tanker Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: A Storm Over Arizona and Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Preparing Our Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Saving Mothers Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: THE ARTS

title: A Crowd With Pity for Goldman
description: Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Belgium: King Accepts Governments Resignation
description: The Belgian political crisis worsened on Monday when King Albert II, left, accepted the governments resignation, tendered last Thursday, after negotiations failed to solve a dispute between Dutch- and French-speaking legislators over a bilingual voting district. The king asked Prime Minister Yves Leterme to continue in a caretaker capacity, since Belgium takes over the rotating presidency of the European Union on July 1. New elections are likely in the country, which is deeply divided between Dutch-speakers in the north and French-speakers in the south.

title: West Bank: Israeli Forces Kill a Hamas Militant
description: A Hamas militant long wanted by Israel was killed Monday by Israeli forces in Beit Awwa, in the West Bank, according to the Israeli military and Hamas. The military said that forces surrounded a house where the militant, Ali Suweiti, was hiding, that he refused to surrender, and that he was killed in an exchange of fire. Israel said that Mr. Suweiti was responsible for several shootings, including one in which a border police officer was killed. Hamas issued a statement hailing its fighter as a martyr who had refused to surrender.

title: G.M. Plans to Upgrade 5 Factories
description: DETROIT  General Motors plans to announce Tuesday that it will spend $890 million to retool five engine and component plants as the automaker uses its growing cash reserves to increase investment in new products.

title: Mexico: 5 Arrested in the Killing of 7 Police Officers
description: Mexican soldiers have arrested five men who confessed to killing seven police officers last week in a brazen midday shooting in the border city of Ciudad Jurez, the authorities said Monday. The gunmen ambushed the officers on a main street, spraying a police pick-up truck with bullets. A 17-year-old civilian was also killed. The suspects, who said they were members of La Lnea, the enforcement arm of the Jurez drug cartel, confessed to 36 other killings since the beginning of 2009, the Chihuahua State attorney generals office said.

title: Game 7 Arrives Against Red Wings, and Coyotes Hope to Stick Around
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.    The Detroit Red Wings deep-seated tradition runs the gamut from Gordie Howe to Stanley Cup championships (11) to octopus-tossing to star-studded international rosters. The Phoenix Coyotes are famous mainly for going bankrupt a year ago and almost moving to Hamilton, Ontario.

title: Bloombergs Bermuda
description: Neighbors and friends say Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is in Bermuda about twice a month, depending on the weather in Bermuda (no sun, no Bloomberg) and the political climate in New York.

title: Confidence About Greek Debt Falters in Germany
description: BERLIN  Confidence in Greek assets sank to a new low on Monday, as Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany kept up the pressure on Greece, insisting on tougher austerity measures.

title: Russia: American Seeks Denial of Visas to 60 Russian Officials
description: Senator Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland, asked the State Department on Monday to deny visas to 60 Russian officials who he said were involved in prosecuting and detaining Sergei L. Magnitsky, a 37-year-old lawyer who died in a Moscow jail after having requested medical care. Mr. Magnitsky was held in a tax evasion case against the Hermitage Fund, whose American-born owner had clashed bitterly with Russian officials. The sanctions would apply to senior officials in Russian law-enforcement agencies and their family members. The proposal is based on a 2004 presidential proclamation denying visas to people engaged in corruption.

title: Somalia: Pirates Abandon Town as Insurgents Approach
description: Pirates based in the notorious pirate town of Xarardheere evacuated after Islamist insurgents took over a nearby coastal town late last week, officials and residents there said Monday. Residents said the pirates had all left and the town was now quiet. Last week, the Shabab, Somalias most powerful Islamist insurgent group, fought local clan militias in central Somalia, taking over several towns. At least 40 people have been reported killed, mainly from the warring groups. On Saturday, the Shabab looted a warehouse used by the United Nations World Food Program and distributed the food to the local residents, local news media reported.

title: Italy: 31 Charged in Illegal Immigration Ring
description: Three months after violent race riots shook the Southern Italian city of Rosarno, Italian authorities on Monday broke up an illegal immigration ring in the area, arresting 31 people from Italy and North Africa and seizing 20 businesses and farmland valued at $13.3 million. Prosecutors in Calabria said that middlemen, most from North Africa, had procured immigrants for Italian landowners, who paid them wages as low as $33 a day to work in the fields. The arrests were not directly tied to the riots, in which about 50 people were wounded, but authorities said the illegal immigration ring contributed to the tensions in the area. In January, the police arrested eight people for inciting the riots, but human rights groups have criticized Italian authorities for not making more arrests.

title: Setbacks in the Air Add to Lure of Virtual Meetings

title: Famous Faces in Fences
description: Since its Broadway debut on March 26, 1987, "Fences" has been August Wilson's most widely produced play. The roles of Troy Maxson; his friend Jim Bono; his wife, Rose; his sons Lyons and Cory; and his brother Gabriel have offered rich parts to black actors. Some have gone on to fame; others have played the same roles in various regional theaters; yet others, as they've gotten older, have moved from one role to another. "A whole army of people have cut their teeth on that work and are making a living in the business," said Lou Bellamy, artistic director and founder of the Penumbra Theater Company in St. Paul, Minn. (He has both played Troy and directed the drama.) "Where else is there a writer who allows black people to go deep," he said of Wilson, "and still stay black?" Following is a selective guide to some of the actors who've stepped into Wilson's Pittsburgh backyard.

title: Wind Project Is Crucial Step for U.S. Sector

But despite a decade of efforts, not a single offshore turbine has been built in the United States, The New York Timess Tom Zeller Jr.writes.

title: Australia Suspends Emissions Trading Proposal
description: SYDNEY, Australia  After two years of deadlock, Prime Minister Kevin Rudd said on Tuesday that his Labor government had put its carbon emissions trading plan on hold. The proposed emissions trading system had aimed to cut Australias emissions by 5 percent of 2000 levels by 2020, while giving significant concessions to energy-intensive industries. The plan was twice rejected by a bloc of conservative and Green Party lawmakers in the Senate last year and faced almost certain defeat were it to go before Parliament again this year.

title: Report Calls Zambias Prisons Death Traps

title: Alphabet Chic
description: In their nearly 20 years together, the graphic artists Michael Amzalag and Mathias Augustyniak  who go by the name M/M (Paris)  have designed more than 50 typefaces, from an alphabet built from the sliced-up photographs of 26 male models to the inky resin letter forms that spell out Medulla on the cover of Bjorks 2004 album. Their latest, the Pradalphabet (above), was originally conceived as a temporary five-letter logotype for the house of Miuccia: Prada-M. (The M stands for Milano and M/M.) But the duos ideographic tendencies got the best of them, and in the end, M/M designed a whole alphabet of ornamented initials, each representing a hazy portrait of the Prada brand. Its like looking at a planet from afar, says Augustyniak, who along with Amzalag spent up to six hours hand-drawing each letter. You can see a continent, but its impossible to say whats inside. Examine the letters closely, however, and youll spot cleaning implements, Italian phrases, strange machines and a picture of two men standing on a balcony. (Theyre inhabitants of the Prada world, Amzalag says.) For now, they live in a collectors edition of T-shirts, each silk-screened with a P, R, A, D or M and packaged in a cloth-bound box with a 64-page album describing the project. Other letters are available on demand at Prada stores worldwide.

And one embarrassing moment. When the head of Goldman Sachs was going through security, he was asked to empty his pockets and five Republican senators fell out.

title: US Airways and United Post Narrower Quarterly Losses
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, and US Airways, which broke off merger talks last week, both reported narrower losses in the first quarter on Tuesday as an improving economy allowed airlines to raise fares and increase revenue.

title: New Zealand Inoculates Itself for Bieber Fever
description: Please be advised that if you see Justin Bieber on his tour of the Southern Hemisphere, do not attempt to apprehend him yourself, as he may be adorable  and dangerous. One day after the seemingly harmless 16-year-old singers planned appearance at Sydney Harbor in Australia led to pushing and shoving that forced the cancellation of the event, the authorities in New Zealand are taking no chances when Mr. Bieber brings his floppy hair and boyish pipes to their country on Wednesday.

title: Not Pets, but Rescued and Returned
description: In a dimly lighted warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a handful of orphaned baby animals, no bigger than dormice, squinted and opened their tiny black eyes for the first time a week ago in cages the size of shoe boxes.

title: Hikers: Can You Hear Me Now?
description: The next time you lace up your boots and head out for even an hours jaunt on a Bay Area trail, bring your cellphone. Thats the lesson that local park officials hope amblers will learn from the rescue of two Bay Area hikers on Friday night.

title: Lessons in Tough Love at a Court for Truants
description: Trayvon Johnson stepped into one of New Yorks newest courts the other day in East Harlem, nervously squeezing a balled-up tissue. So far, it was a familiar court scene.

title: The Morning Skate: Habs and Halak Push Caps to Game 7
description: When a team has a chance to close out a playoff series on home ice and fails, that often signals trouble ahead. The Red Wings had a chance to dispose of the Coyotes in Game 6 at the Joe Louis Arena on Sunday, couldnt do it, and now face a Game 7 in Phoenix. And anything can happen in a one-game series. Jeff Z. Klein has an article on that contest in Tuesdays New York Times.

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: In the Beginning, There Was the Word  A Word From Our Sponsor, Who Art in Heaven
description: Once, advertising by churches and religious organizations was seen only in local markets, particularly in so-called Bible Belt states. But in recent years, such marketing outreach has been increasing, as tens of millions of viewers noticed on Super Bowl Sunday in February when CBS broadcast a commercial from Focus on the Family.

title: Graduate Students Ask N.Y.U. to Recognize Union
description: Graduate students who assist professors with teaching and research may not seem like typical workers, but more than 1,000 such assistants petitioned New York University on Monday to recognize a union that would represent their interests.

title: Buy a House, Get a Ferrari F40
description: Three years ago, home sellers on the exclusive north side of Malibu, Calif., could incite bidding wars simply by opening their doors. In the current market, sweeping ocean vistas and the cachet of celebrity neighbors barely bring out the tire-kickers, let alone buyers with real offers. Recognizing this, one Malibu listing agent has hatched an incentive that commands considerably more curb appeal than any federal tax credit.

title: How to Lower the Burden of Student Loans
description: President Obama recently signed legislation that changes the federal student loan program. The new law eliminates fees to private bank intermediaries, expands Pell grants and makes it easier for students who borrow money, starting in July 2014, to pay it back.

title: Obama Tells Debt Commission Everything Has to Be on the Table
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama told his bipartisan debt commission on Tuesday that everything has to be on the table, while the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, suggested overhauling the nations tax code to raise more revenue.

title: A Good Bad Week for Catholicism
description: Last Wednesday, the Vatican formally accepted the resignation of Bishop James Moriarty, the third Irish prelate to step down over his role in sex abuse cover-ups. The next day, a German bishop, Walter Mixa of Augsburg, offered his resignation over allegations that hed been involved in physical abuse at an orphanage in the 1970s and 80s. Then on Friday it was Belgiums turn: The bishop of Brugges resigned after publicly admitting to having sexually abused a minor two decades ago. And over the weekend, Swedens lone Catholic bishop announced his willingness to resign over a womans claim that hed failed to respond to an allegation of sex abuse against one of his dioceses priests.

title: Charter School Teachers Back Off From Union
description: Charter schools came under a harsh spotlight last week, with State Senator Bill Perkins holding his long-awaited hearing in an attempt to examine how the privately operated schools spend their public money. The hearings prompted several articles in the papers exploring potential conflicts of interest and other practices that have raised the ire of critics  and the issues are not limited to New York. And The New York Post took on Mr. Perkins with zeal in its editorial pages.

title: Chinas Motives on Climate and Energy
description: Mark Lynas, the author of Six Degrees and an adviser to the president of Maldives on climate policy, wrote in following my post yesterday touching on Chinas stance in the entwined arenas of climate and energy policy:

title: Goldman Shares Are Up as Executives Testify
description: Shares in Goldman Sachs were up slightly in morning trading on Tuesday, as current and former executives of the firm testify before a Senate panel investigating the financial crisis.

title: Having The Talk With Your Child
description: April is both National Child Abuse Prevention Month and Sexual Assault Awareness Month, and the twin subjects keep Sierra Black awake at night. A former journalist who now lives in the Boston area with her three children, she is also a rape survivor, and keeping her daughters safe from sexual violence is on her mind 12 months a year.

title: Profile in Style | Kelly Wearstler
description: Kelly Wearstlers life is as vibrant and busy as the rooms she creates. With her husband and sons Oliver, 7, and Elliott, 6; residences in Beverly Hills and Malibu, Calif.; and a business that takes her from Los Angeles to Anguilla to Paris in the space of a week, her only downtime is in the air. (Not a fan of flying, she travels with her good-luck charm, Franc, the stuffed bear that belonged to her grandmother and mother. She had him re-covered in linen since his fur had been loved off, and sewed on the buttons from her grandfathers navy blazer to replace his eyes.) When she does escape, she says she likes places where I can relax, but also go into a city and be inspired and shop. Otherwise I go stir crazy. View interactive >>

title: Cleaning-Products Companies Spat Puts Petals to the Metal
description: Remember the old song that starts, Daisy, daisy, give me your answer do? A couple of companies that market household cleaning products are looking for an answer as they duke it out over dueling daisies.

title: Squeakquel Breeds a Chipmunks Lawsuit
description: In more innocent days, when Alvin and the Chipmunks needed an authority figure to get something done they turned to a witch doctor. Now they go to their lawyers: The Hollywood Reporter said that the production company behind the Chipmunk characters and a relative of their creator are suing 20th Century Fox, saying that studio owes them half of the profits from last years hit film Alvin & the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel.

title: Banyan Tree Opens Third Thai Hotel
description: Despitecontinuing political unrest in Thailand, Banyan Tree is expected to open its third resort in the country  this time on the island of Koh Samui  on July 15.

title: Sting Sells Co-op on Central Park
description: A duplex apartment owned by Sting has just gone into contract.

title: Living for Years With Late-Stage Cancer
description: Tuesdays Cases column explores the world of late-stage cancer patients who dont die. Its written by Katherine Russell Rich, who was given two years to live after a diagnosis of stage IV breast cancer. Shes now on year 17.

title: Standard & Poors Lowers Greek Debt Rating Sharply
description: Greeces debt has been downgraded to noninvestment status by Standard & Poors amid mounting fear that the debt crisis in Europe is spiraling out of control, The Associated Press reported Tuesday.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Enron'
description: The director Rupert Goold narrates a look at  a scene from the new Broadway show.

title: On Our Radar: Australia Shelves Carbon Trading Plan
description: A carbon emissions trading plan founders in the Australian Parliament.

title: Why We Blame Our Parents
description: If you blame your parents for your problems, or even if you dont, be sure to read this fascinating obituary of Alice Miller, a psychoanalyst whose focus on family dysfunction started it all. Her work alerted therapists to the problem of child abuse, but it also offered adults the opportunity to blame their difficulties in life on their upbringing.

title: In Lawsuit on Adoption, Focus Is on Disclosure
description: Scores of complaints have been made in recent years against adoption agencies by people claiming they were inadequately informed or ill-prepared for problems their children turned out to have.

title: Oh My Lady Gaga
description: A replacement for Oh My God (O.M.G) among Chinas young Internet users.

title: An Image in Tatters
description: Todays Leading Off pays homage to the word-generating computer that Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger used to create his clearly from the heart apology to Steeler Nation in response to his six-game N.F.L. suspension for aggravated loutishness. If you missed his statement, so touchingly e-mailed to interested parties, the highlight quickly became a classic in robot-created poetry circles. Roethlisberger vowed he would make the necessary improvements, although he did not elaborate whether he could get that done at the same place he gets his oil changed.

title: Democrats Take Aim at Romney as Wall Street Pal
description: Maybe the Democrats and their supporters have tired of painting Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican minority leader, as the villain in the financial regulatory debate. Or perhaps some of you, as readers and followers of the legislative impasse, have grown weary of the name-calling, too.

title: China Moves to Tighten Data Controls
description: BEIJING  China is on the verge of requiring telecommunications companies and Internet service providers to halt and report leaks of what the government deems to be state secrets, the latest in a series of moves intended to strengthen the governments control over private communications.

title: TimesCast | April 27, 2010
description: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Tuesday.  Today's show is devoted to the battle for financial regulation in Washington.

title: Words Worth
description: A graphic design primer.

title: Eskendereya and the Racing Gods
description: Teresa Genaro writes regularly about New York racing at Brooklyn Backstretch.

title: Hamas Prods Israel With Cartoon Threat
description: According to a Palestinian news agency, Mahmoud Zahar, a senior Hamas official, has criticized his partys military wing for broadcasting an animated video on Sunday that implicitly threatens the life of Staff Sgt. Gilad Shalit, an Israeli soldier who has been held captive in Gaza since 2006, when he was seized in Israel, near its border with the Palestinian territory.

title: Googles Andy Rubin on Everything Android
description: Andy Rubin, a vice president for engineering at Google, leads one of the search giants most important effortsthe development of Android, Googles open source platform for smartphones and other mobile devices.

title: Citi Names Managing Director on Health Care Team
description: Citigroup has hired Jennifer Jarrett from Credit Suisse to join its global health care investment banking team as a managing director, according to an internal memo obtained by DealBook.

title: Its Light Extinguished, a Canceled Soap Opera Sells Its Scenery
description: What happens to a long-running soap opera once it has been canceled, after all its characters have recovered from amnesia, reconciled their marriages and made amends with their evil twins who were recently revived from comas? It has to find new homes for all the props and set pieces it accumulated during its decades on the air.

title: Full of Fight, Brown Still Lags With British Voters
description: ABOARD THE SOUTHAMPTON-LONDON TRAIN  In the newspapers, cataclysm was looming for Prime Minister Gordon Browns faltering Labour government. Cabinet ministers were reportedly scheming, squabbling and snapping Shut up! at one another in panicky strategy sessions. The question was not whether Labour would lose the election on May 6, but how thoroughly.

title: Cosmetic Surgeries Get a Little Nip and Tuck
description: COSMETIC surgery wasnt as popular in 2009 as it used to be, according to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons, which annually surveys its members as well as dermatologists and ear-nose-and-throat doctors.

title: Color Fields | Beautys Brightest Hues
description: The photographer Eric Maillet takes a fresh look at this seasons makeup shades, turning blushes and shadows into brilliant works of art. View interactive >>

title: Strict Abortion Measures Enacted in Oklahoma
description: HOUSTON  The Oklahoma Legislature voted Tuesday to override the governors vetoes of two abortion measures, one of which requires women to undergo an ultrasound and listen to a detailed description of the fetus before getting an abortion.

title: Like the N.H.L.? Share It With Friends
description: The N.H.L. recently announced a partnership with Facebook that would integrate various features from the popular social networking site into NHL.com. Visitors to the league site immediately noticed that they could now like teams and players and have that information shared with their Facebook friends.

title: To Get the Citys Attention, Be Creative!
description: As Goldmanfreude continues in Washington, it seems a good time to highlight some ordinary, artistic, non-market-moving forms of local creativity floating around today.

title: Senators Cant Resist a Few Bad Words
description: Not once, not twice, but about eight times did Senator Carl Levin use a vulgar term during a Senate hearing today with Goldman Sachs executives  a term we cant even partially spell out here, because of The Timess strict rules on proper language.

title: How Close Should We Get to the Wild (and Vice Versa)?
description: Among the first items I heard after I turned on KCBS radio on Tuesday morning was one about a mountain lion. It had appeared, early Sunday morning, on the porch of a home about a half-mile from mine on the Peninsula.

title: Learning About U.S. Immigration With The New York Times
description: Update: May 21, 2013

title: A Genentech Eye Treatment Is Found to Help Prevent Vision Loss in Diabetics
description: The drug Lucentis can improve eyesight being lost to diabetes, researchers reported on Tuesday, a finding they hailed as a major advance in combating a common cause of blindness.

title: Roll-Call Votes and Roulette: Times APIs
description: Its been far too long since we last looked at some creative and instructive uses of Times APIs. Heres a quick sampling of apps and tools that will help you explore Times APIs  and maybe even inspire you to build something of your own.

title: After 44 Years, England Wonders if Its Time Is Now
description: LONDON  It has been reported that Englands national soccer team will sleep in special tents to prepare for the altitude in South Africa, site of the coming World Cup.

title: Jordan to Play in Pro-Am, but Not With Woods
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  An answer arrived for at least one of the burning pre-tournament questions at the Quail Hollow Championship on Tuesday morning: yes, Michael Jordan will be playing in the Wednesday pro-am.

title: Howard Going Hollywood?
description: Maybe theres something about being an All-Star center for the Orlando Magic that sparks the desire to perform.

title: On Climate Certainty and Climate Credibility
description: In 2003, Judith Curry, a climate researcher at the Georgia Institute of Technology, wrote the following passage in a submission to a federal effort aimed at charting how to reduce uncertainties in the science pointing to a growing human influence on climate:

title: Judge Rejects Plea Deal on Guidant Heart Device
description: A federal judge in Minnesota on Tuesday rejected a plea agreement between the federal government and the Guidant Corporation, saying that the deal did not hold the company sufficiently accountable for an episode in which it sold potentially flawed heart defibrillators.

title: In Shanghai, Hiding Bootlegs Before the World Visits
description: SHANGHAI  The latest mystery in Shanghai, complete with sliding bookshelves, secret passageways and contraband goods, is this: Why are all the popular DVDs and CDs missing from this citys shops?

title: College Students Transfer Rate Is About 1 in 3
description: Lost in the shuffle of university admission and graduation rates is a reality that those statistics often mask: about 1 in 3 students who enroll in either a four-year or two-year college will probably transfer at some point. This, to me, is the takeaway statistic in a report issued Tuesday by the National Association for College Admission Counseling.

title: For Summer Sentinels, a Firefly Count
description: I have fond childhood memories of counting fireflies on summer nights in Ohio.

title: Car Sharing Expands to Nashville
description: WeCar, a car-sharing program operated by Enterprise Rent-A-Car, recently expanded into Nashville, where members can hop around town in a Nissan Cube for $8 an hour. The service, however, will have only four cars to share at first.

title: Financial Tuneup: Consider a Flexible Spending Account
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: Obsessions | Suction Without the Lipo
description: Having given birth almost a year ago, I now have modest hopes for a slim figure. Where I once aspired to look like the Olympian Dara Torres, Im now hoping to resemble Oprah at one of her less zaftig junctures, like the pop-epic moment when she pulled the red wagon loaded with 67 pounds of fat onto the stage of her talk show while wearing those teeny-tiny jeans. To a certain weight-obsessed group of women, Oprah in her size-10 skinny jeans and black turtleneck was as important a sociocultural milestone as the landing on the moon.

title: For $520 Million, AstraZeneca Settles Case Over Marketing of a Drug
description: AstraZeneca has completed a deal to pay $520 million to settle federal investigations into marketing practices for its blockbuster schizophrenia drug, Seroquel, the Attorney General, Eric Holder, said at a news conference Tuesday afternoon.

title: Remembering the Last Act
description: Sally Mehls 75th birthday celebration was shaping up to be a major bash. All five children and six grandchildren would come to the small house in Roseland, N.J., where theyd grown up; the siblings were already parceling out responsibility for the food and the cake. Her daughter Ann would take Mrs. Mehl to the beauty shop for a wash-and-set. Even her cockapoo, Sarah, would be groomed in honor of the occasion.

title: Federal Plaza, Manhattan, 12:25 P.M.
Lessons From the Icelandic Volcano Eruption
description: THE airlines use the phrase irregular operations to refer to travel disruptions caused by blizzards, power failures and thunderstorms. But what happened in the wake of the Icelandic volcano eruption was referred to by a different phrase: total chaos.

title: In Monroes Own Handwriting, New Book Documents Search for The Real Marilyn
description: Some of the most personal correspondence that Marilyn Monroe wrote in her life, as well as the messages, both intimate and trivial, that she jotted for herself will be published for the first time in a book planned for the fall.

title: War and PeaceIn Sudan
description: We in journalism are pretty good at covering wars after they start. But we make a lousy early warning system about wars that are approaching on the horizon. Thats mostly because until people start shooting, theres not much to write about or film; the prospect of war just isnt very dramatic, especially in visual terms.

title: TimesCast: Goldman Bankers Testify on Capitol Hill
description: Goldman Sachs is in the hot seat today, as former and current officials from the investment bank testified before a Senate panel that they did nothing wrong when marketing mortgage-based investments in the months before the global economic crisis.

title: The Future  Theres an App for That
description: Lately, Ive settled into a gloomy rut with my iPhone.

title: Obama Makes Iowa Appeal
description: OTTUMWA, Iowa  President Obama, returning to the scene of one of his greatest political triumphs, appealed today to the Iowa voters who helped send him to the White House to keep Democrats in Congress come November.

title: Do Gay Couples Give Up Their U.S. Citizenship?
description: American expatriates are having a more difficult time living and working abroad, a recent Times article found, causing a small but growing number of them to renounce their United States citizenship.

title: Countdown Begins for Derby Horses
description: The majority of horses who are pointing to run in this years Kentucky Derby have completed their final workouts.

title: Would You Pay $1.9 Million for This Business?
description: Some businesses have the power to capture the entire essence of a community, city or region. This working lobster wharf and restaurant, currently being offered for sale in a popular tourist destination on the coast of Maine, is a perfect example.

title: Nelsons Investment in Berkshire Hathaway
description: 5:50 p.m. | Updated Senator Ben Nelson, the Nebraska Democrat who switched sides this week to help block consideration of an overhaul of financial regulations, reported last year that he and his wife, Diane, owned up to $6 million in stock in the investment company run by the famed Nebraska investor Warren E. Buffett, who could be hurt by passage of the measure, records show.

title: News Business Lags at High Schools, Too
description: This has been a bad month for statistics about newspapers. Monday brought new misery-by-the-numbers: Circulation figures showed a drop of 8.7 percent in weekday newspaper sales for the six months that ended March 31, compared with the same stretch of 2008 and 2009.

title: Float Me Out to the Ballgame
description: Inrecent years, the Mets have urged fans to take the train to games to avoid the traffic jams and parking bottlenecks. Now, they can avoid both and take a boat instead.

title: Americas Multiethnic Military
description: The French Foreign Legion is famous for taking recruits of any nationality and molding them into premier soldiers. If recruits complete the arduous training, they not only join the ranks of a prestigious military unit but also become French citizens. The United States military has, in many ways, also adopted this method of immigration.

title: Rolls-Royce and G.E. Cut Price to Build F-35 Engines
description: Fighting to save a significant contract, General Electric and Rolls-Royce said on Tuesday that they had once again cut their prices in an offer to build alternate engines for the Pentagons Joint Strike Fighter.

title: Q&A: Miami on the Cheap
description: Q.

title: Smith Calls Nuggets Selfish
description: So does guard J.R. Smith really think his Denver Nuggets teammates play selfish basketball?

title: Tim Burton Retrospective Packed Em In at MoMA
description: Evidently there are a lot of people in New York who identify with the forlorn Edward Scissorhands (and possibly with the murderous Sweeney Todd, too). The Museum of Modern Art said on Tuesday that its retrospective on Tim Burton, the filmmaker of Edward Scissorhands, Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street and Alice in Wonderland, drew the third-highest attendance of anyexhibition in the museums history. During the run of the show, which opened on Nov. 22, 2009, and closed on Monday, 810,500 visitors went to see artifacts like Mr. Burtons early illustrations and a prop of Sarah Jessica Parkers severed head from his movie Mars Attacks! (Additionally, 10,700 people attended ticketed screenings of Mr. Burtons films as part of the exhibition.)Mr. Burton is now in the rarefied company ofPicasso, whose 1980 retrospective atMoMA remains the museums most popular (with 976,800 visitors), andMatisse, whose 1992 retrospective is still the runner-up (with 940,000).

title: Rubio Criticizes Arizonas Immigration Law
description: WEST MIAMI, Fla.  While Marco Rubio said Tuesday that he sympathized with Arizona and its concern about crimes committed by illegal immigrants, he said provisions of the states new law that give the police more power to arrest immigrants go too far.

title: Apple Buys Intrinsity, a Maker of Fast Chips
description: Apple wants the fastest chip for its mobile devices and has bought another chip maker to gain an edge over its competitors.

title: Letters: Budget Bicycling
description: To the Editor: Regarding Pushing Pedals, Not Budgets (April 25): I spend winters on Maui, and this year we purchased bikes on Craigslist and sold them for the same price a few months later. The cost of flying my bike to the island or renting locally was prohibitive. The bikes needed a little T.L.C., and anticipating that, I brought a few tools along.

title: LRB Panel: The Future of Reading
description: The writers on The London Review of Bookss panel The Author in the Age of the Internet this past Saturday might have been divided into two categories: those who know how to operate a portable electronic gadget, and those who dont. In the do camp: James Wood (critic, novelist, subject of YouTube finger drum video) and John Lanchester (journalist, novelist, proud owner of new iPad). In the dont camp: Colm Toibin (novelist, teacher, enthusiastic chronicler of gay chat-room culture), who claims such an aversion to phones, mobile or not, that hes grateful that in the Age of the Internet, we have e-mail, which doesnt ring. Also on the panel was Mary-Kay Wilmers, editor of the Review, and Nicholas Spice, publisher, who moderated. Neither was forthcoming about his or her gadget use, although there were some early, tricky moments having to do with a microphone.

title: What Does Howards Deal Mean for Fielder?
description: Ryan Howard, a big and powerful National League All-Star first baseman, cashed in Monday by signing a five-year, $125 million contract extension with the Phillies. How will this affect Prince Fielder, the Brewers larger (270 pounds to 255 pounds) and just as powerful All-Star first baseman, who will potentially join a list of high-profile free-agent first basemen heading into the 2012 season?

title: A Dust-Up in the Ukrainian Parliament
description: After a rowdy debate, the Ukrainian Parliament narrowly approved an agreement to allow Russia to extend a lease on a naval base in Ukrainian territory.

title: A Divine Escape in Sons of Perdition
description: As former Mormons, Tyler Measom and Jennilyn Merten were naturally drawn to the subject of their new documentary playing at the Tribeca Film Festival, Sons of Perdition. The film follows three boys who escaped from a polygamist sect led by Warren S. Jeffs, the self-proclaimed prophet of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, which broke away from the mainstream Mormon church about a century ago.

title: Facebook Stirs Privacy Concerns Again
description: Last week, Facebooks move to provide Instant Personalization on partner Web sites stirred privacy concerns once again. But another related change is also being received poorly by some users.

title: Travels With Gordon
description: It can be easy to forget, in all the excitement over the current election, that Britain is a small country that does things in a small way. Its election season is a paltry four weeks long, though it can sometimes stretch to six. The two main parties typically spend about 18 million pounds (not much more than $27 million) apiece on a national campaign (Labour, which has had trouble raising money this past year, is likely to spend considerably less this time around).

title: The Golden Years: Feisty, Fit and Flirty
description: Its not true that there are no old people on television, but they mostly stand out in ads that veer between extremes. The elderly are either vernally lithe, active and amorous (Cialis) or feeble home-care patients dependent on emergency alert systems and Exelon, an Alzheimers patch, to stave off undignified and agonizing deaths.

title: On Patrol With the Reef Ranger
description: Gilbert Martnez has his work cut out for him. A reef ranger for the Belize Department of Fisheries, he spends his days patrolling a 87,000-acre Marine Protected Area called Glovers Reef, an azure paradise of an atoll about 28 miles from the countrys mainland. I met him while reporting for an article in Tuesdays Science Times about a reef-monitoring project in the atoll that is sponsored by the Bronx-based Wildlife Conservation Society.

title: Malibu Wines
description: If anybody said this was Malibu, youd say they were crazy, says Richard Hirsh, the millionaire clothier-turned-vintner standing in the vineyards of his Cielo Farms estate.

title: Critics Notebook: New Orleans Dining
description: Four of the restaurants that embody the city and its post-Katrina comeback.

title: A Familiar Voice in Unfamiliar Territory
description: The Garminfone, an Android phone with the full Garmin GPS features, will sound familiar to lots of people. Not because of Garmins nearly forgotten Nuviphone, but because of a new feature called Garmin Voice Studio, which allows you to replace the voice that gives you directions with that of anyone who will agree to be recorded.

title: Met Opera Announces Principal Guest Conductor
description: The Metropolitan Opera, hobbled by the ailments to its maestro, James Levine, has moved to bolster its musical direction by appointing a principal guest conductor  only the second in its recent history.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: When we last left Sergei Supinsky of Agence France-Presse at the Ukrainian Parliament in early March, he was recording the departure of Yulia V. Tymoshenko from the chamber after a no-confidence vote removed her as prime minister. At the time, the scene seemed to reflect the best peaceful transition school of legislative behavior. On Tuesday, however, the scene was strikingly different. Mr. Supinsky (and Efrem Lukatsky and Genia Savilov) depicted members of parliament throwing punches, igniting smoke bombs, tossing eggs and abandoning decorum completely. Those of us who live in New York State could take momentary comfort.

title: Want to Make an Impact? Join Jordan
description: Dear LeBron:

title: Senators Ask Facebook for Privacy Fixes
description: 4:09 p.m. | Updated  Added a report from the senators meeting with Facebook executives.

title: The Met Anoints a Guest Conductor
description: The Metropolitan Opera, hobbled by the ailments of its maestro, James Levine, has moved to bolster its musical direction by appointing a principal guest conductor, only the second in its recent history.

title: Few, but Tanatalizing, Hints of Uniteds Deal Talks
description: During United Airlines first-quarter earnings call on Tuesday, executives stayed tight-lipped about the companys merger talks with Continental Airlines. (DealBook broke the news that the talks had hit a snag over the mechanics of a potential transaction.)

title: Study Questions Number of Cyclists in New York
description: The Bloomberg administration has worked tirelessly to turn bicycling into a mainstream mode of getting around New York, creating more than 200 miles of bicycle-only lanes and placing protected bike paths on major thoroughfares like Broadway and Ninth Avenue.

title: The Cohesion Crisis
description: Enough with the PIIGS, a totally unhelpful acronym. What were really seeing now is a crisis of the cohesion countries  the countries that entered the EU relatively poor, and for a time received substantial aid in the form of cohesion funds. (In Eurospeak, its important to know the difference between cohesion and convergence: cohesion means convergence in per capita GDP, while convergence means getting inflation rates in line so that monetary cohesion is possible. Get it?)

title: Titans of Tangled Finances Kick Up Their Heels Again
description: In Lucy Prebbles Enron, the flashy but labored economics lesson that opened on Tuesday night at the Broadhurst Theater, money doesnt just talk. It sings. It dances. It puts on funny animal costumes. And of course it blows bubbles.

title: Properties of $275,000
description: Properties in Pittsburgh, Cochiti Lake, N.M., and Baton Rouge, La.

title: A Bank Tax as Insurance for Us All
description: Washington

title: What You Get for $275,000
description: PITTSBURGH

title: On a Hillside in Macao
description: A five-bedroom three-bath apartment in Macao is on the market for $1.42 million.

title: Vegas for Budget Betters
description: New hotels in Las Vegas tend to target high rollers. But in these recessionary times, a string of old motels that are being rehabbed and rebranded are making a splash.

title: A Change for American Nmirovsky Translation
description: The English translation of The Life of Irne Nmirovsky, by Olivier Philipponnat and Patrick Lienhardt, which arrives in bookstores next month is slightly different from the English translation of the biography that appeared in Britain.

title: Waiting on a Derby Moment
description: In a bucket list moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont Stakes. She hasnt stopped going to the races since  when she isnt taking on a wildfire, hurricane or volcano as the nations leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

title: In Budapest, a View of 'O Street'
description: Erik D'Amato and Janet Haven bought their 1,600-square-foot apartment in Budapest for around $100,000 in 2001.

title: In Budapest, Uncovering Walled-Over History
description: BUDAPEST  The walled-over doorframe behind Erik DAmato and Janet Havens bed  paired with another one at the other end of the apartment  hints that their home, as large as it might appear, must have originally been quite a bit bigger.

title: House Hunting in ... China
description: A FIVE-BEDROOM THREE-BATH APARTMENT IN MACAO

title: Conan OBrien Will Appear on 60 Minutes on Sunday
description: Conan OBrien will break his post-NBC silence Sunday night when he gives his first interview about his departure from The Tonight Show to CBSs 60 Minutes.

title: A Pointillist Tour, Revolution to Riots
description: If youd like a status update on Britains tangled feelings about its neighbor France, you could do worse than study The Sunday Times of Londons current hardcover nonfiction best-seller list. At No. 9 is the book in front of us now: the British historian Graham Robbs admiring Parisians: An Adventure History of Paris. More beloved by English readers, though, at No. 4, is a book by Stephen Clarke with this impish title: 1000 Years of Annoying the French. Garon, theres some snark in my soup.

title: Paterson Raises the Prospect of Furloughs
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson said on Tuesday that he would seek legislative approval to begin furloughing state workers one day per week, saying that the refusal by their unions to reopen their contracts or accept other concessions on pay and benefits amid New Yorks fiscal crisis left him little choice.

title: Whos Afraid of a Bank Tax?
description: You wont be surprised to learn that Wall Street doesnt like the idea of a bank tax. Wall Street lobbyists argue that a tax on banks  meant to discourage risky investments and cover the costs of financial crises  will keep banks from being able to lend to worthy borrowers. Thats not theoretically impossible, but it doesnt seem very likely. The taxes under discussion would have a low rate. Its also worth remembering that Wall Streets lobbyists often claim that they are just looking out for the interests of borrowers.

title: Summers Heat Breeds Love, Loathing and Darwinian Competition
description: Man will only become better when you make him see what he is like, Anton Chekhov wrote in one of his notebooks. Such a man emerges in Anton Chekhovs The Duel, a very satisfying and tonally precise English-language adaptation of an 1891 Chekhov novella. Set in a seaside town in the Caucasus, where Europe meets Asia against stark mountain ranges and the blue of the sky as it melts into the darker sea, the story turns on a handful of Russians during a sweltering summer. Amid this small world, there are moments of comedy, dark sentiments, invocations of Tolstoy and a generous attitude toward human frailties.

title: Henry Blanco, Cecil Fielder and Feats of Base Stealing
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.This past Saturday, Henry Blanco stole second base in the fifth inning for his first stolen base since 2001. It had been 522 games, 1,593 at-bats, 359 hits and 120 walks since he had stolen a base.

title: This Bucolic Midwestern Town Is Friendly. Or Is It?
description: You should know where you stand on Happy Town just a few minutes into the pilot on Wednesday night. Thats when Tommy Conroy (Geoff Stults) gives his young daughter a speech pooh-poohing his wifes notion of moving to California from their middle-American paradise in Minnesota.

title: Los Angeles Times Adds Paid Links in Articles
description: The Los Angeles Times, which has pushed ad-edit boundaries with a number of print advertisements, began adding sponsored links within some online articles today.

title: Republicans Reject Finance Bill Again, and Offer a Plan of Their Own
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans thwarted the Democrats efforts to overhaul financial regulation for a second day on Tuesday and floated an alternative proposal with some crucial differences in the regulation of consumer lending.

title: Hints a Murder Suspect Had More Targets
description: On a sleepy Connecticut cul-de-sac on Monday morning, the police said a man drove up in a red minivan, armed with three handguns, 1,000 rounds of ammunition, Google maps and dossiers on three former colleagues  all of whom were involved in his dismissal from a Brooklyn hospital.

title: A Hitchcock Dialogue, From Screen to Stage and Back
description: The first sign of changing times may have been when scenes started becoming shorter. Then projections, video and animation started flashing across stage walls, and live theater became less so. That the movies were radically altering the way plays are made was once a cause of concern. Now its just a fact, and in the experimental world, where the most sophisticated multimedia is done, it is fully embraced.

title: Tim Burton a Hit at Moma
description: Evidently there are a lot of people in New York who identify with the forlorn Edward Scissorhands (and possibly with the murderous Sweeney Todd, too). The Museum of Modern Art said on Tuesday that its retrospective on Tim Burton, the filmmaker of Alice in Wonderland and others, drew the third-highest attendance of any exhibition in the museums history. During the run, which opened on Nov. 22 and closed on Monday, 810,500 visitors came to see artifacts like Mr. Burtons early illustrations and a prop of Sarah Jessica Parkers severed head from his movie Mars Attacks! Mr. Burton is now in the rarefied company of Picasso, whose 1980 retrospective at MoMA remains the museums all-time most popular (with 976,800 visitors), and Matisse, whose 1992 retrospective remains runner-up (with 940,000). Above, one work from the exhibition.

title: M.I.A. Video Pulled From Youtube
description: Within a day of its widely discussed debut on the Web, the video for M.I.A.s song Born Free has, in some instances, been removed from YouTube and in others labeled with an age restriction. The video, made for the first single of M.I.A.s coming album and directed by Romain Gavras, the son of Costa-Gavras, depicts an unspecified military force, with some members wearing American flags on their uniforms, rounding up redheaded men from an apartment complex and taking them to a desert to be tortured and executed. In its community guidelines, YouTube says videos can be taken down from the site for violations like excessive violence, and can be flagged if users believe the videos violate these guidelines. YouTube declined to say if any versions of the M.I.A. video were taken down due to its violent content. The video is also posted on M.I.A.s Web site, miauk.com.

title: Title Match Remains Tied After Game 3 Is Drawn
A Soap Opera Sells Its Scenery
description: Soap opera fans will have a chance to own pieces of broadcasting history when the props of a long-lived and recently canceled television serial are sold at an auction on Saturday. The catch is that Procter & Gamble wont give permission for the name of the soap opera to be used in the promotion of the auction. But heres some guidance: the show was the longest-running scripted program in broadcasting history before CBS ran its final episode in September. Castners Auction & Appraisal Service will sell hundreds of items from  uh, that show  on Saturday at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The inventory is being sold by Props NYC, which is owned by Nicole Stiegelbauer. Her familys scenery company, Stiegelbauer Associates, built sets for shows like As the World Turns and a certain other soap opera before the shows were canceled. When you clean out a soundstage for a show thats been in existence for 20, 30, 40 years, its levels upon levels of history that just all of a sudden unravel, Ms. Stiegelbauer said. Youre like, What does one do? In this case the items will be gathered by the truckload at Building 10 at the Brooklyn Navy Yard; a preview will begin at 9 a.m. on Saturday with the sale starting at 11 a.m.

title: Squeakquel Breeds a Chipmunks Lawsuit
description: In more innocent days, when Alvin and the Chipmunks needed an authority figure to get something done, they turned to a witch doctor. Now they go to their lawyers. The Hollywood Reporter said that the production company behind the Chipmunk characters and a relative of their creator are suing 20th Century Fox, saying that studio owes them half of the profits from last years hit film Alvin & the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel. The lawsuit was filed in United States District Court in Los Angeles by Bagdasarian Productions and the writer Janice Karman, whose father-in-law, Ross Bagdasarian Sr., created the Chipmunks and originally provided the voice of their human caretaker, David Seville. The suit says Ms. Karman wrote a script for an Alvin & the Chipmunks sequel after the original 2007 film grossed more than $361 million worldwide, and though she never reached a deal with Fox on her compensation, she provided additional revisions after two other writers were hired to polish what Ms. Karman says was her draft. The plaintiffs say they are co-owners of the script to the Squeakquel, which grossed more than $442 million worldwide, and that Fox also breached a producers agreement. In a statement to The Hollywood Reporter, Fox said the claims were completely without merit.

title: Art and Auction | Wines at the Whitney
description: On Wednesday, the worlds of wine collectors and art collectors will merge at the Whitney. There, they will bid on limited-edition bottles of 2007 Ornellaia with labels designed by Ghada Amer and Reza Farkhondeh to benefit the museum. The lot of 18 double-magnums with the phrase Happily*Ever*After spelled out among them is pretty, but the obvious keepers are the imperial (six-liter) bottles whose labels feature hand embroidery, and the salmanazar (nine-liter) bottle with its one-of-a-kind painted and embroidered canvas label signed by the artists. The question is: drink it or frame it?

title: Dancing Dominates
description: Dancing With the Stars dominated another Monday in the ratings as ABC earned its sixth consecutive victory on the night as the most-watched network. According to Nielsens estimates, 20.2 million viewers tuned in to a 90-minute installment of that dancing reality show. Fox ranked runner-up on the night with solid ratings for House at 8 (10.6 million) and 24 at 9 (9.2 million), while CBS placed third with a lineup of mostly all reruns. NBC was fourth. On Sunday night, the History Channel posted its best ratings ever as part one of its miniseries America: The Story of Us attracted 5.7 million viewers.

title: Vietnamese Immigrants Carry on a Cajun Food Tradition
description: ATLANTA

title: In Arkansas, They Brake for the Woodpeckers
description: Generally speaking, bird-watching is a pastime that is extremely interesting to a few people and not at all interesting to anyone else. But Scott Crocker has turned a bird-watching tale into a multilayered story that will fascinate practically everybody in Ghost Bird, a witty, wistful documentary about the supposed rediscovery in Arkansas of the ivory-billed woodpecker, a bird thought to have been extinct for decades.

title: Kennedy Tribute Draws Star Narrators
description: With more than 240 credits among the three of them (but surprisingly only three Academy Awards), it was merely a matter of time before Robert De Niro, Morgan Freeman and Ed Harris found the right project to appear in together. In this case it is the debut performance of the multimedia work The Dream Lives On: A Portrait of the Kennedy Brothers, which will take place as part of the Boston Pops 125th anniversary season, the orchestra said. The work, which will have its premiere on May 18 at Symphony Hall in Boston, will feature the actors narrating as three of the Kennedy siblings: Mr. De Niro as John F. Kennedy, Mr. Harris as Robert F. Kennedy and Mr. Freeman as Edward M. Kennedy. The work, composed by Peter Boyer with lyrics by Lynn Ahrens, will receive additional performances May 19 through 22 and July 3 and 4. It will also be performed on July 18 at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., with Alec Baldwin narrating, and on Aug. 1 at the Hyannis Village Green in Hyannis, Mass., where it will be narrated by Chris Cooper.

title: Voters Spar With David Cameron
description: She may not end up becoming as famous as Joe the Plumber, but Chloe Green, a 19-year-old student who engaged in an impromptu televised debate with David Cameron, the leader of Britains Conservative Party, on Monday has earned herself the postmodern equivalent of 15 minutes of fame  her name is now a hash tag on Twitter.

title: A Time to Play, in a Flashback to the 70s Art World
description: Participatory art came to the Museum of Modern Art long before Marina Abramovic began her daylong vigils seated opposite one random museum visitor at a time. It arrived at least as early as 1970, with the interactive, sewn-canvas sculptures of a young German artist named Franz Erhard Walther. These works were included in the museums Spaces exhibition, a show of installations by five artists and one collective that was itself among the first of its kind.

title: NBC Is Upfront About Returning to a Traditional Upfront
description: After two years of experimenting with different ways to woo advertisers and agencies ahead of the coming fall TV season, NBC is reassuring Madison Avenue that it is returning to the tried-and-true rituals of the so-called upfront week.

title: In New Orleans, the Taste of a Comeback
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: A Program Served With a Side of Wings
description: Dino Anagnost, the music director of the Little Orchestra Society, had some big programming ideas for his ensembles concert at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening. He had a theme and a title, two titles actually, yoked together: Music Takes Flight  Airborne Symphonies. He had plenty of music to choose from, particularly once he decided to look beyond the classical orchestral canon and include pieces like Robert Crawfords U.S. Air Force  you remember it: Off we go, into the wild blue yonder  and Bill Contis theme for  The Right Stuff.

title: Epistemic Closure? Those Are Fighting Words
description: It is hard to believe that a phrase as dry as epistemic closure could get anyone excited, but the term has sparked a heated argument among conservatives in recent weeks about their movements intellectual health.

title: Sleep: Loss
description: I used to think that the only thing worse than having insomnia is having insomnia next to someone who falls fast asleep and stays soundlessly so till morning.

title: Can Gizmodo Win the iPhone Legal Battle?
description: As we move into the second week of the iPhone-left-in-the-bar saga, the plot is moving from a technology news story to a legal one  and entering a cul-de-sac of speculation.

title: Donatella Arpaia Is Putting Chefs Whites Over Her Prada
description: CLICKETY-CLACK. Here was Donatella, coming through, charging into her new $2.5-million restaurant construction site. Donatella, nervelessly pushing past the yellow caution tape to traverse the splintery floor in nude-patent-leather four-inch Louboutins. Donatella, in short-short Prada silk. Donatella, pointing. Donatella, dishing. Donatella, certamente!

title: Republicans Offer Alternative Financial Overhaul
description: Senate Republicans have put forward an alternative proposal to the Democratic bill to overhaul the nations financial regulations. A review of the 20-page summary of the proposal shows substantial differences from the Democratic measure, which has the support of the Obama administration.

title: Will DreamWorks Animation Abandon Paramount?
description: Is DreamWorks Animation getting ready to drop Paramount as its distributor? Wall Street analysts have been chattering about the possibility, but Jeffrey Katzenberg, chief executive of the animation studio, poured cold water on the idea in a quarterly conference call on Tuesday.

title: A Moment in Time: Strasburg at Class AA
description: READING, Pa.  A giant yellow duck cavorts around the field at First Energy Stadium right now, and a few hundred school children are clustered along the left-field line. Two men wearing WaWa Fan-Cam sweatshirts are scanning the stands behind the plate. There are picnic tables beyond the outfield wall, but no stands, just a vista of rolling green hills.

title: Village Tart and the Spot Dessert Bar
description: GIVE Pichet Ong credit for his faith in dessert.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Ros Roundup

title: French-Style Fresh Cheese From Vermont
description: This French-style fresh cheese from Vermont is a little like fromage blanc, only richer. Originally from the Loire Valley, La Faisselle is made from fresh curds hand-ladled into molds that are perforated so extra whey can drain out. But its made from whole milk. Place it on a plate with some of the strawberries that are bound to hit the market soon and you have dessert.

title: Striking Oil With Squash Seeds
description: Greg Woodworth and Kelly Coughlin were selling cookies in Geneva, N.Y. Peter Martin was a farmer processing butternut squash for supermarkets, with seeds to spare. Now, the three are producing Stony Brook butternut squash oil  golden and nutty, tasting slightly of sesame. They also have a delicata squash oil the color of raspberries, with a more floral flavor.

title: Off the Menu
description: Openings:

title: Argentina Opens the Tap for Malbec
description: FOR the last few years the wine business has been riddled with dire warnings and disastrous portents. In the United States and around the world, producers have struggled with the bad economy and the sluggish market. One slender segment, seemingly alone, has not only weathered the storm but also prospered: malbec from Argentina.

title: Il Cantuccio Bakery Settles in Greenwich Village
description: Simone Bertini (above left), Lorenzo Palombo (above right) and Camilla Bottari, bakers from Prato, not far from Florence, Italy, found a space in Greenwich Village for Il Cantuccio, an American edition of their Tuscan bakery cafe. They renovated, but a fire last fall forced them to start again. They are finally open.

title: A Fresh Batch of Spices for True Indian Flavors
description: I ENJOY cooking Indian food, though I never prepare it as often as I think I will. Not that it stops me from shopping for ingredients. When I make my annual pilgrimage to Kalustyans, the hub of international spices on Lexington Avenue near 28th Street, I tend to stockpile, ending up with so much Imperial Hot Curry Powder that by the time I get around to using it three years later, I could coat chicken nuggets with it and toddlers wouldnt blink an eye.

title: Stale-Bread Pizza
description: Adapted from Donatella Arpaia

title: Getting the Big Picture From Phone Photos
description: The great thing about the phone camera is that it is almost always there when you need it.

title: Republicans Block Bill Again, and Offer Their Plan
description: While most of Wall Street was focused on the Senate smackdown of Goldman Sachs on Tuesday, lawmakers in Washington continued their partisan wrangling over the financial regulatory bill.

title: The Mark Restaurant by Jean-Georges
description: ONE of Jean-Georges Vongerichtens newest ventures is a tangle of given names called the Mark Restaurant by Jean-Georges, in the Mark Hotel on East 77th Street. It lies behind a small bar filled with low-slung pony-skin chairs. Older men unsure of how theyre going to get out of them sit there, pondering the issue over vodka as cubs and cougars banter and text. Dinner seems unlikely.

title: On the Mark
Military Disputes Taliban on Korangal Valley Outpost
description: KABULLocal people, some of them armed, have taken over the Korangal outpost, which was recently abandoned by the American military, according to residents of the area and Afghan officials. However, there is no indication that the Taliban are using the post as a fighting position despite boasts made on a satellite television channel.

title: Do C.D.O.s Have Social Value?
Senate Panel Will Get Some Ft. Hood Files
description: The Obama administration will allow a Senate panel to review the personnel file of the Army psychiatrist accused in the shooting that left 13 people dead at Fort Hood in Texas last November.

title: E.P.A. Makes Its Case on Climate Change
description: Polls show that tackling climate change is a low priority for the American public. Indeed, a Yale poll found that only 12 percent of Americans were very worried about global warming.

title: Top Chechen Ordered Abduction, Austria Says
description: Chechnyas president, Ramzan A. Kadyrov, ordered the kidnapping of a Chechen whistle-blower in Vienna last year, in which the man was fatally shot, Austrias counterterrorism department concluded after a yearlong investigation. The nations public prosecutors office released the news on Tuesday.

title: A Little Danish Mermaid Comes Up for Air in China
description: COPENHAGEN  Some call it mermaid diplomacy; others, tongue in cheek, speak darkly of illicit trafficking in young women.

title: Democrats Use Goldman to Push Bank Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  Politicians like nothing more than a convenient foil, and Democrats locked in a stubborn impasse with Republicans over new rules to govern Wall Street believe they have found a gold-plated one in Goldman Sachs.

title: Controlled Burn Considered for Gulf Oil Spill
description: With a vast oil slick now within only 20 miles of the ecologically fragile Louisiana coastline, Coast Guard officials said they were considering a controlled burn of the petroleum on the surface of the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Report Details Torture at Secret Baghdad Prison
description: BAGHDAD  The torture of Iraqi detainees at a secret prison in Baghdad was far more systematic and brutal than initially reported, Human Rights Watch reported on Tuesday.

title: Russian Adoptees Get a Respite
description: Hundreds of adopted children, most of them Russian, travel to northwest Montana to find healing on Joyce Sterkel's Ranch for Kids.

title: Sweep by Mets Puts Them in First Place
description: In the first game of a successful doubleheader Tuesday against the Los Angeles Dodgers, Johan Santana was what he usually has been: a determined, focused competitor who overcame adversity.

title: A Frenzied Pace for Lawyer Behind Vatican Suits
description: ST. PAUL  Jeffrey R. Anderson, the lawyer whose pursuit of the Roman Catholic Church has been perhaps the loudest, is the center of his own tornado. As employees race in and out of his ornate offices, Mr. Anderson is planning a news conference in Los Angeles about an abusive priest, answering calls from the family of a victim of another from Florida, and preparing a lawsuit in Milwaukee naming the Vatican and the pope as defendants. And this is only a Monday.

title: A Hip-Hop Contest to Promote a Brand
description: MAGNUM, the Trojan subbrand of large condoms, has climbed steadily from a 4.6 percent share of the condom market in 2001 to an 18.8 percent share today, according to the SymphonyIRI Group, a research firm whose data does not include Wal-Mart. What may strike some on Madison Avenue as more remarkable than that growth, however, is that although Trojan has been widely advertised, parent company Church & Dwight has never advertised Magnum specifically.

title: Gamble Sours for Many Kentucky Horse Breeders
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  The for-sale signs on horse farms are as common as the bluegrass and the limestone fences here, and breeders have grown accustomed to sending horses through the auction ring and feeling fortunate when they fetch half of their asking price  or anything at all. The run-up to the Kentucky Derby is normally an exciting time for lawyers playing matchmaker between deep-pocketed clients and owners of cant-miss stallion prospects.

title: Live-Blogging the Senate Hearing on Goldman
description: Brendan Smialowski for The New York Times Lloyd. C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, looks through hundreds of pages of Senate exhibits.

title: New York Citys Inspection Scandal
description: New Yorkers are rightly alarmed at the ease with which an inspector who was licensed to test buildings and construction sites for lead or asbestos risks got away with filing hundreds of false reports for at least a decade. The Bloomberg administration says reforms that were already in progress when the deception was uncovered will make it less likely to happen in the future.

title: Europeans Fear Greek Debt Crisis Will Spread
description: As Greece inches closer to the brink of financial collapse, fear that the debt crisis will spread is engulfing Europe.

title: Deep Thoughts Before Armageddon
description: Beginning any moment now, youll see a month-long trickle of news articles, op-eds and blog posts about the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty review conference, which gets underway in New York City this Monday and lasts through May 28. Since the fate of the world could hinge on stemming the spread of nuclear weapons, and this goal could in turn hinge on strengthening the treaty at these every-five-years review conferences, you may feel you should read much of this coverage. And your likely failure to do so may cause guilt feelings.

title: Whats More Compromising Than Money?
description: The Supreme Court abdicated its responsibility to address fundamental questions of ethics and fairness when it declined to review the case of Charles Dean Hood, an inmate on death row in Texas.

title: Wall Street Casino
description: Congressional Republicans have concluded that screaming foul about the banking bailout and blocking financial reform is a clever strategy for the fall elections.

title: Goldman Sachs Faces Questions on Sale of Investments
description: Goldman Sachs officials met with confrontation and blunt questioning as senators from both parties challenged them over their aggressive marketing of mortgage investments at a time when the housing market was already starting to falter.

title: For Some on Wall St., the Spectacle on TV Was Background Noise
description: Maybe it was the deepening debt crisis in Europe. Maybe it was the rare treat of a Mets-Dodgers doubleheader starting just before happy hour. Or maybe it was the lack of a Holy cow moment.

title: Celebrating U.S. Future in Space, Hopefully
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  With rock music blaring, fifth graders count down from 10-9-8 to the rocket boosters firing up, and blasting the computer-generated astronauts toward space.

title: Failure Is Not an Option
description: China is having a good week in America. Yes it is. Id even suggest that there is some high-fiving going on in Beijing. I mean, wouldnt you if you saw Americas Democratic and Republican leaders conspiring to ensure that America cedes the next great global industry  E.T., energy technology  to China?

title: Getting Out
description: Nine Angus bulls are moving down the fence line in a pasture along Clear Creek, north central Wyoming. I can see only their backs, black and as powerfully angled as the mounded coal in the hopper cars running north to Montana. There is a man on horseback ahead of the bulls and another behind them. They turn the bulls, out onto the asphalt just at the highway crossroads.

title: University of Washington President Named to Run N.C.A.A.
description: Mark A. Emmert, the president of the University of Washington, was named the president of the N.C.A.A. on Tuesday, concluding a seven-month search for the successor to Myles Brand, who died last September of pancreatic cancer.

title: Laura Bush Opens Up About Crash
description: Laura Bush has finally opened up publicly about the mysterious car accident she had when she was 17, a crash that claimed the life of a high school friend on a dark country road in Midland, Tex.

title: Korean Is First Woman to Scale 14 Highest Peaks
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Climbing on all fours after 13 grueling hours, a diminutive South Korean woman, Oh Eun-sun, reached the summit of one of the Himalayan giants on Tuesday to lay claim to being the first woman to scale the worlds 14 highest mountains.

title: Power From Trash ...
description: ITS been 25 years since the New York City Board of Estimate, under Mayor Edward Kochs leadership, approved a plan to reduce the need for putting municipal garbage in landfills by developing facilities to burn it to create energy. At the same time, the city took the first steps toward creating a recycling program. Since then, disposal costs have risen faster than inflation, and the need to find better methods of getting rid of wastes is even greater.

title: European Countries Are Cautioned to Be Even-Handed in Assisting Airlines
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union warned governments on Tuesday against lavishing emergency aid on airlines to make up for losses from disruptions caused by the volcano eruption in Iceland.

title: Obama Sticks to a Deadline in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama approved a plan to withdraw combat forces from Iraq this summer, it was based on the assumption that a newly elected government would be in place by the time Americans headed home. Fourteen months later, that assumption is exploding but the plan remains the same.

title: How Fans Can Do the Wave on the Way to the Ballgame
description: In recent years, the Mets have urged fans to take the train to games to avoid the traffic jams and parking bottlenecks. Now, fans can avoid both and take a boat instead.

title: Immigration Issue Poses a Complex Test for 2 Parties
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain of Arizona took to the Senate floor the other day to embrace a tough new Arizona law giving the police the authority to detain people they suspect are illegal immigrants. Mr. McCain, long an outspoken champion of giving illegal immigrants a path to citizenship, is facing a primary challenge this summer from a conservative who backs tough immigration measures.

title: Olive Oil and Snake Oil
description: WASHINGTON

title: ... And Sewage, Too
description: Leeds, England

title: Talented Filly Had No Plans for Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Much has been made about the filly Devil May Cares running on Saturday in the 136th Kentucky Derby, but perhaps the reason she will be competing against the boys is that she would be running for second place in the Kentucky Oaks.
