title: Sharks Earn Chance to Fail Once Again
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  George Bernard Shaw never played professional hockey. But his quotation about his reputation growing with every failure could very well apply to the San Jose Sharks, a team renowned for its superb regular seasons and disastrous early playoff exits.

title: E.U. Proposes Measures to Help Airlines After Ash
description: The European Union warned governments against lavishing aid on airlines but proposed measures to help after a week-long shutdown of travel. Read more.

title: Lidge Says Hes Ready, and Praises Strasburg
description: READING, Pa.  Brad Lidge had been on the mound for the final out of the World Series, and Stephen Strasburg has never thrown a pitch in the major leagues. Yet when Lidge walked into a packed conference room down the right field line at FirstEnergy Stadium on Tuesday, he smiled and said, Strasburg mustve thrown tonight.

title: Citing Obesity of Children, County Bans Fast-Food Toys
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It was not a happy day for the Happy Meal.

title: Bankers Remain Fans of E-Mail
description: Embarrassing e-mail messages arent new to Wall Street. After the dot-com bubble popped, star technology analysts were condemned for sending messages mocking the same stocks they had urged investors to buy.

title: Nimbi
description: Im a little teapot,Short and stout

title: The Spectrum Still Has a Hold
description: PHILADELPHIA  Reverently bathed in spotlights, its concrete walkways and stair steps kept tidy, its prim interior virtually untouched, the Spectrum looks as if it could reopen tomorrow, even though it played host to its last event six months ago and its future is doomed.

title: A Surprise on Wall Street: Luxury Rentals May Benefit From Stabilization
description: Ben Rosen, a 23-year-old private equity analyst, never had second thoughts about moving into 37 Wall Street, a luxury Beaux-Arts building that houses a Tiffany store and sits among the countrys halls of financial might. It had all the amenities any titan in training might want.

title: Despair Grows on Devastated Street in Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  More than 100 long days after the earthquake, Ginette Lemazor, her husband and their impish 5-year-old boy are still living in a filthy mechanics lot on Avenue Poupelard.

title: On the Road With Gordon Brown
description: As Prime Minister Gordon Brown finished a day of campaigning on Monday, the man who might not lead Britain for much longer dismissed the alarming reports about his prospects as merely agitation by the news media.

title: Here to Aid His Family, Left to Die on the Street
description: He persuaded his father to bless his departure from their poor village in the mountains of Guatemala by laying out a plan. He would go to New York, work hard and save enough money to buy his family a bigger piece of land.

title: Oil Rig Blast Complicates Push for Energy and Climate Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The loss of life and the looming ecological catastrophe from the oil rig explosion in the Gulf of Mexico have piled political complications onto the push for energy and climate change legislation here, officials and interest groups say.

title: Deutsches Profit Surges, but Forecasts Are Cautious
description: FRANKFURT  Deutsche Bank, the largest German bank, said on Tuesday that its profit rose by a third in the first quarter of 2010, well above expectations, driven by a revival in investment banking.

title: Agency Owes Millions to City, an Audit Finds
description: The agency responsible for economic development under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has failed to turn over to the city more than $125 million in payments, taxes and fees, according to an audit conducted by the city comptroller to be released on Wednesday.

title: Allen Swift, Voice Actor for Radio and TV, Dies at 86
description: Allen Swift, the voice of Mighty Mouse, Dinky Duck and, for a brief period, Howdy Doody, not to mention an Eveready battery, a toilet plunger for Drano, Vitas Beloved Herring Maven and other characters both human and inanimate in more than 30,000 television and radio commercials, died on April 18 at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: A Law Facing a Tough Road Through the Courts
description: Can Arizonas controversial new immigration law  allowing the police to stop people and demand proof of citizenship  pass constitutional muster?

title: Museum Board Member Caught in Russian Intrigue
description: Since joining the board of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation three years ago, Janna Bullock, a Russian-born real estate developer, has been a frequent and glamorous presence on the circuit of art fairs, galas and biennials. She has sponsored art exhibitions in Venice and Miami, socialized with artists and collectors and even taken a motorcycle trip from St. Petersburg to Moscow with the actors Dennis Hopper and Jeremy Irons and Thomas Krens, the former Guggenheim director.

title: Elizabeth Post of the Etiquette Family Dies at 89
description: Elizabeth L. Post, who succeeded her grandmother-in-law, Emily Post, as the doyenne of etiquette in repeated editions of Emilys celebrated advice book, died Saturday in Naples, Fla.

title: U.S. Begins Inquiry on Spy Network in Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has opened an inquiry into whether a top Defense Department official violated Pentagon rules by setting up a network of private contractors to gather intelligence in Pakistan and Afghanistan.

title: Paying for the Sins of the Fathers, and of Others, Too
description: Should it be possible to sue the city of New York for sexual abuse by public school teachers that happened decades ago? How about doctors or hospital attendants? Police officers? Welfare workers? Playground attendants?

title: Fleeting Glimpses of a Rising Star and His Fastball
description: READING, Pa.

title: Yanks Turn the Capital a Bit More Bipartisan
description: BALTIMORE  For devoted Yankees fans like the Supreme Court Justices Sonia Sotomayor and Antonin Scalia, posing for photographs Tuesday with the World Series championship trophy must have been a thrill. For a devoted Red Sox fan like Justice Stephen Breyer, seeing the trophy might have been agonizing.

title: Mavericks Force Game 6; Celtics and Cavaliers Clinch
description: DALLAS  The first member of the Dallas Mavericks to break a sweat Tuesday night was the owner. Mark Cuban was climbing virtual stairs and breathlessly batting away doubts about his teams flagging playoff fortunes.

title: Sudans Future Is Now, U.S. Envoy Says
description: WASHINGTON  A day after Sudans leader coasted to victory in a fraud-tainted election, a senior Obama administration official defended the vote, and said the United States should turn its attention to getting southern Sudan ready for its likely future as an independent state.

title: Authorities Vow to Close Mines Found to Be Unsafe
description: WASHINGTON  Federal regulators told Congress on Tuesday that they would become more aggressive in enforcing mine safety laws, vowing to close mines with repeated safety violations and shut down sections of mines when inspectors find serious violations.

title: Study Finds Young Hispanics Face Obstacles to Integration
description: A snapshot of Hispanic youngsters  the fastest-growing group in the United States by age and ethnicity  concludes that the obstacles and inequalities they face today may hinder the broader integration of Latinos into U.S. society if left unattended.

title: Pace of Planning for East Jerusalem Projects Slows
description: JERUSALEM  After a recent spike in Israeli-American tensions over Israeli building plans for Jewish housing in contested East Jerusalem, there appears to have been a lull in the planning process.

title: Russian Plan to Bolster Security Agency Evokes K.G.B.s Powers
description: MOSCOW  Russian lawmakers are considering extending new powers to the F.S.B., the successor to the Soviet-era K.G.B., allowing its officers to summon citizens and issue verbal or written warnings that their activities are unacceptable and leading toward a crime, even if no violation has occurred.

title: Arthur Winograd, Hartford Symphony Music Director, Dies at 90
description: Arthur Winograd, the founding cellist of the Juilliard String Quartet and later the longtime music director of the Hartford Symphony Orchestra, died in Morristown, N.J., on Thursday, his 90th birthday.

title: In Greeting Iowa Voters, Obama Focuses on Finances
description: OTTUMWA, Iowa  President Obama strongly criticized Senate Republicans on Tuesday for blocking proposed legislation to tighten regulation of the financial system, vowing that he would not let this effort fall victim to industry lobbyists who want to kill it.

title: Trailing Disasters: Savings, but at What Price?
description: In the past two months, political demonstrations have gripped the streets of Bangkok. Tens of thousands of supporters of former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra  the so-called red shirts  have shut down parts of the city, forcing cancellation of an Association of Southeast Asian Nations meeting and prompting security responses that have resulted in the deaths of at least two dozen people.

title: Devils Move Paying Off for Team, and Newark
description: NEWARK  An hour before a recent playoff game, Jeff Vanderbeek, chairman of the Devils, was mobbed as he gave away red towels to fans at the train station, a short walk from the teams home, Prudential Center.

title: Corrections
description: A television column on March 19 about Breaking Bad, on AMC, misstated the length of the character Jesses stay at a rehabilitation center. He leaves at the end of the seasons first episode; he is not there for the first few episodes. The error was pointed out in an e-mail message from a reader the day the column appeared; this correction was delayed for research.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: How Bombing Case Helped Shape Career of a Potential Justice
description: WASHINGTON  Days after a huge bomb killed 168 people in Oklahoma City in April 1995, Merrick B. Garland was on the ground even as bodies were still being recovered, examining the crime scene and preparing for an eventual prosecution.

title: Profiting From Low Interest Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: The Goldman Deal and the Housing Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Dorothy Height and an Apology From Barnard
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside the Units Treating War Trauma
description: To the Editor:

title: Found Alive: The Loch Ness Monster of the Northwest Prairie. Alas, It Disappoints
description: HELENA, Mont. Once feared extinct, the giant Palouse earthworm, reputed to grow up to three feet long and smell like lilies, has been found alive.

title: Ex-Official Is Criticized for Misusing State Workers
description: ALBANY  When Lee Kyriacou left a financial-services consulting firm to become the director of a small state agency in 2007, he had certain expectations of his staff that did not go over very well.

title: In New Jersey, a Civics Lesson in the Internet Age
description: It was a silent call to arms: an easy-to-overlook message urging New Jersey students to take a stand against the budget cuts that threaten class sizes and choices as well as after-school activities. But some 18,000 students accepted the invitation posted last month on Facebook, the social media site better known for publicizing parties and sporting events. And on Tuesday many of them  and many others  walked out of class in one of the largest grass-roots demonstrations to hit New Jersey in years.

title: Thomas H. Connell III, Longtime Met Stage Manager, Dies at 67
description: It wasnt so much the extraordinary that kept Thomas H. Connell III on his toes  not the singing horse or the stumbling soldier or the curious incident of the dog,  Falstaff  and the beckoning tree stump. It was the routine things  the fire-breathing dragons, the indoor blizzards, Valhalla collapsing in flames as the Rhine overflows  that night after night were the truest tests of his skill.

title: Just Vazquezs Luck
description: BALTIMORE  The way things are going for Javier Vazquez, this had to happen: A wicked liner off the bat of Nick Markakis zoomed into the Yankees dugout in the fifth inning Tuesday night. Vazquez was quick enough to avoid sustaining a direct hit, but the ball caromed off the back wall and struck him in the side. If it had nailed him on the fly, Vazquez said it really would have stung.

title: Robert Natkin, Abstract Painter, Is Dead at 79
description: Robert Natkin, a painter who rose to prominence in the late 1960s and 1970s with work that blended Abstraction with Post-Impressionist colors, died on April 20 in Danbury, Conn. He was 79 and lived in Redding, Conn.

title: Laura Bush Writes About Fatal Car Crash
description: The Timess Anahad OConnor reports how Laura Bush, in her new autobiography, finally opens up about the car crash she was involved in that took the life of a friend when she was a teenager. A copy of the book, Spoken From the Heart, which is to be released in early May, was obtained by The Times at a book store.

title: Orioles Long Road Eases for One Night Against Yankees
description: BALTIMORE  The Orioles, like every team, were full of optimism and good cheer three weeks ago. If their rotation thrived, their bullpen performed and their lineup produced, they would have a good season. They could finish in fourth place.

title: Two Convicted of Denying Access to Abortion Clinic
description: For the first time in New York City, federal prosecutors have used the Freedom of Access to Clinics Entrances Act to secure a conviction in a case where access was blocked to a clinic that provides abortions.

title: Community Pacts Questioned in the Zoning Process
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suffered an embarrassment last December when the City Council rejected a major developers plan to spend hundreds of millions of dollars transforming an unused armory in the Bronx, the citys poorest borough, into a shopping mall.

title: Laura Bush Writes About Fatal Car Crash
description: The Timess Anahad OConnor reports that Laura Bush, in her new autobiography, finally opens up about the car crash she was involved in that took the life of a friend when she was a teenager. A copy of the book, Spoken From the Heart, which is to be released in early May, was obtained by The Times at a bookstore.

title: Connecticut Quadruplets Will Attend Yale
description: After each received an offer of early acceptance to Yale last fall, the Crouch quadruplets of Danbury, Conn., went on to collect letters of admission this spring from more than a dozen other colleges.

title: Grand Makeover Is Set for Maryland Strip City
description: ROCKVILLE, Md.  Over the last century, Rockville Pike in Montgomery County, Md., has grown, unfettered and unplanned, into a sprawling strip city  a hodge-podge of shopping centers, parking lots and gridlocked traffic that frustrates motorists and discourages pedestrians.

title: Kim to Have Thumb Operation
description: Anthony Kim and his management team will decide soon when to have the detached ligament in his left thumb surgically repaired. Kim, coming off a victory at the Shell Houston Open and a third-place finish at the Masters in his last two outings, said he would have the operation and was prepared to skip major championships to be ready for the Ryder Cup in September.

title: Ex-Brooklyn College Student Admits Conspiring to Help Al Qaeda
description: In a widely watched terrorism case, a former Brooklyn College student admitted in court on Tuesday that he had conspired to provide Al Qaeda with what prosecutors described as military gear.

title: Afghanistan: U.N. Pulls Workers
description: The United Nations withdrew most of its local staff members from Kandahar on Tuesday and instructed its local Afghan employees there to stay home in the coming days because of what it called the deteriorating security situation in the southern city, a spokeswoman said. The United Nations is often a bellwether of the level of insecurity, and the decision forced it to effectively suspend its operations, said Susan Manuel, the organizations spokeswoman in Kabul. We hope it will be temporary, she said. There are about 200 United Nations employees in Kandahar.

title: Margherita, Primavera, Siciliana e Viola
description: Jeannie Oliver-Cretara introduces herself in the fourth installment of Ozier Muhammads series, Sounds From Uncommon Spaces. Her remarks, to Mr. Muhammad, were condensed and edited for brevity and clarity.

title: Egypt: New Trial in Singers Death
description: The retrial of a real estate mogul and former legislator, whose death sentence for the murder of a Lebanese pop diva was thrown out last month by Egypts highest court, opened this week under heavy security. The mogul, Hisham Talaat Moustafa, and his co-defendant, Mohsen al-Sukari, a retired police officer, pleaded not guilty on Monday, state media reported. Mr. Moustafa is accused of paying millions of dollars to Mr. Sukari to stab the 30-year-old singer, Suzanne Tamim, who was found dead in her Dubai apartment in July 2008.

title: First Defendants Trial in 2007 Newark Triple Murder Begins
description: NEWARK  Nearly three years later, this city on Tuesday began to relive one of the most notorious crimes in its recent history, as the first of six defendants went on trial in the execution-style murders of three students in a schoolyard on a summer night.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 27, 2010

title: A Bad Hughes Is Still Pretty Good
description: BALTIMORE  When Phil Hughes struggled in this very ballpark last May, he faced 16 batters and allowed eight of them to score. When Hughes struggled at Camden Yards on Tuesday night, he gave up one run and two hits in five and two-thirds innings.

title: Iran: Opposition Calls for Protests
description: The Iranian opposition leaders Mehdi Karroubi and Mir Hussein Moussavi called Monday for protests on June 12 to observe the anniversary of last years presidential election, which they say was marred by widespread fraud. It was the first public call for protests by the leading opposition figures in months. The two men also deplored the governments economic policies, imprisonment of reformists and what they said was corruption by the vice president. These acts are anti-Islamic, Mr. Moussavi said. He added, I truly dont understand how they will answer to God.

title: Argentina: Pardons Overturned
description: The Supreme Court overturned pardons of a dictatorship-era president and economy minister on Tuesday, paving the way for them to be tried for kidnapping and extortion. Former President Jorge Videla, left, and his economy minister, Jos Martnez de Hoz, are accused of detaining Federico Gutheim, a textile merchant, and his son Miguel for five months in 1976 and 1977 to force them to settle a trade dispute. The court upheld a lower-court ruling that the pardons were unconstitutional.

title: Doctors Raise Questions About St. Vincents Plan
description: New York States decision to pick Lenox Hill Hospital to run the new urgent care center at St. Vincents Hospital was a curious choice, some doctors said on Tuesday, if only because Lenox Hill is on the Upper East Side, while St. Vincents is in Greenwich Village.

title: China Lifts Ban on Visitors Who Are H.I.V. Positive
description: BEIJING  Days before travelers worldwide are to begin arriving for Shanghais world exposition, China has lifted a two-decade ban on travel to the country by people who carry the virus that causes AIDS or who have other sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Brooks: The Goldman Drama
description: Between 1997 and 2006, consumers, lenders and builders created a housing bubble, and pretty much the entire establishment missed it. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and the people who regulate them missed it. The big commercial banks and the people who regulate them missed it. The Federal Reserve missed it, as did the ratings agencies, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the political class in general.

title: How Much Are You Influenced by Advertising?
description: A federal agency is trying to teach young people about how advertising works so they can make better, more informed choices when they shop, according to an article from the Business section. Do you think you or your peers need to learn more about how advertisers persuade? How often do you buy things in response to an ad? Do you think advertising influences you in ways you arent aware of?

title: News Quiz | April 28, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Europeans Fear Greek Debt Crisis Will Spread
description: As Greece inches closer to the brink of financial collapse, fear that the debt crisis will spread is engulfing Europe.

title: Lakers Start Fast and Finish Strong
description: LOS ANGELES  When the Lakers returned home from Oklahoma City in a position they did not expect to be in, a series that was all even, it turned out they were not the only ones in for an attitude adjustment.

title: Democrats Use Goldman to Push Bank Bill
description: Politicians like nothing more than a convenient foil, and Democrats locked in a stubborn impasse with Republicans over new rules to govern Wall Street believe they have found a gold-plated one in Goldman Sachs, Carl Hulse reports in The New York Times.

title: Leonhardt: Bank Tax as Insurance for Us All
description: The financial regulation bill before the Senate has the potential to do a lot of good. But it also has at least one major flaw: it would not do enough to prevent taxpayers from paying the bill for a future crisis, David Leonhardt writes in his latest column for The New York Times.

title: Panel Assails Goldman; Greek Fears Seize European Union
description: Even before the first question was leveled inside the Senate chamber, Tuesday was going to be uncomfortable for Goldman Sachs.

title: In Rare Road Game 7, Red Wings Rout Coyotes
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The proud legacy of the Detroit Red Wings is safe.

title: I.M.F. Promises More Aid for Greece as European Crisis Grows
description: Hoping to quell its biggest crisis since the Asian woes of 1997, the International Monetary Fund promised on Wednesday to increase the 45 billion-euro aid package for Greece to as much as 120 billion euros over three years.

title: Death Zone
description: The altitude at which there is insufficient oxygen to sustain normal human functions.

title: B.C. Regulators Quash Lions Gate Poison Pill
description: Regulators in British Columbia on Tuesday voided a shareholders rights plan by Lions Gate Entertainment that would have prevented a takeover attempt by investor Carl Icahn, The Associated Press reported.

title: China Said to Block Real Estate Fund-Raising
description: China will place a moratorium on capital-raising by real estate firms as part of a broader campaign to rein in property price rises, state media reported on Wednesday, citing unidentified sources.

title: Bezos, Dell and Carey Invest in Qliance
description: Jeff Bezos, Michael Dell and Drew Carey are coming together to invest in Qliance Medical Management, a Seattle firm that intends to deliver primary care to patients by excising insurance companies from the chain.

title: Corrections
description: A review last Wednesday about the restaurant SHO Shaun Hergatt misidentified an ingredient in the beurre blanc served with striped bass and crayfish tails. It is vin jaune, meaning yellow wine, from the Jura region  not young wine.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the Cooking Channel, a cable network scheduled to start on May 31, misidentified the country of origin of Indian Food Made Easy, one of its programs. It is England, not Canada.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Dining Calendar on April 14 referred imprecisely to the group Hand in Hand, which held a benefit cooking demonstration on April 21. The group supports cooperative Arab-Jewish schools in Israel, not Arab-Israeli schools.

title: Investors Lagardere Move Thwarted
description: Guy Wyser-Pratte, an activist investor and hedge fund owner, saw his effort at gaining a seat on the board of Lagardere thwarted on Tuesday, when shareholders rejected the attempt with 78 percent of votes.

title: The Goldman E-Mails, or How to Sell Junk
description: Evidence released Tuesday by Senator Carl Levin, the Michigan Democrat in charge of the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, includes a series of e-mail messages sent by executives at Goldman Sachs as the bank attempted to shed mortgage-related assets in the run-up to the subprime crisis of 2007.

title: Zong Dials Up $15 Million
description: Zong, a company that allows customers to buy virtual goods using their mobile phones, has closed a $15 million funding round with backing from Matrix Partners, TechCrunch reported.

title: Bay Areas Anchor Brewing Is Sold
description: Anchor Brewing, the San Francisco beer company that helped spark the modern microbrewery movement, has been sold to two Bay Area entrepreneurs who are in the artisan beer and spirits business, The Associated Press reported.

title: Apple Buys Intrinsity, a Maker of Fast Chips
description: Apple wants the fastest chip for its mobile devices and has bought another chip maker to gain an edge over its competitors. To that end, Apple has acquired a small Austin, Tex., company called Intrinsity, known for making zippy versions of a computer chip often found in mobile devices, The New York Timess Ashlee Vance and Brad Stone reported.

title: Icahn Plans to Fix Whats Broken at Genzyme
description: If elected to the board of Genzyme, billionaire investor Carl Icahn will work to understand and help the company fix what is broken, according to proxy documents filed on Tuesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Reuters reported.

title: Pru Takeover May Be Undermined by Exodus
description: The Financial Times reports that many senior AIA executives, actuaries and agents dont plan to stay after the British insurer Prudential Plc closes its $35.5 billion takeover.

title: S.E.C. Said to Probe Funds Side Pockets
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is taking a closer look at whether hedge fund managers abused a practice known as side pockets to prevent clients from withdrawing billions of dollars during the 2008 financial crisis, TheWall Street Journal reported.

title: Sales, Not I.P.O.s, Becomes Popular in Australia
description: Private equity firms looking to sell some of their midsize Australian businesses are finding strong enough interest from trade buyers so that they may be able to avoid I.P.O.s, Reuters reported.

title: Leonsis Gets Washington Wizards and Verizon Center
description: Ted Leonsis, owner of the Washington Capitals hockey team, has reached a deal with the Pollin family to acquire a majority share of the Washington Wizards basketball team and the Verizon Center where the teams play.

title: TheWrap.com Gets $2 Million in 2nd Round
description: TheWrap.com, a Hollywood business news Web site,has received a fresh injection of $2 million in a second round of funding, PaidContentreported.

title: Swiss Banks to Crack Down on Euro Clients
description: Swiss banks want to crack down on European clients who may be avoiding taxes in their home countries, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: How to Be a Bollywood Star (O.K., an Extra)
description: Being a star in a big Bollywood production takes lots of training. But if all you want is to be an extra, join the tourist crowds on Colaba Causeway, at popular spots like Leopold Caf or Caf Mondegar.

title: Good News From the Housing Sector
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Whitman on Hot Seat Over Time at Goldman
description: Meg Whitman, the former eBay chief executive, said Tuesday she regrets taking part in a now-banned stock sale practice at Goldman Sachs and said she left the investment banks board in 2002 after 15 months because she wasnt a good fit.

title: Backed by Flowers, Shinsei Plans Sell-Off
description: Shinsei Bank, the Japanese lender backed by the investor J. Christopher Flowers, plans to sell more than 100 billion yen ($1.1 billion) of overseas investments, two people with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News.

title: American Idol: The Top 6 Tackle Shania Twain
description: Siobhan Magnus > Michael Lynche > Crystal Bowersox > Casey James > Aaron Kelly > Lee DeWyze

title: Pro-Football-Reference.com Reviews Drafts of Giants and Jets
description: For those with N.F.L. draft delirium tremens (seek help if you would give anything to hear the sound of Todd McShays voice)

title: Sinopec to Sell Nearly $3 Billion in Bonds
description: Sinopec will carry out Chinas biggest exchange-listed corporate debt issue when it sells up to $2.93 billion in bonds on the Shanghai Stock Exchange next month.

title: Adam Smith, Mr. Softee
description: Todays idea: Adam Smith wasnt the free-market fundamentalist hes cracked up to have been, writes a Nobel-winning economist, arguing the 18th-century philosopher had a soft spot for government welfare and the little guy.

title: British Authority Asked to Investigate Uralchem I.P.O.
description: The U.K.s Financial Services Authority has been asked by a former minority investor to take a closer look at the proposed $600 million London listing of Russian fertilizer firm, Uralchem. The Telegraph reported that the investor claims Uralchem has not been sufficiently forthcoming about the risks to its business in the prospectus for its I.P.O.

title: How I Got My Company Back
description: We started 2010 with a very short list of projects on the books. I needed to close some deals or we would run out of work and cash by February.

title: Ander Monsons Vanishing Point': The Future of the Book
description: The writers participating in The London Review of Bookss panel on Saturday speculated about the future of reading and writing, but they had a slightly harder time trying to imagine how the Book of the Future might change the reading experience. John Lanchester predicted that if a book were to interact with the Web, it would most likely resemble a video game.

title: Word of the Day | tangential
description: tangential \tan-jen(t)-shl\ adjective

title: Generation Text Goes Cold Turkey
description: WHAT did a University of Maryland study discover about social media? WHAT experiment did the Riverdale Country Day School try recently?

title: Inquiry Into Gizmodo Bloggers Computers Halted
description: An investigation into the computers and other devices seized last week at the home of a blogger who came into possession of an iPhone prototype has been suspended pending discussions of whether or not the process conflicts with Californias shield law.

title: Dowd: Olive Oil and Snake Oil
description: From Maureen Down on The New York Timess Op-Ed page:

title: A Reprieve for the Tiny Pupfish
description: So far as we know, the strong Baja California earthquake that shook parts of Mexico and Southern California this month did not generate a tsunami. But the tiny Devils Hope pupfish who live in a cavern pool deep in the Death Valley desert might have a different perspective.

title: Giant Beef Producer to Sell $1 Billion in Shares
description: Three months after delaying the listing of its United States unit, JBS is ready to raise $1.04 billion by selling new voting shares. The worlds largest beef producer, based in Brazil, will sell 230 million shares, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, April 28
description: Here are some highlights from Wednesdays editions of The New York Times:

title: For Some on Wall St., Hearings Were Background Noise
description: Maybe it was the deepening debt crisis in Europe. Maybe it was the rare treat of a Mets-Dodgers doubleheader starting just before happy hour. Or maybe it was the lack of a holy cow moment.

title: Rusty Aston Could Fetch More Than $250,000 at Auction
description: No superlatives will be used to describe the condition of the 1964 Aston Martin DB5 that will be offered at Bonhamss Monaco auction on Friday. In fact, Bonhams will dutifully point out that the automobiles paint is chipped and faded, the metal is rusted, the leather seats are ripped and cracked, and the filthy, corroded engine hasnt been started in two decades. Yet, this rusting hulk is expected to bring as much as $266,000.

title: Sampler: Fast-Food Toys Tossed, and iPhone Inquiry Stalled
description: Santa Clara Tables Toys with Fast-Food Meals | Happy meals were sad in Santa Clara County on Tuesday. Supervisors voted by 3-2 to prohibit restaurants from serving toys with meals packed with fat, sugar and calories. The ordinance, the nations first such law, seeks to fight childhood obesity. The laws practical impact will be extremely limited, however, because it only applies to restaurants in the unincorporated areas of the county, like San Martin, Cambrian, Burbank and Stanford University. Before the toy ban takes effect, the board will vote to reaffirm the decision on May 11. [The San Jose Mercury News]

title: Auction Begins for Philadelphia Newspapers
description: The auction to determine the next owner of Philadelphias bankrupt newspapers finally got off the ground early Wednesday morning. The bidding was expected to start at 11 a.m. Tuesday, but it was delayed until almost 4 a.m. Wednesday because of wrangling over the initial offers, according to a company spokesman.

title: The Editors: Wall Street Casino
description: Congressional Republicans have concluded that screaming foul about the banking bailout and blocking financial reform is a clever strategy for the fall elections, The New York Times editorial board writes.

title: E.On Said to Approve $6 Billion Sale of U.S. Assets
description: The sale of the U.S. arm ofthe German utilityE.ON for over $6 billion was given the go-ahead by the companys supervisory board Tuesday, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people close to the matter.

title: Gordon Brown Calls Voter Bigoted
description: Last Updated | 12:25 p.m. Apparently unaware that his microphone was still on as his motorcade sped away from a stop on the campaign trail on Wednesday, Prime Minister Gordon Brown was overheard telling an aide that a woman he had just sparred with on the campaign trail was bigoted. Mr. Browns remarks, made in Rochdale, England, about a woman named Gillian Duffy who complained to him about immigrants from Eastern Europe, can be heard near the end of video posted on the Web site of Britains Channel 4 News.

title: Q. & A. With Julie Sahni
description: Julie Sahni is the owner of Julie Sahnis Indian Cooking School inBrooklyn Heights, N.Y., and the author of 10 cookbooks, including SavoringHerbs and Spices and Classic Indian Cooking. She istaking questions on how to prepare Indian food. Please write them in thecomments below and she will answer them throughout the week. Related article.

title: A Photographers Trail to Appalachia
description: Correction appended | Exactly four decades ago today, Ken Light, a student at Ohio University, took photographs of an antiwar rally there that were published worldwide. (It was a week before four students were killed at Kent State.)

title: Clip Clip
description: Video | Laziness is the mower of invention:

title: Thai Police Clash With Protesters
description: BANGKOK  Antigovernment protesters clashed on Wednesday with security forces who fired their weapons in a short, sharp encounter on the edge of the city.

title: Big Wind Farm Off Cape Cod Gets Approval
description: BOSTON  After nine years of regulatory review, the federal government gave the green light on Wednesday to the nations first offshore wind farm, a fiercely contested project off the coast of Cape Cod.

title: The Early Word: Financial Fights
description: Senate Democrats will try for the third straight day to bring a financial overhaul bill to the floor for debate, after Republicans blocked it twice.

title: AOL to Sell ICQ Service to D.S.T. for $187.5 Million
description: AOL said on Wednesday that it had agreed to sell its ICQ instant messaging service to Digital Sky Technologies, a Russian investment firm, for $187.5 million in cash.

title: The Data-Driven Life
description: Humans make errors. We make errors of fact and errors of judgment. We have blind spots in our field of vision and gaps in our stream of attention. Sometimes we cant even answer the simplest questions. Where was I last week at this time? How long have I had this pain in my knee? How much money do I typically spend in a day? These weaknesses put us at a disadvantage. We make decisions with partial information. We are forced to steer by guesswork. We go with our gut.

title: Nocturnalist | Still Pretty (but Not in Pink)
description: Twice a week, Nocturnalist, City Rooms newest feature, goes out at night and brings the story home to you.

title: Making Officials Answer for Sexual Abuse
description: What were reading this morning:

title: Chaos Follows Justin Bieber to New Zealand Arrival
description: As Bill Bixby used to warn each week at the beginning of The Incredible Hulk, you wouldnt like him when hes angry. Now it appears that fans have stirred a slumbering giant within the diminutive figure of Justin Bieber, the 16-year-old pop star.

title: An Apology After Dolphins Are Criticized for Being Callous
description: The Fifth Down recently debated the issue of loyalty and whether the Jets were cold-hearted in their dealings with Alan Faneca, Leon Washington, Thomas Jones, Jay Feely.

title: How Will the Homeless Benefit?
description: Q.

title: Rich Sound From a New Sound Dock
description: Joni Mitchell used to sing that you dont know what youve got til its gone. And in the world of electronic gadgets, you dont know what youve been missing until you get something new.

title: Guggenheim Board Member Caught in Russian Intrigue
description: Janna Bullock, a Russian-born real estate developer who joined the board of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation in 2007, abruptly left that position two weeks ago to deal with a business dispute in Russia  a conflict involving her husband, who was a regional finance official there, and a company connected to the former judo coach of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin. Ms. Bullocks departure from the board, which oversees the Guggenheim Museum, is the latest twist in an operatic life of a woman who immigrated from St. Petersburg, and worked as a nanny in Brooklyn before starting a New York real estate business that grew into a $2 billion company. A report by Kate Taylor and Andrew E. Kramer of The New York Times can be found here.

title: Let the Good Meals Roll
description: Sam Sifton had a pretty good time finding out what defines New Orleans dining these days. He sipped vodka with caviar at Stella!, tucked in to the cochon at Cochon, snacked on banh mi at Dong Phuong and finished up with a banana cream pie at Emerils  all places were chefs can hold their heads high.

title: Jane Hotel Ballroom Is Allowed to Reopen
description: Updated, 10:27 a.m. | The ballroom at the Jane Hotel, which earned enmity from its West Village neighbors for the throngs of partygoers drawn to the exclusive and lushly restored space until the city shut it down in October, could be on the verge of reopening. It has been given two important stamps of approval by the city.

title: What a Dish
description: Rudolf Stingel has a lot on his plate these days  literally. The New York-based conceptual artist collaborated with Bernardaud, the French porcelain company, and the Art Production Funds WOW (Works on Whatever) on a pair of luscious-looking dinner plates that are almost too beautiful to mar with a meal. The plates, which come in an edition of 2,500 in both black and white, are based on photographs of a wall relief that Stingel began in 2008. Fittingly, that project was inspired by the wallpaper in the dining room of his childhood home. Why make tableware? I like to eat, the artist says. And I like to look at my work  two birds, one stone. Its not the artists first excursion into the everyday. In 2004, he famously swathed Grand Central Stations cavernous Vanderbilt Hall in floral carpeting. Impressive, of course. But this is one project hell be able to dine out on for years. And at $98 each, so will you. Available at worksonwhatever.com and Bernardaud boutiques in New York and Chicago.

title: American Idol: If the Shirt Fits
description: As American Idol enters the home stretch, Simon Cowell may not be able to put his thumb on the scale for the contestant Crystal Bowersox as blatantly as he did at the start of the season. (In fact, were pretty sure his dismissal of her performance of Shania Twains No One Needs to Know on Tuesday nights show was all part of some elaborate head game.) But another not-so-subtle endorsement of Ms. Bowersox slipped onto the show, in the form of a T-shirt worn by a man she identified as her boyfriend. A close-up of the shirts message appears below:

title: Stocks Higher as Earnings Lift Sentiment
description: Stocks pushed past concerns over a widening European debt crisis and closed higher on Wall Street on Wednesday, after the Federal Reserve reassured investors that the economy was improving and left interest rates untouched as predicted.

title: Best Outside Linebackers in N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
description: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely - but not strictly - by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, though the future isnt ignored. Stats werent acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally dont make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. Thats why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what youre about to read.

title: A Five-Ton Bid for Pizza Supremacy
description: In New Yorks fiercely competitive pizza landscape, how can a new Neapolitan pizzeria stand out? At Donatella Arpaias forthcoming restaurant, called Donatella, the oven is the thing.

title: Cherished Parks Closing in Arizona
description: Desperate to narrow one of the worst state budget gaps in the nation, Arizona legislators have slashed their parks budget by 80 percent in the last two years, leaving more than a third of the 30 state parks closed or facing closure in coming months.

title: Anthony Kim to Have Surgery on His Thumb
description: Anthony Kim and his management team will decide soon when to have the detached ligament in his left thumb surgically repaired. Kim, coming off a victory at the Shell Houston Open and a third-place finish at the Masters in his last two outings, said he would have the operation and was prepared to skip major championships to be ready for the Ryder Cup in September.

title: The Opus of the Local Photographer Who Took on Al Gore
description: If a picture is worth a thousand words, then Ken Light, a photographer from Orinda, has written an epic. Thats apparent in a lush display of his work showcased on the Lens Blog in The New York Times.

title: Fallon: A Lot Easier to Spend
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: After meeting with his deficit commission today, President Obama said that its a lot easier to spend a dollar than it is to save one. Even the deficit commission was like, Who invited grandpa?

title: Letterman: John McCain, Also an Immigrant
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Anybody here from Arizona? They have that new tough immigration law, and they say now because theyre getting a lot of reaction, theyre saying it isnt targeted to Mexicans. The immigration law, they said, is not about keeping Mexicans south of the border. As a matter of fact, they had a crew out today of government agents looking for Dutch people.

title: The Morning Line: Filling the Eskendereya Void
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

title: Leno: They Could Be Very Angry
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: The famous scientist Stephen Hawking says in a new documentary not only does he believe aliens exist, he believes we should not make contact with aliens because they could be very angry beings, especially aliens from Arizona.

title: If Fire Comes, Blame It on the Rain
description: After three years of drought, the Bay Area is dripping with relief. But theres a potentially fiery flipside to all this rain weve been soaking up, including Wednesday mornings showers.

title: Do-Good Design
description: Whats the point of design these days, anyway? Thats the question the curators at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum wrestled with for nearly three years as they assembled Why Design Now?, the museums fourth National Design Triennial, which opens May 14. Their response, presented through 134 projects from around the world, might be the design equivalent of the Hippocratic oath. Many are high-minded, utilitarian responses to critical problems overseas (cleaner-burning stoves, a land-mine-removal suit) and at home (New York Citys new Hoop bike rack, M.I.T.s prototype for a lightweight electric city car). Theres room for high-style design, but there also needs to be room for the rest of the world, says Matilda McQuaid, the museums deputy curatorial director. But its definition of socially responsible has room for whimsical conceptualism (Interactive Institutes Energy Aware Clock, above), architectural grandiosity (Foster & Partners sustainable city of Masdar in Abu Dhabi) and simple beauty (Heath Ceramics tableware). Even Twitter made the cut. People say the focus on socially responsible design is just because of the Wall Street crisis and isnt going to survive once things are back to normal, McQuaid says. I think its here to stay.

title: Wednesday Reading: Disaster-Related Travel Deals
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Discovering Promises in Modernism
description: THAT GIRL flirts with Mad Men in the set design for the new Broadway revival of the 1968 musical Promises, Promises, a frisky tale about trysting in the 60s that stars Sean Hayes and Kristin Chenoweth.

title: Senator Lindsey Graham, Our Hero
description: Gail Collins: David, can we talk about immigration reform? This is not a subject on which we get a whole lot of sensible behavior, so whenever you do see a legislator going out of his or her way to try to solve the problem you have to offer a certain respect. I really did respect John McCain for working with Edward Kennedy to come up with a sane bill in 2007, and it did cost him politically. Although not a whole lot in the end, what with his being nominated for president and all.

title: Size of Spill in Gulf of Mexico Is Larger Than Thought
description: NEW ORLEANS  Government officials said late Wednesday night that oil might be leaking from a well in the Gulf of Mexico at a rate five times that suggested by initial estimates.

title: The Slow, Winding Path to Adulthood
description: Many a parent believes that their children are growing up too fast. Eight is the new 12, and 12 is the new 18. Todays middle schoolers dress like adults, know how to swear like adults and are exposed to drugs. They also know about sex, talk back and reach puberty earlier than we ever did.

title: The Economics of Horse Racing
description: Horse racing isn't what it used to be. With the Kentucky Derby just around the corner, Times reporter Joe Drape talks about the economic decline of the sport.

title: The Good Wife Also Addresses Muhammad Cartoon Controversy
description: Days after a series of South Park episodes caused a stir by showing a character said to be the Prophet Muhammad, that holy figure very nearly turned up in a new episode of the CBS drama The Good Wife, which also addressed the subject of showing Islams founder in cartoon form.

title: A Scene From 'The Arbor'
description: A scene from "The Arbor," a merging of documentary and narrative film directed by Clio Barnard.

title: Video: The Economics of Horse Racing
description: Horse racing isnt what it used to be. With the Kentucky Derby just around the corner, Joe Drape talks about the economic decline of the sport. For more on this topic, check out Drapes story on the sports economic decline.

title: On This S.N.L., the Weekend Update Is About How Fresh the Lettuce Is at the Greenmarket
description: Live from New York, its Salad Night.

title: New Liberal Voice Casts Eye on Bloomberg and Beyond
description: The first head of the Drum Major Institute for Public Policy, Fernando Ferrer, left to run for mayor against Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Counting Calories in Diet Pet Food
description: Dog and cat owners who buy diet pet foods may be feeding their animals more calories than they realize.

title: Found Poem Favorite | Art in Adolescence
description: Todays poem, chosen from nearly 200 submissions to our Found Poem Student Challenge, comes from Abigail, who is 17 years old and from Columbus. (Ohio? Georgia? Were not sure.)

title: Interview: Clio Barnard
description: Clio Barnard, the director of "The Arbor," describes her unique approach to shooting her hybrid documentary/narrative film about the playwright Andrea Dunbar and her daughter Lorraine.

title: The Pletcher School of Racing
description: Molly Jo Rosen has been involved with thoroughbred racing from coast-to-coast: from Churchill Downs to TVG, to Smarty Joness personal assistant to managing a major New York racing operation. She serves her blend of pony punditry on her blog: Focused Filly.

title: Portugal to Accelerate Cuts After Debt Downgrade
description: A day after Portugal saw its credit rating downgraded by Standard and Poors, the countrys prime minister and opposition leader came together to announce they were ready to use any means necessary to address market uncertainty, and that they would speed up the implementation of their austerity program.

title: The Best Way to Insure Your Valuables
description: Have fine art, jewelry or other valuables in your home?

title: Iced Tea Boycotts and Cultural Capitals
description: The Harvard Business Review has some advice for companies: Short the burbs and go long on cities.

title: High Gloss
description: If you are strong enough not to be moved by dolphin console tables and rococo plasterwork, Syrie Maugham is probably nothing more to you than the wife of the sulfurous literary lion W. Somerset Maugham. For the rest of us, its a different story. A domestic-arts arbiter of adventurous originality, Syrie set up shop in London in 1922 and went on to forge a triumphantly theatrical look celebrating glamour and luxury. Some of her ideas were odd, some immensely profitable. She said that by stripping peonies of their leaves, party guests could be fooled into believing they were wax, a look she preferred to fresh. Indifferent antiques were ruthlessly cut down, painted, pickled or otherwise improved until they sang arias of sustained chic. Were dealers already referring to amusing pieces  furniture with little intrinsic worth but a surfeit of charm  before Syrie Maugham came on the scene? I suspect it all began with her. As it happens, were on the verge of a Syrie fest. Two forthcoming books, Selina Hastingss The Secret Lives of Somerset Maugham (Random House) and Pauline C. Metcalfs Syrie Maugham: Staging the Glamorous Interior (Acanthus Press), make the point that no pedestal was too high for the woman who popularized the all-white room, an icily moderne cocktail of mirrored screens and fireplaces, geometrically sculptured carpets, shagreen tables, satin slipcovers, towering plaster lamps in the form of palm trees and velvet  velvet!  lampshades. You would have thought that with two books already out there  Syrie Maugham, a rare 1978 monograph, and 1980s The Scandal of Syrie Maugham  to say nothing of Beverley Nicholss 1966 screed A Case of Human Bondage, which was dedicated entirely to her toxic marriage, there was nothing left to say or dig up. Happily, this is not the case. Too much is never enough for Syrie cultists.

title: Copenhagen Restaurant Rated No. 1 on S. Pellegrino Best 50
description: Bloomberg is reporting, the Copenhagen restaurant Noma has been ranked No. 1 in the S. Pellegrino Worlds 50 Best Restaurants list for 2010, rising from No. 3 last year. At No.2 was El Bulli, which was No. 1 last year. It is run by Ferran Adri in Spain and has been in the top three since the awards were begun in 2002. Fat Duck, operated by Heston Blumenthal in England, was rated No. 3 after being ranked at No. 2 last year. Rounding out the top five were two other restaurants in Spain: El Celler de Can Roca and Mugaritz.

title: High Gloss
description: Syrie Maugham decorated as fearlessly as she lived. Christopher Petkanas reports. More

title: Values of Top Brands Rose Last Year, Report Finds
description: Not much that was valuable increased in value last year. But according to a report from Millward Brown, a research division of WPP, top brands diverged from the woeful results of 2009.

title: Cutting No Corners on This Side of the Street
description: LETS begin at the end, with me walking out of Epaulet in Brooklyn, bag in hand, purchases swaddled in neon-green tissue paper, content. This is how I want to feel when leaving a store having parted with cash  somehow more whole, as if Ive snapped a puzzle piece successfully into place. In shopping, at least, tenacity rewards the shallow.

title: A Life In and Out of Sync
description: Clio Barnards film The Arbor is hard to categorize. Its a documentary, as it uses the interviews of real people to tell its story of the British playwright Andrea Dunbar (who died in 1990 at age 29) and the difficult relationship she had with her daughter Lorraine. But its also a narrative feature, because it uses actors to lip-sync the audio of those interviews in highly stylized scenes. Also mixed in is a performance of Ms. Dunbars play The Arbor, staged and filmed on the street where she lived in Bradford, England. The film screens Wednesday night at the Tribeca Film Festival and includes a post-screening panel.

title: Oakland Teachers to Strike on Thursday
description: Public school teachers in Oakland plan to pick up picket signs for a one-day strike on Thursday. The action follows a controversial new contract imposed last week by the Oakland School Board that left teachers without pay raises for at least a year.

title: A Good Night for the Old Guard
description: Sometimes, sports provides a moment of truth for a dynasty, a proud team facing its inevitable decline but given a chance to fight back, if only one more time. The tension becomes whether pride and experience are enough to hold off a younger, spunkier opponent giddy with its chance to play giant killer.

title: A Thumbs Up on Cape Wind
description: The federal government has given the green light to the Cape Wind project off the Massachusetts coast. The Interior secretary, Ken Salazar, announced the decision in Boston. Read the story here.

title: French Jockey Hopes for a Trip to Churchill
description: Gina Rarick has been training horses since 2001, alongside a career in journalism. She left the newspaper business to train full-time last year, becoming the first American woman licensed as a professional racehorse trainer in France. You can read more on her blog, Gallop France.

title: City of Endangered Languages
description: New York has long been a city of immigrants, but linguists now consider it a laboratory for studying and preserving languages in rapid decline elsewhere in the world.

title: The Self-Appointed Twitter Scolds
description: JOHN CUSACK tweets with his iPhone and, much like the characters he plays, his style is fast and loose. Im pretty new to it, and if theres a spell check on an iPhone, I cant find it, he said by telephone. So I basically get in the general ballpark and tweet it.

title: Espada Paid Workers $1.70 an Hour, Cuomo Says
description: ALBANY  The Senate majority leader, Pedro Espada Jr., paid janitors for his Soundview health clinics $1.70 an hour, according to a lawsuit filed Wednesday by the office of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo. The federal minimum wage is $7.25.

title: Cleanup Crew Eradicates Banksy Rat
description: Where Banksy is involved, there usually are no accidents, but in this case it truly does appear to be an accident that a street-cleaning crew in Melbourne, Australia, painted over a mural by that pseudonymous graffiti artist and provocateur. The Associated Press reported that Susan Riley, the deputy lord mayor of Melbourne, dispatched street cleaners to the citys Hosier Lane after residents complained about squalid conditions at an alley known for its displays of public art. Among the works painted there was a stencil of a goggle-wearing rat, created by Banksy during a visit to Melbourne in 2003  and removed by the crew, which was instructed to remove all graffiti from the area. In an interview on Australian radio, Kathy Alexander, the chief executive of the city of Melbourne, said, Unfortunately, the contractors were not made aware by us that that was an important piece and unfortunately that means the piece is gone.

title: Soundtracks Top Charts
description: Billboards album chart this week is all about soundtracks. The Power of Madonna (Columbia), the seven-song companion to last weeks all-Madonna episode of the Fox show Glee, opened at No. 1 with 98,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and 75 percent of its sales were as digital downloads  an extraordinary number, although not quite record-breaking. (In January, Keshas Animal had 76 percent, and the Hope for Haiti charity album was released only online.) Not far behind Glee, the all-AC/DC soundtrack to Iron Man 2 (Columbia) reached No. 4 in its first week, with 76,000 sales. Billboard reported that it is the first time in the five-decade history of its main album chart that two soundtracks have made their debuts in the Top 5.

title: Washington Post Unveils New Political Homepage
description: Move over New York, youre not alone with a budding local news war. A battle is also heating up in Washington.

title: Butler, Mavericks Late Arrival, Is Just in Time
description: DALLAS  Caron Butler has been a Texas resident for 10 weeks, hardly long enough to compare and contrast barbecue chains, adjust to the oddities of the local highway system or absorb the Mavericks playbook.

title: TimesCast | April 28, 2010
description: A look inside The New York Times newsroom and stories being covered Wednesday.  Today's topics include efforts to burn  off the Gulf oil spill, the lost iPhone controversy and more.

title: Comcast Earnings Beat Expectations
description: Comcast said that its revenues increased by 3.8 percent in the first quarter of 2010, to $9.2 billion, beating Wall Streets expectations.

title: What Were Reading: Musicalizing Fraud
Motorman Fatally Stricken at Controls of a G Train
description: The motorman on a G train suffered a fatal heart attack Wednesday morning while guiding the train out of the Court Square station in Queens, transit officials said.

title: On Our Radar: A Carbon Trading Raid
description: German prosecutors raid banks and utilities in a carbon-trading tax evasion investigation.

title: Milan Report | The Wrap-Up
description: The Milan Furniture Fair and its outside exhibitions and events seem to get bigger every year. In fact, its getting to the point where no one person can see everything  even if you find yourself with a few extra days on your hands, waiting for a volcanic ash cloud to blow away. And there was a lot worth seeing  so much, in fact, that T has put together a roundup of some (but not all) of the things we couldnt fit into reports from the field.

title: Spill Response: Burn Baby Burn
description: As federal officials prepare to test whether they can ignite a patch of the oil slick spreading from the seafloor wreckage of the Gulf of Mexico well, seasoned specialists say the logic in pursuing this option is clear and well established by decades of testing.

title: College Enrollment Rate at Record High
description: 7:13 p.m. | Updated

title: Financial Tuneup: Get a Better Deal From Your Cable Company
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: Republicans Block Finance Bill, Again
description: Senate Republicans on Wednesday blocked an effort by Democrats to begin floor debate of legislation overhauling the nations financial regulatory system  the third such vote in three days as Democrats sought to paint the Republicans as obstructing tighter rules for Wall Street.

title: Lookin at Lucky Draws Inside Post
description: Lookin at Lucky was made the 3-1 morning-line favorite for the 136th running of the Kentucky Derby and will start from the inside post on Saturday. The front-running Sidneys Candy, who was made the second choice at 5-1, will start from the outside position at No. 20.

title: Graduating From Lip Smackers
description: IT began for Alyssa Pometta, as these habits so often do, with the soft stuff. We are talking, of course, about lip gloss.

title: Ride Home With It
description: ROMPERS, jumpsuits and now ... unitards? SoulCycle, the indoor spin-class studios, has just added the one-piece made famous by Queens Freddie Mercury to its latest collection of workout clothes (right). And very, very confident New York women have been spotted wearing them outside the spin class, accessorized with high boots and long cardigans. We were inspired by all the jumpsuits out now and the 80s music we were listening to, said Julie Rice, a SoulCycle owner, whose play list features Pat Benatars Hit Me With Your Best Shot. Seventies-era Spandex has been replaced by Vaporex, a moisture-wicking fabric ($150). Available at the SoulCycle studios in Manhattan, including 1470 Third Avenue; (212) 639-1300, and online at soul-cycle.com.

title: Business as Usual for Woods at Quail Hollow
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  It was 45 degrees and quiet when Tiger Woods walked to the first tee Wednesday morning, threading his way from the putting green through a dewy, roped-off corridor at Quail Hollow Club. His pro-am time was 7:30 and his breath was visible in the morning chill as he told a couple of kids pleading for autographs that he would sign after the round.

title: It Fights Aging, but It Gets Old
description: AGING ANTI-AGERS Makeup spoils. From the moment a mascara or a face cream that contains plant-derived substances is opened, it is a petri dish for bacteria. But stickers like these from Beauty Alert ($8.50 for 24) can help keep track of when its time to say goodbye, as can the labels in the Once Opened Beauty Expiration Kit ($9.95 for 24).

title: Spains Debt Rating Cut as Finance Officials Meet
description: The ratings agency Standard & Poors lowered the debt rating of Spain on Wednesday, its third downgrade of a European country in two days, The New York Timess Landon Thomas Jr. reports.

title: Paying With Your Phone
description: A wave of new technologies are making us less and less dependent on cash.

title: Toyota Announces Another Recall
description: Toyota announced a second recall Wednesday related to the vehicle stability control system on its sport utility vehicles, this one concerning the 2003 model year Sequoia.

title: Quiet Progress on Senate Climate Bill
description: Although the public progress of the Senate attempt to write a comprehensive climate change energy bill has ground to a halt because of a protest by one of its chief sponsors, an outline of the bills major provisions is moving forward.

title: Self Magazine Hands Out Product Awards
description: PRODUCTS PRAISED Pomegranate is in. Or so proclaimed the 1,108 testers who helped Self magazine select 88 products for its Healthy Beauty Awards, which are named in the May issue. Elaine DFarley, Selfs beauty director, said at a breakfast for winners and members of the news media, Eyes are the new focal point.

title: Plastic-Surgery Group Starts Advice Web Site
description: NEW ONLINE At a new site from the American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery  ProjectBeauty.com  there are articles about fitness and skin care, and videos from patients who underwent breast augmentation. The site is not meant to drive business to plastic surgeons, one of its creators said, but to offer unbiased information.

title: G.O.P. Agrees to Start Debate on Financial Bill
description: Senate Republicans ended three days of resistance on Wednesday and signaled that they are ready to allow debate of legislation to overhaul regulation of the nations financial system, David M. Herszenhorn and Edward Wyatt of The New York Times report from Washington.

title: Bipartisan Agreement: Raise Taxes, Cut Spending
description: To coincide with todays big deficit gathering in Washington, the Peter G. Peterson Foundation has released the results of a new survey. Heres how the foundation describes the people approached for the survey:

title: TimesCast: The Political Calculus of the G.O.P.
description: Republicans in the Senate have once again prevented Democrats from bringing to the floor legislation that would overhaul financial regulations.

title: Cellphone Payments Offer Alternative to Cash
description: You win a bet, but the loser does not have enough cash on him to settle it. If he has a credit card, and most people usually do, there is finally a solution. A number of big and small companies  including eBays PayPal unit, Intuit, VeriFone and Square  are creating innovative ways for individuals to avoid cash and checks and settle all debts, public and private, using their cellphones.

title: Bigoted Woman
description: Gordon Browns private description of a 65-year-old Labour supporter.

title: Smoke Alarm, but No Fire, Leads to Chilly Outdoor Passion Play
description: In its performances at the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, Epic Theater Ensembles production of Sarah Ruhls Passion Play aspires to a certain bare aesthetic, though perhaps not quite as bare as what its cast members experienced at the shows first preview on Tuesday night.

title: The Morning Skate: Good Vibes for Capitals or History for the Habs?
description: A hugely entertaining opening round of the Stanley Cup playoffs ends tonight in Washington when the Capitals, the N.H.L.s best regular-season team, try to advance in Game 7 against the Canadiens, who finished 33 points behind them in the standings.

title: Why Does This Pair of Pants Cost $550?
description: EVEN in a season when designers made no secret about reining in prices to appeal to the newly chastened luxury consumer, it is still possible to walk into a store and wonder what exactly they were thinking when a pair of khaki cotton pants  right there on the hanger, no special packaging or 3G plan or anything  can cost as much as an iPad.

title: Feeling Free of All Ties
description: GIRLY-GIRL sneakerheads with a passion for sequins and fond memories of the playgrounds of their youth may want to check out a new line of Keds designed by Stacey Bendet, founder of Alice + Olivia. These stylish mash-ups, which Ms. Bendet sees as an alternative to the ubiquitous ballet flat worn with dresses, jeans and leggings, may have had roots in her own childhood, when she was not one to obsess about keeping her kicks clean. My Keds were a chalkboard, she said. I would draw all over them  even the white leather version. Ms. Bendet remembers that as a budding trendsetter she carried off the de rigueur look of the time: slouch socks, leggings, no laces. Drawing on those memories, she took the laces out of this collection. The shoes (left) are $88 at Neiman Marcus stores and neimanmarcus.com.

title: Dress Like a Benefactor
description: CIVIC-MINDED shoppers (and, after all, who isnt one?) will be able to buy a cage dress designed by Christian Cota (left, $3,950) without feeling too bad about that four-figure price tag. The dress is one of 17 created by emerging fashion designers for Saks Fifth Avenue, which says it will donate 10 percent of the proceeds to benefit the Whitney Museum of American Art. There are also several dresses by Prabal Gurung, including a one-shoulder blue crepe dress ($1,750), and a black-and-white one-shoulder cocktail dress ($2,850), as well as three playful print floral dresses by Erdem Moralioglu ($1,240 to $700), all named Frances, after a friend of the designers who accompanied him on an inspirational trip to Japan. Also represented are Doo.Ri, Marios Schwab and Aquilano.Rimondi. Saks Fifth Avenue, 611 Fifth Avenue, (212) 753-4000.

title: One Teams Dream Is Another Teams Obsession
description: 4:41 p.m. |Inter Through to Final

title: Land of Lonely Tongues
description: An article on the Web site of The Times this afternoon describes the efforts of the Endangered Language Alliance at the City University of New York to track down New Yorkers who speak languages that are not only rare here but may be falling extinct in their homelands, too.

title: Goldman Wins Top Spot in Private Equity Ranking
description: Goldman Sachs may be a bank holding company, but its private equity unit is ranked first place on Private Equity Internationals latest list of the largest private equity firms, supplanting pure-play firms like last years winner, TPG.

title: Dust Off the Old Stock
description: THE new Gant Rugger store on Bleecker Street  the first stand-alone retail outlet for the Rugger brand  channels factory chic from the companys manufacturing roots in New Haven, with exposed industrial piping and a sewing machine in front of the dressing rooms. Christopher Bastin (above), the head designer for Gant Rugger and a self-proclaimed vintage nerd, also mined the sportswears past by updating fabrics and silhouettes. I basically went on eBay and started buying vintage Gant to build up the archives, Mr. Bastin said. A Hopsack blazer ($495), available in navy and gray, includes 30-year-old buttons recently unearthed at the companys Portugal factory. Also featured are madras shirts ($125), chinos ($125), polo shirts ($79 to $89) and a single-speed cruiser bike ($995) in a limited edition of 20. Gant Rugger, 353 Bleecker Street, (212) 620-5949.

title: Bill Clinton, on Immigration and Wall Street
description: Former President Bill Clinton waded into two of the seasons biggest controversies on Wednesday with the bravado of someone never facing election again, calling for more immigration and expressing doubt about whether Goldman Sachs broke any laws, as the government alleges.

title: Celtics Not a Trendy Upset Pick
description: Anyone picking the Boston Celtics to upend the high-flying Cleveland Cavaliers in their second-round N.B.A. playoff series?

title: Too Busy for Oil Awards
description: Scratch the awards luncheon for offshore drilling safety.

title: USC to Create an Oral Archive of Behind-the-Scenes Hollywood
description: Now it can be told! The stories behind the Hollywood stories from years past will apparently find their way into history via a new oral archive project at the University of Southern Californias School of Cinematic Arts. The now-retired Times correspondent Bernard Weinraub, who long held the Hollywood beat, is listed among the first contributors to the archive, which is being initially funded and produced by the powerhouse entertainment law firm, Hansen, Jacobson, Teller, Hoberman, Newman, Warren & Richman.

title: Crist Drops More Hints
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Gov. Charlie Crist on Wednesday solved one part of his campaign mystery by saying there was no chance he would drop out of the race for the United States Senate.

title: Obama to Nominate Three to the Central Bank
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will nominate Janet L. Yellen on Thursday to be vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, and fill two remaining seats on the central banks board of governors, officials said Wednesday evening.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. The Arizona House of Representatives passes a provision that will require President Obama to show his birth certificate to get on the states ballot in 2012. At which point a morose civil servant will ask, Dont I know you from somewhere?

title: How They Do Things Back in St. Olaf: Flirting Fleetingly With Betty White
description: Thank you for being a friend  but not that kind of friend.

title: You Dont Mess With Sassoon
description: He was Picasso, Copernicus, a Shakespeare with shears. Yes, those are grand comparisons, but theyre consistent with the gushing of hair geeks interviewed for Vidal Sassoon The Movie, a documentary that had its world premiere on Friday at the Tribeca Film Festival. Was Sassoon really so great? From his Bond Street salon in the 1960s, he created a geometric approach to the cut, exemplified by the five-point, which coiffeurs still speak of like its their Rosetta stone. You cut hair like we cut clothes, the Swinging Sixties designer Mary Quant tells Sassoon during a tender scene in which they sift through old pictures of the models Nancy Kwan and Grace Coddington. A narrative quickly emerges: Quant popularizes the mini-skirt, Sassoon tops off the Kings Road look, and the rest  the shampoo bottles, the global network of salons and styling academies  is history. Well, not quite.

title: A Day in the Life of an Exercise Rider
description: Today I thought I would take you through my morning activity, so you can get a sense of what an exercise rider does. Exercise riders are those guys who are piloting the Kentucky Derby horses around the track for their morning training. I have never had the privilege of galloping a horse that is preparing for the Derby, but I have galloped at least one horse who ran in the Derby. Storm Treasure, trained by Steve Asmussen, ran the year Barbaro won. He came up to Woodbine in 2008 and 2009 when I was galloping for Asmussen in Canada.

title: Warning: Measure Your Salt
description: I was a Diamond Crystal baby. Diamond Crystal kosher salt was the only salt my mother used, the only one I knew as a child. Now, half a century later (yikes!), it remains the salt I reach for first  although I now have to fish for it among half a dozen that sit on the shelf. All those fancy sea salts, however, are used to finish dishes or added at the table, where their varied textures are a source of tactile delight. For cooking, I rarely use anything but the kosher salt of my childhood; I can judge, by eye and by feel, how much I need for any task from making a well balanced vinaigrette to seasoning a steak.

title: Travel Deals: Variety and Carnival Cruise Sales
description: Variety Cruises, a fleet of upscalelarge yachts with 25 to 36 cabins, is offering two-for-one fares, starting at $2,690, on cruises along the Adriatic Coast.

title: Beyond Bouncy Castles and Pony Rides
description: Have you noticed how almost no one sells products or services anymore, but rather experiences? And its the experience offered by Games2U, a fleet of vans stocked with video games, that David Pikoff, a co-founder of the company, says will make the venture a success.

title: 26 in Egypt Are Convicted in Terror Plot
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court on Wednesday convicted 26 men of belonging to a Hezbollah cell that was charged with planning to attack Israeli tourists in the Sinai Peninsula, fire on ships passing through the Suez Canal and smuggle weapons, supplies and people through tunnels to the Gaza Strip.

title: Bryant Redefines Role and Reinvigorates Lakers
description: LOS ANGELES  In recent weeks, Kobe Bryant had aged before the worlds eyes. The broken right index finger, which has morphed into an arthritic knuckle, had diminished his ball-handling ability and shooting touch. His twisted left ankle had compromised his leaping ability and his swollen right knee had become so troublesome that Bryant, for the second time this season, took a week off to rest it.

title: China Lifts Ban on Visitors Who Are H.I.V. Positive
description: Days before travelers worldwide are to begin arriving for Shanghais world exposition, China has lifted a two-decade ban on travel to the country by people who carry the virus that causes AIDS or who have other sexually transmitted diseases. Read full story

title: Answers About New York School Data
description: Following is the first set of responses from Robert Gebeloff, a computer-assisted journalist with an expertise in education, who has been working on an extensive database of New York education statistics for The New York Times.

title: Lawmakers Call for Action on Immigration
description: The political challenge that Arizonas tough immigration law poses for both parties was evident Wednesday as members called loudly for federal action.

title: Shift of Funds at the Metropolitan Opera
description: The Metropolitan Opera last year freed up $22 million of its $242 million endowment to help cover operating expenses. With the permission of the donors, $15 million was shifted into the less restrictive endowment trust as an emergency reserve. The move, reported in the Wall Street Journal on Wednesday, was yet another effort by the Met to manage a deficit that is expected to be about $4 million for this fiscal year. With the permission of Chevron Texaco, the Met also moved $7 million in restricted funds. The Met has reduced the total budget by $18 million for the current fiscal year, resulting in an operating budget of about $300 million.

title: Scouting Report
description: ON THE SHELVES

title: In Area With Few Options, Rigs Are Mixed Blessing
description: JONESVILLE, La.  Here, people live on streets named after their grandfathers.

title: On a Holiday for Afghans, Tight Security and Violence
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The celebration of the 18th anniversary of the victory of the mujahedeen commanders over the Communist government in 1992 put Afghanistans contradictory impulses toward war and peace on public display on Wednesday.

title: Needle and Thread Still Have a Home
description: HOW is the garment district like a coral reef? A coral reef, as Animal Planet instructs us, shelters diverse species of sponges, snakes, clownfish and barracudas. So does the garment district. A coral reef is a rich universe with its own organically evolved architecture, home to its own assortment of beasts and weeds. Garment district buildings are the same. Plunge down alongside a reef and hang in the flow, currents eddying around you, and as the designer Yeohlee Teng said recently, You never know what is going to swim by.

title: Science Quiz: Happy Birthday, Hubble!
description: The Hubble Telescope was launched into space 20 years ago, on April 24, 1990. To mark this anniversary, instead of a regular science lesson we present a 12-question interactive quiz about the observatory that astronomy educator and blogger Phil Plait calls arguably the worlds most famous telescope.
