description: Hugh Raffless beautifully written Insectopedia  part reference, part narrative and wholly engrossing  begins with an evocative image. On Aug. 10, 1926, a small monoplane began flying missions from Tallulah, La., to assess the population of insects in a vertical column of air. It was the first time insects had been collected by plane, and the results were astounding. In a square mile, rising to 14,000 feet, there were as many as 36 million insects.

title: Shanghai Expo
description: China has spent $45 billion to mount an elaborate World Expo, inviting 189 countries to showcase a polished, vibrant Shanghai that it envisions as a financial capital for the region, even the world.

title: Guilt and Death, North and South
description: Hanoi, Vietnam

title: American Power Act
description: In 1860, Samuel Curtis, a Republican congressman of Iowa, sponsored a bill to create a transcontinental railroad. The debate over that public-private partnership was long and messy. Democrats said the proposal was unconstitutional. Others rightly argued that it meant huge giveaways to the rich.

title: Oil Spills Blow to BPs Image May Eclipse Costs
description: HAMMOND, La.  BP says that the offshore drilling accident that is spewing thousands of barrels of oil a day into the Gulf of Mexico could cost the company several hundred million dollars.

title: Saigons Fall, 35 Years Later
description: Philadelphia

title: Turmoil Builds at Aspen Music Festival and School
description: The tensions that have simmered at the Aspen Music Festival and School in Colorado since the resignation of its music director, David Zinman, on April 8, boiled over on Thursday, when the festival corporation delivered a vote of no confidence in the festivals president and chief executive officer, Alan Fletcher.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 29, 2010

title: Eyes on Woods, but Everyman Takes Control
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  On a day when the No. 1-ranked golfer in the world could barely find a fairway and the No. 2-ranked player was ill and stumbled at the finish, a rank-and-file golfer played a flawless first round Thursday to grab the lead at the Quail Hollow Championship with a seven-under-par 65.

title: Leslie Buck, Designer of Iconic Coffee Cup, Dies at 87
description: It was for decades the most enduring piece of ephemera in New York City and is still among the most recognizable. Trim, blue and white, it fits neatly in the hand, sized so its contents can be downed in a New York minute. It is as vivid an emblem of the city as the Statue of Liberty, beloved of property masters who need to evoke Gotham at a glance in films and on television.

title: Where Washington's Younger Half Lives
description: Where Washington's Younger-Half Lives

title: More on Craigslist and Its Adult Services Ads
description: As I wrote in The New York Times on Monday, Craigslist, the largest classified advertising Web site in the United States, is making a lot of money from its sex adverisements. Whats not exactly clear is what the company is doing with the money.

title: All the Obama 20-Somethings
description: This party, Herbie Ziskend announced, is in honor of John Quincy Adams. The dirty-blond, blue-eyed 24-year-old, who once handled luggage for Barack Obamas campaign and now works in the vice presidents office as a staff assistant, stood in the living room of a red-brick row house in Washington and flung his arms in the air as if to pay tribute to Americas sixth president. Then he paused, deflated: But the police are here.

title: How the Destinies of Motorola and Palm Grew Apart
description: For much of this decade, the fates of Palm and Motorola were intertwined. Both were early innovators in the mobile phone industry, but neither had had a hit in years.

title: Justice Dept. Said to Open Goldman Inquiry
description: Federal prosecutors have opened an inquiry into trading at Goldman Sachs, raising the possibility of criminal charges against the Wall Street giant, Louise Story and Michael J. de la Merced of The New York Times reports, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: A Fairy Godmother to Help With College Aid
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  The envelope arrives with good news. The college is pleased to announce that the student has been offered acceptance and, if he or she is fortunate, some scholarship money.

title: Manhattan Woman Guilty in Husbands 1990 Murder
description: A Manhattan woman pleaded guilty on Thursday to arranging the killing of her husband in a murder-for-hire that occurred two decades ago on the Upper East Side.

title: What Were Reading: iPhone Finder
description: The tech editors and reporters of The New York Times were intrigued by these items Thursday:

title: Posada Sits, and Yanks Hope Its Not for Long
description: BALTIMORE  When Ramiro Pena arrived at Camden Yards on Thursday afternoon, he was given a protective sheath for his left thumb. It would come in handy, he was told, if he were pressed into emergency duty at catcher. Perhaps fortunately for Pena  and for his team  the Yankees were not expecting to need his services for their game against the Orioles.

title: Getting a Good Look at Lookin at Lucky
description: Eric Banks has written for Slate, The Financial Times, The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times, The Chronicle of Higher Education, The Guardian, and The Wall Street Journal. He is a former editor of Bookforum, was a senior editor of Artforum and is a board member of the National Book Critics Circle.

title: Greenwich Village, Heal Thyself
description: Drawings and interviews with people at St. Vincents Hospital before it closed its doors  ending 160 years of serving New York.

title: Crushed Corn Creation
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Ive talked about this before, but part of the thrill of crosswords is that you know things you dont think you know. Or at least you know enough about them to EKE out the words, even when you dont quite understand what they mean. Your examples will be specific to you but heres what I mean.

title: Former Variety Critic Starts a New Web Site
description: Todd McCarthy, left, the film critic laid off in March by Variety as part of a cost-cutting campaign, has landed.

title: Shakespeare: The Question of Authorship
description: Shakespeare is not only peculiar in himself, but the cause of peculiarity in others. The surviving traces of his life, which the Shakespearean scholar Stephen Greenblatt describes as abundant but thin, depict a man whose parts arent entirely in sync: a provincial who grew wealthy but sued for paltry sums, a literary genius who seems never to have written a letter  or owned a book. But the alternate histories offered by people who reject Shakespeares authorship are far stranger, abounding in secret ciphers, baroque conspiracies and readings of the plays as fantastical as whats in them. Barring the discovery of a doorstop-size autobiography or the invention of a time machine, well never get a really satisfying explanation of how Hamlet and Henry V and all the rest were written, only varying degrees of improbability.

title: Why Some Doctors Dont Like Their Jobs
description: Many doctors love the work they do caring for patients and their families. But increasingly, practicing physicians are becoming frustrated with the constraints of a medical system that doesnt always let them do their jobs the way they want to, writes Dr. Pauline Chen in todays Doctor and Patient column.

title: Promise Seen in Drug for Retardation Syndrome
description: An experimental drug succeeded in a small clinical trial in bringing about what the researchers called substantial improvements in the behaviors associated with retardation and autism in people with fragile X syndrome, the most common inherited cause of these mental disabilities.

title: Cano Makes Sure Yankees Go Home Happy
description: BALTIMORE  There may be no such thing as an antidote right now for Robinson Cano, but the Orioles must have figured they had one in the top of the eighth inning. As Cano warmed up by the on-deck circle, Alberto Castillo, a left-handed reliever with more arm angles than an octopus, jogged in from the bullpen. He had yet to allow a hit to a left-handed batter this season, but that changed when Cano turned on an inside fastball and slugged his second homer of the game.

title: Housing Subsidy Has High-Profile Foe
description: The mayors office is urging Gov. David A. Paterson to veto a bill that would offer greater rent relief to 11,000 New York City residents with H.I.V. or AIDS, saying the measure would tax the citys strained budget.

title: Ask the Expert: Raynauds Phenomenon
description: While its normal to feel cold when you step outside on a winters day without a jacket, the feeling of cold comes way too easily for sufferers of Raynauds, writes Winnie Yu in The Times Health Guide: When Cold Fingers Mean Raynauds, or Worse. Holding a cup of yogurt, strolling through the freezer section of the supermarket, even touching a glass of water can turn fingers a mottled mix of white and blue and create chills normally reserved for the iciest exposures. And while Raynauds is just a minor nuisance for the great majority of sufferers, for a small minority, coldness in the fingers and toes is a prelude to a more serious ailment like lupus or scleroderma.

title: Last Call Looms at Freddys, in the Path of Atlantic Yards
description: Sometime next week, workers will start digging under the floor of a bar where a bartender known as Johnny Seatcovers poured an oceans worth of whisky, where police officers and anarchists alike shouted to be heard above the music, where young bands got their start and Blue Oyster Cult played a late-career gig.

title: Obama Says Liberal Courts May Have Overreached
description: WASHINGTON  In a seeming rejection of liberal orthodoxy, President Obama has spoken disparagingly about liberal victories before the Supreme Court in the 1960s and 1970s  suggesting that justices made the error of overstepping their bounds and trampling on the role of elected officials.

title: States Decide on Running New Pools for Insurance
description: WASHINGTON  The fight over the new health care law shifted Thursday to the states, as some governors claimed federal money to run a new insurance pool for people with serious medical problems, while officials in other states said they would not operate the program.

title: Talk of Truth and John Edwards
description: Rielle Hunter, who told Oprah Winfrey in a program broadcast on Thursday that John Edwards had a secret affair with her because he wanted to live a life of truth, is a tough interview, tougher in some ways than President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran.

title: Ministry by Priest Broke Deal, Suit Says
description: A woman from New York who says she was abused by a priest from the Jesuit order of the Roman Catholic Church has filed an unusual lawsuit accusing the Jesuits of breach of contract for allowing the priest to perform public ministry even though he was barred from doing so because of a settlement stemming from an alleged sexual assault.

title: Victoria Manalo Draves, Olympic Champion Diver, Dies at 85
description: Victoria Manalo Draves, an Asian-American diver who overcame ethnic prejudice early in her career to become the first woman to win springboard and platform gold medals in the same Olympics, in 1948, died on April 11 in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 85.

title: Promoting Gender Equality in School Sports
description: To the Editor:

title: Slavery Reparations? Healing the Wounds of the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Free Speech Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: No Glimmers of Recovery Seen From Financial Aid Office
description: Earlier this week, I took the train from New York to Providence, R.I., to spend an afternoon with Sandra J. Oliveira, executive director of the office of financial aid at Providence College in Providence, R.I. I was particularly curious whether the glimmers of economic recovery evident in some car showrooms and department store checkout baskets had reached her spare, wood laminate desk.

title: Judge Wont Add 4th Officer as Defendant in Abuse Lawsuit
description: A federal judge on Thursday rejected a request to make a police officer who is a potential witness against three other officers accused in a sexual abuse civil case a defendant in the matter.

title: Evelyn Cunningham, Civil Rights Reporter, Dies at 94
description: Evelyn Cunningham, a civil-rights-era journalist and later an aide to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. She was 94 and lived in Harlem most of her life.

title: Spurs Advance, as Mavericks Fall Short Again
description: SAN ANTONIO  Dirk Nowitzki grimaced and gritted his teeth, plunged into traffic and contorted himself in the lane. He bounced off every obstacle, flung those high-arching jumpers and pushed the Dallas Mavericks within inches of a revival.

title: Bloggingheads: Tea Party Defamation
description: John McWhorter, left, of the Manhattan Institute and Glenn Loury of Brown University discuss the anti-progressive strain in American history.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: A Moment in Time (or, F.A.Q. on U.T.C.)
description: Update, May 17 |

title: Vision for Transforming Hunters Point Comes Before Supervisors
description: From the barren hilltop, you can see downtown San Francisco and the Bay Bridge, across the bay to Oakland and south to the San Mateo-Hayward Bridge. It is the kind of sweeping San Francisco view that could sustain million-dollar condominiums.

title: The Political Lives of Charlie Crist
description: Gov. Charlie Crist's pragmatic brand of politics has recently obscured the conservative positioning that had made him a darling of Republicans in the past.

title: Free Money Left on Table
description: What if residents of California  a state reeling from unemployment, a sagging economy and a gaping budget hole  had access to more than $1 billion, but did not use it? What if Alameda County residents had access to $29 million and failed to take it out of the federal treasury?

title: Need an Appointment at the D.M.V.? Do You Feel Lucky?
description: The toughest reservation to snag in San Francisco these days is not a table at the latest Michelin star restaurant, but instead a destination few would consider particularly appetizing: the Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: House Wines as Distinctive as the Address
description: Guests who are lucky enough to claim any of the 47 seats at Frances, Melissa Perellos hot new restaurant in the Castro, are offered not only the wine list but also the choice of house wine, red or white.

title: The Toughest Reservation in Town: The D.M.V.
description: When I think of the Department of Motor Vehicles, I envision the characters Patty and Selma Bouvier from The Simpsons  Homers chain-smoking sisters-in-law who revel in making customers miserable with petty displays of their bureaucratic muscles.

title: Hispanic Leadership Presses to Expand Political Influence
description: When United States Representative Luis V. Gutierrez harshly criticized Gov. Patrick J. Quinn in an off-the-cuff speech early this week that recalled his cocksure political origins, the outburst said as much about roiling disagreements in the Hispanic political community as it did any substantive appraisal of Mr. Quinns record in office.

title: New Curator Is Chosen for M.C.A.
description: When Madeleine Grynsztejn became director at Chicagos Museum of Contemporary Art in 2008, the then-40-year-old institution was in the throes of what she called a healthy midlife crisis: slightly adrift, re-examining its place and purpose in an art landscape dominated by the Art Institute and its coming Modern Wing.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with a television review of The Vaccine War, a Frontline report on PBS, referred incorrectly to the rally in Washington in 2008 at which the actors Jenny McCarthy and Jim Carrey were shown. Participants were calling for the elimination of what they said were toxins in childrens vaccines and for a reassessment of mandatory vaccination schedules for children; it was not an anti-vaccine rally.

title: A New Emotional Intimacy in a Class on Human Anatomy
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Dorothy Provine, Shapely Actress in 60s, Dies at 75
description: Dorothy Provine, the leggy, blond actress perhaps best known for her quirky role in the Stanley Kramer movie Its a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World and as the flouncy nightclub singer on the 1960s television series The Roaring 20s, died on Sunday in Bremerton, Wash. She was 75 and lived on Bainbridge Island, Wash.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on April 21 about Ramchand Pakistani referred incorrectly to the character with whom Ramchands mother, a Hindu, carries on a discreet flirtation. He is a Muslim, and thus is not a member of a caste. The review also referred incorrectly at one point to the place Ramchand and his father are imprisoned, and referred incorrectly to the official for whom Ramchand becomes a servant. She is a police officer, not a military official, and Ramchand and his father are in a jail, not a military encampment.

title: Way Up High, Where the Real Fans Are
description: Describing a subset of sports enthusiasts as 300-level fans doesnt stir the imagination  it lacks the catchy panache of, say, Bleacher Bums. But the third balcony at the United Center during a Blackhawks game is filled with the same type of quirky behaviors, faith-based knowledge and deep-seated passion that was so unerringly recounted in Bleacher Bums, the long-running play about the eccentric, obsessed regulars who hung out in Wrigley Fields bleachers more than 30 years ago.

title: Democrats Tweak Bank Bill to Preclude Bailouts
description: The Senate opened debate on Thursday on a far-reaching financial regulation bill, and Democrats moved quickly to demonstrate that the legislation would not provide any future taxpayer bailouts of failing financial companies  answering a Republican criticism that the Democrats had dismissed as false.

title: Alexander Gorlizki
Elliott Hundley
Crist Announces Independent Run
description: Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida said he would drop out of the Republican primary and continue his Senate bid as an independent, creating a three-way race.

title: News Quiz | April 30, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Joe Zucker
Alix Pearlstein
Reinventing Hunters Point and Other Highlights From Fridays Bay Area Report
description: Plans for a New Face on San Franciscos Eastern Edge |Today, the Hunters Point Naval Shipyard, now idle for more than 35 years, looks like a ghost town. Buildings stand empty. The few people on the property are involved in the continuing cleanup or are among the sculptors, painters and photographers who created an improbable artists colony in some of the shipyard buildings. But a crucial decision is facing the Board of Supervisors in a few weeks. It will open  or close  the door to the Lennar Corporations $7 billion redevelopment plan for the 770-acre site, one that would include 10,500 homes, large amounts of retail and commercial space and even new accommodations for the artists colony. The development project is headed by Kofi Bonner, a vice president at Lennar who spearheaded the redevelopment of Emeryville, which, like Hunters Point, was plagued by toxic waste. Mr. Bonner served as San Franciscos economic development director under Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. during the 1990s.Wine on Tap | At Frances, the restaurant in San Franciscos Castro neighborhood getting all the buzz these days, customers pay by the ounce for the wine they drink. But that is not the only difference from the way most of the citys other eateries handle their drinks. The beverage director, Paul Einbund, blends the house wines creating unconventional blends from the fruits of the Sierra foothills  himself, after they are brought from the wineries in kegs.

title: In Europe, a Delicate Decision on Rates
description: Europes collective anguish over Greece was interrupted by some good news on Thursday. German unemployment fell more than expected, while earnings surged for some of the countrys biggest companies, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

title: Watchful, U.S. Defers to Europe on a Debt Crisis
description: The United States is the largest shareholder in the International Monetary Fund and has played a forceful, interventionist role in financial crises since the early 1990s, in countries like Mexico, South Korea, Russia and Argentina.

title: Norris: Save Greece, Protect Germany
description: From Floyd Norris in his latest High and Low Finance column:

title: Will Other Bidders Emerge for Palm?
description: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

title: Ruling For Former Bengals
description: A federal judge in the Southern District of Ohio rejected an attempt by the Cincinnati Bengals to block several of their former players from filing or collecting workers compensation claims in California for injuries sustained while with the team. The Bengals said that the players contracts required them to file any claims in Ohio. California is the only state with a workers compensation system that lets retired professional athletes file claims for long-term injuries sustained on the field years before as long as they played at least one game in the state.

title: Stunned China Looks Inward After School Attacks
description: BEIJING  In the wake of a fourth horrific attack on Chinese schoolchildren  this time by a crazed man who on Friday beat five toddlers with a hammer, then set himself on fire with two other children in his arms  this shocked and bruised nation was of two distinctly different minds.

title: Hedge Funds Seek $2 Billion From Porsche
description: Six more hedge funds joined a lawsuit against Porsche over alleged securities fraud and manipulation on Thursday, with the plaintiffs doubling the damages they are seeking to $2 billion, Reuters reported.

title: Yaka-Wow
description: A misheard portmanteau of yuck and wow that became an Internet hit.

title: Dubai Worlds New Offer May Fall Flat, Analysts Say
description: Dubai World, which is in talks to restructure $26 billion in debt, is offering lenders an additional 1 percent in interest upon maturity of new debt, but the deal is unlikely to satisfy banks, analysts told Reuters on Thursday.

title: India Tells Mobile Firms to Delay Deals for Chinese Telecom Equipment
description: NEW DELHI  Worried about reports of Chinese hackers and spying, the Indian government has effectively barred local mobile phone operators from making deals with Chinese telecommunications manufacturers, according to the head of Indias main cellular industry trade group.

title: Barclays Posts 29% Profit Rise, Under Expectations
description: Barclays reported Friday that profit rose 29 percent in the first quarter, helped by its investment banking business and a decline in bad loans, Julia Werdigier reports in The New York Times.

title: Moore Settles With C.F.T.C. for $25 Million
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commissions investigation into Moore Capitals actions in the platinum and palladium futures market culminated in a settlement Thursday, with the hedge fund ordered to pay $25 million to the regulatory body.

title: Barclays Profit Is Up 29% in First Quarter
description: LONDON  Barclays reported on Friday that its profit rose 29 percent in the first quarter, helped by its investment banking business and fewer bad loans.

title: Survey: Valley V.C.s Are, Like, so Done Being Down
description: An improved exit environment is increasing liquidity opportunities for venture firms and providing better returns to limited partners, the latest Silicon Valley Venture Capital Confidence Index survey notes, according to VentureBeat.

title: Heres to You, Biology Hackers
description: Todays idea: If the cocktail party of The Graduate were held today, the one word of career advice imparted to Dustin Hoffman might be biology instead of plastics. At least, thats what Bill Gates seems to think.

title: Arpa-E Green Tech Gets $106 Million
description: The Department of Energy has given out $106 million more in stimulus funds to 37 green technology projects under the banner of its Advanced Research Projects Agency  Energy (know best as Arpa-E). The money will be funneled into microbe, battery and carbon capture research, VentureBeat reported.

title: S.E.C. Sues Texas Wireless Provider
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed a lawsuit against Dallas-based wireless service provider TierOne Converged Networks, which is suspected of selling unregistered and misleading securities, The Dallas Morning News reported.

title: JPMorgan to Halt Tax-Refund Loans to Paid Preparers
description: JPMorgan Chase will no longer offer independent American tax preparers financing for tax-refund loans, a company spokesman said.

title:
BP Is Criticized
Over Oil Spill, but U.S. Missed
Chances to Act
description: NEW ORLEANS  Officials in the Obama administration began for the first time Friday to publicly chastise BP America for its handling of the spreading oil gusher in the Gulf of Mexico, calling the oil companys current resources inadequate to stop what is unfolding into an environmental catastrophe.

title: Credit Suisse Taps Mathers as New C.F.O.
description: From Julia Werdigier, a DealBook colleague:

title: Record Profit for Chinese Banks Not Likely to Last
description: Chinese banks, flush from record profits that were bolstered by a yearlong lending binge, are expected to face a business slowdown as the government tries to slow lending to keep the economy from overheating, Reuters reported.

title: Yahoo C.E.O. Gets $47.2 Million for 1st Year
description: Yahoo C.E.O. Carol Bartz received a $47.2 million compensation package during her first year on the job as the Internet company tried to motivate her to engineer a turnaround.

title: In London, Art Out in the Open
description: For art lovers, almost nothing equals the thrill of discovering what goes on behind the scenes in the studio. With that in mind, artists who live in Havelock Walk, a mews in southeast London, began opening their studios to the public nine years ago, providing visitors an opportunity to view art and the artist  in their natural state. This years Open Studio weekends are scheduled for May 8 to 9 and 15 to 16.

title: Where All That Money Went
Economy Is Improving Significantly, Buffett Says
description: Warren E. Buffett says the economy is finally starting to show signs of significant improvement, The Associated Press reported.

title: Goldman and Other Banks to Face Munis Case
description: Goldman Sachs and other high-profile banks must defend allegations by 15 California cities and counties that they conspired to rig bids for municipal investment contracts and derivatives, a United States judge ruled, according to Reuters.

title: China Ports Operator Increases Stake in Sigma
description: Chinese ports operator Cosco Pacific said it had agreed to acquire a further 13.7 percent stake in Sigma Enterprises, increasing its stake to 20.55 percent.

title: Today Is Walter Jones Day
description: Offensive linemen arent appreciated. Todays an exception because Walter Jones, one of the greatest players of his generation, is an exception. (Fast-forward the video to the three-minute mark, where man meets road grader.)

title: Macquarie Profits Jump 21 Percent
description: Macquarie Group said Friday that its full-year profits had jumped 21 percent to 1.05 billion Australian dollars ($977 million).

title: Essar Energy Said to Reduce Asking Price in Giant I.P.O.
description: Londons biggest proposed stock market listing in over two years will reduce its asking price in a move that highlights the instability of the market in the United Kingdom for new offerings, especially amid the havoc from the crisis in Greece.

title: Seeds of Change Take Root in Racing
description: Jim Squires is the breeder of the 2001 Kentucky Derby winner, Monarchos, and the author of Horse of a Different Color and Headless Horsemen.

title: Pritzkers Sell TransUnion Stake to Madison
description: The Pritzker family has sold a 51 percent stake in TransUnion to Madison Dearborn Partners, in a deal that values TransUnion at more than $2 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the transaction.

title: Bringing Home the Bacon: Tripe-Based Drug Hits Gold
description: A drug harvested from pigs intestines has made a low-profile Chinese couple the nations wealthiest overnight. Husband and wife Li Li and Li TansShenzhen Hepalink Pharmaceutical sold 10 percent of its shares this week in an I.P.O. that values their stake at about $6.2 billion, The Financial Times reported.

title: Embattled Movie Executive Sues Zwirn and Fortress
description: Embattled film executive David Bergstein has countersued hedge fund D.B. Zwirn, blaming the bankrupt firm for the lions share of his and business partner Ronald Tutors woes, The Hollywood Reporter said in an article posted to its Web site on Thursday.

title: Stray Questions for: Hugh Raffles
description: Hugh Raffles, a professor of anthropology at the New School, is the author of Insectopedia, reviewed in the Book Review this weekend.

title: Think Blankfein Will Resign? Want to Bet?
description: Goldman Sachs, if you listen to Congress, is little more than a casino where gamblers masquerade as traders and bet on the fortunes of the rest of us. Well, now the rest of us can bet on Goldman, Nelson D. Schwartz of The New York Times reports.

description: elaborate \i-la-b(-)rt\ verb and adjective

title: H.P. and Palm  P.D.A. Powerhouses Unite
description: The year was 2005 and things didnt look all that awful for Hewlett-Packard and Palm when it came to selling mobile devices. In fact, things looked quite good.

title: What Cause Would You Rally Others to Support?
description: This week four immigrant students arrived at the White House after walking from Miami to raise support for legislation to open a path to legal status for students who are illegal immigrants. Meanwhile, in New Jersey, a college student started a Facebook page and used it to rally 18,000 students to protest school budget cuts. What cause would you be willing to rally your peers to work toward? What have you done lately to support a cause you care about?

title: On Our Radar: Putin Frets Over Polar Bears
description: Prime Minister Vladimir Putin of Russia says that Arctic warming threatens polar bears.

title: After Downgrade, Spain Hit by Unemployment Report
description: Spanish unemployment has risen above 20 percent, the countrys statistics agency said Friday, a number not seen since 1997. The announcement came just days after Spain had its debt downgraded by Standard and Poors amid Europes wider credit crisis.

title: Sampler: Oakland Mayors Phony Pay Cut, and Free Popcorn for Students Skipping School
description: About That Pay Cut, Mayor Dellums | Last June, Oaklands mayor announced at a press conference that he would take a 10 percent pay cut.

description: Mac users searching for a particular document can summon Apples Spotlight search bar by holding down the Command (Apple) key and tapping the space bar  but what if the file in question is a photo or document that relies on visual recognition?

title: Brussels to Question High-Frequency Traders
description: High-frequency trading faces a European Union clampdown, as regulators investigate whether traders could use the practice to manipulate financial markets, Bloomberg News reports.

description: Here are some highlights from Fridays edition of The New York Times:

title: European Union Calls Greek Deal Imminent
description: Authorities at the European Commission in Brussels said on Friday that a loan package for Greece should be decided imminently, and they dismissed calls by some economists and other commentators to restructure Greeces debt, James Kanter reports in The New York Times.

title: Canadian Newspaper Sale in Jeopardy
description: Torstar, the parent company of The Toronto Star newspaper, could lose its key financial backer as a bidding deadline approaches for the CanWest group of papers.

title: Appaloosa Barred From Foreclosure Suit
description: Appaloosa Investment will not be allowed to join in a lawsuit intended to foreclose on Manhattans Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village apartments, Bloomberg News reported.

description: Any readers take Oprahs No Phone Zone pledge yet?

description: Wall Street ended the month on a down note Friday as shares struggled from the open.

description: Todays poem, chosen from nearly 200 submissions to our Found Poem Student Challenge, comes from Yiyang, who is 16 years old and lives in Winchester, Va.

title: On This Day in History | The Fall of Saigon
description: Our popular feature, On This Day in History, still lives on our old site, but you can visit it daily here.

title: Consumers Help Drive U.S. Economy to 3.2% Growth Rate
description: The United States economy has expanded for three quarters in a row, the Commerce Department said on Friday, helped along by consumer spending. Now the question is, Will the jobs follow?

title: Tips for Riding in the Dirt
description: PROFESSIONAL instruction cant be summed up in bullet points, but here are some tips from BMWs school:

title: Tip Sheet for Enjoying Your First Derby
description: Well, congratulations for making the decision to attend the Kentucky Derby! Last year I broke my Derby maiden, and I wanted to share a few tips for your enjoyment.

title: The Bitter Pills in the Plan to Rescue Greece
description: ATHENS  Racing to secure financial aid and avoid a debt default, the Greek government has agreed to austerity measures totaling 24 billion euros (about $32 billion) that will include cutting some workers pay and some public sector jobs as well as opening up parts of the economy, Greek officials said Friday.

title: Last Call at Freddys Bar
description: Sometime next week, workers will start digging under the floor of a bar where a bartender known as Johnny Seatcovers poured an oceans worth of whiskey, where police officers and anarchists alike shouted to be heard above the music, where young bands got their start and Blue Oyster Cult played a late-career gig. Within a few months, all traces of the bar that was called Freddys will be gone, brought down to make way for the Atlantic Yards development project. [NYT]

title: A BMW Riding School Far Off the Beaten Path
description: GREER, S.C.

title: Welcome to The Colbert Machine
description: While the music industry collapses all around them, the members of OK Go, the Los Angeles-by-way-of-Chicago rock quartet, have endured the carnage on the strength of clever videos like This Too Shall Pass, in which theyperform that song inside a massive Rube Goldberg machine.

title: A Graduation Party in Baghdad
From Punch Line to Prison Time
description: WHAT WAS IT? 2000-2 Daewoo Lanos

title: A Designer Who Makes Impalas Do the Limbo
description: Bay Shore, N.Y.

title: Possessed by Germans, but the Spirit Is British
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.

title: Best Defensive Ends in N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
description: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely - but not strictly - by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, though the future isnt ignored. Stats werent acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally dont make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. Thats why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what youre about to read.

title: Homage Alla Bolognese: Osteria Morini
description: They have a seafood-centric restaurant whose name is an Italian word for tide  Marea  and a restaurant whose elegance and northern Italian inclination are suggested by its name, Alto, which principally means high or tall.

title: British Banks Say Capital Rules May Mean Double-Dip
description: The largest British banks cautioned leaders of the G20 that new laws forcing them to substantially increase their capital holdings could drive the country back into recession, The Guardian reported.

title: TriBeCa Festival Announces Prizewinners
description: When We Leave, the German director Feo Aladags drama about a womans flight to her family in Berlin from her abusive husband in Istanbul, won the Founders Award for best narrative feature at the Tribeca Film Festival, and its star Sibel Kekilli, above, won for best actress in a narrative feature, the festivals organizers said on Thursday. Dana Adam Shapiros feature Monogamy, about a Brooklyn couple on the verge of marriage, was named best New York narrative, and the French director Kim Chapiron was named best new narrative filmmaker for the feature Dog Pound, about teenagers in a youth correctional center in Montana. Other award winners included Eric Elmosnino, for his portrayal of the French singer-songwriter Serge Gainsbourg in the film Gainsbourg, Je tAime ... Moi Non Plus by Joann Sfar, and Alexandra Codinas nonfiction film Monica & David, about a couple with Down syndrome, which was named best documentary feature.

title: Varietys Former Critic Has a New Job
description: Todd McCarthy, the film critic laid off in March by Variety in a cost-cutting campaign, has landed. Mr. McCarthy said he has agreed to start a Web site called Todd McCarthys Deep Focus, at (toddmccarthyreviews.com), in association with SnagFilms as part of its IndieWire network of blogs. Mr. McCarthy said he had considered quite a few possibilities before agreeing to align with Snag. Ill do what Ive always done: in-depth review of major films and other writing, Mr. McCarthy said in a telephone interview. Varietys decision to cut Mr. McCarthy and other staff members sent a shock through Hollywood, which has long held special regard for the trade papers powerful staff critics, who often get the first word on a new movie. At the time, Variety executives said they hoped that Mr. McCarthy would continue writing for the paper regularly on a freelance basis. Asked whether he intended to do that Mr. McCarthy said, No.

title: Getting Saucy in the Kitchen
description: If youre tired of the same old steamed vegetables, its time to get saucy. As Martha Rose Shulman explains in this weeks Recipes for Health, the right sauce can inspire endless meal combinations. She writes:

title: Nocturnalist | In Honor of Luxury
description: On impulse, Allen Salmasi bought his wife, Nicole, a necklace for around $250,000 on Thursday night. Mrs. Salmasi now found herself at a loss  she did not have anywhere to stash the roughly $700,000 diamond necklace she was already wearing. So, she wore both.

title: Memories of the Empire Diner
description: The Empire Diner, a Chelsea mainstay for more than three decades, will serve its last meal on May 15. Betsyann Faiella, a producer, publicist and occasional entertainer who is a former waitress at the restaurant, sent her memories of the place to Diners Journal, and provided the photograph, at right, of Teddy Dewis, a waiter there, taken around 1986.

title: Study: Derivatives Rules Would Cost Banks Billions
description: Goldman Sachs could lose up to 41 percent of its earnings if Congress approves tighter regulation of the derivatives market, according to an analysis by Bernstein Research. Thats equivalent to wiping away$3.9 billion in Goldmans earnings this year if the stricter regulations were in effect for the entire 12 months, according to a subsequent analysis of the numbers by DealBook using Bernsteins 2010 earnings-per-share estimates.

title: The Oil Spill Is Obamas Fault
description: No, I havent lost my mind  thats not what I believe. But you know thats what the talk-show hosts will be saying soon, if they havent already started. The only question is what the story will be.

title: The Early Word: Immigration
description: Senate Democrats broke out the framework of an immigration plan on Thursday. But it remains to be seen how much traction they can gain with six months left before Election Day.

title: Philosophy Football
description: The countdown to the 2010 World Cup South Africa can now be measured in days.

title: Susan Boyle Tops Global Sales Chart
description: When American album sales for last year were tallied up, Taylor Swift edged out Susan Boyle for the No. 1 spot. But Ms. Boyle has the last word when it comes to the global charts.

title: Parties Snipe at Crist, but May Court Him Later
description: WASHINGTON  A bipartisan scolding broke out in the wake of the decision by Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida to ditch the Republican Party and make an independent Senate bid, with leaders of both parties calling his move a self-serving piece of aggrandizement, rather than an act of principle.

title: A New School of the World Class Variety
description: Signs that the economy is on the mend: Hamptons house sales are on the rise, Manhattan restaurants are teeming, and another expensive New York City private school is getting ready to open its doors.

title: Ferraris Bar Code, and a Visit to the Ferrari Factory
description: Ferrari is the last team left that has a sponsorship contract with a tobacco company, but like all other teams, it ceased putting that sponsors logo on its car years ago. Now it is under fire from anti-tobacco activists who claim that the teams bar code and the red color of the car evoke the sponsor  Marlboro  in everything but actual type. (Take a look at my video below to see how prevalent the color red is for Ferrari, even on their road cars.)

title: The Morning Line: Focus Narrows on Derby
description: The Derby coverage reaches a peak on Friday. After a focus on Thursday on the post position draw, Fridays interest swirls around the scene and conditions at Churchill Downs and the selections of the major handicappers.

title: Why Isnt Britain In More Trouble?
description: There have been various versions of the Britain is the next Greece! story out there; a good rundown at FT Alphaville. As they note there, however, the CDS and bond markets dont seem to agree:

title: Moodys Downgrades Debt Ratings on Greek Banks
description: Moodys downgraded the debt and deposit ratings of nine Greek banks on Friday, as the countrys leaders attempt to reach an agreement with their European counterparts on a rescue package, and with their population on austerity measures.

title: Car Crash During Campaign Event in Britain Not a Metaphor, Ruling Party Insists
description: As embattled Prime Minister Gordon Brown and several members of his cabinet unveiled a last-ditch billboard advertising campaign in Birmingham, England on Friday morning, a loud car crash close to the outdoor venue briefly interrupted the event.

title: Complaint Box | Exacting Change
description: I dine out often, and lately Ive noticed a new trend occurring in some restaurants. I call it the Great Roundup.

title: Vanderbilt Tops Yale, in a Squeaker
description: After months of waiting and weighing, Ive finally come to a decision on the momentous topic of college  which surprises me, given that last week, I was stuck between two titans: Yale and Vanderbilt.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Bad Meaning Good
description: This week is all about villains. The first volume of Gotham City Sirens stars a cabal of Batmans female arch-foes  Catwoman, Poison Ivy and Harley Quinn  and is at No. 9 on the hardcover list. The book, published by DC Comics, emerged after a reshuffling of the line of Batman books after the apparent death of the Caped Crusader. At No. 7 on the softcover list is Deadpool: Suicide Kings, the latest collection of adventures starring that mutant mercenary whose powers seem to include an infinite reserve of popularity: In June alone, he is the title character in five books published by Marvel Entertainment, and he guest-stars in a sixth.

title: Behind the Fade-Out of Options Backdating Cases
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Making College Applications a Full-Time Job
description: A few years ago I interviewed a mother named Gail Wiggin for a Lifes Work column because she was an outlier  shed just quit her job in order to focus her time and energy on getting her son into college. She might not have been the only person to ever have done that, but she was certainly the only one Id run across, and response from readers hinted that they thought she was a bit extreme, too.

title: Letters: The Estrogen Dilemma
description: Cynthia Gorneys early menopause symptoms were very close to my own. The estrogen patch saved my sanity and returned my life to normal. When the Womens Health Initiative study came out, I tried to cut back my hormones but had too much anxiety to do that. Im now 63 and still taking hormone-replacement therapy, but Im afraid to stop. Im so glad to hear that there are studies going on regarding the type of estrogen and the timing of taking it. We need more articles about this subject; too many of us are winging it just to maintain our quality of life. NANCY LEONARDNevada City, Calif.

title: Letter: Dr. Does-It-All
description: In the early 80s my husband and I were reading the morning papers when a very good-looking young kid running by our house waved at us. We knew his dad, Mustafa, who was our next-door neighbor, but we had never met Mehmet, then away at school. This whirlwind climbed in through our breakfast-room window, was charmingly chatty and challenged my husband, then in his late 30s, to a little hoops in our driveway. While mopping up the driveway with my husband, Mehmet mentioned that he was in University of Pennsylvania medical school and getting an M.B.A. from Wharton at the same time. When my husband said that seemed pretty ambitious, Mehmet just brushed that off, saying that his dad said that to practice medicine today, you have to have an M.B.A. Sounds like he hasnt changed much  hes not just a world-beater, hes becoming a world-changer.JEAN KENNEDY HUNTERHouston

title: Letter: A Closer Reading of Roman Vishniac
description: In Thomas McGoverns letter to the magazine in the April 18 issue, he mistakenly writes that Robert Capa stated he discovered how undiscovered Vishniac was. To begin with, it wasnt Robert Capa who said this (he diedin 1954); it was Cornell Capa who championed Vishniacs work in exhibits, books and lectures at the International Center of Photography, which he, Cornell Capa, founded. I was an assistant to Cornell Capa for 35 years, and what Cornell clearly meant in his statement was his surprise that Vishniacs work, as important as it was, was not more widely known prior to his own efforts after 1966. For McGovern to go on to say that Capa (either Robert or Cornell, take your pick) had a similar impulse to encourage the viewers to believe things that werent really there is a gross misinterpretation of the facts, and unfair conjecture.ANNA WINANDNew York

title: Friday Reading: Asking for More Financial Aid
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Turtles vs. Tourism in Puerto Rico
description: At first there were only a few nests. But over the last two decades, hundreds of leatherback sea turtles have made the beaches near the El Yunque national rain forest in northeastern Puerto Rico a popular Caribbean destination.

title: He Does His Homework at the Track
description: Remember this girl? Two years ago, at 12 years old, she appeared in a YouTube video and named all the Kentucky Derby winners to that point, in order, by memory.

title: Going After a Reporters Sources  Change We Can Believe In?
description: Excuse an utterly self-interested comment from a scribbler about reporters protecting confidential sources. You see, this was an ongoing point of contention during the Bush administration. Prosecutors sought to subpoena reporters to find their confidential sources, and courts then threatened to throw them in prison if they refused to reveal those sources. We had thought that the Obama administration would be different, a little less likely to want to menace and jail journalists. But, alas, the Obama Justice Department has now issued a subpoena for my Times colleague James Risen (although its for a book he wrote, not for material that appeared in the Times). Speaking obviously just for myself, not for my institution, I find this utterly disappointing. The Washington Post article writes:

title: Putting a Limit on Tarmac Time
description: A new rule to protect airline passengers from being held on a plane on the tarmac for too long went into effect Thursday. The rule, issued by the Department of Transportation, was announced in December after a series of cases on various airlines left passengers stranded on the tarmac for hours.

title: Doctors, Let Me Pay You for E-Mail
description: I get that primary care doctors are busy. And I understand, as a study we featured in Thursdays paper points out, that they do lots of things  like reading lab results and consulting with specialists  that they dont get paid for.

title: Q. & A. With Julie Sahni (Round Two)
description: Julie Sahni is the owner of Julie Sahnis Indian Cooking School in Brooklyn Heights, N.Y., and the author of 10 cookbooks, including Savoring Herbs and Spices and Classic Indian Cooking. She is taking questions on how to prepare Indian food. Please write them in the comments below and she will answer them throughout the week. Related article.

title: Dispute in Los Angeles Over Arts Financing
description: Arts advocates in Los Angelesare pushing back against new efforts by city officials to sap the funding streams that keep their organizations alive, The Los Angeles Times reported. They have flooded city hall voice-mail and e-mail in-boxes to oppose a proposal by Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa to redirect $415,000 in arts grants from groups that qualified under a standard competitive application process to four groups of his choosing. The proposal was part of the mayorsbudget recommendations, which call for a nearly 25 percent cut in city arts spending. They were presented to the City Council on April 20 and were reviewed by the councils budget and finance committee on Thursday.

title: Life Sciences Dominate at Wharton Competition
description: The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania held its 12th annual business plan competition  on Wednesday. Eight finalists were selected from the 231 teams that applied.

title: Billionaire Greene Enters Florida Senate Race
description: 3:18 p.m. | Updated MIAMI  Floridas eye-catching Senate race has just received another entertaining addition. Jeff Greene  a billionaire who bet against the housing market and whose friends include Heidi Fleiss, the Hollywood madam, and the boxer Mike Tyson, who was the best man at his wedding  announced today that he was entering the race as a Democrat.

title: Weighing Risks of Coastal Oil and Cleanups
description: As officials assess the first reports of ribbons of oil coming ashore along the Gulf coast, the questions are shifting to the coast, as well. Should teams be deployed to mop up the mousse  the technical term for the tan emulsion of crude and seawater  or should it be left alone? Heres a closeup from the latest NASA (Modis) image of the slick, showing one strand reaching out toward Blind Bay and adjacent bayous:

title: Your Room as Cocoon: Teeny, Cheap and Chic
description: At a boutique hotel near the exclusive shops and hangouts of New Yorks meatpacking district, a bellman, polite and formal in the classic uniform of burgundy trimmed in gold, pushed open a rich wood door for a guest the other day. Beyond it was a carefully designed space with luxury touches: high-thread-count cotton sheets, large flat-screen television, bathrobe and spa sandals.

title: Say Goodbye to the Empire Diner
description: Readers are invited to share their stories about the Empire Diner, a Chelsea mainstay for more than three decades, which will serve its last meal on May 15. Read more on Diners Journal

title: Avoiding Surprise Bills With Homework and Negotiation
A Medical Bill You May Not Have to Pay
description: Have you ever received a doctors bill for the amount your insurance plan didnt cover? The practice is called balance billing, and as Walecia Konrad explains in todays Patient Money, its a bill you may not be required to pay.

title: The Rise of Self-Publishing
description: I love out-there theories and the people who are seized by them. Im a sitting duck for crackpots. Maybe thats why I like the Web.

title: Sold for a Song or Two
description: CELEBRITY is an odd thing. Why do we know that Gordon Sumner, a middle-aged Englishman, is extremely flexible?

title: Theater Talkback: The Awards Season is Upon Us
description: Happy last day of the official 2009-10 Broadway season, everybody!

title: Reader Photos: Joys of the Window Seat
description: On March 28, Mark Vanhoenacker wrote about rediscovering the romance of the window seat and we asked readers to share photos of their favorite window seat views. Browse through hundreds of submissions.

title: Rhapsodys iPhone App an Improvement
description: Thursdays PhoneSmart column mentioned the introduction this week of a new version of Rhapsodys iPhone app, and for those familiar with Rhapsodys music-streaming service, now is when the app truly gets interesting.

title: Triple Coverage for This Listing
description: EVERYBODY loves cheering for the underdog  except perhaps Yankee fans. The problem with that plan is that the underdogs usually lose. But not always: In Super Bowl III, in 1969, the New York Jets handed the Baltimore Colts such a tremendous upset, winning 16-7, that we can still get a kick out of it.

title: Former Indianapolis Mayor Joins Bloomberg Administration
description: Stephen Goldsmith, the former mayor of Indianapolis who gained a national reputation as a pragmatic problem solver, is returning to political life, but in a new city, with a lesser title: He is joining Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs administration as the new deputy mayor for operations.

title: Inside the List
description: HUMORIST VS. GOD I: Sarah Silvermans memoir, The Bedwetter, which enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 9, is about pretty much what the title says.

title: Now Screening | The Woodmans
description: The photographer Francesca Woodman had all the markings of becoming the next big art star: precocious talent, beauty, charisma and a driving ambition and a work ethic to match. The trajectory of her life, however, followed an all-too-familiar story line: the artist who died too young. The Woodmans, a new film about her and her family, took the top prize for the best New York documentary on Thursday night and is screening Saturday at the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Its Time for School
description: Now that the major training is completed and we are only a day from the big race, many of the starters will have started to focus on the finer details of race preparation, which includes schooling both in the starting gate and in the paddock. It is really important that a horse is as relaxed as possible as it prepares for its race, and schooling helps with this. When I worked for Steve Asmussen, we paddock-schooled every horse before each of its races, and we gate-schooled every horse once a week. With a race as important as the Kentucky Derby, those activities take on a greater significance.

title: Expo Offers Shanghai a Turn in the Spotlight
description: The Worlds Fair may have lost the luster it brought decades ago to world capitals like Paris. But China has dusted off the concept in an attempt to give its second city, Shanghai, the same coming-out party that the 2008 Summer Olympic Games were for Beijing.

title: Goldmans Shares Plunge on Inquiries and Downgrades
description: How much trouble is Goldman Sachs really in?

title: Artie Shaw: Swing and Loathing
description: Artie Shaw, the swing eras other great clarinetist, knew just about every romantic self-immolator in the history of jazz. He roomed with both Bix Beiderbecke and Bunny Berigan, he hired Billie Holiday to sing with his band and  at least by his own account  he turned down Charlie Parkers bid to join his saxophone section. (I said, Bird, you couldnt play in my band, youre too much of an individualist! ) Superficially, Shaw couldnt have been less like these doom-bound drunks and drug addicts. In Three Chords for Beautys Sake, Tom Nolans absorbing if somewhat sketchy new biography, we see him drunk exactly once  when he was in his teens and a prankish band mate fed him shots of rye with beer chasers  and once, at about 20, half-stoned on weed with Berigan. Thanks to clean living, good luck and, surely, a measure of cussedness, Shaw lived to be 94 and died, in 2004, the way Robert Frost recommended: Better to go down dignified / With boughten friendship at your side / Than none at all. Provide, provide! He even kept his sense of humor, or at least his memory of an old Myron Cohen joke. His personal assistant (who stayed with him for 11 years, sometimes by dint of repeating the word mortgage to himself) and his home-hospice caregiver were changing the old mans bedclothes during his last days and asked if he was comfortable. I make a living, he said. He did, too. Though Nolans book doesnt say so, Shaws estate was probably worth around $3 million, and he hadnt played on a record for half a century.

title: Updates on the Oil Slick in the Gulf of Mexico
description: As my colleagues Campbell Robertson and Liz Robbins report, Federal and state officials criticized BP on Friday for what they said was an inadequate response to the growing oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The Lede will track news of the oil slicks spread on Friday. Video of the deadly fire on the oil rig that exploded last week is in a previous post on the disaster.

title: Real Golfers Wear Rain Suits
description: I admit I have a thing about golf rain suits. What I find most amazing about rain suits is that so few golfers have one. And I concede, I was one of those golfers who spent years trying to make due with a heavy windbreaker and lots of towels. Then I got a rain suit made for golf and wondered why I had been torturing myself. A lot of golfers will think nothing of spending $100 to play golf for one day but wont spend $400 on a quality rain suit that might last 10 years and allowthem to enjoy 40 more golf rounds when its raining. So think of it as an extra $10 for every round it rains. You spend that on a hot dog and drink at the turn.

title: Artie Shaw and the High C
description: This weekend, David Gates reviews Three Chords for Beautys Sake: The Life of Artie Shaw, by Tom Nolan. Gates quotes a scene from the book recounting an exchange between Shaw and a well-known clarinet player who once asked Shaw if he was ever afraid of missing the high C at the end of Concerto for Clarinet. As Shaw told it:

title: What Makes Marion Jones Run?
description: The sky was still dark on the March morning in 2008 when Marion Jones, the five-time Olympic medalist, folded her long legs into the passenger seat of her Honda Pilot. She had barely eaten that morning and sat silently, staring out the window as her husband began the three-hour drive to a federal prison in Fort Worth, Tex., where Jones was to begin a six-month sentence. During the ride, her husband, Obadele Thompson, pulled off the highway twice because Jones felt sick to her stomach. In the prison parking lot, Jones and Thompson hugged and kissed a couple of times, before she asked to stop; she did not want to cry. She had with her the few things she was allowed to bring: an inexpensive watch, her wedding band, small silver stud earrings, a Bible.

title: If Football Is Favres Future, Quarterback Will Need Surgery
description: Its been at least a few weeks since there was an update in the annual Brett Favre retirement watch. On Friday, we got one.

title: Goldman Shares Dive on Inquiries and Downgrades
description: 2:33 p.m. | Updated Already facing investigations on two fronts into its practices in the mortgage market, Goldman Sachs came under pressure from investors as well on Friday.

title: After 26 Derbys, He Still Doesnt Know
description: With over 26 years of wagering on the sport of kings and mild success, David Buc Geier has as many opinions and ideas, as he does uncashable tickets in his desk drawer. Like Sisyphus and his rock, he will someday get to the mountaintop. If not, hell start over once again.

title: The Worst of the West
description: This little book is a cri de coeur  an outburst of rage and sorrow in equal parts. The language of Ill Fares the Land is felicitous and polished, as befits such an intelligent and erudite author. But unless the reader belongs to the choir to which Tony Judt preaches  call it the Europhile liberal left, who would rather sell their Prius than forgo their New York Review of Books  he or she may ask: Where have we heard this before? A pugnacious reader might stab a felt pen at every other paragraph and scribble: Caricature! or What about . . . ?

title: Court Voids Injunction on Would-Be Catcher in the Rye Sequel
description: 3:26 p.m. | Updated A United States appeals courton Friday vacated a lower courts order to enjoin the publication of a novel described as a sequel to J. D. Salingers Catcher in the Rye. The appeals court sided with a district courts judgment thatSalingers lawyers would probably prevail on the merits but sent the case back to that lower court to re-evaluate whether the injunction should be ordered.

title: Chinese Rights Lawyer Disappears Again
description: BEIJING  Gao Zhisheng, a prominent human rights lawyer whose 13-month disappearance at the hands of Chinese security agents stirred an international outcry until he resurfaced in March, has again vanished, his friends said Friday.

title: U.S. Chamber of Commerce Backs Democrat (at Least for Now)
description: The conventional wisdom is that Senator Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas, up for re-election this fall, is one of several Democrats in danger of losing her seat. But right now, a Republican opponent is the least of her worries. Ms. Lincoln, one of the most conservative members of her caucus, is facing a tough primary challenge from the left, in the person of Lt. Governor Bill Halter. And on Tuesday, Salons Mike Madden reported that she was receiving help from an unexpected quarter: the United States Chamber of Commerce, in the name of small business.

title: Emo-Tourism
description: In Deanna Feis first novel, A Thread of Sky, three generations of a familys women confront identity issues, both timeless and of the moment. Irene, a Chinese scientist living in Queens, has sacrificed her career to stay home, making her American-born daughters the center of her universe. This disappoints her own mother, a failed revolutionary who thinks women must push and strain forward or be part of the backward pull. In turn, Irenes outwardly perfect children forsake much of lifes joy in the name of ambition. But with Harvard, Yale and Stanford on their rsums  and all three girls were high-school valedictorians  Irene now wonders if she shouldnt have raised them to feel quite so special.

title: Like a Pigeon on a Train
description: Why did the pigeon take the train?

title: Corporate Etymologies
description: When Keds kicked off a retro advertising campaign in March as the original sneaker, the venerable brand tripped over its own laces. Claiming that Keds are the first shoes to be called sneakers, the companys Web site provided a seemingly authoritative origin story: The term, coined in 1917 by Henry Nelson McKinney, an agent for the advertising firm N. W. Ayer & Son, refers to their soft, noiseless rubber soles, which allow the wearer to sneak up on unsuspecting friends or family.

title: Faux-Authentic Uniforms
description: In March, Burton  Snowboards announced that later this year it would begin selling pants similar to those worn by the U.S. Olympic snowboarding team. There is a logic to this move, because the most notable thing about the teams uniform was how much it looked like a trendy retail product. The pants, which will cost $250 in their consumer version, had the look of baggy, prefaded distressed jeans; the top was a plaid hooded jacket. Pretty ho-hum stuff compared with, lets say, the spangles and feathers worn by figure skaters or the skintight hooded unitards of lugers, attire shaped either by functionality or by a kind of amped-up aesthetic spectacle. The American snowboarders appeared to have stopped off to compete in the Olympics on the way home from the mall, without even bothering to change their clothes.

title: Once Bitten
description: What do you make of the vogue for vampires in this country? The heroine of your Sookie Stackhouse novels, a telepathic waitress who lives in Bon Temps, La., and consorts with supernatural friends, is about to re-emerge in a new season of the HBO series True Blood, as well as in your 10th best seller.  Well, Dead in the Family wont really be out until May 4, and I hate to count my chickens before they hatch.

title: The Sweet Hereafter
description: About a year ago, our neighbors beloved mutt, Bruno, went to dog heaven, followed six months later by Bear, the sweet brown Newfoundland down the block. I am not speaking metaphorically but repeating the wisdom of my 3-year-old daughter, who learned her theology from Dog Heaven, a picture book by Cynthia Rylant. All dogs get biscuits in Dog Heaven, Rylant writes. Even better, The dogs in Dog Heaven who had no real homes on Earth are given one in Heaven. . . . And each dog is petted and reminded how good he is, all day long.

title: The Talents of a Middle-Aged Brain
description: After we hit 40, many of us begin to worry about our aging brains. Will we spend our middle years searching for car keys and forgetting names?

title: Beasts of Burden
description: Yann Martels second novel,    Life of Pi, won him much acclaim, many readers and the 2002 Man Booker Prize. At least one reason for the books appeal was a story easily reduced to a one-line pitch: An Indian boy is stranded on a lifeboat with a Bengal tiger. Martels latest novel demonstrates the same gift for vivid description and wholehearted feeling, but its a lot more resistant to summary. Beatrice and Virgil is allusive, teasing, fragmentary.

title: The Spurs Rediscovery
description: For all but the most rabid of their fans, the San Antonio Spurs are like that plant that keeps blooming in your backyard every spring. While its comforting to see something so durable reappear annually, you also wouldnt mind it not coming back so you could replace it with something with a little more pizzazz.

title: Acura Recalling 167,000 TSX Models for Fire Hazard
description: Honda is recalling about 167,000 of its 20048 Acura TSX modelsbecause ofa fire hazard, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. It is the third recall of an Acura model for a similar problem, now affecting almost 500,000 vehicles.

title: Jeff Stark and The Sweet Cheat
description: A slide show of photographs from the The Sweet Cheat.

title: Room for One
description: The suicide itself happens offstage at a Valentines Day party. Excuse me, says a man, stepping out onto the balcony, letting the black draperies fall behind him. While his wife helps the hostess arrange fresh berries on a platter, he jumps  but a long time passes before the police knock on the door to ask if a guest is missing. Like Breughels Icarus plunging into the sea, he dies unwatched.

title: Love, Labor, Loss
description: Robert von Lucius is on his way to meet Herr S, a patient in a Kafkaesque asylum in Vienna in 1865. Delusional, paranoid men line the halls  one lives in a universe of color, another repeatedly demands a hearing, . . . a hearing  but Lucius idealizes the clinically insane, seeing them as privy to ancient presences caught between the lunar and solar. To him, Herr S, who blames himself for the spread of a deadly childbed fever epidemic, looks as if his bones had been broken, and had mended strangely. Lucius vows to prevent Herr S, a k a Dr. Ignaz Semmelweis, from descending deeper into madness.

title: Leading Mansion
description: I first came upon Villa Necchi Campiglio, an extraordinary house discreetly tucked away in the chaotic center of Milan, when I was supposed to be looking at shoes. Tods, the luxury accessories label, had taken over the place to showcase its latest collection. But lovely as they were, I had a hard time concentrating on the pebble-bottomed loafers: their surroundings stole the show. So I did what anyone in my place would do: snatched a glass of Champagne from the nearest waiter, snuck away for a wander and dizzily allowed myself to be dazzled. This house, I said to myself, should be in a movie.

title: Public Enemy No. 1
description: Tell people in Belfast or Melbourne youre from Chicago and some of them are still apt to mimic a tommy assault, spraying you with 400 rounds of hot lead per minute. Ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah! A tommy, of course, is a Thompson submachine gun, the weapon of choice for Al Capones outfit, which deployed the guns to dominate the hooch and protection rackets in and around Chicago for most of the Roaring Twenties. Old associations die hard.

title: The Flesh Machine
description: The Swedish writer Henning Mankell has remarked that too often we learn everything about how an African dies, but nothing about how he lives. Mankell, who spends half the year running Teatro Avenida in Mozambique, has a point. African lives in the Western media are skewed toward their ends in statistical catastrophe, as if a continent with more than 50 countries were reducible to one vast, tangled necropolis. Many African lives may be foreshortened, but they can also be cut short in a second, imaginative sense as our emphasis on reporting disasters ignores the twists and turns, quotidian or remarkable, that shape the experiences of individuals over the long haul.

title: Weekend Competition: Its a Mad Mad Mad Mad Mad Men World
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to devise slogans for things not normally advertised.

title: Vain Glorious | Whittemore House
description: Who: Victoria Hunter and Larry Raspanti

title: The Big Banks Consumers Recommend Most Often
description: Among the big banks that people talk most about online, PNC gets the most positive recommendations while JPMorgan Chase brings up the rear, according to new data released Thursday by marketing firm Zcalo Group and research firm M/A/R/C Research.

title: Inside the Mind of Bob Bradley
description: How would you put together a roster, plan a strategy and prepare for the World Cup? United States soccer fans, never shy, have as many opinions on how Bob Bradley should approach his job as there are blades of grass on a soccer field.

title: I Rush Through the Japanese Night
description: I confess, dear reader: Ive always had a problem with William T. Vollmann. I cant fail to admire his tender heart and wide-awake conscience, and its hard not to appreciate his energy, his intensity, his unstoppable curiosity about the world and everything in it  women, violence, death, war zones, the night. Who else would give us a subtitle, as in his new book, that spills over and over, and begin a work of 504 pages, complete with bibliography, glossary, chronology and five appendixes, with a modest disclaimer about his short book? Actually, it is short when compared with his seven-volume 2003 treatise on violence, Rising Up and Rising Down, and the 811-page novel, Europe Central, that won the National Book Award in 2005. Its now been all of 10 months since the 1,306-page Vollmann opus Imperial appeared, serving up everything youd thought to ask about the Mexico-California border, and much you probably hadnt.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE PUBLISHER: Henry Luce and His American Century,  by Alan Brinkley (Knopf, $35.) The creator of Time and Life used his magazines to advance political favorites, paint an uplifting portrait of the middle class and promote American intervention in the world.

title: Paperback Row
description: SHOP CLASS AS SOULCRAFT: An Inquiry Into the Value of Work,  by Matthew B. Crawford (Penguin, $15.) This beautiful little book about human excellence and the way it is undervalued in contemporary America, as our reviewer, Francis Fukuyama, described it, argues against the idea that the United States labor force needs to be retrained to face the challenges of a high-tech, global economy. On the contrary, argues Crawford  a philosopher who operates a motorcycle repair shop  blue-collar work leads to knowledge both about the world and about oneself. He illustrates by explaining in detail just what is involved in rebuilding a Volkswagen engine.

title: The Paper
description: This first novel by Tom Rachman, a London-born journalist who has lived and worked all over the world, is so good I had to read it twice simply to figure out how he pulled it off. I still havent answered that question, nor do I know how someone so young  Rachman turns out to be 35, though he looks even younger in his author photo  could have acquired such a precocious grasp of human foibles. The novel is alternately hilarious and heart-wrenching, and its assembled like a Rubiks Cube. I almost feel sorry for Rachman, because a debut of this order sets the bar so high.

title: Up Front: Christopher Buckley
description: Although Christopher Buckleys most recent book, Losing Mum and Pup, is a memoir of his parents, William and Pat Buckley, hes known primarily as a political satirist and the author of darkly comic novels like The White House Mess, Thank You for Smoking, No Way to Treat a First Lady and Boomsday.

title: Privacy Concerns Limit Online Ads, Study Says
description: Privacy advocates have had an impact on Madison Avenue after all, according to a new study.

title: NBC Rolls Out the Red Carpet
description: When viewers tune in Saturday to watch what Bob Costas calls an incredible piece of Americana, something will be different.

title: Obama Hits Pause on Offshore Drilling
description: President Obama has ordered that no new offshore drilling leases be issued until an extensive review is concluded and oil rigs have new safeguards put in place, as the White House dramatically strengthened its response to the worsening oil leak in the Gulf.

title: Gabriel Byrne Buys in NoLIta
description: The actor Gabriel Byrne has just bought a two-bedroom condo at 211 Elizabeth Street in Manhattan for $3.36 million.

title: Dont Cry for Charlie Crist
description: No doubt there will be some talk, in the wake of Charlie Crists completely unsurprising decision to run for Floridas Senate seat as an independent, about how this shows that the intolerant Tea Party spirit is driving moderates out of the Republican Party. As Ive argued before, this is exactly the wrong way to look at the case of Charlie Crist. The Florida governor may be a moderate in some sense, but his real loyalties are to cynicism, self-interest (though this time, Im pretty sure that hes misjudged where those interests lie), and the persistent pursuit of the budgetary free lunch. At a time when the country desperately needs politicians who are equipped to make tough choices, Crists record suggests that hes the last person that anyone  conservative or liberal  should want to see in a position of responsibility in Washington D.C.

title: Switzerland Says It Does Not Seek Sealed Testimony in Polanski Case
description: Swiss justice officials said on Friday that they did not require access to the sealed testimony of a prosecutor involved in thesex case against the director Roman Polanski, even though lawyers for the filmmaker have said the testimony was needed for the officials to rule on his possible extradition to the United States. On Thursday, Mr. Polanskis American lawyers filed a motion in Los Angeles County Superior Court seeking the sealed testimony ofRoger Gunson, a retired deputy district attorney, about a sentencing plan devised by Judge Laurence J. Rittenband. Mr. Polanski pleaded guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl but fled the United States in 1978 before he could be sentenced by Judge Rittenband, who died in 1993.

title: About Face
description: In 1928 Neville Chamberlain wrote a perceptive and generous private letter about one of his cabinet colleagues. He is a brilliant but wayward child, Chamberlain said. One doesnt often come across a real man of genius. . . . Winston is such a man and he has les dfauts de ses qualits.

title: The Lure of Carbon Capture
Ad: 'Is She You?'

title: Final British Debate in 60 Seconds
description: Readers who want to relive Thursdays final debate of the British election campaign, among the three men vying for the keys to Number 10 Downing Street, can watch extended video highlights on The Lede, take in a witty analysis of the tape on The Guardians Web site, or read what my colleagues John Burns, Alan Cowell and Stephen Castle had to say about it during the event. Readers with somewhat less time on their hands might enjoy the highly condensed version of the proceedings from the Web site of Britains Channel 4 News above, which sums the whole thing up in 60 seconds.
